column2: There is to be a change of diet for those who are dwelling on Blackwell's Island in the various institutions there. It was brought to the attention of Commissioner Folks of the Department of Charities that the people of the island were suffering from a surfeit of beef. They had beef for breakfast, dinner, and supper.

ROME, Dec. 15. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Foreign Minister, Signor Prinetti, replying to an interpellation, made a statement on the subject of Italy's attitude toward Venezuela. He reviewed the causes leading up to the British-German action, and said:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15 -- T. Lloyd McConchie, a New York lawyer, was refused a hearing by Chancellor Magie in a small Prerogative Court matter here to-day until he had been properly introduced by a Newark lawyer. Chancellor Magie said that he was unwilling for lawyers from New York or other States, not associated with New Jersey counsel, to be heard in the New Jersey courts unless they were introduced.

The Car Passengers' Rights Society, composed of women who have begun a fight for adequate seating accommodations, met again yesterday at the residence of Mrs. Dore Lyon, the Treasurer, at 100 East Ninety-fifth Street. They made some progress in the work, which at present hangs rather heavily upon them, by the adoption of a constitution embodying the object and purposes of the organization.
CARACAS, Dec. 15. -- United States Minister Bowen, at the request of the Dutch Minister, Dr. Van Leyden, who is ill at Curacao, lias taken charge of Dutch interests here.

--Discussing the recent blockades on the elevated roads, a correspondent of The Electrical Review who signs himself "An Engineer" evidences easily comprehensible anxiety that the blame for the trouble be put where it is deserved and not charged against either the engineers of the company or the system of propulsion.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- Directors of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company held a protracted meeting to-day and tonight. It was announced that the election of a successor to F.H. Lewis, who resigned the Presidency last week, was not regarded as an urgent necessity and that the office would remain vacant for the present.

Yesterday's security market had a discouraging opening. There was absence of activity, but practically every transaction represented declines. The whole list was weak. Even the professional bargain hunter was undiscoverable. Venezuela news was made to do serious service for the speculative contingent, whose profit is in the creation of distrust, Money on call was at 10 per cent.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Money was in active request to-day. Discounts were easier, owing to the Continental demand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Arrangements for the funeral of Mrs. Julia Dent Grant will not be made until Brig. Gen. Fred D. Grant, her eldest son, arrives from the West. It is expected that he will reach here Thursday.

With the advent of Winter and the practical cessation of golf as a competitive sport the adherents of the latter game are devoting considerable attention to squash. The interest in the game is greater this season than ever before, and those who renounced it temporarily last Spring in favor of ping-pong have now returned to their first favorite with more enthusiasm than ever.

The Manufacturers' Association of the City of New York last night, at its headquarters in Montague Street, Brooklyn, considered the condition of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit cars and passed resolutions declaring that the service is shamefully inadequate, and that the company had done nothing in answer to repeated requests for better service, except unfulfilled promises.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- No more welcome fleet of vessels ever rounded Cape Cod and entered Massachusetts Bay than that sighted from the Highland Light observation station about 8 o'clock this morning. It consisted of barges, steamers, and tugs many days storm-bound at Vineyard Haven and Sound, waiting for a favorable opportunity to proceed to Boston with thousands of tons of coal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in to-day's TIMES entitled "Baer on Liberty" was quite interesting. Theoretically Mr. Baer is correct in his reasoning, but he does not seem to take into consideration that with an increase of population certain property rights may cease to be private.

If President CASTRO'S reply to the British and German ultimatum was correctly summarized in the cable dispatch from Minister HAGGARD, read by Lord LANSDOWNE in the House of Lords yesterday, further hostile action against Venezuela by the two European Powers would be quite without warrant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The so-called lottery cases were reargued to-day in the Supreme Court. They wore first argued in October, 1901, and a reargument was had in April, 1902. On account of Judge Gray's death a further reargument was ordered, which was commenced this morning. The cases are important, as the ability to prevent lotteries in this country may depend upon the final decision.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- In the House of Commons yesterday afternoon Charles Ernest Schwann (Advanced Liberal) moved an adjournment of the House to discuss Venezuelan matters.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- In the Jacob shipyard here the lines are being laid down for a fine new steam yacht designed by Henry J. Gielow of New York for Spencer Kellogg of Buffalo. The new craft will contain all conveniences and an endeavor will be made to deliver her about the middle of June.

TRENTON, N.J. Dec. 15 -- Francis D. Carley, the New York broker who failed recently for over $1,000,000, charged, in the United States District Court here to-day, that the Kentucky National Bank was being duped into opposing his discharge from bankruptcy by persons who were seeking to extort money from William K. Vanderbilt and other financiers.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Dec. 15. -- The lighthouses at Point Judith, Watch Hill, and Block Island are without coal and Superintendent H.H. Knowles has been unable to relieve them. He has reported the fact to Superintendent Kimball of the Life Saving Service in Washington.

It was rather dull yesterday. The musical morning at the Waldorf-Astoria, a card party at Mrs. Street's, and two debutante receptions, and a few dinners in the evening, with the opera, constituted the programme. To-day it will be quite busy with its numerous receptions, its card parties, and its very brilliant dance at Mrs. R. Fulton Cutting's, where Miss Alice Roosevelt is a guest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The coal famine has produced one calamity in Washington that has greatly exercised several public officials. The Washington Monument is gradually turning dingy and black from the dense clouds of smoke that hover over the southern part of the city day and night.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- In spite of the present apparent tranquillity in Macedonia, says a dispatch from Salonika to The Times, all the factors making for disturbance are still actively at work. Well-informed people consider the actual state of affairs full of danger, and as threatening increasing gravity unless effective remedies are applied in the next few months.

A mother and her two children lost their lives in a fire which partly burned the tenement at 2,412 First Avenue early yesterday morning. The father of the victims was badly injured in efforts to save his loved ones.

That Mr. CANFIELD, a citizen strongly suspected of aleatory practices which were also illegal, should have his place "pulled" is a novelty in the local enforcement of the statutes of the State of New York. That Mr. CANFIELD should contemplate civil and criminal prosecution of the invaders of his peace and privacy is also a novelty.

A campaign in this State against Mormon polygamy was started last night by several co-operating women's organizations. The first meeting was held in the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Ninety-fifth Street. Other meetings will be held within the next few weeks in cities and towns throughout the State.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- A dispatch from Shanghai to The Times says that Viceroy Chang-Chi-Tung has memorialized the throne against compliance with the establishment by Russia of frontier Custom Houses in Manchuria independent of the Imperial Maritime Customs Service inspectorate.

Mayor Low received a call yesterday afternoon from Richard J. Dohovan, attorney for the Citizens' East Side Improvement Association, which includes several hundred property owners and others interested in Park Avenue property. This assocoiation, which includes among its members the Rev. Father Lavelle of St. Patrick's Cathedral, is the pioneer in the demands for an improvement in the service of the New York Central management in the matter of its passage through Park Avenue.

The coming of rain last night, following a snow flurry in the early evening, brought relief to the minds of the Street Cleaning Department officials, who had been struggling with the snow problem during the past two days. The temperature, too, which kept rising all day, at midnight had reached 35 degrees, jumped 5 degrees by 2 o'clock.
"Fallen Among Thieves" is a play with a moral. The moral is "Let all farmers' daughters study art."

The activity in the curb market yesterday was limited to two or three Issues. The general course of the market during the earlier part of the session was downward, but later improvement was noted, and Northern Securities, the most active stock, after declining to 100 1/2 from 107 3/4, the opening sale, subsequently rose to 108 1/4, and closed at 107 7/8, Saturday's final sale.

Mrs. Annie Stapleton of 435 West Thirty-sixth Street is a patient in Bellevue Hospital, suffering evidently from hysteria. She had been taken from an electric car of the Ninth Avenue line at Forty-second Street. There was no indication of a burn on the woman, but she was paralyzed on the right side in a way that the physicians could not account for except on the theory that she had received a severe electric shock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have followed with keen interest the correspondence that has been going on in your columns about the English drink, "half and half," and was somewhat amused to read in yesterday's paper Mr. Aplin's reply to the various correspondents who have contributed to your columns.

BERLIN, Dec. 15 -- The Lokalanzeiger says the libel proceedings against the Socialist Vorwaerts for the allegations made by that paper against the late Herr Krupp have been stopped by the Public Prosecutor, at the request of the family of the deceased.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- The price movement in this market was irregular today. In certain stocks no little strength was displayed, but in others weakness appeared -- the result of liquidation. American Railways and Lehigh Navigation each receded a point, and Philadelphia Rapid Transit and Union Traction lost a half.

Prof. Adolf Lorenz, the famous Vienna University orthopedic surgeon, performed his first public operation in New York yesterday at the Hospital of the Ruptured and Crippled, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street. At that place he was the guest of Dr. Virgil P. Gibney, the chief surgeon of the institution.

Some allowance must be made for possible errors in reporting in considering the remarks attributed to Mr. J.J. HILL, at St. Paul on Sunday. The weaknesses of human organization in the interviewer and in the interviewed are such that we cannot be sure that the great railway President really said all that was sent over the wires.

The announcement was made in Wall Street yesterday afternoon that a money pool of $50,000,000 had been formed by a number of Banks to be used as a safeguard against a possible money panic. The announcement caused a rally in prices of securities on the Stock Exchange, and had a decidedly sentimental effect in favor of the bulls.

Mayor Charles A. Bookwalter of Indianapolis, who is also President of the American Bowling Congress, the National Association of Bowlers in this country, did not arrive in this city Sunday evening as expected. The train upon which he came was due at 6 o'clock, but did not arrive at the Grand Central Station until about o'clock yesterday morning.

A desperate encounter between a man and woman, in which the woman was shot four times and the man once, took place in Jersey City yesterday. Notwithstanding the fact that all the shots were fired at close range, none of the wounds is serious.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Those Republicans who favor Postmaster General Payne's plan for cutting clown the Southern representation in the National Conventions have found a Southern recruit. Jt is Senator Pritchard of North Carolina. Mr. Payne'a plan includes the cutting down of the Southern representation in the House of Representatives, but Mr. Pritchard does not go that far.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Dec. 11 the "Topics of the Times" disposes of the Christmas tree question with graceful rhetoric and apparently to his own satisfaction. His fatal mistake, however, is in taking periodicals instead of nature as his source of information.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- There is no longer any concealment at the State Department of the fact that the Venezuelan situation is regarded as serious. It is made more serious by the obvious unrest in Congress and the country.

MANILA, Dec. 15. -- The court-martial which is to try Major Edwin F. Glenn of the Fifth Infantry has decided to summon Gens. Chaffee and Smith from the United States to testify as to orders given during the conduct of the campaign on the Island of Samar and to the character of the campaign waged there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Senator Quay insisted on taking up the Statehood fight to-day, and the opposition to the House bill entered on the argument. Senator Dillingham spoke for the majority of the Committee on Territories and gave a running account of the trip that the Beveridge sub-committee made through Oklahoma, New Mexico, and Arizona.

CARACAS, Dec. 16. -- Details of the seizure of the Venezuelan war vessels at La Guayra have been received here. When the combined fleets arrived at that port the German commander delivered to each of the Venezuelan Captains this document:

"You must not give anything to an Irishman; you must not do anything for an Irishman." This was the radical statement made by the Right Hon. HORACE PLUNKETT on Monday evening before the Society for Political Education in explaining the work of the Irish Agricultural Organization Society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Venezuela troubles were the subject of discussion today at the Cabinet meeting, and briefly at the executive session of the Senate.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 16. -- An advance in sleeping car rates between Boston and New York is the latest contribution to the era of high prices. Beginning yesterday, the charge for this form of transportation on both the New York, New Haven and Hartford and Boston and Albany Railroads was increased to $2 for lower berths and $1.50 for uppers.

It has been discovered by the appraisers who investigated the estate of Fernando Yznaga that he was worth over a million dollars more than was estimated when he died on March 6, 1901. At the time his very brief will was filed his lawyers stated that his personal property would not amount to much more than $50,000, but the appraisers have found it to be above $2,000,000.

Auxiliary No. 2 of the Guild for Crippled Children will hold its annual meeting at Tuxedo Hall, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, to-morrow evening; Among the speakers will be Dr. H.L. Taylor, Dr. H.P. Mendes, David Leventritt. and Prof. H. Leipziger. Dr. Lorenz, the Vienna surgeon, has promised to be present.

After two protracted and acrimonious sessions yesterday, at which some additional testimony was adduced and the final argument made on the motion to grant a new trial to Albert T. Patrick, who was convicted of having murdered William Marsh Rice. Recorder Golf last night took all the papers in the case and reserved decision.

With the exception of the site of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company now holds title to the entire block bounded by Madison and Fourth Avenues and Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Streets.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Judging from statements given out by the Foreign Office, the Venezuelan situation to-night is no nearer settlement. Up to a late hour to-night no suggestion had been made that Great Britain could eventually see its way clear to submission of its claims to arbitration.

A doll sent by a little boy to the child of J.Ogden Armour, after she had undergone the operation for dislocation of the hip, performed by Prof. Lorenz, the Austrian specialist, caused the Chicago millionaire to take such an interest in the sender that next Sunday the boy, who is similarly afflicted, will be operated upon by Dr. Lorenz at the New York State Hospital, at Tarrytown.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 16. -- The trial of Miss Laura Biggar, Dr. Charles C. Hendricks, and ex-Justice of the Peace Samuel Stanton, on a charge of conspiracy to secure the estate of the late Henry M. Bennett of Farmingdale, began this morning before Judge Heisley, in the Monmouth County Court of Quarter Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The "Lily White" fight in North Carolina has broken out in a new place, and Surveyor James S. Clarkson of New York is to be brought into it in a new way. A "Lily White" politician was to-day sent to New York to enlist Mr. Clarkson's aid in preventing the removal of the Collector of Customs at Newberne, N.C., and in fighting Senator Pritchard's candidate for the place.

Nothing in the conduct or in the declarations of the two allied Powers now operating against Venezuela has been of a nature to give so much satisfaction to the people of the United States as the statement of Lord LANSDOWNE in the House of Lords yesterday that "it was not intended to land a British force, and still less to occupy Venezuelan territory."

Yale was defeated by the Hockey Club of New York last night in the first hockey match of the season, which was played in the St. Nicholas Rink, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The game was a closely contested one, as the victors won by the narrow score of 2 goals to 1. Notwithstanding the unfavorable night, the attendance was large and there was a fair Yale delegation to stir up considerable enthusiasm.

This evening there will be the dance for Miss Gertrude Pell given by Mrs. Walden Pell. The programme otherwise consists of dinners and small entertainments. With Mrs. 11. Fulton Cutting's ball, and meetings of dancing classes, yesterday was very gay, and the downpour did not seem to dampen in the least the spirits of the debutantes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Judge Elbert H. Gary, on behalf of the United States Steel Corporation, announced to-day the purchase of the Union and Sharon plants of the Union Steel Company near Pittsburg. The transaction will involve a bond issue of $45,000,000. Judge Gary gave out a statement embodying details of the transaction:

-- Not at all for the sake of having the last word, but simply to keep the Christmas-tree topic before our readers for their own moral welfare and the advantage their increase in wisdom may have on the forests of the future, we will gently manhandle once more that friend in Tunkhannock who so fondly imagines that rusticity is a better foundation than science for opinions about the conifers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Dr. Herran, Charge d'Affaires for Colombia, called at the State Department to-day and informed Secretary Hay that Minister Concha had sailed from New York for his home in Colombia. Concha, however, technically continues as Minister and will so continue until he personally presents letters of recall or such letters are presented by his successor.

There was a large attendance last night In Colonial Hall, One Hundred and First Street and Columbus Avenue, to protest against the plan of the Rapid Transit Subway Company to do away with the proposed station at Central Park West and One Hundred and Fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Senator Quarles of Wisconsin to-day introduced a bill for the amendment of the anti-trust law, the purpose of which is to prevent trusts from forcing ruinous competition on rivals in the same line of business. The bill proposes a new section to the existing law, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- There was no division of sentiment in the Senate this afternoon in an hour's discussion of the Venezuelan trouble. The subject was taken up in executive session, and several prominent members expressed their views. The general tone of the speeches by members of both parties was that the position of the Nation should be one of watchfulness.
It is evident that the President made no mistake in the selection of the Anthracite Strike Commission. Commissioner and Judge GRAY alone has a dozen times over shown himself worth his weight in gold.

The Pennsylvania Railroad obtained yesterday from the Board of Aldermen by a vote of 41 to 36, the right to tunnel under the Hudson River to the Borough of Manhattan, to the projected terminal of the company below Thirty-fourth Street, between Seventh and Ninth Avenues, thence eastward under the East River to the Borough of Queens, to connect with the Long Island Railroad system recently acquired by the Pennsylvania Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- An investigation into the advance in the freight rates on grain and grain products, dressed meats, and provisions from the Mississippi River, Chicago, , to New York and Eastern points, governed by the New York rate, was begun to-day by the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

The Greater New York Irish Athletic Association games at the Garden on Dec. 27, by agreement of the managers, must start promptly at 8 P.M. The officials have received notice to be on hand at 7:30 o'clock sharp to get everything in readiness. This order was necessitated by the fact that great numbers of entries are pouring in, especially for the sprints.

"When Johnny Comes Marching Home," according to the programme" a spectacular military opera" and according to the libretto" an American spectacular comic opera," in three acts, book by Stanislaus Stange, music by Julian Edwards, was produced last night for the first time in this city at the New York Theatre.
LA GUAYRA, Venezuela, Dec. 16. -- The arrival of the British cruiser Charybdis and torpedo boat destroyer Quail here yesterday morning caused fear of another bombardment and consequent excitement.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- During the fiscal year ended June 30, 1902, the surface and elevated railroads of the City of New York carried 924,754,211 original passengers; that is, passengers paying fares. Counting the transfers, the total number of passengers carried was 1,100,030,344. It has been estimated that the railroads of New York City carried last year over one and one-half billion passengers.
SAN SALVADOR, Salvador, Dec. 16. -- The newspapers here are urging the South American republics to support Venezuela, but the Government of Salvador is not likely to take any action.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Supplies were limited, money was in active demand and rates were firm to-day. Discounts were easy, owing to the scarcity of bills.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- Vice President Green of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-night expressed his gratification over the action of the Board of Aldermen of New York in sanctioning the tunnel project. He said:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16. -- Rowdy G. fell in the third race and broke Jockey Leblanc's shoulder. Prince Blazes was cut off in the last race, stumbled and fell, throwing Jockey Treanor. The horse showed lame after the accident. After the last race the Stewards sent for Jockey Hicks, whose recent riding on Latson, War Cry, and Moabina, and others horses, is under suspicion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Senator Tillman, who is nothing if not virulent on the negro question, expressed his views to-day on the plan urged by Senator Morgan of Alabama for the colonization of the colored people of the South in the Philippines. He discounts the idea entirely, and predicts that the negro would not go if he could, and the Government, he said, cannot afford to ship him.

With her foot and ankle caught between the edge of an elevated station and a rushing express train yesterday morning, a courageous young woman caught the platform guard rail, and, clinging to it, probably saved her life. The train swept on, and of the crowd that witnessed the accident none moved to help her.

Joseph Donaughey of North Eleventh Street and Kent Avenue, Williamsburg, and James McDermoit of Maspeth, brakemen employed in Palmer's freight yards, North Fifth Street and Kent Avenue, Williamsburg, were killed last night by being caught under a drill engine which was moving freight cars from a float.

EAST ORANGE, Dec. 16. -- Some things about the weakness of the ministry were spoken by the Rev. Dr. James D. Burrell, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Church, New York, in an address before the Presbyterian Union in Brick Presbyterian Church here last night.

The Court of Appeals has just handed down a lengthy opinion holding that the shares of stock which George Jones, the veteran editor and Part owner of THE NEW YORK TIMES, held, while living, in the joint stock association which published that paper are taxable under the inheritance tax law as personal property.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The President entertained at dinner this evening, when his guests were the Secretary of the Navy, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Senators Allison, Hale, Gallinger, Perkins, and Hanna; Representatives Grosvenor, Dalzell, Cannon, Foss, Dayton, and Gen. Granville M. Dodge.

Chancellor Henry M. MacCracken of the New York University in his speech before the New York Alumni Association of the University of Rochester at its annual dinner at the Hotel Manhattan last night declared that he favored twenty-five years as a sufficiently advanced aged for a professional degree.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- While the final arrangements for the obsequies of Mrs. Grant will not be made until after the arrival here of Gen. Grant and other members of the family next Thursday, it is settled that there will be short religious services in this city, and that the remains will be placed by the side of those of her husband in the tomb at Riverside Park, New York.

Chief among the incidents of a day full of action in District Attorney Jerome's war on gamblers in general, and Richard A. Canfield in particular, was the arrest of Jesse Lewisohn of the banking house of Lewisohn Brothers, at 11 Broadway, charged with contumaciously refusing to answer a question put to him before a Magistrate.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- The money market holds firm, and funds are scarce, even at the higher rates. The big banking pool in New York has had no effect as yet. Call loans, 6@6 1/2 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 6@7 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 6 1/2@7 per cent; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 10@8c discount; clearings, $26,011,709; balances, $1,825,227.

The response of the market to the relief measures adopted by the banks on Monday showed in the outside market by a general steadying of quotations accompanied by a few substantial advances. In most parts of the list trading was not very active, but the betterment in prices made up at least to some extent for the absence of much activity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- General Tasker H. Bliss, who was sent to Havana to aid Minister Squiers in drafting a reciprocity treaty between the United States and Cuba, reached Washington this morning and delivered to Secretary Hay the treaty signed in Havana last week. It provides for a 20 per cent. reduction in the tariff charges on Cuban products entering the United States and heavy reductions on American exports to Cuba.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 16. -- Notwithstanding the fact that the mine workers announced yesterday that they had closed their case with the exception of calling one more witness, the entire two sessions of the strike commission to-day were consumed in hearing witnesses for the men. The most important testimony was given by John C. Haddock, an individual operator, and President Samuel Gompers of the American Federation of Labor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16. -- A lengthy conference began this afternoon and ended to-night between Prof. Ira N. Hollis, Chairman of the Athletic Committee; E.E. Krumhaar, 1904, and J.J. Storrow, 1885, for Harvard, and Walter Camp. Theodore S. Woolsey, Henry B. Sargent, the Rev. Anson Phelps Stokes, Jr., and Captains and managers of Yale's Athletic Association.

The brief on behalf of the plaintiff appellees I. Aspinwall Hodge and others, in their case against the United States Steel Corporation, which was made public yesterday, contains many interesting arguments. The brief was filed in Trenton, the defendant corporation having appealed to the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals from the order for a preliminary injunction granted by Vice Chancellor Emery.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- Secretary Hay's note excepting American ships from certain restrictions of the Venezuelan blockade is favorably received by the German Government. The Foreign Office treats the matter as not raising any essential difficulty and as being within precedent, since Secretary Sherman made a similar reservation in the Cretan blockade.

With a view to arranging the details for the reception of the Scottish curlers who are to visit New York during the Winter, and to fix a schedule of bonspiels for the season, a meeting of the Grand National Curling Club of America was held last night. The regularly accredited delegates and others met in the clubhouse of the Caledonian Club, Seventh Avenue, near Fifty-fourth Street.

In the gymnasium of the new Polo Athletic Club, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, last night six representatives of the Columbia University Handball Club played their first handball match against an outside club and were defeated by the New Polo Athletic Club players, but not until a tie was played off, which gave the home players the victory by 4 games to 3.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 17 -- Money conditions remained firm, with call money inclined to a further advance. Indeed, one bank has already raised its rate on call loans to 7 per cent., while the going rate for the bulk of the buisness is from 6 to 6 1/2, with Clearing House money, however, still quoted at 5 per cent.

SANTA FE, New Mexico, Dec. 17 -- New York, Virginia, and New Mexico capitalists to-day incorporated the California Short Line Railway, capitalized at $1,250,000. A line 126 miles long has been surveyed from Alamo Gordo to Deming, crossing the Rio Grande at Las Cruces.

Joseph Jacobs, the ex-Deputy Sheriff of the State of Washington, on whose evidence District Attorney Jerome made a raid on the gambling establishments of Richard A. Canfield and Frank Farrell, was under fire on the witness stand for several hours yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 17 -- James, alias "Red," Callahan, who escaped from the Tombs Prison in New York, is now occupying a ceil in the St. Louis holdover, and declares he will not go back to New York. He says that as he is wanted there merely for a misdemeanor requisition papers cannot be secured for him.
NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 17 -- Mrs. Joseph Todhunter Thompson has rented the Parker cottage on Parker Avenue for the season of 1903.

BUFFALO, Dec. 17 -- John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers, stopped off in Buffalo to-night for an hour. He came from his home in Spring Valley. Ill., and is going to Scranton to continue attendance at the investigation of the Coal Strike Commission.

Either the British Prime Minister spoke without due consideration in the House of Commons yesterday or the earlier declarations of British intentions toward Venezuela must have been made hastily and without much weighing of the responsibilities of official utterance. We are told now by Mr. BALFOUR that a state of war exists between Great Britain and Venezuela.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Dec. 17 -- To prevent the licensing of a saloon by placing a cemetery within eighty rods of the proposed location is the novel attempt that has been made by the temperance people of Fulton.

Only a few outside stocks yesterday developed much activity, but those in which the totals were fairly large showed more animation than has recently been displayed. Prices were somewhat irregular, but those that showed improvement over Tuesday's prices were sufficient in number to indicate a continuance of the inCreased confidence which began to appear a day or two ago.

Controller Grout received yesterday a letter from Eugene E. McLean, engineer of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad, in which he submits President W.H. Newman's proposition to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in relation to the enlargement of its terminal yards from Forty-second Street to Fifty-seventh Street.

Lieut. Col. Crosby P. Miller, Deputy Quartermaster General in addition to his present duties, will report to the commanding General, Department of California, for temporary assignment in charge of the office of the Chief Quartermasters of that department, to relieve Col. Daniel D. Wheeler. Col. Wheeler will proceed to New York City and assume charge of the general depot, relieving Major Isaac W. Littell until relieved by Col. Charles F. Humphrey, Assistant Quartermaster General.

The stock market dragged through a dreary day yesterday, only professionals giving life to the trading by their operations. The public and the commission house element continued to hold aloof, as lately they have done: being apparently indisposed to make any commitments so long as the Venezuelan incident adds to the uncertainty of an already uncertain situation.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 -- In the investigation of the riding of W. Hicks, who was suspended yesterday, the Stewards have uncovered the bookmaking firm of Stitzel Grefer as the alleged instigators of the boy's questionable work in the saddle. They have, therefore, suggested to C.S. Bush, Steward of the Western Jockey Club, that W. Stitzel and F.J. Grefer, operating under the title of the Iowa Club, be ruled off the turf.

Columbia's cane sprees between the sophomores and freshmen of the college classes were decided yesterday, and resuited in a victory for the sophomores, who won two out of the three sprees, Their victory prevents the college freshmen from smoking pipes or carrying canes on the campus.

SCRANTON, Penn. Dec. 17 -- Innings of the coal operators came in the hearings before the coal strike commission to-day. Counsel for the miners closed their case, and the case of the employers was outlined and the introduction of evidence begun.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- There was a strong demand for money in the market to-day. Discounts were firm, owing to the fact that there is less confidence that there will be no rise in the Bank of England's rate of discount before the year's end.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 17 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad was held in the general offices of the company here to-day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The following cablegram was sent to-day by the Navy Department to Admiral Dewey, in command of the combined fleets, adressed to San Juan:
To the Editor of The New York Times: The present financial and commercial condition of the country seems to be a very peculiar one.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 17 -- Iron and steel circles are considerably, exercised over the extension of the United States Steel Corporation's interests. Predictions are freely made that the affiliation of the Jones and Laughlin and Cambria Steel Companies either as auxiliary companies or an integral part of the great combination is not far distant.

A test of the experimental steel road recently laid in Murray Street, between Church Street and Broadway, by the Automobile Club of America was made yesterday under the direction of Gen. Roy Stone, the originator of the movement in favor of these highways, and the results were a remarkable demonstration of the value of the system.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- In the course of a long statement in the House of Commons yesterday the Premier, the Right Hon. A. J. Balfour, said there was no such thing as a "pacific blockade." A state of war actually existed with Venezuela and an intimation of the blockade would shortly be given to the powers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- There was less activity in this market to-day, while the price movement was irregular, indicating the continuance of liquidation whenever the market would take stock at current quotations. Consolidated Lake Superior issues were lower on delay in the expected statement showing the actual conditions of the company.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The trial of Laura Biggar, Dr. Charles C. Hendricks, and ex-Justice of the Peace Samuel Stanton for conspiracy to obtain the estate of Henry M. Bennett was resumed before Judge Heisley in the Monmouth County Court of Quarter Sessions this morning. Miss Biggar appeared to feel the strain of the trial.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Chairman Payne of the Ways and Means Committee to-day reported a bill providing for the exchange of commodities between the United States and the Philippines at 25 per cent, of the rates imposed by the Dingley Tariff act. The bill passed at the last session providing for a civil government for the Philippines fixes the rates at 75 per cent. of those imposed by existing laws.

"General Peanuts," the midget clown of the Barnum Bailey and the Forepaugh and Sells Brothers circuses, was found dead in bed yesterday afternoon in a boarding house at 207 East Fourteenth Street. The belief is that he had heart disease. He was a native of Japan, and he had been in this country about four years.

Prof. Adolf Lorenz, the Austrian surgeon, had yesterday what might be called his most strenuous day in New York. He performed five operations, and the most interesting one was that in which he straightened a clubfoot. That operation was performed in the Post Graduate Hospital, at Second Avenue and Twentieth Street, before the largest assemblage of noted surgeons of those that have gathered to witness exhibitions of his skill in this city.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A correspondent of The Times, telegraphing from Fez, says that the pretender to the throne has complete possession of Tesa and the neighboring districts.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The lawsuit of the American jockey "Johnny" Reiff against the Vie au Grand Air, arising from that newspaper's charges that Reiff had "pulled" the horse St. Saulge, was heard to-day in the Ninth Correctional Tribunal. A number of turfmen were among the spectators.

Assessment of real estate at its full value on the market and publicity of estimates of Assessors so that all property owners might satisfy themselves that they were not being taxed excessively in comparison with the known holdings of their neighbors were spoken of last night by James L. Wells, President of the Tax Department, as the most important reforms necessary to secure an equalization of taxation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The first state dinner in the renovated White House will be given to-morrow evening, when the President and Mrs. Roosevelt will entertain in honor of the Cabinet officers and their wives. The company will, however, be increased by the presence of fifty additional guests who are to include numerous out-of-town friends of the host and hostess.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- James Paxton Voorhees, a son of the late Senator Voorhees, has been laboring for a number of years to create sentiment in favor of the erection of a National theatre at Washington, somewhat after the manner that such institutions are now maintained in France. A bill having this object in view was introduced to-day in the House by Mr. Miers of Indiana.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The House today killed the bill prohibiting military and naval bands from competing with civilian bands.

A tie game between the Andover College and Cutler High School ice hockey teams, played last night in the St. Nicholas Rink, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, gave glowing promise of what is to come in interscholastic hockey, if the play in this game preliminary to the opening of the regrular series was anywhere near a truthful test of relative strength.

Henry Kaufman, a detective in the employ of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, has been cited to appear before Justice O'Gorman of the Supreme Court to-morrow and show cause why he should not be punished for contempt of court, his offense consisting in an alleged attempt to tamper with a juror in a damage case in which the Metropolitan Street Railway Company was the defendant.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The developments in the Venezuelan imbroglio, as revealed by Premier Balfour's statement yesterday in Parliament, have resulted in bringing out in the press this morning stronger expressions than ever of the desire to reach some pacific settlement of the difficulty.

The first Cinderella dance, the theatre party and dance given by Mrs. Leverich for Miss Schuchardt, Mrs. Astor's dinner, and Mrs. Henry Poor's dinner for Miss Edith Poor are some of the events in society to-day. At the Cinderella dance the cotillion is to be led by Alexander Hadden, who has done yeoman's work this Winter.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 17 -- Thomas A. Cleage, leader of the December corn deal, was the target for a speculative bombardment in to-day's market. All the forces which have been arrayed against him since he went forth single-handed to do battle in the pit were concentrated.

The White Star liner Oceanic and the American liner St. Paul sailed yesterday from this port laden with Christmas gifts in letters, packages, bundles, and dry goods boxes. The big liners are due to arrive at Southampton and Liverpool on the day before Christmas, which will permit of the distribution of the greater part of the enormous.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 17 -- In discussing the Venezuelan Imbroglio, the Mexican Herald says:
It was a dull day in the real estate market yesterday, and important transactions were few and far between.

There was something of a flurry in official circles yesterday when it was reported around that the New York and Jersey Railroad Company's tunnel, for which a franchise was granted by the Board of Aldermen Tuesday night, was to be used by the Erie and the Delaware and Lackawanna Railroads to secure a direct connection with Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Senator Depew to-day introduced a bill authorizing the issuance of emergency currency by the Treasury Department. It provides that such currency shall be supplied to any National bank with a capital of not less than $50,000 to the extent of 50 per cent. of the bank's capital.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The Times announces that Strathfieldsaye, the famous seat of the Duke of Wellington, near Reading and Basingstoke, is in the market, to be let with shooting.
CARACAS, Dec. 37 -- It has been decided that the Venezuelan difficulty shall be arbitrated, and the discussion of terms of settlement is now going on.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Representative Fowler, Chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, introduced a bill to-day which was drawn by him in accordance with the views of the Republican members expressed at recent conferences, and which will be urged instead of the Currency bill reported to the House at the last session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The first antitrust legislation of the session was passed in the House to-day without waiting for the Administration Anti-Trust bill. Its passage was totally unexpected and was the result of Democratic manoeuvring.

After the most exciting election in the history of the Twenty-ninth District Republican Club, the forces of Robert C. Morris, the Chairman of the County Republican Committee, were defeated last night by a vote of over 2 to 1. The Morris candidate for President of the club was Newbold Morris.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- A.H. Soden, President of the Boston National League ball club, practically admitted to-day that the probabilities favor a consolidation of the rival baseball leagues, and said that he was ready to sell. The understanding is that a twelve-club circuit will be the result and that Ban Johnson will be the head of the new organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The question of the arbitration of the dispute between Venezuela and Great Britain and Germany remains in abeyance, and is evidently still under consideration by the Foreign Offices at Berlin and London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Government of France has now entered the field as an active party in the Venezuelan trouble.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18. -- The Land Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia, as trustees for holders of gold certificates of the Asphalt Company of America, instituted suit to-day in the United States Circuit Court against Henry Tatnall and John M. Mack, receivers for the Asphalt Company of America and the National Asphalt Company.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 18. -- It was learned here last night that a new turf congress will be formed, and a bitter fight will be waged against the Western, Jockey Club. John J. Ryan, who will open the Newport (Ky.) course for Winter racing next Saturday, stated last night that a meeting of representatives of the tracks not members of the Western Jockey Club will be held in this city next Friday.

The terminal station of the Long Island Railroad at Long Island City, which was built in 1891, at a cost of about $200,000, was destroyed by fire last night. The flames spread so rapidly that within a half hour after the fire had started the station was falling in.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 18. -- In order to relieve the coal famine here the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad has entered into an agreement with the Gould management of the Western Maryland Railroad that if the latter would furnish the cars, engines, and coal the former would permit the Gould men to haul fifty cars per day over the Baltimore and Ohio tracks from Cumberland to Cherry Run and thence to Baltimore over the Western Maryland.

Yesterday's stock market was buoyant from beginning to end, with substantial and sustained advances appearing throughout the list. Sentiment, for some time hopeful, had been given decided encouragement overnight by the favorable turn taken in the Venezuelan matter and by the news from Washington of the introduction in Congress of a bill designed to give relief to the financial situation.

DERBY, Conn., Dec. 18. -- Plans are now completed, the companies incorporated, and the capital found for the construction of the final link in a system of trolley roads connecting Boston with New York City. This is a line from Hartford to New Haven. The backers will be Gay Co., bankers, of State Street, Boston, and James E. Shaw Co., another banking firm of that city.

The people of the United States would hear with great satisfaction that President CASTRO had granted the prayer of many prominent citizens of Venezuela who submitted to him a petition asking that full powers be given to Minister BOWEN to make a settlement of the republic's dispute with Great Britain and Germany.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 18. -- Material for a celebrated case in insurance annals is furnished by the death of Robert C. Whayne, President of the Whayne Manufacturing Company and a prominent business man of this city. He carried $340,000 insurance and had been accepted for $30,000 more. Of this insurance the Equitable Life Assurance Society of New York carried $200,000 and the Provident Savings Life Assurance Society of New York $120,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18. -- The local market responded to the improvement in New York, and became strong and active, under the leadership of Reading, the buying of which came largely from commission houses. Electric Storage Battery advanced 10 points to 85, all stock offered being taken by houses representing inside interests.

No play of the season has been richer in idyllic sentiment and in poetic charm than "Alt Heidelberg" as it was written by Wilhelm Meyer-Foerster and interpreted at the Irving Place Theatre. Anything more flat, stale, and unprofitable than Mr. Aubrey Boucicault's production of his version of the same, which was given for the first time last night at the Princess Theatre, it has seldom been the fate of indulgent first nighters to contemplate.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- A fact which impresses foreign observers here is the indifference of the newspapers and people toward the Venezuelan affair. Not a Berlin newspaper has a leading article on the subject to-day, and the news published is largely an abstract of what the London and New York papers are saying.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 18. -- Counsel for the non-union miners scored an important point before the Coal Strike Commission to-day when it was decided that the strict rules of evidence should not be permitted to shield those who were responsible for the violence and boycotts during the recent strike.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Judge Fitzpatrick, in the United States District Court to-day, heard argument on the rule to show cause why an injunction should not issue to restrain the Pennsylvania Railroad Company from removing, or interfering with, the Western Union Telegraph Company's wires along its system.

Undoubtedly Senator HOAR surprised the Senate when on Wednesday he asked permission to introduce a bill for the regulation of trusts, but that is nothing to what he can do. The Massachusetts Senator is entirely capable of introducing his trust measure, of supporting it stoutly in debate, and then in the end of voting against his own bill.

-- By raising from $100,000 to $250,000 the amount of public money that they are in reality or pretense trying to use in buying coal for "the poor," those ever interesting Aldermen of ours apparently hope to recover some of the popularity they have lost by their prolonged and mysterious hesitations in the matter of the tunnel franchise.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- President Castro has clothed United States Minister Bowen with full powers to effect a settlement with Great Britain, Germany, and Italy. Mr. Bowen simply awaits the consent of the State Department to assume this task, assuming that the nations named are willing that he shall undertake it.
NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Louis Q. Jones closed their cottage to-day, and went to New York for the Winter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the Police Commissionership, a couple of thousand years ago Plato said: "It is better to be governed by good men than by good laws." The struggles of the race since have not been able to evolve better doctrine for human government, except that in these strenuous days we should have to say "good and strong men."

Borough President Cantor has decided to aid the Merchants' Association in the movement, started by the Car Passengers' Rights Society, for better service on the surface and elevated railroads. A reform is to be brought about, he said yesterday, "peaceably if possible, but forcibly if necessary."

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy has been filed against Frederick A. Wahl, who kept a restaurant at 225 and 227 Fifth Avenue, by the following-named creditors: G. S. Nicholas and G.S. Nichalos, Jr., $7,918; the Wilson Distilling Company, $10,364, and Leubrie Elkus, $338. The claims are on notes and for merchandise, principally wines and liquors.
Daniel D. Lawson has sold to an operator the plot at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-eighth Street, 100.11 by 80.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 18. -- As understood here, the blockade to be declared by the allies against Venezuela on Saturday Is to be a "war blockade," as contrasted with the "peace blockade" which has been in operation since the trouble assumed an acute stage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day agreed to favorably report a bill making the gold dollar of the United States the standard unit of value in the Philippines and the lawful money of the United States legal tender in the Philippine Islands for all debts, public and private.

Over 600 Columbia University students assembled in mass meeting at Earl Hall yesterday to do honor to Football Capt. Harold H. Weekes and Coach William R. Morley for the valuable services which they rendered during the past season to the Columbia football team. It was a meeting which will be long remembered by those who witnessed it, as well as those who took part in it.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- Behind the recent movement in Pere Marquette and Hocking Valley Railroad securities is believed to be a merger plan of more than ordinary dimensions.
In a speech delivered last night at the annual banquet of the New York State Bankers' Association, Group VIII., William B. Ridgely, Controller of the Currency, outlined his plans for currency reform.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Navy Department to-day made public a cablegram from Admiral Dewey announcing the proposed itinerary of the vessels of his fleet during the Christmas holidays. The plan provides for no undue, concentration of ships near the Venezuelan coast, and, so prudently have its details been drawn up, that Secretary Moody to-day cabled to the Admiral the department's approval of it.

Before the largest crowd which has yet witnessed him operate. Dr. Adolf Lorenz yesterday restored to their normal position the feet of a child who had suffered since birth with double congenital dislocation of the feet.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18. -- John Peters and Commissioner Forester were the only winning favorites here to-day. W.W. Finn, who bought Suburban Queen for $1,000, sold her to-day to C. Johnson for $1,200. Finn ran Commissioner forester up to $1,700 to-day and bought him at that figure.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 18. -- Three interesting bits of information concerning the baseball outlook for next season were gleaned here to-day. The Directors of the Washington Baseball Club have just received word from President Postal and Manager Tom Loftus, who are now in the West, that all ramors about the latter's Having accepted the management of the New York American League team are false and groundless.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 18. -- The third day of the trial of Laura Biggar, Dr. Charles C. Hendricks, and ex-Justice of the Peace Samuel Stanton, for having conspired, as alleged, to obtain possession of the estate of the late Henry M. Bennett, opened before Judge Heisley this morning.

ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 18. -- Capt. Charles C. Soule, Jr., of the Naval Academy football team for the season of 1903, has appointed Midshipman Arthur G. Caffee of Missouri manager of the team for next year. Midshipman Caffee is a member of the second class, and captained his class football team. He stands fifth in his class as a student.

The plan for an organization of the "Amateur Skating Association of the United States" was announced yesterday in the form of a circular letter, copies of which have been sent to every athletic association in the United States over the signature of Clifford E. Dunn, who has an office in the Pask Row Building, the Secretary and Treasurer of the new organization.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 18. -- President E.P. Ripley and his associates have incorporated the Eastern Railway Company of New Mexico. It is intended to construct the line from a point at or near Rio Puerto on the Santa Fe Pacific in Valencia County, New Mexico, to a point of connection with the Pecos Valley and North-eastern Railway at or near Toxico, near the eastern New Mexico boundary.

Adrian Iselin, Jr., has leased for a long term of years from the Jones estate the two five-story dwellings 711 and 713 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets. It was reported that Mr. Iselin intended to dispose of his present residence at 9 East Twenth-sixth Street, and that the Fifth Avenue houses were to be extensively altered and converted into one large dwelling for his occupancy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt opened the official season this evening by entertaining a company of seventy-five at the first of three state dinners to be given in the remodeled White House. The guests of honor this evening were the members of the Cabinet.

Without doubt that is a judicious order which has just been issued from the War Department, and which sets forth that both officers and enlisted men shall henceforth have permission to visit other posts than their own for the purpose of taking part in athletic contests, without having such absence charged to themselves as "furlough" or "leave of absence."

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Parliament was prorogued this afternoon until Feb. 17 by royal commission. Only a score of members of the House of Commons were present when Black Rod summoned the lower house to the House of Lords to hear the King's speech, which was an unusually long recapitulation of public events since January.

When the two days allowed by law have elapsed Fire Commissioner Sturgis can dismiss Chief Croker from the department. Justice Leventritt of the Supreme Court has vacated the stay ordered by Justice Fitzgerald just after the Chief was ousted in consequence of the trial held before the Commissioner.

TRSNTON, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Further than to make an offer to mediate the ninety-five strikes which have occurred in the State within the past year, the Stare Board of Arbitration has performed no public service. The board admits its uselessness in its annual report to the Legislature now in the printer's hands, and discusses at some length the question of arbitration.

For half a century the Children's Aid Society has held a conspicuous place in this community as the friend of helpless and dependent children. During its long existence it has always possessed the confidence of men whose standing in the community would of itself be a guarantee as to the value of its endeavors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Senate Committee on Labor to-day agreed on a bill based on the provisions of the House measure known as the Eight Hour bill. The amendments made by the Senate Committee are numerous and radical, and several of the features of the House bill that were regarded as essential by the representatives of the labor organizations have been changed.

Prices in the outside market yesterday were steady, bat they showed no such advances as were recorded in the Stock Exchange market. Some declines occurred, but they were few in number, and the stocks which suffered most were one or two very inactive stocks that of late have been in very poor demand.

Gen. Wager Swayne, who had been in bad health for two years and seriously ill for the last fortnight, action of the heart having been weakened by diabetes, died at 3:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon in his home, at 10 West Forty-third Street.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The officials of the Foreign Office say that the reply to Venezuela's arbitration proposal has not yet been sent. The Foreign Office is still exchanging views on the subject with London.

While three boys were skating on the Morris Canal, at Jersey City, yesterday, near the Pacific Avenue Bridge, they fell through. The boys were James Garlin, twelve years old; John Werthwine, clever-years old, and Richard Gill, ten years old, all of 106 Manning Avenue."

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- The money market holds firm, but a distinct improvement is noted in sentiment, due to the belief that the worst is over and that the first of the year will be passed without serious difficulty. Call loans, 6@7 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 6@6 1/2 per cent. Time loans, mercantile paper, 6 1/2@7 per cent. Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- It appears, says the Johannesburg correspondent of The Times, as if the protestations of the Afrikander Bond are no more believed by the Dutch loyalists than by the British.

Cornelius Vanderbilt, who has been suffering from typhoid fever at his home, 22 Park Avenue, for nineteen days, was said to have taken a turn for the worse yesterday, and it was admitted last evening by his physicians that his condition was very grave. The fact developed that the seriousness of his illness has been minimized by his physicians in their reports made public.

But for the tact of Prof. Richard Gottheil and the repeated raps of Chairman N. Taylor Phillips's gavel last evening, the Zionist demonstration in the Temple Emanu-El was in a fair way to be carried away by listeners who took exception to the speech of Jacob De Haas, Secretary of the Federation of American Zionists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce to-day decided to recommend the increase of the appropriation for the removal of the big rock recently discovered at Pier 1, in the North River, from $25,000 to $45,000. The money will be diverted from the Ambrose Channel appropriation.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Money was much wanted in the market to-day in connection with calls due for an aggregate of $4,500,000, principally for the Japanese loan. Discounts were firm. It is believed that further large withdrawals of gold for South America are not likely.

No royal progress, or other form of personal parade possible in our time and in our country, can be compared, in those elements of a "triumph" which a rational and moral man should and must value, with such a triumphal progress as Dr. LORENZ, the Viennese surgeon, is now making in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Messrs. Lyman J. Gage and John Harsen Rhoades, representing the New York Chamber of Commerce, had a conference to-day with Chairman Fowler of the House Banking Committee on the question of the currency and submitted a copy of the resolutions on this subject adopted by the Chamber at a recent meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Negotiation of the Panama Canal treaty with Colombia has again been delayed, and it is now said that no treaty can be expected before Christmas and probably not until the beginning of next year.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Eugene Hughes of Syracuse, who succeeded Col. John F. Gaynor as Treasurer of the Democratic State Committee, died suddenly in Buffalo on Wednesday night of heart disease. He had been ailing for about a year. Mr. Hughes was a member of the contracting firm of Hughes Brothers Bangs, and had been in Buffalo superintending the building of a breakwater.

MR. AUSTIN DOBSON'S new life of the inventor of the English novel (If we may use phrase) is thorough piece of work, executed with care and evident relish. Richardson's was not a personality to arouse enthusiasm, and his life was for the most part plain prose.

In his little quarrel with Sir Edward Clarke, to which we have already alluded, Mr. Edmond Gosse finds the most serious offense of the distinguished lawyer to lie in the fact that he criticises a profession not his own. "By what right," cries Mr. Gosse, "does a member of one profession bring a railing accusation against the whole of another profession?"

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Both Laura Biggar and Dr. Hendricks testified to-day in the trial of the charge of conspiracy to secure the estate of Henry M. Bennett, in which they, with ex-Peace Justice Stanton, are involved as defendants.

In the preface to this monograph on the loyalists in the Revolution Mr. Van Tyne professes to regard their treatment and banishment at the hands of their Whig brethren as "a tragedy but rarely paralleled in the history of the world." He cites as somewhat analogous, at least in their disestrous effects on the respective countries, the banishment of the Moors from Spain and the exile of the Huguenots from France.

MAN rises superior to all other animals, because he cooks. You are not to take this statement as a half truth. It is absolutely and unequivocally correct, and must be accepted. Once man roasted, boiled, or baked, even in the crudest fashion, then human progress had its beginning.

Henry W. Knight, who was mentioned in dispatches from Cincinnati in connection with the Jones Brothers Publishing Company of that city, which has made an assignment, is a book publisher at 150 fifth Avenue, this city. He declined yesterday to say anything about his affairs.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Prices moved irregularly in the local market to-day, and the range of fluctuations reached a wide range in certain issues. Pennsylvania Steel preferred broke five points to 90 on forced liquidation, and Consolidated Lake Superior preferred was down 1 1/2 from the same cause.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I think the correspondent to whom you recommended "Curiosities of Popular Customs" would also like to know of Chambers's "Book of Days," published by the Lippincotts. It can be found at most reference libraries.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 -- John W. Barringer, recently promoted to be office engineer of the St. Louis, Memphis and Southeastern Railroad, was stabbed to death in his office in the Granite Building at 10 o'clock this morning by Thompson Morton, a civil engineer out of work. Morton swallowed bichloride of mercury after stabbing Barringer four times, but prompt use of the stemach pump saved him from death.

District Attorney Jerome and Alfred Lauterbach appeared before Supreme Court Justice Scott yesterday morning to argue the writ of habeas corpus obtained in behalf of Jesse Lewisohn, who was arrested at the District Attorney's instigation because of his refusal last Tuesday to tell Justice \Vyatt or the Grand Jury whether he knew Richard Canfield, the gambler.

Preparatory for the sale of the works of art collected by the late Henry G. Marquand which remain a part of his estate and were not presented to the Metropolitan Museum, the firm having charge of the sale has issued a very sumptuous catalogue, limited to 250 copies, which surpasses in beauty and elaborateness anything heretofore printed for the sales by the American Art Association.

There was a pathetic scene in Judge Warren W. Foster's court yesterday, when Grace Swales Galloway, the "Gypsy Bride," who a few days ago pleaded guilty to the charge of manslaughter in the first degree, was sentenced to fifteen years in the State Prison for Women, at Auburn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Highly optimistic is the view taken of Cuba's progress and future by the British Minister at Havana, Lionel Carden. Officials at the State department are greatly interested in his recent report to the home Government, a copy of which has just been received here. It is completely at variance with many pessimistic reports which have been published in this country.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- Ambassador Charlemagne Tower presented his credentials to Emperor William at the Palace at 2:30 P.M. to-day. All the members of the staff of the Embassy were present. They were driven to and from the palace in royal equipages.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for the estate of James W. Wilson to the State Realty and Mortgage Company the plot on the north side of One Hundred and Eleventh Street, 275 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue, 100 by 100.11.

The very sensible talk of Controller RIDGELY at the bankers' dinner on Thursday evening was in effect, though not professedly, an introduction, and an admirable one, to the Currency bill reported by the House committee the day before. Nothing could be plainer or more convincing than the Controller's statement as to the imperfect way in which the bank currency of the country can, under the present laws, do the work that la thrown on it.

IT IS asserted by The Century Company that "Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch" has been in greater demand than any other book which has hitherto borne these publishers' imprint. No figures are given, but when it is considered that "Mrs. Wiggs" has for the last six months been consistently conspicuous among the "six bear selling books," its widespread popularity is beyond doubt.

SYDNEY, N.S., Dec. 19 -- It is authoritatively stated here that the Dominion Iron and Steel Company will shortly issue either $5,000,000 or $10,000,000 additional common stock to aid in developing its plant here and at Marble Mountain.

THE death of Joseph Parker, the pastor of the City Temple, London, which occurred on the 20th November last, has railed forth various comments by both the English and American press. In the United States his memory will remain, not alone on account of his books, but, in larger measure, because he was a personal friend of Henry Ward Buecher.

BOSTON Mass., Dec. in -- The "American Henley," of which so much has been said during the past two years, now promises to become a reality. The movement first started in this city and the promoters of the idea have been quietly at work. A meeting was held in New York on Dec. 6, but the results were kept secret, the statement being made that full particulars would be announced at a later day.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- A special dispatch from St. Petersburg says nearly 1,000 persons were killed by the earthquake Dec. 16 at Andijan, Russian Central Asia. They were mostly native Turcomans.
ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 19 -- Four hundred thousand persons are reported to be destitute and starving as a result of the crop failure in Finland.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 19 -- Non-union men, some of their relatives, and others to the number of thirty, appeared before the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission to-day and told their stories of alleged boycotts, intimidations, dynamiting, and violence in various forms during the late strike. Each witness called was a sufferer in one form or another at the hands, they alleged, of union men.

THE world wants to know all it possibly can about the lovable Personality of Robert Louis Stevenson, and therefore it will welcome the slight volume, "Memories of Vailima," contributed conjointly by his stepchildren, Mrs, Isabel Strong and Mr. Lloyd Osbourne.

AMONG the children's books there are always some of a serious nature, and among those this year which are outside the ordinary class of fiction is Dickens's "A Child's History of England," (E.P. Dutton Co., $2.50.) It is a comfortable, thick volume, of a good size for holding, with a bright picture cover, the frontispiece and title page with a colored border and the many full-page and text Illustrations in black and white.

Nov. 26-29 Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge sold in London the library of the late Henry W. Cholmley of Howsham Hall, York, 1,063 lots, bringing a total of u5,271 17s. The feature of the library was a fine collection of early printed books and early books with woodcuts.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- New and authoritative chapters on the life and character of Charles Dickens will begin in the January number of The Magazine of Art by Dickens's daughter, Mrs. Perugini. It is an essay entitled "Charles Dickens As a Lover of Art and Artists," and comprises reminiscences, ancedotes, and illustrations never yet reproduced.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19 -- The University hockey team will play in Albany on Feb. 5 and 6, and in New York on Feb. 7 with Yale, at the St. Nicholas Rink. The following men have been retained at the training table: Class of 1903 -- S. McClave, Speer. A. Roche, Jr., Alexander; 1904 -- L. Purnell: 1905 -- King, Leak, Auerback, L. Loyd, Rulon, Miller; 1906 -- Larned, Rafferty, G. Patton.

Senator Platt and Gov. Odell both feached this city last evening, but though they both dined at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, they did not meet. Immediately after he had dined, Gov. Odell went to the Ninth Regiment Armory to review the regiment, and Senator Platt also had an engagement out. It is expected that the Senator and the Governor will meet to-day to talk over matters of legislation and appointments.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- At a meeting at Tremont Temple this evening it was voted by a large majority to extend a call to the Rev. Dr. George C. Lorimer, now pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, New York., Dr. Lorimer left the Temple for his present charge and should he accept the call it will be the fourth time he has become its pastor.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The demand for money was active in the market to-day, and supplies Were short. Borrowers were largely dependent on the Bank of England.

With the designation of Minister BOWEN as the representative and plenipotentiary of Venezuela, her dispute with Great Britain and Germany passes into an easier stage, and our anxieties are thereby much diminished. According to the terms of the document in which he is authorized to act, Mr. BOWEN has full power to effect a settlement, and he is to use "all means possible to protect the interests of Venezuela."

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Probably The late Mr. G.A. Henty was the most Prolific story writer of the day. Nobody seems to know exactly how many stories he has written, but he has poured them out at the rate of three or four a year for many years.

GOUVERNEUR MORRIS has gone back to the opening of the civil war for the scene of his latest romance, "Aladdin O'Brien," but his book is removed as far as possible from the many tales which have lately been built upon that muchabused theme, and its title, with its odd suggestion of East and West, is quite in harmony with the quaint fancies and delicate humor that are so adroitly mingled with strong and pathetic situations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Provisions of the treaty negotiated with Cuba by Gen. Bliss were made known here this evening. This convention was made the subject of several important conferences at the Capitol and White House and will be one of the chief topics for discussion after the holiday recess.

The Senate has held an interesting debate on the militia bill prepared by the War Department. When debates in the Senate are not vitiated by faction they are very apt to be not only interesting, but illuminating.

Mr. Rudyard Kipling's story in Collier's Christmas number, a number in every way so creditable, is doubtless the chief ornament of the magazine. It will cheer up a great many American readers with the testimony it gives that the story teller has regained the complete possesssion of his faculties.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Responses have been received from Berlin and London to the proposal of President Castro, made through United States Minister Bowen, to arbitrate the differences with Venezuela.

The Annual Book Number of The Springfield (Mass.) Union is full of trustworthy and readable articles on current literature, as it could not fall to be, because a large part of its contents were "lifted" bodily from various numbers of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF Books. Some of the articles thus appropriated, including one on "Christmas Books," and Mr. Gilder's eloquent appreciation of Mr. Janvier's "Christmas Kalends," are duly credited.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 19 -- After keen competition and extended trial of the different systems of train control, the Brooklyn elevated railroad has awarded the contract for all its trains to the Westinghouse Electrical and Manufacturing Company for the Westinghouse electro-pneumatic control.

Dr. Adolf Lorenz yesterday performed four more operations for congenital hip dislocation, with the same successful results which have attended his efforts since his visit to New York. In fact, in one case of double dislocation of the hip bones he established a good record by reducing one of the deformed hips in one minute and twenty-five seconds.

H.M. Brock, an imaginative and poetic artist, who is, we assume, related to the Charles E. Brock who some years ago performed the difficult feat of providing a set of pictures to illustrate "The Essays of Elis," and did it so well that the most jealous admirer of taipb must gratefully admit that the charm of his writing was actually enhanced by the Illustrations, has clone the same thing for Dr. Holmes.

ITHACA N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The annual dinner in honor of the Cornell track team was given here to-night. The guests of honor were members of the cross country team, who recently won the intercollegiate championship in New York City. The final basket ball game between the track team and the crew to determine the athletic championship of the university was postponed in order that the track five might attend the dinner.

LAPSING, Mich., Dec. 19 -- Gov. Bliss will not permit the McGovern-Corbett fight, which was to have been held in Detroit next month before the Metropolitan Athletic Club. He wrote this afternoon to Sheriff Dickson of Wayne County, calling his attention to the law on the subject and telling him that he expected him as Sheriff to see that the fight was not held in Detroit.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 19 -- A large consignment of bronze rivets for the new cup boat arrived to-day. This fact is taken as indicating that the work of riveting will soon begin. Accompanying the rivets, which were made in New York, is a specially constructed crucible for the heating process when the plates are fastened.

The Appellate Division yesterday held, by Justice Ingraham, that the complaint in the action brought by the city against the Third Avenue Railroad Company and the Metropolitan Street Railway Company to recover car license fees aggregating $25,750, due from the former company to the city during the years 1894 to 1899, did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action as against the Metropolitan Company.
Thomas Hardy, the novelist, writes to The Dorset (England) County Chronicle in remembrance of Mrs. Baxter, known as "Leader Scott," who died Nov. 10 in Florence:

The controversy started nearly two years ago by the proclamation by Prof. KOCH that bovine tuberculosis is not communicable to human beings will derive fresh impetus by the insistence of that learned specialist that his original contention was correct and that no contradictory, evidence thus far produced is convincing or entitled to serious scientific consideration.

Arrangements have been completed in this city for the interment ceremonies over the body of Mrs. Julia Dent Grant, which will take place at the tomb of Gen. Grant at 11 o'clock to-morrow morning, when the body of the widow of the illustrious soldier will be laid to rest beside that of her husband.

Mr. Fountain's personnlity which renders the reading of his "The Great Mountains and Forests of South America" such a continued surprise. "With his calling we have nothing to do, for he styles himself a "peddler, or rather, traveling huckster, wandering on the outskirts of the settled country."

IN "The Call of the Sea "Mr. Tooker shows no very remarkable qualities, nor does he attempt any metres that are not easy. Artistic elaboration is not a part of his plan, nor does he on the other hand mold his simplicity to austere forms.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- A slump in Title and Trust shares, which took them from 115 down to 106 on sale, ex-dividend of 1 1/2 per cent., was the feature of the trading on the local Exchange. The stock has met constant pressure for several months, and to-day it developed that the competition which the company is likely to encounter will be worse than was expected.

IN these days of travel and exploratton, when the earth has been getting smaller and smaller as mechanical invention has annihilated distance and the spread of knowledge dissipated ignorance, it might seem surprising that a country of gigantic proportions should exist almost at our very doors whose interior has been practically a sealed book to the world and whose physical characteristics have been almost unknown.
