John F. Carroll resigned the Democratic leadership of the Twenty-ninth District last night at a meeting of the District Committee held at 45 East Fifty-ninth Street, and Joseph F. Mulqueen was elected as his successor. The meeting of the committee was called to elect officers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave her third large tea this afternoon from 4 until 6 o'clock. The north door was used, the guests entering directly into the great Colonial hallway, which combines all the space of the former lobby and red corridor. The red parlor in which the guests were received is now completed, the furniture having arrived several days ago.

Three persons were dangerously, perhaps fatall, injured and fifty-seven others bruised and severely shaken up in a trolley car accident in Weehawken at midnight last night. The three badly injured are:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The severity with which the coal famine visits suffering on the peer was shown here to-day in consequence of a hoax played by some unknown advertiser in a local paper.

CARACAS, Dec. 19 -- The correspondent here of The Associated Press has secured a copy of the answer of the Venezuelan Government to the German note of Dec. 7, addressed to Lopez Baralt, Venezuelan Minister of Foreign Affairs, by Herr von Pilgrim-Baltazzi, the German Charge.
Great as is the popular interest in the personality and the private life of actors and actresses, the life behind the footlights has never proved more than moderateiy fruitful to the story teller.

To-day the most notable event is to be the wedding of Miss Kountze and Robert Livingston in Grace Church. There are several debutantes to be brought out. Mrs. John C. Calhoun will give a reception for Miss Julia Calhoun, at which the debutante and her mother will be assisted by several distinguished Southern matrons and young women.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: There has been so little said in New York City about Mr. Viele's "The Last of the Knickerbockers," whereas in Chicago there has been so much, that I should like to make a few critical remarks about the book myself, particularly now, when every one is glad to know of a good book as a possible Christmas or New Year's gift.

Our contemporary The American Economist, which is the organ of those who believe in protection for what there is in it, has been prompted to sarcasm and betrayed into a blazing indiscretion by the comments of THE TIMES upon the President's message.

Sir Walter Besant once said his one demand for a novel was that it should take him in Us grip and refuse to let him go. It is difficult to apply this test for the public behoof, since the story that grips one mind may possess a mercurial elusiveness to another; hence, no doubt, the widely diverse criticisms which provoke the scoffer's unholy mirth.

Members of the Canadian Society of New York and their guests assembled at the annual dinner of the society last night at Delmonico's, enthusiastically applauded the sentiments expressed by Sir Frederick W. Borden, Minister of Militia and Defense in the Canadian Government, who was the guest of honor of the occasion, and responded to the toast, "Canada."

Dec. 3-5, Stan. V. Henkels sold in Philadelphia Harold Peirce's choice collection of engravings and etchings and original drawings by Sir Edward Burne-Jones. The feature of the sale was the special collection of fifteen chalk drawings by Burne-Jones, this being the first time that examples of his work were offered to the American public.

Yes, the time has passed, never to return again, when that dear old mammy existed, "that black foster-parent," who lived only for "dem white chillun." It was simple adoration on her part. Call it animal at your peril, for it was tempered with such tenderness and thoughtfulness as only could come from a specially organized being.

Mr. Alden, Youth. Mr. Alden, the veteran editor of Harper's Magazine, tells about the early life of the boys and girls of New England sixty years ago, in the Editor's Study of the magazine for January. His early boyhood, he says, was passed in a district in the mountains of Vermont near the source of the Otter Creek.

The most perplexing duty that falls to the lot of the librarian or book committee of a public circulating library is the determination of the books to be placed on the shelves. When fewer books were published the limitation in this regard might be determined largely by the size of the book fund.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Increases in wages amounting to $600,000 a year are to be granted the locomotive engineers and firemen employed by the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad and its branch lines, through an agreement reached to-day between officials of the railroads and committees representing the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen.

Price movements in the outside market yesterday were not as uniform as they had been for the past two days, and the gains recorded were to a greater extent intermingled with losses. But the most important changes were still on the side of advances, and in no case were the net declines of a size to be discouraging.

The Lippincott Company is earning for itself an honorable distinction among American publishing houses by the attention it is paying to local history, especially in the way of "fixing" reminiscences, both in picture and text, that otherwise would be fleeting.
SUBJECT -- Review. GOLDEN TEXT -- Lord, Thou hast been our dwelling place in all generations. -- Psalm xc., 1.

The biographical method of musical history has many drawbacks, chief of which is the liability of the historian fall into a mere cataloguing of names and a brief summarizing of works. The result is apt to be dry, and too frequently fails to give a lucid view of the general movement and development of the art, A view of the road is impeded by the trees.

Alfred H. Henry's romance of Mormonism, "By Order of the Prophet," is a story sufficiently well told to hold the reader's attention closely and arouse his sympathies. Doubtless, too, it is essentially true to history and to the facts concerning the development of Mormonism in Utah.

Some improvement was reported last night in the condition of Cornelius Vanderbilt, who is ill with typhoid fever, complicated by peritonitis, at his home, 22 Park Avenue. At 11:20 o'clock the following bulletin was issued:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The principal business transacted by the House of Representatives to-day was the passage of the Pure Food bill introduced by Mr. Hepburn of Iowa. Four bills for the purpose have been introduced in the House, but the Hepburn bill was reported from the Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce, of which Mr. Hepburn is Chairman.

For the dinner of the Tariff Commitee of the Reform Club last evening in the clubhouse, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, covers were laid for 120. Wallace "MacFarlane, who presided and acted as toastmaster, announced that the subject to be discussed was "The Tariff: Its Relation to Exports, Trusts, and Trade Restrictions Generally."
The Frencn liner La Savioe arrived yesterday from Havre, having completed an unusually rough passage in remarkably quick time.

Through the arrest yesterday of four men, two of whom are known to the police, following the arrests of four other men and a woman since Dec. 16, the police of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Stations believe that they have cleared up the mystery of a long series of robberies in stores on One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 20 -- Work will be started very soon on a new station for the Pennsylvania Railroad at Albany Street and Easton Avenue, New Brunswick, to cost approximately $50,000. Railroad men say that no town of New Brunswick's size on the Pennsylvania system will have a handsomer building.

IT may be acute observation, it may be the more habit of reiteration that the oracles know so well it may be the chronicle of just plain matter of fact, but sure is this: A Wall Street news bulletin cannot be picked up these days without there looms, in some verbiage or other, the item that announces:

CAN any of you gentlemen lend me a two-cent stamp for thirty days, taking my nine as security?" asked the Idiot, as he took his place at the breakfast table one morning not long before Christmas. "I've a very important letter to mail, and I haven't a cent with which to pay the postage."

IT WAS the first Christmas after the war. Appomattox had not been forgotten, and desolation still hung over the South like a great black shadow. The plenty of the past, the poverty of the present, the dark uncertainty of the future, haunted memories, and heartaches and tears were in the place of joyous feeling and gladful smiles.

THE magnate was a satisfied man. As he sat in his library that night, Nov. 11, 1902, to be exact, he could not help but think that things were well with him. He and his associates had managed to shake out the well held stocks that Mr. Gates and his associates had guarded to long and so well.

The reception room in Bellevue Hospital had the appearanee of having been struck by a small cyclone late last night, after a woman patient had done a few things. She was a stylishly dressed woman of about thirty-eight years of age, who gave her name as Margaret McCarthy. She had been brought in a hansom cab from 202 West Forty-third Street, by a man who said he was William Emmett.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 5 -- It has often been made a matter for wonder that Brussels has never been a favorite place of residence with Americans. This seems to be all the more remarkable, because the many advantages of the Belgian capital as a residential town have long been recognized by persons of other nationalities -- English, German, and Russian, for instance.

WHEN the Legislature meets the first Wednesday in January the names of twenty-eight Republicans and twenty-two Democrats will be called from the Senate roll, and the names of eighty-nine Republicans and sixty-one Democrats from the Assembly roll. Of the Senators thirty-one were re-elected, or 62 per cent.

Definite anouncemtnt may now be made that a new Wanamaker store will be built covering the entire block bounded by Broadway and Fourth Avenue, Eighth and Ninth Streets. Many of the details of the new enterprise are still in an imperfect shape, and just how soon the work of construction will be begun is not known.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If you would allow the necessary space in the columns of your paper I would like to answer Mr. Sayre's question of the 28th of November, viz.: What kind of officers can those be who claim that discipline and efficiency are promoted by allowing what the experience of all other employers teaches them to forbid?

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last Sunday I heard the Rev. Dr. Silverman of Temple Emanu-El lecture before the Zion Educational League. Among the many wise sayings of the rabbi, the following are, I think, worthy to be analyzed:
To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading a report of the speech of Mr. Baer at the Waldorf-Astoria, my thoughts reverted to an incident that occurred in England about thirty-five years ago.

Edward F. Croker, Chief of the Fire Department, vacated his office yesterday in recognition of Justice Leventritt's decision, and stepped out of Fire Department service at noon, to bo succeeded by Charles D. Purroy as Acting Chief of Department.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 20 -- The adjournment of the Constitutional Convention and the radical nature of its work has aroused both enthusiasm and disgust. Especially is there condemnation of the countenance given the woman suffragists. Here and there one meets objection to some of the other proposals, but to this one there is something like general dissent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt, accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt and four of their children. Theodore, Jr., Kermit, Archie, and Ethel, left Washington at 12:05 P.M. to-day for Rapidan. Va., to pass Sunday with Joseph Wilmer and family. Not an inkling of the President's intentions had been permitted to become public.
THE man with the ear trumpet was encountered in a Broadway car. After the conventional salutations had been nassed, the question, Well, what do you hear that's new! was asked.

The Oratorio Society's Christmas performance of "The Messiah" will be given in Carnegie Hall on Friday afternoon and Saturday evening under the direction of Mr. Frank Damrosch. The solo singers will be Mme. Suzanne Adams, soprano; Mme. Kirkby Lunn, contralto; Theodore Van Yorx, tenor; Herbert Witherspoon, basso.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Anent the renewed interest in the extraordinary consumption (?) of water in this city. I wish to call attention to one of the causes of a great deal of waste which I have not seen mentioned in the public prints, viz., the placing of uncovered hot and cold water pipes in close proximity in the walls of flats and apartment houses.

YES," said Charley Slowboy, "it is queer, deucedly queer, how quick some young ladies are to take offense or get miffed over some little thing and give a fellow the cold shoulder without letting on what it is all about.

The yellow fever symposium of the American Public Health Association Wednesday night was a most Interesting contribution to sanitary science and on many points convincing to the laity. A disease which caused America the loss of thousands of lives and many disturbing panics in the past was stripped of most of its horrors and shown to be one of the most easily controlled and protected against.

HONOLULU, Dec. 13, (via San Francisco, Dec. 20.) -- The opening of the cable between Honolulu and San Francisco will be celebrated here as a holiday, and the Merchants' Association is preparing to observe the occasion publicly. The first message will be from President Roosevelt to Gov. Dole, and the Governor's reply will be the first message sent from Honolulu.
J.Q.A. BOGGS, Jr., the scion of an aristocratic house, stood on one leg, about which he twined the other. At the same time he twisted his small body into graceful curves.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since you have been good enough not yet to "closure'' the interesting correspondence in regard to half-and-half in particular, and incidentally malt liquor in general, I should like to say two words.

NEWARK, Dec. 20 -- Elizabeth Auer, who keeps a notion store at 29 Bowery Street, this city, is locked up at Police Headquarters, charged with shoplifting, and her stock of goods, estimated at $200, has been confiscated and identified as having been stolen from various department stores. The goods consist of lace, ribbons, thread, wearing apparel, c.

There has been considerable activity within the past week among the billiard players, both professional and amateur. In the absence of any plans being formulated for the usual Amateur Athletic Union championship, Ferdinand Poggenberg, one of the leading amateurs, has arranged that the Liederkranz Club will hold an amateur tournament the latter part of next month.

Mayor Low, Controller Grout, and several officials of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company held a conference yesterday in reference to the depression of tracks in the Park Avenue tunnel and the improvements incidental to the change of power in the tunnel from steam to electricity.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I ask the courtesy of your great journal for a little space to make a few suggestions as to the transportation of men and women in New York.

A conference of Republican leaders was held in Senator Platt's headquarters at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Those who took part in it were Senator Platt, Gov. Odell, Col. Dunn, Chairman of the State Republican Committee, and Lieut. Gov. Woodruff. The meeting had to do with State affairs.

CHRISTMAS celebrations at the different town clubs will not be general. Neither will there be any marked notice made of New Year's, as in former times. The existence of country clubs and the many house parties all over the country residence area will take many men away from the clubs during the holidays.

In certain periods the nice conduct of a clouded cane has been deemed a praiseworthy exercise imparting self-discipline and refined instincts and worthy of celebration by the foremost poets of the time. A chastened art in the management of one's personal appurtenances and belongings goes in general with and signifies a high grade of merit and moral as well as aesthetical qualities of a superior order.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- According to a ruling of Justice Gavnor, no policeman has the right to make an arrest without a warrant, unless he sees committed an act that is in violation of the law.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The semiannual examinations of the Cadet Corps have begun. They will be completed next Tuesday. This is the first time these examinations have taken place in December.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Right Hon. Horace Plunkett, one-time representative in Parliament of Dublin University, in his speech before the League for Political Education, in Berkeley Lyceum Monday evening, was picturesque, at least, in all fairness be it said; but he certainly was not convincing.

THIS day had finished the loading of the vessel for her trip across the ocean, and now, as the sun was sinking behind the shrouds of the ship, to the west, the stevedores filed in front of the officer who was checking off and paying for the hours they had worked.

"MY husband is just too mean for anything!" There were tears in the eyes of the young wife as she said the words, but as it was into her mother's confiding ears she poured her tale of woe her grief was hidden from the world at large.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- E.H. Harriman of the Southern Pacific and Union Pacific Railroad Companies and the Pacific Mail Steamship Company to-day had a conference with Secretary Root about taking over, either under charter or by purchase, the Government's fleet of army transports now plying between San Francisco and Manila and operating the ships in conjunction with the Pacific Mail Company to form a new line of steamers between San Francisco and the Orient.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- It is not often that a great, municipality is willing to make a noted dramatist and poet its Mayor. This, however, will soon happen in Berlin, for a committee of the City Council has recommended to that body the appointment of Dr. Georg Reicke, a premising young writer.

For the last time the members of the Union Club gathered last night in their club house at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, which for nearly half a century, has been the home of the organization. It was an occasion when the few old-timers and the younger members of the club met to revive the memories of the past and bid farewell to the old building.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- A publication has just been issued here which should be of great convenience to foreign students who are desirous of taking up studies in Paris among surroundings more or less identified with the spirit of their respective countries. This is the "Livret de l'Etudiant," which is a handbook on the asociations and societies of students in Paris, issued under the auspices of the Minister of Public Instruction.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- At a special meeting lasting less than fifteen minutes the Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-day made changes in the operating department of the company far more important than those which have ever attended any change in the Presidency, broke precedents in jumping young men over those supposed to be established for life, and arranged to transfer to other offices men in high positions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Pritchards "Lily White" machine to-night is boasting of a victory. The President has nominated Mr. Pritchard's candidate, D. H. Patrick, to be Collector of Customs at Newberne, N.C. The "Lily Whites" are hardly able to contain their exultation, and they are predicting that Postmaster Vick will be removed at Wilson, although impartial observers of the President's course do not think there is any probability of that.

THE long controversy concerning the new High School for the Borough of Richmond has been settled at last. The cornerstone of the new building was laid last week by Commissioner Lummis, Chairman of the Committee on Buildings of the Board of Education, and from now on the work will be pushed forward with all possible speed.

There were several first -- class swimming races decided in the natatorium of the New York Athletic Club last night and, although there were only three events on the programme, the trial heats in each brought out about half a score of lively contests. Honors were equally divided, as first prize in each event went to representatives of different clubs.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 -- Jockey Buchanan landed Moor two lengths in front of The Lady to-day at the finish of the Crescent City Handicap, worth $2,040 to the winner. The Durnell Herz pair, The Lady and Scotch Plaid, were decided favorites at 13 to 5. The Simon pair, Moor and Major Mansir, opened at sixes and were backed to 9 to 2.

If there ever was a time when Mexico objected to immigration it is long past and belongs to the period when clericals and imperialists were opposing progress of all kinds tooth and nail. At present there is a grand outburst of energy in Mexico, stimulated by the foreign capital poured into the country, and this energy calls for laborers in many fields, in mines, new railroads, new buildings, plantations.

No temptation more frequently and more insidiously besets the jaded first highter than the temptation to discover unsuspected powers in actors of the second order, and to herald such actors as superior to the stars of the companies in which they happen to be playing. It seems so discriminating, and it gives such a dramatic turn to the report of a performance.

Those who have followed what is popularly known as the Taff Vale case will be interested in learning that the King's Bench Division of the British High Court of Justice, Sir ALFRED WILLS presiding, has rendered a decision in favor of the railroad and against the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants involving damages for a strike and its attendant evils brought about by the action of that society.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 -- At the fifty-fourth annual dinner of the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce, held to-night, the guests of honor were Gov. Nash, Adjt. Gen. Corbin, Gen. S.M.B. Young, and Gen. A. E. Chaffee. United States Army; John G. Milburn of Buffalo, and Senator M.A. Hanna.

Once again Clyde Fitch has reached down into his magician's bag and brought forth a play, which will be christened at the Savoy on Christmas night. "The Girl with the Green Eyes" is described as an entirely original play, in four acts, deriving its title from the nickname which Jinny Tillman, who has just been married to Jack Austin, received from her parents.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 20 -- "Locomotives cannot be had for favor or money just now," said President Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to-day in discussing the lack of handling power. "For seven years the Baltimore and Ohio has been pouring money into improvements and increased facilities, and we have had more money to spend than we could possibly use.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The postal officials throughout the country and especially in the large cities are just now having the most arduous work of the year, owing the general use made of the mails in forwarding Christmas presents and greetings. This work is progressive, each year adding to the burdens of the mails and consequently to the burdens and annoyances of those whose business it is to handle and safely deliver letters and packages.

THIS Cristmas season will go down in history among the manufacturers and dealers in toys as one of the most remarkable on record, for it has been distinguished by the introduction of several distinctly new and costly toys which it is said are bound to take a permanent place in the business.

THE best information in the office of the Tax Commissioners is to the effect that the total assessed valuation of real estate in the five boroughs comprising the Greater New York next year will be approximately $5,000,000,000. That, one of the best-informed officials there said to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, would work no hardship unless the State authorities returned to the system of direct taxation.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Three bank-note forgers who were committed far trial Dec. 10 pleaded guilty and were sentenced in the Old Bailey this morning, Philip Bernstein to twenty years', Solomon Barmash to fifteen years', and William Barmash to ten years' imprisonment.

BAKED beans are becoming almost a National dish. They are a standby of the dairy restaurants in New York and other large cities as well as Boston, which gets the credit of developing its brain forces upon them. They are a special Saturday night and Sunday morning dish all through New England, and in the lumber camps and the navy and army, where nourishing food at low cost is desired, they are staples.

The deep concern and displeasure with which the people of the United States have read the British proclamation of blockade against Venezuela will be tempered only by the simultaneous announcement that Great Britain and Germany have joined in a proposal that President ROOSEVELT arbitrate the issues between themselves and the South American republic.

THE recent extreme weather has warranted the display of milady's furs in all their splendor, and from sables to squirrel there has been a brave showing. Fur is becoming to every one, provided judgment is shown in the selection of color and the cut of the garment or stole.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Money was demanded at the beginning of this week, the market subsequently becoming quieter. The demand slightly increased on Wednesday, but the market was uneven. Money was much wanted early on Thursday, owing partly to an installment on the last Japanese loan being due, but it became more abundant in the afternoon.

The largest attendance of the season of preliminary hockey games last night in the St. Nicholas Rink, Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue, witnessed a victory by the Princeton University seven over the St. Nicholas Skating Club by a score of 4 to 1 after about the fastest and prettiest contest of the young season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The necessity for close restriction having passed, active recruiting for all branches of the army will be resumed under certain modifications of the regulations. Until further orders, persons under the age of twenty-one years will not be enlisted, and extreme caution is enjoined in the cases of young men applying for enlistment who say they are twenty-one years old, or a few months over that age.

LISBON, Dec. 10 -- If the present British negotiations for the right of way through Portuguese West Africa go through, as there is every reason to believe they will, and if the plan of an English company, to construct a railway from Lobito Bay to the eastern frontier of Portuguese West Africa be accomplished within reasonable time, the position of this country among the nations of the world will be materially changed.

THE answers-to-inquiries editor being ill, Mr. Inkleigh, the railroad editor, was pressed into service, as there was an unusually heavy lot of inquiries. It was the Christmas season, and, of course, everybody wanted some advice about what to give. It may be said that Mr. Inkleigh accepted the task with cheerfulness, even with delight, and that he toiled late one night in the laudable endeavor to answer each and every query.

The incorporation of the General Education Board by Congress, which will undoubtedly be accomplished at the present session, draws public attention afresh to the purposes and methods of that important organization. These are received, it is hardly necessary to say to our readers, with approval fairly proportioned to the intelligence of those who study them.

ROME, Dec. 12 -- Now that an official announcement has been published in La Tribuna di Roma giving the exact date -- April 20-25 -- of the visit of the Czar and Czarina to Rome, the papers are seriously discussing the supposed international aspects of the affair, while the undisguised annoyance of the Paris press forms the subject of many pithy paragraphs.
SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 20 -- The anthracite coal strike commission held its last session of the year to-day and adjourned to meet in Philadelphia on Jan. 6.

The annual dinner of the Builders' League of New York was held last night at their clubhouse, 74 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street. The guest of honor was Jacob A. Cantor, President of the Borough of Manhattan. John P. Leo, President of the club, presided. He first introduced Mr. Cantor, who said in part:
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The official proclamation of the blockade of Venezuela ports was gazetted this morning, and becomes effective to-day.

The market situation has witnessed as yet no change from the conditions which have governed it for the last month or six weeks, and with brokers who handle large operations, the Wall Street money rate continues to be quite as much a subject of attention as other matters more obviously of a real estate character.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your edition of Sunday, Dec. 14, you published an account of some modern maladies which have been discovered through the cleverness of the author of the article referred to. I was much surprised to find that in your "medical researches" you have not mentioned "Telephonitis," and I ask you to kindly publish the following in your next Sunday edition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The two houses, after brief sessions, to-day adjourned until Jan. 5. The adjustment of the differences between the two bodies on the bill providing for the compensation and expenses of the Coal Strike Commission seemed to be the only matter of importance which held them together.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Should the Railroad Commission of this city give its consent, an interesting experiment in passenger transportation will be made here. A private company has offered to build a "hanging" railway (Schwebebahn) to reach territory not now covered by the transportation lines.

John Jacob Astor has decided to sell about forty additional parcels of real estate on the lower east side to the present lessees of these properties -- the transaction being similar in its main features to that of two years ago, when he disposed of the entire block bounded by Avenue A and First Avenue, Fourth and Fifth Streets.

MADRID, Dec. 20 -- The police have arrested the entire Humbert family, which became notorious in connection with the great "safe fraud" in Paris. The members had been in this city since May 9. The prisoners comprise Mme. Humbert, her husband, Eva Humbert, and the three d'Aurignacs, Remain, Emile, and Marie.

Mr. Louis Solyom is perhaps the most accomplished linguist In the Congressional Library. Ho speaks ten languages, and reads in a still larger number. He is one of the few Americans who are able to read and speak the Chinese, Japanese, Turkish, Hungarian, and Polish languages, and, among other duties, attends to the cataloguing of works in the Chinese, Turkish, and other Oriental languages owned by the library.

Gen. Charles Dick, who is an avowed candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of Ohio, is now serving his third term in Congress as Representative from the Nineteenth District of the State, and has been elected to the next Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Krishna, a Water Cress colt, from the stable of Walter B. Jennings, won the California Jockey Club Futurity Stakes at Ingleside to-day. The event had a gross value of $13,254, which made it one of the most valuable races ever decided on the Pacific Coast.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ever since the close of the eventful day when Admiral George Dewey played that shell game with the Spaniards in Manila Bay the press has continually harped upon "the moral and material advantages that will surely accrue to the people of the Philippine Islands by the benevolent assimilation and annexation and supervision of these United States."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- Trading was limited, the sales aggregating 22,134 shares and $29,400 bonds. The only features were the developement or further weakness in the Consolidated Lake Superior issues, a 2-point break in Pennsylvania Steel common, a recovery of a like amount in the preferred, and an advance of 2 points in Electric Storage Battery on the statement that the deal with the General Electric Company will be consummated the coming week.
A conference at which the Police Commissionership was discussed was held yesterday between Gov. Odell and Mayor Low. The place where it was held was not disclosed.

AFTER an examination of the long lists of American slave ships, (now long since forgotten) that can be found in she old-time documents of Congress, it appears likely that the most notable of them all was the clipper ship Venus, built at Baltimore, in 1838, "for foreign account."
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Wednesday number of THE TIMES you publish a leader on "German Absolutism and the Tariff." In this you state:

OUT on Hudson Heights, a suburb of Jersey City, Mrs. Charles Betz conducts the most successful and largest English bulldog farm in the vicinity of New York. There are on this farm fifty-nine bulldogs and a few Boston terriers, but Mrs. Betz counts the latter simply as "dogs," and though she gives them good care she is not as watchful of them as she is of the English "bulls."

Some eighteen months ago the Governor of Yakutsk informed the Imperial Scientific Academy of St. Petersburg of an unusually interesting discovery in Siberia. A Cossack had learned from the natives that a gigantic animal with huge tusks had been found imbedded in the ice on the Beresovska, a tributary of the Kolyma River, about two hundred miles from Svedin-Kolymsk.

HAVANA, Dec. 12 -- For more than a month past every steamer has brought many tourists to the island. Even the very rough weather of late, during which the big ships have come into port with sea-washed decks, has not checked the stream of travel. Places of interest are filled with strangers, there are many on the principal streets and in the shops.

According to a referee's report, which is to be submitted to the Supreme Court immediately, Mrs. Heloise Durant Rose is entitled to $753,931 from the estate of her father, Dr. Thomas C. Durant, founder of the Adirondack Railway, and one of the men whose fortunes suffered in the crash of the Credit Mobiller.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- The American Derby, to be run next year on June 20, will have its value increased by $5,000. The Washington Park Club will add in all $25,000 to the great classic, which trill bring the total value of the race up to close to $30,000. Announcement of the stake list of the club's twenty-five-day meeting was made to-day by Secretary Howard.

The last bulletin concerning the condition of Cornellus Vanderbilt was issued by Drs. Austin Flint, Jr., and E.G. Janeway at 7:30 o'clock last night, after, a consultation with Drs. Delafield and Brown. It read:

THERE is an idea prevalent among most folks that Christmas is a time for secrecy. And, to be sure, the mysterious rings at the bell, and the whisking of equally mysterious parcels out of the way is awfully jolly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the name of a large number of persons who are lovers of art I wish to protest against the removal of the glorious Watts picture, "Love and Life," from the Corcoran Art Gallery in Washington to the President's private apartments in the White House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Advices have reached here from Manila to the effect that the bands of ladrones which are harassing the rural population of the islands are in many instances led by negroes who have been discharged from the army and are employing their military knowledge in drilling the ladrones and organizing them in a crude military way.

Dr. Adolf Lorenz was lionized by many New York society women yesterday. They assembled in the lecture room of the New York Orthopaedic Hospital and Dispensary in East Fifty-night Street, near Lexington Avenue, crowded around him, and presented large bunches of flowers to him. The surgeon bowed, uttered polite remarks, and kissed the hands of the women to whom he was introduced.

THE Professor was one of those profound thinkers who are led so far away from their physical surroundings in pursuing a great idea that it takes them some time to get their "bearings" when they let go of it.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day. The Bank of England charged 4 1/2 per cent. for loans on short bills, which hardened discounts.

TOKIO, Nov. 25 -- A Japanese landscape is distinguished by the torri which invariably belongs to it. Wooded hills and waterfalls, overlooking miles of fertile valley and shaded roads fringed with wayside flowers appeal more strikingly to travelers than in other lands, because nature, having none too much room, was forced to compress her material.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Mrs. M.E. Olmsted entertained this evening at a costume dinner in honor of Miss Texas Bates, who is to be married to Dunn McKee next Saturday. The entertainment was a dinner in place of the usual luncheon in order that the bride and her friends might celebrate the approaching event at the same time the groom-elect was giving his bachelor dinner in New York.

MARLEY was dead. The author must insist at the very outset that the reader take that for granted; which, being said and done. there will be no occasion to follow the established precedent and devote pages to a description of the exact degree of Marley's deadness.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 20 -- The annual meeting of the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association adjourned to-night after re-electing the present officers, as follows:

Richard Mansfield a few seasons ago announced it as his belief that it was practical and sufficient for an artist to confine his advertising to newspapers. He began to eliminate in consequence certain features of pictorial advertising. He stopped using small novelty picture cards, and the use of his lithograph in show windows.

THERE are a number of women in town just now who are practicing going without corsets for half an hour each day to became accustomed to the unusual condition. They are the women who are to play with Miss Elizabeth Tyree in "Gretna Green." the romantic comedy which is to be brought out at the Madison Square Theatre on Jan. 5.

RUSSIAN railway officials will shortly make experiments with some inflammable railway carriages on the German-Russian frontier. The carriages have been constructed in Prussia by a private firm, and will be formed into a special train. This will be set on fire when leaving Edythuhnen, if this will be possible.

It will not strengthen the executive management of the Manhattan system in public confidence to manifest impatience of criticism based upon the conditions daily and nightly developed in train operation. Doubtless some of this criticism is unintelligent and better calculated to annoy than to stimulate the management, but so long as good ground for criticism exists more significance should attach to the facts than to the manner in which they are presented to the public.

VENEZUELA may seem to the present generation of Germans a new field for investment, and perhaps it is considered a poor one, in view of the fact that the Government has been using the railway built by German money without paying for transportation, and that on top of refusal to pay other legitimate debts.

THE scent of Winter violets greeted Poindexter on Christmas morning as he leaned out of his open window to look through the pallid dawn toward the west, where his thoughts had so often strayed during the lonely months following her departure. This air was clear and crisp and tinged with the icy breath of the snow-capped ridge thirty miles away, but the fragrance of violets pervaded the coolness with an exquisite suggestion of departed Summer.

Dressed in the garb of the Little Sisters of the Poor, Mrs. Emma Meyer, thirty years old, of 405 East Sixteenth Street, was arrested last evening by Policeman Sullivan of the East Fifty-first Street Station, charged with obtaining money for charity under false pretenses. She was arrested on complaint of Mrs. Sadie Murty of 912 Second Avenue, at whose home.

The holiday crowd that makes the most of the Saturday before Christmas was out in force yesterday. The day crowd was mainly of those in comfortable circumstances, or of carriage folk or of chronic "shoppers." That of the night was of the people at large, wage-earners, salaried folks, or those who are paid for labor by the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Morgan's revelation made in the Senate a few cays ago in regard to the expenditures made by the Panama Canal Commission, of which Admiral Walker was the President has brought forward a resolution in the House which will elicit from the Secretary of State a report and which will show in detail all the expenditures made by that body.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- The close of the week finds the money market considerably improved. The change is largely sentimental, as rates are still high, but the recent stringency also was mainly a thing of sentiment rather than of actual distress. The usual table of local rates, , follows:

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 7 -- Constantinople may be the abode of smells, of germs, of unnamable insects, and, worst of all, of myriad dogs; but in spite of these and many other and equally disagreeable features, there is a charm about it which compel forgiveness for its deficiencies and forgetfulness of them when they are out of sight.

Notwithstanding many features that make the performance of "Tosca" as it is given at the Metropolitan Opera House one of remarkable power, Puccini's opera does not seem yet to exercise a great attraction over the patrons of the institution. At the repetition of it given there yesterday afternoon the audience was not a large one: the near approach of the holiday season may have had much to do also with the comparatively light attendance.

ANSONIA, Conn., Dec. 18 -- Stephen Charters, Ansonia's "Carpenter Mayor," and his fifty-five trades union city officials have completed their first year in office, and for the first time in America the question whether a city composed two-thirds of workingmen can best be administered by workingmen themselves has been given a thorough test.
SCENE -- A large department store, toy department, the day before Christmas.

The week before Christmas is usually given up to the young people. All of the schools have vacation, and trains have been pouring in at the Grand Central station crowded with the young hopefuls of society. The future cotillion leaders and riders to hounds and amateur chauffeurs and elubmen will have a jolly time this fornight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt has proposed to the allied powers that the Venezuelan dispute be submitted to the arbitration of The Hague Tribunal. The powers have replied with a counter proposal that President Roosevelt himself arbitrate the issues.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- With Christmas so close, Paris is now denuded of Americans, save the regular residents.

IF CHRISTMAS EVE comes in mild and warm and Christmas morning follows its gentle prophecy, the florists will be the happiest men in New York. That will mean that the thousands of boxes of Christmas flowers which must be delivered on Christmas forenoon can go out with only the ordinary packing.

Fair wages are as indefinite as the size of the traditional piece of chalk. Judge Gray of the Anthracite Strike Commission used the phrase, but with evidently no intention of defining it, or ascertaining its meaning or building any conclusions upon an assumption of what constitutes fair wages.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Two hundred of Chicago's prominent business men were at the dinner of the Chicago Bankers' Club tonight. The chief speaker of the evening was Secretary of the Treasury Shaw, who addressed the club on "Possible Financial Legislation." His remarks were warmly received.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A well-dressed New York woman was arrested here to-day by two of the detectives who are watching the stores during the Christmas shopping period. There is the usual Christmas demand for extra cash girls, and the fifteen-year-old daughter of William White of 1,013 New Jersey Avenue, Southwest, was applying for a position for the holidays.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 10 -- The formal statement of the Russian Government regarding the future of Port Arthur and Lalny, published in The Gazette, adds another item to the long list of Russia's broken promises.

SAMUEL WRIGHT, bachelor, capitalist, and millionaire, gazed at four heaps of letters. "What's the matter, George?" he asked of the smooth-faced, imperturbable young man at the opposite side of the big square desk, "have you robbed the Post Office?"

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- There is much talk in the London halfpenny press just now about an arbitration scheme for settling differences between France and Great Britain. This naturally interests people in Paris, and as the scheme is mainly identical with that which Lord Salisbury unsuccessfully attempted to establish a few years ago with the United States, it may have some retrospective interest for Americans.

A story about the happenings of one day in District Attorney Jerome's office has been written for The World's Work by Alfred Hodder. Mr. Jerome's Private Secretary. He tells of the many sorts of crime tales that the public prosecutor and his assistants hear in every twenty-four hours, the difficulties and intricacies of the inside office, and the inquiries held behind closed doors and never repeated outside.

The announcement that in the Christmas performance of "The Messiah" by the Oratorio Society. Mr. Frank Damrosch, the conductor, win use a new revision of the score of Handel's masterwork is one of interest to musical amateurs. "The Messiah" is the most popular of all the works of its kind and the most often performed.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Chancellor von Buelow received the correspondent of The Associated Press to-day. The correspondent, in asking for the interview, represented that a statement from Emperor William's first Minister at this time might clear up any doubt which might exist of Germany's purposes.

The body of Mrs. Julia Dent Grant was placed in the sarcophagus next to that of her husband, Gen. Ulysses S. Grant, last night, after which the sarcophagus was closed and sealed. The hope of the soldier that he and his wife should be buried together was realized. The religious service at the tomb is to take place to-day.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The week's end at Tuxedo was exceedingly lively. The beautiful weather of Friday and Saturday attracted a large gathering to the clubhouse for the sleighing, coasting, and skating.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 20 -- The Coroner's jury which investigated the death of R.C. Whayne, a prominent business man, who was found last Thursday night in the vicinity of Jacob Park with a gunshot wound in the breast, late this afternoon returned a verdict of accidental death. Great interest was manifested in the case, as Mr. Whayne carried life insurance policies aggregating $390,000 and had applied for $50,000 more.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 20 -- No such doctor as Henry Loeber, who was held up in New York, is known here.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Venezuela has been the absorbing topic of conversation this week, dwarfing all matters of domestic politics into insignificance, though these include the final passing of the Education bill, placing it as an act on the statute book of the realm.
CLOTHES may not make the man," said an observant lawyer the other day, "but they have considerable effect upon the wearer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Don't let up on the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company because the weather is clear. No ice on the third rail this morning and not a down-town train in sight at Eighteenth Street and Third Avenue at 9 A.M. Every morning at the same point and hour wide saps between trains are usual.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- I learn on the highest authority that not only does Germany desire that President Roosevelt act as arbitrator of the Venezuelan difficulty, but that in fact the acceptance of arbitration by Germany and Great Britain is the logical outcome of a written agreement between the United States, Great Britain, and Germany.

The question which is now causing more discussion among the Republican politicians of the city than any other is, Was the defeat of Dock Commissioner McDougall Hawkes for the Republican leadership of the Twenty-fifth Assembly District dictated by Senator Platt, or was it merely due to district differences?

WASHINGTON, Dec 20 -- A report on the Eight-Hour Labor bill was submitted to the Senate to-day by chairman McComas of the Labor Committee. A large number of amendments were made to the House bill in the committee, so that aside from the principle involved the two bills are radically different.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The indignation formerly aroused by coal-mine operators and turned now against parents, some of American-Irish name, who permit little children to work in mines under miserable and life-killing conditions for a pittance, may seem at first justifiable wrath.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through the columns of your broad-minded and humane paper I wish to call attention to the evils which the Manhattan Elevated is inflicting on a long-suffering public.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 -- The first payment in the absorption of the Louisville and Nashville by the Atlantic Coast Line Company was made to-day at the Safe Deposit and Trust Company, fiscal agent of the Atlantic Coast Line. It was 25 per cent. and amounted to $2,656,250. The other 75 per cent., amounting to $7,968,750, will be paid before Feb. 14.

Charles J. Muntwegler, nineteen years old, of 1,712 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, who has been employed as a clerk in the State Bank at 378 Grand Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Flammer, in the Essex Market Court, yesterday on a charge of forgery in connection with the deposit and discounting of a note for $600, alleged to be fictitious.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- After a series of experiments covering a period of more than five years. Dr. W. Byron Coakley of Chicago has determined to his own satisfaction that to administer local treatment to the heart is not the impossibility the world's scientists always have held it to be.

That the majority in Congress is not so hopelessly Bourbon as it was at one time, and not long ago, that it can forget and can learn some things, is shown by the favor with which the bill is received cutting off three-fourths of the duties on imports from the Philippine Islands. The measure has so far met with no serious opposition.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 21 -- After eight experiments, conducted with the greatest secrecy, Marconi announces that he has solved the problem of wireless transoceanic communication and has successfully transmitted wireless messages from the shores of Canada to the coast of England.

DUBLIN, Dec. 21 -- The land conference between Irish landlords and tenants was opened at the Mansion House here yesterday. The proceedings were secret. An official report issued to-day announces that Lord Dunraven, John E. Redmond, Lord Mavo, William O'Brien, T.W. Russell, and others were present.

Dr. Adolf Lorenz performed his last public operation in this vicinity yesterday, when he went to Tarrytown and operated upon the six-year-old son of Thomas Black, a canalboat Captain, at the New York State Hospital for the Care of Crippled and Deformed Children. He will leave for Boston this morning at 10 o'clock, and will operate an hour after he arrives in that city.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 21 -- The North China Daily News has received the serious information from Shen-Si that Tung-Fu-Siang, the exiled Chinese commander, whose execution was demanded by the powers, but who is supposed to be protected by the Dowager Empress, is mobilizing in Kan-Su 10,000 well-equipped troops, among whom are included the provincial garrison of 4,000 men, who were disbanded by imperial command.
PLYMOUTH, England, Dec. 21 -- The Hamburg-American Line steamer Deutschland, with her starboard engine disabled, arrived here at 2:15 this afternoon.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 21 -- The blockade of Venezuelan ports was begun with an effective force at midnight last night. The British have the cruisers Indefatigable, Alert, and Tribune, the special service steamer Columbine, and the torpedo boat destroyer Rocket along the coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The non-contiguous territory of the United States is supplying a large and growing market to the producers and manufacturers of the country. The October statement of the Treasury Bureau of Statistics shows that the shipments of merchandise from the United States to Porto Rico in the ten months ending with October, 1902, amounted to practically $10,000,000 -- $1,000,000 a month -- against $6,750,000 in the corresponding months of last year.

DENVER, Dec. 21 -- Attorney General Charles C. Post is the central figure of the hour in the Colorado Sena orial situation. By his vote in the Board of Canvassers on Monday Mr. Post may decide the pending struggle in favor of Senator Teller or ex-Senator Edward O. Wolcott, or he may cause a legislative deadlock that would mean a vacant chair in the United States Senate for two years.
A double collision by which two men were injured and a parlor car destroyed occurred in the Waido Avenue freight yard of the Pennsylvania Railroad, Jersey City, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the various names mentioned in your paper from time to time as the possible Police Commissioner of the City of New York, there is one who, in my opinion, if he will accept the position, would be the most eminently qualified for the position with its most onerous duties, and that gentleman is Gen. Francis V. Greene.

The Central Federated Union took up yesterday the subject of the overcrowding of the surface and elevated cars. The following preamble and resolution, submitted by Delegate McConville of the Safety Association of Engineers, were adopted:

The Earl of Rosslyn arrived yesterday on the Cunarder Etruria, minus u310 which he lost on the trip over, not in trying to put into practice his sure-thing gambling system, but in the good old game of poker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Considerable information bearing on the development of railroading in India and the present condition of railways in that country is given in a report from R.F. Patterson, United States Consul General at Calcutta, on this subject, issued under date of Nov. 12.

The assurance we were able to give in our news columns yesterday morning that the leaders of the Republican Party have decided that the Buffalo canal plan shall be submitted to the Legislature at the approaching session is very encouraging.

We have already remarked on the speech of Controller RIDGELY and its direct bearing on the Currency bill of the Banking Committee of the House. The bill also receives strong support in the clear and pointed address by Secretary SHAW in Chicago on Saturday evening.

A double force worked at the General Post Office and the foreign branch at West and Morton Streets all day yesterday and last night, and it was said the office would be turned over to the day force coming on this morning with all work finished up to the hour. This, considering the fact that in addition to the heavy Christmas mail at this season, over 6,000 bags of foreign mail arrived since Saturday evening.

Coroner Williams of Williamsburg and Coroner's Physician Wuest yesterday made an investigation touching the death oh Saturday night from the effects of carbolic acid of Elizabeth Hansen, the eight-year-old daughter of Christopher Hansen of 207 Monitor Street, Williamsburg. Hansen and his wife went out to buy Christmas presents Saturday night, and the girl felt very bad because she could not go along.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- A special messenger has left here for Madrid with all the documents necessary for the extradition of the Humberts. The prisoners are expected here on Wednesday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 21 -- The last obstacle in the way of transferring the coveted beach front and the sewer system to the city has been removed, and the transfer papers, which were signed by "Founder" Bradley and his legal representatives in New York City yesterday, are to be presented to the Aldermen at a special meeting to-morrow evening.

Probably for geographical reasons, bringing centres of population nearer together and giving shorter hauls between them and from agricultural and manufacturing districts to the seaboard, the steam railroads of the United Kingdom are more apprehensive of permanent injury from the competition of electric lines than the great railway systems of this country appear to be.
The Regents of the University of the State of New York have granted a charter to the American Institute of Social Service. The first Board of Trustees will consist of the following incorporators:
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- It is believed that President Roosevelt's answer to the proposal made by the allied powers that he arbitrate the Venezuelan issues has been received in London.
BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- During the past week the Boerse has in no manner been influenced by the Venezuelan situation. Values remained firm, with light trading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- According to men who recently have arrived in this city from Washington, the next Senator from that State will be Levi Ankeny of Walla Walla, between whose career and that of J. Edward Addicks they say there are many resemblances.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The affairs of the Chinese Imperial Maritime Customs, says the Shanghai correspondent of The Times, are attracting serious attention within and without the service. It is generally recognized that the recent actions of certain powers are calculated gravely to affect the future of the administration.

With the reception this afternoon the Metropolitan Museum of Art inaugurates the new wing on Fifth Avenue, and at the same time adds a good many galleries to its space for exhibits. The old portion has definitely taken its place as the centre of a widespreading building, which eventually will have three more wings or fronts -- north, west, and south -- that will screen the middle section.

MADRID, Dec. 21 -- According to published interviews, Frederic Humbert, who, with Mme. Humbert and the other members of the family, was arrested here yesterday declares that the revelations to be made by the family will rival the Panama scandals, and show that he and the others were the victims of robbers who exploited them.

Beside the sarcophagus that contains the body of Mrs. Julia Dent Grant in the tomb of Gen. Grant a brief burial service was conducted yesterday morning. The members of the Grant family were there with many friends, and all of the officers of the army and navy who are stationed in and near this city.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 21 -- Alfred Mosely, who has just made a tour of the United States with a number of representatives of British labor unions, for the purpose of studying American industrial conditions and the relations in America between capital and labor arrived here to-day on the Cunard Line steamer Umbria from New York.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 21 -- The average grain crop gathered in Finland is valued at $30,000,000. The estimated value of the 1902 crop is $20,000,000. While there has been loss throughout Finland, the failure of the crops is almost total in the northern third of the country, where are the Provinces of Uloaborg, Kuoplo, Vasa, St. Michel, and portions of Viborg.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice in your issue of the 19th a letter signed "C.E." on the subject of an article on college slang quoted from a Philadelphia paper in THE TIMES of Dec. 14, in which the writer of the article referred to is said to wonder whence comes the verb "to gray," meaning to get drunk.

If precedent counts for aught, Saturday's bank statement should prove to be the last unfavorable one for some time, though as a matter of fact that statement was really not unfavorable, showing as it did a substantial reduction in loans. The disappointing part of it lay in the loss in cash, for the reason that the known investments of money had indicated a gain for the week.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The Times to-day publishes the following poem by Rudyard Kipling, called "The Rowers":

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 21 -- The Rev. E.G. Richardson of St. James's Episcopal Church preached on "The Drink Evil and Common Sense Temperance" this morning, in the course of which he declared the army canteen should be restored.
NEW MILFORD, Conn., Dec. 21 -- Fire to-day in Ingleside School, a large and fashionable seminary for girls, conducted by Mrs. William D. Black, caused damage estimated at $40,000.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 22 -- That the war of the rebellion was a necessity from the very nature of the Constitution of the United States and that right was with both sides to the contest, was the contention made to-night by Charles Francis Adams historian and biographer. He spoke at the Yule-tide banquet of the New England Society of this city on " Necessity."

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Dec. 22 -- The local Post Office is in receipt of 2,000 letters from a New York collection agency addressed to residents here. Each of the letters contains a claim for $1.20, said to be due for the purchae of jewelry. A suit is threatened in case of non-remittance.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22 -- A dispatch from Quebec recounting the work of the conference held there last week by the representatives of the different provinces of the Dominion, which resolved to meet again when Sir Wilfrid Laurier returns to Canada, and to go in a body to Ottawa to ask better terms from the Federal Government, says most of the provinces are unable to pay their way at present.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Attorney General Davies this afternoon gave a hearing on the application of Col. John N. Partridge, as Police Commissioner of New York City, for the authorization of proceedings to test the title of nineteen Police Captains appointed in December, 1900, a short time before the law was passed to abolish the bi-partisan Police Board.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day and borrowers were entirely dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were firm.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: I perfectly indorse Mr. Murray's remarks relative to the fairness of THE NEW YORK TIMES's leading articles relative to the Venezuela trouble, yet at the same time I think he is giving himself needless anxiety concerning the outcome of the same, especially as, to quote his own words, "the matter is in safe hands with our President Roosevelt and Secretary Hay."

VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- Prof. Baron von Krafft-Ebing of the University of Vienna, the celebrated nerve specialist, is dead at Graz-Styria. He was at one time an adherent of Prof. Lombroso, but later held views antagonistic to those of the Italian scientist.

The poem of Mr. RUDYARD KIPLING, which we yesterday copied from The London Times of the same date, does not, we think, contain anything calculated to wound American sensibilities. Of German sensibilities it does not make any pretense of taking account. That it is not wounding to British sensibilities may, apparently, be safely inferred from its appearance in the chief organ of British opinion.

At times in the market for outside securities yesterday considerable strength was displayed, and a number of substantial advances appeared in various parts of the list. For the most part these gains were followed by reactions, but the net results of the day were still sufficiently favorable to be regarded with satisfaction by the friends of improvement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Commander Diehl of the Marietta, which now lies at La Guayra, has sent to the Navy Department this message, by way of Haiti, dated yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Stories from London that President Roosevelt has indicated his acceptance of his post of arbitrator of the differences between Venezuela and the allied powers are denied officially. It is said that no invitation to the President his been extended, although one may be on the way.

BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- The Allgemeine Elektricitaets Gesellschaft, with $22,125,000 capital in bonds, and the Union Elektricitaets Gesellschaft, having $85,000,000 capital, have reached an agreement amounting to a practical consolidation, the Directors of each company being elected members of the board of the other, so that the management is identical, though the companies nominally remain separate.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Laura Biggar resumed her testimony this morning in the Quarter Sessions Court, before Judge Neisley at the trial for alleged conspiracy to secure possession of the Bennett estate. She was subjected to a long cross-examination by Mr. Wilson at counsel for the State.

While the Merchants' Association and other organizations were vigorously waging their warfare against street car inconveniences in this city yesterday the troubles of passengers, especially on the elevated railroad lines, were by no means lessened. Platforms were crowded, trains were packed, and many were complaining.

CARACAS, Dec. 22 -- There is no truth in the report published in the United States that President Castro is suffering from a mysterious illness. The correspondent of The Associated Press saw the President today. He is enjoying his usual health.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- The Wartburg Orphan Asylum, that has about 250 children, on the outskirts of this city, is without coal. The children range in age from three to thirteen years. The rooms of the eight buildings have high ceilings, and it has been found impossible to heat them with gas or oil stoves.

The general effect of the report on the matter of ship subsidies in Great Britain is adverse to the system as it is used in other countries. The committee, which was a particularly strong one, reported that subsidies directly given to British ships would do no good in building up a mercantile marine, and would be apt to do harm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The contest for the ratification of the Cuban reciprocity treaty promises to be determined and interesting. Leading opponents to the movement to bring about reciprocal exchanges with Cuba last year were Senators and Representatives from beet-growing States, and these gentlemen resisted every proposition looking to a reduction of tariff rates on merchandise coming from the island.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The formalities in the matter of the extradition of the members of the Humbert family, who were arrested in Madrid last Saturday, and of escorting them back to the scene of their former triumphs, are proceeding rapidly. The public awaits with intense interest the return to Paris of the famous fugitives.
DRESDEN, Dec. 22 -- The Crown Princess of Saxony fled from her home during the night of Dec. 11-12.

Ernest Gabler Brother's piano factory, at 214-224 East Twenty-second Street, was destroyed by fire early last night. The loss is estimated at $350,000, fully covered by insurance, but it will be at least two years, according to one of the owners of the factory, before the plant can be replaced and business resumed.

The old home of the Union Club was invaded yesterday by the public, eager and curious, to search through the big house at Twenty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, where an auction was held. Incidentally, they were there to pick up bargains. The shrewd ones did, but the bargains were few and far between.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The second edition of The Times to-day prints the text of a wireless Marconi message received from the Canadian Government as follows:

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Dec. 22 -- Robert Giles, a Government road contractor and manager of the Automobile Transportation Company, has been arrested in connection with the smuggling cases. He has been arraigned, charged with smuggling. He pleaded not guilty.

Miss Josephine Dodge Daskam, the author, rather astonished the members of the Pilgrim Mothers' Society yesterday afternoon when she expressed her views on "The Girls of the Future." The women who hold membership in the society, after a dinner in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria, had been listening to responses to toasts on women in business, in law, in medicine, and at the ballot box when Miss Daskam spoke.

Mr. CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS is the most ingenious pacifier of the age. He has in one short address, delivered at the banquet of the New England Society in Charleston, S.C., last night, put an end to a discussion which has raged among us in the mouths of orators and of cannon for more than a century.

VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- The flight of the Crown Princess of Saxony has caused great excitement here. It is reported that the Archduke Ferdinand, accompanied by one of the Court Chamberlains, went to Geneva, whither it was supposed the Princess had fled, but he failed to find any trace of her.
Blankets for toy dogs are of velvet, satinlined, with high collars, edged with swan'sdown or some fine, soft fur.

The new wing of the Metropolitan Art Museum, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-first Street, was opened formally to the public yesterday afternoon. A prayer by the Right Rev. H.Y. Satterlee, D.D., Bishop of Washington; brief addresses of delivery and acceptance by W.R. Willcox; President of the Department of Parks, and F. W. Rhinelander, President of the Trustees of the Museum, and an address by Mayor Low constituted the exercises.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The question of the effect of murder upon a life insurance policy when issued upon the life of the murderer to-day was passed upon by the United States Supreme Court in an opinion delivered by Justice Brewer. The case in which the opinion was delivered was that of S.M. Burt vs. The Union Central Life Insurance Company.
George A. Kingsbury, representing H.W. Savage, is sending out as Christmas gifts German beer steins bearing the words "Here's to the heart that beats for me -- the Prince of Pilsen."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 22 -- The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of Bishop John J. O'Connor's ordination to the priesthood was begun this morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral, where a pontifical high mass was celebrated. Bishop O'Connor was the celebrant, and the Rev. A.H. Stein, pastor of the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, was master of ceremonies.

George C. Edgar's Sons have sold the new five-story American-basement dwelling 7 East Eighty-eighth Street, 24.6 by 100.8. This sale disposes of the last of a row of three houses erected by the sellers at that point.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- The stock market was harder to-day and active for Sugar and Amalgamated Copper Range and some other specialities. Manifestly attempts to depress Calumet have ended and the buying orders for a few shares started the price upward as rapidly as it was falling a few weeks since.

BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- The notes of Germany and Great Britain formally inviting President Roosevelt to act as arbitrator in the Venezuelan dispute were handed to the United States Ambassador here and to the United States Charge d' Affaires in London to-day.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday resumed the secret proceedings before Justice Wyatt in the case of the people against Richard Canfield, which were so suddenly interrupted last week by the refusal of Jesse Lewisohn, the young banker, to reply to a question as to whether he knew Mr. Canfield.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- By juggling the Constitution of the American League, the annual meeting of that baseball organization held here to-day was made a "special" meeting, and it was decided to hold the annual meeting in New York some time during the month of January.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your issue of this date contains an item under the heading "Methodists Disappointed" which, unexplained, is misleading. First, it is not true that there was a loss of 2,182 members in "Manhattan and the Bronx and Brooklyn" in 1902. There was an apparent loss of precisely that number of members in the entire territory covered by the New York and the New York East Conferences in 1902.

On the eve of his departure for home it is due to the great Viennese surgeon, Dr. ADOLPH LORENZ, to offer him such an expression of the thanks of the American people as a journal of opinion may feel itself authorized to express.

The suggestion of abolishing the Coroners' Office or substituting a system for medical examiners was discussed at the meeting of the Medical Society in the lecture room of the Academy of Medicine, in Forty-third Street, last evening. For several hours X-rays were discussed, and then by a resolution the X-rays were turned upon the Coroners' Office.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- At the Clearing House balances between the banks loaned at 5 per cent. and New York funds sold at 15 cents per $1,000 discount. The exchanges were $17,116,773 against $16,644,876 a year ago to-day, an increase of $1,471,897, or 9 per cent., and the balances were $1,230,397. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 1/2 per cent.; time money, 6@7 per cent.; commercial bills, 6@7 per cent.

Yesterday's stock market was strong from the opening minute of the session until the closing. The improved outlook for an early settlement of the Venezuelan trouble, the easier tone in the money market, and the growing conviction that prices are down in many cases to a ridiculously low point, far below, indeed, their investment level -- these were the factors influencing to the market's strength.

OMAHA, Dec. 22 -- After being snowbound for three days, twenty-four hours of which were passed completely under an immense snowdrift, passengers of the Burlington's train from Denver to Deadwood were this morning released from their long imprisonment.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- C.L. Rand, 1903, and J.R. Mitchell, 1906, were to-night chosen to represent Cornell in the triangular tournament between Pennsylvania Brown, and Cornell, which will be held at the Manhattan Chess Club, New York Jan. 1, 2, and 3. M.J. Clurman, 1906, will be the substitute.

The handicap catch-as-catch-can wrestling bout which took place between George Bothner of this city and Tom Jenkins of Cleveland, at the Grand Central Palace last night, almost ended in a free fight, in which Tom Sharkey, the sailor pugilist, and one of Bothner's handlers figured most conspicuously.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- The American tour of Pietro Mascagni and his Italian opera company came to a sudden close to-day in this city, with the cancellation of all dates. The culmination of Mascagni's woes came last evening when an attachment was made on his personal effects by a constable representing a local claimant for $134.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- War exists between Venezuela and the European powers which sent ships to her coast originally to conduct a peace blockade.

Seventeen seamen, saved in a raging sea from a dismasted hulk in mid-ocean, were brought to this port yesterday on the Napolitan Prince, Capt. Adamson. The sailors were rescued from the Norwegian bark Bayard, an ancient craft, after they had abandoned hope, on Wednesday night. A "flare-up" that they kept burning on the poop, where they were huddled, was the signal that resulted in their lives being saved.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 -- The market showed signs of settling down into a holiday quietude, though the feeling was sufficiently favorable to warrant some scattered gains. Seaboards developed a better tone, the advance being a continuation of the recovering tendency which began last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- It has been an open secret here for several months among friends of Secretary Root that he intends to retire from the War Department, the time for retirement being contingent upon the accomplishment of certain reforms which the President and Secretary of War are desirous of securing in the administrative branches of the military service, the establishment of a general staff corps being the principal one of these reforms.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- Almost crazed from their sufferings, frostbitten and helpless, ten men in a boat were picked up yesterday by the schooner Manhassett, forty-five miles off Highland Light. Then, for the first time, it was learned that the schooners Frank A. Palmer and Louise B. Crary had been in collision, and had been sunk off Thatcher's Island on Wednesday evening.

By a unanimous vote, and without formal discussion, the name of the Rev. G. K. McDonald, who resigned the pastorate of the East Avenue Baptist Church, in Long Island City, it was said, to open a saloon in the Bronx, was stricken from the rolls at the weekly meeting of the Baptist Ministers' Conference at the Twentythird Street branch of the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- The factional fight in the Republican Party in Clinton County, which has been waged for six years by the followers of ex-Congressman John M. Wever against the faction supporting Gen. Stephen Moffitt and Supreme Court Justice Alonzo Kenogg, practically was ended here to-day when the weekly and daily newspapers controlled by the two factions were merged in one company, to be known as the Sentinel Publishing Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Lieut. Robert Sterling Clark, United States Army, formerly of New York, but now on duty at the War Department, entertained this evening at a beautifully appointed ball at the New Willard, the company being the largest and most fashionable the season has yet. known. The 400 guests represented the diplomatic, official, and resident population of Washington.

MARCONI has won a reputation for veracity and conservatism in announcement which would warrant the technical world in accepting without question his unsupported and unverified statement that he has exchanged intelligible messages between Cape Breton and the Cornwall coast.

The ninety-seventh annual festival of the New England Society in the City of New York was held yesterday in the banquet hall of the Waldorf-Astoria. There were present 618 persons of New England ancestry and a considerable number of others as gruests, who were somewhat amazed at the liberties the men of New Sngland had taken with a Trench menu.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The Directors of the Lake Superior Consolidated Company to-day met the representatives of several banking institutions of New York and Philadelphia for the purpose of negotiating a loan. Vice President Theodore C. Search, after the conference, made the statement that the banking concerns had taken up the matter and would look over the company's property before negotiating the loan.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The active leaders of the local market to-day were Reading and United States Steel, in both of which a large arbitrage business was done. New York taking the buying end. Over one-half of the day's business was in these issues. Prices generally were firm, under a steady demand from commission houses.
