Some opposition has developed to the plan for the reorganization of the American Bicycle Company as prepared by the Reorganization Committee, and under which deposits of securities are now being requested. This opposition comes mainly from the bondholders.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 22 -- The vessel on fire which attracted attention off this port last night was Standard Oil barge No. 48, which was loaded with gasoline. She was a derelict and was being towed into this port by Capt. Hamilton of the Gloucester fishing schooner Blanche.

The manager of a saloon in Sixth Avenue was held up at the muzzle of a rifle in his place of business last night by a restaurant keeper of the neighborhood, and before the assailant had been landed in the Tenderloin Police Station the saloon had been emptied of a score of terrified patrons and the vicinity agitated.

ALBANY, Dec. 23. -- Before Justice D. Cady Herrick to-day. Attorneys Alexander C. Eustace and David C. Robinson, representing the New York Building Loan Banking Company of New York City, made application for the appointment of a referee to examine into the affairs of that company, and also for a writ of prohibition restraining State Superintendent of Banking F.D. Kilburn from asking or the appointment of a receiver for the corporation.

The gayety of the holiday season has found fitting expression at the Irving Place Theatre in an admirably spirited representation of Benno Jacobson's Palais Royal farce, "Le True de Seraphin," ("Seraphin's Artful Dodge,") which, under the name of "Seln Trick," is booked to continue until Tuesday, Dec. 30.

MIMEOLA., L.I. Dec. 23. -- Now that he has lived two years with a broken neck, Walter E. Duryea, son of Edgar K. Duryea of Glen Cove, the starch manufacturer, will come into a fortune that amounts to nearly $500,000. The elder Duryea died on Aug. 10, 1900. A year previous the son broke his neck while diving at Oyster Bay.

Though enormous quantities of anthracite are now being shipped here, the drop in temperature yesterday increased the demand to such an extent that many of the dealers were out of coal in a few hours. The largest crowd that has yet attended the depot of the Communipaw Coal Company, established at 602-608 West Fifty-first Street, to sell coal at 10 cents a pall to the poor since it was opened was on hand yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- Announcement was made to-day that control of the United Power and Transportation Company has been sold to the Inter-State Railways Company at $75 a share, payable in forty-year collateral trust gold coupon bonds, to be issued by the Inter-State Railways Company.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Dec. 23. -- The bachelors' ball in McAlpin Hall to-night was one of the largest subscription dances held in Morristown this season. All of the single men of the social set were on the committee, and the list of patronesses included nearly all of the women of prominence in society.

The flatiron building is more of a monstrosity than other skyscrapers, because it can be seen from more directions, but it carries all the better the warning because it is so conspicuous. The warning alluded to is not with regard to aesthetics, but the practical results of erecting such human hives on Manhattan Island.

ASHKABAD, Russian Turkestan, Dec. 28. -- Even the worst of the earlier reports of the recent earthquake disaster at Andijan quite underestimates the appalling loss of life. A telegram to-day from the scene of the catastrophe puts the number of victims in the native quarter of the town at 4.000. Already 800 corpses have been disinterred from the ruins.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Although the formal proposal has not been received from the European powers that the Venezuelan dispute shall be arbitrated by President Roosevelt, there are indications of strong opposition to this plan. Pressure is being exerted by prominent men from all parts of the country against acceptance by Mr. Roosevelt.
CARACAS, Dec. 23. -- The Red D Line steamer Caracas safely entered the Harbor of La Guayra at 8 o'clock this morning. The mail, freight, and passengers of the vessel were landed at 10 o'clock.

The wedding of Robert S.R. Hitt and Miss Edith R. Gray, a daughter of Judge John Clinton Gray, was celebrated at noon yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Church by the Rev. Dr. Battershall of St. Peter's Church. Albany, assisted by the Rev. David H. Greer, rector of the church, and the Rev. A.R. Gray of Suwanee College, Tennessee.

VIENNA, Dec. 23. -- The flight of the Crown Princess of Saxony is the absorbing topic of the day here. All kinds of sensational reports are in circulation. When she left Salzburg, accompanied by her brother, Archduke Leopold Ferdinand, the Princess went to Munich, where a French tutor awaited her. Her brother was also joined there by a beautiful Viennese woman, and the two couples proceeded to Brussels and thence to Geneva.

Ex-Capt. Daniel C. Moynihan, when his trial on a charge of bribery was resumed yesterday before Justice Davy in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, took the stand in his own behalf, told of his war record and his real estate holdings, shed a few tears, and entered a general denial to all the accusations brought against him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Demand that Apolinario Mabini, Aguinaldo's former Secretary of State, shall be released from exile and captivity, is made in a letter sent to President Roosevelt. It is signed by Charles Francis Adams, Carl Schurz, Edwin Burritt Smith, and Herbert Welsh, leaders of the anti-imperialist movement.

DRESDEN, Dec. 23. -- King George and the Crown Prince Frederick know where the Crown Princess Louise has sought refuge, but they have decided to accept the estrangement of the Princess and her husband as irreparable. They have made the Cabinet privy to the circumstances of the Princess's flight, as they see them, and a decree of divorce is talked of as a necessary sequence to the Princess's resolution to leave the Court forever.

Immediately on reaching his office yesterday morning Mayor Low announced that he had decided to appoint Gen. Francis Vinton Greene as Police Commissioner, to succeed Commissioner John N. Patridge on Jan. 1. Gen. Greene accepted the appointment on Sunday last. The selection is understood to have been made on the Mayor's own initiative, although Gen. Greene is a close personal friend of President Roosevelt and of Gov. Odell.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 23. -- The Silent Five basket ball team of New York lost to the South Side in the game at Odd Fellows' Hall to-night in a hard contest by the score of 30 to 13. The first half was played under National League rules, which are in vogue here, and the score ended 12 to 6 in favor of the local team.

Little change was reported yesterday in the condition of Cornelius Vanderbilt, who has been desperately ill with typhoid fever at his home, 22 Park Avenue, but the news that came was distinctly of a hopeful character. Information at the house at 8 o'clock yesterday morning was that Mr. Vanderbilt was resting very quietly and that there was no change in his condition.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 23. -- The Leslie and Southern Railway Company, with a capital stock of $3,000,000, has been granted a charter under the laws of Arkansas. The proposed line is to be built from Leslie, in Searcy County. Ark., to Little Rock, a distance of 120 miles.

Mrs. Gertrude Beverly Motley has notifed the Surrogate of this county that she will sue to recover $25,000 as a creditor of the estate of Cornelius Roosevelt. President Roosevelt, a cousin of the man whose property is in question, is among the numerous members of that family to whom citations have been sent, directing them, to tell what they know of the case.

Conditions in the outside market yesterday were not quite as favorable as on Monday, and in practically all stocks a reactionary tendency appeared. With very few exceptions the losses recorded were confined to fractions, so that the net results, although somewhat unsatisfactory, were not of a discouraging character.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A small dance at the Country Club took place this evening. Each of the thirty members of the club invited six guests. The spacious old house, once the home of ex-Secretary W. C. Whitney, was decorated with holly and mistletoe. Mrs. Eugene Hale, wife of Senator Hale, the President of the club, received the guests.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- The tone of the local market was less firm to-day, notwithstanding favorable developments, which include the adoption of ordinances favorable to the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and the Philadelphia Electric Company, and the probability that the Electric Storage Battery Company will receive more favorable terms than have yet been stated in its deal with the General Electric Company.

The heirs of Hugh O'Neill yesterday through Richard M. Montgomery and H. H. Cammann Co., disposed of all their property on Sixth Avenue, Twentieth, and Twenty-first Streets, including the store, six dwellings, the stable, and the department store business of H. O'Neill Co., to William C. Strange and others.

The City Republican Committee of Greater New York met last night at Lyceum Hall, on Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue, to organize for the ensuing year. The meeting was called to order by the Chairman, William R. Spooner, who, after stating the purpose of the meeting, called for nominations for temporary Chairman.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The Most Rev. Frederick Temple, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of all England, who had been ill for some time past, is dead.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Over $1,000,000 will be spent by a New York syndicate, headed by Herbert M. Taylor, in establishing a model settlement in the western section of this city similar to that of Overbrook, Penn. Four blocks will be devoted to the purpose, and the company will install its own water, electric power and light supplies, as well as a central steam-heating apparatus, which will supply all houses to be erected.

Christmas Eve is devoted to the distribution of gifts, to Christmas trees, to children's parties, and to the general festivities of the season. Many house parties have gone to places in the country, including Aiken, Shelburne Farms, Biltmore, Staatsburg, and Tuxedo. Shopping in the very fashionable places has been rather slack recently.

BETHEL, Conn., Dec. 23. -- The Rev. Benjamin M. Adams, one of the oldest preachers in the East New York Methodist Conference, and known throughout New York State, died here to-day aged seventy-eight years.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Money was much wanted at 4 per cent, in the market to-day.

It is equally impossible for us to ignore or for Germany to avow the thought that underlies her urgent request that President ROOSEVELT become the arbitrator of the Venzeuelan dispute. We earnestly wish and intend to hold aloof. The acceptance of this office by the President would bring us within the field of controversy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- At a meeting here to-day the executive officers of the Western railroads agreed to exchange annual passes with railroads in the Central Association territory and Southern lines, but not to issue any free transportation to officers or agents of the roads east of Pittsburgh and Buffalo or to representatives of fast freight lines of which trunk lines are members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- One of Prof. Lorenz's patients in this city was Charles Willett, a ten-year-old boy. He was operated upon for a severe case of club feet. Dr. Lorenz said it was one of the worst he had ever seen.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23. -- A special from Jefferson City, Mo., says Mrs. A.M. Dockery, wife of the Governor, was taken critically ill yesterday afternoon. She is suffering from heart trouble. The military ball which was to have been held at the Gubernatorial mansion on Jan. 1 has been indefinitely postponed.

Mayor Low was asked yesterday by a committee of the Merchants' Association to take up the question of transit reform in New York, in order to see whether some means could be devised to improve the facilities for passengers of the Metropolitan system and the Manhattan Elevated Lines.
LA GUATRA, Dec. 23. -- The Red D Line steamer Caracas will not be permitted to enter Puerto Cabello. She will be obliged to land the remainder of her cargo at Willemstad, Curacao.

A committee of the City Club appeared yesterday before the special commission appointed by Mayor Low to investigate the waste of water in New York and the future sources of supply. The hearing was in the City Hall. Wheeler H. Peckham, President of the City Club, introduced Horace E. Doming, Chairman of the Committee on Water Supply, the members of which for several months have been gathering information from experts about the matter.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Charles Summer Pike, a local versemaker of some note, and Western representative here of an Eastern magazine, accepted a wager with Miss Mar garet Lord that he could not act as butler in her house for one evening without betraying himself.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 23 -- The Lackawanna Steel Company, the largest independent steel manufacturing concern in the world, received its first consignment of ore from upper lake points to-day. The steamer Moses Taylor, with 6,200 tons of ore steamed up the new ship canal to the steel company's mammoth new plant and anchored at the unloading dock.

The Board of Aldermen held a session yesterday. The first part was taken up with a discussion as to whether President Haffen of the Borough of the Bronx voted in the affirmative on the franchise of the New York and Jersey Railroad Company to tunnel under the Hudson River. Alderman Devlin said that President Haffen was ill at home and had requested that he be recorded in the negative.

There was unpleasant significance in the dispatch we published yesterday morning as to the disposition of the Senate toward the Cuban treaty of reciprocity. It appears that, while the beet-sugar men profess to have retired from the fight, the out-and-out protectionists of the type of ALDRICH of Rhode Island and QUAY of Pennsylvania have taken their places and are preparing to defeat the measure by dilatory tactics.

The gamblers yesterday took the aggressive in the war between themselves and District Attorney Jerome. Ex-Gov, Black, who is the attorney for the Burbridge-Farrell-Walbaum combination, whose gambling house in West Thirty-third Street was invaded by the Tenderloin police on evidence furnished by Detective Joseph Jacobs of Mr. Jerome's staff, took steps to have the detective arrested on a charge of perjury.

Two fires in crowded five-story tenements in Sixtieth Street, between Amsterdam and West End Avenues, shortly before dawn yesterday were unmistakably set, confirming the suspicions of the police that more than a dozen similar blazes in the near neighborhood, which have been discovered within the last ten days just in time to save life, were also incendiary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A novel view of President Roosevelt is contributed by Louis Michel, editor of Der Deutsch Amerikaner, who was introduced to the President last Wednesday at the White House by Representatives Wachter and Schiem of Maryland.
According to Sharon, Penn. dispatches the Hall furnnce of the Republic Iron Steel Co., which has been idle for nearly two months, has resumed operations.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- The Vossische Zeitung, one of the most cautiously edited newspapers published here, says to-day in an editorial statement on the flight of the Crown Princess Louise of Saxony that the Crown Prince beat his wife. The paper adds:

Christmas, like all great holidays, is a dies non as far as society is concerned. Time was when everybody celebrated Christmas in town. The fashions have changed. Every one who can get away for the holidays has departed. Tuxedo and the various clubs in the country adjacent have entertainments.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 24 -- The man who sold the Biggar-Hendrick Christmas tree was put in a pretty mess by the verdict. It was announced yesterday that in case of an acquittal the Hotel Belmont would be the scene of the lighting of the tree. It was "for the boys," as Miss Biggar expressed it. She has one well-grown lad, while Dr. Hendricks has three, small ones.
TRINIDAD, Col., Dec. 24 -- Six men were killed in a freight wreck on the Colorado and Southern Railroad near here to-night.

A jury, after listening to the evidence in the case of ex-Capt. Daniel C. Moynihan, who was tried before Justice Davy in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court on a bribery charge, last night returned a verdict of not guilty. Capt. Moynihan wept when the verdict was announced. He seemed dumfounded for a moment.

When the members of the National Athletic Club assemble to-morrow evening for their annual meeting, at their well-appointed club house, 11-13 Cedar Street, Brooklyn, they will hear a flattering report of the progress of the organization during the past year. During the last twelve months the club membership has been increased by over 200, and the prospects for the ensuing year are brighter than at any time since the club was organized fifteen years ago.

What the President said in his message about the necessity of a strong and efficient navy to prevent our proclamations of the Monroe Doctrine from becoming waste paper found an echo in the consciousness of every American citizen who had had occasion to consider international conditions.

Police Commissioner Partridge yesterday promoted thirty-eight patrolmen to the grade of Roundsmen. The Commissioner told the men that if they desired they could wait until there were vacancies near their homes, but none accepted the offer. He mentioned the fact that in the appointment of Sergeants on Tuesday he had purposely left out of the list some men who, although eligible, had shown by their records that they were "anything but good Roundsmen."

MANILA, Dec. 24 -- Several official inquiries into charges of alleged cruelty to natives by soldiers are at present progressing throughout the islands. Some of these cases have been investigated previously.
Col. Henry Clay Lockwood, soldier, author, and lawyer, died in Bellevue Hospital yesterday after a short illness. He was sixty-three years old.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- N.S. Beardsley, President of the National Salt Company, announced to-day that, on account of the more convenient location of Ithaca with reference to the company's salt plants, the general office of the company would be moved here from Scranton, Penn., immediately.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Christmas in official Washington really began to-day. President Roosevelt determined to make Christmas as much of a real holiday as possible, and his Cabinet has aided him in carrying out his intention. He declared that he would transact as little business as possible during the holiday season, but would get out in the open air and enjoy himself all he could.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- John R. McLean, the President of the Washington Gaslight Company, manifested to-day one of his periodic symptoms of a youthful penchant for fire fighting.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- There is no abatement of public interest in the abduction case planned and carried out by the latter-day Lochinvar, M. Maurice Marcile, who spirited away in his autocar Mile. Cordelia le Play. Attention is all the more aroused owing to the young lady's family connections and to the position of her father, the doctor and ex-Senator.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 24 -- Additional charges of fraud and conspiracy are made against the National Salt Company's officers and Directors in a suit brought to-day in the bankruptcy division of the United States District Court by James P. Lee of Tuxedo Park, William H. Burger of New York, and Ophelia Jones of Brooklyn, holders of certificates of indebtedness of the salt company.

Business on the Stock Exchange was at a low ebb yesterday, brokers for the most part giving themselves over to skylarking and to Christmas celebration. All told, transactions during the day approximated barely 325,000 shares, with two stocks, Brooklyn Rapid Transit and Reading, contributing one-third of all the market dealings.

The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold for the Marshall O. Roberts estate the plot at the northeast corner of Columbus Avenue and Eighty-first Street, 102.2 by 100. It is understood that the buyer will improve the property.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Nate Salsbury, principal owner of Buffalo Bill's "Wild West" Show, died at his home in Liberty Street, this place, to-night from stomach trouble, from which he had long suffered. He had long been prominently identified with this town, and two years ago spent $200,000 in erecting upon the sandy waste near North Long Branch, the group of handsome cottages known as the Reservation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The President and Secretary Hay were in conference for some time this afternoon over the proposals from Great Britain and Germany that the President arbitrate the issues involved in the Venezuelan claims controversy. They went over the communications very thoroughly, considering the subject from every viewpoint.

The letters of Mayor Low to the management of the Metropolitan and Manhattan systems relative to the provision of better and more ample passenger accommodations will make for good. In many respects these are very different letters from those which a person familiar with the traffic problems of a city railroad would have written, and they ask some questions which, appear to answer themselves.

A fire which did damage amounting to $5,000 was discovered at 10 o'clock last night in the offices of the Savannah Steamship Line, on the north side of their pier. 35 North River. Three alarms were turned in, but the fire was quickly extinguished by the fireboat New Yorker, which arrived on the first alarm and threw four powerful streams of water on the flames.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The officials of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad assert that the present facilities for carrying passengers on their lines cannot be bettered, and they resent any criticism upon the present management.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Daily, teams slip, horses fall and are injured and strained, axles are broken, wheels come off, and merchandise is injured and delayed by the incumbering and abandoned horse car tracks on Broome Street, between Wooster and Broadway. Because the traction company wants to retain some franchise rights the nuisance is not abated.

A holiday shopping season of astonishing activity indicated that to-day will be an unprecedentedly happy Christmas in New York. Everybody's stocking should be full, and there will be no reason why anybody should not dine at least plentifully, for Christmas dinners by the ten thousand will be dispensed in various parts of the city.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 24 -- The Pennsylvania Limited, running almost an hour late, crashed into the rear end of the Leetsdale Accommodation at Quaker Valley Station to-night at 11 o'clock. The big engine of the Limited plowed into the rear car, the smoker, like a knife thorugh paper, and the little car was pushed through the one ahead of it, making the two cars the length of one.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- As a result of conferences between Premier Combes and Minister of Justice Valle complete arrangements have been made for the reception of the members of the Humbert family, arrested in Madrid on Dec. 20. However, the precaution has been taken of not disclosing what prison the fugitives will occupy or where they will be taken in the train, as a popular demonstration is feared.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- The 4,700 engineers and firemen on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul system have received an increase in pay of about 10 per cent. The joint committee of the locomotive engineers and firemen on that system, which has been in Chicago since Dec. 1 adjusting the wage scale, reached an agreement with the management of the system to-day.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 24 -- The most elaborate private observance of Christmas in Vermont was held this afternoon and evening at Shelburne Farms, the palatial country residence of Dr. W.S. Webb, when he entertained the hands of the various departments on the estate and their families to the number of 125, and the following party of New York and Boston people: Mr. and Mrs. W.D. Sloane and son M.D.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 24 -- The Court of Pardons, in secret session to-day, gave a hearing to counsel for Paul Woodward, the Camden murderer, who is under sentence to be hanged on Jan. 8. Counsel asked for a commutation of sentence on the ground of insanity. The court postponed decision in the matter until next Tuesday in order to give counsel an opportunity to present testimony.

It is reported from Berlin that Germany objects to a reference of the Venezuela dispute to The Hague court of arbitration because of her belief that the President would reach an earlier decision. The objection does not seem to us well taken. It appears to have been overlooked that The Hague Convention gives the widest latitude to the parties making use of the tribunal.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Money was in active request to-day and the supplies were short, considerable cash being due to the Bank of England. Discounts were harder.
ROME, Dec. 24. -- There is absolutely no foundation for the report that the Pope is ill.

William Brookfield, President of the independent Republican organization which bears his name, announced, last evening that at the coming session of the Legislature a bill would be introduced amending the primary election law so as to abolish special enrollments -- that is, the enrollments which are made on affidavits filed by the district leaders.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Dec. 24 -- By an explosion of gas or gasoline this afternoon in the cellar of the Turf Exchange, a club house and pool room, operated by Chambers Walker, the building was badly damaged and thirty persons were injured. Sixteen of them are in a serious condition.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 24 -- The jury in the trial of Miss Laura Biggar and Dr. Charles C. Hendrick and ex-Justice of the Peace Samuel Stanton brought in a verdict at 1:45 o'clock this afternoon, acquitting Miss Biggar and finding Dr. Hendrick and Stanton guilty of conspiracy as charged in the indictment.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Dec. 24 -- The examination of witnesses before United States Commissioner Anderson in the cases against Lieut. Commander George W. Mentz, United States Navy, and James Btennan, an employe of the Country Club, who, with others, are charged with smuggling wines and liquors from St. Thomas on the United States steamship Uncas and the lighthouse tender Laurel, was continued to-day.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- Official papers have been issued which give full details of the new scheme for naval education, which is to be unified and simplified by the adoption of a single system for the training of cadets for all three branches of the service -- executives, engineers and marines.

OKMULGEE, Indian Territory, Dec. 24 -- Chief Isparahacher of the Creek Indians died suddenly here to-night at the age of ninety years. He had been prominent in Creek affairs for three-score years and had been connected with every treaty of importance between the United States Government and Indians during that time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the management of the Manhattan Railroad, I wish to make one suggestion. In the morning I frequently take a downtown train at Forty-second Street and Sixth Avenue. When a train comes along the platforms, the cars are often crowded to their fullest capacity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Union Station bill, which is now in the hands of the Senate Committee on the District of Columbia, after passing the House with amendments which changed the measure radically in some respects, is likely to be the subject of further contest.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 24 -- Ex-President and Mrs. Cleveland will pass Christmas Day in their home on Bayard Lane. The holiday will be observed simply, attention being chiefly given to making merry with the children. A big Christmas tree, hanging full of good things for the four children, stands in the library, the headquarters for the little ones.

The State Board of Railroad Commissioners took a hand yesterday in the agitation carried on by the Merchants' Association and others for the improvement of traffic facilities on the surface and elevated railroads. President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan also came into the foreground, and issued the following statement of the proceedings at a conference held in the City Hall yesterday:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Regarding some, at least, of the overcrowding of the cars, the reason seems obvious and the relief simple.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 24 -- Through the efforts of District Attorney James P. Niemann of Nassau County and the detectives employed by him, the Italian murderer, Tomaso Addazio, who, on Oct. 27, 1901, shot and killed Michael Saccone at Glen Cove, has been apprehender by the authorities in Italy, and is now being tried over there for the offense committed here.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Regarding some, at least, of the overcrowding of the cars, the reason seems obvious and the relief simple.

The series of events through which we are now passing is even now evidently of international, and may ultimately become of world-wide importance. In fact, to us Americans, the landmarks seem to have somehow been suddenly shifted. We seem to be trying to make a landfall on what Mr. KIPLING the other day described as a "lightless coast."

-- Only a few years ago -- anywhere from twenty to ten -- the name of the Cobden Club brought to the mind of every good American protectionist a horrid vision of British free traders banded together in a wicked conspiracy to send gold over here by the shipload for the purpose of indoctrinating us with economic heresies and bribing such of our citizens as were poorer than proud to vote the Democratic ticket.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On a recent occasion when lingering around a late dinner table the conversation dropped into a succession of remarkable stories regarding canine sagacity. As it chanced, the dogs whose careers had been made notable by abnormal degrees of smartness were reared up the State or some distant place, where disproof of the accuracy of the stories was difficult, if not impossible.
SALT LAKE, Utah, Dec. 24. -- George W. Thatcher, a Utah pioneer and for years prominent in political and church affairs, is dead at his home in Logan, Utah, after a long illness.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 -- The money market is very firm and will undoubtedly continue so until well after the first of the year. The usual table of local rates follows: Call loans, 6 to 7 per cent; time loans, collateral, 6 to 6 1/2 per cent. Time loans, mercantile paper, 6 to 7 per cent. Clearing House loans, 5 per cent. New York funds, 15 to 20 cents discount.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- Conferences between the Japanese political parties have commenced, says the Tokio correspondent of The Times.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 24. -- Charles G. Warner, Vice President and General Manager of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, was stricken with ilness at the Noonday Club this afternoon. Mr. Warner, while at the table, sank unconscious from his chair. Physicians were summoned, and after an hour's work restored Mr. Warner to consciousness.

DOVER, Del., Dec. 25 -- Interest in poltics is growing strong here with the approach of the contest which will be waged in the Legislature over the election of two United States Senators. Possibility that the eight regular Republicans who hold the balance between the Democrats and the Addicks Republicans will make a combination with either side has set all the politicians to figuring.

There were only five competitors in the Christmas Day shoot of the Crescent Athletic Club at Bay Ridge yesterday, and the silver cup offered by the club was won by F.B. Stephenson with a score of 46 out of a possible 30. A trophy match, fifteen targets, was won by F.B. Stephenson after a tie with H.M. Bingham.

One hundred and fifty patrons of the Hotel St. Denis. Broadway and Eleventh Street, were awakened from their ear Christmas slumbers about 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning by the crash of breaking window glass and the clamor of all the fire gongs in the hotel.

At the Clermont Avenue Rink. Brooklyn, the indoor skating racing season of open events was inaugurated yesterday afternoon and continued last night with a series of handicap, scratch, and novice races, in which some of the crack players were seen at their best. The management promised tbs rink's patrons a novel contest and kept its word.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Mme. Eleanora Duse saw her first Santa Claus to-day. He was impersonated by Harry Gordon Selfridge dressed up in pillows, red cloth, and a white beard, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Selfridge. 117 Lake Shore Drive, where the Italian actress was a guest.

OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- A variety performance was given in Sing Sing Prison for the entertainment of the convicts. The prisoners appeared to enjoy the show greatly, and indicated their approval by vigorous applause. Extra Rations were added to the usual bill of fare in celebration of Christmas Day.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 23 -- A local newspaper publishes the following:

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 25 -- Dr. Hendricks and ex-Justice Stanton, who were convicted yesterday of conspiracy with Laura Biggar to obtain possession for her of the Bennett estate, she being acquitted of any guilt in the matter, had a jolly Christmas dinner. It was served in the county jail where Dr. Hendricks and Stanton are awaiting the passing of sentence.

It was not a merry Christmas for several officials of the Street Cleaning Department or for the contractor who has undertaken to remove snow from the streets of New York under a new form of contract adopted by Commissioner Woodbury this year. For three hours the Street Cleaning Department kept the telephone wires busy trying to get men and trucks at the work on Broadway.

It was a white Christmas -- the first of its kind enjoyed in this city in many years -- and for half of the day at least one of the most beautiful holidays that the younger generation of New Yorkers has experienced.
WILLIAM B. SHAUT, who was Colonel of the One Hundred and Thirty-first Pennsylvania Volunteers in the war of the rebellion, died Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles, Col.

Christening a baby was the unusual feature of the twelfth ball of the Holschen Verein, meaning "wooden shoes." at Sulzer's Music Hall. Second Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, last night. The baby was the child of John Hinz and was born Sept. 20. The family home is at 154 Reservoir Avenue, Jersey City, where the father is an electrician.

-- Bearing directly upon the question whether we were right or wrong in denying that Americans really do wear themselves out in a wild rush for wealth, is the revelation by the mathematicians at work on the figures of the last census that there are more centenarians in this country than in any other with statistics as trustworthy as ours, and that the number of our centenarians is steadily increasing.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 25 -- Francis J. leeker of the Newark Firemen's Relief Association is a prisoner at Police Headquarters, charged by Assistant Fire Chief William C. Astley. President of the assoiation, with embezzlement. The special charge as sworn to before Judge Lambert involves $5,000, but the total shortage, it is aid.

A Milwaukee Magistrate has rendered an opinion which will be grateful to a great many householders. It is not an uncommon experience for a family to have its comfort disturbed and its pleasures banished by untimely visits from distant relatives who do not wait for the formality of an invitation.

Local athletes Were quite concerned yesterday over the announcement that the weight which had been used in several of the athletic meets in this city, and with which records had been established, was found to be one and a half ounces light and the handle longer than the rules allowed.

A search of twenty-one years for a father seems to have come to an end for Katrina Hattmansburger, who lives with her aunt. Mrs. Herman Neukrantz, at 102 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street. She thinks her father is Philip Hattmansburger of 645 West Harrison Street.

Mr. Fitch's new play at the Savoy is a little more sparing than usual in what one of his admirers has called his "incidences" and "functions." This is by no means a bad thing, for at times Mr. Fitch's cleverness in making brisk scenes has diverted him from the more serious business in playmaking.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Dec. 25 -- Raymond W. Armour, sixteen years old, a student at Cutler School in New York and a son of William Armour, the New York banker, was severely injured here this morning while driving with his parents in a surrey. The horse took fright at a passing automobile and ran down the boulevard, striking a loaded coal wagon.
The big seven-masted schooner Thomas W. Lawson has sailed from Boston for Newport News in a third attempt to get a full cargo for a ship that seems to be too big for any of the coal ports.

Six deaths, and possibly more, are believed to have resulted from a fire which, starting at 12:15 o'clock this morning in the cooperage plant attached to the Arbuckle sugar refinery, in Brooklyn, destroyed that great building. It extended from 206 to 216 Plymouth Street. The victims were foremen working upon Water Tower No. 1 which was directing a stream into the blazing five-story brick structure.

The junior Senator from New York has shown in a number of his speeches an intelligent understanding of the difficulties imposed on the business of the country by the rigid nature of the law governing the issue of bank currency and a desire to promote legislation that shall remove such difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Another contribution to the long-drawn-out controversy over the continuance in office of Postmaster Vick at Wilson, N.C., has been made to Postmaster General Payne. This time it is a letter from ex-Representative H.G. Ewart of North Carolina, for a time Judge of the Federal Court for the Western District of the State on a recess appointment.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 -- As a Christmas gift to the Masonic fraternity William it. Elkins to-day announced his intention to establish a home for the orphan daughters of Masons. The gift, which is expected to amount to $1,000,000, is the largest ever made to any fraternal organization in the world, and the institution, which Mr. Elkins purposes to found and endow, will be without a counterpart anywhere.

The suggestion of Mr. C.M. CARPENTER of Dayton, Ohio, in a paper communicated to the Civic Federation relative to the creation in large industrial establishments of boards to have the regulation of practically everything affecting the interests of labor was eminently practical and should be carefully considered by all for whom the subject has interest.

The full text of the treaty with Great Britain for the regulation of a part of our trade with Newfoundland shows that it is more favorable to the extension of our markets than had appeared from the published abstract.

There is a tone of sad conviction in Senator VEST'S talk about the trusts, the tariff, and the Republican Party. Combinations of capital that have monopoly for their object are the greatest menace that threatens the country to-day. It is difficult if not impossible to reach and restrain them through Federal regulation of inter-State commerce.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 -- On a warrant charging an attempt to murder her mother by the administration of arsenic, Miss Catherine Richardson, thirty years old, is under arrest in Revere. Dr. Eunice M. Kinney brought about the arrest of Miss Richardson.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 25 -- The way Santa Claus treated Mascagni was "something scand lous." There being no Italian saint of that sort, the Anglo-Saxon gift giver ought to have been generous, but the best he could do for the composer was to hand him a package marked "More Trouble."

Snowballing sport threatened to end in a lynching at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street, yesterday, when a party of small boys selected William Garry, a negro thirtyfive years old, of 235 West Fifty-third Street, as a likely target. They had been pelting pedestrians and drivers to their hearts' content, and nobody seemed to mind until Garry got angry.

It is an ancient and stalwart British proverb which assures us that "a green Yule makes a fat churchyard." There is no statistical justification for it that we Know of, even in the British Islands. And our climatic conditions are so different from those of the British Islands that such a proverb could be transplanted only at great risk.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 25 -- "Dan" McLeod won the catch-as-catch-can wrestling championship of America by defeating "Tom" Jenkins in the-presence of 1,100 spectators at Mechanics' Hall this afternoon. Jenkins was forced to give up the contest after each man had scored one fall, as he was suffering from blood poisoning caused by the points of a brass buckle perforating one of his legs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Gen. Hasbrouck of the artillery, who has just been promoted from the rank of Colonel to the grade of Brigadier General, will be retired, at his own request, so that the President may fill the vacancy by advancing another of the old Colonels who served in the civil war.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- State Senator Patrick F. Trainor of the Sixteenth Senatorial District of New York County died at 7:20 o'clock this morning at the Ten Eyck Hotel. He came here from Clifton Springs last August, suffering from an insidious nervous disease. He had been improving of late, but began to fail last midnight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- President Needham of the Columbian University expresses much gratification in the success which has attended a course of lectures on commerce, recently delivered before the School of Comparative Jurisprudence and Diplomacy of that university by O.P. Austin, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics.

ITHACA, Dec. 25 -- The Cornell University Register, which will be published to-morrow, is a thick volume of 554 pages, which is about 30 pages more than in any previous edition. Several added courses of instruction and the enlarged roll of registration account for this increase. Every college and department of the university is shown to be in a flourishing condition.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Henry Miller launched Richard Harding Davis as a playwright at the Lyceum Theatre here this afternoon, when "The Taming of Helen," a comedy, was produced for the first time.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 -- Wealth and McChesney were the winning favorites to- day. Scotch Plaid was run up $305 after he won the second race, and was bought in. The Christmas Handicap, with $1,000 added, and worth $1,635 to the winner, went to McChesney. He was ridden by Redfern, and ran a sensational race, winning in a drive by half a length from Old Hutch.

Christmas harmony was marred by many sadly discordant notes in St. Simon's Protestant Episcopal Church at Concord. Staten Island. when with the exception of Arthur W. Hall the entire choir refused to sing Hymn 319. beginning "Thou didst leave Thy throne," when directed to do so by the Rev. Dr. William Gordon Thompson, the rector, during the morning service.

It would be interesting to know what the Czar of Russia thinks of the studied avoidance of The Hague tribunal by Germany and Great Britain. It was through bis initiative that the conference assembled. The treaty and the Permanent Court are the fruit of his personal interest in arbitration for the settlement of disputes between nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- It was said at ths State Department to-day that the President had reached no decision in regard to the invitation of the powers that he arbitrate the Venezuelan matter. It is possible that this decision will not be forthcoming for several days.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your issue of Nov. 29 last, Mr. J.M. Boddy asserts that most of the British and European authorities and scientific writers, when they have occasion to refer to the colored people, spell the word negro with a "capital" N. He maintains that this is the proper form, and he censures American writers for spelling the word with a small "n."

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 26 -- Henry P. Smith of this city has married Miss Madeline C. Pritchard of Pottsville, a nurse in the Vanderbilt family. He is forty-eight years old, and the son of Edward A. Smith, with whom he boarded.

THE fame of Columbus rests upon his vital connection with the greatest material event in history, the discovery of America. Lief Ericson's accidental glimpse of the New England coast had no rational significance, for it fitted in to no need, no expanding world-plan, and so fell mute and still-born.

Major Ebstein and Capt. Piper will be continued as First and Second Deputy, Police Commissioners by Gen. Francis Vinton Greene, who will succeed Col. J.N. Partridge as head of the Police Department on Jan. 1. Gen. Greene announced the fact last evening.

With this lesson we turn from considering God's promises to begin again the consideration of the strong foundation on which they all rest. That foundation is the finished work of the Lord Jesus Christ as our substitute and Redeemer. "For all the promises of God in Him are -- Yea; and in Him -- Amen; unto the glory of God by us," (II. Cor., i., 20.)

BY lineage, (in larger part,) by language, and by law we are English. Our early development in the Colonial times was English. In the exchange of the social amenities we followed out Anglo-Saxon methods.
DURBAN, Dec. 26 -- Colonial Secretary Chamberlain and Mrs. Chamberlain, who left Portsmouth, England, on Nov. 25 on board the armored cruiser Good Hope, landed here at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 26 -- The police heard to-day that a man had jumped from the South Street Bridge into the Elizabeth River, and that not far from the bridge a double-breasted black sack coat had been found. The coat had cuts that might have been made by a knife and spots that appeared to be blood stains on one arm and the front.

Since 1895 Mme. Adam has been at work on her memoirs, and this Fall the first installment of them, comes to the public. "The Romance of My Childhood and Youth" is an elaborate and detailed account of everything that occurred during that time from the date of her birth-indeed, it goes considerably further back than that eventful date, and includes the romance of her grandmother and even that of her great-grandmother.

It is a great pity that the good news we print to-day should not have been published Thursday morning. For the very best effect it does come two days late. Christmas Day was the day, of all days in the year, for such a proclamation of "applied Christianity," for such a reiteration of the original lesson of the day.

The letter of Vice President and General Manager SKITT of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad to his Honor the Mayor, replying to the official communication of that officer respecting the provision of better accommodations for the public, was no doubt meant to be as conclusive as it was respectful.

To the reader who wants plenty of action, "The Master of Appleby" is to be recommended, for, of its kind -- a historical romance of the "bloggy" variety -- it deserves praise. One can scarcely look for individuality or style in these hasty tales of love and adventure, and so, accepting the story for its plot alone, no render will be apt to feel dull while reading its pages.

With every new issue from the office of the State Historian in New York comes a new proof of the wisdom of the Legislature in creating the office. We are justified in adding that there comes new proof also of the good fortune of the State in securing the services of Mr. Hugh Hastings as the incumbent of the office.

The large sum of $580, given at the Alexander sale at Libbie's, in Boston, Dec. 5, for an autograph letter of George Washington written to Patrick Henry Oct. 29. 1785, has been referred to by several writers as the highest price yet paid at auction for a Washington letter or document. This is not so as the following list will show:
PEKING, Dec. 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Miles arrived here to-day on a short visit. The General will be received in audience by the imperial family and will review the Chinese troops to-morrow.
JAMES J. LONEBGAN, President of the City Foundry Company, died last night at Cleveland, Ohio, after an illness of a year's duration.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- General strength developed in the local market to- day under the leadership of Reading, for which stock a good demand came from commission houses. In most cases, however, in the general list offerings were sufficiently liberal to hold prices in check, so that net advances were largely fractional.

Christmas time without the annual performances of "The Messiah" by the Oratorio Society would not be Christmas time to a great many excellent people whose interest in music begins and ends with this annual function. The first of the two performances of the work was given yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, with an audience that filled every seat, and stood in almost as great numbers as the standing room of the hall permitted.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have just laid down a book of the present season, called "The Reflections of Ambrcsine," and I feel impelled to put upon record concerning it a few reflections of an old-fashioned woman, brought up in reverence of things decent and seemly in everyday conversation and literature.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- The money market continues very firm, with conditions practically unchanged. Call loans, 6@7 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 6@7 1/2 per cent. Time loans, mercantile paper, 6 1/2 @7 per cent. Clearing House loans, 5 per cent. New York funds, 15 cents discount. Clearings, $20,610,874; balance, $1,363,708.

The fire which destroyed the cooperage plant of the Arbuckle sugar refinery, in Plymouth Street, Williamsburg, early yesterday morning, had about burned itself out yesterday, although several streams of water were kept playing on the smoldering ruins. The report that the bodies of several firemen lay buried beneath the beams and girders was thoroughly investigated during the early morning, and proved to be incorrect.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Dec. 20 there seems to me to be a curious statement, signed A.J. Chinman, relative to Jackson's birthplace. I have a "Complete History of the Private, Military, and Civil Life of Andrew Jackson," by Amos Kendall, published byHarper Brothers in 1843 and accepted by Congress.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Dec. 20 a reviewer makes this assertion: "The truth is, that a hundred and fifty years ago they were only beginning to write prose -- good English prose. Although a vast deal of wonderful poetry had been written before that in England, her prose was a new art."

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 26 -- The Republican Senators at a conference held to-night in the rooms of the local Republican Club decided upon Senator Elijah C. Hutchinson of Mercer County as the President of the next Senate.

Messrs. Sotheby's sale of Dec. 4-10, complete reports of which have just reached this country, was easily the most important book auction held since the beginning of the season, 1,528 lots bringing the large total of L10,555 8s. The most valuable item was Lot 1,157 -- the excessively rare original edition of Carswell's Gaelic translation of John Knox's Book of Common Order, printed in Edinburgh in 1567 by Robert Lepreuik.

New that the text of the treaty with Cuba has reached the public, it is easy to estimate at its true value the opposition to it which is shown by the extreme protectionists in the Senate and which the sugar-beet lobby threaten to aid.

WHEN one is confronted With 1,500 pages of fairly close Print on such a subject as "Democracy and the Organization of Political Parties," one's first inquiry is whether the book is readable or whether it must simply be stored away on the reference shelf.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- It is announced here to-day that Lord Rosebery is writing a book on the American War of Independence.

By to-morrow the Street Cleaning Department promises to have New York cleared of snow, provided, of course, another downfall does not intervene. Contractor William Bradley after his bad luck on Christmas Day, when nearly all the unemployed he could get in communication with refused to work because of the day, had his agents out early yesterday, and by 7 o'clock 2,500 men were at work, picking and shoveling the frozen snow into wagons.

AS the author of an admirable brief biography of Theodore Parker, and editor of the excellent ten-volume edition of his sermons; as the writer of "Broken Lights," as a veteran champion of female suffrage, and as an honored guest in past years, Miss Frances Power Cobbe has many friends in Boston.

THE reason for this book must be looked for beyond its value as history, except for the side-lights it throws upon the making of it; for the time and its events have long ere this been chronicled in historic form.

It is a little curious that the mind of the British Ministry should be disturbed by the recent book and magazine writing of Sir Horace Rumbold in a manner which has never occurred in what some of our "kin across sea" like to call the shirt-sleeves diplomacy of the United States.

In most outside stocks yesterday the trading was very limited, but interest was given to the day's operations by the developments in three, or four stocks which were affected by special influences. As a whole the changes in quotations were of a favorable character, there being more advances than declines and some of the gains being quite large.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Permit me to deplore the tendency of your correspondents to chortle and gibe at poor Mr. J. Cotton Dana. Far from making the judicious grieve, his proposition to distribute literature by State lines instead of linguistically should stimulate our United Slates pride.

For the second time in three days the police of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station last night had to deal with a shooting affray in Lawrence Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, known as "Little Africa." William Forbes, colored, of 124 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, was shot in the abdomen and the right shoulder, by another colored man.

The agreement to refer the Venezuelan dispute to The Hague tribunal for arbitration is a new triumph of American diplomacy. That the judgment of that tribunal ought to be invoked has been the American position from the beginning. The President has urged that course upon the parties to the controversy.

Oswald Weber, Jr., a coffee merchant, and also an insurance broker, died in the Grand Union Hotel soon after noon yesterday from the effects of prussic acid poisoning. He had an office at 128 Pearl Street, where he acted as agent of the building for J.R. Suydam.

The week-end is to be very dull in town. Some of those who have been at house parties will remain until Monday, and others will remain until after New Year's Day. The ball given by Mrs. Alexander Brown in Baltimore was one of the out-of-town attractions. The opera had a good house, as is usual on Fridays, even in the holidays.

ITHACA, Dec. 26 -- When Coach Hugh Jennings of the baseball team went away for the holidays he left instructions regarding the preparation of the cage and baseball paraphernalia and announced that the candidates for the nine will begin their training soon after the opening of college. Crew work will at that time be started in full force.

THE AMBASSADORS," Henry James's new story, will be the first work of fiction to be published in The North American Review. It will appear serially, beginning with the January number, which will therefore be enlarged to 160 pages.

One gets the idea from some illuminative remarks in the Editor's Easy Chair of the January Harper's that Mr. William Dean Howells has about decided that "realism" does not pay in this country. He says:

Charles W. Dahlinger's book on "The German Revolution of 1840," to be published shortly by G.P. Putnam's Sons, is an "account of the final struggle in Baden for the maintenance of Germany's first national representative Government." Mr. Dahlinger's father was one of the exiles, who, at the end of the struggle in Germany for freedom, came to this country and helped to free the slaves.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have derived much amusement from the various letters which have recently appeared in your literary supplement -- some of them facetious, some funny -- concerning the origin of the names Bronx and Hobo- ken.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Those Senators who are opposed to the ratification of the several reciprocity treaties pending in the Senate are reported to have in view a scheme by which the opponents of each will be brought into a union to oppose all of them, including the Cuban reciprocity treaty.

PRINTED below will be found the contents of the leading American magazines for the coming month. While the lists of contents are not absolutely complete, the omissions mainly relate to regular departments and to illustrations and contributions of lesser importance.
M.L. C. Ernst have bought from the Provident Realty Company the eight-story fireproof building 11 East Twenty-second Street, 115.11 feet east of Broadway, on lot 26 by 99.11.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 -- Sarilla and Potente were the winning favorites. The Stewards, after satisfactory evidence that the horses heretofore run in the name of Hatfield and Ownby and Hatfield, Ownby Co. are really the property of James Ownby, have recommended that Ownby be restored to all privileges as owner and trainer.

The eleventh annual intercollegiate tournament between four students each from Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton, which is to begin on Monday, to be continued on Tuesday and ended on Wednesday at the Columbia Grammar School in this city, promises to become a rather exciting contest, to judge from the players and the schedule.

IT IS to utter a commonplace If we say that to know the whole mind of Shakespeare on the moral life would merit endless investigation, and that any effort with that design would he of boundless interest.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 26 -- The extensive electric power plant being constructed on the Susquehanna River for supplying power to Baltimore, Wilmington, and other towns in Northern Maryland and Delaware will be connected with a new railroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Rear Admiral Walker, President of the Isthmian Canal Commission, is disposed to regard the introduction of the resolution in the House calling for a detailed statement of the expenditures of the commission as an effort by those who favor the construction by the Nicaragua route to discredit the commission because of its final recommendation in favor of the Panama route.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Italian Ambassador and Mme. Mayor des Planches entertained at a small dance at the embassy, 1,400 New Hampshire Avenue, this evening. The company was limited to their younger friends in official and resident circles. The ballroom, which is a picture gallery, as well as the drawing rooms, were decorated in holly and smilax, with the orchestra in the gallery above the ballroom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Though the Venezuelan situation is still extremely delicate and a false step at any time may produce serious results, it is felt to-day that very satisfactory progress has been made toward a solution of the difficulty.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 26 -- Debutantes were barred from the dance in McAlpin's Hall to-night. It was a junior dance, and the young women in the social set from fifteen years up were invited, with the exception of the debutantes. The line had to be drawn somewhere, and it was thought best to include only the young ladies who are home from boarding schools and seminaries for the holidays.

PITTSBURG, Kan., Dec. 26 -- It is reported that Joe Godley, a brother of Montgomery Godley, who was lynched by a mob here yesterday, is wounded and in hiding at Weir City, Kan., and later investigation of the trouble between Officer Hinkle and the Godley brothers tends to show that Joe, and not the man who was lynched, fired the shot that killed the policeman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- As it has been practically determined that the Venezuelan dispute shall be referred to The Hague tribunal, the Constitution of that tribunal and its methods of procedure are matters of general interest. The convention by which the tribunal was instituted provided for its organization, methods of procedure, and rules of conduct.

JAMES MARTINEAU'S long, busy, and useful life in its effective activities covered nearly three-quarters of the nineteenth century. He was born in 1805, his public intellectual life began soon after the close of the first quarter of the century, and his voice was stilled and his pen laid down only a few months before his death, in 1900.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Fugitive reports are reaching Washington from Missouri that indicate the friends of Senator Vest are trying to get together and give him a spontaneous re-election to the Senate. Senator Vest himself realizes his age and ill-health, and says he has not at any time reconsidered the determination made several years ago to retire at the end of his present term.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26 -- The Princeton hockey team fought valiantly to-night at Duquesne Garden, cheered on by a host of friends among the spectators, but the skilled Keystone team was too much for the collegians, and the local team won the first game of the season here by a score of 5 to 0.

Dr. Lorenz was the guest of honor at a dinner last night given by admiring Austro Hungarians at the Arion Club. There were about fifty persons present, most of them men distinguished in the profession of medicine. Many speeches were made, and all of them were in German. The physicians did not go into technicalities or long scientific talks, but indulged in fun, some of it at the expense of the distinguished guest.

L'ART NOUVEAU" and what are you going to do about that? Are you to turn your back on grandfather's clock? Is there going to be an aesthetic revolution? Did the Athenian begin with the vase first, make it lovely, and did the temple, that masterpiece, follow after?

If Mr. Carnegie were a Prince instead of a simple citizen of the United States this biographical sketch would be called courtly. Prom beginning to end its tone is one of high-wrought eulogy. No sketch of this remarkable man and his wonderful career from messenger boy to multi-millionaire can well be other than interesting, but the courtly style of biography is from the nature of the case unsatisfactory.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 26 -- J.R. Warner, store keeper at Illiamnia Bay, Alaska, for the Trans-Alaska Company, is here to spend the Winter, the army of men employed by the company having been disbanded. Warner says the project to build a railroad from Illiamnia Bay to Yukon has been abandoned indefinitely.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Confirmation was obtained here to-day by the Associated Press of the announcement from Washington that the arbitration of the Venezuelan questions is now assured and that, failing the acceptance by President Roosevelt of the invitations tobecome arbitrator, the matters in dispute will be referred to The Hague tribunal.

A NOTEWORTHY figure in Anglo-American society in Paris, it is as an amateur singer that Miss Fanny Reed has won distinction and fame. Her artistic sympathies have brought her into contact with many of the great minds of the century.

The funeral of the late E.C. Walker will take place from his recent residence, One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street and Jerome Avenue, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The deceased, who was a well-known turf writer, lost his life by being run over by a street car last Monday.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The Christmas numbers of the illustrated papers are all out, a month in advance of the date, as usual. If a Christmas number may be published in the latter part of November, there is no reason why it should not be published four or six months earlier.

Detective Joseph Jacobs, who obtained the evidence on which District Attorney Jerome and the police raided Canfield's and Farrell's gambling houses, narrowly escaped being locked up for last night in the Yorkville prison. As matters stand, his bondsman is to go to court and surrender him this morning in order that a return may be made on a writ of habeas corpus obtained yesterday.

WHAT do we know? Are we not overarrogant in 1902? True is it that the achievements of the last 100 years, as far as scientific observation goes, have been marvelous. But no one can read a volume precisely as is Prof. Newcomb's "Astronomy for Everybody" without understanding at once what are man's limitations.

-- We will leave to correspondents with more courage and fewer public responsibilities than we have to tell stories about dogs that can, without special training, be sent for brooms and can get them, if necessary, by robbing a neighbor. We like such yarns, as flights of fancy and tests of faith, but we cannot in our capacity as guardians of the truth "stand for" any dog story of that particular kind.

A VIGOROUS appeal to Southerners for the establishment of a Southern magazine or review of the highest class is made by The New Orleans Picayune. Such a magazine. The Picayune thinks, should fairly rival the famous monthlies of the North in both its literary and its pictorial content, but the idea seems to be that its only contributors should be Southern men and women.

The East, which was the birthplace of literature, has waited long for an appre- ciative and adequate record of its achievelent in letters. Of Hindu literature, par- tiularly the splendid Vedic era, there is no fitting story. It is even worse with regard to the vast and magnificent bulk of Chinese writings.

Those who admired Mr. Crawford's carefully written pages taken from the old Roman chronicles as they appeared four years ago in two elaborately illustrated volumes, and yet found the work beyond the reach of their purses, may now have reason to rejoice that this season sees "Ave Roma Immortalis" presented in a compact, student's edition at moderate price.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Commander Seaton Schroeder, Governor of the Island of Guam, in his annual report dated July 16, which has just reached the Navy Department, indicates a stringency in the island finances owing to the failure of Congress to appropriate the sum asked for last year.

LEON H. VINCENT dedicates his "Moliere," the fourth volume in the author's series of Brief Studies in French Society and Letter in the Seventeenth Century, "To Francis Wilson, in memory of the days and nights in the library of The Or- chard."

ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- S.C. Mead, Secretary of the Committee on Transportation and Franchises of the New York Merchants' Association, spent two hours with the State Railroad Commissioners to-day conferring upon the statement of facts and suggestions to be presented at the hearing in New York Tuesday on the alleged insuf- ficient interurban traffic facilities in New York.

"Love and Louisa" is one of those books that tells a very ordinary story in a not unusual way. There is neither brilliancy of style nor originality of plot. Louisa is an irresponsible young person who seems to court sorrow, and when the opportunity to be happy finally does present itself doesn't grasp it until several chapters later, at the end of the book, when the awakening occurs.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 26 -- The papers all comment on the arrival of W.J. Bryan here, but it is understood that his visit is merely one of pleasure and recreation. He is accompanied by his wife and children.

Doubleday, Page Co. will begin the publication in February of their Elizabethan Shakespeare, the first volume being "The Tragedie of Macbeth." The work is edited by Prof. Mark Harvey Liddell, a Princeton University man of the class of 1887, who has for a number of years been engaged in collecting material for a new edition of Shakespeare.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: YOUR correspondent, Kate Louise Roberts of Newark, in reply to the critics of Mr. John Cotton Dana, relative to New Jersey literature, says of Elizabeth, in Longfellow's "Tales of a Wayside Inn," "It gives but little hint to the casual reader of a special New Jersey atmosphere."
YOUNG Mr. P. Chauncey Dickerson surveyed himself with an air of satisfaction, in his full-length mirror in the corner. Then he picked up the note of invitation and read it through once more.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The British Government has just published a Blue Book, in the Treaty Series, which contains an important convention signed at Adis Ababa, the capital of Abyssinia, last May 15. There have been rumors that this country had succeeded in obtaining important concessions from the Emperor, Menelek, and the agreement now published will certainly not prove a disappointment -- except to foreigners.

IN the eyes of most persons safe breaking comes under the general classification of criminology. It is a matter for the police to deal with, and one in which the ordinary newspaper reader takes only a casual interest.

THIS is the age of the plate. The oldtime dinner set for the people who make the slightest pretense of living fashionably or serving course dinners has passed into innocuous desuetude. Vary little if anything is served at the table. My lady must have different style plates for every course, and these, if they are in fine china, will cost her anywhere from $12 to $300 or $400 a dozen.

ONE night there was a dance down to Angels," said the Old Settler, "an' Reub Bannerton, bein' kinder lone- some, c'ncluded he'd go. He was a mishty modest man. Reub was, an' he was sittin' by the wall, not calc'latin' to dance, when a girl he never saw walked up to him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Washington telegram in to-day's edition of THE TIMES, headed "Raising Rank of Veterans," recalls to public attention the most glaring, invidious distinction between the treatment of the army and of the navy by Congress that the United States statutes afford.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Business was very quiet this week on the Stock Exchange, which was closed on Thursday and yesterday.

The plan presented by the committee of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment is one which the management of the New York Central Railroad would show its wisdom in making haste to accept. It is extremely liberal to that corporation, and might be considered too liberal if any haggling or dickering were indulged which should result in reopening the whole subject for public discussion.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 27. -- The bank at Union, Mo., was robbed of $15,000 in a sensational manner by burglars between 1 and 2 A.M. to-day, according to a dispatch received here. Residents in the vicinity of the bank were aroused by the sound of an explosion and some of them rushed into the street.

DELIVER me from a vacation if I have to spend it at home," said a fat, red-faced man the other morning to a friend he met on the Harlem train. "I am going back to business, glad to be released from too much domesticity."

To quote an old phrase in police parlance, Detective Joseph Jacobs of the Citizens Union staff of sleuths, again tried to "break into jail" yesterday. At first he didn't succeed, but he wasn't discouraged, and tried, tried again till he succeeded.

That Long Island Sound is the stretch of water in the vicinity of New York City by far the most suitable for yacht racing has been agreed by yachtsmen generally for some years, and the fact was brought out very distinctly by the action of the Regatta Committee of the New York Yacht Club in arranging a number of races for next season on the Sound.

Members of the Faculty of the New York University have declined the invitations to them to be present at the annual dinner of the Association of American Universities at Sherry's on Tuesday night, at which President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia is to act as toastmaster. The reason for the declination is that the policy of the association is "too exclusive."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- A question of interest to all married men in the navy is involved in the case of Commander John D. Roller, who has been punished by Rear Admiral Robley D. Evans for allowing his wife to make her home on board his ship. Commander Roller was in command of the gunboat Monocacy, on the Asiatic station with Admiral Evans.

"The late Senator John E. Kenna's statue reminds me of how that distinguished man first became known politically," remarked a Senator from West Virginia as he passed through the "Hall of Fame" the other day at the Capitol.

At Madison Square Garden last night, over 5,000 persons saw one of the best indoor athletic meetings ever held in this city. There were National, intercollegiate, and junior champions among the competitors, and while no records were equalled the performances in general were of a high order of merit and some of the finishes evoked hearty cheers from the unlookers.

WORKMEN were engaged last week in removing the old, dust-covered parchments from the Register's Office, commonly known as the Hall of Records, and in regard to the proposed destruction of which a war of words has been waged for many years among the antiquarians of the town.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your leader in to-day's issue, discussing the necessity of a strong and efficient navy to prevent our Monroe Doctrine from becoming a mere brutum fulmen is both able and timely. It is a masterly presentation of the whole case in few words.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The marriage of Misa Henrietta Bates, eldest daughter of the Paymaster General of the Army, to McKee Dunn McKee, took place at 4 o'clock to-day at the Bates residence, in N Street, in the presence of relatives and a few intimate friends. The ceremony took place in the music room, which was decorated with palms, Bride roses, and lilies of the valley.

To the Editor or The New York Times: That our customs duties are excessive and that our currency is contracted are generally conceded, and the proneness of the human family to go to extremes may be illustrated by an extent of level country in New Zealand known as the Canterbury Plains and by a region of hilly country in Sullivan County, State of New York, known as the Beech Woods.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 27. -- Despite the extra vigilance of the local police since the two recent hold-ups near this place, two more persons last night were the victims of highwaymen. Alvin Parker, a Fair Haven fish peddler, went to Lincroft on his route yesterday. He had a good day's sales, and in his pocketbook was about $20.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- A verdict having a significant bearing upon the right of labor organizations to maintain or assist in enforcing a boycott was rendered this morning in Judge Vall's court, whereby George Hinchcliff was awarded $22,000 damages against the members of the Chicago Masons and Builders' Association and the Brick Manufacturers' Association.

THE CASE OF THE PASSIONIST FATHERS -- In the opinion of an ex-French Minister of Public Works, contained in a private letter to a friend in this city, the French Government is almost certain to reconsider its rejection of the application for authorization under the associations law made by the Passionist Fathers, who officiate at the church for English-speaking Catholics in Paris.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27 -- The Crane Company, an Illinois corporation, began suit to-day in the Court of Chancery to have a receiver appointed for the Lakewood Gas Company. It was alleged that the company's liabilities will exceed its available assets by nearly $100,000. The defendant concern was chartered in 1899, and it has a capital of $200,000.
The performance of "Die Walkure," planned for Wednesday at the Opera House, is postponed, and in its place Puccini's "Tosca" will be given with the same cast as has been heard heretofore this season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The question of arbitration in the case of Venezuela, Great Britain, Germany, and Italy is probably attracting fully as much attention, official and otherwise, in this city as in any of the other capitals involved.
BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- The close of the week finds the following rates ruling in the money market here:

Evidence afforded by current business is all in the direction of showing the market's strength, and of materially brightening the outlook for a Spring season, which will compare favorably with any corresponding period since the present movement in New York real estate began to gather strength about three years ago.
SAYS the editor to the impecunious scribe: "There ought to be a lot of stories in the Broad Exchange."

ACCORDING to Prof. Eller of Bonn and the Rev. J. Fischer, Professor of History and Geography at Feldkrich, Austria -- working independently of each other -- the name America used in reference to the land of the Western Hemisphere was first employed in "Cosmographiae Introductio," published at Saint-Die, in the Vosges, in 1507 by the German geographer, Martin Waldseemuller.

BUCHAREST, Roumania, Dec. 27 -- At to-day's session of the Senate, during a discussion of the Question of the naturalization of Jews, the Minister of Public Instruction, M. Haret, referred to the "calumnies against Roumania so widely disseminated" in connection with the Jewish question.

NEW YEAR is more enthusiastically observed by the canny Scot in his native land than in any other country. It is a day given up to fostering domestic harmony and repeating the gospel of peace on earth and good-will toward men. No other period of the year is so potent as this with the Scot in healing the wounds of friendship and in warming the hearts of his countrymen toward his fellows.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -- The sport at Ingleside to-day was marked by the victory of Aunt Polly, a 100 to 1 shot, in the first race. She was one of a field of eleven and was not thought to have a chance.

Gen. FRANCIS V.. GREENE, who is to enter upon the duties of the Police Commissionership within a few days, has doubtless followed with interest the reports of the trial of Capt. MOYNIHAN. If so, he must have been impressed by the fact that, to secure conviction on such evidence as can be had in cases of this character, a great many things besides the guilt or innocence of the accused must be depended upon.

WHITECASTLE, La., Dec. 10, 1902 -- Hon. J.B. Foraker, United States Senate, Washington, D.C.: Dear Sir -- I wish to express my high appreciation of your efforts to have our Government mark in a proper manner and care for the graves of the Confederate soldiers who died in prison or hospital during the civil war and are buried in Northern cemeteries.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 27. -- District Attorney John Weaver, who is slated to succeed Mayor Ashbridge, arrived here last evening with his wife and little son, and is stopping at Haddon Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every spasm of Anglo-Saxon morality quickly reaches the absurd, and that gracious state seems already to have been reached by the recent outbreak in New York.
