If the attacks on the motives of Signor D'Annunzio and of Mr. Pinero were absurd, what should be said of an attack on the motives of Count Tolstoi?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Senator Cullom, who was Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Committce until he was made Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, has been considering the possibility of passing at this session a hill to strengthen the inter-State commerce law by con ferring additional power on the commission.

Matters of more than usual importance are in the golfing atmosphere at present, but they will be brought down to earth in tangible form within the next two months. The annual meeting of the United States Golf Association will be held in this city in February, and all true golfers are awaiting the results of certain questions at that time with great interest.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 27 -- Napoleon Lajoie, the Captain of the Cleveland Baseball Club, is suffering from a severe attack of pleurisy. His condition became quite serious last night, but he is said to be much improved to-day.

We own that we are proud of the American press in its course in the controversy concerning Venezuela, of which the most critical stage appears to have passed. And when we say the American press we necessarily mean the American people, whose casual mood the American press has never failed to reflect with accuracy.

At the present moment the revolutionary movement seems to be almost entirely confined to the Bulgars, and it is believed that the Serbs are taking no part in it. The lead in the movement is openly taken by the Macedonian Committees, which are nearly all Bulgar. The rebel bands, according to the Constantinople correspondent of The Standard, are armed and equipped in Bulgaria.

The Cloth Hat and Capemakers' National Union, which has been in convention since before Christinas Day in the Manhattan Lyceum, 66 East Fourth Street, passed resolutions yesterday denouncing the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen for making President Roosevelt an honorary member.

NOT all the tragic and comic turns that take place in a theatre are enacted on the stage or behind the scenes. A good many of them are played through with tremendous reality right out in the auditorium, even as far away from the footlights as the top gallery.

The holidays make a lull -- a kind of intermission -- in the comedy of the Winter. From Christinas to the New Year there are very few entertainments of note. Everybody who can goes to the country. Those who remain in town attend family dinners and superintend children's festivities. The boys are home from colleges and the girls from boarding schools.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- A move to secure the great packing plant and business of the John P. Squire Company is foreshadowed by an offer being made to holders of the common stock by Dennett. Crane Blanchard of $13 a share for 51 per cent. of the stock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the article in this morning's TIMES under the heading "Weaknesses of Warships," it appears that the warships are weak in that they are tied to the repair shop and coal yard; this appears to be the gist of that article.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- The first professional racquet match played on the new racquet court at Tuxedo since its completion last Summer was played between George Standing, the professional of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, and Robert Moore, one of the leading players in England, and now professional of the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Dec. 27 -- Gilbert Polhemus, Sr., aged seventy-eight, and Phoebe Richardson, aged sixty-five, residents of this place, have announced their marriage. The ceremony was performed on Christmas evening, the Rev. E.M. Stanton officiating. The bride had been a widow for twelve years, and the bridegroom a widower for two years.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 19 -- The Government of the Congo Free State has recently taken energetic measures to prevent the ruthless slaughter of elephants in the State, and renewed efforts are now being made under the auspices of the Government to domesticate the African elephant. To prevent the total extermination of these useful animals is a problem of vital importance for the future of Belgium's great African dependency.

President Haffen of the Borough of the Bronx has prepared a statement of the appropriations made by the Board of Estimate and the amount expended in local improvements in the Bronx. The Board of Estimate authorized $4,000,000 of work during the last six months of 1902, and resolutions for other improvements which are under consideration will bring the total appropriations for the borough up to $5,000,000.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Dec. 27. -- The Government navy yard tug Sioux was sunk at the navy yard dock about 6 o'clock to-night by collision with a coal barge, the crew barely escaping with their lives, but losing all their personal, effects.

Weather Prophet DEVOE, harking from Hackensack, anew illustrates the mental balance and moral grace of consistency by promulgating another wrong forecast. The date which he set apart for a blizzard of hyperborean severity rode through its course under an aspect of particularly soft and alluring Winter beauty.

London is troubled, like New York, by the obstinacy of her city fathers and the builders of her new bridges. The former scorn all suggestions that bridges should be beautiful as well as useful and the latter fancy themselves competent to produce a fine thing in the line of bridges without asking counsel of artists.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- There was a smart gathering of American and French society people at the "Reveillon," or Christmas Eve party, given at the Ritz Hotel. Dancing was kept up till an early hour of the morning, and the supper and the Christmas tree gifts were on a lavish scale.
EBEN HOWELL, Sr., Secretary of the Illinois State Mining Board and prominent in mining circles throughout the country, died yesterday at his home in Springfield, Ill., aged fifty-three years.
Doane Robinson, Secretary of the South Dakota Historical Society, is to write a two-volume history of that State, the work to be completed by July, 1904.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 -- Buchanan landed the mare Wealth a head in front of Golden Rule to-day in the New Orleans Handicap, worth $1,190 to the winner. Federal was favorite at 8 to 5. Wealth was backed from 6 to 1 to 4 to 1. Weather clear, cold; track fast. Summary:
To the Editor of The New York Times: The American people must not be misled into the idea that the Canadian born residents in the United States are loyal to the British crown. This is not so.

MR. BOLTON is very fond of reading aloud. Before he was married he used to read aloud for his own satisfaction and the torment of his neighbors who could hear him through the thin partition, and wondered if he was not losing his mind when he laughed so heartily over the jokes.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- County Clerk A. R. Thompson and District Attorney Jarvis O'Brien of Rensselaer County came before Judge Herrick in Special Term here to-day and made application for an order directing the Sheriff and County Judge of Rensselaer County to show cause why the panel of Grand Jurors drawn yesterday should not be set aside.

The fiscal year for National banks ended with the last call of the Treasury Department for statements as to condition at the close of business Nov. 25, and it is interesting at this time to compare these reports with those filed on Dec. 10, 1901, and thereby determine the earnings of these institutions.

NEW YORK CITY will spend during the year 1903 nearly $1,000,000 for printing, stationery, and supplies. Superintendent Cowen of the Board of City Record is making every effort to economize, but the orders for books, blank forms, and the thousand and one other kinds of printed matter needed by the heads of the city departments are piling up at rapid rate.

TACOMA, Dec. 27 -- Miss Marguerite Ducksworth Livingstone, a New York girl, is the central figure in a charming romance which ended last week, when Miss Livingstone became the bride of Dr. Frederick Cane, Postmaster of White Horse, Yukon Territory.
THE man who walks across Central Park every morning says he has found a new virtue in cleanliness.
NODD -- I wonder how the market is to-day?

AN immense furnace for the cremation of rubbish is one of the features of one of New York's newest shop buildings. The disposition of old boxes, papers, string, rags, and refuse of all kinds, quantities of which are brought in with every invoice of goods received, is a matter of importance in an establishment carried on on the large scale of the big department stores.

Mrs. Lulu E. Wuest has begun a suit for separation against her husband, Dr. Charles Wuest, a Coroner's physician of Brooklyn. Through her lawyer, A.H. Hummel, she has served a complaint in which she makes many and varied charges, among them being the accusation that the doctor was wont to take as many as seven cold baths nightly.

THIS story was told to me by Mac Wade, a comedian who has seen so much of the unlovely side of "road" life that he might well be the writer of tragedies, but in whom the innate sense of humor is so strong that he is the comedian, in spite of himself, even while endeavoring to be most serious.

ST. JOHN'S, Dec. 24. -- Progressive and far-seeing capitalists are now coming to regard Labrador as an Eastern Klondike. Scientific investigation has determined that the territory is rich in timber, minerals, and farm lands, and its extensive exploitation is assured in the near future.

About 200 members of the Bankruptcy and Admiralty Bar of the City of New York discussed in the United States Court, in the Federal Building, yesterday, the necessity for asking Congress to create the office of an additional District Judge for this district.

TUESDAY, DEC. 30 -- By the McVickar Realty Trust Company, foreclosure sale. Ely Rosenberg, referee, 20 Beekman Street, northeast side. 115.10 feet southeast of Nassau Street, 23.6 by 83.4 by 23.6 by 85.5. five-story stone-front building. Due on judgment, $54,662.

UNDER instructions issued by the Board of Education, the Principals of Greater New York recently made a careful enumeration in their respective schools of the children whose mental capacity is below the normal standard. This standard, presumably, is the measure of ability shown by the average child of equal age to advance under the present methods of teaching.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- School Principals from all over the State, will assemble here Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday of next week to attend the eighteenth holiday conference of the Associated Academic Principals of the State of New York. It is generally credited with being the rallying time for the most influential educational forces in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- There will be strong opposition to Senator Morgan's proposal to make the salaries of the Panama Canal Commissioners $5,000 a year and require them to perform their duties and keep their offices on the Isthmus.

Conspicuous a dozen years ago for the extent of additions made to length of road operated, the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company is no less conspicuous at the present time for the large mileage which quite recently it has either constructed, leased, or acquired in one way or another, building up a system which now stands for an excess of 7,000 miles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If it be true that the request for President Roosevelt to act as arbitrator in the Venezuelan case came from the German Emperor, it certainly shows the anxious desire of that great monarch to act with the United States, instead of Europe, in whatever compulsory measures may hereafter be adopted, and I think our people should appreciate that fact.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Chicago faces a grave coal situation which will stop the fires in half the down-town buildings within a week, according to C.L. Dering, manager of the S.C. Schencks Coal Company, one of the largest in the city.

ALL the principal hotels in New York employ a house surgeon. They do not pay him a salary, but merely provide him with a sleeping apartment and office. In return he treats the ills and aches of the staff, from the head man down to the kitchenmaid. This is not a particularly easy task, as there are from 500 to 800 men and women on the pay roll of the large hotels.
To the Editor or The New York Times: In to-day's issue you say (in effect) that there is no valid reason why the Venezuelan question should not be referred to The Hague tribunal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been expecting to see some expression of opinion by THE NEW YORK TIMES upon the eight-hour workday, for which the leaders of labor unions all over the country -- if not the laborers themselves -- are so persistently clamoring. This expression appeared in your issue of the 22d inst.

Russell Sage, Director of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad, boarded one of the crowded trains on the Sixth Avenue Line on his way to his banking office yesterday morning. He was pushed and jostled, and by the time the train reached Cortlandt Street Mr. Sage was much perturbed and weakened.
Grand and Attorney Streets, northeast corner, for a six-story brick tenement, 40 by 90; A. Silverson of 236 East Sixty-first Street, owner: G. F. Pelham of 503 Fifth Avenue, architect; cost, $42,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 27 -- One of the largest crowds that has ever witnessed an athletic contest in Duquesne Garden saw the Princeton hockey team this afternoon defeat the Pittsburg all-inscholastic team by the unusually close score of 1 to 0. Princeton scored its first victory in this city, and the contest closed amid loud cheers from the followers of the New Jersey collegians.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- The ferryboat Rockland, owned by the North River Steamboat Company, is frozen fast in the ice half a mile off here, and is floating up and down the river with the tide. There are ten passengers and a crew of eight men aboard the boat. Among the passengers are two women and two children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The work of the Senate Park Commission has received compliments recently from two widely separated sources. The Park Board of the City of Seattle has examined the plans of the Washington commission, and decided to follow them in working out a park system for that city.

Though broken by a holiday, the Wall Street week has been one of favorable aspect. Money rates ran up once or twice and as quickly receded; and there have been some other factors made a great deal of by speculators for the de- cline. But sentiment, in the face of all opposition, has shown material improvement, and changes in quotations for the week form a substantial list of advances.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of this morning states that "Mme. Sembrich was unable to sing at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening on account of what an announcement in the lobby called 'indisposition.' Fortunately it is not an indisposition of the voice, and admirers of her singing may expect soon to have the pleasure of hearing her again."

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Baron d'Estournelles de Constant, the French Deputy who was one of the delegates of France to the International Peace Conference and who is a member of The Hague Arbitration Tribunal, has written a strong congratulatory letter to President Roosevelt on the submission of the Venezuela arbitration to The Hague court.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 27 -- Politicians are looking forward with keen interest to the coming session of the Connecticut Legislature. Besides, important legislative measures which will come before that body, there is a possibility of a notable fight in the Senatorial election.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- After all the Government may find the moment propitious for bringing forward the recently eschewed Divorce blll without waiting for Signor Giolitti's industrial and economical reform measures to assume the all-important attiude.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Friday last I received a copy of the address of the Rev. W.P. ODELL, which was delivered a few weeks ago before the New York preachers' meeting and aroused a discussion severely commented upon in your columns.

TOKIO, Dec. 2 -- Seasickness does not always attend travel by rail in Japan, but an experience furnishing a good counterfeit of that malady may be had on parts of the Government line between this city and Kobe. Cars lightly trucked, bounding springs, and rails ballasted for obduracy and yielding qualities alike surprising, supply the moving causes for this sensation.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt's decision not to act as arbitrator of the Venezuelan dispute is regretted here, not so much on diplomatic as on personal grounds. His acceptance would have caused great satisfaction because of the universal confidence his character inspires.

The latest foreign automobile novelty is a motor car which is planned to be used ordinarily as a railway inspection car, but which, in case of war or of rioting, can be quickly converted into an armored car, to be used in keeping open the line and preventing depredations upon the track and rolling stock, or to be rushed to any point of the line where artillery might be needed.

Forty-one boys, whose ages ranged from eleven to sixteen years, marched into the Children's Court yesterday, and the presence of each was a surprise to the others. They were there to be congratulated. Each carried in his pocket a letter from the pastor of his church, announcing that he had reformed and had been living a religious and honest life.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading your editorial in Wednesday's TIMES on President Roosevelt as an arbitrator in the Venezuelan trouble, entitled "Inexpedient and Unsafe," it would seem, if the President must act in such a capacity, that the only course for him to pursue would be to act not quite as an arbitrator, but as one assuming a protectorate over that country.

IT is a far cry from decolletee opera gowns, foamy with tulle and rich in lace, to skating costumes of cloth and fur, but the girl who flies like an arrow in the latter during the morning may be seen languidly toying with a fan in one of the parterre opera boxes a few hours later.
Money on call, 6 per cent., nominal. Time money, 6 per cent, for sixty to ninety days, and 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent. for four, five, and six months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The "Lily White" issue is spreading over the South, and the President is obliged to take cognizance of it in State after State. Texas is the latest one in which the issue has developed. Mr. Roosevelt to-day received George G. Green, Marshal of the Northern District of Texas, who has come here to fight against removal.

President Roosevelt, in his New England tour last Summer, said that the first duty of a good citizen was to be a good father. He said it with meaning, for the natural increase of the population of the United States is nothing like sufficient to secure the progress of the Union in the same ratio as that of other powers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- The announcement by Israel W. Durham, the Republican leader in this city, that the organization had decided to name District Attorney John Weaver for Mayor was received with astonishment by Republicans and Democrats alike, and has completely taken the wind out of the sails of the independent Republicans.
IT WAS her poodle that did it -- bless the fourlegged darling!
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- With the approach of the year's end the pressure for money was strong to-day, though less keen than anticipated, owing to previous preparations. Discounts were firm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The terrible story told on Page 2 of your issue of yesterday, regarding the suicide of a little girl of the tender age of eight years, who killed herself with carbolic acid, surely ought to stir this community to action in regard to the sale of that poison and the passage of a law restricting its sale to properly prepared mixtures and solutions duly prescribed.

XXVIII. IT was Sunday morning and the Idiot came to the table with a cast of countenance that caused more than ordinary wonderment among his fellowboarders. He appeared to be not so much solemn as depressed, and there was that in his eye which served to avert rather than to invite the usual badinage as to his frame of mind. Mrs. Pedagog, too, was downcast, and the Schoolmaster stirred his coffee glumly.
YES, a certain amount of flirting," began Portia thoughtfully, "a certain amount of flirting is good for husbands. It keeps them from brooding too much on being -- husbands."

The orchestral works of Berlioz, like those of Liszt, reappear from time to time in the concert programmes as a tribute from orchestral conductors to men who loom large in the history of modern music and who were both consumed with a desperate ambition to play the part of great composers in it.

HAVANA, Dec. 19 -- Obispo Street is deserted in the early afternoon. The shops have almost no customers, and the few are foreigners; it is unusual for a Cuban woman to appear on the shopping streets between the hours of 12 and 4. Arrayed in the airiest of Summer gowns, usually an organdy over a color, with bright ribbons, she goes to make her purchases in the morning or evening.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 27 -- Two hundred buffers, polishers and platers in the employ of the International Silver Company, who went on strike six weeks ago for a change in rates for piece work, will return to work on Monday, the strike having been called off. The company will make no concessions.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Queen Alexandra's dinner this afternoon to the widows and children of those killed in the South African war formed the most striking demonstration in London's observance of Christmas. Long before the festivities began crowds gathered in the streets adjacent to the Alexandra Trust Building, which was gayly decorated without and within.

Chairman Dunn of the Republican State Committee said yesterday that the makeup of the legislative committees would not be finally decided until the conference which is to be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel next Friday between Senator Platt, Gov. Odell, Lieut. Gov. Higgins, Speaker Nixon, and the State Chairman.
THE man got in the car at Sixty-third Street and sat down near the door, leaving a space of about six inches between himself and the rear corner of the car.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The Foreign Office officials say a note from Secretary Hay similar to those presented at Rome and Berlin has been received here.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- John Barker Ellison, one of Philadelphia's most prominent clubmen, died at the Bryn Mawr Hospital to-day, after suffering for five weeks from an attack of typhold fever. Two weeks ago he had rallied to such an extent that it was thought he would recover, but the improved condition prevailed for only a short time.

Though the dealers and the operators were disposed yesterday to minimize matters, it was learned that a coal famine will result in this vicinity if a cold wave comes now. A representative of the New York, Ontario and Western Company said that it will probably be a week before the output at the mines per day reaches the tonnage achieved before Christmas Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The solution of roadmaking problems that is going on in the Province of Batangas, on the Islahd of Luzon, under the direction of Gen. J. Franklin Bell, has been thorough and rapid during the last season. Under Spanish rule the roads were entirely neglected, and dur- ing a large part of the year following the rainy season the thoroughfares were wholly impassable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tour timely editorial this Christmas morning on the two great republics should appeal to all thoughtful citizens. It is well to chew the cud of thought, which act demonstrates our fitness for true citizenship in this great republic and in the prospective "parliament of man" and the "federation of the world."

OF the theatres in New York where performances are given in Yiddish, one of the most interesting, because most primitive, is located near the corner of Grand and Suffolk Streets, and is devoted to vaudeville. Upon the outside of the building there is none of that glittering illumination which distinguishes the more pretentious theatres uptown, and only a modest sign, in the Hebrew character, informs you that this is a temple of the Thespian art.

I WAS once with a polar expedition," said the man with the seafaring trousers, "and we didn't have no hardships and didn't get into none of the scraps that seems to go with a long stay in the arctic regions, neither. We cut out all that by taking along a good cargo of ice, and plenty of pajamas and palm-leaf fans.
THE woman who squanders much mental force in wondering about other people's affairs has picked up three fragments of life which she would like to piece into the original tissue.

Notwithstanding the fact that the weekly bank statement was somewhat more unfavorable than had been expected, and that room traders were generally bearish and inclined to offer stocks down, yesterday's stock market closed decidedly strong, with many substantial advances appearing in the list.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 27 -- Lakewood's holiday visitors awoke Christmas morning and found the pines shrouded in a mantle of purest white. They rejoiced at the prospect of a sleigh ride around the lake, a pleasure not often enjoyed by Lakewood visitors. The sun came out bright and early, however, and by noon the roads were as bare of snow as though none had fallen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great number of the parents on Washington Heights have been planning, ever since the completion of the new school at One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, to send their girls there, as the school was built with the express purpose of having a school for girls only in this portion of the city.

The tale that Germany will insist upon the payment to her of a few hundred thousand dollars of Venezuelan money in settlement of an adjudicated claim before she consents to arbitration by The Hague court lacks official confirmation, and if confirmed would not create alarm.

For some time past it has been stated that options have been given on coal lands in the Western Kentucky coal field, and these options are being taken up in the interest of Eastern parties. The proposition is to consolidate the mines in the district. The Western Kentucky district is an extension of the great central coal fieid, and in 1901 it produced 3,101,094 tons.

Frederick W. Ruckstuhl, who has resigned from the office of Chief of Sculpture of the St. Louis Exposition, yesterday made the following statement giving the reasons that prompted him to take the step:

I AM a parish visitor in the service of the east side mission of one of the up-town city churches. During the two years I have served in this capacity, during two others also that I spent in fresh air work, and during those even before that when I was a kindergarten teacher, also in the slums, I have naturally formed a wide acquaintance among the children of the poor.
THIS story is true," said the city missionary. "I know the girl, and the street, and I have watched her pigeons.

It is a commonplace of criticism that it is difficult to render permanent judgment upon the work of a contemporary. In the case of Mr. Clyde Fitch, whose "Girl With the Green Eyes" has brought him again to the fore the difficulty is raised almost to an impossibility. Not only are his plays in the aggregate of very unequal merit, but each particular play is usually a most tantalizing medley of excellencies and defects.
LAI SANG peered anxiously with short-sighted eyes at the stream of Chinese passengers descending from the lower deck of the great trans-Pacific liner.

THE New Year will be celebrated at the various clubs with festival and rejoicing. Tuxedo gives a New Year's ball, which is considered to be the wind-up of the season there. The Calumet will have a formal gathering on New Year's Day, at which their guests of the Union will be present.

"He will see for himself, and he cannot easily be misled." That seems to be the general feeling in South Africa as to the extraordinary visit of the Secretary for the Colonies. It is a hopeful sign for the success of his mission, for undoubtedly he goes to see for himself and he strongly wishes not to be misled.

Funeral services for State Senator Patrick F. Trainer, who died in Albany Christinas morning, were held yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Cross in West Forty-second Street. For two hours the church and the street without was lined with those who had come to pay their last token of respect.

Magistrate Henry A. Brann of the Yorkville Court, who on the last day of December will lay down his office after seven years of service, was at the close of yesterday morning's session of his court, waited upon by a roomful of lawyers, ex-Judges, and court attaches, who congratulated him, made him speeches, and presented gold-framed resolutions, a diamond stud, and a gold watch with a charm suitably inscribed.

Funeral services for Nathan Salsbury, entertainer and showman, who died at Long Branch on Christmas Eve, were held at the showman's late home, 30 West Ninety-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon. The service was under the direction of Munn Lodge, F. and A.M. The members of the lodge attended the funeral in a body.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 28. -- Mrs. Jessie Benton Fremont, widow of Gen. Fremont, died last night at her home in this city.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Dr. Lorenz, who came here to-day to visit George J. Gould at his country place, Georgian Court, tried his hand at patching up the broken spokes of a runabout which was demolished in a collision with a runaway team on the Lake Drive this afternoon, and he found the job much more difficult than mending bones.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Within a short time will begin the shipbuilding race between the Navy Department, which has undertaken to construct at the Brooklyn Navy Yard the battleship Connecticut, and the Newport News Shipbuilding Company, to which has been given the contract for the building of the Louisiana.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- The story is current here to-night that Theodore P. Gilman of New York City will resign his office as Deputy State Controller, and that Controller Miller will name ex-Assemblyman Otto Kelsey, who failed of election as County Judge of Livingston County, to succeed him. There is coupled with the story of Mr. Gilman's contemplated retirement the statement that he does not resign of his own volition.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Mrs. Mary Heaton, twenty-three years old, a bride of less than a month, has been forced to have her husband, William Heaton, twenty-one years old, arrested for desertion and nonsupport. The warrant was sworn out by Overseer of the Poor Baldwin, to whom the young wife complained.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 28. -- Thomas Bruce, a mineralogist and geologist, well known throughout the country, was arrested to-night, and is held at the Central Police Station upon the charge of bigamy. Mr. Bruce is a cousin of W. Cabelle Bruce, a leading lawyer of Baltimore, and is well known here, both in financial and social circles.

Mr. CHARLES A. PROUTY, on Saturday, in Philadelphia, put forward the plea of the Inter-State Commerce Commission for new powers. It is not a new plea, but has been urged by the commission in its reports for the last five or six years. The specific action advocated by Mr. PROUTY is, we believe, likely to attract some attention.

To the Sunday night patrons of the Metropolitan Opera House Rossini's "Stabat Mater" is apparently a never-ending source of inspiration and genuine enjoyment. It never fails to crowd the vast temple of music, as it did last night, and the audience, like all "Stabat Mater" audiences at the Metropolitan, departed satisfied.

The announcement that Charles H. Van Brunt, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court was to act as President of the Windsor Trust Company, which is to open its doors for business at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street to-day, led to the report that Mr. Van Brunt had resigned from the bench.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The Venezuelan Government is now in possession of the complete notes of Great Britain and Germany containing the various reservations made by those Governments before the decision was reached that the issues between Venezuela and the European Governments having claims against her should he referred to The Hague tribunal for arbitration.

The Central Federated Union decided yesterday to take hold of its biggest task, the amalgamation of the United Hebrew Trades, composed of twenty-five or thirty trades unions, representing more than 15,000 workers, with the central body. A committee of seven was appointed to meet a like committee of the United Hebrew Trades with this object in view, and an effort is to be made to bring the two committees together some time this week.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 28. -- Authorities on live-stock matters say the loss of the past week in Eastern Colorado and Western Nebraska will not be less than 5,000 head. More than ever this year the Humane Society is agitated by reports from the cattle ranges and the suburbs of the cities and towns of Colorado where dumb animals are left to starve and freeze.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kindly permit me to contribute a few words to the subject of car crowding. The Metropolitan people declare that all is done that is possible to accommodate the public. I admit that during the rush hours it may be simply an impossibility to give better service, but the company utterly disregards the public comfort at other periods of the day.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 28. -- George H. Smyth, Jr., of this city has been appointed junior assistant to the Rev. Dr. Donald Sage Mackay, pastor of the Collegiate Church. Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street, New York. Mr. Smyth, who is in his senior year at Union Theological Seminary, will enter upon his new duties on the first Sunday of January.

An intercity handball match was arranged yesterday between "Mike" Egan, the world's champion, and James Flaherty Jersey City as partners, and Oliver Drew and Dr. Shea of Brooklyn. The date has not been decided, but the pairs will play home-and-home games, and if necessary, a rubber on either the Brooklyn or Jersey City courts, or perhaps on some neutral court.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- The first annual report of Fiscal Supervisor Harry B. Bender, who, under the legislation enacted by the Legislature last Winter upon the recommendation of Gov. Odell, now controls the expenditures for the State's charitable institutions, makes the claim of a considerable saving to the State under the new system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Soon after the reassembling of Congress Senator Mason will introduce his bill empowering the Attorney General of the United States to go into court and ask for the appointment of a receiver to take possession of and operate any coal mine that may remain idle for any unreasonable length of time because of a strike.

BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- A water famine threatens Boston and the scores of outlying towns supplied by the Metropolitan water system. Figures given out by the Water Commissioner prove conclusively that with continuous cold weather, such as now holds Boston in its grip, and the consequent excessive demand, there will not be water enough to meet the requirements upon the Metropolitan system.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Patrolman William H. Schenck, known in Trenton as "the evangelist cop." died here suddenly to-day of valvular trouble of the heart.
If an art museum has a lot of second rate pictures, presented or bequeathed, have the Directors a right to dispose of them by public sale?

A good deal of interest attaches to the formation of the legal committee to work in harmony with the Merchants' Association for the reforming of abuses connected with existing street car conditions in New York. The array of legal talent enlisted, under the Chairmanship of Mr. THERON G. STRONG, is sufficiently formidable to promise results if any are to , be reached by the only measures which lawyers are capable of taking.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- The Chateaugay Railroad from Cadyville to Lyon Mountain a distance of twenty miles, was changed to-day from narrow to standard gauge. Several hundred section men left here at 2 o'clock this morning, equipped with lanterns and all necessary tools, and at 3:15 o'clock this afternoon the work was done.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Believing that Queen Anne's accession to the throne of England ruined all her hopes of ever ruling over Great Britain, Mrs. Jennie Weinstein of 218 Bainbridge Street, attempted Saturday to destroy the large oil painting of the Queen in Independence Hall. She was arraigned before Magistrate Cunningham in the Central Station this morning, and held in $500 bail.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 28. -- In a hockey game played here last night the Victoria team of this city defeated the St. Nicholas team of New York by a score of 8 to 1. The play on either side was not very brilliant, and the small score of the visiting players was mainly due to their not taking chances of shooting goals from a distance.

-- A portion of the career of Mrs. MARY BAKER GLOVER PATERSON , EDDY, which the High Priestess of Christian Science has for many a year done her not altogether unsuccessful best to conceal from friends and foes alike, is recalled by a letter signed "J.W. PEEBLES, M.D.," and published by The San Francisco Philosophical Journal.

The judges who will pass on the merits of the exhibits in all classes save one of the twenty-seventh annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, to be held in Madison Square Garden on the four days from February 11 to 14, have been selected by the association. The list is as follows:

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- Earnings of employes in this State have averaged higher in most trades this year than in any other recent year. This statement is made by State Commissioner McMackin in his quarterly report of the Labor Bureau. The Commissioner goes on to say:

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- The London Times's special correspondent at Delhi sends a graphic description of the vast tented city, covering an area approximating that of London north of the Thames River and west of Charing Cross, which has been conjured up for the coronation durbar out of the great barren plain west and northwest of Delhi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The figures of the foreign commerce of the United States during the eleven months ending with November, which have just been completed by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, indicate a phenomenal activity among the manufacturers of the country and exportations quite as large as could be expected in view of the crop shortage of last year.

BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- Prof. Charles L. Norton, Assistant Professor of Heat Measurements at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, makes public the results of his experiments on the heat values of different substitutes for coal. A British thermal unit is the heat required to heat one pound of water one degree Fahrenheit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The fight over the Statehood bill will not be the only territorial subject of legislation demanding the attention of Congress this session. A delegation of Alaskans is on the way to Washington to urge that a number of amendments be made to the act adopted last session to remedy many unjust laws which have gone into operation within the past year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- In a recent public utterance Admiral Fremantle of the British Navy declared that not less than six nor more than ten warrant and petty officers of the navy should be promoted every year to commissioned rank. This declaration from a veteran officer of the English Navy has given encouragement to those who have been advocating the advancement of the enlisted man in the United States Navy.

Secretaries of the old-time pattern, a moderately old time, not long enough ago to be of artistic outlines, but comfortably convenient, are pieces of new furniture, with bookcase tops, desk drops, and drawers.

In a prelude to his sermon last night, at the Calvary Baptist Church, the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur spoke strongly in favor of reform in the street car service in this city, and made several suggestions regarding the nature of the reforms that ought to be made. He said:

Ideal sleighing weather and a snow patch that has not been equaled for several seasons past drew a record-breaking throng of road drivers to the Speedway yesterday morning who, with their trotters and pacers keyed up to winning form and speeding cutters, furnished one of the liveliest day's sport of the year.

It is gravely announced that the beetsugar men to assemble in convention on the 8th of next month in Washington will decide whether the trade treaty with Cuba shall be ratified by the Senate. The net protection which the beetsugar men enjoy against the competition of Cuban sugar is acknowledged to be 11-3 cents a pound.

PARIS, Dec. 28. -- Although the train bringing to Paris the members of the Humbert family, who wore arrested in Madrid, is approaching Paris it is impossible to ascertain when or at what station it will arrive. The train is due at 4:52 o'clock tomorrow morning, but owing to an accident it arrived at the Spanish frontier two hours late and then missed connection with the Paris express at Bordeaux.

It is an unquestioned fact that sentiment in Wall Street is much improved, and that, unless there be untoward developments, prices on the Stock Exchange should, reflecting this improvement, show decided and steady betterment for some time to come. That is not to say, however, that forthwith there is to be either a great "boom" or a "runaway" market.
LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The Right Rev. John Wogan Festing, Bishop of St. Albans, is dead. He was born in 1837.

President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company met William F. King and other representatives of the Merchants' Association yesterday and agreed with them on a joint conference between representatives of the company and of the association on Jan. 7, when the whole question of providing better transit facilities on the surface roads is to be taken up for consideration.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 29. -- The Italian Ambassador and Mme. Mayor Des Planches entertained to-night at the first of a series of evening receptions at their new embassy, on New Hampshire Avenue. The company represented the entire Diplomatic Corps and many friends of the host and hostess from resident society.

Meetings of several of the dancing classes are to be held this evening, including the Fortnightly in the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Stanley Mortimer will give a theatre party for her niees, Miss Eleanor Roosevelt, and Mrs. Norman de R. Whitehouse will have a card party. William K. Vanderbilt will have a large house party at Idle Hour over the holidays.

In the tournament of the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum Bowling League last night the Empire State Council bowlers won two games, defeating the Nassau Council and the J.F. Price Council teams. The scores follow:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- Isaac H. Taylor, Director of Works of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, to-day criticised the conduct of F.W. Ruckstuhl, while acting as Chief of Sculpture of the World's Fair. Mr. Taylor declares that one of Mr. Ruckstuhl's chief reasons, for resigning was the objections urged by the Director of Works to Mr. Ruckstuhl's action in assigning to himself $17,500 worth of sculpture work. He said:

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 29. -- The 'Frisco Railroad, which has attracted so much attention by its sensational growth during the past year, has decided to build two lines which will give it a road from Minneapolis and St. Paul on the north to New Orleans on the south. The information was given out here to-day by E.F. Service, General Western Agent of the road, who has just returned from a conference with President Yoakum.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 29. -- With their clothing covered with ice and firmly frozen to the icy platform of the baggage car, so that escape was rendered impossible, Albert Gray and Herbert Mason, two tramps, stealing a ride from Buffalo to Rochester on the Empire State Express, were captured by railroad detectives here to-day.

We printed yesterday an interesting Washington dispatch upon the possible promotion of warrant officers to commissions in the navy. The text was supplied by a recent deliverance of Admiral FREMANTLE of the British Navy, td the effect that the promotion of a limited number of warrant officers would be good for the service.

BOSTON, Dec. 29. -- There was the biggest kind of trading in Amalgamated in the stock market, but it resulted in a loss of about 2 points. The decline doubtless reflects profit taking and forced liquidation resulting from the squeeze in money. Copper Range, like Amalgamated, was soft. Naturally, these two speculative shares suffered from tighter money.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day, promising a busy week of borrowings for Stock Exchange and year-end requirements, besides various dividend calls which necessitate large disbursements. Discounts were firm.
MADRID, Dec. 29. -- The latest news to reach Madrid confirms the previous reports that Fez has been invested by the rebels.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Gov. Odell, as Commander in Chief of the State National Guard, has selected his military staff. The order appointing them will be issued after New Year's. The following have been chosen:

Amid mingled hisses and applause the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman addressed a meeting in the Educational Alliance Building last evening, at which Bishop Potter and several other prominent men also voiced their ideas concerning the social and economic standing of the Jew. It was the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman's first appearance at the Alliance, since in his two lectures some time ago he gave expression to his opposition to the propaganda of Zionism.

It is almost a full generation since India presented so gorgeous a spectacle as was yesterday presented at Delhi. It was the same capital of the Moguls which witnessed both, and the occasions were similar. The earlier, on New Year's Day of 1877, was given on the occasion of the proclamation of Victoria as Empress of India.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- The members of the Humbert family, who were recently arrested in Madrid in connection with the great safe frauds in this city, arrived at the Orleans Railroad Station here at 7:40 o'clock this morning, and were conducted to the Conciergerle Prison.

Sellers of rain coats and rubber shoes took the centre of the stage yesterday and declared that they were prepared to weather the storm. It was just a portion of about everything on the forecaster's list, all jumbled up together.

Capt. George M. Wells, Assistant Surgeon, will proceed to Fort Bayard and report for duty to relieve First Lieut. Horace D. Bloombergh, Assistant Surgeon, who will proceed to San Francisco and report for duty with the troops en route to the Philippines, and upon arrival at Manila, will report for assignmant to duty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A special to THE TIMES from Washington published yesterday contains an interview with a man from Honolulu named B.K. Blackwell, in which he advocated the letting down the bars to permit at least a limited importation of Chinese coolies to work on the sugar plantations -- he being a sugar planter himself.
ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 29. -- A dispatch from Moscow announces that an Armenian millionaire named Jambarov was murdered while entering a church there.

The Standard Oil Company has presented to its employes a New Year's surprise in the shape of an announcement regarding the formation of a general pension plan for their benefit. The plan is to take effect Jan. 1, and it is expected that quite a number of the employes who have reached the age limit prescribed by the plan will take advantage of it to retire.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A report on crime, submitted for the information of Congress by Dr. Arthur MacDonald, specialist in the United States Bureau of Education, makes this statement:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the present general denunciation of transit management, it is perhaps well to remember what it was a few years ago and compare the speed and comfort now and then. Also the physical difficulties which have been overcome and those which remain.

Mrs. Langtry opened last night in "The Crossways." a new play which she has written in conjunction with her leading man. Mr. J. Hartley Manners. A large and hopeful audience greeted her pleasantly; but if it is a case of crossing the heart and hoping to die, it must be deposed that the occasion was not as a whole enlivening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- President Roosevelt has not been wounded in the forehead with a rapier wielded by Gen. Wood, nor has he been swinging a broad sword at that officer, as reported in New York to-day; but he has been whacking his military friend over the head with a single-stick, and Gen. Wood has been returning the compliment.
BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- Acceptance of arbitration of the Venezuelan dispute by the German Government after the blockade was begun is certainly not received with popular favor in Germany.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- A dispatch from Tangier, dated yesterday, received in London to-day, gives notice of the departure of the English women missionaries at Fez and Tetuan for the coast. No mention is made of the departure of the Americans, several of whom were stationed at Fez and Mequinez nor of the departure of the English male missionaries.

-- Exercising that mysterious substitute for leason by which jurymen, as distinguished from, all other men -- including themselves in their ordinary phases of citizenship -- so often reach their conclusions, twelve estimable residents of Flowton, England, have just decided that one Prof. CHILD must pay to one ALFRED COE the sum of u10 as penalty for giving, for a consideration, bad advice as to where to dig a well.

About 250 citizens of Brooklyn attended the public hearing in the old Council Chambers in Borough Hall yesterday to substantiate and add to the charges that were brought against the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company by the Manufacturers' Association of the borough. Nearly all of the trade organizations, as well as civic associations, in the borough were represented.

The Inter-University Lacrosse League, which is composed of Harvard University, Cornell University, Columbia University, and the University of Pennsylvania, held its annual meeting at Browne's Chop House last night and elected officers for the coming year as follows: President, C.C. Miller, Crescent Athletic Club, and Columbia 1891 Law; Vice President, W.S. Finlay-Cornell, 1904; Secretary, W.S. Sugden, Harvard, 1903; Treasurer, John A. Freeland, University of Pennsylvania, 1903.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Senator Scott of West Virginia called on the President today to ask for a Federal appointment and got cold comfort. By a curious coincidence as he left the White House he indicated that he was not in favor of the Cuban reciprocity treaty, which the President desires to see adopted.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- Charles A. Conant, Treasurer of the Mortem Trust Company, New York, who has made a special study of the monetary question in the Philippines, was one of the speakers on "Currency Problems in the Orient" before the American Economic Association this evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Robert S. Armstrong, who came to the Treasury Department with Secretary Shaw last February as private secretary, has been selected to succeed Assistant Secretary Spaulding. The announcement of this fact was something of a surprise to those familiar with the workings of the Treasury Department and of the special qualifications, technical knowledge, and training required for the successful discharge of the duties that are being performed by Assistant Secretary Spaulding.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- A request by President Hart of the Chicago National League Baseball Club to postpone the peace conference to be held in Cincinnati next week between committees representing the National and American Leagues was denied to-day by President Johnson of the American League.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Greatsinger's letter in THE TIMES of Sunday indicates that all the Brooklyn Rapid Transit needs now in order to perfect its rapid - transit scheme and make every one happy is the proper kind of terminal arrangement. At one time in the history of this organization its nominal possession of the bridge was necessary to that end.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- J.K. Wood, General Passenger Agent of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, has appointed Colin Studds Assistant Eastern Passenger Agent, to succeed W. W. Lord, Jr., who has been promoted to the post of Passenger Agent for Middle Division, with headquarters in this city, to succeed J. K. Shoemaker, transferred.

Charles Thorley has bought the property of Isabella Cattanach, at 32 1/2 and 36 West Forty-fourth Street, between the Yale Club and the Bar Association's Building, and will erect thereon an apartment house. This parcel is of a very odd shape, and may, perhaps, be best described as a "U," surrounding 34 West Forty-fourth Street, which is a three-story house, 18 by 65.

DELHI, India, Dec. 2O. -- The Viceroy, Lord Curzon of Kedleston, made his state entry this morning into the capital of the Moguls. This constituted the official opening of the Durbar held to celebrate the accession of King Edward as Emperor of India.

Does every one know that key tags can be bought by the box for 25 cents? They are strong tags of parchment, and just the things to tie to keys of chests and trunks or boxes to make it possible to find the right one at the right moment.

Among the members of the rowing clubs along the Harlem River the game of handball has become very popular. It just affords the right sort of strenuous exercise for the oarsmen, who keep up a vigorous course of training throughout the Winter months, and so many of them have become fairly expert at the game that club tournaments are now in progress in nearly every clubhouse on the river.

In the present stage of his invention criticism is worth far more than compliment to MARCONI. Sir WILLIAM PREECE, an eminent English electrician, is doing his best to help on the development of wireless telegraphy by pointing out the present defects of the system.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 29. -- The Philadelphia Stock Exchange had its first session in its new building to-day, and, as usual when it makes a change in abode, it did so on a declining market. Prices were heavy rather than actually weak, losses being limited to small fractions, except in the case of Lehigh Navigation, which was off one-half.

The Palestine Exploration Fund has news of the discovery by the excavator Macalister of a temple to the goddess Astarte, the Ashtoreth of the Old Testament. It was found in a tumulus near the road between Jaffa and Jerusalem called Tell-el-Jesar, on the site of the ancient town Gezer, which the Pharaoh of King Solomon's time captured and gave to his daughter.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 29. -- Word has just arrived at Bristol that Shamrock II, may not be in commission next season, as it is maintained that Designer Fife had rather send the Shamrock I, across the water to act as a trial horse for the new challenger than have Shamrock II, rigged and placed in commission for that purpose.

Prices in the outside market yesterday were irregular and for the most part transactions were small. A few stocks, including Northern Securities, showed totals which compared favorably with the more active flays of last week, but even in these issues there was not sufficient change in price to attract attention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Secretary Hitchcock, with the approval of President Roosevelt, to-day asked Binger Hermann, Commissioner of the General Land Office, to tender his resignation, and he agreed to do so, to take effect Feb. 1. This action is the result of an accumulation of petty irregularities in the Land Office for which Mr. Hermann, without himself being guilty of any of them, is held responsible.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regrard to your editorial, "Car Crowding and Public Rights," you seem to be in doubt as to who has the proper authority to compel the railway companies to respect the public rights. Permit me to state that the authority to deal in this matter belongs to the Board of Aldermen of this city and the Railroad Commissioners of the State of New York.

During the discussion at a motion for the appointment of a receiver for the Antoinettes, an apartment house at Fifty-eighth Street and Park Avenue, the life history of Peter Herter, the builder, was thrashed out before Justice Fitzgerald yesterday, and testimony was given as to the Herter Realty Company; which is composed of Mr. Herter, his wife, and his son.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 29. -- John J. Dickey, Superintendent of the Fifth District of the Central Division of the "Western Union Telegraph Company, and one of the oldest officials in the service of that corporation, died at his home in this city to-night of pneumonia. He had been ill but a few days.

Lovers of skating, not only in the New York locality, but throughout the country, are giving support and interest to the proposed Amateur Skating Association of the United States, which was practically organized two weeks ago, but which will be permanently organized at a general meeting of skaters on Jan. 16.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29. -- The local market showed greater strength to-day with signs of a reviving activity which was prevented from becoming aggressive by the reactionary tendency in New York, aggravated by the continuance of tight money here. The buying was of a good order, however, resulting in advances in Atlantic Coast Line, in Seaboards, and the United Rail-ways issues.

The people of the United States will obbserve with satisfaction that in two great nations of Europe the value of the Service rendered to humanity by President ROOSEVELT in causing the Venezuela dispute to be referred to The Hague court is duly appreciated. In St. Petersburg it is reported that the President receives many compliments for insisting upon the recognition of the court brought into existence through the initiative of the Czar.

We have had our own troubles with silver at home. We are threatened with more of the same kind in the Orient, where we have taken over a mixed Oriental and Spanish people with a motley currency of various sorts of silver under a somewhat confused set of Spanish laws, and of customs fixed in part by foreign bankers and dealers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- This was a day of waiting in regard to the Venezuelan situation. The United States' active part in the affair is about over, or so, at least, it is hoped.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Chicago wholesale coal dealers to-day declared that the situation has become acute and that there can be no relief except as a result of united action on the part of the coal-carrying railroads.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday scored another point in his war on the gamblers, when Justice Scott of the Supreme Court dismissed the writ of habeas corpus and certiorari obtained on behalf of Jesse Lewisohn, the young banker, after the arrest which followed his second refusal to answer questions when a witness before Justice Wyatt in the secret proceedings against Richard Canfield.

Professional football was introduced for the first time in New York at Madison Square Garden last night, and 3,500 persons availed themselves of the opportunity to witness its inauguration. There were two games played, as there are two indoor championships to be decided -- lightweight and heavyweight.

Mayor Low went to Albany yesterday and had a conference with Gov. Odell. returning to the city last evening. When seen on his arrival at the Grand Central Station and asked what he and Gov. Odell had conferred about the Mayor replied that they had talked about possible, legislation affecting the financial condition of the city. He refused to specify as to the nature of the legislation.

BOSTON, Dec. 29. -- At a meeting of the Pere Marquette Railroad Company to-day the following were elected to the Directorate: Thomas H. West of St. Louis, W.K. Bixby of St. Louis, Samuel R, Shipley of Philadelphia, Newman Erb of New York, Myron J. Carpenter of Chicago, F.H. Prince was elected President and M.J. Carpenter Vice President and General Manager.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Navy De- partment will adopt heroic measures to protect the enlisted men at the Puget Sound Navy Yard, near Seattle, Wash., from the evil enfluences which exist at Bremerton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- A decision was rendered to-day by the Commissioner of Patents that will meet with general approbation, however much it may be decried by those enterprising gentlemen and firms who act upon the theory that nothing is sacred when advertising their wares. An application was made by a party for a trade mark bearing the name "Roosevelt Rose."
Details will be found in another coulumn relative to the purchase of the Langham Hotel property, Fifth Avenue and Fiftysecond Street, by the United States Realty and Construction Company.

The advances made within the year by American makers in the construction and equipment of motor carriages will be demonstrated strikingly at the annual Automobile Show, in Madison Square Garden, opening Jan. 17. Two years ago the makers were copying foreign machines, but the coming display will furnish convincing evidence of the originality and mechanical genius of the American workmen, as exemplified in the power driven machines.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 . -- A report from Battle Creek, Mich., says: In the total destruction to-night of the big building occupied by The Review and Herald Publishing Company, the Seventh Day Adventist colony is brought face to face with a second heavy loss by fire within a year, the Adventist Sanitarium having been burned down only last February.
Major Louis A. Craig. Fifteenth Cavalry, is directed to report for examination to Major Gen. Samuel B.M. Young, President of the army retiring board appointed to meet at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Navy Department to-day made public the following extract from a letter written Dec. 19 by Rear Admiral Taylor, Admiral Dewey's Chief of Staff, relative to the Caribbean manoeuvres:

Details were made public yesterday of the new design of torpedo boats, six of which, according to bills introduced in the Senate by Senator Depew and in the House of Representatives by Congressman Sibley, it is proposed to add to the United States Navy. The new vessel is in some respects like a submarine boat and in some like an ordinary torpedo boat.

Borough President Cantor had a further conference yesterday with several delegates from the United Board of Building Trades and with Nicholas Ryan of the firm of Ryan McFerran, the contractors engaged in the work of alterations in the City Hall. President Cantor said he was still hopeful of effecting a settlement of the differences between the contractors and the striking union men.

MADRID, Dec. 30. -- Great Britain and France have notified Spain that they have no intention of taking any advantage of the situation in Morocco, and that they desire the maintenance of the status quo, even in the event of the Sultan being dethroned and his place being taken by the pretender.

Since their return home the mechanics brought to this country from England by Mr. ALFRED MOSELY have been submitting reports to the bodies they represented and talking for publication to reporters. On the whole, their comments on American conditions have furnished the English people very satisfactory Christmas reading matter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Mrs. Roosevelt, accompanied by Senator and Mrs. Lodge, Mrs. Walcott of Boston, and Secretary of War Root, occupied a lower box at the New National Theatre to-night, witnessing Miss Annie Russell's performance of "Mice and Men."

Presidents Eliot of Harvard and Hadley of Yale, ex-Attorney General Wayne MacVeagh, and James W. Alexander, President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, were the speakers who responded to toasts at last night's dinner of the Association of American Universities. Sherry's grand ballroom was comfortably filled with members and guests.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 30. -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to-morrow will give notice to their employes of a new schedule of wages which goes into effect New Year's Day. The advance will not be horizontal, because in many cases employes are receiving as much as is paid on the Pennsylvania Railroad system now, and the wages on that system will be taken as the standard.

The combination passenger and freight elevator in the five-story building at 156 to 160 West Twenty-seventh Street fell from the fourth floor to the bottom of its well yesterday afternoon, killing Harry Savage of 81 West One Hundred and First Street and fatally injuring Conrad Wedlesch of 202 First Avenue.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30. -- The market was better all through the list. There were rumors of impending developments of importance in Atlantic Coast Line which put those issues up sharply. United Railways incomes continued to advance on reports of excellent achievements in the way of earnings.

Play in the intercollegiate chess tournament was resumed at the Columbia Grammar School, in this city, yesterday, when the Columbia players were pitted against Harvard and Yale against Princeton. When play was given over for the day Columbia had maintained herself in the lead, with half a point over Yale.

It is many years since the American stage has seen a production of a great Shakespearean tragedy as temperately vigorous, as richly beautiful, and as consistent and even as a whole, as Mr. E.H. Sothern's "Hamlet," which was presented last night at the Garden Theatre. Strictly speaking, the production is a revival, but the first performances here took place out of season, and continued for a brief time only.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The sum of $2,537,445 has been brought into the State Treasury in fees and taxes from trusts seeking shelter in New Jersey, according to the annual report of the State Board of Assessors, completed to-day. It appears that 15,000 industrial corporations do business under New Jersey charters, outside of the railroad and canal companies, which are taxed separately.

The early gray or dawn yesterday found hopeful treasure seekers in Broadway, Forty-second, Forty-first, and Fortieth Streets mining for the diamonds which the night before had been spilled by the young man who broke the window of R. Simpson Co.'s, pawn brokers at 143 West Forty-second Street, and carried off a $10,000 trayful of jewels.

After struggling through an enormous crowd at the Rector Street station of the Ninth Avenue Elevated line, and securing standing room near the centre of a car that was packed to the doors. Charles Wessel of 231 West Eighty-seventh Street dropped dead just as the train was about to pull into the Cortlandt Street station.

Pushball on horseback was the great attraction last night at the fifteenth annual Christmus music ride in the Durland Riding Academy, West Sixty-sixth Street, near Central Park. In addition, there was a basket ball contest and a section of a fancy dress ball in which eight riders wore the costumes of four past centuries; but the pushball event was really the novel and most amusing feature.

After a conference yesterday between the State Railroad Commissioners and the officials of the Manhattan Railway Company. Chairman Ashley W. Cole promised that in less than forty-eight hours the public would be informed of the improvements in the traffic facilities which the State officials think should be made to remedy in part the "shocking conditions which undoubtedly do exist" in local traffic arrangements on the elevated and surface lines.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Dec. 30. -- Judge Orr of the County Court has admitted the will of the late W.S. Stratton to probate over the protest of the contestant of the will I Harry Stratton. Orville S. Dines. Dr. D.H. Rice, and William Lloyd. the latter Mr. Stratton's Secretary during his life were the only witnesses examined and they simply testified to the executing and signing of the will.

The Church Club, after a discussion on "The Need of Better Art in Church Building and Decoration," last evening passed a resolution empowering the President of the club, George Macculloch Miller, to appoint a committee of five who shall confer with the Architectural League and other organizations of the allied fine arts for the purpose of taking steps to improve religious art in this country.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- The report of the Chicago Sub-Treasury for the past year places it next to that of New York in the volume of business, which aggregated $703,384,645, an increase of $143,760,215 over 1901. In silver shipments the Sub-Treasury here leads, the amount being $14,052,141, which exceeds the combined shipments of Boston, Philadelphia, and Baltimore by $3,000,000.

CARACAS, Dec. 29 -- (Delayed in transmission.) -- Barquisimete, capital of the State of Lara, which for some time past has been in the possession of the Venezuelan revolutionists, has been recaptured by Government forces. The towns of San Carlos and Tinaquillo have also been reoccupied by the Government.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 30. -- It appears that the public has to a certain extent been under a misapprehension as to the location of the portrait of President Lincoln, which will not be placed in the "Mississippi Hall of Fame," as has been generally thought, but simply hung in the Historical Department.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 30. -- A bold attempt was made by a lone robber to hold up the New Orleans-Cincinnati north-bound express of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad as the train was entering South Louisville at 2:30 o'clock this morning. The highwayman secured but little booty, and is believed to have been shot by the conductor, J.D. Keene.

Madison Square Garden was again the scene of some lively football last night, two games of the indoor professional series being decided. The attendance was much larger than on the opening night. A large gathering of Long Islanders had seats reserved on the north side of the Garden, and they were present for the purpose of cheering the Warlow Athletic Club players of Whitestone, L.I., who were pitted against the Knickerbocker eleven of this city.

BOSTON, Dec. 30. -- The money market continues firm. The local situation is very sound and no apprehension exists as to the ability to finance the January settlements. Rates are high, but the best opinion among bankers favors ease after the first week in January.

Republic of Cuba has taken her place among the sovereign nations during the year now ending; the Transvaal Republic and the Orange Free State have passed under the British flag. The question whether they have not thereby exchanged the shadow for the substance of freedom depends upon the policy pursued by their new overlord.

Tammany Hall's Executive Committee for 1903 was organized last evening in the Wigwam and William S. Devery was left outside of the breastworks. The ex-Chief of Police will have to satisfy the Committee on Credentials of the organization that his election as district leader of the "Fighting Ninth" was not secured by fraud and corruption at the primaries.
According to Lebanon (Penn.) dispatches the Lackawanna Iron and Steel Company has bought thirty-five acres of land to extend its Colebrook furnaces.

Watch night or the reveillon, or whatever it may be called, is always observed in New York, although New Year's festivities have changed very much in fashion during the last quarter of a century. This evening there will be many small parties who will wait to see the new year in and to bid farewell to the old one.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Profits of the First National Bank of Chicago for 1902 will be approximately $1,680,000, or 21 per cent. on the capital stock of $8,000,000. The bank earned last year about 22 1/2 per cent. on the other capital of $5,000,000. The showing for 1902, in view of the capital increase of $3,000,000, indicates the handsome returns that have been realized on banking capital in the last half of the current year.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Money was in increasing demand to-day. Discounts were easier in view of the cheaper rates for money which are expected soon to prevail.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- There was little response to the strength displayed in the New York market by the local issues, probably because little, if any, short interest existed in Philadelphia stocks, and probably, also, because of the late slump in Consolidated Lake Superior stocks, which did more damage here than the public knows.

Nicholas Haughton, who died Sunday, and whose funeral will take place this afternoon from his late residence, 335 Second Avenue, was at one time a power in the politics of New York. Mr. Haughton, who was born in Ireland, came to this country at an early age, and when he was eighteen years old started in the liquor business for himself.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- King George of Saxony has ordered the preparation of a full official account of the elopement of the Crown Princess Louise and the circumstances leading up to it for the Saxon people, among whom the most fantastic stories are in circulation to the detriment of the royal house, especially with reference to the future King.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The report is revived here, with some evidences of authority, that Justice Shiras is to retire from the Supreme Bench, probably in February. Gov. William H. Taft is named as the successor selected by the President. Justice Shiras has been eligible for retirement since the opening of the October term of the court.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30. -- John Peters and Swordsman were the only winning favorites today. If You Dare was run up to $1,100 and Swordsman to $600. Both were bought by Dur- nell and Herz. Weather clear, cool; track heavy. Summary:

As the result of a fire in the cellar under 27, 29, 31, and 33 John Street last night Capt. John F. Higgins of Engine Company No. 32 was taken to Hudson Street Hospital suffering from the effects of gas. Lieut. John Hartman and Firemen Coakley, Thayne, Mullen, Brannigan, and Hicks had also been overcome by gas, but revived sufficiently to attend to their duties in the engine house after the fire was out.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Two investigations into the cause of the scarcity and high price of coal in Chicago were begun to-day. At the Palmer House Attorney General Hamlin held a conference behind closed doors with representatives of the coalhauling railroads and of the coal trade; at the City Hall the Council Committee on Railroads held a public session, hearing statements from men who direct the movement of coal, on the railroads entering the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The AustroHungrarian Embassy was the scene of a brilliant reception this afternoon when some 300 or more guests were entertained, the occasion marking the return to society of the Baroness Hengelmuller after a tedious illness, and the introduction of her young relative, the Baroness von Palm of Germany, who has come to spend the season in Washington.

It is a curious position which the war- ring tribes at Morocco and their nominal sovereign occupy in the northwest corner of Africa. "Occupy" is almost too definite a term, general as it is. The great body of them are like the Irish- man's pig, wriggled around so that it could not be counted.

Cheerful indeed is the prospect offered to us wretched creatures who are neither coal miners nor coal mine operators, but to whom both the miners and the operators can and do say "Your money or your life," by the news that the recent rise in the price of fuel is to be used next month by the men in the bituminous region as the basis of a demand for higher wages.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30. -- Miss Margaret Emerson, youngest daughter of Issac E. Emerson, the wealthy drug manufacturer, clubman, and member of the New York Yacht Club, was married this evening to Dr. Smith Hollins McKim, a prominent young society man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- There is good reason to expect that when Congress meets after the holidays the subject of the Panama Canal will be brought up in the Senate and there will be an airing of details connected with the negotiations for the needed concessions from Colombia.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 30 -- Miss Mary Barber, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M.C. Barbor, this evening became the wife of Major Ralph Hartzell. The ceremony was performed at the commodious old Saxton homestead, formerly the home of the McKinleys, now occupied by the Barbers, and was witnessed by Mrs. McKinley.

Justice Scott of the Supreme Court, through a decision rendered yesterday, upset the plans of District Attorney Jerome to obtain evidence against Richard Canfield, as far as those plans concern Jesse Lewisohn, who on two occasions when a witness at the proceedings declined to answer questions and was arrested on warrants charging contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- President Castro's answer to the allies' proposal to arbitrate the Venezuelan troubles has not been received. In fact, Secretary Hay has nothing of importance on the Venezuelan situation to communicate to the Cabinet.
The following general order was posted in the barns of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company (Interurban Street Railway Company) at 1 o'clock this morning:

ROCHESTER, Dec. 31 -- There were more than fifty receptions and balls in this city to-night, and nearly all who attended were forced to walk. On account of a strike declared by the local union of coach drivers at noon to-day not a livery stable in the city could send out a vehicle.

There is a growing feeling not only in Europe, but in this country, that the policy we have been compelled to adopt under the title of the Monroe Doctrine will ultimately involve a responsibility that has not heretofore been recognized. Exactly what will be the nature or extent of that accountability or by what means it will be imposed or discharged, it is too soon to say.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- The end of the year finds the money market very firm and rates considerably higher than they were at this time last year. The situation is much better than it was expected to be a few weeks ago.

-- Milwaukee has a Superintendent of Public Schools whose name is SIEFERT, and therefore it is more than a little curious that he should be much worried over the fact that the city is paying some $55,000 a year to special teachers of the German language, and should be advising that this expense be cut off.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Alderman Dever has determined to try to anticipate the Committee on Local Transportation in the "one city one fare" idea, and get such a reform at once. He holds that under the decision of the Supreme Court in the transfer case the Council has the right to demand a one-fare scheme now, and will introduce an order looking to that end at the next Council meeting.

Many persons have been buying Indian moccasins this Winter. They are the work of Canadian Indians, and the prices are $1.50 a pair for women's and $2 for men's sizes.
