They come in many different colors and shades, including two shades of brown, tan, red, a particularly pretty, soft shade, and the natural color of the leather.
Reports from the South that the deal effecting the combination of the malleable iron concerns of the country has been closed and that the transfer of interests will be made this month.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The inauguration of Gov. B.B. Odell for a second term to-morrow will be attended with more display than has been witnessed in Albany since the second inauguration of David Bennett Hill. Gov. Odell is the first Republican Governor to be re-elected within the memory of the present generation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Evidences are not lacking among Democratic leaders to show that there exists a very strong belief in Democratic circles that the chances for electing their candidates for President and Vice President in 1904 are not only encouraging, but are steadily growing stronger.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The State Department has been officially advised through its fiscal agents in China that the second installment of the Chinese indemnity fund, which falls due to-morrow, must be paid in silver, or rather on a silver basis. Therefore to-morrow the department will have placed to its credit $496,002, for it has without hesitation decided to accept the payment en the basis proposed.

Capt. Piper, Second Deputy Commissioner of Police, is authority for the statement that, according to information in the possession of the police, New York's gamblers have consolidated their interests, formed a defensive and offensive alliance, and decided to spend $1,000,000 if necessary to obtain a victory.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- A mule which has been taught to bray at given signals figures in a suit which will be tried at the January term of the Supreme Court. The Drake Hardware Company is suing the Louis Wrought Iron Range Company, a, rival stove firm. The plaintiff firm claims that the defendants have followed their country salesmen with a mule.

The great question in the year 1903 is to be that of supply and demand; primarily, of the supply of commodities and the demand for them, and dependent upon those factors, supply and demand in the labor and money markets. Statistics sent out from Albany the other day showed that practically the entire labor ferce in New York State is employed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The year is going; let him go; Ring out the fasse, ring in the true. The pulse beats of the dying year are fluttering to a close. Before it is laid to rest in the tomb of the twentieth century let us take a quick glance at the record it is leaving and try to separate the good from the evil it has wrought.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The Consolidated Tobacco Company to-night filed papers with the Secretary of State, increasing the capital stock from $30,000,000 to $40,000,000. An attempt was made to file the papers this morning, but they were rejected because of technical imperfections. The papers filed tonight contain the names of J.B. Duke, President, and Charles F. Keene, Secretary.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Western railroad managers speak with great enthusiasm of the prospects for 1903. Large as the business of the Western railroads has been during 1902, they think it will be still greater in the coming year.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 31 -- Yale's hockey team made its first appearance of the season at Duquesne Garden this evening, and was greeted by a large crowd of enthusiasts who cheered the representatives of old Eli to the echo, but could not bring a victory, the representatives of the Blue going down to defeat by the score of 8 to 3 at the hands of the expert Keystones.

A trio of alleged "green goods" men were arrested yesterday by the police of the Stagg Street Station, Williamsburg. It is believed that the prisoners succeeded in getting at least $20,000 from business men in Williamsburg. The accused are Samuel Mandel, a real estate dealer of 148 McKibbin Street, and Samuel and Harry Faust, father and son, living at 164 East Ninety-seventh Street, Manhattan.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- Melbourne Eclipse and Potheen were the winning favorites to-day. Potheen was run up to $1,000 and sold to Ed Trotter. Jockey Pickering will be permitted to ride after Jan. 1. Weather cloudy and cold; track heavy. Summary:

Miss Jeanette M. Thurber, daughter of Francis B. Thurber, the merchant and lawyer, on Tuesday night entertained a burglar in her home, at 40 West Twenty-filth Street. There were two other burglars in the house at the time, but Miss Thurber had dealings with only one, who, she declares, was extremely polite for a person in his line of business, though he did threaten her with a big revolver.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Director Roberts of the Mint read a paper on "Monetary Reform" to-day before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

With his brows sternly knitted and a look of high resolve in his eye, William S. Devery walked with martial stride yesterday afternoon into a saloon near Brevoort Hall, Fifty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue, while the Board of Building Trades was meeting in the hall. He was accompanied by Assemblyman-elect Richard Butler of the Ninth Assembly District.

Policemen were called to the City Hall yesterday to enforce the order issued by President Cantor that the firm of Ryan McFerran should stop work on the repairs to the building because they were not following specifications. The order was the result of the long fight which has been carried on between the labor unions and the contracting firm.

Mrs. James Speyer, 257 Madison Avenue, Treasurer of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following as a partial list of donations received since last publication. A supplementary list will follow:

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Local stocks showed very good activity in the closing session of the year. Can shares again were the centre of most interest, 1,000 shares of both common and preferred being traded in up to noon. The preferred showed a good advance by topping 49. Box Board issues were firm, and the preferred for a time held a gain of a point.

Father Mechler, the rector of the Little Church of the Holy Family, in Union Park, the Bronx, has moved all his household goods and his housekeeper into the basement of the church, because Alderman Frank Gass, one of the pillars of the parish, has dispossessed the priest of his former residence -- a near-by cottage, which is owned by the Alderman.

An appraisement of the estate of Marcellus Hartley has been made, and it is brought to light that he did not have nearly so large a fortune as was estimated when he died in January, 1902. His personal property is appraised at $10,560,285, and the net personal fortune, after deductions for debts and administration expenses are made, amounts to $8,419,827.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- The annual New Year's Eve ball, the principal Winter event of the season at Tuxedo, was given to-night at the Tuxedo Club. Among those who had opened their cottages for the week were Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Alexander, Mr. and JMrs. James W. Henning, Mr. and Mrs. Cooper Hewitt, Mr. and Mrs. R. Fulton Cutting, Mr. and Mrs. George Rutledge Gibson, and Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Foster Carey.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The Rev. E.M. Fairchild of Albany, who has been called into consultation by the workmen interested in the formation of the National League of Independent Workmen of America, said tonight:

The eleventh quadrangular college chess tournament, between Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton, came to an end last evening. Columbia, with half a point in the lead, broke even in her games with Tale in the final round yesterday and won thereby the tournament, the representatives of the dark blue remaining one point behind.

The two circulars of the United States Steel Corporation printed elsewhere in this issue will be read with unusual interest. They detail the wisest and most far-sighted plan ever devised for identifying the interests not merely of capital and labor, but of one class of labor with another.

VIENNA, Dec. 31 -- After a protracted conference Dr. von Koerber, the Austrian Premier, and Herr de Szell, the Hungarian Premier, surmounted the difficulties in the way of reaching an understanding with regard to the Ausgleisch at 9 o'clock this evening, and it was then announced that the Premiers had agreed to a compromise.

The transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange for the month of December aggregated 15,719,742 shares, as against 17,117,313 shares in November, 16,348,360 in October, 20,932,087 in September, 14,317,393 in August, 16,317,937 in July, 7,813,049 in June, 13,485,777 in May, 26,570,732 in April, 11,954,672 in March, 12,950,699 in February, and 14,782,291 in January.

The Board of Education yesterday received partial reports of the Committee on Buildings showing in a general way results accomplished during the year and indicating the more urgent requirements for the year to come. Contracts for new buildings and additions have been awarded as follows:

Two well-contested skating races formed the special attraction last night at the Clermont Skating Rink, Brooklyn. Each was hotly contested and aroused considerable, enthusiasm before the victors crossed the finishing line. A dozen starters lined up for the first event, a half-mile novice, all at scratch.

At Madison Square Garden last night there were two football games decided, one of which was the third match of the indoor heavy-weight championship series of the regular American game, and the other a Gaelic game, which proved to be both interesting and amusing.

Definite plans for relieving the street railroad situation in this city, according to Col. Ashley W. Cole, Chairman of the Railroad Commission, are to be recommended by the commission early next week. The commission regards the suggestions it will offer as in the nature of commands. Those propositions, it is said, will not be influenced by the cost of carrying them out.

PEKING, Dec. 31 -- The Ministers here of the foreign powers have telegraphed their governments the refusal of China to pay the International indemnity in gold notes and have discussed the matter among themselves. It is proposed to inform the Chinese Government that failure to fulfill the obligations provided in the protocol will entail grave consequences.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. F.B. Thurber's defense of the management of the elevated and surface roads in New York would be amusing were it not, under the circumstances, exasperating and his advice that we "don't shoot the fiddler when he is doing his best" argues an entire ignorance on his part of the conditions which are the cause of the present agitation.

There was no doubt, when the clocks struck the midnight hour that 1903 had arrived, for everybody who owned a voice or a tin horn was out to celebrate the event. A hundred thousand people who had grudges against the old year worked them off in an uproarious welcome to the new.

The Society of College Gymnasium Directors completed its sixth annual meeting at the club house of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, and after electing officers for the coming year adjourned to meet a year from yesterday at Princeton University, where the delegates will be the guests of Prof. George Goldie.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 31 -- Ever since the Town Assessors made a general increase in taxable property values of New-Yorkers two years ago there has been a rush to the Town Clerk's office on the last afternoon of the year and nearly the last hour to see the tax book which the Assessors file at that time.

On the Stock Exchange, so far as the market was concerned, the old year may fairly be said to have gone out in a blaze of glory. Prices began to advance in the early trading, nor did they stop to any degree until the final minute of the last business hour of the year called the halt.

New Year's is fast becoming a holiday for house-party-giving folk. It is celebrated in the country more than in town, as far as society is concerned. Mrs. Gardiner Sherman has the first of a series of receptions this afternoon at the Buckingham Hotel for her daughter, Miss Sherman, and this evening there will be the second meeting of the dancing class organized by Mrs. Dallas Bache Pratt.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Counsel for the United States Steel Corporation this afternoon filed with the Court of Errors a brief answering the argument of counsel for J. Aspinwall Hodge and others seeking to restrain the conversion of $200,000,000 the corporation's preferred stock into bonds.

Major Flood-Page of London, the managing director of the Marconi International Maritime Communication Company and a Director of the Marconi Wireless Telegraphic Company of London and La Compagnie Telegraphique Sans Fils of France, who has been in Nova Scotia for the last six weeks with Mr. Marconi, arrived in New York on Tuesday and is at the Holland House.

ST. LOUIS. Dec. 31 -- According to H.E. Rice, a St. Louis promoter of musical enterprises, plans are being perfected for the erection of a new theatre and hotel building on Grand Avenue. He says three sites for the structure between Pine Street and Page Boulevard are under consideration.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- There was great pressure in the money market to-day for year-end accommodation, and it was estimated that the borrowings from the Bank of England probably exceeded $75,000,000. Discounts were easier on the scarcity of bilis and Continental competition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Miss Kean, sister of Senator John Kean of New Jersey, gave a dinner dance this evening at her home, 1.700 I Street, complimentary to her niece, Miss Christine Roosevelt of New York, a debutante of the present season. The company consisted of eighty young people, who were seated at ten round tables in the dining room and library.

Hundreds of men and women bicyclists gathered at Bedford Rest, Bedford Avenue and Eastern Boulevard, Brooklyn, late last night. They assembled there to witness the start of two road runs, which were to usher in the New Year. The majority of those assembled were not prepared to take part in the midnight trips, but over eighty of the most enthusiastic were among the competitors.

Arrangements were made yesterday in a downtown hotel by the members of the committee representing the strikers at the shops of the Union Pacific Railroad who remained here after Tuesday's conference with President Burt of the railroad, for resuming the conference to-day. It was stated that James O'Connell, President of the International Association of Machinists, who went to Washington after Tuesday's preliminary conference, will be on hand at the conference to-day.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

-- Even the people who have viewed Mr. WILLIAM S. DEVERY with the severest eyes have hitherto credited him with a certain rude originality of expression, and, despite a lurking suspicion that perhaps his speeches owed something to reportorial ingenuity, have yet regarded them as appreciable mitigations of the horror which Mr. DEVERY'S manners, methods, and motives excited in respectable minds.

CARACAS, Jan. 1 -- There have been persistent rumors in official circles and generally throughout this city since yesterday that President Castro had refused to agree to the proposals of the allies to refer the Venezuelan issues to The Hague tribunal.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 1 -- The Yale Hockey Team scored another defeat in its game to-night at Duquesne Garden. This time it was the Bankers Seven who save the collegians a trouncing. The locals skated off with a victory by a score of 6 to 0. The visitors had plenty of time to rest up today, and they could not advance their excuse of yesterday that they were tired.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Several thousand persons to-day attended the New Year's reception at the White House, and were received by the President, Mrs. Roosevelt, Miss Alice Roosevelt, and the wives of the Cabinet officers. It was the first opportunity the public has had of inspecting the improvements in the Executive Mansion, and general admiration was expressed at the beauty and effectiveness of the decorations.
"I wish you a happy New Year," said one old Tenderloin gambler to another of the profession whom he met on Broadway yesterday.

An even score of shooters took part in the holiday shoot of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn at Bay Ridge yesterday, ana because of the large field and the perfect shooting weather the scores were the highest and closest that have been made so far this season. The shooting began at 10 o'clock in the morning, and, except for an intermission at noon, continued until darkness put an end to the sport.

TUXEDO, Jan. 1 -- Never before was there such a gathering of society folk at Tuxedo on New Year's Day as to-day. The beautiful weather brought out large crowds on the early trains, and those who came out for the New Year's Eve dance remained over. The skating on the large lake and coasting on the hills were the chief attractions of the day.

No date has been fixed for the beginning of the inter-city handball match between Champion "Mike" Egan and James Flaherty of Jersey City and the Brooklyn partners, Oliver Drew and Dr. Shea. All four of the players are hard at practice every day, however, and just as soon as the preliminaries are arranged they will lose no time in bringing the match to a conclusion.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Following is the weekly statement of the Bank of England: Total reserve increased L1,049,000, circulation decreased L32,000, bullion increased L1,017,029, other securities increased L13,076,000, other deposits increased L15,346,000, public deposits decreased L211,000, notes reserve increased L967,000, Government securities increased L1,000,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- The Inaugural address of Gov. Odell was as follows: My Fellow-Citizens: Our Commonwealth, in its rapid progress, in the magnificent achievements of its people, in the upbuilding of its many and varied industries, requires at all times faithfulness and devotion upon the part of those who have been intrusted with the management of its affairs.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The most striking effect of the Venezuelan imbroglio, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, has been to fortify the prestige of the United States as a world power and to evoke expressions of admiration for President Roosevelt. It is recognized that he has given to the court at The Hague a chance to become quite a popular institution in the settlement of international difficulties.

DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -- Tens of thousands of people from the City of Delhi and from the villages far and near began gathering at daybreak this morning on the great plain outside the city. There they waited patiently for the supreme announcement of the durbar that King Edward was Emperor of India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- There is some talk here of an effort to have Chief Gunner Morgan of the navy sent before an examing board with the purpose of having him retired from active service. The special physical point on which Morgan could be retired is his eyesight.

A possible panic among the worshippers because of a slight fire in the chancel was averted in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul, at Court and Congress Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday morning by the coolness and presence of mind of the pastor, the Rev. William J. Hill, and James Monroe, one of the congregation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Dec. 30, under the heading, "Topics of the Times," there occurs this remarkable statement, in re Mrs. Eddy and mediumship: "Spiritualism and Christian Science are to each other about as pocket-picking is to highway robbery," and "sensitives" or "mediums" are also referred to as "commonplace charlatans."

From the east side to Broadway, from poor lads to theatreowners, from Belasco's "Heart of Maryland" to Fitch's "Stubbornness of Geraldine," tells the history of the career of Lew Fields and Joe Weber, who last night celebrated the twenty-fifth year of their connection on the stage.

Arrangements have been about completed for the absorption of the Thompson-Starrett Company by the United States Realty and Construction Company. Negotiations looking to this end have been in progress for several weeks, but no details have reached the public until now. The final contracts have not been signed, but it is said that the deal may be completed within the next few days.

Herr Bonn disclosed his long-expected performance of Hamlet last night at the Irving Place Theatre. He was welcomed by a large audience with hospitable appreciation and considerable spontaneous applause; but it is doubtful whether the assumption will add greatly to his reputation.

The annual catalogue of Columbia University, just issued, shows in the registra- tion figures an increase of 160 students, the gain being largely in the Engineering Schools, where there has been an increase of seventy-three in a year. There has also been an increase of eighteen in the Teachers' College, and thirty-two in the Graduate Schools.

Mayor Mark M. Fagan of Jersey City made memorable the reception he gave in the City Hall yesterday by throwing a bombshell among the local Democratic politicans. The only one of the governing boards of Jersey City that is elective is the Street and Water Board. It consists of five members.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Jack O'Brien, the middle-weight pugilist of Philadelphia, beat Al Weinig in the International Athletic Club, at Fort Erie, this afternoon, after one of the bloodiest fights ever seen in this locality. Weinig was knocked completely out in the twelfth round from a terrific right-hand uppercut, and a shove which banged his head against the floor and made his arising within the required ten seconds an impossibility.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- Despite unfavorable conditions, the attendance at the races to-day was good. There was a light, steady rain from dawn till dusk, and the track was almost at its worst. Light Hunt and Witful were the only winning favorites, the latter crediting Albert Simons with the New Year Handicap, worth $1,280 to the winner.

The first of the transatlantic steamships to dock in the new year was the Neckar of the North German Lloyd Line, which left Quarantine early yesterday morning. The White Star liner Teutonic was the next ship to reach her dock, while the French liner La Champagne was the first vessel to sail from this port.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Specific news of serious conditions at Fez is contained in a dispatch from the correspondent of The Times at Tangier, Morocco.

William Colford Schermerhorn died yesterday at the family residence, 49 West Twenty-third Street, after a brief illness, from pleurisy. He was eighty-two years old. Two days ago he was in his usual health, and visited his law offices at 41 Liberty Street. Yesterday he became seriously ill, and lost strength rapidly until the end.

After losing its motorman by throwing him from the front platform into a ditch, a trolley car on the West End line, Brooklyn, ran wild for about a mile over the Coney Island meadows early yesterday morning. The car, under the charge of John Gallagher, motorman, and Charles Rupert, conductor, was filled with passengers who were returning from a New Year's celebration in a Coney Island dance hall.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The stable of race horses owned by Thomas W. Lawson of Boston, and under charge of Ralph Black, the trainer, will Winter here. The hordes arrived to-day and will remain here until next Spring, when they will return to Massachusetts. The stable is located at the Horse Haven annex of the Saratoga Racing Association's park.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 1 -- William Horrax, thirteen years of age, was shot through the heart and almost instantly killed this evening by his brother, Gilbert Horrax, fifteen years old. The shooting was accidental. The boys are the sons of Edwin Horrax, an importer of 475 Broadway, New York City, living at 103 Park Street, this place, and socially prominent here.

There has developed of late a disposition among the citizens of New York to seize every convenient opportunity to indulge in spontaneous street carnivals. Popular movements of this kind always have their origin in some latent trait or tendency of the people. They Cannot be effectively encouraged nor stimulated by organization.

Police Commissioner GREENE begins his official career in just the way to be expected from a man who has undertaken a serious responsibility and means to make a success of it. His orders are precisely those best calculated to make the uniformed force realize that the Commissioner understands himself perfectly and does not propose to elaborate a system of police reform while they, in turn, are elaborating a system for making it ineffective.

ALBANY, Jan, 1 -- Benjamin B. Odell. Jr., to-day entered on his second term as Governor of New York, being the first Executive of this State to succeed himself since 1885, when David B. Hill was the one who enjoyed that honor. The ceremony to-day took place in the Assembly Chamber of the State Capitol, and was witnessed by a large gathering of distinguished persons.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Enthusiasm marked the second day's sessions of the Archaeological Institute, Prof. T.D. Seymour of Yale presiding. The papers were received with applause, and most of them were followed by spirited discussions.

New Year's Day was celebrated more quietly than usual in this city, but although there was scarcely a vestige of the friendly old custom of calling, there was plenty of good cheer for all. The fine weather sent crowds to the country, where every little pool was crowded with skaters, the ice being in fine condition in the early hours.

The Merchants' Association has given wide currency to a letter addressed to its Committee on Franchises and Transportation by Dr. GEORGE A. SOPER, sanitary expert, which, while not admitting of specific contradiction in any point, illustrates how much easier it is to find fault with existing conditions than to suggest a means of remedying the least of them.

Enthusiastic bicyclists representing several clubs in Greater New York welcomed the New Year by participating in three bicycle road runs which began in Manhattan and Kings Boroughs a few seconds after the midnight chimes rang out yesterday morning. One of these runs began at the Park Circle in Manhattan and the other two at Bedford Rest, Brooklyn.

Wall Street will resume business today for the new year hopeful and confident in respect to the future. In the last two weeks of the old year conditions, monetary and otherwise, were measurably improved, with the consequence that slowly but none the less surely the at one time omnipresent pessimism gave way to optimism, which has been, growing steadily ever since.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- The New Year's reception at the Elysee Palace was attended by the foreign diplomats, Government officials, and members of the Chamber of Deputies. The diplomats were presented to President Loubet by the doyen of the corps, Mgr. Rinaldini, the Apostolic Nuncio, who made a speech, in which he conveyed the good wishes of the foreign representatives to the First Magistrate of the republic.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- There were two developments here to-day which aroused much interest among the politicians. One was the visit of Col. George W. Dunn, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, to investigate the report of an anti-organization Republican cabal in the Senate.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- Mrs. John T. Gardner threw open to-night the magnificent Venetian palace which has been the cause of so much fanciful description and mysterious gossip. It was not exactly thrown open to the public, though that is, it is understood, to be the ultimate intention of the owner, but to a select number of people, friends of Mrs. Gardner.

A crusade on some of the big up-town hotels, it was said yesterday, may be one of the next steps of District Attorney Jerome in his war on gamblers. Mr. Jerome has received positive information to the effect that the gamblers, feeling insecure in their establishments, had removed their headquarters temporarily to some of the big hostelries on upper Broadway.

There is a sort of aesthetic charm about a book with uncut leaves, which one with leaves neatly trimmed by machinery never possesses. But busy men find uncut leaves it great nuisance. People buy books to read, and not to do mechanical work over. In England there is a strong protest against uncut leaves in ordinary books and magazines.

ONE of the incongruities in which Boston delights is the choice of the Cadets' Armory for the distribution of tickets for the Lowell Free Lectures, of which Col. Higginson's course on "American Literature in the Nineteenth Century" opens next Monday evening, and Prof. Bowditch's on "Some Problems of Modern Physiclogy," next Tuesday.

For him whose traveling is done mostly in his library Mr. Zummerman's book would scareely stand as a subsititute for the magic carpet. As guide-book it might win higher approval, for the author has conscientiously reported details, and has morecover, in many cases placed at the disposal of his readers the benefit of his own experiences.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- As a result of Count Lamsdorff's visit to Austria, a scheme will be drafted whereby Russia and Austria will take joint action for the amelioration of the condition of the Christians in Macedonia, says the Vienna Correspondent of The Times. This plan will shortly be submitted to the powers and pressed on by the Sultan.

DO WE grow fat because we laugh? You are not to smile, because Mr. James Sully wants you to consider the entire toplc of laughter in a most serious manner. The author seems to be conscious that the subject selected by him will be met with "irritating objections."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The monthly statement of the public debt slums that at the close of business Dec. 31 the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $947,164,670, which is a decrease for the month of $10,032,602. which is largely accounted for by an increase of nearly $10,000,000 in the amount of cash on hand.

ONE day, in my aspiring youth, I happened into the office of The True Flag, a story and literary weekly of the old-fashioned type, published in Boston. To the white-haired editor -- William Moulton I offered some manuscripts, and this is a summary of what he said: "My dear young man, please don't leave your matter here, it is out of the question for me to accept it.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Walter E. Egan, the young Chicago and Harvard golfer, who was runner-up to Walter J. Travis for notional championship honors in 1901, met defeat to-day in the Lakewood Golf Club's tournament. He was beaten in the second match play round for the chief cup by M. K. Waters, of the home club, by 4 up and 3 to play.

IT IS appropriate that, in the current number of The North American Review. William Dean Howells should have an article on "Henry James's Later Work," when Mr. James's new novel. "The Ambassadors," begins its serial publicaton.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 2. -- Cecil Fairs, known as "Punch" of the Princess Club. London, and Frank Forrester, the professional in charge of the indoor tennis court at Georgian Court, George J. Gould's country place, played a tennis match here to-day, which was a pretty exhibition of the fine points of the game.

In these seven stories Miss Sutherland has touched upon all the intricacies of love from both its gayer and its graver sides. The stories range from comedy to tragedy, with a far greater leaning, however, toward the latter. The under-current of pathos and misery that finds its place in many of the stories makes them, at times, dismal reading.

The "Seven Royal S.'s." what fire they? Mr. Francis M. Ware tells you, as far its the horse is concerned. They are Symmetry, Speed, Style, Size, Shape, Substance, and Safety. In his first chapter the author enters into the question of the cost of the horse. If you want a good beast he prepared to put up a fair figure for him.

HONOLULU, Jan. 2. -- The completion of the first section of the submarine cable that is eventually to connect the United States with the Philippines and Asia, at 8:40 o'clock last evening, when the first message was flashed to San Francisco, 2,000 miles away, was effected only after a memorable struggle with wind and wave.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 2. -- The New York flier, north-bound, collided to-night with a wild engine on the Rutland Railroad opposite Dr. W. Seward Webb's estate in Shelburne. The engineers of both engines were killed and their firemen probably fatally hurt. No passengers were seriously injured.

HOBART CHATFIELD-TAYLOR in the current number of The Bookman gayly but not ironically urges the establishment of "ateliers of fiction." Great painters and sculptors admit pupils to their workshops, why should not the novelists? That is Mr. Chatfield-Taylor's chief argument.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2. -- Judge Wickes ordered to-day that the sale of the American league Park by J.L.V. Murphy and John C. Tolson, receivers for the Baltimore Baseball and Athletic Company, to Edward Hanlon for $3,000 be confirmed, unless cause to the contrary be shown on or before Jan. 14.

II. The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In a recent issue of your valuable NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS Mr. George Edwin Jepson took upon himself the duty of enlightening an interested public in the matter of Philip Freneau. He acknowledged that he was the possessor of considerable genius.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Money was plentiful and cheap to-day owing to borrowings from the Bank of England, the willingness of the joint stock banks to lend, and large dividend payments. Discounts were unsettled.

An article on "The Venezuela Question" by Richard Harding Davis opens the current issue of Collier's Weekly. The same number contains a short story by F. Hopkinsou Smith, entitled "Marny's Shadow," with illustrations by Frederic Dorr Steele; the concluding chapters of I. Zangwill's "The Serio-Comic Governess," and the begining of a story by Stanley Weyman entitled "The Long Night."
ROME, Jan. 2. -- The Pope is about to issue an encyclical against the practice of dueling.

ONE of the lecturing Boer Generals (perhaps it was Viljoen) has said that De Wet is a newspaper General; that the correspondents made his fame; that he got the credit for successful raids and escapes when he was actually hundreds of miles away. On the other hand, reviewers and editorial writers commenting on De Wet's book have classed him with Stonewall Jackson, and even with Grant.
The Lespinasse estate has sold the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 58 West Twenty-second Street, on lot 23.6 by 100.
ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- Gov. Odell has appointed Jan. 27 as the day for the special election in the Sixteenth Senatorial District of New York to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Trainor.

The first day's trading in the new year in the market for outside securities was not accompanied by very much activity, but generally speaking the strength which appeared on Wednesday last was still felt and resulted in further net gains. Nearly all the stocks which had been in the foreground in the recent past continued to lead the market, there being but few additions to the stocks which were given special attention.

The Treasury statistics relative to imports of iron and steel during the first eleven months of 1902 are especially interesting as showing how and to what extent the manufacturing industries of the United States permit themselves to be taxed by duties on raw materials which are as unnecessary for purposes of protection as they are burdensome upon those who pay them.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Jan. 2. -- F. G. Kitton has collected Charles Dickens's occasional verses from various publications in which they originally appeared, including The Daily News, during Dickens's editorship of that journal, The Examiner and Household Words.

THE book named below is a small folio, handsomely and carefully printed on paper of Pleasant surface and color, with leaves entirely untrimmed, and with many plates. Errors in the proofreading may be discovered, but those noted so far are obvious ones and can hardly mislead the reader.

DR. VAN TYNE'S prefatory account of the vicissitudes of Webster's correspondence is too elaborate for reproduction here, and it does not admit, so intricate is it, of satisfactory abbreviation. The confusion of the whole business has infected Dr. Van Tyne's presentation of the matter.
The Citizens' Union yesterday sent to Gov. Odell a communication with reference to the Raines law which reads as follows: The Hon. B. B. Odell, Governor, State of New York.

The Heart of Woman," by Harry W. Desmond, is a story laid in New York in the early days of the Revolution and patterned after the ubiquitous historical novel to the extent of containing some real names and of being told in the first person by a rather prosy person called Alexander Adams, who, in this case, is not the hero himself, but his fidus Achates.

The test of the new system, to be tried for the first time this year, of assessing real estate at its full value, will come on Monday. Jan. 12, when, according to law, the books of the Tax Department will be open for inspection, correction, and revision. It will be found what increases in assessments have been made by the Assessors in their field work.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Information about the wonderful progress being made in the Russianizing of Manchuria is furnished by The Times correspondent in Peking in a letter describing the building of the Russian railway, which is giving to Russia a firm grip on the country.

IT is easy to think of the poet who writes over the name of "Owen Innsly," us Mr. Archer, in his recent volume on "Poets of the Younger Generation," says he has tried to write of each of those considered by him, "as if he or she were the only poet of the younger generation in England or America."

Continuing, in the January number of Dominicana, his depreciation of the French writers of the Flaubert school, Zola, the Goncourts, and Daudet, Mr. John A. Mooney treats in an emphatic way of the last-named romancer. Mr. Mooney writes with conviction and with practical knowledge. His judgment may be prejudiced, but it is honestly and clearly expresssed.
In an address before the Dante Society of London the other day Alfred Austin, the Poet Laureate, said:

Price movements on the Stock Exchange were somewhat irregular yesterday, reflecting heavy profit taking incident to the advances which lately have come about. Yet despite selling for this account as well as for the short account, on the theory that a reaction was due, the market held substantially strong throughout the day, with the undertone essentially sound.

In certain cases the truthful setting of a purposeful, controversial novel forms an element of interest quite independent of the author's bias. For this reason his work may be appreciated by those who would deny his premises and hence remain unimpressed by his arguments. Such a case is that of Mr. Richard Bagot and his "Donna Diana."

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- The annual statement of the Bankers' Clearing House shows that the clearance of 1902 again reached the record, the total aggregate of checks, bills, passing through amounting to $50,143,710,000, or over $2,335,000,000 above the amount in 1901.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 2. -- The cold weather has been hailed with rejoicing at Harvard, where it has meant exceptional opportunities for the developing of a strong hockey team.

MANILA, Jan. 2. -- A boat's crew from the United States cruiser Don Juan de Austria made the first successful attack on the mine-fields near Subig Bay. The boat capsized as it was approaching the mines and part of the crew, with Ensign Babcock leading, swam a mile, though the water was infested with sharks, towing counter-mine buoys, which were successfully placed.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: MR. WILLIAM ROSCOE THAYER whose review of the first volume of The Cambridge Modern History was published in last Saturday's Supplemen seems to be considerably wrought up over what he calls Dr. Richard Garnett's " efforts in kalsomining Alexander," otherwise Rodrigo Borgia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The War Department has made public the report of the Uniform Board, headed by Gen. Young, of which Col. Patten is the recorder, setting out in detail the changes made in the army uniform.

Park Commissioner Willcox made public yesterday a report of the special commission appointed to examine Central Park and make recommendations as to improvements of the soil and sanitary conditions. The result of the report will be that the Park Commissioner will ask the Board of Estimate to issue $50,000 of bonds to begin the work of renovating the Park and for a further sum of $50,000 for cleaning the lakes.

First among the practical results of the recent agitation in favor of more adequate street railroad accommodations in this city was an order issued by the State Board of Railroad Commissioners last night, specifically directing the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company to make certain improvements in its service.

This letter was addressed to the little company of believers in Philippi. Undoubtedly each one took it to himself or herself. We may look upon it, therefore, as a personal letter to the jailer whose case we considered last week, as well as to each of his fellow-disciples. That it was addressed to him, and to others like him, indicates that a very great and blessed change had taken place in him and in them.

Although it was written several years ago, James Jeffrey Roche's "Her Majesty the King" now comes from the publisher in so pretty a dress and with such charmingly quaint and characteristic illustrations by Oliver Herferd, that it really bears all the attractiveness of a brand-new book.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. William Roseoe Thayor, in his review of "The Renaissance," the first volume of Lord Acton's monumental history, in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW for Dec. 27, 1902, criticises Dr. Richard Garnett very severely for attempting to whitewash Pope Alexander VI.

Theatrical subjects are generally avoided in this REVIEW or BOOKS as having no relation to its plan and also because they are always so generously treated of else where. But a dramatization of "Paradise Lost" is so unlikely ever to get in the theatre that it is, perhaps, not a theatrical subject, properly speaking.

FOR some time it has been an open secret among the friends of Mr. Carl Schurz that the celebrated German-American publicist was engaged in writing his autobiography. The work is now so far advanced that it may possibly be ready for publication during the coming year.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 2. -- Abandoned workings of the Eddy Creek Colliery of the Delaware and Hudson Company, beneath the very heart of the town of Olyphant, caved in this afternoon and engulfed four frame buildings, covering an aggregate ground space of 6,000 square feet.

THE author of a "true" history of the American Revolution must or course disagree with that which has previously been written on this subject and which does not specifically lay claim to veracity. He must advance new theories and, if he can, it will be to his advantage to promote a lively controversy.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It will be a universal surprise to hear Roger Williams, the great apostle of religious liberty, called an Agnostic. Yet this is what Mr. Richman virtually calls him in his recent work. "Rhode Island, Its Making and Its Meaning."

Of horsy romances, "Thoroughbreds" is the most particularly horsy. The leading characters are Lauzanne. The Dutchman, Diabelo, and the entire string. Trainers, jockeys, stablemen, bookies, and owners of racing establishments occupy but secondary places. You must be an enthusiastic frequenter of race courses to understand what Mr. Fraser writes about.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 2 -- It was announced to-day that the rowing schedule for the Annapolis cadets for 1903 had been arranged as follows: May 2, University of Pennsylvania; May 9, Yale; May 23, Georgetown. The second navy crew will race the Pennsylvania freshmen on May 2.

The satisfaction of reporting at the end of its first year of official responsibility a lower death rate than the city has ever known is probably greater to the Commissioner and executive officers of the Health Department than could be derived from any other statistical fact. The rate for 1902 was 1874 per 1,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- George F. Baer, President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, announced today that the Directors of the corporation had approved of a pension system for its employes, which became operative on Jan. 1. Action was taken by the Directors in a meeting on Dec. 17.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The beginnings of our native poetry are so precious that one would expect editors and authors to be reasonably accurate in their comments and quotations. Freneau's graceful little lyric "The Wild Honeysuckle," as the first genuine bird note in the early Springtime of our literature, naturally receives some attention from all writers who profees to give a historical account of our literary product.

-- Exercising what must be extremely laborious ingenuity on a recent disquisition of ours on the names of the three Territories now seeking admission as States. The Santa Fe New Mexican declares that "THE NEW YORK TIMES is of the opinion that the principal objection to the admission of New Mexico to Statehood is its name."

The interchange of messages, announced yesterday, between the United States and the Sandwich Islands by the newly laid and opened cable may not seem to our more limited anti-imperialists to amount to much. But to the great mass of American citizens it must seem to amount to something very considerable.

The year of 1901, remarkable for its bibliographical surprises in the form of record prices, witnessed none greater than those connected with the name of Shakespeare. The year of 1902, though it fell behind in some respects, nearly approached it as regards the establishing of record and surpassed it in general interest, various sales in London and New York bringing forward a greater number of items possessing rarity and importance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- In the Cabinet meeting to-day the conditions in Venezuela were discussed. Secretary Hay presented a statement showing that no definite responses have been received from any of the allied powers to President Castro's last communication. It is evident that further negotiations will be required to bring the parties to a final agreement, but it is not doubted that this will succeed.

The communications which Commissioner WILLCOX yesterday submitted to the Board of Estimate ought to interest every dweller in the Borough of Manhattan. The "accompanying document " which contains the report of the experts upon the condition of Central Park is most calculated to arrest public attention, and also to quiet public apprehension.

We are a very good customer of Germany -- one of the best she has. In the last fiscal year we imported her products to the value of $101,997,523. From no other country except Great Britain were our imports so large. She stands second also on the list of our customers. Last year she took our products to the value of $170,222,737.

Jacob Owen, otherwise known as "Doc," whom the police accused of being a card sharper with a good practice on transatlantic liners, demands through the courts that his picture be taken out of the Rogues' Gallery at Police Headquarters. He was one of the men arrested on the charge of swindling the Earl of Rosslin during a recent voyage from Liverpool aboard the Cunard liner Etruria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- President Roosevelt to-day directed that the Post Office at Indianola, Miss., be closed, not to be reopened until the people in that district are ready to accept as Postmaster Mrs. Minnie M. Cox, colored. The President his also directed that the Attorney General proceed against certain residents of that town, who have, it is alleged, made threats against Mrs. Cox.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- The Philadelphia market was decidedly erratic today. Marked weakness developed in the Consolidated Lake Superior issues, as a result of the forced liquidation of a speculative account, and in Philadelphia Electric on account of rumpus of another assessment and the report in the resignation of John M. Mock from the directorate.
House parties continue, and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Vanderbilt have been added to the list of hosts and hostesses. They have a large party at Newport. The parties will continue until Monday.

A new edition of " The Wouldbegoods," by E. Nesbit, has just been issued in London. Mrs. Nesbit Bland is one of the most, industrious of the English novelists, and is popular on both sides of the ocean. She writes for old and young, and her last novel, " The Red House," published by Harper Brothers, is a story for young married people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. James Hoy have issued invitations to the marriage of their daughter. Miss Martha Hoy, to Pierre Rogestvensky, Second Secretary of the Russian Embassy. The ceremony wil take place on Tuesday, Jan. 20, and the officiating clergyman is to be the pastor of the Orthodox Greek Church in New York.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 2. -- Mayor Hayes has formally announced his candidacy for renomination. The Democratic Party managers will defeat him if they can. He has kept them in hot water for four years by setting up a political machine of his own as against that controlled by Senator Gorman and I. Freeman Rasin.

THERE are four customary methods of writing naval history -- by taking individual commanders, wars as a whole, separate engagments or by treating the navy as an entity. A fifth method has new been followed by Lieut. Frederic Stanhope Hill, who has taken twenty-six historic ships of the United States Navy and related the story of each in separate chapters with interesting illustrations, some of which are now published for the first time.

NOT me least ably handled and not the least important of the several volumes of "The Periods of European Literature Series," which have come to hand, is that by Mr. J.H. Millar, which is entitled "The Mid-Eighteenth Century," and might not inappropriately have been called The Age of Reason.

BOSTON, Jan. 2. -- Capt. W. M. Olys of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery is authority for the statement that Lord Roberts of Kandahar, otherwise "Bobs," the captor of Cronje and the idol of Tommy Atkins, will be the guest of the Ancients at their field day next September. Capt. Olys added that there was a possibility that the Prince of Wales and his royal uncle, the Duke of Connaucht, will come as well.

REAL ESTATE BROKER'S COMMISSIONS. -- A. Conroy Haynes, a real estate broker, on behalf of a customer, induced Horatio N. Fraser to sell a certain piece of property at a mutually satisfactory price. Haynes although known to Fraser as a real estate broker, was recognized by him merely as the agent of a prospective buyer.

Gen. Ferdinand Pinney Earle, long prominent as the proprietor of several wellknown hotels, and also in military circles, died yesterday afternoon in the old Jumel mansion, which he purchased six years ago and renamed Earle Cliff. He had been in poor health for three years, and his death was due to heart disease.

Albert E. Gallatin. NOTE. -- The first draft of the bibliography of Whistler criticism was published in the form of rough notes a little less than two years ago in The Literary Collector. It has since been revised and amplified.

The anonymous author of "Aspects of the Jewish Question" is a strong opponent of Zionism. Endowed with a particularly pungent style, and possessing perfect freedom in religious thought, as well as due respect for the creeds of others, the volume is a spirited attack directed against those who believe that the exodus of the Jews is one of the necessities of to-day.

There are books that are born in obscurity and bear a humble name, and come to us as silently as the morning light -- royal books withal, like a King cradled in a manger. And when they come they are of the nature of a revelation; they take possession of us and resist criticism -- books that go some way toward solving the riddle of existence.

The New York Times Satuirday Review of Books: It seems to me somewhat remarkable that as Braintree. Mass., was such a focus of rebellion against the assumptions of monarchy, Braintree, in Essex. England, was the starting point of a rebellion against the assumptions of the Established Church of England.

THE merits of Robert Harl's Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer are not readily appreciable. In rogard to the man himself, what wrote has left its impress to-day -- that Harley's intellect "was small and dull."

ASHFORD, Conn., Jan. 2. -- After hearing the preliminary evidence against Mrs. Leila Manson and George Wilson, who were in jail on the charge of poisoning Wilson's mother-in-law, Mrs. Julia Wilson, Justice of the Peace Knowlton held both the prisoners for trial in the Superior Court. It was testified that arsenic was discovered in the dead woman's stomach, and her physician said he had not prescribed that drug.

Police Commissioner Francis V. Greene yesterday signalized the second day of his rule as the head of the department of this city by an order which remands to patrol duty in uniform every precinct detective and patrolman doing duty in plain clothes, whether in the districts or in the precincts, and whether detached to duty by the Police Commissioner or by Inspectors of districts or the Captains of precincts.

Mr. Victor Herbert, the director of the Pittsburgh Orchestra, has written a symphonic poem, "Columbus," which was performed for the first time by the Pittsburg Orchestra at a regular concert in Carnegie Music Hall, Pittsburg, on Friday evening. Jan. 2. The titles of the different movements (descriptive of the landing of the discoverer in America) are "Sunrise on Granada," "At La Rabida," "Murmurs of the Sea," and "Triumph."

While the immigration officials at Ellis Island point with pride to the fact that owing to recently enforced rigid methods of inspection the percentage of deportations has greatly increased, organizations representing the nationalities so affected are preparing a protest against what they claim is the harsh and unfair treatment of immigrants and will shortly lay the facts in their possession before the President and Congress.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Alexander Dumas Watkins, the only negro who ever instructed Princeton undergraduates in their regular curriculum work, is dead. When the students of the histological department return they will miss the demonstrator who appeared before them for eight years.

The settlement on the 28th of May last of the boundary question between Chile and Argentina, which threatened war, promises an improvement in business conditions throughout the Chilean Republic. The Government will now be enabled to inaugurate some radical reforms of an economic nature.

JACK HARDY had often laughed at his friends and business associates about turning over a new leaf or "swearing off" on New Year's Day. He was inclined to be-proud of his cynicism, for he had never known of a single pledge having been kept longer than a fortnight.

AS I entered the dentist's office," said a woman the other day, "I saw a man sitting in a chair rocking violently and with a wild look of misery writ on every feature. Next him sat a demure looking trained nurse. After a few minutes, during which we all three sat and pitied each other, the dentist entered, dressed for out doors, and he beckoned the man.

In a letter published upon this page a few days ago Mr. Louis RHEAD tells a story of wrong and grievance, concerning which we think it just that a paradoxical remark should be made. The remark is that real as are the woes and substantial the grievances of which Mr. RHEAD complains, it is good for him and it is for be public welfare that the should have been in this manner wronged and outraged.

The general expansion in every channel of trade has been reflected in the continually increased area of cotton production. The acreage planted for the crop of 1902-03, according to the Government, is estimated as the largest on record, and nearly 3,000,000 acres in excess of that planted in 1898-9, when the commercial crop amounted to 11,275,000 bales and there actually came into sight 11,400,000 bales.

RICHNESS of material and brilliancy of coloring were the notable features of the costumes worn by young girls at a recent fashionable wedding. Miss Gwendolyn Burden was in a vivid sapphire blue with purplish lights, and her large blue hat was half covered with ostrich plumes of the same hue.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 3 -- German Bauer, of Cincinnati, have purchased of George Mills, manager of the Melbourne Stud, the two-year-old brown filly by Rainbow, dam The Brown Countess, by Wagner, for $14,000.

The entire year has been characterized by slow recovery from a very bad industrial, financial, general economic reaction. It is expected that the process of convalescence will continue, provided a crop failure does not intervene, but that it will, in all events, require two or three years.
THE value of a good "demonstration" was illustrated by a street merchant on Broadway the other day. He had before him a tray on which a top was spinning.

The financial situation in Belgium was not particularly satisfactory at the beginning of the year 1902. During the last two years Belgians lost a good deal of money in Russian enterprises and various speculations in the Congo causing great depression in financial circles, notwithstanding the fact that at the close of the year many securities increased in value and public confidence.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- A demand for a wage increase varying from 13 to 20 per cent is to be made by all the bituminous coal miners of the country the latter part of this month, about the time it is expected that the Arbitration Commission will report in the case of the anthracite miners. It is estimated that the demands would be for an annual increase of $2,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among all the editorials, accounts of meetings, and communications bearing on the subject of the inhuman conditions of travel on the elevated and surface railway lines of this city which have appeared in your excellent paper. I have been surprised to find no statement of the advantages of municipal ownership and operation of street railways.

Minneapolis millers, who last year ground nearly 70,000,000 bushels of wheat into 15,800,000 barrels of flour, look with optimism toward the remainder of the present milling year, which began Sept. 1. Speaking more particularly for the Northwest, they say the outlook is favorable for a fairly profitable year -- better than last.
THE railroad President had the floor. The financiers who had made him President had had the same floor for an hour or two before him.

The outlook for the provision trade during 1903 is much brighter than it was one year ago, and in every way presents a more favorable aspect for trade both at home and abroad. Crop conditions have been favorable: the farmer is prosperous, and the trade generally reflects the prosperity of the country.

It will be recalled that during the fiscal year 1901 the agricultural exports of the United States were decidedly the largest in the history of the country, having a value of $952,000,000. Compared with these exceptionally high figures, the value of the farm produce exported in the fiscal year 1902, amounting to $60,000,000, showed something of a decline, although exceeding the records of all years prior to 1901.

The year 1902 may be set down as fairly prosperous for the Netherlands. The depression which neighboring Germany has felt has not been manifested here. A general complaint is, nevertheless, heard that business is close, and there is not visible quite the same buoyancy that characterized the period ending in 1900.

An Eastern financier a year or two ago, in reply to the question, "What is Denver's greatest need?" said: "Funerals." He intimated that the business men of Denver and the State were so down in the mouth over the depression of silver and the halving and quartering of inflated values of the "boom days," that their eyes were closed and never would be opened to the marvelous possibilities of the State in every other direction.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 15 -- The Winter is upon us in earnest. But neither the price nor the scarcity of coal seems to be in the minds of the people, as turf and wood are plentiful and no dearer than last year.

The transactions of the New York Clearing House during the past year were over $76,000,000,000, which amount has been exceeded but once before, i.e., in the year previous, 1901, when the exchanges amounted to over $79,000,000,000.
MADRID, Dec. 24 -- A curious case has arisen here between a cousin of the King and the Prefect of Police, which, for obvious reasons, can hardly fail, at the present time, to interest New Yorkers.

The chief exports of Denmark in order of quantities are butter, pork, eggs, beef, horses, hides, and skins. None of these except the last can be exported to the United States, as the latter itself is a large exporter of the same products.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No other topic than that which has been so thoroughly ventilated through the press of late and before the Railroad Commis- sion this week could more deeply concern the heathen Harlemite. He has followed the discussion closely, and would like to squeeze into the amen corner long enough to indorse what has been said about public infelicities arising from traffic infacilities.

In writing for THE NEW YORK TIMES a year ago a review of the business situation in Germany and the prospects of American trade here, I stated that the outlook for our goods depended upon two very uncertain factors, viz., the probable duration of the crisis here, and the effect of Germany's tariff legislation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 3 -- Announcement was made to-day of the appointment of Edward L. Pollock to be Purchasing Agent of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company. Mr. Pollock formerly was a resident of Pittsfield, Mass., and has been connected with the purchasing department of the road since Jan. 1, 1898.
ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 20 -- Finance Minister Witte and Minister of the Interior Plehvehave reached a settlement of the recent difficulties between them. The terms, however, are not known.

Leading Cincinnati bankers and merchants are optimistic as to the business outlook for 1903, basins their predictions on the signs of the times and the wonderful prosperity of the past year. President W.W. Grander of the Chamber of Commerce, who is at the head of one of the largest grain, hay, and feed companies in the country, takes a roseate view of the situation.

From so splendidly dramatic and romantic a performance as Mr. E.H. Sothern's Hamlet to the dry and dusty fields, of scientific research in literature would seem to be a far cry, but it so happens that, whether or not Mr. Sothern intended it, there is the closest of bonds between them. "Only six men will read my book," remarked the German professor of popular anecdote "and only two will understand it."

Mr. HOAR'S anti-trust bill is largely an attempt, with the best intentions, to use powers not granted in the Constitution in ways most of which are impracticable for purposes of doubtful utility. It is not at all surprising that after reading it the Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee should declare that it confirmed his opinion that Congress can do nothing in this direction without an amendment of the Constitution.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The year's turn brought to the money market distinct ease, though earlier in the week money was strongly in demand, and a very large business was done by the Bank of England in loans and discounts.

No one branch of trade so well reflects the general industrial condition of the country as the jewelry business. The slightest labor disturbance, or even an unfavorable crop report, goes vibrating throughout the length and breadth of the jewelry world with a disquieting influence that is readily and firmly felt.

In 1901 Portugal's imports were valued at $58,640,000 and the exports at $35,200,000, as against $60,800,000 and $37,600,000 in 1900. Although the figures for 1902, obtained from Consul Thieriot at Lisbon, cover only the first half year, this decrease in imports appears to be still going on, for the imports are valued at $26,400,000 and the exports at $16,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the public criticism of the management of the elevated railways and in the suggestions for the amelioration of the present discomfort of the patrons, the subject of the car with the side-door entrance is not, it seems to me, receiving the attention it merits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I regret to observe that in the list of "reforms" demanded of President Vreeland by the Merchants' Association, two that are highly important to residents of Bronx Borough were omitted. These are the great need of shelter at transfer points and more frequent suburban service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Roosevelt's summary action in the case of the Postmaster at Indianola, Miss., has created a genuine sensation among the Southerners in the city, and some of the expressions used concerning his proceeding, even by Congressmen, are bitter.
Consul General Gowdy, when asked his opinion of the measures most advisable for improving the financial and commercial relations between France and the United States, said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hope you will continue to urge better treatment of its patrons by the elevated road. While it no doubt needs a man of railroad experience to operate the road, yet at the same time from the view of a layman a little good, sound common sense is also an important factor.

COPENHAGEN, Dec. 24 -- The foreign colony here has lately been augmented by the presence of Ali Nouri Bey, who was formerly a trusted political agent of the Sultan of Turkey, but later became a member of the Turkish Legitimist Party and was forced to flee or suffer a long term of imprisonment.

Since Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer, sought the fountain of youth in Florida hundreds of thousands of Ameri- cans have gone there in search of health and pleasure. There is no more interesting place in Florida than St. Augustine. It is the oldest city on the continent, and the picturesque beauty of the old city mingles with its modern gorgeousness in an enchanting manner.

When nearly 80,000,000 people are enjoying an unparalleled prosperity and are able to add over $600,000,000 to their credit in the savings banks of the United States within five years, it follows that the grocery trade, which distributes a large share of the food, should also be prosperous, and when the demand for American food products from foreign countries is added, the trade assumes vast proportions and is of international consequence.

The grievances of the Director of Sculpture at the World's Fair in St. Louis which caused his resignation cast a light on the management of the great undertaking up to this time which does not bode well for its success. That friction between managers is inevitable goes without saying, and it may be that the artist was not so quiet and diplomatic in his contentions as the Director of Works could wish.

So far as the general business of the country is concerned there is no evidence of an abatement of prosperity. The high prices prevailing for all kinds of merchandise, together with the fact that the demand for goods continues to exceed the supply, is sufficient evidence that there is no over-production in merchandise.

HER sister Amy was the elder, a girl of mild manners and indefinite opinions. She was brought out the preceding year; but Susan trod closely enough on her heels to gain some knowledge of the drawing room, and of how Amy conducted herself therein.

Government receipts of $10,624,166 against expenditures of $9,149,244,39 furnish the book return in the Philippines for the last fiscal year. Totals look better than details for customs supplied four-fifths of the income and the outlay went largely for salaries.

Theobald Chartran, the French genre and portrait painter, arrived yesterday on the French liner La Lorraine. His portraits of Mrs. Roosevelt and Miss Alice Roosevelt attracted much attention at the last Paris Salon, and on this visit, M. Chartran will paint a portrait of the President.

Atlantic City has no season. It is perennial. Its great Boardwalk teems with people at Easter as well as in the hot days of July and August. The "open door" policy is maintained all Winter, and even in January the resort has thousands of visitors, who find no tonic so beneficial as the ozone-laden breezes off the ocean.

SESSIONS of the House of Bishops are not altogether the solemn occasions the reverend nature of that body would indicate. At a recent meeting a difference of opinion developed into a rather lively contention, and one member after another, trying to relieve the situation, succeeded only in making the mess worse.

The flood-tide in Canadian business which has been spoken of during the past three or four years in the annual financial summaries in THE NEW YORK TIMES still rises. The business of the past year has been the best both positively and proportionately in Canadian history. The position of business at the present moment is probably better than at any time during the year.

"The railway outlook for 1903 is all that any reasonable manager could expect. It is much more encouraging, indeed, than the average observer will be likely to estimate. Such troubles as afflict the railway situation are largely superficial -- are not lasting, can be readily disposed of, and satisfactorily."

There is a superstition among the Japanese that certain years are unfortunate, and are foredoomed to disaster and misfortitne; 1902, called by them "the year of the tiger," is such a year, and shortly before it opened an unusual number of marriages were celebrated, these events having been, hastened to avoid the untoward results which might be expected to fellow if the ceremony were permitted to take place during a year of such evil import.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The State Department has received confirmatory advices from Peking of the declination of the powers to receive their second indemnity installment on the silver basis. It is not understood that the declination was accompanied by a threat, but the action itself is regarded as sinister, if, as has been suggested, it is not taken with a view to making a record of the position of the powers in this matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are a great many people shouting and swearing about the elevated roads of this town, and I am willing to wager one half of them don't know what they want. Tell me, do they want more trains than there are, so that it will take three hours instead of two to get home?

Virginia Malbrook Dudley, a young woman of refined appearance, who is said to be a member of a highly respectable family of Louisville, Ky., is a prisoner in Jefferson Market, suspected of having, in conjunction with her husband, William Cole Dudley, stolen numerous articles recently from department and jewelry stores, prominent hotels, and restaurants in this city.

If the visitor to the resorts of North Carolina be a lover of nature he will find himself quickly enraptured with the lofty grandeur of the mountains all about him. If he be an invalid it will not be long until he feels the insidious tonic influences of the superb climate bringing quicker and more healthful pulse beats and replacing his languor with strength and vitality.

MAKE 'em str-ong," is the direction which President Roosevelt gives when he orders shoes in a certain little boot shop in Sixth Avenue, where he has had his footwear made since the days when he wore out much shoe leather as Police Commissioner trying to better the discipline of the force.

California can fittingly be called the land of wonders. Its giant trees are one of the marvels of the world, the Yosemite Valley is admittedly one of the masterpieces of nature, and the scenery along the Shasta route -- that is, the route from San Francisco to Portland -- has no superior. The climate of California is a delight all the year round.

THEY were not exactly three of a kind, but they all had one peculiarity in common -- they were handicapped with some vocal affliction. The man with his back to the window stuttered, his vis-a-vis lisped, and the one at the end of the table was the victim of a chronic hoarseness that caused him to speak in a high-pitched whisper.

The improvement in the commercial progress of San Francisco has been more clearly defined during the year just closed than in any previous year in the annals of the city. In almost all the leading branches of business there has been a broadening out and a general desire to cover fields of trade heretofore neglected and unoccupied.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is extremely gratifying to an English-man to read that the comments on American industrial conditions made by the English mechanics brought here by Mr. Alfred Mosely" have furnished the English people very satisfactory reading matter." The chagein displayed by the writer of the article in THE TIMES is somewhat gratifying, too.

The rapid growth of trade between the United States mid Japan is probably best illustrated by the greatly increased facilities now being provided for handling that trade. Forty-eight steamships are now plying regularly between Pacific coast ports and the seaports of Japan. Their average size is much larger than a year ago, and they are going out with full cargoes.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has intrusted the work of the mechanical and electrical equipment of the power houses, passenger stations, and the complete underground system of the Pennsylvania tunnel to the firm of Westinghouse, Church, Kerr Co., designing and constructing engi- neers, whose pricinpal offices are at 10 Bridge Street.

The holidays having passed, the business of entertaining has been taken up in earnest again. From present indications this season is to be in marked contrast with that of last year. There will be few if any very large entertainments. The receptions to be given by Mrs. Astor and by Mrs. Gerry are the only social affairs to which more than three or four hundred guests have been bidden.
Meeker Magner have been appointed Illinois general agents of the General Accident Insurance Company of Perth.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The bye-election at Newmarket yesterday to fill the vacancy in the House of Commons caused by the death of Harry McCalmont resulted in a Liberal gain. The Anglo-German alliance against Venezuela played a prominent part in the campaign, C.D. Rose, the Liberal candidate, vigorously opposing the alliance.

Pliny Fisk of Harvey Fish Sons, in reviewing the bond market during the past year, expresses the opinion that the dullness in investment bonds which existed during nearly the entire year was due to the fact that so much attention was given to speculation that those who would usually make investments were, instead, using their funds in the stock market.

JOB PARKER and his friend were bowling north in a surface car one day lately. The car had been well filled with people, but had gradually emptied. It stopped to take on a passenger, and Job looked up from his paper, as car passengers will, to see what manner of man or woman the stranger might be, and as he did so was attracted by a glittering something on the seat opposite.

MID-AIR dining clubs have become a unique feature of New York club life. In all there are perhaps two dozen occupying the upper or top stories in the "skyscraper" buildings, and with the exception of the Business Women's Club all are for men. They are situated from the Battery to Forty-second Street, and practically cover the business section of the city.
