Since last writing under this heading, one year ago, peace has been proclaimed, and this country is slowly regaining normal conditions. The mining companies have partially resumed work, and the burghers who were taken as prisoners of war to foreign lands are gradually being returned to what formerly were their homes.

OF the many obstacles which have stood in the way of the completion of the subway, the latest is the inability of the New York Central Railroad and a sub-contractor to come to an agreement relative to the tunnel that must go under the Central's tracks at Park Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 3 -- Chris Miller, who for the past eleven years has been a familiar figure on the southwest coast of Alaska and along the Aleutian archipelago, reached Tacoma this week and is entertaining his friends with an account of his travels.

The session held yesterday at the Criminal Courts Building by the Commission in Lunacy appointed by Justice Lambert of the Supreme Court to examine into the mental condition of Henry J. Rose, the stage manager who killed his wife, Isabella, last September, was brought to an abrupt close by the sudden collapse of Mrs. Marie Zimmerrnan, a sister of the dead woman.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- A certificate of incorporation of the Lorenz Orthopedic Charity Hospital of New York City has been filed for approval with the State Board of Charities. The Directors are: W. S. Brewer, C.F. Smith, F.E. Sylvester, D. B. Sanneman, and B.F. Curtis, all of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The Spectator to-day gives much prominence to a long letter from Sidney Lee, a well-known lecturer and writer and Trask Lecturer at Princeton University, denying that the Anglo-German co-operation in Venezuela is in any way due to the action of King Edward.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Jan. 3 -- The Mayor of this city, Manuel Egozcue, has been arrested and is held on a five-thousand-dollar bail on the charge, made by Insular Official Inspector Holst, of destroying the records of the city water receipts which constituted the only evidence of alleged extensive peculations and embezzlements.

The record of metal mining in the United States in 1902 has been an excellent one, though the increases in production have not been equal to the phenomenal gains recorded in iron and steel. This could hardly be expected, indeed, since the possibilities of expansion are less and progress necessarily slower.

The series of concerts of ancient instrumental music which Mr. Sam Franko has carried on for a couple of years he has made a delight, not only on account of the beauty and charm of the music be has performed, but also through the glimpses they have given into some of the forgotten by-paths of musical history.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Business was quieter on the Boerse to-day, though the undercurrent was firm. Internationals and banks were well maintained. Collieries were somewhat easier on realizations and Canadian Pacific was slightly easier on New York advices.

HAVANA, Dec. 26 -- A week more and it will be four years since the Spaniards took their colors down from the citadels and towers of Cuba; four years since the Stars and Stripes were raised in their stead. Needless to say there have been many changes in the island in that time, some that were predicted, many that were not.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me a word apropos your editorial in this morning's issue as to commissions for warrant officers. The idea of promotion from the ranks, through the various grades to a commission, of a limited number of men, is undoubtedly a good one and should be given a fair trial, despite the animus or objection of officers.

THAT an officer of the law could be wholly an instrument of execution was exemplified by Sheriff Turner. During twenty years of rounding up criminals of all sorts he had never once allowed personal feelings to interfere with duty. With him an order was not to be tampered with, even in the mode of executing: and if he was susceptible of such unofficial weaknesses as sympathy or indecision, they never appeared upon the surface.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A new development of the coal famine is likely to be the institution of suits at law against coal dealers to restrain them from discriminating in favor of their regular customers. Some of the residents of Washington have employed counsel, who, it is stated, are preparing to bring suit.

LENOX, Jan. 3 -- Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes has been in Lenox for a few days, arranging to open Shadow Brook next week for a large house party from New York. Her guests, to the number of about fifty, will come up in her private car.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Kipling, in one of those impassioned lyrical outbursts so characteristic of the man, once exclaimed "What do they know of England who only England know?" This question is one which many Englishmen must have put to themselves this week, as each morning, on unfolding their newspaper, they found it full of the doings of their fellow-countrymen in distant lands over which "our sovereign lord King Edward the Seventh" holds undisputed sway.

Eleven months' figures of the foreign commerce of the United States, which have already been received, seem to justify an estimate for the year of $1,340,000,000 of exports and $950,000,000 of imports. This would make the total exports of the year $125,000,000 less than those of last year and the total imports $70,000,000 more than those of last year.
After a brief respite over the holidays, the machinery for meting out criminal and civil justice in this city will agan be set in motion to-morrow, when the current judicial year begins.

Regarding the present condition of New England railroads, so far as the business is concerned, and referring especially to the business of New England, the business of all the roads seems to be in a very prosperous condition, so far as the freight business is concerned. The passenger business hits also held up exceedingly well but, of course, aside from holiday travel, the passenger business is now somewhat reduced, as usual in the Winter season.

The seventh annual FINANCIAL REVIEW of THE NEW YORK TIMES appears with this morning's issue, presenting interesting and instructive information on many subjects that pertain to finance and commerce. The article, with data collated with great care from the best authorities, treat of the past, present, and future.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The North German Lloyd steamer Kaiserin Maria Theresia, which is to sail from Bremen to-day and from Southampton to-morrow, will take among her passengers Admiral Lord Charles Beresford. There is no truth in the report, circulated in the United States, that the Admiral is to take a position with the International Mercantile Marine Company.

After disposing of the bric-a-brac and furniture in the estate of Mr. S.D. Warren of Boston, in that city, the executors have chosen to sell the old and modern paintings, pastels, and water colors collected here and abroad by the late Mr. Warren and his widow. The auction will be held soon at the American Art Association on Madison Square.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As doubtless with many others, I was much interested in your editorial Tuesday on "Naval Officers."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The ball of the Assembly in Washington Hall to-night was a brilliant affair. It is the fourth in a series of eight, and it was to have been on Saturday next, but, because many people will leave town next week it was arranged for to-night. The crowd was as largo as that at the first of the series.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have carefully read and considered an article in this morning's issue of your paper, headed "Defense of Street Railways," by Mr. F.B. Thurber. I find that Mr. Thurber is a lawyer of this city, and hence in a position to ably protect any contention as set forth in his letter.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 24 -- It is a gracious tribute to the rural aristocracy of Russia that many of its members have been selected to act on local committees which are being organized under the personal supervision of the Czar for the amelioration of the condition of the peasant class.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Stephen T. Garland, for many years actively identified with railroad interests, died at his home here to-night after a lingering illness. He was sixty years old.

After much unsettled planning for tournaments and match competitions, the billiard players, both professional and amateur, have apparently made New Year resolutions that will result in some real sport. Up to this week the majority of the players and lovers of the game seem to have been in a quandary, but now that the murky atmosphere of their indecision has cleared the prospect is excellent.

THE great time marks on the dial plate of the firmament are not coincident with the beginning of the year in our calendar. This grand division of our time takes no note of the equinoxes and disregards and ignores the far more impressive and important dates indicated by the solstices or "standing places" of the sun.

Candidates for the Columbia crews will begin work for the year to-morrow, when they will report to Robert B. Bartholomew, Captain of the Varsity crew. The men will start at once in practice in the rowing machines, and will also take a daily outdoor run, besides exercise in the gymnasium.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Money was in great abundance in the market to-day. Discounts weakened and caution was manifested, on account of the weakness of Parts exchange.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- The Post will say to-morrow that a gigantic rival to the anthracite coal combination has been formed under the name of the John H. Morrison Coal Company, backed by the Rothschilds and other European capital, and that its purpose is to supply Boston and New England ports with foreign and domestic coal.

But for wholly artificial and almost accidental obstacles, it would have been far and away the most prosperous these industries have ever known.

At the same time during the last few months money has been extremely scarce and high in the New York market.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- A dispatch to the Matin from Caracas says the city is menaced by revolutionary forces which are in the neighborhood. The correspondent describes the situation at Caracas as critical.

The week just ended was marked by the popular appreciation of three Shakespearean productions. Mr. Mansfield has been doing splendid business for several weeks at the Herald Square, Mr. Sothern promises to do as well at the Garden, and Mr. Bonn was likewise successful at the Irving Place.

CHARLEY, aged four, had the time of his life on Christmas Day. He and his father dined with friends who live in a boarding house. It was Charley's first experience in boarding house etiquette, and most of the people and their doings impressed him as being very queer.

The year 1902 will go down in the history of the shoe and leather trade as a most peculiar and trying one. Surrounded on all sides by industries which have prospered amazingly, the shoe manufacturing trade, while not having so much to complain of in volume of business, is suffering from certain abnormal conditions which have tended to make the year anything but a profitable one for shoe manufacturers.
BERLIN, Dec. 26 -- Domestic politics in Germany have received renewed impetus through a recent article published in defense of Social Dmocracy by Prof. Mommsen, who is now in his eighty-sixth year.

THE amiable, gentle-minded Czar of Russia had until a few months ago a perfect double in the person of a brilliant and immensely popular nobleman, who held a very great position in the Russian Army. So striking was the likeness between the two that the Emperor warned his friend over and over again of the terrible danger he was running simply through this resemblance.

It is only the day-to-day philosophers in Wall Street, or those precipitate persons who have no philosophy at all, who will now throw care to the winds and confidently set their sails for the year on the strength of the fine bank statement put out yesterday. The money current has changed its flow, and the much needed millions are now coming back to New York.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- The Boston stock market was not nearly as active as it was Friday, and most of the buying power disappeared. The upward movement of the coppers stopped, for a time at least. This cessation is a natural consequence of the advance of the week, but it was due in part also to the figures on the production of copper metal given by the New York Metal Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Representative Oscar W. Underwood of Alabama expresses the opinion that the President by the means he is adopting to bring about reciprocity with Cuba, is violating the Constitution. Mr. Underwood is an advocate of Cuban reciprocity, but considers the President's methods dangerous and revolutionary.
WHAT is the picture that comes to mind at the mention of Elsinore, the home of Hamlet? It would be easy to define it beforehand.

NEW YEAR'S DAY seemed to be a gala occasion for the New York clubs and those in the suburbs. There were a number of delightful entertainments given on New Year's Day itself, and the old year was buried and the new one greeted with extensive festivities at some and with private reunions at others.
NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 3 -- A. Langear Norrie of New York has rented for the season of 1903 the C.C. Baldwin cottage, corner Bellevue Avenue and Narraganset Avenue.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 31 -- The greatest activity and progress have marked alt lines of business on Puget Sound and throughout Washington during the past year. The State is prosperous as never before, and its varied resources are being developed with a rapidity that is almost phenomenal.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- The New Year's week at Tuxedo has never been equalled for gaiety. The large crowds which visited Tuxedo for the annual New Years' Eve ball, remained over Sunday to enjoy the fine skating on the Tuxedo Lake; the coasting and the tobogganing. On the numerous hills throughout the park sleighing parties were numerous and in fact everything seemed full of life.

The hand was fine, the nod -- as well as the compressed lips that emphasized it -- was fascinating. "I laid the money here to have it ready for the gas man.

District Attorney Jerome decided yesterday to give out for publication the text of the letter that he sent to Jusice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, on Friday, although he had not received an answer.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Quite a heated discussion is being carried on between Le Gaulois and Yves Guyot's paper Le Siecle as to whether a terrible fate has more quickly overtaken the principal anti-Dreyfusards or those who prominently identified themselves with the defense of Dreyfus. Additional interest has been added to the discussion by the dispatch of the German General, von Schwarzkoppen, on a special mission to the Czar.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I might relate a grievance, if too many such have not already been mentioned. I might tell how I took a Seventh Avenue Amsterdam car yesterday at noon at Twenty-third Street, as there seemed to be more of those than of any other kind. It was full, and we went on until we reached the Circle at Fifty-ninth Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 -- Marcos won the Audubon Handicap worth $1,350 to the winner by a narrow margin to-day. Two or three strides more would have given the verdict to Major Tenny at 50 to 1. Weather cloudy, track heavy. Summaries:

Perhaps in no branch of the country's wonderful growth has its energy been more strikingly shown than in the wonderful activity of its builders, but if current developments may be made the bases of judgment, the twentieth century promises to become famous as the age of re-builders.

LONDON Dec. 13 -- To the financial world of London the year 1902 was a great disap- pointment. It brought peace in South Africa, but the peace boom -- the long promised rise in consuls and Kafirs "as soon as the war was over" -- developed into a dreary period of slack business and drooping prices, accompanied by occasional spasms of something like panic.

The Chemnitz industrial world, like the industrial world of the German Empire, of which it is a part, a reflection, is continuing to labor more or less under the ban of business laxity and trade depression. In some branches much of the old prosperity has returned, but in the many lines of trade a recovery is unnoticeable or but slightly progressed.

LESS than five miles from Madison Square, and within the limits of Greater New York, are to be found several farms run by Chinamen. Until a few years ago the great farm country of Long Island contained no Chinamen; then a colony of these taciturn foreigners settled half way between Long Island City and Astoria.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 31 -- The South has come to her own. Of the depression which followed naturally enough the gigantic strussle of the sixties, not the slightest vestige remains. In fact, Dixie has become the very synonym of prosperity. Its present is triumphant with justifiable self-assurance and knowledge of its brilliant possibilities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much interested in your to-day's suggestive editorial on "Museum Ethics," and it awoke me to a new realization of the number of perplexing problems that are constantly arising with the steady advance of civilization. The labor problem, the rapid transit problem, the problem of how to establish stable democracies on unstable foundations, are among those that cry for solution; and now comes the museum problem.

France is bursting with riches, thrift, and industry, patriotism and pessimism. Crops this year have been fair, and as every properly constituted Frenchman has an acre, a cow, and an ass, money has been distributed with a fairly even hand.

The past year in a business way has been a good one for Baltimore. There have been no disasters of any moment, while there have been signs of an expanding, or reaching-out, tendency in several of the departments of activity. The year closed not merely with a sense of satisfaction of what has already been accomplished, but there is a sanguine feeling that there are better things in store.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 3 -- It will be some time before Lakewood will settle down to the staid, dignified resort that it was before the holiday crowds came and transformd it into a maelstrom of gayety. The fanfare of coaching horns has stirred the village from early morning until late at night, for coaching parties have been extremely popular during the week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What's the matter with the Erie Railroad? For several months the train service gradually has been deteriorating, until now it is almost a novelty for an Erie train either to reach Jersey City on time, or to make time going west. Commuters are grumbling all along the line.

The new Legislature of Arkansas is expected to pass a bill for the erection of a State Capitol by a non-partisan commission, of which Gov. Davis shall not be a member, and over which he shall have no control.

THE undergraduates of Columbia University have a daily newspaper, two literary magazines, a comic paper, a monthly for the law students, and a weekly for the girls of Barnard College, to say nothing of the three annuals. It is the first four publications, however, in which the greatest interest is taken, and to which the students give the most attention.

While the advance of several of the leading European powers within the territorial limits of China and the occupation of socalled "spheres of influence" during the last few years have unsettled trade conditions and retarded commercial progress, they have not interfered as much as might be expected with the trade relations of America with that great Oriental nation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Reading Philadelphia Electric, Philadelphia Rapid Transit and United States Steel were the only active stocks in the Philadelphia market to-day. All other issues were practically neglected. Prices generally were firm, but United Gas receded a point on sales of odd lots, on the report that President Dolan of the company has incurred the enmity of the city administration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Republican Party should nominate David B. Henderson for Vice President on the ticket with Roosevelt in 1904. Gen. Henderson is an honest man, true to his convictions and his conception of the duties of a public servant. He is in no sense a "policy" man, and could never be per- suaded to compromise his rigid and welldefined principles for the sake of attaining public office.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Senatorial elections were held to-day in thirty-four departments of France, Algeria, and in the Colonies of La Reunion and Guadeloupe, to select ninety-eight Senators, of whom ninety-four will fill seats the terms of whose occupants have constitutionally expired, while the other lour will fill vacancies caused by deaths.

BABRLON, L.I., Jan. 4 -- The High School here will not resume its sessions to morrow, and it is impossible to tell when it will be able to do so. The board met last night and decided not to attempt to reopen it until they obtain a supply of coal. All efforts to obtain enough for even a month have failed.

The New York Historical Society is the pioneer of a movement looking to the collection and preservation of all historical matter pertaining to the State of New York. Prof. Osgood of Columbia has been looking into the Massachusetts system for several years and believes that New York State should follow her example.

DELHI, India, Jan. 4 -- The Chapter of Indian Orders, held last night, was one of the most brilliant functions following the Durbar. It was attended by Lord Curzon of Kedleston, Viceroy of India, and Lady Curzon; the Duke of Connaught, representative of King Edward, and the Duchess of Connaught, and scores of native Princes.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 -- The Government is without information regarding the landing of German marines at Puerto Cabello, Venezuela. The Foreign Office says that if such landing occurred it must certainly have been transient, and regards the reported seizure of the Custom House at Puerto Cabello by German marines as a canard.

The action of the State Board of Railroad Commissioners in issuing the order just made public requiring the management of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad to make certain sweeping changes in their arrangements for handling the travel dependent upon them will be received with satisfaction.

Francis Neilson, stage director of grand opera in the Covent Garden Theatre, London, arrived yesterday on board the St. Paul to produce for Charles B. Dillingham the new play by Frances Hodgson Burnett, "A Little Unfairy Princess," in the Criterion Theatre for a season of special matinees, beginning Jan. 14.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- The marriage of Albert Edward Tower and Miss Mary Towne Bogardus will be celebrated on Wednesday at the home of the young woman on Smith Street. The wedding will be a simple and quiet one. The Rev. A.P. Van Glesson, pastor of the First Reformed Church, of which Miss Bogardus is a member, will perform the ceremony, which will be witnessed only by the immediate relatives of the contracting parties.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 4 -- Chairman Herrmann of the National Baseball League Peace Committee to-day made the positive statement that his committee had full power to act in negotiating for peace with the American League. Herrmann protested against the construction which President Ban Johnson placed on his letter of last Friday, and when asked for a statement said:

Mr. JEROME has received the highest compliment ever paid to a District Attorney in New York, in the announced readiness of those engaged in the practice of gainful vice and crime to drive him from office if it costs a million dollars of their dishonest accumulations to effect that purpose.

TANGIER, Morocco, Jan. 4 -- According to official news received here from Fez, the adroit move of the Sultan in bringing his brother, Mulai-Mohammed, to the capital has attained the desired-object of depriving the Pretender to the throne of his prestige, and the latter has retired, discredited, to Taza.

The Rev. Dr. Frank Oliver Hall of Cambridge was installed last night as pastor of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street. The service was conducted by the Rev. Charles F. Patterson, and the installation prayer was read by the Rev. H. R. Rose of Newark.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with surprise and regret the special plea made by Mr. F.B. Thurber for the poor, downtrodden, misguided men who Invested their money in the surface and elevated railroads of the City of NewYork. Their investments have reduced them to beggary and the use of "water" in large quantities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The annual report of the Philippine Commission and a separate report by Gov. W.H. Taft, made public at the War Department to-day, gives a review of the results of the year's work of the commission, and contain recommendations for legislative action by Congress deemed essential to the welfare of the islands.

During the reading of the annual report at the tenth annual meeting of the Board of Directors of the Educational Alliance last evening the announcement was made that $50,000 had been donated for the enlargement of the organization's building. The men who gave the amount jointly because of a hint which was dropped in the last annual report are Felix M. Warburg and Mortimer L. Schiff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Southern Congressmen have been arriving in town today to attend the reassembling of Congress, and every one of them is angry to the fighting point over the President's action in closing up the Post Office at Indianola. Miss. State lines have nothing to do with it, and Congressmen from Mississippi are no hotter than others from other States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Without referring to the general features of the new administration of the Police Department, which, I hope, will lead to radical improvement, I venture to say that suspen sion of officers under charges is simply common sense, and should always have prevailed.
Dr. William S. Rainsford yesterday celebrated the twentieth anniversary of his installation as rector of St. George's Episcopal Church. Bishop W.C. Doane of Albany took part in the morning service.

William F. King of the Merchants Association said yesterday that if the statement of the Railroad Commission to the effect that it would be a wise move to put the rapid transit question in the City of New York in the control of a local board was made in earnest the Merchants Association would request Mayor Low to commence such, proceedings as would be necessary to carry the views or the commission into effect.

After repeated efforts to play the deciding golf match for the Garden City Golf Club's championship, the final round of this long-deferred event was contested yesterday over the club's links, and Walter J. Travis beat Clarence B. Macdonald at the 36 holes by 3 up and 1 to play, but the players broke the club's unwritten law against the playing of competitions on Sunday.

-- As a representative of the United States Marine Hospital Service is co-operating with the State Quarantine officers of Texas in the protective measures which the latter have been moved to take by the appearance of the bubonic plague at Mazatlan, Mexico, it is at once surprising and disappointing that the dispatches on the subject indicate the doing of nothing except the adoption and enforcement of the exclusion policy against refugees from across the border.

KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 4 -- A sensation has been created by the arrest here late last night of the Rev. Carmelo Falconi, who is stationed at the Italian Catholic Orphan Asylum, in Belgreve Drive, this place, charged with assaulting and threatening to kill the Rev. Clement Cardarelli, an assistant priest at the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, at Orange.

Prof. D.A. SUTHERLAND has lately made a series of analyses of the air of the London "tubes" which give results so surprising, and even startling, as to challenge attention and prompt the suggestion that the capable and conscientious engineers of the New York Rapid Transit Commission and of other underground improvements should give serious thought to the problem of subway ventilation.

One more illustration of the fact that music lovers of this city are ever on the lookout for and ready to encourage any movement to provide programmes of serious musical study was given last evening at the beginning or a series of Sunday night concerts in Carnegie Music Hall by Franz Kaltenborn and his orchestra, assisted by a corps of soloists.

The officials of the Tammany Hall General Committee have been summoned to court at the instance of William S. Devery. The ex-Chief said last night that he would drive the "Fourteenth Street gang" as far as money could do it. Justice Scott of the Supreme Court on Saturday issued an order returnable at 10 o'clock on Wednesday, requiring Tammany to explain its treatment of Devery.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Frederick D. Kilburn. Superintendent of Banks, has issued his annual report. It is directed to the Legislature. In this report he makes several recommendations which in his opinion would lead to the greater safety of banking institutions, particularly the savings, building and loan, and other associations trustees of the savings of the poor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The seesawing that has been going on of late in regard to the time when Justice Shiras is to retire from the Supreme bench is accounted for in some quarters by the expectation that there will be opposition from the Pennsylvania Senators to the selection of a successor to Justice Shiras from outside the State of Pennsylvania.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 4 -- The Senatorial situation in Colorado is becoming decidedly complicated. The solid support of the Democratic wing of the Legislature for Teller is still maintained, while the Republican strength is parceled out among four candidates, of whom ex-Senator E.O. Wolcott is the most conspicuous.

The issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday was the largest in its history. It had 118 pages, of which 28 were devoted to the news sections, 50 to the Annual Financial Review, 4 to the Quotation Supplement, 10 to the Magazine Supplement, 6 to the Magazine Section, and 6 to the Winter Resort Section.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- The answer of G.B. Markle Co., independent coal operators, to the demands of the miners, was made public here to-day. The answer will be submitted to the Anthracite Strike Commission, which reassembles in this city tomorrow. It was written by John Markle, managing partner of the firm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- At the Capitol to-morrow there will be launched a movement to rejuvenate the Democratic Party. The first step contemplated is the displacing of Representative Richardson of Tennessee, as the minority leader and the selection in his stead of John Sharp Williams of Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Anti-Trust bill of Senator Hoar has not been given the approval he expected it would receive, and it is very probable several of its features will undergo change in the Judiciary Comittee. It is fully expected that the bill in amamended form will come from the committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The official batting averages of National League baseball players who participated in fifteen or more games during the season of 1902, as compiled by Secretary N.E. Young, were made pubic to-night. They show that the ten best run-getters were J. Wagner of Pittsburg, leading with 105; Clarke, Pittsburg; Beaumont, Pittsburg; Leach, Pittsburg; Crawford, Cincinnati; Tenney, Boston; R. Thomas, Philadelphia; Keeler, Brooklyn; Sheckard, Brooklyn, and Beckley, Cincinnati.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 4 -- Floods now raging throughout Washington are causing damages to traffic and business estimated at millions of dollars. For three days mail, passenger, and freight service has been paralyzed. Six hundred landslides have come down on railroads, chiefly through the Cascade Mountains and in Western Washington.

BOSTON, Jan. 5 -- Grade crossings and general improvements that will cost $4,000,000 are being undertaken by the New York Central management of the Boston and Albany Railroad. The Boston and Albany is required to stand 65 per cent, of the cost. Over $100,000 is to be expended in track ballasting, and $250,000 on engine houses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Considerable discussion has arisen in regard to what has been called the congestion of traffic in this city. Not a few letters have been written to our daily newspapers, and their news columns contain enough daily about the same to furnish interesting reading while engaged in that congestion in the morning and again in the evening.
According to Akron (Ohio) dispatches six of the independent sewer-pipe concerns of Ohio and Pennsylvania have formed a combination with a capital of $2,000,000.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 5 -- The strong upward tendency in Cotton Duck incomes and the reviving bullish sentiment in G.B.S. Brewing issues were to-day's features. Cotton Duck incomes continue to advance on reports of good business, and the brewing, issues are stronger on the known fact of any accumulating surplus.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- It is said at a late hour here to-night that the Third Appellate Division of the Supreme Court will, within twenty-four hours, hand down a decision declaring the Franchise Tax law passed by the Legislature of 1899 unconstitutional so far as it relates to the State Constitution.

BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- Great Britain and Germany came to an understanding four days ago to enforce the blockade of the Venezuelan coast precisely as though the negotiations for arbitration were not going on. It was doubtless in consequence of this understanding that the vessels at Puerto Cabello were taken.

With a report that could be heard for a block or more and a blinding flash of light one of the fuses in the main generator in the power house of the United Electric Light and Power Company, at 418 East Twenty-ninth Street, blew out last night and darkened many hotels, theatres, stores, and private houses.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday received a reply to the letter which he sent Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, a few days ago, requesting the name of the "truthful person" the Justice referred to as his authority in an article written for The North American Review, in which he criticised the conduct of the police during a recent raid.

The Trustees of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, of which Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst is pastor, yesterday considered an offer by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to purchase the church property on the southeast corner of Twenty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue. In the event of the deal being completed, it is believed that the congregation will build its new home on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street.

-- What was, perhaps, a more important achievement of MICHAEL J. DUFFY than any of those recorded in the brief obituary articles published yesterday was his invention of a word which, while it has not actually established itself as a part of our written language, yet has won a place in several dictionaries and for colloquial use is recognized as good enough by all except particularly stately speakers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Strength was again developed in the local market to-day. Lehigh Valley was lifted to 30 1/3 but shaded off fractionally before the close. Philadelphia Electric securities became bucyant on revived talk of a deal with the United Gas Improvement Company, although the latter's Stock was stagnant.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday included a larger number of stocks than have appeared in recent outside trading. This broadening of the market was the more acceptable because of the strength which accompanied the increase in activity. A few declines were noted, but they were relatively small compared with many of the gains which resulted from the day's operations, the net losses being considerably outnumbered by the net gains.

Columbia's basket ball team is rapidly getting into shape for the opening of its season with Princeton in the Columbia gymnasium on Jan. 13. The team has been in training since November, and has been playing games ever since the 4th of December, so that its members therefore have had quite a lot of experience.

That there was an active and strong Movement in stocks yesterday was the result mainly of the easier conditions of money. There was no other development of importance. Saturday's bank statement, reporting a notable grain in cash, due chiefly to the return of money used in the holiday trade, had been unexpectedly favorable.

MADRID, Jan. 5 -- Ex-Premier Sagasta died at 11 o'clock to-night. At 6:30 o'clock he had an attack of heart failure, and it was then thought he was dead; he rallied, however, and lived for four hours and a half. His funeral will probably take place next Wednesday. He was born in 1827.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 -- Thane, Peat, and Rankin were the winning favorites. The Stewards have restored Jockey Hicks to all privileges. They have recommended that Thomas Hatfield of the former firm of Hatfield Ownby be excluded from the grounds. Jockey Landry has been refused permission to accept mounts and denied all privileges.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Great dissatisfac- tion in Constantinople is reported by the correspondent of The Times in conse- quence of the lavish distribution of hon- ors and pecuniary rewards among persons to whom the Sultan had given official positions in order that they might render him service to which honorable men would not stoop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- In an opinion handed down by Justice Brown to-day the United States Supreme Court decided in the Downs case that the money paid by the Russian Government on sugar exported is a bounty, and that the Collector of Customs at Baltimore was justified in levying a countervailing duty on Russian sugar under the terms of the Dingley law.

BRISTOL, Jan. 5 -- Much of the work on the cup boat at the Herreshoff shops at Bristol during the week past was confined to the continuation of the shaping of the craft's frames and assembling them in convenient places near the mid-section of the boat. Each day's work gives ample proof that the design and manner of construction are superior to the Constitution, and there were but few defects for criticism on that craft.

President H.H. Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railroad system told the Board of Railroad Commissioners yesterday at a public hearing in the Fifth Avenue Hotel that the congestion of cars in Broadway would necessarily continue indefinitely unless the police kept the tracks reasonably, clear of trucks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Justice Holmes of the United States Supreme Court to-day delivered the first opinion promulgated by him as a member of that court. The case was that of Otis Gassman vs. F. Parker and involved the question as to whether the State Constitution of California prohibiting dealings in margins on stocks contravenes the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 5 -- The special permit granted by Admiral Douglas, R.N., to the steamer Bolivar of the Orinoco Steamship Company, to pass the blockade and proceed to Ciudad Bolivar, has caused much adverse criticism here.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Mr. William St. John Brodrick, the British War Secretary, and Miss Madeline Stanley, daughter of Lady Jeune, were married at St. George's Church. Hanover Square, this afternoon. The scene was brilliant, the church was crowded with fashionable people and the centre aisle was lined with non-commissioned officers and men belonging to the Surrey Yeomanry, of which Mr. Brodrick is honorary colonel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Census Bureau report on the cotton ginned from the 1902 crop up to and including Dec. 13 last is 9,311,835 bales, irrespective of shape or weight, equal to 8,003,503 bales according to commercial counting. This is 90.2 per cent, of the crop. The report in part follows:

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against the firm of S. Zeimer Feldstein, importers of artificial flowers and feathers at 622 and 624 Broadway and in Paris, France, by Hays Hershfield, attorneys for Joseph Goldstein of Long Branch, N.J., a creditor, for $37,803, being money loaned to the firm between Dec. 10, 1896, and December last.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Miss Lovina Cushman, a public school teacher at New Rochelle, has fallen heir to a large share of the fortune of her granduncle, Joseph B. Cushman, who died here a few days ago leaving an estate estimated at between three-quarters and one million dollars.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Comparison of the development of the United States and of South Africa is made in an article by Benjamin Kidd, published this morning in The Times. Speaking of South Africa he points out that its prosperous future depends upon its rapid settlement by the largest possible white population.

The full effect of the abrogation last week of the contract, by which the coal-carrying companies have been selling over 8,000,000 tons of independent coal at circular price began to be realized yesterday. The contract which the independent dealers had with the railroads provided, according to the independent dealers, that the coal should be sold at market value.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Representative Fitzgerald of New York to-day introduced a bill making it illegal for any person engaged in trade to use for advertising purposes the name or picture of any living person without having first obtained their consent in writing. A maximum penalty of one year in prison and $1,000 fine is provided.

Gen. Francis V. Greene yesterday followed his apparent policy of placing responsibility for police conditions on the superior officers of the uniformed force, leaving it to them to deal with their subordinates, by writing to Chief Inspector Moses W. Cortright two letters, based on the Commissioner's impressions received during his flying trip over the Borough of Manhattan on Sunday.

When Mme. Eleonora Duse returned to New York yesterday to close her American tour it was with the news that she will be able to establish this Summer, through the aid of Miss Anne T. Morgan, daughter of J.P. Morgan, and other women, the theatre which the Italian actress and Gabriele d'Annunzio planned to build in Italy some years ago.

A "double bill" was presented last evening for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which was uncommonly well filled, and which echoed to more general applause than it often has this season. The operas were Donizetti's "La Fille du Regiment" and Leoncavello's "Pagliacci," and the occasion was widely felt to be a highly stimulating one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Some time ago the sub-committee on the House Judiciary Committee, which was charged with the preparation of an anti-trust bill, asked Attorney General Knox to send suggestions for such a measure. The Attorney General to-day informed the sub-committee, together with the Senate Committee on Judiciary, that he had prepared the suggestions asked for and would submit them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In search for a way to pass the time yesterday morning, and with a vague notion, gotten I know not how, that St. Bartholomew's was an old and well-reputed Protestant Episcopal church, I thought I would try it -- if some other church of that or some other denomination did not attract me on the way.
The message of the Mayor treats of the finances of the city in a frank, sensible, and businesslike fashion, and what he has to say is at once intelligible and encouraging.

Samuel Goldsticker has sold for Justice P. Henry Dugro to Solomon Salomon the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, four-story brownstonefront flats, with stores, on plot 100.11 by 95, known as 968 to 976 Sixth Avenue and 76 and 78 West Fifty-fifth Street. Mr. Salomon does not contemplate any improvement of the property, at least for the present, but win hold it as an investment after making some alterations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Southerners fear that trouble will result from the President's action in the case of the Post Office at Indianola, Miss. Reports from that town which are beginning to come in indicate that public sentiment is certainly wrought up.
Mayor Low appointed twenty-two members of the Brooklyn Public Library Corporation yesterday. They are:

The January Grand Jury was sworn in yesterday before Recorder Goff. The foreman is Edward J. Cuddihy, an undertaker, of 348 East Fifty-fifth Street, who has acted in that capacity several times before. The other members are as follows:

The President should know or should be advised that he cannot lawfully punish an entire community for the offenses of some of its members. When the resignation of the negro Postmistress of Indianola, Miss., was received, the President and the Postmaster General certainly had before them a case for investigation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The House resumed work to-day after a recess of two weeks, but within two hours the machinery broke down for lack of a quorum and an adjournment was taken.

At a meeting of the Race Committee of the Automobile Club of America held at the clubhouse, 753 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, it was decided that all entrants for the coming race for the Bennett International Cup must have their cars in this city by Saturday, April 11, and must place them at the disposal of the committee on that date for such tests as may be imposed.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The plenitude of money was unabated in the market to-day.

The situation in the Philippines, as described in the report of the Civil Commission, and especially in the report of Gov. TAFT, is unquestionably serious, though by no means desperate. In substance it is a situation of relative order, threatened by famine and the brigandage to which industrial distress invites in a people only too prone to it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Scarcely had the Senate reconvened to-day after its holiday recess when the coal question was brought up. Three measures, each directed against the duty on anthracite, were submitted to the Senate by Messrs. Lodge, Culberson and Vest.

The portions of the message of Mayor Low relating to the development of facilities for local and interborough transit should be read with care and attention by every citizen. While it adds nothing to what was previously known, the whole matter is reviewed with a thoroughness and intelligence which makes it easily intelligible to the citizen, property owner, and taxpayer for whom the facts have practical interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Another surprising change was made to-day in the arrangement of European diplomatic posts. David Jayne Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, was nominated for Minister to Switzerland; Francis B. Loomis, now Minister to Portugal, was named to succeed Dr. Hill as Assistant Secretary of State, and Charles Page Bryan, present Minister to Brazil, was nominated Minister to Portugal.

Mayor Low's annual message about municipal affairs is to be made public in three installments. To the Board of Aldermen yesterday the Mayor sent a document of sixteen printed pages about sinking fund matters, real estate assessment, rapid transit extensions, bridges, and public libraries. The second part of the message that, he said, is to be issued in about a fortnight, will deal with the current work of city departments.

In the tournament of the Harlem Bowling League last night the Morris Club bowlers won two games, defeating the Phoenix and the Audubon teams, and thereby taking the lead in the tournament. Capt. Mc Donald of the Morris Club rolled 228 in the last game. The scores follow:

Society, which took a rest during the holidays, has resumed activities, and the week promises to be gay. Again the fact is brought to mind that New York, like London, is a very large city, and it is impossible to chronicle all the dinners, dances, and smaller entertainments among the many different sets.

Ex-Commissioner John N. Partridge talked at length last night on "The Mew York Police Department, as It Was and As It Is," before the League for Political Education. The address was listened to by an audience that crowded Berkeley Lyceum in West Forty-fourth Street, and he was interrupted several times by applause.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Mrs. Roosevelt entertained to-day at the largest afternoon reception the season has yet known, nearly 800 guests being received between 4 and 6 o' clock. For the first time the entire first floor was thrown open to the visitors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Minister Bowen's advices from Caracas show that conditions there are very much disturbed; that internal revolutionary troubles have intensified, and that President Castro is sorely beset.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 5 -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court in Philadelphia, reversing the decision of Judge McClung of Allegheny County, which granted the Carnegie and Western Railroad the right to enter Pittsburg without the consent of Councils, has stopped all work in Pittsburg. The road is the Allegheny County extension of the Wabash Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- Twenty-two men, all but one of whom were employed in and about the coal mines, appeared before the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission at its first sessions in this city today and recited the oft-told tales of persecution they and others underwent during the late coal strike because they chose to work rather than join the strikers.

DELHI, India, Jan. 6. -- The State ball following the Durbar, which was held tonight in the palace of the Grand Mogul, proved to be one of the most attractive features of the Durbar festivities. The European dance among the columns and pillars of the palace was a strange and wonderful sight.

The protectionist Senators will be put to a cruel test during the debate on the bills to remove the duty on anthracite coal. How they will bear it, how they will behave under the searchlight, was foreshadowed by a remark made on Monday by Senator ORVILLE H. PLATT of Connecticut.

A. L. Mordecai Son have sold for the Long Acre Realty Company two adjoining plots, each 40 by 100.5, on the north side of Forty-seventh Street, just east of Long Acre Square, one covering Nos. 149 and 151 and the other Nos. 153 and 155. The purchaser in either case is a, builder, and both plots will be improved by the erection of nine-story apartment hotels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Russian Ambassador, Count Cassini, and Countess Marguerite Cassini celebrated Christmas to-day according to the Russian calendar. Count Cassini invited several Russians temporarily residing in Washington to share the Embassy dinner with his official family.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 6. -- Sensational developments to-day again caused a postponement in the passing of sentence on Dr. Charles C. Hendrick and Samuel Stanton, ex-Justice of the Peace, convicted of conspiring with Laura Biggar to get the entire estate of the late Henry M. Bennett, whom the woman claimed as her husband.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 6. -- Joseph B. Bechtel of Chicago and Miss Imogene Van Vechten of Trenton were married at the First Presbyterian Church parsonage to-day by the Rev. Dr. Frederick F. Stanley. The wedding is the culmination of a chance meeting in this city several years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Bids for the construction of two first-class armored cruisers, the Tennessee and the Washington, to cost in the neighborhood of $4,500,000 each, were opened at the Navy Department to-day, in the presence of representatives of nearly every shipbuilding concern or note in the country, together with a host of sub-contractors who supply structural material for the big ships.

Almost simultaneously Charles Honeymeter, a job printer, and his eighteen-year-old daughter, Jennie, were found in antipodal sections of the city yesterday -- the girl dead and the man dying. She was lying on a bed in a squalid rear room at 228 East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Honeymeter in the entrance to the printing establishment of B.H. Tyrell Co., at 129 Fulton Street, where he had been employed for twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Attorney General Knox has addressed identical letters to Senator Hear. Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Representative Littlefield, Chairman of the sub-committee of the House Judiciary Committee, giving his views on the subject of trusts. These letters are in reply to communications sent him by Senator Hoar and Mr. Littlefield, asking the view of Mr. Knox.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Attorney General John Cunncen received to-day the recommendation of the Grand Jury of Kings County that he institute proceedings to annul the charter of the street railway companies forming the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system. The recommendation is as follows:

The crowing, cackling, and peeping of 5,000 chicks, hens, and roosters; the cooing of as many pigeons, the quacking of ducks, hissing of geese, gobbling of turkeys, the chattering of parrots, and singing of tropical and domestic birds announced to the world yesterday morning the opening of the fourteenth annual exhibition by the New York Poultry, Pigeon, and Pel Stock Association in Madison Square Garden.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- In an effort to avoid payment of a judgment of $6,495, obtained oy George Salem, a golf caddy, whome he struck in the face with a golf stick, David Fleming of 115 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia, will remain for six months within the jail limits of Elizabethtown, Essex County.

Miss Evelyn Burden, daughter of I. Townsend Burden, was severely burned about the feet and ankles at the Burden residence, 5 East Twenty-sixth Street, yesterday morning, by the overturning of an alcohol lamp which set fire to the house. Her maid, Gurda Fargequist, who attempted to extinguish the flames, was also badly burned, and was rescued by Policeman McKay of the Tenderloin Station, who distinguished himself by an act of daring gallantry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Southerners here now admit that the race question in the South seems to be again in full life and vigor. This view is borne out by information that has been received here indicating that active resentment of President Roosevelt's recent action on this problem has taken form.

The attitude of the representatives of the Merchants' Association of New York before the State Railroad Commission at its meeting on Tuesday last, and again yesterday, in refusing to appear as complainants and declining to produce witnesses to be examined and cross-examined, seems to have been generally misunderstood.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company among the more important matters to be brought up for consideration will be an increase of the capital stock of the company, an increase of the bonded indebtedness, and the acquisition of the corporate property and franchises of railroad companies.

There was a further expansion yesterday of stock speculation on the bull side. Transactions exceeded a million shares, and in spite of many sales for realizing profits, prices made remarkable gains, closing generally at the top figures for the day. Only about 30 of the 170 issues traded in closed with net declines.
ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The Republican Senatorial caucus this evening nominated the following officers:

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 6. -- Miss Ruth' Sears Baker, daughter of Edwin Howard Baker of the firm of Bliss, Fabyan Co. of New York, and John. Teele Pratt, a Brooklyn lawyer and millionaire, were married at the Second Congregational Church this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 . -- At the Clearing House balances between the banks loaned at 5 per cent, and New York funds sold at 16 2-3c per $1, 000 premium. The exchanges were $27,416,371 against $25,109,810 a year ago to-day an increase of $2,306,761, or 9 per cent., and the balances were $2,330,497 Call loans, 6@7 time money, 3@6: commercial paper 3 1/2@7.

SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 6. -- An injunction was served yesterday on the Bostonian Opera Company by Manager John Coot of the Northwestern Theatrical Association, to prevent that organization sailing from Vancouver on the steamer Miowera Jan. 9 for Australia.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Eighty-seven Republican Assemblymen caucused in the Assembly Chamber to-night for the purpose of selecting candidates for Speaker and other officers of the Assembly. There were two absent Assemblymen -- Gratton of Albany and Dowling of Kings.

The conditions existing in the anthracite coal trade are difficult of comprehension unless it is assumed that the coal roads and the independent operators are working at cross purposes and that the former are afraid to do anything to check or restrain the mercenary spirit which prompts the latter to take the largest advantage possible of the exigency of the demand to charge for coal whatever they can get.

A mass meeting of residents of the upper west side, held last night in the Assembly Hall of St. Michael's Memorial Parish House, 225 West Ninety-ninth Street, under the direction of the Independent Club, brought out with increased emphasis the protests against the crowded condition of surface and elevated cars.

There is a strong possibility that the owners of small boats racing on Newark Bay, more popularly known as the mosquito fleet yachtsmen, will join the Pavonia Yacht Club of Bayonne this season, thus contributing toward the establishment of a large and prosperous yachting centre in the Bayonne locality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. G. -- In the Senate Senator Hoar made his promised speech in explanation of the elaborate Trust bill which he has introduced. He was listened to with the profound attention from his fellow-Senators that is always accorded his utterances on any public question, but there was no applause to break on the finished periods of the speech.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 6. -- At the conclusion of its first day's business the Fidelity Title and Trust Company, a bank recently organized here, took in deposits amounting to $139,000. Aside from its regular banking business, the company will guarantee real estate titles in Connecticut, an enterprise that has only been recently conducted in this state.

The United States Steel Corporation yesterday made public its preliminary annual statement for the year ended Dec. 31 last. The statement does not permit of comparisons with the previous year, as the fiscal year was changed in May last so as to make it end with the calendar year instead of on March 31.

We have at last the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States that the Treasury Department is within the law in the little tariff war started over the importation of sugar from Russia on which it was contended that an indirect bounty had been paid. We have never at any time thought that the decision would be different.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- Activity and strength increased in the local market today, Lehigh Valley being a, feature, advancing to 39 5/8, its highest price since 1895 when it sold at 43. The buying is rumored to be for the Pennsylvania Railroad, which is said to have arranged with J. P. Morgan to have control of the property turned over to it.

At the hc-arhis before the Railroad Commission in Brooklyn yesterday the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company assumed the attitude of a much-persecuted corporation. For six hours the commission listened to testimony by citizens with complaints against the road, and the road itself made reply through a formal statement and through a speech by ex-Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan of counsel for the company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The following officeis will report to the department commanders indicated for assignment to stations and duty pending the arrival of their regiments in the United States:

The adjourned conference between the officials of the Union Pacific Railroad and the representatives of the striking machinists, boilermakers, and blacksmiths in the shops of the company at Omaha, Neb., which took place in this city yesterday resulted, contrary to expectation, in another dead-lock.

John N. Golding has sold for the estate of Henry G. Marquand the plot, 50 by 100.5, on the north side of Sixty-eighth Street, at the rear of the Marquand residence, which stands at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. The lots have been purchased by John J. Emery, whose house at 5 East Sixty-eighth Street occupies the adjoining fifty-foot frontage to the west.

The Board of Trade and Transportation at its annual meeting approved the inland or Mohawk-Seneca route, for a 1,000-ton barge canal in preference to the Ontario route, and discussed immigration, street signs, and urban car traffic. In the absence of President Oscar S. Straus, who has illness in his family.

DELHI, India, Jan. 7 -- The Viceroy, Lord Curzon of Kedleston, and Lady Curzon and the Duke and Duchess of Connaught today reviewed the retainers of the ruling Chiefs in the Durbar arena. The variety of costume and paraphernalia afforded one of the most striking pictures of the Durbar festivities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A throng of persons of note assembled this afternoon to attend the ceremonies incident to the dedication of the Washington Public Library. The participants in the exercises included the President of the United States and Andrew Carnegie, the donor of the building.

W.M.V. Huffman has called the attention of the Directors of the National Horse Show Association to the fact that a first prize in thr recent Madison Square Garden show was unduly awarded, but owing to the late date at which the statements were presented to the Directors, there is little likelihood that any change will be made in the original official awards.

The death of Gen. EARLE, the owner of what is much belittled by being called "the Jumel mansion," makes a municipal concern of the future of that dwelling house. We say it is belittled by its popular and current appellation, not only because it is much older than the appellation would give it credit for being, but also because it was much more dignified and important.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -- It was announced to-night by the Yale baseball management that Dr. W.H. Murphy of the class of 93, will be the head coach of the baseball squad during the coming season.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 -- The merger of the Consolidation Coal Company of Maryland, the Fairmont Company of West Virginia, and the Somerset Company of Pennsylvania, controlling the most extensive soft-coal interests along the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, means that the railroad and the operators, with which it has close relations, are preparing to oppose the Gould interests in the soft-coal fields of the same States.

Police Commissioner Greene yesterday reorganized the Detective Bureau, consolidating the Manhattan and the Brooklyn offices under the general supervision of Inspector Nicholas Brooks. In Mulberry Street Capt. Titus was deposed and sent to do precinct duty at the Oak Street Station. He is succeeded by Capt. Langan, who got his commission only yesterday morning.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- The money market continues to work easier, though rates are not appreciably lower. The situation is considerably easier than it was expected to be so early in the year. Call loans, 6 per cent.: time loans, collateral, 5 1/2 per cent; time loans, mercantile paper, 5 @ 5 1/2 per cent; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.: New York funds 162-3@13 cents premium: Clearings, $26,022,372; balance, 1,517,725.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From time to time large sums of money have been expended in trying to prevent the erosion of our coasts, especially on the sandy beaches of Long and Coney Islands by the erection and repairing of sea walls. The money might just as well be pitched directly into the sea.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- There was less snap to the demand for the local issues today, and many of them suffered declines, although in most cases the losses were trivial. An exception was Welsbach 5s, which were sold at 59, a loss of 10 3/4 points from last previous sales. The common stock, which sold some time ago at 33, was offered at 27, without a buying order appearing.

Capt. Miles O'Reilly of the Tenderloin yesterday, instead of sending his new wardmen out to study suspected places in their own way, drew them up in military formation and led them himself to these resorts, with a uniformed detail bringing up the rear. Consternation marked their advance through the precinct, and at every corner sharp-eyed men and boys rushed on ahead to spread the tidings.

As a result of a movement by certain politicians to prevent President Louis FHaffen of the Borough of The Bronx from altering the Van Wyck administration's map of proposed street layouts, Justice Leventritt of the Supreme Court decided yesterday that Mr. Haffen could not make changes arbitrarily.

It was reported yesterday that the Interborough Rapid Transit Company had reached a decision not to purchase and lease the plot of land between One Hundred and Forty-first and One Hundred and Forty-fifth Streets, Lenox Avenue, and the Harlem River to the American League for use next season as a baseball ground and that this action rendered the American, League virtually powerless to hold games on Manhattan Island next season.

Those who deny -- as many gas engineers and some fire underwriters do -- that the leakage of gas mains into the ground is attended with appreciable danger to life and property, either do not read the newspapers or prefer to overlook the almost daily evidence of the fallacy of their contention furnished by the uninterrupted succession of accidents due to this cause.

Gov. ODELL'S message gives proof that the minds of men and of Governors are fallible. Four years ago the Legislature enacted a franchise tax law. THEODORE ROOSEVELT, who was then Governor of New York, enthusiastically approved the principle of the law, called the Legislature in special session to remedy its glaring defects as first passed, and, as we believe, viewed it with pride as one of the chief monuments of his administration.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Politicians in Albany are centring their attention to-night on the message of the Governor. His advocacy of the repeal of the present franchise tax law, his position on the canals, and his recommendations regarding the Police and Fire Departments in New York City and the primary law have chiefly attracted attention.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Odell's annual message was read in both houses of the Legislature to-day. It was as follows:

The Hispano-American Club, an association of Spanish-American and descendants of Spanish-Americans, the object of which is to promote and encourage the reading and study on the Western Hemisphere of Spanish literature, was organized last evening. The club is non-political and of a social character.

There are many events for to-day, but several of them appeal only to certain sets, and there will be little conflicts Mrs. Gerry's musicale, preceded by a dinner, is to be the most notable entertainment. It is to be for the very fashionable set, and many of the guests are to be married people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt had a conference to-day with Speaker Henderson and Representative Grosvenor of Ohio, with regard to proposed "anti-trust legislation." The conference lasted for a considerable time, the situation in the House being discussed thoroughly.

United States Customs inspectors, aided by policemen from the Old Slip and Church Street Stations, made seizures on Monday of Holland gin in bottles at various saloons in Washington, West, South and Front Streets. Every bottle of Holand gin of the "keg" brand was confiscated, the customs inspectors claiming that they had been smuggled into the country in a novel manner.

Stocks lower. Money easy, 3 @ 5 1/2 per cent. on call. The reaction in the stock market yesterday was not unnatural after the recent sharp advances. The general desire to realize profits would of itself have probably produced the reaction, but in addition to this the market was depressed by heavy London selling, estimated at more than 60,000 shares.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Both houses of the Legislature met and formally organized to-day, and the lawmaking of the year began. Outside of the Governor's message interest centred in the Republican bolt in the Senate. The organization state went through, however, by a majority of one. The organization of the Assembly was lacking in unusual incident.

Thanks to the fact that the "deal" of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company involves an exchange of lots separated only by a narrow street, and not an out-and-out sale, the question of "unearned increment" as related to property exempt from taxation is considerably complicated, and the transaction will not be discussed as much or in the same way as was that of the Broadway Tabernacle people.

It was learned yesterday that four witnesses, examined before Justice Wyatt in the "John Doe" proceedings, had testified that they visited the Canfield gambling establishment as recently as the evening of Nov. 26, the day before Thanksgiving, and played both faro and roulette under Mr. Canfield's management.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The non-union men continue to occupy the attention of the coal strike commission, in presenting evidence of lawlessness in the anthracite coal region during the strike. The testimony included many acts of violence from murder down to plain assault and petty larceny. Dynamite played a leading part in the alleged persecution of non-union men and their relatives.

The interesting quarterly statement of the United States Steel Corporation will be likely to suggest to the average reader some instructive comparisons. If we compare the liabilities of the corporation as represented by outstanding bonds and stock with the national debts of great powers, we find that its capitalization of $1,322,250,300 is larger than the national debt of any nation except France, the German States, Italy, Russia, Spain, and the United Kingdom.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Heavy repayments to the Bank of England decreased the supplies of money in the market to-day, and there was less eagerness manifested to offer the surplus available. Discounts, consequently, hardened.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations took up the Cuban reciprocity treaty to-day and devoted the session to a discussion of its features. No opposition to the trade concessions proposed was developed and the session was without incident or occurrence that in any way augured difficulty for the friends of the treaty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- There was a long conference this afternoon between Senator Aldrich, Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Chairman Payne of the Ways and Means Committee, and Representative Dalzell, a member of that committee, on the proposition to remove the duty on coal.
Brokers usually identified with interests close to the management were the largest buyers of Illinois Central, but the action of the stock suggested that no public following was desired at present.

The entries so far received for two of next season's big turf events exceed in number the previous year's nominations for the same races. H.D. McIntyre, Secretary of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, made public yesterday the entries for the Brooklyn Handicap to be run this Spring on the opening day of the forthcoming meeting of that club.

Cats were the feature yesterday at the New York Poultry and Pigeon Association's annual show in the Madison Square Garden. The exhibit of felines in the concert hall of the garden, under the auspices of the Atlantic Cat Club, was opened in the morning, and for the greater part of the day the room was crowded with lovers of these familiar household pets.

During a fire which destroyed the home of Lieut. William Miller of Engine Company No. 45, at Daly Avenue and One Hundred and Eighty-first Street, in the Bronx, late yesterday afternoon, Matilda Miller, nineteen years old, the fireman's daughter, was rescued while unconscious by Miss Grace Anderson, her music teacher, who also helped out Margaret Miller.

A speedy repetition of the performance of "Tristan und Isolde," given last Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, was a foregone conclusion from the great public interest that was manifested in it and the somewhat unexpected success of Mr. Anthes, the new Tristan, and hence of the performance as a whole.

The Coroners of the Borough of Manhattan gathered in solemn conclave at high noon yesterday to dispose of charges pending against Dr. Albert T. Weston, one of their physicians. In the course of a stormy session that followed an-open break in the hitherto unanimous Board developed and when the smoke of battle had cleared away the Coroners found that they still had Dr. Weston on their staff.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Helen Marion Finlay, a golden-haired baby girl, the four-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J.M. Finlay, residents of the Corcoran Manor section of this city, was murdered this morning in the home of her parents by a coachman who had been in the employ of Mr. Finlay, Albert King, the murderer, after he had almost severed the child's head, went into another room and shot himself in the head.

First Lieut. Stuart Heintzelman, Sixth Cavalry, will proceed to St. Louis and report to Major Edward A. Goodwin. Tenth Cavalry, for duty upon the arrival of his regiment in the United States, when he will join it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The House to-day passed the Philippine Constabulary bill, with an amendment limiting the number of assistant chiefs to four.

The wild stories from Albany about a plot to prevent the re-election of the Hon. THOMAS C. PLATT to the United States Senate have not caused the old Senator to lose a wink of sleep. Good men, knowing what a lot of evil there is in the world, and feeling the insecurity of their position, are often timid and troubled when their foes whisper together in groups of two and three.

Stocks strong. Money easy, 3 1/2@5 per cent, on call. The dissolution of the $50.000,000 bank pool to relieve the tight money situation, which was announced yesterday afternoon, was perhaps the most suggestive incident of the day in Wall Street.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Rates for money hardened in the market to-day, owing to the heavy depletion of supplies. Discounts were firm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The statement of the Pall Mall Gazette cabled to-day, to the effect that the cotton crop reports of the Department of Agriculture are not believed and are regarded as worthless, and also that the crop reports generally of the department are a scandal, is denounced at the Department as a falsehood intended to discredit the reports in order to influence the market.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 8 -- Andrew J. Coakley, for two years pitcher on the Holy Cross baseball team, announced to the faculty to-day that he was a professional, having played several games last season with the Philadelphia Athletics under an assumed name. This will debar him from playing with his college team next Spring.

DERBY, Conn., Jan. 8 -- William Ambrose, a saloon keeper of Union City, near here, preferred exposure to smallpox to arrest by United States Deputy Marshal William L. Parmelee yesterday. When the Marshal appeared with a warrant, charging violation of the internal revenue law, Ambrose took refuge in the rooms of a quarantined smallpox patient.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Judge Charles E. Parker, Presiding Judge of the Appellate Division of the Third Department, who arrived here to-day for the opening of the court to-morrow, to-night authorized this statement:
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Vesta Tilley, the music hall actress, has signed a contract to appear in New York during the Autumn in a comedy written by Brandon Thomas and Raiph Caine, son of Hall Caine.

CARACAS, Jan. 8 -- It has been learned from an authoritative source that United States Minister Bowen has received orders to leave Venezuela next Saturday for Washington, where he will present the Venezuelan case to the British-German Commission. An American warship will call for Mr. Bowen at La Guayra.

Price movements in the outside market yesterday were somewhat irregular, but on the whole the pet results of the day's operations were favorable. Standard Oil dropped down 5 points more, and several declines appeared elsewhere in the list, but these were more than offset by the gains which were made by Interborough Rapid Transit, Havana Tobacco, and other stocks.

In a hockey game which was replete with accidents the New York Athletic Club team defeated the picked seven of the St. Nicholas Skating Club at the St. Nicholas Rink last night by a score of 5 goals to 1.

PRETORIA, Transvaal, Jan. 8 -- A meeting of influential burghers yesterday drafted an address for presentation to Colonial Secretary Chamberlain and the Legislative Council embodying the views of the leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The departure of Dr. Von Holleben, the German Ambassador, for Germany on Saturday next is sincerely regretted here. The Ambassador has been confined to his room for several days with a severe attack of grip, and has been granted a long vacation to recruit his health.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Mr. Jenkins, Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, introduced late this afternoon two bills drawn by Attorney General Knox to regulate trusts. He explained that these measures were administration propositions, and would be taken up by the committee and considered at once.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- The principal feature of the proceedings before the Coal Strike Commission to-day was the exception taken by President Mitchell to a remark made by Chairman Gray that he would like to see the Miners' Union come up out of the mire that is around the baser parts of it into the sunlight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The determination has been reached by the President and his advisers to accede to the wishes of Great Britain and Germany in regard to the "open door" in the Philippines. The request was recently made by those Governments with special reference to the removal of the export duties in Philippine ports on cargoes of hemp.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Because or a misapprehension regarding the recently issued report of State Superintendent of Banks Kilburn, a run occurred to-day on the Schenectady Savings Bank, one of the oldest and most conservative banking institutions in the State. The demonstration was confined practically to foreign-speaking persons.

The following-named Second Lieutenants will report to Major Robert H.R. Loughborough, Sixth Infantry, President of the examining board at Port Leavenworth, for examination for promotion: Donald C. McClelland, Eighteenth Infantry; Charles R.W. Morson, Fifth Infantry; William B. Graham, Fifteenth Infantry; Ernest A. Juenta, First Infantry, and Douglas H. Jacobs, Fifth Cavalry.

Poultry, cats, and canaries lost none of their attractions yesterday at the annual show of the New York Poultry, Pigeon, and Pet Stock Association in the Madison Square Garden. An unusually large number of children with their mammas were present in the afternoon, and naturally the fluffy bits of life that the big incubators are now hatching out were of the greatest interest to the little ones.
