Ex-Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage declared at a dinner at the Reform Club last evening that the National bank credit system of this country was as cumbersome as the antiquated commercial methods of the Chinese, and that the system operated to throttle and kill industry at the very place where it was born -- in the farming districts.
Henry D. Winans May have sold for August Heckscher to Joseph Fox, President of the Columbia Bank, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling, with extension, 17 West Fifty-sixth Street, 25 by 100.5.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Confirmation was received here to-night of the reports from Caracas to the effect that all barriers in the way of a settlement of the claims of Great Britain, Germany, and Italy against Venezuela had been removed by the lastnamed country yielding to the demands of the European allies.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 8 -- President Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad officially confirmed the published report of the purchase for his company of stock in the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and the later reported sale of a part of that stock through the Pennsylvania Company to the Vanderbilt interests.

Mr. Arnold Dolmetsch, with the assistance of Mrs. Dolmetsch and their pupil, Miss Mabel Johnston, gave a further exposition yesterday of the nature and effects of the archaic musical instruments. It was in the form of a lecture delivered in the Manhattan Theatre, with a large number of musical illustrations.

That the Vanderbilt interests had taken a half share of the stock of the Reading Company held by the Baltimore and Ohio for the Pennsylvania Railroad was reported at various times during the last three months, but that this purchase had been actually completed was officially confirmed yesterday for the first time by President Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and was also semi-officially confirmed in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day took favorable action upon an amendment to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill suggested by Senator Lodge appropriating $2,500,000 for the purchase of draught animals for the Filipinos, who lost their stock by disease. The measure was prepared in response to a suggestion by Gov. Taft.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Gov. Odell will go to New York to-morrow. He will attend the conference called by Senator Platt to meet in his rooms at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Saturday to decide finally upon the committee assignments for the Senate and Assembly.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 -- Gannon's ride of Major Mansir, the favorite, and Redfern's judgment in placing Warranted tell the story of the Jackson Handicap, the feature of to-day's card, and a race worth $1.430 to the winner. Carl Kahler and L'Etrenne were the winning favorites. The former was run up to $2,005 and bought in.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Attorney General John Cumeen to-day received from District Attorney Jerome of New York County a request that he take charge of the prosecution in the trial of Police Inspector Brooks of the New York police force, who is charged with illegally entering the house of Richard Canfield, where gambling was supposed to be in progress.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Therese Humbert was interrogated to-day for the first time since her arrest. The questioning was conducted by M. Leydu, Judge of Instruction. Mme. Humbert traversed the courtyard of the prison to the underground passage leading to the Judge's chambers with a proud and energetic bearing.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Right Rev. Dr. Randall Thomas Davidson, Bishop of Winchester since 1895, has been appointed Archbishop of Canterbury, in succession to the Most Rev. Dr. Temple, who died Dec. 23.

As a sequel to the inquest into the death of Leonard F. Roos, the wealthy Fifth Avenue art dealer, which was concluded yesterday, Coroner Jackson ordered the arrest of Michael Timpano, a Deputy Sheriff from Brooklyn; Louis J. Somerville, a lawyer of 110 Nassau Street, and Miss Elien Long, who were with him when Roos died.

DELHI, India, Jan. 8 -- The review to-day by the Viceroy of India, Lord Curzon of Kedleston, of 30,000 British and native troops, led by Lord Kitchener, was the last important event of the coronation Durbar.

The most important development in respect to the money market situation yesterday was the announcement that the $50,000,000 money pool formed some weeks ago to finance the end-of-the-year settlements has been dissolved, the managers agreeing that the necessity no longer existed for the maintenance of the pool.

ADA, Ohio, Jan. 8. -- Three men dead and fourteen or more other persons injured, one fatally, is the result of a collision between two trains on the Pennsylvania system, on the main street of this city at 5 o'clock this evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency to-day authorized Chairman Fowler to press for an opportunity to bring before the House for consideration the Currency bill introduced by him in accordance with the views of the Republican members of the committee.

At the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in the headquarters at Madison Avenue and Tweniy-sixth Street yesterday afternoon reports were presented by the President, John P. Haines, and the Secretary, John Mason Knox. The President noted a substantial growth in membership and activities.

On Sunday evening a citizen wandered through the convenient "side door" into a saloon which was doing business in violation of law with very little effort at concealment. It was not a hotel and had no cafe attachment. The perfunctory sandwich was not even kept in evidence.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Strong commendation of the receivership law of 1902 is a feature of the report of John C. Davies, the retiring Attorney General. Some twenty receiverships of banking and insurance companies have been determined under its provisions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The demand for an increase in pay of the engineers and firemen of the Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad has been acted on and they will receive from 10 to 12 1/2 per cent, increase. General Manager Cramer of the railroad men's organization, who presented the petition to the company, left here last night for his home in St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries to-day directed that a resolution be introduced asking the House to authorize the committee to investigate the entire subject of coal transportation. The scope of the resolution, it is understood, will embrace land and water transportation.

An echo of the failure of Marquand Co., which-brought about the collapse of the Seventh National Bank in June, 1901, resounded through Wall Street yesterday, when it became known that George W. Wickersham was holding a fund of $100,000 for distribution to certain creditors of the firm which had been raised by relatives of H. Marquand and Frank B. Poor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Vest's resolution to instruct the Senate Finance Committee to report a bill to remove the tariff on anthracite coal caused a spirited partisan debate in the Senate to-day. In the course of it the Republicans endeavored to show that the Democrats deliberately left a duty on coal in the Wilson bill.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- Sales of stocks on the local exchange to-day aggregated 54,429 shares; and of this number 33,347 shares were furnished by the anthracite coal stocks. Reading leading with sales of 17,150 shares. A feature was the trading in Erie common, which is not listed here; nevertheless sales amounted to 8,500 shares.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 8 -- The Grand American Handicap shoot at inanimate targets will be held in Kansas City April 14, 15, 16, and 17, at Blue River Shooting Park, arrangements for the grounds having been completed to-day by Elmer E. Shaner, Secretary and manager of the Inter-State Shooting Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs to-day authorized a favorable report on Senator Proctor's bill, which provides for the retirement of army officers who served in the civil war, with advanced rank.

The situation of the retail trade in anthracite coal in this market admits of no logical explanation or statistical warrant. The price charged by the retailer is maintained for no other or better reason than that he can get it, and that he has no competition in distribution. For the coal supplied by the carrying companies from their own mines he pays $5 per ton at wharf.

"The people are learning of the imminent danger to the commerce of the State in the elimination of the Erie Canal as a competitor of the railroads," says Mr. H.B. HEBERT, Chairman of the Canal Association of Greater New York.

The Yankee schooner Jennie A. Stubbs arrived here yesterday from Baracoa with 100,000 cocoanuts and one mutineer in irons. The mutineer, whose name is James Lilii, stole the Captain's revolver while the schooner was in the West Indies, and reinforced himself with a harpoon, the ship's grains, and a broadaxe.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The Chicago delegation to the peace conference between the National and American Baseball Leagues left for Cincinnati to-night, where the conference will begin to-morrow. The American League was represented by President Ban Johnson, Charles A. Comiskey, and Henry Killilea.

It was learned on the best of authority last night that District Attorney Jerome has recalled the subpoena he at one time issued for Reginaid C. Vauderbilt. The young millionaire, who is just now preparing for his approaching marriage to Miss Kathleen Ncilson and will not return to this city until the time set for that event, is no longer wanted as a witness in the Canfield proceedings.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- School District No. 1, White Plains, is to receive the Wadsworth Prize of $100 for the best-kept school grounds in the State. The second prize, $50, has been awarded to District No. J. Mexico. Oswego County. These prizes are offered by William A. Wadsworth of Geneva and are awarded through the State Department of Public Instruction.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 8 -- The coal situation in Toledo has reached the point where a physician's certificate is required by local coal dealers before they will sell even a ton of coal.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Rates for money were firm to-day; there was a growing scarcity of supplies and borrowers again were dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were affected by the state of the market, and caused a hardening of rates on the Continental Exchanges.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mistakes regarding this little poem have several times been corrected by as competent an authority as the late Horatio Hale of Clinton, Ontario, Canada, whom Max Muller called the Nestor of American philology.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- Ambassador von Hoileben was not recalled form Washington, but, learning that his Government was not wholly satisfied with his work and feeling ill and depressed, he cabled for a long leave of absence, which was immediately granted. He will not return to Washington.

Henry D. Winans May have sold for the J. C. Lyons Building and Operating Company the plot 51.10 by 100.5 at 9 and 11 East Eighty-sixth Street. This is the sixth time that this property has changed hands within a few months. The buyer in the present transaction is said to be a prominent banker, who will erect a handsome residence on the site.

Poultry fanciers at the annual show of poultry, pigeons, and pet stock, which will end this evening at the Madison Square Garden, are all well satisfied with the awards made during the last three days. The officials of the New York Poultry, Pigeon, and Pet Stock Association also are pleased with the results as this year's show has proved to be a greater success financially than any of its predecessors.

-- Well-founded as is the general objection expressed in Gov. ODELL'S message to the constant increase in the number of statutes relating to special places or small classes, one cannot help thinking that if he had given a little more thought to the matter he would not have made the suggestion he did in regard to the game laws of the State.

CARACAS, Jan. 9 -- The port of Tucacas was reoccupied yesterday by forces of the Venezuelan Government after, a fight with the revolutionists of one hour's duration. Tucacas, which is about forty miles northwest of Puerto Cabello, has been occupied for the last four months by the revolutlonists.
SUBJECT -- Paul at Thessalonica and Berea. Acts xvii., 1-12.

It is a very striking new departure for the venerable and youthful North American Review to go publishing serial fiction. Not, of course, that it is any necessary derogation of the function of a political and commercial guide, philosopher, and friend to publish fiction, provided the fiction be serious enough, but that it is traditionally construed to be so in England and what Mr. Brownell calls "its literary dependency, ourselves."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- After occupying eight days, during which time they presented about 150 witnesses, the non-union men, who are a party to the arbitration agreement, closed their case to-day before the Coal Strike Commission.

Dr. John J. Dooling, a prominent physician of the Bedford district of Brooklyn, who lives at 256 Tompkins Avenue, has asked the police of that borough to hunt for a man who married a woman under the doctor's name, and thereby caused the latter much trouble. Dr. Dooling is a bachelor.

Many people think that the turning of immigrants into Americans in one or two generations is a comparatively new thing. It went on from the days of the earliest settlements here. Yet there is no denying the fact that political and social assimilation is now taking place more quickly and on a far larger scale than ever before, and presenting new problems which the statesman and sociologist must take into account.

Extremely high prices were realized at Sothoby's sale of Dec. 20, when a large pumber of interesting relics, drawings, and autograph letters of W. M. Thackeray were sold. All the items disposed of were formerly the property of the late Miss Kale Perry and her sister, Mrs. Elliot, (nee Jane Perry.) the intimate friends of Thackeray.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 9 -- The baseball peace conference began here this afternoon between the committees appointed by the National and American Leagues. When the rival representatives began the executive session the following were present: Messrs. Herrmann. Robison, Hart, and Pulliam of the National League, and Johnson, Comiskey, Killilea, and Somers of the American League.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 9 -- There was a maintenance of the steady tone in the local market to-day, resulting in some issues attaining a better level. Fidelity and Deposit was higher, showing a gain for the week of about seven points. This is ascribed not only to the good report of the company, but also to its fullness of detail in form. Continental recovered another point of its recent decline.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have been waiting for some one better Qualified than 1 to give the true meaning of "Hoboken" as a Dutch word. As, however, no one seems to be forthcoming, and as Mr. Remingion is anxious to close the discussion, you will perhaps grant me a little space in your columns to break a lance in its favor.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 - The State's Attorney, in the course of his petition to Judge McEwen for a special Grand Jury, says:

Bags that are pretty to see and also useful are for soiled handkerchiefs, collars, darning cottons -- anything useful. They are made of a heavy scrim, some in cream, some white and others in a plaided scrim. A broad band at the bottom of each is of a bright colored cretonne find the inside of the top where the bag is drawn is faced with the same material.

Mr. Pigott took up the studies of ornithology and entomology for no ulterior scientific purpose, but as a needed avocation, a relief from the hard routine of professional toil. He made observation of birds and bugs his Hobby with a capital "H." He noticed those around him, in his daily walks, and London with its chain of notable parks and its multitude of little green squares is almost as full of birds as of bugs.

THIS is the fifth edition of Clarence King's "Mountaineering in the Sierra Nevada," the single volume the of literary work which this strong and gifted man permitted himself, in his active career as a scientist.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- State Controller Miller, it is understood, will recommend to the Legislature an amendment to the tax of the surplus and the undivided earnings of the savings banks, which is found to bear more heavily on small banks than large, so that the burden shall fall equally on all banks.

ONE of Andrew Jackson's biographers (Amos Kendali) remarks that "Gen. Jackson founded a new political school in the United States." With all deference to Mr. Kendall's skill in political management and his aptness as a party organizer, we must question the accuracy of his estimate of the relation that Jackson bore to the events of his time.
Capt. Perry L. Miles, Fourteenth Infantry, will proceed to West Point, N.Y., for duty at the Military Academy.

Mr. Carlo de Fornaro, in the volume of caricatures, entitled "Millionaires of America." issued by the Medusa Publishing Company of New York, some of which were executed by Max Cramer de Pourtales, takes pains to print in a conspicuous place in tne front of the volume the following notice.

At a meeting of the Retail Cigar and Tobacco Dealers' Association in Maennerchor Hall 203 East Fifty-sixth Street, last evening, a communication that proposed National legislation was received with hearty applause and was put in the form of a resolution to be sent to President Roosevelt and the Attorney General after it has been submitted to the attorney for the organization.

To say that it is indispensable is perhaps the highest praise we can accord to the almanac annually published by our neighbor, The World. The issue for 1902 is up to the high standard of fullness and accuracy which have characterized its predecessors, and we observe the inclusion of new features and matters not appearing in preceding issues.

When Mr. Lee's article on Queen Victoria appeared in "The Dictionary of National Biography," the public recognized it as the first serious attempt to arrange the data of her life and services in a comprehensive manner, and with intelligent, although brief, comment. Owing to the limitations of the "Dictionary," however, it was impossible to present an exhaustive account of the events which underlie on every side the action and altitude of the Queen.

So much is written about Washington's public life that many people do not know what a great business man he was in private, the extent of his commercial operations, the variety of agricultural products and manufactures which engaged his attention, and the close study he gave to material progress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The House Naval Committee to-day voted against reporting the bill to place Capt. Richmond Hobson on the retired list. There was a bare quorum present and the vote stood four yeas to five nays.

At least ten burglaries, committed within less than two months in the block bounded by Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets. Fifth and Sixth Avenues, have alarmed the wealthy families living there. The mysterious robberies have continued despite all the extra guards and precautions that could be taken.

At a meeting of the Stewards of The Jockey Club, held at the office of August Belmont, 23 Nassau Street, yesterday, two matters of great interest to horsemen and horse owners all over the United States and Canada were disposed of. These were the appointment of racing officials and the allotment of racing dates for the season of 1903.

The Appellate Division yesterday, by a divided court, reversed Justice Hall of the Supreme Court and decided that Fire Commissioner Sturgis had authority to direct Fire Chief Croker to continue his vacation when he suddenly returned to duty last August, after having, only taken sixteen days of the ninety days' leave of absence which had been granted on his own application.

FIRST among the Harper publications for the coming year is Mrs. Humphry Ward's novel, "Lady Rose's Daughter," which, on its completion as a serial, will be issued in March in three editions-one-volume, two-volume, and an autograph two-volume edition of 350 sets.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- On the back of the title page of a new book by Mr. Laurence Housman, entitled "Of Aucassin and Nicolett," appears the announcement, by the same author," An English woman's Love Letters."

Without doubt the bill introduced into the House of Representatives by Mr. GRIFFITH, M.C. from the Fourth District of Indiana, to restrict the wealth of citizens of this Republic, is calculated to promote the grayety of nations and increase the public stock of harmless pleasure.

After having obtained a separation from Charles Bradley Adams, formerly a broker, on the ground that he had deserted her and swindled her out of $16,000, Mrs. Sarah C. Adams of this city has been served with a South Dakota divorce summons. Mrs. Adams, whose once ample fortune is a thing of the past, lives at 41 East Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The public discussion of a possible change in the standard of currency in Mexico adds interest to a statement just prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics regarding the trade relations between the United States and that country.

AMONG the Spring books will be the Rev. John White Chadwick's "William Eliery Channing," the biography of a man who began his ministry at an age when, under the present system, he would still be an undergraduate.

Stocks active, but irregular. Money easy, 4@5 per cent. on call. The movement in the stock market yesterday bore some resemblance to the active days of 1901. The volume of trading was immense. About half a million shares were dealt in during the first hour, and the total for the day exceeded a million and a half.

In her smart but sometimes flippant volume of reminiscences entitled "Celebrities and I,"Henrietta Corkran describes one of the "Sunday nights" at Dr. Westland Marston's house in London years ago. "I went." she writes, "with Mrs. Lynn Linton. The long rat-a-tat-tat was not answered with the celerity she expected.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 -- Cogswell was the only winning favorite to-day. Nettie Regent was claimed out of the last race for $725, and Cogswell, the winner, was run up to $725 and bought in. Weather fine; track fast.

Mr. OGDEN'S dinner at the Waldorf on Thursday evening and the meeting at Carnegie Hall last evening gave to the men engaged in the work of the General Education Board opportunity to review what has been done and to explain their plans for the immediate future.

The Boston Museum of Art will get several of the finest paintings of the S.D. Warren collection. It will get the top-notch picture by J.L., Gerome, "L'Eminence Grise," which was knocked down to S.P. Avery, Jr., on Thursday evening for $16,000, and it will get not only several of the finest paintings of that sale, but five of the rarest of those which were disposed of at Mendelssohn Hall last evening.

The combination of independent operators who have now control of the anthracite market in New York advanced the tidewater price of anthracite to $10.50 a ton yesterday. This virtually means the minimum price, as the tidewater price will advance with increasing cold weather to any figure any independent operator can command for the coal.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It requires a good degree of courage, perhaps even of boldness, for any one to take issue with that which appears on the editorial page of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, for the opinions there expressed are uniformly sane and usually indisputable.

The January number of The Messenger, a Catholic monthly published in this city, contains, among other readable articles, an excellent account of the new Roman Catholic Cathedral in Westminster, London, written by Thomas Henry Poole. There are a number of serviceable illustrations. This specimen of Byzantine architecture has no counterpart in Europe north of Munich or west of Russia.

In another column will be found a review of "Mountaineering in the Sierra Nevada," by the late Clarence King. The book has been out of print for a good many years, owing to the wish of the author to revise it, which, in the absorbing occupation of his professional life, he did not find time to do completely.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Mrs. Roosevelt entertained this evening at a very enjoyable musicale, at which some 200 guests were present. The artists were Mark Hambourgr, pianist, and Francis Rogers, baritone. Among the guests, in addition to the officers of the Cabinet and members of the President's official family, were Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid and the Assistant Secretary of War and Mrs. Sanger.

The eleventh annual dinner of the New York Society of Colonial Wars was held at Delmonico's last night. The ballroom was filled with members and guests, and the speakers' table had as its special adornments two models of old-time windmills, one placed at each end. The toastmaster was James W. Beekman.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 9 -- The Supreme Court to-day held that a bequest for masses and education of priests was a trust not authorized by law, in the case of William Shanahan and Bridget Walsh against James C. Kelley and others, appealing from the District Court of Houston County.

NOT so very long ago Mr. Charles H.E. Brookfield was ill, and one English newspaper commenting on him said, "Never a great actor, he was invaluable in small parts," while another remarked, "But, after all, it is at his club that he will be most missed."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- The passing of the Reading Company into the hands of the Pennsylvania and the Vanderbilts jointly has stirred up busy conjectures as to the future of the Lehigh Valley, as many reasons exist, railroad and financial men say, why the Pennsylvania and its new ally should acquire control of that road as of the Reading.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Messrs. Longmans, Green Co. will publish next month the long-expected book by the late W. H Myers, entitled "Human Personality and Its Survival of Bodily Death." It is in two volumes. The editors are Dr. Hedgson and Miss Alice Johnson.

Comparisons are invidious, but there is only one Paris. Rome is grandly imposing. Venice is superb, London, with its Tower and St. Paul's, is simply huge but without artistic qualities. "Paris n'a ete bati dans un jour," and that adage we ali appreciate. Then we know that Paris is "la ville ou l'on s'amuse."

Commissioner Greene yesterday announced that he is at work on a new patrol system for the Police Department that it is hoped will mean less hardship to the men in the ranks than the two-platoon system of Col. Partridge and afford better protection to the city than the three-platoon system of Col. Murphy, which was abolished soon after the incoming of the reform administration.

ANDREW LANG is not a syndicate, as everybody knows now, not a literary trust, not a soulless corporation organized to produce literature, but one almost wishes that he was, after reading his slighting remarks about "Little Dorrit" in his article on Dickens, a noteworthy feature of the first number of The Booklovers' Magazine.

The Board of Estimate considered the inter-borough transit problem yesterday, and discussed plans for the purchase of a large strip of land, 16 feet wide, from Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, down to the terminal of East River Bridge No. 3. The plan was put forward for the first time by Controller Grout, and several city officials thought that it would settle the difficulty of carrying passengers to Brooklyn.

Speculative sentiment was more or less disturbed during the day by the persistent liquidation and consequent decline in Reading common stock. All told, a trifle over 75,000 shares were traded in, with the price at one time breaking 3 3/4 points, and with the close showing but a fractional recovery from the low of the day.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 9 -- Pittsburg coal that has gone down the rivers to the Gulf has been sold there to be loaded for the long trip around the Atlantic coast for consumption in Boston.

Mrs. Barr has written a nice book for girls -- sweet, fresh, and pure. There is nothing improper, vulgar, or unladylike about it. Maria Semple is quite beantiful enough to be forgiven any little vanities, while Agnes Bradley is perfect beyond the dreams of perfection. The men of the story are all hottest and dountless, and the finale as happy as any one could wish.

In an article on the reproduction by the Clarendon Press of the First Folio Shakespeare, The London Times says: "As the sole surviving source of first-hand knowledge of much of Shakespeare's noblest writing it [the First Folio] has a unique claim upon our regard. Yet the authority of the volume has boon most diversely estimated.

HELENA, Mont., Jan. 9 -- Radical indeed was the action of the members of the House to-day when sixty-one of the seventy-two members decided to return the passes furnished them Thursday by the Northern Pacific Railway Company through its local counsel.

President William H. Baldwin, Jr., of the General Education Board announced at a largely attended mass meeting in Carnegie Hall last evening that within a short time an appeal would be made to the country for funds to supplement the gift of $1,000,000 of John D. Rockefeller last Spring for carrying on the work of the board.

VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 9 -- Dr. Eagan, Secretary of the British Columbia Board of Health, who went to San Francisco to investigate the reports regarding the bubonic plague, has made a report to the British Columbia Government, in which he states that a force of men is employed at San Francisco in collecting rats, and rats that have been found dead have showed plague bacilli when examined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Public opinion on the sudden departure of Dr. von Hoileben has settled down to the view that he was recalled by the Berlin Government for reasons which are apparent in the state of affairs with regard to Venezuela and also for reasons which are more remote.

BY FAR the most thorough and exhaustive, and in some respects the most startling work upon Mont Pelee which has thus far appeared is from the pen of Prof. Angelo Heilprin, who, at the time of the first cruption, showed enterprise and zeal in getting to the affected districts, and has since made a second visit, which yielded ample and unexpected material.

According to excellent authority the gambler who gave District Attorney Jerome the evidence against Richard A. Canfield's house on East Forty-fourth Street is George Clark. He is under indictment for maintaining a gambling house on West Forty-third Street, and the place was raided by Mr. Jerome before his election as District Attorney and when he was connected with the Committee of Fifteen.

The friends of the Philharmonic Society could have but rejoiced at many of the features of the fourth afternoon concert which was given yesterday afternoon. There was some of the finest playing heard in it that the orchestra has achieved in a long time: and there were a buoyancy and vitality about the performance that are what have been sorely missed and anxiously hoped for in much of the society's work in recent times.

A great many people are beginning to be apprehensive of what may follow the decision of the Anthracite Board of Arbitration. If the finding of the commission is favorable to the contention of the miners as presented in the strike issues, the discussion will be ended. The operators are bound in honor to abide by the finding of the board, and would scarcely venture to dissent therefrom in any essential particular.

The possibility of Senator Elsberg breaking away from the Senatorial combination which has created such a serious situation for the Republicans in the Legislature was the most interesting suggestion made last night in political circles in connection with the conference of Republican State leaders which Senator Platt has called to meet in his rooms at the Fifth Avenue Hotel today.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Jan. 9 -- According to United States Senator Thomas Kearns, President Roosevelt and Senator Hanna have intervened in the Utah Senatorial situation to prevent the election of Apostle Reed Smoot.

The report that Ambassador VON HOLLEBEN is to retire from his post at Washington, and probably from the German diplomatic service, will evoke expressions of sincere regret from the Ambassador's American friends, who will note with added regret, net unmixed with sympathy, the statements rather freely made here and in Germany that he has failed to please his Government or to retain its full confidence.

The story of the wanderings of the Hebrew race from the days of Abraham until the conquest of Canaan, which is one of the most impressive and dramatic in the history of the world, has now been told for young readers in a compact form by Calvin Dill Wilson and James Knapp Heeve, under the title of "The Flight of the Hebrews."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Were it not that Mrs. Gertrude Atherton, in your issue of Jan. 3, requested certain information of the writer, I would not again intrude upon the columns of your deservedly esteemed review. At first glance the impression intuitively formed might be that imparting or conveying information to Mrs. Atherton rivals in absurdity the carrying of coals to Neweastle, still, as the request has been made.

SUPPOSABLY every great river runs its course, not so much for the general purposes of nature, but for special usefulness, and that is, for the benefit of man. Rivers opened the way for trade, commerce, and-to employ a commonplace term -- for general utility.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- A feature here to-day was the heavy selling of Reading for the account of New York, over 33,000 shares being dealt in. Pronounced weakness affected Lehigh Valley, which was sold on the same theory that induced liquidation in Reading -- that, as the floating supply was in the minority, its attractiveness to operators has been materially advanced.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the death of King Victor Emmanuel II. was observed to-day by a pilgrimage to his tomb, in the Pantheon. The procession was two miles long, and 30,000 persons participated in it, including delegations from all the provinces and 1,000 veterans of the war of independence, with whom the King. Victor Emmanuel III., shook hands.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- The Cologne Gazette to-day, in an apparently inspired statement, denies that Ambassador von Holleben's retirement from Washington is connected with President Roosevelt's refusal to arbitrate the Venezuelan dispute or to the alleged ill-feeling in the United States toward Germany.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- A brilliant reception was given this week by Mrs. Dr. Clarke, in her magnificent apartment in the Avenue Henri Martin, at which Mrs. Cheatham Thompson sang with won- drous effect. Among the guests were Gen. and Mrs. Porter. Miss Griswold Gray. Mrs. Speneer, and Miss Van Bergen.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- The week's end at Tuxedo was unusual for the number of visitors, and the park, where coasting and sleighing were fine, had plenty of patrons. Usually many of the cottagers return to the city after the holidays, but this season they have remained longer than usual.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The resignation of Justice Gilbert Collins from the Supreme Court of New Jersey directs attention to the inadequacy of the salaries of the Judges in this State. Many of the most brilliant and learned members of the bar cannot afford to give up their lucrative practice for the honor of occupying the proud position of Justice of the Supreme Court.

-- Excitement of mind and vehemence of language, both carried to a considerable extent, are fully justified in discussing the conditions to which those who must use New York's present means of transportation are exposed, but it delays rather than hastens reform either to exaggerate or to misstate the nature of our troubles.

Over 400 athletes competed in the joint indoor games of the St. Bartholomew Athletic Club and the Hospital Corps of the Eighth Regiment, which were held last night in the Eighth Regiment Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue. A few weeks ago mismanagement spoiled what ought to have been a most enjoyable set of games in this armory, and last night the same state of affairs existed.

SYDNEY, Dec. 8, 1902 -- The latest available Commonwealth statistics throw some light on the course of trade between America and Australia during 1902 and indirectly indicate the possibilities of 1903.

Two skating races and a hockey game furnished amusement for a large crowd at the Clermont Avenue Rink last night. The hockey contest was between teams representing Columbia University and St. Francis Navier College. It was won by the university players, who scored 2 goals, and prevented their opponents from scoring.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter by your correspondent, Mr. Ellison, in your issue of yesterday, comes closer to hitting the nail on the head as regards the real obstacle to increasing the transportation facilities on the surface roads in this city than anything you have yet published.

Mr. George Ade's "The Sultan of Sulu" is so good, so very good, as to make one wish with all his heart, churlish as this may seem, that it had been just a little better. As a rule musical comedies are so had, so very bad, that, unlike the Kentuckians whisky, it is only a question of which is worse than others.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have noticed frequent articles both in your news columns and editorially which are devoted to the water supply question. You will surely agree with me when I say that the subject has been under discussion long enough to have produced some result other than the primitive state it occupies at the present time.

With dancing men at a higher premium than ever before, it is little wonder that the despairing hostess is seeking terpsichorean novelties in order to attract any men that still remain who have not yet deserted the ballroom for bridge.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Jan. 10 -- With the courtroom packed to the limit of its capac- ity, with people perched on windowsills and an immense throng struggling to retain positions in the remote parts of the corridors, Samuel M. Shortridge of San Francisco began the closing argument in behalf of the defendant in the Tingley-Times libel suit to-day.

TOKIO, Dec. 16 -- When one visits a decorator of satsuma in Japan, an invitation to inspect the factory almost invariably attends the first exchange of civilities. This establishment is usually an upper room, where a dozen men or less are engaged in the various processes through which the ware must pass.

Police Commissioner Greene in a two-seated automobile, and accompanied by Secretary Coursey and Inspector Brooks, made an unheralded tour of down-town station houses yesterday. In the Elizabeth Street Station House he surprised Capt. Gallagher in the act of making a raid. Gen. Greene had been in the house hardly a minute.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- Edwin J. Dunning, a State Street banker, was arrested and held in $20,000 bail to-day to answer a charge of larceny. It is charged in the indictment found by the Suffolk Grand Jury that he obtained $23,000 by fraud from Francis A. Brooks, for years a leading member of the bar, who died last Fall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While recognizing your evident desire for justice, I am yet at times astounded at the mental strabismus that seems to characterize your view of the larger questions involving the moral progress of the human race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Capt. Leutz, commanding the new battleship Maine, was at the Navy Department today conferring with the officials in regard to the disposition of that vessel. It is probable that the Maine will leave Philadelphia in about two weeks for a cruise to the Gulf of Mexico in order to shake down her machinery before being regularly assigned to a station.

Conditions for the old Scotch game of curling were at their best yesterday, and the members of the Grand National Curling Club in this vicinity turned out in force at Van Cortlandt Lake, where the annual competition between the North and South of Scotland took place. The South Scotland curlers, who held the Dalrymple medal, captured the prize and the honor again, the score being largely in their favor -- 107 to 61.

Golfers are awaiting the report of the Nominating Committee of the United States Golf Association with considerable interest, and there is a general expectancy that it will be issued this week. It may be postponed, however, for by the requirements it does not have to appear until thirty days before the annual meeting.

The Radical Democracy of Brooklyn gave a dinner last evening in honor of two of its members. Congressman-elect Robert Baker and Assemblyman-elect Edward A. Miller, in the Hotel Argyle. The speakers were Clarence S. Darrow of Chicago, chief counsel for the coal miners before the Strike Commission; John S. Crosby, Henry George, Jr., Lee Meriweather, Robert Baker, Edward A. Miller, Joseph McGuinness, and Henry D. Lloyd.

The people of New York have so many things to interest them that they are apt to overlook important matters of local concern until they assume an aspect sufficiently grave to furnish material for a brief panic. The condition of Central Park is a case in point. For years the people of New York have thought very little about it.

VERY often one idea serves for a good many jokes," says Marshall P. Wilder, who should be considered an authority on the subject, as he has passed the merry quip with more people than any man in the country to-day. "Gen. Sherman once wrote me a seven-page letter about jokes and other solemn things," he says.

Dr. John A. Irwin, ex-President of the British Schools and Universities Club of this city, was the recipient of a loving cup last Monday night, at the dinner of the members of the club, held at Delmonico's. The cup is of Tiffany make, fourteen inches high. The three faces, between the handles, are engraved, the first with the inscription:

The market has experienced a decided lull during the last week. Nobody seems disposed to regard this circumstance as anything more than might be expected at the opening of the new year, when many large interests are engaged with other affairs demanding immediate attention, whereas it is the experience of brokers that almost any excuse is sufficient for postponing real estate negotiations.

Senator Platt and his friends yesterday made their demand of Gov. Odell for a straight-out declaration as to his position with regard to the re-election of the Senator and got it. The following authorized statement from the Governor was given out by Luther B. Little, Secretary of the Republican State Committee, after a meeting between the Senator and the Governor:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The record of the Court of Inquiry, appointed at the request of Capt. Malvern-Hill Barnum, Eighth Cavalry, to investigate certain allegations made against his official conduct by Major Charles G. Ayres, Eighth Cavalry, has been received at the War Department from Gen. Bates, commanding the Department of the Missouri.

To the Editor of The New York Times: National interest is again centred on Wisconsin, and seems to be divided between the Capitol at Madison and the School of Lost Mysteries at Point Loma, San Diego, Cal.

To the Editor of The New York Times. In the article in THE TIMES of Sunday, Jan. 4, giving a review of the growth of Washington State no mention was made of the remarkable progress of its leading city, Seattle, but only several facts concerning Tacoma, at one time considered by some its rival for commercial supremacy in that State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Roosevelt, following the precedent set first by Grover Cleveland, and adhered to by Mr. McKinley, has declared his disapproval of the election of an apostle of the Mormon Church to the United States Senate. This action has been taken to warn the Legislature of Utah against carrying out its manifest intention to choose Apostle Reed Smoot as the successor of Senator Rawlins, whose term expires on March 3 next.

THROUGHOUT the habitable portion of North America, confined neither to the large cities nor the large hamlets, though ever present in the former and frequently to be found in the latter, there flourishes a race of men who differ in no small degree from the natives whom they encounter in their wanderings.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- "Our Industries in Process of Development Neither Destroy Nor Arrest Them, but Peopleize Them" was the topic of Judge Peter S. Grosscup of the United States Circuit Court at a banquet given by the Hamilton Club to-night. Judge Grosscup said, in part:

It has been only seventy-five years since oven the London newspapers began to publish daily reports of the stock market. It has been only within the present generation that stork market reporting has been put upon anything like a scientific basis. But even now there is a wide difference of opinion as to the duties and responsibilities of the financial writer.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 10 -- The ice yachts Scud and Dreadnaught, owned respectively by James B. Weaver and James C. Doughty, were put on the cars here to-day and shipped to Gull Lake, Michigan. The boats are the representative first-class yachts of the North Shrewsbury River Ice Yacht Club, and will take part in the series of races arranged for week after next by the Kalamazoo Ice Yacht Club.

IT IS worth while to visit the Syrian Orthodox Church in Pacific Street, Brooklyn, white a wedding is in progress. The ceremonies are the same as those that have been practiced in the Syrian provinces since the sixth century, and are extremely pretty.

ARCOLA, Ill., Jan. 10 -- The fuel famine here has been broken. An Illinois Central coal train, consisting of sixteen cars, bound for Chicago, stopped here this morning and was confiscated by a party of 300 citizens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- How many of the persons who read the announcement made in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 1 that the United States Treasury held an aggregate of $617,000,000 in gold coin and bullion appreciate the full significance of that fact, or have any intelligent idea of the bulk of that vast sum of the yellow metal?

LILLIAN GRAHAM is tall, brown-eyed, and good to look upon. She lives in a suburb of New York. William, better known as "Bat," Peterson is short, thick-set, with a scar over his left eye. "Bat" entertains no sentiments of gratitude toward Miss Graham. She would be shocked at the idea of knowing him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- No credence is attached here in diplomatic circles to many of the stories that have been out in circulation in regard to the retirement of Dr. von Holleben from Washington. That the Ambassador has failed to meet the expectations of the Emperor in connection with the Venezuelan matter is generally believed, and his virtual recall is attributed to that fact.

REAL live animals and imaginary wild beasts galore live in the deep Washington Heights tunnel that forms a section of the subway. The eight mules, as sightiess as the blind fishes of the Mammoth Cave, are genuine flesh and blood. The hairy dogs, resembling somewhat the description of Conan Doyle's "Hound of the Baskervilles," and the pink-eyed rats and roaring tigers, are products of the Italian miners brains.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Heavy repayments to the Bank of England quickly absorbed all surplus credit, and on Thursday the market was compelled to renew a small part of the amounts due. On Friday there was fresh borrowing and a consequent recovery in rates both for loans and discounts.
WELLINGTON, Nov. Zealand, Dec. 10 -- The women showed their power in the recent triennial Parliamentary election in New Zealand on the question of the licensing of the liquor traffic.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 -- The baseball war which has been waging for the last two years between the American and National Leagues virtually ended to-night when the Peace Committee of both Leagues adjourned after coming to an agreement.

MADRID, Jan. 10 -- As King Alfonso, Dowager Queen Christina, and the Court were returning from church this afternoon a man, who afterward save his name as Feito, fired a pistol at one of the carriages to the royal procession. The bullet went wild and no one was injured.

Much comment is being caused among the students of Columbia University by the refusal of E.C. Madden. Third Assistant Postmaster General, to admit The Spectator, the college daily, to the mails as second class matter. For over twenty years The Spectator as a weekly and semi-weekly paper was admitted at second class rates, but last October, when the changing of the paper to a daily necessitated a new application, this application was refused.

MADRID, Dec. 30 -- Lefebre, the French Charge d'Affaires here, has received from M. Valle, the French Minister of Justice, 15,000f, to be distributed among the Madrid police who were instrumental in placing the Humberts under and key. The sum has been turned over to the Chief of Police, Sefier Ribarola, for distribution.

FEW persons in search of the Atlantic Shipping Company would think of going to the heart of the tenement house district in First Street, on the east side, to find it. But there it is, its sign emblazoned in red letters and gilt, and iron railings with cubby holes in them to keep men who swarm about the place during business hours from getting out of bounds.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 10 -- While going a mile a minute the Washington express on the Pennsylvania Railroad struck a steel freight car at 6 o'clock this evening, and smashed the engine, derailed three coaches, and badly injured Paul Schaler of Philadelphia, engineer of the express, and mortally injured Patrick Carmody of Trenton, conductor of the freight train.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Whatever disadvantages may attach to being what it called a world power boredom cannot be said to be one of them. As soon as one ticklish problem seems in a fair way of satisfactory solution another springs up unexpectedly to take, its place.

In a hockey match that was remarkable for the strenuous effort of both teams, the men from Princeton University defeated those representing Brown University last night by 7 goals to 1. The contest was the first of the intercollegiate championship series, and was played in the St. Nicholas Rink, Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue, before several thousand enthusiastic spectators who crowded the buildins and displayed a partisan feeling toward the Princetonians.
PEDESTRlANS along the line of the elevated road stood in groups sazing up at the structure and congested traffic. As far as eye could reach ap- peared immovable trains.

ROME, Jan. 1 -- Baron Sonnino and his intelligent supporters in the rational opposition have been placed in an embarrassing position. I have already shown in these letters wherein differed Sonnino's measures for the economic relief of the South from that of the Government -- the former would cure the South at the expense of the North, while the latter promised a cure for all, even where health prevailed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nine out of ten business men believe that a holder of even one share of corporation stork has a right to know how the business in which his money is invested is conducted, and believes that he has a right to demand information about its condition, or even to seek such information for himself in the books of the company.

It is obvious that the coal roads will have to do something to protect the public against the rapacity of the independent operators, and do it quickly, if they would relieve themselves of the suspicion of tolerating for reasons of their own a condition of affairs which they affect to "deprecate."

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- Quite a business was done in the coppers. Copper range was strons and even. Arcadian awakened from its long slumber and went up a point. The latter was active. Centennial and Amalgamated moved upward and then reacted. Most of the coppers closed lower than they were Friday.

To the Editor of The New York times: It was my privilege, ever a decade ago, to lead in the introduction of the only successful cheap cab movement ever introduced in New York, and I was therefore deeply interested in the practical suggestions made upon this subject by a correspondent in your columns a few days since.

THE all-white furs, in both ermine, fox, and caracole are especially popular with young girls. Miss Cathleen Neilson's has already been described. Miss Jean Reid has a short coat of ermine, and the turned-over collar is edged with appliques of Irish point lace, which is also used on the cuffs.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- It may be recalled that last year the Prussian Government set aside 200,000,000 marks to be used to strengthen the German position in East Prussia by the purchase of estates there held by the Poles. The result of this political enterprise is now being commented on by the papers here.

TWELFTH NIGHT was celebrated at several of the clubs with the wassail bowl and the usual ceremonies. The Fine Arts Bad one of the celebrations and the Century another. The general custom of celebrating the day has fallen into disuse. In fact, observances of particular days were never popular in New York clubs, except those of a political cast, where dinners are given on certain anniversaries.
A LITTLE Southern woman lately settled in New York tells the following story of a recent experience in "bluffing."

The action brought in 1895 by Mrs. Heloise Durant Rose, wife of C.H.M. Rose, of 601 West One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street, against her brother, William W. Durant, to compel him to make an accounting to her for her share of their father's estate, terminated yesterday, when Justice James A. O'Gorman, in the Supreme Court, confirmed a report of ex-Judge Augustus C. Brown, as referee, deciding that Mrs. Rose is entitled to $753,000.

Indications now are that the month of January will live up to tradition. At one time the severe illness of Cornelius Vanderbilt and the death of Heber R. Bishop threatened to put a stop to much of the gayety of the year. But Cornelius Vanderbilt is convalescing, and the term of mourning for collateral relatives for Mr. Bishop has expired.

Twenty recognized schools in the United States are devoted exclusively to training men and women for physical directors, and they are not able to turn out enough to supply the demand. There is such a demand simply because of the growing interest in physical exercise or physical culture. Most people know comparatively little of the new profession of physical directorship just coming into existence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- While arrangements have not yet been made for the meeting of the Venezuelan Commission, some attention has been given to the subject, and it appears that the United States Government will be expected to provide accommodations for the body. It is probable that accommodations will be procured, in one of the hotels here, for the State Department has no available room to devote to such purposes.

READING, Penn., Jan. 10 -- There is an interesting story connected with the recent sale of a New England primer which was purchased for 12 cents, and recently sold for $2,500. This little book, much sought after by biblicphiles, was found in the Berks village, Lobachsville, founded by David Lobach, an educated man, who came to this country nearly 200 years ago.

To the Editor to The New York Times: Your article, "Coupon Clearing House," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the 11th ult., has stimulated discussion under this head and is doing good in the right direction. There is every reason why the handling of coupons should evolve into better methods and keep pate with other banking improvements.

PARIS, Jan.10. -- The report from Madrid that an attempt had been made to assassinate King Alfanso is confirmed. It appears that the attack on his Majesty was not successful. The dispatches from Madrid on the subject have been mutilated.

The difficulty which railroad traffic managers are experiencing in their efforts to take proper care of the heavy volume of freight continually coming forward is not only attracting increased attention, but is a matter which is compelling serious consideration on the part of those to whom the shipping public look for prompt and efficient service.
Controller Grout issued yesterday the following statement in reference to the Ford franchise tax law, which Gov. Odell proposes to repeal for a substitute tax law:

ON THE Long Island shore of Long Island Sound, a few miles to the west of Theodore Roosevelt's residence and the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Clubhouse of Oyster Bay, there lay several years ago a rolling strip of country unimproved, just as it had been for generations, with a few old-fashioned homesteads scattered here and there, and a mosquito ridden, pestiferous marsh at one side.

To the Editor of The New York Times. Through the medium of THE NEW YORK TIMES I would like to voice the unanimous sentiment of the respectable element of my fellow-citizens regarding the strenuous, persistent efforts of District Attorney Jerome in suppressing gambling wherever found, whether on the Bowery or in Fifth Avenue.

FORTUNE tellins with playing cards is a source of great fun during the long Winter evening's. Those occasional periods of dullness that will occur in an evening can be readily overcome if there is some one among the guests who can tell fortunes.

CAR NO, 1,313 is on the Broadway run. One night a passenger who traveled on that car noticed a strange matter. It struck him as thcu car passed Thirteenth Street. He was standing on the rear platform, talking occasionally to the conductor. He noticed that the-number of the conductor, was 3,913.
B-U-R-R, whizz, s-k-t-t-t, b-r-r-r-r. Low the coming roar; then the quick flash past, and the reverberating rumble losing itself in the distance.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- In a game that resembled football and boxing more that it flirt basket ball, the Jefferson Medical College triumphed over the Columbia University of New York this afternoon at St. James Hall by a score of 17 to 14. It was Columbia's first appearance in this city to basket ball followers, and a good sized crowd was on hand to welcome the intercollegiate league team.

Ten shots from a revolver woke up the residents of West Sixty-eighth Street at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Running low and close to the stoops was a man in a black leather coat with an automobile cap pulled over his eyes. George H. Gale of 44 West Sixty-sixth Street was shooting at him from a third-story window of his house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nothing can be more clear, we think, than the rapid combination of the great transportation interests of this country in a few hands and the determination of those in control of this imperial power to make themselves not only the absolute rulers but the absolute owners of the American people and of their property.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The Secretary of State received to-day for filing twice as many certificates of incorporation as he was able to examine and pass upon. Those left over in most instances were larger corporations than the ones whose certificatfs were filed. These will be Riven the proper authority on Monday. Following were among those filed to-day;

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- There is danger that the Cuban reciprocity treaty will fail of ratification, not because it cannot command the necessary two-thirds vote, but because the opposition will take advantage of the rules of the Senate and prevent a vote from being reached.

The Commission in Lunacy appointed by Judge Lambert of the Supreme Court to examine into the mental condition of Henry J. Rose, the actor-manager who killed his wife last September, held another brief session yesterday afternoon in the Criminal Courts Building. The defense in the Rose case, represented by Howe Hummel, set up the contention that Rose is insane and suffers from "akromegaly," a newfangled disease, about which alienists confess they know little.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Yarmouth (Nova Scotia) Telegram of last Friday has the following paragraph: Anthracite coal is selling for $16 a ton in Gloucester, Mass., and is scarce at that figure. Several parties in Boston have had small shipments of hard coal made from Yarmouth during the past few weeks, as the price, $7.75, enabled them to procure it cheaper than it could he supplied in that city.

There is one argument that has been used in connection with the appointment of negroes to Federal offices in the South which is plausible, but which is based on a fallacy, to whichever race it is applied. It is the plea that the negroes, being recognized by the Constitution as entitled to equality before the law, ought to have open to them the reward of office as an incentive to deserve it.
VAN WORTER wore his customary bored air when he sauntered into the club the other evening.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 10 -- Brown defeated Lafayette by 14 to 12 in a basketball contest here to-night. The game was close and exciting and the outcome was in doubt up to the last moment of play.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with considerable interest your editorial "The Hawaiian Cable" in THE TIMES of Saturday, Jan. 3, and, agree with you fully that the completion of the cable to Honolulu is an achievement of importance and benefit to both the business and political interests of the United States and the Hawaiian Islands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A dispatch from Pittsburg, printed in the Times of Jan. 19, says that an Allegheny County Judge has placed in the wheel for jury duty the names of many of Pittsburg's millionaires. The reason given for thus rudely invading the immunity from public service of the nobility of our country is that the judge desires a better class of jurors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ever since governments have existed the people have been inclined to hold their rulers responsible for the social and economic conditions that may prevail. Hard times, and the other events that cause popular discontent and agitation, are believed by a majority of mankind to be the result of bad government, and he who so asserts is always regarded as a patriot and a statesman.

Stocks active and irregular. Money easy. While the gain in cash reported by the bank statement yesterday, $4,740,100, was much less than Wall Street had been led to expect by the high estimates of the day before, and is considerably less than the actual movement of money nevertheless the statement was better than the stock market traders in their disappointment over the moderate gain in cash seemed to think.

The upper burgomaster of the good Polish-Prussian city of Posen takes the occasion of a banquet given him on his retirement to remark on the error of the statement that thing's German show improvement in his bailiwick. The Germans are losing ground, he exclaim, with a frankness due to the fact that he is no longer responsible.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tues- day:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- The nonunion men having closed their case, the coal companies opened their side of the controversy to-day before the strike commission. Chairman Gray is still confined to his home in Wilmington, suffering from a cold, and Gen. Wilson again presided.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Concerning the inadequate transportation facilities vouchsafed by the Manhaltan elevated systems, perhaps a hint as to the unseen forces -- the powers behind the throne -- may be of interest.
SHE whirled over toward one corner and seated herself with a flutter of furs and frou-frou of silk petticoats at the table we had just selected for our quiet midday luncheon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest the very able and fair editorial headed "Indianola and Charleston" published in your paper of Jan. 6. As a native and former resident of Charleston, S.C., I have taken great interest in the question of the appointment of William D. Crum, a colored man, to be Collector of the Port of Charleston.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 -- Sloppy weather and a slushy track interfered with sport and attendance to-day. The Gentilly Handicap, worth $1,680 to the winner, lacked the spirit which the character of the on entries promised. Philo, backed from threes to 11 to 5, was a decided favorite, and was admirably ridden by Fuller, who sent him to the front when ready and won cleverly by two lengths.

TUCSON, Arizona, Jan. 10 -- A joint meeting of the Town Boards of Nogales, Arizona, and Nogales. Mexico, has been held to protest against reports sent out by cor- respondents about the existence of a plague in Guaymas and other Sonora towns. Advices from Guaymas say that the business of the State has been damaged by the false reports.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I supplement the remarks made in your issue of Sunday last by "Londoner" with a few of my own, founded on impressions formed during a five years' residence in this State?

AFTER the stock had been seen to for the night, the hen Jiouse door, locked, and the woodbox filled with chunks, Ezra and Cindy sat clown to supper. The biscuits were never lighter, the tea never more savory; as for the sausages they had never reached such a perfect seal brown before.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Examination of the Boards of Directors of the New York city banks reveals a curious condition. The financial situation is completely controlled by not to exceed a dozen institutions. Their boards are controlled by not to exceed a dozen men. That wheel has still another wheel within it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Cannot something be done to prevent Mr. Hillis and his admirers from desecrating the grave of Henry Ward Beecher, the site of which he himself selected as desirable, and which has been sanctified by the many visits made it by his noble wife during her life, and where, also, rest the remains of his little children?

Panic was rife at 12:20 o'clock this morning among the several families living in the five-story tenement at 217 West Sixty-first Street. The hallways filled with smoke, people crowded out on the fire-escapes, and several were carried down by firemen. The fire was discovered under circumstances that led Michael Horn, the janitor of the house, to believe that it was started by some small boys whose arrest he had threatened.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every honest American will heartily commend and indorse your editorial of yesterday entitled "A Fraud and Its Defenders." Your fine denunciation of the trick of the Senate Committee in fixing a duty of 67 cents a ton upon anthracite coal is well deserved.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the letters on the subject of overcrowding on the elevated roads published in your issue of Sunday. Jan. 4, none seemed to more nearly cover the points of Compiaint, with suggestions for remedy, than that of "G.A.A." His advocacy of side doors is particularly good.

THE project for the erection of the new armory for the Seventy-first Regiment, National Guard, to replace the structure destroyed by fire last Winter, and which involved such a serious loss of life at the Park Avenue Hotel, has so far advanced that the plans and specifications for the new building are in the hands of the Armory Board awaiting final approval.

Customs officials, aided by the police, last evening arrested one man, charged with smuggling, and made a search of the Red Star steamship Finland, lying at the foot of Fulton Street, North River. The man, who was found to be wrapped with tobacco cleverly concealed under his clothes, was taken to the Church Street Station, where he described himself as Jacob von Sternbergen, twenty-six years old, a donkey engine man on the steamship.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- Miss Julia Tenney Emerson, daughter of Mrs. Arthur W. Emerson of Winchester, and John Henry House. Jr., of New York, a son of the Rev. J.H. House of Salonica, Turkey, were married at noon to-day in the Union Congregational Church. Allen Cox of Boston, Jerome Alien of Providence, Robert Chapman of Newton, and Sewall Newman of Winchester were the ushers, and the best man was Ralph Shepard of New York.

With the reopening of Yale last Wednesday all of the various athletic departments began the Winter season's work. Capt. Waterman started the long drill for the race in June with Harvard, and will keep the candidates at gymnasium work and rowing in the tanks until the ice leaves the harbor.

IT IS my opinion, based on long and close observation." paid a well-known lawyer, "that a large percentage ofthe unhappiness in the world is caused by joyless labor -- that is by people following the wrong occupation or proffession.

The New York playgoer of to-day asks a good deal more in the way of safety and convenience in the theatre than did the amusement seekers of even a very few years ago, for the reason that the large number of new homes of the drama that have been erected recently in this city have each in turn educated the public taste in that direction by some new feature along these lines.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10 -- Railroad men here express the opinion that the surveying and buying of rights-of-way through Southern Pennsylvania, via York, are really in the interest of the proposed Tidewater and Susquehanna River Railroad, which is said to be a project to connect the Baltimore and Ohio with the Reading by a new route.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- Count Reventlow has written to the Neue Freie Presse an article warmly advocating a purely naval alliance between Germany and England. The paper has been favorably commented on in spite of the fact that the Neuesten Nachrichten declares that such an alliance, however advantageous it might mutually be, would be utterly out of the question so long as anti-German feeling remains what it is among the papers of London.

IF the clerk in an all-night drug store had nothing to do but fill the occasional prescriptions that come in he would have a pretty lonesome time of it. But there are other diversions. The telephone is one important factor contributing to the gayety of post-midnight hours.

To cure insanity in its early stages is the effort of physicians attached to the Psychopathic Hospital, connected with the New York Infirmary, East Fifteenth Street and Livingston Place. The doctors feel certain that this may be done by hypnotism, where the superposing of many ideas until the central idea has been reached and confirmed is employed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Great interest is manifested in the expected examination on Monday in the Senate coal investigation of James A. Lounsberry, the local agent of the Reading Coal and Iron Company. Mr. Lounsberry was summoned to appear yesterday, but he failed to come, and sent word that he would be present Monday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 10 -- The annual meeting of the athletic representatives of West Point and Annapolis was held at the Army and Navy Club in Washington to-day. The meeting was for the purpose of arranging details for the annual football game. After the conference the Naval Academy committee returned to Annapolis.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Bend Or, the famous race horse, who won the Derby in 1880, dropped dead while exercising this morning.

EVERY town has its Munchausen and every forecastle has its liar, but the father of them all was Jeff Weller, cook of the good ship Trident. Capt. Helling, plying between South Street, New York, and the West Indies. Said the Captain:

In a recent article published over his name Mr. Wilhelm Gericke expressed his feelings regarding the modern tendencies of musical art, which he characterizes as toward "noise and orchestral turmoil." He likes to turn back to the classics, to find in them "peace, contentment, and real beauty of form and expression."

TWO women entered a Columbus Avenue car the other night away up town. They stood in the aisle, the only people standing. At their right were three young men engaged in a most engrossing conversation, so engrossing in fact that it was palpably but a blind. On the left was a row of men and women, all of the class that live "up town."

Hamilton College graduates met last night at the Hotel Manhattan to hold their annual reunion and dinner and to celebrate the one hundred and forty-sixth anniver- sary or the birth of Alexander Hamilton, the founder of the college. The college colors were much in evidence, and Hamil- ton songs and yells enlivened the occasion.

To the, Editor of The New York Times: An inclosed list of lives lost in 1902 from vessels sailing out of Gloucester reveals the fact that these vessels were not only manned but commanded by foreigners, chiefly Nova Scotians, and that over so per cent, of this loss of life occurred from vessels prosecuting this fishing business during winter months, stimulated as this inhuman business is by an almost prohibitory duty.

PARIC Jan. 1 -- Apropos of the ratification to the international sugar convention by France Le Siecle examines the economic consequences of M. Rouvier's law on sugar, which will come into force Sept. 1.

These lines, taken from the soldier's "Hike" song in "The Sultan of Sulu," are a typical sample of the lyrics which George Ade has provided. He has succeeded rather better than is usual in wording a dialogue which has some touch of humor, apart from the business and accompanying action of the theatre.
THE Sunday School librarian keeps his books under lock and Key, but he opened the doors to the benighted visitor right gladly.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 10 -- Fire entirely destroyed Warehouse No. 4 of the General Cartage and Storage Company, a five-story building in Prospect Street, this morning. The loss is placed at $50,000, with no statement of the insurance. The ground floor of the building was occupied by J.T. Higgins's saloon.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- A National convention at Washington, for the purpose of impressing on President Roosevelt the urgent needs for immediate relief from the stringency of the coal situation, was decided on to-day at a conference in the Grand Pacific Hotel. The call for the gathering will be issued probably on Monday by Mayor Maybury of Detroit, acting as Chairman of the Permanent Committee of the Detroit Coal Convention.

A FLAG hung listlessly from the tall staff; the huge white library stood gleaming in the Summer son: the red brick walks wound in and out in ugly contrast to the soft, cooling velvet of the lawns; groups of students flocked across the campus, coatless, hatless, with perspiring, hot faces, smudged with dirt and grass stains, fresh from an inter-class fight over the taking of the freshman class picture.

A Progressive Diamond. LOOK it this stone," said a young journeyman jeweler in a street car the other day, removing a tissue paper wrapping from a piece of white wax, in the centre of which blazed a beautiful diamond. "That is worth at least $180."

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould will give a dinner and musicale at their town house, 857 Fifth Avenue, Thursday evening, Jan. 22. One hundred invitations have been issued. After dinner there will be a musical programme, in which Kocian, Mme. Emma Eames, and M. Gilibert will take part.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 -- As the labor representatives hold the balance of power in the Federal Parliament, and can therefore make and unmake Ministries, considerable importance is attached to the decisions of the Political Labor Conference which has just closed its session in Sydney.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- Athletic quarrels and unpleasant quibblings over technicalities which have marred college athletic sports for several years past were fully discussed at the fifth annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Athletic Conference, which was held in the Harvard Union, in Cambridge, to-day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Harlan W. Brush, United States Consul at Niagara Falls, Ont., has some interesting things to say in a recent report to the State Department on "Development of Niagara Power." He says:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 10 -- John T. Brush of the New York Club, when shown the dispatch detailing the story of the Cincinnati Peace Conference, denied in positive terms that he had been in communication with the committee of the National League, and stated that he did not agree to the peace pact as stated.

The Committee on Revision of City Records and Accounts and Water Supply of the Merchants Association made public yesterday a communication sent to the Mayor on the 8th inst., in which it criticised the Aqueduct Commission and called upon the Mayor to cite the commission to show cause why the members should not be removed.

MADRID, Jan. 11 -- Feito, the man who fired a pistol yesterday at the carriage in the royal procession in which the Duke of Sotomayor, the Grand Chamberlain, was supposed to be riding, was examined again to-day. His bearing confirmed previous reports that he is suffering from monomania. A careful official inquiry has shown that Feito is not connected with Anarchists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The programme for the Senate for the week includes the continuance of the discussion of the Statehood bill each day after 2 o'clock and the intermittent discussion of the Militia bill during the morning hour of each day when it is not cut out by some other matter.

Gen. Samuel Thomas died suddenly last midnight of heart disease at his home, 17 West Fifty-seventh Street. While he had been ailing for more than a year, he was up and about until yesterday afternoon. He is survived by two sons and a daughter, E. R. Thomas, R.E. Thomas, and Mrs. Livingstone Beekman.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 11 -- The stirring arraignment of fashionable society by a Philadelphia clergyman has called forth the following from Mrs. Julia Ward Howe:

The principle that the National Government may properly use its revenues for the construction, or to aid in the construction, of roads between the States was long ago settled. There was a hot fight over it, and HENRY CLAY won much of his reputation as a Congressional leader in the contest.

The chief object of the police legislation which it is reported will be sought at Albany this Winter is in substance to give the Commissioner greater facilities for the wholesome investigation and organization of the force and a larger force for the work of the department.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 11 -- A dispatch from Walton, N.Y., to the effect that relatives of the late Leonard Case, Jr., were about to lay claim to his $30,000,000 in this city, published this morning, caused considerable comment here. While the Case estate is not a myth, and it is true that Leonard Case died a bachelor and without a will, no heirs can claim a penny of it.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 11 -- The list of entries to the stakes of the new Memphis Jockey Club's Spring meeting at Montgomery Park, as announced by Secretary McFarlan, shows so far the largest list that has ever been received here.
