A comparison of this and last year's entries shows an aggregate number of oil nominations for the slakes to be decided at the coming meeting against 400 for last year's fixtures.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 11 -- The carpenters, bricklayers, plumbers, and others working upon various buildings along the shore, from Atlantic Highlands to Point Pleasant, where there are fully 100 cottages under construction, decided at meetings held last night to strike to-morrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- The Rev. Dr. H.S. Hoffman, who for thirty years has not accepted a penny of salary in the various churches where he has labored, today announced his resignation as pastor of the Reformed Episcopal Church of Our Redeemer, Sixteenth and Oxford Streets. The announcement caused deep regret to the members of the congrgation with whom he has been for eleven years.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 11 -- Mayor W.C. Maybury arrived home to-day from Chicrigo, where he attended the meeting of the permanent committee of the Detroit "getcoal" convention of several months ago. Mayor Maybury, who is Chairman of the committee, will to-morrow issue the call for the convention at Washington decided on in Chicago yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The paragraph in to-day's paper relating to the proposed permanent orchestra fund interested, no doubt, those of your readers who, like myself, think the metropolis of the country should have a first class permanent orchestra directed by a first class conductor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The experiments that have been under headway for the past month at the Department of Agriculture to determine the effects on healthy persons of the average American prepared foods is to take a new turn. It is under- stood that thus far the experiments have shown that there is no deleterious sub- stance in our canned meats and other foods.

In trying to save the lives of her husband, children, and servants. Mrs. Florine Henry, wife of Philip S. Henry, the coffee merchant and daughter of the late Leonard Lewisohn, the millionaire banker, lost her own life by suffocation in an early morning fire at 34 East Fifty-fourth Street, where Mr. and Mrs. Henry had a temporary residence.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- The Boerse has had another strong week, although the volume of transactions was below that of the previous week. The efforts of the professional elements to entice outsiders to participate in the present bull movement have not yet been realized.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Consul General John K. Gowdy in his latest report from Paris writes of the Bank of France, founded by Napoleon in February, 1800, and granted the sole privilege of issuing notes, a privilege ever since retained. He says in part:

DENVER, Jan. 11 -- The interest which the leaders of the National Republican organization are taking in the Colorado Senatorial situation is shown by the following telegram, received yesterday by William Stapleton, editor and manager of The Denver Republican:

WASHINGTON. Jan. 11 -- Senator Dubois of Idaho, in which State, as well as in Montana, the Mormon element is a large and perhaps a controlling factor in politics, expresses great surprise that there should be interference by the President with the election of a Senator in Utah, in view of the deal he alleges was made by Republican campaign managers with Mormon leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Ex-Gov. Murphy of Arizona, the immediate predecessor of the present Governor, has issued a statement about the opposition to the Statehood bill, in which he claims to give the secret motives inspiring the Senators who oppose the measure. Although a Republican himself, he flays Senator Beveridge and his colleagues on the Committee on Territories.

The forthcoming presentation of Ibsen's "Ghosts" at the Princess, by Mary Shaw and others is attracting considerable attention among certain classes of playgoers. These special matinees represent an effort to revive in New York City the independent theatre idea, and should they succeed financially it will mean the permanent appearance of talented actors in plays not generally produced.

Since Police Commissioner Greene "shook up" the detective force in Brooklyn recently some of the sleuths there have been doing work that would make Sherlock Holmes feel like a mere novice. Yesterday a white man, while in a house on Hudson Avenue, occupied by negroes, was robbed of $100.

A petition with numerous signers, many of them persons of experience and authority in such matters, has been submitted to the Legislature for amendments to the laws regulating child labor and providing for compulsory education.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The annual report of the State Superintendent of Public Works, made public to-night, covers the disbursements for ordinary repairs and operating expenses; trade and tonnage of the canals of the State during the season of navigation of 1902; the condition and the work of improvement connected therewith, under special appropriations, in progress or completed during the year ended Dec. 31, 1902, and the expenditures on account thereof.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 11 -- Following the adjournment last night of the joint con- ference committees of the National and American Baseball Leagues, there was an informal conference of the National representatives here during the night and today. While the time was spent largely in festivities over the declaration of peace, there was much talk about the meeting of the National League here on Jan. 19, one week hence.

There was a terrific explosion in the yards of the Consolidated Gas Company's works at Forty-fifth Street and the North River about 9 o'clock yesterday morning. Although there were several men at work in the vicinity, only one man was hurt. He was Hugh McFarland of 465 West Forty-sixth Street, a workman, who was struck in the head by a piece of flying iron.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday afternoon talked at length concerning the gamblers that operate above Twenty-fourth Street in Manhattan, said all of them were crooked, and then proceeded to give his reasons for saying so. He denied that he would bring the Canfield case before the Grand Jury to-day, and said that he would not disclose the date when the case would be brought before that body.

The probable reason for the boom in basket ball this Winter is because all of the colleges, schools, and athletic clubs have taken up the game and are represented by strong teams. The colleges and schools have formed leagues while the athletic clubs, as a general rule, have arranged their games with sanctioned A.A. U. teams.

Some idea of the great upward movement in the stock market last week is conveyed by the fact that out of a total of 226 stocks traded in, 158 made net advances, of which 57 scored gains of 2 per cent and more. The volume of trading averaged more than a million shares a day.
ARCOLA, Ill., Jan. 11 -- Every one in Arcola wears a self-satisfied look, to-day.

Many entries have already been received for the annual dog show of the New Jersey Kennel Association, Which is to be held in Orange Feb. 18, 19, 20, and 21. Richard Croker, Jr., will enter his famous $5,000 prize bulldog Rodney Stone. C.G. Hopton has also entered several fine specimens, as has Joseph Byrne, President of the New Jersey Kennel Association.

Albert J. Akin, who is in his one hundredth year, is critically ill at his home, 4 West Fifty-sixth Street. He contracted pneumonia in December, and had apparently recovered, when complications set in. At 1 o'clock this morning it was said that his condition was very serious.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 11 -- Mrs. Sarah Merritt, a young woman who has been missing for a week, was found in a snowbank at West Charleston Saturday afternoon. She had been lying in the snow since Tuesday, and was so badly frozen that she died an hour and a half after being found.

Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, who has been suffering from obstructive jaundice for some weeks, and has been confined to his bed at his home, 9 Lexington Avenue, since last Thursday, was very low early this morning.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The annual report of Cornelius V. Collins, Superintendent, of State Prisons, for the year ending Sept. 30, 1902, was made public to-night. In a general summary of the year, and with reference to the three State prisons, at Sing Sing. Auburn, and Dannemora, Mr. Collins says:

Not the least interesting machines to be exhibited at the Madison Square Garden Automobile Show, which opens on Saturday evening, will be those built for practical purposes instead of for pleasure only. Even in this comparatively early stage the automobile has been subjected to the severest kind of tests in the commercial world with noteworthy success.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 11 -- The Rev. D.N. Stafford, pastor of the Pitman Methodist Episcopal Church of this city, has decided to give the women an opportunity in the church's government, and he has carried out his views by appointing two to the Board of Stewards.

Quite contrary to his intent. Controller GROUT succeeds in proving that the Ford franchise tax law is an ill-judged and dangerous piece of legislation. Gov. ODELL'S recommendation that the law be repealed alarms the Controller because of the effect upon the borrowing capacity of the city of striking off so large an amount of property assessed as real estate.

All or nothing was the enthusiastic declaration of several contestants who are to take part in the Montauk Academy sweepstakes pool tournament. Fulton Street, Brooklyn, when the matter of division of prize money was brought up for discussion at a meeting of the players held yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The caution which President Roosevelt expressed last October to Secretary Wilson against the inordinate passion for printing which seemed to be upon the Department of Agriculture, and the prevalent desire that seemed to be running riot there for unnumbered fine half-tone engravings, appears to be fully justified, to judge from the statements made by George William Hill, the editor of the department.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 11 -- Several thousand persons witnessed a thrilling tragedy at Juarez this afternoon. A monster wild bull caught the noted bandarillo Francisco Mattillera of Madrid on his horns, inflicting injuries that undoubtedly will prove fatal. The fame of Sehor Francisco Mattillera, the skillful and daring bandarillo, attracted thousands of people to the fight.

BRISTOL, Jan. 11 -- Though the cup craft in the Herreshoff shops in Bristol is not in such an advanced form, apparently, as is the new challenger across the water, the launching, it is said, will be carried out at the time arranged months ago, some time in April. The process of construction is of such a character that a good part of the work is being done on the shop floor.

Mr. T.S. WHITMAN, writing from Annapolis Royal, Nova Scotia, calls attention to the fact that the Gloucester fleet of fishing vessels, which has long demanded high protection on the plea that it is a school for seamen for the United States Navy, is not only manned but commanded by foreigners, chiefly Nova Scotians, and that of the considerable mortality among fishing crews during 1902, aggregating eighty lives lost, only four were Americans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The needs of Greater New York should be considered and provided for in remodeling the terminal for the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad and New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

"I am for Senator PLATT'S re-election to the Senate unequivocally and unreservedly, for I believe that the Republican Party owes to him this renewed honor because of his service to it." This perfectly frank and quite shameless statement puts an end to a lot of silly gossip about the Governor's position, and tends to lull the suspicion that Gov. ODELL might prove to be better than PLATT or better than his party.

When Americans make pilgrimage in the precincts of Fleet Street they generally have a look at "Goldsmith's House," as it is sometimes called, in Wine Office Court. At present they would find it propped up with strong beams, in case it should be dis- turbed by the taking down of the building next door.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 11 -- The trial of Louis A. Disbrow on charges of murder in the cases of Miss "Dimple" Lawrence and Clarence Foster is to be begun to-morrow afternoon, probably at about 1 o'clock. Judge Maddox will come from Brooklyn in the morning to preside. Sixty talesmen have been called specially.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Advices received here indicate that while Minister Bowen comes as Venezuela's Commissioner in negotiations looking to a settlement of the claims of the allies, President Castro has made it a condition that the blockade shall be raised before Mr. Bowen shall proceed with the preparation of the protocol for the peaceful adjustment of the claims.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- Members of the Southern and General Education Boards were guests of honor at to-night's meeting and reception of the American Alderman of Tulane University, Robert C. in The New Century Drawing Boom. Addresses were made by President E. A. Alderman of Tulare University, Robert C. Ogden of New York, Provost Charles C. Harrison of the University of Pennsylvania and Dr. L. S. Rowe of the Academy.

Police Captain George S. Chapman, who won fame as the raider of the Seeley dinner, the Czar of the Tenderloin, the wielder of the axe, and the enemy to " The " Alien, was retired from the department yesterday. His application was acted on favorably by Commissioner Greene, and the Captain will receive the half-pay pension.

Henri Fournier, the champion automobilist of Europe, who arrived on La Bretagne yesterday, to attend the Automobile Show which opens in Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, stated that he was willing to race Alexander Winton on track or road for the championship of the world.

MECHANICSBURG, Penn., Jan. 12. -- The Journal Building, owned by Col. Robert H. Thomas, and ten other buildings burned to the ground to-night. In The Journal building three newspapers, including The Farmer's Friend, had their offices.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- The demand for money was strong in the market to-day, owing to the fact that there will be heavy calls during the week on new issues of capital, dividend payments, and Stock Exchange requirements. Discounts hardened.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Following the conference at the White House last night attended by Senator Aldrich and Speaker Henderson, there has been a great deal of discussion to-day among the Republicans of the Senate as to the prospects of antitrust legislation during this session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The Washington Jockey Club to-day recorded a deed conveying the Bennings race track property to August Belmont of Hempstead, N.Y., for a nominal consideration. This action is in accordance with the recent reorganization plans of the club designed to settle the large indebtedness to Mr. Belmont and third parties.

The minimum price of independent coal at tidewater was advanced yesterday from $10 to $10.50 a ton, and from $11 to $12 a ton wholesale was charged in many cases. The cold snap caused such a demand for hard coal that the supplies in many of the yards were exhausted in two hours. Large shipments of coal came to tidewater, but, as dealers said, the greater part was independent coal.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 12. -- Secretary of the Navy William H. Moody was seriously but not dangerously, injured on the Naval Academy grounds to-day in a runaway accident. Accompanied by Senator Hale, Chairman of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee, the Secretary arrived here at 2 o'clock to inspect the new buildings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12. -- Sales of mining shares to-day were the heaviest for years, and there was advance in all principal stocks, with an upward move of the whole Comstock list. This advance is due mainly to reports of good ore in Best and Belcher and Union, and in the prospect of speedy drainage of lower levels of Consolidated Virginia, Ophir, and other mines where prospecting is expected to reveal rich ore.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Mitchell (Rep., Ore.,) submitted the report of the sub-committee of the Senate on its investigation of affairs in the Hawaiian Islands.

-- Among the speeches made at the recent meeting in this city of the Civic Federation was one by Mr. JOHN R. COMMONS, who is associated with the United States Bureau of Labor and has had charge of the investigation in this country and Europe of the subject of the restriction of production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The position taken by the President in advising Apostle Reed Smoot not to become a candidate for election to the Senate from Utah because of his peculiar relation to the Mormon Church seems likely not to be effective. Since Senator Kearns gave out here the substance of the President's communication to him on the subject Mr. Smoot has been heard from, and in no unmistakable terms, on the matter.

The President seems to have been making the same kind of mistake in objecting to the selection of the strongest and most popular candidate for the vacant Senatorship from Utah that he has made in trying to force on two Southern communities local officials who were unacceptable to them.

There is evidently a "combine" in the Senate to defeat the treaty of reciprocity with Cuba. It is not a creditable association of honorable Senators for public purposes, but a more or less secret one of interested persons resorting to underhand methods for an unworthy end. The object of the conspiracy is to defer action on the treaty until after the 31st of January, the date fixed for its ratification.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers of America to-night issued a circular letter to all local unions in the anthracite district. It reads:
LONDON, Jan. 13. -- An interesting view of the developments of political Strife among the Czar's Ministers is given in a dispatch from the correspondent of The Times at St. Petersburg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The announcement from Rome that the Catholic University in this city is to be transferred from the Congregation of the Propaganda to the Congregation of Studies and that Mgr. Dennis O'Connell is to be the Rector is regarded as indicating a continuance of the liberal or American policy of administration for the institution.

VIENNA, Jan. 12. -- News has been received in this city that serious marital difficulties have resulted in the desertion of the former Crown Princess Stephanie by her husband, Count Lonyay. The Count is said to have left his wife at Mentone on Jan. 7, and has since given no intimation as to his whereabouts.

ROME, Jan. 12. -- Negotiations between the co-operating powers relative to raising the blockade of the Venezuelan coast are proceeding, the main point being the question of guarantees for the payment of claims should the warships be withdrawn.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 32. -- The proceedings before the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission to-day consisted principally of the calling of witnesses by the Delaware and Hudson Company to tell of the conditions existing in and about its collieries and to refute certain testimony presented against the company when the miners' side was being heard.

Acting Inspector Walsh last night gave the Tenderloin such a shaking up as it had not had in years when at 11 o'clock, with Capt. O'Reilly and precinct detectives, he raided all the principal resorts of doubtful character. In order that there should be no "tipping off " the descents were made simultaneously, the police holding everybody as prisoners until the Inspector arrived and picked out those he wanted.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 12. -- Western Nebraska has turned from the coal dealers to the farmers for fuel, and thousands of bushels of corn are going into stoves instead of into grain elevators.

It is extremely difficult for the average English journalist to understand American methods in business and finance well enough to discuss them intelligently and dispassionately. An interesting illustration of their proneness to misunderstand what happens on this side of the ocean is furnished in the comments of the London papers on the dissolution of the $50,000,000 pool formed to steady the New York money market some weeks ago.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 12. -- The money market is comparatively easy, but the banks are not overanxious to put out funds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The Alton B. Parker boom for President is growing with great rapidity. Most of the Democratic statesmen who have been interviewed recently about the party's candidate in 1904 have come out for Parker. The sentiment is by no means confined to those Democrats who have stood by the party merely for the sake of regularity, and care nothing for the Chicago and Kansas City platforms.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 12. -- The engagement of Miss Ethel Roland, daughter of Horace Roland of Reading, Penn., to H. Berlin Voorhees of Baltimore, son of Vice President Voorhees of the Reading Railroad, has been announced. Miss Roland is said to be the original of the heroine of Gilbert Parker's novel "The Right of Way."

Wall Street gave most of its attention yesterday, stock marketwise, to the movements of Atchison, Erie, and Rock Island. With the exception of Erie and Reading the most active security on the list was Atchison, which was dealt in to the extent of over 75,000 shares and was early a very strong feature, though suffering in the late reaction.

Receptions and card parties are among the events for to-day. There are also several dinners for this evening. The dancing classes come around again, and the most notable of those meeting this evening is the Fortnightly in the Waldorf-Astoria. The concert at Sherry's in aid of the Babies' Ward of the Post-Graduate Hospital will attract many.

In the outside market yesterday price movements were confined to much narrower limits than during last week, when there were many wide fluctuations. Considerable irregularity was shown by the market, but on the whole the reactionary tendency proved stronger than the forces working for higher prices, and so a majority of the day's changes were on the side of declines.

TRENTON, Jan. 12. -- Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day modified his order of last week, making W. C. Prather of New York and J. Kearney Rice of New Brunswick temporary instead of permanent receivers of the W. C. Praether Company of New York, the coffee and spice roasting concern that was burned out some months ago, and whose assets consist of insurance policies and book accounts.

Mr. BENJAMIN KIDD is contributing to The London Times a series of instructive articles on "Economic South Africa." It is commonly known that the labor question is the most urgent problem in the situation, but Mr. KIDD has collated and presented the facts more fully than any previous writer.

The full valuation plan of assessing real estate devised by the Mayor and the Controller breaks down on the very first trial of it. If the Mayor and the Controller took careful thought about their plan they must have expected it to break down. It was too suddenly sprung upon the public and too soon applied to permit of that diligent, systematic working out which was demanded by so important a piece of municipal business.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 12. -- Capt. Charles Barr, who will be skipper of the 1903 cup yacht, visited the boat shops here to-day. He is looking after his part of the arrangements for getting the craft into racing form as soon as she is in the water and rigged.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- It is probable a joint resolution will be passed before the close of the present week providing for the free admission of coal of every description for a period of six months.

Preliminary meetings will be held to-day of the stockholders of the Seventh National Back, the Mercantile National Bank, and the National Broadway Bank, to authorize the carrying out of the plans, announced some six months ago, but delayed from time to time, for a consolidation of these three banks.

There was a decided falling off in the volume of speculation yesterday, and this was attended With a pretty general decline in prices. There were evidences of extensive sales for realization of profits, and as the outside public failed to supply the needed new crop of buyers, the absorption of the stock thus thrown on the market was insufficient to maintain values.

The Sixteenth Senatorial District Convention met last night at Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue to nominate a candidate to succeed the late Patrick F. Trainor and William S. Devery, whose district, the Ninth, constitutes a part of the Sixteenth Senatorial, was very much in evidence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Mrs. Roosevelt received this afternoon from 4 to 6. Her visitors were a few personal friends and several detachments of schoolgirl pupils in the fashionable boarding schools of the District. Tea was served in the state dining room, and the entire first floor was open to the company.

Mrs. Astor gave her annual ball last evening at her residence, 842 Fifth Avenue. This ball is always the most prominent social event of the season. It is the one large entertainment to which all that is representative in society in New York is invited. In the list of private entertainments it stands first.

At a dinner at the City Club last evening ex-Senator John Ford, who is a Republican, made a violent attack upon Gov. ex-State Senator John Ford, who is a Republican, made a violent attack upon Gov. ernor's recommendation in his latest annual message of the repeal of the Ford franchise tax law.

After occupying the position as President of the Military Athletic League for six years, Lieut. Col. C. H. Luscomb, unattached, was defeated for re-election last night at the annual meeting of the League at the Ninth Regiment Armory. Although some of those in attendance said the meeting was practically harmonious it took from 8 o'clock until 11:30 to get things in order for the coming year.
The condition of ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, who lies near death's door at his residence, 9 Lexington Avenue, remained practically unchanged at 2 o'clock this morning.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 12. -- Louis Disbrow, indicted for murder in the first degree in connection with the death of Clarence Foster at Good Ground on June 14 last, when the body of Sarah or " Dimples " Lawrence was also found floating in Tiana Bay, was put on trial before Supreme Court Justice Maddox at this place to-day.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 13. -- The budget estimate for 1903 places the ordinary revenue at $948,516,339, the ordinary expenditure at $940,202,614.50, the surplus at $8,313,724.50, and the extraordinary expenditure at $95.631,121.50. The latter item will be met by the foregoing surplus, the extraordinary revenue of $1,250,000, and the Treasury reserve of $86,067,397.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- There was an exchange of cablegrams between Washington and Rome to-day which decided a number of details connected with the important action which the Pope has taken as to the Catholic University. It is settled that Mgr. O'Connell will come to Washington at once and take charge in his new responsibility before the end of the university year, probably arriving just before Easter.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- The money market is unchanged. The demand is large enough to prevent any pronounced accumulation. The banks are neither expecting nor encouraging low rates as sterling exchange is so near the export point that any further weakness would probably result in gold shipments.

Without question the President of Venezuela is within his rights when he insists that the blockade of Venezuelan ports shall be raised by the allies before the submission or discussion of the protocol of the treaty of arbitration. The continuance of the blockade is resented by Venezuela both as an injury and as an indignity.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 13. -- There is now from four to seven inches of ice in the south branch of the Shrewsbury River, and a number of ice yachts from the two local clubs -- the South Shrewsbury Ice Boat Club and the Shrewsbury Ice Boat Club -- were out skimming over the smooth surface of the frozen river during the greater part of the day.
Stocks weak. Money unchanged. 4@5 per cent, on call.

Directors were elected by many National and State banks and some trust companies in this city yesterday. In several of the banks the Directory was increased. In a few instances the officers were chosen by the Directors, but in the large majority of cases the selection of officers will be made later.

Many families in a two-story tenement house at 200 Mott Street and one woman in the four-story brick building at 21 Spring Street were rescued early this morning from probable death by the quick action of the police and firemen. The fire started under the stage in the Theatre Royal Marianette on the first floor of the Spring Street building, and which adjoins the Mott Street tenement.

At the January meeting of the New York Interscholastic Association, which was held yesterday afternoon in Columbia Grammar School, a change was made in the interscholastic hockey schedule. F.L. Ellingwood of Dwight School protested the schedule previously made up. A new committee was appointed, and the games to be played are as follows:

A line of blue-nosed ice "boomers" gathered around the margin of the Central Park lakes early yesterday morning, eager to begin their rush when the red ball, hoisted above the Arsenal, gave notice that New Yorkers were at liberty to indulge in figure eights, spread eagles, onter rolls, and grapevines, sitting down suddenly, and scrambling up sheepishly.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 13. -- There was a savor of Jersey swiftness in the Disbrow trial here to-day before Justice Maddox, and though there was no morning session, when court was adjourned at a few minutes before 9 o'clock to-night, one-quarter of the witnesses for the people had been examined. The twelfth juror was obtained early in the day.

The frightful death by fire of Mrs. HENRY, and the no less frightful death of a servant in her family by falling from the fourth story to the ground, give new point to a familiar and disgraceful condition of our "palatial residences." The dwelling in which these tragedies occured was in one of the most fashionable and costly of our residential regions, in a region built up without regard to expense.

Men stood up in vindication of the club, while women listened with skeptical smiles, at the January meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club, held last night in the rooms of the Aldine Association. The topic of the evening was "The Influence of the Club on Modern City Life," and the men who spoke said it was all good.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13. -- Shrine and L'Etrenne were the only winning favorites to-day. In the handicap Erne crossed the line in front of Major Tenny, shutting him off, and was disqualified, third place being given Major Tenny. Weather clear; track slow and lumpy. Summary:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Republican advocates of high protective duties, and particularly the maintenance of existing rates, were given a warm time to-day in the Senate. A general tariff debate arose over the question of making imported coal free.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The report of Nathan L. Miller, State Controller for last year, was made public to-day. It shows an actual surplus in the State Treasury of $8,001,346. This sum is more than $2,000,000 more than the estimate made last year, despite the fact that the direct taxes were $3,879,847 less than the year before.
LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Money was in active demand in the market to-day and supplies were not plentiful. Discounts were firm.
S.E. Forsythe of Chicago has been appointed Western general agent of the Atlantic Underwriters, the Mercantile, Lloyds and the United Fire Insurance Company of North Carchns.

Whether anything will come of the Mayor's conference with the executive officers of the coal roads yesterday we shall probably know when we find out. An appeal to dealers is not likely to be effective in changing the conditions. So long as they are able to maintain the present scale of charges they will probably do so.

Rear Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, C.B.M.P., who paid a visit to friends in this city last September, is here again, having arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Kaiserin Maria Theresia. This time, he said, he comes to promote his pet idea, the commercial unity of the two nations.

The full valuation plan of assessing real estate is under criticism on its demerits. The Mayor, the Controller, and the Department of Taxes and Assessments are open to criticism on the ground that the real reason for the change of method was not the avowed reason, and that they have not lived up to their own system by actually assessing or attempting to assess real estate at full valuation.

Sir Bache Cunard, President of the Cunard Line of steamships, recovered a judgment yesterday in the Supreme Court, after an inquest before Justice Herrick and a jury, for $1,657,709.81 against his first cousin, Charles G. Francklyn, who for some years had the management of his property in this State.

Mayor Low and representatives of the coal-carrying roads held a conference yesterday about the shortage of the coal supply of New York, with a view to bettering the conditions. The conference was called by Mayor Low on authorization of the Board of Aldermen. President George F. Baer of the Reading arrived at the City Hall accompanied by John B. Markle of the independent coal operators, F. D. Underwood.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- Two-thirds of to-day's transactions on the local Stock Exchange were in Reading. Erie, and Le-high Valley, the movement of whose prices closely followed New York's lead. The movement elsewhere was irregular. United Gas advanced 2 1/2 points on facorable earnings, and Broad Top common moved up 1 on the declaration of a 2 1/2 percent, dividend the first since January, 1897. when 1 per cent, was paid.

The opinion already expressed in these columns that Arizona is not fit for Statehood, seems to be shared by everybody who has given disinterested study to the subject. One of the most entertaining and instructive of Mr. OWEN WISTER'S tales of the Far West is largely devoted to the material, social, and moral conditions of the Territory in question.

The New York Zoological Society, at its ninth annual meeting, at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, elected as members of the Board of Directors of the class of 1906 Levi P. Morton, Andrew Carnegie, Morris K. Jesup, John L. Cadwalader, Philip Schuyler, John S. Barnes, Madison Grant, William White Niles, Samuel Thorne, Henry A.C. Taylor, Hugh J. Chisholm, and William D. Sloane.
Despite the cold last night the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church was comfortably filled by members of the Bible Class conducted by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. George F. Peabody and Edward M. Shepard spoke.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, on the application of James L. Reynolds, has granted an order for the Bank of Mount Vernon to show cause at a special term of court to be held at White Plains on Saturday next why a petition should not be granted for an examination of the bank's affairs by a referee.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The falling gavels of President Hutchinson and Speaker Horner in the Senate and Assembly, respectively, at 3 o'clock this afternoon marked the beginning of the one hundred and twenty-seventh session of the New Jersey Legislature. Organization in both houses was effected by electing the officers nominated by the Republican caucuses several days ago.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The Prussian Diet was reopened to-day. The Chancellor, Count von Bulow, read the speech from the throne. No mention was made of foreign matters, nor of the Canal bill. The speech took a gloomy view of the finances of Prussia. It said that the account for 1901 closed with a deficit of $9,375,000, and added that it was not anticipated that the accounts for 1902 would be apreciably more satisfactory.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- Having occupied nearly three days in calling witnesses to testify in opposition to the demands made by the anthracite miners, the Delaware and Hudson Company closed its case before the Coal Strike Commission this afternoon. The commission's attention was then called to the conditions existing in and about the collieries operated by the Erie Company.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- The Argentine Government has sent a representative to the United States on a search for teachers and professors for its normal schools. James H. Fitzsimons, the representative, is at present in Boston. He says: "We want two competent men as Professors, of Pedagogy and Experimental Psychology in the higher normal schools of Buenos Ayres.
Collins Collins have sold for Mrs. Sadie S. Dearborn to Dr. Joseph B. Bissell the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 46 West Fifty-fifth Street, 20 by 100.5.

-- Criticism of the elevated road's third rail is resented with somewhat amusing vehemence by The American Electrician, and, in its effort to defend the engineers who installed the new system, it attacks the managers of the company's traffic department with a severity that will seem excessive even to those who have written the fiercest letters to the papers about the inadequacies of the train service.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Alfred Skitt, Vice President of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company, appeared before the State Board of Railroad Commissioners this afternoon and secured the approval of the board to the lease by the Manhattan Company to the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.
The open and zealous advocacy of the nomination of Judge PARKER for the Presidential candidate of the Democratic Party by Senator CARMACK of Tennessee is extremely significant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Senator Kean of New Jersey entertained at a small dance this evening at his home, in I Street, in honor of his niece. Miss Christine Roosevelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Emlen Roosevelt of New York, and at present a guest at the White House.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13. -- The highest prices of the year in many Comstock shares were reached this morning. Best and Belcher going to $4.15; Consolidated Virginia to $3.50; Mexican to $3.15, and Union to $2.55. In the afternoon, however, heavy selling orders beat down the prices of the whole list.

LA GUAYRA, Venezuela, Jan. 13. -- The Russian bark Feodor, from Cardiff, with a cargo of coal for the La Guayra-Caracas Railroad, arrived off this port during the morning and was notified to heave to. The bark continued heading for the port until the British cruiser Tribune arrived, fired two blank shots, and signaled to the British dispatch boat Columbine to approach.

By a score of 4 goals to 3 the St. Nicholas Skating Club hockey team defeated the representatives of the Brooklyn Skating Club at the St. Nicholas Rink last night. It was one of the series of championship games of the Amateur Hockey League, and while these two teams are the weakest of the five entered, the game toward the close became very interesting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- It is learned at the State Department that Ambassador Tower has received from the German Foreign Office an unequivocal denial of the statement that found some currency a few days ago to the effect that the German Government was endeavoring to secure control of the Panama Canal franchise.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- Just as Cornell and the University of Syracuse were drawing together and seemed on the eve of resuming in all branches their interrupted athletic relations, it is learned that the latter has taken action which will probably sever rowing relations altogether. Last Fall Cornell sent invitations to Pennsylvania, Harvard.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 14. -- Representative Sulzer of New York introduced a bill today appropriating $30,000 for a statue to Samuel J. Tilden to be erected in Washington.

NEW HAVEN. Conn., Jan. 14. -- A committee to be known as the Graduate Advisory Committee on Track Athletics in Yale University has just been elected by the members of the Yale track team of 1902. The object of the institution of the committee is to insure a more definite and consistent policy in the management of track athletics.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 14. -- A new theatre to be erected here next summer by Nixon Zimmerman of Philadelphia will stand on the north side of Sixth Avenue between Montour Way and Cherry Alley. The properly was purchased from Henry W. Oliver and D.P. Black, the deal being made today between the Real Estate Trust Company and S.F. Nixon for the consideration of $600,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Concessions to the sugar interests were made by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations today, when an amendment designed to mect their demands was inserted into the Cuban treaty. It is believed that this change will insure support of the treaty by all the Republican members.
LONDON, Jan. 14. -- The conditions of money and discounts were unchanged today.

This afternoon is to be devoted as usual to receptions and teas. Mrs. Richard Lounsbery will give the second of her days, and Mrs. Schuchardt will give a dinner and a theatre party for her debutante daughter.

Stocks irregular. Money easy: 3 1/2@4 1/2 per cent, on call. The stock market yesterday, may be almost summed up in one word -- Erie. One-fourth of the total transactions of the day were in the common stock of that company. There were also heavy dealings in the bonds.

GREENWICH. Conn., Jan. 14. -- The first meeting of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club took place this evening. Commodore Frank Tilforcl was elected for the third time. George Lauder, Jr., was elected Vice Commodore, and H.P. Whittaker Rear Commodore. Richard Cutwater was elected Treasurer and Charles P. Geddes Secretary.

It is not often that Wall Street sees a break of nearly 50 points in the price of a standard railroad stock, but that is what it saw yesterday. The issue was Michigan Central, which, not traded in since Aug. 5 last, when it sold at 174 3/4, was offered down to 126 yesterday before a bidder was found.

With the gallery and every available inch of Space in the rear of the board room crowded with expectant femininity, the Board of Education at a special meeting yesterday afternoon decreed that matrimony is an offense for which the offending woman teacher must stand trial, and that a woman was "unfitted for the ardnous duties of an Associate Superintendent."

Never since the coal roads first became anthracite carriers was there such a congestion of that fuel at the docks where it is usually distributed throughout Greater New York and its vicinity as yesterday. The favorable conditions of the last two days enabled the companies to bring large freights of coal to tidewater much faster than it could be handled.
Several new elements have appeared in the Board of Directors of the North American Trust Company. The new Directors, who were elected Tuesday, and the inter-, ests' they represent, are:

Judge McMahon, sitting in Part III., Court of General Sessions, yesterday issued a warrant for the arrest of Coroner's Physician Albert T. Weston. who had failed to obey a subpoena and appear as a witness in a murder case which was being tried in that court. The warrant charges him with contempt of court.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Senator Plunkitt tonight introduced a bill for the repeal of the law chacted last session providing that all of the water front between West Fiftyfirst Street and West Fifty-fourth Street. Norch River, in the City of Greater New York, be reserved from March 29 to Dec. 31 actually for the exclusive use of the canallupts and barges engaged in the transportation business on the Hudson River.

The protectionist Republicans are not shameless. They are sensitive about their reputations. They have a manly way of standing by each other. Feeling that the injury of one is the concern of all, Senator HALE jumped to his feet the other day to defend the reputation of the late NELSON DINGLEY against a charge which he felt to be a calumny.

Four witnesses were examined yesterday in the secret proceedings held before Justice Wyatt for the purpose of getting evidence against Richard Canfield. Among them was George A. Kessler. the wine merchant, who was subpoenaed at the French Ball, and whose application to the Supreme Court for a writ of prohibition was refused earlier in the day by Justice Leventritt. Mr. Kessler.
T.W. Dennett, and J.H. Hollister represented Williams. The judges were Hammond Lamont and Professors Carroll L. Maxcy and George R. Carpenter.

BERLIN, Jan. 14. -- The Reichstag to-day adopted by 143 to 70 votes the Tariff Committee's resolution asking the Government to consider whether it is not in the interests of the nation to place a differential duty on refined petroleum, as against crude, in order to establish a national refining industry. The resolution is directed against the Standard Oil Company.

NEWARK, Jan. 14. -- Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick of the United States Circuit Court. District of New Jersey, handed down a decision to-day permanently enjoining the Pennsylvania Railroad Company from removing the poles and wires of the Western Union Telegraph Company from its railroad lines located within the jurisdiction of the court.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 14. -- Another Louisville girl is to become a peeress, according to a letter received by Mrs. William Bennett from her sister, Mrs. Josephine Armstrong of Louisville, who is now sojourning in Vevay, Switzerland. Lord Rosebery, ex-Premier of England, it is said, is to claim as a bride the handsome Mrs. Alice Carr Chauncey, formerly Miss Alice Carr. whose sister is now Lady Newborough.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 14. -- Two races were sailed this afternoon by the Shrewsbury Ice Boat Clubs. The first, for the club championship pennant, fifteen miles, six times around a triangular course of two and one-half miles, was won by J.E. Green's Eagle in 44:06; Walter Content's Clare L. was second in 44:14, and E.W. Reid's Florence A. was third in 45:05.

Police Commissioner Greene yesterday transferred Capt. Becker from the East Thirty-fifth Street Station to the Union Market Station, at Houston and Sheriff Streets, to take the place of Capt. Gorman, whom he suspended last Sunday for permitting excise violations. Then he asserted that he had reason to believe that there was blackmail being exacted in the precinct, but he would not mention any names.
Army. Lieut. Col. Joshua W. Jacobs, Deputy Quartermaster General, will proceed to Fort Smith on official business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Demand that the Republican Party shall cause the enactment of a law to pension former slaves was made to the President to-day. The penalty of refusal will be the renewal of a movement to organize a bolt of the Republican Party by the Northern negroes.

The report of the Nominating Committee of the United States Golf Association will be sent out to-day. Its members are Deveraux Emmet, Garden City Golf Club; Herbert Jaques. Country Club, Brookline, and W.A. Alexander, Exmoor (III.) Golf Club. The ticket will be elected at the annual meeting on Feb. 17, at Delmonico's, as there is no question of an opposition ticket.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- In the list of Senate Committees handed down by Lieut. Gov. Higgins to-night the olive branch is held out to Senators Brackett, Brown, and Elsberg, the three bolters, who had been threatened with disciplining by the organization.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 14. -- The opening race of the winter of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon, when eight of the third-class boats competed in a race of fifteen miles for prizes offered by Commodore Samuel W. Morford. The race was exciting from start to finish, and was watched by hundreds of spectators.

BOSTON, Jan. 14. -- The American Board of Commissioners for foreign missions received a cable to-day from Ahmednagar, India, announcing the death from blood poisoning of George W. Harding, M.D. Dr. Harding was born in India, the son of the late Rev. Charles Harding, a missionary of the American Board at Sholapur.

According to an opinion submitted yesterday to Corrections Commissioner Thomas W. Hynes by Corporation Counsel George W. Rives there are many women and men in the penal institutions of the City of New York who ought to be free and are unjustly detained.
The Governing Board of the New York Stock Exchange last night listed the following securities:

The very interesting interview with Senor ENRIQUE CREEL which we published the other day indicates that the Government of Mexico is working in a careful and intelligent manner toward the adjustment of its currency to the gold standard to which all financial relations with the rest of the world have to conform.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Coal provides the overshadowing issue in Congress. Republicans acted with Democrats to-day in enacting a bill which puts anthracite coal on the free list and provides rebate of duties on all coal for a year. It was passed by the House by a vote of 258 to 6, and was rushed through the Senate with only enough time to observe formalities.

President H.O. Havemeyer of the American Sugar Refining Company at the annual meeting of the company in Jersey City yesterday. In presenting the annual report, made some statements regarding the lower price of sugar and in connection with this made some criticism on legislation against trusts.

While firemen were fighting flames and rescuing tenants at 1,764 Madison Avenue last night, a young baby sat unguarded on the stone coping of a second-story window overlooking the street, and probably enjoyed the spectacle, for when the excitement had died down, she was found crowing and laughing.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 14. -- At the trial to-day of Louis A. Disbrow for the murder of Clarence Foster, whose body, with that of "Dimple" Lawrence, was taken from Tiana Bay, near Good Ground, last June, the greater part of the sessions was devoted to testimony by expert witnesses. It was the evident purpose of the District Attorney to prove that Foster had been killed before he was thrown into the water.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- Thomas Dormady, one of the oldest railroad engineers in the United States, died this morning at his home In this city, as a result of a stroke of apoplexy, aged seventy-five years. He run first, in 1850 on the old engine "Rochester" formerly 'he "John Bull" and in 1852 he went to Canada, running the first passenger train over the Grand Trunk betwen Hamilton and Niagara falls.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. Jan. 14. -- The quiet investigation that Gov. Nash has been making of the coal situation for several days bore result this afternoon, when Attorney General Sheets, at the instigation of the Governor, filed in the Supreme Court quo warranto suits against six big coal companies to oust them from their charters.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Improvement of the canals was brought promptly to the attention of the Legislature to-night when a bill providing for the l,000-ton barge plan was introduced in both houses. This measure was prepared under the direction of the Canal Association of New York City, which represents the great commercial associations of the metropolis.

Joseph Kirkland of Washington, D.C., the nineteen-year-old pool expert, defeated Thomas Burns of New York last night by a score of 125 to 75 in the fifth game of the professional sweepstakes pool tournament at the Montauk Billiard Academy, Brooklyn. Kirkland, although beaten in the opening game on Monday night by Stofft of Cleveland, gave promise of redeeming himself during his later games, and his effort last night was brilliant in every sense.

The American liner St. Louis, which sailed from Southampton on Jan. 4, and is now nearly three days overdue, had not been sighted up to an early hour this morning. Those who have relatives and friends aboard are beginning to feel some anxiety, for after making ample allowance for the liner's reduced steaming power on account of her leaky boilers, the St. Louis should have made port on Monday.

The proposition to create a Democratic campaign fund for the next Presidential election from the sale of soap is novel, perhaps, but incongruous only because the principal use of campaign funds is for the benefit of the class of citizens who do not themselves use soap enough in four years to pay the costs of one good-sized demonstration.

M. Lindheim Co. and Ranald II. Macdonald have sold for Elizabeth A. Wilcox to Edward H. Litehfield the Arlington apartment hoted, a new eleven-story fireproof structure, on plot 30 by 98.9. on the south side of Twenty-fifth Street, just west of Broadway, and adjoining the Hoffman House.

Assistant District Attorney Morgan is authority for the statement that George Bissert, ex-Police Captain Diamond's old wardman, and once a plain clothes man under Police Captain Herlihy, has told both his counsel and District Attorney Jerome all he knows about the collecting of blackmail in the department, and also has told "where the money went."

By a clever piece of detective work Capt. Martens ou the West One Hundred and Twenty-firth Street Police Station, with the assistance of six of his precinct detectives, yesterday rounded up and placed under arrest a sextet of policy men who are believed to have been operating with great success in Harlem for several weeks past.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 15. -- J.E. Green's Eagle, won the championship pennant of the Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club, covering the triangrular course of 15 miles in 29:00, which is considered fast time. Jesse Potters, Commodore, was second, one minute behind. Two other starters, the Gypsy Girl, and the Clare L., broke down and withdrew.

The Panama Canal situation is now at a stage when neither negotiator can afford to make any false moves. Finesse is exhausted, and all concerned are face to face with facts. As between the United States and the canal company the offer to sell the company's concession lapses by its own limitation on March 4.

It is a great pity that the Senate should have stricken out that part of the Militia bill which provides for the establishment of a reserve force, to the number of 100,000, consisting of men honorably discharged from the army, the volunteers or the National Guard, who shall report yearly their residences, and who shall hold themselves in readiness to be mustered into service immediately on the outbreak of war.

Hundreds of live pigeons were slaughtered at the old racetrack, Guttenberg, N.J., yesterday in order to decide the Eastern Team Championship at live birds. Pigeon shooting has been outlawed in New York State, but as there Is no ban against it in New Jersey, matches are of almost daily occurrence there, and many residents of Greater New York and Long Island are to be found among the gunners who take part in the events.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The National Board of Trade to-day adopted a series of resolutions in favor of reciprocity. The resolutions were presented by Nathan French of the Illinois Manufacturers' Association, on behalf of the Committee on Reciprocity. The important resolution of the series is that following the preamble.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt left Newport again to-day for New York to meet Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and Miss Gladys Vanderbilt on their arrival from Europe. Reginald C. Vanderbilt remains at Oakland Farm, and is busy overseeing the extensive improvements which are being made at his farm at Sandypoint.

Gen. Francis V. Greene, the Commissioner, under the authority conferred on him by Section 300 of the City Charter, yesterday issued an order, under which Rule No. 51 of the Police Department is so amended that dating from 7 P.M., Sunday, Jan. 25, the present two-platoon patrol system of four sections will be succeeded by a six-section system without any platoon designation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- Most of the testimony presented to the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission to-day was of a corroborative rature, the Eric Company, which has not yet concluded its case, producing numerous witnesses to prove that the miners' union is responsible for the alleged restriction of the hard-coal production.

The American Protective Tariff League at its annual meeting yesterday, adopted resolutions declaring that reciprocity in competitive products by treaty is unsound in principle, pernicious in practice, and is contrary alike to the principle of protection to the fair treatment of domestic producers and to friendly relations with foreign countries.

The American liner St. Louis, now nearly four days overdue, had not been sighted at an early hour this morning. A widespread anxiety as to her whereabouts was made manifest yesterday at the American Line offices in the Empire Building, into which poured a constant stream of inquiries in regard to the missing liner.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The American Line steamship St. Paul, which arrived at Southampton at an early hour this morning from New York. Jan. 7, reported having encountered heavy weather, and inquirers at the offices of the American Line here today were given this and leaky beilers as the probable cause of the delay in the arrival of her sister ship, the St. Louis, from Southampton Jan. 4.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 15. -- The taking of testimony in the trial of Louis A. Disbrow for murder in the first degree was concluded to-day. The accused young man did not take the stand in his own behalf. Rowland Miles, his counsel, followed the lead established by the District Attorney yesterday, and was brief with all witnesses, and there was little cross-examining.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to-day ordered a favorable report on the Cuban reciprocity treaty, and it was reported this afternoon in the executive session.

An opinion was handed down yesterday in the United States Circuit Court by Judge Wheeler, sustaining the validity of the United States tax imposed upon the Vanderbilt estate under the War Tax act of June 13, 1898, amounting to $311,681.36, as assessed and collected by United States Collector of Internal Revenue Ferdinand Eidman.

BERLIN, Jan. 15. -- Baron Speck von Sternberg, the newly Appointed Charge d'Affaires of Germany at Washington, spent the greater part of the day at the Foreign Office. He probably will be received by the Emperor in audience next Saturday.

If Mr. ONNARD and the beet-sugar men have agreed to abandon their opposition to the reciprocity treaty with Cuba in consideration of the amendment adopted by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, they are easily satisfied. They ought to see, the Foreign Relations Committee doubtless does see, that the amendment introduces no additional safeguard for the Beet-sugrar Trust, and is without binding force.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Members of leading firms representing South African interests held an important meeting at the offices of Wernher, Beit Co. this afternoon and definitely agreed on a war contribution of $150,000,000, payable in three annual installments and covered by a loan not redeemable before ten years.
During yesterday's meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission. Mayor Low, in describing a recent trip he had through portions of the subway, said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The President signed the Free Coal bill at 1:15 o'clock this afternoon. It was carried to the White House by Representative Wachter of Maryland, Chairman of the Committee on Enrolied Bills. The President commended Congress in acting so promptly, and remarked that it gave him great pleasure to approve the measure.
ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Theodore P. Gilman, First Deputy State Controller, resigned his office this morning to accept the Presidency of the General Electric Inspection Company of New York.

The action of both houses of Congress on Wednesday in regard to coal, which resulted in putting anthracite on the free list and according a rebate on bituminous coal for one year, suggests some thoughts which may be discussed in a kindly spirit with the intelligent membership of the United Mine Workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The engagement is announced of Miss Carola De Peyster, daughter of Col and Mrs. Johnston L. De Peyster, of this city and New York to Garrett P. Kip of the latter city. Miss De Pesyter made her debut at the Connecticut Avenue home of her parents two years ago, and has enjoyed great popularity.

Over 800 persons who have been accustomed to vote the Republican ticket every time there was a chance with the regularity of their habit or getting up in the morning and going to bed at night, gathered last night in the Concert Hall of Madison Square Garden on the occasion of the annual dinner of the Republican Organization of the Nineteenth Assembly District.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- There was a strong demand for money in the market to-day owing to its being Stock Exchange pay day.

The concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, given last evening in Carnegie Hall -- the first of their third trip to this city for the present season -- was of uncommon interest for several reasons. First, it brought to the attention of their New York friends for the first time two new symphonic works by Mr. Charles Martin Loeffler.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15. -- L'Etrenne and Hargis, both of whom scored easily, were the only winning favorites to-day. Paul Creyton was run up to $1,205 after the second race and bought in. As the barrier went up in the last race. Rough Rider, the favorite, reared up and was left at the post.

With the Erie shares contributing one-fourth of the entire market transactions, which, all told, exceeded little more than 500,000 shares, there is not much to be said of the movements in particular stocks -- this because few issues were affected by developments or news special to them.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 15. -- Six of the third class boats of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club sailed a race to-day for the club challenge pennant in that class, and the winner was Charles Irwin's Georgie. George J. Gillig's Wizard was second, four minutes later. Ivy Hance's Northwest was third; Charles Robin's Snail was fourth; Edward Asay's Daisy, fifth, and Daniel Asay's Zero, sixth.

Stocks heavy. Money easy, 2 1/2@4 1/2 per cent. on call. While money was easier yesterday and Exchange lower, the stock market was dull and heavy. As the bull manipulation of last week failed to inspire any large measure of outside interest, so the reaction of this week has not led to public participation in the market.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 15. -- The sudden buoyancy of the Fidelity Bonding Companies was the feature of to-day's trading. American Bonding has a good run and scored an advance of ten points before the arrival of the noon hour. This was ascribed to the report of a large increase in the net earnings during the last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Tillman (Dem., S.C.) continued his discussion of trusts and monopolies, basing his remarks on the Vest resolution regarding the removal of the duty on coal.

ALBANY, Jan 15. -- The Republican and Democratic Senatorial caucuses will be held next Monday night after the session. The expectation is that Senator Thomas C. Platt will receive the votes of all of the Republican Senators, except Senators Brackett and Brown.

Two thousand persons attended the annual athletic games and cycle races of the Ninth Regiment, which were held in the Armory in West Fourteenth Street last night. The contests were sanctioned by the Military Athletic League and among the competitons were most of the best athletes belonging to the other local military organizations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- Securities on the Chicago Exchange were only fairly active to-day. Gossip turned this way and that on the local traction situation. Holders of stocks besieged brokers and politicians to give them inside information on the question of franchise settlement. Traction stocks fluctuated contrarily.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 15. -- N.G. Gonzales, editor of The State and widely known throughout the South, is at the Columbia Hospital in a critical condition as a result of a pistol wound inflicted by James H. Tillman, Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina. The shooting occurred on Main Street, just at the intersection of Gervais Street, in full view of the State Capitol, a few minutes before 2 o'clock.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator Hill of Buffalo, to whom was given the bill prepared by the Greater New York Canal Association, introduced in the Assembly last night by Mr. Bostwick of New York, decided today not to introduce the bill until after he had had a conference with the canal men. This conference will be held in Albany next Monday.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- The Times publishes an account from a correspondent of the "etherization" of plants, a new process whereby plants naturally flowering in the Spring are made to produce blossoms during the previous Autumn.

Irregularity was again shown by the trading in the outside market yesterday, but in most cases where the changes were substantial they were on the side of net gains. In a number of issues the buying was sufficiently determined to bring about considerable improvement, the gains in some stocks amounting to one or more points.

The Corcoran Gallery at Washington is showing the water colors of a local painter, Mr. Walter Paris, including a picture of Pennsylvania Avenue during the blizzard of 1809, Summer work from Colorado and Massachusetts, and aquarelles taken during trips to England and France. These pictures are in the hemicycle.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Assemblyman Finch to-day introduced several bills relating to the police force of Greater New York. The principal one provides for the virtual recreation of the office of Chief of Police, which was abolished when the reform administration came into power as a means of getting rid of Devery, the then Chief.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- From the headquarters of the Amalgamated Association of Street Railway employes to-day came the positive announcement that Clarence S. Darrow has agreed to submit his name as a candidate for the Mayoralty.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- More mine officials were called to the witness stand to-day and informed the Coal Strike Commissioners that under the influence of the union the mine workers restricted the production of anthracite coal and otherwise interfered with the discipline of the employes.

At the annual dinner of the New York Lehigh Club, at the University Club, last evening, a perceptible echo of the coal strike of last Summer interrupted the opening speech of the toastmaster, H.F.J. Porter, Vice-President of the Lehigh Club, the toastmaster, was discussing the subject of education and the obligation educators were under to help labor and capital to settle their disputes.

Col. McClure's political papers have given in general form what he now presents, surrounded by recollections of personal Import. Formerly the individuality of the writer was somewhat overshadowed by the prominence of his subjects. Here the author is first, and the reader sees Generals, statesmen, politicians, as well as actors and editors, through his eyes and bound more or less by his personal contact.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- The will of Dr. Bushrod James of this city, which was probated to-day, devises to the City of Philadelphia $55,000, several pieces of real estate in this city and several lots at Island Beach, N.J., for the purpose of establishing a free hospital here for the treatment of diseases of the eye, throat and lungs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt were the hosts at a dinner of twenty covers this evening, and afterward held a large musicale in the East Room, at which the company numbered three hundred. The artists of the evening were Miss Josephine Sullivan, harpist: Miss Lilian Littlehales, cellist, and Miss Mary Golden Tracey, soprano, with Mr. Charles L. Safford, accompanist.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Representative Fitzgerald of New York to-day introduced a bill "to encourage and promote and develop the merchant marine of the United States." Such titles generally indicate a subsidy proposition, but Mr. Fitzgerald's does not. It is as follows:

"Ideas of Good and Evil." by the wellknown Irish poet. W.B. Yeats, is in press at the Macmillan Company. Good ideas and bad ones, declares the author, are derived from poetry and art. He says in one of his essays that he believes in "the practice and philosophy of what we have agreed to call magic, in what I must call the evocation of spirits," and he adds:

A decision of interest and importance to real estate brokers, in the case of Morris Grossman, appellant, vs. Jacob Caminez and Simon Berg, respondents, written by Supreme Court Justice John Woodward, was harded down yesterday in the Appellate Division, Supreme Court, Second Department.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT has written an introduction to "A Woman That Toils," which will be published early in February by Doubleday, Page Co. It represents the combined work of Marie and Bessie Van Vorst, the former of whom is the daughter of the late Judge Van Vorst of New York.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The Winnecomack Gun Club of Commack, Suffolk County, was incorporated to-day to operate in Smithtown and Huntington, Suffolk County. The directors are: President, Henry O. Havemeyer; Carl L.S. Burr. Jr., of Commack: George W. Elder, Islip, Long Island: and Harry Peters and Samuel T. Peters of New York City.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Controller Nathan L. Miller to-day completed the compilation of the assessed valuation of real and personal property in the several counties of the State as reported to him by the local authorities for the purposes of taxation.

Calling Policeman Magner of the West Thirtieth Street Station, on post at 7 o'clock last night, Commissioner Greene told him that the residence next to his own, 31 East Thirtieth Street, had been undergoing repairs, and that several charcoal stoves had been placed in the rooms to dry the plaster.

Col. Thomas Wentworth Higginson is lecturing in the Lowell Institute (Boston) course this year on "American Literature in the Nineteenth Century." "The Philadelphia Period" was the title of his second lecture, delivered last week. Some of the statements in this were striking and uncommonly suggestive.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 10 -- N.G. Gonzales, editor of The State, who was shot and seriously wounded by Lieut. Gov. James H. Tillman yesterday, is holding his own at 9 o'clock to-night. There has been no change in his condition and the crisis is yet to come. The best physicians in this part of the State are doing all they can to save his life, but hold out, little hope of his recovery.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 16 -- The Connecticut Cat Club will have its first annual show in the armory here next week, as planned, but there will be no slaughter of mice. The field event for kittens and rodents has been scratched owing to the opposition to such a demonstration that developed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator McLanrin of Mississippi has given up his attempt to have the Post Office at Indianola reopened. He said to-day that all the compromise propositions he offered, however fair they might be, had been rejected. He first tried to have the Postmaster General designate one of Postmaster Minnie Cox's bondsmen to act as Postmaster temporarily, but without effect.

Gov. Odell last evening answered the attacks that have been made on him for his advocacy of the repeal of the franchise tax law and the substitution of a law taxing the gross earnings. Merchants, lawyers, insurance men, and others listened to the statements of the Governor as to the methods which were being used by State officials in reducing the burden of taxes on New York real estate, and shouted approval.

AS material for study the Professor of English literature in Knox College has written a special volume in which there pass in review all the leading English men of letters, from Beowulf to Browning. In the introductory chapter the author presents the Anglo-Saxon period.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- Comparative ease still holds sway in the money market, but easing of rates is very gradual. Call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 5@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount; clearings, $34,363,932; balances, $3,438,034.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Gov. Odell has approved the findings of a court-martial which convicted Lieut. Joseph T. Griffin of Company D, Fourteenth Regiment, of Brooklyn, of disobedience of orders and of making a false certificate affirming his presence at drill. Lieut. Griffin was fined $100 and ordered reprimanded in general orders.

Do the Democrats of the Senate really think that it is good politics to oppose the Cuban reciprocity treaty simply to "put the Republicans in a hole"? That is the report of our exceptionally well-informed correspondent in Washington, and it is confirmed by reference to previous action by the Democrats in like cases.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books : The article in your last issue, printed under the above caption, attracts my notice from the way in which the case is stated.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Henry Charles Lea has the distinguished honor of having been declared infalliable in the matter of the monograph in the Cambridge History Series, Vol. I., by the reviewer of that volume. William Roscoe Thayer. At least, that is what is implied in the verdict of Mr. Thayer:

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- At a conference of the Supreme Court Justices here to-day it was decided that Justice Dixon should take the Hudson circuit left vacant by the resignation of Justice Collins. Justice Pitney will succeed Justice Dixon in the Passaic Bergen circuit. Justice Swayze, the new Justice, will take the Mercer circuit.

Ex-Justice William Rumsey died of heart disease at 2 o'clock yesterday morning in his home, at 200 West Fifty-sixth Street. Although he had not been in the best of health for a year there was no intimation of his death when he left his law office, at 26 Liberty Street, on the previous afternoon.

Frances Weston Carruth has displayed a rare amount of research and patience in the compilation of her "Fictional Rambles In and About Boston," for she has followed nearly every character of modern fiction whose paths lead along the road to Boston, even in cases where the hero or heroine in question simply strolled across the Common or rested beneath the shadow of the Shaw Monument.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. William Roscoe Thayer, in his "Statement of the Real Character of the Bortgia Pope." in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, did not squarely meet the objections made to his remarks as published on Dec. 27. While the statement was vigorous, it was not at all to the point.

The journal of the forty-first annual meeting of the National Educational Association, held at Minneapolis last July, has just appeared. Its 1,000 and more pages contain matters of interest to all who are even remotely connected with education, whether college, kindergarten, or physical. Among the life Directors of the association are President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia.

Longmans, Green Co. are about to issue a new and revised edition of Prof. W. Basil Worsfold's "Principles of Criticism." The purpose of the book is to present an account of the main principles of literary criticism, and these principles are illustrated by quotations from great writers. Prof. Worsfold has done the translations from the French, German, and Greek.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 16 -- Louis A. Disbrow was acquitted of the murder of Clarence Foster this afternoon and was set at liberty. District Attorney Smith seemed greatly disappointed. He was asked whether he would try Disbrow on the indictment charging him with the murder of "Dimple" Lawrence, the girl who disappeared with Foster on the night of June 10 last, and whose body was found with his in Tiana Bay.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- There will be introduced in the Legislature next week several bills providing for similar changes in the government of the Fire Department of New York City to the changes proposed for the Police Department in the measures introduced this week by Mr. Finch.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- A firm tone characterized the local market to-day, but there was no improvement in the trading, which was very dull. Traders bought Reading, but there was evidence of liquidation in Lehigh Valley, which receded slightly, while Reading advanced a substantial fraction and Lehigh Navigation rose a full point.

During a fight which followed a disagreement over a dinner bill last night in the Black Cat Cafe, 551 West Broadway, near Bleecker Street. Detective Sergeant William D. Welsh, who is attached to the District Attorney's office, was shot through the neck. He is said to be dying in St. Vincent's Hospital, where he was removed.

There was much uneasiness in the Police Department yesterday and speculation was rife regarding the identity of those implicated in the confession of George Bissert, the Wardman of ex-Capt. Diamond when he was in command of the "Red Light District."

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Manager R.W. Singer of the Baseball Association this evening made public the Princeton schedule for next season. It contains twenty-eight games, the same as last season, but will open one week later. The most notable feature of the list is the game with the University of Pennsylvania, which will be played here on May 9.

It was a thesis play in four sermons, by the author of "Degeneration." with which the Empire dramatic students chiefly wrestled yesterday afternoon. It was called "The Right to Love," but quite as good a title would have been a tragic cry of yesterday's heroine. "Mommer, why did you marry me : "The thesis is that you have no right to love, and that mommer has every right to marry you.

The American liner St. Louis, five days overdue from Southampton, was sighted off Nantucket Lightship at 6:40 o'clock last evening. The belated liner was proceeding very slowly and was apparently disabled. The St. Louis made signals to the South Shoal Lightship, but a heavy gale was blowing, and it was impossible to make them out from shore.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- By a vote of 141 to 67 the Reichstag to-day adopted the substitute for the resolution of Baron Heyl zu Herrnsheim, asking the Government to denounce the most favored nation treaties, which was directed against the United States and Argentina. The substitute requested the Government to denounce treaties with countries where experience had shown that the most favored nation clause was injurious to Germany's interest.

Commissioner GREENE deserves credit for the vigor and independence with which he has taken hold of the vexed question of the distribution of the time of policemen. He has refused to be shut up to the choice of either the two-platoon or the three-platoon plans, which have become the subject of so much heated partisanship.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In a communication printed in your isuue of Jan. 2, 1903, the Rev. Dr. Henry M. King of Newport. R.I., take's exception to the statement made by me in my "Rhode Island. Its Making and its Meaning," that "Roper Williams came as near as his age would permit in the case of a soul at once supremely honest and truly devout to being an Agnostic."
