LONDON, Jan. 17 -- In a dispatch from Cairo the correspondent of The Daily Mail reports the discovery in Syria of one of the oldest Hebrew manuscript Bibles. It consists of the five books of Pentateuch, written in Samaritan characters on gazelle parchment in the year 116 of the Moslem era.

If approbation from Sir Hubert is priceless, what shall we say of the other thing? We suppose that any man of whom Mr. J. PIERPOUT MORGAN had said he was one of the ablest railroad managers in the country might consider his fortune made. Great corporations would be likely to compete for the services of a man who had Mr. MORGAN'S confidence in this degree.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books : There is in the literary career but one thing more interesting than writing the book: that is the constant contemplation of the facile adaptability of the cricle's mind. For instance, because I policayed Jefferson in his true colors I was accused of feminine prejudice and partisanship "Of course a woman must be expected to fall in love with her hero and hate his enmies,"

Does it not sound strange to call Sir Francis Drake "the chief pirate of Queen Elizabeth"? When the boy, Francis Drake, was born (1541), there was intense hatred born of religious differences. Moral standards wore lax and life was held cheap. With his first breath little Francis drew in "a fierce hatred of Spain, and a mastering love of the sea."

In view of the 10-point rise in the foreign exchange market yesterday and the suggestions of probable gold exports next week, the following statement by C. Schumacher, an expert in the matter, is of interest:

The mild weather of yesterday caused a change of attitude in the camp of the independent coal operators, and one independent firm reduced the tide-water price of anthracite from $10 to $8 a ton. The others determined to go slower, but the price generally dropped from $10.50 a ton at tide water to $9.75, and its owners were hustling all they could to get it into market.
Barely a dozen stocks were active in yesterday's market, and of these only a few were influenced by news or developments special to them.

Mr. Bowdoin's interesting article, on another page of this number of THE REVIEW, will give people who are not professionally or commercially interested in the subject a new notion, we should imagine, of the remarkable increase which has taken place in this country of general interest in bookbinding.

The speech attributed by one report to the editor GONZALES, after the Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina had shot him once and was pointing his pistol at him for a second shot fitly expresses the opinion of the assailant which will be held by all civilised people. GONZALES exclaimed:" Shoot again, you dirty coward!"

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 16 -- An ice yacht race, which was probably the closest and most exciting ever held on the North Shrewsbury River, was decided here this morning. The contest was for silver prizes offered by George J. Gillig of New York, a member of the North Shrewsbury Club and owner of the yacht Wizard.

Aside from sheer material Information the value of description of place depends upon the author's ability to reflect from the page his own impressions of things seen or emotions aroused -- always admitted, of course, that these impressions and emotions are worthy of perpetuation. And where one employs figures of speech, references or poetical quotations, one should be sure that their analogy is generally understood.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- A decision was given by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to-day in the case of the American Bell Telephone Company vs. the National Telephone Manufacturing Company. The suit involved the Berliner patent for a telephone transmitter, which patent Judge Brown, in the Circuit Court, sometime ago held to be invalid.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 16 -- A sensation was caused in the Circuit Court to-day when Judge Cantrill summoned into open court the Grand Jury which has had under investigation the Goebel murder case, hearing the testimony of Henry E. Youtsey, Judge Cantrill said to the jury:

SIMPLICITY appears to be a characteristic of the lesser poets of the present day. They may be sentimental and frequently are; they may sin against the laws of prosody; they may sacrifice the rhyme to the reason or the reason to the rhyme, but they are not, as a rule, either affected or elaborate.

At the Opera House last evening " Die Walkiire." the first part of Wagner's trilogy of "The Ring of the Nibelung." was given in the performance of the complete cycle now in progress there. It was again made plain that the admirers of the trilogy do not all take seriously the necessity of including the prologue.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: After I read the remarks by Messrs. Thayer, Hanren, and Walsh on Alexander VI. in your issue of Dec. 27 and Jan. 3, I turned to the new edition of " The Realencyclopadie, filr protestantische Theologie and Kirche." Leipsic, 1896-1902, now in course of publication, to find out what it had to say.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day, and there were renewed borrowings from the Bank of England, estimated to amount to $15,000,000. Discounts were maintained.

In the world where every one can converse in French and every one dines at 8, and where it is equally creditable to live on an inheritance or on debts -- in this world, at once an Almanach de Gotha of snobbery and a democracy of clearness, there is no individual more to be envied than the diplomat.

To-day is to be devoted to Hymen, as there are to be three weddings in the afternoon. That of Dwight Braman and Miss Helen Stuyvesant Dudley is to be a quiet home affair. The bride is a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant. Her sister, Miss Dudley, and a cousin, Miss Winterhoff, will be her attendants.

ONE of the oddest instances of literary success from unforeseen causes is the sale of Mr. George Wharton James's "Indian Basketry." Written as a fragment of ethnological study. It has gained vogue because basketmaking happens to be one of the present amusements in fashionable circles, having found its way thither from the vacation schools and Settlement houses.

THE great question, Whence came the Indians? receives no solution from this painstaking and useful work, in which Mr. Carl Lumholtz has embodied the results of his various residences in Mexico during the past ten years.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. William Roscoe Thayer, In his reply in THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Jan. 10, 1903, to my exceptions to his criticism of the chantcter of Alexander VI., as given by Dr. Richard Garnett in Volume I. of the "Cambridge Modern History, says that " Dr. Garnett's portrait leaves the Borgia an almost all-round monster."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. William Roscoe Thayer, In his reply in THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Jan. 10, 1903, to my exceptions to his criticism of the chantcter of Alexander VI., as given by Dr. Richard Garnett in Volume I. of the "Cambridge Modern History, says that " Dr. Garnett's portrait leaves the Borgia an almost all-round monster."

Rutgers College Alumni Association of New York and its vicinity intends to build a clubhouse. The intention is to have it on Thirty-fourth Street, as near to Fifth Avenue as the money subscribed will allow.

From time to time the extreme youth of the Windy City is strikingly brought home to us by the anouncement in the papers of the death of a man who, it is said, was born in Chicago when the nearest dwelling was three miles distant. But here we have a book written by one of the earlier settlers who to-day is one of the most prom- inent citizens of the great metropolis on the lake.

ONLY eyestrain, indeed, but that is quite enough, as it seems now to be the cause of more than half the ills that flesh is heir to. We have already referred, with polite amazement, but not irreverently, to Dr. George M. Gould's new book, called "Biographic Clinics," which attributes the ill-health of De Quincey, Carlyle, Darwin, Huxley, and Browning to a "morbid function" of the eyes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senators Spooner, Lodge, and Aldrich, in a conference this morning with the President, assured him that the Cuban reciprocity treaty was reasonably certain to be ratified by the Senate. The situation has been carefully canvassed by the Republican leaders, and the judgment expressed by the three Senators is based thereon.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- John Lane will publish here soon E. J. Carpenter's book called "The American Advance: A Study in Territorial Expansion." illustrated with a unique map showing the gradual growth of the United States from the time of the Revolution to the present day.

Volume II. in the Athenian Drama, a series of verse translations from the Greek dramatic poets, is devoted to "Sophocles," by Prof. John Swinnerton Phillimore of the University of Glasgow. It is published by Longmans, Green Co.

This essay on "The Religion of Plutarch," by John Oakesmith, D. Litt., M.A., which is shortly to be brought out by Longmans. Green Co., is a reprint of the volume which was issued for private circulation about a year ago under the title of "The Religion of Plutarch as Expounded in His 'Ethics.'"

FOND DU LAC, Wis., Jan. 16. -- Managers representing fifteen theatres, making a circuit from Fond du Lac to Duluth, perfected an organization to-day to be known as the Northwestern Theatre Managers' Association. The object is to secure a better class of attractions for the theatres in the circuit.

The authorities of Balliol College, Oxford, and Henry Frowde, the publisher, have conferred a real boon on thousands by the selection and publication in a cheap and convenient form of passages from Prof. Jowett's introduction to Plato's Republic and other dialogues. The five fat volumes of the original work are too formidable for the busy man who may not be exactly a scholar and is assuredly not a specialist in Greek literature.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 16 -- Ohio mine workers, in convention to-day, voiced a demand for the reconstruction of existing injunction laws. They declare for modifications as follows:

MANILA, Jan. 16 -- At the continuation to-day of the trial of Major Edwin F. Glenn of the Fifth Infantry, who is charged with unlawfully killing seven prisoners of war in Samar, a Spaniard, who was at one time held prisoner by the insurgents, testified that while he was confined at the headquarters of Gen. Lukban, in Samar, in May of 1900, he saw an American prisoner roasted to death.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- These bills were in- troduced in the Assembly to-day:

"Historic Highways of America" is the title of a series of sixteen volumes to be issued by Archer Butler Hulbert, the author of "The Queen of Quelparte." The first volume, called "Paths of Mound-Building Indians, and Great Game Animals" was reviewed Nov. 1. The second volume is entitled, "Indian Thoroughfares."

The name of thy city where the action of the Rev. Charles M. Sheldon's story "The Reformer" takes place the author does not give. There is no necessity for guessing. The city bears the strongest family resemblance to many centres of population in the United States. Are the conditions those relating to the tenements of the past or of the present?

THE woman who lives on the top floor of one of the new apartment houses was standing at the head of the stairs, preparatory to descending to the street, when her attention was arrested by a procession that wound its way slowly up the stairs, and effectually barred her way.

An innovation is contemplated in Columbia rowing this year by the formation of a Morningside graduate crew, composed of weteran oarsmen of the university who have been under Edward Hanlan's tutelage. The only contest in which it is proposed to have the alumni eight compete is the new contest for intermediate eights to be raced for the Watson Cup at the Harlem regatta on May 30.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- The New York State Historical Society is supporting the bill introduced in the Legislature yesterday to place the State Historian in practical charge of the records of every political division of the State and to obtain a return from private individuals of any public books or records.

ESTHER MOREHOUSE was neither a beauty nor a belle. She was merely an average-looking girl with some good points, but more poor ones. Had she, however, possessed the qualifications essential to belleship they would have availed little, for Papa Morehouse had been heard to say, with much pomposity, that the popularity attending a belle was "vulgar," and that he would never allow his daughter to have a lot of "silly young men dangling about."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 17. -- The Brown basket ball team defeated Trinity here to-night by the score of 49 to 6. The Brown men outplayed their opponents at all points and but for occasional poor shooting would have won by a larger score.

BOSTON, Jan. 17. -- The week ends with the money market considerably easier, and indications point to still further ease. Nearly all the January dividends have been paid, and the funds thus released are available in the money market. Then, again, money is returning in large amounts from the interior, and it is only natural that rates should decline.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In one of your contemporaries an editorial recently appeared which vehemently denied that women were insulted in the crushes on the elevated trains. This editorial ended with the statement that it would be decidedly dangerous in New York City for a man to insult a woman in public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- After a long debate in the House this afternoon the Department of Commerce bill was passed with an amendment providing that it shall not go into effect until July 1. The Democrats made a fight to have the Bureau of Labor made a separate department, so that I it might not be under the control of the Secretary of Commerce.

DENVER, Jan. 17. -- Ex-Senator Edward O. Wolcott, who is a candidate for election to the seat in the United States Senate now held by Henry M. Teller, has issued an appeal to the Republican members of the House to unite and expel seventeen Democratic members whose seats are contested. Otherwise, he declares, a Democrat will be elected Senator.

Cleveland H. Dodge, owner of the sixty-eight-foot cutter Hester and President of the New York Young Men's Christian Association, has just ordered two of the Seawanhaka fifteen-footers which will be one of the features in the racing programme this season of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.

RICHMOND, Ind., Jan. 17. -- Some time ago Francis T. White of New York City offered Earlham College, this city, $25,000 for its endowment on condition that enough money is raised to free the institution from indebtedness. There is yet $7,000 to raise, and a strong effort will be made to get it by May 1. which is the limit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- It is well assured that a majority of the Democratic Senators will oppose the ratification of the Cuban reciprocity treaty, and that they may be able to prevent it from coming to a vote.

The new sixteen-inch gun was tested yesterday in the Government proving grounds at Sandy Hook. The most powerful weapon in the world does not make the deafening crack and crush of the twelve-inch and guns of smaller calibre. There is not the same concussion, but a deep note which seems to linger.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Assertions that Brazil has fomented serious disturbances in the Bolivian territory of Acre were made to-day by Senor Jorge B. Zailes. Charge d'Affaires at the Brazilian Legation in this city. He thus explained the controversy. which threatens the peace of the two countries:

Just as the crowds came from the theatres last evening, the down-town service of the Sixth and Ninth Avenue Elevated railroads came to a halt, and for more than an hour there were no south-bound trains in the theatre district.

During the last two days of the week just past the market for outside securities showed considerable improvement, and with the advance in quotations came a substantial increase in activity. In a number of stocks gains which amounted to several points resulted from the week's operations, the advances in most cases being due apparently to an increase in the general demand for the more substantial of the stocks traded in on the curb.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The prospects of currency legislation are brighter now than they have been at any time during this session of Congress. The Committee on Rules to-day decided to adopt a rule for the Fowler Currency bill. No date was determined on but the committee intends to have it brought up soon.

Practicability is beyond doubt the keynote of the third annual automobile show which opened at the Madison Square Garden last night and will continue through the present week. The crude and experimental aspect of the two former exhibitions is wholly lacking, and on every side are evidences of solid merit and proved practicability.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- There is considerable speculation here in German coal values on account of the American coal famine, but the authorities declare that the sanguine feeling is unwarranted, as America would first consider English coal.
The New Jersey Geological Survey has in Press, almost ready for publication, a full report upon the glacial geology of the State, which will contain much information of popular interest.

SAULT STE, MARIE, Mich., Jan. 13. -- It is now definitely decided that the fiftieth anniversary of the opening of the marvelous Sault Ste. Marie Canals shall be fittingly celebrated next June. To this end arrangements are now well under way. Congress will be asked for an appropriation of $50,000 to aid in making the celebration a grand success.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present position of the coal situation is so grave and abnormal and fraught with such serious consequences to the entire population of the country, both rich and poor, that it seems to me to warrant heroic measures to remedy the same.

Mayor Low delivered an address of welcome at the opening of the first formal session of the second International American Customs Congress, which met yesterday at the City Hall. Ex-Mayor Grace, who was elected temporary chairman at a preliminary meeting held on Thursday, called the congress to order and introduced Mayor Low, who said in part:

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 14. -- If it be true that murder will out, then the mystery surrounding the identity and circumstances of the death of the unknown man who lies in the little cemetery at Tower, Minn., on the shores of beautiful Lake Vermilion, may some time be revealed.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- Dullness was extreme in the local market to-day, and the only feature, if it can be called such, was the pressure in Consolidated Lake Superior issues, after a rather strong opening. The common receded fractionally, but the preferred broke a full point. Financial institutions announced to-day that the rate on call loans will be reduced Monday to 5 per cent.

IN SPITE of apparently reassuring reports from the duel-fighting nations on the European Continent, dueling is on the increase in some countries. It is commonly Relieved that the practice is now regulated by modern, humane measures in such a way as to cheek its growth and ameliorate us effect, but this is not the case.

HAVANA, Jan. 8. -- Within the past few months several well-known institutions have changed their names. The Tacon Theatre, the largest one in Havana, has become the National Theatre; the Inglaterra Hotel has become the Louvre; the International Hotel is now the National. Those who have known all of these under their old names find it hard to accustom themselves to the change.

Do the officers and responsible men of the American Line understand the gravity of their situation? The inadequate and in some respects shocking statement made yesterday by Mr. CLEMENT A. GRISCOM. Jr., concerning the trip of the St. Louis indicates that they do not.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- An important, discovery in medical science has been made by Prof. William Dunbar, a native of St. Paul, Minn., now at the head of the famous Hygienic Institute at Hamburg, and it is expected that it will cause something of a sensation in scientific circles in America. His dscovery is nothing less than a cure for hay fever.

SHE was a liberal woman, in one sense -- she weighed two hundred. Her dress was elegant. Her jewels -- especially that long chain attached to the gem-inerusted lorgnette -- told their own story. Genuineness was stamped on everything she wore.

The continued mild weather yesterday disorganized the plans of the independent anthracite operators. For the first time since they started to boom prices they found, that the coal dealers were not anxious to buy Though the demand was as keen as ever, the dealers did not want to be caught with dear coal.

PARIS, Jan. 2. -- Until the Humbert trial begins in open court there will be a lull in public interest as regards the case. People who profess to know say that the family will get off with a light sentence. They predict that the charge of forgery will be abandoned, and that the whole story will be reduced to the proportions of a confidence trick transacted on a colossal scale.

Detective Sergeant William D. Welsh of the District Attorney's office, who was dangerously wounded in a shooting affray on Friday evening at the Chat Noir Restaurant, 551 West Broadway, was holding his own last night in his battle for life at St. Vincent's Hospital.

In the course of the recent rather ramoling talk in the Senate on the general subject of "trusts" several of the speakers have adorned their remarks with the familiar lines of the "Deserted Village" Ill fares the land, to hastining ills a prey, Where wealth accumulates, and men decay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Accept my humble commendation of your strictures on Gov. Odell's position respecting Mr. Platt's renomination to the Senatorship. As a Republican of thirty years' standing, in the ranks, 1. in common with all other Republicans who are jealous of the party's honor and dignity, object to any act which would lay that honor and dignity in the dust.
THERE are eclipses of the sun and of happines but they do not last long, being, in each instance, a specles of overturning of the natural order of things.

ERE brother met brother in fratricidal strife on the sanguinary fields of battle in the war of secession, known to modern United States history as the "late unpleasantness." Luties Leathers was by far and a way, the prettiest piece of calico in Oxvillo, Tennessee, and James Tanner was desperately in love with her.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Forty indictments have been voted by the special Grand Jury, which during the last week has been investigating the causes for the shortage of coal in this city. No names were given out. State Attorney Deneen said that inasmuch as the indictments had been merely voted and not returned no list of the accused men will be announced before 10 o'clock Monday morning, when the jury will reconvene.

ONE year ago Sir Ernest Cassel gave to King Edward VII. the sum of $1,000,000 to be used for whatever charitable or utilitarian purpose he should select. The King immediately decided to devote the larger portion of the gift to the erection of a sanatorium for tuberculous patients.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- There is an interesting fish story being told in connection with a recommendation made by Governor Odell in his message. "The Legislature could well afford, under the direction of the Forest. Fish and Game Commission," he said, "to accord to the boards of supervisors the right to regulate, under a general statute, the game laws for their own particular localities."

SUCH a variety of inducements are now offered by trust companies and the smaller discount banks, particularly for the accounts of the householder and the wage earner, that the subject has attracted the notice of the State Banking Department, and Superintendent Kilburn expressed himself rather vigorously in opposition to some of these schemes in his recent report for the year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am amazed that a journal like The American Electrician should seek to shield the engineers who have devised the third-rail system on the elevated railroad. As you justly remark in your "Topics of the Times " of to-day, this journal is not particularly convincing in its arguments declaring the system all right.

ABRM S. HEWITT has always been a believer in clubs. He belongs to a number of them. They are quite characteristic of him. There is the Union, of Which his brother-in-law. Edward Cooper, is President; the Century, at which he has often been seen; the Metropolitan, of which he is one of the original members: the Engineers, his fraternity club; the Tuxedo, and the Players.

This week offers six new plays, "The Wizard of Oz," held over from Thursday, and Mme. Duse still at the Metropolitan, making it even more strenuous for the first afternooners and nighters than last week. The grand rush opens with one woman and two men stars.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 17. -- An order was issued, taking effect this morning, placing an embargo on all shipments of hay, grain, lumber, and iron ore.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If Mr. Thomas Whitman of Annapolis Royal, N.S., is in possession of any practical knowledge regarding Gloucester's Winter fishing industry he has carefully withheld it from his letter published in your Sunday issue.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Jan. 17. -- Six men were killed and three others were injured, two of them probably fatally by the explosion of a powder charge of an eight-inch gun on the United States battleship Massachusetts yesterday rooming while at target practice off Culebra Island. The Massachusetts arrived here to-day.

WHEN the young woman typewriter announced her intention of joining an evening law class her friends remonstrated on the ground that the study of law makes a woman seem so masculine, but she insisted that she was obliged to do it in self-defense.

The second of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's concerts on their third trip to this city was given yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall before an audience that, as at the previous concerts this season, filled nearly every seat in the auditorium. The music that it heard was mostly familiar, and the performance was of the sort with which the Boston Orchestra most rejoices the hearts of the discriminating.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- German scholars are beginning to give unusual attention to American intellectual progress, Prof. Wetz of Freiburg University, comparing the scientific development of Germany and the United States, says the real American danger exists in intellectual rather than economic things.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

To the Editors of The New York Times: After all that has been said on the servant girl question, I suppose there is no excuse for reopening the subject unless one has something new to contribute. My letler is simply an appeal for information which some experienced TIMES reader will Perhaps be able to supply.

Again it is farewell to Duse, but this time there is hope of a speedy return next season. What has the present experience added to our knowledge of the great Italin actrers? Something to be sure, for the march of the years, even while it has left its impress on that wonderfully sensitive and flexible masque, has deepened the soul of the artist and added strength and range to her already powerful and varied resources.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your columns to-day reported an address of mine under the caption "Zionism Reconsidered" that did not quite represent my views. The paragraphs were placed in quotation marks, as though a reproduction of my exact language; as a matter of fact, the language was that of the reporter.

ROME, Jan. 9. -- The only event worth recording during the present recess of Parliament has been the "denunziatione" of the Italian-Austrian commercial treaty by the Austro-Hungarian Ambassador to the Quirinal, Baron de Pasetti. Such action on the part of the Vienna Government has long been expected here, for politicians of small knowledge could hardly fail to perceive that the treaty was notoriously in favor of the peninsula.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 17. -- With five years in State prison staring him in the face. Josse Williams was married, in the county jail here this morning to his sweetheart, Elevetta Curtis.

THERE are some few railroads in this country on which it is considered quite the right thing for conductors on passenger trains to supplement the earnings of their legitimate trade by a little money "on the side" made from change passengers. Such a road is Texas and Pacific, for instance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Just now we are hearing and reading a great many complaints as to the high prices of coal. Now, let us look over the situation somewhat. The coal miners asked for a raise of wages amounting to about 10 to 20 cents per ton, and their request was denied.

According to a recent statement issued by Sir Henry Irving, M. Sardou and M. Moreau have based their drama. "Dante," which Sir Henry will produce at the Drury Lane Theatre next Easter, on incidents in the "New Life" and "The Divine Comedy," which have been amplified and run together.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- Forty years ago last Summer, at the battle of Seven Pines, Va., W.S. Merritt of the Seventy-sixth, New York Volunteer Infantry, lost a gold medal which had been presented to him a day or two before by Gen. Meade.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- The annual banquet of the American Chamber of Commerce was held to-night in the Bonvalet Restaurant, the banqueting hall of the famous hostelry being elaborately decorated for the occasion with American and French flags and with palms and flowers.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Two military publications have come to hand which throw a sidelight respectively upon Russian and German army development. The first announces the establishment at the Oriental Institute of Vladivostok of a college for the Japanese, Korean, Mongolian, French, and English languages.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on "Fat Policemen" you have treated humerously a very real evil. The public service demands a certain standard of, physical efficiency of its constables and requires the passage of a somewhat searching physical examination at the hands of applicants for appointment.

TWO stylishly gowned women boarded an Amsterdam Avenue car at Fifty-second Street that very cold morning of last week, talking animatedly and disdainfully about a certain club President whose recent action in the matter of regulations had greatly offended them.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Archie Pell of New York, who have been spending a portion of their honeymoon at Swanswick, on Otsego Lake, have returned to the city. Swanswick is the country seat of Leslie Pell Clarke, an uncle of Archie Pell. Archie Pell married as his first wife Miss Sadie Price, a Baltimore belle, and their legal separation about a year ago is recalled.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Some anxiety has been occasioned here this week owing to Mr. Balfour's renewed indisposition, which, although pronounced slight, has been sufficiently serious to confine him to his bed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The conditions of affairs existing during the rush hours, morning and evening, at the Houston Street station of the Third Avenue elevated road are simply appalling and astounding in their nature. Appalling in the fact that a traveler virtually takes his life in his hands in trying to ascend and descend the stairways.

William Hepburn Russell, the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Greater New York Democracy, announced yesterday that the organization which he represents in all likelihood would, nominate Controller Grout for Mayor. As Mr. Russell is one of Mayor Low's Commissioners of Accounts, it is net thought he would make the announcement of the Greater New York Democracy's probable action unless such action had practically been decided upon by the leaders who control the organization.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Recently in your editorial columns it was suggested that new words should be coined to describe the sending of wireless telegraphic messages by electricity.

The Trustees of the Hebrew Technical Institute, Steinham School of Metal Workers, have put the recent addition to their piant to a new use, hoping that it will prove to be of great practical value. They believed that the building that was completed a few months ago might be used in the evening as well as in the daytime, and the general idea was to establish a class in mechanical drawing and toolmaking.

LANGTRY, Texas, Jan. 6. -- This is one of the few Indian trading places remaining in the United States. By this is meant the genuine Indian trading such as existed at many frontier points until the red men were either exterminated or brought under the influences of civilization. This has been an Indian trading post for half a century and more.

The Fall games of the Athletic Association of the Twelfth Regiment were held last night in the armory, and Company G won the point trophy by defeating Company D in the final race of the evening, the one-mile relay. The programme contained thirteen events, and as numerous trial heats were necessary the contests were not over until nearly midnight.

WHEN the woodsmen gathered as usual at the Post Office last Saturday night, Lem Lawson turned to the commercial traveler who was going to remain at the Hiawatha House overnight in order to go hunting rabbits next day, and said:

ON a Third Avenue car the other evening I had an experience, said the shabby gentleman, which I venture to say has happened to but few people in New York City. I got in the car at the bridge and sat beside a gentleman who seemed to be badly scarred, as if from smallpox.

In a sermon yesterday at the Temple Emanu-El, 521 Fifth Avenue, the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman replied to a recent address of Dr. Felix Adler defending the Ethical Culture movement, of which he is the head. Dr. Adler's subject was "The Right of Secession in Religion." Dr. Silverman preached yesterday on "Loyalty Versus Secession in Religion."

ON Broadway, just opposite the Criterion, there was until recently a fish market which did a big "carriage business." The fish market moved away, and a theatrical agency moving into the neighborhood at just the same time, the theatre people got the fish man's old telephone number.

THE small boy, accompanied by his father, was looking at the display in the window of a big store on Broadway, where all manner of wearing thing were on exhibition. In one corner was a great rack decorated with a brilliant collection of socks and bearing the sign:

Announcement has just been made that the fourth annual squash championship for the amateur title and trophy of America will begin the week of Feb. 21. The meeting will be held in the courts of the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club, at Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and is expected to last for four days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Senator Tillman is gathering evidence to be presented to the Senate against the confirmation of Dr. Crum, the colored man recently nominated to be Collector of the Port of Charleston, S.C.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The fact that the sentiments of nations, as well as those of individuals, undergo sudden and radical changes is well illustrated by a comparison of the sentiments entertained by Americans for the French in 1808, as indicated by the American press of that period, with the feelings entertained 'by the Americans for the French in 1902 and 0903, as evidenced by the same organs of public opinion.
The monthly dinner of the Male Teachers' Association of New York in the Hotel Marlborough last evening was attended by about 200 persons. President Silas C. Wheat presided.

LITTLE children are the most misunderstanding as well as the most misunderstood, people in the world," said a young man on who before her marriage had been a school teaeher: they are blamed and often scolded for inattention and carelessness for failing to do a task right when oftentimes the fault has been entirely that of the teacher who has not been clear in directions.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17. -- The feature of to-day's racing card was the first two-year-old race of the season. The distance was three furlongs, and twelve starters went to the post. Spencerian was left at the post. The Walden pair, Miss Nancy and Petunia, were made favorites at 9 to 5, but neither figured in the race.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Because of the demand for money this week, the Bank of England did a very large business. On Thursday loans were made at 4 1/2 per cent., and short discounts were quoted at 4 per cent., while outside rates advanced. Short dated bills were less sought.

The belated American liner St. Louis arrived yesterday with a new record for the slowest transatlantic voyage ever made by a first-class twin-screw ocean steamship, and with 275 of the most indignant passengers that ever hurried down a liner's gangplank. The St. Louis left Southampton on Jan. 4, and she legged the total of 3,043 knots at an average speed of 9.7 knots an hour, a speed which any trump can excell.

Aside from fluctuations in what may be termed panic prices, the value of coal does not appear likely to decrease, and the effort to get coal land is unabated. There are also groupings together of present coalproducing properties, so that there will be "harmony" among the producers, and the value of the properties in the future will not be reduced from any undue competition.

ON ONE occasion late Thomas B. Reed and Richard Croker were fellow -- passengers on the American liner New York. One of the passengers recounts one of their conversations as Mr. Croker recently told it to him. It was an unusually rough voyage, and for the greater part of the time the passengers were unable to be on deck.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 17. -- The condition of N.G. Gonzales, editor of The State, who was shot on Thursday afternoon by Lieutenant Governor Tillman, was reported at the hospital to-night to be improved, although no assurance of the patient's recovery was given.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Admiral Higginson in a cable dispatch from San Juan, Porto Rico, under to-day's date, says that by an explosion of powder in the eight-inch turret of the battleship Massachasetts five men were killed and four injured. At the time the message was sent Tacke was still alive. The text of the Admiral's dispatch is as follows:

DAVY was shaving in his bedroom when he heard his wife's voice and his little daughter's engaged in earnest converse in the parlor. He realized that some weighty matter was being discussed and pretty soon he heard the little one sobbing. This made him so very nervous that he cut a gash in his chin.

HOW many typewriter operators know that machines have been invented for peoples using more than twentyfive different languages? The latest, patent is the Arabic typewriter, with a keyboard no larger than the one we use in America, although the Arabic of textbooks is described as having 638 different characters.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- Columbia defeated Cornell to-night in the University Armory at basket ball by a score of 29 to 13. After the first few moments the Columbia players showed that they had the game well in hand, and afterward were never headed. The visitors excelled in every point of the game.

The announcement of a specific for septicaemia, or blood poisoning, which has excited the obstetricians and led one well-known physician to declare it "the most important contribution of this generation to medical science," belongs in the classification created by the journalists of the last generation of" important if true."

FLOWERS, artificial and natural have been used this season for decorative purposes more freely than for several seasons past. The craze has even extended to the butcher's shops, and all up and down the avenues one sees festoons. wreaths, and bunches of impossible magenta.

Two members of the committee of three of the Board of Estimate disagree as to whether it has been decided to construct a new City Hall on the site of the Stewart Building, the Emigrant Savings Bank, and the American News Company Building, to cost about $20,000,000. President Cantor said yesterday that the new City Hall plan had been agreed upon.

Thirteen men and a cat, rescued from a leaking rudderless and propellerless steamship several hundred miles east of Sandy Hook last Thursday, arrived in New York yesterday morning. The men had constituted the crew of the Norwegian steamship Siggen, and were brought to this port by the Hamburg-American liner Pennsylvania, sailors from which vessel had saved them at the peril of their own lives.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Supreme Court of the United States, in its decision handed down last week in the Downs case, commonly known as the Russian sugar bounty case, has dealt a staggering blow to our protective tariff.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have for THE TIMES a respect as a public forum, and for its editorial views as being dispassionately just ones, which causes me to take time out of a very busy life to address you and through you your readers upon a question that, always a smolderings tire, has recently been fanned into a blaze.

ALTHOUGH a chimney sweep is rarely a poet and not always a lover, there is nothing he appreciates so much as a moonlight night. With its aid he can work, unhampered by lantern or flickering torch, for his best customers, the hotel proprietors, who always hire him to sweep chimneys between midnight and 1 A.M., while their patrons are asleep.

Capt. Lantry of the East Fifty-first Street Station, and a force of detectives and uniformed policemen last night raided a prize fight that was being held on the top floor of the six-story building at 520 Fifth Avenue, two doors from Sherry's. The principals and twenty-two spectators, most of whom were in evening dress and wore silk hats, were arrested.

THAT there is a science of marine surgery no one can doubt who any time within the next fortnight, by chance or by design, finds his way to the shipyard and marine railway at the foot of Conover Street in the Erie Basin, South Brooklyn. For there, hauled up on land, is a Hudson River Steamship in strange case.

One phase of the antagonism developing in Central New York between the trades unions and the National Guard has not been as clearly and forcibly presented to the attention of labor as it should be. We refer to the folly of it.

TOLEDO, O., Jan. 17. -- A mob including over 200 men, women, boys, and girls, this morning seized five carloads of soft coal which had just arrived in the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railroad yards, consigned to the National Malleable Casting Company and local oil men.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- There will be no "House of Lords" in Albany this year. Of the Senators who kept house last year t 5 ELk Street Lieut. Gov. Higgias and Senator White are the only two who remain in the Senate. The other members of the household were Senators Elisworth, Stranahan, Krum, and Humphrey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Senator Kean, of New Jersey, entertained at a class dinner this evening at his home on I Street, his guests being a party of Yale men. '76, who meet annually as the guests of one of their number. This evening's company included Eugene Carter. Walter Jennings, Stephen Dudley Dexter.

The opening of the revised assessment rolls has been received with the same widely divergent opinions as followed the first proposal of the scheme. Aside from the probability that an increased credit and generally enlarged money-raising powers will pave the way for municipal extravagance, especially in the hands of a corrupt administration, the ultimate effects of the change are as much as ever a subject of discussion.

IN 1838, an Englishman who hid his identity under the pseudonym of "Saxula," wrote to The London Mechanics' Magazine describing a steam motor carriage, which he had invented ten years previously. With the article, he enclosed a drawing of the carriage, which was published by the editor.

THE famous "good cheer" and hospitality of the historic Van Cortlandt mansion were recalled several days ago when a gang of laborers at work in the park surrounding the dwelling unearthed a number of large green bottles bearing the seal of Frederick Van Cortlandt and the date of 1765.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "Letters to the Editor of THE TIMES " which appear from time to time in your columns are interesting as crystallizing the trend of public opinion, and the facts are brought to light. In the matter of the present robber baron prices charged for coal facts and actions are what the people are asking from their official representatives.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the subject of street railway accommodations is before the public. I hope it is not too late to offer some suggestions which I think are for the most part new, yet which might tend to relieve the situation.

AUG. 1, 1902 -- I have just spent an unspeakably long hour by the fire, listening (or trying not to listen) to my master, who was reading to my mistress "The Confessions of a "Wife." I won't deny that I caught a few naps between some of the longest letters. I think everybody should read them that way.

The alarming frequency of small incendiary fires in tenement and apartment houses, started by thieves who wish to stampede the tenants and loot apartments, is of unusual popular interest. So large a proportion of our population is domiciled in multiple apartment houses that any menace to them touches all classes very closely.

Local golfers are well pleased with the officers who have been selected by the Nominating Committee for the United States Golf Association during the coming year. The annual meeting will be held at Delmonico's on Feb. 17, much earlier than in former years, when the last week in that month has been chosen for the annual conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Hudson County Bar Association paid Judge Collins a high compliment when it asked him not to resign from the Supreme Court of New Jersey, The bar associations of that State and of this should go further: they should change conditions so that our best and ablest lawyers may not feel that they cannot afford to accept the honor of being elected to the Supreme Court.

It has been a busy week in society, but there are many complaints of dullness, as large entertainments have not been numerous this season. But there have been numerous dinners, cards have taken new life and bridgre and euchre are the favorite games.

Army. Lieut. Col. John G. Butler and First Lieut. Samuel Hof. Ordnance Department, will to Fort Michie, Fort Terry and Fort Wright, Fort Adams, Fort Wetherell, and Fort Mansfield, R.I.; Fort Preble. Fort Williams, Fort Levett, and Fort McKinley, Maine; Fort Constitution and Fort Foster.
WHEN E.A. Southrn entered this laconic note in his diary at New Orleans Dec. 6, 1839: "Boy born at 79 Bivnville Street at 7 A. M.; named Edward, "he hadn't like some fond fathers, career.

A fine specimen of the tusks and palate of the monster called the imperial mammoth has been added to the exhibits in the Fossil Mammal Hall of the American Museum of Natural History. The name elephas imperator was given to the creature in 1858 by Joseph Leidy, who had as basis only a single tooth.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 17. -- Another interesting ice yacht race was sailed on the North Shrewsbury River to-day. The third class pennant was again sailed for and was easily won by George J. Gillig's Wizard in 31 minuter. The Wizard beat her nearest competitor, Charles P. Irwin's Georgie (by 4 minutes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not a few stories have appeared of late in which the respective managements of the N.Y. Central, the Metropolitan, the Manhattan and B.R.T. have been scored and a number have held up for comparison the enlightened way in which the Pennsylvania is run.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- The attention of the whole world in the last weeks having been directed to two scions of the noble house of Tuscany, it will be of interest to hear something of this remarkable family within a country and without a throne.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I submit the following reflections on the money power. The United States is today acknowledged to be the richest country on the globe. Its growth, during the last quarter of a century, has been phenomenal: in fact, is without a parallel in the annals of civilized nations.

POUGIEKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- Few in the audience that witnessed the unfolding of the plot in the drama presented by the Stration Stock Company at the Opera House this afternoon knew that Campbell Stratton, the leading man and one of the proprietors of the company, who played a dual role, had just been notified of the sudden death of his favorite brother, William Stratton, a Brooklyn lawyer.

THE man who has a closet full of Spring clothing left over from last year will be glad to know that the tailors and furnishers promise few changes in fashions for the coming season. If he will have the ample "bags" eliminated from his trousers it will be about the only thing he must do to make his stock of suits up to date.

President CANTOR has been making representations to Commissioner WILLCOX to the effect that the Washington Statue in Union Square "must go." It not only will bestride the subway, or nearly so, if it is left where it is, but it will be in the way of a station, and, if it is, at much trouble and expense, retained in its present position, it will no longer be satisfactorily visible.

A letter written by Simon Fraser, Lord Lovat, in prison shortly before he was beheaded on Tower Hill, Edinburgh, for his participation in the rising of 1745, fetched $18 fit a sale of an interesting collection of autograph letters and documents by Bangs Co. 91 Fifth Avenue, Friday. "I hope to live," he says, "but do not fear whatever be my fate.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In response to your editorial of Jan. 5, entitled "Women and Their Rights." beg you to print the following questions and remarks:

Among the 400 men at the seventeenth annual dinner of the Ohio Society of New York, held last night in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, were the Ambassadors to the United States from Great Britain. Italy, Russia, Austria-Hungary, and Mexico. The German and French Ambassadors were represented by their Counselors of Embassy.

Racquets and court tennis will be at the height of their popularity during the next two months. The American amateur championships will be held next month in the Racquet and Tennis Club of this city, but before that leading event of the year the amateurs of Philadelphia and Boston, as well as of this city, will engage in a number of competitive and trying-out matches.

Police Commissioner Greene yesterday made another tour in an automobile, accompanied by his secretary and Inspector P.M. McLaughlin of Brooklyn. This time his inspection was devoted to Queens and the neighboring transpontine borough.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Dissatisfaction with the existing management and the recent policies of the Lehigh Valley Railroad is expected to be made vigorously manifest at the annual meeting Tuesday. A strong opposition party has been formed. If this proves strong enough it will place a new man in the Presidency, a Western railroad man of large experience and proved capacity.

DENVER, Jan. 18. -- Interest in the Senatorial fight in Colorado centres in the report of the House Elections Committee, which has been investigating the contests filed against the seating of seventeen Democratic members of the House.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 18. -- The Italian residents of this city are preparing to retaliate upon those persons who were instrumental in securing the passage by the Orange Common Council recently of the socalled "anti-noise" ordinance, which prohibits the indiscriminate ringing of church bells, the ringing of junkmen's bells and the discharging of firearms or fireworks on any day but the Fourth of July.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- It is accepted as reasonably sure that there will be legislation this session to place the currency of the Philippines on a gold basis. The House Committee on Rules having allowed a day for the consideration of a bill, it is now assured that action of some kind is likely to be reached.
To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to a leading article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one who has studied the negro question pretty closely for the past ten years, I have been very much interested at the apparent sudden development of the negro pension question before the public, as referred to in your article a few days ago.

The Delaware, LacKawanna ana Western, Erie, and New York, Ontario and Western Railroads had men working all day yesterday at their terminal points, handling anthracite, of which large shipments came in yesterday and Saturday. Good progress was made in unloading cars which came here with the coal frozen together in a mass, and large deliveries are looked for in this city to-day.

Whatever Mr. HEWITT may have been in the course of his long and active life, he never failed to be interesting, and that in a multitude of ways. This is an unusual trait in the career of a man of profoundly serious mind, of great learning, of broad and original views, and of high moral purpose.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 18. -- Perhaps a black cat which darted in front of the automobile soon after they started was the "handoo" of Mrs. Elbridge Gerry Snow's journey by automobile from New York to Lakewood on Thursday. Something "hoodooed" the trip from the very start and Mrs. Snow is inclined to think that it was the black cat.

DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 18. -- A deal was closed last night by which the Southern Pacific Railroad Company becomes owner of $15 acres of oil land in the Saratoga fields. Three hundred and fifty acres are in the Proven field, and contain two producing wells.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 10. -- The greatest and most modern armor plate press of the world has just arrived for the new works at Homestead. It will cost several millions of dollars. It was built at the Bethlehem Steel Works, and its operation, it is understood, will materially improve the system of manufacture.

Applause punctuated frequently the proceedings at the annual meeting of the friends of the Hebrew Technical School for Girls in Henry Street yesterday in the banquet hall of the Hotel Savoy. Many women were present, and among the men were Louis Stern, Jesse Lewisohn, Max Nathan, Column Haas, Isaac Wallach, Randolph Guggenheimer, Edward Lauterbach, A.S. Solomon, Jacob A. Cantor, and Abraham Gruber, several of whom commended the work of the school.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 18. -- Harry C. Pulliam, President of the National Baseball League; Frank De Haas Robison, President, and M. Stanley Robison of the St. Louis Club, and Barney Dreyfus, representing both Pittsburg and the Philadelphia clubs, are the only ones here to-night for an adjourned meeting of the National League to-morrow.

Handball players in Jersey City and Brooklyn are busily engaged in arranging inter-city contests, and several matches have been made. One of these was begun yesterday at Egan's Jersey City court, and there were many Brooklyn followers of the game on hand to see the contest. The competing pairs were Joe Hanlon and Edward Ficke of the Jersey City Handball Club and Patrick Gibbons and John Tiernan of the Knickerbocker Handball Club of Brooklyn.

WELLFLEET, Mass., Jan. 18. -- Signor Marconi has been at work all day and night, and now hopes to send a message to Cornwall, England, to-morrow. The tests and experiments made to-day showed that the apparatus is in working order, and the inventor is confident of success.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- In a report to the Legislature, Charles R. Skinner, State Superintendent of Public Instruction, says that despite the ruling of his predecessors that the practice of reading the Bible in the public schools is a violation of the Constitution he will not stop such reading provided there is no sectarian teaching accompanying it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Next Thursday Senator Tillman will begin his fight against the confirmation of Dr. Crum as Collector of Customs at Charleston by presenting the protest of the citizens of that place. Mr. Tillman himself was originally rather lukewarm in the matter, but has taken up the fight because the people of his State want him to do so.

When the athletes lined up yesterday for the regular weekly cross-country run of the Mohawk Athletic Club the officials decided to cut the distance from four and a half miles to two miles owing to the intense cold. Only seven men started and of these six were members of the club and the other, Robert Todd, of the Union Athletic Club.

Seton Hospital, at Spuyten Duyvil, was the scene of considerable excitement last evening through a fire which started in the institution shortly before 8 o'clock. There are about 200 patients there at present, most of them suffering from consumption.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18. -- Mrs. Catherine McGrath, as guardian of her nine-year-old son, Alfred Charles Mooney, has begun suit to have set aside the probate of the will of Harriet Mooney, mother of Harry Mooney, Mrs. McGrath's first husband. Harry and his brother Fred carried on an express business here until 1893, when Harry was killed in a trolley accident.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- A statement prepared by the Inter-State Commerce Commission shows that during the three months ended September 30, 1902, there were 263 persons killed and 2,613 injured in train accidents. Other kinds of accidents, including those sustained by employes while at work and by passengers in getting on or off the cars, etc., bring the total number of casualties up to 12,007, the killed numbering 845 and the injured 11,162.

The Legislature stands in the sight of all the people between the railroads and the canals. All the people of the State are curious, a majority of them are deeply interested, to know whether the lawmakers will cleave to the railroads and forsake the canals.

The Sunday night concert patrons turned their faces toward the Metropolitan Opera House last evening with a feeling that they were bound to suffer a disappointment. So much was promised them in the programme that it seemed as though something must happen "owing to the indisposition" of somebody.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to the twenty-five year franchise about to be disposed of for the ferry to this borough from Manhattan, it seems to me that the situation can be summed up in a nutshell.

Belated exhibitors at the Automobile Show in the Madison Square Garden, who, on account of various unexpected transportation delays were unable to have their exhibits in order in time for the opening on Saturday evening, labored industriously yesterday, and it is assured that the entire exhibition will be in order to-day.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Burton of the sub-committee of the Senate on its investigation of affairs in the Hawaiian Islands, is quoted in THE TIMES as using the following language:

There was an impression at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union that District Attorney Jerome would be there, in accordance with an invitation sent to him, to explain his views as to the honesty of labor leaders, and to face a fusillade of questions on the subject. The result was that the hall in the University Settlement Building, where the Central Federated Union meets, was crowded as it never had been before.
SEATTLE, Wash., Jan. 18. -- A special to The Times from Dawson says:

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- A great increase in the gross earnings of the steam surface railroads operating in New York State is shown in the annual report of the Railroad Commission, to be submitted to the Legislature this week, but almost corresponding increase in the operation expenses is reported.

PEKING, Jan. 18. -- The dedication of the von Ketteler Memorial Arch, which occurred to-day, was an impressive ceremony. The arch was erected by China. Baron von Ketteler was the German Minister who was killed by Boxers at the outbreak of the Boxer trouble.

BERLIN, Jan. 18. -- The Boerse showed several strong features last week. While the market was disappointed over Minister of Finance Rheinbaben's pessimistic utterances on the business situation, and lower estimates in the Prussian budget for railroad supplies than were expected, values generally were well maintained.

One fireman is dead and two firemen and two civilians are in the hospital as a result of a stubborn fire that was discovered a few minutes before 3 o'clock yesterday morning in the storeroom of the Boston Excelsior Company, at 394 and 396 Bowery. The fireman who lost his life was James G. Corbett, a member of Hook and Ladder Company No. 9.

JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 18. -- In the course of his remarks at the banquet given here yesterday evening to Colonial Secretary Chamberlain in the Historic Wanderers' Hall, Mr. Chamberlain explained at length the details of the financial settlement with the new colonies. The principal features of this settlement were announced by The Associated Press Jan. 13.

It is rather late in the day for an official as intelligent as Borough President SWANSTROM of Brooklyn to take the ground that the several boroughs of the great City of New York should have control of the school system in each borough. If the experience of consolidation has shown any advantage for the people of the various sections of the city it has been in the superior organization and administration of the schools.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 18. -- A special convention having for its object the appointment of a Bishop Coadjutor to assist Bishop Thomas Alfred Starkey of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, will be held in Christ Church, this city, beginning at 10:30 o'clock on Tuesday morning.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 18. -- Miss Phebe Milnor, seventy-five years old, killed herself at her home here yesterday a few hours after the death of her sister, Miss Fannie Woods Milnor. The sisters had been lifelong associates. They had for many years lived together in a cottage here, and their devotion to each other was remarkable.

An incident of the past week that attracted much attention in the Street, and which in some degree was responsible for the increased strength and activity of Southern Railway and Louisville and Nashville, was Mr. Morgan's testimony before the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- No information could be had at the State Department tonight in regard to the reported attack on the Venzuelean fort, at San Carlos by the German cruiser Panther. Secretary Hay and Assistant Secretaries Hill and Adee are not in the city and officials in charge report that no dispatches had been received during the day.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 18. -- The fourteenth annual convention of the United Mine Workers of America will begin here to-morrow morning. President Mitchell arrived shortly after 4 o'clock and was escorted to ills hotel by a reception committee representing the Central Labor Union of Indianapolis and the citizens of Indianapolis.

-- As was inevitable, our denial that dogs understood words in any other way than that in which men understand the barks and whines of dogs has awakened dissent among the admirers of these animals, and they have begun to send us anecdotes to prove that we were wrong. A typical letter on the subject comes from a physician over in Flushing, and concerning the facts contained in it there is of course no question.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 18. -- As an experiment the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company operated its Brisbin, Cayuga, and Diamond collieries in this city last night until 10:30 o'clock and its Storrs colliery until 8 o'clock, making fifteen and twelve hours respectively for the day. The output of the collieries for the day was 8,500 tons, or 2,200 more than their normal output.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The fallacy of exclusive models was amusingly illustrated at Edward Morrell's smart tea on Saturday afternoon, when Miss Alice Roosevelt, who was attired in a most becoming gown of white cloth, elaborately trimmed in Russian lace, was suddenly confronted by a companion attired in its counterpart, which had been made in New York.

Capt. William L. Flanagan, part owner of the Marie Antoinette Hotel and President of the Flanagan Nay Brewing Company, died last evening at the Grand View Hotel, at One Hundred and Sixty-second Street and Fort Washington Avenue, of heart disease, where he was taken ill early in the afternoon after arriving there on an automobile trip in company with three friends, two of whom were named Riker and Perry.

If any one unacquainted with the trade that is carried on between the American ports of the great lakes were told that the arrivals and clearances of these ports in the single month of October of last year exceeded in net tonnage those of the Port of London -- the busiest of the world -- for the entire twelve months of 1901, he would probably be greatly surprised.

At a public hearing, held yesterday, the Aldermanic Committee on Laws and Legislation received several suggestions from prominent citizens for the regulation of street and road traffic with a view to relieving the dangerous congestion caused by reckless and indifferent drivers of passenger and freight carrying vehicles.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The new passenger and freight trunk route between Albany and New York is to be established by the New York Central. The new line is to be via the Boston and Albany Railroad tracks from Albany to Chatham, and from Chatham to New York over the present New York and Harlem Railroad.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Assemblyman Uilr in to-night introduced a bill which provides that every corporation or individual doing business on the installment plan shall pay a tax of $500 and shall also give a bond in the sum of $5,000 for the honest conduct of the business.

Mayor Low and Controller Grout have decided to advocate an improvement in the new method of levying assessments on real estate. The system of publication of assessments, approved by the Chamber of Commerce, has been indorsed by the city officials, and a new tax bill will be introduced at Albany this week.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- New York exchange to-day was 30c premium. Time and call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A conference of representatives of health authorities in twenty States and Territories and the District of Columbia, which assembled here to-day to consider the subject of bubonic plague in the United States, adopted a resolution declaring that the presence of the plague in San Francisco has been established beyond a doubt.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 19 -- The wedding of Miss Julia Delacour Hill of this city to Granville Whittlesey of New York City, which took place at the bride's home here this noon, was a notable event in local society. The bride is the daughter of Eben Hill and a niece of United States Senator E.J. Hill of Norwalk.

Through the recent removal of an old wooden partition in the registry division of the General Post Office the mystery that for two years has surrounded the loss of a package of interest-bearing coupons of the bonds of various well-known railway corporations has been cleared away.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- These bills were introduced by members of the Legislature this evening:

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Just as soon as the Legislature convened to-night Assemblyman Scovel of Camden introduced a bill that provides for a Board of Automobile Examiners the five members to be appointed by the Governor. Under the terms of the bill each person who desires to operate an automobile in the State must go before the board and be examined as to fitness for so doing.

As coolly as an acrobat swinging from one trapeze to another. Frederick Zimmerman, twenty-three years old, of 310 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, last evening leaped seventy-five feet from a burning building into a net which was held by the firemen on the street below.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States Supreme Court to-day again passed upon the validity of divorces granted in South Dakota to non-residents. The case was that of Annie Andrews vs. Kate H. Andrews, and the question at issue is as to which is entitled to administer upon the estate of Charles S. Andrews, whom both women claimed as husband.

Though there was no especial pressure on Erie until toward the close, that stock was noticeably a laggard all day, with a great deal of long stock apparently for sale on every show of strength. In the afternoon this selling became more urgent, and under it the price broke over a point -- this decline, together with the sharp break in Rock, Island, contributing to the general market unsettlement.

Plans that Abram S. Hewitt had entertained for the development of Cooper Union, in which a great part of his interest was centred, became known yesterday. They contemplate the use of the entire building for the activities of the institution, and the acquisition of either the Astor Library Building or the old armory of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, near by, both of which are expected to be made vacant soon.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 19 -- The National League of Baseball Clubs met here to-day in adjourned session from the annual meeting in New York, Dec. 10, to hear the report of its committee appointed at that meeting to confer with the American League regarding terms of agreement.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 19 -- Though coeducation has been indorsed by the Trustees of the Rutgers College Preparatory School, the boys who attend the institution have started a policy of objection. Heretofore the girls have been permitted to take part in the class elections, but this year the senior class set the precedent of barring the girl members.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Brief sessions were held in both houses of the Legislature this evening. Several measures of interest to New York City were introduced.

The presentation of Wagner's trilogy of "Der Ring des Nibelungen" was continued at the Opera House last evening, when "Siegfried." the second part, was given. The audience was large, and the manifestation of interest in the freshest, most genial, and spontaneous of all Wagner's inspirations in lyric drama was as great as it ever is when the public has reason to expect a performance of it somewhere approaching adequacy.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 -- The money market continues to work easier. There is a good supply of money, which is being constantly increased by returning currency from the interior. Call loans, 5 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 5@ 5 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5@4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10@3c discount; clearings, $22,821,910; balances, $1,716,297.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Juuge D. Cady Herrick of the Supreme Court to-day handed down a decision declaring unconstitutional that portion of the election law which wild make candidates ineligible for public office should they fail to file within ten days after election a statement of their election expenses.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- A true bill was returned this morning against forty-five coal operators and retailers, charging conspiracy to do an illegal act injurious to public trade. The indictments are against both corporations and individuals doing business in Illinois and Indiana. Bail was fixed at $1,500 each.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The report circulated in the United States that the Board of Trade will institute an inquiry into the circumstances under which the American Line steamer St. Louis, which arrived at New York Saturday a number of days overdue, was allowed to sail, is unfounded. The Board of Trade officials cleared her as usual the day she sailed from Southampton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Word was received here late this afternoon from Manila of the death of Hadji Mohammed Jamalul Ki-Raam, the Sultan of Jolo or Sulu, the ruler of the warlike and savage Moros of the southern portion of the Philippine archipelago.

The specific provisions of the liquor tax law, commonly known as the "Raines law," were much more strictly enforced and observed on Sunday than at any time since the Low administration began. The number of arrests for violations of this law was considerably greater, but the actual number of violations was very much less.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Roosevelt was the guest of honor to-night at the banquet commemorative of the fiftieth anniversary of the Washington Young Men's Christian Association and the International Committee of North America. Over 300 guests were invited. Helen Gould and Mrs. McAlpin, President of the Women's Auxiliary of the Young Men's Christian Association, were conspicuous among those in the balcony.

It is always a new delight when Miss Annie Russell appears again among us, for she has that rarest attribute of genius eternal freshness and surprise. There are moments when she reminds one of Leonardo, her charm is so poignant and so deep: yet she lacks the inserutable mystery of his subtly smiling ladies.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Mrs. Elbridge Gerry Snow, Jr., yesterday told the story of her all-night automobile journey from New York to Lakewood last Thursday when she was refused shelter by the innkeeper at the deserted village of Allaire.

Society, which was inclined to hold aloof from the Automobile Show in the Madison Square Garden on the opening night, gave it the favor of its presence yesterday, and many persons prominent in social and business circles were present during the day, among them being President Albert R. Shattuck of the Automobile Club of America, President Winthrep E. Scarritt of the American Automobile Association.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- In the joint caucus of the Republican members of the Legislature to-night to vote upon the selection of a candidate for United States Senator, Thomas C. Platt received 108 votes and Elihu Root 1. There were 23 Senators and 84 Assemblymen in the caucus. The absentcees were Senators Brackett, Brown, and Elsberg, and Assemblymen Clark, Outterson, Morgen, Plank, and Wainwright.

Ex-President William H. Kimball and Gamaliel W. Rose, ex-paying teller of the Seventh National Bank, were placed on trial before Judge Thomas in the Criminal Branch of the United States Circuit Court yesterday upon the charge of overcertifying checks on the Seventh National Bank during the few weeks prior to the failure of that institution on June 27, 1901.

The one hundred and twenty-five pieces of luggage of the Duke and Duchess of Manchester, which were taken from the Lucania on her arrival at this port on Saturday to the Holland House, are under a Sheriff's attachment at that hotel. The trouble is over a bill for $695 which the Frederic Diamond Company or this city says his Grace owes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- With the closing of the Indianola Post Office as a text, a lively discussion of the Southern question is to be precipitated on Congress by the friends of the Administration. Mr. Crumpacker of Indiana has been chosen to lead the way in the House, and Mr. Spooner of Wisconsin in the Senate.

At the session of the Customs Congress of American Republics in the City Hall yesterday reports of committees on various subjects were accepted. Among them was that of the Committee on Nomenclature, presented by Javien Arrangoiz, a delegate from Mexico, urging the adoption of the metric system.
DENVER, Jan. 19 -- With the State Senate divided into two hostile bodies and armed men in the State House ready to defend the claims or either, the legislative situation has assumed a serious phase.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Senate devoted two brief executive sessions to-day to the Cuban reciprocity treaty. At the first session the treaty was read at length and at the second session Senator Cullom. who as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has charge of the treaty, made a statement of its purpose and effect.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19. -- Memphian and Belvino were the only beaten favorites here to-day. The latter finished second in his race, but was disqualified for his interference with Lady Alberta. The latter was given second place, and third place went to Ben Frost. Weather cloudy, track heavy. Summary:

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- The American Carnation Society was incorporated to-day with the Secretary of State. It is formed to increase the general interest in the cultivation and use of the carnation, improve the standard of excellence in the flower and the methods of its cultivation, property supervise the nomenclature of the different varieties, and to stimulate the growing of improved seedlings and crosses of such flower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The subject of a maximum and minimum tariff policy was brought to the attention of the Senator to-day by a resolution offered by Senator Ledge directing the Finance Committee to inquire whether certain countries are discriminating against the United States, and, if so, what legislation is necessary to give preferential duties to countries that give us fair trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Criticism of the American consular service was a feature of the House proceedings to-day. Discussion was precipitated by Mr. McClellan (Dem., N.Y.,) during the debate on the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day, in connection with repayments to the Bank of England. Discounts were fairly maintained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Secretary Shaw has written to the banks that had substituted State and Municipal bonds for Government bonds as security for public deposits, that be would like to have a resubstitution of Government bonds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Secretary Hay called upon the President early to-day. He also saw Secretary Moody, and it is supposed that these talks had reference to the Venezuelan situation, which is regarded as approaching another crisis according to the news dispatches from Maracaibo.

Col. William Conant Church, editor of The Army and Navy Journal, was the guest of honor at a dinner given last night at Delmonico's by members and ex-members of the Army and Navy. The only decoration of the hall consisted of festoons of American flags back of the speakers' table and along the side walls.

It becomes increasingly clear that it was an excellent thing for all concerned that the British Secretary for the Colonies should have taken the notion of going to see for himself what were the conditions of that part of South Africa which has lately come under his official jurisdiction.

The return to this country of JOHN S. SARGENT with a commission to paint the portrait of the President of the United States is an event that ought not to pass without some sign of public recognition and congratulation. Unfortunately, we cannot say that this is "the return of the native," since the painter happened to be born in Florence, the son of an American physician.
