Receptions and dinners and cards formed the chief part of the programme yesterday. Mondays are always a trifle dull until the house parties get back in town and start the week. There was an excellent attendance at the opera. The most notable event this evening will be the dance given by Henry T. Sloane for Miss Jessie Sloane at Sherry's.

-- Leslie's Weekly, having, apparently, more confidence than we have that by 1909 New York's transportation facilities will be so much improved that a big anniversary celebration here will not be an unmitigated nuisance to the resident population, attacks with some vivacity our recent statement that between the voyage of the Half Moon up the Hudson and what has since happened in this region the relation is not exactly obvious.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The Times's insurance cot-respondent says that a good deal of sympathy is felt alt Lloyds with the passengers of the American liner St. Louis. The correspondent, continuing, says that while it would be too much to say that the vessel was unseaworthy when she left Southampton, yet the bad state of her boilers was an open secret, and few underwriters were surprised when it was announced that the vessel was overdue.

WASHINGTON, Jan.10 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt, Justice and Mrs. Holmes of the United States Supreme Court, and Senator and Mrs. Lodge occupied a box at the Columbia Theatre to-night at the performance by John C. Rice and Thomas A. Wise of the comedy, "Are You a Mason?" There was a good house present, and the play was well received.
The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold for L. Smith the seven-story apartment house known as the Unadilla, at 126 and 128 West Eleventh Street, on plot 43 by 129.7. The buyer is an inventor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Mrs. Dewey's regular Monday afternoon reception was a particularly pleasing affair to-day inasmuch as the many visitors were welcomed not only by the hostess, but by the Admiral, the latter having just returned from duty in the Southern seas.

Beauty, said Goethe, is at once the ultimate principle and the highest aim of art. Other poets and thinkers have defined poetry as the blossom and the fragrance of all human knowledge, human thoughts, human passions, emotions, language; the apotheosis of sentiment; enthusiasm with wings of fire.

Those who fancy that the trust is peculiarly an American institution, the mushroom, product of prosperity, may be comforted to know that Germany has more than four hundred well-developed trusts, and that at last accounts they were multiplying rapidly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senator Quay gave a Statehood dinner to-night at his residence on I Street. There were seventeen Senators present and the delegates from the three Territories that are seeking admission. Senator Quay met every attempt to get a list of the names of his guests with a point blank refusal.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- There was a fair demand for stocks in this market today until late in the afternoon when, with the weakness in Reading and Erie on New York selling, prices eased off slightly. Lehigh Valley was the active feature, and the buying was sufficiently aggressive to advance the price 3/4 to 41.

In the formulation of grievances by the committee of the passengers of the belated steamer St. Louis occurred the following phrase: "Providence has indeed been extremely kind to us, and we are extremely grateful that through her tender mercies we have thus far been spared a calamity too horrible to contemplate."

Mayor Low on behalf of the City of New York and officials of organizations with which ex-Mayor Hewitt was connected took appropriate action on his death yesterday, and delegations were appointed by several of the organizations to attend the funeral.

Richard Croker's return to New York is scheduled to take place on April 1, according to some friends of the ex-leader of Tammany Hall. Just prior to April 1 he is expected to leave his estates at Wantage and take the steamer. The first authentic news of his home-coming was issued by Laurence Delmour, one of the most faithful of the "old guard." who for years hailed Richard Croker as chief."

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 20 -- The reading of his annual report by President John Mitchell was the feature of this morning's session of the miners' National convention. Of the many important events affecting the interests of the toilers of the country, he said, the anthracite coal strike stood pre-eminent.
VIENNA, Jan. 20 -- Dr. Lorenz, who arrived here to-day from London, spoke freely regarding his impressions of the United States.

With a dash of brilliant discovery "The Wizard of Oz" last night discovered the north pole of the Broadway theatrical world in the Columbus Monument, at Fifty-ninth Street. In a proximity as close as that of the Majestic Theatre frosts undoubtedly threaten, just as there is said to be a gathering chill in the theatres situated near the south pole in the Flatiron Building.
The three-story dwelling 14 West Twenty-fourth Street, 19.8 by 98.9, has been sold by Mary McGrath. The purchasers in the transaction are represented by Townsend Wandell, as attorney.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department, practically wipes out the State Tax Commission in its decision, handed down this morning, in the case of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company against the State Board of Tax Commissioners.

Among the entertainments this evening will be a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lewis Morris for the bridal party taking part in the wedding of Miss Eleanor Morris and Robert Hall McCormick, Jr. Receptions will be given by Mrs. Robert Fulton Weir, Mrs. Stewart Duncan, Mrs. Edward Chester Center, Mrs. Augustine Jacqueline Smith, Mrs. L. Vaughan Clark, and Mrs. Robert E. Bonner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The fight over the Southern question in Congress has been deferred until Monday. The House Committee on Post Offices will then take up Mr. Crumpacker's resolution calling upon the Postmaster General for the papers relating to the closing of the Indianola Post Office. Mr. Loud of California, Chairman of the committee, said that the resolution would in all probability be reported to the House that day.

Interest in the third annual Automobile Show, now in progress in the Madison Square Garden, steadily increases, the crowd last night being equal to that of the opening night, while there was also a very large attendance during the day. Among the visitors were A.A. Housman, W.J. Arkell, J.J. Rodgers, Jr., W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., H.H. Vreeland, Charles Osgood, and J. Leonard Fisk.
BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- It is announced here that the German cruiser Vineta has been ordered to Maracaibo. Chancellor von Buelow discussed the Venezuelan situation in the Reichstag to-day.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- With the repayments to the Bank of England completed, the tendency of money rates to-day was to be easier, though supplies were not plentiful. Discounts were easy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Quay's Statehood dinner brought on a sharp and threatening situation in the Senate to-day. Having the courage of his 17 Republican votes, which, with the 32 Democratic votes, would pass the Three-State bill, the Pennsylvania Senator forced the fighting and boldly demanded an agreement for a vote.

A bomb decorated with gilt and containing three-quarters of a pound of black powder was placed on the front doorstep of the home of Peter Doelger, the millionaire brewer, at Riverside Drive and West One Hundredth Street early yesterday morning. It was made of iron pipe two inches in diameter and nine inches long.

The twelfth annual meeting of the Consumers' League of this city was held yesterday afternoon at Assembly Hall. Fifth Avenue and Twentieth Street. The hall was crowded with a large and fashionable audience. There was the reading of the annual report, showing that many of the great stores were on the list of those described as "white" by the league because they were shortening hours of work.

Support was voted at the annual meeting of the New York Zoological Society at the Down Town Association yesterday to the bill introduced into Congress by Senator Perkins of California, empowering the President of the United States to set aside such areas of the public forest reserve as he may deem best for the protection of wild animals, birds, and fish.

The committee of retail dealers appointed last week by Mayor Low to consider the question as to how to get more company coal brought to tidewater had a conference with the Mayor at the City Hall yesterday afternoon. The committee consists of G.D. Curtis of Curtis Blaisdell; G.I. Herbert of H.L. Herbert Co., and Michael Burns of Burns Brothers.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- When the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upon the franchise tax law was first made public to-day, the general expression around the Capitol was that the whole law had been declared unconstitutional. Within half an hour after the decision had been rendered groups of legislative lawyers were poring over the opinion to decide what it meant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Minister Bowen, accompanied by Mrs. Bowen, reached here shortly after noon to-day. They were met at the station by their nephew, Hamilton Holt of New York, and were driven at once to the Arlington Hotel. Mr. Bowen refused to discuss his mission. After luncheon he called at the State Department, where he had a long conference with Assistant Secretary Hill.

After an illness of varying severity of several weeks, during which time he was able on occasions to be about the city, Julian Ralph died suddenly at 7:43 o'clock last evening, at 118 West Seventy-sixth Street. The immediate cause of death was an effusion of blood and foreign matter into the lungs, causing suffocation.
ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 20 -- After having taken ton ballots the special convention of the Newark Episcopal Diocese, called to elect a Coadjutor Bishop, was still dead-locked at midnight.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- The money market is easier and rates are slightly lower. In local banking circles comment is very favorable regarding Secretary Shaw's action in calling for the substitution of United States bonds for State and municipal securities as collateral for Government deposits. Call loans to-day were 4 1/2 to 5 per cent: time loans, collateral.

The election of officials of the Mercantile National Bank, which was accomplished at a meeting of the Board of Directors yesterday, marks another step in the plan for the merger of that bank with the Seventh National Bank and the Broadway National Bank.

The decision of the Appellate Division in the Third Department will chill the ardor of the defenders of the franchise tax law who have been preparing by agitation and mass meetings to prevent its repeal. Having been declared unconstitutional by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, the law will be a nullity anyway until the Court of Appeals has rendered the final decision.
Money unchanged, 4@4 1/2 per cent, on call.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The House to-day passed the District of Columbia Appropriation bill. The general debate on the District bill was largely devoted to discussion of the Alaska boundary line dispute.

DENVER, Jan. 20 -- Both Houses of the General Assembly balloted for United States Senator at noon to-day and Henry M. Teller received fifty votes, only one less than is needed to elect. Senator McGuire, a Democrat, refrained from voting, but he has said he would vote for Teller if it should appear that he could be elected.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Six ice yachts participated in the handicap race to-day for the champion pennant, sailed under the auspices of the Shrewsbury Iceboat and Yacht Club. They were the Florence A., owned by Commodore E.W. Reid; Eagle, J.E. Green; Clarel, Walter Content; Harold, B. Dominick, Jr.; Gypsy Girl, George P. Joline. and Commodore, Jesse Potter.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 20 -- The National Baseball League to-day had the hearing of the injunction cases at Philadelphia postponed untll Friday, so as to continue the consideration of the conference report on terms of agreement with the American League at this adjourned annual meeting.

Ex-Wardman Bissert, who made a confession to District Attorney Jerome in olving high police officials and Tammany politicians, yesterday afternoon made a mysterious visit to the District Attorney's office, conferring with Mr. Jerome and Mr. Morgan. Mr. Jerome declined to discuss Bissert's visit.

The act of 1901, discontinuing the regimental organization of the artillery and substituting for it the organization of a corps, has been in operation long enough to prove that it was a measure unmixedly beneficial. The arguments for it were overwhelming. In no sense whatever can the "unit" of artillery be described as the regiment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at dinner this evening the Minister from the Netherlands, Senator and Mrs. Lodge, Mrs. Douglas Robinson, and Mr. Hansen of the Russian Embassy. The party later attended the gala performance of "Philemon et Baucis " at the Lafayette Opera House.

-- French children seem to be fonder than those in other lands of playing with little soldiers made of tin or some other convenient material. Vast quantities of them are sold every year at prices to suit both the poor and the rich. Most of these toys are manufactured in Germany, and the tastes of the French customers are, of course, consulted in painting the uniforms.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The New York State Bar Association gathered this morning for the first session of the annual meeting. The opening session was devoted to organizeation and the consideration of routine business.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The first entertainment to be given in the new home of the Country Club of Lakewood, of which George J. Gould is President, was a luncheon which Benjamin Nicoll gave this afternoon. Mr. Nicoll's guests included Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould, Mrs. Mary Kingdon, Miss Greta Pomeroy, Mrs. William A. Hamilton, Miss May Van Alen, T. Suffern Tailer, and James H. Hyde.

After a large portion of the testimony for the prosecution had been presented William H. Kimball and Gamaliel W. Rose, who were President and paying teller of the old Seventh National BanK, pleaded guilty yesterday to the indictment charging them with violating the National banking law in over-certifying checks.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Hope of peace among the Republican members of the Senate took wings to-day when the three bolters whose independence has troubled Senator Thomas C. Platt's supporters during the vote which insured his re-election to the United States Senate joined in denunciation of the methods of the leader of their party.

We should say that the triumph of a re-election to the Senate would be somewhat shadowed if not embittered for Mr. PLATT by the tone of the words spoken by the three State Senators who voted against him.

Alleging that the concern has been taking from the city's mains thousands of dollars worth of water for several years without having paid anything for the same, the city authorities have brought legal proceedings against the Gravesend Hygienic Ice Company, of which Col. Michael J. Dady, the Brooklyn Republican leader, is referred to as the President.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Senator Elkins to-day introduced a bill which covers the features of anti-trust legislation so far as it relates to railroads. It contains the provisions which have been recommended by Attorney General Knox as to the punishment of those who receive as well as those who give rebates.

DENVER, Jan. 21. -- A joint session of the two branches of the General Assembly for the election of United States Senator was held to-day, but only Democratic members participated, and there was no election. After concurring in adjournment of the House until 2 o'clock Friday, the Democratic Representatives proceeded to the Senate chamber, where the joint session was called to order by Senator Adams, President pro tem. of the Senate.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- President Shattuck of the Automobile Club of America and Congressman-elect Townsend Scudder of Long Island, who is also the Secretary and General Counsel of the Long Island Highway Protective Association, were here to-day in the interest of some amendments to the law which was passed at the last session regulating the speed of automobiles.
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of a residence site at 1 and 3 East Sixty-second Street by John R. Drexel.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- Mrs. Odell gave her second public "at home" this afternoon from 4 to 6 in the Executive Mansion. Assisting her were Mrs. William H. Stott, Mrs. William Barnes, Jr., Mrs. William J. Wallace, Mrs. George H. Thatcher, Mrs. Henry Jackson, Mrs. William C. Warren of Buffalo. Mrs. Samuel B. Ward, Miss Hildreth. Miss Hamilton, and Miss Gwendolin O'Brien.

The melancholy knight -- or was it Sancho? -- was not altogether right; for the pantomimic nest in which birds sing one year in Drury Lane is sure to be killed the next with equally melodious fledglings on Brcadway. John Bull's pantos very soon fit Jonathan. A little making-over of course is necessary. When Mr. Bluebeard turns up on Broadway, he is a sort of red white and Bluebeard.

Probably the plan of tucking into the bill for the Department of Commerce the "publicity" clause of the Knox Anti-Trust bill is the only one that stands any chance in the present session. The Department of Commerce bill has passed both houses, and is in the stage of conference, where pretty nearly anything desired may be done with it.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21. -- The Princeton basket ball team defeated Jefferson Medical College of Philadelphia here this afternoon by a score of 46 to 13. This is the first game on the home floor this season. The excellent passing and the accurate goal shooting won easily for the Tigers. Line-up:

Adolf Philipp, who was for many years manager of the Germania Theatre, on Eighth Street, until it was demolished, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday, with liabilities to the amount of $65,426 and no assets. Of the liabilities, many are for breach of contract with various actors and theatrical managers.

District Attorney Jerome sprang a surprise yesterday when he placed the case of Richard A. Canfield, whom he is seeking to have indicted for keeping a gambling house, before the Grand Jury. As his first witness he called David W. Bucklin, Canfield's manager. Bucklin declined to answer the questions put to him before the Grand Jury, and he may be summarily committed for contempt this morning by Recorder Goff.

Frank A. Keeney and Byron Stark, the latter one of the amateurs who are preparing for the coming championship billiard tournament in the Hanover Club, played an unusually close match at the Knickerbocker Billiard Academy, Brooklyn, last night. It was for 230 points, at 14.2, and Keeney won by the narrow margin of 5 points in 27 innings. Stark had 245 in 26 innings. The scores are:

Shrewd market observers declare that there is every indication that the market was largely oversold and that the short interest was greater than at any time in nearly two years. The remarkable part of the matter is that this interest does not show to any material extent in the loan crowd, where the borrowing demand is little above the normal.

The Trust Company of the Republic yesterday made public its first annual report for the nine months of its existence. This report contains a statement regarding the company's financing of the United States Shipbuilding Company, about which there was considerable discussion at one time. The report says:

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Money was fairly plentiful in the market to-day, and it was difficult to maintain discounts in the face of the Continental competition. An early reduction of the Bank of England's rate of discount was regarded as probable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Just before the adjournment of the Senate this afternoon there was a little scene that will be memorable for many days. Senator Spooner had made the motion to adjourn when Senator Burton asked him to withhold a moment to give him opportunity to ask for consideration of a bill which he named by its number.

BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- Chancellor von Buelow, replying in the Reichstag to-day to an assertion of Herr Richter, the Radical leader, that the country and the Crown itself were harmed by the too frequent utterances of Emperor William without consulting his Ministers, said:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- New York was again an active buyer of Reading common in this market to-day, and transactions in that stock contributed one-half of the day's business. Lehigh Valley was less active, and some realizing was apparent, but the buying was so persistent that only a small fractional decline resulted.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- The management of the International Mercantile Marine Company has begun a series of radical changes and financial reforms in the conduct of the affairs of the fleet of ocean liners which it controls. Although the plans have been kept secret, it was learned to-day that they embrace the changing of the registry of several of their steamers, which will shortly be placed under the British flag.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The charge made by Representative Lessler of New York that a bribe of $5,000 had been offered to him to vote for an appropriation for submarine torpedo boats was investigated to-day by the sub-committee of the Naval Affairs Committee which was appointed for the purpose.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 21. -- The National League officials met to-day to hear the minority and majority reports of the Committee of the Whole on the proposed peace agreement with the American League. The minority report was made by the New York and Brooklyn Clubs. The two Boston representatives, Soden and Conant, have been courted all the week by both sides.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Senator Cullom led the Republican opposition to the Statehood bill into ambush late this afternoon, and the enemies of the bill were routed with great slaughter. The friends of the Territories are jubilant to-night.

The reports as to the witnesses who are able and willing to corroborate the testimony Wardman BISSERT is alleged to have given as to corruption in the Police Department must, of course, be accepted under all due reserves. It is not the policy of the District Attorney's office to publish its case in advance, and rumors as to the class to which the witnesses belong are only too easily circulated.

SALEM, Ore., Jan. 21. -- The two houses of the Legislature in joint session to-day balloted for United States Senator. The ballot resulted as follows: C.W. Fulton, 31; L.T. Gier, 18: H.L. Pittock, 5; M.C. George, 4; E.S. Wood, Democrat, 17; remainder scattering; necessary to a choice, 46.

Crowds of men, women, and children openly rifling coal cars may be seen every morning at the yards of the Kings County Elevated, near Sutter Avenue, a street lying in the border region between Brownsville and East New York, in the Borough of Brooklyn. Ever since the coal famine began the populace of Brownsville have been cking out their supply of fuel by levying contributions in this manner upon the railway.

BUTTE, Mont., Jan. 21. -- George Van Buren, one of the most noted characters of the Northwest, committed suicide in a cabin in Rattlesnake Valley, north of Missoula. He placed the barrel of his rifle against his heart and touched the trigger with a stove poker.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- What is generally thought to be the first step of the Republican organization to discipline Senator Brackett for leading a bolt against Senator Platt was taken to-day. Senator L'Hommedieu of Orleans County introduced a bill which provides that the Sheriff of any county may arrest a prisoner on a warrant directed to any Sheriff.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- The Times says that each of the three acts of "For Sword or Song," produced at the Shaftesbury Theatre last evening, begins with an ingredient of what it would be unkind to call pantomime opening and too kind to call a masque. The second ingredient is a good thick slice of romantic drama.

In the judicial construction of statutes the court tries to ascertain the intent of the Legislature and declares that to be the law. Ex-Senator FORD in his counterfeited glee and Controller GROUT in his unconcealed alarm would have done well to bear in mind this general principle before they declared, perhaps too hastily, that the Ford franchise tax law still stands, except as to those sections declared unconstitutional by the Appellate Division at Albany.

John R. Drexel has bought, as the site for a new residence, 1 and 3 East Sixty-second Street, a plot 42 by 100.5 feet, now covered by two four-story brownstone-front dwelling's. The seller of No. 1 is Martin E. Green. No. 3 was acquired from Mrs. Prudence Boynton, through Broker Herbert A. Sherman.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. Jan. 21. -- The United States tug Leyden, bound from San Juan, Porto Rico, for Newport, ran ashore on the south side of this island to-day, and is a total wreck. She is fast going to pieces. Six of her crew left the wrecked tug in a small boat, which was dashed to pieces on the rocks a short distance from the shore.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Jan. 21. -- The American barkentine Abiel Abbott, salt laden, from Turks Island to New York, beached off Harvey Cedars last night and went to pieces. Of her crew of nine only four-are living. One body is ashore, the man having been brought in alive, but he died soon afterward.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- "There must be some kind of canal legislation at this session if the Legislature stays here all Summer."

BOSTON, Jan. 21. -- Money rates seem to be gradually approaching a lower level. The continued receipts of currency from the interior and the large grain to the banks through the Treasury operations are responsible for the improvement. The usual table of local rates, , follows:

SALT LAKE, Utah, Jan. 21. -- Apostle Reed Smoot was to-day formally declared elected to the Senate of the United States and made a speech of acceptance to the Legislature, in which he defined his attitude toward the Mormon Church and National issues. He promised that every vote in the Senate should be absolutely free and untrammeled.
LONDON, Jan. 22. -- The Times has the following dispatch from its correspondent in Vienna:

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- Declarations that the Judiciary of New York is being dragged into politics and is being demoralized by the use and abuse of executive authority were made before the State Bar Association today. Simon Fleischman of Buffalo, speaking on "The Supreme Court Dilemma," and Martin W. Littleton of Brooklyn, speaking on "The Independent Judge," agreed that present conditions are prejudicial to the dignity of the bench.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- Chicago Union Traction stock dropped quickly to-day from 15 to 12, but recovered two points at the close. There was an impression that Union Traction would not be in control of the proposed consolidation, but rather the underlying companies. It is a fact, however, that present efforts have all originated with the large holders of Union Traction shares rather than the holders of the underlying issues.

It is not an unfair inference that Secretary ROOT sent the petition of AGUINALDO to Congress because of its expression of the general need of the Philippines and of its author's admiration for the Civil Governor rather than because he regarded it as containing any feasible plan for the relief of the islands.

-- Wasn't Mr. CARNEGIE unduly severe upon the men of other times -- our ancestors and others -- when, in eulogizing a boy who had saved a man from drowning, he said that in the past the name of hero was to be won only by wholesale slaughter, and that this age was the first to reward with glory the courage that preserves life and adds to the total of human happiness?

What the police consider to be a novel swindling scheme was disclosed yesterday in the arrest of William G. Furlong, who for the last month has had offices at 82 Wall Street. For several weeks past Furlong has been inserting in New York and Philadelphia papers this advertisement:

The funeral services yesterday over the remains of ABRAM S. HEWITT were doubly impressive in their dignified simplicity and the absence of all ostentation. The gathering was as great as the edifice selected would accommodate, and the assembled company was the most distinguished ever assembled in New York to do honor to the memory of its foremost citizen.

While the princely gifts of paintings to he Metropolitan Museum has left that portion of Mr. Marquand's artistic estate somewhat impoverished the tapestries and rugs in his collection show the connoisseur. The paintings will be sold to-morrow night it Mendelssohn Hall in Fortieth Street, but the embroideries and textiles will not be reached until Saturday afternoon, a week later, namely Jan. 31.
A number of special prizes have been added to the list for the annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club, to be held in the Madison Square Garden Feb. 11-14. Among them are:

With the driver and the firemen flung from an engine that was responding to an alarm from the residence of Thomas F. Ryan, Vice President of the Morton Trust Company, the three horses rushed down Fifth Avenue last night, plunging between lines of carriages, and only halting when one of the runaways had dashed its life out against a lamppost.

ROME, Jan. 21. -- The Minister of Posts and Telegraphs, Signor Galimberti, has announced that at the reopening of the Chamber of Deputies he will ask for an appropriation of $150,000 to erect wireless telegraph stations for a service between Italy and Argentina.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 21. -- Gen. and Mrs. Draper entertained this evening at dinner. The company included Justice Brown, Justice and Mrs. Holmes, the Spanish Minister, Rear Admiral and Mrs. Ludlow, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Patterson, Mr. Riano of the Spanish Legation, and Mr. de Oliveira of the Brazilian Legation.

President Wells and the officials of the Tax Department are preparing to make large increases in the assessments on the corporations having franchise rights in New York. This action was taken after consultation with Controller Grout, when the text of the decision of the Appellate Division in Albany was discussed.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Money was easy in the market to-day and supplies were increased by the repayment og $12,500,000 of Treasury bills, which was partly offset by the call for $7,500,000 of the last Japanese loan. Discounts weakened consequently and also owing to the condition of the Continental rates of exchange.

SCITUATE, R.I., Jan. 22. -- Death to-day followed the knock-out blow given Eugene McCarthy of New York, the schoolboy pugilist, by Hugh Murphy, also of New York, in a bout here last night. Concussion of the brain was the cause.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The treaty between the United States and Colombia for the construction of the Panama Canal by the United States was signed to-day in this city.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- From expressions made by Republican members of the Legislature it seems safe to say that Controller Grout's tax bills are sure to meet with opposition which will be personal to the Controller.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- Gov. Odell to-day received the Legislative Committee of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers. They urged him to reappoint Frank M. Baker of Owego a member of the State Board of Railroad Commissioners. Mr. Baker's term will expire this year.
BOSTON, Jan. 22. -- The money market is dull and easy. The demand for accommodation is limited owing to the inactivity of Stock Exchange speculation and the supply is accumulating as a result.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22. -- Extra dullness prevailed in the local market to-day and a heavy tone characterized the trading, which was active early in Lehigh Valley, Reading, and Philadelphia Electric. Pressure was exerted against the latter on the reviving of the report that the trouble among the Republican leaders in Pennsylvania will operate against the company securing certain legislation which had been promised it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The Venezuelan question has again entered on a highly unfavorable stage in consequence of the second bombardment which took place at Fort San Carlos, and for which the odium will have to be borne by the Berlin Government.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 22. -- Bishop McFaul, after reading a dispatch from Rome relative to the charge that he and Bishop Mesmer of Green Bay aimed "to organize a Catholic party in local and National-politics on the model of the Catholic Centre Party of Germany, which, by holding the balance of power in the Reichstag, has been able to get many valuable concessions for the Church," said this evening:
One of the handsomest and most notable entertainments of the season was the dinner and musicale at which Mr. and Mrs. George Jay Gould were the host and hostess last evening.

FORT MORGAN, Colo., Jan. 22. -- J.E. Jewel to-day received a postal card written and mailed to him twenty-one years ago. At that time he lived in Independence, Iowa, and the card was started on its journey at a town only a few miles distant. The card has been in the dead letter office for years.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- Gov. Odell said tonight that any statement that he thought of giving up his fight against the present franchise tax law was made out of whole cloth. He did not believe that the people wanted to go back to the direct tax, and his proposals would, if carried out, assist in preventing that.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Representative Littlefield of Maine, Chairman of the sub-committee of the House Judiciary Committee, to which all anti-trust bills were referred, will report to-morrow to the full Judiciary Committee a bill which has been drawn and adopted by the sub-committee. Several weeks have been devoted to the preparation of the bill.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The Times says the comic opera "A Princess of Kensington." by Basil Hood and Edward German, which was produced at the Savoy Theatre on Thursday, may have been suggested partly by "A Midsummer Night's Dream." its theme being a game of cross-purposes played by certain mortal lovers as a consequence of Puck's practical jokes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22. -- President Cassatt of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and George J. Gould, the controlling factor of the Wabash and Missouri Pacific Transcontinental system and of the Western Union Telegraph Company, will probably have a clash of interests at Harrisburg during the session of the Legislature which has just opened.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Authority to prosecute a formal investigation of the charges made by Representative Lessler of New York that attempts had been made by corrupt means to influence his action with respect to appropriations for submarine torpedo boats was obtained from the House by the Naval Committee to-day.

-- Recently collected statistics indicate -- perhaps it would be safer to say hint -- that more women now than formerly go to college without any intention of putting the education they acquire to direct use in the earning of money. In other words, there is an increasing tendency to make intellectual training an end and not a means.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 22. -- The National Baseball League to-day concluded its sessions. The resolution ratifying the peace agreement, which was unanimously adopted early in the morning was:
Money easy, 2 1/2@4 1/4 per cent, on call. Stocks irregular.

After having suffered what appeared to be at least a temporary set-back in his efforts to have David W. Bucklin. Canfield's manager, punished for contempt of court by Recorder Goff, for his refusal to answer questions before the Grand Jury, District Attorney Jerome yesterday announced that he was ready to take Bucklin's own case before that body.

The fine words of the German Chancellor in the Reichstag are outrageously belied by the behavior of German gunboats on the coast of Venezuela. "Rudeness is not dignity," said Chancellor VON BUELOW; and "business need not necessarily be transacted with bad manners." No. not "necessarily," unless the necessity springs from ignorance of good manners, or is inherent in the character of the offender.

The Central Brewing Company of New York, whose plant is at Fifty-eighth Street and the East River, Manhattan, held its annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday. Officers and Directors were voted for on one ticket, and all the old officials were re-elected except that Henry Herstberg was elected Vice President in place of George B. Diminger, who wished to retire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The bankruptcy bill which Senator Hoar called up just before the adjournment of the Senate last night and which was expeditiously passed, will probably become a law during this session. The Senate amendments were examined to-day by Mr. Jenkins, Chairman and other members of the House Judiciary Committee, and it was agreed to recommend concurrence with the Senate amendments.

Plans for the construction of a moving sidewalk from the Williamsburg end of the new East River Bridge to the Wall Street district in Manhattan will be submitted to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to-day. There is to be a hearing on the general subject of approaches to the new bridge, and this proposition will be offered by Bridge Commissioner Gustav Lindenthal in behalf of Schmidt Gallatin, brokers of 45 Broadway.

MARACAIBO, Jan. 22. -- The bombardment of Fort San Carlos by the German cruisers Vineta, Panther, and Falke was continued yesterday afternoon until 6 o'clock. It was resumed this morning at daybreak. Seven or eight shells were hurled at the fort at 4 o'clock at long range.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When a small boy, disregarding warnings, persists in throwing stones and insults at a bigger boy, and the latter finally catches and cuffs the little tormentor, some one surely happens along to shout "Coward!" And if the small boy only can count on such championship, how pluckily he yells "Bully!" and keeps up his impudent aggression.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The Charleston people who object to the appointment of Dr. Crum as Collector of Customs had a hearing before the Senate Committee on Commerce to-day.

CONTRACT FOR LIFE EMPLOYMENT. -- The defense of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company to an action brought against it by John H. Usher to recover for the breach of a contract, whereby the railroad company agreed to employ him for life as a flagman, was that such contract was beyond the authority of Division Superintendent William G. Watson, who made it.
ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- These bills were introduced in the Legislature to-day:

A tall, broad-shouldered young man, well dressed in a business suit, a light-colored raglan coat, and a light fedora hat, separated himself from the crowd of pedestrians on the Brooklyn Bridge last evening and sprang on a big supporting cable where it passes up beside the foot passage from the anchorage on the Manhattan side.

Maurice Grau will abandon his management of the Metropolitan Opera House company this Spring, and it is believed by his friends that his failing health will prevent him from taking much active part in the future in supplying grand opera.

There was recorded in the Register's Office yesterday a mortgage for $75,000,000 made by the International Mercantile and Marine Company in favor of the New York Security and Trust Company, and covering the former corporation's "title to leasehold in Piers 14 and 15, North River, and all its property, both real and personal."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22. -- The question of who is responsible for the apparent shortage in the supply of anthracite coal was the subject of considerable debate today by the attorneys representing the parties before the strike commission. It was testified to that the miners are not obeying President Mitchell's request to make extra efforts to produce more coal to relieve the situation.

By a score of 5 goals to 3, the Brooklyn Skating Club's hockey team defeated the New York Athletic Club seven at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink last night. The victory of the Brooklyn players was unexpected, although the manager of the New York team did not have all of his best men in the game.

That is a sensible looking bill for a new City Hall which Senator McCARREN has introduced at Albany. It is said to have the sanction of the Mayor, and we see no reason why it should not have it. For it authorizes the Mayor to appoint a commission, with certain members ex officio, who shall, in short, do what they like with regard to a new municipal building or buildings.

A fearless bar and an incorruptible bench are among the pillars of our safety. The bar of New York County has repeatedly shown that it is not afraid -- not even of the bench. The Bar Association has not hesitated to speak plainly about unfit nominations made by bosses or about the unseemly conduct of Judges.

The completion, by the President's signature, of the enactment of the Militia bill effects one of the two reforms which will make this session of Congress memorable in military affairs, and tend to put the National defense upon a much sounder footing than it has ever been on before.

At a conference between the Contest Committee of the Automobile Club of America and a number of representative manufacturers of motor vehicles for business purposes, held at the clubhouse, 753 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, it was decided to hold a test of this class of automobiles next May.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 22. -- The House leaders went down to signal defeat to-day when the House by a vote of 146 to 128 rejected the Philippine Coinage bill reported by the Insular Affairs Committee and adopted the substitute offered by the minority for the introduction of American currency and the American coinage system in the islands.
Changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Corps of Engineers:

With a wonder not unlike that of Rip Van Winkle come down from his long sleep in the Catskills to behold the changes time had wrought in the life and appearance of his village there came yesterday into the rush and the roar of the great metropolis, which had been his home, an old man, for nearly a quarter of a century immured within the walls of Sing Sing Prison.

BERLIN, Jan. 22. -- Neither the Foreign Office here nor the Navy Department has received reports of the bombardments of Fort San Carlos. They both say 110 orders were given to bombard the fort. The naval officials admit they knew the Vineta was proceeding to Maracaibo, but they did not anticipate a bombardment.

Those who have sworn at and others who have borne in meekness the pranks of the winds at the junction of Broadway, Fifth Avenue, and Twenty-third Street will be interested in a suit for $5,000 damages brought against the owners of the "Flat-iron" building by Gibson N. Vincent, a clothing merchant, whose store is at 940 Broadway.

DENVER, Jan. 22. -- Another attempt was made by the Democratic members of the Legislature to-day to obtain a quorum in joint session and re-elect Senator Teller. Representative William H. Kelly of Montezuma County was absent and could not be found. With his vote the quorum would have been complete.

Writers on hygiene have found a congenial theme for more or less intemperate denunciation in the fact that as a community we have accustomed ourselves to house temperatures so excessive as to predispose us to grave evils of one kind or another, especially colds, catarrh, pneumonia, and the like.

Were it not for the interest taken in Northern Securities yesterday's market in outside securities would have attracted very little attention. Only a few stocks showed activity, and even in these the price movements were generally too narrow to be worthy of special comment. Such changes as did result from the day's operations were so divided between losses and gains that the market cannot be said to have shown any decided tendency in either direction.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The opinion of Gen. Boguslowski of Germany that the bombardment of Fort San Carlos was fully justified by the necessity of making the blockade effective on the Lake of Maracaibo and that the German ships would have neglected their duty if they had permitted the transportation of coffee from Colombia to Venezuela to be continued, finds support in the English press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The Statehood bill has consumed one more of the thirty-five legislative days that were left at the close of business yesterday. Little that was eventful and nothing that was exciting marked the day's proceedings. Senator Burnham was still the ostensible speaker, but he really did little of the talking.

The question of marriage and divorce, the proposed change of name, and other questions which have agitated the Protestant Episcopal Church of this country during recent years, came in for a great deal of discussion by such eminent churchmen as Bishop Potter of New York and Bishop Burgess of Long Island at the sixteenth annual dinner of the Church Club, held at Sherry's last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- There is a probability that State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh will be called before a committee of the Legislature to explain his connection with the bribery charges of Congressman Montague Lessler, made to the Naval Committee of the House of Representatives.

After posing for almost a week as the heroic defender of his employer's home from robbers, James Reilly, twenty-one years old, second butler for Augustus D. Juilliard, of 16 West Fifty-seventh Street, spent last night in a cell at Police Headquarters. He is according to Capt. Langan of the Detective Bureau, a confessed thief and forger and inventor of and the sole actor in the "burglary" which excited the whole neighborhood.
BERLIN, Jan. 22. -- Chancellor von Bulow again spoke on Venezuela in the Reichstag to-day in answer to the criticisms of Herr Bebel (Socialist) on the Government's policy. The Chancellor said:

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 -- "Nothing new" is the most concise phrase in which the local market can be summarized. There was an abundance of bidding and asking but very little in the way of actual selling. The tone was fairly steady. It might be counted as encouragingly steady in view of the very slack demand on the buying side.

Three women were killed and twelve persons were seriously injured, some of them probably fatally, in a mad rush to get out of a fancied danger from fire in the cigar factory of Leopold Miller Sons, at 155 and 157 Crosby Street, yesterday morning. The fire was next door, and those who became so panic-stricken were in no peril from the flames.

The latest number of Out west, published monthly in San Francisco, contains an article on the attractions of San Francisco by Charles F. Lummis, who is publisher, editor, chief contributor, and principal illustrator of this periodical. The article is up-to-date and well illustrated.

STEPHANUS JOHANNES PAULUS KRUGER was four times President of the South African Republic by no accident. When he was a boy he began to acquire his ascendency over other people by courage and efficiency in war and hunting, and that ascendency he held until after he left his country in the Autumn of 1900, within a month of his seventy-fifth birthday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- The principal features of the local market to-day were the heavy buying of Lehigh Valley, which advanced its price to 42 -- the highest since 1895; a 5-point break in Delaware County Railway 4s to 80, and the demand for other issues of bonds, including Philadelphia Electric, Indianapolis Street Railway 4s, and Choctaw General 4s.
PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 23 -- It is understood that Charles M. Schwab will sail from here Jan. 26 direct for New York:

It is not clearly apparent from anything published what Dr. ALVAREZ DE TOLEDO had in mind when he urged the American Customs Congress to promote the extension of the Monroe Doctrine to commerce. It cannot be supposed that he meant to forbid Europe to trade here. But although the idea is not permissible in that exact sense, it is already effective in a sense not very different.

The Evening Post has rendered a public service in unearthing proof of a fact previously known to those for whom the subject had interest, but not substantiated by such evidence as is now presented by the Newfoundland correspondent of that journal, of the real character of the Gloucester "fishing" industry, which has been tenderly fostered by the protective tariff as a school of hardy seamen for the American Navy and merchant marine.

PRINTED below will be found the contents of the leading American magazines for the coming month. While the lists of contents are not absolutely complete, the omissions mainly relate to regular departments and to illustrations and contributions of lesser importance.

ANOTHER writer has arisen to take his palce among that school of stern realists of which Ibsen, Sudermann, and Hauptmann are among the master. In his "Deeps of Deliverance "Herr van Eeden has presented a temperamental study of an extraordinarily searching order.

This is the last day of the Automobile Show at the Madison Square Garden, and persons who have not yet visited the exhibition and who desire to see the largest and finest collection of motor vehicles and their adjuncts ever shown in this country must do so before 11 o'clock to-night, when the doors will be finally closed.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- It is understood that the capitalization of the new coastwise schooner combination, to be known as the Coastwise Transportation Company, will be $3,000,000.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Mr. Kipling's poem in The Times is a characteristic one. It is full of vigor and patriotism; full of that strong, rushing melody of which he alone has the mastery. As a poem it will add to his reputation, and there is no doubt that the sentiment it voices will find an echo in thousands of English breasts.

THESE are studiew of labor and socialism at first hand, Mr. Brooks states that he began, as most students of social and economic questions do, with a too exclusive study of books, and found that for "live questions," such as strikes, trade unions, the influence of machinery, , few had more than slight value.

DENVER, Jan. 23. -- There was no solution of Colorado's Senatorial dead-lock today. The Democrats were unable to got a quorum at their joint session and the Republicans are still divided into hostile factions.

A petition in bankruptcy was filed yesterday against John and Herbert W. Wilde, who composed the firm of Samuel Wilde's Sons. wholesale dealers in coffees, teas, and spices at 11 and 13 Dutch Street, by Morris J. Hirsch, for H.C. Bennett Co., note brokers, of 71 Wall Street, creditors for $103,500 for money loaned to the firm between Aug. 21 and Nov. 17, 1902.

ST. PAUL. Jan. 23 -- The Supreme Court to-day held that an advertisement is binding upon the advertiser in the case of M. C. Rettner against the Minnesota Cold Storage Company. A verdict of $380 against the company, awarded because a lot of celery stored in the company's plant was spoiled by too high temperature, was sustained.

Charles G. Harper, the historian of old English coaching roads, whose latest volume, "The Cambridge Road," has been well received in England, seems to have availed himself of some of the facts in a forgotten book, "The Autobiography of a Coachman," by Thomas cross, which was published forty years ago.

Edmund Gosse says that Henri de Regnier's new volume of poems, "La Cite des Eaux," just published in Paris, is the most important book of poetry produced in France thus far this Winter. Regnier has been before the public sixteen or seventeen years. In Mr. Gosse's opinion "his verse is learned, copious, varied, and always distinguished.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Mrs. Roosevelt entertained this evening at her usual weekly musicale, when the new piano recently made for the White House was used for the first time. This instrument is a concert grand with gold colored case decorated with the shields of the thirteen original States.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Book: MR. FRED H. COMSTOCK seems to misapprehend my phrase to the effect that Dr. Wilson, in his "History of the American People," is the first historian to tell us why Andrew Jackson was.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Under "Topics of the Week" in your issue of Jan. 10 I find a statement that the demand for a "high-grade literary journal" was "put into forcible words" by myself at the late meeting of the Central Division of the Modern Language Association of America.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- The money market is extremely duli and comfortably easy. Call loans. 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; time loans, on collateral, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; time loans, on mercantile paper, 4 3/4 @ 5 1/4 per cent. Clearing House loans, 4 1/2 per cent. New York funds at par. Clearings, $26,926,573; balances, $1,256,666. The fornign exchange market is firm.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Another covert attack upon the proposed legislation for the improvement of the canals was made in the Senate to-day when Senator Ambler introduced a resolution which, if passed and approved by the Governor, would permit the sale of the State waterways. Senator Ambler's resolution reads:

The performance of Wagner's trilogy of "Der Ring des Nibelungen" that has been in progress at the Metropolitan Opera House was completed last evening, when "Goetterdammerung," the crown and chief glory of the great work, was given. It was representation, as was to be expected from those that have preceded it, admirable in many respects, and worthy to take its place at the climax of the series.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Money was fairly easy in the market to-day. Discounts were weak on the figures of the Bank return and increased expectation of an early reduction of the Bank rate. Rates, however, are not expected to go much lower, in view of the heavy revenue collections, until the end of the quarter.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- A series of illustrated practical handbooks dealing with country life is announced for publication by John Lane. The editor will be Harry Roberts. Every aspect of country life will be dealt with pleasantly by experts whose desire is to rank among disciples of Gilbert White, Thoreau, Jefferies, and Borrow, rather than to be classed as armchair naturalists and sportsmen.

HAVANA, Jan. 23 -- One of the heaviest importers of dry goods in Havana predicts that within one year after the ratification of the Cuban-American reciprocity treaty 75 per cent. of the Cuban dry goods trade will be in the hands of the United States.

"A Daughter of Raasay" is a title that sounds simple, unoffending, and unhistorical, but in one of those affected "forewords" which have lately taken the place of prefaces, the author, Mr. William Macleod Raine, Speedily reveals that

MYSTERIOUS are the fortunes of books published both in the United Kingdom and the United States. Sometimes the English reviews precede their subjects by months; and, again, long after a story has been read and forgotten on this side of the Atlantic it makes a new avatar in London, and one renews one's youth in reading of it.

The Venezuelan complication, if it may be so termed, dominated the stock market yesterday. It was, however, more a subject of discussion than of actual influence upon prices, for the market displayed no marked weakness, even to spite of the wild talk of possible war with Germany, talk in which even one of the prominent Senators at Washington was reported as indulging.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 23 -- A spirited fight is being started by the White Pass Railway to prevent New York and English capitalists from constructing a railroad from Eagle City on the Yukon to Dawson before the White Pass line can set a railroad in operation between the points named.

Perhaps none of Matthew Arnold's own books, interesting and suggestive as they are, is more interesting or suggestive than the "note books" he made a practice of keeping, and which have now been published by the Macmillan Company with an introduction by his daughter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs to-day began the investigation authorized by the House in consequence of the charges made by Representative Lessler of New York during a recent session of the committee, that he had been approached with an offer of money for his vote in committee in favor of construction of submarine torpedo boats.

The name of Whipple, for instance, or of Dr. Holland, now scarcely appeals to the memory of most young students. The shadow of obllvion in even overtaking the name of the brilliant George William Curtis, and even one so recent as that of Charles Dudley Warner.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- Count von Ballestrem has resigned the Presidency of the Reichstag in consequence of disapproval with his attitude during the attempt Jan. 20 of Herr Vollmar, Socialist, to raise a debate in the House on the charges brought against the late Herr Krupp and on Emperor William's telegrams and speeches on the subject.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Leonard Pearson, Dean of the veterinary department of the University of Pennsylvania to-day announced that experiments covering a period of more than two years had proved conclusively that cattle may be rendered immune from tuberculosis by vaccination.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The Times in its City article to-day says that money was in fair demand yesterday morning, but was extremely abundant toward the close of the market for the day, and discount rates were again easy.

THROUGH thick and thin, fair and foul, Mr. John Willcock stands up in defense of Archibald, the eighth Earl and the "only Marquess of Argyll," and we may give the author the credit of being an able champion.

The big White Star liner Celtic was sighted off Fire Island at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and left Quarantine at 7:45 last night, but the biggest ship in commission had so many difficulties to contend with in the way of wind and tide and darkness that her first passenger was not landed until fifteen minutes before midnight.

It was inevitable, perhaps, that our remarks last week on the hint of unpracticality in some passages of the recent report of Mr. Edwin White Gaillard of the Webster Free Library should arouse some resentment because we expressed the opinion that money raised by city taxation should not be used to provide free books in the Bohemian language for immigrants from Bohemia.

A "WANDERER'S SONGS" is perhaps more historic than poetic. The author has attempted to reproduce the "chanties" which now are only sung on deep-water sailing vessels, and which he describes as follows:

A copy of the Papal bull concerning the religious questions in the Philippines, which have furnished so much controversy during the past year, was given out yesterday. This bull sets at rest the question of the immediate withdrawal of the friars, as Pope Leo distinctly says that they will remain in charge of the parishes until their places can be taken by native priests.
D. Appleton Company will publish Feb. 6 "The Journal of Arthur Stirling." edited by his friend, who furnishes the introductory sketch.

HAVANA, Jan. 23 -- Public sentiment is retarding the completion of the agreement between Cuba and the United States with regard to coaling stations. The Cubans, while realizing their obligations toward the United States, dread having their ports placed between fires in the event of a conflict between the United States and a foreign power.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Didler's reply to my criticism of his Bookman article on "The Poe Cult" is not wholly convincing. In the first place, in defending his statement that the British Museum copy of "Tamerlane" is "imperfect," though that imperfection consists solely in the absence of the original paper wrappers, he says: "I know that the British Museum copy is not regarded as a perfect one."

The utter futility of opposition on the part of the representatives of vested interests to so much of progress in applied science as they do not control, appears to be difficult of comprehension by those who view with alarm any encroachment upon their monopolies. The forces which make for progress are irresistible.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The officers of the Panama Canal Company are highly gratified at the signing of the treaty between the United States and Colombia providing for the construction of the canal. They have received private advices from Washington, confirming the press reports on the subject, but not giving details regarding the terms of the treaty.

Although the United States Senate has been called the graveyard of treaties, there is reason to hope that it may be graciously pleased to give life to the canal treaty with Colombia just signed by Secretary HAY and Minister HERRAN. Whatever other Senators may do, Senator MARK HANNA must vote for ratification.

Postmaster Van Cott was a witness in the Harlem Police Court yesterday against W. T. Gridley of Syracuse, who was arrested several weeks ago on a charge of forgery growing out of transactions in connection with the National Mercantile Agency, through which Mr. Van Cott lost money, as he declared.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Lemuel E. Quigg made the following statement to-night with reference to the testimony before the House Naval Affairs Committee by Representative Lessler:
NEWARK, Jan. 23 -- At a meeting of the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association here to-day arrangements were made for the baseball season. The schedule is as follows:
BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- Commodore Scheder, commander of the German fleet in Venezuelan waters, officially reports the bombardment of Fort San Carlos from Maracaibo, under date of Jan. 21.

A.L. Mordccai Son have sold for E.A. Wheaton to an operator the plot 147.6 by 100.11, on the north side of One Hundred and Sixth Street, 150 feet east of Columbus Avenue, and have resold the westerly half of the property to a builder, who will erect thereon a six-story apartment house.

FLUX and reflux, The higher and the lower level. When Cromwell was dead and his great acts forgotten, then came Charles II, and reaction. He was the "merry monarch," and how he smirked when he pocketed the allowance that that most Christian monarch Louis XIV, doled out to him.

TACOMA, Jan. 23 -- Samuel R. Carron of Montreal, a prominent engineer, who will have charge of the surveys in British Columbia and through the Rocky Mountains for the extension of the Grand Trunk Railroad to the Pacific Coast, has announced that the terminus of the main line will be at or adjacent to Port Simpson village, just north of Queeen Charlotte Island.

Episcopal, Presbyterian, and Methodist committees, in furtherance of common action by religious bodies to secure uniform marriage and divorce laws, have met in this city, and have elected an Executive Committee, of which Bishop Doane of Albany has been made Chairman and the Rev. Dr. W.H. Roberts, Stated Clerk of the Presbyterian General Assembly, Secretary.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Your article in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS Dec. 27, referring to "Southern Literature" suggests much to the thoughtful mind. It is as was mentioned in the article, not a question of patriotic reverence for the idols of one's own section nor yet artificial stimulation by means of publishing houses when one seeks to establish a literature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- At the Cabinet meeting to-day Secretary Hay presented a draft of the Panama Canal treaty signed last evening, and both the President and his associates in the Cabinet expressed satisfaction with the results achieved through the long and difficult negotiations.

Nobody can deny that the conviction of Col. LYNCH is quite just. No jury could have done anything else, on the evidence, but to find him guilty, and no Judge anything else, on the verdict, but to sentence him to death.

The Board of Estimate held a long session yesterday. Among the first questions considered were the applications of the Union Railway Company and the Interborough Street Railway Company for franchise rights in the Bronx and also for authority to lay tracks on Macomb's Dam and other bridges across the Harlem River.

The story of the Delaware Indian Nemacolin's Path, which Washington widened and made practicable for military uses in 1754, is the third volume in the Historic Highways series. This great highway, the line of which is closely paralleled to-day by the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, was one of the absolutely necessary links in the chain that kept the Middle West in the Union.
TO think that Henry Hudson when he found the Hudson fancied that he was an route for the furthermost Ind: What a bitter disappointment it must have been to him when he noted that there was tidewater.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- In a dispatch from Willemstad, Curacao, the correspondent of The Daily Mail says:

Guglielmo Marconi, having completed the equipping of his wireless transatlantic stations in Cape Breton and at South Well-fleet, on Cape Cod. Mass., arrived in New York yesterday morning. Mr. Marconi is at the Holland House. He will remain here until Wednesday, when he expects to sail for England on the White Star liner Celtic, and will finish the work of getting the station at Poldhu in readiness for transoceanic communication.

MR. WILSON brings to an interesting subject an enthusiasm which is stimulating and contagious. He has qualified himself for writing his book by wide reading and careful study, long familiarity with the local situation, and a period of residence in the fine old house which is preeminently associated with the Quincy name and fame.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Carl C. Burt, 103, manager of the basket ball team of Colgate University, has announced the following schedule: Jan. 24, University of Rochester at Hamilton; Jan. 31, Washington Continentals at Schenectady; Feb. 7, Hamilton College at Hamilton; Feb. 14, Syracuse University at Hamilton; Feb. 21, University of Pennsylvania at Hamilton; March 7, Hamilton College at Clinton; March 12, Syracuse University at Syracuse; March 13, University of Rochester at Rochester.
TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 2 -- The Scotch curlers were defeated this afternoon by the Toronto Club by 60 to 52.
WASHINGTON, Jan 23 -- While the Administration regards the bombardment of San Carlos by the German warships as unwarranted, the United States has no intention of taking cognizance of it.

That Charles M. Schwab is sick beyond hope of recovery, and that he will never again take active charge of the United States Steel Corporation, of which he is still the formal head, have now come to be accepted as facts in financial circles, and are even privately admitted by officials of the Steel Corporation.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23. -- Andes, McChesney, and Benson Caldwell were the winning favorites to-day. The first two outclassed their fields easily, and in each case the result was a foregone conclusion. Benson Caldwell was run up to $1,500, and bought in. Weather cloudy; track good. Summary:

Say you have a fad, and that is the accumulation of Japanese objects. You see on them certain emblems, often repeated, and you want to know what they mean. In "Mythological Japan" you will read about the symbolisms of mythology in relation to Japanese art. But there is something beyond that.

Prof. J.H. Wright of Harvard has edited a collection of "Masterpieces of Greek Literature" (Houghton, Mifflin Co.) The actual work of choosing the worthy originals and the fitting translations, however, was done by a recent graduate of Bryn Mawr, Clara Hitchcock Seymour, with the advice of her father, the Hillhouse Professor of Greek in Yale.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Cornell defeated Harvard to-night at basket ball in the university armory by a score of 23 to 9. The playing lacked the rough features of the Cornell-Columbia game of last week and was, moreover, a much better exhibition of basket ball than Cornell played then.

The most interesting event in the outside market yesterday was the course of Northern Securities after the announcement of the increased dividend which was declared Thursday afternoon. Apart from the trading in this stock there was very little feature to the market, and relatively few changes of importance resulted from the days operations.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- James E. Dolan, National President of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, who resides in this city, will to-morrow issue a circular letter to all of the Hibernians of the United States and Canada, calling upon them to hold indignation meetings protesting against the condemnation of Col. Arthur Lynch, and asserting their undying allegiance to the principles of Irish nationality.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- John McCullagh's an- nual report as the State Superintendent of Elections for the Metropolitan Elections District was made public to-day. He lays stress on the primary election of 1902, and says it was remarkable for the widespread frauds which characterized it, principally in the Assembly districts in which the Democratic factions contested, for supremacy.

At the St. Nicholas Skating Rink last night the Yale University hockey team defeated the Brown University seven by a score of 2 to 0 in the fourth game of the intercollegiate hockey championship series. In comparison with the lively and rough struggles which the several college teams had played previously in the same rink, last night's contest was very slow and almost tame.

A case in which hypnotism, Christian Science, and faith cure were mixed up was heard before Vice Chancellor Stevenson in Jersey City yesterday. Jacob Hosbach of 475 Grove Street had brought suit against William J. Devoursney to compel him to surrender $5,000 of stock in the Hosbach Dry Goods Company, which it was alleged he had obtained without rendering any equivalent.
Mr. Daniel Wait Howe is right when at the very beginning of his volume he says:

The fifth volume of the International Encyclopaedia has just been published by Dodd. Mead Co., embracing the field from Coleoptera, or beetles, to Desiderius, the last King of the Lombards. There are 40 full-page engravings, 10 maps, and 2 colored plates. One of them, illustrating Decorative Art, is a very good reproduction of a Pompeian wall painting: the rich red tone of the background is faithfully rendered.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Col. Arthur Lynch, member of Parliament for Galway, was found guilty of the charge of high treason here to-day and was sentenced to death.

THE KEMPTON-WACE LETTERS" is to be published anonymously by the Macmillan Company early in the Spring. These letters develop a discussion of the function and significance of love. Herbert Wace maintains that love is a convention and inconsistent with his philosophy, smothers his love for a woman who is not free to become his wife, and becomes engaged to a girl whom he merely likes.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: May I be allowed a brief space in which to notice Mr. Richman's courteous reply (Jan. 17) to my criticism published Jan. 3. It is very evident that Mr. Richman uses the term Agnostic in a sense quite unusual, or else that he misunderstands Roger Williams's position.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Though not a member of the New York Library Club. I was fortunate enough to be a visitor at its last monthly meeting at Columbia University. The talk on the "Dangers of Overreading," by the Rev. Joseph H. McMahon of the Cathedral Library, interested me very much.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- The independent operators of the Wyoming and Lackawanna regions, in which Scranton and Wilkesbarre are situated, occupied the time of to-day's session of tee Coal Strike Commission. The attorneys, representing the thirty companies in these two regions called about a dozen witnesses, who represented different concerns.

The preliminary report of the special Engineering and Sanitation Committee of the Merchants' Association, made public yesterday, deals with conditions of travel on surface street car lines, and, taking up suggested improvements, has something to say for or against each one.

MONTREAL, Jan. 17 -- The development of Canadian railways during the last twenty years has been enormous. In all sections of the country has this improvement been taking place. The Government reports for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1881, and that ended June 30, 1901, show the following figures:

In some important respects the service of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad has materially improved since public attention was focused upon the conspicuous defects of its management as a corporation. It is more amenable to the force of public opinion than any one connected with it in an executive capacity would be willing to admit.

New York won the inter-city racquet competition with the Philadelphians yesterday in the last half of the inter-city match played on the courts of the Racquet and Tennis Club, West Forty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue. The teams were practically the same as played last week at the Philadelphia Racquet and Tennis Club, when the New Yorkers won both sets.

CHICAGO, as well as New York, is fast outgrowing its rapid transit facilities. City committees, corporation officials, skilled accountants, and expert engineers have been spending their time in devising plans of relief, and the Mayor of the Western metropolis now has in his possession a multitude of ideas on the subject.

TO THOSE husbands whose form of amusement at certain times is the beating of helpless women New York City last week served clue and formal notice to stop such crimes or take the consequences. The peculiar fact is that for years the City Magistrates of New York, and also the Judges of the higher courts, have come face to face with difficulties which could not be surmounted in punishing wife-beaters.
Over three hundred members and guests of the Automobile Club of America were present at the annual dinner of that organization held in the large banquet hall of the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

The performance of Wagner's Trilogy, "Der Ring des Nibelungen," just completed at the Metropolitan Opera House, marks the fulfillment of an annual function to which the management of that establishment appears to consider itself obligated. There is never much enthusiasm on its part in entering into it, and there have been lamentable instances in recent years of imperfect preparation for it, and inadequate results.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 10 -- The Duke and Duchess of Orleans, accompanied by the Comte de Gramont and Mile de Villeneuve-Burgemon, made a flying visit to Brussels last week. The only interesting point, about the coming of the French Pretender is the proof it affords of the low ebb to which the fortunes of the Royalist party have fallen.

ONE day last week a well-dressed man of gentlemanly appearance walked into the music department of the Congressional Library in Washington and asked to see the catalogue. There was only one clerk in the department at the time, and she was a young woman.

THE Board of Education of this city has boon endeavoring for several weeks past to find the solution for a problem which has been presented to the members by a plan submitted by the Chairman of the Committee on Buildings for the erection of a "sky-scraper" schoolhouse, of steel skeleton construction, eight or ten stories high.
In Gov. Nathan J. Bachelder the State of New Hampshire has the first real farmer who has occupied its executive chair since 1842.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 24 -- The expected debate on the Southern question was begun to-day in the Senate. Senator Spooner made his long-anticipated speech on the Indianola affair, and was followed by Senator McLaurin of Mississippi. It is understood that Senators Tillman and Carmack will make speeches us soon as possible.

Now that the incident of the proposed mouse-killing contest for pet cats at Stamford is closed to the satisfaction of all in interest, the cats and mice included, there remains just a suspicion that the estimable women who were credited with the purpose of putting the vermicidal capacity of their pets to the test were perpetrating a joke upon those who took them quite seriously.
WITH plenty of women, young, middie-aged, and old, single and married. The Man Who Calls never loses his popularity.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 24 -- It is expected that the new ninety-foot yacht now building at the Herreshoff shops will be all framed in next week, as at the close of work to-night more than half of the ribs were in place. The work of plating the boat was commenced to-day, one of the bronze plates being attached at the garboard strake amidships.

The resignation of G.I. Cummings as First Vice President of the Erie Railroad was announced yesterday. The resignation of Mr. Cummings had been expected for some time, rumors about his retirement having been in circulation for the last six months. Mr. Cummings some weeks ago left on an extended vacation, and at that time the reports wore renewed, without any special confirmation, however.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 24 -- As was to be expected, the skaters found their enjoyment of this sport shortlived. Warm rains early in the week soon made short shrift of the ice in the lake, and the zip. zip, clippety-clip of the steel runners no longer echoes through the pines. Not in many seasons have Lakewood's Winter visitors enjoyed such full measure of this exhilarating sport as they have so far this season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have to thank you for your semi-editorial in to-day's issue toning down Andrew Carnegie's "fervid oratory" in prerenting something or other to a boy who had saved somebody, (a very ordinary occurrence in civilized life, although it may not have been so among the unathletic, although cheeky and conceited, weaver boys of Andrew's native town of Dunfermline in the ancient Kingdom of Fife.)

THE delegation from the North Side Board of Trade which recently visited Washington to urge the removal of obstructions to navigation in the Bronx Kills, and was accorded an audience with President Roosevelt and Congressman Theodore E. Burton of Ohio, Chairman of the House Committee on Rivers and Harbors, returned well satisfied with the result of its efforts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The period of time fixed for the ratification of the Cuban reciprocity treaty expires Jan. 31, one week from to-day. It is considered very doubtful whether ratification can be secured before that date, and the State Department therefore has taken steps to have the limit of time extended.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a controversy between a living editor and a dead poet, especially on an economic subject, the odds would seem to be overwhelmingly in favor of the former. I cannot help feeling, however, that in your criticism in last Sunday's issue of the famous lines beginning, "Ill fares the land to hastening ills a prey," you have distinetly the worse of the argument.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The invitation extended by King Edward to the German Ambassador here. Count Wolff-Metternich, to dine at Windsor Castle next Tuesday, Emperor William's birthday, has aroused considerable interest. It is the first time that Emperor William's birthday has given formally observed by the British Court, and therefore the King's action has given much satisfaction at Berlin, where it is regarded as emphasizing the friendship between the two countries.
