Having come to be recognized as a distinct and regular feature in the general scheme of theatrical exploitation, interviews with star players of current productions are nowadays generally accepted without question and with no attempt at analysis. In a general way they are distinctly lacking in originality, though, when studied as a whole, prolific in point of suggestion.

Commissioner Greene and Inspector Brooks, despite the snow, made another automobile tour of police precincts yesterday afternoon. The stations favored with visits were, with a single exception, on the upper east side, the precinct on the west side that received a call being the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station.

The Panama Canal treaty with Colombia, made public yesterday, provides that the United States shall pay to Colombia $10,000,000 on the exchange of ratifications, and $230,000 annually beginning nine shears after the date of ratification and continuing "during the life of this convention."

Two events of last week that have a bearing upon the Wall Street situation are carried over into this week. These are the Venezuelan complication and the signing of the Panama Canal treaty. The former has had, and may continue to have, more or less effect upon the market, but it is noteworthy that its effect thus far has been more to deaden than to weaken it.

DENVER, Jan. 25. -- The annual meeting of the National Jewish Hospital Association began here to-day. The meeting is being held at the Jewish Hospital for Consumptives, an institution founded by the association, and, though non-sectarian, supported by contributions raised by the association.

The annual agitation for changes in the football rules is on and controversies galore have taken place, though the most publicity has been given to the opposing forces of the great American game because the men who have voiced their sentiments in regard to curbing the strenuousness of football contests have been of more or less importance in their several communities.

Bob, the "canine barometer," arrived yesterday on the trim American bark Adam W. Spies. At 3:45 yesterday afternoon, when the bark was tied up at the foot of Forty-second Street, Brooklyn, Bob's tail was pointing straight up at the sky. That meant that it was going to stop snowing.

The resolution of Senator HOAR of Massachusetts, tendering the thanks of Congress to Signer MARCONI for the benefit to mankind resulting from his work in the field of wireless telegraphy, was a graceful tribute to one who has merited such honors by doing something of permanent advantage to the world.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- The Times's Dublin correspondent says that the sentence of death passed on Col. Arthur Lynch for high treason in fighting in the Boer Army during the South African war has not in any way excited public opinion in Ireland. Lynch is only a name to the vast majority of Irishmen.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- The Bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association has received from the manufacturers complete statistics of the production of all kinds of pig iron in the United States in 1902.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- An effort will be made this week to get the Statehood bill out of the way, so that the necessary work of the session may be proceeded with. With only thirty-two working days remaining to the Fifty-seventh Congress, it is realized that the obstacle to the progress of legislation must be speedily removed if the appropriation bills and other important measures are to be disposed of before March 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A report prepared by Representative Littlefield to accompany the Anti-Trust bill reported to the House by the Judiciary Committee was presented to-day by Representative Overstreet of Indiana, Mr. Littlefield being in New England investigating the coal situation along the coast.

The emotions of the audience that oozed out of the Manhattan Theatre yesterday afternoon were, to put it mildly, mingried. Matinee girls were there, and intellectual persons, and theatrical reporters, and tribunes of the mid-Victorian moralities. Some said: "What do you suppose was happening to that poor young man?

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20. -- The quiet selling of Seaboards, due to the small increase in net earnings shown in the last report, aggravated by uneasiness over the rumors of efforts by hostile interests to secure control of St. Louis and San Francisco, grave to the aggregate sales for the day a larger total.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 26. -- President Roosevelt to-day talked about the negro question to nearly everybody who came to see him, and the impression conveyed was that he was considerably upset about the attacks which have been made upon him in the Southern papers. He was particularly aggrieved at the editorials criticising him because some negro women were invited to the reception at the White House last Thursday.

Ex-President Grover Cleveland, with tears In his eyes and with his voice so unsteady that at times it became quite indistinct, delivered an eloquent eulogy on the life of Abram S. Hewitt at the City Club last night. From the works of Mr. Hewitt he drew many lessons of which, he said, the people, as custodians of the scheme of free government, should not lose sight.

The first large entertainment of a busy social week was given last evening by Mrs. John Jacob Astor in her residence, at 840 Fifth Avenue. It was a cotillion that was led by Elisha Dyer, Jr., who danced with the hostess. As for all large entertainments given by the Astors, the residence of Mrs. Astor and that of her son were thrown open.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Senator Morgan, Chairman of the Interoceanic Canal Committee, to-day offered in the Senate a resolution questioning the credentials of Senor Herran, Charge d'Affaires of Colombia, who recently signed with Secretary Hay the Isthmian Canal Treaty.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 26. -- Susan B. Anthony, the woman suffragist, believes that there are two sides to the Reed Smoot Senatorial controversy and that the law is on the side of the Mormon apostle. Miss Anthony is familiar with conditions in Utah.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce today unanimously agreed to report the Elkins amendment to the Inter-State Commerce act. Only two members of the committee were absent, Patterson of Colorado and McLaurin of Mississippi, and both are in favor of the measure.

To-morrow will be set apart in the House for the Currency bill of the Banking Committee, of which Mr. FOWLER is Chairman. There will be some lively opposition, it is reported, but the friends of the bill are confident that they can send it to the Senate.

Information was received by The Tobacco Leaf yesterday in a cable dispatch to that journal from its Havana correspondent which confirmed the report of Friday last that four of the largest cigar manufacturers in Havana have signed an agreement not to sell their brands or their plants to the Tobacco Trust for ten years.

At the dinner of the Confederate Veterans' Camp of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria last night Charles Francis Adams of Boston, in a toast to Robert E. Lee, suggested that, instead of appropriating money from the National Treasury for the erection of a statue to the Confederate leader, a popular subscription be raised to build an effigy in his honor at Arlington overlooking the Potomac.

We have already called attention to the evident intimation, in Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S South African speeches, that the solution of the labor problem in the Transvaal is simply that the Kafirs shall be forced to go to work. That the labor problem is the crux of the whole economic and industrial situation in South Africa is admitted by everybody.

The Rev. Father Joseph H. McMahon during the course of a lecture delivered yesterday before a large number of the Alumnae Association of the Academy of Mount St. Vincent on the Hudson, assailed modern literature and authors, especially those who he declared had attempted to write about the Church from a superficial knowledge of its canons.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 26. -- The receivers of the Asphalt Company of America today filed their answer to the petition of Henry C. Spinks of Newport, Ky., argued last Monday before Judge Kirkpatrick. Mr. Spinks seeks to compel the receivers to defend the suit brought by the Land Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia for a court order to sell the assets pledged to secure the $30,000,000 of gold certificates.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26. -- John Thomas, a negro who shot and killed Sheriff Benjamin F. Dry in St. Charles Parish early to-day, was lynched this afternoon.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Looseness of the Republican lines in the Senate was strikingly shown at to-night's session when an issue was made by Chairman Malby of the Finance Committee over the reference of Senator Warner's resolution calling for the printing of 300 extra copies of the Tenement Mouse bill.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- "The Jewel of Asia," a new musical comedy, was produced by George W. Lederer at the Park Theatre to-night. The libretto was written by Frederic Ranken and Harry B. Smith, and the music by Ludwig Englander. The comedy and music are bright. The audience received it with hearty applause.

The opening games of the Metal District Bowling League, comprising fifteen down-town business firms, were rolled last night on Reid's Church Street alleys. The Corlies, Macy Co. bowlers won two of the three opening games, defeating the Central Stamping Company and the F.W. Devoe and C.T. Reynolds Company teams.

Charles W. Morse is reported to have sold his residence, at 724 Fifth Avenue, a four-story brick dwelling, on lot 25 by 100, between Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets. Mr. Morse would neither confirm nor deny the report yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The attention of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission was to-day directed to the claims and charges of the independent operators, the first case presented being that of G.B. Markle Co., whose collieries are located in and about Jeddo, in the Lehigh region.

With a total athletic entry of 400 the indoor games of the Pastime Athletic Club and Company K, Eighth Regiment, which will be held in the latter's armory at Park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, next Saturday, give promise of being one of the most keenly contested among the indoor events in the metropolitan district this season.
PASSAIC, Jan. 26 -- From the deck of a chartered tug Mrs. Robert Long of Lyndhurst, N.J., to-day scattered the ashes of her husband to the north, east, south, and west.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- It was learned to-day by a representative of The Associated Press that Great Britain and Germany have informed their representatives at Washington that they consider Minister Bowen's proposals regarding Venezuela's guarantees to form a satisfactory basis for further negotiations.

Gen. BOOTH of the Salvation Army gravely announces the purpose of that enterprising organization "to go after the millionaires of the United States and enroll them as members." They have not usually been considered promising revival material, but perhaps the effort to reach them has not been made in just the right way.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- There will be a conference of canal men here to-morrow, the purpose of which is to reach an understanding about canal legislation which will be satisfactory to all parties interested in the improvement of the State's waterways. A preliminary conference of the different delegations was held to-night, and the spirit shown augurs well for the settlement of all differences.

Justice John J. Freedman of the Supreme Court has sent to the special Judiciary Commission appointed by Gov. Odell a pamphlet giving his views as to what should be done to remedy the delays in the administration of Justice in the State courts. In the last part of the pamphlet, after having dwelt upon delays and disadvantages due to jury trials, the Justice says:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Executive Committee of the National Afro-American Council in session here to-day passed a resolution urging confirmation by the Senate of the nomination of Dr. W.D. Crum to be Collector of Customs at Charleston, S.C., and adopted an address to the country on the race question in general.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 20. -- Pneumonia, following a dangerous surgical operation, threatens to bring another death this month into the family of Senator W.A. Clark of Montana. Yesterday morning pneumonia complicated the condition of Mrs. Frank Shaw, who was brought to a Denver hospital two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Secretary Hay and Senor Quesada, the Cuban Minister, to-day signed a convention extending the time for the ratification of the Cuban reciprocity treaty sixty days. This will carry the time limit to March 31. The fact that the time has been extended beyond the life of the Fifty-seventh Congress la taken by some as an indication that there is apprehension the treaty will not be ratified before March 4.

Money easy, 3 1/2@4 per cent, on call. Stocks firm. While the news regarding the Venezuelan complication was most favorable, foreshadowing an early and satisfactory settlement of the dispute on the basis of terms submitted by the American Minister, Mr. Bowen, this had the effect of strengthening the stock market yesterday rather than of imparting any activity to it.

The Wall Street gossips yesterday busied themselves with reports of a new "deal" involving three separate and distinct and important systems, namely, Pennsylvania, Southern Railway, and St. Louis and San Francisco, all of whose stocks were strong. The "deal," however, exists, so far as can be learned, only in talk, for diligent inquiry failed to develop any solid basis for it -- certainly so in respect to Pennsylvania.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26. -- Potheen, Censor, and Little Scout were the winning favorites here to-day. The weather was fair, but the track was muddy from early morning rain. Summary:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- There is no information in Washington to justify the positive statement contained in the Caracas dispatch that the Venezuelan blockade will be raised on Wednesday. Minister Bowen is hopeful that such a happy consummation will result from the pending negotiations, as he latest proposition he has made to the allied Governments is regarded by him as an eminently fair one.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- The money market shows little or no change, but seems to be gradually working to a lower level. Call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 4@5 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 4 1/2@5 1/4 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent; New York funds, par@5c premium; clearings, $16,051,579; balances, $973,075.

The snowfall of Saturday night and Sunday was attacked with satisfactory results as to some important thoroughfares on Sunday night and squarely tackled yesterday by Contractor Bradley, who had at work in Manhattan 2,000 laborers and 1,400 men with horses and carts in thirty-five "gangs."

Lively bidding among competing dealers and amateurs for Chinese porcelains made the sales yesterday afternoon of the art treasures collected by the late Henry G. Marquand even more interesting than the previous ones. The total sum thus far realized is $246,646, the sales yesterday afternoon of porcelains and Japanese lacquers, 100 pieces, bringing $26,938,50.

William S. Devery is entitled to take his place in the inner council of Tammany Hall, the Executive Committee, and his friends will also continue as members of the Tammany General Committee from the Ninth District. The victory of the ex-Chief of Police was won in the Supreme Court by a decision of Justice Leventritt yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 26. -- Written declarations regarding raising the blockade of the Venezuelan ports have been exchanged between Minister Bowen and the representatives of Great Britain, Germany, and Italy. In their declarations the representatives of the European powers promised to consent to the immediate raising of the blockade as soon as an agreement is concluded between them and Mr. Bowen embodying the conditions laid down by the powers.

STRATFORD, Iowa, Jan. 26. -- Stratford citizens are greatly excited over the arrest of more than thirty persons for holding up a Northwestern coal train here yesterday and seizing several cars of fuel. But little coal has been shipped to Stratford for weeks, and a famine existed.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26. -- It is reported in railroad circles that a movement is on foot to draw the Gould Wabash lines into the "community of interest" arrangement of She Pennsylvania, the Reading, and the Baltimore and Ohio.

Proceedings were instituted in the Supreme Court yesterday to compel the Commissioner of Street Cleaning to remove ashes and garbage from the department stores of the city. Since Nov. 24 the Commissioner has required the department stores to remove their refuse. The Retail Dry Goods Association, through nine leading firms, now asks the court for a writ of mandamus to prevent the discrimination.

The Rev. Dr. William F. McGinnis of Brooklyn. President of the International Catholic Truth Society, in an address delivered before the Catholic Converts' League at the Catholic Club last evening, spoke of the necessity of exercising more zeal, if the Church is to hold her ground in face of the growing tendencies of the age.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 26. -- The Rev. William Henderson Watts, assistant rector of Christ Episcopal Church, and Miss Mary Gardiner Bach, daughter of Major and Mrs. James B. Bach of 94 Lenox Avenue, were married this morning in the church by the Rev. William Whiting Davis, rector.

The members of the Central Federated Union of Manhattan had before them at their meeting on Sunday a circular signed and issued by President GOMPERS and the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor. We quote one paragraph from the circular:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The only activity displayed in the local issuses today was in Reading common, Lehigh Valley, Philadelphia Rapid Transit, and Consolidated Lake Superior common and preferred. The latter stocks were distinctly weak, especially the preferred, which receded to 32 1/2, which is the lowest price ever recorded for the stock.

President Harry C. Pulliam of the National Baseball League was one of the busiest men in New York yesterday afternoon. He had just arrived at the head-quarters of the National League, in the St. James Building, and begun to dissect an enormous mail, relative to business as well as personal matters, which had accumulated during his trip to Cincinnati.

As the results of the work of Dr. LORENZ in the performance of his special operation are being attested in the steady and in some instances rapid progress of his little patients toward complete recovery, public attention may properly be called to the large and attractive field for practical benevolence offered in the foundation of orthopedic hospitals.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Senator Elsberg tried in the Senate to-day to hurry through a bill he introduced providing for the abolition of special enrollment and primary transfers under the primary election law, in accordance with the suggestions in Gov. Odell's message. He asked that the measure be advanced to third reading, saying it was necessary to consider this legislation quickly in order to make it effective.

About 100 porcelains have just been, added by J. Pierpont Morgan to the "Morgan Collection" in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This was what was formerly the "Garland Collection," and even when James A. Garland, its originator, died it was the most valuable collection of its kind in the world.

The cross-examination of Mrs. Bessie Starr-Keefer Martin and her redirect examination by her own counsel, occupied the entire session before Health Commissioner Lederle yesterday afternoon, in the case in which the woman, her husband, Dr. John McLeod Martin of Boston, and the six-months'-old girl, which he asserts is not his wife's, are the principal characters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- After a long and exciting session the House Committee on Naval Affairs concluded to-day its investigation of the submarine boat scandal. During the day the name of another Republican Congressman, Ernest W. Roberts of Massachusetts, was brought into the affair, and Mr. Wheeler of Kentucky labored earnestly to show that Mr. Roberts had some connection with the Holland Company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- It was a different story in the wheat pit to-day. Millions of bushels of long May wheat held by the Armour interest and others were dumped upon the market, and the price of that commodity tumbled headlong amid the joyous shouts of the bears. Armour's sales to-day were estimated as high as 10,000,000 bushels.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 -- Bp special invitation of the managers of the Readville trotting track, the Stewards of the Grand Trotting Circuit met here to-day. Ten tracks were represented, one application for membership -- that of the New York Driving Club of New York -- was received, and one track -- Terre Haute -- by not sending a representative, forfeited its membership in the circuit.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27 -- Senator Scott of West Virginia addressed the Senate today on his resolution providing for a committee to suggest changes in the pension laws. Mr. Scott, in the course of his address, declared in favor of granting pensions of $12 a month to all soldiers who served ninety days in the civil war.

In the tournament of the New York Stock Exchange Bowling League last night the T.J. Taylor Co. bowlers won two games, defeating the Stewart, Barr Co. and the Ellingwood Cunningham teams. The scores follow:
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The demand for money increased in the market to-day, and supplies apparently decreased, chiefly owing to revenue collecting. Discounts were harder.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 -- There was a slight rallying tendency manifest in Seaboard stocks to-day. This had a favorable influence on local sentiment, inasmuch as that particular group frequently reflects the temper of speculative feeling here. There was a firmer tone in Cotton Duck issues, due to the persistency of the favorable talk now current.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- It is denied by the powers concerned that there has been friction between them in the negotiations for settling the Venezuelan affair. The following statement was made at the British Embassy at noon to-day with the assent and indorsement of Signer Mayor des Planches, the Italian Ambassador, and Count A. von Quadt-Wykradt-Isny, the German Charge d'Affaires:

Four men, one of them a public official, were arrested yesterday at the instance of District Attorney Jerome in connection with what he declares is an extensively organized scheme to defraud the Tax Department, by which the city has lost millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Quay made an effort to-day to hold the Senate in continuous session to consider the Statehood bill, but failed to hold a quorum and was compelled on that account to allow the Senate to adjourn at 6:20 P.M. He secured another ballot, however, to test the sentiment of the Senate, the vote standing 17 to 20 in his favor.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- Considerable progress was made to-day by the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission, and it is probable that, the independent operators will have concluded their cases by to-morrow. The Reading Company will follow, and will occupy the attention of the commission during the remainder of the week.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day received from the Manhattan Railway Company of New York a new schedule of train service devised on recommendation of the board to improve transit facilities on its lines. This schedule was considered in secret session this afternoon, but it was announced that until the board decides to approve or disapprove the document it will not be made public.
Dr. Walter Laidlaw. addressing the Federation of Churches and Christian Organizations at the Carnegie Lyceum last night. said:

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- During the year 1902 the number of trust companies organized under the laws of New York and authorized to do business in this State grew from sixty-two to seventy-seven. Those in New York City reported resources on Jan. 1, 1903, and Jan. 1. 1902, as follows:

The Executive Committee of the Greater New York Democracy held a long and somewhat stormy session last night at the headquarters of the Twenty-fifth Assembly District organization, Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street.

In the industrials the strongest stock in the active list was Amalgamated Copper, the buying of which was declared on the floor to "look good," some of it being attributed to the Standard Oil following.

To-day will not be an especially busy one in society. One of the Wednesday Cotillions will be held at Delmonico's, and the last of these will take place on Feb. 18. This set of dances will then be discontinued, but a new set, known as "The Century-Dances." managed by almost the same patronesses, will succeed it.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 -- Optional and Ahumada were the winning favorites today. Weather cloudy and sultry; track heavy. Summary:

As the latecomers were straggling into Mrs. Osborn's Playhouse toward 9 o'clock last night they were hustled and jostled by a band of people in doublet and hose who elbowed their way to the front seats accompanied by two orange girls crying their wares. These were the masters and prentices of the pit of the Swan Theatre, London, and their date was 1596.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 27 -- The Postmaster General and Mrs. Payne, who are playing the leading role as Cabinet hosts the present season, entertained at dinner this evening the Italian Ambassador and Mme. Mayor des Planches, Mr. and Mrs. Wayne MacVeagh, Mr. and Mrs. J.B. Henderson, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Foster, Gen. and Mrs. Bates, Mr. and Mrs. Dalzell, Senator Altison, Senator Warren, Mrs. Cameron, and Miss Jones.

Another day of dullness in the stock market. The news was favorable, and the prevailing sentiment was cheerful, but this did not lead to any break in the speculative dead-lock. The market has got into the same rut in which it traveled in January a year ago. The only difference is that the transactions in bonds thus far this year are less than 70 per cent. of the total in the corresponding time last year.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- At a conference of the Democratic leaders to-day it was decided to make the Stewart bill, providing for the redistricting of Elmira, a party measure. It will come up before the Assembly to-morrow, and the Democrats will oppose it solidly.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Twenty-four persons were killed and a score were injured in a rear-end collision on the Central Railroad of New Jersey tracks near Graceland station, this evening. Many persons are missing, but it is impossible to give any authentic list of the missing. It would consist of scores of men and women who are now at home safely.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Two women and a man, who arc said to live in Montclair, arrived at the Broad Street Station to-night from the wreck at Graceland. They refused to give their names. They were brought in on a special car, and at once took cabs for Montclair.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- These bills were inintroduced in the Legislature to-day:

Interest was again manifested in music of bygone times at the second of Mr. Sam Franko's aeries of orchestral concerts yesterday afternoon. Daly's Theatre was well filled, and there were evidences in plenty that the works that were presented exerted a singular charm upon the cultivated music lovers who make up Mr. Franko's audiences.

The project now taking shape in Pennsylvania to preserve as a State park the little area occupied by WASHINGTON'S army for its Winter encampment at Valley Forge commends itself as worthy of all encouragement. There are incidents and periods of our history much more worthy of commemoration than victories won by our armies in battle, and especially in the battles of the civil war.

STEELVILLE, Ill., Jan. 27 -- Robbers blew open the vault of the Bank of Steelville early this morning and secured $3,000, with which they escaped in a carriage. The Sheriff at Chester was notified at an early hour, and he has left with a posse for the scene of the robbery.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The following statement was authorized by the German Embassy here:

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Fifty lunatics, perhaps more, were burned to death this morning in a fire that destroyed five wooden buildings of the Colney Hatch Insane Asylum, a few miles out of the City of London. All of the victims were women. The institution, which was established in 1851, is one of the largest of its kind in the United Kingdom, affording shelter nominally for 2,545 patients, but in reality accommodating more than 3,000.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Outside the rush hours the service is certainly better than it was three months ago; more and longer trains are run, and all who wish to ride can find seats.

A GERMAN SQUADRON. Americans have read with interest the report published in Washington dispatches yesterday that the raising of the Venezuela blockade would not be followed by the complete withdrawal of the allied fleets from American waters. A British fleet, it was stated, would remain in its usual Winter quarters in the Caribbean.
The retirement from active service of Brig. Gen. Edward M. Hayes is announced.

The dullness of the everyday routine of things in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, was relieved yesterday by Frank C. Sniffen, a manufacturer, living at 300 Washington Avenue. On Monday night Mr. Sniffen formed some new acquaintances in the neighborhood of the Borough Hall, and accepted their invitation to attend a little party in a house on Washington Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- It is admitted by Vice President Oppenheim of the Chicago Great Western, who has just returned from Europe, that negotiations are under way for the transfer of the road to one of the largest Western railroad systems. He declines, however, to say what line is negotiating for control.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 27 -- A bear raid, instigated at the time a liquidating order was placed in Consolidated Lake Superior preferred, drove the price down to 30, a loss of 3 1/2 points from yesterday's final, and the lowest price reached by the stock so far. The common sagged off only a small fraction, although the selling in it was on a very much larger scale than on the preferred.
Theodore F. Hicks is the buyer of Charles W. Morse's residence 724 Fifth Avenue. Collins Collins were the brokers in the transaction.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- According to the Paris correspondent of The Times, Gustave Stoskopf. founder of the Alsacian Theatre and author of seven plays on Alsacian subjects, has come to Paris to produce a comedy called "Monsieur Le Maire" at the De Jazet Theatre. The playwright's company is composed of native Alsacians, but the translator has loft out the Alsacian patois.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 -- In an address before the Mine Workers' Convention this afternoon, delivered just before the final adjournment, President Mitchell made a plea for conservatism in trades unions. In the course of his address he said:

It is still believed here that all the matters in dispute will be satisfactorily arranged at Washington without resorting to The Hague Arbitration Court. -- Berlin (Jan. 26) Associated Press dispatch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Senator Quay puzzled the Senate leaders to-night when he suddenly moved to adjourn instead of demanding a night session for the further consideration of the Statehood bill, as he had announced he would do. The Republican leaders had supposed up to the last moment that they were in for a long and wearying siege.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Revised lists of the victims of the railroad disaster near Westfield last night, when a "flier" of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad crashed into an accommodation train on the tracks of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, show that twenty persons were killed and more than fifty others injured, some so seriously that it is feared they cannot survive.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and her daughter, Miss Gladys, who have been abroad for the past four months, arrived last evening on the Hamburg-American liner Bluecher. They were accompanied by W. E. Shepherd and Mrs. Shepherd, who is Mrs. Vanderbilt's sister; W.E. Shepherd, Jr., and Miss Maud Shepherd; Mrs. Elliott F. Shepard, who is a sister of the late Cornelius Vanderbilt; Williams Burden, and Mrs. James A. Burden, and the party occupied Staterooms 87 to 101.

So dull was the outside market yesterday that the trading resulted in very few changes of any importance and traders found little opportunity for profitable operations. While the market was too irregular to be very satisfactory to either those who are desirous of higher prices or to those who would welcome further reactions, the market appeared at the end of the day to be in a somewhat stronger position than on Tuesday.

W.G. Besler, Vice President and General Manager of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, after having spent most of the day investigating the causes and circumstances of the wreck, said last night that he could not see how it was possible for the engineer, James F. Davis, not to have seen the danger signals.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28. -- The market today was overlaid with a new installment of bullish expectations, without a corresponding show of actual bullish trading. Nevertheless the mere bullish talk is counted as a favorable feature, because both gossip and trading have been so quiescent of late that the market seemed to be losing all hopes of resuscitation.

Club owners and representatives of the Eastern League of Baseball Clubs assembled at the Victoria Hotel, Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday to resume their adjourned meeting. President P.T. Powers presided, and the following were present: W.W. Pierce, George Stallings, and T.G. O'Brien, Buffalo; Jesse Applegate, Toronto; Charles Dooley and C.F. Nicholson, Montreal; President Puder and W. Burnham, Newark; George P. Cressy, Providence; P.H. Hurley, Worcester, and William Murray of Jersey City.

PARIS, Jan. 28. -- It was learned to-day that the Belgian Charge d'Affaires at Caracas, M. van der Heyde, has informed his diplomatic and official colleagues that Belgium will undertake the administration of the Venezuelan customs in behalf of the allies and other foreign claimants, thus relieving the United States and other parties interested from the responsibilities of administering the settlement.

Capt. James Gannon, formerly of the East Twenty-second Street Police Station, took the stand in his own behalf yesterday, when his trial on a charge of neglect of duty was continued before Recorder Goff. The charges grew out of his failure to close up the Webster Hotel, an alleged disorderly resort in his precinct, and much of his testimony had to do with the efforts he had made to suppress the resort.

PHILDELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- Demand that the Presidents of the anthracite coal railroads should be summoned before the Coal Strike Commission was made by Mr. Darrow, counsel for the miners. He said he wished to show that it was the operators and not the miners who had restricted the output of coal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Panama Treaty was not considered to-day by the Senate Foreign Committee, mainly for the reason that several members were absent. Senators Fairbanks and Spooner being among the absentees. The two Senators named left Washington to be present when the Legislatures of their respective States returned each to another six years in the Senate.

A board of officers is appointed to meet Feb. 10, at the Army Building. New York City for the examination of such persons as may be ordered before it to determine their fitness for appointment as chaplain. Detail: Col. W.A.E. Dougherty, Major William H. Arthur, Capt. Charles E.W. Kennedy, Capt. Edgar S. Walker, First Lieut. E.H. Hartnett, and First Lieut. John F. James, recorder.

The Raines law in its relation to other legislative systems as affecting cities and the effects of the law on neighborhood life in New York were discussed yesterday at the second day's morning session of the conference of the Federation of Churches and Christian Organizations at 150 Fifth Avenue.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 28. -- A bill was introduced in the House to-day providing for a reward of $50,000 for whoever may discover an effective preventive for boll weevils. The contest is to be free and open to all.

It would be a good thing for all concerned if the House and the Senate would permanently adopt the plan experimented with in the House last week and relegate to Sunday all proceedings of a memorial nature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The Italian and British Ambassadors and the German Charge d'Affaires, at a joint conference today, agreed to cable their Governments urging a prompt acceptance of Mr. Bowen's last proposition to enable the lifting of the Venezuelan blockade at once. In this cablegram, which was sent at noon, it was suggested that the consideration of the details of the proposition be postponed until after the signing of the preliminary protocol.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- A firmer tone characterized trading in the local market to-day. The Consolidated Lake Superior issues strengthened in consequence of denial by Speyer Co. that any hitch had occurred in their financial deal with the company. Lehigh Valley was in active demand and moved up to the highest price quoted for it since 1893.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Senator Davis, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Canals, to-day introduced the Thousand-ton Barge Canal bill agreed upon by the conference of canal men which was held here yesterday. It provides for the expenditure of $82,000,000, including $1,000,000 extra for twelve-foot locks on the Champlain Canal between Troy and Fort Edward.
ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Assemblyman Ellis has introduced a bill to repeal the present law which levies a tax of 1 per cent. upon the surplus and undivided earnings of savings banks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- Armour brokers still gave the pit large allopathic doses of May wheat to-day, but the market found it easier to take than yesterday, and the price only sagged 1 3/8c. as a result. Yesterday at the close of 'Change it was thought Armour had liquidated practically all his big holding, but to-day it was seen that he still had several million bushels more to dispose of.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Three experts were busily engaged in the office of the State Railroad Commission to-day comparing train schedules which the Manhattan Elevated Company offers to put into effect next Sunday with the schedules in force a year ago to determine just what improvement of service the new schedule would effect.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 28. -- The Northern Pacific liner Victoria, which arrived here to-night, brought news from Yokohama that Dr. W.E. Geil of Philadelphia had strange experience recently of the manner in which Russian officials treat strangers in Manchuria, which Russia is supposed to have evacuated.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- Several Philadelphians who were passengers on the express train arrived here this morning and related their experiences. M.M. Reinhard, a salesman, told this story:

SALT LAKE, Utah, Jan. 28. -- "Health Day" is the name of a new legal holiday created by a bill introduced in the Legislature to-day. By its provisions the first Monday in October is created a legal holiday throughout the State.

The executive officers of the Central Railroad of New Jersey assert that the block on which the Easton Express was stalled by a hot box between Cranford and Dunellen was closed, the signals set to stop any train seeking to enter it, and everything right, and that DAVIS, the engineer of the Reading Express, deliberately disregarded these signals, entered a closed block, and ran his train into that standing on the track.
Details will be found in another column relative to the sale of part of the old Macy store property to Herman Sieleken.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Money was in more active request in the market to-day, borrowers being mainly dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were firm. In some quarters it was anticipated that there would be a reduction of the Bank's rate of discount to-morrow.

At the afternoon and evening sales of the Marquand art treasures in the rooms of the American Art Association, 6 East Twenty-third Street, yesterday, the bidding was lively and the prices realized above the amounts expected. The auction room was crowded, and though Dutch spoons sold as low as $2 each, yet the average for the two sales was high, notably so when outsiders outbid the professionals in daring fashion.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- It was said at the Foreign Office this afternoon that there was no change in the Venezuela blockade situation. The reports that it will be raised immediately are premature. Everything depends on the compliance of Venezuela with the terms laid down by the representatives of the powers at Washington.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 28. -- Harvard's track authorities are worried over the probability that J.E. Haigh, one of the university's sprinters, will not run on the Crimson team this year. Haigh is taking his first year in the Law School, and believes it will do him good to cease from athletics for a year.

Everybody will understand and sympathize with the purpose of Mr. JOY of Missouri in introducing a bill providing for the immediate authorization of twenty-five new battleships, and the construction of them as speedily as may be. But it does not appear that the House Naval Committee has accepted his bill, which would be an indispensable first step toward the enactment of it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Chief Clerk Hills of the Treasury Department overcame the difficulty of getting coal this week in a summary and expeditious manner. The bunkers were running low, and there seemed a likelihood that the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, which had been working some of its branches night and day, would be forced to shut down.

Stocks dull. So dull was yesterday's stock market, measured by modern standards, that the movement of prices had no representative character. It reflected nothing, and it would be idle to waste many words in comment upon it. This condition of stagnation is liable to continue for some time, and is not of itself an unfavorable feature of the business situation.

The Directors of the Pressed Steel Car Company met yesterday when they declared an extra dividend of 1 per cent, on the common stock to be paid in four quarterly installments, elected James A. Blair to succeed H.E. Moller, who resigned as Director, and received the annual report for the year ended Dec. 31.

Police Commissioner Greene announced yesterday his denial of an all-night license for the Delavan Hotel, application for which was made by the proprietor, Thomas O'Rourke, for a period of two weeks. The Commissioner also gave out a letter he sent to Chief Inspector Cortright, in which he said:
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 28. -- The full list of the dead, and the names so far reported of the injured, as the result of last night's railroad wreck, is as follows:

There was very little rough play indulged in by the members of the hockey teams representing the Hockey Club of New York and the St. Nicholas Skating Club in the amateur hockey championship contest which was decided at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink last night. The Hockey Clubmen won by a score of 6 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- In consequence of the wide circulation given to Senator Morgan's project for the transportation of the American negroes to the Philippines, a colored lawyer of this city, Thomas L. Jones, wrote to the Senator asking if it was intended that the emigration should be compulsory.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- The will of Samuel Thomas, who died in New York City on the 11th inst., was filed for probate in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court to-day. The instrument was executed on July 20, 1900. The value of the estate is not given, but it is estimated to be $10,000,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The Elmira Gerrymander bill, a party measure, was held up in the Senate to-day by the action of Senators Brackett, Brown, and Elsberg in voting with the Democrats. The reason for the action of the triumvirate is said to have been an incident in the Cities Committee yesterday.

The report prepared by Mr. LITTLE-FIELD to accompany the Anti-Trust bill reported by the Judiciary Committee of the House contains several passages which one disputatiously inclined might debate at much length and with some warmth. For example:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- There was pause in the Venezuelan negotiations today that approached perilously near a breach, and the end is not yet in sight. It all grows out of the attitude of the allies in insisting upon preferential treatment for themselves in the settlement of their claims.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The General Education Board recently chartererd by Congress for the promotion of educational work in the United States, organized here to-day. The board consists of W.H. Baidwin, Jr., Wallace Buttrick, J.L.M. Curry, Frederick T. Gales, Daniel C. Gillmore, Morris R. Jesup, Robert C. Ogden, Walter H. Page, George Foster Peabody, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and Albert Shaw.

The Hebrew Free Loan Association held its eleventh annual meeting last night in the rooms of the Young Men's Hebrew Association, at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, and addresses were made by Prof. S. Schechter, Prof. Morris Loeb, the Rev. Dr. B. Drachman, the Rev. Dr. M. Asher, the Rev. H. Masliansky, and Daniel P. Hays.

All three upper floors of the factory of the Stanley Soap Company, 642-650 West Thirtieth Street, a four-story structure close to the river front, were burned out by a fire starting from the boiling over of a caldron of grease at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. Victor Rieche, forty-two years old, of 406 East Eighty-third Street, night engineer of the plant, was killed by suffocation, and there were many narrow escapes.

The annual dinner of the Sheriff's Jury (second panel) was held last night at Delmonico's. William H. McElroy, a veteran member of the panel, was toastmaster of the evening. On his right sat Sheriff William J. O'Brien, the guest of honor.

Gen. Charles H. Grosvenor of Ohio, one of the Republican leaders of the House of Representatives, who was an intimate friend of President McKinley, has written some biographical sketches for a volume entitled "The Book of the Presidents." The plan of publication is somewhat unusual, and the methods employed to sell the book are considered innovations in the book trade.

Edward M. Shepard, one of the speakers at a Philippine discussion in Cooper Union last evening, gave some figures for the purpose or showing that Mr. Roosevelt's and Secretary Root's congratulatory statements about advanced prosperity in the archipelago were not based on facts. There had been no such betterments as had been told of in messages and reports, he said.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- A firmer tone characterized trading in the local market to-day. The Consolidated Lake Superior issues strengthened in consequence of denial by Speyer Co. that any hitch had occurred in their financial deal with the company. Lehigh Valley was in active demand and moved up to the highest price quoted for it since 1893.

Stocks firm. There was some increase in the volume of trading yesterday, but not enough to impart an appearance of activity to the stock market. Little commission house business developed, and the arbitrage dealers practically suspended operations and did not even cable quotations.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 -- The strength of United Railways incomes was the one and only feature of the day's trading. Ever since the successful arrangement of the plan for the lease of the Baltimore, Sparrows Point and Chesapeake Line has become a fact, instead of a possibility, these issues have been hardening, on the theory that the income will be increased as the result of the acquisition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Gen. Grosvenor, in speaking to-night of his relation to the publication known as "The Book of the Presidents," said:

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Assemblyman Settler of Kings to-day introduced a bill to amend the general tax law so as to reach wealthy persons who have removed from New York City in recent years in order to escape taxation upon their personal property, but have continued to keep their holdings in the shape of stocks and bonds in the banks and trust companies of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The publication of a French Yellow Book to-day, detailing the efforts made by France and Russia during the past year to induce Turkey to institute reforms in Macedonia, which resulted in the tour through the Balkans of Count Lamsdorff, and in the Austro-Russian agreement regarding press reforms in Turkey, is held to point to the fact that an acute phase of the Balkan question has arisen.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Major Gen. Elwell S. Otis, in a lecture before the students of the College of Commerce and Administration at the University of Chicago to-night, declared that prominent Filipinos urged him to put down the rebellion in the Philippines by devastation and murder.

Policeman Spencer of the West Thirtieth Street Station found a young girl wandering aimlessly last night about 11 o' clock at Thirty-second Street and Fourth Avenue. The girl told him that her name was Mollie Cummings, that she was fifteen years old, and had just come from Springfield, Mass., to visit the family of George De Leon, a cigar manufacturer, who lived on "some avenue in New York."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The bill to es- tablish a Department of Commerce was reported to the Senate to-day with a recommendation for a conference on the disagreeing votes between the two houses. It is a Senate bill to which the House made a number of amendments, among these being the addition of a section creating a Division of Corporations.

Bidding was more lively yesterday at the auction of the art and literary collections of the late Henry G. Marquand than it has been since the sale of the pictures belonging to the collection. The prices realized were high. According to the experts attending the sale at the American Art Association, 6 East Twenty-third Street, the figures represented the full value of the articles.
The will of ex-Mayor Abram Stevens Hewitt was filed in the Surrogate's Court yesterday in Paterson, N.J., where the testator had had legal residence for two years past, and was admitted to probate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at luncheon to-day Lord Beresford, Sir Michael Herbert, Secretary Hay, Secretary Root, Admiral Dewey, Rear Admiral Taylor, Capt. Cowles, Gen. Young, and Gen. Crozier.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, the last of the large coal companies to present its case to the Coal Strike Commission, took up the time of to-day's sessions of the commission. At the afternoon session announcement was made that the mine workers and the Reading Company's officials had agreed that the weighing of coal in the southern coal fields is impracticable.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Gov. Odell to-day sent to the Senate the name of Capt. Joseph M. Dickey of Newburg for Railroad Commissioner, to succeed Col. Ashley W. Cole. The nomination was referred to the Committee on Railroads. That committee met immediately alter adjournment and voted to report the nomination favorably.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate...

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- R. Fulton Cutting, President of the Citizens' Union of New York City, came to Albany to-day to have a talk with Gov. Odell about excise legislation. He saw the Governor and they had a rather stormy interview.

President P.T. Powers of the Eastern League of Professional Baseball Clubs, who also is President of the National Association of Minor Baseball Leagues, has invited "Ned" Hanlon and Harry Goldman of Baltimore to come to this city today for the purpose of reaching an amicable agreement in regard to the Montreal Eastern League franchise which each of these men is anxious to secure.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 29 -- James E. Davis, engineer of the Philadelphia "flier" which caused the Graceland disaster on Tuesday evening, died early this morning, making the twenty-first fatality. He had made two statements -- one to Chief of Police Kiely and the other to County Physician Westcott.

LIVERPOOL, Jan. 29 -- The British steamer Brunswick, Capt. Brown, from Maranham, Brazil, via Funchal, Island of Madeira, arrived here to-day and landed five survivors of the British bark Veronica, Capt. Shaw, from Ship Island, Miss., Oct. 6, for Montevideo, who were picked up at sea by the Brunswick before arriving at Funchal.

Trading in the outside market yesterday presented few features that in any way suggested a change from the general conditions prevailing during the past two days. While there was some increased activity there were, except in the copper stocks, few or no changes of importance. The stocks which recently have been the most prominent were to such an extent neglected that the day's trading in most of them din not exceed a few hundred shares.

Everybody who pays attention to National affairs is of the opinion that the power of the Senate "has increased, is increasing, and ought to be diminished." Mr. HENRY LOOMIS NELSON, in an interesting article in the current Century, gives under the title of "The Over-shadowing Senate," and in much detail, the reasons that an experienced observer of affairs at the capital has for entertaining this opinion.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 29 -- Charles Beeler, who robbed the Wells-Fargo Express Company of $52,000 at San Antonio, four years ago, will be released from the State penitentiary on the 15th of next month, when he will have served out his sentence of five years, with time allowed for good conduct deducted.

Frank Wilbert Stokes, an artist who accompanied Lieut, Peary on one or more of his expeditions to the north pole and also visited the south pole with the Swedish antarctic expedition, has painted the supposed unpaintable -- namely, the aurora borealis in its pale and vivid, its fiery, its green, and its blue phases.

To the Editor of The New York Times: M. Le Comte Montesquiou-Fezensac is not the first one of his countrymen who has been surprised at the vast possibilities of the English language. A very learned Frenchman in 1630, in conversation with Dr. Wallace of Oxford, after extolling the French language for its copiousness and its opulence in derivations and synonyms, produced by way of proving his claim the following lines on rope making:

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 29 -- Cyrus Cobb, sculptor, painter, and musician, die today at his home in Allston. Mr. Cobb and his brother, Darius, have been among the most remarkable twins of modern times. It was Darius who brought to the newspapers the news of his brother's death.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial to-day about Englishmen in America your last sentence, where you advise one in disfavor to commune with his own heart and in his own chamber and be still," ends rather too abruptly. The last clause is a go-to-thunder-and-mind-your-own-business piece of advice which will observe your true meaning.

Everett V. Abbot has written an open letter to Controller Grout which discusses some important aspects of the sinking fund question. Mr. Abbot premises his discussion of the question by saying that it is to be assumed that Mr. Grout desires a full discussion of the subject, and that he has been compelled to reach a conclusion adverse to the opinions of the counsel consulted by the Controller.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Protests against Assemblyman Ellis's bill authorizing New York City to expend $250,000 for coal for the poor were made before the Cities Committee to-day by representatives of nine charitable societies of New York City. They asserted that the societies were capable of supplying all the coal needed by the poor.

The West Side Republican Club commemorated the anniversary of William McKinley's birthday by holding its annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. The banquet was held in the grand ballroom, 600 or more persons being present. Above the speakers' table and draped in the National colors was a large oil portrait of the dead President, loaned for the occasion by Louis D. May.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- The gem of the last day's offering in the May Library sale at Libbey's to-day was a copy of Paul Revere's history of the Boston massacre, the "Bloody Massacre perpetrated in King Street, Boston, on March 5th, 1770, by a party 29th Regt. Engraved, printed, and sold by Paul Revere, Boston."

Capt. James Gannon, who was tried before Deputy Commissioner Piper in Police Headquarters last week on charges preferred against him by the District Attorney, and had been on trial before Recorder Goff in the Court of General Session this week on a charge of neglect of duty in failins to suppress a resort while in command at the East Twenty-second Street Station, was dismissed from the police force by Commissioner Greene yesterday.

As we have had occasion to remark, the only satisfactory thing about the bombardment of Fort San Carlos is the patient, persevering attempt of the Germans to explain it. They exhibit a certain sensitiveness to public opinion, and that is a favorable symptom. Explanations are still forthcoming.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The demand for money was increased in the market to-day by Stock Exchange requirements. The borrowing of large sums from the Bank of England only partly relieved the stringency, which resulted among other causes from the payment of $7,500,000 of Japanese loan call money into the Bank of England.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Ex-Gov. John D. Long, Secretary of the Navy under President McKinley, as well as for some months under President Roosevelt, lies critically ill at St. Margaret's Hospital in this city. To-night three physicians are at his bedside; his wife and daughter are close at hand, and his young son Peirce has been summoned from Hingham.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 -- Sheriff Bell, who owed his laurels to Buchanan's masterly ride, and Chickadee were the winning favorites to-day. Maxilla was run up after the last race to $1,505 and bought in. Weather fair and track heavy. Results:

The tournament of the Knights of Columbus Bowling League ended last night at Starr's alleys. Castilian Council won first place with 26 games won and 2 lost, McGivney Council was second with 23 games won and 5 lost, and Riverside Council tock third place with 20 games won and 9 lost.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt to-day sent the following message to Congress:

Mr. CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS, in his speech at the Confederate reunion the other evening, made a needful explanation of his suggestion, originally made at Charleston, for the erection not merely of a Confederate but of a National statue of ROBERT E. LEE. It was naturally inferred that he meant the commemoration to be made by act of Congress, and in that form the project naturally elicited much criticism.

We hear of a bill to reorganize the Rapid Transit Commission, drawn by ex-Senator JOHN FORD, and said to be now in the hands of the experts of the Citizens' Union Legislative Committee. It gives the Mayor the power to appoint six additional members of the commission, and provides for submitting various questions to a popular vote.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- To-day's was the brightest, most interesting market Philadelphia has had for some time past. Electric Storage Battery advanced four points. Consolidated Lake Superior 1, the preferred 3 1/2. United 1 1/4, and Lehigh Valley, which was again the active feature, 1 3/8, to 44 3/4, which was bid for it at the close.

George Obermeyer, partner and manager in the "ball blue" manufacturing firm of Charles Fischer Co. of 45 Harrison Street, killed himself by inhaling gas at his home. 59 West Eighty-seventh Street, early yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- James H. Hayes, a negro lawyer of this city, delivered a speech last Monday before the AfroAmerican Council, at which William A. Pledger of Georgia presided. A good deal was said about the wrongs of the negro, and Hayes was quoted as saying that the time for peaceable measures had passed, and that the Southern negroes should inspire respect for themselves by the use of the sword and the torch.

In his preface Mr. Trowbridge announces that his heroine is not a triumph of the imagination, but a real woman, who once lived and suffered for the cause she held just. However, whether real or fictitious, she is undoubtedly picturesque and romantic enough to have been created by the most imaginative of authors.
Army. Capt. John A. Perry, Thirteenth Infantry, is directed to report to Major Gen. Robert P. Hughes, President of the retiring board to meet at San Francisco, for examination by the board.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Some weeks ago, as I was browsing over the shelves of the Mercantile Library in my customary manner, I picked out a book entitled "Human Nature and the Social Order," by Charles Horton Cooley, Instructor in Sociology at the University of Michigan, and the following, which really strikes the keynote of the author's theme, attracted my attention:

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Gov. Odell talked briefly to-day about his position with regard to excise legislation. What he said made it clear that he favors the enforcement of the Raines law in New York City, not oniy because it is the law, but because he is a believer in the policy of the law.

The notes from Mexico and China sent to Congress by President ROOSEVELT with a recommendation that he be given authority to comply with them, deserve consideration, and should have very careful study.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- The first shipment of raw sugar of this year's crop from Cuba is being discharged at the McCahan Sugar Refinery from the British steamship King Gruffyd. Several thousand tons of the product came from the north side of Cuba.

The Yew York Times Saturday Review of Books: On the first page of to-day's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS you state that "according to a veracious English corresponent all Italy is Stirred up by the rumored presence of and American of fabulous wealth, who is called the 'King of Books.'"

The study of history to-day has for its fundamental principle the conception of unity, summed up in the statement that "history is one." Mr. Mann's little book on "America in its Relation to the Great Epochs of History" tries to show the vital connection between the New World and the Old; and it considers four epochs in American history which coincide with world epoch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senator Quay succeeded to-day in obtaining from a majority of the individual members of the Committee on the Organization, Conduct, and Expenditures of the Executive Departments, of which he is Chairman, a favorable report on his proposed amendments to the appropriation bills, each of which is a copy of the pending Statehood bill.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 30 -- The standing of the midshipmen who graduate Monday has been made out. The figures represent the aggregate in all studies for four years of the course. The class leaders are Raymond Donald Battles of West Mill Creek. Penn., and Alexander Hamilton Van Keuren of Howell, Mich., who are tied with the multiple of 562.12 for the course.

"The Making of Our Middle Schools," by Prof. Elmer Ellsworth Brown of the University of California, is the title of a solid 547-page volume which Longmans, Green Co. have in active preparation. Evidently from the author's style the work invites examination from parents who have children to educate, as well as from educators themselves.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- New York Exchange was 10 cents premium. Time and call loans. 5@6 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Senator Malby, Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, probably will introduce in the next two weeks bills which will provide that the Railroad Commission, the Banking Department, and the Insurance Department shall hereafter become a charge upon the State.

In this little book, as the publishers suggest on the wrapper, "Dr. Savage discusses problems which have vexed intelligent minds to a greater extent than any other saving those of the religious life." In fact, they are problems altogether too large for the size of the book. With the direct and forcible style of the author we are all familiar.

One of the most disturbing developments of the day came in last hour of business, when Union Pacific and Southern Pacific issues broke sharply as the result of the publication of a dispatch from Omaha reporting an abrupt conclusion of the strike settlement negotiations. The dispatch read as follows:

-- Judging from the cabled summary of the report just made by the experts who have been investigating the uses and abuses of hypnotism for the German Ministry of Education, the document is the result of careful and intelligent work, and study of it may clear away the fogs from many minds now full of exaggerated and fallacious notions as to the miraculous powers of "suggestion" in one or another of its myriad forms.

Henry Siegel yesterday authorized a statement to the effect that he had leased the ten-story building, running through from 56 West Fourteenth Street to 55 to 61 West Thirteenth Street, from Herman Sielcken, by whom the property was purchased a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Some anxiety is felt here for the safety of Capt. W.S. Overton of the Artillery Corps, who left Washington for San Francisco the first part of the week. Nothing has been heard from him since his departure, and it is thought possible he was on the west-bound train which was wrecked in the collision on the Southern Pacific Road near Tucson.

BUFFALO, Jan. 30 -- A bolt of lightning Struck the power house of the Niagara Falls Power and Conduit Company's plant last night, and a fire resulted, which compelled a temporary shut-down. It was 19 hours before repairs could be completed, and an electrical famine of a magnitude perhaps hitherto unparalleled ensued.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Mme. Edmond Adam's "Romance of My Childhood and Youth" will shortly be published here by William Heinemnnn. Messrs. D. Appleton Co., who have already published this book in New York, have secured three more books by Mme. Adam, entitled, respectively.

In our recent lessons two very important facts have, demanded our attention. The one concerns the grace of God: the other. His sovereignty. To the Jews of Thessalonica Paul showed from the Word of God His abounding grace. To the Greeks at Athens he showed from the works of God His everlasting sovereignty.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 30 -- Riotous scenes in the streets made this the most exciting night since the strike of the motormen and conductors of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company began, twenty days ago. Crowds surrounded the cars run by non-union men in the centre of the city, while in the outskirts cars were stoned.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your review of Mr. E. Mayhew Bacon's very valuable and interesting book. "The Hudson River," you quote a passage purperting to give the origin of the name Knickerbocker, which is, to say the least, misleading. I take the liberty of sending you an extract from The Genealogical Magazine for January, which will, I trust, throw further light upon the subject.

The first number of a new quarterly entitled The Medical Library and Historical Journal is dated January. 1903. It is published in Brooklyn. Dr. Lewis Stephen Pitcher writes of "Jacobus Berengarius Carpensi and His Commentaries on Mundinus," particularly describing a fine copy of the "Commentaries" he found in a Florence book shop a year or so ago.

SAN FRANCTSCO, Jan. 30 -- Showers fell at intervals to-day and the truck was sloppy at Oakland. In the six and a half furlongs handicap Kenilworth took up 131 pounds and won easily from Princess Titania and Yellow Tail. Stuyve was practically left at the post. Owing to the condition of the track the hurdles were dispensed with.

Does an occasional phase of humor, a certain felicity of phrase, and reasonable amount of sanity endow a book with enough charm and value to make it worth while? If so, then the volume of misrellaneous essays entitled "Auto Da Fe," by the anonymous author of "Essays in Paradox," "Time and Days," and "Exploded Ideas" should be read with eagerness and pleasure.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Seats for 175,516 more passengers each day are to be provided by a new train schedule which will so into effect next Monday on various lines of the Manhattan Elevated Railway in New York City. Cars will be added to trains for the rush hours, and for the non-rush hours there will be 277 additional trips on the various lines.

Prof. Oman, who has long been known as a writer of excellent textbooks on various periods of history, presents to the world in this little portrait gallery of famous Romans a new specimen of his style and erudition. One feels throughout these biographical sketches that the author is imbued with Freeman's sense for the unity of history.

In defeating the New York Athletic Club hockey team at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, last night the Crescent Athletic Club players secured a firm grip on this year's Amateur Hockey League championship. It was a lively game all the way through, but all the scoring was done in the second half, the Crescent Athletic Club team scoring 3 goals and the New York players only 2.

The trend of trading in the outside market yesterday was the same as that prevailing during the last few days, and had it not been for the prominence of Tennessee Copper the market would practically have been featureless. While Tennessee Copper and British Columbia Copper advanced, Greene Consolidated, on the other hand, declined three-quarters of a point, and closed at the low figure.

The first part of the collection of the late Peter Gilsey was sold by John Anderson, Jr., on the evenings of Jan. 20-23. The 1,127 lots included original drawings, engraved portraits, (many in mezzotint.) autograph letters and documents, theatrical portraits, rare playbills, daguerreotypes,

To make the reader better acquainted with the method of story telling or romance writing of the period of Charles I., we quote a trifling episode to be found in Chapter IV. of the "Nova Solyma." Somebody is just about commencing a story, and "they," an audience of two, "betook themselves to the seats close at hand."

A book that will add materially to the gayety of nations is the latest "Observations by Mr. Dooley" upon a large variety of topics that sound businesslike and sections enough in the table of contents, but become irresistibly comic when looked at from Mr. Dunne's peculiar point of view.

This book is the work of one who has read widely in literature as well as in nature; has weighed his reading in a dis- cerning way, and tells what he thinks about it. He may think of many things as others have done before him, but it is his own thought, and new as the sunlight is new every morning.

THE long-awaited book on psychology, with special reference to solved and unsolved problems of mental or spiritual phenomena, by the late F.W.H. Myers, is now positively announced for publication in February by Longmans, Green Co.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Detailed information concerning the German tariff is contained in a report to the State Department by United States Consul General Mason at Berlin, just published. Mr. Mason estimates that the new act will go into operation between January and July. 1904.

Twoscore landscapes and figure pieces by American painters occupy the large dining room of the Lotos Club, where they will be seen to-night by members and on Sunday and succeeding days by those provided with admission cards. They have been hung by Mr. W.T. Evans, Chairman of the Art Committee of the club.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Two more deaths occurred to-day as a result of the railroad disaster at Graceland on Tuesday evening, making the total number of lives lost twenty-three. The latest victims to succumb to their injuries were J. Everett Reighten and William M. Clark, both of this city.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- Increased activity in the local market to-day was attended by an irregular movement of prices. Certain issues displayed strength, while others were heavy to weak, among the latter being the principal arbitrage stocks and Philadelphia Rapid Transit, which was depressed half a point.

The original work out of which this volume has been directly or indirectly clipped was published in eight volumes octavo, and was characterized in France as containing historic lies and scandals. It is written of as having fallen into the oblivion it deserves, and only now looked at by those who wish to read its obscene details.

J. Pierpont Morgan appeared yesterday before a Tax Commissioner in reference to the assessment levied on his personal property for 1903. Last year Mr. Morgan was assessed for $600,000, which was reduced to $400,000, and on which sum Mr. Morgan paid taxes. This year Mr. Morgan was assessed for $600,000, and he informed the Tax Commissioners yesterday that nearly all of his properly was not subject to taxation.

John Mackenzie was born in Morayshire, within the sound of the River Spey. Spiritual longings came to him early in life, and with them a desire for a higher education. He entered the London Missionary Society when young, and sailed for South Africa in 1858. Just before his departure he was married.

Matthew H. Beers has bought from George W. Bell the eight-story fireproof building 10 East Eighteenth Street, running through to 7 East Seventeenth Street, having frontages of 24.6 feet on the former and 37.6 feet on the latter. In part payment Mr. Beers gives 89 Fulton Street, a five-story building, 25 by 60, and 101 Bleecker Street, a five-story building, on lot 25 by 125.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Lord Cranborne, Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs, speaking to-night at the banquet of the Sheffield Chamber of Commerce, said the Government's policy in Venezuela was dictated by determination to defend the interests of British subjects, and that there was no infringement of the Monroe Doctrine.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- With the exception of the presentation of statistics the coal operators closed their case before the Coal Strike Commission to-day, and it is expected the striking miners will begin calling witnesses in rebuttal on Monday.

OF these two recent volumes of poems by Mr. Cawein the earlier is composed of short poems selected from various collections of the author's work, chiefly representing him in England. Mr Edmund Gosse has provided a preface written with his customary grace of style, in which he estimates Mr. Cawein's art with generous and discriminating criticism.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 30 -- President Burt of the Union Pacific Railroad to-day met representatives of the striking shopmen of that system to continue the conferences begun in New York three weeks ago. To-day's meeting resulted in the shopmen leaving without reaching a settlement, and they declare the strike will now be continued indefinitely, and will be extended over the Southern Pacific system.

AN ENGRAVER Is an artist who cannot draw." That was the sharp criticism made by a French Academician as early as 1753. It was, however, conceded at the time that since engraving was a necessity, those who wished to carry on that special calling should be taught how to draw.

John Anderson, Jr., issued this week the catalogue of the collection of manuscripts, books, and autographs from the library of John Greenleaf Whittler, which for some time has been in preparation. The sale will occur Friday evening, Feb. 6, and will undoubtedly be one of the most important auctions of the season.

Yesterday's concert of the Philharmonic Society was not one of those that make glad the hearts of its friends. Both in the interest of the matter it offered and in the manner of its performance, it fell considerably below what the society has reached in its previous concerts this reason.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- The money market continues dull without material change in rates. Money between banks is somewhat easier. Call loans, 4@5 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/4 @ 5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; New York funds, par@10 cents premium.

JUST how much American literature lost by the death of Frank Norris is a difficult question, to which there will be many answers, none conclusive. That the work he had already done contained much of promise and something of achievement will probably be admitted by all.
BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- James M. Whitney. the retiring librarian of the Boston Public Library, told to-day some of his observations of public taste in reading.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day, but the pressure was lessened. Discounts were firm.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Jan. 30 -- A detachment of Turkish troops has defeated a strong band of Macedonians near Lake Okhrida, Albania.
