PARIS, Jan. 31 -- The correspondent of the Matin at Caracas telegraphs that food supplies in that city are rapidly diminishing. Twelve bakerles have had to close owing to the scarcity of flour.

Controller Edward M. Grout, before the Franchise Tax and Municipal Ownership League last night, uttered his defi to the Legislature for holding up city bills. It has been rumored around City Hall for several days that some dissatisfaction has been expressed by certain members of the city government, especialy those who are Republicans, at what they considered the excessive amount of "talking" by other officials.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- David Flemming of Philadelphia, who has been on the years of the Essex County Jail since Jan. 6 rather than pay a judgment of $6,000 for accidentally knocking a caddy's eye out with a golf club at Lake Placid last Summer, was to-day released, his attorney having effected a settlement with the boy's lawyers for $1,850.

The most interesting feature of the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, which was held at 166 Montague Street. Brooklyn, yesterday, was the dropping of President Greatsinger from the Board of Directors and the election in his place of E.W. Winter.

Henry G. Marquand, in the history of the world of art collections, will not be put down as one of the enthusiasts of large means who devoted themselves recklessly to gathering the treasures of the centuries. The verdict of the bidders at the unrestricted public sale by order of the executors of his estate, given at the American Art Association, is that he knew what he was buying when he bought.

A final hearing was given before the Board of Estimate yesterday on the plans of the New York Central to depress the tracks and improve the Park Avenue tunnel and also make extensive improvements in the Borough of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- White Calf, a leading chief of the Blackfoot tribe of Montana, died at midnight last night at Providence Hospital of pneumonia. He had come to Washington ten days ago with a delegation of head men in charge of Dr. George Bird Grinnell, the editor of Forest and Stream, who for many years lived among the Blackfeet and is one of the tribe by adoption.

The number and variety of books recently published on Italy have already been commented on in these columns. Most of them, as has been shown, deal with the interpretation of art subjects, of politieal problems, of social or national tendencies, or are descriptions of palces and monumenis which the prospective tourist would like to visit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The European allies have not yet answered Minister Bowen's proposition, made several days ago, that there shall he no preference of claims of Great Britain, Germany, and Italy, against Venezuela, over those of other nations against the South American country.

NO PERIOD of American history, with the exception of the civil war, has Proved as difficult of calm, dispassionate literary treatment as the era of the rise and fall of the Second Bank of the United States.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Isaac Levenson died to-day in the Alexian Hospital. He was born in Jerusalem 100 years ago, and he had been a citizen of the United States since 1839. He was a dry goods peddler, and a familiar figure in many of the towns of New Jersey and New York. He continued to peddle his wares until unable to walk a few months ago.

GEOGRAPHICAL considerations have all to do not only with the history of a people, but with their art. Around Athens were many natural beauties. The climate was a pleasant one, and tourists today will expatiate on the luminous haze characteristic of the once-famous city devoted to Minerva.

All who play racquets, tennis, or squash and are anxious to play those games better will find a wealth of instructive and interesting material in this book by Eustace H. Miles. As the holder of the indoor amateur tennis championship of Great Britain for the last four years and the American champion in 1900, it may be assumed that the author is well qualified to speak with authority on these three kindred sports.

The first account of the manner in which Gen. GROSVENOR'S "Book of the Presidents" had been brought to the notice of the buyers of books of its class did not present the learned author in a pleasing light. It appeared as if the laurels of RICHARDSON had disturbed the repose of the member from the Eleventh District of Ohio.

Smarting under the charge of laxity in guarding residences in the "millionaires' district," Police Capt. Lantry of the East Fifty-first Street Police Station yesterday sent his detectives out to find how many private houses they could enter easily and unchallenged. When the policemen reported, it was found that they had been in forty-six houses, filled with every variety of valuable goods, penetrating sometimes as far as the second floor.
The investigation into the Bellevue alcoholic ward charges was begun yesterday afternoon before Magistrate Pool in the Tombs Police Court.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 30 -- The Big Four Railroad to-day placed an order with the American Car and Foundry Company for 1,000 coal cars to be delivered as soon as possible.

Stocks weak. The two salient influences in the stock market yesterday were the free offerings of call money by several leading banks at 3 and 3 1/2 per cent., and the report from Omaha that the conference between President Burr of the Union Pacific and a committee of employes had ended in a failure to arrive at a settlement in regard to piece work.

Samuel Cowan, who will be recalled as the author of that elaborately illustrated book, "Mary, Queen of Scots, and Who Wrote the Casket Letters," seems to be proceeding along the path folowed by Mr. Andrew Lang, for, like the latter, he has been seeking to probe the mystery of the Gowrie Conspiracy.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Meyer Jonasson Co., capital $225,000 was incorporated to-day by Meyer Jonasson, James C. Coane, and Julius Hertz.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- The first and second rounds of match play for the Lake Worth Cup were finished on the links here to-day. In the medal play yesterday the players were handicapped, contrary to custom. C.B. Cory of the Oakley Golf Club, Boston, won the medal for the lowest gross score, with 144 for the 36 holes, the record for the season so far.
Ex-Capt. James Gannon was convicted of neglect of duty yesterday before Recorder Goff and is liable to a sentence of a year or a fine of $500, or both.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: May I be permitted to smile (in print) at a comment made in last week's SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS by the Boston correspondent when writing of a new novel.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- The Foreign Office here received this morning lengthy official advices giving details of the rejection by the allies of the proposal that France and other countries receive equal treatment in the Venezuelan settlement. The French officials had not doubted that equal treatment would be recognized, and this unexpected turn of events has caused much surprise and concern.

No international golf match will be played this year between teams of women representing England and this country. The delegates to the annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday decided against sending a team to England, as it was considered impossible to get a sufficiently strong aggregation together at this time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After a man of sense or sensibility has been trying to get a little money out of one of our savings banks he is apt to ask himself the question whether it would not be worth while to forfeit his whole account.

There are yet three weeks before Shrove Tuesday, and the calendar of important social events is nearly exhausted. At present the events in prospect arc the dance to be given on Friday evening next by Mr. and Mrs. Whitclaw Reid, and the charity ball on Thursday. There is to be on Tuesday one more meeting of the Junior Cotil, lion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The greater part of the time of the Senate to-day was devoted to exercises in connection with the acceptance from the State of Maryland of statues of Charles Carroll and John Hanaon, which henceforth will stand in Statuary Hall at the National Capitol. Several bills were passed, including the House bill providing for the creation of a general staff of the army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Baron Speck von Sternburg, the special representative of Germany in the Venezuela negotiations, who arrived in Washington last night, was presented to President Roosevelt to-day by Secretary of State Hay. The call was formal, the Baron desiring to present his credentials as Special Minister from Germany to this country before taking charge of the Embassy's affairs in the absence of Ambassador von Holleben.

COAL, BRIQUETTES, composed of soft and hard coal dust, with a strong binder of pitch or similar substance, have been extensively used in Europe for many years, and in the past few years several factories have been established in this country to utilize in this way the enormous waste of fine coal dust near the mines.

There was no development yesterday calculated to cause depression and much in the general situation that might naturally inspire confidence, but the stagnation in the stock market continued. The bank statement was favorable, but failed to impart any activity to the closing minutes of the market.

Transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange for the month of January aggregated 16,006,304 shares, as against 15,719,742 shareo in December. 17,117,213 in November, 16,348,360 in October, 20,953,987 in September, 14,317,393 in August, 16,317,957 in July, 7,813,049 in June, 13,483,777 in May, 26,579,732 in April, 11,934,672 in March, and 12,,930,699 in February, 1902.

CARACAS, Jan. 31 -- All the newspapers of Caracas have published articles to the effect that the action of the allies in imposing upon Venezuela special preferential treatment in the settlement of their own claims is on a par with all their previous acts since the beginning of the present difficulty, namely, unjust and unreasonable.

He would indeed be hard to please to whom something in the long list of current attractions made no appeal, for it has been many a long day since so diversified an array of entertainments has invited the attention of metropolitan playgoers. If there is a preponderance of any particular kind of attraction it is in those which, music forms a part.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 -- Miss Alice Roosevelt will reach New Orleans on Feb. 16 and will spend the carnival week here as the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Edward McIlheney. Mr. McIlheney served in the Rough Riders troop and is a personal friend of the President.

Prominence of Missouri Pacific in the recent market has, as usual, been connected with a variety of rumors regarding pending developments, which are spoken of as involving the whole Gould system of roads, with more emphasis this last time laid upon the progress of the company's earnings and the prospects for these to receive further stimulus from the known favorable conditions prevalent in the States of the Southwest.

To the Editor of The New York Timer: I waited with a feeling akin to eagerness for your review this morning of "Ernanl" last evening, and in the main am not disappointed. Not to criticise your critic, however, he seems to have written as one who had substituted a later for an earlier admiration.

DURING the past year the subject of transoceanic telegraphy has received considerable attention, not only from those who are engaged directly in this June of work, but from the general public, particularly those who read the newspapers. The announcement was made a few months ago that a transpacific cable had just been completed and was in operation for the first time.

In developing the theory that a man could train himself so that he could live without food, Joseph William Sheppard came to his death yesterday morning in a room he rented in the boarding house of Mrs. Madden at 159 West Eighty-third Street. The facts preceding the old man's end came to light because the Board of Health declined to accept a death certificate signed by Dr. Julian P. Thomas of 26 West Ninety-fourth Street.

One of the many repertory theatres in Berlin recently revived the seventeenth century German version of "Hamlet" which in all probability was founded upon Kyd's "Mr. Hamlet." Crude, obscene, and childlike as this German "Hamlet" is, it throws a strong light on the esthetic atmosphere of the theatre in which the great "Hamlet" tragedy developed.

FROM accounts that have reached this city the book written by George Ade for "Peggy from Paris" contains many lines that are said to be funny. Here are some specimens called by one who was present on the night the piece was produced in Chicago.

THE MEN who live in hotels may wake up some morning before long to hear that they must pay about a third more than they have been paying or else seek other quarters. According to many of the proprietors, the time is bound to come, and that very soon. when a raise in rates will be absolutely unavoidable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Secretary Root has forwarded to Congress the claim of Julian Pedrera Roman of Bacolod, and the papers in the case have been referred to the Committee War Claims. They were printed to-day. It is not often that a claim for the modest sum of $100 calls forth such wealth of language as has been expended in the documents in this case.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the witnesses who appeared before the Coal Strike Commission during the week in behalf of the G.B. Markle Company was Gertrude Martin, a trained nurse, who testified that Mrs. John Markle employed three nurses to look after the sick among the coal miners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad has filed with the Inter-Stte Commerce Commission a statement alleging that its recent increases in freight rates on grain, grain products, dressed meats, and provisions are reasonable and just and based on existing business conditions and the present increased cost of transportation.

THE Suburban Girl lives in the most attractive suburb of the big city. We have four trains a day and a trollay. If we start early enough we may arrive in town in time for the second act at the theatre, and we generally run down in January and July for bargains.

Jack Curry, who for the past couple of years has trained the fast horses of David Lamar's racing and speedway stable, has signed an agreement to go to Kirkwood, Del., and train the horses in Dr. J.C. McCoy's stable. There are several 2:10 trotters in Dr. McCoy's string, and one very promising green mare which Curry says he has great faith in.

With the English mails to be heard from, and it is known that a number of entries are in them, the entry list for the annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will be held in Madison Square Garden from Feb. 11 to 14, should be larger than that of last year, which was the largest ever known in the history of dog shows.

Local golfers experienced an unusually severe loss last week in the death of W. Allston Flagg, one of the organizers and prominent members of the Morris County Golf Club, and Vice President of the Metropolitan Golf Association. His name was proposed nearly a month ago by the Nominating Committee of the local organization for the Presidency, succeeding Percy Chubb, who declined a re-election.

The residence of Charles T. Barney on the northeast corner of Thirty-eighth Street and Park Avenue was protected last evening with shores, anchored, wedged and seated in the masonry of the contour facade and the Thirty-eighth Street cornor, so that no subterranean settling along the line of the Rapid Transit Tunnel could interfere with its safety.

If the prognostication of the Paris correspondent, of Die Zeit of Vienna comes true, the emphatic steps and nimble struttings of the "cake walk" will soon absorb the attention of the Austrian capital. According to Die Zeit's correspondent, it is to M. Houdique of Paris that the honor is due of introducing "the great American dance" to Europeans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In discussing the recent Westfield disaster too much attention is given to the causes or blame for the collision itself, and not enough to the negligence of the railroads in hot providing safeguards to the traveling public in event of such collisions. The deaths and mutilations are due, not to the collision, but to the frail cars and improper methods of heating.
WHAT in the world is "Jim Keene doing over there, talking to De Gourcey Forbes?" asked a friend of Col. Phil Thompson's one evening last week at the Waldorf.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to express my view in connection with the present strife between the promoters of Zionism and their antagonists.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Herbert W. Knight, special examiner of the Supreme Court heard testimony to-day in an action brought by Edward L.J. Looney of New York to have set aside an order of arrest issued against him because he had failed to satisfy a judgment of $800 obtained against him by James McGarrigle, a coachman, of Morristown.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 -- The semifinals in the tournament for the Lake Worth Cup were played here to-day. C. B. Cory of Boston won the cup, defeating McElwee of the Exmoor Club, Chicago, by 3 up and 2 to play. Sidney Maddock of the Crescent Athletic Club defeated S.P. Shaw by 1 up for the Consolation Cup.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The Elmira gerrymander bill will come up for final disposition in the Senate to-morrow night. Senators Brackett, Brown, and Elsberg say that their action in voting against their party associates on the motion of Senator Raines to substitute the Assembly for the Senate bill is not to be taken as an indication as to what their action will be when the measure is considered upon its merits.

When Coxey's Falstaffian crew was making its grotesque march to Washington a few years ago "our dear friends in Europe" were convinced the end of the United States was in sight. The Republic lacked the stability to survive such organized demonstration of discontent. But nothing in the Coxey incident equaled the scenes in London within the past few days.

The retirement of Mr. Maurice Grau from the management of the opera now seems to be a certainty. Whether it be for a longer or a shorter time, it can hardly fail to be to the loss of opera lovers in New York. Mr. Grau has been almost a unique member of his profession in that he has made operatic management, since he has had the control, a profitable business.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Money was in demand all this week, and it was increased on Thursday by the conclusion of the Stock Exchange settlement and by the transfer to the Bank of England of the proceeds of the recent installment on the last Japanese loan.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Lakewood's Lenten visitors will not lack for entertainment during the penitential season. J.J. Dwyer, the well-known Master of Hounds of the Ocean County Hunt, is arranging a series of gymkhana games to be held on Saturday afternoons during March on P.S. P. Randolph's grounds on the Toms River Road.

The success which attended the recent cycle of "Der Ring des Nibelungen" at the Metropolitan Opera House was so decided that, in answer to numerous request's which have reached it, the management has arranged to give an extra cycle of Richard Wagner's great music-drama during February.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 30 -- The Harvard Memorial Society has just attached to Hollis Hall, the oldest Harvard building still used as a student dormitory, an explanatory bronze plate for the benefit of visitors to Cambridge as well as of undergraduates to whom the traditions of the college are sometimes lost sight of in the daily activities of the modern university.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Jan. 31 -- The international ice yacht regatta at Gull Lake was begun just before noon to-day, after postponements for nearly two weeks. The wind was light, and it was doubtful whether the yachts would be able to finish within the time limit of the first event, the Stuart international trophy.

THOSE who carefully observe the western sky after twilight this month will see a soft, nebulous column of pearly light, generally conical in form, extending upward from the western horizon to a point in the heavens not far from the Pleiades. The delicate and shadowy phenomenon is the Zodiacal Light.

THE season has now advanced so far that there is little that is either new or novel in the sartorial world. Hats and toques, of course, are articles of dress that need frequent replacing and many and handsome are the new ones worn of late.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- The end of the week finds the money market quiet and fairly easy. The banks are well supplied with funds, and the absence of any speculative borrowing leaves large sums of money idle. If these conditions continue, lower rates may be expected. Call loans, 4 @ 5 per cent.

I have read with much interest the letters of some of your correspondents on the present jury system which prevails in New York, and the need of a speedy reform. Having just finished a term of penance as a juror in one of our Supreme Courts, and having received the magnificent sum of $4 for my services, I can fully agree with the opinions expresed by your former correspondents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Mrs. Roosevelt entertained this afternoon at a small musicale in the East Room, when some fifty or sixty personal friends were invited to hear Mme. Roget-Mielos, who gave a number of selections from Schumann, Chopin, and Liszi on the now concert grand piano which, with its gold case, is now the most conspicuous article of furniture in the entire White House.

The plans regarding the opera for next season at the Metropolitan Opera House are becoming more definite, so far as regards the Maurice Grau Opera Company, which hopes to be able to renew its lease for five years. It has finally found a man to take Maurice Grau's place as director, so it was reported yesterday, this person being Charles A. Ellis of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

By the creation of two new Vice Presidencies, announced yesterday, an important change has been made in the organization of the New York Central Railroad. Heretofore the men who have now been created Vice Presidents were under the jurisdiction not of the President of the company direct, but of officials subordinate to him.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Money was wanted in the market to-day for month-end requirements and the Consols settlement. Discounts were easy owing to the scarcity of bills and Continental inquiry.

There was another landslide on to the New York Central tracks near Staatsburg, ten miles north of Poughkeepsie, shortly after 9 o'clock last night, and within three minutes a good part of the twenty-four hours' work of more than a hundred men was undone. The tracks had been nearly cleared of the oozy blue clay that, loosened by rainfall, had been washed from the acctivities on either side.

YUM SEN was ironing. The long sleek cue swayed rhythmically to and fro, and gave an extra little switch as the flatiron dug more heavily into the bosom front. Yun Sen was thinking. His face ran a race with a brick wall in expression. The brick wall won.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am sorry not to see more general protest in the North against the Southern policy of the Administration. It is distinctly a policy of reaction -- a retrograde movement -- and must undo much of the good accomplished by the wiser and more practical methods of other Presidents.

IT WAS a great day for the flat dwellers when they moved into a whole house. They had so much room that they did not know what to do with it. Neither did they know what to do with themselves -- that is, none of them knew except the mother of the family. She found out what she wanted done before she had been in the house five minutes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad's famous twenty-hour train from New York to Chicago, upon which the company has spent at least a half-million dollars, for equipment and in bringing to perfection the arrangements for its phenomenal runs, is to be abandoned, temporarily at least, so that the railroad company may break the freight congestion and relieve the coal shortage in the East.

Commissioner De Forest appeared before the East Side Civic Club at 548 Grand Street last evening to tell of the workings of the Tenement House Department under the new charter. He sounded a note of warning and said that attacks were being made on the foundation of tenement house reform by legislation at Albany.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial comment of this morning on a supposed bill drafted by me and affecting the Rapid Transit Commission is evidently based on erroneous information. You speak of it as proposing to add six members to the commission. No such suggestion has ever been made by me, although a report to that effect appeared the other morning in one of the newspapers.

A most interesting showing was made at the recent Automobile Show in the Medison Square Garden by a Reading manufacturer, one of the pioneers in the business, who distributed a booklet containing illustrations and descriptions of twelve vehicles, representing twelve years of actual work an automobile building.

Most people have assumed that the tenement house reform was now quite secure from attack, since Commissioner DE FOREST consented, for the sake of conciliating opposition, to the amendments added to the law last year. He went, as he made clear at the time, to the utmost limit of the concessions that could be made without destroying the value of the reform.

Tom Jenkins of Cleveland and John Piening of this city two of the leading wrestling experts in their respective styles, catch-as-catch-can and Graeco-Roman, wrestled for two hours and ten minutes in Madison Square Garden last night, and at midnight, when, the police stopped the bout, the referee called the contest a draw.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Although Senator John Raines was elected the Republican leader of the Senate, it is a fact which has been much commented upon that Senator Malby, Chairman of the Finance Committee, has been doing most of the leading. About the only occasion when Senator Raines undertook to direct the majority was on the Elmira gerrymander bill, and in that fight so far he has been worsted.

MR. MORENSTOUT suddenly aimed a vicious kick at the hat of the lady walking in front of him, which fortunately fell short by about three feet: gyrated wildly for a second or two, an expression of abject terror smothering his usual placid smile, and sat down on the slippery sidewalk with an undignified haste which broke one tooth short off and seemed to put all the rest out of business.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- The discussion of the army budget in the Chamber of Deputies to-day brought out considerable general debate relative to the strength of the army and the necessity of maintaining it on a strong fighting basis. Gen. Andre, Minis- ter of War; Col. Rousset, a Republican-Liberal member of the Chamber, and other leaders of the military element took an active part in defending the army from criticism.

Augustus Thomas has departed temporarily from the "geographical drama" with which he so long has been identified, and his latest creation, "The Earl of Pawtucket," which will be seen at the Madison Square Theatre on Thursday evening, will be an up to date and metropolitan affair.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- The first obstacle has been removed for Philadelphia to secure the National regatta, as Commodore William Innes Forbes of the Schuylkill Navy announced to-day that the eleven boat clubs which comprise the navy and the local devotees of amateur rowing had practically promised to subscribe $1,700, the amount necessary to defray the cost of the big aquatic spectacle.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 -- McChesney and Scotch Plaid ruled favorites at even money in the Merchants' Handicap, worth $2,110 to the winner, the principal number on to-day's card. Despite all sorts of interference the chestnut son of MacDuff galloped home a head in front of his field. Edward Corrigan's Hargis ran a surprising race, but was outclassed.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 31 -- Dr. J. H. Carmichael of this city this morning formally announced the success of the use of the new formalin treatment for blood poisoning on a case operated upon five days ago and this morning pronounced out of danger.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The allies have rejected Minister Browen's last proposal that all nations having claims against Venezuela be given the same treatment as the blockading powers.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- A year ago a lecture bearing the sensational title of "Babel and Bible," delivered by the famous Assyrian and Babylonian scholar, Prof. Friedrich Delitsch, attracted the attention of the whole scientific and theological world. Additional interest was given to the subject by the presence of the Kaiser, who follows the results of Assyrian and Babylonian excavations with the greatest interest.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 -- Through more than half a dozen years Wall Street activity and Wall Street buoyancy have been predicated upon National prosperity. Through all this period there has been continual dispute of the soundness of this prosperity. Wall Street expansion in volume of business and in market values has been confronted uninterruptedly by a professional pessimism that has insisted that good times chronicles were inventions.

Polo, as well as golf, begins in England much earlier in the year than in America, and this fact has been brought into prominence recently by the announcement of some of the season's important polo tournaments by the leading English clubs. The Hurlingham Club will give its opening tournament on April 28, the events continuing through to May 2.

By an immemorial custom, the wisdom of which has never been disputed, one day in the year is consecrated to fools and folly. Last week, as it happened, was given over in the theatrical world to fads and faddists. On Monday we had a revival of Ibsen's grewsome tragedy of "Ghosts," and on Tuesday an attempt to revive archaeologically an Elizabethan production of "Romeo and Juliet."

Ex-Gov. Charles P. Johnson of Missouri, in a paper read at the Winter meeting of the Missouri Press Association at Columbia, talked most interestingly of Thomas Hart Benton, whom he styled the most prominent historical character of the State. In the course of his address he said:

AND there it stood beside his glowing hearth, a big awkward cretonne draped monstrosity, bordered grostesquely with a double row of brass nail heads, a hideous blot among the beautiful equipments of his studio. A letter, addressed in his sister's careful hand, was pinned on the top of the singular object.

GOOD GROUND, L.I., Jan. 31 -- Louis Foster, nineteen years of age, a brother of Clarence Foster, who was drowned with Miss Sarah Lawrence in June last, is missing. He was oystering in Tiana Bay late yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senator Quay forced the fighting on the Statehood bill to-day. Should he fail now it will not be because he has not labored with the shrewdness of a veteran in legislative manipulation. Events are beginning to show With what extraordinary cunning he has laid his plans.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- The sale of those leasehold lands, in Central New York concerning which there is interesting history has begun with the purchase by John D. Camenga of the old Gov. Dix farm, in the town of Brookfield, Madison County. There are upward of 200 acres in the place, and the price averages a little less than $20 per acre.

The near approach of the close of the regular Princeton midwinter examinations next Wednesday has turned the attention of the Captains of the baseball and track teams to their work. Both Capt. Pearson and Capt. Horton have been keeping careful watch on likely candidates that they may not be prevented from playing by any failure in their examinations.

ONE of the recent innovations in Andrew Carnegie's new home at Ninety-third Street and Fifth Avenue is an English billiard table which he has had made to order in this city for $1,500. There is a very fine billiard room in Mr. Carnegie's house, better, it is said, than in any other home of the long row of multi-millionaires palaces that line the avenue.

When Virginia Harned returns to New York in a few weeks to invite opinion again as to the merits and demerits of the unhappy lady Iris, heroine extraordinary of a modern London flat, she will probably feel like a battle-scarred veteran returning from long sieges and battling in hostile foreign camps.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The patrons of saloons generally patronize those places for the want of more congenial surroundings. In some instances it may also be attributed to a discontent arising from a deranged nervous system, a disease, which corporations are daily inflicting upon thousands of clerks by compelling them to work with the methodical regularity of a flywheel.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- Nearly one-half of to-day's local transactions were in United Gas, which was strong and active on the announcement that a stock allotment of 30 per cent, has been recommended to the shareholders at par, $50 per share. This will increase the capital from $28,250,000 to $36,725,000.
The election in Vermont on the question of sustaining prohibition or substituting a high license law with local option is to be held on Tuesday next, Feb. 3.

HEZEKIAH GRAHAM of JenKins Corners was the possessor of a fine farm and a goodly portion of this world's goods. Yet he was far from happy, for fate, as a drawback to these advantages, had made him the most bashful man in that part of the State.

The demolition of the old Hall of Records is proceeding as rapidly as could be wished. But no more rapidly. We do not know any example of what may be called local piety more misdirected than the agitation to save this ugly old sham, the room of which is so much more desirable than its company, excepting, indeed, the proposition to take it away piecemeal and re-erect it.

The swimmers of Columbia University carried off the lion's share of the honors in the swimming races in the natatorium of the New York Athletic Club last night. With the exception of the novice race at 50 yards and the water polo match which concluded the evening's events, all the competitions were handicaps.

IT IS a puzzle to most people to decipher the ordinary time table of a trunk line railroad. Infinitely more complex is the problem of arranging that schedule. It is a problem to solve which the best railroad talent developed through seventy, years of tradition and training in the railroad business is necessary.
To the Editor of The New York Times. Please permit me to explain some matters about the South as to which you have confessed edtiorially that they are beyond your comprehension.

The officers and Trustees of the Corn Exchange Bank celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the foundation of the bank with a banquet at Sherry's last atight, and by presenting to every employe of the institution yesterday morning a corncob in which was a fifty-dollar gold piece.

The final details for the amateur billiard championship tournament which is to begin at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, tomorrow night, were arranged last night at a meeting held in the clubhouse. Rules to govern in the various contests were drawn up, and part of the schedule was arranged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The disfranchisement of the negro in several of the Southern States, the Lily White movement, and the advancement of the colored race, in some individual cases, to political position have unfortunately aroused the old spirit of sectionalism which the Spanish-American war had done so much to allay.

The new lion house, which is to be opened at the New York Zoological Park to-morrow, is the finest building in the world to be erected for such a purpose. It has every possible modern improvement, many of its features being entirely novel for such a structure. It promises also to remain for tome years to come the most elaborate and attractive of the buildings in this park.

IT IS reported on reliable authority that a prominent philanthropist, who declines to permit his name to be published, has established a fund to aid the deserving infant industries of the United States in their terrific struggle for existence. This gentleman has been identified with some of these infant industries since their infancy, that is to say, since their comparatively early infancy.

WHEN the tall girl was invited to help make up a second table at whist she declined on the ground that she had had no practice at card playing this Winter and would spoil the game for everybody else. The hostess was surprised at that excuse.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- The Foreign Office this evening was very calm, as its close relations with its ally, England, are at present, not questioned.

PALM BEACH,. Fla., Jan. 31 -- The heat here for the last three or four-days has literally driven everybody into the sea. The temperature of the water yesterday was 78, and that of the air about two degrees higher. During the bathing hour the tennis courts are deserted. Golfers who have reached in their pilgrimage the hole called "the ocean" leave their clubs with caddies for a while and take a dip.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- It is the general opinion that the Evansville and Terre Haute Railway will soon change bands. There is considerable speculation as to whether the road will fall into the hands of the St. Louis and San Francisco, which controls the Chicago and Eastern Illinois, or whether it will go to the Louisville and Nashville.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- There is a good prospect that action will be taken on the Panama Canal treaty in the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations.

THE educational work which the United States has set out to do in the Philippines is new to the world. No adequate attempt has ever been made to educate a Malay people. The noteworthy efforts of Siam, however significant as an attempt of an Oriental people at self-development, do not constitute an example, inasmuch as they aim at the maintenance of Malay political and social customs and the vernacular.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 21 -- The severe illness of the Grand Duke of Luxembourg, followso closely upon that of the hereditary Grand Duke, has made the Luxembourg question one of great present interest in official circles here. The perplexed problem of succession to the Grand Ducal throne may be opened at any moment, and its solution is naturally a matter of importance to Belgium.

Practically the only feature of the market yesterday was Delaware and Hudson. whose rise of nearly 4 points was on a continuation of the same kind of buying that has been in evidence for some days. There was absolutely no news to explain the advance except the talk that the forthcoming December statement of earnings will be a record breaker.

MONTREAL, Jan. 31 -- The Canadian Northern Railroad to-day bought the Great Northern Railway of Canada, thus acquiring an important link in the proposed transcontinental line which the Mackenzie and Mann interests are said to be contemplating.

The Tacoma (Washington) Evening News worthily takes great pride in a "Prosperity Edition" which it issued on Monday, Jan. 12. It comprised sixty-eight pages, with many illustrations, and was. The News claims, an unprecedented journalistic achievement in that city. Its half-tone views of Tacoma are especially attractive, and the issue contains a vast quantity of historical, commercial, descriptive, and financial matter concerning the thriving City of Tacoma and the rapidly growing State of Washington.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31 -- The Lenten season at the seashore has been anticipated this year in the instance of Atlantic City, at least, by several weeks. The crowds of the past week have exceeded those of any similar period in the history of the resort. Last Sunday all of the big board walk hotels held almost their midsummer quota of guests, and the bookings for to-morrow are as heavy.

Keith's patrons next week will see Charlie Grapewin in what probably will be his last vaudeville appearance, as he is to be starred in farce comedy next season. Papinta is held over for another week. Stephen Grattan and Maud White present their sketch, "Locked Out at 3 A.M." Tom Lewis and Sam Ryah are back in the varieties again after a long absence, offering their skit, "The Two Actors."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- J. Pierpont Morgan, as one of the guests of the Gridiron Club this evening, witnessed a burlesque on his business methods at the Arlington Hotel. Prominent men in the financial world mingled with army and navy chiefs, political leaders, and diplomats at the annual dinner of this organization of Washington newspaper correspondents.

Prologue. I, WHO write these words, am myself a Gevarre. Need I say more? I Am a Gevarre! Others are not Gevarres. Poor wretches! I cannot blame them; yet it is well to remember that they are not Gevarres. They have made their own beds, therefore, let them lie in them.

AH," observed Mr. Toddlemore, elaborately folding his paper so as to read more comfortably, "in view of my trip to Florida next week, here is a very timely article, a very timely article indeed. It's really surprising, my dear, how frequently I find helpful and useful hints in this paper. It really is."

Better laws for the security of the settler are essential to material improvement of conditions in Alaska, according to Col. W. J. Sutherland, who has returned from a year's sojurn in that Territory, as a mining engineer and operator, and is stopping at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

The importance of Signor Prinetti's illness at this time is not exaggerated in the TIMES special published yesterday morning. From a position of practical distrust when he entered the Zanardelli Cabinet two years ago, he has grown to be the strongest man in the Ministry, and his rearranging of the commercial treaties, especially that with Austria-Hungary, was looked forward to by intelligent Italians with considerable faith in Italy's ultimate advantage.

Clarence Moore, janitor of the private apartment house of 65 Central Park West. caught burglars in the act of rifling some trunks, which contained valuable clothing and silverware, early yesterday morning. Moore did not become frightened, nor did he run out and summon the police, but tip toed back to the hallway and summoned the superintendent of the building, Robert McAllister.

Interest at the joint games of Company K. Eighth Regiment, N.G.N.Y., and the Pastime Athletic Club, held at the Eighth Regiment Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue, last night, centred in the two relay races, one for interscholastic teams, and the other for club or college teams, both at a distance of one mile.

THE holidays were happily over; and the beneficiaries of Santa Claus had returned to school with the Jaded looks and poor complexions of those who have eaten "not wisely, but too well." With one accord they fell upon "teacher" and into her ready ear poured tales of acquisition and adventure.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Official sentiment is more hopeful of an adjustment of the Venezuelan questions, owing to the receipt of advices to the effect that the representatives of the allies have asked their respective Governments for further instructions.

The final weekly competition for the January Cup offered by the shooting committee of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn to the member making the best three scores in the weekly club shoots was decided yesterday afternoon at the club traps at Bay Ridge, and the trophy was won by L.C. Hopkins, whose best three scores were 50, 49, and 47, a total of 146 in a possible 150.

New York's method of carrying on public business and the bookkeeping system of the various city departments has been attacked frequently of late. The Merchants' Association declared that a rigid investigation was necessary and that the entire system should be revolutionized. Mayor Low became interested in this matter and appointed Worthington C. Ford, one of the leading statisticians employed by the government at Washington, to do the work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The purchase of the canal is in a fair way to be put through. We have tempted the Colombians, and -- under the subterfuge of a one-sided lease -- they are going to renounce their sovereignty over part of their dominion. Have we weighed the portents of this!
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Lieut. Gen. Miles, and Col. Marion P. Maus have arrived at the Hotel Continental.

SAY, I don't know when ter be sor.riest fer a gentleman customer -- when he comes with his wife, or when he braces in alone. When agent comes with his wife, he always carries a valise, and looks like he was being run in by a copper.
A PARTY of New England men were seated at a table in an up-town cafe, and the conversation turned upon the career of the late ex-Speaker Reed.
THE man who finds fault with everything except other men, said he was proud of his sex. The woman said she did not see why he should be.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Tact is the great need of the race." Mr. Bates has in your issue of to-day, put his finger upon one of the main causes of the absence of a thorough understanding between Englishmen and Americans. Of the two Englishmen (unless they live in official or diplomatic circles) are more deficient" than Americans in this admirable quality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The District Commissioners had a good deal of fun today over a suggestion that comes all the way from Kalispel, Montana, in regard to a new hotel for Washington. As an evidence of good faith the writer sent his photograph, and in order that his idea should not be lost entirely, he duplicated his communication to the President.
THIS last time Mr. Hill was in New York he was interviewed by a young lady who wanted what she called "a sketch."

If any one imagines that ballet on the Bowery is a neglected art, a peep into the places of amusement on that classic thoroughfare will bring about a change of opinion. "Queens of Burlesque" are as plentiful there as plain citizens on Broadway, and the members of the coprs de ballet could give a point or two in the matter of grace and skill to the dancers in more pretentious localities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A perusal of your editorial article yesterday containing the views of Bishop Burgess on the change of name of the Protestant Episcopal Church leads one to wish that Bishops would confine themselves in giving opinions about questions of theology, and would leave questions of law to the lawyers.

PRESIDENT LOUBET will visit Algeria about the middle of April, leaving Paris on Easter Eve. He will spend two days at Marseilles to witness some gymnastic fetes. The French President will not confine his stay to Algiers, but will make a tour inland, visiting Oran and Constantine, and he may even proceed along the coast as far as Tunis and Bizerta.

The first theatre in New York ever erected expressly and exclusively for foreign-speaking Jewish patronage of the better class will open its doors Thursday night. Other playhouses, such as the Thalia and the People's, not built for the Jews, have been leased, and, as everybody knows, one may hear in these houses plays in Yiddish any day in the week, but the house to be opened Thursday is brand new.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have before me a copy of Bill No. 128, introduced in the Assembly on Jan. 20 by Mr. Miller of the Twenty-first Assembly District, Brooklyn, read once, and referred to the Committee, on Affairs of Cities.

UTICA, Jan. 31 -- During the last few years the business part of the city has been steadily growing up about the Church of the Reconciliation, on Seneca Street, and now the Trustees have been asked to place a price upon the property.

Although, as is well known, Mohammedanism forbids the use of alcoholic liquor, according to advices from Constantinople the Turkish inhabitants there are not among the most temperate people in the world. Recent drinking in taverns at Para had seriously threatened the peace, followed, as it usually was, by stabbing affrays and downright murders.

PROFANITY," said a Chicago clergyman, "becomes such a habit that some men use profane language in absolute ignorance of the fact that they are doing so. I have known several men of this kind, and their virtues were such that I could not honestly blame them as I should when they were guilty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much has been said about different ways for improving the service of the elevated roads. Some of the suggestions have been good, and I think the one for a loop at South Ferry excellent. Please permit me to make one.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is strange that in a city like New York, where the drinking question is of such vital importance, steps taken to abate the evil do not meet with more encouragement. The laboring man goes to his work these cold mornings in many cases with only a cup of weak and pale tea and a piece of stale bread for his breakfast.

Fire originating from an overheated furnace in the basement of the four-story brownstone front dwelling at 225 West Forty-fifth Street at 4 o'clock yesterday morning burned upward through the stairway and cut off the means of escape of several men and women who occupied rooms on the upper floors.

Some interesting reforms are being meditated by Gen. Andre, the French Minister of War. The first is a bill which will make it possible for an officer dismissed from the army to re-enter it. The second consists of two decrees which concern military salutes and messes.

Wall Street was startled yesterday by the unusual scene of a fire in business hours, right among its fireproof "skyscrapers," when the United States Assay Office was discovered to be on fire about 12:30 o'clock. Thousands of clerks, officeboys, typewriter girls, and bankers, brokers, and lawyers crowded the approaches to that, part of Wall Street on which the Assay Office is situated, and filled every window of the many "skyscrapers" in sight of the fire.

Capt. John J. Lantry yesterday morning awoke to find himself by far the most talked-of man in the New York Police Department, owing to the original means he had taken the day before to prove that all a thief had to do in order to enter the homes of the rich in his precinct was to go to the house, open the door, walk in, and help himself to anything that might strike his fancy.

KENOSHA, Wis., Jan. 31 -- John Alexander Dowie, general overseer of the Christian Catholic Church in Zion, to-day announced to 7,000 followers that all plans for the invasion of New York City had been completed, and that within a few weeks excursion trains will carry to the Eastern metropolis 3,000 workers, who will make an effort to establish the creed of the overseen in that city.

The Police Commissioner does not approve of Capt. LANTRY'S mode of teaching the house occupants of his precinct how very careless they are in keeping proper guard of their houses, and how easy it would be for sneak thieves to rob them.

Oil no account will the United States join France, Spain, Sweden and Norway, Denmark, Belgium, and Holland in a counter-demonstration against the allies who are now at war with Venezuela. These European countries, like ourselves, are creditors of Venezuela. France is really in the position of a judgment cred- itor, her claims having been allowed and in part paid.

THE most important club event of tin week was the annual meeting of the Meadow Brook Club, which tool place on Tuesday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astorla. It was more or less a ratification meeting. The ticket had been in the field quite a long time and there was no opposition.

The Police Commissioner does not approve of Capt. LANTRY'S mode of teaching the house occupants of his precinct how very careless they are in keeping proper guard of their houses, and how easy it would be for sneak thieves to rob them.

Oil no account will the United States join France, Spain, Sweden and Norway, Denmark, Belgium, and Holland in a counter-demonstration against the allies who are now at war with Venezuela. These European countries, like ourselves, are creditors of Venezuela. France is really in the position of a judgment cred- itor, her claims having been allowed and in part paid.

To the Editor of The New Yort Times: From Richmond Hill to the Brooklyn Bridge via Myrtle Avenue trolley or elevated railroad it is practically a straight line. By improving the service the time would be about twenty minutes quicker than by any other route, and would relieve the congestion on Jamaica Avenue and East New York loop.
Recent compilations of railroad statistics, official and otherwise, have shown that railroad capitalization per mile for the late year ran to the highest average recorded.

The meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday afternoon was the occasion of a spirited and personal debate, it having been reported that no such thing as a gold medal bearing the union label could be secured in this city. The communication was from the Jewelrymakers' Union, and was to the effect that a medal presented recently to Delegate James Barry of the Actors' Union was minus the official label.

Wall Street will enter upon the business of this week with general conditions much more favorable than the pessimism of a month ago would admit to be possible. The monetary situation is so easy that rates for loans are no longer burdensome. The return of currency from the interior has been on a much larger scale than was expected even by the Treasury experts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- It is expected that the Fowler Currency bill will come up for consideration in the House Wednesday. It has been the subject of considerable speculation since it was first laid before the committee, and its fate is problematical. It will have general support from Republicans.

When Capt. GANNON heard from the lips of the foreman of the jury that had heard the evidence in his trial the verdict of "guilty," he fairly collapsed with amazement. He had not paid much attention to the finding and sentence of Deputy Commissioner PIPER, apparently regarding that as one of the misfortunes to which changes in politics exposed the officers of the force.

HIGHLAND LIGHT, Mass., Feb. 1. -- The life-savers of the Pamet River station, just above Highland Light, would very much like to know the whereabouts of the crew of the schooner Lyman M. Law of New Haven, Philadelphia for Boston, and their reasons for hurriedly leaving the vessel, which the life-savers found to-day anchored four miles off the station, in apparently good condition.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 1. -- The Rev. Robert Street, an aged retired minister, was burned to death this morning at 3:40 in his room, at 129 Chestnut Street, Roselle Park. In an attempt to save him his daughter was terribly burned about the neck, face, and shoulders. She was taken, unconscious, to the home of Mrs. Benjamin Carpenter, opposite, where she now lies in a precarious condition.

TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 1. -- This year has opened up with an unprecedented demand for fir lumber and cedar shingles. Orders now booked will keep more than 500 lumber and shingle mills in Western Washington busy for months to come. The present brisk demand insures that the output this year will greatly exceed last year's record, the cut amounting to 2,000,000,000 feet of lumber and over 8,000,000,000 shingles.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29. -- In measurement by percentages it is the country that trades chiefly with St. Louis and through St. Louis that has made rapidest and largest commercial progress in the past wonder working decade. Here is the Southwest's gateway. In population, in tangible wealth, in volume of trade, in railway traffic and in manufacturing, its expansion is phenomenal.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a very important study that should more engage our schools, and colleges. It might be entitled "The Rise and Fall of Nations and the Causes Thereof."

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- The upward movement on the Stock Exchange grained in strength and volume last week, almost all the departments scoring rises. The principal causes for the rising tendency were the abundance of money, the large Government loan operations to be carried through in the near future, and in a lesser degree the improved tone of the iron market, which last week made further progress.
BOSTON, Feb. 1. -- On Feb. 14 the Boston Athletic Association will hold its fourteenth annual open handicap meeting in Mechanics' Building. The programme will be as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Propositions involving a compromise of the allied powers' contention for preferential treatment in the settlement of their claims against Venezuela have been submitted to the Governments of Great Britain, Germany, and Italy by their representatives at Washington, and while no answers have been received at yet.

At a People's Institute meeting in Cooper Union last night Charles Sprague Smith told his audience that the name of Abram S. Hewitt should be sacred in Cooper Union. He said he had received several letters during the week accusing him of infringing on the right of free speech.

Miss Clara Barton has written a letter to President Roosevelt, in which she takes pains to explain that she believes him to be misinformed in regard to the American Red Cross, of which she is the President.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, in making his announcements for the week at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday morning, referred to affairs in the South in a way which caused a Southerner in the congregation to protest when he had a chance to speak to the doctor after the close of the service.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 1. -- Joseph Burtis Husted, a native of this town, has brought suit in Kings County. New York, against the estate of Theodosis F. Secor for all over $18,000, which William Rockefeller paid Mr. Secor when he purchased the Husted homestead for his son William several years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A pension of $30 a month was recently granted to the widow of Admiral W.T. Sampson. That was done under the general law governing in such cases. It is the same rate of bounty allowed, according to rank, for the widows of other military officers who lose their lives from causes arising out of the performance of duty in the service of the country.

Over 90 per cent of the members of the Star Athletic Club visited the clubhouse, at Fourteenth Street and Vernon Avenue, Long Island City, yesterday, and there was nothing but praise showered upon the four athletes -- P.J. Lee, P. Waters, L.J. Rottger, and J.G. Hoben -- who made up the club's victorious team in the relay race at the Eighth Regiment Armory games the previous night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Too much credit cannot be given by the public to President Lederle of the New York Board of Health for his energetic endeavor to expose the dangerous methods of many retail druggists. Selling and passing off in compounded medicine vile and dangerous substitutes in place of the genuine article, for the sake of the extra profit gained thereby, is only one of the wrongs they frequently commit.

Messrs, Yamanaka Co. of Osaka, Japan, have placed in the Fifth Avenue Galleries, 366 Fifth Avenue, a collection of antique earvings in wood and metal, mostly Buddhistic in origin, made by a Mr. Hirase, which will be sold on the afternoons of Thursday, Friday, and Saturday next.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The Commissioner General of Immigration yesterday gave a hearing to a delegation of women who talked about the five female Inspectors who are to be appointed for duty at New York. They were opposed to the selection of women who are merely experienced in hospital nursing or in Red Cross service in Cuba and the Philippines. They wanted higher qualifications.

The question whether or not only graduates of the public schools should be admitted to the Hebrew Technical Institute was discussed at the nineteenth annual meeting of the officers and patrons of the school at 36 Stuyvesant Street yesterday morning.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 1. -- Fourteen companies of militia arrived here this evening, and, together with two local companies, are under arms, prepared to prevent any further riotous outbreak by trolley strikers and their sympathizers. The troops belong to the First and Second Regiments and are under command of Brig. Gen. Russell Frost of South Norwalk.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 1 -- Both Argentina and Chile, through their respective Ministers in Washington, have proposed to the United States the purchase by this Government of the armored cruisers and battleships the two South American countries have under construction in Europe.

A committee, of which President ELIOT of Harvard is Chairman and ex-Gov. CRANE of Massachusetts, President TUCKER of Dartmouth, and Mr. RICHARD WATSON GILDER are members, has undertaken to use -- if they can get it -- the somewhat startling sum of $425,000 in creating a memorial of the late ALICE FREEMAN PALMER, the first President of Wellesley College.
AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 1. -- The Mexican Government has issued official notice that it has never authorized the change of the name of the Port of Topolobampo to Port Stilwell. The notice reads:

Revolver and carbine shooting are now attracting the attention of the Squadron A troopers, and two or three interesting competitions for Special prizes are to be shot before the opening of the Spring season. The first cup competition of the season was shot on Saturday night. It was a revolver match, thirty yards distance, standard targets being used and the revolvers of 45 calibre.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 1. -- Walter Ramsey, a middle-aged widower, who lived with his mother on Fifth Street, Harrison, was killed in the apartments of Mrs. George McDowell, at 414 Fourth Street, Harrison, early this morning. The murder was done by Mrs. Mc.Dowell's husband, from whom it is said she had separated.

With the announcement of the weights allotted by W.S. Vosburgh to the horses entered in the Suburban and Brooklyn' handicaps, comes the information that the Brooklyn Jockey Club, following the ruling of the Coney Island Jockey Club, has refused the entry of the horse Gold Heels, and that animal is now barred from the two great handicaps of the season.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1. -- Several interesting foursomes have been played on the links here during the week. In a match in which A. Sidney Carpenter of the Philadelphia Country Club and Davison Lloyd of Pittsburg played against Harry Suydam of Lakewood and R.H. McElwee of Exmoor, Chicago, who won the championship of South Florida last year, the latter team won by a score of 4 up and 2 to play.

Prior to the first production of "The Wizard of Oz," the idea was conveyed that the piece would in a measure be in line with the old-time sort of pantomime which children of an older generation will recall with mingled feelings of satisfaction and regret -- satisfaction that they were youthful at a time when this form of entertainment still prevailed, regret that the term as used nowadays is altogether a misnomer.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- New York State's area of 50,200 square miles has a population of 150 per square mile. In the divisions of the State Department of Health the maritime district has the greatest population, 1,728 to the square mile: the Lake Ontario and western the second greatest, 200, and the Adirondack and northern the least, 26 to the square mile.

The traveler from Acambaro to Morelia, the capital of the State of Michoacan, may admire the strange ranks of the organ cactus, whose green, fluted columns form the palings of fences on a superb scale. He may have welcomed the artificial lakes for irrigation, dotted with wild duck, and cast an appreciative glance toward the hills that pass from green to stony grays and purples, as they rise one behind the other.

Police Commissioner Greene made a third automobile tour in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, going to station houses be had not visited on his two previous trips and completing his inspection of the precincts of the borough.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 1. -- There were four more funerals to-day of those who lost their lives in the accident on the Central Railroad of New Jersey on Tuesday night. The largest was that of Elias Glles, which was held at Trinity Reformed Church at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon, the Rev. Cornelius Schenck officiating.

Tax Commissioner STRASBOURGER had an interesting and instructive interview with two taxpayers on Friday of last week. The taxpayers were Mr. J. PIERPONT MORGAN and Mr. JACOB SCHIFF. They had called at the tax office to see about their personal tax assessments. Last year Mr. MORGAN paid taxes on a personal assessment of $400,000; this year he is assessed at $600,000.

"Jasper" is the name of the fattest and crankiest snapping turtle in the Aquarium. A turtle in captivity grows very tame, and does not often draw his head and legs into his shell. Jasper's neck has become so stout, and his legs have grown so fat, that he couldn't get himself back into his shell if he tried to.

For the second time in nearly half a century the front door of the old Olive Tree Tavern, at the southwest corner of Thirtysecond Street and Third Avenue, bore a bit of cardboard Saturday night, upon which was written:

The Austrian imperial archives have been lately conveyed from the Hofburg to the great house built for them adjoining the Foreign Office. They will later on be opened for public inspection, from the most ancient documents down to those of 1830. The rooms containing the secret archives are of ironwork, each story being completely separated from the next one, so that neither fire nor water can penetrate.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 1. -- The Government has been investigating how bubonic plague came to be introduced into Mazatlan, and it appears probable that it came by the steamer Curazao, proceeding from San Francisco.

Considering the proverbial tenacity or the typical Englishman in the defense of what he considers his rights. Parliamentary legislation is often surprisingly radical. An illustration of this is found in the law which went into effect on Jan. 1, popularly known as the Jane Cakebread act, which, as curtailing the rights of publicans and frequenters of public houses, is little less than revolutionary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- To-morrow the sub-committee of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, which was appointed to prepare the report on the submarine boat bribery case, will hold its session. Intimations that the sub-committee's delay is "mysterious" or "suspicious" are not well founded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The latest expectation in the Statehood fight is that the Republican leaders will inject into the consideration of the bill the charge that the struggle for the admission of the three proposed States is wholly a political one and that Senator Quay occupies the position of having made a coalition with the Democrats against the majority of his own party.

BOSTON, Feb. 1. -- President Eliot of Harvard spoke to a crowd of newsboys in Wesleyan Hall this evening, and entertained then for a half hour with advice which, judging from the applause which they gave him, the boys liked. Following are some of his sayings:

The annual report of the Department of Trade and Commerce of the Dominion of Canada contains some statistics of the foreign trade of that country which are surprising, and show that our northern neighbors will bear watching. The aggregate foreign trade of 1902 exceeded that of 1901 by a little over $37,000,000.

Edward Reinhardt, twenty-one years of age, of 840 East One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street, who said he was an operator in the Melrose Exchange of the New York Telephone Company, saved a woman and a child from what seemed almost certain death while riding on a southward-bound Third Avenue car last evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The Thomas Jefferson Memorial Association, organized for the purpose of erecting at the National capital a memorial of the "author of the Declaration of Independence." through its President, Admiral George Dewey, has issued an appeal to the American people for funds to carry out the object of the association.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 1. -- At yesterday's Cabinet meeting it was decided to summon Parliament to meet on March 12. The session promises to be a long and busy one. Inthe first place there will be a lengthy and important bill of fare presented by the Government, and in addition to this there will be a large number of public and private bills.

To those familiar with the collection and with the tastes and preferences of its highly trained author, it is not surprising that the rugs and tapestries of Mr. MARQUAND made Saturday the most successful and exciting day of the sale. The actual receipts for this portion of the collection were $234,564, or more than one-third of the total of $706,019.

It is stated in Washington dispatches that the allies are by no means likely to accept Mr. BOWEN'S compromise offer of one month's preferable treatment in the collection of their claims against Venezuela, for the reason that even if the full 30 per cent, of the revenues of the republic were set apart for them, it would take six or seven years to liquidate their claims.

Without a dissenting vote the congregation of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church at a meeting yesterday authorized the transfer or the present church property to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, whose building at Madison Avenue and Twenty-third Street it adjoins, and to take in exchange a plot of the same size at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street, across the way from the present structure, and $325,000 in cash.

In the stock market yesterday there was a marked improvement in sentiment, accompanied with some increase of activity and a considerable accession of strength. The speculation was still of a professional character, and the com- mission house business was light, but a much more hopeful feeling prevailed.

There was a decided falling off in the volume of trading in the outside market yesterday, but notwithstanding this a firm undertone prevailed and a number of issues made fractional gains and a few stocks substantial ones. Havana Tobacco common advanced 1 1/2 points and -- appeared to be in good demand, selling from 52 up to 53.

WASHINGTON, Feb 2. -- Gen. Grosvenor issued a statement to-night in regard to "The Book of the Presidents," in which he emphatically denies that he had any connection with the sale of the work, and pronounces the Elliott Norton letter, to which his name is attached, a forgery. Gen. Grosvenor thus describes his relations with the publication:

Cardinal GIBBONS'S denunciation of the increasing laxity of the marriage tie and of the increasing facility of divorce contains nothing new in doctrine, but of course it derives importance from the eminent and representative position of the preacher, as well as from his personal character.

Sightseers gathered yesterday on the west side of Park Avenue between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets in the expectation that they might see the residences opposite crumble into the subway. It was bleak and cold, but many stood until late into the afternoon watching the workingmen shoring up the houses.

The Governor of Connecticut seems to be an executive who has a realizing sense of his responsibilities. It being necessary to establish and maintain order in Waterbury and permit the operation of the public utilities of that town against the wishes and in spite of the violence of mobs representing the lawless partisans of organized labor, the Governor promptly called out the State troops, and under their protection the railroad company is operating its cars.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Because of inability of Eastern roads to handle an the traffic offered to them. Western roads have issued blockade notices that affect several of the necessaries of life. Among the latter is flour, which the Northwestern roads will not receive for delivery to Eastern roads until further notice.
BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- The money market continues quiet, with rates practically unchanged. The usual table of local rates, , follows:

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra were to have gone on a visit to the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, at Chatsworth, this afternoon, but their departure was postponed at the last minute for the reason that the King was suffering from a feverish cold. His Majesty was planting trees at noon some distance from Windsor Castle and appeared then to be in excellent health and spirits.

In the industrial group the feature of the market was Amalgamated Copper, which, having reacted on profit taking in the latter part of last week, resumed the upward movement begun earlier in that week and, despite more or less professional pressure, closed the day at the highest price, for a net advance of over 2 points.

A new service schedule for the Manhattan Railway Company went into effect yesterday. An official of the system was "positive" that the schedule was that adopted by the State Railroad commissioners Jan. 30, which affects the Second, Sixth, and Ninth Avenue lines, the full Third Avenue schedule not going into effect until next Monday, because of the non-completion of the Bronx Park station.

Mrs. Libby Byrnes of 160 West Fifty-third Street was called to her front door Nov, 24 last by a young man, Who said he had a message for her, but who snatched a sunburst from her throat and escaped. Mrs. Byrnes says it was worth $5,000. A young man called last night to negotiate for the return of the jewel.

We wonder if President ROOSEVELT is aware of the present whereabouts of his recommendation for a Tariff Commission to take the question of import duties out of politics and guide Congress in the scientific treatment of the matter.

Holders of the stock of the Woman's Hotel Company received notice yesterday that the Hotel Martha Washington, at 129 East Twenty-ninth Street, a hostelry built by that company for use by women, is to be ready for inspection to-day. The capital of the company, which was incorporated in this State in March, 1900, is $400,000, divided into 4,000 shares of $100 each.

ITHACA, Feb. 2. -- At a meeting of the Cornell Electric Society to-night, Prof. Frederick Bedell of the Physics Department of Cornell University announced a new discovery in electric power transmission whereby an alternating and a direct current may be sent at the same time.

The Elizabethan audience at Mrs. Osborn's Playhouse last night was rather dull. There were twenty-two of them. On either side in a box alone was an imitation fine lady with a profile, one dark, one fair. On the stage below each of these boxes lounged stiffly three painted gallants in silks and tights.

Cycle track owners and cycling race meet promoters will gather at the fifth annual meeting of the National Cycling Association, which will be held at the Astor House to-day, beginning at 10:30 A.M. The principal business which will come before the meeting will be in connection with the proposed National paced circuit which a number of the track owners are endeavoring to organize.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- A resolution intended to prevent the introduction of the bubonic plague from the Pacific Coast States into this State was unanimously adopted by the Assembly to-night. It was presented by Assemblyman Ellis and read as follows:

At the monthly meeting of the Trustees of Columbia University yesterday afternoon in the library of the university donations to the amount of $120,250, received from the Due de Loubat, the Temple Emanu-El, and others, were announced. Corporation Counsel Rives was elected Chairman of the board, to succeed the late William Colford Schermerhorn, and the degree of Doctor of Laws, honoris causa, was conferred upon President Andrew Sloan Draper of the University of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- President Roosevelt, accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt, Senator and Mrs. Lodge, and Justice and Mrs. Holmes, occupied one of the boxes at the National Theatre to-night when Miss Ethel Barrymore appeared in "A Country Mouse."

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Feb. 2. -- It was announced at Gall Lake to-day that ice yacht races for the Stuart International Trophy Cup have been declared off until next Winter, owing to the unsafe condition of the ice. The frozen surface is covered with two inches of water, and while the smaller boats were able to manoeuvre satisfactorily the conditions precluded the larger yachts being raced.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- With the exception of Reading, Lehigh Valley, and United Gas, the local issues to-day were without activity. Most of them displayed a sagging tendency, but such declines as were suffered Were not important, the only exceptions being a point loss in United Gas, Consolidated Lake Superior preferred.

Henry A. Rogers was elected President of the Board of Education yesterday after-noon. The new President of the board, chosen to succeed Charles C. Burlingham, was born in this city fifty-eight years ago, and is a dealer in machinery and railway supplies at 19 John Street. For twelve years he has been one of the most active members of the board, and before that time he was a Trustee under the old system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A hard blow to the Addicks, or Union, Republicans of Delaware was dealt by the Judiciary Committee of the Senate to-day. By a decisive vote the committee recommended the rejection by the Senate of the nomination of William M. Byrne as United States District Attorney for the State.

There were no large dances yesterday, Mrs. Loring gave a reception in the Hotel Savoy, and Mrs. Frederick J. De Peyster gave a dinner. Miss Mary Constance Greer the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Greer, and Thomas S. McLane are to be married in St. Bartholomew's Church this after-noon.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 2. -- The consolidation of the Savings and Trust Company and the Citizens' Savings and Loan Association of this city was formally ratified today at a joint meeting of the stockholders of the two concerns. The total deposits of the combined banks are about $21,000,000 exclusive of trust funds.

Here is a list of birth stones as they are ready-mounted in charms. It differs from some, but it has been prepared by an expert, and the charms are to be seen in one of the best jewelry stores in the city. For January, garnet; February, amethyst; March, Jasper; April, sapphire; May, chalcedony; June, emerald; July, onyx; August, carnelian: September, chrysolite; October, aquamarine; November, topaz; December, ruby.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Senator Quay has announced that his programme for the passage of the Statehood bill not only contemplates the use of the rider on the Agricultural Appropriation bill, but that he has in mind opportunities for effective operations in other directions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Jan. 31, 1903, the total debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $943,942,563, which is a decrease for the month of $3,222,116.
The London Times very sensibly suggests that the situation of China is quite different from that of Mexico with reference to any plan for maintaining stable relations between silver and gold moneys.
