Ex-Capt. James Gannon appeared in the Court of General Sessions yesterday to receive sentence on the charge of neglect of duty, and Recorder Goff let the convicted police official off with a fine of $250.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2. -- The local market failed to develop any feature to-day. Tradins was quiet and steady, no one issue attaining prominence either by activity or price movement. Money on call was 4 1/2@5 per cent. Complete transactions for the day, amounting to 299 shares of stock and $54,000 worth of bonds, were as follows:
CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- The open Board of Trade and several railroad companies will help the famine victims in Sweden and Finland.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 2. -- After remaining quiet all day, in face of the fact that armed militia rode on every trolley car that was run, the lawless element broke out in a demonstration to-night, under cover of a dense fog.

J. Byron Stark of Wilkesbarre, Penn., and the former Class B billiard champion of the Amateur Athletic Union beat Charles F. Conklin of Chicago, a well-known player in former Amateur Athletic Union tournaments, last night at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, in the first match of the annual amateur championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiards Players.

-- "Better ignorance on ten points, other things being equal, than false information on one," says The New York Medical Journal in the course of a long discussion of the vexed question whether doctors should announce their discoveries and express their opinions on professional topics through the regular newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Ambassador from Austria-Hungary and Mme. Hengelmuller have gone to Philadelphia for a three days visit, where they will be the guests of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Reilly, who entertained at dinner in their honor this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- Young Corbett," the champion featherweight pugilist, and "Billy" Maynard of New York sparred six rounds at the "Washington Sporting Club to-night, Corbett was very fat and appeared to be out of condition. In the first round he succeeded in flooring Maynard, which was his best effort during the bout.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I hope that your widely circulated paper will continue the crusade so happily begun in the editorial on personal taxes which is published in to-day's issue?

Four business men, one a member of the New York Produce Exchange, were arrested in their offices on Lower Broadway late yesterday afternoon and taken to Police Headquarters, where they were locked up. It is alleged by the police that the prisoners were connected with a "wheat syndicate" -- a concern that promised in advertisements to pay astonishingly big profits on money invested in wheat through them.
Capt. William M. Williams, upon his own application, is detailed as Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the College of the Immaculate Conception at New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- In the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill which was reported to the House to-day provision is made for the expenditure of $385,500 for improvements at the Ellis Island Immigrant Station. For extension and additions to the present hospital $100,000 is provided, for construction or purchase of a twin screw ferryboat $110,000; sundries, $20,000, and construction of a new island, $150,500.

The conditions which produced the anthracite famine and ran retail prices to figures so unequal, and in many cases so nearly prohibitive, are so far relieved that unless something unforeseen happens the market is expected to return to a normal condition by easy stages from now until the end of the Winter.
LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Money was more plentiful in the market to-day, and rates were easier. About $20,000,000 was released by the payment of interest and dividends. Discounts were also easier.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- Henry Erben of 2039 Delancy Place will be married to Miss Susan Cummins of Smyrna, Del., Wednesday, Feb. 11. Henry Erben, Jr., will act as best man. The ceremony will take place in New York in Christ Church Chantry at noon. A small breakfast will be given in the apartments of Mrs. Cummins's sister, Mrs. Henry C. Lea, the Blenheim, 62 West Fifty-eighth Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 2. -- Stephen J. Meeker, proprietor of the iron foundry of D.M. Meeker Son, at 95 Clay Street, and President of the Smillie Coupler and Manufacturing Company, at 91 Clay Streets, filed to-day two deeds of assignment for the benefit of his creditors, naming Henry A. Potter of Bast Orange as the assignee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Much of the time of the Senate to-day was spent in consideration of the Army Appropriation bill and continued debate on the Statehood-bill and the death of Father Augustin in the Philippines.

Three transatlantic ships got in yesterday, after very rough passages. The vessels were the American liner St. Paul, the Atlantic Transport liner Minnehaha, and the oil tank steamship New York. All three, especially the oil carrier, reported having, encountered the roughest kind of weather.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Gov. Odell received to-day a letter from Charles S. Hayes, a lawyer, of New York City, announcing his willingness to prefer charges against District Attorney Jerome of New York County for failure to prosecute persons charged with violating the State liquor tax law at the Morris Park race track.
John P. Kirwan has sold for the estate of George Wiley the southwest corner of Eleventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, old buildings on plot 98.9 by 125.
BENNINGTON, Vt., Feb. 2. -- The election to-morrow will settle the question whether this State will change its liquor traffic law and adopt local option.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The establishment beyond doubt of the fact that Admiral Sampson was suffering from the disease which finally killed him a full year before he was assigned to the command of a squadron in the war with Spain has made clear many things which before were only hinted at.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Members of the Legislature who came from New York City to Albany on the afternoon trains to-day were an angry lot of men. The cause of their indignation was the opinion given by Attorney General Cunneen that members of the Legislature violate the State Constitution when they accept passes from the Pullman Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Weather Bureau's monthly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

In a very lengthy game of the amateur handicap 14.2 billiard championship series, at the Knickerbocker Billiard Academy, Brooklyn, last night, J. Keane, playing 165, defeated J. Dalton, whose handicap is 120. The final scores were: Keane, 165; Dalton, 109. Keane's best effort was a run of 28, and Dalton's highest run netted 15.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 3 -- There was a lively riot in the Elizabethport section to-night among strikers and their sympathizers from the Townsend Downey shipyards on Shooter's Island. The police had difficulty in clearing the streets, and several persons were hurt. There is much uneasiness as to what will happen tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A majority of the Committee on Naval Affairs of the House to-day agreed upon a report on the Lessler bribery charges in relation to the Holland submarine boats. The following are the findings:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A new factor has entered the fight for the confirmation of Dr. Crum as Collector at Charleston. It is the Afro-American Council, the leading negro organization of the country, which is taking a hand in about every fight that comes up over the race question now.

It seems quite clear that Mr. EUGENE HEITLER LEHMAN of Colorado, at present a private tutor in this city, but named by the Governor of Colorado as one of the beneficiaries from that State of the Cecil Rhodes scholarships a Oxford, is a very brilliant scholar. Of course he must have and must have proved other than merely scholastic qualifications to the satisfaction of the Governor of Colorado, and of his "Minister of Education."

-- There have been occasional lamentations over the waning everywhere of the personal element in modern journalism, and its almost complete disappearance in some parts of the country, but according to The Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle it is precisely because this change has not gone far enough in South Carolina that the Tillman-Gonzales feud took the form it did and ended as it did.

Action was taken at the annual meeting of the National Cycling Association, held at the Astor House yesterday, which will result in the establishment of a National circuit for motor-paced cycle racing during the coming season, and consequently in the official determination of a National championship in that class of cycle racing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- It is believed here that the firm attitude Mr. Bowen took in his reply to the allies was the result of a complete understanding between himself and Mr. Hay for the purpose of withstanding any move on the part of the allies which would have the tendency to break down the prestige of the United States with the South American republics and the world at large.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- The local market showed a broadening tendency today, and there was a marked increase in the number of stocks designated as "active." United States Steel led in total transactions, with Philadelphia Electric a good second. Over 7,000 shares of the latter changed hands, nearly all of them at 8, but offerings at that figure were made at the close.

The total of sales of stocks yesterday, exceeding 500,000 shares, indicated a fair degree of activity. The bond transactions were also larger, amounting to more than $5,000,000. But the market for stocks was entirely professional and in the main inconsequential, while that for bonds was made up chiefly of two issues that are for the moment the object of some speculative interest, namely.

Manhattan Bridge, the altered plans of which were shown for the first time yesterday, will be a structure of architectural beauty as well as one of great usefulness. In many particulars conventional lines in bridge building have been departed from, and although they are not entirely new to bridge builders in detail, they will be novel in their entirety.

The advance in the Wabash shares, and especially in the Wabash debentures, was on purchases following the announcement of the favorable vote in the Pittsburg Council allowing Wabash an entrance into that city. Singularly enough, it was said that the movement was almost wholly a speculative one and that it had not met with encouragement from inside sources.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3 -- If You Dare and Brush By were the only winning favorites to-day. The Stewards have forbidden Jockey Buchanan to accept mounts outside of the stable of his employer, Sam Hildreth.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin to-day received a cablegram from Gen. Davis, dated Manila, Feb. 2, as follows:

Would it not be a sensible thing for President ROOSEVELT to make a public statement of the ideas by which he is guided in his Delaware appointments and of the facts connected with the application of those ideas?

The McVickar Realty Trust Company has sold for Thomas B. Hidden the plot, 75 by 100.11, on the south side of One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, 194 feet east of Riverside Drive. The buyer, who was represented in the deal by Hall J. How Co., is Nelson D. Stilwell. The property will probably be improved in the near future.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Prominent advocates of improvement of the State canals appeared this afternoon before the joint Canal Committee of both houses, which gave a hearing on the Bostwick-Davis bill, providing for the submission to the people at the next general election of a project to issue not exceeding $82,000,000 worth of bonds for the enlargement of the Erie, Oswego, and Champlain Canals into a twelve-foot canal available for thousand-ton barges.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Cabinet to-day decided on the award of bids recently received for the armored cruisers Tennessee and Washington. Secretary Moody made public the following statement:

The late David C. Lyall of Brooklyn Borough was always generous with his pictures, so that many canvases, pastels, and water colors in his collection, which is shown to-day at the American Art Galleries, are familiar to those who frequent loan exhibitions. It is some years since he died, but the impression made by certain pictures he owned is likely to abide in memory.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Assembly to-day had its revenge on Major Francis G. Landon, who represents the Second District of Dutchess County, for his action in obtaining a decision from Attorney General Cunneen that members of the Legislature have no right to use Pullman passes.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Late to-night Baron Knollys informed inquirers at Windsor Castle that King Edward's progress was quite satisfactory. An indication that no anxiety is felt regarding the King's condition may be found in the complete absence of a shoal of inquiries from foreign Courts, which was the usual experience on the occasion of his Majesty's previous illnesses.

The Inspectors of Police, and, if the Inspectors do their duty, the Captains, are now in the way of doing their duty under an entirely new conception of what that duty is. Commissioner GREENE took occasion at the beginning of his second month of office to explain to the Inspectors briefly but with unmistakable clearness what he should expect of them and what they might expect of him.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against the Bailey Restaurant Company, which had six restaurants, at 5 Hanover Street, 194, 469, 542, and 1,233 Broadway, and 108 West Thirty-fourth Street, by Austin, Nichols Co., creditors for $1,350 for groceries sold to the company.

Charles Lanier, 17 Nassau Street, the General Treasurer of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following additional contributions to the collection for the Associated Hospitals, now in progress:
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- New York exchange was quoted to-day at 10 @ 15 c premium. Time and call loans, 5 @ 5 per cent.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The rates for money were firm to-day, repayments to the Bank of England restricting supplies. Discounts were weak owing to Continental competition.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 4 -- At mid-night the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company as usual closed its trolley day and the withdrawal of the cars brought to the strike-afflicted city relief from the tension of an exciting day.

One of the most largely attended weddings of the season took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church, when Miss Mary Constance Greer, younger daughter of the rector of that church, the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, became the bride of Thomas S. McLane, a son of Dr. James W. McLane.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 3. -- It seems probable that George H. Wilson of this city will succeed Maurice Grau in the management of grand opera next year. Mr. Wilson returned from New York this morning, where he had several conferences with the directors of the Metropolitan Opera House. He said there are a number of other candidates for the position, one of whom is John S. Duss, the well known Pittsburg bandmaster.

William Hooper Young, grandson of Brigham Young, will go on trial this morning before Justice D. Cady Herrick, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, on the chargs of having murdered Mrs. Anna Nilsen Pulitzer last November. The trial may not proceed, however, for W.F.S. Hart, Young's counsel, will ask for delay on a number of grounds, one of them being that his client is physically unable to withstand the strain of the trial.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The "right" of the New York City police to enter anywhere without a warrant on the ground that they are "inspecting" or "supervising" is attacked by a bill introduced to-day by Assemblyman Metcalfe, amending the charter relating to the duties in general of the police force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- No conclusion was reached by the conferrees on the Department of Commerce bill in a long session to-day, and another meeting was called for to-morrow. The proposed trust amendment which the Senate committee desires to place on the section in regard to the new Bureau of Corporations was discussed, and from what was said the prospect seems good for favorable action thereupon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter published in THE TIMES of Saturday and addressed to "Nigger Hayes" by some alleged members of the Coliseum Club of New Orleans, La., is evidently not an official document. It is manifestly the work of some blackguard who used the name of this club because of its well-known character and standing as one of the first clubs in the City of New Orleans.

Interest in local golf was well shown last night, when over sixty delegates from different clubs in the Metropolitan Golf Association met at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, for the annual meeting of that organization. Nearly thirty of the forty-nine clubs in the association were represented.

Repeated burglaries recently on Staten Island have so alarmed the residents there that a mutual protective association has developed, with pistols, dogs, and telephones all figuring in the scheme of house-holders to guard their lives and property. There is an understanding that a telephone call is to be answered instantly, for none knows, whether it may be an appeal for help against burglars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Italian Ambassador and Mme, Mayor des Planches entertained this evening at a small dance at the embassy. The company was limited to unmarried persons, although Mine, des Planches was assisted in welcoming her guests by Mme, de Margerie and the Baroness Moncheur.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Revenue measures initiated by Controller Grout had hearings before Senate and Assembly committees to-day. Mr. Grout was here and led a body of representative New Yorkers who were present to urge the legislation. He made arguments on his measures to permit the use by New York City of the surplus of the sinking fund and to advance the time for the collection of taxes from October to January.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 -- The money market is firm. Rates are about where they were two weeks ago. The bank statement of Monday showed that the Boston banks had lost considerable money, but there is still an ample supply as the demand is not large.

A board of officers is appointed to meet at Fort Crook for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it to determine their fitness for promotion. Detail -- Col. James Miller, Twenty-second Infantry; Major William H. Corbusier, Surgeon; Majors John J. Crittenden and Abner Pickering, Twenty-second Infantry; Contract Surgeon, James K. Ashburn; First Lieut. Lawrence A. Curtis, Twenty-second Infantry, Recorder.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- When the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission resumed its session to-day, Daniel T. MeKelvy, a Justice of the Peace of Hazleton, who was a witness yesterday, was recalled for crosseximantion. Counsel attempted to show that the witness had neglected his duty as an officer of the law because of his partiality toward the strikers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Panama Canal treaty has been reported to the Senate by the Committee on Foreign Relations. This was accomplished with the affirmative votes of all the members except Messrs. Bacon and Morgan. The former is favorable to ratification, but voted with Mr. Morgan for the reason that the Alabama Senator was forced to suspend his opposition until the treaty shall be taken up in the executive session of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Disturbed conditions in Honduras, growing out of the recent Presidential elections in that country, have caused certain American commercial interests to appeal to the Government here for protection. Bonilla, who was elected to the Presidency, has taken refuge on Amapala Island, where he is organizing a force to displace President Sierra, the present incumbent, who refuses to surrender the reins of power.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Governor Odell did not send to the Senate to-day a nomination to succeed Frank M. Baker as Railroad Commissioner as was expected. It is learned on good authority that this nomination may be held over for some time. The representatives of organized labor are demanding that a practical railroad employe shall be selected to fill Mr. Baker's place.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Secrets of the committee room at the last Republican State Convention, which came out this afternoon at the hearing on canals, gave the politicians something to talk about to-night. Assertions that the Republican Party and Gov. Odell are pledged against canal legislation that will involve direct taxation form the chief topic in political circles.

The only sugar refineries in active operation in this neighborhood yesterday were those of Arbuckle Brothers. It was said that they were turning out their full output, but James N. Jarvie of the firm declined to talk either of its affairs or those of other refineries, which are classed in lower Wall Street as rivals of this sugar and coffee house.

Mr. COHN is announced to be the introducer and sponsor, "by request," of a remarkable project of law just sprung upon the Legislature of New York. It is Assembly Bill No. 320, and is entitled "An act to impose a tax upon all ablebodied bachelors and spinsters who are found to be deliberately persistent in their celibacy."

Charles F. Conklin of Chicago, one of the most promising amateur billiard players in the country, outplayed and defeated the amateur champion, Wilson P. Foss of Haverstraw, at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, last night. It was in the third game of the championship 14.2 billiard tournament of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players that these two experts met and the unexpected happened.

The development of the trouble in "Waterbury, Conn., from a strike by some ninety motormen on a street railway to a condition demanding the presence of a considerable body of State troops to preserve order and protect life and property makes it in many respects typical of disturbances of its kind.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 3 -- There was direct contradiction in the testimony, adduced to-day at the first session, of the Coroner's Jury, called to place the responsibility for the railroad disaster near Westfield on Jan. 27. The death-bed affidavits of James Davis, who was the engineer of the Philadelphia express, that crashed into the rear ena of the Easton local passenger train, were read, and the testimony of many railroad employes was taken.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 -- The City Council to-day adopted, by a vote of 14 to 3, the ordinance of the New Orleans and San Francisco Railroad Company, granting to that corporation all the concessions, rights, and privileges asked by it for the purpose of entering New Orleans.

LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 4 -- During the girls' basket ball game here this afternoon in which the Lowell High School team defeated Melrose High School 83 to 5, Miss Ruth Bailey, left forward for Lowell, broke what is claimed to be the world's record for basket throwing for girls, making 33 goals. The former record was 17 goals.

Justice John Woodward of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department, writing to his constituents in Erie County, in a letter addressed to Simon Fleischman, Adalbert Moot, and James L. Quackenbush of the Bar Association of Erie County, under date of Tuesday, said:
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Money was in active demand in the market to-day. Discounts were steady.
First Lieut. W.C. Valentine, Twenty-sixth Infantry, is transferred to the Fourth Infantry, and First Lieut. Cyrus A. Dolph, from Fourth Infantry to the Twenty-sixth Infantry.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- After a truce of two legislative sessions the controversy between the State Board of Regents and the State Department of Public Instruction was resumed to-day at a hearing before the Assembly Ways and Means Committee. In the course thereof Danfortn E. Ainsworth, Assistant Deputy State Superintendent of Public Instruction, shook his finger at Bishop William Croswell Doane of Albany and demanded an explanation of remarks he had made.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 4 -- It was Reading's day in the local market, nearly one-half of all the sales made being in Reading common. Rumor had it that the first and second preferred stocks are to be retired, but it was given little credence, while Reading officials said they knew of no such plan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:
WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Stormy weather and extra precaution on the part of the authorities carried Waterbury through the dangerous hours of to-night without serious trouble.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The Rome correspondent of The Times says the wretchedness of the southern provinces of Italy is a melancholy contrast to the general prosperity of the country, and suggests a doubt as to whether legislation has not fostered the industrial North at the expense of the agricultural South.
BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- Henry L. Higginson, the founder and supporter of the Boston Sympiiony Orchestra, now in its twenty-third year, in a letter to the public which will be published to-morrow, says:
BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- "The wages question" was discussed by Carroll D. Wright, United States Labor Commissioner, to-night before the Twentieth Century Club. In his address he said:

With two bullets in her brain and hovering between life and death, Mrs. Lena Hein, forty-two years old, of 71 East One Hundred and Fifth Street, lay in the Harlem Hospital last night, while in another part of the hospital, blind from the effect of two bullet wounds self-inflicted in his head, Emil Hein, the woman's husband, lay dying.

The committee of the Aldermen that has charge of the arrangements for celebrating in May the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the conferring of municipal powers upon the city met in the City Hall yesterday and some preliminary plans were prepared.

Owing to the renewal of heavy transactions in Tennessee Copper yesterday's total in the outside market was somewhat larger than on the first two days of the week, but, except in the copper shares, there was no marked increase in activity. The strength of the Stock Exchange market, accompanied by moderate increase in transactions, was reflected outside by a number of advances, which were somewhat better sustained than those which occurred on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senator Jones of Nevada, who will retire from the Senate with the termination of the present Congress, declared to-day that he is tired of public life, and will hereafter devote himself to business pursuits. He has large and important mining interests, in Alaska and Mexico, to which part of his time has been devoted.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- The money market is dull and unchanged. Call loans, 4 @ 5 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 4 1/4 @ 5 per cent. Time loans; mercantile paper, 4 1/4 @ 5 per cent. Clearing House loans, 4 per cent. New York funds, par @ 5c premium. Clearings, $23,779,020; balances, $2,199,744.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 4 -- The Kansas Mutual Insurance Company of Topeka, one of the largest insurance companies in the State, was to-day declared insolvent by Judge Hook in the Federal Court, and he suggested the appointment of ex-Gov. N. Morrill for receiver.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- For hours to-day Chicago was isolated from the rest of the world in consequence of the blizzard that has been raging throughout the country. Telegraph wires throughout the city were out of service east and west, not a single wire stretching north and south was working. Meagre communication was had with Milwaukee on the north and St. Louis on the south during the forenoon.

The continued strength of Amalgamated and Anaconda Copper stocks on the Exchange and of the lower-priced issues on the curb makes pertinent the declaration of D. Houston Co., in their copper circular, issued yesterday, that the brighter trade conditions previously commented upon have been maintained.

After ineffectual efforts to bring about a postponement by counsel for the defense the work of selecting a jury to try William Hooper Young:, the grandson of Brigham Young, the Mormon prophet, accused of the murder of Mrs. Anna Pulitzer last September, was begun yesterday afternoon before Justice Herrick in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court.

-- It is natural enough that the members of our Legislature who have been using sleeping and parlor car passes should be angry with the fellow-member who has been so inconsiderate as to fix public and official attention on a form of economy that is sure in the end to be very expensive for the State.

The upper rooms of the American Art Galleries not occupied by the Lyall pictures are filled with a Japanese collector's treasures in wood carving, metal work, old stamped and carved leathers, and paintings on paper and wood, which form in themselves a small museum of objects of the applied arts of Japan and China.
One Inspector, a Captain, a Sergeant, and a wardman were dismissed from the Police Department by Commissioner Greene yesterday after all had been tried before him or the Deputy Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Cashier George B. Wilson of the New York Assay Office has tendered his resignation to the Secretary of the Treasury. It has not been acted upon. Whether or not it will be accepted depends on the results of an investigation that is in contemplation. Mcanwhile Cashier Wilson stands suspended.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- John I. Platt, in an interview to-day regarding his utterances before the joint canal committea on Tuesday, said: "I am much surprised at the excitement produced by my remarks yesterday before the committee. Really, some of the misrepresentations are remarkable.

How much or little attaches to the press dispatch from Berlin under date of Feb. 2 of the discovery of a scarlet fever serum from which good results have been obtained, and which is believed to be a specific in the treatment of this dread disease, which has been well described as "the scourge of the nursery," is still indeterminate.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Senator Marshall made a statement to-day about the bill which he introduced, providing for an amendment to the tenement house law, which is construed as a virtual abandonment of it. He said, that the measure had been given to him by the Builders' Association, and he introduced it without carefully going over its provisions.

BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- The co-operating powers, standing by their first condition that the blockade shall not be raised until an adequate guarantee for the payment of the reserved claims is given, have instructed their Embassies at Washington to insist upon such an adequate guarantee. Otherwise the blockade will continue for months or for years, if this is necessary to persuade President Castro to meet the demands of the allies.

Amendments to the constitution of the Clearing House Association were presented yesterday at a special meeting called for this purpose. The amendments, which have been generally outlined in these columns, relate to the regulation of the facilities to be extended to non-members, that is, trust companies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Legal restrictions placed on corporations by the State of Illinois resulted to-day in the announcement that the Diamond Match Company probably will move its home shortly to some State where exactions are not so severe. The occasion was the annual meeting of the stockholders of the company, held in the assembly room of the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank Building.

Few of the ordinary sketches of vaudeville will stand the tests of time and second hearing, but there is an occasional exception to the rule. Such is the case with "The Awakening of Mr. Pipp," which Charles Grapewin and his wife, Anna Chance, are again presenting at Keith's this week.

The weather schedule went all awry yesterday. A large, damp cloud dropped out of its orbit and fell all over this city, and last evening a thunderstorm, which was not due until the middle of April, broke in and drove the cloud away. Midwinter thunderstorms are not the usual thing here, and most persons who saw the first flash waited for a second one to decide that it was real lightning.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- In the midst of wealth and luxury John Lord Curtis, the last member of one of the oldest and at one time one of the most aristocratic families of Boston, committed suicide Tuesday night by taking morphine. The suicide took place at his home, 23 Beaumont Street, Dorchester.

The German Ambassador at London, Count WOLFF-METTERNICH, in a dispatch to his Government referring to British public opinion on the Venezuelan question and the British Cabinet's attitude in consequence thereof, says that the Government is conscious of lack of popular support in its association with Germany, especially of the disapproval of the middle classes.

Notwithstanding the Western storm, which broke telegraphic communication With Chicago, and the continued stagnation in arbitrage dealings with London, the stock market yesterday broadened out considerably, and the total sales were larger than on any day in three weeks. With this increase of activity there was a further accession of strength, and altogether the speculative outlook showed much improvement, without, however, any change from the professional character of the trading.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- At the joint hearing before the Senate and Assembly Committees on Taxation to-day on the Governor's Notarial Tax bill, the objections urged against it were so numerous and so serious as to create consternation among its advocates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Every effort is making by the representatives of the allies here to secure an early settlement of the Venezuelan dispute without referring it to The Hague. In this effort the Italian and British Ambassadors and the German Minister, Baron Speck von Sternburg, are receiving the indorsement of Mr. Bowen, as well as the cordial approval of the Government of the United States.

Mr. JENKINS of Wisconsin does not seem to be a very Solon, even though he happens to be Chairman of the House Committee on the Judiciary. He proposes to deal with polygamy through an amendment to the Constitution providing against plural marriages, and giving Congress, of course, power to enforce the prohibition through legislation.

Returning to her home, 504 West One Hundred and Forty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, at 5 o'clock, a daughter of Frank F. Davis, a lawyer, with offices at 33 Nassau Street, found the doors of the apartment locked. After a time Miss Davis had a bell boy, William Robinson, climb in through a front window.

Secretary G.A. Cormack of the New York Yacht Club has given notice of the first general meeting of the year, to be held at the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, on Thursday, Feb. 12. at 9 P.M. At this meeting the reports of the Secretary, the Treasurer, and the various standing committees will be presented, and officers and standing committees for the coming year will be elected.

The McVickar Realty Trust Company has bought the ten-story building 7 Pine Street 21 by 74, from the estate of Malvina Schleicher. The purchasing company, the offices of which are now at 24 Nassau Street, intends to occupy the lower part of the building as soon as it can get possession, which, however, will probably not be for at least a year.
At a meeting or the Board of Directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States yesterday Henry Rogers Winthrop was elected Assistant Secretary of the society.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Several interesting incidents occurred during to-day's session of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission. The morning session was chlivened by the rigid cross-examination of H. D. Newcomb, a statistician of the Reading Company, by Attorney Darrow, for the miners, and the spirited passages between the lawyer and the witness.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 4 -- Sixty midshipmen, candidates for positions on the academy eight-oared crews, reported in response to Capt. Rodgers's call to-day, and went through some preliminary work at the rowing machines in the gymnasium this afternoon. Practice work will be held in the gymnasium until the weather will permit the crews to take to the water.

England and the United States, bound together through common racial origin, a common language and literature, a common heritage of tradition and common interests of trade, by ties stronger than Legislatures can enact or diplomats create by formal alliance -- this was the thought at the dinner of the Pilgrim Society of the United States in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria last evening.

The second of the thirty-one suits brought by clients of Howe Hummel to recover bets made on horse races was begun before a jury and Justice Murray in the Tenth Municipal Court in West Fifty-third Street yesterday. The case was that of Moulton as against a bookmaker, and the Westchester Racing Association, as a co-defendant, and was based on a fifty-dollar wager made and lost by Moulton at Morris Park last October.

Card parties, luncheons, and dinners were among the chief entertainments yesterday. There is a crowding of reception days and dinners and affairs of that kind before the general rush for Florida and Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Array Staff bill was again reconsidered in the Senate to-day on motion of Senator Cockrell, (Dem., Mo.,) and the provision associating the Secretary of War in authority with the President was restored in changed form.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 4 -- Montreal is threatened with a street car strike for Friday. Employes have organized and demand recognition of the union, increase of wages to 18 and 20 cents an hour, cessation of dismissals without cause assigned, as well as reinstatement of men so dismissed since Jan. 1.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Senator Marshall today introduced two bills, prepared in the Corporation Counsel's office in New York City, the purpose of which is to stop all further obstructive tactics of the Board of Aldermen against the Pennsylvania tunnel project.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 4 -- The persistency of dullness was varied somewhat today by the revival of confident predictions of an early improvement. The resistfulness against depression, despite the slow trading, was accepted as conclusive proof of the solidity of value. Moreover, more facts have come to the surface about the low-selling issues which promise to increase the demand for them as well as to lift the price.

JOHN I. PLATT of Poughkeepsie is an absolutely fearless and outspoken opponent of the canals. He meets the canal men face to face. He denounces without concealment or palavering all plans of improvement. His hostility lasts the year through; it has no seasons. He never dissembles, not even during a Gubernatorial campaign.

Henry P. Stofft of Cleveland leads all the other contestants in the professional sweepstakes pool tournament which is being decided at the Montauk Billiard Academy, Brooklyn. He has won all of the eight games which he took part in, and has only one more to play. His nearest competitor is Charles Weston of Chicago, who has won seven out of eight games, and he and Stofft will play the ninth game next Friday night.

The trust companies and the banks have a like interest in the maintenance of adequate banking reserves in this money centre. A sufficient reserve is the anchor of safety in the banking business, and safety is the paramount considera- tion. It cannot be said that profits are of greater importance to a bank, for profits earned by unsafe methods rest upon a basis too unstable to satisfy either managers or stockholders.

WIDOW'S PORTION -- The Special Term of the Supreme Court and the Appellate Division upheld a demurrer to a complaint in an action brought by Polly Lavinia Crawford against Eugene Nassoy, her husband's administrator, to recover from him certain property which he should have turned over to her as her widow's portion, on the ground that a widow cannot reduce such property to possession except through the regular course of administration.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Several New York City bills were put on the Senate calendar for passage to-day on favorable reports from the Cities Committee.

Drawn revolvers, threats to shoot, and the smashing of a heavy iron door figured in a raid yesterday by Capt. Miles O'Reilly of the Tenderloin Precinct on an alleged gambling house at 109 West Thirty-first Street. The Captain says the place is generally known as being run by "Big" Frank Felton. Five men were arrested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A general order dated Jan. 27, making a number of highly important military assignments was issued at the War Department to-day. Under this order the following changes will occur...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Chairman Loud of the Post Office Committee delivered his valedictory in the House to-day, and made it the occasion of a solemn warning.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- The Free Religious Association, of which Ralph Waldo Emerson was one of the founders and Vice Presidents, is to commemorate the centennial of its birth in July by devoting the principal session of its annual convention in anniversary work to the subject of Emerson's religious influence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senator Hanna to-day introduced a bill providing for pensioning colored people who were slaves until emancipated by the proclamation of President Lincoln. This is not a new proposition, but surprise is expressed that Senator Hanna should bring it forward at this time.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 5 -- Official announcement was made by the Pennsylvania Company (lines west) to-day that the embargo on freight, placed several weeks ago, has been lifted and the entire Pennsylvania system is free to accept consignments to and from all points along its lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Reading common continued the active leader of the local market to-day, and while it was strong, it did not hold its improvement like the first and second preferred. Floor traders and arbitrage houses were active in the stock, and this was also true of Erie and United States Steel, which were also active.

In a series of three "doubles" matches at handball the New Polo Athletic Association's players defeated the representatives of Manhattan College by winning two out of three. The games were played last night in the Polo Association's gymnasium at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Park Avenue.

The Senatorial graveyard yawns, and another treaty has been swallowed up. The report from Washington that the President and the Secretary of State despair of the ratification of the Hay-Herbert treaty, providing for a court or commission to determine the Alaskan boundary question, confirms rumors that were already current portending the failure of the treaty.

The fourth of Mr. Herman Hans Wetzler's orchestral concerts, which took place last evening in Carnegie Hall, introduced a new violinist and a new composer to New York. The new violinist is Mr. Hugo Heefmann, who comes from Frankfort, in Germany, where he is highly regarded as a teacher of his instrument in a well-known conservatory of music, though his name.

There could be no news more cheering and more reassuring to patriotic Americans everywhere than the news that ADDICKS has withdrawn from the contest for either of the vacant Senatorships from Delaware. The man has carried on a campaign of corruption which for extent in time and expensiveness in money has probably no precedent in American politics.

Yesterday was a busy day in society. There was the Oelrichs musicals, in addition to numerous dinners which preceded the Charity Ball, and the MontesquiouFezensac-lecture; also the Benkard-Bartlett wedding and the musicale at the residence of Mrs. Robert W. De Forest, among the guests at which were many of the down-town residents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The House today entered upon the consideration of the Littlefield Anti-Trust bill. It was taken up under a special rule, which provides for ten hours of general debate and three hours devoted to consideration of the bill under the five-minute rule.

Andrew Carnegie's speech was the feature at the inauguration exercises held at Steven's Institute, Hoboken yesterday afternoon to usher into office the new President, Alexander C. Humphreys. The assembly hall of the Carnegie Laboratory of Engineering was well filled. Chancellor Magic of New Jersey administered the oath of office to the institute's new head, and among the guests of honor were representatives of various educational institutions.

Anton L. Olsen has bought from Alfred Lockwood Brown, through A.M. Johnson Co. the plot 83 by 98.9, at 149 to 155 West Twenty-fourth Street. Mr. Olsen will improve the property by the erection of a six-story loft building.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Mrs. Alexander Robinson, the old-time circus woman, who died here at her home on Broad Street Tuesday morning of old age, was known to every member of the circus fraternity of the country. With her husband, Alexander Robinson, of this city, she traveled extensively, and in the circus managed by them for thirty-five years some of the most noted performers of the country were educated.

-- Curiosity which for some reasons should be shared in this country is expressed by The London Shipping World that one of the companies "merged" in tha International Mercantile Marine Company is now having built in American yards two vessels of 13,400 tons, two of 9,800 tons, and two of 8,900 tons.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Discounts were tolerably firm to-day owing to the stringency of money and the maintenance of the Bank of England's rate of discount.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5-- The following cablegram has been received at the State Department from United States Consul Mce at Tegucigalpa, Honduras, dated Feb. 5:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 5 -- That large volumes of steam escaped from Engine No. 27, which caused the wreck on the New Jersey Central Railroad near Westfield, was testified to by half a dozen eyewitnesses before the Coroner's jury this afternoon. That the steam obscured his vision was the excuse offered by James Davis, the engineer, for not paying attention to the block signals at Cranford and Westfield.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 5 -- D.H. Moffat to-day emphatically denied a published report that the United States Steel Corporation, through the newly incorporated Frontier Coal and Steel Company, is to secure control of the iron deposits of Northwestern Colorado, and that it will build the proposed $15,000,000 plant at Denver.

There was a continuance yesterday of the improvement in the stock market, and the prevailing sentiment was bullish. In spite of much selling for realization of profits, which produced considerable irregularity, prices made substantial net advances for the day, although there was some reaction at the close.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- Money rates are unchanged, and there is no urgent demand for accommodation. Call loans, 4 @ 5 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/4 @ 5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents premium; clearings, $24,565,112; balances, $1,580,326.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 5 -- After a session lasting an hour and a half, the conferrees who met to-night in an attempt to arrange a settlement of the trolley strike, parted at 9:30 with agreement apparently as far away as ever.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Odell to-day made an interesting statement about canal legislation. It was prominently displayed in the columns of the official organ of the Republicans here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate Commerce Committee went over the Crum case to-day and left off where they began. The meeting was behind closed doors, and the opponents of Dr. Crum, who was nominated to be Collector of Customs at Charleston, S.C., were given the floor for the day.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 5 -- The local market displayed a shade more activity to-day without scoring any special movement in prices. There was an obvious effort to "wash" Cotton Duck issues to a lower level with the view of nullifying the effect of good news about the company which was current during the day.

If the findings of Gilbert M. Speir, referee in the litigation instituted by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company against the Tax Commissioners, the city will lose many hundred thousands of dollars.

When the suit of the firm whose plate glass windows came to grief by reason of air currents alleged to have been deflected from the towering and oblique sides of the "Flat Iron" Building reaches a hearing in the courts some interesting problems will be presented for judicial solution.
WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 5 -- J. Edward Addicks has given the Regular Republicans a puzzle to solve with an alleged withdrawal from the race for United States Senator, which was made this afternoon.

Here is a little something about "comfortables," as an antidote before taking a dose of Spring hats. The "comfortables" sound more in keeping with the February winds. These are of down and just the thing for the apartments where the janitor saves coal by turning off the heat at night.

In all parts of the outside market yesterday transactions were limited, and the only interesting developments were the movements of more or less consequence which occurred in some half dozen issues. For the most part the changes which took place were in line with those that had occurred earlier in the week, few stocks being given attention except those which for some time had held places of more or less prominence.

The purchaser of postage stamps at the window of the General Office is now supplied with stamps of the two-cent denomination which he is likely to regard with feelings akin to those which would take possession of him if some one should substitute for his favorite picture a tea store chromo.

Miss Ethel Smythe, composer of "Die Wald" and protege of the ex-Empress Eugenie of France, was among those who arrived on the Oceanic yesterday. She is at the Albemarle Hotel, and has come to America to supervise the production of her opera, which will be given at the Metropolitan.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The Marquis of Castellane, the father of Count Boni de Castellane, has an article in the Eclair this morning, in which he advocates an alliance between the United States and France, with the object of keeping Germany and the rest of Europe out of South America.

A novel feature of the skating carnival at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, last night, was a bowling game played on the ice by two five-men teams. It was said to be the first attempt ever made to bowl under such conditions, and the scores justified the contention, as the Federkase team, which won the match, scored a total of 364. while the Clermont team made 352.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The fear of an extra session is beginning to have its effect on the Statehood deadlock in the Senate. At a time when possibly the State bill is receiving the hardest blows that it has yet encountered in the debate the Republican leaders are getting down to definite work on a proposition to resolve differences and agree on admitting two States and a third conditionally.

A new amateur competition record for 14:2 balk line billiards was made by Wilson P. Foss, the thrice champion of the Amateur Athletic Union, last night at the championship tournament of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, which is in progress at the Hanover Club. Foss finished the game of 300 points in 19 innings.

Two more police Captains were appointed yesterday by Commissioner Greene. They were Sergts. Owen Rooney of the Brownsville Station, Brooklyn, and Nathaniel N. Shire of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station. The latter has been acting as Captain. Four eligible candidates appeared before the Commissioner.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 5 -- The lives of 200 passengers were endangered last night when the east-bound Great Northern overland train became stuck in the Cascade Tunnel. The train was held in the funnel for four hours and thirty-five minutes on account of an accident to the air brakes.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- There was a meeting of the Trustees of the Capitol to-day, and one of the things considered was the filling of the place of the Superintendent of Public Buildings. This is a place which William Barnes, the Albany leader, has been most anxious to obtain for one of his trusted political lieutenants.

The alarming growth of pulmonary tuberculosis among the tenement house population in this city and the lack of facilities to cope with its spread were discussed at length last night at a meeting of the Academy of Medicine. Physicians united in an urgent plea that, either by public appropriation or private charity, some means of cure and prevention be provided by which consumption's victims may be aided and its ravages checked.
PLYMOUTH, N.H., Feb. 5 -- Capt. George H. Colby, Boston and Main station agent here, was shot by mistake by Policeman Lewis C. Mills about midnight and is now lying dead at his home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- No one here connected with the management of Republican Party affairs can explain the reported withdrawal of Mr. Addicks from the Senatorial contest in Delaware, nor the purpose of Mr. Addicks in this movement. When in Washington last week Mr. Addicks talked freely about the contest and seemed as persistent as ever in the determination to remain a candidate to the end.

A condition or general warfare prevails throughout a large part of the trade of Europe. Even when the great NAPOLEON was issuing his decrees from Berlin which sought to suppress the commerce of England and England was responding with orders in Council no less sweeping and arbitrary, the interference with the trade of the peoples was not more cruel, though it was more extended than at present.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The debate on the Statehood bill to-day turned on polygamy. Mr. McComas started it yesterday by criticising the pending bill as being too liberal.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Believing that the Assembly Cities Committee is holding up the Sinking Fund bill which he introduced at the request of Controller Grout, Assemblyman Clark will on next Tuesday, if favorable action is not taken by the committee before that time, make a motion in the Assembly that the committee be discharged from further consideration of the measure.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- The feature of to-day's carnival was the hockey match between the Montreal and the Saranac Lake teams. Two thousand persons witnessed the sport. The Montreal seven won by a score of six goals to three, making five goals in the first half to one by the home team.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- Miss Alice W. Cayvan, a sister of Miss Georgia Cayvan, the actress, died last night after an illness of several weeks. She was born, in Bath, Me.. in 1856, being two years older than her Bister Georgie. She came to Boston when twelve years old. Here she received her education, and lived until her twenty-fifth year, when Georgia went to New York to begin her career on the stage.

WINSTED, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Driving at a rapid pace toward his home in a violent electrical storm last night, Eugene Merchand, thirty-two years old, proprietor of the Blackberry River Farm in West Norfolk, saw a brilliant flash of lightning and then heard a deafening report.

LONDON, Feb 6 -- The Daily News this morning starts an agitation on the Macedonian question. It publishes a three-column letter from its "Special Commissioner" at Dubnitza, Bulgaria, describing in great detail alleged Turkish atrocities, as related by fugitives there.

Franklin Roberge repeated the assertion yesterday that it is an injury for a veterinarian to have a rich and famous patron. That was in his suit against the estate of Robert Bonner to recover $100,000 which he asserts Mr. Bonner intended to bequeath to him as compensation for caring for his horses, but omitted from his will.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The President late this afternoon signed the bill which amends the bankruptcy law of 1898. William H. Hotchkiss of Buffalo, President of the National Association of Referees in Bankruptcy; William A. Prendergast, Secretary of the National Association of Credit Men, and S.C. Mead, Secretary of the Merchants' Association of New York, were present when the bill was signed.
Is it only imagination, or has this advertisement appeared in the agony column of the Herald?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Post Office Appropriation bill was passed by the House to-day after the annual contest over the item appropriating $144,000 to the Southern Railway Company for carrying the fast mail between Washington and New Orleans. A motion to strike out was rejected by a vote of 100 to 120.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The business of forcing riders on appropriation bills bids fair to increase. Senator McComas has introduced an amendment to the General Deficiency bill providing for the retroactive payment to mechanics and Government employes of every class for all work done in excess of eight hours daily since May 18, 1869, the date when by the proclamation of President Grant the eight-hour law was established on all Government work.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Republican Senators indulged in sharp debate when the Elmira gerrymander came up in the Senate to-day. It was passed, however, by a strict party vote. Senators Brackett and Elsberg were among those who said "aye" on the roll call. Senator Brown, the third of the triumvirate of bolters, was not present.

ST. LOUIS, Feb., 5 -- William Paull, of London, England, leading baritone of the Castle Square Opera Company, showing at the Century Theatre, here is dead as the result of a fall from the six-story windaw of the Southern Hotel. His skull was fractured and his left arm was broken. When picked up on the pavement Paull was unconscious.

There were only two vacant seats in the Jury box when the trial of William Hooper Young, for the murder of Mrs. Anna Pulitzer, was adjourned yesterday by Justice Herrick in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. Three jurors had been obtained on the first day, and the ten men thus far chosen are as follows:

The City of Bloomington, Ill., has experienced vicissitudes. It was almost destroyed by fire in 1890, was promptly rebuilt, and from its advantages of location attracted large and diversified industries. Meanwhile organized labor obtained a control so firm that other industries were deterred from coming to Bloomington and its prosperity was threatened.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Reforms desired by the New York City administration in the Fire Department were brought before the Assembly to-day in bills introduced by Mr. Bostwick to amend the city's charter.

As a result of the favorable decision by the New Jersey Court of Errors in the Steel Trust's bond conversion plan, activity on a scale not seen in some months developed in the stocks of the corporation, resulting in an advance in each case of a point or more. Greatest activity showed in the common, where approximately 135,000 shares were traded in, while in the preferred but 35,000 shares changed hands.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- After a sitting of exactly fifty-one days, the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission concluded the hearing of witnesses at 5 o'clock this afternoon and adjourned until next Monday, when it will begin to hear the arguments of counsel representing the several sides. The arguments will take up five and a half days, the operators having been assigned three days and the miners the remainder of the time.

TENTON, N.J., Feb. 5 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals, by a unanimous decision, to-day reversed the decision of Vice Chancellor Emery that enjoined the United States Steel Corporation from converting $200,000,000 worth of its 7 per cent, preferred stock into 5 per cent, second mortgage bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Army Staff bill was sent to conference to-day. One of the amendments made by the Senate provides for the retirement of veteran officers with a grade above that held by them at the time of retirement. A similar amendment was also placed on the Army Appropriation bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Quite the most brilliant of the season's balls took place this evening at the New Willard, where about 400 guests were entertained by the officers of the Army Medical School, recently established in Washington, and having on its roll forty surgeons. The music was by the military band from the Washington Barracks, and each of the military guests appeared in full uniform, with side arms.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 6 -- Agents for a New York syndicate are working to form a combination of mine ear and supply companies in Western Pennsylvania and West Virginia. They have options on about eighteen concerns, and are negotiating for others. All large companies, with a few exceptions, have, it is said, named a price and given an option.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 6 -- Dr. Charles Henry Hoffman, Professor of Histology and Bacteriology in the Iowa College of Physicians, a department of Drake University, has resigned because he was requested to show his diplomas.

William Barclay Parsons, Chief Engineer of the Rapid Transit Commission, has bought from the United States Realty and Construction Company the lot, 25 by 100.5, at 35 East Fiftieth Street, north side, 173 feet west of Park Avenue. Mr. Parsons will erect a residence on the site from plans by architects Clinton and Russell.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The active request for money was intensified in the market today by the payment of $5,000,000 for New South Wales Treasury bills. Discounts were firm.

THE STORIES of the birds told by the little daughter of Menee, the witch of Dollyhyde Swamp, are related in the true dialect of the Southern darky and have the abrupt turns and unexpected flashes of shrewdness that make the utterances of Uncle Remus so delightful.

Capt. Max F. Sehmittberger of the West Forty-seventh Street Station, who, to save himself from severe punishment, became a witness before the Lexow Committee, when he gave testimony damaging to himself and many other members of the police force, came in for some caustic remarks yesterday from District Attorney Jerome.

Arthur B. Archibald of Archibald Dougherty, Jersey' City lawyers, said yesterday that the firm had been retained by Herbert S. Edwards, a resident of Jersey City, to demand indemnity, through the United States Government, from the Argentine Republic for the unwarrantable arrest of their client.

WE HAVE here the second volume of an "Expansion of the Republic" series of which Dr. Hosmer's "History of the Louisiana Purchase" was the first. Other very interesting numbers are promised. Mr. Mathews brings to his subject and argument a sympathy and enthusiasm which will be contagious for many of his readers, deterrent to a few of colder blood.

WINSTED, Conn., Feb. 6 -- Judge William S. Case in the Superior Court here to-day granted eight divorces in less than two hours. Six of them were on the grounds of desertion, but all the parties asserted that they never had any differences. This caused the court to remark that there had been "a most amazing lot of sudden departures."

ASERIES of Little French Masterpieces, including half a dozen 16mo volumes, is in preparation by G.P. Putnam's Sons. There will be one volume devoted to Merimee and one apiece to Flaubert, Gautier, Balzac, Daudet, and de Maupassant.

THE salient feature of Dr. Woodrow Wilson's "History of the American People" is the terseness with which he analyzes the characters of great men with whom he has to deal. I have already noted his concise survey of Andrew Jackson, and now direct attention to his portrayal of a Abraham Lincoln.

THE last two, or rather, let us say, the third and fourth vol- umes of "Studies of a Biographer," for most renders will hope that Leslie Stephen, has other like volumes in store for us are made up largely of criticisms on the life and work of various English men of letters and publicists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Naval Constructor Richmond P. Hobson's resignation has been accepted by Secretary Moody, who has written Mr. Hobson as follows:

NEWCASTLE, Penn., Feb. 6 -- By the collapse of a portion of the conrete roofing of the seven-story building of the Laurence Savings and Trust Company, under construction here, Gilbert Achre was crushed to death, and John McClure was seriously injured. Architect H. Gilvery of New York was cut and bruised.

The amateur competition average of 15 15-19 made by Wilson P. Foss at 14.2 balk line billiards on Thursday night in the championship tournament of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, now in progress at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, was broken last night, and the same player had tHe honor of making the new record.

GOUVERNEUR MORRIS, author of "Aladdin O'Brien," is a greatgrandson of the statesman of that name, who took a prominent part in the American Revolution. Young Morris is a Yale man of '08. His ancestor is about to figure in a novel written by another author.

The first book of the Graeco-Roman Archaeological Series, published for the University of California, with the imprint of the Oxford University Press, is on "The Tebtunis Papyri," which, at the same time, is the annual volume of the Gracco-Roman Branch of the Egypt Exploration Fund for 1900-1, and, on account of its length, for 1901-2.

It is reported that considerable criticism has been made in police circles of the questions asked in the examination of Captains for promotion to the grade of Inspector, and especially of the questions in the so-called "mental examination."

WASHINGTON Feb. 6 -- The two days' anti-trust debate in the House closed this evening with speeches by Mr. Littlefield and Mr. De Armond, the respective party leaders on the question. In one respect it was a remarkable debate. The trust question has been heralded as the issue of the session, and the legislation upon it was expected to be the most important of the three months.

IS there mental receptivity for certain religions assorted to races? How otherwise account for the rapid progress made by Mohammedans after the death of the Prophet? Mr. Stanley LanePoole's volume, "Mediaeval India Under Mahammedan Rule," covers a period of over 1,000 years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Just as people who had attended the President's reception were coming out of the White House at midnight last night a youth shot and killed himself near the Jackson statue in Lafayette Park, opposite the White House grounds. The departing guests heard the shot.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- The Cuba Eastern Railroad Company was incorporated here to-day, to operate railroads or traction lines in Cuba. The authorized capital stock is $2,000,000, and the incorporators are Louis N. Wheaton, Stallo Vinton, and Frederick B. Mearkles.

President Ban Johnson of the American Baseball League arrived in this city last night, and when seen at the Criterion Hotel, Broadway and Forty-first, Street, he showed the effects of his recent illness, but was brimful of bright hopes for the success of an American League club in this city.

Exhibitions of paintings and water colors are so numerous this year that the artists in white and black can scarcely make themselves heard. A little group of illustrators for the press who held an exhibition of their work last winter have returned once more to the charge and under the title Society of Illustrators have opened their second annual show at the Taft-Belknap Galleries, 1 East Fortieth Street.

Dante, who scoffed at the pride and arrogance of the Sienese with equal pride and arrogance, and called them a "gente vano," has found emulators down to the present day. We even search in vain, in the otherwise excellent history of Florence by Prof. Pasquale Villari, for any mention of Siena or of the Sienese.

"Her Lord and Master," which was first presented as a play by Martha Morton in the Spring of 1902, has now been made over into a novel by her sister, Victoria Morton. It is still but a thinly disguised play, with "he said"and "she said" connecting the dialogue, and its very apparent' staginess is a decided defect of the novel.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 6 -- "What can a university contribute to prepare for business life? "was the question discussed this afternoon at the Business Men's session of the Convention of Educators and Business Men in progress here. The subject was considered from the respective points of view of the manufacturer, the transporter, the wholesale dealer, and the corporation lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- President Roosevelt has declined the invitation of the allied powers to arbitrate the question as to whether they shall receive preferential treatment in the settlement of their claims against Venezuela over the other creditor nations. He reached this decision shortly before 4 o'clock this afternoon, and instructed Secretary Hay to dispatch a note to the British Embassy at once advising the British Ambassador to that effect.
The Republican District Committee of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District, which first elected President Roosevelt to the Legislature, held its fourth annual dinner at the Hotel Savoy last night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 6 -- Edward J. Berwind and Mr. and Mrs. W. Storrs Wells, New York, and Mrs. W.R. Watson, Philadelphia, are at the Muenchinger King Cottage. Mr. Berwind and Mr. and Mrs. Wells are here in connection with improvements which are being made to their estates.

Those few artists of excellence who can use their pens with the same sense of construction and discrimination in imagination with which they ply their brushes usually write what is worth reading. Their treatment of themes is full of impressions and devoid of judgments and opinions except where they look upon a scene purely from the painter's point of view.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- A dull, heavy tone characterized the local market to-day. The volume of business was less than one-half of yesterday's transactions, and nearly everything dealt in reflected net losses at the close. The only exceptions were found in the bond department, where Citizens' Passenger of Indianapolis 5s advanced a point, and Philadelphia Electric sold at 52 1/2.

In this volume ("Mediaeval Stories," New York: Imported by Charles Scribner's Sons, $1.75,) Prof. H. Shuck has gathered together a number of old romances which, though none of real Swedish origin, were, nevertheless, put into Swedish verse early in the fourteenth century by order of the Norwegian Queen Euphemia for the amusement of her prospective son-in-law, Eric, a young Swedish Duke.

PLAINFIELD, Feb. 6 -- The Rev. Andrew M. Egan, pastor of St. Mary's Church, to-day appeared before the Coroner's jury selected to investigate the wreck on the New Jersey Central, near Westfield, and declared that Davis, the engineer of the flier, had told him that steam was leaking from the locomotive, preventing him from seeing the danger signals at Cranford and Westfield.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- M. Pelletan, the Radical Socialist Minister of Marine, seized the opportunity during to-day's discussion of the naval budget in the Chamber of Deputies to explain his policy and to defend himself from the attacks of which he has been the object. He said:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Dr. King's letter, printed in your issue of Jan. 24, contains but one statement to which, as it seems to me, an answer is required, and that is that in describing an Agnostic simply as one uncertain as to the things of religion, I disregard authoritative usage.

BRUSSELS, Feb., 6 -- The trial of Gennaro Rubino, the Italian Anarchist, on the charge of attempting to assassinate King Leopold on November 15, by firing three shots at his Majesty while the latter was returning from the Cathedral here after attending a Te Deum in memory of the late Queen Henriette, was opened to-day in the Assize Court.

Apart from the copper stocks, the outside market yesterday was very dull and presented almost nothing of interest. And even in the mining stocks there would be little to relate were it not for the effort that was yesterday made to establish here a market for a number of the well-known Boston copper stocks.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Three minutes were consumed in the session of the Assembly to-day. Assemblyman Bostwick's bill providing that a crime committed before the age of sixteen shall not make a citizen ineligible to hold a State office was passed. The session of the Senate lasted one minute and a half and was the shortest in the history of the Legislature.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- The fourth race for the Jackson Cup was sailed by the rough-weather boats of the Orange Lake Ice Yacht Club to-day. The entries were: Squall, E.A. Walsh; Breeze, James O'Brien; Junior, W.A. Kidd; Gale, Robert Kernahan. The wind was from the west, and the ice in good condition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- There are indications of a stubborn contest over the Senate amendment to the Army Appropriation bill to advance veteran officers one grade above that held by them when retired from active service.

Our readers will recall the recent plaint of one of the German university professors that Germany was lagging in the race of learning and the United States was forging ahead in various respects. He especially noted the superior equipment and organization of Columbia University for the advanced study of comparative literature.

Bucket shops or discretionary pools in grain or produce or anything dealt in on the Produce Exchange are to be discouraged as much as possible, and, in fact, will be offenses punishable by expulsion, if an amendment to the laws of the Exchange which has been recommended by the Board of Managers is adopted when it comes before the Exchange for a vote on Feb. 19.

A notable sale at auction of manuscripts, books, and autographs from the library of the Quaker poet John Greenleaf Whittier took place last evening at the rooms of John Anderson, Jr., 20 West Thirtieth Street. The sole purpose of the sale was the procuring of necessary funds for the care and permanent maintenance of the old Whittier homestead.

In this book of M. Barine's can be found more of a commentary on the life and times of Louis XIII, and the regency of Anne of Austria than any remarkable event directly connected with the youth of Anne-Marie-Louise d'Orleans, Duchess of Montpensier, daughter of Gaston, younger brother of Louis, and also related to royalty through her mother, Marie de Bourbon.

There was a tempestuous meeting of the Beard of Estimate yesterday, when that body considered the public improvement maps of the Bronx. President Haffen of that borough charged that politicians were trying to bulldoze him, and that they were all a "lot of public improvement plunderers."

You need not be "fanatico per la musica" to find amusement in Mr. Frederick J. Crowest's stories of musicians. You might study Grove and yet come across much that is novel in the "Musicians' Wit, Humour, and Anecdote." The compiler of the volume writes: "Many of the anecdotes are new, many old; some have been in print before, and some have not."

NEW ORLEANS, Feb., 6 -- Monos and Brief were the only winning favorites and the latter's victory was won at the price of serious injury to Jockey Redfern. The lad's good riding overcame the obstacles which the mare met in the race and just as her nose crossed the finish, she stepped in a hole in the track, stumbled and fell.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The notice in your issue of the 24th ult. correcting a misstatement in New Shakespeareana as to your views of that excellent Shakespearean scholar, Mr. Sidney Lee, leads me to call your attention to an article in the October-December issue for 1902 of that periodical.

Credit, with incidental glory, is claimed for Baron AVEBURY, the British banker-scientist, because, in a recent geological book entitled "The Scenery of England" he says, in reference to the northern districts of that country; "Rocks occur many where." On first inspection "manywhere" seems to have, if not elements of grandeur, at least promise of usefulness.

In The Phrenological Journal for this month Dr. Adolph Lorenz is the chief topic. According to the phrenologists, individuallty, firmness, destructivenes, continuity, ideality, benevolence, human nature, and order are the highly developed "bumps" of this great man.

Henry P. Stofft of Cleveland met his first defeat in the professional sweepstakes pool tournament at the Montauk Billiard Academy, Brooklyn, last night. Charles Weston of Chicago outplayed him in hollow style by the score of 125 to 44, and these two players are now tied for first honors, each having won eight games and lost one.

Joseph Ramsey, President of the Wabash Railroad, was yesterday elected President of the Western Maryland and of the West Virginia Central and Pittsburg Railroad, to succeed Winslow S. Pierce, who held the Presidencies of both roads from the time of the acquisition of control by George Gould to the election yesterday, which took place in the offices of the retiring President at 120 Broadway.
Elihu Root, Secretary of War, declared last night in a public speech that the people of this country had failed in their experiment of enfranchising the negro.

The jury to try William Hooper Young for the murder of Mrs. Anna Pulitzer was completed yesterday morning. Assistant District Attorney Clarke made his opening address, and before Justice Herrick adjourned court eleven witnesses, had been examined. The two men necessary to complete the jury were George W. Wells, a clerk, of 138 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, and Michael Cunningham, real estate, 707 Columbus Avenue.

In spite of the "string" which ADDICKS attached to his withdrawal, the withdrawal was a confession of weakness from which its author cannot escape. With the exposures that are all the time making, and of which Mr. KENNAN'S is the latest as well as the cruelest, it is calculated to encourage the decent Delawareans and to discourage those Delawareans whom ADDICKS has acquired by purchase.

An exceedingly sound, sensible, and able appeal to the Democratic Party in the Southern States is made by Mr. THOMAS F. RYAN in an article in the February number of The North American Review, entitled "The Political Opportunity of the South." Mr. RYAN appeals to the pride as well as to the common sense, the patriotism, and party loyalty of Southern Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Naval Ap- propriation bill reported to the House today carries $79,048,420, or $6,142,089 less than the estimates submitted by the Navy Department. The current appropriation is $78,856,363.
