WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 6 -- Closely following the departure of the militia from the city, disturbances broke out anew, and early in the evening cars returning from the outskirts of the city bore evidence of a renewal of stone throwing. Not a car came to the centre of the city with windows unbroken, although deputies rode on every car.

IN Mr. Bonnell's criticism we certainly gain the satisfaction of seeing the writers described intimately, and through a sympathetic medium. Obviously, he has read not merely to provide agreeable material for his pen to work upon, but to saturate his mind with the writings under his consideration, to get out of them all that they can yield him, and to make the product of his study an inspiration to other readers.

The London Times, undoubtedly reflecting the feeling of the British public, declares that when "redress and satisfaction are secured we shall feel the greatest satisfaction in being rid of the Venezuela mess." We can assure our London contemporary that it is the fervent wish of the American people that we may soon be rid of the mess and of the blockade.

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 6 -- All traffic on the main line of the Erie Railroad was at a standstill for three hours as the result of an accident at the sharp curve at Franklin Crossing here at 5 o'clock this afternoon. A work train, bound for Jersey City, was wrecked by a car, loaded with bolts, that jumped the track.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 6 -- No Senators were chosen to-day at the joint session of the Delaware Legislature, despite the withdrawal of J. Edward Addicks on condition that the regulars enter a caucus and abide by the result.

Earl Percy of the ducal house of Northumberland though opposed to the American policy of his country in the War of the Revolution, came to America with his regiment in 1774, and was for a time in command of the British forces. The letters in this volume were written to various persons -- to his father, the Duke; to Dr. Percy of "reliques" fame, and others.

THE great memorial meeting on the tenth anniversary of Phillips Brooks's death is to have an unexpected but agreeable result in the shape of a book by Dr. Lawrence, based upon his eloquent and just eulogy of his predecessor, the most remarkable of the many remarkable speeches delivered on that occasion.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It is evident from Mr. J. Hervey Cook's courtesy and urbanity that he does not belong to that large army of little failures who attack an author's latest, book partly for the sake of sotting their own names before the public for a moment, partly to get dolorous ease for an itching soul.

Out of deference to the man whose name it bears, the Maurice Grau Opera Company decided yesterday not to present opera except under his direction. Mr. Grau himself, looking pale and ill, was able to be present, at the regular monthly meeting of the company, held in the Metropolitan Opera House, and officially notified his colleagues of his determination to abandon all business cares for at least a year.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Henry James has nearly finished his life of Story, the sculptor and poet. Its title will be "William Wetmore Story and His Friends: From Letters, Diaries, and Recollections."

President Henry Hopkins of William College was the guest of honor at the annual dinner of the Williams Alumni Association of New York at Delmonico's last evening. In his address, which was taken as an outline of his policy in the management of the affairs of the college, he declared himself as in favor of the old standards of academic education.

The churchmen of the last century were not all of them what is generally understood as men of nesthetic culture. The science of taste had not, during a great part of the period covered by this book, made many disastrous inroads on their theology or their methods. They had a theological system and stuck by it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- There is some feeling between the House and the Senate in regard to anti-trust legislation. The House people have been diligently at work since the beginning of the session formulating the bill which culminated in the Littlefield bill now under consideration in that body.

Capt. Stephen E. Brown of the east Sixty-seventh Street Station, who has been thirty-four years on the force, presented himself before Commissioner Greene yes- terday and asked for retirement, explaining that he thought it was about time he took a rest. His request was immediately granted.

ABRAHAM GAMS -- Judge Adams of the United States District Court has appointed Robert G. Ten Eyck receiver of the assets of Abraham Gams, grocer at 2,302 Second Avenue, against whom a petition in bankruptcy was filed on Thursday.

IN a quiet corner of the clubhouse a number of them were discussing alligators. Discussing alligators, because one of them had but Just returned from Florida and had been telling some rather tall stories about shooting the saurians from the deck of a river steamboat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While Commissioner Greene is giving the public satisfaction in his efforts to uphold our laws, will he not be good enough to have Police Captains instructed in all the boroughs to order day and night patrolmen to arrest all those men and boys about our streets depositing "ad" matter in the letter boxes of apartment and flat houses?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Disclosure of a secret alliance between Germany and Italy constituted the most important development in the Venezuelan situation to night. This fact has been made known to the British Ambassador, and it will, put all of the negotiators more closely on their guard in the drafting of the protocols which they' hope to submit to Minister Bowen during the next few days.

Opposition to the garbage crematory which it is proposed to erect near the Southern Boulevard and One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street has reached fever heat through that region of the Bronx, and property owners and residents, many of whom have their all invested in their little homes, declare their intention of fighting the project by every means at their command.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter characteristic of the writer and of the class he represents appeared in last Sunday's TIMES concerning your article in THE TIMES of a recent date about the case of Col. Lynch, who was tried and convicted of treason to Great Britain, and signed I. M. Wall.

DISTRICT ATTORNEY JEROME has spent part of a flight in a prison cell. How the present Prosecuting Attorney of New York was locked up in a cell, and how he was brow-beaten by a policeman, forms a chapter in his life which last week he wase forced to make public.
ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- As a result of the Republican bolt in the Senate, the Assembly has this year become the burial ground of legislation which the leaders do not desire enacted.
I'VE been thinking." said the Poet to the Editor, "I've been thinking that -- what are you doing?"

Schedules in bankruptcy of Cummins Stockbridge, exporters and importers, of 11 Broadway, with offices in London, Paris, Hamburg, and Sidney, who were petitioned into bankruptcy in August last, were filed yesterday. They show liabilities to the amount of $1,177,188, nominal assets to the amount of ,$722,712, with actual value of unpledged assets $100,000.

The firemen of the Borough of Manhattan were kept busy for two hours last evening responding to ten alarms in various parts of the city between the hours of 5:30 and 7:30 o'clock, as the result of nine small fires. Two alarms were sent in for a fire on the second-story rear of the Demorest Building, at 114 Fifth Avenue, where the firemen experienced much difficulty in locating the fire.

Much of the opposition to the Marshall bill, which practically repeats all tenement laws in existence since 1867, originated in Brooklyn, where many supposed the measure would have little or no effect. But now that the bill is practically dead. Senator Marshall having abandoned it, various Brooklynites will continue their efforts to bury it and to defeat any other schemes calculated to hamper the operations of the De Forest tenement house law.

England and the Dardanelles. Although Russia's new policy in the Balkans still remains enigmatical, and will probably so remain until the joint note of Austria, and Russia concerning the project of reforms in Macedonia shall have been made public, some idea of what the Dardanelles, affair means may be gathered by a review of Russian diplomacy touching that question since the signing of the original agreement of the powers in 1841.

THIS is the story the Captain told me as we sat in the club window watching the girls go by. It is true that the Captain has just returned from duty in the Philippines, that he bears a cruel scar between his eyes, ana that I would unhesitatingly take his word for any amount you care to name; still -- well, the Captain can speak for himself.

A MAN can't go around buying castoff clothes many years without running up against some queer experiences," remarked the "cash clothes man," as he fumbled through the pockets of a suit which he had just purchased for $1. "Of course. I don't expect to find anything -- nothing except maybe some old letters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have withheld favoring you with the following until the present that it might not be said that it would in any measure come in contact with the inquest now before the arbitration commission. That commission having gotten well along in its useless inquiry, almost any truth may now be told without any effect.

SHORT-SKIRTED costumes are now used almost entirely for morning and street wear. Younger women usually wear them when walking and even women quite along in years have adopted them for both shopping and exercising. Many of these costumes are made up in corduroy, especially for the younger girls, who prefer the deep reds, bright blues, and rich greens.

BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- It was not formerly the custom to draw the person of the ruler of Germany into the debates of the Reichstag, but all this has been changed since Wilhelm II. came to the throne. The Emperor in recent years has repeatedly formed the subject for discussion in the German parliament.

To The Editor of The New York Times: It is to laugh, and who can help it? If any of your unbiased, readers have not found any hing among your "Nuggets" this morning to cause a smile to o'erspread their countenance, let them read the following taken from the Courier des Etats-Unis of Feb.3:

To the Editor of The New York Times: With respect to the many recommendations for the immediate and ultimate relief of the much-talked-of troubles in the street car and elevated railway service. I would like to offer a few suggestions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Wednesday's TIMES was an editorial on the murder of a non-union miner of the name of John Smith. The title of that editorial was " A ' Union' Murder," and the inference is left that the men who committed the murder did so because they were union men, and in the cause of unionism. To this I take issue.

The difficulty experienced by the managers of the track team, baseball team, and rowing crew of Harvard to get candidates from whom to make satisfactory selections, owing to the preference of the undergraduates for basket ball, hockey, lacrosse, and fencing, is perhaps significant of a wholesome change in the character of college athletics.
LONDON, Feb. 7. -- There was an active demand for money in the market to-day, though the pressure was slightly lighter Discounts, consequently, were firm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- It can be stated by authority that, unless anti-trust legislation, at least reasonably satisfactory to the Administration, is enacted at the present session, President-Roosevelt, on March 5 will call an extraordinary session of the Fifty-eighth Congress. The President himself has told members of Congress of his desires and of his determination in that regard.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- William J. Bryan today declared that he would refuse to attend any banquet to which Grover Cleveland is to be invited. Col. Bryan's declaration was made through an intimate friend to the officers of the Iroquois Club, which intended to invite Bryan, Cleveland, and other Democratic leaders to a banquet to be held on the anniversary of Jackson's birthday, March 16.

The two performances at the Opera House yesterday afternoon and evening were attended by many thousand people. At both, in fact, the house was filled as it has not been many times this season, and at both repetitions of uncommon interest were given. In the afternoon there was a "double bill," including" La Fille du Regiment" and "Pagliacci."

While nothing new developed yesterday in regard to the installation of an American League baseball club in this city, the matter was thoroughly discussed in local circles and the general impression is that President Ban Johnson will surely fulfill his promise of having a baseball team here during the coming season.

Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, heard argument yesterday on an application for writs of habeas corpus for the discharge of nine men who were arrested in raids made by the Society for the Prevention of Crime on alleged poolrooms at 44 Grand Street and at Bedford Avenue and South Eighth Street, Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing an article in your paper criticising certain amendments to the Tenement House act and mentioning certain bills introduced by Mr. Ellis to amend said act, I respectfully request that this communication be given equal prominence with the article in question.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7. -- Rear Admiral Frank Wildes of the United States Navy died suddenly on board the steamship China yesterday morning. He was on his way home from China, on sick leave when death overtook him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through all the voluminous comment going the rounds of the American press anent the present Anglo-German alliance, one note is predominant, viz., that England as a country is opposed to the doings of the British Government in this matter on account of friendly feeling for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Fred C. Postal, President of the Washington Baseball Club, who arrived here to-day from Detroit, announced positively that Delehanty will be kept with the Washington Club, and that Ryan also will be signed again. "I have letters," said Mr. Postal. "from six of the eight club managers offering to take Delehanty off my hands, but I propose to keep him."

The weekly Clearing House statement issued yesterday was wholly and unexpectedly unfavorable, though the most unfavorable item was largely of a technical nature. This was the increase of $20,447,900 in loans, and is explained to be due in large measure to the change in the capital of the Weatem National Bank from $2,000,000 to $10,000,000, this change having become operative during the Week.

SHE was a social belle of Cincinnati before her marriage, and after it one of the leaders and a patroness. At the wedding, which, was a very fashionable one, she received innumerable presents, consisting of many duplicates. It is the penalty one pays for having big weddings.

It must have occurred to many of the frequenters of the Opera House since the present season opened -- and the thought has been emphasized during the week just passed -- that there is an almost shocking disparity between the artistic value of some of the voices and personalities of the company and the operatic works in which it is possible to employ them.

SAY!" said the ticket chopper wearily, "if you think that it's a cinch and that I'm not earning my pay at this job just you stand here and watch me work. I'll bet you wouldn't take the job for $5 a day.

BERLIN, Jan. 23. -- The Oberlandesgericht, an appellate Court of Prussia, has sustained the objection of the Police President of Berlin against the presentation of Paul Heyse's great drama, "Mary of Magdala." In October the District Court of Berlin overruled the objection of the Police President, and gave permission for the production of the play.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Cabinet dinner given this evening by the Postmaster General and Mrs. Payne in honor of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, like that given last week by the Secretary of the Navy, proved to be one of the very brilliant functions of the Winter. Owing to the size of the party the dinner was served in the private parlor of the Arlington Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- While the House has been debating the much talked of Littlefield Anti-Trust bill, which nobody expects to see enacted into law, the real anti-trust work of the session has been done in the conference committee on the Department of Commerce bill, consisting of Senators Nelson, Hanna, and Clay and Representatives Hepburn, Fletcher, and Davey.

The stock market last week exhibited a desire to get out of its rut. There has been, a little broadening out of speculation, and while it is still professional and largely artificial, there has been a decided improvement in sentiment and a movement toward a higher level of prices.

WITH the possible exception of the theatres occupied by German-speaking actors, and the attempt made many years ago to establish a French theatre, the opening of the new Grand Theatre on Thursday night marked the culmination of efforts designed to provide a playhouse in this city for plays in a foreign tongue.

There were good speeches good wine, and good people at the annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee in the Waldorf-Astoria, last evening, but they are not new for Genesee dinners. The speakers in cluded George van Skal, editor of The New Yorker Statts-Zeitung, a native-born German, who told how German Americans were real Americans and would not be found of doubtful allegiance if any occasion to test them should ever arise.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Lord George Hamilton, the Indian Secretary, spoke at Bradford to-night. The Secretary was present at the Cabinet meeting this morning. In his speech this evening he said he sincerely hoped that in the course of a very few hours the Venezuelan controversy would be concluded.

PASSAIC, N. J., Feb. 7. -- Prof. Lawson Hermann, a hypnotist, put Samuel Powell to sleep in a coffin at the Empire Theatre on Thursday. He was to awaken him last night at midnight. A big crowd was on hand to witness the reawakening of Powell, but the professor failed to put in an appearance.

In the expectation that there wag to be a conference of State leaders yesterday, there was quite an assemblage of Republican politicians at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Senator Platt had expected to meet Chairman Dunn of the State Committee on Friday night and to breakfast with him yesterday. But through some misunderstanding Col. Dunn did not arrive until yesterday afternoon, several hours after Senator Platt had departed for Washington.
THE professional joke writer picked up his trusty pen and wrote:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -- With weather conditions that were ideal for golf a mixed foursome was played on the links here to-day. The silver medal for the best gross score was won by H. P. Dixon of Huntingdon Valley. Penn., and Mrs. James W. Scully of Pittsburg, with 87. H. M. Boals and Mrs. Thomas McKee of Pittsburg won the bronze modal for the best net score -- 69 strokes.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- All London was startled on Monday by the newspaper announcements placarded in the largest type throughout the city "Illness of King." Ill-luck seems to dog the foot steps of the King since his accession.

YOU Northern fellows don't understand the relations of the whites and the blacks down South," said Senator McLaurin of Mississippi, who had been discussing the Indianola incident in his committee room. " Explain it to you? Lord, no; it would take too long to explain it to a Northern, man, and after I'd got through you wouldn't believe me.
Little Willie (at the breakfast table) -- I want to see the valentine Mr. Squeesicks gave Maud.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 7. -- The lawyers of the ex-Crown Princess of Saxony to-day received a telegram from Dresden definitely refusing the Princess's request to be allowed to see her sick child under any circumstances.
The general balance sheet of the Manhattan Railway Company, as of Dec. 31, as filed in Albany, was made public yesterday. It shows as follows:

A good deal of interest attaches to the speculation as to what will come of the effort of the Rhode Island Chapter of the Society of the Cincinnati to secure a new tune for America by the offer of a gold medal to the successful competitor for the approval of the Committee of Award and their advisers.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7. -- When Sheriff Bell galloped home an easy winner in the Clubhouse Handicap to-day he placed $1,500 to the credit of his owner, M. L. Hayman. Fuller picked the best going for him, and when called on he came away without an effort, winning by four lengths. Paramount was sold to-day for $1,500 to J. P. Gibbs.

Money nominal at 3 per cent, on call. Stocks firm. An unfavorable bank statement and activity in the Gould stocks, especially Wabash, preferred, were the only points of interest in yesterday's stock market. The former was worse than had been expected, although a loss in cash and probably in surplus was anticipated.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- George Fleming's adaptation of Rudyard "The Light That Failed," was produced at the Lyric Theatre to-night with decided success. Forbes Robertson as Dick Hilder, and Gertrude Elliott as Daisie, brought out the pathos and human interest of the novel, the plot of which was followed faithfully throughout the three acts.

ATTENTION for the moment is turned on New Orleans, where Miss Alice Roosevelt will be the truest of Mr. and Mrs. McIlhenny during the Mardi Gras festivities. New Orleans is a city or clubs. The Boston Club is the oldest and corresponds to the Union of this city. The Pickwick was for years its rival, and in old days the Louisiana was the meeting place for all the young set of bloods.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- Regarding the reports which have appeared in the American press to the effect that differences of opinion exist between the Minister of the Interior and the Foreign Office as to the readmission of American insurance companies, the Foreign Office has asked your correspondent to say that the Minister of the Interior, Posadowsky, who is a man of liberal ideas, is willing to settle the question.

To the Editor of The New York Times. If anything were needed to establish the character of THE TIMES for the higher qualities, the assumed partial absence whereof is lamented by J. M. Wall in his letter in your issue of this date, such need would be more than supplied in the simple fact that you published it.

New Yorkers will have a chance next week to view the largest ocean-going steamship ever constructed. The vessel which holds this proud distinction is the giant Cedric of the White Star Line, which is scheduled to sail from Liverpool next Wednesday for New York.

ANSONIA, Conn., Feb. 6. -- That 90 per cent, of women drawing Government pensions prefer $8 a month to a husband, is the assertion of local pension agents, and their statistics appear to bear out the statement. It is also noticeable that the few who have remarried have taken as their husbands veterans who are themselves receiving pensions.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The month's turn brought little relief to the money market, which had been unable to repay fully the large amounts borrowed from the Bank of England during the last days of January. Discount rates consequently showed a slight hardening tendency, which would have had a more pronounced effect but for the strong Continental demand for English bills, rates in Paris and Berlin being less remunerative.

Byram W. Winters, a clerk in the Custom House Service, in charge of the Customs Bureau at the Post Office, was arrrested yesterday morning by United States Marshal Henkel on a charge of embezzling $8,683.40 from the receipts of his department during the last Seven years, and was held in $10,000 bail for the United States Grand Jury by Commissioner Shields.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is evident that the people of Connecticut are not going to tolerate the interference of lawless gangs with the transmission of public utilities, and the dispatching of troops by the Governor of that State to Waterbury, where men are now on strike, indicates clearly that there is an unmistakable determination on the part of the civil authorities to uphold the majesty of the law.

That William Hooper Young, who was put on trial last week for the murder of Mrs. Anna Pulitzer, had formed a fool-hardy plan to escape from the Tombs by the aid of another prisoner became known yesterday through a statement of Assistant District Attorney Studin. Young's fellowprisoner, it was said, betrayed him to Dr. Campbell, the physician in the city prison, who divulged the secret to Mr. Studin.

Published by Arrangement with The London Times. DURING the past year the foreign powers have, with hardly an exception, continued to advance the work of programmes which have been previously announced. The French programme, which extends to 1906-7, has already had several of its features altered, and, owing to modifications of policy introduced by M. Pelletan, it is highly probable that several of its provisions will not be fulfilled by the dates originally fixed.

More than a hundred members of the General Association of Graduates of New York State Normal Schools -- the teachers of teachers -- dined in the St. Denis Hotel last evening, the occasion being their fourteenth annual reunion. Changes that have come about in the methods and character of teaching, conditions that the normal school instructor works under, and the compensation the labor brings were discussed after the dinner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been a great deal of recent discussions in the press and elsewhere concerning the druggist. He has been arraigned as an unprincipled substituter, a careless dispenser, a purveyor of contraband liquors, and denounced as "guilty of unnumbered crimes unwhipped of justice," and now some wise woman steps forth and recomands that he be licensed, like his brother, the saloon keeper.

The development of rioting as an adjunct and accompaniment of the street car strike is an interesting phenomenon. In Montreal on the 5th inst. a meeting of street car employes was held. It remained in session until midnight, when a strike was decided upon, and the dispatch states it as a matter of course that "rioting by the striking employes and their sympathizers began promptly after midnight."

The first week's play in the tournament for the championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, ended last night with the game between C. F, Conklin of Chicago and Dr. L. L. Mial of this city. Conklin won the contest by a score of 300 to 248.

JHE landlady said it was no use to expect her to say a word till she had bathed her forehead with camphor. "I am so upset that I can't talk now," she gasped. Later on she declared that it was the most glaring imposition she had ever heard of.

BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- The only unmarried American woman who was presented at the Kaiser's Court last Friday evening was Miss Nelly Lytle, daughter of Judge Lytle of Delaware, Ohio. This was an exceptional honor, for only in rare cases are untitled persons admitted to the aristocratic Berlin Court.
When Dr. Zamenhof, a Polish M. D., was eight years old his mind began to be troubled at the confusion of tongues in and around his native village, which is near Warsaw.

Battlesign, the bay gelding with a mark of 2:13 1/4 who was purchased at last week's sale by Dr. A. D. Krahmer, has been turned over to the care of Trainer Isaac Fleming, who will prepare him for the 1903 circuit. Dr. Krahmer has great faith in the horse, which took the first heat in the ten-thousand-dollar M. and M. Stake at Detroit in 1900.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 31. -- Member of the California Sportsman's Club say that the flocks of wild geese that have been coming down the coast from British Columbia and the North Pacific Islands during the last few weeks are the largest known in this region for seven of eight years.

Polo playrs who expect to compete in the annual championship games must be careful hereafter to see that they play at least six games from the first of each year and before the championship tournament on the grounds of the club from which they intend to enter. Failure to do this by Lawrence Waterbury of the Lakewood team has cost the latter club the championship emblem for the current year.

Guided perhaps by the knowledge that Police Capt. Miles O'Reilly, all his detectives, and a large proportion of his uniformed force were engrossed with the Arion ball at Madison Square Garden, a little party of expert safe burglars seized the occasion Friday night to organize a successful carnival of their own in his precinct, and are a few thousand dollars richer in consequence.

FISHES have held a very important place in the world's attention almost from the beginning of time. The oldest folk-lore extant, the Buddhist, abounds in morals and significances drawn from the finny tribe, and one of the oldest of worships, the Phallic, finds under the symbol of these creatures a conspicuous expression.
EVERY, Wednesday morning Miss Sterling gets a letter from her niece. Janet Sterling, who lives in Meadville, Penn. In one of these letters Janet said:
To the Editor of The New York Times: By chance this morning picked up a TIMES of Jan. 18, Sunday, and I cannot express with what pleasure * * * I read the "Topics of the Drama." * * *
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Recent additions to the New York colony are Mr. and Mrs. Oliver H. P. Belmont, who are at the Hotel Royal Poinciana, paying their first visit to Palm Beach.

TWO hundred acres of Long Island sand a wedge of land close to the waters of Hempstead Bay and near Valley Stream and the Cedarhurst of polo playing, are to be made productive this coming Spring, raised from practically waste ground to a high degree of fertility within a few months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The taxation question is again being made the all-important one in New York State legislation this year, as it has been for a number of years past. It is accurate to state that most of these measures affect the City of New York as now constituted, and indirectly affect each and every inhabitant of the city.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7. -- Columbia's basket ball team defeated Harvard on the Crimson's own floor to-night in one of the fastest, roughest, and most exciting games that has ever been seen in Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Polygamy was discussed in the Senate to-day in connection with the Omnibus Statehood bill. The charge was made that the Mormon Church has not really abandoned the practice, and opposition to the bill declared there were Slot sufficient safeguards against plural marriage in the proposed States.

Commissioner Thomas B. Connery of the Board of Education expressed some of his views yesterday concerning public school problems. He has been a member of the board for a year, and in that time he has formed ideas in regard to the management of the schools which differ considerably from the views of the majority of his colleagues.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7. -- Ideal weather conditions, a big crowd, superb ice and large fields in all the events, with exciting finishes, combined to make the speed skating championships of America held here to-day under the auspices of the Amateur Skating Association of Canada and the National Skating Association of America, a great success.

The students of the Stanhope-Wheat-croft Dramatic School on Tuesday afternoon will give three-plays, the first of which is "Cupid's Messenger," a romantic play in one act by Alfred C. Calmour. The casts is as follows:

District Attorney Jerome yesterday followed up his denunciation of Capt. Schmittberger by declaring that he did not believe the Captain would be appointed to an Inspectorship. He spoke with the air and assurance of a man who had good authority for what he said, and at any rate made it perfectly plain that there would be no cessation in his fight against the Police Captain, no matter what turn events might take.

HOOSICK FALLS, N. Y., Feb. 7. -- Railroad officials have come to know Hoosick Falls as a place filled with coal thieves, and the business of stealing coal from passing freight trains has been developed almost to a science since this season's scarcity first began to affect the neighborhood. The robberies grew in extent until finally somebody pilfered a whole carload of anthracite.

No opposition has thus far appeared in local golf circles' against the application of the Deal Golf Club for this year's metropolitan championship tournament. So far as the expression of opinion from many leading players goes there seems to be little doubt that the aspirants for the local championship will meet on the popular 18-hole course near Deal Beach, New Jersey, either in May or June.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7. -- The third class of midshipmen, consisting of 124 members, was restricted this afternoon to the Naval Academy grounds. The Superintendent had demanded of this class specific promise that they would cease further molestation of the "plebes," or fourth class men.

Interest in the Bible study conference, called by the Council of Seventy to meet in Chicago on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday next, has increased considerably since the publication of comments. The Council is connected, in a way with the University of Chicago, but Prof. Frank K. Sanders of Yale is the acting President of it.

The word "Finis" can be written soon on the last page of the history of the city season of 1902-03. The Charity Ball has been held and the last large dance has taken place. Perhaps between now and the Carnival-seidom celebrated in New York-there may be arranged some very important function.

PERU. -- The Peruvian Government has granted Marconi the privilege of his inventions; it has also granted a group of capitalists a concession for an electric and trolley system between Lima, and Chorillos, with a maximum fare of 20 cents Peruvian money. It will be concluded in two years.

A case was decided in the Supreme Court of the United States last week which is of more than ordinary interest, since it settles a disputed point in the theory and law of copyright on which strange views had prevailed not only in the public mind, but in the minds of the Judges of the lower courts.

There is a convention of educators and business men in session at Ann Arbor, Mien., which was addressed on Friday by JAMES B. DILL, Esq., of this city. We gave yesterday a pretty full report of his interesting address. It ought to be instructive to the educators who listened to it because it is the well-weighed view of a man of ability and wide experience.

WHEN one orders a plate of soup in the dining room of a large New York hotel, it is hard for him to realize, even after his friend the chef has told him, that the plate contains one portion out of in aggregate two hundred gallons that are prepared in the same hotel for dinner every night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Littlefield anti-trust bill was passed by the House today in the same mechanical fashion in which it bad been debated by a unanimous vote of 245 to 0. The amendments made were of no particular importance. The Democrats endeavored to make several radical changes, but were always beaten on a party vote.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 5. -- During the reconstruction period in South Carolina, which followed the close of the civil war, the management of State affairs for a time was left to the tender mercies of the negro. Officers who served with the Governor were negroes, there were negro Judges, and practically every county in the State had its black representatives in the General Assembly.

It appears to be the policy of those who have the management of lawn tennis affairs to keep their, plans as secret as-possible. This has always teen so, especially in the case of the international events. Of course it would be somewhat premature to designate a place for holding the challenge contests for the Dwight F. Davis Cup before the receipt of the formal, document from the English Lawn Tennis Association.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- There is a serious controversy between Prof. Delitzsch and Prof. Hilprecht. Delitzsch and five other German Assyriolpgists state that it is untrue that Prof. Hilprecht was engaged for fourteen years in the excavations at Nippur, made by four American expeditions.

On Broadway, at Forty-first Street, at 9 o'clock last night, a thief wrested from Mrs. Lee M. Brewster of Washington a chatelaine bag containing a $500 Government bond, $7.50 in cash, a gold watch with the initials "L. M. B.," and a number of visiting cards. He escaped, but was forced to throw away the bag, which was recovered.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial with the caption, " Local Option in Vermont," in the issue of Feb. 5, you say, " We should like to believe that the motive has been an abhorrence of the meanness and hypocrisy inevitably and invariably induced by a nominal prohibition which cannot be made effective."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The President of the United States has invitations to take part in every description of enterprises, from the publication of a book to becoming a stockholder and Director in gigantic corporations whose only existence is in the minds of the individuals who design them.

Tale's hockey players, the Intercollegiate champions, were defeated last night by the Princeton team at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, the score being 4 to 1. The game, which was one of the intercollegiate championship series, was decided in the presence of the largest and most enthusiastic gathering of followers of colleges athletics that has visited the big rink this season.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 7. -- The Philadelphia and Langhorne Street Railway Company has filed notice of a proposed extension over the turnpike from Somerton to Feasterville and Willow Grove. The maps cover a line from Morrisville via Langhorne to Somerton, where connections will be made with an extension of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company's lines for Philadelphia.

In the Pratt Institute gymnasium, in Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, last night was given the first public demonstration of a new game, invented by Dr. J. M. Voorhees, Physical Director of the institute, and called ring hockey. Two teams, representing respectively the freshman and sophomore classes of the institution, played a spirited game of two halves of twenty minutes each, the freshmen, winning by a score of 12 1/2 points to 5.

NEW ORLEANS. Feb. 7. -- Col. P. N. Wicker, United States Appraiser, died today. He was born in Akron, Erie County, N. Y., in 1838, and served as Second Lieutenant in the Twenty-eighth New York Volunteers, and subsequently with the Signal Corps during the civil war. He was second in command to Col. Buckley in the Passo-American telegraph expedition to Alaska in 1867, and wrote articles upon the Bering Sea seal fisheries.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 3. -- With the departure of the last of the German troops today for Kiautschou the evacuation of Shanghai by foreign force is completed. The process has occupied something more than a month.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 7. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press returned here yesterday from Helsingfors. He found the measures for the relief of the distress in Finland to be apparently excellently organized. The distribution of funds is carefully supervised. The Finnish National Relief Committee has received up to the present $16,000 from American relief organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Preparations are being made to give to Gen. Booth of the Salvation Army an enthusiastic reception upon his arrival here on Tuesday next. The General is now in the South visiting cities in that section in furtherance of his religious work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In rejoicing editorially this morning: over the retirement of J. Edward Addicks, Delaware's perpetual candidate for the Senatorship, you are, unfortunately, over-hasty. It is dollars to doughnuts that the crafty gentleman is dissembling, and that the Addicksite proposition to name Senators in joint caucus is a Trojan horse that the regular Republicans are justified in scrutinizing with extraordinary care.

Mr. JOHN D. CRIMMINS'S project of roofing over the lower reservoir in the Central Park and making an addition of its area to the available surface of that pleasure ground is as public-spirited as might be expected from its author. But it is complicated, in his presentation of it, with another proposition which has nothing necessarily to do with it, and which is even incompatible with it.
ACROSS the deck appeared the swarthy face of the leading boarder. His eyes had a fierce glare. "Draw! " I cried.
Antoinette Szumowska, the pianist, now Mrs, Josef Adamowski, after several years' absence from New York, will give a recital in Mendelssohn Hall on Saturday afternoon, March 7.

President George Cromwell of the Borough of Richmond, has declared squarely and finally in favor of retaining the Staten Island terminal of the ferry from Manhattan in its present location at St. George instead of removing it to Tompkinsville, as advocated by Henry H. Rogers, the Standard Oil capitalist and trolley magnate of the island, and by many of the residents.
Mayor Flavius O. Heal has been nominated by the Republicans of Bangor, Me, for his seventh term in his office.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- A recount of the votes in the Sixth Congressional District was ordered to-day by the Election Commissioners in the contest brought by Allan C. Durborow, Democrat, against William Lorimer.
WEEK'S CALENDAR. MONDAY -- Princess, Amelia Bingham in a new Fitch play, "The Frisky Mrs. Johnson." Fourteenth Street, Andrew Mack in "The Bold Soger Boy." Circle, reopened with vaudeville bill.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are wont to boast of our progress in civilization, making our progress in applied science and art synonymous with that social condition. Nothing, however, could be more fallacious, nor could the confounding of any two conditions be more misleading.

President George Cromwell of the Borough of Richmond, has declared squarely and finally in favor of retaining the Staten Island terminal of the ferry from Manhattan in its present location at St. George instead of removing it to Tompkinsville, as advocated by Henry H. Rogers, the Standard Oil capitalist and trolley magnate of the island, and by many of the residents.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 7. -- An ambitious scheme for the development of this resort is taking shape. It is backed by a syndicate of railroad men and, inferentially, by the Pennsylvania Railroad. It has for its object the solution or the rapid transit problem along the ocean front and the development of the beach front all the way from the Inlet to Longport.

BOSTON, Feb. 7. -- The week closes with the money market fairly easy, though rates show hardly any change from those of a week ago. Call loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 4 1/4@5 per cent. Time loans, mercantile paper, 4 1/2@5 per cent. Clearing House loans, 4 per cent. New York funds, 5@10 cents premium.

Of all the influences now at work to create new areas of activity and new avenues of travel -- and never have there been so many as at present -- none can be of greater interest than the approaching completion of the new Williamsburg Bridge, because it means that five years hence a large section of the city, now a world into itself, will be traversed by thousand daily.
PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Charles M. Francis, former United States Minister to Greece, and family are stopping here on their way to New York.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been interested in the correspondence which has been appearing in your columns on the above subject.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7. -- The Shawinigan Falls-Montreal electric power transmission line, eighty-four miles long, was put in operation to-day. The work of construction has been rushed since it began last August, and bonuses for the early delivery of materials and machinery have hastened the completion of the line.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- An invention which seems to go far in simplifying photographic processes has been made by Prof. Ostwald and Dr. Gross of Leipsic, and, has attracted much attention in scientific and photographic circles here.

To the Editor of the New York Times: Permit me to state that I am heartily in favor of District Attorney Jerome's bill before the Legislature permitting the opening of saloons on Sundays between the hours of 11 A. M. and 1 A. M. It is needless to state that the present Raines law, known as the excise law, is the most iniquitous law that was ever placed on a statute book.

CAREFULLY worked out and being held in readiness for the early days of Spring, its details fully planned, is the New York Health Board's anti-malaria campaign. Little has been made public in connection with it, which is strange, for the movement is far-reaching, decisive, and radical in the extreme.

Four out of the six bills announced for the week at the Metropolitan Opera House will be devoted to Wagner. On Monday evening "Tristan und Isolde" will be performed, with Mmes. Nordica and Schumann-Heink as Isolde and Brangaene, Mr. Anthes as Tristan, Mr. Bispham as Kurwenal, and Mr. Edouard de Reszke as King Marke.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Serious railway accidents during the last few months, accompanied by loss of life, physical injury, and damage to property, are in almost every instance traceable to the indefiniteness and insufficiency of Rule 90 of the Standard Code, which says:

The Stage Society of London has just produced Ibsen's "When We Dead Awake" at Mrs. Langtry's Imperial Theatre. The condemnations of the London critics, if not more spirited and efflorescent in verbiage than those of the New York critics on "Ghosts," is quite as unanimous.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7. -- A 25 to 1 shot, Horton, the grandson of El Rayo and Fusillade's Last, carrying the colors of Bianchi McGovern, won the $10,000 Burns Handicap at Ingleside to-day from one of the best fields that ever contested in the event. Cunard of the Morris stable was second, with Claude, owned by M. J. Daly, next in line.

THAT famous billionaire, Mr. Keyworth Joynes, President or the Cake Trust, was preparing to leave his office at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, the financial centre of the city, for his residence in Chicago, now extending all around the shores of the Great Lakes, and the favorite dwelling place for people of fashion.

For the purpose of formulating plans to relieve the famine-stricken population of Northern Scandinavia and Finland, a meeting was held last night by representatives of every Swedish organization and many of the Swedish churches in Greater New York, at which the preliminary arrangements were made for a large benefit concert to be held either at the Metropolitan Opera House or Carnegie Hall on March 22.

A GOVERNMENT bill has just been presented in the Belgian Senate which contains a clause fixing certain penalties, including imprisonment, upon any one convicted of "uttering obscene cries, songs, or discourses." In the debates which followed the presentation of the measure the Opposition pointed out that nothing could be more dangerous than to create a law which which might put an instrument.

Through a suit brought by David C. Johnson in the Allegheny County Court at Pittsburg against the estate of Theodore Hostetter one of the most remarkable stories of gambling that has ever been truthfully told has been revealed, showing that the young millionaire of Pittsburg, owing to a passion for gambling, lost to the gamblers of New York in one year something like $1,000,000.

King's Crown, the general undergraduate society of Columbia University, has started a movement in regard to the granting of college insignia, which, if carried through, will prove a decided innovation at the Morningside university. In the past the Columbia insignia, consisting of the "Varsity C," the 'Varsity and class stripes of blue and white, and the class numerals, have been the only insignia granted to Columbia undergraduates, and these exclusively to members of athletic teams.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, who often is credited with having instigated the appointment of the Lexow Committee, yesterday sent a letter to Police, Commissioner Greene in which he takes up the case of Police Capt. Schmittberger, and declares it to be his belief that the Captain's record since he was a witness before the committee has been such as to entitle him to appointment as an Inspector.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- The Rev. T. T. Clay, a professor of Semitic languages and archaeology at the University of Pennsylvania, who is associated with Prof. Hilprecht in the work of deciphering the cuneiform inscriptions, when seen to-day regarding the attack of the Berlin Assyriologist, Prof. Delitsch, upon Prof. Hilprecht's work at Nippur, said:

A five-minute speech by Gen. Leonard Wood was the feature of a mass meeting for men only held under the auspices of the West Side Branch of the Young Men Christian Association at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The great hall was filled, orchestra, boxes, and galleries, and when Gen. Wood came to the front of the platform the audience rose as one man and cheered.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Entries for the American Derby of 1903 have closed with 120 nominations, the pick of Eastern and Western three-year-olds being named as possible starters for the Washington Park Club's great classic. The race, which is at a mile and a half with $25,000 added money as the rich prize, will be run on the first day of the Washington Park meeting next June.

After long litigation, the affairs of the firm of G. Edward Graff Co., stock brokers, who failed about two years ago, have been wound up and a settlement made with the creditors of the concern. The firm was composed of G. Edward Graff and ex-Fire Chief Thomas Nevins of Brooklyn. The principal customers of the firm were Brooklyn, politicians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer who signed "W.J.W." in a communication entitled "Possibilities of the English Language," which appeared in your edition of the 31st ult., is evidently handling tools with which he is unfamiliar, and consequently meets the fate which usually overtakes artisans of his character -- he cuts himself.

Mr. LITTLEFIELD'S Anti-Trust bill, which the House passed without a dissenting vote, seeks to restrain corporations and combinations declared to be unlawful by prohibiting inter-State commerce in their products. We need not now inquire whether the Senate is likely to pass this bill.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Our social and political welfare could be vastly strengthened by the regulation of two vital questions:
The annual convention of the Independent Order Free Sons of Israel, having a membership of 50,000, was held at Terrace Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The Acre dispute has caused considerable interest here, and the news that there is a prospect for its settlement without recourse to war is exceedingly gratifying to all concerned.

An American dramatist of some prominence has been at pains recently to explain the methods pursued by successful playwrights in their efforts to supply material for the theatre. His generalization and conclusions, based not only on personal experience, but upon a careful study of the works that have been most successful, resolve themselves in a statement that the playwright, practically speaking, works in exactly the opposite direction from that of the novelist.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was very nice of Lord Charles Beresford to tell us a few evenings ago all about the Monroe Doctrine, and also how the two great English-speaking nations of the world should "get together." Some of us might fear that such a partnership on the part of Great Britain would be an attempt at the interesting game of "heads I win, tails you lose."

That most popular form of track competition, relay racing, will be the main feature of the games of Columbia University, which will be held at the armory of the Twenty-second Regiment on the afternoon and evening of Feb. 28. The relay part of the programme will include the following events: One-mile intercollegiate, two-mile intercollegiate, one-mile National Guard, one-mile athletic club, and one-mile inter-company, open to members of the Twenty-second Regiment.

Arrangements were completed yesterday for an inter-city doubles match, at handball between Dr. Shea and James Dunne, Jr., of Brooklyn and "Mike" Egan, the world's champion handball player, who will have James Flaherty as a partner. The last two will represent Jersey City, and the first half of the home-and-home match will be decided at Egan's Mercer Street court, Jersey City.

Green leaves and pale blue velvet are combined in a round turban that is one of the new hats. The crown and deep rim are covered by the leaves, while around the crown, just inside the rim and showing above it, are folds of the velvet. More of the velvet is looped toward the front and tacked flat at the back.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Feb. 8. -- According to reports brought back from Arizona the copper field which has been discovered there will far excel even the almost inexhaustible deposits in the upper peninsula of Michigan. It is said that several millionaires have taken up land in the vicinity of the find.

The Rev. Merle St. Croix Wright talked to an audience in Cooper Union last evening about what he said the church was doing to learn the needs of workingmen. The subject, which he said Charles Sprague Smith, the Director of the People's Institute, had chosen for him, was: "The Church and the Workingman," and the regular attendants of the Sunday evening lectures were present in somewhat larger number than usual.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The question of the possibility of ceding a small portion of the Erie Canal to the United States Government for ship canal purposes in spite of the prohibition of the State Constitution is answered in the affirmative by Attorney General Cunneen in an opinion forwarded to Major Thomas W. Symons, head of the United States Engineering Corps for this Buffalo District.

BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- An irregular tendency, accompanied by a diminished volume of trading, prevailed on the Stock Exchange last week. Domestic Government securities were slightly higher, while foreign loans were to some extent lower, owing to realization sales. Spaniards advanced upon purchases from Paris and Spain.

Public comment on the decision of the New Jersey courts disposing of the "strike suits" brought to restrain the United States Steel Corporation from carrying into effect the plan of converting its preferred stock into bonds all runs in one groove. There is everywhere a disposition to exchange congratulations that vexatious litigation of this character has been discouraged.

The retiring Regatta Committee of the Atlantic Yacht Club will have an interesting report to present before the annual meeting of the club to-night. The schedule of races adopted last Spring was carried out last season without a break, and several additional races were given. Fifteen races in all were sailed, including the ocean races, which met with an unusual amount of success, and the restricted class events for smaller boats.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 8. -- Harry Gilder, alias "Harry Smith," who is known to the police, led several Fourth Precinct men a lively chase to-day, during which he jumped through two windows in different houses, and was finally captured some hours afterward as he was about to jump from a third story window in a policeman's house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the citizens of this city are not heartily tired of the monkeying of the politicians and jobbers of the State of New York with the Erie Canal and its improvement is inexplicable on any ground other than that they are being fooled or give the matter no attention.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- Delegates from various street railway unions of the Old Colony and the Boston and Northern systems of the Massachusetts electric companies will meet in Boston to-morrow to take preliminary steps toward securing a substantial advance in wages, the recognition of their unions, and generally improved conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The universal opinion in Washington is that Minister Bowen, the representative of Venezuela in tie negotiations that have been in progress in Washington for some weeks, has conducted himself with rare ability and good sense and with the highest advantage to the Government he represents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The House will resume work on the appropriation bills this week. To-morrow is District of Columbia day. Beginning Tuesday the appropriation bills will be kept to the fore. The Sundry Civil and Naval Appropriation bills are both on the calendar. The former probably will be considered first.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 8. -- One year ago to-night the great fire which, on the late hours of the 8th and the early morning of the 9th, swent through the business section of the city, started causing a loss of more than $6,500,000. To-morrow night there will be a public meeting in Sons of Veterans Hall to celebrate the event.

With eleven games decided out of the twenty-one which make up the series for the National amateur championship 14.2 billiard turnament, those who have watched the efforts of the seven competitors during the past week are now figuring as to the outcome. The members of the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, must be congratulated on the successful progress of the tourney, which is being held in their well-appointed clubhouse at Rodney Street and Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

-- Compulsory pilotage laws have always seemed like legislative anomalies to lands-men, but their propriety has been taken for granted, and, as they were supposed in some mysterious way to increase the safety of sea travel, the landsmen have heard with entire composure the occasional growls of the ship owners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The representatives of the allies here are busily engaged in the preparation of the protocol which they are to sign with Mr. Bowen, Venezuela's representative, for the reference to The Hague of the question whether the blockading powers shall be entitled to preferential treatment in the settlement of their claims.

Worry over her continued ill-health is believed to have impelled Miss Elizabeth Shipley to shoot and kill herself yesterday at her home, 456 Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn. Miss Shipley was a daughter of Edward Shipley, a Brooklyn merchant, who died about two years ago. Since then Miss Shipley had lived with her sister, Miss Emma Shipley, in the Vanderbilt Avenue residence.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Augustus Thomas, the playwright, was arrested at his home here this evening charged with assault by Henry Sweet, editor of The Pioneer Justice Phelps paroled Mr. Thomas in custody of his counsel, J.J. Crennan, to appear to answer tomorrow morning.

No authoritative information has been given out concerning the measurements of the new cup defender now building at Bristol. Several descriptions of the new boat claiming semi-official inspiration have been printed. Such descriptions, however, can be regarded only as guesses, for as in the case of the Columbia and the Constitution, details of design will be jealously guarded.

Pennsylvania's ninth annual relay races will take place on April 25, and preparations are already being made by the management. This is necessary because of the great volume of work that is connected with these races. Below will be found the groupings for the coming races. The classes have been changed greatly this year.
The President ought without further delay to appoint a Postmaster at Indianola -- a white Postmaster.

TRENTON, Feb. 8. -- That pretty Dora Cooperstein here is a victim of witchcraft is firmly believed by herself and her parents. Dora is twenty-one years old, and a hopeless invalid with paralysis of the spinal column.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 8. -- To-day, the beginning of the fifth week of the strike of the men employed by the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company was extremely quiet. A light snow fell in the morning, which soon changed to a heavy downpour of rain, and this aided materially in keeping the people from the streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The publication to-day of the story that John D. Rockefeller had sent telegrams to a number of Senators declaring that the Standard Oil Company was opposed to the enactment of any anti-trust legislation and directing that all such legislation must be stopped created a decided sensation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- According to a dispatch from Mobile, H.F. Crosby, a negro, has been arrested for getting money from people of his race in furtherance of the ex-slave pension scheme. The method adopted by Crosby seems to have been much cruder than that adopted by the various "associations" which have been getting negroes to subscribe monthly sums to secure the passage of the bill.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Probably the most important of the bills to be introduced during the coming week in the Legislature will be the mortgage tax measure suggested by Gov. Odell in his annual message. Senator Green, Chairman of the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, says that the bill is ready for introduction, and he will present it in the Senate early in the week.

There is general dissatisfaction with conditions among the employes of the Manhattan Railroad Company, and it is said a strike may occur at any moment that will stop traffic on all the elevated lines. It is understood that motormen, engineers, firemen, guards, and "choppers" are interested in the movement, but that the porters and office men, who have organizations of their own, have not so far been invited to co-operate.
May Company, Cleveland, Ohio; W.C. Clark, domestics and wash fabrics; C.E. Carlson, furnishing goods: P.J. Dolt, laces, handkerchiefs, and notions; 704 Broadway.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Another of the moves in the present Legislature in the interest of a better understanding between capital and labor appears in a bill to be introduced tomorrow night by Assemblyman John S. Bradley of Erie. The measure is designed to create a co-operative insurance fund in certain perilous occupations and designates the State Superintendent of Insurance as the custodian of such fund.

Louis Mendel, fifty-five years old, of 234 East Eighty-sixth Street, was found murdered in the dingy little office of his scrap-iron yard, at 437 East Twenty-third Street, yesterday morning. Two blows of a hammer such as roofers use had crushed in his skull at the forehead and in the back.

Magistrate O'Reilly, in the Ewen Street Court, Williamsburg, yesterday held Mrs. Josephine Van Winkle, an eighteen-year-old actress connected, with a musical comedy company, in $500 bail pending a hearing to-morrow on the charge of bigamy. Her accuser was William Hughes, said to be a well-to-do traveling salesman of Blissville, L.I., where he lives with his mother.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The report that Gen. Uribe-Uribe has committed suicide causes considerable surprise here. After his surrender to the Colombian authorities he performed valuable services for the Colombian Government, inducing various guerrilla chieftains to desist in their opposition to the Government and to surrender.

It is not probable that the discussion now in progress in Indianapolis over the scale for next year will end in disagreement or be followed by a strike. In 1897 the price paid the miner for mining lump coal was 48 cents a ton. In the scale now in force it is 80 cents. This, however, applies to lump coal, the miners receiving nothing for slack.

The programme for Mme. Roger-Miclos's recital, which will take place in Mendelssohu Hall to-morrow at 3 o'clock, "has been somewhat changed. She will play Schumann's "Carnaval," Haydn's ''Ariette Variee." Chopin's impromptu in F sharp, a valse posthume, and the ballade in A flat; Ten-Brink's gavotte, (dedicated to Mme. Roger-Miclos,) Borbdine's "Au Couvent," Godard's fourth mazurka, and Liszt's Rhapsodie No. 13.

The Rev. Father Patrick R. Fitzsimmons, chaplain at Seton Hospital, Spuyten Duyvil, is charsed with assault on last Friday night by William Stuart, nineteen years of age, who lives with his grandfather, James Cooper, in what is known as "the Cooper House." Application was made in Morrisania Court yesterday morning for a warrant and a summons for the priest, but it was refused until the sole witness of the affair can be present.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The case of W. M. Byrne, who was nominated for District Attorney of Delaware, will be pressed before the Senate, notwithstanding the brief time that remains of this session, and in spite of the efforts of the majority of the Judiciary Committee to have the nomination withdrawn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Charles Moran, the crack short stop of the Georgetown College team, has signed with the Washington Baseball Club.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Assemblyman Hornidge at the Twenty-second Assembly District of New York City to-night introduced a resolution providing for a special committee of five to investigate the selection, purchase, and public use of textbooks in the schools of the State. It is aimed at the American Book Company, commonly known as the "Book Trust."

More than a score of detectives on special detail and all of the uniformed police force searched Greater New York from end to end yesterday for Joseph Rucco, the Italian suspected of murdering his employer, Louis Mendel, in the latter's office at 437 East Twenty-third Street on Sunday morning.
LONDON, Feb. 9. -- The supplies were light and money was in active demand in the market to-day. Business in discounts was poor.

BOSTON, Feb. 9. -- Upon application of Attorney Moorfield Storey, Judge Richardson this afternoon agreed to appoint a master in the case of J.F. Doherty and others vs. the Mercantile Trust Company of New York and others, a bill in equity to restrain the Boston Gas Companies from transferring certain shares of stock advertised to be sold in New York to-morrow.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 9. -- The study of French, which for a while was abandoned at the Naval Academy, has been restored to almost its former place in the course. Instruction in French was stopped when it was ordered that the date of graduation of all the classes be brought forward. This order has now, been changed, and only one class will now graduate sooner than usual.

Second Lieuts. William Fitzpatrick, Seventh Infantry, and George R. Crawford. Eleventh Infantry, will report to Major Robert H.R. Loughborough, President at the Examining Board convened at Fort Leavenworth, to determine their fitness for promotion.

William Hooper Young, who has been on trial before Justice Herrick in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court for the murder of Mrs. Anna Pulitzer, yesterday pleaded guilty to murder in the second aegree.

The notable event of to-day is to be the wedding of Baron Andre de Neuflize and Miss Eva Barbey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry I. Barbey, in St. Bartholomew's Church. Among the other entertainments are a card party in Mr. and Mrs. Walter Rutherfurd's house, a dinner in the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chishoim, Mrs. William H. Osgood's bridge party at Sherry's, and the concert for the Stony Wold Sanitarium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Discussion of the Statehood bill was continued in the Senate to-day. When the bill was taken up Mr. Kean (Rep., N.J.,) resumed his speech in opposition to it. Mr. Rawlins, answering some references of Mr. Kean to the Mormons, said that in Salt Lake City the non-Mormons are glad to aid in electing Mormons to important political offices because of their desire to give to the municipality good government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Senator Aldrich introduced to-day a bill which would make important changes in existing laws with regard to the deposits of public money with National banks. Section 5,153 of the Revised Statutes provides that all National banks designated as depositories shall receive on deposit Government revenues, except customs, and it also prescribes that Government bonds shall be deposited with the Treasurer as security for such deposits.

Seven members of the Board of City Magistrates, a bare Quorum, were present last night at the annual meeting of the Board, which was held in the chambers in the West Side Court House. Although it was the annual meeting, officers for the ensuing year were not elected, for when this order of business was reached Magistrate Zeller moved an adjournment, which was adopted without discussion.

There are persons who consider buckwheat cakes a plebeian dainty. That is because they do not know how much money can be put into the dishes in which they are served. A silver-plated buckwheat dish, with a cover, will cost $22.60 and one of solid silver $65. A silver-plated cover alone will cost $12.50.

The Democracy of Tilden was the spirit of the dinner in honor of the eighty-ninth anniversary of the birth of Samuel J. Tilden, given last night at the Tilden Club, Broadway, between Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth Streets. The speakers urged the Democrats to return to the platform of 1876, when Tilden was the candidate for the Presidency.

The two champion billiard players, Wilson P. Foss of the Amateur Athletic Union and Edward W. Gardner of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, were the victors yesterday in the seventh day's play of the championship tournament under the auspices of the latter organization, in the Hanover Club, Brooklyn.

LIVERPOOL, Feb. 9. -- The new White Star Line steamer Cedric, which is to sail from here Wednesday for New York, on her maiden voyage, will have among her passengers R. McCreery and Sir Cavendish Boyle, the Governor of Newfoundland.

-- As between the correspondent who implored us to begin a war on hand organs and the grinders thereof and the correspondent who begged us to do no such thing, we do not hesitate to proclaim that if the street musicians are safe from, any misfortunes and persecutions except such as we bring or take port in bringing, upon them, they may regard the future with perfect composure.

MANILA, Feb. 9. -- A force of 100 constabulary under Inspector Keithly yesterday defeated a body of 200 insurgents near Mariquina, a small town seven miles from Manila City, after a severe engagement, in which Inspector Harris and one man of the constabulary were killed and two other men of the constabulary wounded.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 -- Argument of counsel, which will bring to an end the anthracite coal strike arbitration, began today. Daniel J. McCarthy of Hazleton, Henry Deinarest Lloyd of Chicago, and exCongressman Charles M. Brumm of Minersville outlined the case which they thought had been proved for the miners.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Assemblyman Clark will not carry out to-morrow his threat to move in the Assembly for the discharge of the Committee on Cities from the further consideration of the bill prepared by Controller Grout, which provides a way in which the City of New York can obtain the use of the surplus moneys now paid into the sinking fund.

NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 9 -- Augustus Thomas, author of the play " The Earl of Pawtucket." appeared as a prisoner before Special Sessions Justice Edgar L. Phelps this morning, having been arrested on a warrant sworn out by Henry Sweet, to whom he dealt a blow on the neck just after churchtime Sunday morning.

A well-known ironmaster of the Cumberland district has published a report which will be read with interest at home, and we venture to say without consternation in this country. He is convinced that there is no place in the world better situated for ironmaking than the Middlesborough district, and that the furnace owners of that favored locality do not need to fear competition if they will utilize their advantages.

The public has received with grins of incredulity the story of Mr. ROCKEFELLER'S telegrams to Senators. It refuses to believe that the chief of the Standard Oil Company is quite so artless as all that. Nobody doubts that the very idea of anti-trust legislation is abhorrent to Mr. JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER. The Nelson amendment to the Department of Commerce bill, especially, must seem to him almost like a personal affront.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9. -- Dullness prevailed in the stock department to-day, but dealings in bonds were on a larger scale than for some time past, the transactions including the sale of a fifty-thousand-dollar block of Lehigh Navigation collateral trust 4 1/2 s at 102 3/4. Welsbach 5s developed weakness, declining a point.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- These bills were introduced in the Senate to-night:

Pease Elliman have sold for Major Gen. Charles F. Roe the four-story brick and brownstone dwelling 40 Fifth Avenue, 25 by 100. The buyer will occupy the house. The same brokers, in conjunction with De Blois Eldriage, have sold, for Major Gen. Roe to a client the four-story dwelling 10 West Eleventh Street, 25 by 94.10.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Scrubwomen have thrown down the mop in sympathy for their fellow-unionists and are now the recognized allies of the elevator conductor, window washer, and janitor in their strike which has inconvenienced tenants, employes, and the public in a number of downtown office buildings since last Friday.

Revelations of a wholesale traffic in Civil Service examination papers were made yesterday by District Attorney Jerome in the course of the trial in Special Sessions of Max Charles Benisch, a physical culture professor, formerly of 895 Third Avenue, who was convicted on a charge of agreeing to accept a fee of $400 for procuring an appointment to the Fire Department for Thomas B. Gavin, a cutter, of 93 Bedford Street.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- There were some sharp interchanges in the Assembly to-night over a resolution introduced by Mr. Rogers, the Republican leader, calling upon the State Engineer to furnish the Legislature with a revised up-to-date estimate as to the probable cost of the proposed improvement of the canals and for a lot of detailed information on the same subject.

WILMlNGTON, Del., Feb. 9. -- There was no serious effort at the joint session of the Legislature to-day to elect United States Senators despite all the hubbub that has been crested by Mr. Addicks's alleged withdrawal. The balloting showed no change.

The Elkins bill passed by the Senate last week without discussion or amendment is much stricter and more important than is indicated in the press reports. Its general aim is to prevent or punish discrimination or advantage given by common carriers to customers. Unquestionably such practices have been the basis on which the most objectionable "trusts," or monopolistic combinations, have been erected.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Conduct of the District Attorney's office of New York County in the prosecution growing out of the death of William M. Rice was criticised before, the Court of Appeals to-day. John C. Tomlinson and Edgar J. Kohley, counsel for Albert T. Patrick, obtained an extension of time in which to complete the papers in the appeal of Patrick from the verdict of murder in the first degree.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 9 -- In response to a direct inquiry as to whether he was a candidate or would accept another nomination for the Presidency, the following has been received from ex-President Grover Cleveland:
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a leader issued in your esteemed journal on Feb. 3, it was said:

MONTREAL, Feb. 9. -- At the meeting of the Board of Directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway to-day a dividend of 2 per cent, on the preferred stock and 2 1/2 per cent, on the common stock was declared for the half year ended December last. The report says that after the payment of working expenses, fixed charges, and dividends, there is a surplus for the half year of $3,202,907.

The number of stocks traded in yesterday in the outside market was considerably larger than those which figured in the trading on most of the days last week. At the same time the transactions in various parts of the list outside of the raining stocks assumed larger proportions, so that the total for the day compared favorably with recent records.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- When Secretary Shaw came out of the White House this morning after seeing the President he looked around for his hat and did not find it. Then he looked-for the hat that most resembled his own, and examined its interior. It bore the initials "T.C.P." in gilt letters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- After the reading of the Journal in the House to-day Mr. Richardson (Tenn.) took exception to the presentation of the conference report on the Department of Commerce bill at yesterday's memorial session. He contended that the action of yesterday was. void. The Speaker ruled that it was regular.

Unquestionably the existence of an organized tribunal such as is provided by The Hague Conference is proving itself a practical aid in preserving and in securing peace. The incidents that have arisen in connection with the Venezuela matter might readily have had a different course and a very different outcome if the tribunal had not been already in existence and in working order.

A conference lasting for two hours took place yesterday between a sub-committee or the Grievance Committee of the motormen employed on the Manhattan Railway Company lines and Superintendent of Transportation Smith and other officials of the company. Both sides after the conference was over said that there was no trouble with the motoriwen, who when the road was operated by steam power were engineers and are still members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.

Senator John W. Russell of the Nineteenth District took to Albany yesterday a bill that provides for the creation of a Board of Railroad Commissioners of the City of New York. It is to be introduced in the Senate. It proposes, the, following as an amendment to the New York charter:

DENVER, Feb. 10 -- By quo warranto proceedings, which were begun in the District Court to-day, the State seeks to annul the charter of the American Smelting and Refining Company, and to prevent it from further operating in this State unless it pays its taxes. This is the case in which the validity of the flat tax law will be tested.

Several complaints have reached this office concerning the operations of the National Meter Testing Company, which has offices in the basement of 130 East Twenty-third Street, near Lexington Avenue. Jastrow Alexander, State Inspector of Gas Meters, has been flooded with similar allegations of peculiar dealings, and in some of these harsh charges are made.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 10 -- Charles F. Hoffman of New York has purchased of the Trustees of the estate of the late George W. Wales the property known as Edge Cliff, at the end of Yznaga Avenue, on the Cliffs. The estate adjoins that of Mrs. Victor Sorchan and the late Christopher M. Bell, and is near the William Waldorf Astor estate and the property purchased by E.C. Knight, Jr., of Philadelphia.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 -- The Boston coppers were not as buoyant as they had been during the previous few days, although they were very active.
