More or less realizing was apparent, but the stocks held up well. Copper Range was especially strong, and made a new high quotation. The money market is quiet, with money rate's unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The President to-day nominated Regis H. Post of New York to be Auditor of Porto Rico.
Capt. Samuel E. Allen, Artillery Corps, is detailed as a member of the examining board convened at Fort Sheridan, vice Capt. Lucien G. Berry, relieved.

The annual report of the People's Gas Company for the year ended Dec. 31 was made public yesterday. The figures were considered rather disappointing, in that, while the Street had been led to expect some very large increases, the increase in surplus was but $61,634, or only about one-fifth of 1 per cent, on the stock.

Wilson P. Foss, the three-year Amateur Athletic Union billiard champion, and Dr. L.L. Mial were the victors yesterday in the championship 14.2 billiard tournament in progress at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players. Dr. Mial won his game in the afternoon, beating Ferdinand Poggenburg by 300 points to 286, while Foss defeated J. Byron Stark in the evening by 300 to 148 points.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 -- The attempted advance of Seaboards was the most interesting phase of to-day's trading. A closer study of the company's report, showing the expenditure of large sums on improve- ments, had a favorable effect on sentiment, due to the belief that the system is adding to its earning capacity.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Feb. 10 -- Marie Cahill made her first appearance to-night in "Nancy Brown" at the Lyceum Theatre here. There was a large audience. Many New Yorkers were present. When Miss Cahill had finished singing "On the Congo" the audience demanded a speech. She responded modestly.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- There was some realizing in the stock market to-day, but with the exception of the arbitrage stocks, which eased off in sympathy with New York prices, held well. The only features were the demand for the Asphalt issues and the persistent buying of Philadelphia Company by houses representing inside interests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Great Britain's protocol has been formally accepted by Mr. Bowen for Venezuela. The German and Italian conventions are still undergoing revision, but assurances are given in authoritative quarters that they eventually will be made to conform in all essential respects with that of the British Ambassador.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 10 -- The Quebec Steamship Company's steamship Madiana, Capt. Frazer, which sailed from New York last Saturday with a party of excursionists for a special cruise around the Caribbean Islands, went ashore on the reefs off this island at 3 o'clock this morning.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- When a man disappears and is lost track of by his family and friends for seven years, he is considered legally dead, and any property in which he has a life interest may be distributed among the lawful heirs, but if he holds a fee interest in real estate there is no provision in the New York law by which his heirs can gain possession of that property.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The Assembly Committee on Cities reported favorably to-day the Finch bill reorganizing the Police Inspector system of New York City. It creates the office of Chief of Inspectors, makes assignments, of Borough Inspectors, and an Inspector of Detectives.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Gov. Odell left this city for Washington to-night, having been called there by President Roosevelt. He expects to spend three days at the National Capital. He will discuss with the President matters of Federal patronage, and will also give the President his view of the political situation in this State as it bears upon the chances of the President's renomination and election.

The inquest into the death of Detective Sergeant Welsh of the District Attorney's office, who was shot in the Black Cat restaurant a month ago during a quarrel over the price of a dinner, was brought to a close yesterday, with a verdict in which the jury failed to fix responsibility for the death of the detective.

At the sale in Mendelssohn Hall last night of the collection of David C. Lyall of Brooklyn nineteen water colors, eighty-five oils, and one pastel sold for $251,045. The hall was crowded with dealers, several collectors and a throng of sightseers when Thomas E. Kirby began auctioning off the collection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The persistency with which the affirmation has been made that Speaker Henderson is opposed to trust legislation, and that it was through him the amendment proposed to be offered in lieu of the Nelson anti-trust amendment to the Department of Commerce bill was sent to the conferrees on that measure, has drawn from Mr. Henderson a general denial of the allegations implied in these statements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Apropos of the steps being taken by the Government here to reform the Philippine currency, are Consular reports from Siam, the Straits Settlements, and Indo-China on changes, present or prospective, in monetary standard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Statehood fight took on a new phase to-day by the determination of the Democratic Senators to filibuster against the compromise which is being patched up. Senator Quay yesterday gave his friends on the other side of the Chamber notice that he should not op- pose the passage of a bill making one State of New Mexico and Arizona and ad- mitting Oklahoma without Indian Territory.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- An important conference to consider the tax legislation proposed by the Governor was held this afternoon in the Executive Chamber. Gov. Odell presided over the conference. There were present Lieut. Gov. Higgins, Speaker Nixon, Senators Raines and Malby, and all of the members of the Taxation Committees of the two houses.

Deputy Superintendent AINSWORTH represented the interests and views of the State Department of Public Instruction at the hearing upon the Merritt bill before the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly at Albany on Wednesday last. He expressed himself as having a very poor opinion of the Regents of the University and of the smaller high schools of the State, which have had such remarkable growth and development under the Regents' protecting care.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Senator Eisberg today introduced a bill which amends the banking law so as to provide that trust companies may be able to loan money on first mortgages up to 66 per cent. of the value of the property on which the mortgage is given. Under the existing law they can loan only up to 50 per cent. of the value of the property.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Assemblyman Prince to-day introduced a bill in the Assembly the object of which is to make representatives of organized labor officers of the State in strike difficulties. It provides that the Commissioner of Labor may during strikes, upon the written application of one or more duly organized labor organizations, appoint not more than ten special Deputy Factory Inspectors who are members of labor organizations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Stockholders of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway today voted to increase the capital stock of the company to $100,000,000. The Directors were authorized to issue common stock from time to time in such amounts as they may determine and for any purpose allowed by law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill was taken up in the House to-day, and Chairman Cannon explained in a general way why it carried an increase of $17,500,000 over the appropriation for the current year. The total of the bill exceeds $78,000,000, and when completed by the Senate it would not be surprising if the aggregate should reach a round $100,000,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Assemblymen had a short and sharp dispute to-day over Mr. Rogers's resolution calling for up-to-date figures from the State Engineer on the cost of a 1,000-ton barge canal. They then passed it unanimously.

Conditions in the outside market yesterday were practically a repetition of those which had governed the market on the previous day, and nowhere in the list were there any developments of a kind to attract special attention. As for some time past, the larger part of the day's transactions was supplied by the mining stocks, most of which of course are copper shares.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Chairman Bedell of the Assembly Committee on Railroads today introduced the bill which provides for the $25,000,000 terminal improvement plan of the New York Central Railroad Company in New York City.

It is by no means news that a man may have very striking gifts of literary expression without on that account being possessed of sound judgment in the ordinary affairs of life. But it must be lamented by a wide circle of readers that it should be at the expense of Mr. RUDYARD KIPLING that this moral should just now be pointed.

"With this key," sang Wordsworth of the sonnet, "Shakespeare unlocked his heart." Browning quoted the line, and added, "The less Shakespeare he!" Perhaps; but the artist nature has always delighted to expose its innermost feelings to the public view. Mrs. Browning herself published this "Sonnets from the Portuguese."

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the decisions of the courts below dismissing the complaint in the case of Judge James N. Veazey against the brokerage firm of Henry Allen Co. of New York City, which grew but of the investigation of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company and the American Sugar Refining Company, commonly termed the "Whisky and Sugar Trust," by a Con- gressional committee in 1893.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Controller Grout's secretary, Mr. Hervey, came to Albany, as he stated, to have some verbal corrections made in the Controller's Sinking Fund bill. He took occasion, however, to learn what he could about the Assembly embargo against the various measures being urged by the Controller.

Everything indicates that the stringency of the coal situation is permanently relieved. The retail price of anthracite is now $6.50 per ton, and will probably remain at that figure for the remainder of the Winter unless a blizzard or some other accidental cause temporarily interrupts the movement of coal by rail.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- "Jack" McCulloch of Winnipeg was awarded the five-mile professional skating race held on Flower Lake in this village this afternoon. Norval Baptie of Bathgate was second. John Nilssen of Minneapolis, who defeated these skaters at Montreal Saturday, was disqualified by the judges for haying skated inside one of the blocks marking of the track.

Stocks reactionary. Again a cheerful day is succeeded by a confused, reactionary market. Clearly, the present situation has not stamina equal to a two days' effort. The favorites Monday were stars again yesterday, but the interest in the performance was perfunctory.

Advices from Bristol last night, based on reported authoritative information, give the following figures as the dimensions of the new America's Cup defender: Length over all, 141 feet; beam, 28 feet 8 1/2 inches; draught, 19 feet. The Columbia's dimensions are: Length over all, 132 feet, beam 24 feet inches; draught, 20 feet.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The collection of revenue continued to denude the market of money, the demand was prisk, and borrowers were increasingly dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts consequently were firm.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Total resources of the savings banks of the State on Jan. 1 were $1,191,327,573, an increase during last year of $59,762,949, according to a statement issued to-day by Bank Superintendent F.D. Kilburn.

In his latest report President ELIOT of Harvard lays great stress on the necessity of bringing education to a term at an earlier age than at present. He holds that the school course should close at seventeen or eighteen, the college course at twenty or twenty-one, and the professional training at twenty-four or twenty-five.

Word was received yesterday by Blumenthal, Moss Feiner that the Court of Appeals had affirmed judgment of the Appellate Division and the Special Term of the Supreme Court of this county, setting aside the will of Peter Fuchs, the brewer, who died about four years ago, after having spent many years in charitable and missionary work on the east side of this city.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- The United Mine Workers of America, as an organization, were severely scored to-day by counsel before the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission. The non-union men, through their attorney, John T. Lenahan, presented their side of the controversy and demanded consideration at the hands of the commission, claiming the legal right to earn a livelihood as they might elect, without the consent or dictation of the union.
From a friend who went to the Criminal Courts Building in a state of high excitement, District Attorney Jerome yesterday received information of a plot to assassinate him.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 -- Co-operative book-making on turf investment business which is said to have drawn from the savings banks of this city alone upward of $3,000,000 had come to a disastrous set-back here to-day. The result was due to the announcement yesterday that the Arnold Turf Investment Company, pioneers in the "get-rich-quick" business, had suspended payments of stock certificates.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- I have heard on excellent authority a story which throws light on the Grenadier Guards scandal, which has deeply stirred the English public, and may be made the subject of Parliamentary action.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 11 -- Pleasant springlike weather and a track that is rapidly improving are causing much activity at Churchill Downs, and from now until the Spring races begin, provided that the bad weather does not set in, there will be much work among the horses at the famous course.

The reported purchase by the Trustees of the proposed Rockefeller Laboratory of the plot of land lying between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-seventh Streets, Avenue A, and the East River, if correct, means that the Pastime Athletic Club will have to vacate the property which it has occupied for some twenty-six years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Statehood bill was discussed in the Senate to-day by Mr. Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) and Mr. Depew, (Rep., N. Y.)

BOSTON, Feb. 11 -- As a result of the amending of the Constitution of the League of American Wheelmen at the session of the National Assembly here to-day, there are now but five divisions in the organization. This was brought about by the adoption of legislation providing that divisions shall be discontinued when the membership shall have fallen below 100.

BANGOR, Me., Feb. 11. -- Liquor dealers of Bangor, who for twenty-five years have enjoyed wide-open privileges with a fine of $100 and costs once a year as the only penalty for violation of the organic law of the State, are in a state of panic to-night. A decided setback to their cherished institution, "the Bangor plan," was given in the Supreme Court to-day by Justice Spear.

Mr. ROOT'S declaration that he has no intention of immediately or soon leaving the Cabinet will be commonly accepted as expressive of an intention to remain until the close of the present Administration. According to present political indications, that means an agreement to remain for that period, "with the privilege of renewal."

HAMILTON Bermuda, Feb. 11 -- Capt. Frazer, the second officer, and the native pilot of the Quebec Steamship Company's steamship Madiana, which ran on a reef off this island early yesterday morning, remained in a whaleboat by the ship last night. The vessel was pounding heavily when the tugs left her yesterday with the passengers, crew, mails, and baggage, and it is feared that her bottom is destroyed.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- There was a warm discussion before the Assembly Codes Committee to-day on the Burke bill to permit the playing of amateur baseball on Sunday. William S. Hubbell, representing the New York City Sabbath Committee; the Rev. I.W. Hathaway, representing the American Sabbath Union; J. Talmadge, representing the Christian Endeavor societies; A.A. Robinson of the New York State Sabbath Association, and Assemblyman Jean Burnett appeared in opposition.

"You go first," said Miss Helen A. Taylor," Immigration Inspector No. 1, to Miss Matilda Wichmann, No. 2. The ladder leading from the revenue cutter to the deck of the steamship Ivernia was in front of them. Half a dozen cameras were leveled in their direction from the other end of the cutter -- a fact that seemed to disconcert them not at all.

In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the Fidelia bowlers won two of three games with the Union team. The tie for eighth prizes in the American National tournament between the Phoenix and the Belvidere teams was also decided, the former winning by a score of 1,842 pins for two games to 1,767 for the latter. The scores follow:

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- In the Senate to-day the bill introduced by Senator Fancher in relation to the consolidation of domestic and foreign railroad corporations came up on the order of third reading, and Senator Fancher moved its passage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Germany has ignored her previous agreement made with Mr. Bowen by Count Quadt, her Charge d'Affaires, and has insisted on a cash payment of $340,000 or a lien on the customs receipts of one of the Venezuelan ports until this amount is paid. This information was communicated to Mr. Bowen tonight by Baron von Sternburg, the German Minister.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The House today, on motion of Chairman Cannon, placed on the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill two paragraphs which appropriate over $6,000,000, of which $2,000,000 will be used to extend the Capitol buildings and $4,000,000 to construct an office building south of the Capitol Park for the accommodation of the members of the House.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Local securities were dull. There was some little strength left over from yesterday in Box Board issues. Lake Street sold at 71 1/2. Union Traction sold above 11, but later slipped back to that figure. Match slipped off again to 139 after fractional advances. South Side Elevated shares were in demand at 110. Time and call loans, 5 to 6 per cent. New York exchange not quoted.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Among the many innovations in the management of the State prison is the request of Head Keeper Osborne, made to the Board of Inspectors yesterday, whereby he desires to subscribe to the weekly newspapers, periodicals, and monthlies for the promotion of reading among the convicts.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Gov. Odell was sharply assailed in the State Senate to-day for his, reappointment of H.H. Bender of Albany to be Fiscal Supervisor of State Charities for five years. Senator Grady, the Democratic leader, declared that the Governor was using the Charities Department for political ends and that the retention or Mr. Bender was an insult to the people.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- On Monday night there was a dinner in honor of Thomas Jefferson, given by alumnae of the University of Virginia at the New Willard. One of the speakers was Gen. Basil W. Duke of Kentucky, who served with Morgan's Rough Riders in the Confederate Army.

Yesterday's market resembled its predecessor. Some early strength passed into midday irregularity, which became weakness toward the close. The Eries displaced Rock Island as the most active security, upon intimations regarding an important statement, which may be found in another column, and an exceptionally good quarterly report of earnings.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The demand for money was keen to-day, and there were indications in the market that the scarcity was increasing. Discounts sympathized with the money conditions.

Secretary of the Treasury Shaw responded to the toast "The President " at the thirty-first annual dinner of the Silk Association of America at Delmonico's last evening. He dealt with the responsibilities of the Chief Executive of the Nation, his power, and the dependence of the Nation's free institutions on the President.

Soon after the reassembling of the Legislature each year we begin to hear of bills which, whatever their immediate purpose, would have as their ultimate result an increase of political control over the educational system of the State. Sometimes these measures provide for an extension of the powers of the State Superintendent of Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Mme. Calderon, wife of the Minister from Peru, entertained this evening at a small dance, at which the 200 guests were from the younger ranks of society, the occasion being complimentary to Miss Roosevelt, who is a friend of the debutante daughter of the hostess. The Peruvian Legation, at 1,701 Massachusetts Avenue, is one of the largest of the foreign houses.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Financiers representing the savings banks of the State assembled to-day at the hearing before the Senate Committee on Banks on the Marshall bill prohibiting department stores, trust companies, and any othor concerns from advertising to do or doing a savings bank business as defined by the banking law.

According to Boston dispatches the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of that city will shortly petition the Gas Commissioners for authority to issue new stock to capitalize recent purchases of suburban electric properties.
LONDON, Feb. 12. -- Mme. Therese Humbert's description of her relations with M. Cattaui, the money lender, greatly amused the court yesterday, reports the correspondent of The Times at Paris.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Representatives of union labor took a decided stand to-day against the enactment of the Hughes bill providing imprisonment and fine for any person, corporation, or association that shall discriminate against a member of the National Guard in the matter of employment.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- The members of the Humbert family made their first appearance in the criminal courts to-day when the case of M. Cattaui, was taken up in the Ninth Correctional Chamber. There was great public interest manifested in the proceedings, the court room being packed with people.

The Supreme Court of Massachusetts has handed down four opinions adverse to the whole principle and policy of municipal trading. These opinions were called out by legislative inquiry. What was sought to be learned was whether a city or town might, within its constitutional powers, buy and sell wood and coal for the benefit of its citizens.

Bellevue in all the years that it has ministered to the suffering and sorrowful rarely sheltered a more pitiful case, say those who know it best, than was thus entered upon its brief official records yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The House Committee on Printing gave a hearing today to Representative Henry C. Smith of Michigan on his resolution inquiring into the matter of printing and distributing Richardson's compilation of the volumes known as "Messages and Papers of the Presidents" by the so-called Bureau of National Literature.

William C. Adams has sold the three and four story buildings, 116 to 122 West Forty-second Street, on plot 50 by 98.9. The price is not made public, but is said to be record figures for that section of Forty-second Street between Sixth Avenue and Broadway.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 11 -- A special dispatch from Birmingham Ala., says it is officially announced that the Seaboard Air Line has completed all arrangements for entering this city. For some time the matter of securing rights of way between Birmingham and Irondale, seven miles distant, hung fire through the difficulty of getting the necessary privileges at Woodlawn, an intervening town.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 11 -- The death yesterday of Capt. William Hudson, who for forty years had made Pensacola. Fla., his home, amassing a fortune here in the saloon and soda manufacturing business, brought to light to-day the fact that he had, during his long residence here, been going under an assumed name.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- President Schurman addressed the students of Cornell University to-day upon the typhoid lever epidemic now raging in Ithaca. He gave out that among the students there were to-day sixty-two cases receiving treatment in Ithaca, of which only seven were considered serious, while between 150 and 200 students have been sent to their homes by physicians upon the appearance of fever symptoms.

Two tickets were put in nomination at the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Yacht Club last night at the Clarendon Hotel. On the understanding that Commodore Henry R.M. Cook would not accept a reelection the Nominating Committee put C. H. Humphreys at the head of the regular ticket.

A dozen canvases by Henry W. Ranger light up the gallery of Arthur Tooth Sons, 299 Fifth Avenue. Forest interiors, view of bare fields, and glimpses of seaports and marines without ship or shore have each a different suggestion, but each and all would never make one think of the Holland scenes by which Mr. Ranger first made an impression on New York.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 11 -- A bill authorizing baseball in cities was defeated in the State Senate to-day during an exciting session. It was really killed through the influence of the wife of Senator William H. O'Brien. Because of a pledge made to her he refused to vote when his name was called, and the total vote resulted 24 to 23.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Gov. Odell came to Washington this morning and took luncheon with the President. Afterward he went to the Capitol and visited both houses, greeting many of his old friends. He was the guest of honor this evening at the annual dinner given at Harvey's. Every year the Governor comes to Washington to dine with his old friends in Congress, particularly those of the New York delegation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Senate today ratified the Alaskan boundary treaty.

Capt. Morris K. Barroll, Artillery Corps, is relieved from further treatment at the general hospital. Washington Barracks, and will return to his proper station for such duty as he may be able to perform.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Some unofficial correspondence has been exchanged between Oxford and Cambridge Universities and Harvard and Yale, indicating a willingness on the part of the American Universities to challenge the Englishmen to an athletic meeting. No challenge, however, has yet been received, and it is doubtful if the English universities could accept.

Dogs won their way easily and quickly into favor yesterday with the New York populace. Despite the lack of cheer out-of-doors, all was animation and life within the Madison Square Garden, where the Twenty-seventh annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club opened at 10 o'clock in the morning and will continue during the remainder the week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- The principal brief of the argument for the Beef Trust case was filed in the United States Circuit Court today, and the whole case is now before Judge Grosscup for consideration. It is possible that a decision will be given next week.

There was more fun than real sport at the St. Nicholas Rink last night during the hockey game between Columbia and Princeton. There was little real hockey displayed. It was a rough-and-tumble go-as-you-please game, and although Columbia showed much better form than her opponents, the score at the end of the game was 2 to 2.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Trading in local stocks to-day hardly deserved the name, so dull and featureless was it. The sales amounted to only 17,839, while the net changes in prices were limited almost wholly to eighths and quarters.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Vice Chancellor Emery late yesterday afternoon signed an order which prevented a meeting of the Greater New York Home Oil Company for the election of officers. According to a bill just filed in the Court of Chancery, the present officers intended at yesterday's meeting to vote their stock so as to perpetuate themselves in the control of the corporation "to the irreparable injury of bona fide holders of the stock."

The "iron ball," which in police parlance means a shake-up, rolled yesterday in the Tenderloin. It hit two Roundsmen and four plain clothes men who had been attached there. The order for their transfer was issued by Commissioner Greene after he had held a consultation with Chief Inspector Cortright, Acting Inspector Walsh, and Capt. Miles O'Reilly.

PHlLADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Counsel for the coul operators to-day continued to arraign the miners union in their arguments before the Anthracite Strike Commission., The independent operators of the Lehigh, the Wyoming, and the Lackawanna regions held the attention of the Commissioners for the greater part of the day, the proceedings concluding with the presentation of the Reading Company's argument by Simon P. Wolverton, the company's chief counsel.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Good roads advocates brought forth their plan for improvements of the State highways to-day. Senator Armstrong introduced a resolution providing for an amendment to the Constitution which would permit the State to incur an indebtedness of not more than $50,000,000 at any one time for such purposes.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- These bills were introduced in the State Senate to-day:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11 -- It was announced to-day that the Storrs lectures for the year 1903-1904, in Yale Law School, will be delivered by Sir Frederick Pollock of London.

The hopes on behalf of Mme. RogerMiclos, the French planiste, that were raised high by her excellent performance of SaintSaens's G minor concerto at her debut last week, and again by her playing of Liszt's Hungarian fantasie on Sunday evening, were considerably disappointed at her recital yesterday afternoon at Mendelssohn Hall.

Amid decorations of the college colors hung from the galleries of the walls of the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria and the sounds of the college cry of "Cornell, I yell, I yell Cornell!" encouraged by hundreds of fashionably gowned women observing the scene from the boxes, the annual dinner of the Cornell University Alumni took place last night.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 -- The market today gave further evidence of the home traders' fear of the possible mishaps of a serious turn in Wall Street. The prevalence of the notion that the New York market is artificial has led many here to believe that the early sequel to the metropolitan situation will be collapse.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- In the Senate to-day these bills were passed:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 11 -- "Everything settled. You have Olympic games," is the wording of a cablegram received to-day from Michel La Grave, Wold's Fair Commissioner at Paris, France, by the Louisiana Purchase Exposition officials.

The plan for the financing of the important needs in the way of improvements of the Erie Railroad Company, which has been under consideration for some months, was made public yesterday. It consists of a bond issue, convertible into common stock, of $50,000,000 authorized amount, of which, however, only $10,000,000 is to be issued at once.
F. Schaeffer has resigned as St. Louis Special Agent of the Queen Insurance Company.

-- A dispatch from the little Wisconsin town of Trempealeau, which we published yesterday, announced that the people living there are planning elaborate entertainment for the President of the French Republic if he carries out his rumored purpose, after visiting the St. Louis Exposition, of making a pilgrimage over the routes and to the sites about which cluster memories of the days when France had a great empire in America.

It is likely that the bill presented by Senator ALDRICH relating to deposits in the National banks is all that can be expected from Congress in the session which is now drawing so rapidly to a close. It is worth while, therefore, to examine the probable working of that bill and see how far it can be relied on to meet the needs of the business community.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 11 -- The greatest thing in Kansas City -- chief maker of Kansas City, its prophet, apostle, and crowner -- is:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A rule will soon be brought into the House for the Elkins bill. The present intention is to hustle it through, and there will probably be only a few hours debate on it. There will be little opposition, although the Democrats will utilize whatever opportunity is given them to ridicule the measure as harmless and to make fun of the alleged interference of the Standard Oil Company.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- The Court of Appeals has handed down an important decision in the action begun by the State to recover penalties from the Arctic Freezer Company of New York City for the possession of game out of season. The decision, while not wholly in favor of the State, sustains the propositions of the fish and game law, prohibiting the possession of certain game out of season.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- At the Court House at Hudson to-day the property of the Albany and Hudson Railway and Power Company was offered for sale and was bid in by Charles H. Werner, representing Sheehan Collins, attorneys for the Colonial Trust Company of New York, holders of the mortgage of $2,500,000.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11. -- Hundreds of persons who had invested their savings in the " get-rich-quick " concern known as the E.J. Arnold Turf Investment Company learned that they had thrown their money away. Attempts which had been made to convince the people that the concern would pay its obligations were abandoned and admission was made that it was insolvent.

Senator Culiom, from the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, has reported an amendment to the General Deficiency bill providing for the payment of $5,000 to the Italian Government on account of the killing of two Italians in a riot at Erwin, Miss., In 1901.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 -- Little or no change is noted in the local money market. Call loans, 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 1/2 @ 4 per cent.; New York funds, 15 cents premium. Clearings, $24,458,224; balances, $1,036,713.

Edward W. Gardner of Passaic still leads the field of contestants in the amateur championship billiard tournament now in progress at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn. He won his fourth consecutive game yesterday, in brilliant style, defeating Arthur Townsend of the Hanover, Club by 300 to 164 points.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 11 -- James L. Kernan, who controls four theatres in Baltimore and one in Washington, has just bought from S.A. Wegfarth of Buffalo, N.Y., the Empire Theatre in Washington and the historic Front Street Theatre in this city, where the Booths, Rorrest, John E. Owens, and other famous actors achieved their earliest successes.

The second annual dinner of the Chicago Society of New York was held last night at Delmonico's. More than 300 men and women were present, and the men were not in a large majority. Among the raised guests table, surrounded by wreaths of flowers, was a row of red electric lights. Behind the table was Daniel Huntington's famous portrait of Lincoln, loaned by the Union League Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

The annual meeting of the New York Yacht Club, held last night at the clubhouse in Forty-fourth Street, was largely attended. Retiring Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard presided, and after the meeting congratulations were extended to his successor, Frederick G. Bourne, whose flagship this year will be the steam yacht Delaware.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12. -- Treasurer Adams of Harvard College states-that-work will begin in the immediate future on the proposed Harvard Medical School buildings in the Back Bay Fens. The architects, Shepley, Rutan Coolidge, are at work completing the plans, several changes having been found, necessary since the project was first outlined.

A shake up in the Detective Bureau and one in the Tenderloin precinct and a letter from Capt. Schmittberger defying his critics to prove anything against him since the Lexow investigation enlivened Police Headquarters yesterday.
CARLISLE, Penn., Feb. 12. -- The fifteenth annual commencement of the Carlisle Indian Industrial School was held at this place to-day.

First Lieut. Samuel Hot, Ordnance Department, will make not to exceed four visits during each of the months of February, March, and April to the works of the Builders' Iron Foundry, Providence, R.I., on business pertaining to the inspection or ordnance material in process of construction.

Holiday strollers through the Tenderloin were thrown into wild consternation at 10:30 o'clock last evening, when two reputed gamblers met before Proctor's Theatre, at Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street, and without wasting any time in preliminaries opened fire upon each other with revolvers in the thickest part of the crowd.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- The demand for money increased in the market to-day on account of Stock Exchange payments. Discounts were maintained. They had an easier tendency at first, owing to hopes of a reduction of the Bank rate.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Senator Whitlock to-day introduced a concurrent resolution, which provides for the increase of the salaries of members of the Legislature. Under the Constitution the Senators and Assemblyman each receives a salary of $1,500 a year. Senator Whitlock's resolution provides that Senators shall receive a salary of $5,000 a year and Assemblymen $3,500 a year.

The third annual dinner of the Italian Chamber of Commerce in New York, known officially as Camera di Commercio Italiana, in the Hotel Savoy last evening had several surprises, including the absence of Ambassador des Planches of Italy, and the address of James B. Reynolds, who, as the representative of the Mayor, praised the excellence of the Italian as a bootblack, while paying tribute to his civic virtues.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Another woman-and-child labor bill introduced to-day by Senator Hill forbids the employment of any female in occupations using any emery, corundum, or stone-polishing machine, and adds to the labor law a section forbidding the employment of children under sixteen in any factory at work dangerous or injurious to life, limb, health, or morals.

"Organized labor" has never put itself, not even in the outrages committed with its approval or connivance during the excitement of a strike, in so wretched a plight as the people who speak in its name at Albany are trying to put it in by insisting upon the right of trades unions to punish their members for doing their duty as citizens in the ranks of the National Guard.

Four new flags were displayed on the City Hall yesterday by order of Mayor Low. One flag, the fifth of a new set, was not hoisted, and in its place the municipal emblem which has done duty for several years was flying. That caused comment, but an explanation was forthcoming. The order had been given to Felix Fennel, who was the lowest bidder, for the new flags.

Now what, in these days of "ocean greyhounds" and vertiginously rapid trains, when a trip Around the World in Eighty Days would be considered slow by the ambitious globe-trotter on record breaking bent, could a Poet of the Ideal say that is not banal on the essentially commonplace subject of travel?

Managers of corporations, whether they be engaged in the sinful practices of trusts or are doing inter-State business in solitude and innocence, will be interested to know what is going to happen to them under the publicity amendment to the act creating the new Department of Commerce at Washington.

ALBANY, Feb. 12.-- Recommendations of the State Board of Railway Commissioners for better service on the Metropolitan Street Railway lines in New York City have been drawn and it is expected that the report will be made public to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 32. -- The distinguishing rule of the Senate, which makes that body the perennial forum of untrammeled and unrestrained speech, were severely strained to-day by the disposition of Senator Morgan to take his time in explaining his opposition to the Panama treaty.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12. -- With weather that was nearly perfect for golf the qualification round of 36 holes for cups offered by Joseph Jefferson and H.R. Rea of Pittsburg were played on the links to-day. There were about fifty entries, the first sixteen of whom qualified for the Jefferson cup and the second sixteen for the Rea cup.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 12. -- George F. Ketcham's world champion trotter Cresceus, owing to the slushy condition of the ice, did not trot against the record here to-day. The fact that he was booked to do so drew out a crowd of some 5,000 spectators. The horse gave an exhibition mile in 2:27.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12. -- Not a favorite finished first to-day. The Stewards have ordered the refusal of entries of all horses from the E.J. Arnold Company and other co-operative racing firms, pending positive proof that such horses are the individual property of the parties officially registered as owners.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Archbishop Ireland of St. Paul was the guest of honor at a banquet given at the Auditorium Hotel tonight by the Lincoln Club, in commemoration of the ninety-fourth anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln. In an address on the great emancipator Archbishop Ireland said, in part:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Bids were opened at the Navy Department to-day for supplying 5,666 tons of armor. The Carnegie and Bethlehem Companies presented precisely similar bids, the prices asked ranging from $400 to $420 a ton, making the total of each bid $2,333,640. The Bethlehem Company alone bid for the supply of 132 tons of nuts and bolts at a total of $52,800.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 12. -- Dr. J.L. M. Curry, ex-Minister to Spain, and one of the most prominent educators in the South, died in Asheville, N.C., at 11:20 o'clock to-night of Bright's disease, at the residence of his brother-in-law, Col. Connelly. Dr. Curry had been critically ill for the past two weeks. Mrs. Curry arrived from Philadelphia last week and was at the bedside of her husband when his death occurred.

For the Presbyterian General Assembly at Los Angeles, Cal., May 21 to June 1, the Pennsylvania Railroad Company has arranged three transcontinental tours at extraordinarily low rates. Special trains of high-grade Pullman equipment will be run on desirable schedules.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- The Assembly Cities Committee to-day heard Elliott H. Goodwin of the Civil Service Reform Association, in opposition to various bills providing for rehearing by the New York Police and Fire Commissioners of the cases of certain discharged members of the departments.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Mayor Low to-day sent word to Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman that by next week the New York City administration would be able to make definite announcement as to its position with regard to the proposed changes in the tenement house law.

The American Jewish Historical Society held its eleventh annual meeting in Carnegie Hall yesterday. Members presented papers on phases of the history of the Americas in which Jews had played a part, and officers were elected.
Yesterday being Lincoln's Birthday, Wall Street could do no business, and, it may be imagined, would not have done much business worth doing if it could, judging from the previous day or two.
The Directors of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company will meet to-day, when, it is expected, a manager of the house to succeed Maurice F. Grau will be chosen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- When the item in the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill was reached to-day in the House, which appropriates $60,000 for maintenance of the White House, a motion was made to cut it down to $45,000, the latter being the amount usually appropriated in former years. There was a sharp debate on the proposition, during which expenses at the White House were criticised from the Democratic side.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- The trial of the libel suit brought by M. Cattaui, a banker, against the Humbert family, which began in the Ninth Correctional Chamber yesterday, was resumed to-day. There were large crowds inside and outside the courtroom. M. Ludovic Halevy, "Gyp," (Countess de Martel,) and other prominent literary figures were among the spectators.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- With less than three weeks remaining of the present Conress some of the Republican leaders at both ends of the Capitol are becoming uneasy over the condition of the public business that must receive attention before March 4 if the danger of an extra session to be avoided.

Probably Mr. CHARLES R. LAMB did not mean to be taken quite literally when he said, at the Nineteenth Century Club the other evening, that for his part he preferred a dishonest man with imagination to one who coupled rectitude with stupidity. He doubtless meant to merely make a striking statement of the fact that in municipal and public as well as in private affairs.

A public hearing will be given to-morrow on an ordinance to compel the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company to run cars over the Furman Street route, between the Fulton and the Wall Street Ferries, along the Brooklyn water front, every ten minutes from 5 o'clock in the morning until 9 o'clock at night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Announcement was made by all persons concerned to-day that there is complete harmony among NewYork Republicans as a result of conferences, at the White House. Senator Platt saw President Roosevelt this morning, and Gov. Odell and Congressman Littauer made a separate call later.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Gov. Yates and James P. Whedon, member of the Joliet Penitentitary Board of Commissioners, are in a dead-lock and the Governor admits he has been outwitted.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 12. -- Chief Justice Pope will hear on Thursday next the application for bail in the case of J.H. Tillman, who killed editor Gonzales. The hearing was postponed from to-day because Tillman's attorneys failed to serve the prosecution with the affidavits which they intended to present Justice Pope.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to answer Andrew McKinley's letter, which appeared in to-day's TIMES. Mr. McKinley's idea is that by limiting the immigration the social and political welfare of this country would be strengthened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The German Government, at the urgent suggestion of its Minister to the United States, Baron von Sternburg, yesterday agreed to waive its demand for a cash payment of $340,000 from Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Feb. l2 -- The nomination of Dr. Crum to be Collector of Customs at Charleston, S.C., was adversely acted on to-day by the Senate Committee, on Commerce. The motion to report the nomination favorably was rejected, the vote standing 6 to 8. Jones of Nevada and Perkins of California, Republicans, voted, with the Democrats against confirmation.

The plot 87.6 by 100.11, on the north side of One Hundred and Twelfth Street, 187 feet, west of Brodway, has been sold by Nelson D. Stilwell to B.J. Moloughney. who has resold the property to Michael Tully. A six-story apartment house will be erected on the site from plans by Israels Harder.

A special meeting of the Executive Committee of the Regents of the University of the State of New York, attended also by other Regents in the city, was held yesterday at the home of Whitelaw Reid, the Vice Chancellor of the university. Consideration was given to the question of educational legislation desired from this session of the Legislature, and especially such as would unify the educational system of the State.

A dispatch from Pittsburg makes the announcement on the authority of President DOLAN of the United Mine Workers of Western Pennsylvania that the new scale of wages adopted at Indianapolis applies only to union men. "Miners not members of the union will not participate in the advance granted by the operators from April 1."

Two men who seemed to reincarnate the spirit of Abraham Lincoln appeared at the Republican Club dinner given at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening and in form and speech the orators reminded the diners of the "rail splitter" who won his way from a log cabin to the White House.

The tournament for the championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, which has been in progress for the last two weeks at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, has now virtually narrowed down to the championship contest itself, and this will be played to-night. Wilson P. Foss, thrice champion of the Amateur Athletic Union, and Edward W. Gardner, the present champion of the National Association, will be the contestants.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12. -- Indictments may be returned against the managers of one or more of the St. Louis turf investment companies as the result of an investigation begun to-day by the February Grand Jury at the order of Circuit Attorney Joseph W. Folk, who is hurrying home from New York and Washington to conduct the inquiry.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12. -- Harvard's baseball candidates were called out tonight and about seventy-five men handed in their names. The men will start work in the cage on Monday, at which time it is expected that many more players will report for work. At the meeting to-night Capt. Clarkson and Coach Wendell talked to the men, and advised them that Yale must be defeated, as she has for the four years past.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- Before an audience that filled every inch of space in the United States Circuit Court room President George F. Baer of the Reading Company made his closing argument for the coal operators before the Strike Commission to-day, and Clarence S. Darrow, chief counsel for the miners, began the summing up for the men.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Few of us think of Dickens as a poet, although every one knows that he had a most objectionable habit of writing blank verse in the guise of prose whenever he wished to be paticularly pathetic.

At the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday Controller Grout and several Coroners exchanged words of harsh criticism. The Controller declared that he was ready to support the bill abolishing the Board of Coroners, and one Coroner retorted that the board would be pleased to hold an inquest on the Controller.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- The best contested game of basket ball of the season was played to-night in the Cornell Armory when Yale beat Cornell by the score of 13 to 5. The first half was probably the best exhibition of the Game ever seen at Cornell. At the end of the half the score stood 2 to 0 in favor of Yale.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 -- The money market is dull and firm. Call loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 1/2@4 per cent.; New York funds, 10@15 cents premium; clearings, $18,176,466; balances, $1,248,032. The foreign exchange market holds quite firm, and rates remain unchanged.

Comparatively few citizens of the North appreciate the breadth and depth of the sense of loss pervading the Southern States because of the death, in his seventy-eighth year, of the Hon. J.L. M. CURRT, which occurred at Asheville, N.C., Thursday. It was a most useful, unique, and interesting personality which disappears from contemporary public life.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 13 -- Mail advices received to-day from Hongkong state that widespread grief exists at Canton and throughout Southern China over the loss of the bones of 500 Chinese who had died during the last few years in New Zealand and Australia. Following the custom of Chinese, the bones were being taken home for final interment along with those of the ancestors of the dead.

SHALL we never have done with reminiscences of Bismarck? And from an Englishman, too, just when the English people are growling at their Government for asking Germany to help in collecting a little debt from a, little South American nation!

LIVERPOOL, Feb. 13 -- Premier Balfour, in the course of a speech at a luncheon given by the Conservative Club here today, declared the British Government had no choice but to take action against Venezuela. The Ministers had shown no undue haste, no greed for money, and no inhumanity. The United States Government had been taken into the confidence of his Majesty's Government at every stage of the proceedings.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Speaker Nixon to-day conceded that the advocates of canal improvement are in control of the Legislature. He said they had 94 of the 150 members of the Assembly and more than a majority of the members of the Senate.

The week closes with dinners and a dance and several charitable entertainments, one of which is to be the St. Valentine's kettledrum at Sherry's and another the Valentine party for the benefit of a hospital fund. Several week-end parties are in the country.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 13 -- Harvard's fencing team won the first dual intercollegiate fencing match with Columbia to-night by the one-sided score of 7 to 2. Although the New Yorkers had won previously from Annapolis by a comfortable margin, they proved far interior to the Crimson team. Their aim was wild and their lunging erratic, and they proved easy victims to Harvard's superior form.

The Overland Monthly of San Francisco, a magazine which may be well called "historic," is now edited by Florence Jackson, formerly of New York. Its reputation is well maintained. Articles on "The Course of Law and Status of Politics in Negroes," "The Chinese Theatre," and "The Builders of California," as well as an "editorial digest" and a "review of recent literature," signed: F.J., are among the contents of the February number, which is well Illustrated.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 13 -- Football captains are assuming a new role at Harvard. In the indoor meet of the Boston Athletic Association to-morrow night two of them will make their debuts as runners, and as runners of an exceedingly high order, too. They are Bob Kernan, captain of last year's football eleven, and Carl Marshall, whose brilliant dodging and returning of punts has made him Captain-elect at the present time.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have no desire to continue the discussion with Mr. Richman as to his unwarranted association of Roger Williams with Mr. Huxley. His summary way of asserting a thing and then announcing it proved is amusing to say the least. He seems to me to overlook entirely the main question, which is a very simple one, viz..

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The last bill on the Administration's anti-trust programme, the Elkins Anti-Rebate bill, passed the House to-day after an hour's debate. This is all the discussion there has been of the measure, for the Senate did not debate it. It will have to be acted upon again by the Senate, for the few amendments tacked on by the House will necessitate concurrence by that body or a reference to a conference committee.

IT MAY interest readers of French historical biography to learn that the author of "The Youth of la Grande Mademoiselle," recently published in an authorized English version by G.P. Putnam's Sons, is Mme. Charles Vincens, who took her pseudonym of Arvede Barine, because she believed that a man's name attached to the title-page of historical biography bore more weight than a woman's.

There was much irregularity in the course of prices in the outside market yesterday, and with the exception of a few issues the day's totals were small. In some parts of the list prices made considerable gains, but these were offset by the losses which occurred in Northern Securities and a number of other stocks.

SIR HERBERT MAXWELL'S work on "Bruce and the struggles for Scottish Independence," and more particularly his "life of the Duke of Wellington," renders him well fitted for the writing of just such a volume as the one entitled "British Soldiers in the Field."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: May I ask interested readers what degree of magnification of American influence and what degree of effacement of British prestige, if any, would result in or justify the naming of our language the "American" instead of the "English?"
According to Trenton (N.J.) dispatches, the Passaic Steel Mills Company will increase its capital from $3,000 to $5,000,000.

Wesley kept his journal through the greater part of a very long life, and published part of it. The whole journal has been made up into twenty-six bound volumes in manuscript, but has not in its entirety been put in type. The present volume is apparently a condensation of Wesley's condensation.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Cuttings of an article from your Rome correspondent, headed "Mr. Bagot and Roman Society," and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Dec. 21 last, have only just reached me. I beg to protest against the entirely inaccurate statements made by your correspondent.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The new "Letters and Memorials of Jahn Welsh Carlyle," which Jonn Lane will publish this Spring, is a collection of hitherto unpublished letters, edited, with an introduction, by Sir James Crichton Browne.

PLAINFIELD, Feb. 13 -- When County Prosecutor English announced this afternon to the Coroner's Jury investigating the railroad disaster at Graceland that all the testimony had been completed. Foreman Charles J. Fisk said that the jury would meet to-morrow afternoon for the purpose of announcing its decision as to the cause of the wreck.

During the progress at the Boer war some sixteen editions of Sir Conan Doyle's book, "The Great Boer War," were produced in England, the last or which also saw light in America. The author has now so amplified, rewritten, and corrected the original work that what was at the time given out as a running narrative of the struggle he would now have people accept as permanent history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 -- The Assembly Committee on Prisons has made a report on its investigation of punishment in the San Quentin and Folsom State prisons. They find that the straitjacket and other methods of torture are in use in both institutions, though the results are more disastrous at Folsom than at San Quentin.

The pleasant weather of yesterday resulted in an increased attendance at the Westminster Kennel Club's Dog Show at the Madison Square Garden, particularly of women and children, and for to-day, which is the last of the show, an even larger crowd is expected. For the benefit of the children an extra performance of the trained dogs was given yesterday at 4 o'clock, and another will be given to-day at the same hour.
Trade reports to the several commercial agencies continue highly favorable. Bradstreet's sums the situation up as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- It is apparent that all efforts to reach a compromise on Statehood have failed, and that no expectation is entertained on the part of those engaged in them to reach an early settlement. The advocates of tHe Omnibus bill are as aggressive as ever. Their power was exhibited in the Post Office Committee to-day by voting to add the Omnibus bill as a rider to the Post Office Appropriation bill.

WITHIN the last two or three years a singular phase of American thought has presented itself through literature. It is the the attempt to rehabilitate certain characters in American history upon which genuine historians have long since said what was presumably the final word.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your number of Jan. 31 Mr. H.K, Viele, a distinguished scron of the original Knickerbocker family, undertakes to identify its founder with the Old Nick, or, strictly speaking, with one of his successful impersonators. Will you admit the testimony of another errant offspring of the same Schagticoke tribe?

Yesterday's early decline in prices discovered to the Street generally two important facts, one that the number of stop loss orders in the market was much less than ordinarily, appears in a trading market; the other that there were some very substantial "standing" orders on the buying side at every slight concession in prices.

A polemic of considerable vigor has been carried on within the last month, mainly in the columns of The Nation, over the customs mode of assessing values for the purpose of fixing the import duties on books. We have no intension of going into the merits of the question at present.

As he was on the way to Sing Sing Prison yesterday at noon in charge of Deputy Sheriffs Van Deesten, Kelly, and Foley William Hooper Young, the murderer of Mrs. Annie Pulitzer, caused a scene at the Grand Central Station. He did not want to be photographed, and made several attempts to kick at the machines.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 13 -- Charles A. Alden, who disappeared from New York Dec. 21, 1901, has returned to the home of his parents in Montague. Alden was at the time of his disappearance private secretary to Commissioner John W. Keller of the New York City Department of Charities and also acting Treasurer of the Department and Trustee of the Court Fund of the outside poor.

In a volume of ornamented cloth, with uncut edges and with gilt top, will shortly be presented through Harper Brothers a collection of speeches delivered by the German Emperor. The benign, patriarchal "Gott und Mir" qualities which have hitherto been given in scrappy cable dispatches, will now be unrolled in all their splendor of rhetoric.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The report made by the State Railroad Commission to-day upon the complaint made by the Merchants' Association of New York City against the Interurban Street Railway Company and the Union Railway Company for failing to supply proper and adequate accommodations to the public lays the blame for the complained-of conditions upon those who have been in charge of the city's affairs rather than upon the transportation companies.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The Anthracite Coal Strike Commission, after being in public session for more than three months, closed its open hearing to-day with an all-day argument by Clarence S. Darrow in behalf of the miners. The commission will meet in secret in Washington next Thursday and begin the considerstion of its award.

WHAT subject could be more appropriate for discussion on Valentine's Day than the dainty amatory verse of Robert Herrick? The valentine was one of his favorite diversions. He says of the anniversary: Off have I heard both youths and virgins say, Birds choose their mates, and couple, too, this day.

Prof. Richard Heath Dabney of the University of Virginia has undertaken to write a "History of the Reconstruction," which cannot fall to be a valuable work, and, indeed, promises to be an indispensable one to future students of American history. He has begun vigorously the collection of "material," unpublished letters, diaries, and other manuscripts, files of newspapers of the reconstruction period, books, and pamphlets.

"The Meaning of pictures" is the title of the new book by Prof. John C. Van Dyke, which Charles Scribner's Sons are publishing. The volume deals with the substance of pictorial art as his "Art for Art's Sake" did with its technic. It contains six lectures elven for Columbia. University at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Mr. David N. Johnson is a venerable resident of Lynn, Mass., who for twenty years served on the School Board of that city and for twenty years was a Trustee of its public library. Mr. Johnson is the author of "Sketches of Lynn," and has long been at work on a more ambitious book of local history coiled "Lynn in the Nineteenth Century," which will shortly appear in a royal octavo volume with illustrations.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: One reader of the late Augustus J.C. Hare's biographical studies mourns sincerely that she may not be introduced, through the medium of Mr. Hare's pen, to more of that goodly company with whom, thanks to him, she feels on terms of intimate friendship.

The New York Athletic Club hockey team won an uphill game last night at the Clermont Skating Rink, Brooklyn, against the Brooklyn Skating Club team amid the demonstrations of a large gallery. The final score was 8 goals to 3, but the game was a much better contested one than the score would seem to indicate.

It is agreed by many who heard it that the speech of ex-Goy BLACK on Thursday evening, in honor of the memory of LINCOLN, was one of the most impressive that have been delivered in this city in a long time. The audience responded to it with spontaneous fervor at one after another of its brilliant passages, and the applause that followed the close was long-continued and renewed.

The selection and arrangement of the Duke of Wellington's dispatches during his campaigns as commander of the British forces in India, Denmark, Spain, Portugal, the Low Countries, and France, and also those relating to America, made by Walter Wood, are timely in view of the interest in Napoleon.

WHILE claiming no unusual merit as a history of one of the most important periods of the development of Germany, this little book is a fair chronicle of the time it undertakes to describe. The first chapter is of particular interest to those who wish to inform themselves briefly of the conditions prevailing in Germany, particularly in its southwestern part, from the era of the Napoleonic invasion to the revolutionary movement of 1818.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- An exciting incident occurred in the Chamber of Deputies to-day when Maurice Binder, Nationalist, sought to interpellate Minister of Justice Valle on the Humbert affair. The Deputy declared that suspicion had long been directed against the Cabinet, over which presided that "weathercock Combes."

Reports that the Equitable Life Assurance Society had bought the Trinity Building property at III Broadway gained currency yesterday only to be met with denials from those who would be the interested parties to any such transaction.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Exposure of the methods of the get-rich-quick "turf investment" companies in St. Louis caused a descent by the Chicago police to-day on several of these concerns. As a result several persons were arrested on charges of conducting bookmaking establishments and gambling enterprises.

RONKONKOMA, L.I., Feb. 13 -- Clinging tremblingly to her father's arm, and sobbing violently, Bessie Milton, sixteen years old, was arraigned before Justice Hawkins . at Lake Grove this afternoon for having placed obstructions on the Long Island Railroad tracks in front of a passenger train.

"Bogus Arbitration Court" is what The London Saturday Review calls the arrangement made in the new treaty for the settlement of the Alaskan boundary. The Review is the special organ of a small group of Tories whose chief article of faith is that the United States must be opposed at every point and who dread nothing so much as any show of friendship for our country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Herbert W. Bowen, Venezuela's representative in the peace negotiations at Washington, to-night signed with each of the allies' representatives here a protocol providing for the immediate raising of the Venezuelan blockade and for the reference of the question of preferential treatment of the claims of the allies against Venezuela to The Hague Arbitration Tribunal.

Doubleday, Page Co. will publish next week "The Story of My Life," by Miss Helen Keller. The volume will contain her letters from 1887 to 1901, fifty in number, including several written to Phillips Brooks, Whlttier, and Holmes, and a supplementary account of her education, including passages from the reports and letters of her teacher, Miss Anne Mansfield Sullivan.

IN a pleasing manner the Surgeon-Naturalist on a Government vessel in the survice of the Marine Survey of India describes the marine fatina of the waters adjacent to India, but at the same time, gives glimpses of the many islands visited by him.

After an engaging preliminary chapter in which the emotions of Eve on leaving the Garden of Eden are touched upon with the sentiment of a passionate gardener, the author of "A Woman's Hardy Garden" descends somewhat unexpectedly to a severely practical and thorough account of her subject.

The argument of President BAER of Reading before the Strike Arbitration Commission is a document of unusual interest and value. It is perhaps much too long to be in the highest degree effective, but as a narrative of the strike, its causes and consequences as seen from the point of view of the operators, it is full of interest and merits careful and studious reading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A negro mass meeting was held last night in South Washington, under the auspices of the National Ex-Slaves' Mutual Relief, Bounty, and Pension Association, at which speeches were made applauding Senator Hanna's bill, introduced by request, to pension exslaves.

If a session before a holiday is not stimulating to good business a session between holidays is less so. This may be a reason why yesterday's activity was at the expense of prices. No special meaning seems to attach to yesterday's relaxing figures, but the fact may be noted for its contrast to recent conditions, when the market showed a tendency to rise whenever dealings became brisk or were made so.

MR. MOLINEUX'S book is not all exactly true. Some of it, he says, is only "founded on truth," comprising products of his imagination. Some of his chapters are taken from letters he wrote from his prison.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- A semi-official answer to the criticisms of the German Government "for allowing the United States to have anything to do with the negotiations between the co-operating powers and Venezuela" was issued to-day, as follows:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 13 -- Guesner, owned by Demarest, lowered the ice record here to-day from 2:18 3/4 to 2:17 3/4. Guesner covered the mile track of the Ottawa Ice Racing Association in that time. The 2:18 3/4 record was made by Jewell, over a half-mile track last Winter.
Money on call on stock collateral loaned at 2 3/4@3 1/2 per cent., with the last loan at 2 3/4 per cent. The majority of the day's loans was made at 2 3/4 per cent.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. l3 -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick dismissed the application of Henry C. Spinks of Newport, Ky., to compel the receivers of the Asphalt Trust to contest the suit brought by the Land, Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia for the sale of the collateral securities pledged to it by the Asphalt Company of America.

SUPPOSE such a dire contingency should arise as a diamond famine -- and strangely enough, remembering our latest experiences, there is a close resemblance between the Koh-i-noor and a lump of anthracite as to substance -- what then ?

The removal of the Erie "mystery" by the announcement over the holiday of the proposed new $50,000,000 bond issue was not received with, favor by the speculative element in the Street, who, in the early trading, made a vigorous drive against all the issues. Under the pressure recessions of two points or more appeared in each of the Erie shares, with an extreme loss of 3 3/8 in the second preferred.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The efforts to discover the identity of the unique personality who has screened her face behind the neutral countenance of Mary Adams have not been extraordinarily successful. Mrs. Ward (Elizabeth Stuart Phelps) is, no doubt, the most likely guess, but her work differs from the "Confessions of a Wife" quite as much as it resembles it.

The Philharmonic Society played in excellent form yesterday afternoon at its sixth public rehearsal -- fully as well as it has at any time this season, and it certainly, for whatever reason, achieved much better results than at its last concert a fortnight ago. There were life and energy in its playing, and the programme offered a delightful succession of familiar musical works.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Feb. 13 -- Because of losses which almost absorbed the surplus and undivided profits and impaired its capital, the First National Bank was closed shortly before noon to-day by direction of the Controller of the Currency, and Bank Examiner John W. Schofield was placed in charge of the institution as receiver.

DOVER, Del., Feb. 13 -- After another futile ballot for the election of United States Senators to-day the anti-Addicks Republicans submitted a proposal to the Addicks men for the election of two Senators, one from each Republican faction, Mr. Addicks to be left out of consideration. All the union Republican leaders declare that the offer will not be entertained.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Match play for the Joseph Jefferson Cup began on the golf links here to-day. The surprise of the day's play was the defeat of C.B. Cory of Boston, who has been playing very strong golf this season, by R.H. McElwee of Chicago. The results were:

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The demand for money slackened somewhat to-day, the market having borrowed heavily from the Bank of England. Continental competition for bills made it difficult to maintain discount rates.

SECOND ARTICLE. LINCOLN was inaugurated amid eclioes of cannons fired against the fing he made oath to defend. He had no fads no fetiches. The men whom he had beaten at Chicago he made the heads or his executive household -- Seward, Chase, and Bates.

During the war of the rebellion Mr. Dufur of the First Vermont Cavairy was wounded and made a prisoner near Richmond, and his volume tells of his life as a captive in Andersonville and Florence. The story is a gruesome one and full of horrors. Is it better to die on the field of battle or to languish in a military prison, and then after long suffering to part with life?

THE first novel of Mr. Churchill Williams, "J. Devlin, Boss," was a study of certain political conditions in an American city in the present day, and was full of vitality and interest. The character drawing was particularly good.

Few more suggestive and inspiriting books are published on technical musical subjects than this one by A. Pirro. Beginning with M. Wider's preface, the little volume is packed full of matter that every intelligent organist will find valuable. M. Avidor has written, not a perfunctory and good natured contribution to a colleague's work, but an acute and valuable essay.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The recent publication by the Riverside Press of their magnificent and costly folio edition of the essays of Montaigne led me to inquire for a library edition of Florio's translation within the reach of the book-lover of moderate means. To my surprise I was informed that there is none.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13 -- Indications that every effort will be made to put an end to the "turf investment" business in Missouri were given to-day. Circuit Attorney Folk arrived from New York to look after the Grand Jury, and the books and papers of E.J. Arnold Co. were seized this afternoon by Deputy Sheriffs.

A victory for Wilson P. Foss over Edward W. Gardner in what was to have been the deciding game in the 14.2 billiard tournament for the championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players last night at the Hanover Club necessitates the playing of another game by these experts, and they will meet again tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 13 -- L'Etrenne and Chickadee were the beaten favorites to-day. McWilliams was claimed out of the fifth race for $1,325 by T.E. Mannix. Weather cloudy; track fair, Summaries:

William J. Bryan of Nebraska is in the city and will remain until to-morrow. Seen at the Victoria Hotel by a group of reporters, Mr. Bryan greeted them cordially, but was not disposed to say a great deal.
IF THERE was one thing more incongruous about Do- lores Drummond than her name it was the generally accepted feeling among her friends that her life was blighted by a secret sorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- The basketball team, of the University of Pennsylvania easily defeated the Princeton University five this afternoon in St. James's Hall by the score of 24 to 14.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- A split between the Radical and Socialist groups of the Extreme Left is the result of M. Combes's declarations in the Chamber in favor of religion. M. Jaures, the Socialist Vice President of the Chamber, has taken a strong lead in the Prime Minister's favor, and has thereby profoundly offended the more antiChristian section of the Radical Party.

A THORN rankled in the sturdy flesh of that naturally, imperturbable young man, Paul Stuart Egerton, as he strode savagely down Broadway one moist morning. The anxiety that had disturbed so admirable an equipoise was perhaps a natural one. And yet it was a difficult one to admit, to accept condolence for, even with one's intimates.

Safe blowers were at work on the upper west side early yesterday morning. The outside door of a large safe in the office of Maguire Brothers, at 527 West Fifty-fifth Street, was blown open and a couple of holes were bored in the inside door, but the contents were not disturbed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this morning's issue the Board of Railroad Commissioners expressed the opinion that "it has done all that can be done until underground transit is a reality." The public knows this is not true, and if the Board is sincere in its statement it shows a most deplorable ignorance of the conditions, at least on the west side of New York City.

AT THE opera a white gown is merely a white gown, and it is nothing more, for whether it be of the richest velvet or the filmiest tulle, the lighting of the house is such that differences in material and detail cannot be distinguished except by the best of eyes, aided by the strongest opera glasses.

FOR the brisk young fellow without special mechanical ingenuity, but who dislikes the idea of clerking or of selling goods, a pleasant and profitable new field is opening. It demands about four months of study and a capital of something like $100 for board and tuition fees at a technical school.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Lakewood will be crowded this week with visitors who are coming to spend Washington's Birthday in the Land o' Pines. The number of city folks who take advantage of this holiday to run down here for a breath of invigorating air increases year after year, but the hotels manage to make room for all who come.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The anti-trust programme of the session is complete, and the legislation all accomplished except a few details. Estimates of what has actually been done vary according to partisan bias. The Republicans assert that their party has done effective work toward the suppression of trust evils, while the Democrats declare that the legislation is as weak as water.

The announcement from London yesterday that the forger of the name of J Pierpont Morgan was known and that a warrant was out for his arrest brought forth the following authoritative statement from the office of J.P. Morgan Co.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- The first sight that greets the traveler to Havana as he comes into port is Morro Castle; the last thing which he sees on leaving is Morro Castle, and it and its neighbor Cabana Fortress are the places that he has in mind to visit, whatever other points of interest may have escaped his notice.

The Macedonian Problem. The news which has recently come by cable in regard to the impending troubles in the Balkans is usually traceable to three sources -- that emanating from, the agents of the Macedonian Revolutionary Committee in Vienna.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Advices received here to-day from Nigeria say that the British punitive expedition commanded by Col. Morland and consisting of 1,200 men belonging to the West African frontier force, occupied Kano Feb. 3 after sharp fighting. Only two British officers were wounded. The enemy lost heavily, but the city was uninjured.
