To the Editor of The New York Times: President Dolan of the union of the bituminous coal miners of Western Pennsylvania is reported to have declared that the new scale of wages adopted at the conference of the operators at Indianapolis does not apply to non-union miners; that only the union miners are benefited by the increased wages.

It was "parole day" at the Children's Court, Third Avenue and Eleventh Street, yesterday, and the result was highly gratifying to those who believe in and have taken an active part in the work done there. In addition to the Judge and other officers of the law, a number of women devote their efforts to trying to make good citizens of the apparently hopeless young criminals brought for trial in the Children's Court.

Exposures of the turf get-rich-quick concerns which followed the failure of E.J. Arnold Co. of St. Louis provided the suggestion which led to raids of similar institutions in this city yesterday. Three establishments, all of them within a block of one another on Nassau Street, were cleaned out by detectives during the afternoon and three arrests were made.

A number of Sixteen-horse-power motor omnibuses recently have been put into service in London, and are giving excellent satisfaction. They carry twenty passengers, eighteen inside and two beside the driver. Each passenger has sixteen inches of seat room on the two long seats, which run the length of the car, and there is as much, room between the seats as in an ordinary omnibus.

THERE never was an excess of good feeling between Uncle Ezra Collins and old Deacon Filkins," said the man from Oklahoma meditatively. "But. it developed into a downright feud after the celebrated race between the Deacon's jackrabbit and Uncle Ezra's two trained hoopsnakes.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The New York Sabbath Committee, which entered its protest this week against the reporting of the Burke bill permitting the playing of amateur baseball on Sunday, and which vigorously opposes the reporting of the Jerome excise bill, is an institution with a history.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Wall's letter on Col. Lynch's treason has aroused the wrath of a true blue Orange man, in spite of his pretensions to the contrary. The Orange argument is that they believe in Protestant ascendency and are opposed to every effort made by Irishmen to redeem the country from oppressive and alien laws.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Mr. Quay served notice to-day that, beginning with Monday he would move each day to take up the Statehood bill immediately after the conclusion of the regular morning business.

Brown and Columbia, each of whom had the distinction of not having won a single game in the intercollegiate hockey tournament, got on the ice at the St. Nicholas rink last night with the determination to arrive at some definite conclusion as to who should remain the tailenders. The result was most gratifying to the crowd of Columbia enthusiasts who occupied all the available gallery space, and the whole rink resounded with their noise.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Max Regis, the former Mayor of Algiers and anti-Semite leader, took part in two duels to-day, and will figure in two more. The first was fought with swords, and his adversary was M. La Basderque. It grew out of a private controversy. In the second encounter pistols were used, and M. Regis exchanged shots with Jacquez Landau.

Interest of no ordinary character in the communication sent to Attorney General Cunneen by the Sub-Committee on Law and Legislation of the West Side Citizens' Rapid Transit Reform Committee of One Hundred in regard to the Manhattan Railway Company was general yesterday, especially in regard to the "no seat no fare" part of it.

SAGAY, Camlguin, P.I., Jan. 6 -- It is all very funny now and the man can laugh over the matter as he looks back, over it and draw ideas of the ignorance of Filipinos and perhaps of the uselessness of trying to do any good to the Filipino race. But it was not a pleasant experience while it lasted.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- "There will be no quarrel in the Republican Party which will bring about its disruption. We have our eye on the Presidential election to be held in 1904. We are not going to accommodate the Democrats by quarreling among ourselves."

HE arrived ahead of the mail on the morning of Feb. 14. He was attached to a messenger by a stout chain, but a thread would have served as well, for he sat in the vestibule unconcernedly and showed no inclination to get away. Around his thick, short neck was a heavy leather collar overlaid with a small chain.

IT WAS a decided shock to the stald residents in the west side boarding house when the young married couple came to dinner. They were comparative strangers, having only passed the three days' probation that was the custom in this exclusive establishment, so of course they were still subject to close scrutiny.
I DON'T s'pose you kin remember as fur back as the Spanish-American war?"

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- The De Soto Hapdicap at six furlongs, and worth $1,645 to the winner, the feature of to-day's card, was won very easily by J.U. Strode's Josette, a second choice in the betting at 9 to 2, who, favored by the start, raced the favorite, Scorpio, off his feet and then came on and won as she pleased.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 14 -- Criticism of the anti-trust measures adopted by the Republicans at the present session of Congress, and prediction that the American public is turning n the direction of radical legislation on property matters, were uttered by Judge Peter S. Grosscup before the Good Government Club of the University of Michigan to-night.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 10 -- Younger, smaller, and far less rich, Kansas City nevertheless is in the race with St. Louis for Southwestern business supremacy. St. Louis has capital in immense surpluses; Kansas City is using every available dollar every day. St. Louis has back of it a rich record of financial accomplishment; its commerce and its industries have foundations unshakable; St. Louis prosperity has advanced far beyond the test point.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 3 -- Last Saturday was a remarkable day for the people of Brussels the last remaining scaffolding was then removed from the western faqade of the Town Hall, and, for the first time in thirty years, the venerable old "Maison de Ville" was divested of the familiar wooden encumbrance which, within the memory of the present generation, has marred the beauty of its outlines.

FIRST NOTICE. With Friday's dinner and Saturday's reception the Architectural League has launched its annual exhibition; it is a trifle fuller then usual, and, like its immediate forerunners, in order to interest the general public depends on the sculpture, paintings, carvings, pottery, and textiles, in fact, on the arts and crafts, more than on what belongs strictly to architecture.

Correspondents of various Paris, Berlin, and London papers in Constantinople have been regaling their readers, with material which is a relief from the interminable speculations as to the Balkans. A fortnight ago what is described as an "American blizzard" swept through Constantinople, with the result that all Pera turned to snowballing.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Considerable excitement prevailed here to-day among the depositors of the Monmouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company because of the fact that the institution failed to open its doors this morning, as promised, and because the officers declined to make any official statement to the public.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is it not about time that those interested in the solution of the so-called negro or race problem should recognize the fact that this question will never be settled by the present methods adopted for its solution?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Roosevelt to-day signed the bill creating the Department of Commerce. Already candidates for places in the department are extremely numerous and new ones are daily cropping up.
WRITING busily in two of the "work rooms" in the upper floor of the American Museum of Natural History may be found two men who have come to the last stage of a long undertaking.

Two well-dressed persons, each about twenty-five years of age, whose manners suggested that they were elopers from the country, went in a cab to the Tenderloin Police Station at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning and asked Sergt. Mott where they could find a "'Squire."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Secretary of Agriculture and Miss Wilson entertained this evening at their annual Cabinet dinner in honor of the President. The other guests were the Secretary of State and Mrs. Hay, the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Shaw, Postmaster General and Mrs. Payne, the Attorney General and Mrs. Knox, Miss Hitchcock, daughter of the Secretary of the Interior; Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Walsh, Miss Grace McKinley, and Jasper Wilson.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- When it was made known that the new Minister, Baron Speck von Sternburg, had been chosen by the Emperor to represent Germany in Washington the question was asked: "Can a German diplomat be appointed to such a position whose wife is an American?" Many, in fact, believe that a law exists forbidding the representative of Germany to be married to a woman of the country to which he is accredited.

Representatives of the majority of the clubs in the United States National Lawn Tennis Association attended the twentysecond annual meeting last night. The meeting was held in the banquet room of the Waldorf-Astoria, and in the absence of Dr. James Dwight of the Longwood Lawn Tennis Club, Boston, Bob Wrenn presided.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- A petition has been filed in the Superior Court by P.M. Baumgardner, who says he possesses $6,000 worth of stock in Siegel, Cooper Co. The petitioner asks the court to dissolve the charter of that concern and wants the business wound up, a receiver appointed, and an injunction issued to restrain the collection of its accounts.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 14 -- George Coppersmith and his wife and three children had a narrow escape from perishing in a fire which started in their home in Hawthorne, early yesterday morning. That they were not burned to death was due to the sagacity of a large Newfoundland dog.

The Illinois State Senate passed, by a vote of 43 to 1, a joint resolution in favor of a constitutional amendment to elect United States Senators by a direct vote of the people of the respective States.

The Berlin papers bring further details concerning the arrest of a Polish nobleman's widow. Countess Isabella Wesierska Kwileska, who is charged with having palmed oft a strange child as her own. The announcement of the arrest was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Jan. 30.

Wagner-while-you-wait is now to be the thing in England. Mrs. Brown Potter, having run through the trades of actor and vaudevillian, has taken to monologues, and Mr. Louis N. Parker, master of the mechanical blank verse, has undertaken to boil down "Tristan and Isolde" into what is called a melo-recitation.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 14 -- Secretary Root made public to-day a letter in which he declined to accede to a request of a Congressman to use influence in favor of the promotion of a Lieutenant.
PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Mrs. McDowell and her daughter of New York, who have been visiting Mrs. T.R. Congdon, have left Paris for Nice They will spend some weeks traveling in the Riviera.

A broken and rather uninteresting week leaves matters about where it found them What business was done yesterday, and the bank statement, are discussed elsewhere in detail. Regarding the general situation as developed by five days' business, it is, therefore, only necessary to say that we are one week nearer to the time when the bulls will dare to buy, or the bears to Bell, in quantities adequate to break the long deadlock.

It is the last week before Shrove Tuesday. Already a number of people have left for the South Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor will go soon, and Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly will leave in the course of the week. At present the principal news seems to come via. Florida and the Carolinas.

The thirtieth annual dinner of the New York Press Club, held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, was enlivened by a speech of Senator Tillman of South Carolina, who told the North directly to leave the South alone in its settlement of the negro quetion and advocated strenuous life in the South in a race war between Caucasians and negroes.

They do a good many things better at the Metropolitan Opera House in the way of stage management than they used to. But there are still a good many that seem so unintelligent and so unnecessarily disturbing that many are moved to wonder that they are allowed to be.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me say a few words regarding President Eliot's statements, in which that honorable gentleman laments the fact of "the late postponement of marriage on the part of educated young men -- a postponement which the protracted education now prescribed for men who enter the learned and scientific professions makes unavoidable."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Roosevelt late this afternoon signed the Army Staff bill and it is now a law. Secretary Root, Secretary Cortelyou, and two or three officials of the War Department were present at the White House when the President affixed his signature to the measure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this morning we note an article on your editorial page regarding the proposed abandoning of the silver basis in the Straits Settlements.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Premier Balfour's reappearance in public after his recent illness is welcomed by men of all shades of politics, and his speech yesterday at Liverpool was eagerly read.

AT the last meeting of the Manufacturers' Association, in Brooklyn, one of the subjects discussed was the improvement of Atlantic Avenue in that borough, work on which is now well advanced. The plans call for the depression of the tracks of the Long Island Railroad part of the way alone the avenue, and for their elevation the remainder of the distance.
Col. Amos Stickney, Corps of Engineers, is detailed as a member of the examining board convened at the Army Building, New York City, vice Col. Samuel M. Mansfield, Corps of Engineers, relieved.

THERE is a rumor that the Union Club men are experiencing a change of heart, and that after all they may give a day on which their new club-house may be inspected by at least such club friends as gave them shelter during the recent short interregnum. There have been a number of "openings" at the Union, as each room, when finished, is thrown open with some little ceremony.

The banquet given by the Colonial Club last night at its clubhouse on Seventysecond Street and Broadway in honor of Chief Judge Alton B. Parker of the Court of Appeal failed to realize the political expectations which were raised, but was not without interest as a political potpourri.

The weekly Clearing House statement issued yesterday was somewhat more unfavorable than had been expected. Reserves on all deposits decreased $3,016,000, reserves on deposits other than United States deposits decreased $3,009,975, loans increased $11,274,800, specie increased $3,788,600, legal tenders decreased $3,772,100, and deposits increased $12,130,000.

ON the east side there are many children's games that have not been catalogued as yet in any cyclopedia of sports, and yet some of them possess an originality that deserves recognition, if not justification.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Money was firm in the market to-day, supplies were scarce, and there was an active demand for loans. Discounts were easier. The usual weekend inactivity prevailed on the Stock Exchange, but prices were fairly firm. Consols were steady, a fair business was transacted in these securities, and they closed slightly easier.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- The week closed with the money market very quiet and with no change in rates. Call loans, 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 4 1/4 @ 5 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 1/2 @ 4 per cent.; New York funds, par 5 @ 10c premium; clearings, $25,920,049; balances, $2,284,808.

THERE are literally a score of such sanatoriums as this within sixty miles of New York City, and to take the word of the physician in charge here they are all filled to overflowing, with patients waiting in adjoining cottages to get admission to the main building, a striking Illustration of the aftermath of a rapid life.

WHEN the doctor asked the women about her appetite and her throat and the pain in her shoulder, she just lay there with closed eyes and said "Oh,oh,oh!" most pitifully. But, when he began to write a prescription she braced up and spoke her first connected sentence of the morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit a word in regard to the universally interesting topic of American art. The current art season commenced even before the Winter's solstice, with the National Academy exhibition in the vanguard, as usual.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- The golf tournament for cups presented by Joseph Jefferson and H.R. Rea of Pittsburg was finished here to-day. In the semi-finals for the Jefferson Cup R.H. McElwee beat P. Waterman, 1 up; John Moller beat Charles Tappan, 1 up in 20 holes. In the finals McElwee beat Moller by 2 up and 1 to play.

While in some parts of the list considerable, activity was displayed, the outdide market, as a whole, during the past week was quiet. The stocks which showed large totals were for the most part those which have been actively manipulated by those interested in them, and the large trading in such issues as these was in marked contrast with the dullness which prevailed in most stocks which are left to follow their own course.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- There was an incident at the White House to-day which afforded the President great amusement, although the joke was on him.

The chief feature of the thirteenth week of grand opera at the Metropolitan Opera House will be the opening of the special cycle of "Der Ring des Nibelungen," and the first performance this season of Wagner's comedy, "Die Meistersinger," with a new Walther von Stolzing in the person of Mr. Anthes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What President Roosevelt has just said about the suicide of the Anglo-Saxon race in this country is matter of common knowledge, and, unfortunately, true. The last census speaks for itself on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The House today passed the Sundry Civil bill, which has been under consideration since Tuesday, and then broke all previous records in the matter of private pension legislation. It was the last opportunity of passing pension bills at this session, and the calendar was cleared, not only of House, but of Senate bills, 325 in all being passed.

We hear a good deal in these days in regard to the prevalence of selfish or sordid aims and the degree to which "commercialism" is taking possession of the minds of men. Many sweeping assertions are made in this direction which have the fortunate attribute for their authors that they cannot be disproved.

Copies of a circular letter explaining the scope of the proposed Henry Ward Beecher Memorial were sent out by the Plymouth Church Committee during the middle of last week to a number of men in all parts of the, country, asking them to allow the use of their names as members of an honorary general committee.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 14 -- There was a riot in and about Jacob's Theatre in this city to-night. The audience, numbering about 800 men, hissed the performers, and later threw ancient vegetables on the stage, causing the artists to run behind the scenes. The curtain was rung down and the lights were turned out.

A cold of whatever nature is not usually considered a matter of other interest than that which conies from the fact that it is extremely disagreeable to the person who has it, and scarcely less so to those who are associated with the victim. Everybody "takes cold" more or less frequently as may be, and with greater or less severity.

EVERY day of our lives some evidence or other of the vastness of New York City is brought to us," said a man who has been watching the city grow for three-score years, "but it is not every day that one has such an evidence as came to me last week.

TOM HEALY says he has found the latest way of summoning the police. A man came into his restaurant the other day bringing with him a stock of refreshments he had purchased on the way up town. He seemed happy enough, until he was told that he needed no more inspiration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with considerable interest, and some surprise, the editorial published on Feb. 12. 1903, in your excellent paper, entitled "Catholic Libraries." From a perusal of the article it is evident that there is some misunderstanding, unintentional on your part, I am sure, with regard to the views expressed by his Grace, Archbishop Farley, at the reception tendered him by the Catholic Library Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Recent criticisms made in Congress on the changes at the White House and the newspaper comments which they have called forth throughout the country have excited much interest in Washington. The alteration of the White House has been one of the leading topics of conversation among Washington residents, and distaste for it is not by any means confined to Congress.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The Rev. George N. Howard, pustor of the Free Bantist Church of Batavia, since last October, has been declared by the Council of Free Baptist Ministers to have forfeited his right to recognition as a clegyman of that denomination, and it demanded the surrender of his credentials.

NEW YORK dealers in domestic pets say that their best customers are spinsters of uncertain age, childless wives, and old bachelors. This would seem to indicate that something to love and take care of is a necessity to those who have no domestic responsibilities or special home duties to engross their attention.

Those are two amazing riders on the Sundry Civil bill which Mr. CANNON has just affixed to it. One of them appropriates $4,000,000 for the erection of an office building for the use of members of the House of Representatives, facing Capitol Park. The other appropriates $2,000,000 for an extension of the Capitol itself.

After nearly nine days of about as rough weather as a transatlantic steamship ever was called upon to pass through, the White Star liner Germanic, from Liverpool, got in yesterday morning apparently little the worse for the severe pounding she received from head seas and high winds. The liner sailed from Liverpool on the 4th and every day of the voyage, according to officers and passengers alike, was one continuation of gales and confused seas.

BRAZIL -- Following is the full text of the Brazilian Government's statement in regard to its attitude toward Bolivia apropos of the Acre trouble, certain portions of which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 26. The document bears the signature of Rio Branco, Minister of Foreign Affairs:

A commendable movement has been started in England by an association of which Lord ROBERTS is President, bearing the amusing name of the "SemiTeetotal Association." Its standard is "no drinks between meals." The members assume a "solemn undertaking never to take intoxicating drinks except at the midday and evening meal's."

Yesterday's bank statement was called "disappointing." Upon a weekly comparison the condition of the banks is disappointing; but upon comparison with 1902, or 1901, the surplus reserve is larger. To find a surplus larger than the present it is necessary to go back to a time of smaller loans and slacker trade.

To THE man whose life is spent in one country and in one clime the meeting of Capt. Clayton Powell of his Majesty's Army and Gilbert West, an American artist, on the porch of a European hotel in Tokio would appear as a remarkable occurrence. To these globe trotters, however, it did not seem at all extraordinary, notwithstanding the fact that they had met and parted just as unexpectedly fully five years before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- There seems to be a prospect that as much of a protest from the moral sentiment of the country will be made against the seating of Senator-elect Smoot of Utah as was shown against the admission of Brigham H. Roberts when he appeared to take a seat in the House four years ago.

It is quite plain that the Macedonian rising is simply a symptom of a chronic disease. Occasionally Turkish misrule becomes so gross and outrageous that flesh and blood cannot bear it. Then a rebellion shows that the chronic disease has again reached an acute stage. The only real remedy for these effects is to remove the cause.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Alleged interference with the affairs of the Catholic Church in the Philippines by the United States officials has caused much discussion among members of that Church in this country.

"It's a peculiar thing," said the man who calls himself a veteran theatregoer, though it is long experience at playgoing rattier than venerable years that gives him such right as he has to the title; "it's a strange thing, I say, that playwrights of even the greatest cleverness fall foul on little things that a first-nighter like myself is pretty apt to spot at a glance."

"I reckon he seen he warn't able to manage Sunlight folks real well, and as he'd ruther resign than be put out, he hinted to the Board of Trustees that the climate of Sunlight didn't suit his constitution, and the Trustees inquired around till they diskivered enough of the real trouble to git him exchanged."

I HAVE often heard it said," remarked a retired army officer the other evening as a group of "old comrades" were sipping their coffee as well as something else, "that no one during the civil war who had occasion to be close to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant ever saw him laugh heartily.

A PROPERTY MAN who has seen many years of service in New York theatres, and who has just lost his position on account of an oversight that almost ruined a first-night production, talked to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter about the difficulties that beset property men in general.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Money was in strong, demand most of this week. A very large amount was lent by the Bank of England on Thursday, and a considerable sum was renewed. There is some slackening now that the Stock Exchange requirements have been met. For the time being rates are therefore rather easier at about 3 1/2 per cent.
To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial in last Sunday's TIMES upon the origin of our National airs attributes "The Star-Spangled Banner" to a Swiss source.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 8 -- Missionaries and others arriving at this port from the interior bring stories of growing bitterness toward foreigners among the native masses. There is a wide disposition not only to give these stories full credence, but also to assume that anti-foreign outbreaks are imminent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent Mr. Davis has written a most interesting letter as an American who has resided in Ireland. As an Irishman how resident in America I should like to add something to the information which Mr. Davis has given to your readers.
MARIE CAHILL,the star of the new musical comedy "Nancy Brown," tells this story:

The National banks of New York have gained a considerable portion of their deposits, and increased loans to a small decree, according to the currently published reports filed in compliance with the call of the Treasury Department for statements as to condition at the close of business Feb. 6.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 14 -- The Grand Jury's investigation into the "turf investment companies" was resumed to-day. Neither E. J. Arnold nor his manager, L. A. Gill, has yet been found by the Sheriff. For evidence in respect to the methods of the Arnold company the Grand Jury is depending on the books and papers of the concern and the testimony of some of its employes.

At the offices of the Red D Steamship Line, 135 Front Street, it was announced yesterday afternoon that the company's ships will resume their trips to Venezuelan ports at once, in view of the blockade being raised. The Maracaibo, which has been laid up here during the blockade, will sail next Monday for Curacao, La Guayra, and Maracaibo, with a full cargo of general freight.

Official announcement was made yesterday of the decision of the Board or Directors of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company under which Heinrich Conried, Director of the Irving Place Theatre, was to be awarded the lease of the Metropolitan Opera House for five years, to succeed Maurice Grau. The other bidders were Walter Damrosch and George H. Wilson of Pittsburg.

RICHMOND, Ind., Feb. 14 -- Members of the Purdue football team, to whom was left the choice of a coach for next year's term, unanimously decided in favor of Harvard's ex-tackle, Cutts, who has twice occupied a place on the all-American football team. The Purdue Athletic Association several days ago considered the names of many applicants for the place, and that of Cutts was among them.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- For nearly a generation the grand old forests of Northern New York have been supplying work for thousands of men at this season of the year, and so productive have been the timber lands that lumbering came to rank high among the great industries of the State.

The Tale 'Varsity baseball season began with an enthusiastic assemblage of the candidates for this year's nine in the trophy room of the Yale gymnasium last Friday. Over 200 men responded to the call of Capt. Burnside Winslow, and were addressed by the Captain, by Walter Carter, '95, Yale's most noted pitcher, and by head coach William H. Murphy, '92.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- In another week the Palm Beach season will have reached its height. Gay as this resort already is, the month of greatest gaiety is ushered in by the Washington's Birthday ball for which arrangements are being made with a view to the presence of over 2,000 guests.

General theatrical interest this week, will be devoted to three new productions. Two of them will be musical comedies, to be added to the already overflowing number of that class of attractions now on Broadway. But the one of larger public interest is the much-talked-of "Resurrection," by Count Leo Tolstoi.

Wilson P. Foss of Haverstraw added new laurels to his title of amateur billiard champion of the Amateur Athletic Union by defeating Edward W. Gardner of Passaic in the "tie" for the championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players of America at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 14 -- After a few months the visitors will have the use of a free library, which will be erected by Andrew Carnegie at a cost of $60,000. His offer as accepted this week by the City Council. The city will also have a new Post Office, which is to be erected at Pacific and Pennsylvania Avenues as a cost of nearly $200,000.

F.T. Bedford, F.B. Stephenson, W.W. Marshall, and H.B. Vanderveer were the successful shooters in the weekly shoot at the Crescent Athletic Club's Bay Ridge traps yesterday. Competition was keen in each event, and ties, which were shot off, resulted in two of the contests for trophies. During the afternoon 2,000 targets were broken.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 14 -- The Coroner's Jury in the case of the fatal railroad disaster which occurred on the Central Railroad of New Jersey, near Westfield Station, on the night of Jan. 27, when a train on the Philadelphia and Reading branch crashed into a local train on the Central of New Jersey branch, rendered their verdict at 3:15 this afternoon.

IT was a big day for Bad Leg when Old. Man Barlow climbed out of the stage and set his foot on Main street, and all the able-bodied men in the city gathered to give him a glad welcome, for he had been well advertised.

IN Fort San Carlos, the Venezuelan garrison were pluckily withstanding the steady fire from the German warships. Shell after shell had exploded around them, men wounded or dead lay here and there, yet manfully they stuck to their guns and knew no fear.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 14 -- Warrants were sworn out here to-day for the arrest of Daniel W. Hanna, son of Senator M.A. Hanna, and John Winder, General Manager of the Kanawha and Hocking Coal Company, a representative of J. Pierpont Morgan's interests in Ohio and West Virginia.

Following are the returns at foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Lessons of international weight and moment have been taught by the course and the ending of the Venezuela foray, and some of the chief nations of the earth have been the beneficiaries of that teaching. To Venezuela herself the lesson has undoubtedly been, if not the most salutary, at least the most severe.

Disgusted with the refusal of the officers of the American Bowling Congress to prohibit the use of the "loaded" bowling ball in the National bowling tournament at Indianapolis next week, local bowlers will send no teams to compete in the event and only a half dozen delegates from the thirty local tournaments will make the trip to attend the sessions of the congress and protest against the use of the weighted sphere.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article upon the case of Col. Arthur Lynch and the letters of "Another Irishman" and Mr. Mortimer Thompson in your issue of Sunday last, are quite beside the real question. Granting your statement of the facts, you do not point out or touch upon the moral, the great underlying fact.

Two young men faced each other in broad daylight yesterday in a duel with pistols in East Thirteenth Street, near Fourth Avenue. Seven shots were fired in all, but so far as the police of the Fifth Street Station have been able to ascertain none was effective. One of the duelists was arrested, while the other made his escape in the crowd that quickly gathered.

LEXINGTON, Feb. 15. -- There is to be a match race here to-morrow between a nine months' old filly owned by W.W. Evans and an aged gelding owned by W. R. Brasfield. The gelding has a trial of 2:14 1/4. The distance is 200 yards and the stake $200.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- Because the Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale, the noted Unitarian minister, took sacrament in Trinity Church Jan. 23, the occasion being the commemoration or the death of Bishop Brooks, which occurred ten years ago, the Episcopalian Church paper, The Living Church, has made a lively attack on the clergy who permitted it, and by inference on Dr. Hale for presenting himself at the chancel rail.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- What is interpreted here as an attack on John D. Rockefeller was made in his sermon this evening by the Rev. Herbert S. Johnson, pastor of the Warren Avenue Baptist Church. In the course of his remarks Mr. Johnson said:

Looting flats and incidentally the WaldorfAstoria on a get-rich-quick plan is the charge that led to the arrest of Mary Burke, thirty-five years old, and William Cox, twenty-three years old, of 213 Ninth Avenue, and the cause of their being held yesterday by Magistrate Mayo, sitting in the Jefferson Market Court, in $1,000 each for examination.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15. -- The congregation of the Trinity German Lutheran Church is dumfounded at the confession of its pastor, the Rev. Hugo Wendel, that he preaches to the spirits of men who died full of "perfect works."

Bishop John Lancaster Spalding of Peoria, Ill., lectured on "How to Make the Most of Life," at the entertainment given by the special work branch of the St. Vincent de Paul Society at Carnegie Hall last evening, and at which Archbishop Farley presided.

According to London telegrams a fund has been raised to prosecute those responsible for the London and Globe affair. A royal Duke and certain Court hangers-on are said to be involved as victims in "one of the most terrible, heartless, and gigantic swindles of the presen age."

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 15. -- Justice Wilmot M. Smith is considering an application for the dismissal of the indictment against ex-Mayor Michael J. Dillon of New Rochelle and some of the former Board of Aldermen and other officials of that city for alleged misdemeanors in office.

The catalogue of the eighteenth exhibition of the Architectural League bears a seated male figure representing architecture on its cover, and behind that figure a bit of New York seen from a lofty perch. The league does not disavow the sky-scraper, that is plain, for sky-scrapers form the burden of this background.

Postal Inspector Cortelyou and Detective McNally of Jersey City at midnight onSaturday arrested Adolph Jacobson, Sr., fifty-three years of age, on charges of grand larceny and obtaining money on false pretenses. Jacobson was found in his home, at 12 Fifty-first Street, Bayonne. The arrest was made on a capias issued by Judge John A. Blair, the Hudson County Grand Jury having found two indictments against Jacobson.
With regard to candidates for the next Democratic nomination for the Presidency, William J. Bryan, at the Victoria Hotel, yesterday said:

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb 15. -- After being out forty-eight hours, the jury in the case of Dr. J.C. Alexander, charged with causing bodies to be procured unlawfully, failed to agree, and were discharged this morning. In the final ballot the vote stood eight for acquittal and four for conviction.

HAVANA, Feb. 15. -- Four hundred Americans this afternoon observed the fifth anniversary of the destruction of the Maine, proceeding to the wreck with a flag draped with crape and wreaths which were hung on the remains of the vessel as a tribute to those who lost their lives in the disaster.

Upon last week's business 56 shares and 22 bonds rose 1 per cent of more, and 24 shares and 6 bonds declines similarly. The tone of the week's market was confused and professional, there being no decided evidence of public interest in either direction, nor any generally important news.

Nearly 2,000 men and women who attended the regular meeting of the People's Institute in Cooper Union last night were roused to excitement by a question. The incident occurred after addresses had been delivered by the Rev. Edgan Gardner Murphy of Montgomery, Ala., and School Superintendent William H. Maxwell.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The Chinese indemnity gold bonds are still unsigned, says the Shanghai correspondent of The Times, although the recent collective note of the foreign Ministers at Peking insisted on the fulfillment of this condition before any reference to their Governments of China's request for the alleviation of her financial difficulties.

After an absence of five months, in which period he has circumnavigated the globe, been entertained by the Emperor and the Empress Dowager of China, and King Edward of England, has visited the insular possessions of this country in the Pacific Ocean, and has inspected the armies of some of the countries he visited, Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles arrived in this city yesterday.

SALEM, Oregon, Feb. 15. -- The last week of the Legislative Assembly will begin tomorrow, and from present indications there will be no Senatorial election until the last day and perhaps the last hour of the session. No joint resolution for adjournment has yet been passed, but the Assembly probably will dissolve either on Friday or Saturday night.

AMAGANSETT, N. Y., Feb. 15. -- Shouting "There she blows" on the beach early yesterday morning, "Nat" Edwards, a fisherman, directed attention to a big bull whale that was disporting a short distance off shore. Immediately afterward flags were raised and bells rung, and the signal was repeated throughout the town, bringing every man, woman and child within hearing distance to the beach, where three whaling boats had already been prepared.

The story of a plot to "do up" District Attorney Jerome at a meeting of the Central Federated Union and his delay in keeping him promise to attend one of its meetings and deliver an address stirred up that body yesterday. Some of the delegates thought that he would be there, and the attendance was unusually large.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- Louis Cure (French) won the first game in the international championship billiard tournament at the Grand Hotel this evening, defeating George Button (American) by 500 to 415. The game lasted three hours. Cure's best runs were 70, 62, and 75, while Sutton's best runs were 83, 55, and 50.
For the third time this Winter the Manhattan Railway Company's elevated road service was badly crippled last night as a result of the ice formation on the "third" or contact rail.

The Union of London and Smith's Bank is an institution of a character which lends weight to anything said in its name. At the half-yearly meeting, Jan. 28, Mr. Felix Schuster, the Governor, expressed exceptionally pregnant views regarding English financial conditions and prospects. The following extract bears upon the relation of London's money market to other financial centres under the stress of the financing of the Transvaal war:

Immediate steps should be taken to secure from the Legislature the authority needed to enable the Water Commissioner to stop waste by any means which he finds necessary to the accomplishment of that end. He now lacks authority under the law to meter dwellings, and even the right to apply meters to private houses for experimental purposes is somewhat uncertain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Attorney General Knox, who is known to have prepared the improtant features of the anti-trust bills now enacted into laws, on being asked as to how they were regarded by the Administration, said:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- It was given out to-day that a number of the out-of-town stockholders of the defunct First National Bank will petition the Government to appoint Edmund Wilson of Red Bank receiver for the institution, in order that the affairs of the concern may be speedily straightened out and a reorganization effected by local capitalists.

Disappointment was again the lot of the patrons of the Sunday night concerts at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Anthes, a tenor who has not been heard in concert, was the promised feature of the programme. He was ill, Mr. Blass, also a stranger to the Sunday concert patrons, took his place.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 15. -- Apostle Smoot, Senator-elect from Utah, will leave for Washington in two or three days to present his credentials. As soon as he does this, it is expected that the warfare over seating him will begin in earnest. Officials of the Mormon Church are now confident that Smoot will be seated.
By much good management and some good luck the short session, usually so barren of constructive legislation, has been made to yield some amendments to the bankruptcy law that are really important.

Attention has been called to the fact that the flagship of the New York Yacht Club will this year be a steam yacht, although, for sentimental reasons perhaps, the flagship has heretofore been a sailing yacht. To emphasize the departure from the old-established custom the flags of the Vice Commodore and Rear Commodore will also this season fly from steam yachts.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 17. -- The long-continued drought has been ended by frequent heavy falls of rain in the last three weeks, and pastoralists have now a prospect of making up in some measure for the heavy losses they have sustained, but it will take two or three successive good seasons to put them completely on their less again.

There were two distinctive features to the police situation yesterday. One was the entry of President Roosevelt into the Schmittberger case by means of a letter to Commissioner Greene, indorsing the opinion of ex-District Attorney Philbin in the matter, and the other was the avidity with which the east side folk sought their sewing machines and spread out their goods on counters for Sunday sale.

HANCOCK, N.H., Feb. 15. -- Broken in spirit, a physical wreck, and changed probably beyond recognition, Dr. Albert Alonzo M. Ames, ex-Mayor of Minneapolis, and who is wanted in that city on an indictment for attempted bribery, was discovered to-day in the home of a local minister and placed under arrest by Sheriff Doane of Manchester.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- In an editorial article to-day on the signing of the Venezuelan protocols The Times says it ends a disagreeable and dangerous situation at a very opportune time, for, serious as the difficulties of the Washington negotiations have been, they would infallibly have been more serious had the agreement not been concluded before Parliament met.

Among the votaries of billiards who closely watched every same of the championship tournament of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players of America which was concluded at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, on Saturday night there is only one opinion and it is that Wilson P. Foss, who by winning now holds the two amateur championships of this country, is deserving of his well-earned honors.
Oscar S. Straus, for the National Civic Federation, has made public the following answer to President Baer's recent remarks concerning the coal strike and the part played in it by the federation.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Col. Henry Watterson lectured in this city last night. Following the lecture a dinner was tendered him by the Binghamton Press Club, which was attended by many of the prominent men of the city. In his after-dinner speech Col. Watterson, speaking of current history, said in part:

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 15. -- Three companies for military drill were formed last week among Yale undergraduates, and before the month is out at least another will be added. Uniforms and rifles will be requisitioned in about a month, and active campaigning will then be a part of the tactics taught the college soldiers.

P.J. Heaney Co. have sold for E.B. Levy to Catharine Romkey the lot 25 by 95 on the east side of Washington Street, 100 feet south of Columbus Avenue; also in conjunction with the North Side Realty Company, for a Mr. Wolf to William Rom- key, the two lots on the southeast corner of Columbus Avenue and Washington Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Minister Bowen expects to begin immediately the preparation of the protocols with the representatives of the unallied powers for the settlement of the claims of the citizens of those nations who have suffered as a result of the troubles in Venezuela. There are eight of these claimant nations, including the United States.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 15. -- The little fishing schooner Kineo came into port today with the shipwrecked crew of the British schooner E.H. Foster of St. John, N.B., abandoned yesterday in what was thought to be a sinking condition, about fifty miles east of Thatcher's Island. The Foster was on her way from St. John to New York, and put into Salem last Thursday.

The negligence of the local authorities of San Francisco in failing to deal with the bubonic plague as a fact which imperils every material interest of the State of California and menaces other parts of the country, is little less than criminal. During the past three years the plague has maintained a definite nidus of infection in Chinatown.

Charles Jarrott, the English automobilist, who won the famous Circuit des Ardennes race last year, gave a very entertaining and instructive account of his racing experiences recently. He began with the night before the race, when he found himself in Bastogne without a bed, and had brought home to him in a very forcible manner how many difficulties the racing man competing on foreign soil has to contend with.

Archbishop Farley, John T. McDonough, who has been appointed Judge of the Philippines; Justice Morgan J. O'Brien of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, and the Rev. Father G. Pettit, rector of Fordham College, were among the speakers at the annual dinner of the Fordham College Alumni Association last evening at Delmonico's.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Senate today passed the Philippine Currency bill. The amendment offered by Mr. Patterson (Dem., Col.,) several days ago, providing for a conference between gold and silver standard countries to fix a commercial exchange, was agreed to without division. Mr. Dubois (Dem., Idaho.) offered a substitute for the entire bill, and briefly explained its features.

The special committee appointed by the New York County Medical Association to investigate the office of Coroner, and to confer with committees from other societies, reported last night at the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street, that "no one has yet been elected to that office in this city who has brought to the performance of these duties adequate knowledge of both professions (medical and legal) to give the best and most reliable results.

There was a sudden and sorry interruption of the "grand annual smoker" of the "Odeon Pleasure Club" in a large room at the rear of the Armory Cafe, near the Salvation headauarters, in West Fourteenth Street last night.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 16. -- The falling tendency in Cotton Duck issues to-day was the nearest approach to a feature. They broke under the influence of disappointment on the non-payment of the January installment of interest on the income bonds. A touch of sober second thought, however, pervaded the market, which induced many to think that the securities are already selling materially lower than their intrinsic value.

Yesterday's market showed less activity than on any full day of the previous week, but the tone was good throughout the list with unimportant exceptions. Among railways it may be remarked that Erie was less affected by the early adverse reception of the proposed bond issue, which upon the curb sold up to 91 1/4.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Six thousand persons crowded into the Auditorium to-night at the demonstration of the local labor unions in honor of John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers. The greatest enthusiasm was shown when Mr. Mitchell appeared on the-platform, and his speech later in the evening was received with cheers.

ALBANY. -- Feb. l6. -- Agitation for a change in the tenement house law led to a conference to-day between Gov. Odell. President J. Edward Swanstrom of the Borough of Brooklyn, Tenement House Commissioner. De Forest, his deputy, Lawrence Veillier, and Superintendent of Buildings W.M. Calder.
Oppenheimer Brothers Veith are the buyers of the block front on Central Park West, between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets, sold recently by the Jai Alai Ball Company of Havana.

William Jennings Bryan spoke for half, an hour to members of the "Women's Democratic Club of Brooklyn at the Clarendon Hotel yesterday afternoon. There were forty or fifty women present, and about a dozen men. Mr. Bryan's address dealt largely with the importance of individual effort for the public good, and the urgency of more unselfish methods among office seekers and public officials.

In the course of his rather too eloquent defense of the operators before the Anthracite Commission President BAER of the Philadelphia, and Reading Railroad said: "This company is too big to be dishonest. It means to deal fairly with all men. It means it because its management is honest and its policy is honest."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- A last effort is now being made to get the Ship Subsidy bill up in the House. It passed the Senate at the last session, but did not get out of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries. If it does not pass at this session the work must be begun all over again at the next Congress.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- There was a long dispute in the Senate to night over Senator Eisberg's bill to amend the primary election law. This measure, which was introduced to carry out the recommendations of Gov. Odell in his message, does away with all supplemental enrollments.
George Haven Putnam and James W. Pryor Secretary of the City Club, talked about New York's needs at a meeting of the League for Political Education last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of George Bruce Cortelyou of New York to be Secretary of Commerce and Labor, and the Senate confirmed the nomination. Mr. Cortelyou's appointment has long been anticipated. He will be succeeded by William J. Loeb, now Assistant Secretary to the President.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Senator Brackett, the leader of the Republican bolt in the Senate, made a speech in Watertown on Lincoln Day and took occasion to make an attack on Senator Platt. Speaking of the methods by which Senator Platt obtained and is enabled to hold his power, he said:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- There was another dull market to-day, but at the same time the trading was not wholly void of feature. Union Traction was in good demand, and moved up to 47 3/4, on the statement that at a private sale Saturday Huhn Sons, known as Widener-Elkins brokers, bought a block of 5,000 shares from Wolf Brothers Co., at 47.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The official reports on foreign crop conditions received from the foreign statistical agent of the Department of Agriculture, under date of Feb. 1, show unseasonably mild weather in most parts of Europe during the greater part of January.

BRISTOL, R. I., Feb. 16. -- C. Oliver Iselin, the managing owner of the new cup defender, inspected the yacht to-day in company, with the designer, N. G. Herreshoff, and on leaving expressed himself as very well satisfied with the progress on the boat. Mr. Iselin would not say whether or not "Republic" had been selected as the name of the new yacht.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16. -- Allyar, in the first race, was the only winning favorite here to-day. Bud Embry was run up to $1,000 after his race and bought by J. Carroll. Weather cloudy and cool; track heavy. Summary:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 16. -- The first official strength test in Hemmenway Gymnasium, at Harvard, to establish a record under Dr. Sargent's new system was made to-day by F. W. C. Foster, a Varsity crew member, and who ran a relay against the Pennsylvania team Saturday. He scored a total of 230,170 foot pounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Much time was spent to-day by Republican Senators in conference in an effort to arrive at a satisfactory solution of the legislative dead-lock in the Senate caused by the Statehood bill, and after the Senate adjourned the Republican steering committee held a meeting with the same end in view.

A task of much responsibility in the selection of the United States Judge recently authorized by Congress rests upon the President, and, incidentally, under the practice in such matters, upon the two Senators from this State. Whatever we may think of the practice, it is well established, and it is recognized by Mr. ROOSEVELT that the wishes of the Senators of his own party shall be, if not absolutely respected, considered in such an appointment.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Henry Tatnall and John M. Mack, receivers for the National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America, filed in the United States court to-day answers to the foreclosure bill filed by the Land Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia and others, as trustees for the holders of collateral gold certificates of the two companies.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16. -- Kenilworth beat a good field to-day and broke the Ingleside track record for a mile by covering the distance in 1:39 1/2. Perfect weather prevailed and the track was fast.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- The unveiling of the second part of John S. Sargent's scheme of mural decoration in the so-called "Sargent corridor" of the Public Library will take place to-morrow. It is entitled "The Dogma of the Redemption." It contrasts forcibly with the decoration on the opposite wall, where is represented the evolution of earlier religions, with the frieze of the Hebrew prophets.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Continuing their policy of aggression against turf investment companies, the police to-day raided the office of J. C. Rose Co. They found the doors locked. Threats of breaking them down were made and the agent of the building admitted the police. A thorough search of the office disclosed the fact that all the company's books had disappeared, only a few papers being found in obscure drawers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands may be requested by the Washington Government to name the umpire who shall pass on the claim of the United States against Venezuela in the event that the persons named by the United States and Venezuela cannot agree.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- A feeling or relief that the Venezuelan business is settled before Parliament reopens inclines, the press not to be captious this morning in its exam

The heaviest downfall of snow in New York during the present Winter came swirling in upon the wings of a northwest win last evening. New Yorkers had been led to expect a cold wave, but were scarcely prepared for the extraordinary fall of snow.

The upper gallery at Knoedler's has its usual annual gathering of portraits by M. Chartran, headed this year by a nearly full-length likeness of President Roosevelt and accompanied by portraits of Miss Alice Roosevelt and Secretary Root. The portrait of Mrs. Roosevelt could not be exhibited because it has become the property of the Nation ever since its return from Paris, where it was shown at the Salon.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Charles Davenport died at Watertown Saturday night. He was born in Newton Centre May 25, 1812, and was for many years the senior partner of the firm of Davenport Bridges, carriage builders. At their factories in Cambridge the first railway cars used in this country were built.

BOSTON, Eeb. 16. -- At the Clearing House to-day balances between the banks loaned at 3 1/2@4 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. The exchanges were $18,213,816, against $18,076,636 a year ago to-day, and the balances were $1,537,854. Call loans, 4@5; time money, 4 1/2@5; commercial paper, 4 1/2@6.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Directors of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition have opened press headquarters in Washington. The bureau here has been advised of the awarding of contracts for statues for the Colonnade of States by the Louisiana Purchase Exposition as follows:

PUERTO CABELLO, Venezuela, Feb. 16. -- After the blockade had been raised here the captured Venezuelan sailing vessels were turned over to United States Vice Consul Volkmar. The German cruiser Vineta is still lying in the bay.

The Women's Press Club of New York City last night gave a St. Valentine's dinner in the Hotel Majestic, which was attended by almost as many men as women. The hall was lavishly decorated with flowers and red hearts, and the diners were as jolly as if they had been drinking wine instead of water.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- So far as North Carolina is concerned, the President has given, countenance to the "Lily White" movement. It was announced to-day that Mr. Roosevelt had decided not to appoint Samuel H. Vick. colored, as Postmaster at Wilson. It was on this office that Senator Pritchard, leader in the "Lily White" movement, made his test fight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16. -- Capt George B. Chadwick unexpectedly called a meeting of the members of the Yale football eleven to-night to elect a Captain to succeed himself. For several weeks three candidates have been under consideration -- E. T. Glass, H. G. Metcalf, and Charles D. Rafferty.
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- A blue book on the Venezuelan dispute was issued last evening.

Our Berlin cable dispatch, published Sunday, tells of the consternation created in the Prussian capital by the appearance of the American Ambassador, in a costume of his own devising, with a stripe of gold lace two inches wide down his trousers, and a cocked hat with, a white plume.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Official announcement of the formal closing of the Monmouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company was made this morning, when State Bank Examiner L. R. Vredenburg caused the following notice to be posted:
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The Times's correspondent at Constantinople says that Russia sternly refuses to admit Bulgaria's plea of inability to restrain the Bulgarian bands in the vilayet of Monastir.

-- Only a few years ago such a sleet-storm as that of Sunday night and yesterday morning would have caused a vast amount of inconvenience and no little actual loss in this city by the havoc it would have worked in the tangled maze of telegraph, telephone, and electric light wires which then hid a considerable fraction of our sky.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of yesterday's papers contains adverse editorial comment regarding the selection of Mr. Heinrich Conried as the future Director of grand opera in this city on the ground that he is not a trained musician.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The disbursement of dividends increased the supply of money in the market to-day. The demand was active. Discounts were quiet and firm. Gold bills were taken cautiously in view of the prospects of considerable exports of gold to South America.
WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 16. -- The following signed statement was issued to-night by J. Edward Addicks, under the caption "The Senatorial Situation":

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Senator Morgan to-day had read to the Senate a recent communication addresed to him by Rafael Reyes, Colombian Minister to Mexico, and which appeared in the public prints, denying the accuracy of a certain statement alleged to have been made by Mr. Morgan in the Senate on Feb. 12, to the effect that the President of Colombia had sold out and abdicated for $1,000,000.

In his address to the students and the Faculty members of the Good Government Club of the University of Michigan on Saturday evening, Judge GROSSCUP of the Federal Court of Appeals in Chicago complained of the existing economic system as one which excluded the workingman from industrial proprietorship.

The wane of the season shows a calendar of dinners, luncheons, and bridge parties. Last evening there were two dances, a large one in Mrs. H. McK. Twombly's residence, and a small dinner, with tetes poudrees, in the residence of Mrs. Dallas Bache Pratt. There are no dances arranged for this evening, except the one on the New Hampshire, which promises to be a jolly affair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to thank you for your witty editorial in to-day's TIMES, "The North Side of the Street." It is such hasty conclusions, as those of Dr. Thayer, based on meagre and insufficient evidence, that tend to throw discredit on medicine and medical theories in the eyes of the true scientific man.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 16. -- That the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company will have a new line over the Alleghanies, in which the old South Penn route with its partially completed tunnels will be utilized, is now assured. Options have been secured for nearly all the rights of way, these options extending from ninety days to two years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Navy Department has received the following telegram from Delaware Breakwater, dated yesterday, and signed by Admason, who is the first officer of the naval collier Alexander, and who was landed at the breakwater from the Admiral Schley:

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Walter Addicks, who has been associated with the Boston gas properties ever since their acquisition by J. Edward Addicks, in the capacity of Chief Engineer, has resigned to become Vice President of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York.

The attempt, on the part of a few of the wilder and woollier of the Democratic members of Congress, to make a political issue out of the improvement of the White House is as unpromising as it is inappropriate. It is doubtless true that the President has taken a personal interest in the additions and alterations.

WASHINGTON, N. J., Feb. 16. -- A headon collision occurred on the Lackawanna Railroad this morning about two miles this side of Phillipsburg. Three passengers were severely shaken up and were taken to Easton, Penn. Their names were not given out by the railroad employes. George Bowden, baggage master of one of the trains, was severely hurt, and it is believed his injuries will result fatally.

A new method of obtaining money from the credulous, built on the foundation of the " green goods " game, was exposed yesterday by District Attorney Clarke of Brooklyn, during the trial of Samuel and Henry Faust. The two men are charged with having operated in the Brownsville district and on the east side of this borough.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- Brooklyn bowlers captured almost everything in fight here to-day and made records for new alleys which have just opened that will be difficult to supplant. The match between picked teams from both cities has been the sole topic of discussion for several weeks among clubmen, and despite the inclement weather the alleys were fringed with a crowd which, while highly enthusiastic, was impartial in its approbation.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- A bill amending the law creating the Rapid Transit Commission of New York City will be introduced in the Legislature to-morrow. It was brought to Albany this evening by Charles M. Hervey, who is a confidential clerk in Controller Grout's office.

Capt. Miles O'Reilly of the West Thirtieth Street Station assigned Detectives Gorman and Hollman to watch the offices of J. E. Gardner Co., the alleged turf syndicate, on the fifteenth floor of the Flatiron Building, yesterday morning. The detectives arrived at the place about 9 o'clock.

RICHMOND, Feb. 16. -- William R. Trigg, founder of the Richmond Locomotive Works and the Trigg shipyards, died tonight. He was stricken with paralysis nearly two years ago, and had not been well since.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Senate Committee on the Judiciary to-day concluded consideration of the Littlefield Anti-Trust bill and decided to report it to the Senate, with a number of very important amendments. The most important changes were made in connection with Sections 6 and 7 of the House bill, for which the Senate committee will recommend complete substitutes.

The event of most interest in the outside market yesterday was the seven point recovery in Standard Oil which followed the announcement of the 20 per cent. dividend on that stock. There were several other changes of more of less consequence in various parts of the list, but they were mostly, in stocks which have not a very large following, and the movements of which are therefore not so much a matter of general interest.

Mr. BALFOUR and Lord CRANBORNE have endeavored to explain away the Anglo-German "co-operation" which the latter frankly called a "mess." Lord LANSDOWNE was doubtless better advised in holding his tongue in public about it. Whatever happens, he will have nothing to take back.

CARLISLE, Penn., Feb. 17 -- Col. Richard H. Pratt, founder of the Carlisle Indian School, resigned his Superintendency of the institution to-day, in a telegram to the Department of the Interior. This resignation followed a few minutes after the receipt here of official notification from the War Department of Col. Pratt's retirement with the grade of Colonel.

The Manhattan Cricket Club held its annual meeting yesterday at the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn, where, despite the unfavorable weather, there was an unusually large and enthusiastic gathering of the members of New York's oldest club. The chief business of the meeting was the election of officers, which resulted as follows:

The last of the Wednesday cotillions will be danced this evening, and from the old organization will spring new century dances, with a smaller membership. This evening's dance will be th'e largest gathering of this date. Wednesday is a favorite for weddings, and this is the last Wednesday of the season, as Lent will begin a week from to-day.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- There was a lively fight in the Senate to-day over the bill introduced by Senator Hill of Buffalo, giving to foreign corporations now having an office in the State the right to compel any one bringing action against them to begin suit in the place in which the corporation's residence in the State is located.

Most of the trading in the outside market yesterday was in the copper-stocks, which showed greater activity than at any time within the last ten days. For some days, past only a few of these stocks held places of any prominence, but yesterday activity was displayed by nearly all the issues of this group, and in most cases the increase in transactions was accompanied by more or less substantial advances.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Opponents of the proposition to spend $82,000,000 or more in improvements of the State canals, according to the 1,000-ton barge project, had a hearing before the joint legislative committee. Representatives of the State Grange, and of localities which would not be immediately affected by the project, made speeches. Replies were made by persons interested in the improvement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I disagree so entirely with an article in your publication of this morning concerning Mr. Theobald Chartran's paintings (now on exhibition at Knoedler's gallery) that I cannot resist rushing into print. That is, if you will offer the hospitality of your universally read paper to a line or two of counter criticism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Army Appropriation bill, which has been in conference several days, was agreed on to-day, and will be sent to the President for approval to-morrow or Thursday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Three more students of Cornell University died from typhoid fever to-day. They were Otto Wohls of Rochester. Henry A. Schoenborn of Hackensack, and Charles J. Schlenker of Batavia.

Weather statisticians did not have to tell New Yorkers that yesterday's snowstorm was the fiercest of the last two Winters. The fact became apparent as soon as one poked his nose out of doors, for drifts three or four feet deep were piled up on The sidewalks. The business of the entire city was set back by the storm, and not until late in the morning did traffic resume even half its usual regularity.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- When, the House of Commons assembled for the transaction of business this afternoon, the Speaker, Mr, Gully read the king's speech to a somewhat slim House. Mr. Gratton, Conservative moved the address in reply to the speech, and in so doing expressed satisfaction at the termination of the Venezuelan blockade and at the fact that throughout the difficult affair cordial relations had been maintained with the United States.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The interest in the international billiard tournament is increasing daily. The Salle des Fetes of the Grand Hotel was crowded to its utmost capacity when George Slosson and George Sutton, the only Americans in the tournament, commenced to play to-night. Besides many noted professionals and amateurs, the spectators included Count Greffulhe, Marquis de Mun, I.S. Thorndike, the Prince and Princess of Barrentasky, Maurice Daly, and many Americans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The fate of the Ship Subsidy bill will be determined next Monday, according to an arrangement reached this morning. At a meeting of the committee, from which several members were absent, Chairman Grosvenor announced that he would not bring the subject up without giving everybody fair notice and getting as full an attendance as possible.

The Century Realty Company has bought, through Richard M. Montomery from William F. Havemeyer, the old six-story buildings running through from 67 and 69 Wall Street to 87 and 89 Beaver Street. The plot has frontages of 73.7 feet on Wall Street and 77.1 feet on Beaver Street, and contains about 8,000 square feet.
Bar silver was quoted in the London market at 22 3-16d per ounce and in New York at 48 1/8c per ounce. Mexican dollars were quoted at 37 3/4@39 3/4c.

Money easy at 2 3/4@3 per cent. on call. Stocks irregular. Yesterday was the anniversary of the great storm of 1902 which disordered the markets until the close of the month. There is not now such unprecedented damage to all forms of communication as was then endured for nearly a fortnight, but business was naturally somewhat deranged both by poor attendance and by interruption to wire services.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, accompanied by Miss Root, reached New Orleans this afternoon. Their train was several hours late owing to the floods and blizzard. They were met at the railway station by John and Paul McIlhenny and driven to the temporary home of the McIlhennys, on Louisiana Avenue.

At a meeting of the University Settlement Council, held last evening in the City Club, a letter sent to Mayor Low earlier in the day, urging a definite policy for the city's beautiftcation, was approved. In addition a committee of five members was selected to call on the Mayor to urge that project and to advocate the immediate establishment of another east side park somewhere between Allen Street and the Bowery, Houston, and Grand Streets.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 17. -- In the sixth round of the international chess tournament here to-day Teichmann beat Moreau, Centre Counter Gambit, in 24 moves; Schlechter beat Reggio, Queen's Gambit declined, in 19 moves, and the game between Mason and Taubenhaus resulted in a draw after 32 moves.

It was not Tolstoi's "Resurrection" that was seen last night at the Victoria, nor yet the faithful stage version of it by the young French disciple of the great Russian, Henri Bataille. It was Michael Morton's English version of the French play, which Beerbohm Tree has advertised as less shocking than the French play to the sensibilities of Mrs. Grundy, and which was simultaneously produced last night at His Majesty's Theatre, London.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Mrs. William Thaw, formerly of Pittsburg, but temporarily residing in Washington; to-day announced the engagement of her daughter Alice to the Earl of Yarmouth, who, with Miss Thaw, is the guest of the latter's sister, Mrs. George Carnegie at Cumberland Island, off the coast of Florida.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 17 -- Federal officers on the Yukon River confirm the story that a gold strike equaling that of the Klondike or Cape Nome has been made in the Tanana River Valley. Two thousand miners are stampeding thither from Nome, Dawson, Eagle, Rampart, and other Yukon camps.

The passage by the Senate or the Lodge bill for regulating the currency of the Philippines is reported to make its ultimate enactment secure, the House conferrees being likely to accept it in place of the bill passed by the House.

Police Commissioner Greene has received complaints concerning the business methods of C.E. Rand Co. of 169-171 Broadway, who advertise to invest money for correspondents on the races, and declare that they guarantee 3 per cent, a week on all deposits, and a quarterly dividend according to their profits, and as a result Detective Sergeants McConville, Peabody, and Clarke raided the place late yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- The money market is slightly firmer, but rates are not materially changed. Call loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 8/4@5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 1/2@4 per cent.; New York funds were offered at 10c discount, but there were no sales; Clearings, $25,587,053; balances, $1,707,004.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, Feb. 17 -- Samuel L. Parrish, in an address on " Colonization and Civil Government in, the Tropics," delievered to-night at the annual meeting of the Suffolk County Historical Society, said, regarding the acquisition of the Philippines:

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Attorney General McCarter to-day obtained a rule to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed for the Monmouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company from Vice Chancellor Reed in this city. The order is returnable on Tuesday next.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- William F. King, Foster Crowell, E. Brinckerhoff, Dr. Soper, F.D. Woodward, and S.C. Mead, representing the Merchants' Association of New York City, called upon Gov. Odell to-day and requested that legislation be enacted increasing the membership of the State Railroad Commission to five.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The Times says that the stage version of Tolstoi's "Resurrection," prepared by Henry Bataille and Michael Morton, which was produced by Beerbohm Tree and his company at His Majesty's Theatre on Tuesday evening, was deeply impressive as a moral lesson, but as a drama it belongs unmistakably to the category of the second best.

So many of the lawn tennis experts have entered for the indoor national championship which begins to-day that the tournament promises to be remarkable for high class sport. The present meeting is the fourth annual tournament since the event was inaugurated. As heretofore, the matches will be played on the drill floor of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- On the reassembling of the House of Lords the Duke of Roxburghe (Unionist) moved the address in reply to the King's speech, and the Earl of Leitrim seconded the motion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Secretary Hay, for the United States, and Mr. Bowen for Venezuela, to-day signed a protocol providing for the adjustment of United States claims against Venezuela by a commission to meet at Caracas.

Had bankers been able to secure sterling at Paris at a reasonable rate yesterday, it is declared that a gold export engagement would almost certainly have been made during the day -- this because of the advance in sterllng at this centre of from five to ten points, bringing the rate practically up to the gold shipping point.

The change in the Presidency of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company is naturally taken as an earnest of an intention to improve the service and meet the needs of the present and future as completely and rapidly as possible.

Mayor Low in the second installment of his annual message to the Board of Aldermen recommends that the term of the executive head of the city shall be four years, and that this change go into effect on May 1, 1906. The first installment of the message was given out several weeks ago, and dealt with rapid transit and other problems.

It is plain that that pestilent agitation for the total or partial nullification of the safeguards of the tenement house law which proceeds from the Borough of Brooklyn will find some reinforcement from the Borough of the Bronx. The conditions in which this agitation originates are similar in both boroughs.

The Crescent Athletic Club and the Hockey Club of New, York will meet in a league championship game at the Clermnont Avenue Rink, in Brooklyn, to-night. While it is almost a foregone conclusion that the champion Crescent will come out on top, they cannot except to beat the lively Hockey Club experts, however, without some trouble.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 17 -- President McDoel of the Monon is authority for the statement that it is the intention of his company to build the branch connecting this city with the Louisville line as soon as possible.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- District Attorney Jerome did not come to Albany to-day to advocate his excise bill at the hearing before the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, and there was not a madder man in the city than Assemblyman Howard Conkling, who introduced the measure at Mr. Jerome's request.
