Nathan Springer, who is considered by District Attorney Jerome to be the chief of the personal tax fraud conspiracy, was placed on trial yesterday before Justice Herrick, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court for attempted subornation of perjury.

Joseph M. Singleton, a Chinaman who wears his hair in the American fashion with the parting on the left side, and attires himself in his American clothes, gave a dinner last night at 24 Pell Street to members of the Supreme Court, the Judges, and Justices of other courts, and a number of American and Chinese friends.
Three alarms for a fire aboard the Rio Grande of the Mallory Line, docked at Pier 21 East River, at Burling Slip, were sent in about midnight last night.
Leave or absence for one month is granted Major Lea Febiger, Seventh Infantry.

Three, games played and one default was the record of the second day's play yesterday for the amateur, racquet championship of the United States at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. George C. Clark, Jr., of Boston, won his way into another round without the necessity of playing. The victors in the three contested games were Payne Whitney and Morton S.Paton of the New York Club, and W.R. Miller of Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House today began consideration of the Naval Appropriation bill under the operation of a rule which made the new legislation relative to the increase of the personnel of the navy and for the increase of the Naval Academy in order. The general debate on the bill was without special feature.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 17 -- The slight increase in the buying of investment, bonds was the chief feature of the day. There was a slight advance in Baltimore Brick, due to the filing of the mortgage for $1,000,000, when $1,500,000 was popularly expected. This cutting down of fixed charges brings the preferred within the range of possible dividend payment during the next two years.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The rates for money and for discount were firm to-day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Representatives Littlefield (Rep., Me.,) and Sulzer (Dem., N.Y.,) clashed in the House to-day as a result of a speech made by Mr. Sulzer last Saturday.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- These bills were introduced in the State Senate to-day:

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- King Edward, accompanied by Queen Alexandra, and surrounded by the Court and all the officers of State, opened Parliament this afternoon. His Majesty read his speech from the steps of the throne, as follows:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The conclusions reached by the State Bank Examiner in the Monmouth Trust Company case reached here this evening from Trenton and have created a sensation. Until this official statement of affairs became known no one here dreamed that the affairs of the company were in anything like the state the Examiner represents.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 17 -- A hurricane struck the passenger steamboat Olive, which plies between Franklin, Va., and Edenton, N.C., early this morning and sent her to the bottom of the Chowan River, off Woodley's Pier, between Mount Pleasant and Oliver's Wharf.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The office of the Nicaragua Company, in the Exchange Building, was raided to-day by Government officers and Frank N. Bittinger, Henry A. Burnham, and Orlin N. Vincent were arrested. The prisoners were charged with a fraudulent use of the mails. Bittinger's bond was placed at $5,000 and that of his associates at $500.

By what public demand or private prompting has Controller GROUT been moved to send to Albany a bill reorganizing the Rapid Transit Commission? The Mayor and the Corporation Counsel, it appears, do not join him in the sponsorship for this measure. Apparently, they have not been consulted.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Charges against Sheriff Henry M. Kaiser of Erie County, were to-day lodged with Gov. Odell and the removal of the Sheriff asked. The Rev. O.P. Gifford, pastor of the Delaware Avenue Baptist Church of Buffalo, stands as sponsor for the charges. The Governor, set March 2 for a hearing, and a messenger left to-night to serve the charges on Kaiser.

In the tournament of the Life Insurance Bowling League last night, the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company bowlers won three straight games from the second team of the Prudential Life Insurance Com- pany. The scores follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- There was a lively debate in the Senate to-day over Senator Quay's resolution declaring it to be the sense of the Senate that there should be a vote on the Statehood bill before the adjournment of Congress. As a substitute for that proposition Senator McComas reoffered Senator Platt's cloture resolution, introduced two years ago, and a motion was made to refer the whole proposition to the Committee on Rules.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Members of the House again indulged in sharp language to-day, the occasion being the discussion of the conference report on the Army Appropriation bill. Mr. Hull (Rep., Iowa.) declared a statement by Mr. Slayden (Dem., Texas,) was untrue, and the result was an interchange of warm remarks.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- At the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Williams, in Brookline, at noon to-day the wedding of their daughter. Miss Gladys Williams, and Albert Francis Bigelow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Smith Bigelow of this city, took place. As Mrs. Williams has recently recovered from a severe illness it was decided to have the ceremony on a simple scale.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 -- Manshak, who landed the Carnival Stakes, worth $1,045 to the winner, by a neck, was the only winning favorite to-day. Backed from 6 to 5 to 9 to 10, and the favorite in the betting, the colt outbroke his field, showing all the early speed, and though tiring at the end had enough left to land the prize.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The stringency in the money market increased to-day owing to revenue collections and preparations for the payment of large railroad dividends. Discounts sympathized with the money market. Opinions regarding the possibility of a reduction of the Bank of England's rate of discount to-morrow were divided.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 18 -- E.E. Clark, Grand Chief of the Order of Railway Conductors and a member of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission, spoke in Faneuil Hall to-day under the auspices of the Twentieth Century Club. The address was a conservative and thoughtful one and was listened to attentively by an audience that was considered too small for the occasion.

Three New Yorkers and one Bostonian are now left in the amateur racquet championship tournament of the United States. They are Morton S. Paton, Payne Whitney, Lawrence Waterbury, and Quincy A. Shaw, Jr. The latter is the Boston representative. He was runner-up for the championship last year to Clarence Mackay, and is regarded as one of the most likely winners of the honor this year.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The New York Bar Association, through the Secretary of its Committee on Amendments, Charles Buckley Hubbell, to-day filed a protest with the Codes Commitee against the bill introduced by Mr. Monroe of Tompkins County which provides that the wages of a workingman drawing a salary of more than $12 a week may be garnisheed for a debt created by him in the purchase of the necessaries of life.

Acting under instructions from Capt. Langan of the Detective Bureau, detectives yesterday went to the building at 63 Park Bow and arrested two men who they say were interested in a "turf investment" scheme.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18 -- As a result of the inability of President Ramsey and the committee of the Wabash trainmen and conductors to come to an agreement the situation has assumed a serious aspect. After a conference yesterday, the committee ordered a poll of the system on the demand for the schedule similar to that granted recently by the St. Louis lines.

The closing arguments were made yesterday in the case of Nathan Springer, chief of the alleged tax fraud conspiracy, on trial before Justice Herrick. No defense was offered on behalf of Springer. Justice Herrick will give the case to the jury today.

An audience that filled the basement of St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church on Forty-third Street, near Lexington Avenue, last evening cheered to the echo sentiments against England uttered by Joseph Devlin, Member of Parliament for North Kilkenny, and the Rev. Dr. Brann, the pastor of St. Agnes's Church.

Albert B. Ashforth has sold for Dr. Edward M. Kellogg 132 and 134 East Thirty-sixth Street, southwest corner of Lexington Avenue, two dwellings, on plot 33.8 by 74, which will be converted into an American basement house by their now owner. Mr. Ashforth has also bought for a client from A.K. and R.T. Mackay the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 130 East Thirty-sixth Street, 16.8 by 74.

Important meetings of major and minor baseball league interests which will have some bearing on the National game during the coming season are scheduled to take place here during the latter part of this month and the beginning of March. The first of these was begun at the Victoria Hotel yesterday, when the National Board of the National Association of Minor Baseball Leagues assembled at the call of President P.T. Powers.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The three bolting Republican Senators to-day enlisted a recruit in a fight which they made in conjunction with the minority to prevent the jamming through of the Governor's bill providing for a tax of 10 cents on every dollar involved in real estate transfers. He was Senator McEwan of Albany County, who voted to recommit the bill for a hearing.
BRISTOL, R.I., Feb. 18 -- Orders were issued at the Herreshoff shops to-day to have work rushed on the new yacht for the America's Cup syndicate so that the hull may be completed by April 15.
Senator McLaurin of South Carolina, who is at the Waldorf-Astoria, said yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- George B. Cortelyou was sworn in to-day as Secretary of Commerce and Labor. The oath of office was administered by Chief Justice Fuller. The Chief Justice also administered the oath to William Loeb, as Secretary to the President.

CUTCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 18 -- The Greenport passenger train with two engines attached, spent a large part of last night in a snowdrift in the Cutchogue cut. The train reached Greenport about 5 o'clock this morning.

Stocks dull and heavy. Between dullness due to holidays past and approaching and stagnation upon general principles, yesterday's transactions in stocks are not an enlivening subject of remark. Amalgamated and Anaconda were again exceptions to the rule of dullness and weakness.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 18 -- It was given out to-day that Councilor Charles E. Cook, in behalf of himself and clients holding claims to the extent of $32,000 against the Monmouth Trust Company, will make application for a local receiver next Tuesday before Vice Chancellor Reed at Trenton upon the return of the rule to show cause why a receiver should be appointed, issued yesterday in behalf of Attorney General McCarter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Major Gen. Hughes will retire from active service on account of age on April 11 next, and, in anticipation of that, the President sent to the Senate to-day the nomination of Gen. Breckinridge, Inspector General, to succeed Hughes, and the nomination of Gen. Ludington, Quartermaster General, to succeed Breckinridgre upon the retirement of the latter, which will follow immediately after he reaches the higher grade.

A thundercloud has been gathering of late in the faces of the established Broadway managers. Since it was announced that Williams and Walker, with their allnegro musical comedy, "In Dahomey," were booked to appear at the New York Theatre, there have been times when the trouble-breeders have foreboded a race war.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Senator Frawley will to-morrow introduce a bill the purpose of which is to revive professional boxing in New York under certain restrictions.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- The attendance at this evening's game of the international billiard tournament between George Slosson (American) and Louis Cure, (French,) held in the Grand Hotel, was very large. Many of the spectators expected that Slosson's recovery of his usual form, which was shown toward the close of yesterday's game, would be continued to-night.

The ninth annual banquet of the Catholic University of Washington, D.C., was held last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria. Father P.J. Hayes, President of the Alumni Association and secretary to Archbishop Farley, presided and made an address urging sympathy and support for the university which, he said, was the crowning glory of the system of Catholic education which has its roots in the parochial school system.

Attorney General KNOX's cablegram to President Bo constitutes an agreement which binds the United States Government to buy the rights and property of the New Panama Canal Company for $40,000,000, provided the pending treaty with Colombia shall be ratified. The rejection of the treaty would release us from the agreement.

There was considerable speculation about the Criminal Courts Building yesterday as to whether Reginald C. Vanderbilt and some of the other prominent witnesses in the case of the people against David W. Bucklin, Canfield's manager, would be on hand on Monday, when the case will be brought to trial before Justice D. Cady Herrick in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- There was no market for New York exchange to-day. The nominal money rate was 5 per cent., with concessions as low as 4 1/2 by a number of institutions. Country banks are about holding their own. Their deposits as well as their accounts with local banks have been increased.

A jury in the United States Circuit Court yesterday awarded Mrs. Cornelia B. Phelps, the widow of Dr. Abel M. Phelps, the $5,000 damages for injuries received on the Netherlands-American Steam Navigation Company's steamship Statendam in July, 1900.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Lord De Freyne has recommenced the action against John E. Redmond, John Dillon, Michael Davitt, and other leaders of the United Irish League which he dropped six months ago. Lord De Freyne last June obtained a writ against these Irish leaders on the charge of conspiracy in connection with the tenant troubles on the De Freyne estate, Roscommon County.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Mrs. Ellen C. Richter of Syracuse, N.Y., is in Washington for the purpose of makin an effort to have the President take up the case of her son, who was an enlisted man in the Twenty-eighth Infantry, and who died in the Philippines under alleged tortures inflicted by direction of Lieut. William S. Sinclair.

A curious pamphlet reaches us from the office of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals of Calcutta which, while not exactly pleasant reading, is interesting and instructive. It epitomizes the literature of a movement to discourage and suppress the practice which obtains among the herders of Mofussil and the United Provinces of removing the skins from goats before killing them.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Justice Van Syckle to-day filed in the Court of Errors and Appeals the opinion in the Steel Trust case, the decision of which was announced ten days ago. The opinion, which covers thirty-nine pages completely, upholds the contentions of the Steel Corporation lawyers.

Ideal sleighing weather and a snow path that has been unequaled this Winter drew a great throng of road drivers to the Central Park drives, Seventh Avenue, and the Speedway yesterday afternoon. In the Park there were sleighs of every kind and description from the home-made box sleigh to the handsome park rig, resplendent in silver, trimmings and drawn by prize-winning high-steppers.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 18 -- The annual bench show of the New Jersey Kennel Association was opened in the Armory Building to-day, and will continue during the remainder of the week. The entry list is unusually large, 935 dogs being on exhibition.

EDINBURGH, Feb. 18 -- The Court of Session to-day awarded to the Government of Spain $337,500 in the action begun here on Jan. 20 by the Spanish Minister of Marine, Sanchez Toca, to recover $375,000 from the Clydebank Engineering and Shipbuilding Company because of the company's failure to deliver on contract time four torpedo-boat destroyers.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 -- The market was inactive, but the feeling and buying were sufficiently good to make possible a preponderance of advances over declines. The advance of 2 1/2 points in Norfolk Railway 5s was hardly a noteworthy, feature because of the time elapsing between the last recorded sale and the one of to-day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- The so-called Beef Trust case was disposed of by Judge Grosscup in the United States Circuit Court today, the demurrer of the packers being overruled and a temporary injunction granted. The attorneys for the packers made no announcement of their intentions. They have until March, 4 to discuss the matter with their principals.

The President has nominated to the head of the new Department of Commerce and Labor his secretary, Mr. CORTELYOU, and to be Commissioner of Corporations in that department Mr. GARFIELD, at present a member of the Civil Service Commission. The former appointment is significant chiefly because the new Secretary is intimately known to the President and his policy in the department will probably represent the President's views very closely.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Senate Cities Committee to-day favorably reported the bill introduced by Senator Elsberg for an increase in the police force of New York City. The bill provides for the appointment by the Commissioner of Police of a Chief Inspector, two Borough Inspectors, for the appointment of 500 patrolmen in 1903, and the same number in 1904, and 200 men annually thereafter, and for more Roundsmen.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Representatives of eighteen trust companies throughout New York State to-day opposed the Marshall bill prohibiting trust companies, department stores, or any firm or corporation from doing a savings bank business or advertising that they receive savings accounts.

William Thorp in Harper's Weekly. During many weeks spent in Venezuela recently I had unbounded oppprtunity to make an intimate study of Castro in his palace at Caracas and during his holiday festivities at La Victoria, when he threw off the Presidential paint and became his natural self.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Objections to the New York Central Terminal bill were presented at the hearing given to-day by the Assembly Railroads Committee.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- The appeal of W.K. Vanderbilt, who was sentenced in default last year to two days imprisonment on the charge of driving an automobile at excessive speed in the Champs Elysees, was resumed to-day before M. Becker, Justice of the Peace of the Thirteenth Division.

In the current number of Charities a temperate but impressive protest is offered against the passage of a couple of bills pending in the Senate for the abolition of the Reformatory for Women at Bedford, the removal of its inmates to the Houses of Refuge at Hudson and Albion, and the conversion of the property into a State hospital for the insane.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- There was not much disposition to trade in this market to-day, the sales aggregating only 20,953 shares and $170,200 bonds. The only active issues were the arbitrage stocks -- Reading, Erie, and United States Steel. The asphalts were more liberally dealt in than at any previous time since their collapse, but prices made little change.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- A report that the Grand Opera House and the Great Northern Theatre had been added to a circuit of high-priced houses to compete with syndicate theatres was dented to-day by Fred Hamling, manager of the Grand Opera House, and at the Great Northern.

Not a day very lively for the carnival yesterday. The Wednesday Cotillion, a few weddings and receptions, Mrs. Frederick Bell's dinner, and that of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherfurd Stuyvesant were among the larger events. This evening there will be the last of the two dinner dances organized by Mrs. Frederick J. de Peyster and J. Montgomery Strong at Delmonico's.
Boston United Gas Company bonds stricken from the list of the Boston Stock Exchange by order of Committee on Stock List.

It was an exhibition game of Hockey that Queens University played against Princeton last night at St. Nicholas Rink, for at no time was Princeton's pan in the game anything more than theoretical. The final score was 11 to 0, but even so wide a difference in the score does not indicate the disparity in the quality of play.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Eight colored men hold commissions as officers of the United States Army, of whom one is a graduate of the Military Academy of the class of 1889. This officer is Capt. Charles Young of the Ninth Cavalry, who is serving with his troop at the Presidio, San Francisco.

Fear that a blizzard had struck the city came to those who happened to be in the streets at 9:50 o'clock last evening, when there came a burst of snow from a cloud rolling over Manhattan Island. For a few minutes the flakes flew so furiously that it was difficult for pedestrians to grope their way along.

Dr. LOUIS BELL, who has had a large and instructive experience with electric transportation in large cities, in a paper contributed to The Electrical Review says of the overcrowding of the surface cars of New York: "The fundamental cause of overcrowding is the combination of a twelve-story city with a one-story street.
In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the Berkeley team won two of three games with the Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark. The scores follow:
ROME, Feb. 19 -- The Pope's jubilee, or the twenty-fifth anniversary of his election, tomorrow, will be ushered in by a high mass in the Basilica, celebrated by Cardinal Rampolla.
Details relative to the purchase of the Sturtevant House by the United States Realty and Construction Company will be found in another column.

Presiding Justice W.W. Goodrich of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department, speaking at the annual dinner of the Brooklyn Bar Association at the Brooklyn Club last evening, protested against what he termed "the vicious invasion which is threatening the usefulness of the bench" and decried the "Judge who is listening with expectant ear to the bee of political preferment buzzing in his bonnet."

Transit schemes of the past in the City of New York become insignificant when compared with the elaborate plans reported to the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday by its Chief Engineer, William Barclay Parsons. His proposed changes, which the Mayor and the commission will push rapidly, include the following:

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Veterans of New York City are interested in a bill which Assemblyman Remsen introduced to-day. It provides that in every case where the salary of a veteran was reduced by the Board of Estimate and Apportion- ment of the city it shall be restored to its former figure, and that amount of money which the veteran lost by reason of the reduction shall be refunded to him.

The Congressional Record of Feb. 17 contains a comparative table of the navies of the world, prepared by the Bureau of Naval Intelligence, and submitted by Capt. SIGSBEE, its chief, which we suppose is to be accepted as the closest bringing down to date of which the case admits of this very interesting and important information.

There was real suffering in New York yesterday, it being the coldest Feb. 19 on record. The lowest official mark was at 8 A.M., when the thermometer of the Weather Bureau recorded two degrees above zero. The temperature recorders in the streets, especially those at wind-swept corners, had lower marks.

Three men were instantly killed, a fourth fatally mangled, three more injured probably fatally, and two others hurt in an explosion of an eight-inch shell at 2:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon in one of the filling rooms in Fort Lafayette, the old fort just below Fort Hamilton, which is used by the ordnance department of the navy for loading and unloading shells used on battleships and cruisers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The postal officials are keeping a sharp lookout for literature prepared to deceive confiding and ignorant colored people in connection with the bill introduced in the Senate by Mr. Hanna to pension ex-slaves. Two years ago fraud orders were issued against efforts of this kind, and it is highly probable that it will become necessary to issue similar orders again.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The stringency of the money market continued to-day.

With the temperature below zero and a high wind blowing from the west, the ferryboat Pierrepont of the Hamilton Avenue ferry line, which left her slip at the foot of Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, went ashore on the east end of Governors Island, and was stranded until noon, when the tide rose and a tug was able to pull her off.

President Roosevelt's policy in regard to the appointment of negroes in the South to Federal places received hearty indorsement last evening at a meeting held in Cooper Union. Bishop Walters of Jersey City delivered an address, in which he told of the disenfranchisement of negroes in Southern States.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 19 -- A brilliant society event was the bal blanc given to-night by Dr. and Mrs. Henry Barton Jacobs at their beautiful home in Mount Vernon Place. There were nearly two hundred guests, including the following:

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Sixteen new cases of typhoid fever developed here today. None of them, however, was among the students of Cornell University. Three fever patients were discharged from Cornell Infirmary to-day and sent to their homes to convalesce. These were the first cases to recover in the present epidemic.

Members of the Delaware Society of New York held their thirteenth annual dinner last evening at Sherry's. Among the speakers were Bishop Leighton Coleman of the Delaware diocese. Capt. P.F. Harrington, United States Navy, and W.W. Smithers. Gov. Hunn of Delaware, who was to have delivered an address on "The State of Delaware" telegraphed from Dover that he was snowbound.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- When the Senate Committee on Education met this evening for a hearing upon the Brown bill providing for the creation of a Board of Education in connection with the Regents to take charge of the common schools of the State, James Russell Parsons, the Secretary of the Board of Regents, asked that the hearing be adjourned for a week.

Quincy A. Shaw, Jr., of Boston and Payne Whitney or the New York Racquet and Tennis Club will meet to-morrow at the latter club to determine the racquet championship of the United States. The semi-final round was played yesterday and to-day the finalists will take a rest in preparation for the supreme match.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- J. Gardner Cassatt, head of the banking house of Cassalt Co., to-day gave out a statement in which he says that Howard T. Goodwin, formerly confidential clerk of the firm, who committed suicide last December, was a defaulter to the extent of from $60,000 to $80,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Senators Brackett and Elsberg have not lost favor with Gov. Odell, despite his displeasure over their action yesterday in voting for the recommittal of his conveyance tax bill. Senator Brackett has been given the assurance that at the first opportunity that offers his friend, W.W. Worden of Saratoga will be cared for.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Just when the way seemed clear to force a vote on the Panama Canal treaty the situation in the Senate took a surprising turn to-day. It was the purpose of the Republican leaders to tire out Senator Morgan with a night session, but Senator Quay smashed the whole programme by allying himself with the Alabamian in filibustering tactics.

As the facts respecting the epidemic of typhoid fever at Ithaca come to hand, they show a deplorable lack of executive capacity and an extremely weak sense of official responsibility on the part of the college authorities. Not only were they unprepared for the emergency which confronts them, but they have neglected to do what the situation forced upon them.

Members of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association assembled last evening in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the seventeenth annual dinner. More than three hundred guests attended. Mayor Low, who headed the list of speakers, commended the manner in which the newspaper publishers had formed their arbitration arrangements with certain branches of organized labor.

A fourth collection of remarkable canvases by old masters will be sold at Mendelssohn Hall on Thursday and Fridayevenings next week. They are on exhibition in three of the galleries of the American Art Association on Madison Square.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Admiral O'Neil, Chief of Ordnance, said that several months ago he had issued orders for the removal of the greater part of the ammunition stored at Fort Lafayette to the new naval magazine on Iona Island, forty miles up the Hudson.

It is no longer an Addicks scandal that afflicts the State of Delaware -- it is a Republican scandal. The ten regular Republicans might at any time end the long contest by agreeing with the Democrats that two Senators should be elected, one a Republican and the other a Democrat.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- At the end of a protracted session the House to-day passed the Navai Appropriation bill.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 -- Old Hutch and Sweet Alice were the winning favorites. Floyd K. was claimed out of the second race by Ed Trotter for $1,525, and subsequently was sold to S.C. Hildreth. Weather fine: track good. Summary:

One man was seriously injured and 300 pupils were badly frightened in a fire which destroyed the Westerleigh College, a private school, at Westerleigh, Richmond Borough, about noon yesterday. The man injured is Louis Griffith, a music instructor at the coliege. He jumped from a thirdstory window to the ground, a distance of seventy-five feet, breaking his right ankle and bruising his body.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- The golf tournament for the championship of South Florida and for the President's Cup, presented by Frederick Sterry; the Secretary's Cup, presented by C.B. Cory, and the Consolation Cup, presented by E.M. O'Neill, began here to-day with the qualification medal play round of 36 holes.

With stern rails smashed, upper davits and stanchions crushed, and signs of trouble, the Kronprinz Wilhelm of the North German Lloyd Steamship Line arrived in port yesterday morning after an adventurous and very rough passage from Bremen. The boat had her port side of the stern dented, her upper deck rail smashed, one of the davits smashed, and some of the stanchions in the stern bent.

We observe with interest that Senator DEPEW'S obituary remarks in the Senate, upon the character and career of the late AMOS J. CUMMINGS, have been "taken up" with a controversial intention by our esteemed contemporary The Tribune. That journal controverts every important statement of fact that the Senator made.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is the earnest wish of those actively interested in the good of our country that the passage of a shameful bill now before Congress be frustrated by the efforts of wise and human people who realize that the healthfulness, moral and physical, of the masses must not be sacrificed to the contemptible commercialism of a few.

NEWARK, Feb 19 -- A trolley car crowded with boys and girls on their way to school this morning slid its locked wheels on slippery rails down the slight hill in Clifton Avenue from Orange Street, crashed through the railroad safety sates that had been lowered, and out on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad tracks just as an east-bound express train sped over the crossing at a rate estimated at thirty miles an hour.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- The money market is considerably firmer. Money is scarce and quite difficult to obtain. Call loans, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 3/4 @ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 15 cents discount. Clearings, $23,596,768; balances, $1,361,679.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was limited to small totals, and the declines which occurred were sufficiently numerous to give the market an appearance or weakness. In some cases the falling off in prices was followed by more or less substantial recoveries, but in many instances the closing prices were very near the lowest of the day.

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 19 -- An official advertisement has been issued by the Southern Pacific Railroad giving notice that formal application will be made to the Legislature now in session by the Texas and New Orleans Railway Company, which is a part of the Southern Pacific system, for authority to sell its Sabine Pass-Dallas line.

Ernest Matthews, who was arrested by Detectives McConville, Peabody, and Clark on Wednesday afternoon for running a "turf investment scheme" in offices at 63 Park Row, under the name of "Dan Smith," was up for examination before Magistrate Breen in the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Feb. 19 -- The twelfth annual Tuskegee Negro Conference closed here to-day with a large attendance of educators from all over the South.

The weeding-out process is rapidly being pushed forward in the tennis tournament for the indoor championship of the United States in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue. The floor space of the big drillroom presented a busy scene all afternoon yesterday, the courts being occupied with players either contesting in their matches or practicing.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- These bills were passed by the Assembly to-day:

The career of Mr. HORACE WHITE in journalism has been long, active, and distinguished. We are glad to learn that it is not to be terminated by his retirement from the editorship of The Evening Post, since, according to the announcement made in that journal, he "retains an editorial connection" with the paper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The State Department has been advised by United States Minister Combs that the Congress of Honduras has confirmed the Presidential decree authorizing President Sierra to take the field as Commander in Chief of the army in the campaign against President-elect Bonilla.

-- In a discussion of the case of an Indiana man who knocked his wife down because she refused to leave the bread she was kneading and join him in family prayers, Harper's Weekly raises the question whether this man is not a curious survival of the past in more than his methods of marital persuasion. "Family prayers," it says, "which used to be common in this country, are a rare observance nowadays.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The President announced to-day the appointment of Judge William R. Day of Ohio to be Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States in place of Justice Shiras, whose resignation takes effect on the 24th inst.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- At the close of the session of the United States Court today Judge Ray summoned before him the jury that since noon had been striving to reach a verdict in the case of Henry Terwilliger, the Syracuse Post Office clerk, charged with robbing the mails. The foreman reported that the talesmen could not agree.
BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Mrs. Jack Gardner's Fenway museum was the scene of a distirguished gathering to-night, when she entertained the club members of the Thursday Evening Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Proctor has an amendment which he will offer to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, providing for the purchase of twenty-six acres of land, and the improvements thereon adjoining Fort Totten, Willetts Point. The land in question lies southwest of Fort Totten between the post and Bell Avenue.

At the fourth evening concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which was given last evening in Carnegie Hall, the audience -- very large in number, as all its New York audiences have been this season -- was confronted with notice of a disappointment as it entered the hall.
ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Increased interest and a larger attendance marked the opening of the second day of the Dog Show of the Now Jersey Kennel Association which is being held in Orange this week.

The dinner dance at Delmonico's was the chief event yesterday. Mrs. David Dow, Jr.'s, class will meet at Sherry's to-day. Among the at homes are to be those of Mrs. Lovell Hall Jerome, 138 West Twelfth Street; Mrs. James Brown, 125 East Thirty-eighth Street, and Mrs. Frank McCoy, 45 West Thirty-fifth Street.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The Russian Foreign Minister, Count Lamsdorff, has communicated to the French Government the fact that Russia yesterday received the last of the adherences of the European powers to the joint note to Turkey on the subject of reforms, thus making the action of the powers unanimous.

Versatile and clever as Herr Bonn has proved himself, the time has come when it is possible to tell in advance just about what he will do with every new part. This is because, on the one hand, his cleverness seldom rises to the height of commanding intelligence, and, on the other, his versatility is superficial, seldom achieving the texture or the freshness and surprise of deeply imaginative feeling.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bill to establish a pension fund with the New York City Bureaus of Buildings was introduced to-day by Assemblyman Bostwick. The project is promulgated at the instance of Superintendent Perez M. Stewart, and is said to have the approval of Mayor Low. It makes provision for pensioning employes who are permanently disabled or who have served twenty years.

There was a partly successful bear raid on Metropolitan and Metropolitan Securities stock, and incidentally on the entiregeneral market, yesterday, which was the culmination of a series of rumors in regard to Metropolitan and its allied interests and stock market affairs in general, which dates back to the end of last year.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: "Words are things and their apt use is power," but alas! without the power evincing soul, feeling, sentiment, the most beautiful of them become meaningless and empty, like a lovely marble, cold and stately, but without life; or further from being inanimate, they may become merely "a sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal," devoid of music.

The editors of the Twentieth Century Textbooks have made an excellent addition to their series in Prof. Gulick's volume entitled "The Life of the Ancient Greeks." The book is a thoroughly admirable attempt to reconstruct the essential elements of Greek civilization in the fourth and fifth centuries from the various sources -- historical, literary, and artistic -- which classical research has opened up to us.

Those who saw "Twelfth Night" as it was given yesterday afternoon by Mr. Franklin Sargeant and his pupils of the Empire Dramatic School received a fuller and truer impression of the manner in which Shakespeare intended his plays to be acted than has ever before been possible to the American public.

At the meeting last night of the Madison Square Republican Club, one of the Republican organizations in the Twenty-fifth Assembly District, Assemblyman Howard Conking presided, but Thomas J. Quinn, a member, occupied the centre of the stage. He wanted Edward M. Shepard indorsed for Mayor.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Money was scarce and in active demand in the market to-day. Discounts hardened on the knowledge that there would be no change in the Bank rate for a week at least.
Samuel Goldsticker has sold for the Beekman estate the five-story iron-front building 124 Front Street, between Wall and Pine Streets, 18.6 by 71.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- It is understood that the Administration is still awaiting a reply from the representatives of the Panama Canal Company in Paris in response to the cablegram of Attorney General Knox sent to President Bo of the canal company last Tuesday accepting the offer to sell the rights and franchises of the canal company to the United States for $40,000,000, contingent on the ratification of the treaty by the United States Senate.

This heavy paper bound volume, which has every appearance of being the sales catalogue of some defunct millionaire's collection of paintings, is really a very, useful and interesting assembly of reproductions in half tone and photogravure of the most distinctive work of Corot and Millet. ("Corot and Millet," with critical essays by Gustave Geffroy and Arsene Alexandre, New York: John Lane. 8vo.)

IN anthropological or ethnological guessing you may spend lifetime trying to find a solution to the double riddle: When or where was it that man found his early paradise? Was it in the wild woods or in cultured garden?

Have you received the Holy Ghost? This was apparently -- according to the A.V. -- the first question Paul asked when he came to Ephesus. It is a very important question for every one to ask himself or herself now. He asked it of professed disciples of the Lord Jesus Christ -- people who had been baptized.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Superintendent of Elections McCullagh came to Albany today and had a conference with Gov. Odell. He denied that his visit was due to reports that the Governor had concluded not to reappoint him. He said he came to see the Governor about an entirely different matter, and that the subject of his reappointment was not broached.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Prof. W.T. Harris, the head of the United States Bureau of Education, has a peculiar contro- versy on his hands. It has grown out of his action in removing from the bureau Dr. Arthur MacDonald, who has for many years been conducting some unique inquiries into the statistics of criminology.

Play in the indoor lawn tennis, tournament for the national championship title yesterday advanced the competitors to the semi-final round of the singles and one bracket in the semi-finals was also gained in the doubles. The light was particularly good yesterday afternoon in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, where the tournament is in progress.

Although it was very much out of season, and the scene was many miles from the pine woods of Canada, the Canadian Campfire Club camped out merrily in Madison Square Garden last evening and dined as they would have had to dine if the members were in their native country with their overcoats on.

Stocks strong. Stocks yesterday were as generally strong as they were weak on Thursday, and with better reason. Thursday's weakness was due to an incident which was correctly interpreted yesterday, and which is a discredit in the first place to those who are guilty of tainting the sources of information, and in the second place to those in authority who permit such things to be done without protest or discipline.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- The Committee on Foreign Relations this afternoon submitted to the Senate its report recommending the ratification of the reciprocity treaty with the United States without amendment. The report urges ratification because, it says, while Cubans might desire still more favorable relations with the United States the treaty as a whole unquestionably favors the interests of Cuba.

An enormous black ship cleaving mountainous waves and flying what seems to be the stars and bars in place of the flag of the United States, the whole on a background whose color would delight an Orangeman -- such is the "sensational" cover of "The American Invaders," (H. W. Bell. London and New York.)

James W. Osborne, as one of the speakers at the dinner of the Maryland Society last evening, attacked Northern Interference in the negro question and said that the President simply was playing for the negro votes in the next National Republican Convention. The expressions of Mr. Osborne's sentiments were applauded by the members of the society and their guests.

IN DISCUSSING the work of minor poets one is usually impelled to follow the counsel of Hans Andersen's Portuguese Duck -- to treat them with respect, since they have "song, manners, and education"; but it is human nature to agree with the Drake in the same philosophic tale -- that to get something to satisfy your hunger is the most important thing.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- London is somewhat interested, judging from the comments of the press, in the new international language called "Esperanto." So far as I have been able to learn any facts about the new language, it is a great improvement on Volapuk, which was preposterous from beginning to end.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- New York exchange was at 20c. discount before clearing, and at 30c. discount after clearing.

E.P. Dutton Co. will bring out next week "Social Germany in Luther's Time," being the memoirs of Bartholomew Sastrow, a Pomerantan lawyer, translated into English by Albert D. Vandam, with an introduction by Herbert A.L. Fisher of New College, Oxford. In this book Mr. Fisher says there "are no genial portraits, no sweet-tempered and mellow confidings of the heart such as comfortable men and women are wont to distill in a comfortable age.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The advance- ment of Inspector General Breckmridge and Quartermaster General Ludington to the grade of Major General, with a view to their retirement from active service, raises the question as to who will succeed them at the head of their respective departments.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: IN THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Jan. 31 Mr. J. Harvey Cook questions the character of Alexander Hamilton. It is probably true that he hated Jefferson.
The thirty-seventh annual dinner of the Harvard Club of New York at Delmonico's last night was distinguished by speeches dealing with matters not only of college interest but with larger questions.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Vignaux (French) won the sixth same in the international billiard championship tournament played here this evening, defeating Louis Cure (French) in twenty-one innings. The score was 500 to 403. Vignaux's average was 23 4-5 and Cure's 19 1-5. The best runs were -- Vignaux, 136, 102, 64, 30, and 26; Cure, 83, 51, 44, 35 and 25.

"The A B C of Photo-Micrography" (Tennant Ward, $1.25) is just what its title calls it, a practical handbook for beginners. The author, W.H. Walmsley of Philadelphia, is a Fellow of the Royal Microscopical Society and also of the American Academy of Applied Sciences, as well as a charter member of the American Microscopical Society.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Secretary of the Navy Moody has ordered the trial by court-martial of Ward K. Wortman, the Ensign in charge of the eight-inch turret of the Massachusetts when the recent explosion occurred on that vessel, which resulted in the death of the entire gun crew of nine.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- Emperor William's faith in God and Christ and in the authority of the Old Testament, as declared in his letter to Admiral Hollman. Councilor of the German Oriental Society, is accepted by the leading authorities of the State and Church as satisfactory evidence of his Majesty's orthodoxy, which for months had been the cause of deep concern to theologians and pastors.

Letters nave a decorative value, and the true artist knows how the printed page may become pleasant to the eye of the reader. Mr. Lewis F. Day tells this of Millet. As a boy he used to write verses of the Bible on the woollen gates in the fields, choosing his text to fit the bars. Each letter, he held, had a decorative value of its own, and its form meant something to him.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Has Mr. Alden's residence in London, which usually exercises a broadening influence on even so brilliant a man's intellectual horizon, so befogged it that he can only see by the dim lights of the linkboys of literature?

Forged naturalization papers are being distributed, according to information -- obtained yesterday afternoon in Commissioner Alexander's office in the Federal Building. If the story of the man who had a bogus document can be relied upon the place of distribution is .n the Federal Building.
The ball at Chatsworth is to be the principal event of the day. There are several luncheons and receptions this afternoon, and this evening the Saturday Dancing Class will meet at Delmonico's.

Through the confession of a man who says he was an accomplice in the scheme by which a band of conspirators in "Little Italy" during the last ten years have swindled more than a dozen insurance companies out of thousands of dollars, the District Attorney has obtained a detailed account of the inside working's of the scheme.

PAUL BOURGET first looked upon the spires of Oxford in the Spring of 1884. A view of Oxford on a clear May day is never to be forgotten. Bourget declared that since he had seen Venice no other city had carried his thoughts "so far away from the present."

To the January Connoisseur Leonard W. Tillingston contributed an account on "The Art of Extra Illustration," which is chiefly remarkable for its defense of the grangerite and its lack of reference to the "art" as practiced in the United States. In a bibliographical glossary the grangerite is defined as "one who mutilates books by cutting out the frontispieces, plates, and title-pages for the purpose of enriching his scrap album, or to extra-illustrate another book."

An essay upon "Spiral Formations in Nature and Art," by Theodore Cook, is in active preparation for early publication in this country by E.P. Dutton Co. Theodore Cook is perhaps known as the historian of some districts in France, but he is unfamiliar to students of biology and mathematics.

G.P. PUTNAM'S SONS have secured the American rights to Lord William Nevill's book, on his experiences of prison life, which they will bring out within the fortnight under the title of "Penal Servitude, by W.B.N."

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- G.R. Mewburn, Secretary of the English Lawn Tennis Association, yesterday dispatched a challenge to America for the international tennis championships. Both the Dohertys have promised to participate if they are wanted, but the representatives of the English association will not be selected until after the championship games here.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 -- After holding half a hundred policemen at bay for several hours, during which scores of shots were exchanged, Lafayette Sims, a desperate negro, was killed by officers early this morning in a negro boarding house. Sime occupied a room in the boarding house, in which there were seven beds.

Every year now there gather at Tuskegee, Ala., several hundreds of negroes from all parts of the South to confer, under the general direction of the Faculty of the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, as to the best means of promoting the permanent interests of their race.

A CRIMEAN NIGHT. LIEUTENANT SUTCH was the first of Gen. Feversham's guests to reach Broad Place. He arrived about 5 o'clock on an afternoon of sunshine in mid June, and the old red brick house, lodged on a southern slope of the Surrey hills, was slowing from a dark forest depth of pines with the warmth of a rare jewel.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Dullness and irregularity prevailed in the stock market to-day. Weakness was developed in the traction issues, the sensational reports about Metropolitan inducing some sympathetic selling of Philadelphia Rapid Transit. Philadelphia Company, on the other hand, was firmer on reports from Pittsburg that there was little prospect of a strike on the company's lines.

All day long from a few minutes after 9 o'clock in the morning until 6 o'clock last evening the ice floor of the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, was crowded with a representative gathering of Scotch and American curlers, many of whom, took part in the farewell bonspiel of the touring players from the Royal Caledonian Curling Club of Scotland.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Charles Frohman and George Edwardes have secured the English, American, and German rights of the musical play "Madame Sherry," which they will produce jointly in London this Spring and in New York in the Autumn. Mr. Frohman has also secured from George Edwardes the American rights of his next musical production.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 -- Wealth, Old Hutch, and Carl Kahler were the winning favorites to-day. Chickadee, the favorite in the fifth race, was beaten by Pollock's weak ride. Stratton II. was claimed out of the last race by F. Gering, Jr., for $1,385. Weather cloudy and cool; track fast. Summaries:

The latest number of The Geographical Journal, (which is the official organ of the Royal Geographical Society,) contains an article on the "Discovery of Spitzbergen," by Sir Martin Conway, whose "History of Spitzbergen" is now in press, and another on "Explorations in Mexico," by Carl Lumholtz, whose "Unknown Mexico" is one of the notable books of a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The President late this afternoon signed the Elkins rebate bill. With the signing of this measure the Administration's anti-trust programme for this session of Congress is completed.

THESE two handsome volumes reveal a markedly unusual type of New England character. Dr. Bowditch seems to have been a man of singularly frank affections, with none of that self-suppression so common in New England.

The largest steamship ever constructed slowly made her way, last evening between 6 and 8 o'clock, up New York Bay and the North River to the White Star piers at the foot of Bank Street. The huge vessel was the new transatlantic liner Cedric, a sister of the Celtic of the same fleet, but ninety-six tons larger.

The novel called "What Manner of Man," by Edna Kenton, is a study of what is commonly known as the "artistic temperament," and it is a novel far enough above the average level of merit encountered in the present year of grace to cause even tired reviewers to wake up and take hope once more.

Seven years ago the Hon. John Bigelow, LL. D., , gave to the world what he modestly termed a "monograph" on "The Mystery of Sleep," and this he has now revised and considerably enlarged to a volume of some 200 pages, besides appendices, published by Harper Brothers.

WILLIAM BURTON, the author of the present publication, is a practical potter. He has had experience in the daily routine of a factory devoted to the production of porcelain, and from this experience of his own he is fitted to judge of pottery products from the standpoint of a practical man.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was too dull to be worthy of much comment. The irregularity which recently has shown in prices was again in evidence, and while a few stocks enjoyed substantial advances, there were many more that added further losses to those recorded earlier in the week.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- According to a dispatch from Sofia published in this morning's Morning Leader, desperate fighting has occurred between a small band of revolutionaries and 800 Turks in a defile close to the village of Berik, near Kastoria, Albania.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- In the House to-day Mr. Overstreet (Ind.) called up the report of the conferrees on the bill for the protection of the President, which was adopted without division.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Though appreciating that you are doubtless yourselves alert, our information from various sources convinces us that there is far more than mere formal pressure on the part of subsidy promoters to secure favorable action at this session of Congress. We summarize as follows the more important of the information we have received from Republicans, as well as Democrats:

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 20 -- The ninth victim was added to-day to the list of lives lost in the disaster of yesterday morning, when a trolley car, crowded with High School pupils, slipped down the grade on Clifton Avenue and out on the tracks of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, where, running into an express train, it was dashed to pieces.

Whether President ROOSEVELT views with indifference or with disgust and alarm the effort of Gen. GROSVENOR to put life into the Frye Subsidy bill will depend upon the Presidential point of view. If the head of the Nation shares the belief of the Nation that the labors of GROSVENOR will come to nothing, the mention of the word subsidy will not disturb the serene atmosphere of the White House.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- St. Clair McKelway of Brooklyn to-day withdrew his resignation from membership in the State Board of Regents. He changed his determination at the solicitation of Gov. Odell and a large number of friends who desired him to continue as a member of that educational body.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The committee appointed by the President to select a site for the proposed, up-town Post Office in New York City has practically accepted the proposition of the Pennsylvania Railroad to sell the site in Eighth Avenue, running from Thirty-first to Thirty-third Street, directly west of the site of the proposed terminal station of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The great Dickens revival of the beginning of the twentieth century will be remembered in the years to come as a period of much activity on the part of publishers, theatrical "adapters," draughtsmen, and journalists who choose the easiest jobs and make as much of them as current "space rates" permit.

How far the railroads serving the commerce of this port have outstripped the canals in development was in part shown by the striking figures cited by Mr. A.B. HEPBURN at the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce on Thursday. We say in part because most of the figures of Mr. HEPBURN related to the progress of the last few years only.

Sally Wister's journal extends over a very brief period, having been begun Sept. 25, 1777, and ended June 20, 1778, when the young diarist was only sixteen years old. The notes wore addressed to her "very dear friend" Deborah Norris, in the hope "that some time hence (they may) give pleasure in a solitary hour," the Wisters having left Philadelphia at the outbreak of the war and taken refuge with friends in the country.
The Pere Marquette Railroad Company yesterday in publishing its earnings for the second week and for the first two weeks in February made the following explanation of the increase shown:

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The frequently mentioned "Memoirs" of the late M. de Blowitz will surely be published next Summer. The famous London Times correspondent's intimate knowledge of the inner workings of European diplomacy and his talent for making political subjects attractive and interesting to the general reader won him the high-sounding appellation of Prince of Journalists.

A little volume of sketches from life among Mocmons and Gentiles in Utah, by Grace Talbot, is called "Much Married Saints and Some Sinners," (Grafton Press.) It is evident that the author believes the Mormons are wicked. In all the tales the object is to show the hard lot of the Mormon woman and the evil of polygamy.

Mr. William V. Schwill is showing a score or more likenesses ou ladies and gentlemen in the Heinemann Art Gallery, 500 Fifth Avenue. Among them are two oil portraits and two preliminary drawings in pastel of Prince Heinrich of Prussia, one of which has been prepared for a New York club.

IN the study of social conditions nothing is more amazing than the changes found in Japan. The decline or the fall of a State generally is a lengthy process, but in the case of Japan, here is an insular country which in a comparatively short period has cast aside feudalism and accepted what looks like a legitimate form of government.

NO wonder that Mr. Winston Spencer Churchill's "The River War" is now in its third edition. That shows the interest taken in the work, for it must be counted among the best of the volumes which have appeared on the war in the Soudan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Filibustering tactics against the Panama treaty were employed again to-day by Senators Morgan and Quay, and with such success that the plan of a night session to force a vote on the convention was abandoned, temporarily at least, by the Senate steering committee.

An exact fac simile reproduction has been made of the twenty-one plates illustrating the "Book of Job," invented and engraved by William Blake, author of designs to "Blair's Grave" and "Young's Night Thoughts" (New York: G.P. Putnam's sons. London: J.M. Dent Co. 1,000 copies. $4 net.)

The exceptional strength and activity in the St. Louis and San Francisco shares led to all kinds of rumors, ranging from Morgan buying to the declaration of a dividend on the common stock or the granting of valuable rights to shareholders. Similar advances, however, have occurred on several occasions recently in the stocks only later to be succeeded by declines, and hence it is that yesterday's movement was looked upon with more or less suspicion.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- In his annual report made public to-day, Harry H. Bender, Fiscal Supervisor of State Charities, made one recommendation which is likely to stir up trouble between his department and the Department of Charities. He suggests the abolition of the department's salary classification commission.

For the second time in his career the doors of Sing Sing Prison will close on George Hamilton Pell, at one time prominent in social and financial circles in this city. Pell, who a week ago entered a plea of guilty on a charge of grand-larceny in the first degree, yesterday was arraigned before Justice Newburger, in the Court of General Sessions, and sentenced to servo three years and six months at hard labor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20 -- The freshman-sophomore inter-class indoor track games were held this afternoon and were won by the freshmen. The times made were not fast, but remarkably good for the condition of the track. Silver cups were given to the winners. C.R. Purtill, 1906, won the quarter-mile run in 57 seconds; Smitz 1905. second.

Mr. HENRY LOOMIS NELSON'S magazine article on "The Overshadowing Senate" has called public attention anew to a very real public nuisance and danger. But just at present it is the overshadowing Senator who appears as the nuisance of the hour. It behooves the Senate itself to take some order to circumvent or suppress him.

PROF. FLINT'S "Theism" long since arrived at the dignity of a classic on its particular line of speculation, and his "Anti-Theistic Theories" did no injury to his reputation as a careful and incisive reasoner upon the highest themes. His latest work is a product of long mental incubation, and, though distinctly a notable birth, its timeliness is less obvious than it would have been a dozen or twenty years ago.

If the city authorities decide to build the great system of subways recommended by Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons, and authorization is given for his proposed elevated railroads, the entire work of providing Manhattan and the Bronx with an adequate rapid transit service can be completed in three and a half years from the time the contracts are signed.

Rumors adverse to the interests of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company stopped short yesterday, and the stories denied or disposed of, the traction corporation and its securities' stocks became practically buoyant in a quiet market, the other stocks raided on Thursday rising with them.

Mr. Foster's a admirable volume on miniature painting in England showed to artists and art critics that he was not only an intelligent writer upon his subject, but that he had besides a certain artistic sense of selection as well as a scientist's patience in research, which enabled him to set off his text in the best possible way.

A sailor man has his own vocabulary -- more or less choice, and so the four-masted bark, the Royalshire, you may call at will a "wind-jammer" or a "lime-squeezer." Anyhow, she was a good craft, and had an able skipper and in her crew for the long voyage from 'Frisco to Liverpool went Mr. Basil Lubbock.

That there had been or was likely to be any clash between him and Rear Admiral Barker, Commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, over the inquiry into the circumstances of the fatal explosion at Fort Lafayette on Thursday was denied last night by Coroner Michael J. Flaherty of Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- The money market holds firm, and business is quiet. Call loans, 4 1/2 @5 per cent.; time loans on collateral; 4 3/4 @5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; New York funds, 15@20 cents discount.; clearings, $22,811,321; balances, $2,079,964.

If the city authorities decide to build the great system of subways recommended by Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons, and authorization is given for his proposed elevated railroads, the entire work of providing Manhattan and the Bronx with an adequate rapid transit service can be completed in three and a half years from the time the contracts are signed.

Rumors adverse to the interests of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company stopped short yesterday, and the stories denied or disposed of, the traction corporation and its securities' stocks became practically buoyant in a quiet market, the other stocks raided on Thursday rising with them.

Mr. Foster's a admirable volume on miniature painting in England showed to artists and art critics that he was not only an intelligent writer upon his subject, but that he had besides a certain artistic sense of selection as well as a scientist's patience in research, which enabled him to set off his text in the best possible way.

"The Private Papers of Henry Ryecroft" is the title of a new book by George Gissing, the well-known novelist and student of Dickens, which is said to be more or less autobiographical. It is in active preparation at E.P. Dutton Co.'s for early publication in this country.

The hero is an honest young man who tells his own story, modestly, in spite of his many victories over the villain and his accomplice. He, the hero, is in New Haven at the time of the outbreak of the Revolution, chafing at his enforced absence from Long Island, where he lives with his uncle, Squire Emberson.

Many black-edged sash ribbons are being shown with the new light gowns. They are bright-colored, flowered ribbons, and the black on the edges is half an inch deep on some of the ribbons, and on others there ate several narrow lines of black.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Rollin Lynde Hartt. in The Library Atlantic, recalling his recent "Literary Pilgrimages"to Ohio, Michigan, Iowa, and the uttermost parts beyond, and his hairbreadth scapes from resentful local criticism, finds poor consolation in the thought that "in the old time it was not so."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, Feb. 7, appeared Mr. John R. Thompson's translation of Nadaud's "Carcassonne." I venture to submit to you a translation of my own, which I think truer to the original and simpler. Why should Mr. Thompson repeat the last line of each stanza, since the original does not?

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Feb. 20 -- Ten lives, according to the best information obtainable, were lost in a fire which started at 2:30 o'clock this morning and destroyed the Clifton Hotel, in this city. Two persons were fatally injured and twoscore or more injured more or less severely, mostly by jumping from windows.

Judge Foster of General Sessions had three guests with him on the bench yesterday morning. They were George Ehret, the brewer, and Capt. von Berg and Capt. Bardelibes of the Imperial German Army. The soldiers have been making a study of conditions in this country, and have visited the West Indies and South America, on orders from the Emperor.

In the arrest of two young men yesterday the police believe they have in custody two of a gang of men that has been causing them much trouble of late. For several weeks past complaints have been received at Headquarters from firms in the neighborhood of the wholesale dry goods district that their messengers have been held up on the street and relieved of goods, and that forged orders have been honored for considerable amounts.

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 18. -- Three cities of National calibre stand conspicuous in the Southwest -- two of them strong, the other bound to be; two of them untouched by any misfortune, the other courageous and confident, magnificently ambitious, in the very wake of disaster too appalling for human mind to comprehend.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is one point in connection with the recent disaster on the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the true significance of which seems, so far as appears from their verdict, to have entirely escaped the attention of the Coroner's Jury, but which, from the point of view of the traveling public, should not, it seems to me, be allowed to pass without notice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice in THE TIMES of Feb. 17 a notice of the death of Charles Davenport. It carried me back fifty years, when I was in railroad work. I knew Mr. Davenport, and bought two passenger cars from him. He was a little over a year older than myself. I was born Oct. 2, 1813.

"Un Ballo in Maschera," which will swell the list of Verdi's works produced this season at the Metropolitan Opera House to six, when it is revived there tomorrow evening, is not well known to operagoers of this generation. It was given here a flew years ago by a traveling Italian opera company at a Broadway theatre.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The letter of the Kaiser repudiating Prof. Delitzsch's theories has caused an immense sensation in Germany. It looks as if the orthodox party, aided by the Empress, had influenced the Emperor to issue the letter. The Emperor undoubtedly felt that it would never do for the head of the Prussian State Church to indorse a scientist who denies the theory of the Revelation.

THE juvenile diplomat was seven -- seven, going on eight. He was serious minded and grave looking beyond even the necessities, although life on all sides was far from a merry jest, the character of it depending of course largely upon the way in which one looks at it.

MADGE BRENT sat at the tea table in Mrs. Van's drawing room. She was an extremely pretty girl, and so graceful that the men took tea, not because they liked it, for their tastes were more virile, but because she poured it with such ineffable charm that they forgot their prejudices in the fascination of watching her.

Last week was a five-day week, like the week which preceded, and the week which will follow. Broken weeks are the bane of those who think correct comparisons are an essential to the formation of opinions. But if comparisons are impeded, conditions remain unaltered, for the events of the week are unimportant.

NEW YORK CITY is known among clothing merchants as the great "cheap goods" manufacturing centre of the country. It supplies the Nation with suits, overcoats, trousers, or single garments of any sort, and it caters to the fashions and peculiarities of every county, no matter whether it be in Maine or in Texas.

There has recently been a potable renewal and increase of the agitation in favor of relatively poor men owning their own houses, and numerous schemes have been given to the public by which the desired end can be reached on incomes of from $15 per week upward.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- As the result of interviews with the Duke of Abercorn, Lord Dunraven, John Redmond, and others, The Associated Press is able to announce authoritatively that the following is the situation to-day as regards the plan to finally settle the Irish land question:

The splendid monument to the memory of the great Duke of Wellington in St. Paul's Cathedral, London, is now regarded as the finest sculptural work ever produced by an Englishman. It was designed by Alfred Stevens, who, in 1857, accepted, "in an evil hour for himself," as one biography says, the Government commission to execute the monument.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- The Humberts scored their first notable success to-day when the Ninth Correctional Chamber announced their acquittal in the libel suit brought against them by M. Cattaui, the banker. Public interest in the result was very great and the courtroom was surrounded by an eager crowd.

Yesterday was the first day of the Exchange's triple holiday. There was, therefore, no business, and, while the banks were open, they did nothing of significance to Wall Street beyond issuing the bank statement, which is of unusual interest. It "proved" technically very well, the net changes in resources and liabilities balancing ap- proximately at about $10,210,000.

ALONG Macdougal Street the other day marched two lads, the elder of whom had not seen eight Winters. He wore a complete suit of "soldier clothes," carried a toy sword, and evidently was in command. His tiny companion was the rank and file, equipped with a make-believe fatigue cap and a popgun.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The only thing to be said of the situation in the Senate at the close of the third day of fillbustering in behalf of the Statehood bill is that there is no apparent change in the dogged obstinancy of both sides of the controversy. There has been to-day much talk of compromise.

MANILA, Jan. 5. -- The question of the admission or exclusion of Chinese labor in these islands is at present under discussion in Manila. The Chinese are the only people in the islands to be depended on for any kind of steady manual labor. If you want a good house servant (all the house servants are men) you get a Chinaman.

Plans were filed at the Building Department yesterday for the new Harlem Hospital, which will be a "T"-shaped building on the east side of Lenox Avenue, extending from One Hundred and Thirty-sixth to One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street.

One of the greatest and most lavish articles lauding Kansas City that the people of the city have ever seen in print was published in THE New YORK TIMES of Feb. 12. The article was written by Henry Aliaway, who was sent to the Southwest by the paper a few weeks ago with in- structions to ascertain the cause of the prosperity in this region, which has set all the East by the ears.

TALK about hair-raising finishes," said Custodian Spencer to a guest at the Aquarium recently, as they stopped opposite the large tank containing the fresh-water bass; "right here in this aquarium occur races that for excitement exceed anything that has ever been 'pulled of' by the New York Jockey Club."

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- The employes of the Lake Street and Northwestern Elevated roads have made an agreement with the companies that gives them an increase in wages that will approximate 10 per cent. This is the third wage concession granted by the companies during the last year. The motormen, it is understood, are to get 28 cents an hour after one year of service and 25 cents before.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 21. -- The condition of the most seriously injured of the victims of the trolley accident of Thursday at the Clifton Avenue crossing was said to-night to be unchanged. Miss Helen McCord, who is in the City Hospital, was said to be resting somewhat easier. The condition of Miss Margaret Commerford, who is also at the City Hospital, is still very serious.

ONCE upon a time, before J. Pierpont Morgan had discovered King Edward VII., so history teaches us, there was a boy called George Washington, the Father of his Country, or the Boy with the Long Name. The chief things he is noted for is his birthday, which gives schools a holiday, when it comes on a week day, and the jolly he once gave the old man about not telling a lie.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 21. -- J.D. Farrell, formerly President of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, has been chosen by President James J. Hill of the Great Northern to become his assistant, with responsible duties on the western end of the system, the appointment being effective March 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with the greatst attention and interest your recent leading article on the subject of water wastage, and trust that a few words of warning may be regarded as timely and useful.

ONE woman whose children go to school in a different city almost every year asked the man who travels how much twice two was in Boston. The man showed pretty plainly that he feared the woman had lost her mind, but he said "Four" with a studied effort at composure.

THE last rays of the sun softened the girl's red hair into a golden halo as she sat upon the log, her bare feet showing beneath the hem of her cheap print. On the log beside her was a sunbonnet, and pressing against the sunbonnet was the helve of an axe, such as only a very strong man was accustomed to wield.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Lieut. Gen. Miles gave a luncheon at his residence this afternoon in honor of his active foe of the late seventies, Chief Joseph, the noted Nez Percez warrior. Mrs. Miles and several other ladies were present. Chief Joseph was accompanied by two of his tribesmen.

Over 400 bright, healthy, and active lads, representing the young athletic talent of New York and New Jersey schools, gave fine exhibitions of their prowess at the first annual indoor scholastic games of the Hamilton Institute, which were decided in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, Broadway and Sixty-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon.

IT SEEMS strange to say that three builders of a New York bridge have met their death underground within a year. Such is the fact, however. The three were caisson workmen employed in making foundations for the Brooklyn tower of what has been called East River Bridge No. 3, otherwise known as the Manhattan Bridge.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- In the fastest and hardest-fought game of the season here the Colgate University basket ball team defeated the team of the University of Pennsylvania by the score of 38 -- 8. Line-up:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- Edward Hines, a stableman formerly employed by James Thompson, a wealthy mill owner of Valley Falls, who eloped with Mary Thompson, his employer's daughter, on Jan. 20, sued out a writ of habeas corpus against his bride's father and mother, which was returnable before Justice Betts in the Supreme Court to-day.

David W. Bucklin, the reputed manager of Richard A. Canfield's house in East Forty-fourth Street, will not be placed on trial next Tuesday, according to the plans of District Attorney Jerome. Justice Mac- Lean, in the Supreme Court, yesterday granted Bucklin a stay until March 3, on the application of John Delahunty, his attorney.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 10. -- The official budget of the Congo Free State for 1903 offers many points of interest and shows the financial situation of Belgium's African dependency to be highly satisfactory. The total estimated expenses for the present year are 27,900,556f. against 28,540,000f. for 1902; the estimated receipts being 28,090,000f., against 28,709.000f. for 1902.

The season is over. With Wednesday comes Lent. It is customary to refer to this period as one of sackcloth and ashes. On Wednesday morning the devout in the Catholic and ritualistic churches will partake of the ceremony of sprinkling the foreheads with ashes in memory of the inevitable end of man.
PARIS, Feb. 21. -- A very successful house warming was given by the Baronne Van Orendorff last Saturday in her artistic salons in the Rue Hamelin.

IF ANY other man leads a life that can be compared with that of a fireman for excitement, it is the member of a crew on one of the Metropolitan Street Railway's "red devils." These clanging, showy vehicles, with their bright red paint glistening as they whirl past corner lights at a twenty-five mile clip race for life and death just as do the fire engines.
