LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Money was in good demand all this week, and some bill brokers, being disappointed because the Bank of England rate was not reduced, raised the quotations on Thursday. Gold from Cape Colony was bought on French account on Monday, but the demand was subsequently distinctly slacker.

That a good violin may repose for fifteen years beneath the arctic snows and still remain unimpaired physically or in tone was proved yesterday afternoon by Prof. Louis Mollenhauer of Brooklyn in a music store on Fulton Street, that borough. Prof. Mollenhauer made to speak again a Violin with a pathetic history whose tones were last heard when its owner, about to die, laid it down forever in the frozen wilds of the polar region.

The erection of a new theatre in Brooklyn "that will cosmopolitanize the Brooklynites and keep them from spending so much money in New York" is announced by the McNulty Fitzgerald Company real estate firm. A diagram of the site shows an entrance projected for 651 Fulton Street and the theatre proper at from 40 to 50 Ashland Place, an area, practically, of 120 by 100.6 for the main structure.

For the third time, and the hope is for the last time, the residents of Park Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Forty-first Streets, on the east side of the avenue, have been alarmed by the cracking of the wall of another residence, indicating again the peril near the subway.

CARL ODELL, the man who wrote and sold for $5 "Gates Ajar," a topical song which later earned some thousands, tries voices and passes on the vocal merits of actresses for H. W. Savage, the producer of George Ade's musical comedies. In the course of events Mr. Odell is compelled to reject about twenty-eight out of every thirty of the ambitious young things who present themselves.

ALTHOUGH Washington's Birthday falls upon a Sunday there will be the usual annual observance of it this afternoon and evening at the Met- ropolitan Club. In the evening there will be many dinners. It is the one day in the year which is celebrated there as a family festival.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Minister Bowen to-night received a cablegram signed by the "prize sufferers of Trinidad," requesting his good offices with Great Britain in securing the return of the prizes taken by that country before the raising of the blockade by the allied powers. The cablegram is as follows:

WHEN Kubelefsky had visited every part of the ship and convinced himself that it had been deserted and that only Toto remained to keep him company, he seated himself on one of the steamer chairs that had not been swept overboard during the gale and gazed out over the sea.

A FRIEND of mine has the quaintest little girl you ever saw," said the clergyman's wife, at the mother's meeting. "She is only four years old, but some very queer ideas come out of her little brain, and always they are so unexpected.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on "The Overcrowding of Street Cars" in to-day's TIMES is, of course, nothing but the truth and common sense. But what good does it do to tell of it? Everybody knows it -- the street car officials know it -- but they do not propose to remedy it until forced to do so in some manner.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21. -- At the invitation of the Crescent City Jockey Club Miss Alice Roosevelt and her party, with other distinguished guests, attended to-day's racing and saw an excellent card. The George Washington Handicap worth $1,550 to the winner, was the feature of the day, and the prize went to the feather-weight Albert F. Dewey.

The fourth matinee concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra was given yesterday in Carnegie Hall; and, as were the others of the present season, before an audience that practically filled the hall to its entire capacity. Mr. Gericke has always made these afternoon concerts somewhat lighter in the character of the music he plays than the evening concerts, and at this he gave no symphony.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 20. -- One of the most interesting pieces of ancient Colonial furniture in this country is the chair used by the President of Harvard University during the annual commencement exercises in June. Aside from the fact that it is very old the chair has the distinction of being almost the only one of its kind in America, so far as collectors have been able to discover.

Altered almost beyond recognition in the appearance of the interior, Madison Square Garden was opened for the ninth annual Sportsmen's Show yesterday afternoon. Visitors to this unique exhibition passed through an entrance filled with boughs and festoons of balsam and fir and emerged upon a vista of wild woodland life calculated to inspire the most indifferent and hardened city dweller with a longing for the wilderness.

New York was never so prosperous as to-day. There has never been a time in the history of the municipality when its citizens have been more generous in private and public gifts, but according to those who should know, in their capacity as Trustees, the great hospitals are so poor that it may be necessary to curtail running expenses to such a degree that wards and laboratories must be closed.

SALEM, Ore., Feb. 21. -- Charles W. Fulton of Astoria was elected United States Senator at 12:20 o'clock this morning, receiving forty-six votes, one more than a majority of the Legislature. All through the evening, beginning at 8 o'clock, the two houses took ballot after ballot. There were few changes until 11 o'clock, when the name of Harvey W. Scott was presented.

NEW YORK CITY is becoming the great emporium for the industries of foreign countries. These industries command high prices here and are in great demand. This is especially true of the handwork of the Russian peasants, enormous quantities of which are bought by people who appreciate filmy laces, exquisite embroideries, drawn work, and the other beautiful specimens of the native industries.

A VERY earnest young Englishman is Prof. Francis H. Tabor, Superintendent of The Boys' Club of Tenth Street and Avenue A. His sociological labors and the fact that he has redeemed whole regiments of east side boys do not wholly detract from the grave impression made by his manners and presence, nor fail to strike awe to the hearts of society debutantes who aid in settlement work.

Nearly 300 pieces of solid silverware, antique and modern, were spread out, and covered a large table in Capt. Langan's private room at Police Headquarters last night, while an inventory of the stolen goods was being made.

Tickets of the "Mexico Lottery Company of Pueblo," thousands of which have been sold, according to the postal authorities and the police, should now be quoted at a big discount in their secret market, for what is believed to be the headquarters of the concern was raided yesterday afternoon, together with the printing establishment which supplied its tickets and literature.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- The 127 savings banks of New York State, distributed in 31 counties, had aggregate resources on Jan. 1, 1903, of $1,191,330,573, which was an increase over Jan. 1, 1902, of $59,765,920. The increase is shown in every county, New York leading with $34,726,455 and Kings second with $8,167,060.

The speeches of Lord Claud Hamilton, the Chairman of the Great Eastern, at the half yearly meetings are always instructive and interesting, but this year his remarks were more than usually deserving of the attention of the shareholders and the public. Perhaps the most interesting part of the Chairman's admirable speech was that in which he dealt with comparisons of American and British railroad methods.

Demands of the Powers on Turkey. The story that the Bulgarian Government has proceeded against the leaders of the Macedonian Committee in Sofia, even if true, should be considered in the light of subsequent advices from Constantinople containing the information that a joint note suggesting reforms in the Turkish provinces had been presented by the powers to the Porte.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kindly allow me space in your paper to offer a few words of remonstrance against a grave evil which threatens the Nation. I refer to the amendment proposed by the Live Stock Association to extend the time during which cattle in transit are kept without food or water.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- Agitation by the historical societies for the creation of the office of Commissioner of Records to look after the records of the counties of the State probably will result in this work being intrusted to the State Historian. He would be given an additional force and additional funds in that event.

The City of New Haven, Conn., has. forty-eight public school buildings and has need of at least one more, the total seating capacity being 17,832, and the number, of enrolled children 18,176. The cost to the city in 1897 to educate each child was $29.12 per year; this had been reduced to $24.04 in 1902.
THE drug clerk played a game of marbles with several little globules of candy that tasted like moth balls.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 21. -- Republicans are likely to regain control of Baltimore in the coming city election, as a result of the bitter fight between the Democratic City Hall machine, of which Mayor Hayes is the boss, and the State and city regular Democratic machines, headed by Senator Gorman and "Free" Rasin.
The speech on the Statehood bill delivered in the Senate by Senator Depew last week was in part as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Gross have pondered long and earnestly over a name for their three months' old boy. Several apt ones suggested themselves and close friends suggested others. That only made the quandary greater than ever, and the parents were in a perplexed frame of mind.
LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Though the demand for money in the market slackened somewhat to-day, rates were maintained in spite of the distribution of railroad and other dividends.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21. -- A portion of the silverware recovered by the New York police from the two negroes under arrest there was the property of William C. Bullitt, of the firm of Castner, Curran Bullitt, coal operators, of the Pocahontas fields in West Virginia. The Bullitt residence at 1,322 Locust Street was robbed some time after midnight last Monday of silver plate valued at $5,000.

At the Lotos Club last night a dinner was given to Edward H. Sothern. The banquet began shortly after midnight, as the guest of the evening was unable to appear any earlier, having taken his usual leading part in the play, "If I Were King," at the Garden Theatre.
PON my word, Elizabeth, I'm sorry." She tossed her head haughtily. "You've told me that several times now," she answered, with an assumption of indifference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Debate upon the Fowler Currency bill occupied the attention of the House to-day. Mr. Fowler, the author of the measure, spoke for two hours, and other speakers were Messrs. Thayer, Lovering, Lewis, and Prince.

GENERAL AVERAGE had been chosen Governor of the Island City, better known as the Metropolis of the Western World, after a long and varying contest between his own party and those of General Virtue and General Vice. In this connection it may be stated without fear of successful contradiction that the city had not known a General Average government in a great many years.

BABBLETON was the most absent-minded person I ever knew. At the club this failing of his was proverbial. And yet it was his reputation for being absent-minded, and not any act of absent-mindedness itself, that at last played hob with Babbleton.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In considering the present rapid social evolution much that is encouraging is found in the growing disposition to study and apply the plain teachings of the Carpenter of Nazareth. It is coming to be considered more important to live the life He taught than to spend time in theological discussions about His nature or the circumstances of His birth.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 21. -- For knocking down and robbing Christopher Lovely, a farmer from Redding, and then inducing him to keep away from the police by representing himself as a detective, Mortimer Deloughery, who says his home is in Orange, N.J., was sentenced to a minimum imprisonment in the State Prison at Wethersfield this morning for highway robbery.

It is TALLEYRNAD who is credited with saying to his friend who did not play whist, "What a sad old age you are preparing for yourself!" a remark perverted, by the late GEORGE T. LANIGAN, as having been addressed to a bank Prestdent ignorant of the art of picking oakum.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21. -- While the rest of the country lay bound in the grasp of the blizzard Atlantic City was enjoying an ideal spell of Winter weather. While it was cold, brilliant sunshine tempered the nipping air and made brisk exercise a joy. The city has been crowded with health and pleasure seekers throughout the week, and to-night the hotels that are open are filled to their capacity.

Much popular interest has of late been excited by the mention in cable dispatches and mail advices from England of experiments with the newly discovered metal radium, which has such surprising properties that Lord KELVIN was moved to say of it that it threatened to overthrow the law of the correlation of forces.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- Herr Ballin, Director General of the Hamburg-American Steamship Company, and Dr. Wiegand, Director General of the North German Lloyd Line, in consequence of United States Immigration Commissioner Williams's close application of the law in inspecting immigrants, have directed their agents in Middle and Southern Europe to take no one who is unable to fulfill the requirements of the authorities at New York.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 21. -- Ice yachting on the North Shrewsbury was resumed to-day. The conditions were almost perfect. There was not as much wind as the ice boatmen would like to have had, but otherwise there was nothing jacking. The ice was good over the entire three-cornered course, and though a warm breeze blew from the south it was as hard as steel.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- The officials of the Panama Canal Company are maintaining a rigid reserve concerning their plans. One of the chief officers said it was considered of the utmost importance, owing to the delicate stage of the negotiations, not to throw anything into the discussion which migh unfavorably affect the results.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 21. -- Society people at Lakewood are giving enthusiastic support to the project for a horse show here. It is to be held on the Lakewood Hotel's grounds April 24 and 25. The prizes to be offered will be sufficiently liberal to attract the owners of thoroughbred horses in Eastern cities to this resort.

Some heads in the Police Department are resting uneasily these nights as the result of the visit to the District Attorney's office on Friday of Capt. John D. Herlihy, formerly of the "Red Light District," and of a visit also paid to Assistant District Attorney Morgan yesterday by ex-Sergt. Churchill.

Now that the challenge has been received from the English Lawn Tennis Association, the American experts know the conditions which they will be called upon to face next August. Every one familiar with the sport knew at the close of last season's play that the Englishmen Reginald F. Doherty and H.L. Doherty expected to return to this country during the season of 1903.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21. -- This week many prominent New Yorkers have arrived here. H. McK. Twombly and James Henry Smith are at the Hotel Royal Poinciana, each with a party. Col. John Jacob Astor arrived in his private car and has attended several small functions. James R. Keene is renewing the acquaintance with Palm Beach which he made last season and found so pleasant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your article of to-day treating of the method of running the cars of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company I would like, by your permission, to add a word or two.

The most important development of the Yale baseball season during the past week has been the appearance of a new-comer in the pitching field -- Frank O'Brien, a fresh- man, of Plattsburg, N.Y. He played last year on the Andover Academy team, and was considered to be one of the fastest school shortstops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- William J. Bryan arrived here last night, and to-night delivered an address to the students of the Georgetown Law School, his subject being, "The Value of an Ideal." In his address he remarked that "it is better to have run and lost than never to have run at all."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your paper of the 13th inst. you insert a communication from Alice Serber on immigration. Please allow me to promulgate the following in reply to the lady: European immigration to the United States will be found, on an open and impartial consideration, to have been attended with its advantages and drawbacks, the latter greatly preponderating.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noting a communication in THE TIMES of this morning signed "Woman Citizen" advocating the pensioning of "Judges," the writer does not specify what class of "Judges" is referred to, but says in general terms:

NOVI BAZAR, almost unknown to the world in general, is a narrow strip of Turkish land toward which the eyes of European diplomats turn whenever that troublesome Balkan question arises. If, as the old correspondent says, "there will be trouble in the Balkans in the Spring," Novi Bazar is certain to have its share.

NOT long ago," said the young man who had just come in, "I had an amusing experience. That is, it seems amusing now; but at that time it struck me as being anything but funny, seeing that I was ill. I had been out of town for a day or two, and had returned feeling wholly miserable and good for nothing.

The announcement of new building operations and further buying by some of the larger speculative interests have combined to add several distinguishing features to recent dealings, while business of more conventional character, in which nearly every section of the city is well represented, is of highly satisfactory proportions.

SENATOR JOHN FORD of the franchise tax law fame has two very pretty little girls, Esther, aged eight, and Edith, seven years old. There had been an iron-clad rule in the Ford household that the children should not venture across the street car tracks, which are but a block distant from the home.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- It was reported in this city to-day that Robert J. Hill of Newburg will be appointed State Superintendent of Public Buildings by the Trustees of Public Buildings at a meeting to be held in this city on Tuesday. The term of office is two years, and the salary is $5,000. Mr. Hill is Deputy Superintendent of Public Buildings, and has been Acting Superintendent since last May.

THE festivities of the Pontifical jubilee of Leo XIII., which began last Friday, will extend until April 28. On March 3, the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Papal coronation and the ninety-third birthday of the Pope, his Holiness will go in state to St. Peter's, and will hear from his throne a Pontifical mass, after which he will impart the apostolic benediction, "Urbi et orbi," all the bells of Rome ringing a merry peal.

The series of tests for business automobiles which the Automobile Club of America hold next May will undoubtedly result in a showing of efficiency and varied capacity for work by these vehicles which will surprise most persons, and which should result in a much more rapid rate of progress in the adoption of motor vehicles for commercial purposes.

ONE of the most interesting new exhibits at the American Museum of Natural History is a case containing specimens of the white-tailed ptarmigan, or "mountain quail," so mounted as to illustrate the unique way in which nature has provided for the protection of her children.

CUERNAVACA, Mexico, Feb. 6. -- That one could witness so strange a sight in America would hardly be credited except by the faithful who Know St. Anthony and what he can still do in God's country, which is always Mexico. It is Cuernavaca, the same old town which Cortez knew as Quauhnahuac.

HAVANA, Feb. 16. -- To the passenger on a ship entering or leaving the Harbor, Havana presents a very beautiful appearance with its low buildings of pink, blue, yellow, or white reflecting the sun's light. Usually it is the light of the rising sun, for passenger steamers come in at that time more often than later in the day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with considerable interest the speech of Senator Tillman delivered at the Press Club dinner. I regret exceedingly that the Senator has publicly denounced the attitude of President Roosevelt toward the negroes. It seems to me that the Senator, like many Southerners, is prone to impute wrong motives to those who in any way take different views of this vital question.

Like those that have preceded it, the seventeenth annual banquet of the Southern Society in the Waldorf-Astoria last evening was enjoyed enthusiastically, and there were exciting moments when birthplaces in the South were mentioned. Devotion to the Union was manifested at every opportunity, the only jarring note appearing when the band, forgetful of tact, played "Marching Through Georgia."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The remarks of THE TIMES this morning on the subject of the payment of jurors will meet with a responsive echo from many of your readers, and more especially from those whose private rights are frequently invaded by demands upon their time, both unjust and, though unknown to many, totally unauthorized in law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter in your columns, dated yesterday, and signed "A Lover of Good Painting," makes me feel that I, too, must "rush into print." I wanted to do so when I read your art critic's most excellent estimate of Mr. Chartran's work, but I refrained from doing so because I thought the subject unworthy of any more notice than that which you gave it.

In its efforts to assist members of the theatrical profession to obtain equity in their business relations the Actors' Society of America has recently discovered a new form of contract used by a certain class of managers, which, it is asserted, exceeds any yet devised for placing the actor entirely within the power of those who engage his services.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- This has been a busy week for the King and Queen, for royalty has its duties as well as its privileges, and England's sovereign is expected to go about constantly to various parts of the country and to take an interest in whatever affects the welfare of his subjects.

THERE was a look of intense dissatisfaction on the ingenuous countenance of the Poet as he slowly seated himself on the mourner's bench at the Club of the Transcendentals, and his neighbor, the Artist with a carbuncle, viewed him with that profound gratification which most people who suffer find in the misery of another.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 21. -- The second annual Dog Show of the New Jersey Kennel Association, which opened here on Wednesday, was brought to a successful close tonight. The management a little more than cleared expenses. Mr. and Mrs. G. Steadman Thomas of Hamilton, Mass., were the heaviest prize winners, their dugs carrying off prizes valued at $395.

It has been a saying in "Washington, ever since the battle of Manila, that "the navy can have whatever it wants." And, in fact, there is no fault to be found with the liberality of Congress on this score. The shipbuilding programme prepared by the experts in the service has been executed as fast as appropriations could expedite construction.

That the form of procedure in criminal cases gives every possible advantage to the accused, and that lawyers often work for nothing -- which to some may seem incredible -- was well illustrated in a case lately before Judge Harrison S. Moore of Queens County.

LENOX, Mass., Feb. 21. -- Anson Phelps Stokes will spend the greater part of the Winter cruising on his yacht, Sea Fox, through the West Indies. He is now with a party of friends off the coast of Trinidad. Shadow Brook, the Stokes country place in Lenox, is on the market. Mrs. Stokes was here recently, and had considerable of the furniture shipped to their new country place on Long Island Sound.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- If the Governor's Mortgage Tax bill, which it is expected will be introduced next week, does not provide exemptions for the mortgages held by savings banks, insurance companies, and building and loan associations, it will provoke more antagonism than his Notarial Tax bill, which he was forced to withdraw.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the failure of the French sardine fisheries was written without a full knowledge of the facts. I was, in 1874, the business manager of the then largest sardine importer of New York, and know whereof I speak. The sardines are being intercepted on their way from the Mediterranean Sea to the north.
I AM out of house and home," said the girl with violets on her muff, "and I am looking for a house without a back-parlor boarder."

MRS. GEORGE CHOCKER'S Irish lace and ermine gown, worn at her musicale, was a fine example of the use of fur with lace. The bodice had an Eton coat effect. First there was a plaited underbodice of white chiffon over white taffeta, over which was worn an Irish lace jacket or bolero, bordered with a two-inch band of ermine.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 21. -- The Ottawa Ice Race Association closed its races here to-day with a free-for-all and an unfinished named race. The purse in the free-for-all was reduced from $1,000 to $100. Several horses were withdrawn, but those that remained in made a hot race. The track was heavy. The results were:

Physicians differ as to whether the grip is now epidemic in New York. The difference is one of definition rather than of fact. All are agreed that it is "extremely prevalent," not only here, but over the whole territory of the New England and Middle States, and that it is moving westward steadily and irresistibly.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- Rouged and powdered, some of them in gauzy ballet skirts and skin-colored tights, a dramatic company of cadets produced a comic opera in the Cullum Memorial Hall to- night. The performance was the closing event of that annual institution which the Military Academy calls the "Hundredth Day."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21. -- Washington's Birthday was celebrated to-day by the University of Pennsylvania in the Academy of Music. Gov. Pennypacker presided and Dr. S. Weir Mitchell was the orator of the day. His topic was "George Washington in His Letters." A feature of the event was the conferring of these honorary degrees:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- In the presence of an assemblage of distinguished people, including the President of the United States, members of the Cabinet and of Congress, Justices of the Supreme Court, representatives of foreign powers, and others eminent in the life of the Nation, the cornerstone of the Army War College was laid here to-day with impressive military and Masonic ceremonies.

Payne Whitney won the racquet championship of America yesterday by defeating Quincy A. Shaw of Boston in the final match at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, Forty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue.
The Atlanta-Birmingham Fire Insurance Company has been formed with a subscribed capital stock of $300,000.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- The fourth annual amateur squash championship tournament of the United States opened at the courts of the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club to-day: There were eighteen entries, including five Harvard players, A.M. Brown, B. Wendell, Jr., E. M. Leonard, A.L. Devens, Jr., and L.L. Green.

ONE of the most curious and interesting volumes hidden away in the vaults of the Columbia library is a small book said to be among the first few printed in New York. It is a "Letter of Advice to a Young Gentleman upon Leaving the University," and was printed by William Bradford in 1696.
Dr. L. Emmett Holt, Secretary of the Board of Directors of the Rockefeller Institute, made public last night the detailed plans of the project so far as they have been determined at the present time.

MRS. BROADWAY was never very anxious to see a woman who looked like her until age and worry had cut little furrows in her face from the corners of her nose down to the corners of her mouth. Then she said she wished she could see one and find out just how horrible she really did look.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- The annual Winter meeting of the Board of Trustees of Cornell University was held here to-day, the following out-of-town Trustees being present: Judge G. Turner of Auburn, Charles Skinner of Albany, Miss Ruth Putnam, H.R. Yekelheimer, Col. H.W. Sackett of New York, Dr. L.O. Howard of Washington, D.C.; Judge F.H. Hiscock of Syracuse, and W. Beahan of Winona, Minn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the father of one Cornell freshman I thank you for your articles of yesterday and of to-day under "Topics of the Times," and your editorial of to-day on the same subject. viz., "The Ithaca Typhoid Epidemic." The views expressed are certainly to the point; they go to most, but not to all the roots of the evil and how to exterminate it.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- In his annual report of the New York State Library School, Director Dewey says: "While our school is maintained primarily for New York State and extra tuition is charged to students from outside the State, it has received the most practical of all indorsements in the fact that 245 students have come to us from twenty-four other States, and from England, Nova Scotia, Australia, Germany, Holland, Norway, and Sweden.

Belle G. Beveridge, residing at 316 West Ninety-fourth Street, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities to the amount of $20,678 and assets to the amount of $314, in household furniture, clothing, books, pictures, and cash, $9. She is the wife of a Wall Street Broker, and she operated in real estate in her own name.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is gratifying to know that before the ending of the present year the Democratic Party will be so rejuvenated in health as to be able to enter and participate in the preliminary Presidential bouts to take place in November. The Republican Party has not as yet enacted any commendable legislation to deprive the obnoxious tariff vampire of the evil diet it has too long been keeping.

The blasts of moral rage that have been gathering for weeks in anticipation of the production of Tolstoi's "Resurrection," came to a head at 8:30 last Tuesday night; but by 9 o'clock, behold! they had subsided muttering. As has several times happened of late, the managerial power to produce plays that are filthy and degrading fell short of the moralistic agility in imagining them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Have the people no redress for extortion? Must they continue to endure the cruel oppression of monopolies, trusts, and the domination of the money power? Are we powerless to resist the misery of the "Meat Trust," and the cruel withholding of the coal supply, and the gross imposition of extortionate prices for the necessaries of life?

We take pleasure in reprinting Senator DEPEW'S very sensible and timely speech on the danger of "diluting" the Senate. It is an argument that ought especially to appeal to Senators. Already the power of the Senate is so great as to be regarded, practically by all men in public life who are not Senators, as a nuisance and a danger.

Nothing could possibly be more characteristic of the German Emperor, than the profession he has just been moved to make of the religious faith that is in him, and consequently ought to be in his subjects. The prefatory explanation, it is true, is so uncharacteristic that we find difficulty in accepting it.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Very great interest has been awakened in clerical circles in Philadelphia, and especially among Lutheran ministers, by the publication of the letter on religion written by Emperor William.

So many international events are being planned in the domain of sports for the coming year that it would be almost out of place not to have the golfers represented in these interesting contests. It had been fully expected that, at the recent annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, a definite and positive plan would be presented for a visit to this country of a team of Oxford and Cambridge players this season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We note that Senator Hanna serves notice on the American people that Uncle Sam has more money than he knows what to do with by proposing the pensioning of ex-slaves. No doubt Uncle Sam is pretty well-to-do, and we know he is inclined to be liberal, and believe he would be more so if encouraged a little by his many confidential advisers.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- It developed last night that another accident, similar to that of Thursday, was narrowly averted at the Clifton Avenue crossing yesterday. According to a report made to Manager David Young by the Superintendent of the cross-town line, one of the company's repair wagons, containing a crew of five men, attempted to drive over the crossing, when a passenger train dashed by at a high rate of speed.

The Society for the Protection of Italian Immigrants, which was formed in March, 1901, has been investigating the methods of a class of boarding-house keepers. "Runners" from the various boarding houses, it was found, awaited the Ellis Island boat at the Barge Office, and as the Italians set foot on shore they were seized by force, their baggage dragged from them, and they were bundled and hustled into express wagons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The quaint old town of Alexandria, Va., will celebrate Washington's Birthday to-morrow with more than usual enthusiasm. Before the war the citizens used to make the day one of the reddest of the year, but of late they have rather neglected it. This year a general feeling of loyalty to the Father of his Country has swept over the community and there will be a grand turnout.

Police Commissioner Greene paid visits on Saturday and yesterday to various Inspecters in Manhattan and discussed their work with them. He examined their method of carrying out Revised Rule 44 of the police rules and regulations, by which the Inspectors are required to make to the Commissioner a full report covering the grounds included in the Captain's reports.

The Salmagundi is a club, a large proportion of whose members are painters; in their pleasant quarters on West Twelfth Street they bring together several hundred paintings in oil once a year, not forgetting to include work by other artists who may not be members, and then on a given evening they hold an auction of those pictures which have not been sold during the exhibition.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb., 22 -- At 3 o'clock this afternoon the jury in the case of Arthur L. Bishop, a shoe drummer, charged with the murder of Thomas I. Wilson, came into court and rendered a verdict of manslaughter. Bishop was in court and his wife was by his side. The courtroom was filled with people, including about fifty commercial travelers, who were here to spend Sunday.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times says that Emperor William's confession of faith has produced a considerable impression in Germany, though less sensation than such a pronouncement would have caused in other countries, because the Emperor is Summus Episcopus of the Prussian Proestant Church, and is known to have long been interested in dogmatic controversies.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Gov. Odell said tonight that there was no truth in the published report that he might appoint Adjt. Gen. Nelson H. Henry to succeed John McCullagh as State Superintendent of the Metropolitan Elections District; that Adjt. Gen. Henry was not a candidate for that position and would remain Adjutant General.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to thank you for your editorial regarding the proposed abolition of the State Reformatory for Women at Bedford, and also to take the opportunity to correct a statement which has been published in at least one dally paper to the effect that the Board of Managers has asked for the transfer of thirty of their inmates to the State Prison at Auburn.
BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- A letter from Honolulu says that the real reason why Japan relinquished her claim to Marcus Island has finally come to light.

Discussing the negro problem, in an address before the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening. Booker T. Washington of the Tuskegee Institute said that he believed the time had come when representative white men of the North and the South should meet with negroes and consider with calmness and business sagacity the whole subject as viewed from every point.

The observation of the average citizen during and since the recent heavy snowstorm in New York has warranted the conclusion that the motor vehicles have done very much better than the horses. Some automobiles have been stalled, no doubt, but that will happen under any conditions.

A big laundry fight has started in this city between the steam laundries and the hand laundries. The steam laundries, on the plea that they have not been paying expanses, have raised the prices of all work to the hand laundries, and the hand laundrymen have raised the prices to the people.
"Rights of the Unborn" was the subject of a sermon delivered last night by the Rev. John L. Scudder at the First Congregational Church, Jersey City. He said in part:

MANILA, Feb. 22 -- A force of insurgent ladrones, under Gen. San Miguel, reappeared in Rizal Province yesterday. They avoided an engagement with the main force to the south, but captured three small detachments of constabulary. The enemy surrounded the towns of Cainta and Taytay, eleven miles east of Manila, Saturday, and captured thirty scouts and ten men of the constabulary, whom they disarmed and set free.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Delay in the completion of war vessels by contractors was made the subject of inquiry by the Navy Department by direction of the President. A week ago the President, in a communication to Secretary Moody, asked for information in regard to the delay in building vessels for the navy, and the latter called on Rear Admiral Bowles to supply the desired facts.

Of the many handball matches which have been decided during the present season on the Brooklyn and Jersey City courts, none attracted so large a gathering of experts and followers of the game as the intercity doubles match which was begun at Egan's Jersey City court yesterday. The opposing pairs were "Mike" Egan, the world's champion, and James Flaherty of Jersey City and James Dunne, Jr., and Dr. Shea of the Brooklyn Handball club.

Col. Alfred B. lies, representing a New York syndicate, left yesterday for Alaska, where he will head an expedition, said to be the largest ever organized, to explore the copper deposits at the head of the Tanana and White Rivers. After the caravan is well under way and warm weather greets the explorers much of the abundant supplies will be cacned at different points.

The proposed amendments to the tenement house law are to be considered by the legislative committees at Albany on Thursday, March 5, and the indications are that the friends of the present law will be out in force.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of the 20th inst., in reference to the epidemic of typhoid fever at Ithaca, you do the faculty of Cornell University a grave injustice when you speak of the "usefulness of this splendid foundation as threatened by the ignorance and timidity of the Faculty."

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 22 -- Relief parties with with food reached to-day the trains which are snow-bound in the interior and supplied them with provisions. The nearest train was freed this afternoon and started backward for St. John's.

At the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday a delegate directed attention to the disappearance of the blackboard on which the names of the Aldermen who voted for the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel franchise had been painted. A del egate had remarked that the committee appointed to revise the spelling of the names of the Aldermen was dilatory in doing its work.

Giovanni Puelo has big dreamy eyes that were meant to gaze on blue Italian skies. They aid him in his business, particularly when the city is snowbound, and he cannot help but shiver as he solicits buyers for his stock of oranges and peanuts. Giovanni has an enemy in the shape of a City Hall policeman, who persists in making Him move on every time that fortune seems to smile and customers are many.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Reed Smoot, Senator-elect from Utah, arrived here last night, and will remain in Washington or its vicinity until after March 4, in order to be here in the event of an extra session of the Senate being called by the President.

ASBURY PARK N.J., Feb. 22 -- Rumors are current on the streets to-day to the effect that the depositors of the recently closed Monmouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company will recover their money, now tied up in that institution, which closed its doors when the Government placed its across-the-corridor neighbor -- the First National Bank -- in the hands of a receiver.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The attitude of your paper, and of the American press in general, is very amusing to any Britisher with a memory for historical debt-collecting facts.

It is a fact not generally known that the ambulance service in Paris is the poorest of any city in Western Europe. The calls for ambulances are usually sent out from Prefecture of Police, and hence a case must first be reported before a call can be made. The police very often press passing vehicles into service, as experience has taught them that it may be three hours before the arrival of an ambulance.

As indicated in our Albany dispatches this morning, there will be a certain amount of opposition to the bill authorizing an increase of the police force for this city. So far as the minority party in the Legislature is concerned, the motive of this opposition is only too easily guessed.

The Regents of the University are fortunate in having as an advocate of their policy of unifying the State system of instruction an advocate so distinguished and influential as President BUTLER of Columbia University. The logic of the matter is irresistible. There is no more sense in dividing the responsibility in the Department of Education than there would be in setting up two heads of the Banking or Insurance Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- This has been a busy day with the Senators who feel themselves charged with responsibility for the dead-lock in the Senate on the Statehood bill.They have been at work like beavers on schemes of compromise, and hope that they have reached a settlement of the whole difficulty.

But nine days remain of the last session of the present Congress. Whatever legislation shall fail before the adjournment fails for good. Nothing can be done with it unless it is started anew. It is this fact which makes the stage-robbers at once so stubborn and so confident, and impels them to play their game in the manner commented on in these columns yesterday.

In view of the fact, that a team of American automobilists, will compete in the annual race for the Bennett International Automobile Cup, representing the automobile racing championship of the world, next Summer, the rules under which, the contest will be held are of interest. The rules are as follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 16th inst. I find an account of the mass meeting at Cooper Union, the evening before, for the discussion of child labor.

A copy of the first newspaper ever published on the Atlantic Ocean through the advantages offered by the Marconi system of wireless telegraphy was brought to New York by the Cunard liner Etruria yesterday, on the last eastward voyage of which vessel, on the 7th of this month, the publication was issued.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Paris is roaring with laughter over the extraordinary scene which has taken place in court between Mme. Humbert and the principals of her gang on the one side, and Cattaui, a banker, who is prosecuting her for having, as is alleged, calumniously denounced him to the police, and his witnesses on the other side.
Hemstitched initial paper is 50 cents aquire.

We learn from a Washington dispatch that the Department of Agriculture, the most interesting and amusing division of the Federal service, is planning a series of experiments with a view to securing a breed of featherleSs chickens. The attempt is to be made at the experiment stations in the South and it gives us sincere pleasure to learn that those interested in the matter are sanguine of ultimate success.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Nearly all of the most important subjects now before the present session of the Legislature will be considered in hearings during the coming week. Canals, taxation, financial affairs, and police legislation for New York City and the Jerome Saloon Sunday Opening bill are among the more important matters.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- The Boerse had a quiet week, no department showing great activity. German and foreign Government bonds were not traded in in the usual volume and mostly weakened moderately. The annual statements of the domestic banks are beginning to be published, the market giving much less attention to them than in previous years.
MANILA, Feb. 22 -- Commissioner Henry C. Ide will sail for home next Tuesday on an extended vacation, owing to bad health. He will visit California, Vermont, and Washington.

The Committee on City Affairs of the Reform Club has made public the programme of the National convention on municipal ownership and public franchises, in the rooms of the club, at 233 Fifth Avenue, on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of this week. C.R. Bellamy, General Manager of the municipal street railway system of Liverpool, will be one of the speakers.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- John McMackin, Commissioner of Labor of this State, will submit to the Legislature to-day the annual reports of the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the State Free Employment Bureau.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 22 -- Delegates to the American Bowling Congress are arriving on every train. Fifteen hundred visitors are expected, and one-half that number is already here. Representatives of Louisville, Cleveland, and Milwaukee have been here all day to urge their claims for the next National congress.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The annual report of Frederick D. Kilburn, Superintendent of Banks, relative to savings banks, trust companies, safe deposit companies, and miscellaneous corporations will be presented to the Legislature to-morrow.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Times publishes a letter from Sir Robert Giffen, the eminent publicist and statistician, attacking the British Government's action in regard to Venezuela, and especially the co-operation with Germany.

DERBY, Conn., Feb. 22. -- The breaking of three reservoirs in the town of Shelton this morning caused damages estimated at between $75,000 and $100,000, and there were several narrow escapes from death.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- In the course of a sermon on "The American Citizen" to-night, the Rev. James I. Vance of the North Reformed Church said:

NEWARK, Feb. 22 -- In accordance with the proclamation of Mayor Doremus, the entire city to-day mourned its dead in last Thursday's grade crossing disaster. Promptly at 2 o'clock the church bells began tolling for over ten minutes, while the Sunday school services in nearly every church were changed to a meeting of prayer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- It is generally believed that the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the lottery cases will tie handed down to-morrow. The cases to be decided are known as Champion vs. Ames and Francis vs. The United States. In their ultimate disposition they may involve important constitutional questions relative to the nature of inter-State commerce and the extent of the Federal power over it.

TUXEDO-PARK, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- The second day's play for the amateur squash championship of the United States at the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club, was marked by excellent squash, each game being hotly contested. The chief feature of the day's play, however, was the meeting of the two champions, George I. Scott and William Post, both of whom have Hens on the championship cup.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the death of Lincoln the Republican Party underwent a great transformation a change for the worse. There was no man who knew better than Andrew Johnson what were the sentiments and plans of his great predecessor regarding reconstruction and the restoration of the Union.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have heard so much of late about our reform Board of Health and its analyses of patent medicines and the publishing of results, to the great delight and satisfaction of the wily patent medicine man, who "laughs in his sleeve" and reaps all the benefits for his patent medicine without any cost to him, that really we are tired of it.

BANGOR, Me., Feb. 23 -- Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., and his brother, Kermit, sons of the President, will come to Maine this year to hunt with Wilmot Dow and "Fred" Sewall of Island Falls, as their father used to come to hunt with the fathers of the two Maine boys.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Hanna's wish that the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries would gratify him by disposing in some way of his Ship Subsidy bill was realized to-day. The committee killed it by a vote of 10 to 6. Those voting to report it to the House were:

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Senator Hoar of Massachusetts delivered an address on "Washington" at the Auditorium this afternoon before the Union League Club members and their friends. Patriotic songs were sung by the audience.

Andrew O'Dea, Wisconsin's rowing coach, has started work with the crew candidates in preparation for the intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie in June. The following men of last year's 'Varsity are back: McGomb, Stevenson, Gaffin, Jordan, Moffatt, and Mather. Lyman, Palmer, Steere, and Gibson are the absentees.

The action of the Central Labor Union of Omaha in formulating a protest against the appointment of Judge SMITH MCPHERSON of the United States District Court for Southern Iowa to the place on the bench of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals which will be made vacant by the retirement of Judge CALDWELL is extremely instructive.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Money was much wanted and scarce in the market to-day and a busy week is anticipated. Discounts were maintained.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Senator Elsberg's bill to amend the primary election law, with relation to special or supplemental enrollments, came up in the Senate to-night in general orders and was advanced to third reading without objection upon the understanding that when it is taken up on third reading Senator Elsberg will offer an amendment which will make it applicable to New York City only.

Dr. Henry M. Leipziger, in charge of the Board of Education's free lecture courses, received a suggestion not long ago that he institute a series of talks on "How to Bring Up Children." He, has arranged to have such a course, and a lecturer, so it is announced, will do the first talking on this topic the first Friday evening in next month, the course to continue on succeeding Fridays for several weeks.
ROME, Feb. 23 -- Queen Helena to-day received in private audience the following Americans:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- While the Senate was considering the Post Office Appropriation bill to-day, Senator Tillman interjected some remarks about the Indianola (Miss.) case. The South Carolina Senator began by saying that he proposed to surprise his friends and astonish his enemies, if he has any, by being very mild and temperate in what he would say.

The London Lancet announces a discovery which may be found to have great pathological interest. It is to the effect that bacteria in food and drink are destroyed and these materials sterilized by sufficiently energetic vibration. Bacterial cultures were allowed to stand in the engine room of a manufacturing establishment, and were completely and rapidly sterilized by the vibration produced by the reciprocal strokes of the engine.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- The holiday horse racing on Lake George at Caldwell drew one of the largest crowds of the season this afternoon. The track was perfect. The named race was won by Mary McGregor (Biggart, Glens Falls.) Best time, 2:27 1/2.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 23 -- President Remson of Johns Hopkins University, in making the announcements at the commemoration day exercises to-day, said:

Mr. and Mrs. James C. Bullitt of 1332 Locust Street, Philadelphia, appeared in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning against Robert Williams and George Roberts, the two negroes arrested Saturday by Detective Sergeants Boyle and Charlton on suspicion of having burglarized the Bullitt home in Philadelphia a week ago yesterday morning, taking away $4,000 worth of heavy solid silverware, consisting of tureens, gravy boats, butter dishes, and silver knives, spoons, and forks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Having failed in the effort to obtain from Mr. Bowen the immediate payment in cash of the 5,500 pounds sterling, which it was provided in the protocol of Feb. 13 should be paid to Germany thirty days from that date, Germany to-day requested Mr. Bowen to give a draft for the amount payable in Caracas on the latter date.

Revelations which may be made the basis for further proceedings have been made in the course of an action begun by the firm of Levy Unger, for the purpose of ascertaining the exact amount of the personal estate left by Theodore Hagaman, a Wall Street broker and part owner of the Hotel Albemarle, who died on Sept. 11, 1900, at the Waldorf-Astoria.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Assembly to-night passed Assemblyman Dickinson's bill amending the Penal Code so as to define the word "building."

MAMARONECK, Feb. 23 -- Mrs. E.W. Heath, editor of The Mamaroneck Democrat, a weekly newspaper, purposes to have telegrams sent to-morrow morning to the police in every city in the United States asking them to watch for her daughter, Irene, who disappeared in a mysterious manner late last night.

Shrove Tuesday is to be without any special observance in this city. It is the last day of the carnival. The only affairs of to-day are a few dinners and a domino party in the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Sackett Barclay. Many persons have sone South and others are going abroad.

Wylie C. Grant of the New York Lawn Tennis Club earned two championships yesterday in the final matches of the National indoor lawn tennis tournament, which was brought to an end on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue. Grant won the title in the singles over Calhoun Cragin of the West Side Tennis Club and the Seventh Regiment Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

"Perjurers" and "vipers" were some of the names by which Mayor Low and District Attorney Jerome were referred to by the Rev. Charles A. Crane, pastor of the People's Tabernacle, Boston, in his address before the Prohibition Conference in Tuxedo Hall last evening, and "Amens " were shouted from all parts of the hall by men and women auditors.

Dedicatory exercises of the Wadleigh High School, the first of four similar institutions, were held yesterday in the presence of Mayor Low, President Henry A. Rogers of the Board of Education, many other city officials, and an assemblage of pupils and their friends, which taxed the capacity of the main auditorium.

OMAHA, Feb. 23 -- Judge Munger, in the Federal Court, to-day granted a writ of injunction restraining the City Tax Commissioner and City Council from making an independent assessment of the Union Pacific and Burlington Railway property for purposes of municipal taxation.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Chairman Plank of the Assembly Excise Committee said to-night that the committee was disposed to give serious consideration to the matter of increasing the excise tax upon a graded plan.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The dinner given to-night by the American Society here in honor of Washington's Birthday was the occasion for a brilliant assemblage, the chief feature of which was the welcome given to D.R. Francis, ex-United States Secretary of the Interior and President of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, and the wishes of success to the Exposition expressed by the speakers.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 -- The Stewardess and Major Mansir were the only winning favorites on to-day's very ordinary card. The weather was fine and the track fast. Summary:

After a brief argument yesterday by District Attorney Jerome the trial of David W. Bucklin, Canfield's manager, whose case was on the calendar of Justice Herrick, in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court, was adjourned until March 9.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 23 -- At its first session to-day the American Bowling Congress adopted the recommendation of the Executive Committee that the maximum weight of bowling balls shall not exceed sixteen and one-half pounds. This will permit the loading of the ball with a pound or two of lead, as the largest size regulation wooden ball weighs only 15 1/2 pounds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Washington's Birthday was celebrated here to-day with the usual literary and gymnastic exercises. Quite a large number of visitors were in town to witness the different events and the students were released from all scholastic duties. The class of 1870 prize debate was held in Alexander Hall this morning the question, "Resolved, That experience has shown the feasibility, of maintaining the Monroe Doctrine."

That this is a Verdi season at the Opera House the advancing weeks make clearer and clearer, and though the promised "Verdi cycle" will not be given, the sixth of Verdi's operas was added to the repertory last evening when for the first time since the days of the German opera "Un Ballo in Maschera," was revived, on that stage.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Athletics at Syracuse are booming, especially in baseball, track work, and crew practice. James A. Ten Eyck, the new coach, who succeeded E.R. Sweetland, is directing the rowing work which at present consists of a twenty-minute spin on the machines, followed by a run in the open.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Republican factions in the Senate have been able at last to draft a Statehood bill upon which they can cast a united vote. Their long conferences have resulted in such a modification of the Spooner compromise that even the radical wing has agreed to cease opposition.

Workmen engaged in tearing down the Hall of Records yesterday began to pry away the bricks of the first floor. Soon after noon on the anniversary of Washington's Birthday the dungeons where Revolutionary patriots had suffered were unsealed, and for the first time in nearly a century and a half the rays of sunshine burst into the gloomy vaults, lighting up the holes in which nothing was ever known except suffering and despair.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Feb. 23 -- Tewfik Pasha, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, notified the Austro-Hungarian and Russian Ambassadors this afternoon that the Sultan had agreed to adopt the scheme for reforms in Macedonia.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Plans practically are complete for the merging of the interests of the firms that compromise the Beef Trust. Unless something unforeseen arises. April 1 will see the official announcement of the incorporation of a securities-holding company, which eventually may control the meat trade of the world.

The decisions of the Supreme Court, in the lottery cases are, as Mr. JUSTICE HARLAN, who delivered the opinion of the majority of the court, well said "of great moment." Their least important but not unimportant aspect is that they mark the termination of a prolonged legal contest over the power of the Federal Government to prohibit, in the interests of public morals, the transmission of lottery matter.

-- Senator BRACKETT calls the large shades of CONKLING and LAMARTINE to justify, him in placing his bark on the highest promontory while waiting for a tide to float it out upon the political high seas. Confronted by the authority of witnesses such as these of course we must admit that the metaphor of the Saratoga statesman was oratorically orthodox, but we are still reckless enough to insist that it was nautically absurd.

Columbia's cross-country club, organized this year for the first time, has proved of immense benefit to the cross-country running at the university. During the first year of cross-country running at Columbia there was much interest in the sport. Contest for places on the 'Varsity team was keen and the rivalry of class teams added to the activity.

There have been several gratifying signs that during the course of what Lord CRANBORNE described as "the Venezuelan mess" the whole theory on which the coercion of Venezuela proceeded was offensive to many Britons. Sir HENRY CAMPBELL-BANNERMAN, while the controversy was acute, expressed disgust that the British Navy should be used as an agency for the collection of bad debts due to British subjects.

A new record for the Crescent Athletic Club traps at Bay Rridge was made in the holiday shoot of that organization yesterday, more than 6,000 targets being trapped in the course of the day's sport. The largest number ever trapped in any previous shoot was 5,000, made on Lincoln's Birthday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Peace reigned supreme at the joint meeting here to-day of the American and National Baseball Leagues and the National Association of Minor Leagues. The purpose of the meeting was to arrange a set of playing rules and a schedule.

More than 10,000 holiday amusement seekers visited the Sportsmen's Show at the Madison Square Garden yesterday, the majority of whom were present in the afternoon. During the matinee performance of the Indian cantata, "Hiawatha," not only were the reserved seats in the second tier filled, but the crowd standing in the passages on both the main floor and balcony was so great that passage in any direction was impossible.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

It is most interesting and encouraging to note that the persistent and devoted efforts of the tenement house reformers in New York for the past quarter of a century have at last been fully and heartily appreciated by their beneficiaries, the dwellers in tenement houses themselves.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Washington's Birthday at Tuxedo was the most successful day the place has had in a long time. The beautiful weather of the past three days brought large crowds out to witness the squash championship matches at the Tennis Club, and to enjoy the skating on Tuxedo Lake and the sleighing through the park.

"The Southern Enchantment" is being produced in the Fourteenth Street Theatre by the Smart Set Company. The programme described it "a spectacular extravaganza in three acts and seven scenes," and the company is of the sort which is sometimes called "black and tan." There are parades of women in military tights and darkies in military uniforms, reinforced by interludes, in which the darkies execute jokes of the approved darky design.

LONDON, Feb. 24 --The Earl of Dunraven was interviewed last night, regarding the report of the Irish landlords and tenants' conference in Dublin, of which he was Chairman. He spoke hopefully regarding the prospects of legislation which he thought would end the difficulties in Ireland.

For two hours before noon yesterday there was good sleighing on the Speedway, but as the sun rose higher the snow melted away so rapidly that the last of the gathering of enthusiasts found it difficult to pick their way back to the stables without scraping over a bare road and pavement. The sport while it lasted, however, was of the best.

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 23 -- A dispatch from Mexico City says the members of the Board of Directors of the Mexican Central Railroad, who are making an inspection trip over the lines of that system, have decided upon some important extensions and new lines. Construction is to be pushed on the Mexico City-Tampico line, and there is to be no cessation in the work of building the new line to San Antonio, Texas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the "impatient, oppressed, and tyrannically imposed upon traveling public," I trust I may be granted space to air my grievances through the columns of THE TIMES. The burden of my plaint is the inconveniences and discomforts that, in common with many others, I have suffered nightly on the 6 o'clock train from New York to New Haven.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The twelfth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution convened in this city to-day. About 1,000 delegates and alternates from all the States in the Union attended.

The New York State Chess Association celebrated its twenty-first birthday with the annual tournament on Washington's Birthday to decide the championship of the Empire State. Twenty-eight engaged in the general tournament, while twelve experts competed for championship honors.

In disposing of a case of excise arrest in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, Magistrate Breen declared that the police under Commissioner Greene were not interpreting the liquor law according to the views expressed by Mayor Low in one of his typewritten talks in August last. The Magistrate quoted from the "talk," in which the Mayor criticised the police for going into the back rooms of saloons in quest of evidence of excise violation.

The present outcome of the bargaining that has been going on for the last two weeks over the admission of new States is a measure that no sane man would think of inventing or approving on the merits of the questions presented. It is a hodge-podge of inconsistent or ill-advised provisions made necessary by the prejudices or the interests of a few Senators and those for whom they stand.

Our Consular Service is considered by so many of ourselves to be bad that it is with even more wonder than satisfaction that we meet with a foreign tribute to it. One such appears, however, in a journal of Berlin, The World's Trade. The journal in question warns the German manufacturers against exhibiting at St. Louis.
Capt. William A. Campbell, Twenty-second Infantry, is directed to report to Major Gen. S.B. M.Young, President of the Army Retiring Board, for examination by the board.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- Mayor Low appeared before both the Senate and Assembly Cities Committees to-day and made arguments which consumed nearly two hours in all for the purpose of convincing the committees of the wisdom of enacting into law several bills desired by the Fusion administration.

There are many pretty stocks and cuffs in heavy linen, embroidered in a soft shade of cadet blue. Other linen sets are in the same quality linen, in blue, embroidered in white. One of these sets is made of perfectly straight bands of the linen with straight edges. There are the two short bands for the sleeves and a longer one for the neck.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- District Attorney Jerome had a full house to-day when he appeared in the Senate Chamber before the Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment of the two houses to argue in favor of his bill to permit saloons in New York City to keep open during certain hours on Sundays. No such audience has attended a hearing during the present session.

Joseph Sibarace, said to be the only survivor of the inhabitants of St. Pierre, Martinique, who were in that city when the terrible eruption of Mont Pelee occurred, arrived here yesterday, ragged and scarred, in the steerage of the steamship Fontabelle. He was in a dungeon of the St. Pierre Prison at the time of the catastrophe.

The London Spectator, which takes great delight in picturesque characterization, has discovered that President ROOSEVELT has some of the essential traits of the old-fashioned British Whig. The Spectator thinks that he "has a great disregard of the personal consequences of any action that he may take" -- and this is not so strange, since he "confesses it" -- but he is of the Whig type of mind.

Justice Bischoff has reserved decision on a motion argued before him yesterday for an order to amend a decision rendered by Justice Blanchard several months ago. The action in which the question comes up is that of Andrew Staender against the city. Staender is a laborer employed in the parks at $2 a day, and is a veteran.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- After it had been violently assailed by Republicans as well as Democrats, Gov. Odell's Conveyance Tax bill was to-day recommitted to a committee, together with a score of amendments.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- What appears to be a statement from Gov. Odell on his plans for improving the conditions of State unfortunates and insane was made to-day before the Senate Finance Committee by H. H. Bender, Fiscal Supervisor of Charities. It was made at the hearing on the bill providing for the transfer of the inmates of the Bedford Reformatory for Women to other institutions of a similar character at Albion and Hudson.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- The Court of Appeals, in a decision rendered to-day, holds that the New York and Harlem Railroad Company and the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company cannot be held responsible for damages to property on Park Avenue, New York City, through the elevation of the tracks of the companies along that street from Harlem southward.

BOSTON, Feb. 24. -- Dr. Joseph B. Heald of this city, the physician who attended Theodore Hagaman, is at present established in this city. He said to a correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day that Mr. Hagaman died from cirrhosis of the liver after he -- the doctor -- had been summoned by telephone, but before he reached the Waldorf-Astoria.

Developments yesterday lead the police to believe that the robberies of west side hotels confessed by Louis Messier, who was arrested Monday morning with John Cullen, another bellboy, were part of a conspiracy to rob hotels all over the country, the central figure of which was a woman.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- The Times's correspondent at Vienna says that the Neue Freie Presse will on Wednesday publish an account of a conversation with the Austrian Minister of Trade and Commerce on the subject of the creation of a Central European customs alliance against the danger of American competition.

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League last night, the New York Athletic Club bowlers won two of three games with the Hariem Wheelmen on the athletic club alleys and at the Catholic Club, the home team won two of three games with the Caledonian Club five. The scores follow:

With the Robert McAllister Lioyd housewarming, the domino party at the Sackett Barclays, the musicale at Whitelaw Reid's, and various other smaller entertainments yesterday was busy indeed. Then there were several weddings. To-day there will be rest. Ash Wednesday is celebrated in the various churches of the Roman Catholic and Episcopal denominations with solemnity, and on that day even the opera is not generally well patronized.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24. -- Trading was limited in volume to-day, little activity appearing outside of the arbitrage stocks and Lehigh Valley. The latter was weak and lower under speculative realizing, which, when it was detected, induced some selling by the floor traders. Prices generally did not show much change either way, but Fairmount Park Transportation was up 1 1/2, Philadelphia Traction 1, and Westmoreland Coal 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Mr. Bowen, the Venezuelan Plenipotentiary, has proposed to the allied powers that the Czar of Russia be asked to name the three arbitrators, who, as The Hague Tribunal, shall decide the question of preferential treatment. The suggestion has been approved by the State Department.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Five Republican Senators broke away from the leadership of Senator John Raines to-day and voted with the Democrats for the Plunkitt bill amending the liquor tax law by providing that in special elections saloons must close only within the district where such election is being held.

Money easy, 2 3/4 @ 3 per cent. on call. Stocks break and recover. The resumption of business by the Stock Exchange after its triple holiday reflected the events of the interval. The bank statement had been interpreted discouragingly through London, and there was an accumulation of domestic selling orders which gave a weak tone to the early dealings in general, with exceptions of specialties.

The pleasant weather of yesterday brought out a large attendance at the Sportsmen's Show at the Madison Square Garden, and in the evening the crowd was almost equal to that of the previous holiday. The best fly casting seen so far during the show was seen in the afternoon in the contest in Class D, for distance only, open to those who had never made more than sixty feet in a similar contest.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24. -- The Carnival visitors swarmed to the track to-day and saw a fairly good card run off, Fuller's wdrk in the saddle was the feature of the day, the boy riding three winners and two seconds. Benson Caldwell was claimed out of the fifth race by L.V. Bell for $1,325.

Exceptional activity and pronounced strength in Wabash preferred stock, which sold up to a new high record, with the common sharing only to a small degree in the movement, were the feature of the market, and gave Wall Street much food for gossip, speculation and rumor mongering.

BRISTOL, R.I., Feb. 24. -- The new cup yacht is growing rapidly. To-day the upper portion of the stem was fastened in place. It is of steel and is attached to the bronze stem underneath, giving to the boat her designed outline at the forward end. In many respects this gives the appearance of a spoon bow, but not to a radical degree, owing to the length of the overhang.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- President Roosevelt has signed the agreement drawn under the terms of the Platt amendment providing for the acquisition by the United States of naval bases at Guantanamo and Bahia Honda, both in Cuba. The document had been previously signed by President Palma and was brought to Washington by Minister Squiers.
LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Money was tight today, the Bank of England's hold on the market increasing as the gathering in of revenue progressed. Discounts were firm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill was reported to the Senate to-day by the Appropriation Committee. Many amendments have been made by the committee and the total amount carried in the House bill is increased $3,420,701, swelling the aggregate to $83,279,650. The amount appropriated by the Sundry Civil act for the current year is $60,652,059.

Interesting items, theatrical, literary, and political, were auctioned last evening by John Anderson, Jr., at 20 West Thirtieth Street, in the sale of Part II. of the collection of the late Peter Gilsey. Among the items sold and the prices fetched for them were the following:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Among other topics the Cabinet considered to-day the report of the commission created by Congress to acquire a site for a Post Office Building in New York City. The commission was composed of three members of the Cabinet. After the President and his advisers had heard the report read, it was transmitted to the House of Representatives by Secretary Shaw.

Henry W. Unger has presented to Assistant District Attorney Francis P. Garvan and to Coroner Moses J. Jackson the legal records showing that Mrs. Frances Freeland Hagaman Delabarre, the widow of Theodore Hagaman, came into possession of more than $600,000 of Mr. Hagaman's money just before his death, and that she transferred large sums for investment to her friend, Dr. R.C. Flower.

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- The investigation into the mysterious change of the furs of the late Mrs. Charles L. Fair was resumed before Consul General Gowdy to-day. Four affidavits from San Francisco witnesses were read. One, made by Marguerite Melbourne, Mrs. Fair's maid, said that the dark fur cloak and muff, received in the effects, are not the Russian sable garments that Mrs. Fair possessed.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Senator Elsberg playfully called it an "inquest" upon the office of Coroner in New York City when a hearing was given to-day by the Senate Cities Committee on his bill to abolish the office of Coroner in New York City and substitute that of Medical Examiner. Coroners Goldencranz and Scholer of Manhattan, Nutt of Queens, Williams of Brooklyn, and Berry of the Bronx were present.

It is due, we think, to an inattentive reading of the decision of the Supreme Court in the lottery cases that attempts have been made to extend its scope not merely beyond the intent of the court, but beyond the limits expressly defined by the court itself in clear and well-considered language as the boundaries of its opinion.

It is not reasonable to suppose that the settlement which Turkey has accepted of reforms in Macedonia is a finality. Experience teaches that no Christian population subjected to Turkish misrule can ever be brought into a satisfactory condition until they have been emancipated from that misrule altogether.

Most of the stocks which showed any activity in yesterday's market for outside securities sold at advancing prices, but the number of issues in which the trading was on a large scale was very small. The most conspicuous issues were, found among the stocks which have not been traded in very long, with the exception of Greene Consolidated, which was throughout the day the stock that was given most attention.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24. -- Baseball practice started to-day, when forty freshmen turned out for preliminary work in the cage. An hour was spent in handling ground balls and batting, under the direction of Coach Hillebrand and Capt. Pearson of the 'Varsity. The calling out of candidates from the three upper classes has been postponed until the available material in the freshman class is picked out.

The French ship owners, under the name of the General Syndicate of Shipowners, have just formed an amalgamation including all the French shipping companies, and having its headquarters in Paris. M. LEBON, ex-Minister of Commerce, is President. It brings together practically all the steamers and most of the sailing vessels of the French merchant marine, to the aggregate of 15,503,894 tons, which is very near the total merchant tonnage of France.

The separation suit of Mrs. Nina Larre Smith Duryea against Chester Burnell Duryea occupied the entire day before Justice Blanchard, in the Supreme Court, yesterday. Duryea is the son of Gen. Hiram Duryea, the President of the Starch Trust, while Mrs. Duryea is the daughter of Franklin Waldo Smith of Boston.

Yale and Columbia met at hockey last night at St. Nicholas Rink, and in one of the hardest fought and best contested games of the season. Yale won by the score of 3 goals to 2. Yale's victory last night concluded the preliminary round of the Intercollegiate Hockey League series, and now the Blues, by a peculiar provision of the intercollegiate tournament, will play Harvard, who has not yet been defeated, for the intercollegiate championship.
