CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- Playing schedules satisfactory to both sides were arranged at to-day's meeting of the committees representing the American and National Baseball Leagues, and the delegates left for home to-night.

Camilie Weidenfeld, a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1890, was found guilty yesterday of charges preferred against him and accusing him of conduct detrimental to the Exchange, and was suspended for one year by the Governing Committee, after a secret session lauting for six hours. McClure made a somewhat sensational statement regarding the method in which the trial of Mr. Weidenfeld had been conducted by the Governors.

Justice Davis in the Supreme Court yesterday decided to dismiss the writ of habeas corpus secured in behalf of Samuel G. Smith, or Hitchins, who was arrested and held for the Grand Jury as the result of one of the Jerome raids. The man was a doorkeeper at the Thirty-third Street bouse which is supposed to belong to the Farrell-Burbridge combination.

Peter R. Gatens, counsel for the mercantile agency of R.G. Dun Co., and Francis L. Minton, a member of the concern, and also one of its counsel, were arraigned before Magistrate Breen, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday. They were arrested on Monday afternoon in a sailors' boarding house in South Street by Detective Sergeants Gargan and Tinker, and held on a short affidavit charging them with conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The House today passed the Senate substitute for the Philippines Currency bill, with two amendments reported by its committee. One strikes out the provision for an international monetary conference. The other adds these words to Section 3:

The Rev. Dr. Kohler, senior rabbi of the Temple Beth-El, Seventy-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue, has received a call to the Presidency of the Hebrew Union College, in Cincinnati, the first and until recently, when a conservative seminary was established in New York, the only seminary in America for the education of Jewish ministers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- Gov. Odell, in greeting the pupils of the Canajoharie High School, who called on him to-day, said that the door was still open to individual advancement in this world and that they should pay no heed to any one who preached a contrary theory. The opportunities awaiting young men and women were as great to-day as ever before in the history of the Nation.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 24. -- A trolley car of the Orange and Passaic Valley Railway, laden with men and women in their way to work this morning, crashed through the lowered gates of the Lackawanna Railroad at the Orange station and stopped with its fender under one of the cars of a train which was just about moving out of the Orange station.

Mr. Mark Hambourg's pianoforte recital in January was announced at the time as his only one in New York this season. But for whatever reason, perhaps because he wished to better the impression left by that performance, he gave a second one yesterday afternoon, which took place in the Manhattan Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Apparently the way was cleared in the Senate for appropriation bills and the Panama Canal Treaty by the action of the Democrats to-day. In caucus they decided to adhere to the omnibus Statehood bill, but not to permit it to interfere with executive measures or appropriations.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 24. -- The Cleveland delegation to the National Bowling Congress at a caucus to-night decided on Mayor Joseph J. Rows of Lakewood, a suburb of Cleveland, to be presented as a candidate for President of the congress. Charles Moll of Milwaukee is being mentioned as a candidate for Vice President, in opposition to Walter V. Thompson of Chicago, the present incumbent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24, -- The British Ambassador, Sir Michael Herbert, and Lady Herbert gave their largest entertainment this evening, the embassy being the scene of the most brilliant ball of the Winter. The large hall, with its wide stairway, was decorated with palms, and the life-sized portrait of Queen Victoria on the platform, facing the entrance of the embassy, was banked in azalias and roses.

-- For some time past the Weather Bureau has been unusually successful in its predictions, and storm after storm has obligingly followed the course laid out for it by the prophetical meteorologists. On Saturday, however, luck turned or science slipped a cog, and things went wrong in the forecast shop.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- When the debate on Mr. Beckett's proposed amendment to the address in reply to the King's speech at the opening of the Parliament was resumed in the House of Commons to-day the attack on War Secretary Brodrick was continued. Winston Spencer Churchill (Conservative) declared that Mr. Brodrick's expectations had only been realized in two directions, namely in the decrease in the number of volunteers and in the increase of expenditure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Some time ago the Mothers Association of St. Paul Cathedral, Cincinnati, addressed a number of letters to United States Consuls asking their opinion as to the value of the United States Consular Service as a career for young Americans, and the proper education of boys for this line of work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Indianola Miss., Post Office case, occupied the major portion of the time of the Senate to-day. Mr. Tillman spoke for three hours in continuation of his remarks begun yesterday on the race question, and was followed by Mr. Carmack, of Tennessee.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Canal advocates were on hand again with a numerous delegation before the joint legislative Committee on Canals to-day prepared to reinforce their arguments in favor of the 1,000-ton barge canal. Among them were Prof. W.H. Burr, of Columbia University, who as Professor of Engineering, as a member of the Isthmian Canal Commission, and as one of the engineers connected with the original State Canal survey, corroborated the statements of Messrs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- That all obstructions to the important business of the Senate are brushed away was made apparent at the beginning of to-day's session of that body. At the outset Mr. Quay performed his prefunctory act of asking that a time might be fixed for voting on the Statehood bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- W.J. Wilgus, Fifth Vice President of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad, offered to the Postmaster General to-day on behalf of that company, for the up-town Post Office to be located near the Grand. Central Station in New York City, three alternative sites situated over the proposed depressed yard of the railroad company.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times says that after more than three weeks' trial on charges of forgery, misappropriation of public money, sale of offices, acceptance of bribes, , Col. Shafroff, Chief of the Kronstadt police, has been found guilty on the main charges.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- King Edward will send Queen Victoria's priceless collection of jubilee presents for exhibition at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition as his personal contribution toward the success of the Exposition.

Staten Islanders raised their voices loud and strong yesterday at the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission against the plan of Dock Commissioner Hawkes to give the Rapid Transit Company another lease of twenty years on the ferry privileges. From every part of the island there came property owners, all anxious to make speeches.

"II Flauto Magieo," Mozart's fantastic Egyptian fairy opera, was produced last evening for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House. It is an opera that calls for a "star cast," and hence it is one that may be relied upon to attract a large audience, as it did last night.
NEWARK, Feb. 25. -- Thirty-four witnesses were examined by the Coroner's jury to-day in the investigation of the cause of the Clifton Avenue grade crossing trolley wreck last Thursday.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- There is a strong suspicion among the friends of Gov. Odell that the action of the Platt Republicans on the Conveyance Tax bill in the Assembly yesterday did not represent their real sentiments upon the merits of the measure, but was to be attributed to a determination to play politics at the Governor's expense.

It is needless to say that yesterday was dull in society. Ash Wednesday is always strictly observed. Even the bridge classes did not meet, and the opera was poorly attended. The number of departures for Europe and for the South is beginning to make a void in the ranks of fashionable folk.

The striking out by the Senate of two items in the Sundry Civil bill, as passed by the House, is distinctly a personal rebuke to Mr. CANNON, the Chairman of Appropriations in the latter body. And it is richly deserved.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The Senate Cities Committee to-day reported out the bill introduced by Senator Elsberg to abolish the office of Coroner in New York City and substitute that of medical examiner. The measure was amended in some unimportant particulars.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- The money market is firm and quiet. Call loans, 4 1/25 per cent.; time loans, collateral. 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 20c discount; clearings, $24,940,920; balances, $1,426,154. The foreign exchange market is somewhat easier.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Feb. 25. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, daughter of the President of the United States, has written, in reply to an invitation from Miss Elizabeth Hunt, daughter of Gov. Hunt, that she will pay her a visit here early in March.

At the Church Club last night Bishop Anthony Koslowski of the Polish Old Catholic Church in the United States presented his proposition for the union of his people and himself with the American Episcopal Church -- an action characterized by several of the speakers as the first move from outside toward accepting the basis of Church unity offered by the famous so-called "Quadrilateral" of the Chicago-Lambeth Conference.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 25. -- The expected arrests of President Albert C. Twining and Treasurer David C. Cornell of the Monmouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company were made at noon to-day. They are now under bonds to appear for a hearing, which will probably be held at Freehold, if at all, as it is likely the men will elect to go to the trial court if the Grand Jury sees fit to indict them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day submitted a report to the Senate in response to a resolution calling for information regarding all the securiaties issued by railroad companies the par value of each class of such securities outstanding June 30, 1900, interest and dividends thereon,
Mayer S. Auerbach has bought 331 West Fifty-eighth Street, a four-story brown-stone-front dwelling, on lot 21.5 by 100.5.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Supreme Court's ruling with regard to the height of buildings in cities is regarded as most interesting and important. The case which brought up the question of regulation of height was that of Bigelow and Ayer. Trustees, against the Attorney General of Massachusetts.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25. -- The market to-day was interested in the report of the United Railways, which was received favorably in view of the surplus of over $200,000 above all fixed charges. There was much interest also in the report of Seaboard's possible connection with St. Louis and San Francisco.

They were two very much astonished detectives -- Feretti and Dougherty -- when, after four hours of search through the lower east side for a supposed desperate Anarchist who was said to have told of a plot to assassinate the crowned heads of Europe, they found, at 8 Baxter Street, a youth of sixteen with flaxen hair, smooth face, calm blue eyes, and a submissive demeanor.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- The release of u3,000,000 in connection with the retirement of Treasury bills, in addition to disbursements for railroad dividends, temporarily somewhat eased the rates for money in the market to-day, but the effect was lessened by the call for u2,000,000 of the Japanese loan.
Special meeting of the Elgin National Watch Company to be held in Chicago on Tuesday next, to vote on a stock increase from $4,000,000 to $5,000,000.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25. -- "We must win the Mott Haven games!" roared Evert J. Wendell of New York, his face flushed with excitement, at a mass meeting of track athletes at Harvard to-night.

Mansfield Allen, twenty-eight years of age, who is said to have been an editor of The Bookman and a contributor to many of the leading magazines and journals of this city, committed suicide last night at the hoarding house of Mrs. Hannah Schumann, at 28 West Eighteenth Street, by taking chloral.

Items relating to Edmund and Charles Kean, Charles, Fanny, and John Philip Kemble, Gen. Robert E. Lee, and Abraham Lincoln comprised the most of the material auctioned off by John Anderson, Jr., at 20 West Thirtieth Street, last evening, at the second day's sale of Part II. of the collection of the late Peter Gilsey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Civil Service Comissioner Foulke was severely criticised in the Senate to-day on account of a letter written by him to Mr. Spooner regarding the dismissal of Elmer E. Foreshay, an employe in the office of the Surveyor General of Idaho, the employe having been charged with receiving campaign contributions.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The sportsmen of the State are manifesting great interest in a bill introduced by Senator Brown, on which there will be a hearing before the Forest, Fish, and Game Committee March 5. Under the present law it is provided that duck, geese, brant, and swan shall not be taken from April 30 to Aug. 31.

Members of the Catholic clergy in this city received yesterday from Rome notices containing a list of eminent scholars who have been selected by the Pope as consultors to the Biblical Commission, which was appointed by the Pontiff about a year ago. Of the forty consultors there is only one American, the Rev. Dr. Charles Grannan, Professor of Holy Scripture at the Catholic University, Washington.

A profit of $30,000,000 already in sight on the contract for the construction and operation of the Manhattan-Bronx subway and an ultimate profit of $50,000,000 on the agreement -- that was the estimate made by Edward M. Shepard in a speech he delivered yesterday afternoon at a session of the National Convention on Municipal Ownership and Public Franchises in the assembly room of the Reform Club, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25. -- The Street Railways Handicap for three-year-olds and upward was the feature event at the fair grounds this afternoon. The distance was one mile and twelve of the best long-distance horses at the track started. It furnished a good contest, the first six horses fighting it out at the last furlong and passed the winning mark heads apart.

We observe that with the exception of The Journal of Commerce none of our New York contemporaries agrees with the view held by THE TIMES that in its decision in the lottery cases the Supreme Court has not decided the whole question of Federal power over inter-State commerce.

A change in the location of the canoe tilting boats in connection with the Sportsmen's Show at the Madison Square Garden was made last night, the contests taking place on the open water at the east end of the island instead of in the narrow lane on the side where they were held on the preceding evening.

The fact that the venerable PARKE GODWIN yesterday celebrated his eighty-seventh birthday, though the celebration itself was purely social and private, is excuse for noting the peculiar and honorable career of the veteran journalist, publicist, and writer and the obligations under which he has placed his country.

As the bill of Senator ALDRICH increasing the authority of the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit public funds in the banks is the only measure of relief that is at all likely to be enacted at this session, it is very much to be desired that it shall pass, and we are happy to say that the prospects for that are good.

In the tournament of the Life Insurance Bowling League last night the Provident Savings Life Insurance Company bowlers won three straight games from the second team of the Fidelity and Casualty Company. The scores follow:
BERLIN, Feb. 25. -- Germany's pig iron production for January was 782,484 tons, beating that of December by 28,489 tons, though December broke all previous records.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- The university basket ball team walked completely away from the Swarthmore College five here this afternoon, winning by the decided score of 63 to 25. At no time were the Tigers hard pushed, and they scored almost at will, throwing away many rosy chances of scoring in the second half by their attempts to practice team work.

Hurled by an extra heavy charge of blasting powder, a jagged rock weighing about fifty pounds was sent high into the air last evening and came down with a terrific crash through the roof of a five-story apartment house at Audubon Avenue and One Hundred and Seventy-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The House today decided by a vote of 157 to 98 to recede from its disagreement with the Senate on the Union Station bill, and this assures the erection of the station in Washington. The difference between the two houses was that the Senate wanted to give the Pennsylvania and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroads $1,500,000 each, and the House wanted to cut this down to $1,000,000 each.

Representatives from over a dozen yacht clubs met last night at the Columbia Yacht Clubhouse, foot of West Eighty-sixth Street, and discussed matters of importance relating to the future racing and classification of motor boats. The Motor Boat Association, which was practically formed a month ago at the same place, was made permanent, but it was voted to change the name to the American Power Boat Association.
August Belmont said yesterday, concerning the suggestions to the Rapid Transit Commission for new transportation facilities in this city:

A special committee of the Trunk Line Association, consisting of the Passenger Traffic Managers of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, the Lettish Valley Railroad Company, the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway, the Brie Railway Company, the Baltimore and Ohio Railway, and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, made an agreement yesterday by which there will be put into practice the plan of issuing interchangeable mileage books.
ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- These bills were passed in the Senate to-day:

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 23. -- The Republican Assemblymen held a long caucus after the morning session on the Powell case. The report of the investigating committee was submitted to the caucus and held that Powell had not been proved guilty of any crime, but that he had been very indiscreet.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 25. -- At Stanniford City. Raleigh County, a fierce battle took place at dawn to-day between the joint posse of Deputy United States Marshal Cunningham and Sheriff Cook on one side and rioting miners on the other, as a result of which three miners were killed, two others mortally wounded, and a number of others on both sides more or less seriously hurt.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The endeavors of non-official Germany, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, have for years been steadily directed toward the Germanization of a portion of Brazil, and a considerable amount of printed literature, in circulation in a semi-private way, refers to this project in undisguised terms.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The Irish leader, John E. Redmond, in the House of Commons yesterday, moved an amendment to the address in reply to the speech from the throne on the subject of the Irish land question.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25. -- Six girls were badly burned by an explosion of fireworks in the small fireworks factory of A.M. Meyer, at Second and Essex Streets, Harrison, this afternoon. The girls were the only persons in the building at the time. The explosion was followed by fire, and the building was destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Dullness and heaviness were continued in the stock market. There was little disposition to trade, and had it not been for the operations of the arbitragers and floor traders, who endeavored to secure scalpers' profit. Complete stagnation would have prevailed. The tone generally was heavy, especially in the Philadelphia electric issues, on the intimatior.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- A pessimistic feeling, says the Sofia correspondent of The Times, prevails in regard to the execution of the scheme for Macedonian reforms presented by Austria-Hungary and Russia; the Sultan's ready acceptance of the demands is regarded as ominous.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Gov. Odell to-day disposed of the report that a bill was to be introduced which would extend to nine years the term of the Police Commissioner of New York. When asked if such legislation was being contemplated the Governor said:

The committee of the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has definitely notified the executors of the estate of the late Peter Marie that his famous collection of minilature portraits of New York women will not be accepted as a gift by the institution.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Enlarged powers for the Rapid Transit Commission of New York City and provision for the construction of transit lines by the municipality are contained in a bill introduced to-day by Senator Elsberg. It was drawn for the Citizens' Union and allied organizations, and is intended to aid the Rapid Transit Commission to carry out the Parsons programme.

Developments yesterday concerning the litigation over the property of the late Theodore Hagaman, and the question is to the cause of his death, brought into prominence the strained relations between Dr. R.C. Flower, who is a prominent figure in the case, and Andrew D. Meloy, formerly connected with some of the doctor's mining deals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- After holding a conference to-day with the President, the Republican leaders in Congress decided that carnost efforts should be made to ratify the Cuban treaty before the present session expires next Wednesday. This decision was reached after the House leaders had insisted that affirmative action by that body is necessary to give effect to the convention.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Republican leaders who were intrusted with the task of drafting a bill to tax mortgages that would carry out Gov. Odell's ideas have completed their labors. They have prepared for presentation to the Legislature a measure which they believe can be passed.

Charles Hathaway Co. made a state- ment yesterday regarding the press dispatch from Oneonta, N.Y., which said that the firm had notified Hugh Adair, Treasurer of Delaware County, that it held a note for $30,000 purporting to be signed by him as County Treasurer. Mr. Adair was quoted in the dispatch as saying the signature was a forgery.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Reading your editorial in to-day's issue on the increase of the police force leads me to offer the following suggestions:

The regular Monthly meeting of the Executive Committee of the Prison Association of New York was held yesterday. The Committee on Detentions, of, which J.G. Phelps Stokes is Chairman, after an inspection of the New York Reformatory for Women at Bedford made by the Women's Visiting Committee of the association, and after attending the hearing at Albany and considering the plans of the fiscal Superintendent for the abolition of that Institution, presented the following report:

To the Editor of The New York Times: When in the course of human events it becomes necessary for the Empire State to alter its long-established customs, and to assume among the States of the Union that exalted and dignified station in educational affairs to which commercial and industrial supremacy entitles it, a decent respect to the opinions of its citizens requires that we should declare the cause which impels us to this action.

Divergence of opinion as to the relative advantages to the public in the municipal and private control of electric and gas lighting plants, water supplies, and telephones was expressed by the experts in attendance at yesterday's session of the National Convention on Municipal Ownership and Public Franchises, which is being held under the auspices of the Committee on City Affairs of the Reform Club in the club rooms at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- The question of jurisdiction in connection with the contracts of Pietro Mascagni, the Italian composer, was passed upon finally by the full bench of the Supreme Court to-day, and the decision is that any difference or questions between Mascagni and his concert managers must be acted on by the civil authorities of Florence, Italy.

PANAMA, Feb. 26 -- News has been received here that forces under the command of Gen. Nicasio Vasquez, sent by President Zelaya of Nicaragua to help President Sierra of Honduras to cope with the revolution begun by President-elect Bonilla, have occupied Choluteca City, sixty-eight miles south of the Honduran capital, Tegucigualpa.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- The law which nullifies the operation of the Statute of Limitations where the defendant has absented himself from the State permitted the indictment on three charges of embezzlement of George J. Hammond, former President of the defunct Combination Investment Company.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Attorney General Cunneen said to-day that he had retained Cornelius F. Collins of 99 Nassau Street, New York City, to assist Deputy Attorney General Blumenthal in the enforcement of the election laws.

Wearing clothing of fine texture, two baby boys about four days old were found wrapped in a bundle yesterday afternoon in the hallway of the tenement house at 22 Hubert Street. They had been left there by a young woman, stylishly dressed, who had driven to and from the neighborhood in a carriage.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- At the Clearing House to-day balances between the banks loaned at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent., and New York funds sold at 20 cents per $1,000 discount. The exchanges were $23,560,896, against $22,336,- 252 a year ago to-day, and the balances were $22,446. Call loans, 5@5 1/2 time money, 4 1/2 @5 1/2; commercial paper, 4 1/2 @6.

Capt. John T. Andariese of Engine No. 1 was fatally hurt, seven firemen seriously injured and several others slightly early yesterday morning in a spectacular fire which wrecked the three upper stories of the Roosevelt Building, on the northwest corner of Thirteenth Street and Broadway.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your article of yesterday. "Call to Rabbi Kohler," you omitted one of his foremost titles to recognition as the leading Jewish scholar of this country -- his participation in the founding and editing of the Jewish Encyclopedia. He, with Prof. Richard Gottheil, has helped Dr. L.K. Funk and myself in placing, in 1898, this great enterprise on a solid, scientific basis.
The-day's news and developments were conflicting, but on the whole favored the cause of the bears.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- These bills were passed in the Senate to-day: Senator ELSBERG'S--Incorporating the Lincoln Hospital and Home for Colored Persons. Senator BRACKETT'S--Extendin to soldiers' and sailors' widows the veterans' burial privileges. Senator BAILEY'S--That the Board of Estimate of New York may fix the compensation of Judges of Nassau and Richmond Counties.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 26 -- A decision of great interest and importance to many settlers along the rights of way of the land-aided railroads of the West was handed down to-day by United States Judge Munger, at Omaha. The case in which the decision was given was a test case, and involved only 600 acres of land in Burt County, Neb., but hundreds of farmers in almost every Western State are interested.

The affairs of the Asphalt, Company of America came up briefly before Vice Chancellor Stevenson at Jersey City yesterday. About a year ago the Land Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia, began proceedings against the Asphalt Company in the United States Circuit Court at Trenton, and Judge Andrew J. Kirkpatrick appointed John M. Mack and Henry W. Tatnall of Philadelphia receivers for the Asphalt Company.

How the Comedians at Keith's and at Proctor's Amuse Their Auditors. "Will you always love me?" "Oh, my; yes." "But you men are so liable to change." _ "Well, it you can find any change on me you may have it." "My brother is the only man I ever knew who could make both ends meet. He's a contortionist."
CINCINNATI, Feb. 26 -- More than one-half of the best square in Cincinnati, bounded by Vine, Fourth, Walnut, and Third Streets, was destroyed by fire today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Not only is the Elkins anti-rebate bill to be the pretext for maintaining high freight rates, but it will also be used to bring about a material increase in passenger earnings. While it will not be possible to increase passenger rates above the present basis of 3 cents a mile, an enormous saving is to be made by cutting off all special privileges and inducements heretofore granted to secure business.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Feb. 26 -- It has become known here that plans are on foot for a railroad across Pennsylvania, which, it is said, is to connect the Wabash system and the Ontario and Western, giving the former road an outlet to tidewater and eventually letting it into New York. Reilly Shale, attorneys, of this city, represent the parties back of the movement.

Dr. Richard Jordan Gatling, inventor of the Gatling gun, which revolutionized modern warfare, died yesterday afternoon in the home of his son-in-law, Hugh. O. Pentecost, at 240 West One Hundred and Seventh Street. He had lived to the age of eighty-four years, but at the time of his death he was perfecting a few business for- malities prior to placing his new motor plow on the market.

Magistrate Breen, whose remarks in the Tombs Police Court on the enforcement of the excise law, a few days ago, were ad- versely commented upon by District Attor- ney Jerome before the legislative commit- tee at Albany, yesterday replied to Mr. Jerome in a letter.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 26 -- At the annual meeting of the Northern Central Railway Company, held to-day at its general office in this city, the following were elected as Directors for 1903-4; A.J. Cassatt, H. Walters, J.D. Cameron, Luther S. Burt, N. Parker Shortridge, Charles E. Pugh, H.H. Arnot, Wayne MacVeagh, Michael Jenkins, S.M. Prevost, A. Louden Snowden, and Samuel Rea.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The Hon. Stewart Rolls, the well-known automobilist, has broken the world's automobile record for a kilometer, covering the distance in 27 seconds. This result was accomplished at a private party given by the Duke of Portland to-day on his Welbeck Abbey estate. The time was taken by officials of the Automobile Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill was completed today by the Senate.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Feb. 26 -- Albert Knapp, the Indianapolis man arrested yesterday, who then confessed to the muder of his third wife, to-day made a full confession of five murders. The victims were all women and girls, two of them Knapp's wives.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The annual appropriation bill was debated in the Assembly to-day, and finally passed by a vote of 82 to 53. The total of the appropriations made is $17,897,231,15. The appropriation bill of last year carried $16,152,901,03. The apparent increase is $1,744,333,12. From this amount, however, there must be deducted the sum of $621,485,44, which comes back to the Stale Treasury in the way of refunds.

We should suppose there was no doubt that the Board of Estimate would make haste to adopt the plan of widening Fifty-ninth Street, from Columbus Avenue to Second, which has already commended itsolf to the local boards concerned. What view the Board of Aldermen will take of course there is no means of knowing, nor even of plausibly conjecturing, so obscure and tortuous are the intellectual processes of that body.

The work of PETER COOPER HEWITT in the field of electro-mechanics is of so much interest and importance as to have commanded appreciative attention on both sides of the Atlantic. The Hewitt inventions include a new lamp and a converter. The lamp differs from those hitherto employed in depending upon the incandescence of mercury vapor for its light-giving powers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- There is some likelihood that the National Guard of New York will not share in the advantages or disadvantages conferred by the militia law enacted by Congress, but will continue as a separate and independent organization. There seems to be an irreconcilable difference of opinion between the New York Guardsmen and the War Department officials over the question of weapons to be used.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The embargo established by the Assembly Cities Committee against the New York City bills was partially raised to-day. The committee late this evening decided to report out the following city measures:
Landscapes in deep tones on Holland cups and saucers, said to be hand painted, are exceedingly pretty and quite different from the ordinary run of china. They cost $2 each.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The demand for money increased in the market to-day in connection with the Stock Exchange pay day. Discounts were easier on the Continent bidding more freely for bills and the influx of gold, which induced Speculation regarding a possible early reduction of the Bank of England's rate of discount.

R. Fulton Cutting, President of the Citizens' Union, appeared before the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday and said that the city had tied itself up for seventy-five years in a disadvantageous bargain when it gave the contract for the Manhattan-Bronx sub-way, now being built by the syndicate of which August Belmont is the head.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Efforts of George Clark, the veteran actor of the legitimate drama, to establish an American Academy of Dramatic Art met with considerable success to-night, when, at a meeting in the Hotel Bellevue, $250,000 was subscribed toward the proposed fund of $2,000,000, with the proviso that the proposed institution be located in Philadelphia.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 26 -- Improvements now in progress, or to be made this year, along the lines of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad between Chicago and Baltimore will cost about $20,000,000. This estimate was made by an official to-day.

-- Extreme vehemence is shown by The School Bulletin in its denunciation of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction for what it calls -- and what can hardly be otherwise considered -- his latest effort to undermine the Board of Regents. His object now is to secure for his own department the administration of the proposed fund to compensate high schools for instructing pupils from districts not provided with such institutions.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your publication of to-day's date is a letter from "A Democrat," in which he asserts that:

Mayor Low made the announcement yesterday that $100,000 had already been subscribed to the Abram S. Hewitt endowment of the Cooper Union. J. Pierpont Morgan subscribed $25,00O, William E. Dodge $25,000, and Andrew Carnegie $50,000 to a proposed fund of $500,000 to continue the work at Cooper Union to which Abram S. Hewitt gave many years of his life.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 26 -- The most phenomenal storm of this phenomenal Texas Winter ended this afternoon after having continued for nearly two days and nights. The storm raged from the Panhandle to the Gulf, and produced snowdrifts and blizzards in the upper half and cloudbursts and fresbets in the lower half of the State.

When ABRAM S. HEWITT died it was the general feeling that the Cooper Union had suffered an irreparable loss. Public-spirited citizens of New York have resolved to do what it is in their power to do to diminish and mitigate that loss. The action taken at a meeting of friends of Mr. HEWITT held at the Mayor's office on the 18th inst. has a double purpose.

DELHI, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- When Hugh Adair Treasurer of Delaware County, took his office Jan. 8, 1900, a note for $10.000, given by his predecessor, C.S. Woodruff, to Charles Hathaway Co. of New York City, was outstanding against the county. This note was paid in January by Treasurer Adair.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Abraham Gruber, a law partner of ex-Gov, Frank S. Black, is said to be partly responsible for a bill introduced in the Assembly to-day by Assemblyman James C. Sheldon of Cattaraugus County. It is in essence the old Black "starchless" civil service law, although it differs somewhat from that law in phraseology.

The report of City Superintendent of Schools William H. Maxwell, for the year which ended July 31, 1902, had other features of interest than those published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, and some terse continents. Chief of his criticisms were the following in regard to the Normal College:
An outflow of currency from this money centre at this season of the year is unusual. There is nothing abnormal about it, however, nothing in the least alarming -- quite the contrary.

Wall Street's interpretation of yesterday's news was unfavorable. Among active stocks there were but two fractional advances, while there is a long list of declines between one and two full points, with greater falls among less representative properties, reflecting the professional view.

After a Winter of sales phenomenal in number and in the prices brought for works of art, the sale last night of the paintings belonging to J.D. Ichenhauser, held at Mendelssohn Hall, Fortieth Street, east of Broadway, attracted half as many people as have been present at the other sales.

President Roosevelt made a flying trip to this city yesterday, addressed a Methodist meeting in Carnegie Hall, went to the University Club, and then returned to the capital, the whole trip occupying twenty hours.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Senate to-day passed the first of Gov. Odell's tax bills. It was that introduced by Senator Stevens, which provides that all direct inheritances of more than $10,000, in either real or personal property, shall be taxable at the rate of 1 per cent, upon the clear market value of the property.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Senator Burrows, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections, to-day presented to the Senate a protest signed by the Rev. J.L. Leilich, in the case of Senator-elect Reed Smoot of Utah, urging that Mr. Smoot shall not be permitted to take his seat in the Senate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a graduate of Cornell, whose feelings of loyalty have steadily strengthened with the lapse of years, I feel constrained to set forth a few words in connection with the present unhappy epidemic of typhoid fever at Ithaca.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Roman Catholics of Utica and Bishop Ludden of Syracuse are right in their opposition to the reacting of the Bible in the public schools. It is unjust to compel school children in schools supported by public tax to listen to theological and religious exposition opposed by them or by their parents.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 -- Ailyar, Jove, and Delagoa were the winning favorites today. Durnell Herz claimed Ben Mora for $1,415 and bought Fading Light for $1,400. Inspector Shea was claimed by the Daniels Brothers for $1,125. Thane was run up to $1,803, and bought by J.J. McCafferty. Weather raining, track sloppy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Senator Hale, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, to- day reported the Naval Appropriation bill. The most important amendment recommended by the committee relates to the increase of the navy.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- The annual report of Frederick D. Kilburn, State Superintendent of Banks, relative to building and loan and co-operative savings and loan associations was made to-day.

This is an advertisement for the Fay Templeton School of Acting -- not a school for the milky way of amateurs, but a school for the bright particular stars, of which Miss Millie James of "The Little Princess" is the latest pupil. Few of the long list of popular actresses whom Miss Templeton has taken off have any need to sigh for the giftie of seeing themselves as ithers see them.

With sewing classes and bridge and minor entertainments, yesterday was not a very dull day, notwithstanding the Lenten season. Mrs. Lovell Hall Jerome of 138 West Twelfth Street will have an "at home" to-day, and Mrs. Frank McCoy and Miss McCoy will receive at 45 West Thirty-fifth Street.

Again Senator MORGAN announces his purpose to talk till the end of the session if need be to prevent the ratification of the canal treaty with Colombia; and again the friends of the treaty in the Senate declare that they will test Mr. MORGAN'S endurance by a continuous executive session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The situation in the Senate on the Panama Canal treaty has been further aggravated by the illness of Senato Morgan. The Alabaman was forced to-day by what seems to be the symptoms of acute grip to leave the Senate Chamber after discussing the treaty as long as he was physically able to do so.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A bill which is said to represent the Republican end of a compact made between the bolting Democrats of Clifton County and the Republican State leaders was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Prime. It provides for an appropriation of $200,000 for the purchase of the proposed Ausable Reservation, in which the famed Ausable Chasm is located, and its use as a Stale park.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the recent agitation and discussion on substitution and adulteration by druggists, the following lines based upon actual knowledge and not hearsay evidence will probably be of interest to your readers:

A decision was handed down yesterday in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Judge Wallace writing the opinion, which was concurred in by Judges Lacombe and Coxe, in a bankruptcy case, that presented the question whether an individual creditor had a right to institute proceedings for the re-examination and disallowance of the claims of other creditors against the bankrupt estate, when there was a trustee in bankruptcy in existence.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 26 -- Willard P. Voorhees, counsel for the New Brunswick, Amboy and New York Steamboat Company, filed as petition in the United States District Court, in Trenton, to-day, asking that the company be adjudged bankrupt. The petition alleged that the company performed an act of insolvency on Oct. 28 last by transferring property valued at $1,000 to Ellen M. Cornell.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The bill introduced by Senator Elon R. Brown to revise the educational system of the State, by abolishing the Department of Public Instruction and substituting therefor a Board of Education to be composed of nine regents to be added to the present Board of Rgents was reported to the Senate to-day by the Committee on Public Education with an important amendment and then recommitted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Amid scenes which recalled the memorable and exciting days of the Fifty-first Congress, when party reeling ran fiercely and the Hail of Representatives resounded with denunciation of the alleged "high-handed methods" of the majority. James J. Butler of Missouri was unseated to-day by the House and George C.R. Wagoner was seated in his place.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 20 -- The Dutch steamship Beta, Capt. Rijkeboer, from Ship Island Feb. 12 for Rotterdam, arrived here last night, having in tow the United States collier Alexander, which broke her shaft on Feb. 10 while on her way from San Juan, Porto Rico, for Norfolk.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Through advices received here from Caracas it has come to light that the representatives there of the French, Spanish, and Belgian Governments have approached President Castro regarding the claims of their countries, and have proposed a scheme of settlement independent of that which is now under consideration by Mr. Bowen and the Washington representatives of these nations.

Dr. R.C. Flower, whose name has figured prominently in connection with the estate of Theodore Hagaman and in the action brought by a brother and two sisters of Mr. Hagaman to compel the widow, now Mrs. Walter Delabarre, to account for hundreds of thousands of dollars, spent much of yesterday afternoon with Assistant District Attorney Garvan.

M. HUGHES LE ROUX, who perhaps is chiefly remembered in America for having claimed the authorship of Daudet's charming "La Belle Nivernaise" last year, is about to publish through Dodd, Mead Co. what may be an interesting coritribution to sociology, entitled "Business and Love."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt to-day received a valuable invitation from the citizens of Pasadena, Cal. What its exact value is has not been made known, but it is worth a good deal, for it is in gold. The invitation, which was handed to the President to-day by Representative McLachlan of California, asks Mr. Roosevelt to visit Pasadena on his coming trip to the West.
Testimony was closed in the Duryea separation suit yesterday, before Justice Blanchard, who allowed Messrs. Wellman and Man, the attorneys in the case, two weeks in which to file their briefs.

At a joint session of Advisory and Executive Committees of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America, held last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, several matters of importance were discussed and some changes in and amendments to the constitution were recommended for adoption at the annual convention, which will take place to-day.

Ralph Harold Bretherton has taken a sensitive imaginative child as his subject, and following the daily round of her life has given a picture of the impressions left on her mind. The study has proved an interesting one. There are many facts that the child cannot grasp, but in a frantic effort to understand them she substitutes strange impressions of her own.

GOLDEN NUMBERS is an anthology divided into many parts, the arrangement of which leaves little to be desired. The first division consists of a calendar of poems appropriate to the different months and seasons of the year.

BUFFALO, Feb. 27.--Edwin L. Burdick, President at E. L. Burdick Co., and of the Buffalo Envelope Company, was murdered early to-day at his home on Ashland Avenue, in one of the finest residence sections of the city. The theory at first advanced, that the crime was the work of a burglar, was abandoned as the police probed deeper into the case.

"When a flood is spread over an expanse of meadow land, and stands in shallow pools, men restrain it by damming it up, and they constrain it to one channel by banking it in. Thus compressed, it becomes a stream, and moves with force in one direction. See how it quickens its pace! See what strength it gathers!

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Aldrich Currency bill was introduced in the House to-day by Mr. Payne, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and on his motion was referred to that committee. The title of the bill was changed to read: "A Bill to Raise Revenue from the Deposit of Public Money and for the Safekeeping Thereof."

LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 27 -- One life was lost and six persons suffered severely from burns and smoke at a fire which partially destroyed the Burbank block to-day. The victim was Mrs. Sarah F. Kittredge, a newspaper correspondent, about sixty years old. Although she was aroused with the other seventy-five lodgers in the building, she stopped to get her bicycle and was overcome by smoke and perished.
Jurors in the action of Bartholomew Donovan against Jacob A. Cantor, before Justice Scott in the Supreme Court yesterday, gave a verdict in favor of the Borough President.

The Board of Superintendents have before them a scheme for the retirement of teachers, submitted by H.R.M. Cook, Auditor of the Board of Education, which he believes could be embodied in a legislative bill and passed this session. The present retirement fund is derived from fines for lateness and absences, and 5 per cent. of the excise fund.

MR. RICHMAN has given us in these volumes an elaborate study of a very short period in the history of the smallest State of the Union, chapters of which have already been discussed in these columns. That he has been fully justified in the labor he must have bestowed upon the work no one can doubt who has the historic sense and an appreciation of the important place Rhode Island holds in our political development.

"A Daughter of the Pit "-- a tale of a north of England coal-mining country -- is referred to by its author as a pathetic, perhaps even a pretty, story. The reader knows exactly what to expect after that characterization, and is not disappointed, for although the book has its good points it nowhere rises above prettiness, and rests for the most part on a somewhat barren level of the commonplace.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 27 -- Sir Charles Tupper, the former leader of the Conservative Party in the Dominion Parliament, arrived in the city to-day and was interviewed regarding the Alaskan boundary dispute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- J.J. Jusserand, the French Ambassador, and Herbert W. Bowen, the Venezuelan Plenipotentiary, signed a protocol this afternoon for the settlement of the French claims against Venezuela by a joint commission, to meet at Caracas, and for the reference to The Hague tribunal of the contention of the allied powers for preferential treatment in the satisfaction of their demands.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- "The Triumph of Count Ostermann," a new novel by Graham Hope, will be published here March 9 by Messrs. Smith, Elder Co., and in New York later by Mr. Henry Holt. It is a Russian story of the last days of Peter the Great and the beginning of the succeeding reign.

Take away from Zola's last novel the narrative of the "cause celebre," with which his name must always be identified, and there remain a number of episodes woven into a forensic in which the promoters of the Associations Law may find plausible justification. Take away these episodes and there remains still an essay on education.

Since Sherlock Holmes introduced his bloodless method of detective work we have become squeamish at any exhibition of detective skill more brutal than his polite methods. In Mr. Hume's story the crime rather than its unraveling is always paramount. Mr. Hume makes his heroine sail under so very black a cloud that from the first one is certain she can't possibly be as villainous as she appears.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 27 -- Almost denuded of paint and with several of her plates bent from impact with ice floes, and in a generally topsy-turvy condition, the revenue cutter Seminole reached here to-day after an ineffectual attempt to release the Gloucester fishing fleet, which is ice-bound at Bay of Islands, Newfoundland.

The handsome books of William Loring Andrews have come upon the market this season in great numbers. In most cases they have sold well, in some instances far beyond former records. Special copies of some of his best works were offered at Anderson's Friday evening, Feb. 20. Prices were as follows:

The passages quoted from the latest work of George Gissing, which we print to-day in lieu of a formal and critical review, which may well be deferred, serve to indicate the scope of "The Pri- vate Papers or Henry Ryecroft" as well as its admirable and uncommon literary quality.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Greater activity was displayed in the local market to-day, the heaviest trading being in Philadelphia Electric, Lehigh Valley, and the arbitrage stocks, especially Reading and Wabash preferred. Lehigrh Valley was again taken in-band by interests prominent in its recent rise and was moved up from 41 1/2 to 42 7/8, receding to 42 1/4 in the late trading.

The Scott-Thaw Company have in preparation a series of folio volumes in which, in the course of ten years, they hope to include one work, at least, of all the classic authors of the world's literature. The first two volumes, which will appear in April, will be Landor's "Pericles and Aspasia" and More's "Utopia," (Ralph Robinson's translation.)

To the Editor of The New York Times: The House of Representatives has recently passed on act extending the time within which live stock might be legally confined in transit from twenty-eight to forty consecutive hours. Is it possible, with so many humane societies to look after the welfare of animals, we have no one among them to protest against such an inhuman law?

THE name of Henry James Ross is in a certain measure known to us as associated with that of Layard, the discoverer of the Assyrian monuments at Tell-Nimrood. "The Letters from the East," now brought together by Mrs. Janet Ross, contain description of her husband's life in Asia Minor, Turkish Arabia, Syria, and Egypt, and, beginning in 1837, end in 1837.

OMAHA, Feb. 27 -- The United States Court here heard arguments to-day in a land case in which James Buckingham and other heirs of the late Alvah Buckingham of New York are suing Charles R. Conkling of Tekamah for $24,000.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- More than four hundred feet of the New York Central Railroad track at what is known as "the loop" are out in the Hudson River buried under tons of earth and rock. All traffic over the road will be blocked until at least noon to-morrow. Meanwhile all through trains are being sent around from Albany by way of the Harlem Road.

Cornell will doubtless recognize with gratitude the kindly intention which prompted Dr. JUSTUS L. BARNES, one of her sons, to write the letter we published yesterday, but her appreciation of his purpose will not prevent, we suspect, the breathing of a brief and equally emphatic prayer that she may be saved from her loving friends.

The eleventh annual dinner of the New York Association of the Alumni of the University of Vermont was held last night at the University Club, with Chester G. McLaughlin, Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, presiding, and about fifty members of the association and guests from other colleges in attendance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A determined effort on the part of Senator Cullom to obtain Senator Morgan's consent to fix a time for voting on the Panama Canal treaty was made while the Senate was in executive session to-day, and was met by just as determined opposition on the part of the Alabama Senator.

Wheeler H. Peckham, Prof. Edwin R.A. Seligman, and ex-Senator John Ford, author of the Ford franchise law, talked about franchise taxes at yesterday afternoon's session of the National Convention on Municipal Ownership and Public Franchises in the assembly room of the Reform Club.

The Pennsylvania Railroad system yesterday made public its annual report for the year ended Dec. 31, 1902. The report treats of every phase of the operation of this tremendous system in great detail. A condensed extract from the report will be found in another column. Below are given a few of the things in the report which are of more general interest.

THE announcement of the Centenary edition of Emerson brought to light an unexpected and welcome embellishment for its pages in the shape of a Whipple daguerreotype taken in 1839. Whipple, be it understood, was at that time "the" Boston daguerreotyper to whom all celebrities went as a matter of course.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The month-end preparations accentuated the stringency of money in the market to-day. The indebtedness to the Bank of England increases daily, and there is little prospect of relief until after the financial year-end. In the meanwhile the Bank is gaining strength. The reserve is satisfactory, but the uncertainties of the outlook render necessary the retention of the Bank rate.

Assignments to cavalry regiments of officers recently promoted: Col. Charles L. Cooper to Fifth Cavalry, Lieut. Col. Frederick K. Ward to Fourteenth, Lieut. Col. Alexander Rodgers to Fifteenth, Major John Bigelow, Jr., to Ninth, Robert D. Read, Jr., to Tenth, Major Eben Swift to First, Major James Lockett to Fourth, Capt. George T. Summerlin to Tenth, Capt. Charles T. Boyd to Tenth, Capt. Henry C. Whitehead to Fifth, and Capt. William D. Chitty to Fourth.

DOUBLEDAY, PAGE CO. have just issued the general introduction to their Elizabethan Shakespeare in an advance brochure, and they promise "Macbeth," the first volume of the work, by the middle of March.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Robert K. Cassatt and H.D. Scott destroyed all chances of the trophy representing the racquet championship of America in doubles leaving the Quaker City, as they defeated Quincy A. Shaw and O.M. Bartlett of Boston in four of the five games played this afternoon in the Philadelphia Racquet Club court.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- Notwithstanding a severe cold, which affected his voice, the Pope, to-day received the diplomats, who congratulated him upon his jubilee. Dr. Lapponi was opposed to the Pope's participation in the ceremony, in view of the fatigue of his coronation on March 3, the twenty-fifth anniversary of that ceremony.

The Society of Municipal Engineers, now forming, promises to be in the highest degree useful and successful and merits the fullest encouragement from heads of departments. One of the most conspicuous defects in our municipal system is the lack of co-ordination among the several departments.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 27 -- The most serious attack upon non-union employes of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company which has occurred since the strike riots made it necessary to call out the Stats troops, was reported to-day, when a non-union motorman and a conductor were taken to the hospital suffering from severe injuries.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Gov. Odell to-day said that he had not come to any decision in the matter of choosing a successor' to State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh. He would not discuss the report that he had ex-United States Marshal John W. Jacobus under consideration for the place.

The Board of Estimate and Apportion- ment yesterday appropriated large sums of money for improvements. The first appropriation of $75,000 for the preliminary work on the proposed new hospital at Bellevue was passed. The cost of the building is to be about $3,000,000. President Swanstrom obtained an appropriation of $22,000 for plans for a new Municipal Building in Brooklyn and President Cantor $2,000 for plans for a new bath and comfort station.

HIS Royal Highness Louis of Savoy, Lieutenant of the Royal Navy, aged twenty-six, born in Turin, so the name of the Duke of the Abruzzi stands in the Duke's journal, at the head of the list of the party of twenty men who sailed with the Stelia Polare into the Arctic Sea, leaving Archangel and civilization on July 12, 1899.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- One of the obstacles to the progress of business in the Senate raised by the Democrats was removed to-day. Senator Blackburn a few days ago, acting for many Democratic and a few Republican Senators, gave notice that he would insist on a vote to take up the Littlefield Anti-Trust bill.

The editor and the author of "Silverwork and Jewelry" describe it as a textbook for workers in precious metals, but the little volume, apart from its technical side, shows good taste, somewhat out of the common run. Take for instance an idea of this kind. There is a worker in gold who wants to make an enameled pendant, and the subject he chooses is a nightingale.

Bell's Cathedral Series (Macmillan Company) is well known and well liked by every one who has followed the footsteps of Kate Douglas Wiggin's lovers in "A Cathedral Courtship." Well printed on excellent paper, with profuse illustrations and most convenient for slipping, into one's pocket, they are so bound that they stay open without falling to pieces.

In yesterday's market like causes produced results resembling Thursday's. There was the same adverse professional interpretation of the money market, the same balancing of hopes and fears over the prospects of relief by Senator Aldrich's bill, a similar disposition to believe unproved reports regarding Rock Island's acquisition of St. Louis and San Francisco, and fresh tales regarding Wabash making even greater drafts upon credulity.

LONDON, Feb. 27.--A gale of almost unprecedented violence swept the United Kingdom all night long. Telegraphic communication northward of Leeds was entirely interrupted, the Continental service was interfered with, and large numbers of ships were forced to seek shelter in the harbors.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Assembly to-day passed Mr. Rogers's bill to improve the quarantine station at Hoffman's Island.

WHAT must strike the reader of such a complete history of Scotland as Mr. Andrew Lang is writing is wonderment at how it came about, that the people who lived on the north side of the Tweed during the fourteenth, fifteenth, and sixteenth centuries ever rose above the conditions of brawlers and have become to-day the representatives of the highest moral qualities.
DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 27 -- Frank C. Pingree, one of the Directors of the wrecked City Savings Bank, said to-day:

WE need not stop to consider whether or not the gossips are justified who call "The Private Papers of Henry Ryecroft" autobiographical, George Gissing has lived the literary life, and doubtless suffered many of its torments.

Municipal ownership is not the Beast of the Apocalypse. There is nothing repugnant to the moral sense in the municipal operation of street railways and gas works. It is a business matter altogether, but considered as a question of policy it divides the minds of men.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It is my good fortune or misfortune -- according to the individual point of view -- to be obliged to road a good many of the modern novels, "current fiction," with reference to library work. In the natural course of events the "Confessions of a Wife" fell into my hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- There was a prolonged and sharp discussion in the Senate Inter-State Commerce Committee over what is known as the Hepburn package amendment to the Inter-State Commerce act. This bill makes all packages of goods shipped from one State to another subject in transit to the laws of the State into which they are shipped.

Harvard decisively defeated Yale last night at St. Nicholas Rink by a score of six goals to two in the first of the final series of three games, the result of which will decide the intercollegiate hockey championship. The game was the roughest and hardest-fought, game of college hockey that has been played here this year, and the enthusiasm of the big crowd of spectators was unbounded.

"The Shipping World Year Book" reaches its seventeenth edition with the issue for 1903. In a volume of 1,300 pages, about the size of Bartlett's Familiar Quotations, are gathered the most important items of information that can be of use to those connected in any way with the sea -- steamship companies, pilot and tug firms, large shippers, customs brokers, marine lawyers,

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 27 -- Admiral Schley, after having been confined to his room all day under care of two physicians, at 10 o'clock to-night resumed his journey to California. Some of his friends advised against it, but the Admiral was determined, and he was taken to the train, bundled up as much as possible.

Wall Street yesterday heard various and pretty definite rumors regarding the future of the Wabash system. There have been persistent rumors of important developments in this property for some time. They have been of two kinds, one concerning itself with the development of the Gould properties and the other with a reported traffic or even closer alliance between the Pennsylvania and the Wabash.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 27 -- The liquidation of marginal accounts broke Cotton Duck income bonds, to-day to 27, but they closed at 28, the market being relieved from the sudden forced pressure which depressed them during the morning call. They were bought by bargain hunters who considered them as selling way below actual value.

The Theatre for March is equal to the previous numbers of this periodical in both the pictorial and the literary departments. The topics of which this magazine treats with sympathy and intelligence relate to the playhouse and its personages and are out of the field of a Review devoted to books and literature.

We note with sorrow that Senator QUAY is harshly criticised by papers claiming to be the particular friends of the Administration because of the dilatory tactics by means of which he has held up some of the Administration measures.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Local capitalists interested in the launching of the new Hamilton Bank met to-day to perfect their arrangements.

In "The Pride of Tellfair" Mr. Elmore Elliott Peake has so well accomplished the difficult task of making an interesting story out of the every-day happenings among the every-day inhabitants of a thriving Illinois town that one is tempted to exaggerate a little, after the accustomed fashion of novel readers, and declare that stories as good as this are few and far beween.

Metropolitan was one of the conspicuously strong stocks of the day, and one of the few to show net gains at the close. There were evidences that recent short sellers were covering, and were finding it rather a difficult matter to get back their stock. The present short interest is variously estimated, but it is believed it is much larger than appears on the face or than the borrowing demand indicates.

SECOND ARTICLE. PRINCE ALBERT, as a German -- a "high, well-born German"--had the defects of his qualities. Thackeray has told us that when he came over to marry the Queen, whose Hanoverian predilections had already aroused the insular susceptibilities, the London streets were filled with songs and caricatures, "indicative of the absurdity of Germany."
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 -- Winning favorites were the rule to-day. Malster was run up to $1,000 and bought by Daniels Co. Weather rainy, track muddy. Sum- mary:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The recent articles referring to the Agnosticism of Roger Williams have caused me no little surprise, from the fact that my early teaching, often confirmed by others, was that he belonged to the very orthodox Baptist denomination.

LHASA is the goal, and many adventurous explorers have tried to reach the religious centre of Tibet and have failed. At last here is a Hindu who has accomplished the apparently impossible, and his name is Sarat Chandra Das.

The tedious litigation in the matter of the suit of the Taff Vale Railway Company against the Amalgamated Association of Railway Servants, for injury suffered by reason of the measures taken to enforce a strike edict, has ended in the award to the railway company of damages to the amount of $115,000, payable from the treasury of the association.

The only entertainment of note on the schedule to-day is the Badminton Club's meeting. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clews and others will give dinners this evening. There are house parties at Tuxedo and Chatsworth.

Very-little interest was taken in the outside, market yesterday for the reason that transactions were, in nearly all cases, small and price movements narrow. Partly as a result of the further declines in the Stock Exchange market the majority of outside stocks were more or less heavy, and in some cases declines of as much as a point were recorded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate this afternoon a special message urging the passage of the Philippines Tariff bill. This measure, which removes or reduces the rates of duty between the Philippines and the United States, passed the House several months ago, but has been held up in the Senate despite the urgings of Gov. Taft and the Administration.

The sale of pictures belonging to J.D. Ichenhauser, held under the direction of the American Art Association in Mendelssohn Hall last night, showed an average in prices above that of the night before.
What are the Democratic leaders in the House thinking of in their threats of filibustering against the passage of the Aldrich bill regulating the deposit of public funds in the banks?

Policeman M.J. Coyne of the Delancey Street Station jumped into the East River at Corlears Street last night to rescue John Harkins, a homeless man, who had fallen in. Both were swept over to the navy yard by the swift current, Coyne all the time holding Harkins. They were finally rescued by two policemen who had put out after them in a boat.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS Feb. 21 the Rev. John B. Tabb makes inquiry regarding the lines of Keats. I quote from Father Tabb's letter:

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The appeals in the five cases brought to test the constitutionality of the special franchise tax clause in the tax law cannot be argued before the Court of Appeals until next term, as the court will adjourn next week until late in March. The "cases and points" in five of the cases have been printed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The President has received a letter from Herbert Welsh of Philadelphia urging upon his consideration statements that Gen. Frederick Funston was guilty of a violation of the rules of war while on service in the Philippines. Mr. Welsh urges that the facts show that our troops were the first to be guilty of violations of the rules of war and not the Filipinos.

From high authority, almost semi-official, it was learned late last night that Police Commissioner Greene had ordered the transfer of Inspector Adam A. Cross from the Sixth Inspection District in the Bronx to the First Inspection District of Manhattan, known as the "Red Light" District, where the Inspector had command at the time charges of neglect of duty were preferred against Capt. John D. Herlihy, Wardman George Bissert, Acting Captain Churchill, and Capt. Diamond.

From high authority, almost semi-official, it was learned late last night that Police Commissioner Greene had ordered the transfer of Inspector Adam A. Cross from the Sixth Inspection District in the Bronx to the First Inspection District of Manhattan, known as the "Red Light" District, where the Inspector had command at the time charges of neglect of duty were preferred against Capt. John D. Herlihy, Wardman George Bissert, Acting Captain Churchill, and Capt. Diamond.

Holdridge, Dennis Preston, in conjunction with John F. Doyle Sons, have sold for Royal Phelps Carroll 70 Wall Street, 25.5 by 100, and 161 Pearl Street, 22 by 94, the two parcels containing 4,800 square feet and forming an "L" around the property of the Seamen's Bank for Savings at the northwest corner of Wall and Pearl Streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The work of this session of Congress is practically at an end except for the passage of the appropriation bills now pending, and these are in the final stages. A limited number of other measures may be passed during the last hours. A summary of the legislation enacted makes an interesting showing. The Fifty-seventh has been a busy Congress, and important results have obtained.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- Mrs. Alice Jones, a Christian Scientist, who trusted to the teachings of that sect, refusing all medical attendance, died at her home, 109 South Thirteenth Avenue, this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read your editorial, "Three Races, One Problem," in to-day's issue. I had listened to Dr. Dewey's sermon. The sermon bore very directly on a contribution solicited to aid the American Missionary Association, which founded a school for freedmen at Hampton. Va., in 1861, and maintains in whole or in part among many, the following institutions:

HALIFAX, N.S., Feb. 28. -- Fire threat- ened the entire business district of Halifax with destruction for several hours to-night. Property valued at $300,000 was burned and three firemen were seriously injured by the collapse of a ladder on which they were standing.

Within the past week there have been occurrences in connection with the Stock Exchange that have emphasized the value of general confidence in the essential honesty of any member of that important body. One of these has, by the unanimous vote of the governing body of the Exchange, been subjected to a very severe penalty for offenses of which he was, after hearing, adjudged guilty.
AN old man, Mehdijah -- whose bones God rest in peace -- had an only son. When Mehdijah felt that he was fast approaching death he grasped his son's hand and led from to a secret chamber.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Considerable speculation is indulged in in railway circles as to what effect the Elkins Anti-Rebate bill will have upon railroad rates. Attorney General Knox, who drew the bill, and the Interstate Commerce Commission, which was a party to it, believe it will be effective in putting an end to the practice of rebate giving.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly allow me to ask through the columns of your paper for a little enlightenment upon the question of "race suicide"?

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Porter's attack on municipal ownership before the National Convention to-day has a "make-up" too obvious to be reliables Any public toacher who distrusts the general body of citizens as Mr. Porter does cannot accurately diagnose city government.

THE friends of Mrs. Robert McAllister Lloyd are telling a pretty bit of romance about her, its memory being revived by the housewarming the Lloyds recently gave in their new house in East Sixty-second Street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- The police now have the weapon with which Edwin L. Burdick, the prominent business am society man here was murdered at his home on Thursday night. It is a steel-tipped golfer's puttre. Where they got it the officials refuse to say at present. It is stated that there are marks upon it believed to be blood stains.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Accompanied by Ellwood Bergey of Philadelphia, Mrs. Ellen C. Richter of Syracuse, N.Y., called at the White House this morning and presented to President Roosevelt a written statement relative to the case of her son Edward C. Richter, who, it is alleged, was put to death by torture, under orders of Lieut. W.S. Sinclair, while serving in the United States Army.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 28. -- The Rev. J. Preston Searle, President of the Faculty of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary of the Dutch Reformed Church in America, where he is Professor of Didactic and Polemic Theology, discusses in a recent issue of The Christian Intelligencer, the Church publication, the practice of the Church in supplying the demand for ministers.

It was at the dinner given by the Lotos Club to Mr. E.H. Sothern to commemorate his success as Hamlet. Between the coffee and the toasts, which is to say between the dessert and the just deserts of those present, Mr. Daniel Frohman was heard to say that in any given production actors, scenery, costume, all were subordinate in importance.

RECENT dispatches from South Africa state that valuable diamond mines have been discovered in the German possessions ou that continent. These dispatches have been followed by exaggerated reports from individuals, speculators, and promoters who claim that the richness of the new discovery rivals that of the Kimberley district.
THE notes from the powers have begun to come in," remarked the Grand Vizier.

Hardly less interesting than the cup races themselves this year will be the preliminary heats in which three big Herreshoff racers will battle for the honor of defending the America's Cup. Many yatchsmen pin their faith to the twice victorious Columbia, but those who think that the Constitution can hold the Columbia in a blow, and can sail around the older boat in all other weathers, are more than a few.
PARIS, Feb. 28. -- Dr. A.D. de Roaldes of New Orleans has been nominated an officer of the Legion of Honor.

There seems to be some dispute about the scope of the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of the Boston skyscraper fronting Copley Square and rearing itself six feet higher than the limit of the law. It has been assumed that the court decided that it was within the province of the Legislature to limit the height of buildings on any ground that to the Legislature seemed good.

ONTARIO, Cal., Feb. 20. -- With the segregation and sales of the great land holdings in California the last chapters of the most romantic and idyllic life in America are having their end. Indeed, the life ended years ago, but here and there have been stray remnants of the oldtime ranchos, while there have been a few instances where the oldtime customs and wonderful hospitality have been maintained in retired Spanish homes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--Several Senators called upon the President to-day and talked with him regarding the Panama and Cuban treaties. They believe, as a result, that an extraordinary session will be called probably to meet on March 5, for the consideration of these conventions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Have you not been rather severe in your strictures upon the authorities of Cornell University relative to the typhoid epidemic at Ithaca? A university is necessarily conducted with a certain routine in professors' laboratories. It is no part of that routine, nor is it any part of the duty of any professor, to make regular or frequent chemical or bacteriological examinations of the city water supply.
THINK how quick-witted you are and how much you can do," said the comfortable woman to the girl who was complaining bitterly because she had no claims to good looks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial to-day on grade crossings is right in every respect. Pray keep the matter in sight and bring it up again and again, as yon so effectually and almost prophetically did in the matter of the tunnel danger.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The British Admiralty to-day denied the reports that the Government had purchased the two cruisers under construction at Genoa, Italy, for Argentina, and the two warships being constructed in England for Chile.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The roseate tinted statements made by the public press during several weeks past as to what the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company was about to do in its terminals in this city satisfactory to the public we may fear will not be realized.

President Rebhan of the Milwaukee Board of Fire Underwriters is quoted in local insurance circles as saving that the fire insurance companies have so far recouped their bad years that Milwaukee agents contemplate considering the appeal of business men in that city for a rescinding of the sharp advance in the rates made after the Waterbury and Paterson conflagrations of early 1902.

Charges of neglect of duty and conduct unbecoming an officer were filed at Police Headquarters yesterday against Inspector Adam A. Cross, late of the Sixth Inspection District in the Bronx. Commissioner Greene, immediately the charges had been submitted to him, ordered the Inspector to appear before him and suspended him without pay pending his trial, which will be begun before Deputy Commissioner Ebstein at Police Headquarters next Friday.

ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON says some-where that there is no more reason why a man should be ashamed of having had an attack of Socialism than of having had an attack of measles. But we see evidence every day that there are persons who have not merely "had" Socialism, but who do not recover.

On the application of her daughters, supported by declarations of other relatives, Mrs. Lydia J.
