Allen, formerly the wife of a wealthy St. Louis merchant, has been adjudged incompetent to manage her affairs, and a commission is to be named to look after her interests. Mrs. Allen is an inmate of St. Saviour's Sanitarium at Inwood, she having been addicted to the use of drugs and intoxicants.

GEN. JAMES FRANKLIN BELL, the man who put "reconcentration" into effect a year ago in the Batangas and Laguna Provinces, Luzon, is, close after Leonard Wood, the young- est Brigadier General in the army. His rise since 1898 has been no less spectacular than that of the former Governor of Cuba.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 28. -- It is now known that Mrs. Emil Schaefer and her two small daughters, who disappeared from the home of the millionaire brewer in New York on Feb. 11, were in Greenwich between Wednesday of last week and Wednesday of this week. Three detectives followed them, and when Mrs. Schaefer and her companion discovered that the men were in town they engaged a coach and were driven to Stamford.

More interest is being shown this season in the work of the Handicap Committee of the Metropolitan Golf Association than has been the case since the first committee was appointed about three years ago to devise something like an equable basis for handicapping members of the various clubs in the association.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The week President Francis of the St. Louis Exposition has spent in England has had unusually quick results in awakening interest here in the St. Louis Exposition and American, matters generally.

Spring athletics at Princeton opened in earnest last Tuesday with the calling out of the freshman candidates for the baseball team. Sixty-one men are now trying for the team under the direction of the coaches and Capt. Pearson of the Varsity. This is the largest number that has ever turned out from the entering class, and some excellent material is present.

The attendance at the Sportsmen's Show in the Madison Square Garden yesterday, despite the unpleasant weather of the afternoon, was almost equal to that on Washington's Birthday, when it was said about 10,000 persons were present and an unusually interesting programme of canoe races and other aquatic events was provided.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Through the confession of a woman recently implicated in a wholesale theft of furs, State's Attorney Deneen has come into possession of evidence that he believes will clear the mystery of the robbery of the Chicago Post Office on Oct. 20, 1901, when postage stamps valued at $74,601 were carried off through a tunnel beneath the vaults.

Whether the toastmaster who introduced one of the speakers at the dinner of the Arkwright Club a few nights ago spoke both facetiously and wisely, or only facetiously, when he described him as one "who has been, and is, a striking example of the attainment of success, usefulness, and honor in spite of early advantages of wealth and ancestry," might be discussed with profit by those who have a taste for genealogies.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer begs leave to submit the following statements:

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to a statement in to-day's TIMES, being part of an address made by the Rev. H.T. Hutchins before a meeting "of pastors" in the City of New Haven, both Eastern and Northwestern Connecticut must be in a most deplorable condition of degeneracy.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- The end of the week finds the local money market firm, in spite of the fact that the supply of funds has been increased somewhat by currency from New York. Much interest centres in the Aldrich bill, and the opinion is general that its passage would cause improvement in conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- John Wesley Gaines (Dem., Tenn.,) caused a spirited incident in the House this afternoon by calling for information as to the alleged sale of White House relics by Col. Bingham, the retiring Superintendent of Public Buildings and Grounds.

Cotton reached the highest prices of the present season yesterday morning, but the figure was maintained for only a short time, the market selling off some 3 to 7 points immediately after the top had been reached. Incidentally, it may be said that cotton is higher now than it has been since January, 1901, when the option for that month sold as high as 12.75, or over 2 1/2 cents higher than it is now.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of he $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I think there can be no question that the present Emperor of Germany has fairly earned the title of the "Admiral Crichton" of his age. Not content with his exalted position as monarch of one of the greatest countries in the world, he is constantly reaching out for leadership in many other branches of human achievement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Representative Fowler, (N.Y.,) Chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, to which committee was referred the Payne-Aldrich Currency bill, to-day introduced a billrin which is first incorporated the elastic currency bill introduced by Mr. Fowler at this session, and which is now pending before the House.

Dr. Luther Halsey Gulick was the guest of honor at a dinner given at the Hotel Majestic last right to welcome him into the school system of the city. He was appointed a couple of weeks ago to take control of the physical training in the public schools, and the hosts were the directors and special, instructors of physical training in the elementary, high, and training schools in the local system.

Another week has passed without intrinsic developments. A fortnight ago we had a storm and a scandal. Last week we had instead a yarn and a flurry. It is rather disrespectful to speak of the statements regarding the acquirement of the St. Louis and Sail Francisco by Rock Island as a yarn.

CAPT. COSGROVE, who was recently retired from the Fire Department, tells this story of "Grand Central Pete," one of the noted criminals of New York. Having been released from prison, friends of "Pete," who had spent a great portion of his life in such institutions, welcomed him at the railway station and proceeded to celebrate the occasion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to the letter from Reginald H. Williams, dated Feb. 17, published in THE TIMES under date of the 22d inst., I wish, with your kind permission, also to make a statement in regard to France's decrease of population.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 27. -- During the past few weeks the Indians living within the borders of New York State have been engaged in a warm political campaign for the election or chieftains of the Six Nations. The contest has been waged nominally, at least, according to the customs of the Iroquois, which have remained unchanged for many centuries.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28. -- The Philadelphia National League Baseball Club was to-day sold by John I. Rogers and A.J. Reach to a syndicate composed of twenty Philadelphians, two residents of Cincinnati, and an Indianapolis man. The transfer was made during the afternoon to James Potter, who is at the head of the syndicate.

It is an unquestioned fact that for the greater part of the day the market was largely under the influence and domination of the professional traders and operators, though on the decline some good independent buying was reported.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28. -- Washington's Birthday ushered in a season of continuous and elaborate entertaining at this resort. The Washington's Birthday ball, which was held at the Hotel Royal Poinciana last Monday night, was a brilliant function. The immense dining room, which will seat about 1,700 persons, was transformed with palms, ferns, and tropical plants into a beautiful ballroom.

A market as narrow as was yesterday's for outside securities presents little that is worthy of comment. Very few stocks succeeded in attracting any attention, and in must issues the totals were extremely small. The irregularity which has characterised the market for a number of days was again shown, and while a few stocks advanced, a larger number showed net losses.

How the chess masters engaged in the third annual international tournament contested their games in the first and second rounds of the contest will be seen from the appended scores. There is only one game missing, that between Wolf and Marco, which was left unfinished in the second round, and which was concluded too late for the first mail to leave Monte Carlo.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28. -- A good ride, good fortune, and freedom from interference landed Amigari a length in front in the finish of the Speed Handicap, worth $1,520 to the winner, to-day. Scorpio, favorite at threes, was used up in makingthe pace, and Amigari, wearing the successive leaders down, outlasted St. Tammany in the final drive and won cleverly.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- After an animated debate the Chamber of Deputies to-day voted a tax of 1 frane 25 centimes per 100 kilos on petroleum, and incorporated in this law a provision asking for the establishment of a Government monopoly on petroleum with the least possible delay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial of Feb. 25 on "Our Consular Service." you express wonder and feel no satisfaction at a complimentary notice paying a tribute to the keenness and activity of the American Consul in Germany, taken from the World's Trade, a journal published in Berlin, in which special mention is made of a report on hosiery and textiles, comming from J.C. Monaghan, Consul at Chemnitz.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--The Democrats continued their filibustering programme in a session of the House which lasted nine hours to-day. The first words to go into the record this morning were from Mr. Richardson, the minority leader, protesting that there was not a quorum present. "We can't do any business without a quorum in this Republican House," said Mr. Richardson, "except to unseat a Democratic member."

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- There are wheels within wheels in the political machinery at Albany this year, and the evolutions are sometimes so rapid as to be bewildering. Those who are best informed are confident that there will be no serious break, but at the same time it is admitted that the tension is great and the unlooked-for may happen at any moment.

There is a good and true story back of the appointment of one of three Postmasters for Pennsylvania whose names President Roosevelt sent to the Senate on Thursday. These three appointees are William T. Dant, at Westgrove, Chester County; Joseph E. Downing, East Downmgtown, Chester County; Moses A. Foltz, Chambers-burs, Franklin County.

THE importance of developing a sense of humor in the minds of children will be one of the subjects treated in the course of lectures arranged by the Board of Education for the month of March. Earl Barnes, the Philadelphia educator, who will deliver the lectures, has made a study of the stages of humor through which a child passes, and will devote one of his lectures to this subject alone.

Hardly a shadow of doubt exists but that the rate situation will command more attention in the immediate future than it has for some time past. Discussion is teing entered into by well-known heads of prominent railroad systems, and by those whose connection with the railroad situation is a close one, the result being to disclose views and forecasts of somewhat striking diversity.

That Portsmouth is an excellent city has always been the pride of its people, but they never expected such a testimonial to that fact as was shown when a Greek, who had been there with smallpox, returned with two of his fellow-countrymen who were suffering from the same disease, preferring the treatment there to that of Ipswich, Mass.

Interesting facts concerning the estate of the late Alfred Corning Clark are given in the report completed yesterday by Edward L. Parris, the referee named to pass upon the accounts of Mr. Clark's widow, Mrs. Potter, wife of Bishop H.C. Potter, as the guardian of the estate of Stephen Carlton Clark, her son, who will become of age in August of the present year.

There was a great gathering of athletes last night at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, and so many persons came to see them perform that extra police were necessary to take care of the crowd. The occasion was the intercollegiate open athletic meet held under the auspices of the Columbia University Truck Association, and the entries, which numbered more than 500, included the pick of the athletic talent of Yale, Harvard, Pennsylvania, Brown.

President Rebhan of the Milwaukee Board of Fire Underwriters is quoted in local insurance circles as saying that the fire insurance companies have so far recouped their bud years that Milwaukee agents contemplate considering the appeal of business men in that city for a rescind- ing of the sharp advance in the rates made after the Waterbury and Paterson conflagrations of early 1902.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- It was said at the State Department of Health to-day that the advice of Dr. Daniel Lewis, State Health Commissioner, that it was safe for Cornell students to return to Ithaca, notwithstanding the typhoid epidemic in that city, was based on a belief that the local health authorities had carried out his recommendations to protect the public, which he has since found they have not done.

During most of the week just past the outside market was very dull, and even on the days when the total transactions were fairly large the trading was principally in a few stocks. A good deal of attention was given to the half dozen issues which for one reason or another were active while the rest or the list was almost entirely neglected.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- The Rev. Dr. J.M. Caldwell, for many years Presiding Elder of the Methodist Church at Chicago, and now pastor of the Union Avenue Methodist Church, attempted to end his life to-day by throwing himself in front of a Grand Trunk train at Forty-sixth Street. He was unconscious when picked up, his leg was broken, and he was internally injured.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Since the abolition of the canteen at army posts, officers of the army have had a great deal of trouble in enforcing discipline among the men, and especially following the periodical visits of the Paymaster.

What is regarded as the greatest triumph achieved by Mr. Chamberlain in the course of his visit to South Africa was the manner in which, at Bloemfontein on Feb. 6, he dealt with a deputation or Liner irreconcilables, headed by Gen. Christian De Wet and Judge Hertzog.

Seven hundred voters gathered yesterday afternoon at New Irvins Hall, 218 Broome Street, in response to a call issued by the Grocers' Association to protest against the action of the Board of Health in closing doors of apartments opening into stores where milk is sold and in revoking permits where such doors are not nailed and sealed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The greater portion of to-day's session, which was extended to nearly 8 o'clock, was devoted to the consideration of the Aldrich bill, providing for the safe keeping of public money. The bill was taken up by a vote of 42 to 18 which furnished its friends good ground for the hope that it will be passed by the Senate.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 28. -- It is given out semi-officially that more arrests of officials connected with the wrecked banking institutions will be made next week.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The Bank of England rate continues to be 4 per cent, and the credit market continues grumbling, though it should be thankful, for if the rate had been reduced on Thursday, coincidently with the net export of 159,000 sovereigns, credit jobbers would have shivered and a worse condition of affairs would have supervened than exists now.

With the departure of Connie Mack's American Baseball League champions from Philadelphia for their Spring training quarters at Jacksonville last Tuesday the baseball season of 1903 may be said to have begun. Other teams will soon follow, and within two weeks all of the players in the major league clubs will be hard at work.

THE Season, with a big S, is as a tale that is told, and with it have come and gone some of the most beautiful gowns ever worn in New York. Now in the penitential season mesdames and misses will spend much of their time with their modistes preparing for the coming Summer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Baron Gever the Minister of the Netherlands, and M. Bowen have signed the Netherlands protocol providing for the settlement of a claims of that country against Venezuela. It is provided that President Roosevelt shall name the umpire in the event of a disagreement.

Dark, overhanging clouds, a heavy rainstorm, and high winds did their best to mar the shooting at the Bay Ridge traps of the Crescent Athletic Club yesterday, but despite these drawbacks all the shotgun experts made good scores and nearly 2,000 targets were broken at the conclusion of the afternoon's sport.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 28. -- Amherst defeated Trinity at basket ball to-night in a fast and scientific game by a score of 25 to 17. The visitors played a strong cover game, and their passing was a feature. Trinity spurted in the last half, but Amherst held them by a safe lead. Line-up:
YES, he is a reviser of plays for the syndicate.

LAST Monday the dedication exercises of the finest high school building in the world were held. In its equipment and in the opportunities it gives for all the branches of learning it is without an equal anywhere. The name of the institution is the Wadleigh High School for Girls, the name being given in honor of Lydia F. Wadleigh, the pioneer in the movement for higher education of women in New York City.
LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Money was much wanted in the market to-day and rates were somewhat easier owing to Government disbursements. Discounts were almost at a standstill.

Transactions in storks on the New York Stock Exchange for the month of February aggregated 10,927,401 shares, as against 16,006,389 shares in January, 15,719,742 in December, 17,117,313 in November, 16,348,300 in October, 20,953,087 in September, 14,317,393 in August, 16,317,957 in July, 7,813,049 in June, 13,485,777 in May, 26,579732 in April, and 11,954,672 in March of last year.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 28. -- The fast passenger train leaving Chattanooga at 11:45 last night for Salisbury was wrecked about three and one-half miles west of Lenoir City, Tenn., this morning about 2 o'clock on the tracks of the Southern Railway. The wreck was caused by spreading of rails. Three persons were killed and twenty-five injured.

The two actions in the Philharmonic Society which have been at variance on the scheme to make over and refinance their organization came to an agreement yesterday. But by reason of this agreement the society has permanently disagreed with the committee headed by Samuel Untermyer and Harry Harkness Flagler seeking to contribute $40,000 or so a year for four years with a view to putting the Philharmonic Orchestra on a permanent footing.
TO-NIGHT, as flight my pipe. I am thinking of a match I did not strike.

ROBERTA HOEY'S first husband died in the insane asylum. He never got really violent, but he was queer, and they put him in the asylum to prevent accidents. So long as Roberta wore mourning her relatives were sparing of advice and recriminations, but the first day she appeared in a colored shirt waist they spoke freely.

Archbishop Farley has issued his first pastoral letter, addressed to the clergy and laity of New York on the occasion or the twenty-fifth anniversary of the coronation of Leo XIII., the full text of which is as follows:

There have been few changes in the amusements of society during Lent, as far as the penitential season has pursued the even tenor of its way. After a rather dull fortnight the season ended in quite a busy Shrove Tuesday, the gayest known for years. In a way it was quite a little carnival. None of the entertainments was of much magnitude, but, as dances and such affairs go these days, some were quite important.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I agree with much in your editorial un- der the heading of the "Citizens' Union" in to-day's issue, and could quite fully agree with it if your assertions about the attitude of the Citizens' Union were correct.

IT WAS a beautiful morning as I paced to and fro in Battery Park looking out upon the varied panorama of the bay. Staten Island, far away, was enveloped in a sunlit haze, giving it a soft lotus-land effect.

The Baltimore School Board has appropriated $100 to secure the services of some well-informed citizen in the selection of names of prominent Marylanders of the past to designate the 109 public schools in the city.

A PROMINENT clergyman in Boston, who is actively identified with missionary work, has recently been preparing some colored clergymen from the South for mission work. Lately he invited them to dine with him.

With several patrol wagons and a large force of policemen. Inspector Elbert O. Smith and Capt. German of the Mercer Street Station raided two Raines law hotels and two houses, alleged to be disorderly, shortly before midnight last night. Intense excitement was caused by the raids and large crowds gathered outside the different places to witness the arrest of the men and women.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- After overcoming most persistent opposition, the friends of the Immigration bill succeeding in passing that measure in the Senate late this evening. The amendments demanded by the New England Senators to favor the temporary immigation of laborers from Canada to the New England States were accepted, and railroads bringing them in were relieved of the responsibility for their character.

The Cunarder Etruria, which sailed for Liverpool via Queenstown at 6 o'clock yesterday morning, and which, after groping her way through the fog at last lost her way, and went aground at the entrance of Gedney Channel about 10:30 o'clock, was pulled back into deep water by a fleet of tugs at 8:40 o'clock last night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- The Southwestern Limited on the New York Central was wrecked shortly before 8 o'clock this evening in the East Syracuse yards, about five miles east of this city, by crashing into a caboose which had jumped from a freight track just as the passenger train approached.

THE bill to repeal the law providing for extra judicial oaths in all civil courts calls attention to the variety of oaths that might be brought into practice in a court of world-wide cosmopolitanism, says The Milwaukee Sentinel. The section of the law which it is sought to repeal has been on the statute book for many years, but has rarely been invoked by either of the parties to an action.
THE Beautiful Woman laughed derisively.

Despite the good offices of Secretary Alfred Reeves of the Empire City track, John A. McKerron, 2:05 1/4, winner of the Boston Challenge Cup for trotters, will not meet Lord Derby, 2:05 2/4, in a match race this year. The plans for McKerron's season were arranged last Fall, and will not be materially altered.

Four collisions between ferryboats, in which two boats were damaged, two men hurt, and many women frightened into hysterics, occurred on the North River yesterday morning. The collisions were due to the fog along the water front, and the expressed belief is that all were unavoidable.

THE world has seen a variety of achievements wrought by man, but no other has made such strides toward the perfection of industry and progress, toward the advancement of the whole world, as the application of electricity.

A somewhat spectacular fire, which did comparatively little damage, was discovered about 8 o'clock last night on the ninth floor of the Jefferson Building, a modern fireproof structure, which runs through from the north side of West Twenty-third Street to the south side of West Twenty-fourth Street, being numbered 117 and 119 on the former and 112 and 114 on the latter street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Dinner giving was resumed this afternoon after several days' rest in all social entertainments.

The Janitors' Society of New York gave its annual concert last night in the auditorium of the Educational Alliance, at the corner of East Broadway and Jefferson Street. The most picturesque and popular feature was the Children's Orchestra of the alliance -- made up mostly of very pretty little girls in red jackets and red caps, with a smaller number of little boys, also in red jackets and caps.

PASADENA, Cal., Feb. 20. -- All day long heavy rain-laden clouds have screened the beautiful mountain range toward the East, and the nun has remained obscured. The much wished for and thrice blessed rain has descended in copious showers to bless this beautiful valley with moisture.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 28. -- The weather man has smiled most benignly on Lakewood this week, and the Lenten visitors have enjoyed a succession of balmy, sunny days. With the disappearance of the snow new impetus has been given to all out-of-door sports. The golfer is in his glory again after three weeks of inaction.

THE Marquis de Castellane, author of "Les Temps Nouveaux," who passes for an "amateur distingue" of diplomacy and political economy in the Salons of the Faubourg Saint Germain, Paris, advocates a Franco-American alliance in an elaborate article printed in L'Eclair. Ail alliance with France, he says, would protect the United States from any infringement of the Monroe Doctrine without their having to enlist a single soldier or shed a drop of blood.

LUCY always felt tired when she watched her mother and the "hired girl" do the housework. Therefore she watched them no more than she could help. Her favorite method of not seeing that which fatigued her was to retire to the parlor, recline gracefully on the sofa, and read a novel.

Points from which observation of recent foreign trade tendencies may be taken are quite numerous. Just row it is the fashion to extend comparison back four or five years, and, operating on this field, to show to what a marked extent our merchandise imports have increased and how, running current therewith, the favorable trade balance, so called, has been subject to contraction.

CARACAS, Feb. 28. -- M. Wiener, the newFrench Minister to Venezuela, who is charged with the renewal of diplomatic relations between the two countries and who disembarked at La Guayra two days ago, presented to-day his credentials to President Castro. In speaking to M. Wiener the President alluded to the friendship existing between France and Venezuela.

The Supreme Court of the United States, Justice PECKHAM writing the opinion, handed down a decision on Monday which determines an interesting and important question of law that has given rise to much academic discussion. The case in question is entitled People of the State of New York ex rel.

The proceedings brought by Anna Hopfensack, the wife, and Charles and Eleanor Hopfensack, the children, of Ernest Hopfensack, against the Board of Education for an order directing the City Chamberlain to pay them the amount of an award for property owned by Hopfensack, taken for school purposes, has given rise to an important opinion by the Court of Appeals on the presumption of death arising from long-continued, unexplained absence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the article in THE TIMES of Feb. 22 entitled "Hospitals in Dire Need." allow me to suggest one way of increasing the revenues of the hospitals -- namely, compel those who seek treatment there and who are able to pay for it to do so.

For the first time since the forming of the Intercollegiate Hockey League a Yale seven was defeated for the championship last night at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink by the rather one-sided score of 5 goals to 1. It was the second of what was to have been a series of three games with Harvard University, but the Crimson players by winning the first contest also made the playing of the other game unnecessary.

IT is very difficult to induce enthusiasts on manual training to admit that utility forms more than a minor consideration in their plea for special training. They continue to cling to the belief that its educational value over-shadows all of the other good things claimed for their pet hobby.

EXCEPT for the fact that Reddy became too well acquainted with Grogan's especially effective brand of red liquor, his romance might even now be concealed within his own bosom. But when the red liquor had had its scientific effect to a certain degree, Larry, who presided over the bar, became the confidant of all who essayed the mysterious concoction.

HOT SPRINGS, S.D., Feb. 24. -- In view of the fact that Wind Cave and its picturesque surrounding's have been converted into a National park, public interest in this subterranean wonder will doubtless be stimulated. The bill establishing what is to be known as the Wind Cave National Park has already become a law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Admirals O'Neil, Bowles, and Bradford, members of the Naval Board of Construction, were heard by the House Committee on Naval Affairs to-day on the naval increase programme incorporated in the naval appropriation bill as amended by the Senate. Admiral O'Neil spoke for the larger ships provided for in the House bill, giving his Reasons for favoring that class in preference to those proposed by the Senate amendments.

TRENTON, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- Three companies, all having a bearing on the development of the cement district, were incorporated here to-day. They are the New Jersey and Delaware River Railroad Company, with a capital of $100,000; the Dela- ware and Northampton Railroad Company, with a capital of $5,000,000, and the Quaker-Portland Cement Company, with a capital of $5,000,000 also.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This Winter, with its unusual musical situation, is remarkable for an event, the like of which has not, to my knowledge, occurred since the first days of music in New York: A young musician, not bearing the customary letters of credit from foreign audiences, assumes the leadership of an orchestra, submits himself to the severest tests and succeeds admirably.

This is the time of year when the average member from the rural district in the average State Legislature endeavors to ingratiate himself with his constituents by introducing an anti-automobile bill which, if passed, would make life miserable for every automobile owner in the State, and in consequence the officials of the various automobile organizations are kept busy opposing the proposed measures.

IT WAS about 6 o'clock in the evening of a Summer day on a Western-bound train passing through a thickly wooded country. The last rays of the burning sun fell through the dull green pines like pure gold. A compartment at the end of the train had stood empty all day.

IT IS more than twenty years since I came to New York. I was born in New England and left home because everything went wrong, and I had to make a start for myself. When I arrived my sole possessions were one hundred small blank books, which I had bought in Boston and from the sale of which I had to make my daily bread.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Rome says that the thirty-five passengers of the British steamer Commonwealth who were recently refused permission to land at Boston by the authorities of that city disembarked from the Commonwealth at Naples to-day and were all arrested.

YES, danger is an ever-constant companion of men who follow my business," said the old Secret Service man. "We know not at what hour we may be called upon to face death in a violent form. But we get used to experiences of this nature, and learn to keep a cool head on our shoulders and to think quickly.

Side lights on the Near Eastern Question. Persons who have been on the "subscription list" of the Macedonian Revolutionary Committee's news agency have noticed a dearth of that committee's "publications" for the last three weeks.

Army. Contract Surgeon Roger P. Ames will proceed to Fort St. Philip, La., to relieve Contract Surgeon Oliver H. Buford, who upon being thus relieved will report by letter to the Surgeon General of the Army for annulment of contract.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter in Sunday's paper on the subject of "Pensions for Judges" should have been signed "Inexperienced," so gross an ignorance of conditions does it display. One can scarcely comprehend any right-minded person opposing so just a measure as that which would provide some means of caring for our aged Judges who have served the State faithfully during a long period of time.

THIS is certainly a wonderful age we are living in," oratorically remarked the boss barber, as, with the end of a towel, he deftly removed a daub of lather from the corner of the bald-headed man's mouth. "In a year or two all a child will be taught at the public schools will be to read handwriting, or typewriting, and to write a graceful, legible hand, or to run a typewriter.

The Vossische Zeitung of Berlin sees in the new measure now before the Reichstag for the redistribution of Parliamentary constituencies a subject upon which all the factions of the Opposition may unite. The Agrarians, it is said, who believe themselves tricked by the Government Canal bills, have now suffered additional humiliation through the failure of their tariff projects, dropped by the Government at the last moment from the new tariff law.

After he had received a lecture from Magistrate Crane, sitting in Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday Frank Hertzel, the sixteen-year-old boy arrested several days ago by Central Office Detective Ferretti on suspicion of being engaged in an Anarchistic riot to kill European rulers, was discharged from custody, Assistant District Attorney Studen representing the District Attorney's office.

THIRD NOTICE. Sculpture has better representation than usual at the eighteenth annual exhibition of the Architectural League. Not only are there groups of statues, pairs and single figures, statuettes and reliefs, but a good deal of statuary for the decoration of buildings such as capitals, friezes, caryatids.

As the days in the Summer are long and bright in the land of the Vikings, so they are dark and short in the Winter, and the Winter is long and dreary, especially to people reared in a more Southern latitude. As a beaming light in all these long, gloomy seasons stands the Norwegian Winter sport, which may be divided into four groups -- skiing, skating, coasting, and sleighing.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28. -- The greatest apprehension is beginning to be expressed over the high-water situation. Not in years has the river at such an early date reached the stage as the gauge now shows. This morning 16.5 feet, of water was recorded, and experienced river men predicted that the highest water ever known is more than a probability.

I DON'T know whether I ought to buy this man a wooden leg or not." The Secretary of the Association for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor was pondering. "The last man I bought one for was so happy that he had to celebrate; and he celebrated so hard that he got into a row and the leg was smashed before morning.
TWO politicians of opposite complexions were discussing President Roosevelt's recent remarks on "race suicide."

A threatening anonymous letter, received early in the week by James Edward Graybill. President of the Georgia Society, as a rebuke for utterances credited to him concerning what is known popularly as the "Booker Washington incident," is agitating the Southern residents of New York, and is regarded as a belated sequel to the "incident" in question.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 1. -- Following a trolley accident, which caused one instant death and may result in two more dying, there was something like a riot in the Italian settlement on the Boston Post Road, on the outskirts of the city, this morning. But for the quick wit of the conductor, the motorman of the car would have been struck with a hatchet.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the pending legislation to tax mortgages I desire to point out some very objectionable features in the proposed bill.

It is an ugly incident that a bill has made its appearance in the Legislature, of which the Hon. ABE GRUBER is the putative father, to re-enact what is known as the "Black law " relating to the civil service. Mr. GRUBER is the partner in the practice of the law of the gentleman who was Governor when that law was enacted.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 1. -- New York detectives, assisted by local police officers, to-day captured two criminals who had started in to make dime-novel records in Missouri. The capture was effected only after desperate resistance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The very interesting letter in your issue of Saturday from Miss Isabella B. Jones might perhaps give the idea that nothing was being done in opposition to the act recently passed in the House of Representatives, extending the time within which live stock might legally be confined in transit from twenty-eight to forty hours.

Some of the residents in the neighborhood of Tompkins Square were joyously celebrating a wedding yesterday, while other residents of the same district were mourning at a wake. And the wake resulted directly from the incidents leading up to the wedding, which occurred on Saturday night.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 17. -- The topic of the day here is the dismissal of Count Albert du Bois, Secretary of the Belgian Legation in Paris, from the diplomatic service. In a recent work, entitled, "Belges ou Francais." Count du Bois advocated the annexation of the Belgian Walloon provinces to France.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--The House of Representatives held a four-hour session to-day and put the District of Columbia Appropriation bill through its last parliamentary stage in the face of the Democratic filibuster. The previous question on the conference report on the Alaskan Homestead bill was ordered, and the vote on its adoption will be taken when the House reconvenes at 11 o'clock to-morrow morning.

So much has been said of late regarding golf rules and their changes that many players have formed the idea that several radical innovations were to be made by the committee appointed by the National Association to suggest changes, and give their interpretations to the new code of rules promulgated on Jan. 1 by the St. Andrews Club of Scotland.

With Mme. Sembrich, Miss Carrie Bridewell, Mr. Dani, and Mr. Scotti as soloists, and Alfred Hertz conducting, and with a programme that was an attraction and not merely an excuse, last night's concert at the Metropolitan Opera House met with a success that demonstrated the popularity of these affairs when the management does not let them descend to the level of mediocrity.

A satisfying breakfast and a sudden death after it await the Ansonia Hotel's "spook" when he wakes up this morning. Having been an unsolved mystery for ten days, causing sleepless nights to the hotel's patrons and frightening the bellboys so that they threatened to resign, he will meet an ignominious end at the hands of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 1. -- It is beported here this evening that the Republican factions will get together at Dover to-morrow and elect two Republican United States Senators. It is said Mr. Addicks has consented to get out of the race altogether, and has named State Senator James Frank Allee as his choice for the Union Republican Senator for the long term.

Seeing that escape from a team of horses that a coachman was driving at high speed toward them was impossible. Mrs. Thomas Walsh of 446 West Forty-ninth Street yesterday aftarnoon quickly placed herself alongside the baby carriage she had been pushing in which was her two-year-old daughter Lucy, leaving on the other side of it her daughter Helen, four years old.

KANSAS CITY, March 1. -- A jury in the case of Annie B. Wood and other heirs of Silas Armstrong, an Indian, to recover Missouri River bottom lands in Kansas City, Kan., valued at $1,000,000 and occupied by the Armour and Fowler Packing Companies and others, has returned a verdict in favor of the plaintiffs.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- It is impossible to conjecture how much additional legislation the Fifty-seventh Congress will be able to enact before the close of its final session at noon Wednesday, although it is obvious that much will be left undone. The calendars of both branches, even at this late day, are quite full and there are many more bills in committee than have been reported out.

NEWARK, N.J., March 1. -- Annie Werner, who asserted that she came from Porto Rico last Tuesday and had been in the employ of Howard Gould's family, is a prisoner at Police Headquarters. She was brought there at 2 o'clock this morning by Detective Sergeant Wriggins from Buehler's Park Hotel at Hilton.

The Cunarder Campania and the French liner La Sayoie got in yesterday twenty-four hours late, both vessels having been delayed on the way across by the tempestuous weather new prevailing at sea. Both liners experienced the worst possible kind of weather nearly all the way across, huge seas sweeping over them time and again, while winds of terrific strength buffeted them during practically the entire voyage.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency today by a vote of 7 to 2 -- a strictly party vote -- authorized a favorable report on the Currency bill introduced yesterday by Representative Fowler, Chairman of the committee. In reporting the bill the committee says:

To the Editor of the New York Times: Nothing was so surprising as the remark made by our Mayor at the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on Wednesday last to the citizens of Richmond Borough, who had assembled to express their views on the ferry question. He said: "Remember, Richmond is getting more than she is paying in."

Passengers on a north-bound Third Avenue car at 3 o'clock yesterday morning were thrown into great excitement by a man armed with a blackjack running through the car from the rear to the front platform in a desperate effort to escape a stockily built man who was following him and calling "Stop thief!"

ATLANTA, Ga., March 1. -- Following are extracts from a letter from President Roosevelt to Clarke Howell, editor of The Constitution, in reply to a request for an exposition concerning a recent letter from Harry Stillwell Edwards of Macon with reference to the matter of Federal appointments in the South:

St. Patrick's Day souvenirs are in the shops. There are many this year, and among them is a realistic small green snake. It is of a beautiful shade of iridescent green, made of twisted wire, and it quivers with uncanny naturalness. It is thirteen inches in length, and it costs only 10 cents.

LONDON, March 2. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says that Prof. Oppert, the leading French Assyriologist, has addressed an exceptionally interesting letter to the Temps, dealing in a tone of genial irony with Emperor William's incursion into that particular field of scientific investigation.

ROME, March 1.--Dr. Lapponi, the Pope's physician, made this morning a last effort to induce his Holiness to renounce his reception of the Cardinals. He remonstrated with the Pope, saying: "Your Holiness, my duty is to point out that your health would greatly benefit by your resting to-day." The Pope replied: "My dear doctor, before your valuable advice comes my duty, which I shall perform until the end."

Oliver Drew's Brooklyn handball court was crowded yesterday by a host of New York and Jersey City experts and visitors, who gathered there to see the final games of the inter-city handball match decided. Only two games were necessary, "Mike" Egan and James Flaherty, the Jersey City players, winning both.
LONDON, March 1. -- The gale was renewed in the British Isles last night and continued to-day, but with less violence.

ALBANY, March 1. -- The coming week promises to be a very important one in the Legislature. The Mortgage Tax bill, after repeated delays due to the extreme care of its preparation and perfecting, is now ready for introduction, and probably will take its place early in the week. Its provisions already have been outlined in these dispatches.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- The entries and weights for the ten-thousand-dollar Hawthorne Handicap to be run at Hawthorne Saturday, May 23, were made public to-day. The race is a sweepstakes for three-year-olds and upward and closed with ninetynine nominations.

SEATTLE, Washington, March 1. -- The Seattle Iron and Steel Company has been formed with a capital of $6,000,000 to build in this city an iron furnace with 200 tons daily capacity, a 100-ton steel plant, and a rolling mill.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with extreme interest the editorial concerning Mr. Hewitt's electrical invention, especially the statement that "It is believed it will be found useful in * * * the treatment of certain skin diseases." I must confess that I would very much like to know in the treatment of what skin diseases this light can be used to advantage.

It is regrettable that the discussion to which the discoveries of adulterations and substitutions in the drug business have given rise has not as yet called out one manly declaration from those in the trade that these evil practices exist and that those who sell honest drugs purpose to differentiate themselves from those who seek to swell the profits of the business by fraud and crime.

The state of business in Congress at the close of the present session is worse than it has been in a long time, and it has usually been bad enough. It is now practically settled that an extraordinary session of the Senate will be called to take action on the Cuban treaty and the Isthmian Canal treaty.

Three great meetings, each attended by about 4,000 men and women, marked the farewell Sunday of Gen. William Booth, head of the Salvation Army, who is to sail for England on Wednesday aboard the steamship Celric, after having completed religious campaign of twenty weeks in fifty-two cities of the United States.

After a good-humored debate the Central Federated Union at its meeting yesterday accepted an invitation to join in the St. Patrick's Day parade of the Ancient Order of Hibernians. The Socialist delegates tried to poke fun at the invitation. Seeing the tendency to indulge in sarcastic laughter after the reading of the invitation, the Chairman said:

To the Editor of The New York times: As one of the leaders of the movement for reform in city politics in 1901. R. Fulton Cutting secured the approval, goodwill, and esteem of thousands of rightminded citizens, but it is not too much to say that he overstepped very much in his speech before the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday.

Twenty-eight competitors started yesterday in the invitation cross-country run of the Star Athletic Club in Long Island City over four and one-half miles of the club's regular course, and all of them finished. The roads were covered with sticky mud, which made the going heavy. The winner was R.W. Kennedy, who voluntarily gave the other contestants nearly two minutes at the start, and he had no difficulty in passing them after going three miles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter in to-day's TIMES on the cattlecar horror gives no exaggerated account of the evils existing in many of the interior towns of the Empire State from which shipments of cattle are constantly being made, and the writer's protest deserves to be sustained and emphasized.
The Rev. Dr. George C. Lorimer, pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, preached last night on the "Creed of the German Emperor." At the start of his sermon Dr. Lorimer said:

James J. Jeffries, the heavyweight champion pugilist, and James J. Corbett, the ex-champion, met at the Delavan Hotel yesterday and agreed to fight twenty or twenty-five rounds in California next June or July. When the big fellows met they got right down to business, and in a very short space of time it was agreed that if Corbett consented to fight in California Jeffries would allow him to wear soft bandages on his hands.

Sir CHARLES did not consider the proposed commission an arbitration tribunal at all, and he did not believe Sir WILFRID LAURIER would accept any such proposition, especially in view of the representatives which the United States had appointed. They were rabid partisans, he declared, and consequently the effect of the present agreement had already been destroyed.

BUFFALO, March 1. -- District Attorney Coatsworth did not leave his house to-day, but Assistant District Attorney Abbott conferred with him by telephone several times in regard to the murder of Edwin L. Burdick, who was killed in his home in Ashland Avenue on Thursday night.

The laying of the cornerstone of the Army War College at Washington Feb. 21, at which addresses were made by President Roosevelt, Secretary Root, and Gen. S.B.M. Young, upon the efficiency of the regular army, has aroused considerable discussion among the rank and file of the army as to the abolition of the depots of instruction for the raw recruit.

SCHENSCTADY, March 1. -- The Potter case has been settled by the Painters' Union backing down from its position, and William Potter will be allowed to go to work as a union painter and at the same time remain a member of the militia -- exactly the terms for which he has been standing out for the last three months.

Business will be resumed to-day after a broken week of trading of irregular tendency, but with reactionary prices prevailing. Only nine stocks advanced so much as one point, but over a hundred fell, and declines were larger as well as more numerous. The movement in the bond market was smaller, only ten advancing and sixteen declining by so much as a full point.

There was an exciting runaway on Stuyvesant Street and other neighboring streets yesterday afternoon, and the driver of the wagon. Charles Denzer, twenty-seven years old, of 99 Second Street, was seriously injured. The runaway horse was slopped by Policeman Arthur Ennis of the Fifth Street Station.

The large confidence of the officers of the Pennsylvania Railroad in the business future of this country is exhibited by their plans for spending the great sum of $117,000,000 in improving and extending their system of roads. Of this expenditure, $50,000,000, provided by an issue of bonds convertible into capital stock, is to be devoted to the construction of terminal and other improvements in this city.

Emma Rausch, the nine-year-old daughter of poor parents, living at 100 Bushwick Avenue, Williamsburg met with a tragic death yesterday afternoon while in a Sunday school class of the Ainslie Street Presbyterian Church by choking to death through swallowing the stem of a small toy balloon which lodged in her windpipe.

MOBILE, Ala., March 1. -- Seven Americans who joined the Boers and fought the British in South Africa have been released in this port, having arrived upon the Isla de Luzon from Manila, which touched at Ceylon, where the British Government turned them over to American authorities, with the understanding that they were to be landed safely upon their native soil.
BALTIMORE, March 1. -- President Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad returned from New York yesterday and made a statement relative to the Stated Island Ferry franchise.

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- Rarely has a more savage duel been seen in Paris than that between Max Regis and M. Laberdesque, at least not within the past fifteen years or so. M. Regis was reconciled to M. Laberdesque quite recently by Ernest Lajeunesse, but they quarreled again almost immediately afterward.

The Rev. Newell Dwight Hillis, at the service in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening, protested against the proposed amendment of the tenement house law, declaring that the amendment would "violate the obligation of the city to safeguard the homes of the poor and the weak." In beginning he said that the improvement of the homes of the poor began about fifteen years ago after the publication of Gen. Booth's "Darkest England."

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Roosevelt to-day set at rest all doubt as to a called session of the Senate to-day by issuing a proclamation to convene that body at noon, March 5. While it was undoubtedly the intention to have the Panama and Cuban treaties considered at this session, there is a possibility that the Cuban convention alone will come before it.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Representative Fitzgerald of New York, who was arrested on Inauguration Day, 1901, for trying to cross a street in disobedience of the police regulations, has been an enemy of the Police Department ever since. He had an item providing for an increase in the salary of Major Sylvester, the Chief of Police, stricken out of the District of Columbia Appropriation bill when it came up in the House.

What the United States Secret Service agents, say was a scheme for defrauding the Treasury Department by means of mutilated bills and false affidavits failed yesterday, and the failure carried with it the arrest of two persons.

If it is an honor nowadays to be made a star, then our stage has few actors to whom this honor is more fully due than to Mr. W.H. Thompson, whose debut was very cordially received last night at the Manhattan Theatre. For he is an actor in the full sense of the word -- a sense in which it has too seldom been used in recent years.

An intercity handball match has been arranged between "Mike" Egan of Jersey City, the world's champion, and Louis Keegan of Chicago for $200 a side. A home-and-home series of fifteen games has been agreed upon. The first seven games will be played at Egan's court, 223 Mercer Street, Jersey City, on Saturday, March 21, and two weeks later the match will be completed at Kennedy's court, Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The papers in the matter of the closing of the Post Office at Indianola, Miss., were sent to the House by Postmaster General Payne to-day. By far the most entertaining feature of the papers is the exhibit made by A.B. Weeks, brother-in-law of Mayor Davis of Indianola.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The credentials of the two Senators-elect from Delaware are to be sent here to-night. A number of Delaware Republicans are coming over to-morrow to see them take the oath.

Relics of the days when Ada Rehan was the star at Daly's Theatre were offered at auction yesterday afternoon at the Knickerbocker Auction Rooms, 7 West Twenty-ninth Street. The place was crowded with relie hunters who must have left their pocketbooks at home, according to C.E. Smith, the auctioneer.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate to-day the appointment of George C. Holt as United States Judge in the district recently created in Southern New York. Mr. Holt was indorsed generally by the bar of New York City.

Copper Trust stock was strong through-out the day on a continuation of the same kind of buying that has been in evidence now for some time and understood in the Street to come largely from trade interests. A further rise of 1/8 cent a pound was reported in the price of the metal.

Capt. Max F. Schmittberger of the West Forty-seventh Street Station was appointed an Inspector of Police by Commissioner Greene yesterday afternoon. That action was taken notwithstanding much opposition from persons holding public office and ex-city officials, and considerable adverse public sentiment because of the Captain's confessed wrongdoing as a policeman in the past.

A double bill exercises a special attraction always at the Opera House, because it means an opportunity to hear more artists and more parts and more variety of music. Especially does such a double bill as that offered last night prove attractive. Rossini's "II Barbiere di Siviglia" was despoiled of its first act to be grouped with Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci" as an evening's entertainment.

The action of Magistrate Crane, who discharged almost 150 prisoners, men and women, gathered in by Capt. Gorman of the Mercer Street Station in a series of raids on alleged illegal resorts in the Jefferson Market district last Saturday night, received the approval of District Attorney Jerome yesterday.

ALBANY, March 2. -- More than $19,000,000 is added to the estimates of the improvement of the Stale canals under the 1,000-ton barge plan by a report made to the Legislature to-night by State Engineer Bond. In answer to the inquiry made by the Assembly he declares that $100,561,091 would suffice to meet all charges under this contemplated improvement.

NEW BRUNSWICK, March 2. -- Ex-Senator Robert Adrain, representing Samuel F. Wylie and Frederick Weigel as trustees in bankruptcy of William F. Fisher Co., has filed an answer to a suit instituted in in the Court of Chancery by the Empire State Trust Company of New York to fore-close a mortgage on lands formerly owned by William F. Fisher Co., brick manufacturers.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 2. -- Miss Helen A. Smith, sixty-five years of age, who had been for many years a prominent member of the Christian Science cult in this place, died Saturday of what the Christian Scientists call a "kidney error," but what people outside the fold term Brights disease.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A determined and successful opposition developed to-day to the passage of the Aldrich bill. When the Senate adjourned Saturday the indications for a vote some time to-day were favorable. It was understood that a number of speeches would the made against certain features of the bill, but it was expected with the acceptance of amendments and modifications the opposition would be content and allow a vote to be taken.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2. -- The John A. Roebling's Sons' Company has just completed an order for 24,000 feet of wire rope to be used for rigging upon the yacht now being built to defend the America's Cup. This rope ranges from 1/2 inch to 1 3/8 inches in diameter, and is composed of six strands, each strand consisting of nineteen wires twisted together.

STEWARTSVILLE, N.J., March 2. -- An explosion in the Edison Portland cement plant, at New Village, two miles east of here, this evening, killed six persons and injured a score of others. Property valued at $100,000 was destroyed.

William G. Rockefeller, nephew of John D. Rockefeller, the Standard Oil magnate, was appointed Foreman of the March Grand Jury, which was sworn in before Judge Cowing in the Court of General Sessions yesterday. On the list of Grand Jurors Mr. Rockefeller is described as an oil merchant with offices at 26 Broadway and a residence at 292 Madison Avenue.

BOSTON, Mass., March 2. -- At the Clearing House to-day balances between the banks loaned at 4 1/2 per cent, and New York funds sold at 15 to 10 cents per $1,000 discount. The exchanges were $17,863,890, against $19,325,940 a year ago to-day, and the balances were $1,164,336.

A northbound Lexington Avenue car struck a brewery wagon at Seventy-second Street last night, dangerously injuring Ernst Meyer of 207 East Eightieth Street, the driver, and a man on the seat with him. The wagon was damaged, one of the horses injured, some of the car windows smashed, and the platform broken, while some of the passengers were thrown in a heap on the floor.

DOVER, Del., March 2. -- The Union and Regular factions of the Republican Party reached an agreement to-day which resulted in the election of two United States Senators by the State Legislature, and for the first time in four years the State of Delaware has secured full representation in the upper house of Congress.

Marooned on an abandoned station of the Kings County Elevated Railroad that has no outlet to the street below, caught in a cul de sac, as it were, a dozen women patrors of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company had a queer and distressing experience for an hour yesterday afternoon.
Renwick C. Hurry has sold for Mrs. John A. Vanderpoel to a client the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 224 Madison Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets, on lot 25 by 95.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Feb. 28, 1903, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $937,972,898, which is a decrease, as compored with Jan. 31, of $5,969,665. The debt is recapitulated as follows:

-- Thanks to the length of time that so often separates the acceptance and the publication of a magazine article, one in The March Cosmopolitan contains a picture and a paragraph that would almost certainly have been eliminated had the author done his work within the past few weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The full text of President Roosevelt's letter to Clark Howell, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, regarding Southern appointments, an abstract of which was published this morning, was made public to-day. In beginning his letter, which is dated Feb. 24, President Roosevelt says:

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- From 11 o'clock this morning until late to-night the House struggled laboriously against the Democratic filibuster, working steadily to wind up the necessary business of the session. Despite another special rule adopted early in the day, legislation proceeded at a snail's pace.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Hugh Guthrie Leighton, a graduate student in the Armour Institute Engineering School, and at one time a prominent athlete at the University of Chicago, died this evening from overexertion in a football game last October. Leighton, who was substitute centre on Stagg's football team for three years, undertook to play his old position in a fierce interclass struggle at Armour Institute last Fall without previous training.

The annual winner of the Speakers' Club of the Tammany Committee of the Thirty-first Assembly District was held last night it New Harlem Casino, Seven Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street. The members of Tammany Hall in the district and from other districts crowded the large banquet tables places on the ball room floor and the galleries were filled with wives and daughters of the members.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Weather Bureau's general summary of crop conditions for February is as follows:

MOUNT VEKNON, N.Y., March 2. -- The local authorities will take no action in the case of Mrs. Alice Jones of 109 South Thirteenth Avenue, who died on Saturday without medical attendance. Mrs. Jones and her husband were both Christian Scientists, and the local authorities have come to the conclusion that the stand taken by Coroner Weisendanger of Yonkers in the case is apparently correct.

Absolutely new in embroidery is the Madagascar straw work. It is perhaps the most effective of anything that has been done in this line of fancy work for some time, and it is inexpensive. The work is done with straw, something of the nature of raffia, it appears to be, which comes in big hanks, 5 cents a hank, and is dyed in exquisite colors.

The stock market opened with fitful temporary strength, but prices sagged through a day of desultory, uninteresting business, and almost through the list. Among the active properties there was but one, Manhattan, elsewhere spoken of, which advanced more than a fraction, but there were a dozen which fell a full point, while several fell more upon less business.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Senator Grady, the minority leader, to-night committed his party associates in the Senate to a position which, if adhered to, may prolong the session of the Legislature into the Summer months.

A board of officers is appointed to meet at Havana, Cuba, for the examination of officers to determine their fitness for promotion. Detail: Col. William C. Haskins, Artillery Corps; Capt. Andrew Moses. Artillery Corps; Capt. Thomas H.R. McIntyre, Artillery Corps; First Lieut. John R. Devereux, Assistant Surgeon; Contract Surgeon Rollin T. Burr. First Lieut. Harry J. Watson, Artillery Corps. Recorder.

London, March 2. -- The demand for money slacked somewhat in the market to-day and supplies were poor, though they benefited by the disbursement of railroad dividends. Discounts were quiet and rates were disposed to be easier.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- A generally heavy tone was developed in the market to-day, and declines extended throughout the list. The losses, however, were fractional in stocks. The most pronounced heaviness was in the Consolidated Lake Superior issues, in which there was more or less short selling; the preferred was down to 29 1/2.

Stuart Robson, who has been touring this season in a "Comedy of Errors," is slightly ill at his home, 738 West End Avenue, from asthma. Mr. Robson was playing in Philadelphia last week, and was barely able to finish his engagement there. His dates for the next two weeks have been canceled.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The omission of the two-million-dollar appropriation for the New York Post Office from the Sundry Civil bill occasioned a lively scene in the House to-day. When the conference report on the bill was presented by Mr. Cannon several New Yorkers demanded to know why the item had been stricken out.

ROME, March 3 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the coronation of Pope Leo was celebrated to-day with all the grandeur and impressiveness associated with the high ceremonies of the Catholic Church, and amid a display of enthusiasm and emotion on the part of the vast assemblage gathered within the walls of St. Peter's such as vied with the greatest of previous demonstrations of reverence and affection for the aged Pontiff.

LONDON, March 3 -- A striking feature of the dinner to Ambassador Choate was the distribution of the guests among fifteen round tables instead of all sitting at one board, as is customary at English public dinners. This innovation, which was attended by the happiest results, brought together curiously dissimilar personalities whose names are well known on both sides of the Atlantic.

The Directors of the United States Steel Corporation have decided to put through the bond conversion plan which had been held up by the various suits brought to prevent its consummation. Announcement to this effect was made yesterday after the regular monthly meeting of the Directors.

In the second of his admirable papers in The Atlantic on "Academic Freedom in Theory and in Practice," President HADLEY of Yale University touches the question of the degree and kind of control that should be exercised over teaching bodies by those who provide the money to support them.
Gen. William Booth, founder and head of the Salvation Army, bade his official farewell to America last night in Salvation Army style in the Metropolitan Opera House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me cry "Hear, hear!" to the vigorous characterization by a woman of the shallow doctrine held by optimists as a body on the question of "race suicide." Hers are the utterances of no selfish soul, merely seeking excuse for avoidance of a hard but natural duty.
LONDON, March 4 -- The Times publishes a report of the Pilgrim Club's banquet to United States Ambassador Choate at the Hyde Park Hotel yesterday evening.

With deep regret the Congregation of Temple Beth-El assembled in the vestry rooms of their edifice, at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, last evening, at a special meeting called to take final action on the resignation of the Rev. Dr. Kaufmann Kohler, who has long been their mirister and who has resisted all the pressure that has been brought to bear to induce him to reconsider his determination.

Incensed at a verdict of acquittal in an excise case after the defendant, according to the District Attorney, had practically admitted his guilt, Mr. Jerome yesterday severely criticised a jury in Judge Foster's court, and then asked the Judge that the twelve men be discharged from jury duty for the remainder of the term.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 3 -- It is naw nearly three months since John Carroll Lathrop, the Christian Science healer of New York, and Mr. and Mrs. John Quimby, through their attorneys, demurred to the indictment found against them by the Westchester County Grand Jury for not providing proper medical treatment for seven-year-old Esther Quimby, who died of diphtheria on Oct. 20 last.

Twenty-five portraits all in a row are apt to be trying to beholders who are not interested especially in the difficult art of portraiture and so miss the amusement of comparing many canvases by the same brush and lack the curiosity to sec how the artist has solved the problem in each case.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The special committee appointed by the Legislature last year to investigate the forestry experiment being made by Cornell University on State lands met here to-night. A statement was made by B.E. Fernow. Director of the New York State College of Forestry, as to the work accomplished.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 3 -- Eight new cases of typhoid fever, three suspected cases, and two deaths have been reported in the last twenty-four hours. The deaths were those of Ledra Bagley at the City Hospital, and Edward Besmer, at the home of his brother, at Dundee, where he went after contracting the fever here.

The Kneisel Quartet's firm hold on the admiration and affection of the most fastidious and intelligent musical audience in New York is shown anew at each of their appearances in this city. Last evening the fifth concert of their season's series was given in Mendelssohn Hall, and, like the last one, to a gathering as large as the audience room could accommodate.

Wounded Buffalo, a Mohawk Indian, whose Carlisle School name is Lewis Simpson, caused excitement at Broadway and Franklin Street at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon by his summary punishment of a tormentor.

Just as McMullen McBean, sub-contractors for the Harlem River section of the rapid transit tunnel, were ready to begin work on the concrete lining in the trench they had completed nearly half across the stream a leak was sprung in their bulkhead dam and the excavated stretch was inundated.

There is reason to believe that the considerations which impelled Commissioner GREENE to promote Capt. SCHMITTBERGER to an Inspectorship were so good that his well-known reluctance to make this promotion was not sufficient to justify disregarding the ambitious Captain's position as head of the eligible list.

LONDON, March 3 -- The pressure for money was less pronounced in the market to-day, but the demand was strong enough to maintain rates and the scarcity compelled more borrowings from the Bank of England. Discounts were steady. Rumors of imports of gold from the Continent and the Cape for the Bank of England revived the prospect of a reduction of the bank rate.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Democratic blockade against all Republican legislation established by Senator Grady, the minority leader, last night because of the refusal of the majority to recall the Stevens Inherit- ance Tax bill from the Assembly so that the Democratic members might change their record on it was raised to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3 -- Judge Kirkpatrick in the United States District Court this afternoon appointed James P. McGovern of New York and George D. Hallock of Plainfield receivers for the Pacific Packing and Navigation Company. The company operates big salmon fisheries and packing plants on the Pacific Coast, and has a paid up capital of $13,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The President to-day gave unequivocal denial to the utterance alleged to have been made by him yesterday in regard to Senator Carmack of Tennessee. A delegation of Tennessee men, including members of Congress from that State, called at the White House to urge the appointment of ex-Secretary of State Morgan of Tennessee as a Commissioner on the Panama Canal board.

The champion Crescents played their oldtime hockey rivals, the New York Athletic Club, last night at the St. Nicholas Rink, and just managed to turn the fierce struggle into a victory. The final score was 5 to 4, but up to the last minute of play it was 4 to 3 in favor of the New Yorks.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Rear Admiral Arent S. Crowninshield, who was Chief of the Bureau of Navigation in the Navy Department during the war with Spain, has asked for immediate retirement from the navy. Admiral Crowninshield is now in commano of the European Station. It is known that he was dissatisfied because he was deprived of the battleship Illinois and given the cruiser Chicago for his flagship.

There will be little doing to-day. One wedding, that of Miss Lane and Mr. Lovell, is to take place, but little else is on the social programme. There are to be small events, sewing classes, dinners, bridge classes, and the opera.

Is it compatible with the maintenance of the Monroe Doctrine that the United States should acquiesce in the use of European navies as collecting agencies for debts owed to their "nationals" by American Republics? That is a question which has become urgent. It has been extensively discussed in this country of late by reason of the Italo-Anglo-German naval combination against Venezuela.

J. EDWARD ADDICKS sat in the gallery of the Senate Chamber yesterday and applauded loudly as the two Senators-elect from Delaware, one of whom is his dummy, advanced to the President's desk to take the oath. The clapping of the hands of ADDICKS was a violation of the traditions of the Senate, but we may well imagine that in that hour of tri- umph he could not restrain himself.

There is no trouble about diagnosing yesterday's stock market. It was weak throughout the list, and almost throughout the day. Such occasional reaction or resistance as developed, especially at the close, was inadequate to establish among active securities a single advance of a full point, but there was near a score of declines averaging more than that.

Edward H. Litchfield has bought from Charles H. Dederer the Hotel St. James, a twelve-story structure at 107 to 113 West Forty-fifth Street, on plot 60 by 100.5. Mr. Litchfield gives in part payment forty-three lots on Eighth Avenue. Fourth and Fifth Streets, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

Having listened to a speaker who complimented the height of the Washington Monument, Russell Sturgis, the architect, was called upon to have his say at the Architectural League's semi-monthly dinner last night. The subject of the evening was "The Artistic Commemoration of Historic Sites."
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Immigration act which has passed both houses of Congress and will be laid before the President for approval is substantially in the form it was passed by the Senate.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3. -- Ahumada and Floyd K. were the only winning favorites here to-day. Frank Rice, running in the colors of his new owner, J.G. McCafferty, showed improvement. E.E. Smathers of Brooklyn, the recent purchaser of McChesney, increased his thoroughbred string to-day by the purchase of the colt Dick Bernard from Durnell Herz, for $8,000.

Down-town business women have had trials and tribulations within the last two or three years because there have been no shops for them, while that part of the city seemed filled with haberdashers' shops. In a few of the men's shops the proprietors have put in a supply of handkerchiefs or overshoes, the absolute necessities which must be had if one happens to forget and leave them at home.

The Civic Federation of New York City was organized yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, 203 Broadway. This is the local committee of the National Civic Federation, organized in pursuance of the policy of establishing local federations which was adopted at the last meeting of the National body.

William H. Maxwell, City Superintendent of Schools, has issued notice of an examination for admission to training schools for teachers and for graduation from high schools, which will be conducted by Dr. Maxwell and begin June 8 next and be continued on the 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th, and 15th of that month.

The trouble regarding the canoe tilting tournament at the Sportsmen's Show in the Madison Square Garden, from which most of the contestants withdrew on Monday on account of the acceptance by the management of the entries of Francis West, a Canadian canoeist, and Shawanoo, one of the Ojibway Indians, the other contestants claiming that West is a professional, was settled yesterday by a compromise.

BOSTON, March 3 -- The money market is practically unchanged. Rates are high and business rather dull. Call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 15@10c discount: clearings, $27,345,186; balances, $1,567,572.

Capt. Guy H.B. Smith, Fourth Infantry; First Lieut. John T. Toffey, Jr., Fourth Infantry, and First Lieut. Gordon N. Kimball, Twelfth Cavalry, will report by letter to the commanding General, Department of Texas, for assignment to duty.

There was twice the usual attendance in Part I. of the Supreme Court yesterday when ex-Justice Fursman arose to address Justice McCall in behalf of the motion for a change of venue for the trial of David W. Bucklin, the reputed manager for Richard A. Canfield, at 5 East Forty-fourth Street. Decision was reserved.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- Increased activity in the market brought increased weakness in the stock department. Not a single issue reflected a net gain at the close, while the losses extended to 1 5/8 in United Gas, 1 1/2 in Consolidated Lake Superior preferred. 1 1/2 in Philadelphia and Erie, 1 in Minehall, and substantial fractions in half a dozen other stocks.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A remarkable situation exists in the Fifty-seventh Congress, which entered upon its last legislative day at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. In both branches the closing hours are marked by bitter fights, which have all but brought business to a standstill. A deadlock, stubborn, resigned, and uncompromising, exists in the Senate and prevents the passage of every contested measure.

St. Patrick's Cathedral was the scene yesterday morning of religious rejoicing, a rare occurrence in Roman Catholic churches during the season of Lent. The cathedral was crowded with worshippers there to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the day when Leo XIII, was proclaimed Pope and enthroned in the Sistine Chapel at Rome.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Educational factions of the State again clashed to-day at a hearing given by the Senate Committee on Education on the bill of Senator Elon R. Brown to create a State Board of Education composed of nine Regents, to be elected for a stated term.

The auction of Ada Rehan's collection of antiques, furniture, and objects of art was continued yesterday afternoon at the Knickerbocker Auction Rooms, West Twenty-ninth Street, the prices being a little above those of the opening sae. The total for the afternoon's auction of 250 objects was $4,837.35.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The conferrees of the two houses on the Naval Appropriation bill reached an agreement at 10 o'clock last night.
