ALBANY, March 3 -- Gov. Odell is getting tired of the criticism to which he is being subjected because of efforts to wipe out direct taxation in the State. He talked with George W. Dunn, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, and some of the leaders of the Legislature on the subject to-day.

Inasmuch as such declines as appeared in yesterday's market were nearly all due to the same general cause -- selling induced by the failure of the Aldrich bill to pass -- it is scarcely necessary to refer in detail to price movements. Here and there, however, appear some issues specially noticeable.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Amid the protests of its friends, the Aldrich Financial bill met its expected fate to-day, when it was displaced in the Senate by the Philippines bill. The death of the financial measure was marked by mutual charges of responsibility for its failure by its supporters and the opposition.

ST. LOUIS, March 3 -- An injunction granted by Judge Adams in the United States Circuit court this afternoon prevented the threatened strike for higher wages of the 1,100 firemen and trainmen of the Wabash Railroad.

Mayor Low's administration was the subject of a long discussion at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. The Tammary members, under the leadership of Aldernan McCall, made a bitter attack on the effort which is being made to pass a bill in the Legislature taking away from the local legislative body the power to fix the salaries of city officials in the departments.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Chamber of Commerce Special Committee on Freshets to-day decided to raise the sum of $5,000 by popular subscription to pay for the services of a steamboat which will endeavor to break up the formidable ice gorge in the Hudson at North Coeymans. One Albany merchant tendered $500 and another $25 for the experiment.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Attorney General Knox, who has been for several days in conference at various times with Attorney Nelson W. Cromwell, the American representative of the Panama Canal Company, reported to-day to the Cabinet that he had received from Mr. Cromwell an acceptance of the proposition he, on behalf of the United States, recently had made to the canal company, to keep alive the option held by this Government on the company's property.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4. -- A wave of uneasiness swept over the financial community this morning as a result of sharp and severe breaks in Consolidated Lake Superior preferred and United Gas. The former, which closed at 27 yesterday, was driven down to 23, which is the lowest price on record, while United Gas suffered an extreme decline from the last sale yesterday of 2 3/8 per cent, before inside buying orders appeared.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4. -- The Cercle Francais of this city formally opened its new clubrooms in the Brokaw Building this evening. The guest of honor was Leopold Mabilleau. Preceding the dedicatory exercises he delivered the annual French lecture in Alexander Hall on "L'evolution de I'idee de patrie en France de 1789 a 1900."

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Senator Allison made the usual statement to-day in regard to the total of appropriations made at the session of Congress just closed, the total at the first session, and the aggregate of the appropriations made by the Fifty-seventh Congress.

LONDON, March 5. -- Referring to his telegram published on Feb. 23, the Constantinople correspondent of The Times says that the Palace, having failed to obtain through the Patriarchate official addresses of thanks from the Greek Bishops in Macedonia, is endeavoring to attain its purpose by other means.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 4. -- The sloop yacht Constitution arrived from New London this afternoon in tow of the tug Argo to be fitted out in racing trim for the season in anticipation of contests with the other sloop yachts of the 90-foot class. The Constitution was anchored off the Herreshoff workshop, and will at once have her spars shipped in place and be rigged.

The last but two of the games to be played in the championship series of the New York Hockey League was played between the teams representing Columbia University and Stevens Institute last night. Columbia having a walk-over and winning by a score of 4 to 0. A small but enthusiastic audience journeyed to the Clermont Avenue rink in Brooklyn to watch the collegians play.

After a terrific fight in a lonely building two burglars were beaten into insensibility last night by Detectives Peabody and Clark, and taken to Police Headquarters. The prisoners are said to be the leaders of a band of thieves who have been robbing lofts throughout the wholesale dry goods district during the last few months, obtaining thousands of dollars' worth of fine fabrics.

ST. LOUIS, March 4. -- Lawyers representing the labor unions which were enjoined from ordering a strike on the Wabash Railroad are preparing to ask for a dissolution of the writ issued by Judge Adams of the United States District Court. They will probably present papers in court to-morrow.
Army. Assignments to regiments of infantry officers recently promoted:
ALBANY, March 4. -- Unless Gov. Odell is sorely disappointed his tax legislation will not fall, and canal legislation will also be passed before the close of the session.
CHICAGO, March 4. -- Judge M. F. Tuley of the Appellate Court to-day criticised the Wabash strike injunction:

Borough President Cantor addressed an east side audience at the Educational Alliance last night on "One Year of Reform." His talk was announced as the first of a series inaugurated by the New Era Club for the purpose of increasing the sense of civic responsibility in the east side.

The heavy fog which settled on this city yesterday morning was responsible for two serious collisions on the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, for a series of accidents on the rivers, and for a general impairment of ferry service. Ocean sailing s were delayed, and it was noon before harbor traffic resumed its normal condition.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The demeanor of the House in its last hours bore testimony to the wearing effect of the all-night session, coming after other sessions almost as long. Everybody was tired. There was no life nor spirit in the House, and when the usual singing of songs began after adjournment many of the voices showed the effects of the long strain.

BUFFALO, March 4. -- The District Attorney and his staff together with the police detectives were busily engaged to-day at their task of unraveling the mystery surrounding the murder of Edwin L. Burdick, the wealthy clubman, but while it is hinted that evidence of great importance is in hand, no arrest has been made.

Are the New York women all built on a larger scale than the out-of-town women, and are all women as large again as they were forty, fifty, sixty, and seventy-five years ago? That was what they yere asking yesterday at the big hall in the Masonic Temple, where the Dressmakers' Protective Association opened its annual convention and exhibition of model frocks.

Stockholders of the Lackawanna Steel Company have received circulars in respect to the issue of first mortgage 5 per cent, convertible gold bonds, just authorized. Under the terms of the issue stockholders of record March 3 may subscribe to such part of the $15,000,000 of bonds at 96 and accrued interest as their stock entitles them.

Wall Street stood pat yesterday, as it long has, and is long likely to stand. "Speculation," testified an expert before a committee investigating corners, "is a method for adjusting differences of opinion respecting future values." Just now there is abundance of differences of opinions, but there is no speculation worth mentioning.

Interest in the outside market yesterday was centred in the trading in bonds, and attention was given to this department almost to the exclusion of the rest of the list. The most noteworthy feature of the day's transactions was the heavy decline which occurred in the price of the proposed issue of United States Steel bonds.

BOSTON, March 4. -- The money market continues firm and the banks are showing a disposition to strengthen their position. No much anxiety is shown over the defeat of the Aldrich bill, for it is believed that if severe stringency should develop Secretary Shaw would take the same action he took last Fall.
The debates in Parliament have not yet furnished any answer to the question about the alliance with Germany against Venezuela, the question most vigorously put by Mr. KIPLING --
There was secrecy about a meeting which a thousand or more elevated railroad employes attended yesterday afternoon in the Horton Building, at 110 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Senator Elsberg today introduced a bill which provides that a permit shall be granted to the Retail Butchers' Association of New York to construct an abattoir at Thirty-ninth Street and Eleventh Avenue.

HAVANA, March 4. -- The report on the reciprocity treaty with the United States was taken up by the Senate this afternoon and went over until Friday, after an animated debate, occasioned by efforts at filibustering by the few opponents of the treaty. The merits of the treaty were not discussed.

Austen G. Fox will offer a resolution to the Bar Association next Tuesday asking that a commission of three Justices of the Supreme Court be appointed to investigate the advisability of building a Court House up town. Many members of the Bar Association are taking an active interest in the agitation, and it is said the scheme is favored by many of the Justices of the Supreme Court.

TRENTON, N. J., March, 4. -- In the Senate this morning the bill repealing the North Plainfleld annexation measure, passed last Winter, was favorably reported from Committee. Also the bill permitting the merging of some constituent railroad companies of the Lehigh Valley Company in the State of New Jersey, under the name of the Lehigh Valley Company, The bill providing for State aid for the improvement of the Newark plank road was passed.

NEW ORLEANS, March 4. -- E. E. Smathers, who has invested nearly $40,000 in thoroughbreds in the last few days, tasted the first fruits of victory on the running turf to-day, when Dick Bernard, his most recent purchase, galloped home eight lengths in front in the Premier Stakes. The Smathers color -- brown -- was carried for the first time by a runner.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 4. -- This town has a citizen whose head is as hard as they make them. He is known as "Benny" Booth. He is a negro and is at least ninety years old. His conversation is almost unintelligible, and the oldest inhabitants of the community testify that he never did have any intellect.

A commendable spirit of respect for law pervades the statement of Grand Master MORRISSEY of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen announcing that the brotherhood will obey as law-abiding citizens the temporary injunction granted by Judge ADAMS of the United States Circuit Court forbidding the officers of the railway men's unions from ordering a strike of the firemen and trainmen on the Wabash system.

LONDON, March 5. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says that the idea of forming a central European customs boycott of the United States is once more advocated from a quarter notoriously devoted to the interests of "Greater Germany."

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Senate assembled in leisurely fashion this morning. It was realized that the work of Congress had been concluded with the close of the night session, and there was expectation of nothing more important than the settling of personal scores and the performance of the little ceremonies that are customarily a part of the final hours of a Congress.

The block in the Senate during the latter half of the short session was due primarily to the machinations of Senator QUAY, who for reasons of his own, thoroughly discreditable so far as he chose to make them known, sought the admission of Arizona and New Mexico in opposition to the deliberate policy of his own party.
LONDON, March 4. -- The demand for money in the market to-day was active, and the supply was scarce. Discounts were fairly firm.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Even in the early hours of the morning just before sunrise, when Congressmen at the night session were inclined to doze in their seats, the speech of Representative Cannon of Illinois, Chairman of the Appropriations Committee, on the General Deficiency Appropriation bill, protesting against "legislative blackmail " in Congress, and insisting upon the right of the majority to rule, caused almost a sensation.

-- Copies of The Bermuda Colonist, now at hand, with full reports of the testimony taken by the board which investigated the loss of the Madiana, confirm in the strongest way our inference from the few facts first cabled that the wreck was in great measure, if not in whole, the result of negligence ashore.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- James I. McCallum, United States Consul General at St. Gall, called at the State Department today. He will not return to his post, finding it impossible to look after his private interests at that distance from his home in Washington. He is a son-in-law of the late John Sherman.

ALBANY, March 4. -- "Think of your own children, under ten years of age, waiting at 4 o'clock in the morning for the early newspapers." cried Dr. Felix Adler to the Senate Judiciary Committee at the hearing on the Child Labor bills to-day. These bills would limit the activities of children as newsboys and messenger boys and in other respects.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Fifty-seventh Congress has come to an end. The deadlock in each wing of the Capitol died only with the Congress. The last daily session was a season of mourning in both Houses. Baffled hopes, disappointed ambitions, strangled legislation, and thwarted policies strewed the scene of final dissolution.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 4. -- The Union County Grand Jury, which has been conducting an inquiry into the wreck of the Philadelphia and Reading flyer on the New Jersey Central Railroad at Graceland on Jan. 27, to-day made a presentment in the Circuit Court to Judge Vail.

BALTIMORE, March 4. -- George M. Shriver has been appointed assistant to President Loree of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. This is a new position recently created, and important, as in the absence of the President the performance of many of his duties will fall upon Mr. Shriver.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- When the Senate convenes to-morrow in extra session it is very probable every one of the ninety Senators will be present. The terms of thirty of the Senators began at noon to-day and all of them are expected to present themselves to be sworn in immediately following the reading of the brief proclamation of the President convening the Senate.

Leopold Well has negotiated a perpetual lease of the Chanler estate's property at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, a plot 60 by 100, now covered by three old dwellings, which have been reconstructed for business purposes. The lessee is Louis Korn. When possession of the property is given on May 1, a modern flre-proof building will be erected on the site.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The House leaders are a little uneasy over the question whether the Democrats are going to keep up their present attitude in the next Congress. The Democrats are in a very ugly temper now, and if they are in the same temper in the Fifty-eighth Congress they can make things very troublesome.

ALBANY, March 5. -- There was a large attendance of sportsmen and those interested in the protection of game at the hearing to-day before the Senate Forest, Fish, and Game Committee on the Brown hill to prevent the shooting of brant, swan, and other wild fowl during the Spring.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The United States Senate met to-day in extra session convened by the President, and received the following message:

Fire discovered beneath the condemned old Sturtevant House at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning threw the 200 guests into panic, and for a time seemed likely to forestall the doom of the once famous hotel. Nobody was hurt in any of the thrilling scenes which transpired along the tangled corridors, and the employes seem to have retained their coolness and to have done efficient work in bringing the terrified guests to the street.

ROME, March 5. -- Dr. Lapponi visited the Pope this morning and found him no worse with regard to symptoms of any specific illness. The physician has forbidden any one to see the Pontiff, except the latter's nephew, Count Camillo Peeci, who entered the Pope's room as Dr. Lapponi left it.

LONDON, March 6. -- Premier Balfour announced in the House of Commons yesterday that the Admiralty had decided to establish a new naval station at St. Margaret's Hope, on the north side of the Fifth of Forth.

Three apartment houses in West One Hundred and Fourth Street have had sleepless nights for a fortnight over a mysterious woman whom the neighborhood knows as the "Black Ghost." Clarence, janitor at 138, which is just half way between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, is in a state of semi-nervous collapse.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 5. -- Thomas Ryan, who was the clarinet and viola player in the famous Mendelssohn Quintet Club of Boston, died here to-night. He was on his way from New York to his new home in Belmont, Mass. He is survived by a widow and two daughters.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Representatives of both sides of the coal strike question appeared before the anthracite coal strike commission to-day. All the members of the commission were present, Judge Gray, the Chairman, presiding. The session was held in the hearing room of the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

The expected happened yesterday when the dividend on Manhattan Railway stock was increased to a regular 7 per cent. basis by the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 1 3/4 per cent., while in addition an extra dividend of 1 per cent. was declared. The last quarterly dividend was 1 1/2 per cent.

ALBANY, March 5. -- Senator Frawley is leading a savings bank reform crusade. He introduced a bill last week which provides that there should be an annual election of Directors on a stated day, and that every depositor should have the right to vote either in person or by proxy. He introduced two more bills to-day, built upon the theory that the savings bank depositor is not getting all that he should.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Roosevelt to-day renewed his nominations of William D. Crum, colored, to be Collector of Customs at Charleston, S.C., and William M. Byrne to be Federal District Attorney of Delaware. Senate committees took unfavorable action on both these nominations at the late session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Republican Senators will make a united effort to obtain action on the Panama Canal treaty and the Cuban reciprocity treaty as speedily as possible. A meeting of the Republican Steering Committee of the Senate was held after adjournment to-day, and that course was decided on.

Representatives of the rival National and American Baseball Leagues held sessions yesterday at the Victoria and Fifth Avenue Hotels. Several of the National League club Presidents made a social call on President Johnson of the American League, during which they declared that the peaceful conditions which now exist between both organizations should be maintained, for the benefit of every one interested as well as the game itself.

BUFFALO, March 5. -- No arrest was made in the Burdick murder case to-day. Although the police and the District Attorney are convinced that they know the identity of the murderer, they are not yet prepared to act. They are keeping a close watch, however, on a house in the Elm Street district, in which the suspected woman lives.

Mayor Low made the announcement yesterday that the city would oppose all the bills for the amendment of the tenement house law so far introduced at this session of the Legislature. This statement came as a surprise to many east side residents who appeared before Mayor Low yesterday to make a protest against changes in the tenement house law.

Announcement was made at Columbia University yesterday that a sum of $1,000,000 had been presented to Barnard College, the women's department of the university, and that the money has already been used for the purchase of land. The name of the donor was withheld, and it is understood that it is known only to President Butler and George A. Plimpton, the Treasurer of Barnard.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- The first tennis tournament of the season was begun on the courts here to-day. It was a mixed doubles invitation handicap tournament for prizes presented by Mrs. A. Sidney Carpenter of Philadelphia and Miss B. Andrews of Lakewood. Col. John Jacob Astor and a number of other prominent New Yorkers participated.

On dull days or in the lengthening afternoons, when the business of the office has been finished up, State Engineer BCND delights to take a pencil and pad and cipher out some additional millions of cost for the canal improvement. He has now boosted his estimates above one hundred millions, and the possibilities of increment are by no means exhausted.

GLASGOW, March 5. -- Sir Thomas Lipton was interviewed to-day after he had made an inspection of the America's Cup challenger. He said that everything was practically ready to launch Shamrock III. at 1:30 on the afternoon of St. Patrick's Day, when a general holiday would be declared in Dumbarton.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The Assembly Cities Committee this evening reported out the bill introduced by Senator Grady permitting the New York theatres to allow persons to stand in the rear of the seats. This measure has passed the Senate.

The closest fly-casting competition yet seen at the Sportsmen's Show occurred yesterday afternoon. In the competition in Class T, casting with trout flies for distance only, open to all who had not cast over 90 feet in a similar event, two of the contestants, W.D. Cloyes of Cortland, N.Y., and V.R. Grimwood of this city, tied three times for first place.

The Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse was a day late in landing the Frenczy Opera Company, which is booked for a season of light opera at the Irving Place Theatre, and when it did land them yesterday morning they were too storm-tossed and battered to put on "Das Susse Madel" in the evening as scheduled.

ALBANY, March 5. -- "This is the blindest bill which has been before the Senate in a hundred years," was the comment of Senator Brackett upon the measure introduced by Senator Goodsell relating to consents for street surface railroads when it was called up in the upper house to-day.
LONDON, March 5. -- The pressure for money was relaxed somewhat to-day, though supplies were not abundant. Discounts were weaker.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- The market opened active and unsettled, with renewal of pressure on the Consolidated Lake Superior issues. Philadelphia Electric, and Reading. Later Cambria Steel, Philadelphia Company, Lehigh Valley, and Philadelphia Rapid Transit also developed a reactionary tendency, but none of them declined to an important extent.

ALBANY, March 5. -- Information was given out to-day that Gov. Odell will take a hand in the bitter controversy over the State schools. He believes that the present conflict between the State Board of Regents and the Superintendent of Public Instruction is unnecessary, and that it should be ended once for all.

-- Salvador, the smallest but most thickly populated of the Central American "republics," has been an independent nation since 1839, and for some time before that it was a State in a self-governing federation. It is, therefore, far from the youngest in the sisterhood of peoples, and ought to have learned a good deal.

RICHMOND, Va., March 5. -- The Rev. Dr. William E. Edwards, Professor of Moral Philosophy at Randolph-Macon College at Ashland, died to-night, aged sixty-two years. He was a prominent member of the Virginia Conference. Methodist Episcopal Church, South. Dr. Edwards entered Randolph-Macon College in 1858 and was graduated in June, 1862.

Inspector Walter L. Thompson, who for many months has been stationed in Queens, yesterday appeared at Police Headquarters and presented an application for retirement, Commissioner Greene immediately signed it, and the old man's connection with the Police Department ceased save for the half-pay pension of $1,750 which he will draw while he lives, and which, he says, and those who know him believe him, is about all he has to live on.

The edict of the Emperor WILLIAM banishing British oysters from the imperial larder and substituting Dutch and Danish oysters in place thereof will doubtless have an important influence in closing the German markets against a prized delicacy. Why any one should consider the diminutive and "coppery" English oyster a delicacy, at home or abroad, is inscrutable to Americans.

LONDON, March 5. -- Over 2,000 emigrants left Liverpool to-day for Canada. The emigration season is considered to have opened, and this month's bookings by all the Canadian steamship lines are the largest for forty years.

Facts and fictions combined to depress yesterday's stock market. Prices opened fractionally down, and fell almost steadily to a weak closing at near the lowest. There were abundant rumors affecting a firm and a trust company and several pools. They were not confirmed, but fears about conjectural trouble are not seldom more depressing than worse but fully known conditions.
BERLIN, March 5. -- American bankers borrowed large sums in Berlin to-day on time loans, at 5 1/2 per cent., on first-class security.
Prof. Charles E. Bennett of Cornell University, who was in this city yesterday, had something to say about the epidemic of typhoid fever in the university and the City of Ithaca.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 5. -- This week or the first of next week trainmen employed on the Boston Albany division will present a demand for shorter hours and more pay. Included in the demand will also be a long list of other things on which the grievance committee has been at work.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Bull manipulation in corn received a heavy blow to-day when the commission appointed some time ago to consider "kiln-dried" corn decided to make no change in the rules regarding its inspection. With kiln-dried corn deliverable on contracts, if otherwise good enough, the local elevator concerns can dry out the No. 3 corn, so abundant this year, and bring it up to grade.

A large and glowing section of periodical literature has been said to repose on the twin bases of corsets and baby food. Both articles are of undisputed prominence in the world's modern markets and afford a justification for no end of advertising outlay to push their rival claims.

Army. Changes in the stations and duties of Quartermasters: Capt. David S. Stanley, in addition to his present duties, is assigned temporarily as Quartermaster at the Presidio of San Francisco to relieve Capt. Amos W. Kimball. Capt. Kimball, upon being relieved, will proceed to the Philippine Islands for duty.
Wood Brothers have been appointed New York suburban agents of the Dutchess Insurance Company.

John H. Berry has sold for the Davis estate and Francis K. Pendleton, respectively, the two four-story brick dwellings 40 and 42 East Nineteenth Street, on plot 43 by 92, to a client, who will erect on the site a ten-story store and loft building.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Decided opposition to the proposal of the Virginia Legislature to place a statue of Gen. Robert E. Lee in Statuary Hall trill probably be made by the Grand Army of the Republic and other organizations in many of the Northern States. Representative Lacy of Iowa, a native of Virginia, deprecates the action of the Virginia Legislature in passing the bill providing for the statue.

The attitude assumed by President Roosevelt toward the negro was indorsed in a rousing mass meeting of colored people held last night in the Bethel Methodist Episcopal Church in West Twenty-fifth Street at which Bishop W.B. Derrick of the First Methodist Episcopal district made a stirring apeal to his people to turn their eyes to the "door of hope opened by the President" to the black race.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 5. -- Lieut. William Henry Hill, Military Instructor and Professor of Mathematics in the University School and Military Institute in this place, who on Wednesday was shown a letter from a woman in England who said she was his wife, left town that day, and he has not been heard of since.

Everything that was ever done on ice, and several things that were never done before, were done last night at the carnival of ice sports at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, the programme including snow-shoe races, foot races on the ice, blind horse races, and potato races. George Davis, for the second time, performed his hair-raising feat of skating down a 110-foot incline at an angle of 45 degrees without killing himself.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 5. -- James J. Corbett and "Billy" Delaney, the latter representing James J. Jeffries, met here to-night and signed articles for a fight for the heavyweight championship of the world. It was agreed that the contest take place in California, in July or August, 1903, under the auspices of the club offering the largest purse.

Prof. Peabody furnishes the reader with a brief sketch of the writer, whose essays he translates and commends. He is, it seems, a man of large experience in academic and political affairs. Since 1800 he has been a member of the Swiss House of Representatives. As a writer his chief concern has been with the science of politics, not as something up in the air, but as something having application to immediate political affairs.

THERE must be thousands at Americans who have heard enough about Nietzsche to know that it is their duty to abhor him utterly as an atheist and dreadful pessimist. A few hundred possibly have come to terms of real acquaintance with him, and millions more have never heard of him at all.

The decay of Bible reading has been so common a theme of late, and has seemed to most commentators, including ourselves, so deplorable, even from the exclusively literary point of view, that one would be glad to believe that the decay itself had been rashly assumed rather than established.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: MONTGOMERY SCHUYLER, in his most Interesting review of Sidney Lee's "Victoria," suggests certain reasons which induced the Queen to exhaust her influence toward modifying the tenor of the original draft of Lord Palmerston's dispatch on the "Trent affair," at the outset of our civil war.

Wall Street, having recovered its nerves, reason resumed its sway yesterday in some degree, and prices assumed a more correct relation to intrinsic conditions. Stocks were worth no more yesterday than on the previous day, which is only another way of saying that they were worth no less on the previous day, when operators rushed en masse to sell everything upon an accumulation of alarms without adequate basis.

The weak points of "The Circle" are obvious in its earlier chapters. There are exaggerations and inconsistencies in certain of the characters; the affair of the jewels, upon which so much, hinges, seems but a clumsy bit of machinery, in the place of which something better might have been devised, and one is impatiently sensible of the fact that the blossoming of the obscure child of poverty into the histrionic star has been sadly overworked.

DENVER, March 6 -- James Stettauer, a prominent clubman and financier of Chicago, died at Mercy Hospital in this city of blood poisoning, resulting from a scratch inflicted while shaving. The injury was received a week ago. A day or so later erysipelas set in and was followed by a complication of kidney trouble.

"Tiffany's is easy," said "Toothpicks " Britton, who, the police say, has served several terms in prison and who was arrested yesterday for purloining silverplate from Tiffany's store, on Union Square. Britton told Inspector Brooks of the Detective Bureau that he had been stealing from the place for a couple of years.

WHAT a regular old standby is Dame Julyans Berners, best known as "The Mother of Fishermen," who published her "The Treatyse of Fyshynge with an Angle" in 1496. Of the four "Gaymes," she puts "fyshynge" in the lead, for the others are "huntynge, hawkynge, and foulynge."
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Since Gov. Van Sant went back to Minnesota with his Vice Presidential boom, an impression has gone abroad that Vice Presidential politics may soon reach interesting stage.

The Amateur Hockey League series ended last night at St. Nicholas Rink with a game between the Hockey Club of New York and the Brooklyn Skating Club. The Hockey Club won by 4 goals to 1, but the score was immaterial, as the apparent object of each man was not to play the puck, but to disable his opponent.

PITTSBURG, March 6 -- The American Window Glass Company issued a notice to its workmen to-day that on March 14 all of the factories of the company will close for the season, irrespective of what other companies may do.
ALBANY, March 6 -- The Assembly today passed Assemblyman Wainwright's bill to define the qualifications of Hell Gate pilots.
SUBJECT -- The riot at Ephesus. Acts, xix., 29-40.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Justice Brown entertained this evening at dinner in honor of the British Ambassador and Lady Herbert.
LONDON, March 6 -- Rates for money hardened to-day. Discounts were firm on the Bank of England return, and the collapse of the arrangements for bringing gold here from the Continent.

A special meeting of the Executive Committee of the New York Metal Trades Association, which includes the proprietors of the shipbuilding yards of New York and its vicinity, was held yesterday at 203 Broadway to take action regarding the strike of the boilermakers and shipbuilders at the yards of Townsend Downey, in Shooter Island.

THE author of "Millionaire Households" has been one of those "managing housekeepers" who are the guiding spirits of homes she tells about. Apparently, also, there is an admixture of moral purpose, for one meets much incidental philosophizing on the "nice sense of justice" which should belong to employers, the "conscientiousness" which good servants should exhibit, and, in general, on the "Ideal Life" and its attainability.

Two books on the city problem in England and America are in preparation by the Macmillan Company. They are "American Cities and Their Problems," by Delos F. Wilcox, Ph. D., and "British Cities and Their Problems," by Milo Roy Maltbie. Ph.D. author of English Government of To-day," "Street Railway of Chicago,"

The title poem of this unequal collection is more original in conception than happy in execution. It represents the god Apollo in colloquy with Keats on the subject of Browning's poetry. Keats is supposed to have been recalled to earth, nolens volens, by his plagiarists, while Apollo, "tired of Heaven's celestial play," is seeking a new thrill among the haunts of mortals.

In the Grant Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday appeared one Michael McDermott, who displayed to Magistrate Steers four big bumps on the top of his head, a swelling on the right cheek, another swelling on the left cheek, a bruise on the chin, a pair of blackened eyes, and a lump in the back of the neck.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Congressional Directory, containing the biographies of members of the Fifty-eighth Congress, written by themselves, came out yesterday. The autobiographies of the new members are full of interest, as revealing the frame of mind in which a man is when he has just become a full-fledged solon.

Maximillan Toch delivered a lecture before the Chemists' Club last night on the "Permanent Protection of Steel and Iron." He illustrated the condition of some of the steel skeletons of the skyscrapers and said:

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- Increased firmness developed in the market to-day, and, while price enanges were as a rule unimportant, they generally were in the direction of improvement. This was notably the case with Consolidated Lake Superior preferred, which advanced from 20 1/2 to 22 3/4.

Svea must be ever so old, for "she is a far-off cousin of Britannia and Columbia." She stands as the tutelary guardian of Sweden, and what she says must be listened to with reverence. She does not pamper her children, though she may insist with just pride that they are singularly honest, brave, and capable.

The Cathedral Library Association has published a memorial to the late Archbishop Corrigan in the form of a highly ornate octavo volume of 234 pages, bound up purple cloth, which contains many half-tone portraits of the Archbishop at various stages of his career and a number of pictures of the larger Roman Catholic edifices in which he was especially interested.

The neighbors of John Van Steinberg, an old man, of 92 Pine Street, Brooklyn, who died on Wednesday, poor and in need as they thought, were greatly surprised yesterday to learn that he possessed $50,000 in money and real estate. Since the death of his wife, about two years ago, he had lived alone in a single room in a tenement and he had little to do with his neighbors.

THE drama from which Mr. Baring's book takes its title has practically but two characters, although eleven are named in the list of the dramatis personae. The Black Prince and Margaret (afterward Alice Ferrers) are the two whose characteristic traits are brought out by the text, and in whose presence the others are made to appear superfluous.

LONGMANS, GREEN CO. are publishing this week a work which has been awaited with some eagnerness by students of psychology. It is Frederick W.H. Myers's "Human Personality and Its Survival of Bodily Death," edited by Richard Hodgson and Alice Johnson, in two large Svo volumes.

A large crowd of wrestling enthusiasts filled the large hall of the New Polo Athletic Association, Park Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, last night to witness the opening rounds in the annual wrestling championship contest of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States.

The bears got decidedly the best of it yesterday in their battle against the cotton bulls, and prices in all the active options took a decided tumble. The activity and excitement were not as great as they had been on previous days, and the drop in quotations was more in the nature of a gentle sliding away than a sudden and abrupt collapse.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday affirmed the decision of Justice William J. Gaynor at Special Term in sustaining writs of habeas corpus and certiorari, and in discharging Rosie Frank, May Clark, and Mamie Smith from the State Reformatory for Women at Bedford. The Frank and Clark women had been convicted and sentenced by Magistrate Crane, and Mamie Smith, by Magistrate Pool.

Though the library of Daniel F. Appleton, soon to be sold by Bangs Co., contains many modern rarities, its chief feature is the fine special collection of Bibles and Prayer Books. First in literary and bibliographical importance is the Coverdale Bible, 1535, the first English Bible, probably printed at Antwerp for or by Jacob Van Meteren.

Clement K. Shorter in The London Sphere. "Wisdom While You Wait" is the title of a little book that has so far been privately printed, the authors of which are supposed to be Mr. Charles Graves and Mr. E.V. Lucas. The book is a satire on the Encyclopaedia Britannica and the enterprise of The Times in promoting the sale of that publication.

District Attorney JEROME encounters many difficulties in his attempt to convict RICHARD CANFIELD of the offense of keeping a gambling house. Some of his witnesses in the preliminary examination refused to testify, and now the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court decides that they are privileged not to testify.

LONDON Feb. 26 -- The life of Robert Buchanan, by Harriet Jay his sister-in-law, has the merit of giving a truthful portrait of the man. As a rule, this cannot be said of a biography written by one who is in warm sympathy with the subject.

WASHINGTON, N. J., March 6 -- The entire end wall of a three-story building, forty by eighty feet, of the compressed air plant of the Empire Iron and Steel Company, at Oxford Furnace, three miles northwest of this place, fell without warning at 7:25 o'clock this morning and killed instantly Benjamin Jones, fireman, aged sixty-four years, and a Hungarian laborer, aged about forty.

Myrta Lockett Avary as "editor" of these reminiscences has succeeded in producing a very interesting collection of recollections, which, possessing the personal element to an unusual degree, prove delightful reading. There are both laughter and tears in the book. Nellie Grey, the heroine, was very young and had only been married a few months when her husband was called to the front as a member of the cavalry.

The Hudson Realty Company has bought from the various owners 129 to 145 West Seventeenth Street, old stables on a plot 193 by 92 by 199.2 by 92. The property will probably be resold in parcels suitable for improvement with store and loft buildings.

DOWN to the present day the long list of Dante books that has come from scholarly Teutonic pens shows little more than a vast number of contributions to etymology and to that theological pilosophy which may or may not have given Luther a slight prick onward toward his break with Rome.

LORD LISTER'S is a name worthy of all respect. There is no operation performed to-day not carried out in exact pursuance with the rules laid down by Lister. Because of the special precautions advised by him, relating to the surgeon's knife and the dressing of wounds, mortality has been marvelously diminished.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The criticism of Frank Norris and his posthumous novel, "The Pit," which appeared in a recent number of THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, though dispassionate. I hardly consider clear-sighted or correct. I am glad that the reviewer left himself the loophole of escape from his rather sweeping statements in admitting that opinions will differ rather widely as to the extent of Mr. Norris's achievements.

Capt. Mahan modestly rejects for himself the title of historian, but in his address before the American Historical Association, which is the leading article in The Atlantic for March, he lets us into the secret of the very marked and distinctive success even he must acknowledge that he has won in picturing the events of the past.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 6 -- The convention of negro Presidents of the Agricultural Colleges adopted the following declaration of principles this afternoon:

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Interest in the Brownell and Sinclair court-martial cases, involving charges of cruelty by American officers in the Philippines, is revived by the appearance of the printed record of the proceedings in these and other similar trials.

Adolph Teitelbaum, an east side installment dealer, who has a record of having sent scores of judgment debtors to Ludlow Street Jail because of their not having paid, all charges on articles purchased from him, yesterday was fined for contempt of the Supreme Court by Justice Andrews.

Sir Alexander Mackenzie started in 1783 to extend the trade of the Northwest Fur Company through frozen Canada in opposition to the all-powerful Hudson's Bay Company. After the severest struggle ever known in this part of the world, during which one partner was murdered and several wounded, the intruders were admitted to a share of the trade in 1787.

The Manchester Guardian is, at least it was, the most important and representative British newspaper outside of London. And so, when The Manchester Guardian announces, as matter of fact, that the German Emperor, during his family visit to England two years ago, "denounced the Monroe Doctrine and its fruits in the most unmeasured terms," we are strongly inclined to believe that the announcement is accurate.
Trade reports to the several commercial agencies continue very favorable. Bradstreet's sums the situation up as follows:
Liebler Co. yesterday arranged the complete cast for the all-star production of "Romeo and Juliet," which commences at Albany April 27 and comes to New York May 25. The cast is as follows:

Another series of reproductions of the principal paintings in the "Wallace collection of Hertford House, London, collected and described by A.G. Temple, F.S.A., Director of the Guildhall Gallery, London, is in preparation at Manzi, Joyant Co. of this city, successors to the American branch of Goupil Co. of Paris.

THOMAS NELSON PAGE has just finished a long novel which will probably appear late in the Spring. It is now nearly five years since Mr, Page's first ambitious novel, "Red Rock," made its appearance and Its author's reputation as a novelist, although, in the meantime, "The Old Gentleman of the Black Stock" has been published -- but that is little more than a sketch.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--Senator German of Maryland was chosen to-day by his Democratic associates in the Senate as their parliamentary leader. This action was taken at a caucus attended by twenty-eight of the thirty-three Democratic Senators, the five absentees being out of the city.

The former home of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, has been sold for about $550,000, and it is understood that the new owners of the property will convert it into an apartment house or hotel.

LONDON, March 7 -- The report of Col. H.A. Ycrke, (Chief Inspecting Officer of the Board of Railways, a department of the Board of Trade,) who recently investigated American railroading methods on behalf of the Board of Trade, was issued last evening in a Blue Book.
PARIS, March 6 -- Prof. Gaston Paris, member of the French Academy and Professor of the College of France, died this morning.

It is just fifty-eight years since Leslie's "Memoirs of the Life of John Constable, R.A.," was published in London. It was, for the most part, a personal biography with just enough criticism of the man's art to show whence he gained his inspiration without being able to prophesy with any exactness as to his future influence.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- An amicable settlement has been made in the case of Mrs. David Bispham, wife of the well-known baritone of the Maurice Grau Opera Company, who came from England two weeks ago to obtain support for herself and the custody of her children. The settlement in the case was made at the Hotel Walton, this city, by John Scott, representing Mrs. Bispham, and S. Davis Page, who acted for her husband.

NOT far from Paris there is a forest -- that of Fontainebleau. This forest is by no means primeval, and, as forests go, not extensive, for it covers an area of some fifty miles, and is not more than ten miles in breadth.

It is a somewhat curious fact, revealed by the researches inspired by the fall of the Campanile di San Marco a few months ago, that there is really no satisfying book in English dealing with Venice which contains an authoritative record of its monuments and at the same time shows what the city has meant to various historical periods.

The Chautauqua textbooks are nothing if not practical, and this one is a model of intelligent compression and adaptation to its end. The legend "multum in parvo" should be placed upon its title page. In 275 duodecimo pages Miss Hapgood surveys the literary output of Russia from the ancient period when fairy tales, folk-lore poetry, epic songs, and religious ballads found oral expression only, to the seventh or modern period of Gorky and Nadson.

ALBANY, March 6 -- What both sides to the educational controversy raging in Albany are most interested in finding out just now is on what side of the question Senator Platt stands. Each side claims to have him committed.
