"The Star Dreamer" has certain fine and unusual qualities which should command for it more than ordinary interest. As a story it grips the reader at once and does not lose its hold until its last word is said. Its characters are very living and their mutual relations are subtle and well sustained.

A pretty little miss of fifteen years, attired in a velvet dress, a red jacket, and a large picture hat, tied up the Eighth Avenue surface cars during the rush hours last evening with the assistance of a little black spaniel. The trouble was all caused because the rules of the railway company forbid passengers carrying dogs on the cars, and because the girl objected to walking from Fourteenth to Eighty-fourth Street.

The formation of negro clubs or societies throughout the North and South to promote the nomination and election of Mr. ROOSEVELT as President must necessarily lead to different results in the two sections. In the North these clubs of "Roosevelt Invincibles" may serve the same ends as like organizations of special classes of white voters.

An English rendering of Jerome Doucet's fantastic little stories has just appeared in print in this country in a form which calls forth special mention even where the literary work of the editor of La Revue Illustree is well known. The greatest praise that a book car receive is that its form and appearance are suggestive of its contents.

BOSTON, March 6 -- The money market holds firm, with business still quiet. Apparently there are no surplus funds here Call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time loans, on collateral, 4 1/2@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans, on mercantile paper, 5@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10@5c discount; clearings, $22,067,352; balances, $1,611,883.

An air of mystery pervaded the convention of the Dressmakers' Protective Association in Masonic Temple just before the opening of the session yesterday afternoon. Nothing masculine, even in the way of uncanny Masonic initiations, could have filled the air -- the little the big crowd of women in the room had not absorbed -- with that peculiar electric thrill that betokens something interesting and unusual under way.

The March number of The Kindergarten Review (Springfield, Mass.,) contains articles on "School Hygiene," by Caroline T. Havens; "Froebel's Shadow Plays," by M.M Glidden; "Kindergarten Activities," by Katherine Beebe, and other appropriate matter.

A dinner, a reception, and a musicale were among the incidents of yesterday. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Maclay Bull gave the dinner, Theodore Bjornsten the musicale, and Mrs. Frank McCoy and Miss McCoy the reception. The Badminton Club will meet this afternoon, and there are to be several dinners in the evening.
MELBOURNE, March 6 -- The Government of Victoria has appointed Thomas Tait, Traffic Manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway. Chief Commissioner of the Victorian Railways.

LONDON, March 6 -- Messrs. A. C. Black will soon publish "The World's Children," by Mortimer Menpes, the text written by his daughter, Dorothy Menpes. It is a companion to the same author's and artist's "World Pictures," and contains more than 100 illustrations, printed in colors, which have been engraved by another daughter of this popular artist, Maud Menpes.

The party of Chattanoogans who are in attendance on little Miss Nell Chambliss, the daughter of Mayor Alexander W. Chambliss of that city, who this afternoon will name the United State cruiser Chattanooga at Blizabeth, N.J., arrived in this city yesterday.

GEORGE MEREDITH, having completed his seventy-fifth year, in good health and the enjoyment of the honest recognition of a very large number of his fellow countrymen and countrywomen as the foremost English novelist, if not the foremost Englishman of letters in this era, the fact that he is "undistinguished by any title or honor "naturally occurs to English Journalists as a subject of comment.

LONDON, March 7 -- Impressed by the recent speeches of Ambassadors Choate and Cambon in London and by Herr Delbruck's observations in the Preussische Jahrbucher, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, the Siecle concludes that Great Britain is being wooed by the nations which two years ago took a very different tone.
BUFFALO, March 7.--Early this morning the police are at work on a new clue in the Burdick murder mystery.

It is no exaggeration to say that fully nine-tenths of the speculative element arrived in Wall Street yesterday, firmly convinced that the market was in for a bad break and that even at the opening semi-demoralization would appear. Prices on Thursday had closed at practically the lowest of the day, with confident selling and not overaggressive buying.

SAYVILLE, L.I., March 6 -- After receiving a great fright from what they thought was an attempt upon their lives by a criminal or maniac, the life-saving crew of the Point o' Woods station night before last captured a young New Yorker, apparently demented, who was sent at once to his home in the city.

The publications or the Mississippi Historical Society have been issued for the sixth consecutive year under the editorship of Franklin L. Riley, Secretary of the society. The book has grown from a modest little pamphlet of 110 pages in 1898, containing 11 contributions, to a substantial octavo volume of 568 pages, with 10 illustrations and maps and 27 articles.
Statement from Montreal that another large cotton mill is to be built at Shawinigan, in that province.

-- Capt. PIPER has been talking to the London reporters about the condition of the London streets and the management of their traffic, in comparison with New York, and his remarks are so complimentary to the older city that its inhabitants are -- wondering how in the world we eudure troubles in comparison with which they own seem to be happinesses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The President declares that he shall not be wholly prevented from appointing to Federal offices some representatives of eight millions of Southern citizens because of mere color. Perhaps one in a hundred of his Southern appointees is an Afro-American citizen.
ST. LOUIS, March 7 -- "We are working on the answer to the injunction," said Judge Irwin, chief counsel for the Wabash employes, to-day.

The remarkable volume of business reported within the last week, while it contained few individual transactions of a noteworthy character, has served to emphasize the fact that seldom has there existed a readier market than at present for so wide a range of properties.

The errors pointed out in various school histories of the United States, in their chapters on the civil war, as presented to the Board of Education at its recent meeting by the President of the board. H.V. Boynton, are here given in detail. The books referred to are not used as text books in the schools of this city.

HOW did I become a detective?" echoed a Central Office man whose name is painfully familiar to all the big criminals in the country. "Perhaps you think it was from reading Old Sleuth stories when I was young. But it wasn't. To tell the truth, I don't think the man ever lived who had his future pointed out to him so plainly us I had.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The fifth annual indoor meet of Georgetown University was held at Convention Hall to-night. An immense crowd was present. Many of the events were close and exciting. The last event, the relay race between the University of Pennsylvania and Georgetown University was the feature of the evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To one who is at all familiar with modern views of education it seems strange that the reading of the Bible in the public schoo's should be opposed on such frivolous grounds as those suggested by one of your recent correspondents. No hint is given as to how the simple reading of the Bible without note or comment would "force" the pupil to endure some "theological teaching."

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Graeme Stewart was nominated for the Mayoralty by the Republican City Convention in session at the First Regiment Armory this afternoon. This choice was made by a vote of 602 for Stewart and 338 for John M. Harlan. Mr. Harlan, the defeated candidate, made a short speech praising Mr. Stewart highly, and pledging him his support in the coming campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Director William R. Merriam of the Census Bureau today called upon the President and tendered his resignation, to take effect May 15. He said that he placed the date so far in advance because he wanted to complete some of the work in the bureau before he left.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 7 -- A letter signed by George and Martha Washington brought $1,150 at to-day's sale of Harold Peirce's library, in Davis Harvey's book auction rooms. The name of the purchaser, a New York collector, was not divulged. He was styled "James," and it was said that was his Christian name.
Basing her action on somewhat novel grounds Mrs. Julia L. Morris, now of this city, has begun an action in the Supreme Court to have annulled her marriage to Benjamin F. Morris.

The increase in the imports of the materials of manufactures to which we called attention last month continues and in progressive ratio. According to the latest bulletin of the Bureau of Statistics, the value of these imports for the month of Jaunary was $42,328,478, which was about $5,000,000, or 14 per cent., more than for the same month of last year.

Because the Erie Railroad delayed his homecoming on several nights in December, and prevented him from having his dinner at the accustomed time, George A. Miller, an attorney of 54 Wall Street and a member of the firm of Carter Ledyard, has brought a Supreme Court action against the corporation, demanding monetary damages to the extent of $100.

LOUISVILLE, March 7 -- Announcement that the Inter-State Commerce Committee will sit in New York on March 27 to continue the hearing of the case of the Railroad Commission of Kentucky against the Atlantic Coast Line in the celebrated Louisville and Nashville "merger" case is of more than ordinary interest on account of the expressed purpose of John W. Gates to "say some things."

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -- President Buchanan of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers, who is in this city to-day, issued a statement giving the reasons for the general strike against the American Bridge Company.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Navy Ap- propriation act makes a considerable in- crease in the number of officers of the navy, beginning with the grade of Lieutenant Commander. There are now 170 line officers of that grade on the navy register, and seven additional numbers advanced for meritorious service.

The Philharmonic Society will give its seventh concert of the season on Saturday evening, preceded by the usual public rehearsal on Friday afternoon. The soloist will be Mme. Roger-Miclos, pianist, and the programme will be as follows:

FOR the last few weeks a gang of laborers has been engaged in what appears to be the simple task of dumping mud into the Harlem River opposite One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street. A stranger might well have asked who wanted to block the channel nearest the Manhattan shore.

CONCORD, N.H., March 7 -- The voters of this State on Tuesday will pass on ten proposed constitutional amendments submitted by the convention summoned in accordance with the will of the electors expressed at the election in November, 1900. Five of the proposed changes are of minor importance, and the five which are specially engaging attention throughout New Hampshire are as follows:

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., March 7 -- In the County Court to-day the Mountain Lake Electric Railroad Company was fined $3,000 by Judge Mills for manslaughter in the second degree in causing the accident on July 4, 1902, in which fourteen persons were killed and sixty injured.

Leoncavallo, the composer of "Pagliacci," recently expressed himself as follows in regard to his new opera, "Roland of Berlin": "Day and night I am at work on this new opera The report spread some weeks ago that I was engaged on two other compositions is false. The only thing that is true is that I bought texts, 'Les Roses de Noel, by Vauclaire, and Le Chevalier d'Eon,' by Cain.

Conditions which unfavorably affected the Stock Exchange market were to a minor extent responsible for the course of prices in the outside market yesterday, and very few of the active issues ended the day without some loss. The trading, however, was for the most part too limited to attract much attention, and the only securities which were followed with special interest were those which for some days had occupied foremost places in the market.
AH doan' bilieve in convictin any man on subcumstanshal evidence," said the deacon.

IT IS an absolute truth, however much some people may object to its assertion, that there is no one totally free from superstition. Even those who poohpooh current superstitions are influenced by them, unconsciously perhape; but if they were to inquire carefully into some of the motives for many of the commonest acts of their lives they would find ideas based upon superstition regulating them.

Horgan Slattery, architects, during Mayor Van Wyck's administration drew plans for mud scows and also got jobs on public buildings ranging from a $100 alteration to a $4,000,000 Hall of Records. Everything artistic and inartistic was put in the way of the Tammany "official" architects because they had the support of John F. Carroll and Mayor Van Wyck.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- In overhauling a number of dust-covered boxes in the attic of the Peabody Museum at Yale. Dr. MacCurdy, Curator of the anthropological collection, came across an unopened box several days ago that has proved to be one of the most interesting finds at Yale in recent years.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 7 -- Mrs. Spottswood D. Schenck has rented the Whitney Warren cottage on Clay Street and Parker Avenue for the coming season. Mrs. Schenck occupied a cottage on Rhode Island Avenue last Summer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Monday morning last, in an editorial commenting on the speech of Sir Charles Tupper relating to the members of the Alaska boundary tribunal appointed by the United States Government. THE TIMES said that those gentlemen whom Sir Charles characterized as "rabid partisans" are "simply three very well-informed Americans, who believe, as all Americans believe, that our position in respect to the true Alaskan boundary is impossible!"

Bringing, as he says, a personal message from J.A. Bailey of the Barnum Bailey Greatest Show on Earth, Tody Hamilton announces that there will be no street parade of the circus in New York this year. Tody says the announcement will be hailed with sorrow by a number of people "conservatively estimated at a million," of whom none sorrow more than Mr. Bailey and himself.

MRS. CLARENCE MACKAY, the youngest of New York's social leaders, is one of the most independent of them all in thought and in action. It is not a defiant independence, but that of one who goes her own way not caring the lift of an eyebrow what others think or say.

BECAUSE a careless booking agent substituted Eleanor for the name Edward, a man from Buffalo, who with his family was a passenger on one of the biggest and fleetest liners afloat, had no end of trouble the other day with the Immigration Inspectors when he started to land at the pier in the North River.

NEW ORLEANS, March 7 -- Telamon's victory in the Oakland Handicap, worth $1,380 to the winner, to-day strengthened the case against Buchanan, the jockey, whose suspension was due to the horse's poor showing. Lindsey rode him, and, though, he outclassed his field, restrained him for the first half mile, sent him to the front on the stretch turn, und won easily at the end.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The recent action of Congress in appropriating the sum of $300,000 for the investigation of and experimenting in submarine and subsurface torpedo-boats is considered by many naval authorities to be the wisest step yet taken by the Government toward the solution of this phase of warfare.

THAT'S just my case exactly," said the woman in the brown velveteen. "I'm bothered to death with peddlers and agents. We live in a large apartment house whose vestibule door is always unlocked; consequently those destroyers of peace read our names, ring the bell, and walk up.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Roosevelt has addressed to Baron Sternburg, the German Minister, a reply to the suggestion recently made at the instance of Emperor William, that the unveiling of the statue of Frederick the Great, which is to be erected in the grounds of the new Army War College, be postponed until 1904.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 7 -- William C. Whitney, August Belmont, F.R. Hitchcock, and other millionaire turfmen, who have established Winter quarters for their thoroughbreds in South Carolina, are delighted with this Southern climate for training purposes. Mr. Whitney's stables in Aiken were practically rebuilt last year in order to afford greater room for the runners.

A COMING rival to the Van Cortlandt manor house in Van Cortlandt Park in historical and colonial museum interest is the King manor house at Jamaica, L.I. Like the Van Cortlandt house, the King house is owned by the city, being one of the gifts it acquired by virtue of the Greater New York charter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No fair-minded person can read the state- ment which appeared in your paper of this morning, giving the view of President Roosevelt regarding his Southern policy, without a feeling of respect. The record of the President for fearless integrity and high purposes can never be questioned, and there is no man in the country who has more fully invited the highest regard of all classes of citizens.

LATE arrivals from Paris are laughing over an incident that befell two English ladies in the gay city. They had ventured into one of the bonbongeries or bakeries, which in Paris are so attractive that they are frequented in preference to a cafe by persons in search of a light luncheon.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

NEVER before in the history of Long Island has there been so much contention and argument among its residents as has been caused by Senator Brown's recent introduction in the New York State legislature of a bill to prohibit Spring shooting of wild fowl.
EVERYBODY seems to have been hunting up George Ade stories since the author came to New York to see his "Sultan of Sulu" at Wallack's, but there's one that seems to have been overlooked in the rush.

BOSTON, March 6 -- The annual product of raw sugar is reckoned at approximately 8,000,000 more than half of which is used in the United States. Of this vast amount practically every pound has to be tested before it goes to the sugar refiners, who eventually prepare it for domestic consumption.

ARTHUR P. GORMAN, again a Senator from the State of Maryland, and appointed by his party associates in the Senate to be their leader in that body, becomes once more a man to be reckoned with in Democratic politics. He is a master politician. No Democrat in public or private life surpasses him in respect to experience in political management.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "T.G.," in your issue of Monday shows up the bigotry and pig-headedness of the clergy in relation to exhibitions of bravery "in the peaceful walks of life," and, after reading his communication the veriest dunce cannot fail to see the relevancy of the criticism.

Other than the opera at the Irving Place Theatre Monday night, held over from last week because of the late arrival of a boat hearing the singers, there are few changes of bill announced for this week. The sensation offered is at Proctor's Twenty-third Street house, where a play by Roland B. Molineux will be produced about 8:30 o'clock Molineux will be produced about 8:30 o'clock but the title is "Was It a Dream?"

CINCINNATI, March 7 -- A deal for the purchase of 2,000 cars of soft coal now on the tracks of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad between this city and Russell, Ky., failed to-day, the railroad declining to deliver to other than the original consignees.

WEST POINT, March 7 -- The fencing tournament between West Point and Columbia this afternoon was interesting and exciting. The gymnasium could have held a much larger audience than witnessed the contest. Enough were present, however, to give generous applause when skillful parrying turned the scale to either side.

The Navy Department at Washington, through the Bureau of Equipment, has by a special order dated Feb. 26 last, notified the commanders of all vessels in commission that the department stands ready, and is anxious, to furnish complete athletic equipments to the various vessels in the active service.

HAVANA, March 2 -- The 24th of February is marked on the calendars of Cuba as a red-letter day. It is one of the two great days of the year, the other being in the Fall. Feb. 24 marks the opening of the last war. Eight years ago the revolution broke out all over the island.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Minister from Salvador and Senora Lopez had as guests at dinner this evening the Mexican Ambassador and Senor de Azpiroz, the Minister from Haiti and Mme. Leger, the Cuban Minister and Senora de Quesada, Senor Lazo Arriaga, the Minister from Guatemala; Senor Calvo, the Minister from Costa Rica; Senor Corea, the Minister from Nicaragua; Mme. Perez, Miss Gouverneur, and Miss Elsen.

A BILL, has recently been introduced in the Legislature providing for an appropriation of $10,000 to be used for the purchase of the old Billopp house, which stands within the manor of Bentley, at Tottenville, S.I. Erected in 1668, this building is rich in historical associations, and it is proposed to make of it a historical museum.

THERE were so many pairs of glasses in the room that it put spots on the woman's sight just to look at them. She had no idea what kind she wanted, but after the optician had worked with her for about three hours she decided that the glasses that gave her most satisfaction were a pair with big round lenses set in black rubber frame.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial in to-day's issue, "Strikes Stopped by Injunction," you observe that "the voluntary agreement of these trainmen and firemen to work for stipulated wages is a contract." Let us inquire a little more closely into this and see if this so-called "contract " really is a contract of the kind which you imply.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Evidence is accumulating that if the State of Virginia persists in the purpose to enforce her undoubted legal right of placing Gen. Robert E. Lee's statue in the Capitol there will be a plentiful stirring up of sectional feeling. Western Congressmen are particularly violent on the subject, and the Lee statue will not get into Statuary Hall without a recrudescence of "bloody shirt" speeches.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much pleasure your editorial on "The Druggist and the Public." The article is timely and will, I trust, be followed by others until public sentiment is sufficiently aroused to demand the proper protection of the community.

An article, believed to have been either written or directly inspired by the German Kaiser, has just bene published in the Grenzbote, the Berlin periodical in which the Imperial views on "Babel and Bibel" were recently set forth. It is an essay on the comparative naval force of Great Britain and Germany.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7 -- It was learned through The Alumni Weekly today that the little song which is being sung by Gertrude Quinlan, leading woman in George Ade's "The Sultan of Sulu," is the work of a Princeton sophomore -- Maurice P. Dunlap of St. Paul, Minn. The title of the song is "The Queer Little Ostrich," and Dunlap wrote both words and music.

Baseball practice has opened up well at Princeton, and Capt. Pearson and Coach Hillebrand are working hard to get a representative team together from the first game against Rutgers on March 28. The Southern trip opens two weeks later. The freshman squad, which was called out nearly two weeks ago.

Samuel D. Davis, one of the partners in the firm of Samuel D. Davis Co., bankers and brokers, formerly at 36 Wall Street, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities to the amount of $988,934 and assets to the amount of $55,178, in stocks, , held as security for creditors. He has also individual assets of $22,803, of which $22,000 are held as security for creditors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Desiring to speak always with perfect respect of the President of the United States, it may still be justly remarked that Mr. Roosevelt, in his negro appointments, is illustrating the disadvantage of combined intense partisanship and extraordinary self-will.

NEWARK, N.J., March 7 -- The Coroner's jury impaneled to conduct an inquest into the Clifton Avenue grade crossing disaster of Feb. 19 last, returned a verdict at 3:45 o'clock this afternoon, holding the North Jersey Street Railway Company chiefly responsible for the accident in that it failed to install proper safeguards at the crossing and neglected other necessary precautions.

LONDON, March 7 -- The turn of the month brought little relief to the money market. The consols settlement increased the demand for cash on Monday and caused an addition to the market's indebtedness to the Bank of England, which was already much higher than is usual at this season.

The dry goods commission firm of Dresser Co. at 15 and 17 Greene Street, whose specialties were hosiery, webbing, and Japanese silks, confirmed yesterday Wall Street rumors of the past week by assigning for the benefit of creditors to Charles S. MacKenzie, a lawyer of 346 Broadway. The assignment was filed just as the County Clerk's office was closing.

IT happened at the annual luncheon of a very pretentious women's club. The reporter of -- call it The Period -- was late, and the Chairman of the club's Press Committee placed her at a table with some personal friends of that Chairman instead of at the press table. There were four women already seated.

Early last October President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University addressed a circular letter to each professor in Columbia University, Barnard College, and Teachers College, inviting a free discussion on the recommendations for a shortened college course, made in his first report to the Trustees.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hardly think that I differ from THE TIMES concerning Mr. Hobson, although the view-points may not be the same. My contention is simply this: Because of his personal daring on one occasion we fell down and worshipped, in his person, the individual strenuous hero.

ONE of the bits of club news of the week is the possible moving of the Lotos Club. The Lotos occupies two brownstone houses on the west side of Fifth Avenue, between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets. Right in the rear of the club is the famous Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, of which for so many years the venerable Dr. Armitage was rector.

BERLIN, March 7 -- Emperor William was saluted this evening by four acres of automobiles, massed in ranks thirty wide and ten deep in the Lustgarten, opposite the Old Palace. The great square blazed with 1,200 electric torches, each machine having four of them, while the garden was rimmed with immense, cheering crowds.

A Sister of the Sacred Heart, in the garb of her order, yesterday appeared in the Tombs Police Court as complaining witness against a man, declared by the police to be the "Lone Burglar of Harlem," who single handed has committed a great number of bold burglaries in the upper section of the city and baffled the efforts of the police to capture him for upward of two years.

THE immense riches of the Philippine forests, the great varieties of species, and splendid size and quality of the fine cabinet woods that grow there, continue to astonish the foresters whom the Government has sent to the islands. Nothing but the vaguest estimates of the amount and value of the timber growing there has been made, but more than half of the area of the islands is surely under forest cover.

Readers of the newspapers have observed with interest, and many of them, doubtless, with regret, that the semimonthly dinner of the Architectural League disagreed with one of the most accomplished and instructive of the guides, philosophers, and friends of that organization.
DO you know," said the girl with the gray eyes, "I think he is simply horrid."

TOM ATWOOD was an athlete, and a good one. He-had played left guard on the 'Varsity in a year when that meant a good deal: he was the best boxer in college: altogether he would have been picked out as a man eminently able to take care of himself. Yet he fell.

CINDY lifted the cat to her knee and stroked its fur while she gazed into the fire: long and earnestly she looked at the flickering flames without say in a word. Ezra glanced over the top of his paper and said, after a slight pause:

THE "Sportsman's Paradise" has not yet been identified in spite of the efforts of sportsmen from all parts of United States during the two weeks the Sportsmen's Show has been in progress and the aggressive claims made the literature distributed by railroad agents proprietors of resorts for gunners and anglers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The marked ability of the present incumbent of the Bishopric of New York, of the Protestant Episcopal Church, has so completely raised the office above the mere limits of a religious association that the "burning controversy" regarding the appointment of a coadjutor or the division of the diocese becomes a matter of public interest.

BOSTON, March 7 -- The American Board's deputation to South Africa, which is about to leave here on its mission, will consist of its editorial secretary, the Rev. Dr. E.E. Strong, the Rev. Dr. Sidney Strong of Oak Park, Ill., and F.O. Winslow of Norwood. The deputation will assemble in London in April and arrange with the British Colonial Office the details of their passage through South Africa.
DR. H.E. ARNOLD, the apostie of games as a factor in education, and who is in charge of the physical training in the New Haven Normal School, declares that most people cannot count three.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -- Very little business was done here to-day, the sales amounting to only 16,441 shares and $36,800 bonds. It was the general opinion on the Street that unless a further decline in New York stocks necessitates it, liquidation in the purely local issues has run its course, for the time being, at least.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Recommittal of the New York Police bill by the Senate has causea more talk of scandal than anything that has occurred at Albany this Winter. It was common gossip among Senators, as well as outsiders, that the real motive which actuated the five Republican Senators in voting for recommittal was to hold the bill up until an agreement could be secured by which the three-platoon amendment could be attached.

The management of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit lines has issued a circular to the guards, conductors, and motormen in its employ urging courtesy and helpfulness to all passengers. If the requirement is enforced by recognition of those employes who observe it and by adequate disciplining of those who violate it, much improvement can be made and in a short time.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 7 -- John E. Madden, the noted Kentucky horseman, who is training a big string of colts and fillies at Churchill Downs, declares that the early racing of two-year-olds is not injurious to them, and cites a number of instances to prove his contention. He says:

MONTREAL, March 7 -- The Richelieu and Ontario Navigation Company's magnificent steamboat, the Montreal, in course of construction, was burned to the water's edge to-night. A huge crowd was attracted by the conflagration and several hundred persons found their way to the roof of an Allan Line shed, which, unable to stand the weight, collapsed.

BUFFALO, March 7 -- In their eagerness to solve the mystery of the assassination of Edwin L. Burdick, the police to-day made a false move. Miss Marion Hutchinson, a church choir singer, was kept in custody for five hours and then released after a writ of habeas corpus had been sued out.

There were several very close finishes in the trial and final heats of the swimming races which were decided in the natatorium of the New York Athletic Club last night. In the handicap events those who finished first and second in the majority of the trial heats were only inches apart, and in one instance the judges could not divide Goodwin and Wenck, and allowed them to compete in the final heat.

BOSTON, March 7 -- The week closes with the money market in a firm position. The supply of loanable funds is very small, as most of the banks are well loaned up. Call loans, 5 @ 6 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 4 3/4 @ 5 1/2 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 16 2-3 cents discount.

PITTSBURG, March 7 -- The Directors of the American Trust Company have asked the stockholders of the institution to vote on a proposition to increase the capital stock of the concern from $1,000,000 to $2,500,00 at $500 per share, for the purpose of absorbing five local financial institutions -- the Columbia National, Tradesmen's National, Savings, Fourth National, and Pennsylvania Trust -- three of which will be liquidated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have taken notice of the criticisms of my letter of Feb. 27, which appeared in your editorial of an early day of the following week. I hope you will give me space for reply.

Although almost every other sport was more or less adequately represented at the annual Sportsmen's Show in the Madison Square Garden during the past two weeks, automobiling was only represented by a few gasoline motors exhibited by the launch makers and not a single completed vehicle was shown.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 -- At the twelfth annual meeting of the Harvard Teachers' Association the question discussed was "The Time Limit of Secondary Education."

THIS is the season of the year when the young girl's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of birds. It is not unnatural that the small girl who feels that she is growing too old to play at housekeeping with her dolls and whose housewifely tastes have no special medium for development should interest herself in the housekeeping of small living creatures which can be kept in any ordinary house, not excepting the New York flat.
Ex-Gov. William Pinkney Whyte resigned on Thursday last the office of City Solicitor of Baltimore, which he has held for just three years.

WILKESBARRE, Fenn., March 7 -- Attorney Ira H. Burns of the independent coal operators is authority for the statement that it is not likely that the Strike Commissioners will decide to accept the new plan of paying miners by weight of coal, which they discussed at the secret session on Thursday.

The cruiser Chattanooga, built for the United States Navy, was successfully launched yesterday afternoon at the yards of the Crescent Shipbuilding Company at Elizabethport, N.J., in the presence of one of the most distinguished gatherings of Southerners ever assembled on a similar occasion since the building of the new navy began.

BERLIN, March 7 -- Although the Tageblatt reports that the trouble caused by the Bishop of Treves has been satisfactorily settled by the Vatican. I learn from a well informed source that such is not the case.

BEFORE anybody can understand how Nathaniel Dow came to be accused of spending his substance in riotous living it will be necessary to go back to the financial reform inaugurated by Mrs. Dow when they moved down to Sixty-fourth Street.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 7 -- "Athletic Club Closed" is the wording of a sign posted on the door of an institution started last Fall by the Rev. J.H. Selden, pastor of the Congregational Church. It was planned as a resort for young men designed to keep them away from saloons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Women societies are holding meetings and adopting resolutions full of the bitterest criticism against the loathsome conditions of our street cars. They find no words harsh enough against the indecency of crowded cars, in which men and women are huddled together like sardines.

TALL grasses on the river bank waved gently; a blundering bumblebee tumbled upon the broad face or a burdock leaf, too overladen with pollen to fly; interlocked branches traced a lacework pattern on the ground, and the September sunlight shimmering upon the bank and water was like a benediction.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the letter of President Roosevelt as published in to-day's TIMES, and I am tempted to rush into print in order to express agreement with the sentiment therein contained.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 7 -- The record of a phenomenal season is still being maintained in Atlantic City. The crowds on the island to-night are as far in excess of those of the same period of previous years as have been those of several weeks past over other Winter seasons. Almost every beach front hotel is crowded, and the smaller hotels are receiving their quota of the unprecedented influx.

The week began with the adjournment of Congress and the failure of the Aldrich bill, and ended with, the practical disappearance of the surplus reserve, Midweek the situation was clouded by false reports, which sprang -- or were sprung -- from nowhere and vanished, after having unsettled a situation already nervous about the closer working of the money market.

DERBY, Conn., March 6 -- An ancient house, the walls of which seem to be lined with gold, needing only to be tapped to shower forth coins, is a strange feature of the little rural village of Huntington Centre, near here. Six times within the past few years, when boards have been removed to make repairs, gold, silver, and copper coins have rolled out of the apertures.

Gov. Odell's mortgage tax plan and the full assessment policy of the present city administration were the subjects of discussion at the eleventh annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of Brokers of New York in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria last night. On the mortgage tax plan there was unanimity of opinion, and it was not the Governor's opinion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent publication of an article which appeared in your paper in connection with the loss of St. Edmund's Chapel property has furnished matter for considerable comment and agitation among the members of that body. Many feel deeply aggrieved on account of certain misleading statements which they justly contend have morally involved their honor and integrity as a Christian communion.

The bric-a-brac habit has not erewhile been wholly without the consideration of psychologists and others interested in obscure mental phenomena, but it has received nothing like the attention to which its importance entitles it. A feature of it which forces itself on the attention of the student at the outset is that it is progressive and generally incurable.

Greater weakness appeared in the outside market during the past week than during any previous week of the present year. The influences which governed the Stock Exchange market and which resulted in so many declines were held responsible for the losses suffered by outside stocks, though monetary conditions naturally affect the curb market less than they do the Stock Exchange market, because of the fact that very few outside stocks are car- ried on margin.

MRS. GILBERT tells in her inimitably humorous way of a lifelong friend of hers, an elderly maiden who is always sent for by nephews and nieces when an interesting event takes place in their households. This maiden aunt had occasion to visit the dentist some little time ago, and was accompanied by Mrs. Gilbert.

With the issuing of the programme of events for the annual Spring tournament of the Lakewood Polo Club, polo activity for the coming year may be said to have fair- ly commenced. This programme was is- sued yesterday by H.L. Herbert, Chaorman of the Polo Association, and it calls for the customary two contests, those for the Georgian Court cups, given by Mrs. George J. Gould, and the Herbert trophies, presented by H.L. Herbert.

LENT has brought no duliness in costumes. The sole concession made to the period of penitence and prayer was on Ash Wednesday, when the women in the parterre row at the opera were all garbed in white or black. There was an unusually large attendance on that evening, which made the general sobriety in coloring of the "glittering horseshoe" all the more noticeable.

NOTHING in modern journalism comes more nearly to the great heart of the people, or the heart of the great people, than those columns in the newspapers which tell about various articles of use and ornament that Dick, Tom, Harry, Susan, Jane, and Mary are now in possession of, but desire to exchange for something else, no matter much what it is.

ALBANY, March 7 -- A story of unusual human interest is revealed in a decision of the Court of Appealh. The case is that of "Brantingham vs. Huff, appellant -- udgment reversed, new trial granted, costs to abide event."

HUDSON, N.Y., March 7 -- Justice Betts, in special term in this city, to-day heard the application for a new trial in the case, of "Whitey" Sulivan, convicted of the murder of Matthew Wilson, a watchman, of Cobleskill, N.Y., in November, 1900. Sullivan was convicted and sentenced to be put to death on on before March 10.

Acting Inspector Walsh of the Fourth Inspection District, which includes the Tenderloin, engineered two highly exciting gambling raids in that precinct last night, on houses at 74 West Thirty-fifth Street, reputed to be operated by Mike Maher, and 122 West Thirty-fourth Street, of which "Lou" Betts is the alleged proprietor.

THE barber was in a communicative mood. The man who had just got into his chair had a very sparse growth of hair on the top of his head. The barber ran his hand over it the wrong way until it stood up on end, showing more than ever that, as a scalp crop, it was a failure.

THE traffic of commuters is on a larger scale than many people realize until they hear statistics. The brand-new commuter learned something with the opening of this month that surprised him. The new commuter is commuting from Summit, New Jersey, where he has been for not quite a month now.

LONDON, March 7 -- America must really be careful of her behavior. There is reason to believe that the Kaiser is deeply offended at her recent attitude respecting Venezuela, so it is not surprising that there should be much talk in Germany of the necessity of teaching the United States a lesson and punishing her for her democratic irreverence toward a ruler by divine right, the imperial master of many legions.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Statehood fight will be taken up again in the next Congress, and so far as Oklahoma is concerned it will no doubt prove successful. Oklahoma might have got in a year ago if she had not tied her fortunes to those of Arizona and New Mexico.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., March 7 -- The regular March term of the Supreme Court came to an abrupt ending here this week by the sudden illness of Justice Mattice, who presided. He is suffering from acute indigestion, and is now at his home in Oneonta.
"Everyman" has been burlesqued in London. The travesty is called "Every Man's Education." and the names of the chief characters are Knowledge, Oxford and Cambridge.
More than 2,000 targets were broken by the twenty-three men who participated in le weekly shoot of the Crescent Athletic club at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday.

Nothing of its kind "would know" how to be more interesting than the announcement that the chess masters now competing for much fame and little money at Monte Carlo have agreed to hold a supplementary tournament, after the completion of this one, which shall be strictly confined to the King's Gambit.

WHILE there may be no lack of persons who will deplore the general giving up of the theatres to musical comedies, there is at least one portion of the community to whom such a state of affairs is an unmixed blessing. No other form of theatrical entertainment provides the opportunity for the employment of so great a number of persons, unless it be, perhaps, the elaborate production of tragedy, which is an exception.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is announced that there is to be a new Bellevue Hospital at a cost to the city of $3,000,000. Is this the conclusion of a competent commission of physicians, familiar with the needs of the poor of the city, its present hospital accommodations, and the condition of the Bellevue Hospital of today?

WATERBURY, Conn., March 7 -- Chair- man Dillsworth of the National Board of the Street Railway Employes organization came here to-day on business in connection with the strike of the motormen and conductors of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company.

The weekly Clearing House statement is- sued yesterday shortly before the close of business made a much more unfavorable showing than generally had been expected. Reserves on all deposits decreased $5.284,925, reserves on deposits other than United States deposits decreased $5,272,730, loans decreased $10,503,000, specie decreased $8,011,800, legal tenders decreased $2,134,800, and deposits decreased $19,566,700.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The comments that appeared in your pa- per on Sunday from the Rev. R.M. Mackey regarding Bishop Worthington ought not to pass unnoticed.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Statehood fight will be taken up again in the next Congress, and so far as Oklahoma is concerned it will no doubt prove successful. Oklahoma might have got in a year ago if she had not tied her fortunes to those of Arizona and New Mexico.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., March 7 -- The regular March term of the Supreme Court came to an abrupt ending here this week by the sudden illness of Justice Mattice, who presided. He is suffering from acute indigestion, and is now at his home in Oneonta.
"Everyman" has been burlesqued in London. The travesty is called "Every Man's Education." and the names of the chief characters are Knowledge, Oxford and Cambridge.
More than 2,000 targets were broken by the twenty-three men who participated in le weekly shoot of the Crescent Athletic club at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday.

Nothing of its kind "would know" how to be more interesting than the announcement that the chess masters now competing for much fame and little money at Monte Carlo have agreed to hold a supplementary tournament, after the completion of this one, which shall be strictly confined to the King's Gambit.

FORT WORTH, Texas, March 4 -- In current phenomenal Southwestern progress agricultural development is the pacemaker. So extraordinary are records in that department that to recite some of them seems fairly to challenge credulity.

PARIS, March 7 -- A brilliant reception was given last Saturday by the British Ambassador and Lady Monson in honor of Princess Henry of Bat- tenberg, Princess Christian, and Princess Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein. Among the Americans present were Gen. and Mrs. Winslow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the midst of multitudinous complaints against the elevated and surface railway companies, not because they are not affording us complete satisfaction in the way of comfortable and convenient transportation, but because "they are not doing as well as they may," it occurs to me to sug- gest that perhaps we as citizens are not doing all that we may in the line of correcting these abuses.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 7 -- Nineteen men were drowned as a result of the capsizing of the ferryboat at Spier Falls this morning at 6:30 o'clock. Spier Falls is ten miles west of Glens Falls, on the Hudson River. More than 1,000 men are employed there at present in the construction of the mammoth dam of the Hudson River Power Company.

VICTORIA, B.C., March 7.--Trouble which for a week past has been brewing in the western division of the Canadian Pacific Railway has suddenly become serious. Originating with the discharge of a freight clerk, it has culminated this afternoon in a strike of employes of freight departments as far east as Winnipeg.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 7 -- Sub-Committees on Athletics from Yale and Harvard discussed a new set of rules to govern all athletics in the dual league at a meeting held in this city this afternoon. Walter Camp, Clive Duval, and George Chadwick represented Yale, and Prof. Ira Hollis, James M. Storrow, and E.R. Krumbhaar represented Harvard.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- Probably the most beautiful and elaborate ball ever given south of Washington was that at Whitehall, the residence here of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Flagler, last Tuesday night. It was a bal poudre. The guests, many of them leaders of New York society, numbered about 400.

WAGE COUPONS -- Edward M. Knox, the has manufacturer, has a custom in his factory by which his employes accept certain coupons, representing the value of work performed. The coupons are payable at the factory office on certain dates. Joseph Sabo, a hatmaker in the factory, received $10 worth of the coupons, but he either lost or had them stolen from him before presenting them for payment.

Society has at last settled down to the routine of Lent. Those who remain in town dine, go to lectures, sewing classes, and musicales, play a little bridge, attend church, and wait for Easter. Florida has had such a vogue this year that the attractions of its resorts, especially Palm Beach, have quite depleted New York of its fashionable population.

The slightly improved temper at Friday's closing was checked at Saturday's opening by quotations reflecting London's forebodings over the bank statement. But Wall Street, of course, was shocked and surprised by conditions apparently more visible at a greater distance.
COAL is so plentiful and cheap now in lovely Lonelyville that the leading citizens are not obliged to go out and pick it up along the railroad track any more.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 7.--Lenten lectures and Lenten sewing classes furnish serious occupation for Lakewood's society people these quiet days. The sewing class of All Saint's Memorial Church, which includes in its membership many of the season patrons of the hotels, held its first meeting at the Parish House on Monday.

The sixteenth and last week but one of the present opera season at the Metropolitan will fulfill several promises made by the management. The programme will include two important revivals, besides the production of the one novelty of the season -- Miss Ethel M. Smyth's music-drama, "Der Wald," (" The Forest.")

To the Editor of The New York Times: The history of our country during the past half century shows how firmly we are wedded to the protective system. At present revision of the existing tariff is uppermost in most minds, but the looked-for revision is to be on anti-trust lines. The experiences that all travelers have in sending home works of art point toward other reforms that are equally important.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems as if there was something out of joint when an editor shows a greater knowledge of trees than the Park Commissioners, but an editorial in THE TIMES of March 1 on "Tree Planting" is sufficient proof that editors sometimes do. Several years ago, when Bryant Park was laid out.

NO outsider can appreciate how very many mutual benefit societies exist in New York's Italian colony. The moral disunity of the old peninsula is transplanted here; each province, each town, each village has a society of its own, and although all on the same plan and serving essentially a like purpose, they never merge in action and seldom mix in their membership.
THE woman who is the best cook apologizes most for her cooking. It is the pretty woman only who says: "I know that I look like a fright today."
HE HAS published a score of papers and brought out more of other people's books and stories than you could read in a lifetime, and says that he is now through with women proofreaders.

There are delicious appearing things in trimmings for hats. One is a strawberry plant, or several of them, in one long vine. It has strawberries of a size and color to fill the heart of the market gardener with envy, besides blossoms and green leaves.

NEW HAVEN, March 8 -- The curious spectacle has been seen for the last two days of an old house in Perkins Street, in this city, guarded by police while the heirs of an eccentric old sea Captain have conducted a thorough search of the place for $17,000 in cash and many rich gems which the Captain is believed to have hidden just previous to his death.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the people of the United States cherish at heart the high ideals which they profess upon their lips, then should they lose no time in declaring in thunder tones of passionate resentment and protest that we do not want and will never tolerate the erection of a statue in our republican capital to the Emperor Frederick the Great.

Thomas Hunter, President of the Normal College, in a communication to THE NEW YORK TIMES, makes a reply to the contentions of City Superintendent Maxwell in the latter's recent annual report to the Board of Education. President Hunter's statement follows:

ALBANY, March 8 -- Among other important matters which it is expected the Legislature will consider this week is the dual proposition of freshet cessation and water storage for power generation, as outlined in a bill approved by the State Water Storage Commission, which has been investigating the subject since last May.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a retired merchant in the eighth decade of life, one hopes the many readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES may value hints gathered during a long business experience, consider North America (the United States and Canada) in a most unsatisfactory condition with respect to the fiscal policies adopted of late years.
To the Editor of The New York Times: And a vision appeared; there stood a man of Macedonia and prayed him, sayings "Come over into Macedonia and help us."

DALLAS, Texas, March 4 -- Finally Texas has plenty of water. Not water merely to drink, not water merely for bathing luxury -- Texas is never so weak as to lament over shortage like that-but water sufficient to soak the vast State's soil and, for one season at least, to put drought out of business.

TACOMA, Washington, March 8 -- Pennsylvania men contemplate spending nearly $5,000,000 in reclaiming 270,000 acres in Snake River Valley of Southern Idaho. The chief shareholder is Frank H. Buhl of Sharon, Penn., and associated with him are Walter G. Filer, H.B. De Long, and P.L. Kimberly of Sharon.

The Rev. George W. Grinton preached last night at the Forty-fourth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, east of Tenth Avenue, upon the theme "What Are New York's Greatest Evils?" The greatest evil of all he declared was the saloon, because it was the incubator of all the other evils. He said, in part:

Several interesting handball games were played on Egan's Jersey City court yesterday, and Egan himself took part in a hard contest in which he successfully opposed J. Hanlon and F. McCabe, beating them two straight and losing the third game by 2 aces. Egan is practicing hard every day in preparation for his coming championship match with Louis Keegan of Chicago, the opening games of which will be decided at Egan's court Saturday, March 21.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The position of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in respect to the child labor bills now in the Senate Committee on the Judiciary has not been accurately reported in the press dispatches from Albany. The society does not oppose, but on the contrary distinctly favors, the passage of three of the four measures dealing with the subject in question.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The clause added to the thirty-fourth section of the immigration act this year, forbidding the sale of intoxicating liquors in the Capitol is the subject of much, discussion among those who have lingered in Washington and who have been in the habit of patronizing the House bar.

A wide diversity of opinion regarding the best power for commercial motor vehicles was expressed at the discussion of that subject at the rooms of the Automobile Club of America last Tuesday evening. It was agreed that steam, on account of being a perfectly elastic power, was the most suitable, except for the danger of the water freezing in the Winter.

Upon last week's business four stocks advanced a full point, and 145 declined similarly. The bond market was much, narrower, only 45 descriptions having that range, but the tone was similar, 48 issues falling a point. There is no distinction in character of securities in such a market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me compromise the monument business with my serious critic, Mr. Pownal Aplin. I will agree not to press for a monument to Benedict Arnold if he and the other Lee admirers will say no more in favor of a monument to Lee.

WASHINGTON, Ind., March 8 -- White River is on the rampage and is rising this evening at the rate of three-quarters of an inch an hour. Indications are that a disastrous flood from White River will result from the heavy downpour of rain of the past two days. Much property has been damaged and miles of fence have been swept away.

We do not think that the people of the United States need feel very much disturbed by the negotiations said to be going on between Germany and Austria to arrange high customs duties against the goods of this country. We do think that we might regard with some humiliation the fact that the plan is simply an imitation of our own narrow and foolish system.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The year 1899 will always be memorable for the birth of The Hague court. It was rather strange, however, that this institution should have come into existence at the instance of Russia, one of the most despotic of nations, coupled with a recommendation for the general disarmament of the nationalities.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 8 -- It is announced on trustworthy authority that, owing to the action of the City Council of Beaumont in refusing to grant the International and Great Northern the necessary franchise for an entrance into that city, the route of the road has been changed, and, instead of being built from Houston to New Orleans by way of Beaumont, it will be built from Spring.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer is not now and never has been concerned in any of Senator Elsberg's political battles, and certainly is not called upon to defend him against the petty charges made by his enemies or the enemies of his most excellent Coroners' bill.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The District Appropriation act recently passed contains a line which legislates out of office the present Chief of the Washington Fire Department. In appropriating the salary for the chief engineer of the department it was provided that no part of the appropriation shall be available to pay a chief engineer who has not had at least five years' experience as a member of some organized municipal Fire Department.

Leavitt J. Hunt, the new Chairman of the Polo Committee of Squadron A, has just issued his first polo circular of the year to the members. He calls attention to the fact that the polo fields at Van Cortlandt Park will be used by the Squadron Club again this season, playing days having been arranged for Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays.

It became known after the death of Col. Michael C. Murphy that a wife survived him. She attended his funeral and mourned almost unnoticed in the procession formed in large part by old associates of the dead Tammany leader, although for twenty or more years she had been estranged from him, and not even willing to be supported out of his plenty.

LONDON, March 8 -- The King has appointed Capt. Sir Archibald Berkeley Milne, Bart., Commodore of the royal yachts, vice the Hon. Hedworth Lambton, who has been appointed second in command of the Channel Squadron. Sir Archibald a couple of years ago figured in a sensational dispute with William Waldorf Astor.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 8 -- Violence has broken out anew in Waterbury in connection with the strike of the motormen and conductors of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company. Policeman Paul Mendelsohn was killed and John W. Chambers, a non-union motorman, and his conductor, George Weberndorfer, were beaten, the latter almost into insensibility.

"In justice to myself," Contractor Mundy has written to the Commissioner of Street Cleaning, "I have decided that the city rather than I should sustain the luxury of having you its Street Cleaning Commissioner."

It is not too soon to renew the movement for the reduction of the tax on distilled spirits, or alcohol, which was urged in vain in the Congress just closed. It ought not to be made a political matter. All interests concerned will be benefited by the reduction and none would be harmed.

BUFFALO, March 8 -- The most important development in the Burdick murder mystery to-day was the discovery by the police of evidence to corroborate the story told by Policeman Meyer of meeting a lone woman on Ashland Avenue about 1 o'clock on the night of the murder.

Police Commissioner Greene last night put the raids on the alleged gambling houses of "Lou" Betts and "Mike" Maher at 74 West Thirty-fifth Street and 122 West Thirty-fourth Street, squarely up to the Detective Bureau, and announced that he was going to ascertain if possible the answer to the "interesting and vital question" whether that particular section of the Police Department "can and will" get evidence against gambling houses.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- At the second session of the Fifty-seventh Congress upward of 170 public acts, not including general appropriation acts, were passed and received the approval of the President. What are known as private acts which were passed and received the President's approval number more than 1,200, of which a large proportion were pension acts, and of the latter perhaps the greater number were acts granting additional pensions.

Inspector Max Schmittberger of the First District, down in the Eldridge Street Police Station, yesterday afternoon gave his first audience since he had donned his new uniform, and it was mostly about his closing up the Bowery at 12 o'clock the night before.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 8.--The official report of Chris Evans, who was sent to the West Virginia coal fields to investigate the killing of colored miners at Atkinsville, has been received at the headquarters of the United Mine Workers.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Oliver J.D. Hughes, Consul General at Coburg, has transmitted to this country a statement, issued by the German Department of the Interior, dealing with German commercial and financial interests in the Chinese treaty ports, which shows that during the past four years German commerce and capital engaged in China have increased to "an extraordinry extent."

Prof. Frederick Hirth, incumbent of the new Dean Lung Chair of Chinese at Columbia University, who has been spoken of as probably the most eminent Chinese scholar in this country, delivered a lecture it the university last week on "Political and Commercial Reasons Calling for the Study of Chinese."

The Central Federated Union decided by a unanimous vote yesterday to co-operate in an agitation for amending the rapid Transit law, so as to separate the construction of underground railroads from the operation, and provide for the appointment of a local Railroad Commission. The object of the amendments is to open a way in which the city may have a share in the control of the underground roads.

Irishmen enough to fill to overflowing the Academy of Music ventured out in the rain last night to pay tribute to the memory of Robert Emmet, the day being the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the Irish patriot's birth. Recorder Goff presided at the meeting, which was held under the auspices of the Clan-na-Gael, in co-operation with the United Irish-American Societies.

In place of the crest which formes the background of the throne of the late Archbishop Corrigan has been put that of Archbishop Farley, his successor. The new crest tells symbolically the history of the Archbishop's career. The shield is violet on a crimson background. The Roman biretta indicates that the Archbishop studied for the priesthood in Rome.

BERLIN, March 8 -- The events in Wall Street received unusual attention on the Boerse here last week, and caused speculators to show great reserve, which was increased by the rising money rates. Domestic and Government bonds lost fractionally, and roost foreign rentes were weaker.

Preliminary work for the seventy candidates for the 'Varsity and freshman lacrosse teams has begun at Columbia, and with the approach of Spring weather the men have settled down to hard daily practice on their ground in South Field. Improvement has been noticeable in the work of the men during the past six weeks, and still further improvement is looked for now that serious outdoor work has begun.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Would it not be well to call a halt on the extravagance and unwisdom of the present administration? As I do not wish to raise an unnecessarily broad discussion, I will confine myself to one point -- the underground railway, the so-called "rapid transit."

Under the direction of Coach Smith the Fordham baseball candidates, numbering forty-five, have begun outdoor practice, and Manager Desmond of the freshman team has arranged the following schedule for the coming season:

ELIZABETH, N.J., March S. -- Unless some arrangement is entered into it is expected there will be a general strike of the workmen at the Townsend Downey yards at Shooter Island either to-morrow morning or Tuesday. The boiler workers who have been on strike for some time have arranged to have all the workmen in the shipyard come out unless the firm yields.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 8 -- If work on the new cup racer keeps up at the present rate, the boat will be in the water by the middle of next month. The keel was cast on Nov. 6 last, and if the syndicate's and her builders hopes are realized less than five months will have elapsed by the time she is afloat -- a new record in cup-yacht construction.

LONDON, March 9 -- The Figaro, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, makes the interesting announcement that the benediction delivered by the Pope on March 3 in St. Peter's has been phonographed.

Temple Beth-El, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, was filled last night by an enthusiastic gathering at the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of District Grand Lodge No. 1, Independent Order of B'nai B'rith. The Rev. S. Schulman opened the exercises with a prayer for the continued good works and prosperity of the organization.

It will perhaps surprise some of the people of the Eastern States to know that the production of bituminous coal, of which they are but spare and indifferent users, was eight times as great as the production of anthracite during the year 1902; for in that year, owing to idleness at the mines, the hard-coal position fell to where it was in the year 1885.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Panama treaty was reported to-day to the Senate from the Committee on Foreign Relations, the only vote against reporting it having been given by Senator Morgan. Mr. Morgan desired to have his amendments presented and discussion entered upon before the committee, but was finally persuaded to allow the treaty to be reported to the Senate when his amendments could be renewed.

-- Perhaps the most important, and certainly not the least interesting, of the many letters from correspondents published in THE TIMES on Sunday was that in which Dr. W.J. ROBINSON discussed the education of pharmacists as it is conducted and controlled in this State; or, to be exact, in this city.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 9 -- Summonses were served to-day in a suit brought by Receiver Schofield against the defendants, signers of a demand note for $10,200, made on the 3d of January, 1899, to the Monmouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company of Asbury Park by the members of the Asbury Park Athletic Association.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- George H. Murphy, Consular Clerk at Frankfort, in a communication to the State Department says:

Yesterday there was another transformation scene on Wall Street. On Saturday sales were limited to the number of buyers willing to make bargains on their own terms. The reduction of the reserves was discussed as though it were irremediable, and it might almost have been thought that December last was at hand again.

Borough President Cantor came in for considerable adverse criticism in connection with the Riverside Drive extension yesterday in Special Term, Part I., of the Supreme Court, when the attorney for the Lansing Investment Company, owners of Audubon Park, sought to obtain from Justice McCall a writ of peremptory mandamus to compel the Borough President to proceed with the improvement.

We remark, with interest, but without sympathy, that the Mayor of Waterbury has announced the opinion that that town is brought into "everlasting disgrace" through the cold-blooded murder of a special policeman by a party of masked assassins. The special policeman was engaged in convoying a trolley car which was in danger from the violence of the strikers, was doing his duty as a guardian of public order.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9 -- The granting of a second divorce has been recommended by the court in the case of Mrs. Belle D. Simpson against ex-Assemblyman Alexander Simpson of Jersey City. Mrs. Simpson obtained her first divorce from her husband in New York State on Sept. 15, 1900.

President Roosevelt's plan for the establishment of a National volunteer reserve militia having failed of approval at the recent session of Congress, the National Rifle Association now proposes to-take up the plan and carry it through without aid from Congress, and at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the association, held in this city yesterday afternoon, the following resolution was passed by a unanimous vote:

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Reports from St. Paul say that the move in the Wisconsin Legislature for an inter-State conference to discuss the negro problem was intended as a means of bringing Senator Spooner prominently before the country as a candidate for President, and that the idea was gotten up at a conference of Spooner boomers at Madison some weeks ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9 -- Harvard's Athletic Committee held an important meeting to-night, but to the keen disappointment of the Crimson undergraduates, failed to ratify the agreement with Yale drawn up at the Springfield conference on Saturday. One or two matters are yet hanging fire, but another meeting of the committee will be held on Friday, and it is expected that the ratification will then be satisfactorily effected.

Tucker, Speyers Co., in conjunction with J. Edgar Leaycraft Co., have sold for E.S. Rappallo to the Life Publishing Company, 17 West Thirty-first Street, a four-story dwelling, 25 by 100. The house adjoins the Life Building on the east, and the purchase has been made to protect the light and air of the taller structure.

BERLIN, March 9 -- In the course of the debate on the military budget in the Reichstag to-day Herr Kunert, Socialist, attempted to criticise the Emperor's military skill in leading the recent manoeuvres. Speaker von Ballestrem ruled that such criticisms were inadmissible. Herr Kunert retorted:

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- The market opened active and weak, with the greatest pressure on the Consolidated Lake Superior rior issues, both of which declined to new low records, the common receding to 4 3/8, the preferred to 19 3/8. The latter made substantial recovery in the late trading, touching 21 at the close -- a net loss of 1 per cent.

All of the Justices of the Court of Special Sessions, of which the Children's Court is a part, have announced their opposition to Senator Hill's bill, now pending in the Legislature, by which it is sought to require newsboys, bootblacks, and peddlers to obtain licenses before they can lawfully ply their vocations in the streets.

The financial writer of The London Times with friendly intent utters a word of warning concerning what he supposes to be our present tendency toward financial dissipation. There is for him a dark mystery in the large reductions in the deposits of the Clearing House banks in the last quarter of 1902.

Judge Adams, in the United States District Court, yesterday appointed Robert C. Morris and Charles S. Mackenzie temporary receivers of the assets of Dresser Co., commission merchants in hosiery, silks, , at 15 and 17 Greene Street, against whom a petition in bankruptcy was filed on Saturday.

There was no raid on the Murray Hill Lyceum, Thirty-fourth Street and Third Avenue, last night, though policemen swarmed into the building. The fact that many carried mysterious burdens which might have contained almost anything appealed to the imagination of persons in the neighborhood.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Controller Grout's Sinking Fund bill came up in the Senate tonight in the form of a report from the Assembly. It passed the Assembly after it passed the Senate, but two verbal changes were made in it.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Felix S.S. Johnson, United States Commercial Agent at Stanbridge, in a dispatch to the State Department, says:

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Almost the whole Cabinet is taking wing, now that Congress has adjourned, and the President himself will not stay in town any longer than the extra session of the Senate makes necessary.
TOLEDO, Ohio, March 9 -- Col. W.J. Bryan was in this city to-day. He told of his recent visit to New York, and said that the people in that State knew less about polities than they do in the West.

Tuesday has become the fashionable sailing day more than any other this year. There is a band of fashionable people booked on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse for departure to Europe this morning. Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel are to be passengers. They are to go to the south of France to join the Anthony Drexels.
In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night, the Sylvan bowlers of Brooklyn won two of three games with the Harlem Circle team, and scored 1,031 in the third game. The scores follow:
LONDON, March 10 -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Times sends word that 20,000 Redifs from Asia and large supplies of amunition have been dispatched from the Turkish capital to Monastir.

The Commissioners appointed by Mayor Low to examine the plans of the Manhattan Bridge across the East River submitted a preliminary report yesterday. The bridge structure will nearly parallel the present East River Bridge, and will have terminals in Brooklyn near the junction of Flatbush Avenue and Fulton Street and in Manhattan in the vicinity of Canal Street.

After much skirmishing, accompanied by various rumors of pacific agreements, the majority faction of the Southern Pacific stockholders, meaning the Harriman interests, has finally declared war on the dissenting minority holders, which are composed largely of the Keene Southern Pacific pool.

ST. LOUIS, March 9 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Missouri Pacific Railroad will be held to-morrow, when President George J. Gould's report will be presented. The report offers these figures on the system's finances:

All Wall Street expected a very decided break at the opening of the market yesterday and a subsequent decline bordering on demoralization. Then the wiseacres -- that is, those of them who had any money left -- were to buy stocks on the collapse and in a day or two sell them out at a profit to the unsuspecting public.

THERMISTOCLES TRAGIDIO -- Thermistocies Tragidio of 66 West One Hundred and Fourth Street has filed a petition in bankruptcy with known liabilities to the amount of $357 to four creditors and five others which are unknown, and no assets.

Ex-President Cleveland, who is visiting at the home of Oscar S. Straus, 5 West Seventy-sixth Street, saw a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES last night and expressed his displeasure at having been misquoted on the subject of his political position.

Police Commissioner Greene yesterday received reports from the various Police Courts showing that of thirty-six arrests for violations of the law regaining theatrical performances on Sunday, twenty-three were held for examination, the others being discharged. The action of the police had been taken on complaints from the Sabbath Protective League and the Actors' Church Alliance.

To-day the proposition to incorporate woman suffrage in the Constitution of New Hampshire, already passed by the Constitutional Convention of that State, comes up for the vote of the people at the polls.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The State Department has not been fully advised of the concessions obtained from the Turkish Government by Minister Leishman. Turkey had up to this point declined to recognize American, medical diplomas, or even those issued to graduates from American institutions in Turkey, a fact which naturally greatly diminished their usefulness.

LONDON, March 10 -- Supporters of a friendly understanding between Russia and Great Britain regarding countries where their interests clash are much interested in what is regarded as being a significant statement made by the Under Foreign Secretary, Lord Cranborne, in the House of Commons yesterday.

A straight rail handicap billiard tournament, in which nine players are to take part, was begun last night at the Montauk Billiard Academy, Brooklyn. The opening game was rather long drawn out, the win- ner requiring seventy-two inning to make his quota of 100 points. C. Lewis, playing 100, defeated George Wesley, (85,) who only scored 73 points in seventy-one innings.

HAVANA, March 9 -- The debate on the reciprocity treaty with the United States was resumed in the Senate to-day. Senator Sanguilly made a lengthy and picturesque speech in which he contended that reciprocity was not a necessity to Cuba's progress. His address, while voicing the fear of the domination of Cuba by trusts was marked by no bitterness toward the United States Government or people.

It is reported in police circles, we cannot say with what authority, that when Commissioner GREENE gave to Inspector BROOKS the warning contained in the letter elsewhere printed, he remarked that he had been a police officer for thirty days and the Inspector for thirty years, and asked him how it would seem if the Commissioner should get evidence against gambling houses which the Inspector could not, or did not, get.

ST. LOUIS, March 9 -- In the Federal Circuit Court to-day Judge Wood made permanent the injunction granted last October against Bennett Wasserman and others, ticket "scalpers," restraining them from buying and selling World's Fair excursion tickets. The temporary injunction was granted at the instance of all the railroads entering St. Louis, and was argued recently.
