Mme. Duse is to make another farewell visit to America next Winter, if she carries out her present intentions, as indicated by a letter that George Tyler of Liebler Co. received yesterday. The tour will be of eight weeks, four of which are to be spent in New York. She will play her old repertoire of "Magda," "Camille," "La Femme de Claude," , having abandoned the idea of giving the d'Annunzio plays.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 9 -- That the murder of Policeman Paul Mendelssohn by masked men who attacked a car on the North Main Street line of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company last night has aroused the people of Waterbury there can be no doubt. Several meetings were held this evening because of recent acts of violence, particularly the murder.

Miss Kate Thedford Hickie, who has figured as principal in many sensational lawsuits in the past, notably those against the Dominican Fathers, was convicted on a charge of perjury yesterday before Recorder Golf, in the Court of General Sessions. She was remanded for sentence until Friday.

ST. LOUIS, March 9 -- The National League baseball teams of Pittsburg and St. Louis, it is announced, have agreed to an exchange of players, St. Louis giving Kruger in exchange for Burke. Brashear goes to Philadelphia.
LONDON, March 9 -- The demand for money was active in the market to-day, and supplies were poor. Discounts were firm.

One of the most artistic pieces for the writing table is a pen tray in a dull green bronze. The tray itself is long and in uneven lines, intended perhaps to represent water, for at the end is a crouching female figure resting against a large, partially overturned water jar, one of those which the Eastern women carry on their heads.
Capt. Tracey C. Dickson, Ordnance Department, will proceed to Fort Leavenworth, for the purpose of exhibiting the new rifle.

BOSTON, March 9 -- It is stated on excellent authortiy that one, and possibly two, professors of the Harvard Law School have been selected for important positions in the Court of Siam. One of the positions is that of legal adviser to the King, a place of great influence and responsibility, as the action of Siam in international questions will depend largely upon the advice of the holder of this office.

BOSTON, March 9.--Saturday's poor bank statement is reflected in increased firmness in the money market. Rates are slightly higher all around, but no uneasiness with regard to the situation is shown. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/4@3 3/4 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 15 cents discount; clearings, 173,142; balances, $983,014.
WASHINGTON, March 9.--The Weather Bureau this morning issued the following special river bulletin: "The heavy...

Price movements in the outside market yesterday were very irregular, the most active issues following more or less closely the course of prices on the Stock Exchange. Early in the day considerable weakness was displayed, and prices in some instances ran off sharply. During the afternoon the influence of the improved conditions on the board was manifested in substantial recoveries in Northern Securities, the new steel bonds, and some other issues.

Brooklyn is famous for big audiences, and nothing would draw them more readily than the memory of their great citizen, Mr. BEECHER, unless it be the presence of Mr. CLEVELAND. The remarkable gathering at the Academy of Music on Sunday evening, all the more remarkable in view of the raging storm, was an evidence of the attraction exerted by both these magnets.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Senator McClelland has in his possession what he considers indisputable evidence that the fire insurance companies of the State of New York have entered into a trust agreement to raise the rates of insurance and to-night he introduced two bills for the purpose of controlling the combination.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Tenement House Commissioner De Forest's bill will be introduced to-morrow. Mr. De Forest, Lawrence Veillier, the Secretary of the Tenement House Commission, and President Swanstrom of the Borough of Brooklyn this afternoon had a long conference with Gov. Odell.

WASHINGTON, N.J., March 9 -- Joseph A. Lundy, proprietor of the large clock case factory that was destroyed by fire on Jan. 20 last, filed a petition in bankruptcy in Trenton on Saturday, with assets to the amount of $8,150 and liabilities of $9,220. He designed about fifty cases for clocks that ranged in price from $23 to $1,200.
OLEAN, N.Y., March 9 -- A score or more people were killed and a larger number were injured by an explosion of oil near here to-night.

VICTORIA, B.C., March 9 -- There is no sign of a settlement of the strike of the Canadian Pacific freight handlers. Au answer to a proposal made by the strikers on Saturday was received to-day. It does not concede the demands of the men, and the strike may spread.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Assemblyman Bostwick received to-day from John D. Lindsay of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children a strong protest against the passage of the Child Labor bill upon which a hearing was given before the Senate Judiciary Committee last Wednesday.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Brussels correspondent of The Times says that the Dutch Railway Servants' Syndicate, supported by the entire Labor Party, is determined to resist the Government's intention to constitute the act of joining a strike by any public servant a punishable offense.

Capt. O'Reilly, followed by a score of policemen bearing axes, yesterday afternoon came sweeping out of Sixth Avenue into Forty-second Street and turned the corner in military fashion, moving eastward. Immediately back of them followed a delegation of sturdy employes of the Department of Parks. They bore crowbars.

BOSTON, March 9 -- A cablegram from Honolulu says that there is no lack of freak legislation by the New Hawaiian Legislature. Favorite bills are those which exempt the natives from taxation by placing their property under an exemption clause.

Deputy Police Commissioner Alexander Ross Piper, who has been in England for the last month studying police methods and conditions in the British metropolis, arrived home yesterday afternoon on the Atlantic Transport liner Minnehaha. Capt. Piper will embody his observations in a report to Commissioner Greene.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- A statement sent out from the anthracite regions to-day that the Reading Company had found its coal accumulating in its storage yards so rapidly that it had been decided to put the miners on three-quarter time was denied by General Manager Henderson of the Coal and Iron Company, Mr. Henderson said:

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Bitterness that has cropped out in Arkansas politics in recent years overrode Senatorial courtesy today when James P. Clarke, the successor to James K. Jones, appeared to be sworn in. His colleague, Senator Berry, refused to escort him to the desk of the President of the Senate, and, declining the arm of Senator Bacon of Georgia, he walked up the aisle alone.

ST. LOUIS, March 9 -- Officers of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen and of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen to-day moved for a dissolution of the injunction restraining them from ordering a strike on the Wabash Railway. The motion and an answer to the bill filed by the company were presented to Judge Elmer B. Adams in the United States District Court this morning.
BERLIN, March 9 -- Emperor William received President Francis of the St. Louis Exposition in audience at noon to-day.

Ex-President CLEVELAND expresses the opinion that the trust question will not be eliminated from the next Presidential canvass, and he is "entirely unable to see how that question can be wholly divorced from the tariff issue." These views are sustained by all the elements of logic and probability that are perceptible to the average understanding.

PARIS, March 10. -- The Chamber of Deputies devoted its session to-day to the discussion of interpellations on the foreign policy of the Government, to which Minister Delcasse will reply to-morrow. The Nationalist Deputy, Lucien Millevoye, opened the debate with a review of the whole international action on the part of France for thirty years past.

At the third and last of the series of chamber concerts, which was given last evening in Mendelssohn Hall, the Kaltenborn Quartet played, as they have before, a number of novelties that gave, on their face, a promise of unusual interest. But before the evening was over they turned out to be in some respects a rather dreary and uninteresting set of pieces.

Dr. Richard C. Flower, who has figured so conspicuously in the litigation over the estate of the late Theodore Hagaman, had everything his own way yesterday at Cooper Union, where the stockholders of the Lone Pine Mining Company held a meeting under a special call issued by holders of more than 40,000 shares of the stock.

DETROIT, Mich., March 10 -- William J. Bryan of Nebraska this morning addressed the State Democratic Convention in Light Guard Armory. Stanley E. Parkhill, the temporary Chairman, in the course of the remarks he made before presenting Mr. Bryan to the convention, said:

Capt. "Lem" Miller, who, will command the Columbia, and Capt. Urias Rhodes, who will sail the Constitution in the trial races to select a defender of the America's Cup, were in the city on Monday, and happening to meet down town they exchanged views on the chances of their boats in the trial races.

Troubles that have been brewing in secret for many weeks reached a climax yesterday afternoon during the annual meeting of stockholders of the American Ice Company, at 13 Exchange Place, Jersey City. For an hour after the reading of President John D. Schoonmaker's report there was a fierce war of words between representatives of dissatisfied stockholders and the officers of the company.

The sympathetic strike ordered late on Monday night by the Marine Trades Council at the Townsend-Downey shipbuilding yards on Shooter Island in support of the boilermakers went into effect yesterday morning. The strike was only a partial one, some of the men remaining at work, but the tie-up is expected to be completed to-day.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Street Cleaning Commissioner Woodbury of New York City appeared before the Senate Committee on Cities to-day in behalf of the bill introduced by Senator Plunkitt to amend the city charter relative to his department.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Champions of canal improvement were disagreeably surprised to-night when the Senate Finance Committee decided to report favorably the Lewis resolution directing the Governor to appoint a commission to consult with Federal authorities and ascertain what arrangements can be made relative to a deep waterway through New York State to the great lakes.
BUFFALO, March 10 -- Tragic death which came to one of the persons who had most prominently figured in the case added to the Burdick murder mystery to-day.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., March 10. -- The veteran racing schooner yacht Amorita, which was recently sold to Richard Mansfield, is undergoing the usual Spring overhauling preparatory to commission at the Jacob yard. The yacht will be in command of Capt. John Bahrr.

BALTIMORE, March 10 -- The market today was dull and featureless, most of the changes being fractional losses. Transactions, amounting to 2,080 shares of stock and $127,000 worth of bonds, were as follows:

ALBANY, March 10 -- The conference of Republican leaders in the Legislature, called by Gov. Odell to meet to-night in the Executive Chamber, and which was presided over by him, developed into a caucus and settled so far as the Republicans are concerned all of the important problems which are now pending before the Legislature.
A strike of coffinmakers is imminent in Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Newark, the men having made their demands and the manufacturers having decided not to accede to them.

COLON, March 10 -- It is understood that the six Congressmen elected for this department last Sunday will meet at Panama next week. Their first business will be the election of Senators. Congress will probably meet at Bogota toward the end of May.

The Keene pool in Southern Pacific stock, which has lately been referred to as the minority holders, answered yesterday the defiance of the Union Pacific interests in Southern Pacific by extending the pool until April 10, or one day after the annual meeting of the Southern Pacific stockholders.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 10 -- A general vote was taken throughout the State to-day in connection with the annual town meeting's and municipal elections in several cities on ten proposed amendments to the Constitution, and although the complete vote will not be known for several days, sufficient returns were received to-night to indicate that nearly all had been adopted.

HAVAKA, March 10 -- Senor Bustamento, the Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and a distinguished lawyer, replied in the Senate this afternoon to the arguments of the opponents of the reciprocity treaty. At the close of the first installment of a logical and earnest speech, he was greeted with loud applause from the spectators and Senators, including the half dozen opponents of the ratification.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Gov. Odell to-day dismissed the charges preferred against Sheriff Harry M. Kaiser of Erie County by the Rev. Dr. Gifford of Buffalo. It was asserted that Mr. Kaiser promised to appoint certain men to office in return for their support in the election.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- The stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company in annual meeting to-day voted to increase the capital stock of the company by $130,000,000 making the total authorized capital $400,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- An informal conference of Democratic Senators was held in the conference room this afternoon after the adjournment of the Senate. Mr. German presided and there were eighteen or twenty other Senators present. The object of the meeting was to exchange views about the pending treaties and other matters with a view to formulating a party policy.

In the opening game of the Business Men's Championship Bowling League last night the Plumbing and Steam Supply League bowlers won three games from the representatives of the Ben Franklin League. The scores follow:

Yesterday's news, which directly affected outside stocks, was favorable, but despite this fact the market showed, very little strength in any quarter. The weakness of the Stock Exchange market was an unfavorable influence too great to be overcome, and it resulted in more or less heavy losses in most of the active issues.

BOSTON, March 10 -- The money market continues very firm. Call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 51/2@ 6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 16 2-3c discount; clearings, $22,329,276; balances, $1,710,807. The foreign exchange market is slightly firmer. Rates, however, are unchanged.

The present system of assessing real and personal property and collecting taxes in this city was arraigned as a "notorious evil" in a report presented and adopted at a meeting of the Bar Association last night by its Special Committee on Taxation. The committee, which was appointed at the last meeting of the association, is composed of the following members: Henry de Forest-Baldwin, Horace E. Deming, Edward L. Heydecker, W.M.K. Olcott, and Ferdinand Shack.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 10 -- In a special message sent to the Senate to-day Gov. Lucius F.C. Garvin declared that bribery was common in many towns of the State, and that many members of the Legislature occupied seats obtained by purchased votes. The Governor recommended the appointment of a commission for a term of three years to employ agents to detect bribery and bring offenders to justice.

Monday's market was a beautiful iream. Yesterday's was a sad awakening to the stern realities first fully discerned on Saturday. In other words, the money market is now the dominating influence, overshadowing the usual consideration of intrinsic values. Plenty of properties now look inviting and normal conditions, but seem uninviting when considered either as speculation or investments amid the monetary vicissitudes of the coming months.

NEW ORLEANS, March 10. -- After the Lord Neville race yesterday the Stewards notified W.H. Fizer to appear before them to-day. The conference was held behind closed doors, and at its close it was announced that Fizer had been ruled off the turf for, violation of the Western Jockey Club's rule relative to the use of drugs on horses.

The statement, by Lord CRANBOBNE in the House of Commons that the prospect was flattering for an amicable understanding with Russia as to Persia and other regions in which both that country and Great Britain have interests is more definite than any that the present Government has heretofore made.

Very large and very small canvases are seen at the Noe Galleries among the score of paintings by Prof. Karl Heffner of Dresden. We have had some of his large landscapes over here in the Schaus, the Oehme, and other galleries, but for the first time have had the opportunity to compare a number at once.

The sale of the literary and art property collected by the late Clarence King and William H. Fuller was begun at the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street, yesterday. One hundred and ninety-five objects brought a total of $10,552. The galleries were well filled with bidders.

Several valuable paintings by local artists that had been obtained from them, the artists said, under false pretenses by J.E. Mills, a son of J. Harrison Mills, once a well-known artist and later organizer of the Artists' Packing and Shipping Company, were recovered yesterday in a pawn-shop on Broadway near Sixty-sixth Street.

A hoard of officers is appointed to meet at Vancouver Barracks for the examination of officers to determine their fitness for promotion. Detail -- Lieut. Col. John T. Van Orsdale. Seven-teenth Infantry; Major Rudolph G. Ebert, surgeon: Major Ephrnim T.C. Richmond and Major Alexandor B Dyer. Artillery Corps; Capt. Jere B Clayton. assistant surpreon: Capt. William L. Kehly. Artillery Corps, recorder.

It is not a pleasant story that our Washington dispatches yesterday contained as to the efforts making by the various aspirants for the Republican nomination for the Presidency to gain the support of the negroes. As we have frequently pointed out, in the South this game is necessarily a hunt for delegates only.

Mrs. Albert Bierstadt, widow of the wellknown artist, who recently purchased Charles W. Morse's residence at 724 Fifth Avenue, has sold her house at 322 Fifth Avenue to Mrs. Christopher M. Bell, who owns the similar adjoining dwelling at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-second Street.

Our public schools are paying more attention than ever before to instruction in elementary art. At international exhibitions our artists are taking medals. In most large cities art schools and societies, art galleries and museums, are in process of foundation where none existed of late, and in the chief cities new organizations are rising beside the old.

BOSTON, March 10 -- Certainly no other woman in Boston and perhaps none in the world has personal charge of so large a sum as that confided to Miss Lucy Bridge, who is a clerk in the State Treasury Department, and in point of service the oldest of the employes of the State in the big building on Beacon Hill.
ALBANY, March 10. -- The Senate to-day passed Senator Davis's bill conferring upon the Mayor of Buffalo the right to veto the items in the general fund budget of that city.

Mr. PLIMLEY is to be congratulated. The office of Assistant Treasurer of the United States is one of dignity and consequence. The Assistant Treasurer who is in charge of the Sub-Treasury Building in this city not only has in his custody a great deal of money, but he is a pretty conspicuous Federal officer.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Both Senator Morgan and the friends of the Panama treaty are protesting against unnecessary delay in the consideration of that agreement. Mr, Morgan said to-night after the executive session: I want a vote just as scon as one can be reached in fairness to my associates in the opposition to the treaty."

ALBANY March 10. -- The bitter contest between the State Board of Regents and the Department of Public Instruction over unification of the State schools threatens to develop a religious controversy which will stir the State. This phase of the matter has been kept in the background so far, but if the Regents persist in their effort to bring the common schools under their jurisdiction it will soon be exploited.

LONDON, March 10 -- Stock Exchange requirements increased the demand for money in the market today. Discounts hardened in sympathy with discount houses raising rates on deposit money. A change in the Bank of England's rate of discount is not expected this week.

LONDON, March 11 -- The Times's dramatic critic, commenting upon Richard Ganthony's new play, "The Prophecy," produced at the Avenue Theatre last evening, says that it is a bold attempt to present a serious play with a pair of twins as two out of three of the chief characters, but twins, though furnishing an excellent excuse for farce, seem out of place in the graver drama.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- There is little to be said of the local market. Trading was dull and prices heavy, declines being noted wherever there was any selling pressure. Liquidation was again apparent in Consolidated Lake Superior common and preferred, while Philadelphia Electric weakened on the rumor that the issues of the Company -- for some reason not disclosed -- were to be raided.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Leo Schlesinger, President of the Mechanics and Traders' Bank of New York City, declared before the Assembly Committee on Banks to-day that unless some legislation were enacted such as that proposed in the J.T. Smith bill to compel trust companies to have a 15 per cent. reserve the State banks would soon be forced to transform themselves into trust companies or take out charters as National banks.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Rapid transit conditions in New York City came in for general discussion to-day before the Senate Committee on Cities, when hearings were given on the four bills now before the Legislature:

Lying about a third of a league off Quarantine yesterday was the Anchor Line steamship Karamania, from Mediterranean ports. The yellow flag of quarantine was flying from her fore topmast, and craft of all kinds gave her a wide berth. During the voyage six out of eight hundred persons on board had died under strange circumstances, and after displaying symptoms which Health Officer Doty fears were those of Asiatic cholera.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 10 -- The best data obtainable as to the status of the typhoid epidemic here are admittedly incomplete. They show that up to the end of last week there had been 755 cases of typhoid in Ithaca since Jan. 10 of which the clinical history is obtainable. The number of unreported cases is a matter of estimate.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- At the conclusion of the Cabinet meeting to-day the following statement was made public at the White House:

ALBANY, March 10. -- Senator Marshall to-day introduced in the Senate the bill embodying the concessions which the New York City Tenement House Department is willing to make to builders. It was the measure agreed upon by the city authorities of New York and by representatives of the builders after various conferences.

Mrs. Helen Brown, twenty-three years old, wife of John Hamilton Brown, who is about seventy years old, and the inventor of the Brown segmental wire gun, was arrested last night while returning to their home, at 68 West One Hundred and Seventh Street, on a warrant charging her with assaulting Matthew Webb, Jr., a real estate agent of 662 St. Nicholas Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The following statement was given out to-night at the Legation of the Argentine Republic:

An official trial of the practicability of the wireless telegraph for the uses of the United States Army posts of the East was held yesterday under the direction of Lieut. Col. H.H.C. Dunwoodie, chief officer of the Signal Service Corps of the Department of the East, when communication toy the De Forest system was established between the military telegraph stations of Fort Wadsworth, S.I., and the new station at Fort Hancock, on Sandy Hook.

PROVIDENCE, March 11. -- Graduates and friends of Brown University in Southern New England met at the Trocadero tonight for their annual midwinter dinner. Among the guests were Gov. L.F.C. Garvin, President William J. Tucker of Dartmouth, the Right Rev. W.N. McVickar, Bishop Coadjutor of Rhode Island; Oscar S. Straus of New York, and Dr. William W. Keen of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The temperance people of Kansas have started a discussion in regard to the christening of the proposed battleship Kansas, which is somewhat premature, as the plans have not been yet drawn.

There was a heated argument before Justice McCall in the Supreme Court yesterday, when attorneys for George Bodine, a grandson and one of the heirs of the late George Chesterman, who died in 1883, leaving an estate said to be worth $1,500,000, moved to have the trustees of the estate discharged because of alleged mismanagement in allowing $29,000 to be taken from the funds without having used reasonable means to prevent it.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- As a result of conferences to-day it is probable that a vote will be taken on the Panama Canal treaty on Tuesday. Senator Frye (Rep., Me.,) had a long talk with Senator Morgan, (Dem., Ala.,) and it was practically decided that Mr. Morgan would consent to the vote next week in consideration of leave to print his speeches against the treaty in The Congressional Record.

BOSTON, March 11.--Should children begin their study in the public schools at the age of five, or should attendance be delayed until the age of seven. That is the question that Frank E. Parlin of Quincy, Superintendent of Schools in that city, raised in his annual report a few days ago.
HAVANA, March 11. -- The Senate to-day by a vote of 16 to 5 ratified the reciprocity treaty with the United States.

The baseball situation at Manhattan College is beginning to look very bright and the students are anxiously awaiting the first game, which will take place on April 2, when Manhattan will cross bats with Tufts College. The services of Harry Thielman, a former member of the Manhattan 'Varsity nine, have been secured for the season as coach.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Considerable irregularity existed in this market today, with pronounced weakness in the Consolidated Lake Superior stocks, both of which declined to the lowest prices ever quoted for them, the preferred going to 16 1/2, against yesterday's close at 20, and the common declining 3 13-16.
Sale on the Stock Exchange of 20 shares of Mount Morris Bank stock at 292 5/8.

ALBANY, March 11. -- Commissioner of Excise Cullinan said to-day that the Excise bill will be ready for introduction tomorrow. The measure will increase the rates of liquor licenses 50 per cent. Where a license is $800 under the present law it will be $1,200 under the new law. It is further proposed to give the State one-half instead of one-third of the revenue from this source.

Under her own steam the death ship Karamania of the Anchor Line left Quarantine a few minutes before 6 o'clock last night, and later completed her illstarred voyage by tying up at her pier in the North River. Capt. Pearce, the chief engineer, and the chief officer, with several borrowed members of the crew of the Ethiopia, which arrived yesterday, were on board.

A special policeman attached to the House of Mercy in Inwood, while on his way from that place to his home heard strange noises emanating from the Summer residence of Thomas D. Trimmer, at the northern end of River Road. He drew closer and found every door and window wide open. He went to the rear and looked in the window of the kitchen.

Officials of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company issued long denials of the published attack made on their financial status yesterday morning. The attack, including reports of two expert accountants in the employ of unknown stockholders, was based on the claim that the company had declared dividends unlawfully when there were no earnings and that the financial reports omitted, among other things, proper statements of liabilities.

A striking feature of the interesting "symposium" on skyscrapers given before the Nineteenth Century Club on Tuesday evening was the unanimity of all the symposiasts upon the necessity of imposing some restriction upon the construction of these edifices. It is true that they differed rather widely upon what restrictions should be imposed.

The general tone of the market yesterday was distinctly better than at any time in the past two weeks, and tended to bear out the opinion expressed in conservative banking quarters that liquidation had about run its course, and that even artificial and manipulative pressure would, in the present temper of the investment public, avail little in the way of lower prices.

MILWAUKEE, March 11. -- Francis Keene of this city, a classmate of President Roosevelt at Harvard, received notice to-day from Secretary Hay at Washington that he would be appointed United States Consul to Florence, Italy.

ALBANY, March 11. -- Senator Davis's $101,000,000 Canal Improvement Referendum bill is out of the Senate Canal Committee and will be reported to-morrow morning. This sudden action came as a surprise tonight to the anti-canal men and to most of the pro-canal men, too, for all were expecting that the final report would be put over until next week.

ALBANY, March 12. -- Five Republican Assemblymen last night refused to be whipped into line for the programme of mortgage and excise taxation outlined at the Senatorial caucus last night. They attended the conference held in the Assembly parlors, but when it was turned into a caucus they walked out.

Yesterday Wall Street had another roseate day, although without corresponding change in conditions. The Sub-Treasury continues to absorb reserve money in volume adequate to reduce the banks below their legal minimum, unless relief is given by reduction of loans, which consideration proved disappointing last week.

BOSTON, March 11. -- The money market shows continued firmness. There has been some calling of street loans, and the banks are not disposed to put out funds on collatoral loans nor to buy commercial paper. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 16 2-3 cents discount.

The position of the outside market was to a certain extent reversed yesterday, and a number of the issues which had suffered losses on Tuesday showed substantial recoveries. The Steel bonds and Northern Securities, the two issues to which most attention has been given of late, were both fairly strong and closed near the best prices of the day.

The management of the Metropolitan Opera House has at last vouchsafed its patrons the one new opera that was promised at the beginning of the season. It was produced last evening in a "double bill," with "II Trovatore," and is a one-act piece entitled "Der Wald," by Miss Ethel M. Smyth.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department, rendered a decision to-day sustaining the State Board of Railroad Commissioners in authorizing the New York and Port Chester Railroad Company to construct an electric street railroad line from Harlem to Port Chester, through Mount Vernon and New Roehelle.
Realistic Easter cards have little downy chickens in shells, little ducks without shells, and fuzzy rabbits in different sizes. The cards upon which they are standing have appropriate Easter verses.

BOSTON, March 11. -- J.J. Bright of this city, one of the three men who formed the Boston Ice Company, read a letter at the American Ice Company meeting yesterday from his nephew, E.H. Bright, formerly connected with the Boston Ice Company, but now associated with the company operating the Commonwealth Hygienic Ice Company, which stated that the Boston Ice Company is being used to its detriment for furthering the interests of an independent company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Child Labor Committee is gratified to learn definitely the position of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in respect to the child labor bills now in the Legislature. Its position is stated by the letter printed in this morning's papers from Mr. Lindsay, the President of the society.

An interesting game of jeu-de-barre was decided at the Durland Riding Academy, in West Sixty-sixth Street, last evening. The players were Mills, Clapp, and Coleman, and Clapp, who generally captures the honors, scored another victory after a hard struggle.

ALBANY, March 11. -- Controller Grout's Sinking Fund bill passed the Senate to-day without objection. It now goes to the Governor. Assurance that the bill would be passed and signed was given to the Controller before he left Albany yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- A department store building to cost $5,000,000 is to be erected on the site of the Wanamaker store at Thirteenth and Chestnut Streets, which will be of the most substantial construction and cover more ground space than any similar structure of its kind in the world, according to the architect.

It is a curious and not a creditable circumstance that a visit of the Secretary of the Treasury to Wall Street should be the occasion of local excitement and newspaper speculation. It is natural that the Secretary of the Treasury should visit Wall Street. The Sub-Treasury, which is a branch of the great department of which he is the head, is there.

-- For those who must form an opinion of the Child Labor bills now before the Legislature from a comparison between their advocates and their opponents, arrival at a decision is extremely difficult, since there are ranged on both sides men whose knowledge is extensive and whose motives are unquestionable.

PARIS, March 11. -- The Foreign Minister, M. Delcasse, made a vigorous presentation in the Chamber of Deputies to-day of the part France is taking in various international matters, dwelling chiefly on the Macedonian, Moroccan, Siamese, and other questions in which France is specially concerned.

NEW ORLEANS, March 11. -- Marion Lynch and Thane were the only winning favorites to-day. The Stewards ordered the refusal of further entry of Banish for refusing to break at the post. Weather showery; track heavy. Summary:

The recommendations of the Fine Arts Association as to the decorations of the Hall of Records, which were formulated Monday night and have been submitted in a letter to the Municipal Art Commission and which are that the decorations should be representative of the history of the city -- its discovery, its principal epochs, its memorable events, and its growth and development, were made public yesterday afternoon.

Incensed at the work done by the Tenderloin police in connection with a raid on a gambling resort known as "French Lou's,'' in West Twenty-eighth Street, early yesterday morning, District Attorney Jerome used plain language in discussing the affair later in the day. "Tipsters," "grafters," and "idiots" were some of the terms he applied to Capt. O'Reilly's plain clothes men.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph Krauskopf arrived home to-day from Cincinnati and announced that he had accepted the Director Generalship of the Isaac M. Wise Endowment Fund Committee of the Hebrew Union College, which office was tendered him during a meeting of rabbis at Cincinnati.

Those persons who scout the idea that classic tragedy still has power to fill theatres might have had their ideas on the subject changed had they attended the Wednesday matinee of "Virginius" at the Murray Hill Theatre. That particular day is cited because the morning was gloomy, with intermittent rain -- just the sort of weather to deter feminine patrons from venturing to the box office.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The Assembly today passed the New York Central Terminal bills. They are three in number. They provide for the substitution of electric for steam power in the tunnel, for the depression of the tracks, and the erection of a new station, and for the necessary grade crossings.

It is to be hoped that the informal decision said to have been reached by the Democrats of the Senate to oppose the treaty with Cuba will be reversed on consideration. It is bad as politics and worse as patriotism.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 11. -- Mrs. Arthur R. Pennell, who with her husband was carried over a ledge into a stone quarry in their automobile yesterday afternoon, died at the Sisters of Charity Hospital tonight at 8 o'clock.

The successful launching of the steam yacht Corinthia, built for J. Adolph Mollenhauer, a member of the New York Yacht Club, also Commodore of the Pentaquit-Corinthian Yacht Club of Bay Shore, L.I., took place yesterday morning at the yards of the builders, tne Gas Engine and Power Company and Charles L. Seabury Co., contractors, at Morris Heights on the Harlem River.
Discussing the condition of the iron and metal trades The Iron Age will to-day say:

At the monthly meeting of the Trustees of the New York Public Library in the Astor Building, yesterday afternoon, it was announced that the consolidation of the Aguilar Free Library with the New York Public Library had been completed. The four branches of the Aguilar Library are now parts of the circulating department.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 12. -- Many towns of Central New York are confronted with grave sanitary problems, the consideration of which is postponed for a more convenient season, but not many of them have problems as complex and difficult or as exigent as those of Ithaca. It labors under natural disadvantages of location and environment which are unique.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The bill providing that Police Commissioner Greene may rehear the charges against Edward O'Neill and reinstate him on the police force if he deems proper, brought forth some lively political discussion in the Senate to-day.
ALBANY, March 11. -- Senator Barnes's bill which provides for vestibules on all cars of street railways excepting in New York and Buffalo during the Winter months was passed by the Senate to-day.
TORONTO, March 11. -- A big sensation was sprung on the Ontario Legislature this evening, at its first session since the general election in May last.

Frank Damrosch, Director of Music of the Department of Education, has, on behalf of the Directors of the Oratorio Society of New York, invited the teachers of assembly music in the public schools of Manhattan and the Bronx to a special rehearsal of Edward Elgar's "The Dream of Gerontius," of which the text is Cardinal Newman's.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In you issue of March 10 I see where Capt. Piper, hot from Edward's islands, states that the New York police compare very unfavorably with the London police. Capt. Piper in his interview has uttered a few things that are facts, a few things that are not facts, and left unsaid considerable that are facts.

BERLIN, March 12 -- Count von Bernsdorf, President of the Potsdam Police, who recently returned to Germany from the United States, has submitted to Emperor William a written narrative of his experiences and observations in America, with appreciative notes on the New York police.

LONDON, March 12 -- The engagement's announced of Marshall O. Roberts, son of Mrs Ralph Vivian, formerly Mrs. Marshall O. Roberts of New York, to Miss Irene Helen Murray, daughter of Sir George Herbert Murray.

Water colors and oil paintings belonging to the collections of the late Clarence King, William H. Fuller, Theodore Well, and H. Victor Newcomb were sold last night at Mendelssohn, Hall, Fortieth Street, near Broadway, under the auspices of the American Art Association. Thirty-four water colors brought $6,155 and sixty-eight paintings brought the total for the evening's sale to $30,205.

PARIS, March 12 -- The Chamber of Deputies was the centre of great interest and animation to-day at the opening of the debate on the religious orders. A large crowd filled the galleries, and the floor of the Chamber was also crowded. The Ministerial bench was occupied by Premier Combes and most of his associates in the Ministry.

With the laudable intention of providing a place where true lovers of billiards can play under ideal conditions, the Amateur Billiard Club of New York, 113 and 115 Seventy-ninth Street, opened its rooms to the members and their guests last night. Some three or four hundred persons responded to the invitations, and all expressed their approval.
ALBANY, March 12 -- The Assembly Cities Committee to-day considered the Weber bill to inaugurate the two-platoon system in the New York Fire Department.

LONDON, March 13 -- The Czar's man- ifesto, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times, excites the greatest interest in Germany. As in regard to everything concerning the policy of "our Eastern neighbor," the inspired press offers nothing but praise, recalling the obsequious comments which greeted the Czar's eirenicon in spite of the views generally held in Germany in regard to arbitration.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Through agreements between the Democrats and Republicans way was cleared to-day for the ratification by the Senate of the Panama Canal treaty and the Cuban reciprocity treaty.
LONDON, March 13 -- A letter in the Eclair by a well-informed writer on Vatican affairs is quoted by the Paris correspondent of The Times.
BUFFALO, March 12 -- Thomas Murphy, Judge of the Police Court, announced this afternoon that he will hold the inquest into the death of Edwin L. Burdick next Tuesday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 12 -- The bodies of Arthur R. Pennell and his wife, the victims of Tuesday night's fatality at Gehre's quarry, were taken from the Niagara Street undertaking rooms to their former home in Cleveland Avenue this evening. After brief funeral services tomorrow they will be taken to Mr. Pennell's former home near Brunswick, Me., for interment.

The second of the six days' "sale ex- traordinary," in which "the magnificent house and its furnishings, 918 West End Avenue, corner of One Hundred and Fifth Street, formerly occupied by Don Eugenio Faria Goanzales de Teixeira, Marquis of Aguila Branca, a member of one of the foremost families in Brazil," are being dis- posed of at public auction, was held yesterday

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12 -- Mrs. George D. Evans, whose husband is connected with the American Transfer Company, and who whipped her way through the strikers yesterday, drove one of her husband's heavy freight vans again to-day. Strikers who saw her raised their hats.

In an action filed in the County Clerk's Office in Brooklyn yesterday, the defendant in a suit for broker's fees claimed freedom from liability as from an ordinary gambling debt. The action was brought by Samuel T. Welch, Henry Dixon, Alfred R. Thomas, and J. Andrews Harris, composing the firm of Ervine Co., stock brokers, of Philadelphia, against Edward V. Douglass of that city.
LONDON, March 13 -- A letter in the Eclair by a well-informed writer on Vatican affairs is quoted by the Paris correspondent of The Times.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 12 -- The Albany and Hudson Railroad Company was incorporated to-day with a capital of $27,000,000. The company has acquired the property and franchises of the Albany and Hudson Railway and Power Company, which operates the third rail electric line from this city to Hudson.

In an action filed in the County Clerk's Office in Brooklyn yesterday, the defendant in a suit for broker's fees claimed freedom from liability as from an ordinary gambling debt. The action was brought by Samuel T. Welch, Henry Dixon, Alfred R. Thomas, and J. Andrews Harris, composing the firm of Ervine Co., stock brokers, of Philadelphia, against Edward V. Douglass of that city.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Several important bills came up for consideration in the Senate to-day.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 12 -- The Chamber was densely crowded when the Ontario Legislature met this evening, and there was intense excitement owing to the bribery charges made last night by Mr. Gamey of Manitoulin against Provincial Secretary Stratton and other members of the Government.

BERLIN, March 12 -- Count von Bernsdorf, President of the Potsdam Police, who recently returned to Germany from the United States, has submitted to Emperor William a written narrative of his experiences and observations in America, with appreciative notes on the New York police.
At the conclusion of a well-attended meeting held to consider the proposed amendments to the tenement house law at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last night, the following resolution was adopted:

Detectives Rowland and Hore of the West Forty-seventh Street Station had a lively time yesterday in the capture of George Young, seventeen years of age, of 708 Eleventh Avenue on a charge of disorderly conduct. They chased him three times on the roofs of a row of houses on Fiftieth Street and then by strategy caught him.

ITHACA, March 12 -- The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of Cornell University this evening signed an agreement with the Ithaca Water Works Company by which the university loans the water company $150,000 for the construction of a filtration plant for the City of Ithaca.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- It was announced here to-night that Justice William R. Day of the United States Supreme Court is suffering from pneumonia. He has been confined to his apartments for several days, but no hint that he was seriously ill was given until to-day. After several reports had been denied, a bulletin was finally issued to-night by Dr. B.L. Haddin.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Through agreements between the Democrats and Republicans way was cleared to-day for the ratification by the Senate of the Panama Canal treaty and the Cuban reciprocity treaty.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The political aspect of the Senatorial and Assembly caucuses held here Tuesday night and last night, respectively, absorbed the attention of the legislators to-day. To those who are interested in State politics the caucuses seem to have had a far-reaching significance.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Herbert Welsh of Philadelphia to-day commented on the letters received by him from the Adjutant General's office relative to Mr. Welsh's recent suggestion that Gen. Funston and others be tried by court-martial on the charge of ordering the killing of prisoners at the battle of Caloocan.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 12 -- The Chamber was densely crowded when the Ontario Legislature met this evening, and there was intense excitement owing to the bribery charges made last night by Mr. Gamey of Manitoulin against Provincial Secretary Stratton and other members of the Government.

Water colors and oil paintings belonging to the collections of the late Clarence King, William H. Fuller, Theodore Well, and H. Victor Newcomb were sold last night at Mendelssohn, Hall, Fortieth Street, near Broadway, under the auspices of the American Art Association. Thirty-four water colors brought $6,155 and sixty-eight paintings brought the total for the evening's sale to $30,205.

Chief Engineer Parsons submitted to the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday his report on a proposed complete system of transit for the Borough Brooklyn. As in his recent report on Manhattan and the Bronx, he urgred the construction of new tunnels and many improvements in the privately controlled elevated railroads.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 12 -- The bodies of Arthur R. Pennell and his wife, the victims of Tuesday night's fatality at Gehre's quarry, were taken from the Niagara Street undertaking rooms to their former home in Cleveland Avenue this evening. After brief funeral services tomorrow they will be taken to Mr. Pennell's former home near Brunswick, Me., for interment.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Herbert Welsh of Philadelphia to-day commented on the letters received by him from the Adjutant General's office relative to Mr. Welsh's recent suggestion that Gen. Funston and others be tried by court-martial on the charge of ordering the killing of prisoners at the battle of Caloocan.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- At the March meeting of the Board of Trustees of the university held here this afternoon the Rev. Dr. Charles Woodruff Shields, Professor of the Harmony of Science and Revealed Religion in the university, tendered his resignation, to take effect next June. He is the fourth of the older members of the Faculty who have resigned in the past year.

LONDON, March 13 -- The leading St. Petersburg paper, the Novoe Vremya, in an article quoted by The Times's correspondent in the Russian capital, warmly applauds the Czar's announcement. It says that, while "the Mir" is to be maintained, it will be rendered easier for the peasants to sever themselves from their communal system, mutual responsibility for taxation being abolished.

Capt. Piper in his interview has uttered a few things that are facts, a few things that are not facts, and left unsaid considerable that are facts.

As in his recent report on Manhattan and the Bronx, he urgred the construction of new tunnels and many improvements in the privately controlled elevated railroads.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- It was announced here to-night that Justice William R. Day of the United States Supreme Court is suffering from pneumonia. He has been confined to his apartments for several days, but no hint that he was seriously ill was given until to-day. After several reports had been denied, a bulletin was finally issued to-night by Dr. B.L. Haddin.

Our exports of domestic products for the month of February show an increase of $20,266,966, as compared with February of last year. In cotton alone there was an increase of $12,654,565, and breadstuffs increased $5,885,256. In cattle and hogs, in meat and dairy products and mineral oils, an increase is also reported.

By the snapping of the overhead trolley wire of the Union Railway Company, Willis Avenue line, in front of 595 Southern Boulevard, where the line passes under the elevated railroad, late last night the motorman of car No. 6 was instantly electrocuted, terribly burned, knocked off his platform, and ground under the car, his body raising the car off the track.

Some three or four hundred persons responded to the invitations, and all expressed their approval.

Director Leist of the North German Lloyd Line arrived yesterday on board the Barbarossa for the purpose of inspecting the work on the line's piers in Hoboken, especially Pier No. 2, that should be ready on April 20. Soon after that date the new Kaiser Wilhelm II. will arrive and use the pier.

"Everyday English, Language Lessons for Intermediate Grades," by Mrs. Jean Sherwood Rankin, (Educational Publishing Company, 50c.,) is written in the form of a sustained monologue for the teacher to instill the essentials of grammar without protracted study on the part of the children.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 13. -- William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., has added another big tract to his already large holdings of real estate about Success Lake, in the town of North Hempstead. His agents have filed in the County Clerk's office here transfers of pieces of real estate aggregating about 110 acres.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 13. -- The text of the temporary injunction granted by Judge Horace H. Lurton of the United States Circuit Court this afternoon in the suits pending between the Harriman and Keene interests relative to the Union. Central, and Southern Pacific stock holdings is as follows:

BUFFALO, March 13. -- The will of Edwin L. Burdick, who was murdered here on the night of Feb. 27, was admitted to probate here to-day, with a stipulation which will permit Mrs. Burdick to contest the fourth paragraph, which appoints testamentary guardians for her children.

THE Anglo-Saxon Century and the Unification of the English-Speaking People," which is written by John R. Dos Passos, author of "Commercial Trusts," will be published by G.P. Putnam's Sons some time in the Spring.

LONDON, March 14. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times says that the press of the German capital, which on Thursday could find no praise too high for the general idea of the Czar's manifesto, yesterday adopted a cooler tone.

You catch some inkling as to the drift of Jaakoff Prelooker's story, "The New Israelite" when you glance over the names of the personages to whom the story is dedicated. The author pays his respects to the Bishops and pastors of Protestant churches, to the General of the Salvation Army, to the Dalai Lama, to the Mullas, to the Literati of Coniucianism, and to his Holiness the Pope of Rome.

The Lelibres, that pleasant little company of poets and romancers in Southern France, of which Frederic Mistral is easily the chief, are still grieving over the death of Felix Gras, one of their singing band, which occurred just as Avignon was about to decorate herself for a festival at which the Legion of Honor was to be handed to Gras with all the emotional surroundings which are to "Meridionales" the breath of life.

WAS Caesarism to die when Julius, pierced with twenty-three wounds, fell dead in the Senate House of Rome? The shattered fragments of the republic never were to be pieced together, for then was founded the empire, and the wonderful and somewhat enigmatical figure of Augustus came to the front.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In a paragraph on the Temple Primer of Mediaeval French Literature, by Gaston Paris, you say, (Feb. 28:) "The translation is marred by the retention of many Latinisms." If "Latinisms" means French words and expressions disguised in alleged English, you are well within bounds.

ALBANY, March 13.--That Senator Platt's autocratic power over the Republican organization of the State has been brought to an end hardly admits of a doubt in view of the further testimony obtained to-day an to how the caucus agreements on the Mortgage Tax and Excise Tax bills were brought about.

The special correspondence on the sanitary situation in Ithaca which has appeared in recent issues of THE NEW YORK TIMES will probably not be found agreeable reading by the people of that city, and perhaps not by the management of the university. When surgery is necessary it is usually the more merciful plan to cut as deep as is necessary to reach and uncover or excise the seat of the trouble.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- In conversation to-day President Roosevelt said that he believed Congress should be called in extraordinary session, to complete the things that were left undone by the last Congress. In this connection the Philippine Tariff and the Aldrich bills were named.

In a motion made by the Public Adminstrator of Kings County, to compel a plaintiff to file security for costs, before Justice Maddox in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, it was disclosed that there had lived and worked alone in a small store in Myrtle Avenue a man who had accumulated in his ninety years of life fully $50,000 in realty and personal property solely through miserly habits.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Streets in Richmond Borough are involved in the bill introduced to-day by Assemblyman Conkling providing that when the original paving of a street was macadam, the first repaving of it would be regarded as an original pavement, and the assessment be divided between the city and the property benefited.

IT WAS Cayley, or some one else of his time and temper, who thus encouraged his critics: I shall be deeply grateful to reviews. Whether they deign approval or rebuke. For any hints they think may disabuse Delusions of my inexperienced muse.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 13. -- The executive officials of the Pennsylvania lines west of Pittsburg are adopting measures to diminish the tip nuisance on their lines. It was announced this morning that train porters will no longer be permitted to perform such services as the turning of scats and like services for passengers in order to receive tips in return.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- Trading was in large volume to-day and business was better distributed, the market displaying a broadening tendency. The feeling in the Street was more cheerful than for a long time past, which was traceable to the substantial recovery in the consolidated Lake Superior issues, the common advancing 1 3/8 to 5 3/8, and the preferred 5 to 20 1/2.

RATHER more than five years ago the editor of The Atlantic Monthly asked Prof. Simon Newcomb, Superintendent of the Sautical Almanac to give the magazine some of the memories gathered during a life in which he had met a large proportion of the civilized persons worth meeting.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 13. -- Premier Laurier, replying to Mr. R.L. Borden, the opposition leader. In the House of Commons to-day on the Alaskan treaty, made a long statement showing the possibility always present of unpleasant consequences as long as the boundary question Was unsettled.

With the exception of President Ban Johnson, all of the American Baseball League officials and club representatives who have been in this city since the early part of last week, attending the annual meeting of that organization, left here for their respective homes yesterday. Before going away they expressed themselves as being delighted with the result of their endeavors to secure first-class playing grounds on Manhattan Island.

DAPPLETON CO., who are the publishers in America of W.E.H. Lecky's "History of England in the Eighteenth Century," in eight octavo volumes, are about to bring out in separate form those chapters of the work dealing with the French Revolution.

The minority stockholders of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company, who yesterday obtained a temporary injunction in the Sixth United States Circuit Court, sitting in Cincinnati, restraining the Union Pacific Company from voting its holdings in the Southern Pacific at the coming election at the latter's Board of Directors have decided to lay their case before the Attorney General of the United States in the event of their present proceedings being unsuccessful.

Senator ALLISON certainly cannot be called an innovator. He is a conservative of the conservatives in all that relates to the customs of the Senate, and as jealous as the most jealous of its prerogatives, whether conferred by the Constitution or usurped as opportunity has offered.

The English firm of advertising solicitors, T.B. Browne, Limited, have issued the seventeenth annual copy of their "Advertisers' A B C, the Standard Advertisement Press Directory." It is a large octavo of over 1,100 pases, bound in brilliant red, printed on heavy calendared paper, and extensively illustrated with samples of the firm's work as "picture advertisers."

Edith Wyatt has defined her admirable little story "True Love" as a comedy of the affections, and in her modesty seems to disclaim any attempt at satire. However, is remains for the reader to experience a delightful surprise in reading the book. The title is so suggestive of the milk-and-honey variety of novel that her absurdly natural observations on the lives of her subjects comes with a delicious and totally unexpected shock.

WE MAKE no apology for departing somewhat from the field of literature to discuss briefly some revelations concerning the first letter of the alphabet which we find in that "leading exponent of the new thought" called Mind.

The March number of The Booklovers' Magazine, though delayed in publication by the fire which destroyed the printing shop and bindery in Philadelphia, is in no way inferior typographically or pictorially to its predecessors. In a literary sense, too, a certain part of its contents strongly appeals to the genuine book lover.

The saying attributed to Sir Robert Walpole is perhaps almost too musty for quotation, the story of how, when his daughter attempted to beguile his illness, and asked what she should read to him, he made answer: "Anything but history. That I know is lies." He had made too much and seen how it was told to care to be told about that which he had not helped to make.

There must have been many in the recent audiences of Count Robert de Montesquiou who have been reminded of the odes and sonnets of Keats by the French poet's recitations from his own verse. To those who thought they grasped the Count's meaning comparisons must have been inevitable. For example, it would be interesting to place side by side Montesquiou's lines on the blue hyacinth with Keats's thirty-ninth sonnet.

At an all-day session of the employes of the Manhattan Railway Company in the Harlem Casino yesterday the men presented many grievances, all of which will be put in shape by the Executive Committee elected last night and presented by a subcommittee to the company--if the company will let them.

George M. Williamson, who last year described his remarkable Stevenson collection in an admirable catalogue, has privately printed a description of his special collection of Whitman's books, letters, and manuscripts. Only 127 copies have been issued, 102 on plate paper and 25 on Japan paper. A limited number of these will be sold by Dodd, Mead Co.

Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, handed down a decision late yesterday afternoon in which he granted a certificate of reasonable doubt to Duncan Young, convicted of murder in the second degree, by a jury in the Court of General Sessions, Manhattan, last November, before Judge Foster, for causing the death of a man named Eberhardt in East Seventh Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues.
LONDON, March 13. -- Money was firm in the market to-day, and the demand slackened slightly. Discounts were steady.

That a man who has a fondness for liquid spirits while on this earth has a harrowing and distressing time of it when he himself becomes a spirit, because of his inability to get an "eye-opener" or a "night cap," was declared yesterday at the convention of the New York State Spiritualists' Association in Crosby Hall, Brooklyn.

As one reads the of Inspector BROOKS to Commissioner GREENE explaining why he had not secured evidence against certain notorious gambling houses one's first impression is that really he ought not to suffer personally for the general inefficiency of the force at his disposal which he describes so minutely.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Through Treasurer Frank A. Branagan of the Philippine Archipelago, the Controller of the Currency has received reports of the condition on Dec. 31, 1902, of banks doing business in the Philippines.

The last of the week brings a few interesting entertainments and general rushing out to the country to enjoy the delightful weather. Tuxedo and Lakewood and the popular Chatsworth have their parties arranged. Although the season at Palm Beach is said to be over, very few of the people have drifted this way.

The immigration authorities on Eills Island, Busk Jevons, the agents of the steamship Hevelius, and the medical officers at Quarantine are in a quandary over the disappearance of a small satchel that is said to have contained several thousand dollars. The money was the property of Antonio Belens, a wealthy Brazilian, who was among the arrivals oh the Hevelius from Brazil last Wednesday.

Yesterday's stock market opened in Thursday's waiting mood, which passed into something like strength about midday. Money then became harder, suggesting unfavorable proapects regarding the bank statement, and announcement was made of the granting of the injunction in the Union Pacific-Southern Pacific case.

Between gratitude that he has not a cancerous growth in his mouth and chagrin that he has spent the savings of years and traveled 6,000 miles simply to have the root of a decayed tooth pulled, W.W. Waddell, a Presbyterian missionary from Brazil, is in what might be described as a state of mind.

The officers of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company have taken the shortest and the only effective way to put a stop to the evidently unfriendly gossip which for some weeks has been rife concerning the bookkeeping and the property of the company. They have opened their books for the fullest inspection of accountants representing the District Attorney, whose investigation is now in progress.

W.D. HOWELLS will have a new volume published this Spring. In all the author has produced fifty-nine published books, mostly novels. When he first began to write it was the poetic form which came most readily to his pen.

For the purposes evidently in view. Mr. Gardner's "Story of Siena and San Gimignano" is distinctive among the many guide books and hastily compiled histories of Italian cities in that it is the unostentatious work of a man who not only knows how to draw from his authorities, but also how to present the material thus drawn in an entertaining and entirely satisfactory manner.

Theodore Andrea Cook is an enthusiast in regard to the spiral, in his volume. "Spirals in Nature and Art,"he deduces innumerable forms known in architecture from the line lessons found in shells. Most entertaining is the way, described by the author, how it came about that his attention was directed to shells, their spirals, as having much to do with artistic line.
UTICA, N.Y., March 13. -- Fred Pray, aged twenty-one, is dead at his home in Sherburne from typhoid fever contracted while a student at Cornell University.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: AN excuse may be found for discossing the meaning of the name Hoboken in a literary paper in the fact that the word ceased to have merely a local interest and became of a National and extra-National one when Washington Irving introduced it to notice in his Knickerbocker's History of New York.

The seventh of the Philharmonic Society's afternoon concerts was given at Carnegie Hall yesterday, to be followed by the usual repetition this evening. The orchestra put its best foot forward in a spirited performance of Tschcaikowsky's fourth symphony in F minor and the three instrumental movements from Berlioz's "Romeo and Juliet," which he called a "dramatic symphony."

Neither Higginson's "Life" of Margaret Fuller, who later became the wife of the Marquis Giovanni Angelo Ossoli, nor her brief biography written by Josephine Lazarus refer to what is probably an important, although brief, episode in her career, which took place while she was living with the Greeley family in this city, between 1844 and 1846 -- just prior to her visit to Italy.

What is probably the first, and certainly the largest, movement ever undertaken in the direction of organizing the real estate interests of this city has just taken definite form in the shape of a call issued to about thirty of the most prominent men in really affairs to attend a meeting, to be held next Wednesday at 3:50 P.M. at the offices of the Knickerbocker Trust Company, 66 Broadway.

IN ST. AUGUSTINE Mr. McCabe finds a much larger subject than he found a short time since in Peter Abelard, bu-if, on the whole, he does not bring to it a talent corresponding to its significance, he gives us an imposing representation both of St. Augustine and his age: perhaps and quite certainly a more satisfactory account of the age than of the man.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 13. -- Ground was broken to-day for a large clubhouse at East Portchester, which, it is said, will be devoted to boxing matches under the provisions of a bill now before the Connecticut Legislature. It is practically admitted that Tom O'Rourke is the leading spirit in the club, and, althongh he failed to get consent from the Legislature two years ago, he feels quite confident of success this season.

Police Commissioner Greone moved swiftly yesterday after he had read Borough Inspector Brooks's reply to his request of last Monday in regard to what he had done, with the entire police force at his disposal and ample funds, since Feb. 2 to obtain evidence against gambling houses.

LONDON, March 13. -- John Murray announces to-day for early publication a new book on Dramatic Criticism by Arthur Bingham Walkley, who reviews the new plays for The Times. The book will have what American journalists call a "news value," because of the quarrel one of the playwrights, H.A. Jones, lately tried, without success, to force on Mr. Walkley and the editor of The Times.

The first visit of Paul to Ephesus was a very short one. It was when he was on his way from Corinth to Jerusalem, and lasted only while the vessel in which he had taken passage stopped to land and take on some passengers and cargo. Possibly some visitors from Ephesus to Corinth during the eighteen months of his ministry in that city may have heard him preach and made his acquaintance.

Possibly some visitors from Ephesus to Corinth during the eighteen months of his ministry in that city may have heard him preach and made his acquaintance.

-- There is general rejoicing in electrical circles over the expiration of the Brush patent for storage batteries. "This patent," says The Electrical World and Engineer, "covered absolutely the use of a metallic support in connection with any improvement offered, which claim practically closed the art to all except the owners of the patent, and rendered subsidiary to it the many hundreds of patents which irrepressible inventors nevertheless insisted upon taking out during its life.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13. -- Safe Guard and Denny Duffy were the only beaten favorites. Jena and Honey Brook were sold at private sale to M. Goldblatt. E. Wight bought Emshee at a reported price of $4,000, and Fickle Saint at private sale. Weather clear; track heavy. Summary:

WASHIXOTON, March 13. -- Capt. and Mrs. Charles Wendall Fenton, who are being very extensively entertained by their Washington friends, were the guests this evening at a dinner at the Chevy Chase Club, their hostess being Miss Wilson, daughter of the Secretary of Agriculture. Capt. Fenton leaves Monday for the Philippines.

That the Czar should be the person in all his dominions most warmly interested in Russian reforms is not only not wonderful. It is almost a necessary consequence of his position. His interest is literally vital. That system of "absolutism tempered by assassination" which was long ago defined as the Government of Russia holds the ruler "personally responsible" for whatever goes intolerably wrong, in the absence of any Ministers who can be held so responsible.
CHICAGO, March 13. -- Prosecution of Indiana coal operators who were indicted by the Grand Jury here for conspiracy to keep up prices ended abruptly before Judge Chetlain to-day.

A GREAT outcry has been raised over the very small discovery that Mrs. Humphry Ward did not invent the "situation" out of which she developed her new novel, but took it ready made from what in the confession that has been expected very easily -- from her, she calls that treasure house of human psychology, "The world of French memoirs."

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The action taken by the Venezuelan Government in raisins the Orinoco blockade was received here with great relief, for although there were no outward symptoms of trouble it is now known that the enforcement of the decree probably would have resulted in serious friction, perhaps involving a re- newal of hostilities.

It may now be definitely stated that the two volumes of "New Letters and Memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle," which have so long been in preparation, will be issued within the fortnight. From a purely literary and biographical point of view it is probably the most important publication ever undertaken by John Lane.

RAWLINS COTTONET is not the first club composer or clubman whose music has been played in New York. Mr. Cottonet is a nephew of Mrs. William Schermerhorn. For many years he was more or less identified with the Meadow Brook Hunt. He was educated abroad, and he plays excellently well, so that he has many and varied accomplishments.

PARIS, March 14 -- With the approach of Spring society is becoming distinctly more lively, and though American visitors to Europe are not numerous yet, a big invasion is expected to begin before long, especially now that the Horse Show is in sight and racing has begun.

The heartiness of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S welcome at Southampton yesterday seems to denote a belief, not confined to that port, but extending throughout the United Kingdom, that during his absence he has been engaged in doing good work for the British Empire. If it implies also that he has been much needed at home we do not see that any fault is to be found with that implication.

It was characteristic of the conditions and necessities long prevalent at the Metropolitan Opera House that the production of the one novelty promised there this year should have been put off till the last fortnight, so that only two performances of it will have been possible before the close of the season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to protest emphatically against the vehement statements of a letter writer named Henry L. Gavan (issue 9th inst.,) on the above topic, for the gentleman is entirely wrong in his historical data and therefore in his conclusions.
HOW well you are looking?" gushed the President of the Psychological Society to the tall, brown-haired girl just back from a trip to the Philippines. "And how did you enjoy your vacation? "

A recent issue of the Frankfurter Zeitung has some tart remarks on the German Consular Service in which that excellent paper says some true things, yet fails to get at the bottom of the matter. It is true that on the whole, and more particularly as regards England, Germany, France, Switzerland, and Holland, our Consular system offers certain features which are properly admired by European experts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whether for its essential verity, timeliness, or generosity, I have rarely read anything with more real satisfaction than your summary of some of the traits of Mr. Beecher in the article printed to-day mainly about Mr. Cleveland. You say: "From his prayer meeting in Plymouth to the ragins mob in Liverpol there was no assembly of human beings on which he could not work his will."

The United States covers an arear of 3,025,600 square miles, populated to the extent of 76,303,387, or 25.22 per square mile. The per capita circulation of money is now $29.48. A Treasury statement reports the total circulating medium as $2,355,750,000, an increase of something over seven millions of dollars for the month of January.

HAVANA, March 11 -- There are a large number of colored people in Cuba, and the color problem is one which assumes an unpleasant aspect from time to time. There seems to be no danger, however, of the island becoming a black republic. The negroes have never been the predominating race either in numbers or power.

AN INTERESTING experiment has been begun this past week among the phthisical patients at the Manhattan State Hospital West, the woman's department for the insane on Ward's Island. Physical ills are often the cause and many times accompany the mental troubles, and there is a special so-called ward, which is actually a separate building, for patients suffering from tuberculosis at the Ward's Island hospital.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- M. Jusserand, the French Ambassador, was the guest of honor at the banquet of the University of Chicago, which was held at the Auditorium to-night. The occasion was made a reunion of the alumni of the institution, and more than 600 guests were present. The banquet was preceded by a reception at the Fine Arts Building, which adjoins the Auditorium.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 27 -- The Socialist press announces that a vigorous revolutionary and republican campaign is about to be undertaken in the Flemish provinces of the kingdom, now represented in Parliament almost exclusively by Catholic Conservatives.

YES, I'm observing Lent this year, and you don't know how nice it is. Of course, I'm not an Episcopalian, but there's an Episcopal church on our block, and people always have such a complacent look as they pass with their Prayer Books that I thought I'd go, too, and see if I couldn't get that expression.

The wedding of S. Osgood Pell of Oils city and Miss Elizabeth Warden of Pittsburg was celebrated very quietly on Friday last at the plantation of the bride's mother, at Camden, S.C. The bride is a cousin of Mrs. Charles Hoffman, and, with her mother, she occupied during the past Winter an apartment at 121 Madison Avenue.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 14 -- The contest between Bishop Bonacum and Father Murphy is of long standing, and grew out of an attempt on the part of the Bishop to force Father Murphy, pastor of St. Andrew's congregation at Tecumseh, to compel his parishioners to contribute a large sum of money for the erection of a palace for the Bishop at Lincoln.

Nothing that has happened in a long time, having a bearing upon the real estate activities of this city, is likely to be hailed with greater expressions of satisfaction than the movement, actively undertaken on Friday, to the end that, when it is proper for real estate interests to be heard, some means of forcible expression will not be lacking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES'S editorial column of to-day under the subject of "Independent Cuba," is not the whole argument regarding Cuba's necessities so abundantly advertised and perhaps sometimes sincerely, too, fairly negatived by the admission that Cuba is now prosperous?

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to Dr. Maxwell's attack on our city colleges, I should like to state these facts: High school plus college is not rip to New York educational thought: the idea has not yet been vaccinated with "New Yorkitis,'' and still has the country thought of collegiate and secondary education.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 14 -- The Texas Legislature has passed a law providing for the extermination of prairie dogs. The stockmen and farmers of the panhandle region of the State have been trying for many years to have such a law enacted, but the matter had always met with so much ridicule in the Legislature that nothing was accomplished.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Leo Schlesinger's action before the Assembly Committee on Banking in holding up such bulwarks of financial strength as the United States Trust Company, Farmers Loan and Trust Company, and a few others of such character as examples of loose banking methods will not help the cause he endeavored to represent: on the contrary, it will tend to hurt it.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Estcs G. Rathbone, who was Director of Post Offices at Havana under the American military Government, and who was convicted of misuse of funds, but was pardoned under the general amnesty proclaimed by President Palma, has made public a statement of his case.

LONDON, March 14 -- Public speakers here have a stereotyped form of words for beginning after-dinner proceedings. It is "In every assembly of Englishmen the first toast is that of the King." Let me follow their example and give the place of honor to their Majesties, who have this week celebrated at Buckingham Palace the fortieth anniversary of their marriage.
