ST. LOUIS, March 14 -- United States Circuit Judge Elmer B. Adams this afternoon denied the motion of the Wabash counsel for an order requiring that certain letters, communications, and records written and received by the committee leaders and lodges of the Wabash trainmen and firemen be produced.

Mr. DEAR," said I to my brand-new wife, "that sewing machine is crying to heaven for oil. It is absurd to run a piece of mechanism without the necessary lubricant. Not alone will you spoil the machine, but you are apt to strain yourself driving it."

Mr. Bernard Shaw is a proud and happy man. Playwrights there are who rejoice when their plays are produced. Mr. Shaw, who is paradoxical in everything and always refreshingly witty with it all, has hoisted his flag because a play of his has been suppressed. In Vienna it has been decreed that "Arms and the Man,' made familiar here by Mr. Mansfield, is revolutionary.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 14 -- A commission under the Presidency of Minister of the Interior von Plehwe has already commenced work for formulating a method for carrying out the reforms in provincial administration, as commanded in the Czar's recent decree.

HAVANA, March 14 -- The United States ship Dolphin with Secretary Moody and the Congressional party on board arrived here from Key West at 3:30 this afternoon and saluted the fortresses at the entrance to the harbor with twenty-one gains and the lowering of the Secretary's flag. Cabanas returned the salute.
PARIS, March 14 -- M. Legouve, the dramatist and member of the French Academy, died suddenly this morning.

WE HAD hunted Easter eggs: we had played "Cock Fight" with the harder of them until nearly all were broken. We had listened to old Easter legends that our grandmother told us, and then we bethought ourselves of "The Quarter." that chief theatre ever open for our amusement.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Representatives of the army and navy athletic associations met in conference here to-day to discuss future athletic contests between the two institutions. No agreement was reached, and the conference was adjourned without a date for another meeting being decided upon.

DELHI, Jan. 12 -- AS we all assembled for 9 o'clock breakfast in the dining tent of our camp on the second day of the Delhi Durbar the talk was all of polo, not of the opening of the Arts Exhibition; but that was to be accounted for easily, as three-quarters of those gathered around the small tables were young men, the army arid the civil service being well represented.

THE Greek Government has just issued a decree which gives to the Minister of Public Instruction a monopoly of the sale of school books, from which it is expected that a sum of $200,000 annually will accrue to the exchequer.
UP and down these streets, in and out of those buildings -- lower New York has its own peculiar phantoms to-day, the Ghosts of the Law!"

WE ARE all familiar with the mild crank who devotes his time searching for that queer specimen of the genus homo known as nature's nobleman. If he could have been a passenger in an elevated train the other morning he would have encountered his rara avis and at the same time have received a back-hand blow that would have knocked his theories into a cocked hat.

LONDON, March 14 -- The release of $500,000 by the paying off of India bills increased the supplies of money somewhat in the market to-day, but it had little effect on rates. Discounts tended to be easier in view of the Continental demand for bills.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 14 -- During the past Winter the North Jersey coast has experienced one of the greatest building booms in many years. It is estimated that $2,000,000 will scarcely cover the amount expended in new buildings. There are many Summer homes in course of construction at present, while a number have been completed since the close of the 1902 season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg to call the attention of THE TIMES to an application for an electric surface railroad franchise covering the Bronx Borough which is before the Board of Aldermen for adoption. The application is made by the Interborough Railroad Company. Among the routes under the franchise are specified one on the Washington Bridge and one on Aqueduct Avenue.

The concurrent action of Commissioner MONROE, on the exact and valuable information furnished by his engineers, and the Mayor on the Commissioner's recommendations, looking to a means of rescuing the city from what is not improperly designated as an impudent monopoly, is certainly interesting and may very well be a great deal more significant than those interested in the gas and electric light business may be pleased to consider it at the moment.

IT IS but natural to associate certain habits, traits, tastes, and preferences with certain families and species of birds. Though these habits can by no means be accounted for, they can be relied upon to a certain extent as regards species. Yet the feathered side of nature is full of contradictions.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The third general memorandum of the cotton crop of India for the season 1902-3, issued by the Statistical Department of the Government, is summarized in a report from R.F. Patterson, Consul General at Calcutta, recently received here.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of March 8 I was amused to read a communication regarding "Pharmaceutical Education," by Dr. Robinson.
Week's Calendar. Monday -- Madison Square. Elsie de Wolfe, as Cynthia. Proctor's Fifty-eighth Street House. "Busy Izzy."

Mme. Malwine Bree, a pupil and for years an assistant of the great teacher of the pianoforte. Theodor Leschetizky, is the author of a handsome volume entitled "The Groundwork of the Leschetizky Method." (G. Schirmer.) An excellent and unusual feature of it is the illustration of the master's hand in various positions and performing various movements upon the keyboard by forty-seven well-executed halftone pictures.

WILLIAMSTOWN, March 14 -- The students of Williams College to-night celebrated Shirt-tail Parade and settled the annual cane difficulty by burning the hatchet in a great bonfire. The struggle of the sophomores, although shorter in duration, was much more fierce than ever before.

DENBEIGH HALL was in the flood tide of its regular "at home." Denbeigh Hall, so called from its London prototype, was one of those escape valves of modern altruism known as social settlements with which the east side dwellers of New York are now as familiar as with their own delicatessen shops.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent of yours recently took occasion to rebuke somewhat severely the savings bank employes in this city for their uncivil demeanor toward depositors. I have had considerable dealings with the savings institutions of New York, and while I have occasionally seen acts of discourtesy under provoking circumstances.

Edward Elgar's cantata. "The Dream of Gerontius," which the Oratorio Society will sing at Carnegie Hall Thursday evening, March 26, will have its first American performance three days earlier in Chicago by the Apollo Musical Club. At the New York performance of "The Dream of Gerontius" Frank Damrosch will conduct and the soloists will be Miss Ada Crossley, the Anglo-Australian contralto; Ellison Van Hoose, and David Bispham.

With a silver spike and a gilded steel hammer Mayor Low fastened down the first rail of the underground road yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was very formal. Heads of city departments, Rapid Transit Cimmissioners, tunnel engineers, capitalists, a few women, and about a hundred other favored spectators gathered underneath the Columbus statue, at Broadway and Fifty-ninth Street, at 3 o'clock, and a few minutes later the Mayor made his speech and drove down the spike.

The Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company met in the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon and adjourned after a two-hour session without taking any announced action in the matter of the pending strike of trainmen and conductors. All except two of the Directors were present, and the time was consumed by a general discussion of the situation after President John M. Hall had reported on behalf of the road's administration.
BERLIN, March 14 -- A scandalous review of American life is contained in a new book entitled "American Diary of a Wayward Prussian Lieutenant" by Curt von Biedenfeld, which is being extensively read.

President H.H. Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company has been summoned to a police court to show cause why he should not be punished for criminal libel for calling William N. Amory a "notorious character" and accusing Mr. Amory of improper motives in instigating the recent fraud charges against the company.

LONDON, March 14 -- The week opened with an uneasy feeling in all departments of the business world owing to the New York bank statement, which disturbed bankers, bill brokers, stock brokers, and the public, causing a rise in money and a fall in securities. The tendency improved later on American steadiness and rumors of Government relief.

BERLIN, March 2 -- The Prussian Diet listened to-day to a debate such as it has not heard since the famous Kulturkampf. The only difference between then and now is that at that time the ultramontane party of Germany was in the minority, while now it has the largest number of members in the Reichstag.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Mayor is making a splendid effort to set the best ferry service possible for Staten Island, yet there seems to be a possible chance of his asking more than will be giver. The recent hearing before the Sinking Fund Trustees developed one or two interesting conditions.

It may be said that railroad earnings are in line for further expansion from traffic if not from rates, despite the level they now touch. Let us look for a moment into this feature. A large community is that engaged in the largest industry in the country, agriculture. This community has shown lately what its condition is by the traffic it creates in response to the traffic it furnishes.

Discussion among golfers during the past week was chiefly centred upon the method to be employed in playing the annual amateur championship. The Executive Committee of the United States Golf Association has mentioned four systems, all of which have been advised by some players as suitable to give a correct and impartial test of championship golf.

The period between two disquieting ank statements is entitled to be called epressing and the wonder is that prices ere not depressed more during the past eek. Comparing the Friday nights of st week and the previous week active ndustrials' averages fell 0.71 per cent., nd active railways fell 1.60.
JOSEPH F. ROPES, a millionaire citizen of Norwich, Conn., died at his home there yesterday after a long illness. Mr. Ropes was born in Boston in 1819.

JOHN KINGSLAND was a splendid engineer. I say "was" not that he is dead, but because somehow he has dropped out of sight building that "across the Andes" railroad. What I was going to say was that if John had been as discerning and quick of judgment when it came to women as he was when it came to gauging a track, why then he probably would not be where he is now.

Nevada Gulch News, July 10 -- Judge Bowie of the Eleventh Judicial District Court, handed down a decision yesterday against Foot, the fake investor from the East, who was suing John Early for alleged frauds in connection with the purchase of the Little Johnny. Foot left last night for Boston.

IT WAS little Harold's ambition to go to Columbia College. His father was educated there, and so were his three uncles. He had never heard of any other place of learning, and to his youthful mind it was the embodiment of all useful knowledge.

Those opposed to the present tendency of the courts to extend the area of their protective influence by broadening the scope of their restraining powers will find food for thought in a motion lately made to the Circuit Court of Chicago by a citizen of that town, praying that an injunction issue restraining his wife from pulling any more hairs out of his head or beard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is it not rather comical to hear that a great scientist has been trying to prove that the earth is the centre and chief object of all created or developed things? And yet we have lately seen an apparently serious discussion of this notion by Prof. Wallace.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- "Bud " Higgins, a mulatto, on trial for the murder of Mrs. Annie Butler, created consternation in the courtroom to-day by confessing on the witness stand that he committed the crime.

SLIPPERY SIDEWALKS -- A judgment for damages recovered by Charles Wittman against this city because of injuries which he received by slipping and falling on an ice-covered sidewalk in front of the fire engine house on East Fifth Street has been reversed by the Appellate Division. The plaintiff's evidence was to the effect that the slippery condition of the sidewalk was caused by a defective leader on the engine house.
The Maine House of Representatives has refused by a vote of 94 to 46 to resubmit to the vote of the people the constitutional amendment prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquors within the State.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 14 -- P.K. Burnham of Erie, Penn., who had a handicap of 20, won the Carolina Cup, offered for the best gross score, with 85 strokes in to-day's golf tournament. G.F. Steele of Brookline, Mass., who had a handicap of 18, won the net score cup with 75 net.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- H.D. Scott again won the amateur racquet championship of Philadelphia in the court of the Philadelphia Racquet Club to-day by defeating Robert Kelso Cassatt in three of the five games played, the final score being: Scott, 61 aces; Cassatt, 44.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The characteristic traits in the average Englishman are very clearly shown by the actions of Great Britain, appealed to, as she has been by Canada, to have reversed, or, in other words, to possess more than the originally acquiesed in, international agreement entitles her to, or Canada to, in the matter of the Alaskan boundary line.
The board of officers appointed to meet at New York City for the examination of candidates for appointment as Chaplains, United States Army, is dissolved.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The last set speech on the Panama Canal treaty was made to-day, when Senator Spooner took the floor in executive session to reply to Senator Morgan, with whose views he differed radically. On Monday the general debate will begin, limited to fifteen-minute speeches, and on Tuesday the amendments and the treaty itself will be voted on.

The rapid development of the automobile as a practical and economical vehicle is causing considerable speculation as to the part which it is destined to play in solving the important problem of rapid transit in large, cities. That it will ultimately supersede the horse drawn vehicle for both business and pleasure use in cities is generally admitted, but to what extent, if any, it will replace electric or steam cars is yet an open question.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14 -- Although New Orleans experienced the heaviest rainfall in many years to-day, the Mississippi River to-night shows no rise, and is up 19.2 feet, only a few inches under the record high-water mark of six years ago.

NEW JERSEY years ago found a solution of the Coroner problem with which the statesmen at Albany have just begun to struggle. The public men of the Commonwealth across the Hudson had long observed that the Coroner was about as necessary to the administration of justice as a fifth wheel to a coach, and began to look around for means of disposing of him.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14 -- John E. Madden and Hildreth divided the honors of to-day's racing. The winner of the Crescent City Derby, Witful, bred by the former and owned by the latter, galloped home twelve lengths in front of her field and joined Modesty and May Hempstead in the list of fillies who have figured as Derby winners.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much interested in reading your remarks in yesterday's TIMES on the subject of applause, but the remarks of the star actor mentioned had much better have been omitted. Mr. Bellew has always had the, credit of being a well-bred man, and if he ever made such remarks it looks as if his profession had metamorphosed him.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 14 -- The flood situation remains practically unchanged. At Ashland the breach in the private levee is widening and a vast area is under water. Refugees continue to arrive at Memphis.

Up to the time of the publication of the bank statement there was no market worthy of the name. The tape stood still for moments at a time, and it was clear that neither the bulls nor the bears cared to make further market commitments until it should develop how the banks surplus reserves stood.

MEDFORD, Mass., March 14 -- Word was received here to-day of the death of Mrs. Charles Brooks Clark, who traveled half way around the world and overcame military red tape to keep her promise to marry Lieut. Charles Brooks Clark of the Sixth Infantry, United States Army, now stationed at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.

PLAUEN, Saxony, March 14 -- All the weavers of lace curtains have formed a combination to regulate the prices of production for three years. The mills in this vicinity sell largely to the United States, and it is expected that prices will advance and thereby affect export orders.
ST. STEPHEN, N.B., March 14 -- An explosion of celluloid in the candy manufactory of Ganong Brothers to-day caused a fire loss of $125,000 and has temporarily deprived 300 employes of work.

The enthusiasm which met the advent of M. Raffaelli's paint sticks has begun to be sicklied o'er with the pale cast of doubt, and even the show in London, where a painter of the rank of M. Besnard was willing to show how near to a water color he could get by using these sticks, has not convinced the skeptics.

MOLLY CARSON stood at the top of the kitchen stairs shielding with glowing fingers the candle that she held above her head. She heard mice scurrying about among the pans that Aunt Sally had left on the table when she went to her cabin for the night, and she shrank from venturing into the darkness below.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

In arranging the schedule of dates for the lawn tennis tournaments of the coming season, several important changes have been made which particularly affect the Metropolitan District. Probably the intention of the Executive Committee of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association is to make the tournaments near New York City stretch over the entire season instead of practically all being within the month of June, as has been the case in former years.

The Greater New York Baseball Association was incorporated at Albany yesterday, with a capital of $100,000, to operate the American League baseball franchise in this city, to maintain athletic grounds and provide for the holding of athletic contests, including baseball, football, and general track events.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It might scarcely be worth while to waste words in criticism of the letter of a Mr. Gavan relating to the statue of Frederick the Great were it not for the fact that the ignorance of history displayed in that letter is by no means confined to himself.

The Russo-Persian Commercial Treaty. Although, as was stated in these columns Feb. 22, the new Russo-Persian treaty appeared on the surface to be merely a substitution of specific duties for the 5 per cent, ad valorem duties on Russian commodities entering Persia, it has remained for the St. Petersburg Bourse Gazette to show how far-reaching the results of the treaty may be.

NO one but the very closest observer might have guessed that she was an artist, so artfully had she disguised her profession. Not a vestige of the "artistic abandon " was discernible about her dress -- no concessions to " color schemes," no odd shapes or fabrics -- but a very correct and stylish tout ensemble gave her quite the appearance of a leader of fashion rather than a worshipper of the paintbrush and easel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is there no remedy under a reform Government for the crying evils of the D.P. W.? Before my window at this moment are four employes of this department, or of the Sub-Department of Highways, leaning on their hoes. One is supporting his manly form by a telegraph pole.

FOR the first time in my life," said the woman who is prematurely gray. "I am actually blessing a whole carload of men, not one of whom offered me a seat. By retaining their grip on the advantages of street car travel they have restored my self-respect and made me feel quite buoyant and youthful.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The country owes a debt of gratitude to the President for his timely, bold, and outspoken words regarding "race suicide." A true patriot is one who will not try to ignore or cover the faults of his country, but will try to correct them. The situation is a serious one.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Before the Fifty-seventh Congress dissolved a large number of its Republican members called on the President and urged him to appoint Mr. Mercer of Nebraska to succeed Gov. Merriam as Director of Census, the latter having resigned to take effect May 1.
NAT GOODWIN receives many letters in the course of a dramatic season. While playing in Brooklyn recently he and his dog inspired the following, which is probably the most original in his collection:
THE great financier was pacing hastily up and down his private office, with a frown of perplexity mussing his brow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Tenement Shade Tree Committee is indebted to you for the generous space alloted it in your editorial columns of March 1. To dignify our modest efforts with as extended notice as would be given a project for two or three new East River bridges is certainly flattering.

Capt. Allies O'Reilly, who only three months ago was selected by Commissioner Greene as the one man to usher in the era of reform in the Tenderloin, was yesterday taken away from that precinct and sent back to Brooklyn with part of the task admittedly unperformed, Sergt. John W. O'Connor, who has been doing clerical work at Police Headquarters, was promoted and sent to fill the place made vacant through the transfer of Capt. O'Reilly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a poor, ignorant foreigner of the pauper-labor variety I beg to make my humble plea for the preservation of a language which I have learned to love, but I which my friends to the manner born treat with the scantiest courtesy.

VICTORIA, B.C., March 14.--The suit entered by Edna Wallace Hopper against James Dunsmuir of this city, the millionaire coal man and proprietor of one-third of Vancouver Island, promises to be an interesting one. It also shows promise of being a very expensive one to whoever loses the case.
NORWICH, Conn., March 14 -- The hearing on the examination of the accounts of the executors of the A.P. Sturtevant estate was continued in the Probate Court today before Judge Parson.
IF I were in Congress," said the earnest citizen, "I'd introduce a bill to pay the campaign expenses of both parties out of the Public Treasury."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Charges were filed with the President to-day by T.C. Campbell, a well-known lawyer of Cincinnati, in which it is alleged that with the connivance of the postal authorities the mails are being improperly used in carrying matter that is fraudulent in character and the transmission of which is forbidden by law.

HAS it ever occurred to you who are the real gardeners of the forests?" asked an old friend of the Central Park squirrels." I never heard a theory propounded that animals plant trees, but from what I have observed during ten years of friendship with the Park squirrels I am satisfied they, and not the acorn, are father to the oak.

BERLIN, March 14 -- Undisguised displeasure exists in German naval circles over America's new naval programme. The disappointing results of the Venezuela expedition have been driven bitterly home and the reflection that this expedition was undoubtedly chiefly responsible for the mighty increase of the American fleet is not a happy one.

A BIG lozenge-shaped room, with a high ceiling, a smooth, polished hardwood floor and almost no furniture, is the health gymnasium. Against the wall are light clothes-horses covered with dull green cloth. When drawn out they help with the wall to form convenient little dressing rooms for the pupils, or patients, as some of them are more properly called.

The Committee on Securities of the New York Stock Exchange, rules, that due bills representing all the rights to subscribe which may be authorized must accompany all voting trust certificates for first and second preferred and common stocks of the Erie Railroad Company delivered after March 20.

LONDON, March 14 -- King Edward, Queen Alexandra, the Princess Victoria, Prince and Princess Charles of Denmark, and three of the children of the Prince of Wales, all attended by their suites, occupied a specially constructed royal box at the Olympia this afternoon and seemed to thoroughly enjoy the Wild West Show.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt have issued invitations to dinner for Friday, March 20.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 14 -- Railroad and hotel men estimate the number of visitors on the Island to-night as over one hundred thousand. This number is 50 per cent. greater than that at the same period last year. This visiting population has remained about stationary during the week and practically all those who are now on the Island are here to remain until after the Easter Day parade.

LONDON, March 14 -- "Southampton Welcomes Home Britain's Empire Statesman," in huge letters, surrounded and intertwined with Union Jacks and Stars and Stripes, was the motto that first greeted Colonial Secretary Chamberlain and Mrs. Chamberlain on landing at Southampton this morning from South Africa.

There will be some gaudy structures along the river front in about four weeks. These are the seven recreation piers in Greater New York, and the embellishing of them in soon to take place. Long ago Dock Commissioner McDougall Hawkes decided to greatly improve these structures, which draw an average attendance every Summer day of about 28,000 persons, so as to make them not only more comfortable, but considerably more attractive in appearance.

Jacob Schoenhof, United States Consul at Tunstall, England, during President Cleveland's administration and an authority on the tariff and economic subjects, died of general debility at 399 West Twenty-ninth Street yesterday. He was appointed Consul in 1884. Tunstall is a great pottery district, and he was appointed to the post under the belief that his observations there would be of value to the Government.

PARIS, March 14 -- The Foreign Office to-day made public the text of the Franco-Venezuelan protocol providing for the payment of the claims of France against Venezuela. It is identical with the agreement on the same subject between Venezuela and the Unites States. The text was printed in full in the Temps and other newspapers, with favorable comments.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 14 -- The Republican City Convention to-day nominated Harvey D. Goulder for Mayor by acclamation. Mr. Goulder is an attorney and is President of the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce.

SOME of the theatre doors of New York are as individual in character as are the men who operate the houses, and if inanimate things may be supposed to have idiosyncrasies, these entrances into the realms or joy -- or otherwise -- may be adjudged to have their share.

Mid Lent shows no abatement of small entertainments, although one might well say that it is anything but gay at the present time. There are luncheons and dinners and the inevitable bridge and cards. The crowds are coming back from Palm Beech. There is the usual stop at St. Augustine for a few days, but the end of March finds Florida uncomfortably warm.

Annoyed by three young men, Louis Castilino, an Italian fruit dealer, known as "Joe the Bum," ran wildly through crowds of people in West Forty-ninth Street last night, firing a revolver as he went. When he had emptied the weapon he was set upon by nearly two thousand people, who beat him until he was unconscious.

NOTHING in the matter of apparel is more interesting to the average woman than hats, for nothing will add to or detract from her good looks more than her hats. The wonder is that so many wear chapeaus more or less trying. Many charming Spring creations are now making their appearance, and one example with lavender-colored thistles is illustrated herein.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- There was unusual interest in one of the early matches in the local squash racquet championship tournament to-day in the courts of the Philadelphia Racquet Club from the fact that it brought together two old football players whose work in their respective positions on the gridiron nearly a decade ago was highly meritorious.

It is not at all surprising that the German press, after a few preliminary and perfunctory compliments to the Czar on his reform decree, should proceed to pick holes in it. The Berlin Post remarks that, after critical examination, "it is soon apparent that there is reason enough and to spare for discounting exaggerated illusions very considerably."
CONGRESSMAN TAYLER of Ohio, while expressing his admiration for Congressman Cannon of Illinois, who is to become Speaker of the next House of Representatives, said:

CHESTER, Penn., March 14 -- A great throng lined the water front of Roach's shipyard this afternoon and cheered as the City of Macon glided gracefully from the ways to the bosom of the Delaware. The new craft is a twin-screw streamship, sister to the City of Memphis, and is owned by the Ocean Steamship Company.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 9 -- They -- which means Oklahoma in its best attitude -- are talking of erecting a statue to David H. Payne. They should There was a hero. Ever hear of Payne? 'Spose not. He was the early prophet of Oklahoma -- prophet, boomer, risker, sacrificer.

A contest of an unusual nature has arisen over the estate of Felix Kucielski, a former Austrian, but a naturalized citizen of the United States, who died abroad three years ago. The litigation brings out the issue as to whether the Austrian courts can secure money placed on deposit by Kucielski in New York banks, as against the interests of relatives in this country.

Ever since the number of yachts became so large, and their variety of design so great, that it became necessary in the interests of fair and good racing to devise some system of handicapping, the great problem among yachtsmen has been to formulate a measurement rule which should adequately tax abnormal features, and put the proper premium upon skill in handling.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 14 -- The flight northward from Palm Beach of the goiters has set in. and most of them have Lakewood as their objective point. They are gathering here for the Spring tournament of the Country Club, which begins on April 17. Warm rains have had a magical effect on the links, and they are now in finer condition for play than they have ever been at this time of year.

Workmen grading the Tenth Avenue extension through the northernmost end of Manhattan Island during the past week have unearthed portions of about a dozen ancient human skeletons in a little knoll about where Two Hundred and Eleventh Street will some day run. Some were nearly complete, but of others only the larger bones remain.

Much, if not all, of the controversy between interests responsible for, and those opposed to, the policy of management of the Southern Pacific -- in other words, to use the Street's designation, between the Keene and Harriman forces -- turns upon the use made of Southern Pacific's income for improvement purposes.

Until the appearance of the bank statement there was nothing doing upon the Exchange, except a decline of 3 1/2 for the day in Consolidated Gas upon the report of its difficulties with the city. After the appearance of the statement business was not active, but it was good in tone, the above decline being the only one exceeding a fraction among active properties, while advances were numerous, although small.

Columbia's runners secured a notable victory over the teams of the University of Pennsylvania and Cornell in the two-mile intercollegiate team relay race at the second annual Winter games of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association in the Madison Square Garden last night, coming up from last place in the very last lap of the final relay, and winning by the narrow margin of only six inches.

NOT all the changes in telephone numbers are made through the exigencies of business. A good many are made at the request of subscribers who are impelled to seek the change through mere whims. Men whose business it is to assign numbers to telephones and to distribute them among subscribers are authority for the not original statement that there is no accounting for tastes.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--President Roosevelt, at the request of the Senate and in conformity with a resolution adopted in executive session, has returned for further consideration the nomination of William Plimley to be Assistant Treasurer of the United States at New York. Mr. Plimley's nomination had been confirmed by the Senate and the President had actually made out his commission, but had not forwarded it, when the request from the Senate reached the White House.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 14 -- Gov. A. B. Cummins announced unexpectedly this afternoon to the delegates in the Polk County Republican Convention that he would carry on a campaign to introduce the "Iowa idea" for tariff revision in the National Convention, and endeavor to have it incorporated in the National platform in 1904.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 14 -- Out toward Jacob Park, and well hidden by splendid trees along and beyond the southern parkway, lies the tiny suburb of Beechmont, which is the legal home of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company. Its greatest ambition is to count within its limits 200 inhabitants that it may become an incorporated village.

The St. Paul Road, which has been prominent for some time past in providing disappointments for Wall Street, chiefly owing to the failure of expected plums to ripen and fall according to non-official schedule, has within the past week furnished a disappointment as to earnings. Published January receipts showed a decrease in gross slightly exceeding $100,000, and this for a period in which it was known that most railroads were choked with traffic.

TACOMA, Washington, March 7 -- William M. Fitzhugh, a well-known British mining expert, left this week for Eagle, on the American Yukon, to start immense hydraulic operations for an English syndicate. He is accompanied by Philip H. Blackwell of London, and Samuel Hale of New York.

ALBANY, March 14 -- David Bennett Hill has accepted an invitation from the Democratic Editorial Association to deliver an address at the association's banquet to be given in this city April 13, the anniversary of the birth of Thomas Jefferson. In his address on this occasion he is expected to sound the keynote of the National and State campaigns.

A SOFT mist came before the eyes of the middle-aged man as he read the familiar lines. Then he closed his eyes, and, leaning back in his chair, indulged in reverie. Presently drowsiness overcame him: the reverie was merged in an actual dream, and he was a boy again -- not a prattling little child, but a boy of twelve or fourteen coming home from school to meet his mother's welcoming smile.

The good weather of the past few days has given the Princeton baseball team a splendid start for the season, and the past week has seen a wonderful development in the playing of the men. Great care is being taken of the 'Varsity pitchers. Stevens was in the box on Friday, but confined himself to easy straight balls.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A special bulletin on the flood situation in the Mississippi Valley was issued by the Weather Bureau to-night. It is as follows:

One of the remarkable things in the life of a great city is the evidence that very often the poor and ignorant show the greatest wisdom in the selection of foods most needed by them. This is largely the inheritance of traditions from their forefathers, or, rather, mothers, who through experience have accumulated a knowledge of their own which physicians declare to be based as a rule on very sound scientific principles.

Mayor Low's administration was given unstinted praise and the Republican Party was urged to support again Fusion candidates in the approaching municipal campaign at the fifth annual dinner of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District Republican Club last evening. The dinner, which was attended by about 700 enthusiastic Republicans and their friends, was held in the Concert Hall of Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, March 15. -- The revised tax programme will be taken up in the Legislature this week and urged by Gov. Odell. It is expected that both the amendment to the liquor tax law advancing fees 50 per cent., and the Mortgage Tax bill will be rapidly advanced through both branches and it is expected will be on the Executive's desk by April 1.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 15. -- A band of White Caps, composed of 200 of the better class of young farmers, has undertaken the moral regeneration of Northwestern Ohio. The organization is divided into three or four sections and apparently has the quiet sanction of the authorities.

ALBANY, March 15. -- At the close of the year 1902, reports State Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks, the fire, fire-marine, and marine insurance companies doing business in this State were possessed of $361,398,011 of admitted assets, not including assess held abroad nor premium notes of mutual companies, an increase of $20,393,198, as compared with 1901.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with keen pleasure that I read the confessions of an architect, narrated under the heading "Methods of the Modern Architect," on Page 32 of your issue of Sunday, March 1, 1903.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I venture to take up some space in your paper in replying to Mr. Snyder's interesting letter in this day's issue? I shall be only too glad to fall in line with his very generous views of Gen. Benedict Arnold if he in return will not advocate the erecting of a monument to that officer's memory.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The theatrical censorship recently refused to permit Paul Heyse's play, "Mary of Magdala," to be produced in Berlin, whereupon the Goethe Bund, with Sudermann, Ludwig Fulda, and Prof. Mommsen as leaders decided to produce the play in private before an invited audience.

The fight that is in progress before the Legislature over the proposition for unification of the educational system of the State, in the opinion of men identified with the higher educational institutions, promises results of vastly more importance than the matter of the survival in authority of one or the other of the two bodies that at present divide responsibility for the conduct of schools and colleges and allied method of public instruction.

HAVANA, March 15. -- While Secretary Moody and his party were making an informal visit on shore this afternoon a squall of tremendous violence swept over the harbor. It became as dark as night, and the wind and the downpour were terrific.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 15. -- The flood situation between Caruthersville, Mo., and Baton Rouge, La., is serious to-night. The river is rising rapidly and it will be little short of marvelous if the levees hold the great volume of rushing water. The gauge at Memphis to-night marks 38.5 feet, a rise of one and two-tenths feet since last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your note under heading of "Topics of the Times" printed in your issue of the 3d inst. regarding the choice of people who build houses in locations where they are liable to be swept away by the periodical rising of the waters of rivers, I beg to say that you seem to overlook the most important consideration in these matters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It appears that the old Jumel mansion, located in the upper section of our city, and for many years an interesting memorial to sightseers, is about passing into other hands under foreclosure of mortgage proceedings, and that strenuous efforts are being made by the Daughters of the American Revolution for the perpetuation of this famous landmark.

BRUSSELS, March 6. -- King Leopold, it is authoritatively stated, has postponed his visit to the United States until next year. He has been prompted in his decision not to leave Europe this year by the number of important Questions now before Parliament, and which might necessitate his presence in Brussels at any moment. It is, however, certain that he intends to cross the Atlantic as soon as possible.

NEWARK, N.J., March 15. -- An explosion, followed by a fire which lighted up both banks of the Passaic for miles and did damage amounting to $75,000, occurred this evening at the works of the Arlington Manufacturing Company on Forest Street, Arlington.

The recent action of President Roosevelt in refusing to serve on the Board of Consultation of the American National Red Cross, and declining to permit the members of his Cabinet to serve, and the letter written to Miss Clara Barton by Secretary Cortelyou, have drawn from Walter P. Phillips of Bridgeport, Conn., who had been associated with Miss Barton in the Red Cross work, a statement in Her defense.

The great audience that left the Metropolitan Opera House last night after a rendition of Verdi's impressive Requiem Mass had their delight over the performance tinctured with regret, because the Sunday night concert season was closed. Take it all in all, the concerts this season have been a source of intense satisfaction to those who like to close their day of rest by listening to really good music.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to answer briefly Mr. Philip Snyder's dissertation in your issue of March 9, on "Lee and Arnold."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 15. -- Miss Julia Toombs, twenty-three years old, was shot and killed to-day by William Stevens Morse, a rejected lover, who during the past three months has been twice in an insane asylum.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Post tomorrow will say:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 15. -- One of the big bronze lions which guard the entrance to historic Nassau Hall was so badly disfigured last night as to render impossible any satisfactory repair. A group of young graduates and a contingent of upper classmen met together on the steps at a late hour to sing their class songs and to have an informal celebration, as has been the time-honored custom upon the return of alumni.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The expectation is that the nomination of William Plimley to be Assistant Treasurer of the United States at New York will come up again for consideration in the Senate tomorrow. Senator Aldrich, who made a request for reconsideration of the nomination after Mr. Plimley had been confirmed, was not ready to announce to-night whether he will press the motion for a reconsideration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although I am well aware of the fact that "hatred makes blind," I was still not a little astonished at the kind of "argument" offered in that paragraph of yesterday's "Topics of the Times" which undertakes to criticise rather haughtily Mr. Bryan's statement as to the stability of principles.

As announced in our news columns, the first practical step toward giving Ithaca a satisfactory water supply has just been taken in the decision of the water company to build immediately a filtration plant on plans made by Mr. ALLEN HAZEN, an engineer of large and varied experience, but probably best known as the designer of the Albany filtration plant.

Thousands of spectators thronged the walks and every point of vantage along the Speedway yesterday morning to watch the fleet roadsters struggle for supremacy. It was the first Sunday of the year that the weather and footing have proved favorable for fast work, and horsemen throughout the city turned out in force to take full advantage of it.

The chief incident last week was the continuation of the weakening of the banks by the absorption of cash by the Sub-Treasury. Each dollar of lost cash was practically reserve money, and required a four-fold reduction, of loans. The week ended with some signs that these distressing and disturbing conditions may soon end, and that the banks may be left free to conduct their banking business with reference to banking conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- General debate was closed yesterday in the Senate on the canal treaty. The real consideration of the treaty will be entered upon to-morrow, when the amendments will be taken up and voted on. It is expected that all the amendments will be disposed of to-morrow, and that the final vote will be taken early Tuesday.

NEW HAVEN, March 15.--Employes of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad confidently expect to know before to-morrow noon whether a strike has been ordered or the men have voted down the proposition which was submitted to them several days ago by the Grievance Committees.

BUFFALO, March 15. -- The Express tomorrow will print an interview with a person who at one time was a stockholder in the Buffalo Envelope Company, and for twelve years a close friend of Edwin L. Burdick. The interview in part is as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Page 27 of your paper of March 8, Mr. Charles A. Dowries says that Mr. Louis F. Post is not a Socialist, but "a consistent follower of Henry George, hence an individualist." Again he says: "In fact, I have never met a refutation of the doctrine of Henry George."

BERLIN, March 15. -- All the weekly financial reviews point out the intense interest of the Boerse here last week in the financial situation in New York. The opinion apparently predominates that conditions in Wall Street have become more favorable -- at least, German apprehensions are less pronounced.

The reading of a letter from Tenement House Commissioner Robert W. De Forest at the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday caused a stormy discussion, lasting more than half an hour, that was ended only when a watchful delegate moved the "previous question," shutting off debate.

LONDON, March 16 -- The Czar's proclamation, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times, continues to form the subject of almost universal discussion. Unless foreign semi-official telegrams are more than usually misleading, observers and critics seem to have jumped to the conclusion that the manifesto marks "a new epoch in the history of Russia," and that the reforms announced are such as to satisfy all reasonable aspirations of educated Russians.

The usual Sunday quiet of the lower east side, and of the west side from Twentythird Street to Thirty-fourth Street, was broken yesterday by the mad run of a bronce which had broken from its stall in Eldridge Street, and was not captured until it had upset at least a dozen men who had tried to stop it, besides frightening many who were perfectly willing to give it a wide berth.

ALBANY, March 15. -- The State Board of Health will submit to Gov. Odell tomorrow night a report stating that the general sanitary condition of the State when compared with former years is satisfactory. The total number of deaths reported during the year was 124,160, making a death rate of seventeen per 1,000 population.

LONDON, March 15. -- Whitaker Wright's wife and family are still in England, and, so far as the police have ascertained, none of his relatives has left the country. Whitaker Wright left London about Feb. 21 and went direct to Paris, where he stayed about four days before proceeding to Havre to embark on the Lorraine.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 15. -- James J. Hill, President of the Northern Securities Company, is said to be planning to invade California by way of the north with lines of the Great Northern Railway. It is stated that two surveys have been made along the California and Oregon coast, between Portland and San Francisco, and that two routes already have been submitted to Mr. Hill.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The selection of Arthur Pue Gorman, immediately on his return to the Senate, as the Democratic leader has been heralded as indicating a change in feeling on the part of Democratic Senators toward Bryan and Bryanism. If it does not indicate that, it is a matter of course manifestation of a sentiment which has long existed.

It shows how completely the sentiment of the business community relating to foreign trade has been demoralized by the long course of protective tariff treatment that the attitude of Gov. CUMMINS and the leading Republicans of the Northwest should be generally described as "bold."

As has been several times remarked, the peculiar nature of the motor bicycle, which by a twist of the wrist or the shift of a belt is instantly changed from a self-propelled to a muscularly driven bicycle, has left its status open to wide discussion and weighted the future with interesting probabilities.

CITY ISLAND, March 35. -- A new yawl for Dr. Richard Schofield, designed by Charles Davis, is nearing completion at the Hansen yard. The deckhouse and inside fittings will be made of mahogany and the best of material only will be used. An eight-horse power gasoline motor will furnish auxiliary power.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An article appears in your columns of to-day's paper under the headline of "Catholic Belief in Christ" that states the position of the Catholic "believers" and the Protestant "believers" as is. This belief idea has been the contention of centuries, and the cause of most of the wars on earth.

Charles C. Nadal, William H. Baldwin, Jr., Horace E. Deming. Wheeler H. Peckham, and Thomas R. Slicer, as a special committee of the Trustees of the City Club, have issued a pamphlet of fifty-two pages, in which they call attention to the present and past management of the Board of Health.

PITTSBURG, March 15. -- Nothing has given this community such a shock in recent years as the announcement to-day of the sudden death of Joseph Owen Brown, Recorder of the City of Pittsburg. Although it was known that he was ill, it was not thought that his, condition was serious.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Philip Snyder's letter, printed in your issue of this date, is an example of the mercilessness of blind prejudice. It reminds me of the time when I was a boy here in New York, when I would listen to gray-bearded men arraigning Gen. U.S. Grant as an execrable monster.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The article published in your issue of Thursday, March 12, places me in a position which is not justified by the facts, and a very unenviable one.
Irish flags for St. Patrick's Day, 12 by 18 inches in size and in silk, cost 40 cents.

Whitaker Wright, Managing Director of the London and Globe Finance Corporation, Limited, in search of whom twelve Scotland Yard detectives are now scouring Europe, unexpectedly turned up in New York yesterday morning and was quickly apprehended and placed under arrest by Central Office Detectives Leeson and Moody, acting under instructions from Inspector McClusky, who had received a cablegram from the London authorities concerning the missing promoter.
ALBANY, March 15. -- State Labor Commissioner John McMackin, discussing the work of his department last year with reference to child labor, says:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 16 -- The St. Francis Levee gave way late this evening at Trice's Landing, Ark., twenty miles north of this city, and to-night the waters of the Mississippi River are rushing through a three-quarter-mile crevasse in the embankment with a roar that can be heard for miles.

The United States Circuit Court was asked yesterday by two of the minority stockholders of the Central Pacific Railroad Company, a California corporation, to declare as null and void as well as fraudulent $120,000,000 of bonds issued by the Southern Pacific Company and the Central Pacific Railway Company, the latter a corporation organized under the laws of Utah.

Tiny brides five or six inches high are dainty souvenirs for the wedding breakfast. Ice boxes come in the form of a white wax-like bell with orangre blossoms on the top, and there are bells in pink or in other colors with flowers to match for ice boxes for the bridesmaids.

An exposure of legal forms and of oppression entirely outside the pale of the law practiced on the poorer and more ignorant of the foreign population of New York has been prepared by Henry R. Mussey and published by the University Settlement Society, under the title "The 'Fake' installment Business," in connection with the efforts of the society to secure legislation to correct the evil.

Contractor McAvoy had a large gang of laborers at work from an early hour yesterday stripping the rocks and boulders from the Washington Heights site for the American League baseball grounds. President Gordon of the new club was present during the forenoon and expressed himself as being perfectly satisfied that the park would be in readiness for the opening game on April 30.

The Marine Trades Council, which represents the unions in the shipbuilding trades, met last night and refused to ratify the agreement reached on Saturday at the headquarters of the Civic Federation, declaring all sympathetic strikes in the ship-building yards off, rending negotiations for a settlement of the original strike of boiler makers in the Townsend-Downey yards.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Prominent Democrats from every part of the country gath- ered to-day to attend the annual JacksonDay banquet, of the Iroquois Club at the Auditorium Hotel. Preceding the banquet many notables in the party held long talks together, discussing suggestions for the Presidential campaign of next year.

The Bishop of Treves does not seem to be a prelate of great sagacity. His injunction upon his diocesan clergy to refuse absolution to all Catholic parents who send their girls to the Prussian state high schools is, we think, further than any of our own "Cahenslyites" have gone in the same direction.

LONDON, March 16 -- John Flower, Chairman of the Shareholders' Committee which instigated the prosecution of Whitaker Wright, the Director of the London and Globe Finance Corporation, Who was arrested yesterday on his arrival at New York from Cherbourg, says:

LONDON, March 16 -- A news agency announced to-day that one of the Vanderbilts had commissioned George L. Watson to design a 1,400-ton steam yacht of high speed. The identity of this member of the Vanderbilt family has not been disclosed. The yacht was ordered some months ago work on her was suspended while waiting the results of the trials of the rbined yacht Emerald, purchased by George J. Gould.

Vigorous warfare was begun upon the petty criminals of the metropolis last night by Inspector McClusky, the newly appointed head of the Detective Bureau. He sent out forty Central Office men with orders to arrest all they saw and lock them up as suspicious persons at the nearest police station or at Headquarters.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Justice and Mrs. Holmes entertained at dinner this evening in honor of the German Minister and Baroness von Sternburg.

The daily routine of one day in Lent is very much like another. There were conferences, lectures, and sewing classes yesterday. The class which is working for the New York Infant Asylum met in the morning in the residence of Mrs. Frederic J. de Peyster, at 14 East Sixty-sixth Street. The sewing class formed in the interests of the Virginia Day Nursery met in the residence of Mrs. Frederic H. Betts.

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 16 -- Engineers in the employ of the Gould lines, it is said on good authority, will start soon from Marysvale, the terminus of the Rio Grande Western in this State, to survey a line west from that point. While no official information is given as to the destination, it is said here that there can be but one outcome, a line to Los Angeles.

DENVER, Col., March 16 -- E.H. Harriman is believed by officials of the Denver, Northwestern and Pacific Railroad (the Moffat Short Line) to be back of the application of the New Century Light and Power Company for an injunction to prevent the construction of the railroad through the Gore Canon.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The President's Western trip is to begin on April 1 and last for two months. He will arrive in Chicago April 2, and stay there all day. His first speech will he made in Chicago, but the rest of the programme for the day has not yet been made up.
Army. Second Lieut. John V. Spring, Jr., Artillery Corps, is transferred to the cavalry arm, at his own request, with rank from Oct. 18, 1902; he is assigned to the Seventh Cavalry.

NEW HAVEN, March 16 -- A communication from the President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company to the committees representing the employes of the railroad has cleared the atmosphere, and to-night the prospect is good that a peaceable settlement of the differences between the company and its men will be reached.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate spent the entire six hours of its executive session to-day in debating and voting upon amendments to the Panama Canal treaty. Every amendment upon which a vote was reached was rejected, and at the close of the session it was apparent that the treaty will be ratified to-morrow by a large majority, and without amendment.

Benjamin F. Chadsey, a Brooklyn lawyer and Republican spellbinder, particularly well known for the diamonds he has worn, is lost cr has strayed away. Some of his friends fear that he has committed suicide.

Franchise rights were granted by the Board of Aldermen at the meeting yesterday to the New York City Interborough Railway Company to operate a trolley system an thirty-six miles of streets in the Borough of the Bronx. The franchise was put through the last detail provided in the charter, and the Tammany and Fusion members joined votes for the grant.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman had a long conference with Senator Goodsell to-night about his bill to revive old consents to traction companies. This is the measure which Senator Brackett pronounced "the blindest bill introduced in the Senator in 100 years."

ASBURY PARK, March 16.--Evidence of an early and prosperous season are seen in the Sixty-seventh Annual Conference of the New Jersey Methodist Episcopal Church, which will be convened to-morrow evening in the First Church, in Grand Avenue, and which will continue its sessions there and in Ocean Grove until next Tuesday.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- Word was received in this city to-day of the death of David Bell, a professional golfer, who was injured recently in New Orleans and died there last night.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Action will be taken by the Western Passenger Association at its monthly meeting here to-morrow on the recommendation of the mass meeting of Western, Northwestern, and Southwestern roads regarding the enforcement of the Elkins law.

TRENTON, N.J., March 16 -- August Belmont and Charles R. Flint, stockholders and creditors of the Safety Bottle and Ink Company, secured an order from the Chancery Court to-day directing that concern to show cause in Jersey City on Monday next why a receiver should not be appointed.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- The new rules of the local Stock Exchange, adopted to increase the trading in small lots of New York securities, resulted in some additional business to-day. Stocks of St. Paul, Steel, New York Central, People's Gas, and Alton were traded in early. In most instances the trading was of the arbitrage sort, with prices in favor of the seller, who generally was a member selling for himself.

BUFFALO, March 16 -- Little was accomplished at the inquest, continued to-day before Judge Murphy, toward clearing up the mystery surrounding the murder of Edwin L. Burdick. Dr. William H. Marcy, the Burdicks' family physician, and the first person to see Mr. Burdick's body after the slayer had covered it up, was the first witness called by District Attorney Coatsworth.
PARIS, March 16 -- The Foreign Office has been advised of Venezuela's willingness to adjust the French claims prior to 1892 without further arbitration proceedings.
BERLIN, March 16 -- In the Prussian Diet-to-night an appropriation of $25,000 for Prussia's educational exhibit at the St. Louis Exposition was voted, although not without sharp opposition.

The auction sale of the various articles which have been placed in the house at 918 West End Avenue, at one time occupied by Don Eugenio Faria de Teixeira, the Brazilian who met with a variety of reverses during his short stay in this city, was resumed yesterday.
LEROY SMITH, Sheriff of Delaware County, N.Y., died yesterday at the home of his daughter at Sidney, where he had been ill about ten days.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Minister Bowen, accompanied by Senor Pulido, the Venezuelan Charge d'Affaires, called to-day at the Italian, British, and German Embassies to inquire regarding the negotiation of The Hague protocol. Several weeks ago Mr. Bowen drew up a rough draft of this convention, providing for the reference of the preferential question to The Hague and stipulating that the Czar select the members of the court.

At the opening yesterday the market needed assistance under the depressing influences familiar to all. No help was given by London's early prices, but rather the contrary. Trading, however, was quiet and sagging, rather than weak, and in a short time some irregular improvement followed.

BOSTON, March 16 -- The Harvard class of 1879, acting under Prof. Hollis's inspiration, has decided to give to the university a stadium -- an athletic field surrounded by permanent banks of seats -- the like of which is to be found only in a few of the ancient cities of Greece and Italy.

BOSTON, Mass., March 16 -- At the Clearing House to-day balances between the banks loaned at 5 per cent, and New York funds sold at 16 to 23 cents per $1,000 discount. The exchanges were $16,541,241 and the balances were $1,109,934.

Whitaker Wright, Managing Director of the London and Globe Finance Corporation, Limited, who is charged with attempting to defraud the stockholders in that concern out of many millions of dollars, and who was arrested on the pier of the Compangie Generate Transatlantique Sunday morning by Central Office detectives, acting under instructions from Inspector George McClusky, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Alexander in the Federal Building yesterday morning.

The problem of New York is the hous- ing of its rapidly growing population within convenient, fairly speedy, and not too expensive reach of the business parts of the city. It is calculated by careful observers that the relief from the new system of subways now building will be exhausted within a very short time of its construction.

In his gratuitous criticism of Police Commissioner GREENE, especially in the matter of Inspector BROOKS, Dr. PARKHURST does not appear to good advantage, and to continue satirical and skeptical as to the work which the Commissioner is doing, with enthusiastic popular approval, will tend to diminish, if it does not wholly destroy, his own influence for good in municipal affairs.

Everything that bears upon the possible visit of an English polo team to this country is, just at present, of the utmost interest to lovers of the sport here, but notwithstanding the somewhat rosy accounts that have appeared from time to time regarding the foreign visit, most of the prominent players have not taken the news too seriously.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., March 16 -- Edward Troinkle, alias Myers, who is charged with murdering Mrs. George Payne, his employer's wife, by stabbing her thirty-six times with a pitchfork at Trowbridge, Penn., Feb. 22, and who has been pursued by officers through four counties, was to-day chased into Brill's Swamp, two miles from Honesdale, Penn.

With the applause of an excited and interested crowd of billiard enthusiasts ringing in his ears, George H. Sutton, the handless billiard player, executed marvellous shots in the opening game of a five-nights' contest, 1,500 points, fourteen-inch balk-line billiards, with Thomas J. Gallagher at the Montauk Academy, Brooklyn, last night.

In introducing his enormous and unprecedented naval budget of $180,000,000, Sir. ARNOLD FORSTER yesterday took, in the House of Commons, a deprecatory, almost an apologetic tone. He "could not help regretting that the great competition and rivalry in the matter of Laval armaments continued to make necessary this enormous and unproductive expenditure."

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 16 -- Riches in the amount of $22,000, hidden within a bundle of old clothes, lay in a corner of Victor's restaurant yesterday for many hours. Not until the owner came back was the small fortune disturbed in its hiding, though a half-dozen waiters and a few irascible patrons had kicked and shoved the little parcel times innumerable.

The members of the "Prince of Pilsen" company, who will appear at the Broadway to-night, arrived in New York yesterday on their special train. H.W. Savage had a lot of new chorus girls to train, and, having little time to do it, utilized an observation car for rehearsals while running from Cincinnati here.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following statement in your influential paper on "Debt Collecting Wars," has been read with interest:
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 -- The steamer Mariposa arrived from Australia to-day, bringing additional news of the typhoon and tidal wave at the Tuomatu group in the Pacific in the middle of January.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Democrats of the Senate held a caucus to-day on the question of the Panama Canal treaty as a result of which it was decided to stand together on two amendments to that convention. However, it was agreed that after these were acted upon the Democrats should be at liberty individually to vote foror against the treaty as they see fit.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Mayor Carter H. Harrison was renominated for a fourth term in the Democratic City Convention here to-day. The remainder of the ticket agreed upon at a caucus of Democratic leaders yesterday was as follows:

E.S. Simon has sold to Lachman Goldsmith the vacant block front on the west side of Fifth Avenue, between One Hundred and Thirty-seventh and One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Streets, 199.10 feet on the avenue, 100 feet in depth on One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street, and 120 feet on One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street: also, the plot at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street, 99.11 by 100.

RICHMOND, Va., March 16 -- Confederate veterans are very much surprised at the failure of Gov. Montague to approve the bill providing for the placing of the statue of Gen. Lee in the Statuary Hall of the National Capitol.

Yesterday's market for outside securities was dull, and about as irregular as was the exchange market. In a few stocks, notably in American Can, the day's transactions resulted in higher prices, but by far the larger number of net changes were found among the declines. Nearly all of the copper stocks were under selling pressure, and in some of the issues of this group the losses amounted to several points.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 16 -- The advance guard of the brewers' lobby has arrived. The agents of the brewers are here to look over the ground and report the situation to their principals before the hearing on the excise bill on Wednesday.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16 -- The local racing passed into the control of the New Louisiana Jockey Club to-day. The weather underwent an agreeable change to fair, but the track showed comparatively little change, particularly next to the rail. True Blue and Worthington were the only winning favorites.

GLASGOW, March 16 -- Everything is in readiness for the launch of Shamrock III. to-morrow. Platforms to accommodate 500 persons have been erected alongside the end of the shed, which has been partly removed, and enough of the challenger for the America's Cup is visible to fully confirm the statements made in these dispatches as to her being a departure from the flat-floored type of all the recent cup racers.

The restoration of the one-thousand-dollar bill which was found on Thursday last by C.B. Small, the colored porter on the ferryboat John G. McCullough, to its rightful owner is proving to be far from an easy matter. Four persons have already appeared as claimants of the bill, and the Erie Railroad officials are weary of their trust.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Speyer Co., bankers, of New York, who hold the $3,500,000 temporary loan against the Consolidated Lake Superior Company, and have been asked to advance $1,750,000 more for present needs, have a force of twenty men overhauling the books of the corporation in this city.

The Municipal Art Society of New York seems to have entered on a new career, and is bidding fair to become what it is intended to be an organization that includes a goodly number of men and women who are interested in seeing a beautiful city, and mean to do what they can to accomplish something toward making it, at any rate, less ugly.

WESTFIELD, N.J., March 16 -- Mrs. Sarah Ann Newcomb of Massachusetts, at present residing in Boston, has filed an application for letters of administration for the estate of the late Nathaniel L. Newcomb of this place. Mr. Newcomb died here on Feb. 27. The filing of the application was a shock to Westfield society, as Mr. Newcomb and a young woman who was supposed to be his wife were leaders in it.

That the city officials are in earnest in advocating the construction of a municipal electric lighting plant is shown by the quickness of action of Commissioner Monroe of the Department of Water Supply, Gas, and Electricity yesterday. The announcement was made that the bill authorizing the city to construct its own lighting plant would be ready this week for presentation to the Legislature.

The public interest excited by the cable announcement that Dr. ALLEN MACFAYDEN has produced a typhoid antitoxin serum, and that Lord LISTER has commended it to the favorable notice of the profession in a paper communicated to the Royal Society, is fully warranted by the importance of the prophylactic sought and the character of the gentlemen whose names are identified with it.

ALBANY, March 16 -- In addition to the bill introduced by Senator Raines adding 50 per cent, to all liquor license fees, in accordance with the decision of the two Republican caucuses, Senator Greene to-night presented one prepared by the State Excise Department perfecting the machinery of the department to carry out the provisions of the law.

ALBANY, March 16 -- When the bill introduced by Senator Bailey giving the Montauk Indians the right to go into court to establish their right to extensive lands on Long Island came up in the Senate to-night Senator McCarren asked to have it laid aside, owing to the absence of the Senator from the First District.

LONDON, March 17 --Admiralty Secretary Arnold-Forster introduced the navy estimates for 1903-04, providing for an expenditure of $179,184,205, in the House of Commons yesterday. In the course of an explanatory statement he remarked that the estimates were unparalleled in time of peace or war, and as a private citizen he could not help regretting that the great competition and rivalry in the matter of naval armaments continued to make this enormous and unproductive expenditure necessary.

LISBON, March 16 -- The troubles at Coimbra started on March 11 with a strike of stall holders in the market against an order to renew their licenses. Riots ensued, the whole working class and the students sympathizing with the stall holders in their protest against the arbitrary action of the authorities.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The suit against Secretary Root brought by Rebecca J. Taylor, was dismissed to-day by Chief Justice Bingham of the District Supreme Court. Miss Taylor was dismissed from the War Department for criticising the Administration's policy in the Philippines.

BOSTON, March 17 -- While the general situation shows some improvement, no change is noted in money rates. Call loans, 5 1/2 @6 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 5 1/2 @6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 16 2-3 cents discount.

Inspector McClusky, the new head of the Detective Bureau, yesterday discussed his plan to make unhappy the existence of the "sure thing" men by "rounding up" and by harassing surveillance. The Inspector demurred to making himself the central figure in the plan to rid the city of such nuisances or menaces.

The Prince of Pilsen had a most friendly greeting at the Broadway Theatre last evening upon his first appearance in New York, for be did not come as an entire stranger. Much of the music of the musical comedy of which he is the chief adornment had preceded him to this city in various ways, and It had a familiar sound.

Juvenile riders, both boys and girls, practically took possession of the Durland Riding Academy, in West Sixty-sixth Street, last night, and they gave a decidedly creditable exhibition of clever horsemanship. It was the fifteenth annual young people's music ride, and the grand entree brought into the tanbark ring over one hundred brightly attired lads and lasses, who rode their high-steppers to perfection.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 17 -- The flaod situation in the portion of the Mississippi Valley contiguous to Memphis is extremely critical to-night. A veritable sea exists in the St. Francis and Mississippi River Basins in Arkansas, extending from one completely to the other.

A society with headquarters at Anderson has just been incorporated in Indiana, under the name of the Independent American Mechanics' Union. It has for its avowed purpose to place a wholesome check upon the aggressiveness of labor unions in Anderson and other local industrial centres, and declares these in its articles of incorporation, as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- For the second time the Senate Judiciary Committee to-day reported adversely on the nomination of William Michael Byrne to be District Attorney for the State of Delaware. Byrne formerly held the office to which he has been nominated, but resigned last Summer to run for Congress on the Union or Addicks Republican ticket.

LONDON, March 17 -- The demand for money lessened somewhat to-day and rates were encouraged by yesterday's influx of gold. The latter also weakened discounts and raised hopes that the bank rate would be reduced on Thursday next, though the monetary situation in New York compels the authcrities to be unusually cautious.

Locking thoroughly rested after his seven months' vacation. Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, walked gayly down the gangplank of the North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm last evening, tipping his silk hat right and left and smiling blandly.

Ex-Secretary David R. Francis, President of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, arrived yesterday on the Kronprinz Wilhelm. At the dock early last evening a delegation met him, asking him to delay his return to St. Louis until Friday evening, when the Beta Theta Phi Fraternity wishes to tender to him a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW ORLEANS, March 17 -- Munro's masterly ride landed Ben Chance, the second choice in the betting, first at the wire in the St. Patrick's Handicap this afternoon. The race was at a mile and a sixteenth, and was worth $1,025 to the winner. Marshal Neil was a strong favorite in the betting, while as good as 4 to 1, and at the close 18 to 5, was to be had on Ben Chance.

ALBANY, March. 17 -- The Senate passed Senator McCarren's bill providing that "execution of a judgment for the recovery of money only shall not be stayed without security for more than thirty days after the service upon the attorney for the appellant of a copy of the judgment, and written notice of the entry thereof."

-- One of the minor, but far from unimportant, features of the Burdick case is its disclosure of a something between a willingness and an inclination, and nearer the latter than the former, on the part of a well-reputed doctor to imperil grave public interests for the sake of protecting the memory of a dead patient and sparing the sensibilities of living ones.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Ex-Senator Charles A. Stadler of New York City, President of the American Malting Company and who ships $600,000 worth of grain every year, was in Albany to-day, protesting vigorously against the proposed $101,000,000 canal bill.

The stock market yesterday retained its familiar aspect of approximate deadlock. About half the Exchange is afraid to buy upon the money market and labor outlook, and the other half is afraid to sell upon the excellent conditions in the commercial and railway worlds. In such a balance of opinion it needs little to start a movement which is likely to grow simply upon its growth in either direction.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 17 -- Sam Karpf, Secretary of the American Bowling Congress, announced that the first meeting of the Executive Committee chosen at Indianapolis last month will be held in Chicago April 22. Forms of drafts for city associations, sanctions, credentials, applications, , will be put in shape at this meeting.

Very little business was transacted in the outside market yesterday. Conditions were unfavorable, both in regard to the amount of trading and in regard to the course of prices. There were few or no advances and a number of issues were dealt in at prices considerably below Monday's closing figures.

An informal matinee was held on the Speedway yesterday afternoon which in many respects was up to the standard of the prearranged affairs which will be returned next month by the Road Drivers' Association. Thrilling finishes came thick and fast, and one was so close that each driver felt sure victory had perched upon his banner.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 17 -- The seniors inaugurated a new custom to-day in honor of St. Patrick, the Irish saint, celebrating the day with a large parade. The paraders were headed by a band, and were dressed in the truly shamrock green, many fantastic costumes being found in the line.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The bill prohibiting the shooting of wild birds in the Spring was resurrected in the Senate to-day and passed. All the expedients for gaining time and position that are known to parliamentary strategists were brought into play. St. Patrick and his day were introduced, and some broad wit was indulged in.

We were quoting the other day some German praise of the pertinacity and success with which American Consuls abroad followed up the chances for American trade, and backed up American merchants.
