Another gratifying piece of evidence, in the same direction, is furnished by the Deutsche Export Revue, the organ, as its name implies, of the German exporting merchants, or of the German merchants who desire to become exporters.

The ferryboat Maine of the Broadway Line, plying between East Twenty-third Street, Manhattan, and Broadway, Brooklyn, was run into last night by Tug No. 6 of the New York Central Railroad fleet, in charge of two floats heavily loaded with freight cars.
L.H. J.W. Slawson have sold for a client to Dr. T.P. Berens for occupancy the four-story stone-front dwelling 35 Park Avenue, 18.5 by 51.

To-morrow will bring Mi-Careme and a small train of entertainments with it. First of all, the Munroe affair at the Howard Constable studio will be the most notable of the evening. Then there will be considerable relaxation as to bridge, while sewing classes, dinners, and musicales will be in order.

BALTIMORE, March 17 -- The sudden rise of 2 points in the bid price of Hammond Ice stock led to a revival of the rumor that negotiations are pending for a satisfactory arrangement between it and the American Ice Company, in so far as the Baltimore business is concerned. It was claimed also that the arrangements, if effected, will prevent the Hammond Company from extending its operations to other cities.

GLASGOW, March 17 -- Sir Thomas Lipton's sloop Shamrock III., challenger for the America's Cup, was launched to-day under the most successful conditions at 1:15 P.M. Lady Shaftesbury, wife of the Commodore of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club, christened the yacht in the presence of a number of distinguished guests.

Four indictments returned by the Federal Grand Jury for the October Term in the so-called "silk fraud cases," which kept the local Custom House officials and the Federal Court authorities in this city busy for months and even led to extraordinary action by President Roosevelt, were quashed yesterday by Judge Thomas in the Criminal Branch of the United States Circuit Court.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Without dote ting an "i" or crossing a "t," even without changing a punctuation mark, the Senate to-day voted to ratify the treaty with Colombia for the construction of an isthmian canal. The vote for ratification was 73 in the affirmative to 5 in the negative.

BERLIN, March 17 -- The correspondent here of The Associated Press, after conversing with a number of bankers of this city, finds that the apprehensions regarding the financial situation in New York are still pronounced. The American demand for German money, continues.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- The statement of Vice President Search of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company to the stockholders was made public to-night by John W. Moffley, Chairman of the stockholders' committee now investigating the affairs of the corporation. The statement in part is as follows:

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League last night, the Century Wheelmen bowlers won three straight games from the Catholic Club five on the alleys of the latter club. The scores follow:

Mayor Low grave a public hearing yesterday on the ordinance passed by the Board of Aldermen allowing the owners of the New Amsterdam Theatre to continue the construction of that playhouse four feet beyond the building line. The hearing was attended by many property owners, who declared that no exception to the law should be allowed.

BUFFALO, March 17 -- Arthur R. Pennell was named to-day as the probable slayer of Edwin L. Burdick. Mr. Pennell was the man spoken of as the corespondent in the Burdick divorce proceedings. Two weeks after the murder of Mr. Burdick an automobile in which Mr. Pennell and his wife were riding plunged into a stone quarry.

There is naturally considerable interest as to the effect on business of the payments under the canal treaty and the legislation for carrying out its provisions. The event is still somewhat remote, and when the time comes to provide for these payments we have no doubt they will be taken care of without disturbance or even inconvenience to the general business of the country.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- With the signing of the resolution of ratification by the President and Secretary of the Senate and its transmission to the President, the Senate concludes its share in making the canal treaty with Colombia. The fate of the canal now rests with the Colombian Congress.

That New York is the most cosmopolitan city in the world is a commonplace of long standing. It has been so since the unquestioned position of New York as the chief port of the country came to coincide with the unquestionable position of the country as, in the old Fourth of July phrase, "the asylum for the oppressed of all countries and the martyrs of every creed."

BUTTE, Mon., March 17 -- More sensational testimony was presented in court to-day in the disbarment proceedings inaugurated against A.J. Shores and D. Gay Stivers, by Judge E.W. Harney of the District Court. Judge Harney charged that they, with Charles W. Clark, son of Senator W.A. Clark, attempted to bribe him with $250,000 to say that he had been bribed by F.A. Heinze in the $10,000,000 Minnie Healey mine case.

The average lifetime of a generation has passed since the Brooklyn Bridge was begun; it is twenty years since it was opened for traffic. During this score of years the population of Brooklyn has increased by 100 per cent., from 600,000, in round numbers, to over 1,200,000.

BOSTON, March 17 -- William A. Webster of Chicago, a traveling man for a New York lace house, fatally shot himself while a guest of one of the down-town hotels to-day. He was found unconscious in the bathtub in his suite by the hotel manager. A revolver lay on the floor.

William S. Courses, private secretary to Police Commissioner Greene, has taken a lively interest in the work of purifying the Tenderloin, having personally assisted in several gambling house raids, but he made a mistake last night, according to the neighbors, in causing the arrest of John Murray, twenty-nine years old, a driver, of 357 West Thirty-eighth Street on a charge of assaulting him.

George J. Gould and Mrs. Gould had a narrow escape from death or serious in- jury while on their way to attend the per- formanoe of "The Eishop's Move," at the Manhattan Theatre, at 8:10 o'clock last evening. They were in a carriage driven by Charles Callais, and had come west through Thirty-second Street.

Three matches were played yesterday afternoon in the continuation of the handicap hand tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club. That which engaged the veteran. J.H. Haslin, (5 points,) and W. P. Robertson, (8 points) proved an exciting contest, lasting through three hardly contested games before Haslin was defeated.
Philadelphia dispatches stating that it is believed that all the steamship lines on the great lakes will have their fleets in service by April 1.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- Almost as many stocks declined in this market to-day as advanced, but most of them belonged to the inactive class. Electric Storage Battery, which had not sold since Feb. 13 last, when 81 1/2 was paid for it, brought 70 1/2 to-day, and it was the only stock dealt in in which the net change in price amounted to as much as 1 per cent.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Commissioner Robert Grier Monroe of the Department of Electricity, Gas, and Water Supply of New York, appeared before the Assembly Cities Committee to-day to make a plea for the passage of the bill introduced by Mr. Morgan of Kings, to amend the New York City charter relative to water meters, and to provide means for placing the same.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A remarkable shooting case, involving a touch of negro superstition, took place here this afternoon. The parties were all policemen, and all of them were negroes. Two of the officers -- J.W. Hall and Prank Waters -- were standing at the patrol box at First and N Streets. Southwest, early this morning.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Water Storage Commission bill was the subject of lively discussion to-day before the Senate Committee on Finance. It was vigorously attacked by Hugh McConnell on behalf of the Board of Trade and Transportation of New York City. He read to the committee a brief on the measure prepared by the Committee on Forests of his association, which condemned the bill unqualifiedly.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The appointment of Dexter North as Director of the Census instead of ex-Representative Mercer of Nebraska was a surprise to-day to the friends or both men. It had been accepted as a foregone conclusion that Mercer, who was Chairman of the Public Buildings Committee of the House during several Congresses and had made many friends, would get the place.

Trading in the stock market yesterday was dull and spiritless, but with the undertone substantially sound and with the short element clearly none too comfortable in its position. There was a marked absence of liquidating sales, such as had been noted on the day previous, while, on the contrary, steady investment demand was reported, suggesting that despite the uncertain money situation, stocks at this level are proving attractive to stable buyers.

PENN YAN, N.Y., March 17 -- In a frenzy of mania Mrs. James Strowbridge of Guyanoga Village, five miles from here, to-day killed her daughter, twenty-six years oid, and her mother, aged eighty years, and after setting fire to the house in which the bodies lay, deliberately entered it and perished in the flames.

FREEHOLD, N.J., March 17 -- It is a long time since Freehold had as lively an hour as the one this afternoon Letween 5 and 6 o'clock. For about half of that time carriages and wagons raced through the streets at a gallop, excited men rushed into stores and shops and residences and dragged their occupants out and into the vehicles without explanation.

RICHMOND, Va., March 17 -- The sixth session of the Conference for Education in the South will be opened in Richmond on the afternoon of Wednesday. April 22, and will close on the evening of the 24th. This body was formerly known at the Capon Springs Conference. The presiding officer is Robert C. Ogden of New York City.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 17 -- Two women are claiming to be the widow of George K. Read, who was killed in the Jersey Central Railroad wreck on Jan. 27 at Graceland, and both of them will appear before Surrogate Fitzgerald on March 24 to tell why they believe he was their husband.

As far as Lent goes, to-day will be as active as any in the season. The feast of St. Joseph, the patron of matrimony, comes usually about the middle of Lent, and much latitude is allowed those who have been doing penance during the first twenty days. This evening will take place the long-talked-of Monroe Doctrine party by Mrs. Constable and Howard Constable.

PARIS, March 18. -- The Chamber of Deputies to-day devoted its entire sitting, which lasted until late this evening, to finishing the debate on the proposal refusing authorization to teach to male religious congregations, which authorization is required under the law of associations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- The Philadelphia market enjoyed a little boom today, and while trading was not active, the demand found fewer offerings than for several weeks past. The most important advances were Central Coal and Coke, 1; Consolidated Lake Superior preferred, 4, with a subsequent reaction of 2 1/8; Lehigh Valley, 3/4; Pennsylvania Steel preferred, 2; Philadelphia Rapid Transit, 7/8; United Gas, 1 1/2; Philadelphia Electric 4s and gold 5s, 1 each.

BOSTON, March 18. -- Money rates show no material change, although the supply of funds is larger. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 12 1/2. 10, and 8 cants discount.

What was one of the most complete collapses in value that the outside market has seen in a long time occurred yesterday in the stock of the Kitchener Gold Mining Company. This stock was first traded in on the curb about three months ago, the initial sales being made between 2 1/2 and 3. The company is capitalized at one million dollars, divided into shares of the par value of $5.

The case or Georg Anthes, the German tenor who has been barred from singing in Germany because he left the Dresden Opera House without permission to join Maurice Grau this season, promises to involve Heinrich Conried, the new impresario at the Metropolitan with the Buehnen Verein, a German theatrical association of which he is a member.

Barring the collapse of Kitchener Mining, yesterday's market in outside securities, presented very little worthy of special note. The number of issues traded in increased somewhat, and here and there in the list were some substantial advances, but in general the market remained in the apathetic state which has existed for some days past.
BUFFALO, March 18. -- A rumor was current to-night to the effect that Mrs. Maria Hull, mother-in-law of Edwin L. Burdick, who was murdered on Feb. 27, had been seriously injured or was ill.

ST. LOUIS, March 18. -- For the first time in the history of the United States Courts, and by authority of a special act of Congress passed last February, four United States Circuit Judges are sitting together to hear arguments in a case, the suit beins that of the Federal Government against the Northern Securities Company of New Jersey, formed to accomplish the celebrated Northern Pacific-Great Northern merger.

The meeting of real estate owners, held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the Knickerbocker Trust Company, was very fully attended, nearly all of those who had been invited, about sixty in all, being present.

The Indiana revolt of labor against trades union oppression seems to be spreading. There is an association of workmen, asserting independence of union dictation, established at Anderson, and another at Muncie, where a novel and interesting suit has just been begun.

Stocks strong. Yesterday's market resembled Tuesday's in its earlier hours and under the influence of similar factors. Labor troubles lost something of their acuteness for the moment, and the money market continued to work easier. The interior gave encouragement of its will and power to spare funds to New York, taken in adjustment of balances to New York, or to take advantage of the opportunity to realize full rates upon credits here.

All of the complicated domestic affairs of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien and Mrs. Abbie E. O'Brien are being aired in the Supreme Court before Justice Scott and a jury as rapidly as the attorneys will permit witnesses to testify. The case has been adjourned again and again during the two years and more it has been on the court calendars, but only yesterday were attorneys able to bring it up for trial.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18. -- The baseball management of Princeton has arranged to play New York University here on March 28 in place of the Rutgers game which the New Brunswick management canceled. The baseball team is fast rounding into form. The warm weather has put the regular diamond into good condition and hard practice is held every day.

Friends of the improvement and development of the New York canals will note with disappointment that the committee of the Assembly, while reporting the bill for the improvement, has also reported favorably the Lewis resolution for negotiations with the United States Government with reference to taking over the canal system.

The scene of the Southern Pacific fight was yesterday shifted, to the floor of the Stock Exchange, where, in the last hour of trading, so spirited a demand appeared for the shares of the company that a rise of nearly five points in the quotation promptly followed, and suggestions were heard of a possible corner in the stock.

LONDON, March 19.--The correspondent of The Daily Chronicle at Constantinople, in a dispatch dated March 14, states that United States Minister Leishman is still vainly waiting for an audience of the Sultan to deliver President Roosevelt's autograph letter on the American claims regarding the missionary schools in Armenia and other matters.

LONDON, March 18. -- The extradition papers in the case of Whitaker Wrigrht, the Director of the London and Globe Finance Corporation, were mailed on the White Star Line steamship Celtic, which sailed from Liverpool to-day.

The Committee on Forests of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation has entered a vigorous and wellconsidered protest against Senate Bill No. 156, entitled "An act continuing the Water Storage Commission and increasing its powers, for the purpose of preventing floods and inundations, promoting navigation, conserving the public health, and developing the natural resources of the State by regulating the flow of streams, and making an appropriation therefor."

Candidates for the Columbia crew plan to take their first outdoor practice of the season, provided weather conditions are fa- vorable, either to-morrow or Saturday afternoon. The crews will be boated from their new house at Sherman Creek, on the Harlem River. The house was purchased from the Lone Star Boat Club, and Has been put in good condition for the Morningside crew men.

ALBANY, March 18. -- At a hearing before the Codes Committee of the Assembly today on the Sunday Opening bill for butchers. Dr. A.H.Lewis, representing the Seventh-day Baptists, and author of "The History of Sunday Legislation," advocated a definite modification of the Sunday law upon the broadest lines.

GLASGOW, March 18. -- The pontoons on which Shamrock III, was launched yesterday were removed this afternoon. The yacht afloat confirms the previous good opinions of her. The doubts whether she would turn on the excessively short keel were partially allayed. She came accurately to the bow floating marks, and under her counter the water just lapped the first water line.

The charge by Abram I. Elkus, counsel for Police Inspector Adam A. Cross, that District Attorney Jerome was using the powers of his office to coerce and intimidate witnesses in police investigations made the first enlivening incident in the trial of Inspector Cross, under charces of neglect of duty, that was begun in Police Headquarters yesterday morning before Deputy Commissioner Ebstein, with the prosecution represented by two of Mr. Jerome's assistants.

Two negroes sat down at dinner last night in a company that included several prominent Southerners of this city. The dinner was one of the monthly affairs of the Unitarian Club at the Hotel St. Denis. Of the three speakers two were Southerners -- Walter H. Page, editor and publisher, and George Cary Eggleston, author.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Before adjourning at 7 o'clock to-night the Senate entered into a unanimous agreement to vote on the Cuban reciprocity treaty at 3 o'clock to-morrow. The hope of securing a vote to-day was dissipated by the discovery that there were more speeches to be made in opposition to the treaty than had been counted upon.

Mr. Charles Prohman has cabled from London that the reported disbandment of the Empire Stock Company is too absurd to contradict. The item is not without interest. It is to be noted, nevertheless, that the statement that the people playing at the Empire Theatre constitute a stock company is also too absurd to contradict.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, to-day brought home to the Tammany Senators that he has his watchful eye on them. He sent Thomas F. Smith, Secretary of the Tammany organization, to Albany with instructions to urge on the Tammany Senators the necessity of a more regular attendance from now until the close of the session.

Pacers were very much in evidence on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, and with few exceptions they furnished the best brushes of the day. The sport opened with a mixed brush, in which the two pacers, Harry L, 2:24 1/4, and Crescent, were matched against the two trotters, Princess Sprague and Blonde, 2:13 1/4.
The recorded conveyances yesterday showed an interchange of properties valued at nearly $3,000,000 between the Manhattan Railway Company and the City Real Estate Company.

-- In a discussion of the problems which confront the would-be navigator of the air, Dr. T.B. COLLINS, writing for The Electrical World and Engineer, rehearses the various recent achievements with motor-driven balloons, and admits that they are considerable, but when he comes to define "mechanical flight, properly so called," he says that it is "aviation in which the gas bag plays no part."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18. -- Charles H. Loven, State Transfer Tax Appraiser for Westchester County, filed his report on the estate of Bradford B. MeGregor, son of the late Andrew McGregor, the Standard Oil official, to-day. Bradford MeGregor died in Mamaroneck on Sept. 7 last after an operation.

ALBANY, March 18. -- For more than a week two detectives, one of them belonging to a private agency, have been guarding Gov. Odell. The guard has not been established because of any unusual threats against the Governor. The letters from cranks with which his mail is burdened have been no more numerous lately or more violent in tone than the usual run of such letters which he receives.

Believers in the stock market and in the probability of the establishment of higher prices were much encouraged by the behavior of stocks yesterday -- that is, up to the time of the Southern Pacific fiasco. Dull up to that time even to the point of stagnation, the market nevertheless more than held its own, with such changes as appeared at the close of the day generally on the side of advances.

ALBANY, March 18. -- No such crowd has been seen at the Capitol this session as today overflowed the Senate chamber and thronged the corridors through interest in the excise hearing. The hearing lasted from 3 until 7 o'clock, and when an adjournment was taken it was with the understanding that the joint Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment would to-morrow morning pass upon the request of the liquor dealers for a further hearing.

Tody Hamilton, mobilizer of adjectives and promoter of publicity, smiled last night as the doors of Madison Square Garden swung open and the Barnum Bailey circus season of 1903 was on. It was the same smile that Mr. Hamilton has been wearing on like occasions for many years. Then he pointed proudly to the programme of the occasion.

The latest number received of The London Saturday Review contains a very sensible and suggestive letter on "Germany and the Monroe Doctrine," by Mr. DOUGLAS M. GANE. The writer calls attention to the great and growing German maritime interests, to the extension of German trade, and even of German possessions in the Far East, and then points out that she does not own or control any "way stations" on the track to these distant belongings.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Col. Charles F. Humphrey was nominated to-day to be Quartermaster General to succeed Gen. Ludington, who will be promoted to the grade of Major General on the retirement of Gens Hughes and Breckinridge, April 14. The Senate confirmed the nomination.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- William Plimley will not be Assistant Treasurer of the United States at New York. The President to-day withdrew his nomination and sent to the Senate the name of Hamilton Fish, and the nomination promptly was confirmed.
Sales on the Stock Exchange of 10 shares of Central National Bank stock at 170 and 10 shares of National Bank of Commerce at 305.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- President Roosevelt entertained members of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission and its attaches at dinner at the White House tonight. The party included Judge George Gray, the Chairman: Thomas H. Watkins, E.E. Clark, Gen. J.K. Wilson, E.W. Parker, Bishop J.L. Spalding, Carroll D. Wright, E.A. Mosely and Dr. Neill., Secretary Cortelyou of the Department of Commerce and Labor, also was one of the guests.
The Royal Insurance Company of Liverpool has re-entered Vermont.

An exposition of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's tunnel plans and a forecast of the points upon which the owners of affected property intend to oppose the excavation and terminal building, were given yesterday at the public hearing on the matter, begun before the Commissioners appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 18.--Although the tributaries or the Mississippi north of Memphis are reported to be falling, the river is 39.8 feet on the gauge to-night, the highest point ever recorded. Because of a break in the levee at Traice's Landing last night all lines of railroad entering the city from the west have been washed out.

NEW ORLEANS, March 19 -- Fuller had little trouble in landing Travers first in the Flight Handicap, a six-furlong sprint, worth $1,000 to the winner, to-day. St. Tammany and Josette were strong favorites, but neither was at any time prominent. Travers led all the way and won easily by three lengths.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 19 -- In a long editorial in to-morrow's Commoner W.J. Bryan will say:

ALBANY, N.Y., March 19 -- The request of President Lindinger of the New York Wine, Liquor and Beer Dealers' Association for an additional hearing on the amendment to the liquor tax law advancing fees 50 per cent, was denied by the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment of the Senate to-day, and the bill was reported favorably in the Senate, with only one amendment, and that not radical.

Judge Holt of the United States District Court has denied a discharge from bankruptcy to Wilbur F. Studebaker of 315 West Eighty-fourth Street, who filed a petition in bankruptcy on March 24, 1902, with liabilities to the amount of $9,304 and no assets. Judge Holt, in his opinion, said that the evidence showed that Mr. Studebaker inherited in 1897 property valued at $150,000.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Though "Tom" and "Ben" at odds may seem And thought by some to disagree, 'Tis safe to claim it's all a fake, As nothing of the sort we'll see.

The vote of the Chamber of Deputies, refusing the right to monks to engage in teaching, ends, for the present, that phase of the conflict between Church and State in France. One cannot help thinking that the conflict ought never to have arisen. With enough of good sense and good feeling on each side, it would not have arisen.

While everything seems to be running smoothly in major and minor baseball circles, there are rumblings of discontent underneath the surface, which, if not quickly subdued, may lead to fresh outbreaks and bring about an even more bitter warfare than that which waged so fiercely, to the detriment of the game, during the last two years.

WASHINGTON, March 19.--The Cuban treaty ratified to-day by the Senate was negotiated in Havana Dec. 11, 1902, between Gen. Tasker H. Bliss, representing the United States, and Senors Carlos de Zaldo and Jose M. Garcia Montes, representing Cuba. The Senate made several amendments to it.

The stockholders of the National Lead Company held a special meeting in Jersey City yesterday and adopted such amendments to the charter of the company as were necessary to make it conform to the amendments and supplements to the General Corporation act of New Jersey adopted since the organization of the company.

Army. Major Samuel R. Jones will be relieved from duty as Assistant Quartermaster in the Department of the East by an officer to be temporarily designated by the commanding General, and, upon being relieved, will proceed to Jeffersonville, Ind., to relieve Col. James M. Marshall. Col. Marshall upon being relieved will proceed to Philadelphia and assume charge of the general depot of the Quartermaster's Department in that city.

BOSTON, March 19 - The money market shows hardly any change, but, with the supply of funds increasing, lower rates may be seen before long. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans, on collateral, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans, on mercantile paper, 5 1/2 @6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount.

Four down-town lodges of the Independent Order of B'nai B'rith -- the Justice, Liberty, Harmony, and Roumania -- gave a dinner last night in Pacific Hall, 209 East Broadway, in honor of Dr. Friedrich Mueller, who first came to this country as assistant to Dr. Adolf Lorenz of Vienna, and who has come again to remain as a Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery in the University of Chicago.
GLASGOW, March 19 -- The mast of the Shamrock III. was successfully stepped this afternoon. The new mast measures 148 feet from deck to truck.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 19 -- Bishop Fowler told the members of the New Jersey Methodist Conference in plain terms to-day that he expects to lose no time in transacting routine business. The Rev. James Eckersly of Lumberton was censured for failing to report the result of the third-year examinations.

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League last night the Century Wheelmen bowlers won two of the three games with the West Side Republican Club team on the alleys of the latter organization. The game between the New York Athletic Club and the Harlem Wheelmen was postponed.

ST. LOUIS, March 19 -- Argument for the Northern Securities Company in the merger case was resumed this morning by ex-Judge George B. Young, in the United States Circuit Court for the District of Minnesota, sitting here.

A reunion of figure skaters was held yesterday afternoon and evening at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink. Invitations were sent out to about fifty skaters, and just half that number responded. Several of the men had not met in recent years, and the recalling of anecdotes proved so pleasant that it is possible that the reunion may become an annual affair.

After a discussion in Which the Mayor and three Commissioners were lined up against Controller Grout, the Rapid Transit Board voted yesterday to abandon the plan for an underground railroad station at One Hundred and Fourth Street and Central Park West. Another matter of interest at the meeting was the reading of a report that outlined another east side subway plan.

There is a lull again after the gayeties of Mi-Careme. Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Satterthwaite of 7 East Eightieth Street will give a dinner this evening, and in the Wallorf-Astoria there will be a concert and in entertainment in aid of the Loomis Sanatorium. The wedding of Stephen Olin and Mrs. Emeline Harriman Dodge is to be celebrated to-morrow.

ST.LOUIS, March 19 -- Two arguments in behalf of the Wabash Railroad were concluded to-day in the injunction proceeding before United States District Judge Adams, and the first statement in behalf of the men was begun by F.M. Judson of St. Louis. The case will certainly continue throughout to-morrow, and possibly throughout Saturday, no restriction having been placed by Judge Adams upon the length of arguments.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 -- At the yearly meeting of the Philadelphian Society, the university branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, B.O. Tatter-while of Louisville, Ky., was elected President, J.W. Cook First Vice President, F. B. St. John Second Vice President, and A. O. Whipple Treasurer.
ALBANY, March 19 -- These bills were passed by the Senate to-day:

BERLIN, March 10 -- An important discussion on foreign affairs, and especially Germany's recent action in Venezuela, took place in the Reichstag to-day. The Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, spoke in defense of the Government's attitude and actions.

The negotiations between the Marconi Company and the British Government have ended unsatisfactorily. The Post Office authorities have issued instructions for the construction of a wire between Poldhu and the telegraph station at Falmouth, but have declined any more intimate relations with it.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Threats of death against organizers of the International Cigarmakers' Union now in Tampa have caused Samuel Gompers. President of the American Federation of Labor, to take action, and to-day he sent this telegram:

Nervousness over the Southern Pacific incident was apparent in the earlier dealings yesterday, but lost force as the day progressed. Whatever the pool's apparent tactics may be, its interests are too large to accord with acts really damaging either to itself or to the general market.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Senate to-day defeated the McClelland anti-tipster bill after an amusing debate. The bill sought to prevent the printing or sale of "tips" on races. The vote against it was 17 to 9.

Ex-Gov. David R. Francis of Missouri, President of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, who returned a few days ago from Europe, whither he went to interest the rowned heads and other high dignitaries n the forthcoming fair was welcomed some last evening by the Missouri Society of New York.

UTICA, March 19.--A. Purdie Lord, a student of Cornell University, who had typhoid fever, died in the Masonic Home in this city to-day. The young man was a Mason's orphan, and last June won a State scholarship at Cornell. He was trying to work his way through college.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Amended so that it must be referred to both houses of Congress at the coming regular session, and in other respects, the Cuban treaty was ratified by the Senate to-day. Most of the day was spent in debate, but at 3 o'clock voting began, and after it was over the Senate adjourned sine die.

A little book entitled "How to Become a Competent Motorman," which we are told is " indorsed by the leading railroad managers of the United States," has reached this office, and its eager perusal has not been repaid in the kind of knowledge sought. In the field it covers it seems to be correct and complete.

TRENTON, N.J., March 19 -- In the Senate Assemblyman Scovel's Automobile bill was passed, 17 to 2, after a short speech in opposition by President Hutchinson, who said that the speed of twenty miles an hour on country roads was too great. Mr. Hutchinson during his remarks took occasion to deny that he had thought of using his position to keep the bill from coming to a final vote.

The object lesson which Capt. PIPER, Deputy Police Commissioner, is giving at the intersection of Broadway and Canal Street in handling streams of traffic moving at right angles, is interesting and commands popular approval. It systematizes what has always been the method by which the traffic of intersecting streets, both important thoroughfares, has accommodated itself, and is neither a discovery nor an invention.

While Jose Palma, son of T. Estrada Palma, President of the new Republic of Cuba, was seeking a means of communication with his father with a view to notifying him of the fact that he has a daughterin-law, the facts of the clandestine marriage were made public yesterday through some agency that was unknown to the bride.
Ex-Borough President James J. Coogan was a caller at the City Hall yesterday, and soon after leaving he talked with Lawrence Delmour, one of the "old guard," who are faithful to Richard Croker.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 --There was less activity in this market to-day, but the business was better distributed than for some time past. Prices were firm to strong, but only a few changes of importance were recorded. Guarantee Trust was up 9 1/2 points from its last previous sale; Lehigh Valley, 1 1/2; Lehigh Navigation, 2; United Gas, 1 1/2, and Union Traction of Indiana 5s, 1.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Gov. Odell's Mortgage Tax bill was introduced to-day in the Senate by Senator Green and in the Assembly by Mr. Dickinson, Chairmen of the Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment. An extended conference was held in the Executive Chamber before the session to perfect the final details.

William E. Callender Co. have sold for F.A. Snow to Henry U. Singhi 152 to 150 East Thirty-fifth Street, a plot 66 by 100, upon which the buyer will erect an apartment house from plans by Israels Harder.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Senator Davis of Buffalo, the Chairman of the Committee on Canals, has served notice on Senator Raines, the Republican leader, that the $101,000,000 Canal bill must be given precedence over the Mortgage Tax and the Excise bill.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 19 -- Charles F. Hoffman, Jr., who recently purchased the Wales estate on the Cliffs, has paid $1,080 for a piece of land at a considerable distance from his house, to be used for the erection of a stable. The land contains 6,750 square feet.

We own we do not quite see the point of the Mayor's reply to the communication of Mr. GEORGE F. GMINDER, representing "The National Retail Liquor Dealers' Association." Mr. GMINDER had expressed a desire to call upon the Mayor for the purpose of protesting against the bill, now pending at Albany, whereby the license fee of liquor dealers is to be advanced 50 per cent.

LONDON, March 20 -- The Times's critic says of "Old Heidelberg," the English version of "Alt Heidelberg," produced by George Alexander last evening at the St. James's Theatre, that it is an agreeable play -- Anglo-Teutonically agreeable. It is agreeable because it "confuses our sense of national identity."

Chocolate mice were the somewhat unusual instruments employed by William Bloch, a candy peddler, twenty-one years old, of 19 Henry Street, to inoculate the infants of the lower east side with the gambling fever. So successful has he been that when Nemesis descended upon him yesterday in the person of Policeman Little of the Delancey Street Station a roll of bills as big as a hornets' nest was found in his pockets.

Mayor Low refused to see a delegation of liquor dealers at the City Hall yesterday, and told them in a letter that he would make an appointment if they would tell about the $3,000,000 yearly fund which was being raised by an assessment of $5 a week on every saloon keeper in the Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The international syndicate, headed by the Seligmans, has renewed on a larger scale than at its first venture the offer to assume Venezuela's debts to the powers on conditions. I.N. Seligman has been in Washington two days in that pursuit. He visited the White House and has communicated with some members of the diplomatic body.

LONDON, March 19 -- Money was fairly abundant to-day, and rates were not materially altered. Discounts were quiet. The fact that there was no change to-day in the Bank of England's rate of discount was attributed to unfavorable advices from foreign exchanges and to the illness of the Governor of the Bank.

"I take it philosophically," the Coroner said, "and will feel greatly relieved, because to be under a constant suspense is trying and exhausting. Having been a Coroner's physician in former years, I am perfectly acquainted with the details in the office, and can say that I have been an advocate for improvements in the office, as I always regarded it as inadequate.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19 -- All the members of the Brotherhood of Trainmen and Order of Railroad Conductors' Joint Grievance Committee will be in New Haven to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock, at which time the Directors' answer will be forwarded to them by messenger from President Hall.

Col. Robert A. Ammon, with L.J. Morrison as his counsel, appeared before Justice Gildersleeve in the Supreme Court yesterday and asked to have vacated an order of arrest granted on Jan. 21 of this year, in an action brought by William F. Eckbert, Jr. The other defendants named in the suit by Eckbert are Alfred R. Goslin, Henry A. Seymour, Frank D. Morgan, Eugene L. Packer, John H. Robinson, and Joseph M. Kortier.

Assemblyman Frank J. Ulrich of the Sixth Assembly District, Brooklyn, is in his home, at Stuyvesant and De Kalb Avenues, with many knife wounds on his head, face, and neck that were inflicted in an altercation at McDonough Street and Reid Avenue at 11 o'clock on Thursday night after he had protected a young woman, who, as he believed, was being insulted on a street car by three young clerks.

Clement K. Shorter in The London Sphere. I am surprised to find a little article in The Manchester Daily Dispatch by Mr. Andrew Liang headed "She Shameless Piracy of American Publishers." This is in reference to the case of Kipling vs. Putnam, which has recently been before the American law courts, with the result that Mr. Putnam won the action, and I think rightly so.
The hostility of this city's administration to the Goodsell Street Railway bill, now in the Senate on its third reading, was voiced yesterday by Corporation Counsel Rives.

In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the Circle bowlers won two of three games from the Metropolitan five, scoring 1,081 in the first game and an average of 1,028 2-3 in the three games. The scores follow:

ALBANY, March 20 -- The legislative situation here is becoming badly tangled. The Republican leaders are confident that the difficulties which now appear to be menacing their programme will be straightened out during the next ten days, but at the same time none of them seems absolutely confident as to what the outcome will be.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 20 -- A communication from the office of President J.M. Hall of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, containing the announcement of the action of the Directors at their meeting yesterday was sent to-day to the Grievance Committee of the conductors and trainmen.
ALBANY, March 20 -- These bills were passed by the Assembly to-day:

Commissioner Greene announced yesterday that he had fined Police Capt. Henry Halpin, formerly of the Church Street Police Station, thirty days' pay for irregularities in the station house blotter, and failing to prefer charges against two Sergeants and a doorman for neglect of duty.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 20 -- If you are to be only exhorters, we've got another bench back there on which you can sit -- go way back and sit down," said Bishop Charles N. Fowler, the presiding officer of the New Jersey Methodist Conference, this morning, in addressing the conference class of candidates.

Major Leonard A. Lovering, Twenty-ninth Infantry, is detailed for service and to fill a vacancy in the Inspector General's Department. He will report to the commanding General, Division of the Philippines, for assignment to duty.

The Metropolitan Magazine for April appears as "The New Metropolitan, edited by John Kendrick Bane" The frontispiece is a colored plate representing lower New York at nightfall, seen from the East River. The "consideration of interesting and entertaining phases of metropolitan life," which is now the avowed object of this periodical, is expressed in both prose and verse.

ST. LOUIS, March 20 -- Arguments in defense of the Northern Securities Company, on trial here before the United States Circuit Court for the District of Minnesota, closed to-day, and the case will be placed finally in the hands of the four Judges tomorrow. During the three days of argument the attorneys for the defendants have occupied nine hours, and up to adjournment to-night the Government has taken five hours.

HARPER BROTHERS are publishing this week "Waldn," by Mary Holland Kinkaid, and Will N. Harben's "The Substitute." Miss Kinkaid's novel, as has been said, deals with the romance of a religious cooperative community in a Western State which baa real existence in fact, although the name of it given in the book is fictitious.

The Rev. John Watson, D.D. (Ian Maclaren,) commenting on the text, "Come unto me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest," (Matt. xi, 2S,) says: "It were difficult to say whether one ought to be more impressed by the authority, or by the grace, of this word of Jesus, and ere the sound of it has died away, one remembers that it is not solitary in the Gospels.

Oscar Hammerstein, who wrote "Sweet Marie" and other light operas, wears an unusually thoughtful expression these days, and the reason given is that he is going to write more operas to produce at the Victoria next season. He recently admitted that he would write a rival piece to "The Prince of Pilsen," entitled "The Duke of Wurtzburger."

PARIS, March 20.--At the close of Sarah Bernhardt's performance in "Werther" at her theatre last evening, following the dramatic climax, the audience was startled by a woman's voice in the body of the theatre crying:

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The present expectation is that the negotiations for the drafting of the protocol for the determination by The Hague Tribunal of the question of preferential treatment of the Venezuelan blockading powers in the payment of the claims of their citizens will be resumed between Herbert W. Bowen and the British Ambassador next week.

One may look in vain among the constitutional histories written by men like Hallam, Stubbs, and Freeman, among the works of jurists like Wilkins, or among the valuable contributions to legislative forms and chronology made by Lords Hale and Lyttelton and others without finding anything which can enlighten the general reader on the question of the exact popular significance of the British Parliament to the British nation and to the Anglo-Saxon race.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The net changes in prices on the Stock Exchange were trifling, one of them exceeding one-half of 1 per cent., and even that was limited to a single stock, United Gas receding from 110 to 109 1/2. At times there was a show of strength, especially by Lehigh Valley and Philadelphia Company, but it was spasmodic, and the former closed at yesterday's final figure, while the latter was up 3/8 net.

"The History of the Five Indian Nations of Canada," by Cadwallader Colden, was first published in 1727, an excessively rare bit of Americana nowadays It was reprinted a great many times until long after the middle of the eighteenth century. He was Lieutenant Governor of the Colony of New York from 1701 at intervals until 1775, dying the next year, at the age of eighty-eight.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Superintendent Frederick D. Kilburn of the State Bankins Department issued a statement to-day showing the condition of the banks of deposit and discount in this State at the close of business on Feb. 26.

Major Gen. A.R. Chaffee told the members of the Methodist Social Union, at the regular monthly meeting in the Hotel Savoy last night, that he had never met an intelligent Chinaman who expressed any desire to embrace the Christian religion. That announcement startled the 200 men and women members of the fashionable church organization who were present.

The tedious steps of the process of awakening the intelligence a human being deprived of all the ordinary means of communication with her fellows at an age so early that practically no foundation had been laid by normal means -- such is the material of this book on the life of Helen Keller, written partly by herself.

Commissioner McDougall Hawkes of the Department of Docks and Ferries yesterday recommended to the Sinking Fund Commissioners approval of an extension of the lease of Pier 24, North River, at the foot of Franklin Street, to the Central Hudson Steamboat Company, for five years and nine months, from May 1, this year, with the privilege of two renewals of ten years each.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 20 -- A professional three-ball thirty-six-hole medal play golf match between Donald J. Ross, Alec Ross, and Bernard Nicols drew a large gathering to-day. Donald Ross won, with 14S strokes, Nicols was second, with 160, and Alec Ross third, with 162.

A conference of representatives of banks and other noteholders of Dresser Co., commission merchants in hosiery, silks, , at 15 Greene Street, has been held in the office of Morris J. Hirsch, at 68 William Street, and an advisory committee has been chosen to consult with the receivers of the firm regarding the disposition of the business, and also to report what offer of settlement should be made to the creditors.

Mayor Low and Controller Grout are at odds over investigations which the expert accountants and investigators of the Fi- nance Department have been making into the various departments. Mayor Low ex- presses willingness to help Controller Grout, but his desire is that all the material of the investigations be kept secret until a policy can be adopted as to their publication or other action.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 20 -- In the midst of a dense fog the big passenger steamboat Plymouth of the Fall River Line and the freight steamboat City of Taunton of the same line came into collision with a crash at an early hour this morning just east of Plum Island, in Long Island Sound.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 20 -- The Missouri Supreme Court to-day found five large beef-packing companies guilty of maintaining an unlawful combination to control prices of meat in the State, and issued an order of ouster prohibiting them from doing business in Missouri and to pay a line of $5,000 each and to bear the costs of the proceedings.

BOSTON, March 20 -- The money market is slightly easier in tone, but rates remain practically unchanged. Call loans, 5 @ 5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2 @6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- Charged with embezzlement and other irregularities amounting to about $20,000, George B. White, the Vice President and a Director of the National Bank of South Pennsylvania, at Hyndman, Bedford County, was arrested by a Deputy United States Marshal to-day, and held in $8,000 bail by United States Commissioner Craig for a further hearing next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- From such imperfect readings of the Cuban treaty as can be had at this stage, the State Department officials have some doubt as to, their ability to do anything whatever with the convention. The amendments made by the Senate, particularly that added to the ratifying article, though probably not so intended, may result in the complete loss of the treaty.

LONDON, March 20.--Messrs, A. C. Black publish Prof. Percy Gardner's "Oxford at the Crossroads. "The author, who is a Cambridge man, but has held the professorship of classical archaeology at Oxford for sixteen years, regards the institution of the Rhodes scholarships as marking an epoch in Oxford's history.

AMERICANS are fair geographers because their own country with its many cities and innumerable towns requires no small amount of study so as to fix their precise whereabouts, but to most of the Russia is pretty much of a terra jjfflits.

At a meeting of the Stewards of The Jockey Club yesterday the following appointments by the Washington Jockey Club of officials for its Spring meeting were approved: Judge -- Clarence McDowell; Starter -- Mars Cassidy; Handicapper -- W.S. Vosburgh; Paddock and Patrol Judge -- J.L. Hall; Timer -- W.H. Berretto; Clerk of the Scales -- H.G. Crickmore.

Capt. Mites O'Reilly, recently transferred from the Tenderloin to the quiet of the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, still pursues the agile and slippery gaming monster, and will not be shaken off. Yesterday the ertswhile terror of West Thirtieth Street sat up out among the rubber plants and baby carriages and took notice of things again.

CHARLESTON, West. Va., March 20 -- The special report of the Federal Grand Jruy in Judge Keller's court on the battle between the miners and the Deputy Marshals at Stannford City on Feb. 25 was made public this evening by permission of Attorney General Knox. The Grand Jury upholds the officers for their course.

At the last subscription night of the season at the opera another double bill was given, consisting of "La Fille du Regiment" and Miss Smyth's music drama, "Der Wald" -- an arrangement like that of the first production of the English lady's work, that was greatly to its benefit in providing a large audience.

While undoubtedly there was an increase yesterday in outside and commission house business, it is not exaggerating the fact to say that the market's chief source of strength came from purchases by the short interest, who, alarmed at the scanty sup- ply of stocks, were beating a retreat as gracefully and as expeditiously as possible.

Borough President Cromwell presented plans for extensive improvements of the ferry facilities to Staten Island at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday. The plans showed that the war between the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and the interests represented by H.H. Rogers of the Standard Oil Company had been declared off, and President Cromwell said that amicable arrangements would now be made for the best ferry service obtainable.
Among the items disposed of at the concluding day's sale last evening by John Anderson, Jr., 20 West Thirtieth Street, of Part 3 of the literary collection of the lat Peter Gilsey were the following:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Apropos of a note in your issue for March 7, commenting upon the article where in Professor Phelpa points out the similarity between Maaterlinck "Monna Vanna" and Browning's "Luria." it may not be amiss to suggest that there is reasonable evidence that the literary Frenchman has before salted his vein of originality with are from an English mine.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The interesting character and commercial value of our monthly consular reports are mentioned with so much approbation in your editorial of yesterday that I am tempted, with your kind permission, to recall the circumstances under which they were instituted.

Putnam Place is by no means inactive in spite of its quiet, orderly ways. The mere fact that it cherishes time-honored customs and certain old-fashioned habits and traditions and shelters in its peaceful bosom kindly old persons whose history holds many a tear as well as smiles in its telling lends to the quaint little place, so cleverly described by Mrs. Collin, a romantic interest oddly at variance with its gentle old inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Commissioner Foulke of the Civil Service Commission does not believe that United States Senators are entitled to the protection of "lese majeste." It was publicly charged in the Senate by Senator Dubois that the Civil Service Commission had secured the removal of a clerk from the Surveyor General's office of Idaho for receiving contributions for campaign purposes.

ST. LOUIS, March 20 -- Arguments in the Wabash injunction suit were concluded this afternoon, and the case was taken under advisement by Judge Adams. He gave no intimation of how much time he might require to prepare his opinion, but the attorneys declared after the adjournment of the court that they would look for a decision in a week or ten days.

President Wells of the Tax Board announced yesterday that New York would this year collect taxes approximately on $600,000,000 personal property, the largest amount ever placed on the final taxrolls after the reductions and the "swearing-off" process had been gone through with. On Tuesday next the tax books will be closed, and those who have not appeared before the Tax Commissioners in answer to notices will have to pay the taxes on the amount assessed.
Trade reports to the several commercial agencies continue generally favorable. Bradstreet's sums up the situation as follows:

The contention of Abram I. Elkus, counsel for Police Inspector Adam A. Cross, that the office of the District Attorney, representing the prosecutors, was using the powers of that office to intimidate witnesses, figured conspicuously in the third day of the hearing of the charges against Inspector Cross at Police Headquarters yesterday.

BUFFALO, March 20 -- The C. Moensch Sons Company and Moensch, Fisher Gaensslen of Gowanda, two of the biggest tannery concerns in this part of the coun- try, are insolvent. Application for the appointment of receivers for both companies was made to Justice White to-day.

A "Manual of French Law" and commercial information by H. Cleveland Coxe, counselor at law, has been imported by Brentano's. In view of the immense number of Americans who go to France for a longer or shorter sojourn, this compendium of the salient points in the law of France should find many cis-Atlantic readers.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--The export trade of the United States is rapidly reaching its normal condition. February figures of the Bureau of Statistics show the largest exports of any February in the history of our commerce, and also show that the exports of the three months ending with February were larger than those of the corresponding period of any earlier year.

The effort in New Jersey to enact a law denying to the representatives of minority interests in companies incorporated under the laws of that State the right to bring suits against them for the protection of what they believe to be their interests is dangerous and mischievous.

Three closely contested hand tennis games were played yesterday afternoon before R.L. Lakeman finally defeated R.A. Brown in the handicap tournament now in progress at the New York Athletic Club. Both men were on the same handicap mark, 10 points, and were very evenly matched. It was the steadiness that Lakeman displayed after losing the first game that gained the victory for him.

Thomas C. Dawson's "The South Arner- lean Republics," which G.P. Putnam's Sons have in preparation, in two volumes, will occupy a place in the publishers Story of the Nations Series. Mr. Degrain is Secretary or the United States Legation in Brazil, and may therefore be supposed to be in a position to secure special information, or, at any rate, to make careful observation.
Mayor Low announced yesterday that he would make answer in writing this morning to the letter received late Thursday evening from the liquor dealers, after he had refused to receive their committee.

Stocks strong. At the opening yesterday weakness in Southern Pacific attested growing confidence that the general market was not menaced from that direction. Relieved from that weight prices took a course opposed to that when the abnormal strength of Southern Pacific caused general alarm.

Statement that the consolidation will be announced in a few days of the Citizens' National Bank of Washington, with a capital of $300,000, and the West End National Bank of Washington, with a capital of $200,000.

William Henry Babcock, in writing his new book, "Kent Fort Manor," has brought forth a curious product which makes the reader wonder which of the elements in Mr. Babcock's literary make-up will eventually predominate. At present one gets the Impression of many qualities at war one with another, in the havoc of which the author has not yet found himself.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Despite the attitude of the Senate toward Dr. W.D. Crum and William M. Byrne, the President to-day, for the third time, appointed the former to be Collector of the Port of Charleston, S.C., and the latter to be United States District Attorney for Delaware.
A very interesting account was given by Mr. DILLINGHAM on Thursday evening of the work doing at the Calhoun School and Settlement in Lowndes County, Ala., of which school he is Principal.

Two interesting public school kindergarten anniversary celebrations are being arranged. They are the tenth anniversary, next Tuesday, of the founding of kindergartens in the public schools, and the birthday, April 21, of Friedrich Froebel, "the Father of Kindergartens."

Because of admissions of having committed bigamy, made in divorce actions by defendants, Justice Truax of the Supreme Court yesterday requested the District Attorney to take steps leading to the prosecution of Prof. Paul S. Strollhofen and Mrs. Marie Mulertt. Bigamy will be the charge.
What will Cuba do about the treaty that was "ratified" on Thursday by the Senate of the United States?

Fritz Lindinger, President of the New York City Wine, Liquor and Beer Dealers' Association, announced yesterday that the united brewery interests of the city were behind the offer made by Charles Stadler. President of the American Malt- ing Company, through State Senator Dowling, to form a corporation to take the canal off the hands of the State under a charter and lease of 100 years.

LONDON, March 5 -- Zola's "Truth," translated by Mr. Ernest Vizitelly, has just made its appearance. Like all Mr. Vizitelly's translations of Zola, it reads easily, and is probably as faithful as the prejudices or convictions of the British public will permit it to be, but it is by no means an ideal translation.

In 1889 the late Dr. George H. Moore, in his "Introduction of Printing into New York," claimed that Bawd and Lodowick's "Narrative," known to have come from William Bradford's press in 1603, was the first book printed in New York. No copy, however, was then known, and its former existence was only made certain by the imprint of the edition of 1703, which says: "Printed at New York and reprinted at London."

DAFFODILS and ousry willows in all the quaint crannies that serve the Boston street florists for booths declare the Spring really begun; and ribbons of violet on sheaves of green paper and ribbons of green on sheaves of violet paper textity to the stationers conviction that Easter follows Lent, and the publishers are keeping abreast of the season by fulfilling the promise of their announcement.

Representatives of thirty-two colleges and universities, members of the Beta Theta Pi, gathered at the Waldorf-Astoria last night on the occasion of the banquet given by the alumni of the fraternity and District II. in honor of Gov. Benjamin B. Odell. Jr., of this State, Gov. John L. Bates of Massachusetts, and Gov. Andrew J. Montague of Virginia.

Nobody is ever surprised by hearing that the irresponsible and radiant activities of the German Emperor have taken a new direction. Nobody ought to be saddened by the announcement that the direction they have taken is toward the amendment of German prose. That is the announcement which comes from Berlin, with every apparent mark of authenticity.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at din- ner this evening the British Ambassador and Lady Herbert, Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Chanler, Miss Eleanor Roosevelt of New York, Miss Alice Warder, Miss De Smirnoff, Miss Hagner, Mr. De Ring of the British Embassy.

There is just one word in Mrs. Staunard's latest story that we could wish changed -- the "Scuffle" of the closing paragraph. That comes with something of a jar into the tender finale of an exquisite little tale, told with enchanting simplicity, directness, and charm.

Ex-Assemblyman Gherardi Davis was appointed Third Deputy Police Commissioner yesterday afternoon. Commissioner Greene received a telegram from Albany announcing that Gov. Odell had signed the bill authorizing the appointment of a third deputy, and immediately sent for Mr. Davis, who left his office at 44 Pine Street and hurried to Police Headquarters, where he received his badge of office.

PROF. JUSTIN SMITH of Dartmouth College, author of "The Troubadours at Home" and the forthcoming volume about Arnold's march from Cambridge to Quebec, which G.P. Putnam's Sons have in preparation, has been invited to edit the memorial volume of the Honourable Artillery Company of London, which is in preparation under the title of "A Tale of Two Worlds in Five Centuries."

Charged with the theft of $1,800 worth of diamonds and jewelry from the mother of her school-girl chum, Rose Christalli, nineteen years old, one of the leaders of the senior class at the Normal College was arrested last night while she sat at the piano in the home she afterward confessed to having robbed.

Erromanga, one, of the islands of the New Hebrides, always had a bad reputations and deservedly. When visited for the first time by Capt. Cook in 1774, from his own account, he tells how he nearly lost his life there, owing to the treachery of the natives. The Erromangans showed themselves to be thieves.

LONDON, March 20 -- Colonial Secretary Chamberlain to-day received in the Guildhall the City of London's congratulations on his mission to South Africa. Lord Mayor Samuel and the Corporation presented to him an address of welcome in the presence of a large gathering of distinguished representatives of politics, the army and navy, art, science, the Church, the law, and the drama.

The wedding of Mrs. William Earl Dodge and Col. Stephen Olin will be the event of most interest to-day. It will take place at noon, and will be a very quiet and small affair. The Badminton Club will have a meeting, and there are to be some minor entertainments. Mrs. F. Dana Winslow's dinner for engaged couples will be given this evening.

"Micheiangelo Buonarroti" is the first volume in an important library of art which is to be published simultaneously in England by Duckworth, Co., and in America by Charles Scribner's Sons. This first volume, which is by Charles Holroyd, keeper of the National Gallery of British Art, includes tranlations of Ascanio Condivl's "Vita di Michelangelo Bounarroti" and three dialogues from the Portuguese of Francisco d'Ollanda, a miniature painter, who was in Rome in 1538.

Edward J. Delehanty and George Davis, the baseball players who have been setting at defiance the dictates of the joint peace committees, have one choice left in order to remain in the National game. Delehanty must fulfill his contract with the Washington American club and Davis will have to do likewise and play with the Chicago American club or else be expelled from professional baseball.

The second port of the Harold Peirce collection, to be sold by Stan. V. Henkels March 27 and 28, in the auction rooms of Davis Harvey, Philadelphia, contains an astonishing array at rarities. Its two chief features are the Iong sets of issues of the finest modern private prases and the special collections of first editions of the works of William Morris, D.G. Rossetti Ruskin, Swinburoe, Tennyson, and Symonda.

The leading fencers of the Columbia University Fencers' Club competed last night at the Salle Murray, in the Tuxedo Building, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, for a medal presented by Dr. G. Alfred Lawrence, W.E. Withrow won. Only the six foremost foilsmen in the club were allowed to compete.

If you have a nature well attuned to the horrors of war and can bear physical, moral, and mental shocks. "Flowers of the Dust" offers every inducement to the reader. It is one continuous and fascinating horror. And this is said in a spirit of humble admiration and without malice. It is astonishing to note the number of disasters Mr. Oxenham cheerfully chronicles in the course of his narrative.

Whitehouse Porter have sold for Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney to Mrs. Robert Livingston Beeckman 728 Fifth Avenue, a four-story brownstone-front dwelling, on lot 27 by 125, adjoining the Whitney residence at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. Mrs. Whitney bought the house something over a year ago to guard against any objectionable improvement of the lot.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 20 -- The Yale Alumni Weekly to-day publishes a long statement signed by seven members of the Yale class of 1887, in appreciation of the late Arthur Reed Pennell of Buffalo, whose name has been mentioned frequently in connection with the Burdick murder mystery, and whose tragic death occurred recently.

Among the low shoes to be worn with pretty, white openwork hosiery are some that are covered with a material that is very much like white madras of shirtwaist fame. Possibly this is the beginning of a season of shirtwaists and shoes to match. The shoes are well shaped and they have high French heels.

It was learned last night that the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee had a heated discussion at its Thursday meeting over the refusal of Mayor Low to receive the liquor dealers' committee.

NEW ORLEANS, March 20 -- Safeguard and Henry of Franstamar were the winning favorites to-day. Foley, who rode Radiant Heat in the second race, was seriously hurt when the horse fell. Weather clear, track slow. The summary:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The University of Cornell has been visited by a grievous epidemic, and, as is invariably the case when a thing of this kind happens, much slander and unjust criticism have been uttered against the university officials and the hospital corps of nurses, doctors, , in their treatment of the sick students.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A densely ignorant immigrant who reaches these shores learns in an incredibly short period that this is the freest of free countries. He scarce knows a dozen words of pidgin-English, but he has already absorbed enough of the spirit of so-called "Americanism" to impudently assert it to our oldest citizen.
