SITKA, Alaska, Feb. 27. -- Although efforts have been made to keep the matter from the public, it has become known that another clash between factions of the Indians here is imminent. The much-mooted frog controversy is at the bottom of the dissension. Five Indians are now serving time at San Quentin for the part they took in the rioting over a year ago.

AS AN operatic singer Signer Scotti, the creator of Srarpia, the finished interpreter of Iago and the ideal Don Giovanni, is well known, but Antonio Scotti, the private individual, has been as a sealed book. During the thirteen years of his stage career he has invariably declined to be interviewed.

There was an enthusiastic gathering yesterday afternoon at Sherry's, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, on the occasion of the annual meeting of the University Settlement. The announcement that Miss Jane Addams of Hull House, Chicago, was to deliver the principal address brought together a large audience, largely of women, so that a glance over the hall revealed a bewildering scene of millinery and the art of the dressmaker.
NATCHEZ, Miss., March 21. -- Torrential trains last night and to-day have aggravated the flood situation along the Sycamore levee in Concordia Parish, La., and it is feared a break will occur.
THE talk had been about the business ability of people who do not handle large sums of money, and one of the party told the following story:

How are the seats of the mighty shaken! Mr. Henry Arthur Jones and Mr. Arthur Bourehier, the actor-manager producing his new play, "Whitewashing Julia," refused on the first night to permit The Times's critic, Mr. A.B. Walkley, (a cable report of whose first-night opinion on important plays appears in our own columns.) to enter the theatre; and playgoing circles in London are in a ferment.

Denunciation of the Board of Education by a teacher of a public school was one of the features of the first annual reunion and dinner of the Alumni Association of Grammar School No. 69 at Shanley's last evening. The remarks were uttered by Bernhard Cronson of Public School No. 125, in Wooster Street.

LONDON, March 21. -- An automobile exhibition was opened in Agricultural Hall here to-day. It formed a comprehensive international display, including vehicles for heavy traffic and municipal purposes and racing machines. Among the latter was the machine with which the Hon. Stewart Rolls broke the world's automobile record for a kilometer Feb. 26, and an American "torpedo" electrical car.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems strange Mr. Hall of Alabama did not acquire a reasonably accurate knowledge of the single tax during his perusal of those writings which are alleged to be complete and conclusive refutations of the supposed vagaries of Henry George. Mr. Hall opines that McRae's heading.

BRUSSELS, March 10. -- The renewed campaign lately begun in England against the Congo Free State is the topic of the day here. The matter is a vital one, for it is generally believed, both in official and unofficial circles, that the question of the Congo Free State's existence as an independent power is at stake.

To a very considerable extent American railroad matters are treated conservatively by the English press. Nowadays, in fact, they are given quite respectful handling compared with the rough usage accorded them in the past, largely, of course, owing to the vast improvement which has taken place in their financial and physical condition, and to the fact that much which really merited criticism from an economic standpoint has been cleaned off the slate.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 21. -- Priests may visit smallpox patients for the purpose of administering extreme unction, provided they exercise the precautions that are exercised by physicians, according to a decision of the State Board of Health to-day.
SENTIMENTAL folks are they who populate the Southwest. A hundred times a day evidence of this is shown wheresoever there be a Southwestern congregation.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21. -- The New Louisiana Stakes, at four miles, and worth $1,690 to the winner, marked the close of the local racing season to-day. Only four horses faced the starter, of whom The Way was favorite at 6 to 5. Major Mansir was backed from 5 to 2, while Latson was at threes and Accolade at tens.

An athletic nicer possessing many novel features and which will be decidedly unique in the large number of competitions that are held in this city, will take place in the Seventh Regiment Armory during the last week in April. It has been termed an inter-Settlement athletic meet, which means that it will be open to all members of any of the Settlement houses belonging to the Neighborhood Workers' Association.

JIM CROWLEY -- we'll give him that name for the purposes of this story -- is a passenger train conductor on the Harlem Railroad. During the thirteen or more years he has run out of New York City he has had many and strangely varied experiences. But none, he confesses, was so humiliating as the one about which all who know him are now talking and laughing.

PARIS, March 13. -- Sarah Bernhardt's travesty of the rule of Werther has not had any greater success than was anticipated. The novel, for a short time after its appearance, is said to have inspired a certain number of sentimental young Germans to commit suicide. The days have gone by when lovers took themselves quite so seriously as that for the same motives.

CARACAS, March 21. -- President Castro has resigned. He placed his resignation of the Presidency of the Republic of Venezuela in the hands of the President of Congress after reading the Presidential message to-day and handed over the exercise of the Presidential functions to the President of Congress.

A very interesting aspect of the general adoption of the automobile and the extensive improvement of highways which now seems near at hand is the probable extent to which transit between the city and its suburbs will be facilitated, and the question arises whether the automobile will become a serious rival of the railroads in that field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The communication published in your columns this week from a civil engineer is so pertinent that I venture to add to it the consideration of the subject from the point of view of the mechanical engineer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from "A New York Cop." published in your issue of the 13th, should be carefully studied by the Mayor. Police Commissioner, and all interested in the reforms that are being sought for the Police Department.

Heralded as a new light in German literature by Adolf Wilbrandt, one of the leading modern poets and writers of Germany, the budding genius of Hugo Bertsch, a Brooklyn artisan, fifty years of age, awaits in Williamsburg the recognition that Herr Wilbrandt so confidently has predicted.

Lent is more than half over. Next Sunday will begin Passion Week; the Sunday after that is Palm, and the opening of Holy Week. It is odd how many persons confound Passion and Holy Weeks. During the fortnight which begins on next Sunday and ends at Easter, those who make any practice or pretense at keeping Lent do not entertain or go out.

ST. LOUIS, March 21. -- The final arguments in the Northern Securities case were tided this afternoon, and the case was left with the Federal Court of Appeals. Because of the enormous mass of evidence and the voluminous arguments which the Judges are called upon to consider, it is doubtful if a decision will be possible within two months, and the probabilities are the time will be longer than that.

LONDON, March 21. -- The announcement that the Government contemplates bringing in a bill providing a modified form of home rule for Ireland complicates the political situation, which already presents an extraordinary muddle.

With the launching of the challenger for the America's Cup last week, and the naming of its probable defender, interest in the international contests had a decided boom. The design of Shamrock III, as seen at her launching was the chief topic of discussion, and the opinions expressed of her qualities were as varied as the reports of her dimensions sent hither by eye witnesses.

POOR Tom! He had once more disobeyed the one injunction about which the master was peculiarly insistent. That was to drop all play when the bell telling the opening of the school session sounded. When the ruler fell upon the desk before that august personage -- the teacher -- Tom, as well as the rest of the scholars, knew they must be at their desks ready for business.

THE opening of the trout fishing season on Long Island next Saturday will find hundreds of devotees of the casting rod eager for the sport. The close season for the island, which has always been much shorter than for the balance of the State of New York, has been shortened by a day this year.

With all the accessories known to romance Adolph Lee Wirth, a wealthy young business man of Milwaukee, and his bride, who was Miss Edna Double of New York and Boston, are at the Savoy Hotel spending their honeymoon, and waiting anxiously for a possible reconciliation with the father and mother of the bride.

To an American, Theodore M. Davies, is due the credit of what is regarded as by far the most interesting archaeological discovery in Egypt of the last season, and, indeed, for a great many years. Mr. Davies's work has resulted in the discovery of the tomb of one of the Pharaohs of the eighteenth dynasty, Thothmes IV., and in this tomb was the chariot in which the Pharaoh rode at Thebes -- a unique find.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have lately read with interest an article, taken from your journal in which you speak of the manufacture of briquettes from coal dust, town refuse, and other waste materials.

Intercollegiate fencing will be one of the most interesting features in the college athletic world during the coming week. The annual intercollegiate championship tournament for team and individual honors will be held on Friday and Saturday in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club. Six teams will be represented -- West Point, the present holder of the team championship; Columbia, Yale, Harvard, Cornell, and the University of Pennsylvania.

WHAT has become of the old-time stage doorkeeper? Like many other features of the past he has disappeared, and the stage door of today knows him not. In olden days it used to be a popular phrase with actors:

IT is expected that the Fourteenth Medical Congress, which is to meet next month in Madrid, will be more largely attended than was the last congress at Moscow. Already 1,200 foreign doctors and 191 women have expressed their intention to attend, together with 243 foreign special delegates from medical societies.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The Goethebund, an organization consisting of the leading dramatists, artists, and writers of Germany, held a large mass meeting yesterday to protest against the action of the Prussian censor for refusing to allow the public presentation of Heyse's "Mary of Magdala," Oscar Wilde's "Salome," and Dreyer's new play, the "Thal des Lebens."

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 21. -- When the inquest into the Burdick murder mystery is brought to a close next Monday or Tuesday it is very probable, unless unlocked for information is forthcoming, that a verdict will be returned to the effect that the crime was committed by a person or persons unknown.
The Directors of the Standard Milling Company have declared a dividend of 1 per cent, on the preferred stock of the company.

Seven games of handball, the first part of the series of fifteen which will decide the professional handball championship of the world, were played yesterday in the court of the Jersey City Handball Club, 223 Mercer Street, Jersey City. "Mike" Egan, who claims the title of champion through default of William Carney of Cleveland won all seven, and his opponent, Louis Keegan of Kennedy's Court, Chicago, was outplayed and out-generaled from start to finish.

GERMANY'S expansion policy in South and Central America has drawn the attention of thoughtful citizens of this country for some considerable time. About as many statements have appeared magnifying as belittling it. What are the real facts in the case? An answer to that question, marshaling the main elements, will show in how far this Nation has reason for disquiet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with surprise and regret that your correspondent read the editorial in Saturday's TIMES on "The Situation in Ithaca." It was not pleasant reading for an admirer of THE NEW YORK TIMES because it was so biased in the views it expressed and untrue in some of its statements.

Publication of the report of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company recently has done much to draw public attention to the change in managerial policy which has taken place the past few years, to the importance of that change, and to the vigor with which the present policy is being carried out.

PARIS, March 21. -- Pierre des Essars, Director of Economic Studies at the Bank of France, delivered a lecture to-night on the American trusts. The assembly which gathered to hear him included a number of financiers and students of economics, and was presided over by M. Hausser, the Chief Engineer of the Southwestern Railroad.

Cocktails, their consumption by naval officers and the effect of them, on the systems of these officers form a considerable part of the interest in an action brought by Capt. Marlin Stuart of the Royal British Navy to recover $75,000 damages for injuries claimed to have been suffered while stopping at the Murray Hill Hotel at the time of the big dynamite explosion in the Fourth Avenue tunnel, on Jan. 27, 1902.

Before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court this week arguments are to be heard on an appeal taken by Mrs. Helena Sommer, in her action against her husband, Frederick W. Sommer, and his sister, Mrs. Josephine Vogel, for an interest in $30,000 worth of property at 8 Second Avenue, title of which she has claimed under an agreement signed on May 8, 1900.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having acquired "THE TIMES habit," have also become accustomed to see a-good many things through TIMES spectacles and in many cases come to TIMES conclusions. Yet in one direction I differ not alone with your valued journal, but also with every other, and the various dictionaries and encyclopaedias as well.

BOSTON, March 21. -- The money market shows a considerably easier tone and rates are slightly lower. Call funds are more plentiful and there is an increased disposition to put out time loans. Call loans, 5 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 5@3 1/2 per cent. Time loans, mercantile paper, 5 1/3 per cent.

Under the agreement entered into on Oct. 21, 1902, by the mine operators and the miners for the appointment of the arbitration commission, both are bound for three years to the acceptance of the findings and terms that are made by the commission.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21. -- It became known to-day that Albert Barnes Cutler Salmon, stenographer and court reporter, had eloped with the wife of his brother, Jesse R. Salmon. The missing man is forty-eight years old, and deserted a wife and seven children, the eldest being a son twenty-three years old.

MOSQUITO Extermination in Practice" is the title of an extended report of the Lawrence (L.I.) Board of Health. The board has conducted during the past year an active campaign against the pests, and sets forth in detail methods which have achieved a considerable measure of success -- methods which are of much interest because they are equally applicable to all places near the coast, that region which has been the mosquito's peculiar kingdom.

The Oratorio Society will give Edward Elgar's cantata. "The Dream of Gerontius," on Thursday evening at 8 o'clock in Carnegie Hull, under the direction of Mr. Frank Damrosch. The soloists will be Miss Ada Crossley, mezzo soprano; Mr. Ellison Van House, tenor, and Mr. David Bispham, bass.

TOFEKA, Kan., March 21. -- Gov. Bailey, the new bachelor Executive of Kansas, will yield to the demand of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union that water instead of wine be used in naming the new battleship Kansas.

LYMAN had come to the decision that he liked the Southerners in "the Woods" better than he did the Northerners, for though it was in the extreme South, there were nearly as many former Michigan and Wisconsin lumbermen engaged in sweeping away the yellow pine of that region as there were Georgians, Alabamans, and Mississippians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prominent merchants of this city, including leading importers and agents of our home manufacturers, are not only surprised but dumfounded at the character of the recent appointments to vacancies in the Assistant Appraiserships at this port.

IT MAY be that the funny man is not always original. Anyhow, he apparently devotes the best days of his life trying to make other people feel jolly -- when they read his paragraphs in the newspapers. Be that as it may, no man needs to be a professional humorist himself in order to get an awful lot of fun sometimes out of the newspaper advertisements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The discussion of the negro problem, which appears to be an absorbing topic at the present time, is untimely, for, while it is interesting to note the different phases of public opinion, the matter should rest until existing prejudices have moderated through time and experience.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Italian Ambassador and Mme. Mayor des Planches entertained a dinner company this evening which included Mr. and Mrs. Gaff, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ellis, Mr. and Mrs. George Howard, the Belgian Minister, Miss Wallach, and Mr. van Roijen of the Netherlands.

The opera season that closed last evening, and with its close brought the end of the regime of the Maurice Grau Opera Company, has been in several respects strikingly different from some of those that have preceded it in recent rears. From the point of view of the management and of the people of society it has been an uncommonly successful one.
Some compensation for the commonplace character of much of current business has been afforded within the last few days by happenings which will have immediate an important real estate influences.
NOW, if you'll listen to me," said the prominent Venezuelan patriot, "I can tell you how all these obligations can be discharged, and it won't cost Venezuela a cent."

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- The report of the Strike Commission was placed in the hands of President Baer of the Reading Railway about 8:30 o'clock this morning. He glanced over it and ordered that a summary of it be printed and placed on the desks of all the executive officers. It was understood that orders went out that no official should give out any opinion of the finding for publication.

The Thirteenth Regiment Cavalry. United States Army, which is under orders to sail for the Philippines, the first squadron having already left San Francisco, has the distinction of numbering among its officers probably the best polo team in the service. The season just closed is the first in which the Thirteenth has made a bid for polo honors.

WHEN the New York Microscopical Society was organized, about seven years ago, it was mainly for the convenience of physicians interested in bacteriological study. They desired to talk and compare notes on the results of their, individual work. They met in the Mott Memorial Library, just opposite Madison Square Garden, twice a month, and enjoyed an intellectual treat, from their point of view.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 21. -- Wire tappers successfully operated between West Baden and New Orleans yesterday afternoon, with the result that the West Baden pool room is $3,500 poorer. A well dressed man with a slight limp in his walk arrived in West Baden several days ago and registered as Baron Fritz von Lassollaye.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your reports from the pen of J.C. Bayles, ex-President of the New York Board of Health, on the causes underlining the present typhoid epidemic in Ithaca and on the remedies suggesting themselves to him, deserve the sincere than not only of your readers but of the country at large, and more especially of the smaller, semi-rural towns.
LONDON, March 21. -- No apology is necessary for beginning my letter with a reference to Mr. Chamberlain, for this week has been Mr. Chamberlain's week.

Shakespeare, who has been so well represented in this season's plays, will be a feature of this week's bill. Mr. Sothern for his last week here revives "Hamlet," with which he drew large houses at the beginning of his run at the Garden in January, while Stuart Robson, who has been touring from the Atlantic to the Pacific in "A Comedy of Errors," will appear in that play at the Harlem Opera House.

The Twenty-first Assembly District Taxpayers' Association has, through its President. Thomas Barrett, addressed a letter to Gov. Odell protesting against the passage of the proposed Mortgage Tax bill. The letter is accompanied by a set of resolutions adopted at a meeting of the association on the 18th instant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of Tuesday relative to the British naval budget ineidently sounds a note of warning which has often before fallen on deaf ears. The sum of $180,000,000 expended per annum for the navy does more than protect them from assault; it makes their dependencies glad to find shelter under the flag which is most respected in every port throughout the world.

Washington Letter to The Boston Transcript. "Be good to the office boy," Is a moral, taught by the career of William Alden Smith of Michigan. He had saved a little money and wanted a place to study Blackstone. This was in 1879. He thought first of Chicago, and even went so far as to go to that city and apply for a place as office boy in the firm of Walker Dexter.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Increase of wages and shorter hours for the anthracite coal miners are awarded by the report of the coal strike commission, which was made public to-day. It provides that the award shall remain in effect from April 1 next to March 31, 1906, and that disputes between the miners and their employers shall be referred to a permanent board of arbitration, lockouts and strikes being absolutely forbidden.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is our National Senate outgrowing its usefulness? Is it being transformed into a syndicate of wind? If so, where are the psychologists? Let them discover the moral bacillus of interminable talk. When found, let their occultism apply the antidote.

THE woman who had dropped in for afternoon tea sighed wearily. " I felt I must has a bit of gossip, just to cheer me up," she said. " I've been having such a worry over housekeeping matters. If Fred would only leave me alone to manage! "

PARIS, March 14. -- From the point of view of artistic interest the sale of M. Zola's bric-a-brac at the Hotel des Ventes has not been the success which was anticipated by the general public. Those who knew the late M. Zola sufficiently well to have had an opportunity of examining his treasures a little closely, however, were already aware that a large proportion of them would not pass muster with connoisseurs.

THE most important increase of the United States Navy was made during the last session of Congress in providing for five big battleships. Not since the work of providing for the new navy was begun has a more significant provision been made, and the legislative generosity, if such it may be called, is almost entirely due to a popular demand voiced through the Nation's press.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 21. -- At the close of work to-day at the Herreshoffs' shops only two plates remained out of place at the bow and three small ones at the stern of the Reliance. As yet there is quite a lot of riveting to be done on the top sides. The after end of the boat is drawn out pretty fine, with rather a narrow stern.

SENATOR Fairbanks of Indiana, who is being spoken of as a possible Republican candidate for the Presidency, has some reputation as an after-dinner talker. His speeches are a mosaic of anecdotes and quaint sayings picked up in political campaigns. Not long ago he told of visiting one of his constituents.

IN LITTLE girldom in New York there is a new game; amusement, it may be more fairly called, perhaps. But whatever its title is -- and it has not as yet been officially named -- it is giving a limited number of small women up town very keen pleasure and proving of no mean educational value to them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to contribute a few lines to the discussion of the highly interesting subject of "Drug Substitution and Adulteration." In the first place, it is my opinion that while your strictures on that pernicious evil are perfectly just and logical, you have nut suited the causes of the evil correctly or impartially.

The case of the assault on Assemblyman ULRICH, in Brooklyn, growing out of disorder in a trolley car, is one of very general interest to a vast number of people. It is, of course, hard to say, and would be unfair to try to decide, just where the offense was as between the parties involved.
THREE women started out to be loved.
BOSTON, March 21. -- Secretary James Wilson of the Department of Agriculture lectured before the Twentieth Century Club to-day on "The National Government and Agriculture."

Interest in developing the sport of lawn tennis among women has received more than the usual amount of attention during the past two seasons. It is evident that there is no abatement in the interest this year and that the game will be materially furthered. There was a meeting yesterday afternoon of the Board of Governors of the New York Lawn Tennis Club, at the courts.

NEWBURG, March 21. -- The annual meeting of the Hudson River Golf Association was held here last night at the Palatine Hotel. Eight clubs were represented, and the officers elected for the year are: President -- Richard Deming, Mount Pleasant Golf Club, Ossining; Vice President -- James S. Taylor, Powelton, Newburg; Secretary -- C.F. Cossum, Dutchess County, Pough-keepsie: Treasurer -- Paul B. Rossire, Saegkill Golf Club, Yonkers.

FOUR years ago a young woman lay in a hospital for cripples in the City of New York. This young woman, who is the daughter of people in modest circumstances, and whose name is May Darrach, employed her convalescence in becoming acquainted with the other patients.

The voluminous report of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission contains few surprises as to its specific recommendations. It would not be true to say that it has been "discounted," but for several weeks those in a position to form opinions as to what the commission would recommend have agreed that its report would be substantially what we find it.

ST. PATRICK'S DAY is always a great one at the clubs. Very few men who can be up town ever miss the procession. Irish whisky is much in demand, and there is a general air of jollity which of course extends to the waiters, many of whom are Irishmen. The procession passed the principal fashionable clubs on Tuesday, and the University, the Union, the Metropolitan, and other Fifth Avenue clubs all had many spectators.

In those delightful "Letters of an Act ress" there is a young theatrical manager who writes a comedy of modern are in a manner more simple and veracious than that in vogue. When the play is produced the sole critic to recognize what it was about and what the author intended was a correspondent of a provincial paper.

During the past week nothing occurred outside of Wall Street to cause anxiety to those interested in prices upon the Stock Exchange. The familiar and cheerful monotony of prosperous progress continues unabated, judged by any of the accepted standards. Looking ahead to the factor of greatest importance and least certainty all that can be said is that the crops promise well.

DETROIT, March 21. -- "The decision of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission is on the whole a decided victory for the miners, and I am pleased with it," said President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers of America in an interview to-night.

PARIS, March 21. -- The first really Springlike weather of the year has come to-day. Paris is rapidly putting on her greenest apparel, and will soon be attracting visitors back from the Riviera, where the season is now at its height. Thither William Brice, ex-United States Consul at Bahia, and Mrs. Brice, (nee De Lacy,) have departed, and are at present at Monte Carlo.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the hope that the publicity given by your journal to a condition of things existing around Madison Square at this time of the year may be remedied, I venture to relate my experience.

Consternation was created in several quarters yesterday by information which reached the city from Albany, that Attorney General Cunneen had rendered an opinion to Gov. Odell involving the title to millions of dollars' worth of property now held, or formerly held, by charitable institutions in the City of New York, and also involving indirectly the proposed five-million-dollar terminal improvement of the New York Central Railroad.

There are few among the colleges of New England which have not their established days of special celebration. The average undergraduate, probably, if one should inquire of these things why it was that such and such a day was set apart always for the observance of this rite or of that, would be entirely unable to explain the raison d'etre.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Hamilton Fish, recently appointed Assistant Treasurer of the United States at New York, took the oath of office at the Treasury Depart- ment to-day and will enter upon his new duties next Monday. His bond of $400,000 was approved to-day.
SLOWLY the door opened. In stepped a short, fat man, with curly blonde hair, merry blue eyes, and a smile. The smile was that of a mortal upon whom mortality rests lightly.

For the past thirty or forty years British investors have been withdrawing capital from the Continent, and, excepting in the United States and South America, have not been investing much in countries outside of the British Empire. There was a time when British investors held immense amounts of the bonds and the railway securities of most of the leading countries in Europe -- Russia, Austria, Hungary, Italy, Spain, Portugal, and so on.

THE most peculiar experience in all my professional career," said the Secret Service man, "occurred in a small but ambitious city in Missouri. I do not believe I ever related all the particulars, even to my most intimate friends, and I am sure my official reports failed to relate the story in its entirety.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 21. -- James H. Hyde made a trial trip with the coach Liberty from New York to this resort today for the purpose of breaking in the horses and equipment for the regular coaching service between New York and Lake-wood. which he is to inaugurate on March 31.

Exporters in this city and all over the world who use the cable are interested in the changes in the vocabulary which are likely to be made during the International Telegraph Convention which is to convene in London in May. All the great cable-companies will be represented in the convention, excepting only the Western Union and the Commercial Cable Company, and even these latter two companies will have indirect representation.
BERLIN, March 21. -- Samuel Untermyer of New York, who is here, says that the most striking feature of the business world to-day is the marvelous industrial development and growth of Germany.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21. -- George T. Powell, director of the School of Practical Agriculture and Horticulture, in this city, announced to-day that the institution will be closed and its property sold. This school was started three years ago on an experimental basis, and since that time about $50,000 has been expended in maintaining it.

BUDAPEST, March 21. -- Two students injured during the rioting yesterday evening on the occasion of the celebration of the anniversary of the death of Louis Kossuth died this morning. Many others who were wounded with swords during the police charge are in a serious condition.

Yesterday's market resembled the previous Saturday's in depending upon the bank statement for its motive force. There was nothing doing worth mentioning until it appeared, and then there were differing views of its interpretation. The increase of the reserve was certainly necessary and welcome, but the manner in which it was reached leaves much to be desired.

" inquired Francois Villon when Katherine de Vaucelles had said to him she would sit at home and at her heart out -- a species of meat eating, by the way, which calls for the emphatic protests of every well-regulated vegetarian and every Breakfast Food manufacturer in this land of plenty of cereals.

ALBANY, March 21. -- In the attack which the Committee on Forest of the Board of Trade and Transportation made upon the Lewis Water Storage Commission bill there appeared a statement about the cause of floods and their prevention, with which the advocates of the Lewis proposition are inclined to take issue.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Secretary Hay to-night received a dispatch from Mr. Russell, the United States Charge at Caracas, confirming the report ou President Castro's resignation but stating that he doubted if the Venezuelan Congress would accept it.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 21. -- Spring seems at least a month further advanced here at Lakewood than in the immediate vicinity of New York. Crocuses and violets are abloom in the village, and at Georgian Court the 50,000 or more bulbs which were set out a month ago by Mr. Gould's land-scape gardener have grown amazingly.

One of the largest and most palatial private stables ever built in this country has just been completed at One Hundred and Ninety-sixth Street and Fort Washington Road for C.K.G. Billings, at a cost of about $200,000. The structure was erected especially for Mr. Billings's string of famous matinee and Speedway horses, eight of which took possession of their new quarters yesterday.

BERLIN, March 21. -- Dr. von Holleben, the perman Ambassador, will return to Washington to present to the President his letter of recall, probably not later than May, Minister von Sternburg, according to the Government's intention, succeeding immediately to the Ambassadorship.

THAT protective laws and a stringent system of forest conservation will go a long way toward the preservation and increase of wild game in the United States is shown by the records in the Adirondack public forest preserve, where, notwithstanding the increasing number or hunters and the constant progress in the effectiveness of firearms, deer are on the increase and the elk and moose lately introduced bid fair to multiply.

M. Lagarde's Successor at Addis Ababa. There seems to be no doubt that the FrancoAbyssinian incident, which a fortnight ago threatened to rupture the relations between the Parisian Government and Emperor Menelek, is about to be brought to a close.

THE Habits and Culture of the Black Bass," a paper by Dwight Lydell, which was read at the thirty-first annual meeting of the American Fisheries Society and forms part of the United States Fish Commission Bulletin for 1902, enriches the literature of fresh-water game fishes, and incidentally, that of expert angling.

Rose Cristalli, a leader of the senior class of the Normal College, who confessed to having stolen $1,800 worth of diamonds and jewelry from the home of her schoolgirl chum, Sadie Scheffler, is likely to go free to-day.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 21. -- S.M. Sexton, editor of The United Mine Workers' Journal, in commenting on the Strike Commission's report, to-day said:

AN animated discussion is going on in the London papers in regard to the employment of barmaids in English public houses, and it is said to be likely, as a result of the preponderance of opinion in favor of making such employment illegal, that the Government will be induced to present a measure to Parliament to that effect.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 21. -- The most important railroad fight in the recent history of Connecticut is having an airing before the Joint Judiciary Committee of the State Legislature, which is holding hearings on the proposed repeal of the present general railroad law. All the railroad interests of the State have been represented at the committee sessions, besides scores of outside interests.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21. -- Secretary of the Treasury Shaw was the principal guest at the first annual banquet of the Board of Trade to-night. Charles Janvier presided. Mayor Capdevielle, S. Locke Breaux, J.W. Porch, and President E.A. Alderman of Tulane University responded to toasts.

HAVANA, March 16. -- Cuba has very few women's organizations, in fact. I may say they are practically unknown. There are no cooking clubs -- cooking is not a necessary accomplishment of a Cuban lady. There are no literary clubs -- Cuban ladies are not fond of reading or study, nor do they spend their time thinking up the best policies for the Government to pursue; that is left to the sterner sex.

That Gen. CHAFFEE does not attach much importance to missionary work in the Chinese Empire may be painful to many good people, but it is not at all to be wondered at. His conclusions are those which any practical-minded person must reach who balances against the sacrifice and cost involved in what may be called intrusive missionary effort among peoples which do not want or welcome it the results which can be measured or calculated.

The New Era Club, a Jewish organization, with headquarters at 287 Henry Street has a tentative scheme for the ownership of its clubhouse. The organization has about 400 members, many under twenty-one years of age, all typical east siders and earners of small wages or small salaries. It has existed for four years.

THE poor have hearts as well as stomachs," said the proprietor of a flower stand at Thirty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue the other day. "Most of my patrons, it is true, are of the well-to-do class." he continued, "but quite often I sell flowers to those whose outward appearances are loud in proclaiming them poverty-stricken.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 21. -- The most important railroad fight in the recent history of Connecticut is having an airing before the Joint Judiciary Committee of the State Legislature, which is holding hearings on the proposed repeal of the present general railroad law. All the railroad interests of the State have been represented at the committee sessions, besides scores of outside interests.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21. -- Secretary of the Treasury Shaw was the principal guest at the first annual banquet of the Board of Trade to-night. Charles Janvier presided. Mayor Capdevielle, S. Locke Breaux, J.W. Porch, and President E.A. Alderman of Tulane University responded to toasts.

His conclusions are those which any practical-minded person must reach who balances against the sacrifice and cost involved in what may be called intrusive missionary effort among peoples which do not want or welcome it the results which can be measured or calculated.

VIENNA, March 21. -- Emperor Francis Joseph to-day attended the opening of the thirtieth exhibition of the Vienna Academy of Art. American art was represented by George Hitchcock. Quincy Adams, and Julius L. Stewart.

THE boy sat cuddled so close to the woman in gray that everybody thought sure he belonged to her, so when he unconsciously dug his muddy shoes into the broadcloth skirt of his left-hand neighbor, she leaned over and said: "Pardon me, Madame, will you kindly make your little boy square him-self around? He is soiling my skirt with his muddy shoes."

WITH the close of the operatic season last week ended also for the season the display in public of decolletee gowns. The fashion of wearing low-cut gowns at dinners in public restaurants has never been adopted here, nor is it likely to be. It is not a fashion that appeals to American women.

"WOMAN may possess a keener spiritual insight than man," said the philosopher who is married; "she may be his equal intellectually; in executive ability she may be in no way his inferior, but in one respect she lacks symmetrical mental contour."
To the Editor of The New York Times: The injustice of the present law providing for the taxing of mortgages as personal property is, I think, clearly shown by the following illustration:

After a long search by Detective Casimiro Cicone, on whose life the band of Italian insurance swindlers have collected $10,000 from various insurance companies, has been found alive, but on the point of death, in a little hamlet in a neighboring State, where he was removed by the conspirators after the investigation of the frauds by the District Attorney's office commenced.

PENNINGTON, N.J., March 21. -- Capt. Pearson has had the baseball candidates, thirty in number, practicing out of doors for the past two weeks, and they are showing splendid form. There are more candidates this year than in five years past, and the team gives every prospect of being the best team in that time.

Sixty men at Princeton are out for the track team, with a number of last season's team yet to appear. The men were called out last Monday, and Capt. Horton and Trainer Robinson have spent a hard week getting them in shape. The older candidates who competed in last season's intercollegiates have not turned out, with the exception of John De Witt, the hammer thrower.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been wondering where those eminent statesmen, the Hon. Grover Cleveland of New Jersey, the Hon. Hoke Smith of Georgia, the Hon. Willard Saulsbury of Delaware, and the Hon. E.M. Shepard of Brooklyn get their enthusiasm from when they declare that the return of the Democratic Party to power in 1904 is an assured fact.

IF THE completion of the Panama Canal is accomplished by the United States, many very important lessons can be learned by this country from the experiences of the French during their temporary invasion of the Isthmus. They failed to complete their undertaking, but common sense, if used by their successors in the work, will greatly simplify the obstacles to be encountered.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- Stagnation was complete in this market to-day. The sales aggregated 9,208 shares and $08,100 bonds, and of the twenty-five stocks in which there were dealings the sales in eleven were less than 100 shares. Prices generally were firm, and there was some good buying of Philadelphia Company, Philadelphia Rapid Transit, Philadelphia Company consolidated bonds, and Consolidated Lake Superior preferred.

IN "The Prince of Pilsen," at the Broadway, the central figure is Hans Wagner, a Cincinnati brewer, traveling in Europe with his daughter. Wagner, who during the action of the piece is mistaken for the Prince of Pilsen, is a philosophical individual, with the usual twisted tongue and the stage German's gift of wit.

I HAVE a severe cold," said the man who sat opposite. " It is one of those permeating colds that begin at your bald spot and work downward until they capture your ankle joints; one of the colds that make you feel you are a moral outcast, with no hope of salvation. But I am glad I am its victim, just the same."

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Secretary Root to-day ordered to be made public the report on the new militia law which the War College Board at his request has prepared explaining and commenting upon the various provisions of the law, their proper interpretation and the best means for putting them into operation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For a considerable time past clients of my office have been in the habit of putting out money on bond and mortgage, the aggregate amounting to a large sum, and other clients have persistently avoided thin form of investment, so that I feel a certain right to voice the sentiments of both classes in regard to the proposed bill fixing a nominal tax on mortgages.

IT IS hard to find out what will influence the minds of little children," said the mother of three. "I have had considerable experience in managing the little ones, yet they continue to be full of surprises to me. Men, they say, can never understand women, but certainly neither man nor woman can understand the little folk.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Secretary Root to-day ordered to be made public the report on the new militia law which the War College Board at his request has prepared explaining and commenting upon the various provisions of the law, their proper interpretation and the best means for putting them into operation.

Surrogate Fitzgerald has sustained an appeal in behalf of the executors of the will of John Daniell, the dry goods merchant, who died in March, 1902, and relieved a trust fund established for the benefit of the widow from taxation as far as her interest in it is concerned.

President Haffen of the Borough of the Bronx announced at the last meeting of the Board of Aldermen that he did not intend to allow Tammany Aldermen under the leadership of Timothy P. Sullivan to hold up public Improvement in his district. He also sent word to Charles F. Murphy that unless Congressman Timothy D. Sullivan stopped interference in politics in the Bronx district there would be trouble.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- There is a sharp difference of opinion between the State Department officials and leading Senators and Representatives about the effect of the conflict of dates in the amended Cuban reciprocity treaty. The treaty contains a clause providing that it is to go into effect ten days after ratifications are exchanged, which is to be done some tints before March 31.

SEVERAL handsome paintings have been placed recently on the walls of the cafe at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The man who hung them evidently has a good idea of the eternal fitness of things. Suspended just over the sign of a firm of Wall Street brokers is a picture of a flock of sheep, the thickness of whose fleeces indicates that they are about ready to be shorn.
In a recent issue of the Frankfurter Zeltung, the leading financial daily of Germany, conditions in this country are editorially discussed, as follows:

SPRING flowers in anticipation of Easter appear in profusion in the windows of the florists long before the hardiest plant in the woods or gardens dare raise its head above the earth; but the choicest treasures are held back until Easter week. The florist must be careful of the lilies and azaleas, which are now timed to bloom exactly at the Spring festival of flowers.

AS SO many others did, I knew "Old Howls" in a casual way, as a note broker of the meanest class. He was always untidy, always in a hurry, never anything else but thinly clad, even in the depth of Winter, and carried constantly -- with a loud laugh and painfully forced jollity that had won him his epithet, "Howls" -- a haggard, hunted expression.

It looks as if the Governor were prepared to use all his influence to press to passage the bill he has had devised for the taxation of mortgages. It is extremely unlikely that it will accomplish what he expects from it; it is unjust in principle, and will be unequal in operation, and a year's trial of it is pretty sure to result in its repeal or in its serious modification.

In an address delivered at a negro mass meeting in the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon a colored preacher, the Rev. Dr. R.D. Stinson of Atlanta, rebuked the advocates of higher education for the masses of the black race. He told his audience that 95 per cent, of their fellows were unfitted for such higher training.

VICKSBURG, Miss., March 22. -- Officers of the steamer City of St. Joseph, which reached here this afternoon from Greenville, report a critical state of affairs along the Issaquena County front. The water is almost level with the crown of the levees, and at several points it is topping over.

Down at Coney Island, where most astonishing things are brought to light now and then, the startling discovery was made yesterday that part of a cabin in which, it is claimed, Jefferson Davis, the head of the Confederacy, once lived, had become grafted upon another cabin which is said to be the one in which Abraham Lincoln, the great emancipator, was born.

-- There is more excuse this year than usual for the failure of the Mississippi levees to serve the purpose for which they were erected, since the river has risen above all its recorded high water marks, and yet one cannot help feeling that there is cause for humiliation as well as for sorrow in the too familiar stories of widespread disaster that are now coming from so many parts of the great delta.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, President of Columbia University, delivered an address upon "Training for Usefulness" in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church last night at a meeting held under the auspices of the Young People's Association of the church. Col. John J. McCook presided, and there was a prayer by the Rev. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson, pastor of the church.

Before Mrs. Julia Walker went up in the Bronx to live she thoroughly concurred in President Roosevelt's views relative to increasing the country's population, but since she has been driven -- in some cases almost forcibly -- from various boarding houses in the Bronx on account of the large number of her progeny, she has decided that children have their disadvantages.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- South Africa is proving an important commercial field now that conditions in that part of the world are returning to a normal state. Figures just received by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics show that the imports into Natal in 1902 amounted to u15,000,000, against u10,000,000 in 1901, and those into Cape Colony u34,000,000 in 1902, against u24,000,000 in 1901.
H. Hier Davies, a representative of Sir Thomas Lipton, arrived on the Etruria yesterday and is at the Waldorf-Astoria. Talking with reporters last night, Mr. Davies said:

The Stock Exchange resumes business this week upon conditions more encour-aging than recently, although not unblemished. The improvement of last week is reflected, in the fact that among the 111 stocks which moved so much as a full point 90 advanced. A ratio of four advances to each decline is an unmistakable straw, however unfamiliar in recent experience.

Mr. DE ARMOND of Missouri does not strike us as a sagacious statesman, but rather as one of those Democratic Bourbons who can learn nothing and forget nothing. Mr. SHEPARD frankly said, in his speech at the Jackson banquet in Chicago, that he was opposed to free silver in 1896, that he is opposed to it still, and that he had no apology to make for his position on that subject.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Gen. Wood has made no change in his plans for going to the Philippines on account of the charges filed against him yesterday at the War Department by Erastus G. Rathbone, ex-Director of Posts for Cuba. He did not learn of the charges until about 5 o'clock, and then only accidentally while in the department to see Secretary Root on another matter.

In the chancel floor of Brington Parish Church, five miles northwest of Northampton, carefully preserved, is a stone, with arms, to Laurence Washington (1616) and his wife. Laurence came of a good old stock, (says "Young England".) of which one scion, in 1532, and again in 1545, was elected Mayor of Northampton.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkburst at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday morning preached a sermon on lying in the course of which he rebuked the American people for condoning the ruse practiced by Kunston to capture Aguinaldo. To the newspaper men present he said, after the service:

It is of more than ordinary interest to learn that the wise men of the Faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have undertaken a course of investigations and experiments which it is hoped will enable them to formulate "the law of breakage."

"The Late Abram S. Hewitt" was the subject of an address delivered last evening by John E. Parsons at the Church of the Archangel, One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, of which the Rev. George S. Pratt is rector. In the course of his remarks Mr. Parsons who was a lifelong friend of Mr. Hewitt, said:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 22. -- New Jersey Methodists "Held the Fort" today in Asbury Park and Ocean Grove, and, despite the storm, the several meetings under the auspices of the Annual Conference, now in session here were well attended and religious enthusiasm was at fever heat all day.

An experienced lawyer the other day remarked that there was scarcely a week passed that cases substantially like the following did not come to his knowledge: A business man applies to counsel for advice as to a contract which the other party to it refuses to carry out, to the great risk and loss, and possible bankruptcy, of the applicant.
MONTEVIDEO, March 22. -- Peace was signed to-day between the Uruguayan Government and the rebels.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 22. -- Preparations are now going on for the launching of the Reliance, which, it is now believed, will take place during Easter week. Many Bristol people have already engaged boats so that they might witness the launching from the harbor front, and many members of the New York Yacht Club will be present on their yachts

One of those incidents which almost everybody has read about but which really seldom occur in the theatres provided added amusement for the audience at the Madison Square Theatre Saturday afternoon during the last act of "Cynthia."
CARACAS, March 22. -- The Venezuelan Congress, by a unanimous vote, has declined to accept President Castro's resignation, and has passed a resolution requesting him to reconsider his decision.

The corpse of a monkey was washed ashore at Governors Island yesterday, and for a while curiosity was rife about it. The monkey arrived in the steamship Alene on Tuesday in company with others at the pier of the United Fruit Company at the Battery. It escaped from its crate and tried to leap from the rail to the string piece.

The delegates to the Central Federated Union were in a state of excitement yesterday on account of the appearance of District Attorney Jerome, who had promised to talk to them on labor leaders and other matters. The meeting was begun at 2:30 P.M., but long before that time delegates began to enter the University Settlement building, Rivington and Eldridge Streets, where the central body meets.

An early golf season seems to be the indication this year. The long-continued mild weather has been of great service in getting many local links in good playing shape much earlier than usual, and in several instances golf committees have arranged competitive matches two or three weeks ahead of the customary time.

GREENWICH, CONN., March 22. -- By sounding his gong continuously as his car sped along a distance of two miles to Greenwich village, a quick witted motorman gave a fire alarm last night shortly before midnight.

BOSTON, March 22. -- Arioch Wentworth, who died in this city last Thursday, left the bulk of his property, estimated to be worth $7,000,000, to be applied to the foundation and maintenance of an industrial school in Boston. The will without doubt will be protested, as it practically cuts off his married daughter, Mrs. Willoughby Stuart, wife of the British ex-Consul in this city, who got into financial difficulties a few years ago.
Capt. Miles O'Reilly's attitude in opposing public euchre parties was the subject of much discussion in Brooklyn yesterday.

Letters of St. Petersburg correspondents in Paris papers give a most glowing account of the costume festival which took place at the Russian Court on Shrove Tuesday. The affair was arranged at the special request of the Czarina, and the scene of the fete was the grand reception room of the Hermitage adjoining the Winter Palace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the article "Advice to New England," as per issue of your paper on the 19th inst., Mr. Vanderlip closes his speech with a remark that so nearly coincides with an article of my own some years since which appeared in The Pittsburg Dispatch about the time of the first meeting of Pan-American delegates in this country, that I would like to call attention to the fact.

LONDON, March 23. -- In regard to the four points on which reforms are most required in Russia -- education, local government, peasants' rights, and finance -- the St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times says the Czar's manifesto is almost valueless. The only useful concessions, he declares, are those abolishing the peasants' collective responsibility for taxation and permitting them to sever themselves from the communes.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- There is a wide difference of opinion between Assistant Commissioner Davenport of the Pension Bureau and Assistant Attorney General Campbell of the Interior Department in regard to the amount that will be disbursed under a pension act passed in 1890 and a point resolution passed July 1, 1902, supplemental thereto.

During the last twelve months a great deal of the old time interest in the game of handball has been revived, and the professional championship contest which, began Saturday between Mike Egan of Jersey City and Louis Keegan of Chicago is the outcome. There is no world's professional or amateur handball champion now.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It Is a matter of regret that THE TIMES, which generally is so reliably in its presentation of facts, should have fallen or allowed itself to have been led into the taking of an editorial position on an important question which the facts do not warrant.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The friends of Miss Clara Barton, President of the Red Cross Society, deny that she will retire or be forced out. The opposing faction, however, has been very busy during the past week trying to devise some way of getting her out, and from this has arisen the impression that her retirement was sure to come.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Every indication seems to justify the expectation that next week will be the most important of the present legislative session. All of the big measures have now been introduced, and probably will appear in some stage of their advancement during the week, in accordance with the definite course mapped out by Gov. Odell and the Republican leaders in both houses.

BUFFALO, March 22. -- The inquest into the death of Edwin L. Burdick will be resumed in judge Murphy's court to-morrow afternoon at 2 o'clock. The first witness will likely be George C. Miller, who was attorney for Burdick and in whose office Burdick and A.R. Pennell met for a conference several weeks before Burdick's murder.

The burden of Police Commissioner Greene's talk with newspaper men last night, in the absence of more exciting, topics, was on the Sunday "sacred concert" issue, which has proved something of a stumbling block for the Police Department through the failure of Magistrates to hold persons arrested for alleged violations of the law governing these performances.

WEST POINT, March 22. -- The ninth annual indoor meet of the corps of cadets, under the auspices of the Army Officers' Athletic Association, came off in the gymnasium last night, and was not finished until after midnight. The results were as follows:

Ex-Water Register Columbus O. Johnson, who was sent abroad last August by the Merchants' Association to investigate the water systems in various European cities with reference to the distribution of water, detection and prevention of waste, and the system of accounts in use, has returned, and his report is now in the hands of the association.

All allegations of conduct unbecoming a gentleman in his professional relations with Crown Princess Louise of Saxony were flatly denied by Dr. Lewis A. O'Brian, the American dentist, who, after living in Dresden thirteen years, arrived yesterday morning era the steamship Pretoria of the Hamburg-American Line.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As there is a misapprehension as to the origin, objects, and scope of the bill now before the Legislature abolishing the office of Coroner in this city, the following statement is submitted:

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Capt. Eugene T. Wilson of the Artillery Corps, who is in command of the garrison at Fort Liscum. Alaska has made an adverse report on the abolition of the canteen. "The present regime," writes Capt. Wilson, "is an era or blind drunks anil pint bottles in garrison.

We learn from The Tribune's London correspondent, who is not apt to forward news discouraging to protectionists, that there is a good deal of difficulty in inducing British firms to exhibit at St. Louis.

Mayor Low made public yesterday two letters on the excise question. One, expected on Saturday, was in reply to George F. Gminder, Chairman of the committee named by Fritz Lindinger, President of the Wine, Liquor and Beer Dealers' Central Association, to wait on the Mayor last Thursday.

"The Lover of the Shepherdess," a modern Greek drama, was given by a company of Athenians in the Grand Central Palace last night to an assemblage of their countrymen which filled the floor of the auditorium. The audience enjoyed it mightily, if frequent applause was any indication, but seemed to take the supposedly tragic situations as a kind of joke.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23.--United States Treasury officials seized 250 bales of French scoured wool to-day, which was consigned to C. Shillard Smith Co. of 16 Letitia Street, by a New York importer named Gobrel. The seizure, it is said, may lead to the exposure of a scheme to defraud the Government.

Jefferson M. Levy has sold the five-story buildings at the northwest corner of Church and Liberty Streets, on plot 35 by 100. Whether this transaction has any connection with the latest North River tunnel project could not be learned yesterday either from Mr. Levy or the brokers in the deal, Horace S. Ely Co.

The boys of Public School No. 15. "the old Fifth Street School," took an affecting farewell of the old building yesterday and marched to the recreation pier at the foot of Third Street, where temporary accommodations have been provided. Many graduates of the school who are prominent in business and public life, some of them from distant States, were present, and others sent letters expressing regret because of their inability to attend the exercises.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of to-day, entitled "Gen. Chaffee on Missionaries," you very rightly state that it is difficult to compare conclusions arrived at by those who believe in missionary work and those who do not, because they view the whole matter from standpoints which are as wide apart as the poles.
"We'll break the six-trip run scheme or break the Manhattan Elevated Railroad."

With so many things in china made these days with silver settings, the Kayserzinn has followed suit. There are liqueur sets, with bottles and glasses that have settings of the metal. Other wine glasses have metal stems and bases also, and a pretty tea set has the cups, sugar bowl, creamer, and teapot in ornamental openwork cases of the metal.

ALBANY, March 23 -- A bill has been prepared to carry into effect the recommendations of the Superintendent of State Prisons with reference to professional and incorrigible criminals. It will provide that when any felon comes up for sentence for the fourth time, he shall be sentenced for life as incorrigible.

The new Real Estate Association of New York, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the offices of the Knickerbocker Trust Company, adopted unanimously the report presented by its Committee on Legislation, which was in substance a severe condemnation of the Mortgage Tax bill now pending in the Legislature.

"Pretty Peggy" had gone through three acts and a half last night at the Herald Square, and nothing doing, when all of a sudden something happened that made the audience sit up in their seats. At that moment, Dumas pere stirred in his grave and dreamed again of his "Kean." Charles Coghlan among the shades may have forgotten Dumas pere, but he remembered "The Royal Box."

-- Despite the fact that Dr. PARKHURST thought the newspapers would find nothing in his sermon of Sunday last to comment upon except its denunciation of the way in which Gen. FUNSTON captured AGUINALDO, we do not feel at all inclined to take up again that thoroughly and utterly academic problem, while we do feel impelled to question the doctor's assertion that the wide prevalence of lying is explained by its "exceeding utility."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Capt. James Fitzgibbon, for many years a trusted employe of the United States Treasury, was Brought here to-day from North Adams, Mass., where he was apprehended after his recent escape from St. Elizabeth's Asylum for the Insane.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 23 -- The New Jersey Methodist Conference came to an end to-night at the close of the anniversary service of the Centenary Fund and Preachers' Aid Society, presided over by the Rev. Dr. J.W. Marshall of Pennington. The conference appointments were made early in the evening, and they caused the usual disappointments.

A board of medical officers, to consist of Major William C. Borden and Capts. Henry A. Shaw and Frederick P. Reynolds, is appointed to meet at the United States General Hospital. Washington Barracks, for the physical re-examination of Fitzhugh B. Alderdice, with view to his appointment as Second Lieutenant.
LONDON, March 23 -- Supplies-of money were not abundant to-day; there was a good demand for loans and rates were firm. Discounts were easier.

An agreement has been reached between Senator W.A. Clark and the Union Pacific by which a settlement has been provided for the various legal differences which have been keeping the western courts busy, differences regarding the rights of way of the San Pedro, Los Angeles, and Salt Lake Railroad Company, the new road from Los Angeles to Utah of which Senator Clark is President.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Assemblyman Bostwick introduced to-night a bill to provide for the erection of a Court House in New York County. It was prepared by a special committee of the New York City Bar Association, after consultation with Justices of the Supreme Court and the Mayor, Controller, and Corporation Counsel of the city.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Spring racing season at Bennings was opened here to-day under most unfavorable weather conditions, but with a good-sized crowd in attendance. The rain which has fallen for the past three days continued up to the moment of starting the first race. It then cleared up, making things more comfortable for the spectators.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 23 -- "A weak and sentimental jury has made the public proclamation that murder committed by a woman is no crime in this country."

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 --James Potter, President of the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club, has written a letter to President Pulliam of the League, indorsing the action taken by the latter with reference to Players Delehanty and Davis. President Potter says:

The gas meter has a reputation for being what Mark Twain once described as "a picturesque, ariegated, and industrious liar." In consequence of this reputation the average householder believes that whenever his gas bill increases the meter in his cellar has been "racing," and that it has recorded two feet, more or less, for each foot actually passed.

HOLYOKE, Mass., March 23 -- Because of the attitude of organized labor the William Skinner Silk Company to-day abandoned the project and canceled the contract for the erection of a one-hundred-and-twenty-five-thousand-dollar mill building, which would have furnished employment to several hundred hands.

A baseball league of Settlement House teams will be organized this season, and it is expected that fully a dozen of the houses that are members of the Association of Neighborhood Workers will be represented. The scheme was tried last year for the first time, and ten teams were in the league.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- It has been learned that Secretary Shaw of the Treasury recently suggested to Postmaster General Payne that Capt. N.M. Brooks, Superintendent of Foreign Mails, should be discharged from the public service because of allegations made by that official in November last against the conduct of certain customs officers at New York.

Notwithstanding the fact that she married Louis Herzog against the wishes of her father and was cut out of a large portion of the estate of the late James Jennings McComb for so doing, Mrs. Fannie Rayne McComb Herzog will not suffer the loss of one cent, under a decision made public yesterday by Justice Truax, sitting in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--The monthly statement of the collections of internal revenue show that for February the total receipts were $16,250,409, a loss of $2,467,250 as compared with February, 1902. Receipts from the several sources are given as follows:

ALBANY, March 23 -- Another attack on the so-called "fire insurance trust" was made in the Senate to-night, when Senator Brackett introduced a resolution calling on Attorney General John Cunneen to submit his opinion as to what legislation will stop the practice of insurance companies combining to raise and establish artificial rates.

ALBANY, March 23 -- When the Goodsell Railroad "Grab" bill was reached on the order of third reading in the Senate to-night Senator Goodsell asked that it be recommitted to the Committee on Railroads for amendment. The request was granted.

Several interesting events, including three open century runs, have been arranged by the Century Road Club of America, New York State Division. The regular Spring run will be held in May; then there will be a Summer moonlight and double run, with possibly a triple century division in connection with them, and a Fall run.

BUFFALO, March 23 -- Mrs. Alice Hull Burdick, widow of Edwin L. Burdick, underwent a relentless examination by District Attorney Coatsworth this afternoon at the resumption of the inquest into the death or her husband, who was murdered Feb. 26. Mrs. Burdick was on the stand when court adjourned, until 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.

Luther G. Gadd, the former head of the defunct Republic Savings and Loan Association of Newark, now in the hands of a receiver, still is in default of his alimony tine to Mrs. Gadd No. 1, notwithstanding the admitted fact that for years he was in receipt of an income of $35,000 annually from the corporation.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 23 -- Charles Pfizer of New York has rented for the coming season the Marquand villa, Linden Gate, on Rhode Island Avenue. He occupied it last Summer.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- There is somewhat of a stir in Congressional circles over the determination of the Tax Department of the District of Columbia to make Senators and Representatives pay on personal property.

Deputy Commissioner Ebstein, at Police Headquarters yesterday morning, resumed the trial in the case of Inspector Cross. Nine witnesses were called for the prosecution, all of these except two, being women, who testified to the existence of disorderly houses in the First Inspection, or "Red Light," District.

The week promises very little in society. People are coming back slowly from Palm Beach and the Southern resorts. Many will sail direct for Europe. Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly and the Misses Twombly are due to-day, and so is Miss Kittie Cameron. Yesterday there were the usual meetings of sewing classes, and a lecture was delivered by Prof. Edouard Lance in the residence of Mrs. Charles De Rham.

LONDON, March 24 -- The correspondent of The Daily Chronicle at Geneva learns on reliable authority that the ex-Crown Princess of Saxony is lying seriously ill in her mother's chateau at Lindau, (on an island in Lake Constance), from the effects of an attempt to commit suicide by taking poison.

There's little use in wasting words over yesterday's Stock Exchange business. It was the dullest day of 1903, with one exception, so far as trading went, and probably also regarding news. Something more was said about the Rock Island affair, which must now be spoken of in the pluperfect tense, since it was completed long ago.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The President's coming trip to the West intensified the rivalry between the towns of Seattle and Tacoma, Washington, and threatened for a time to have a serious effect on Senator Foster's political career. It has taken the diplomacy of a Richelieu for the Senator to extricate himself from the trouble and arrange a compromise.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Senator Raines to-night introduced a new revenue measure, which it is estimated will raise a huge amount. Senator Raines says himself that he doesn't know how much it will raise, and the estimates of the experts vary widely, one going even to $100,000,000.

Wood pulp made from timber grown on the Crown lands of Quebec Province must pay a much heavier duty than that imported from Ontario, according to a decision rendered yesterday by the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers in a case which has attracted wide attention from the paper and publishing trades and from foresters.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -- Trading was almost at a standstill to-day, with prices heavy and lower, although the declines were fractional throughout, the sole exception being Philadelphia Company, which went off a point on the company's February statement of earnings. This showed a total available income of $508,805, against $614,091 last February, and a surplus applicable to common stock of $409,113, compares with $524,507 a year ago.

An inter-city bowling association, comprising teams representing Manhattan, Brooklyn, Newark, and Philadelphia, respectively, was organized under the name of the Eastern Bowling League at a meeting of bowlers from the four cities mentioned, held at Ehler's Fulton Palace alleys, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Assemblyman Clark will to-morrow introduce an excise bill for which the Citizens' Union stands sponsor. It was in connection with this measure that R. Fulton Cutting had an interview with Gov. Odell several weeks ago.

Fire at 3 o'clock yesterday morning in the saloon of Edward Martin, at 119 Harrison Avenue, Williamsburg, imperiled the lives of several families. Martin was arrested on a charge of arson, and his bartender, Edward Brown, was held on a charge of vagrancy.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Senator Raines announced to-night in the Senate that the Excise bill would be taken up by the Senate Wednesday. The intention is to jam it through under a suspension of the rules.
ALBANY, March 24 -- "Has Senator Platt withdrawn his support from the Governor so far as his tax programme is concerned?" That is the question which is being asked in the inner circles here to-night
AUSTIN, Texas, March 24 -- The Legislature to-day passed finally the 'Frisco and Santa Fe Railroad Consolidation bills, and they went to the Governor for his approval.

Impressionists filled the American Art Galleries, on South Madison Square, last night on the occasion of the sale at auction of the paintings of the late John H. Twachtman. There were so many art students present that many of the would-be buyers were crowded out, and it became necessary to clear and reserve a part of the front rows for persons who are known to have the habit of bidding.

C.S. Titus of the Atalanta Boat Club, champion sculler of the United States, whose entry for the Diamond Sculls at the coming Henley regatta was indorsed by the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen at their meeting in this city on last Saturday evening, will not rest content with the approval of that organization and of his club in regard to his fitness to compete for the "blue ribbon" of the rowing world.
According to dispatches from the West the Chicago and Milwaukee Electric Company has increased its capital stock by $4,700,000 for equipment and better service.

HAVANA, March 24 -- The message of President Palma regarding the amended reciprocity treaty was read in the Senate to-day. The President considers that the amendments made by the United States Senate should be adopted, and refers the matter to the consideration of the Cuban Senate.

An interesting illustration of the high development of wireless telegraphy in ship equipment and its practicability in sea searching reaches this office in a private letter from a passenger on the Atlantic Transport liner Minnetonka, which sailed from New York Feb. 28. That vessel and the Cunarder Etruria were scheduled to sail with the same tide, but the morning was foggy and neither got off on time.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 24 -- A cable from London says Mr. Brodrick's statement in the House of Commons to-day in reply to Alfred Davies shows that the War Office still excludes Canadian beef from army contracts. The beef must be English or Irish grown, not frozen or chilled, and not from animals killed at Deptford or elsewhere within ten days of arrival from abroad.

TRENTON, N.J.; March 24 -- The attempt of the Trenton Lawrenceville and Princeton Railway Company, a Johnson line, to lay a crossing over the track of the Trenton Passenger Railway Company at Pennington Avenue and Willow Street to-night resulted in calling out all the police reserves and a crowd of 2,000 persons to see the fight.

One of the most serviceable waists for Summer wear, when something is desired that must do duty for many purposes, is a crepe de chine. In itself this material will wash like a piece of cotton cloth. In a well-made and lined bodice this is not a desirable form of cleaning, though in the latter days of such waists they have been tubbed with great success.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 24 -- Charges of the most serious nature have been brought against Major Gen. Sir Hector Macdonald, commanding the British forces in Ceylon, in consequence of which the Governor of that island, Sir Joseph West Ridgeway. has been authorized to convene a courtmartial to try Gen. Macdonald.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 24 -- Mrs. George F. Stone of this city has been made defendant for the third time in a suit for damages by William D. Marvel, who wants to recover $3,000,000 from the estate of George F. Stone, who died in Morristown in January, 1895.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., March 24 -- Coal operators, miners, laboring men, professional men, bankers, and business men to the number of more than 2,000 gathered here to-day to listen to an open-air address by President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers on the subject of strikes.

NEWARK, N.J., March 24 -- Bad blood of long standing resulted in a scene between Dr. Herold, head of the Department of Health; Dr. Worl, one of the department's doctors; Dr. Robert C. Ribbans, a private practitioner, of 63 Central Avenue, and a trained nurse, in a house of death at 102 Fourth Street on Sunday, according to stories which became public here today, and there are rumors of coming prosecutions.

No trace of George Bossut, the trusted French butler who disappeared on Saturday with thousands of dollars worth of jewels belonging to Mrs. Alfred Nathan of 36 East Seventy-second Street, had been discovered by the police up to last night. Neither had any of the gems or pawn tickets for them been found.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt has displaced Samuel H.
