Vick, the negro Postmaster at Wilson, N.C., as it was announced he would in the New York Times of Feb. 17, and has given the office to B.T. Person, who was formerly a Populist member of the Legislature and is now a "Lily White" Republican.

LONDON, March 24 -- The announcement from Colombo that Major Gen. Macdonald is to be tried by court-martial on most serious charges of immoral Conduct will undoubtedly prove to be the greatest sensation in British military circles since the case of Col. Valentine Baker, who was sentenced Aug. 2, 1873, to pay a fine of $2,500 and to undergo twelve months' imprisonment for indecently assaulting a lady in a railroad carriage.

-- A good deal of decidedly tiresome nonsense has been printed of late in regard to the acquisition in California by a lumber company of a tract of land containing several thousand of the trees popularly known as "big," the intention of the company, of course, being to transform the trees into lumber with all convenient speed.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary Root to-day received a cablegram from Gov. Taft giving the following account of the attack at Surigao:

Mr. CASSATT, in his examination before the commission inquiring into the Pennsylvania tunnels yesterday set at rest the notion that the tunnels were to be used for freight, which has seemed something of a bugbear to the opponents of the project.

Mrs. William G. Mulligan, a lawyer, and the only woman member of the Real Estate Exchange, last night had an altercation with John J. Cox, who keeps a saloon at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street, and received a cut in the palm of the left hand. She says that Cox used a knife, but that he denies.

The circumstances in which honest men come by their dues, according to the old saw, seem to have arisen in St. Louis, where a former Collector of Internal Revenue, his Deputy, and another person have pleaded guilty to collecting political assessments from Federal employes and been fined from $250 to $500 each.

For some thirteen years the case of Mrs. FLORENCE MAYBRICK, imprisoned for life under commutation of a death sentence, has been a subject of intermittent interest on both sides of the Atlantic. The efforts made for her release by those who believed her the victim of a miscarriage of justice have been strenuous.

There was some increase of business upon the Stock Exchange yesterday, but no improvement in tone. Upon the contrary, not a single active stock improved upon the day's dealings, and over thirty declined a point or more. There was no special or adequate news to account for this unusually consistent movement.

The melancholy and in some respects revolting disclosures being brought out in the "inquest" on the murder in Buffalo must strike many readers as futile for the ends of justice. It is true that they bear on the motives suspected for the murder, and the facts to which they relate should be carefully investigated.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 24 -- Twelve natives were Killed and sixty wounded, many of them non-combatants and women, during yesterday's rioting. The Government building was entirely destroyed by the rioters, and the police barracks were damaged by fire and water. All the Government records in the Colonial Secretary's office, the Court House, the Crown Lands' and other departments were destroyed.

In response to an invitation from the Radical Democracy to attend a discussion to-night by Henry George, Charles F. Adams, R.V. Ingersoll, and A.J. Boulton on "The Dangerous Tendencies of Judicial Usurpation," with special reference to the Wabash and Waterbury injunctions, John Brooks Leavitt sent the following reply to M.J. Flaherty, President of the organization, yesterday:

LONDON, March 25 -- The Times in an editorial commenting on the resignation of President Castro of Venezuela, says that whatever be the motives, it is manifest that the event cannot in any way affect Venezuela's international obligations. Americans know the Venezuelans better than the English, says The Times, but even the Americans seem a good deal puzzled regarding the true inwardness of this remarkable message.
RAHWAY, N.J., March 24 -- Six hundred men employed by the Wheeler Condenser Works, at Carteret, are on strike, and the trouble threatens to spread to the other manufacturing interests there.

In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the Sylvan bowlers of Brooklyn won two of three games with the Metropolitan team of Manhattan. The Friendship Boat Club bowlers, won their thirteenth and fourteenth consecutive games in the Harlem Navy League series. The scores follow:

ALBANY, March 24 -- From the upper story of a house on flooded Montgomery's Island a rescuing party at noon to-day took a mother and eight children and the body of the husband and father, who died at 8 o'clock last night. The children were crying for food when the party arrived, and the wife was almost prostrated by the death of her husband.

Yesterday's market was weak from beginning to end, although it was not until the last half hour of business that the selling movement took on proportions at all significant or suggestive. Up to that time the market had merely dragged along, sagging apparently more under its own weight than from any aggressive selling.
NEWPORT, March 24 -- Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt left for New York this afternoon accompanied by William F. Whitehouse, Jr., who has been their guest at Oakland Farm.

Yesterday was one of music. The events included the muslcale at the Gerrit Smith studio. Miss Leila, Livingston Morse's recital, and some smaller affairs, including always Miss Leary's Tuesdays. Mrs. John Jacob Astor entertained at dinner. There will be a large representation from society this evening at Carnegie Hall for the Von Gaertner recital.
ALBANY, March 24 -- By a vote of 32 to 14 the Senate to-day passes the DavisBostwick $101,000,000 Canal bill after one of the hardest fights which has been witnessed in the Legislature in many years.

It is difficult to understand why the representatives of the people of Connecticut should be prepared to consider for a moment the repeal of the existing general railroad law of that State -- unless, indeed, they are willing to have it understood that they are actuated by corrupt motives supplied from the treasuries of the railroads now owning and operating lines in that State.

Major William Stephenson, Surgeon, is relieved from duty at Monterey, Cal., and will proceed to the Precidio of San Francisco, to relieve Lieut. Col. Henry S. Kilbourne, Deputy Surgeon General, who is assigned for duty as chief Surgeon of that department.

The officials of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company have decided to change the night elevated service over the bridge. Instead of using the through trains for both local and long-distance service as at present, a separate system of trains for bridge traffic solely will be installed, and through trains will be sent through to the Brooklyn terminal without stop.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Italian Ambassador and Signora Mayor des Planches had as guests at dinner to-night the Peruvian Minister and Mme. Calderon, Mr. and Mrs. Cabot Ward, ex-Senator and Mrs. John B. Henderson, Mrs. Richard Wallach. Miss Cynn, Miss Stevens, Commander Schafer, Jesse Brown, and Signor Borghetti of the Italian Embassy.

Entries for the twelfth annual horse show of the Durland Company, to be held at the Academy, in West Sixty-sixth Street, on the evenings of April 7, 8, and 9, will close on Saturday evening. All of the prizes this year will be in money, and some $3,000 will be distributed. Heretofore the prizes have been in plate.

CANTON, Mass., March 24 -- At a meeting of the stockholders of the Neponset National Bank of Canton to-day it was voted to reduce the capital of the bank from $250,000 to $100,000, and to distribute $30,000 among the stockholders pro rata.

LONDON, March 24 -- Consols touched 90 3/8 this afternoon, the lowest point on record since the Franco-Prussian war. The fall is attributed to the continued dearness of money and the forthcoming Transvaal loan of $150,000,000. Daily conferences regarding the loan are being held between Chancellor of the Exchequer Ritchie and leading financiers.

There was much conjecture yesterday in Wall Street regarding the latest development in the Southern Pacific fight, which consisted of the advertisement signed by Col. Asa Bird Gardiner asking dissatisfied participants of the Keene pool to confer with him. The Street believed that somebody was back of Col. Gardiner, but they could not decide who that somebody was. Col. Gardiner declined to enlighten the guessers in the least.

The city's lighting problem was discussed last night by Col. Monroe. Commissioner of Water Supply. Gas and Electricity, before large audience in Sulzer's Harlem River asino. Col. Monroe declared most emhatically that there never had been a time as opportune as the present for the estabtlishment of a municipal lighting plant, and appealed to his hearers to exercise every legitimate influence to bring about the necessary legislation.

The Trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine held their regular meeting yesterday in the office of Bishop Potter, 113 West Fortieth Street. There were present besides the Bishop, the Rev. Dr. Huntington, the Rev. Dr. Caldi, the Rev. Dr. Grosvenor, August Belmont. Prof. W.H. Burr, Robert Roosevelt, and George Macculloch Miller.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Notwithing the fact that only a fair card was offered at the second day's racing of the Bennings Spring meeting, a good-sized crcwd was present, better weather materially increasing the attendance. The track, which was a sea of mud yesterday, had dried out considerably and was in fair condition, although very heavy.
BUFFALO, March 24 -- "Have you received any information as to who killed your husband? "

The hearing on the summons issued by William N. Amory, requiring Herbert H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company, to appear and show cause why he should not be prosecuted for criminal libel was opened yesterday afternoon in the private examination room of the Centre Street Police Court before Magistrate Barlow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It hardly seems possible that the hideous rumor we have heard from time to time is now to become a still more hideous fact, and the giant trees of California are to be destroyed by a corporation of lumbermen! The very thought is enough to make one's blood boil, or one's heart ache.

What did we say, apropos of "Pretty Peggy," was the stock in trade of the historical dramatist? "Burth and Flim-flam" the compositor got it. Can it be that the word "bustle" offended the sensibilities of the type-setting machine? But bustle is the word for plays like "Pretty Peggy" in more senses perhaps than was intended.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Police Commissioner Greene of New York City came to Albany to-day to appear before the Senate Committee on Cities and answer any questions wnich members of the committee might desire to ask him with regard to the proposed three-platoon system for the police force.

The Mayor, we think, has only himself to blame if his omission to tell the representatives of the Liquor Dealers' Association what he thought of the measure pending at Albany for higher license was imputed to a hesitation to committing himself on that subject. However that may be, his letter to Mr. FUEHRER supplies the omission and gives reasons for the Mayor's position in a manner as frank as it is interesting.

BOSTON, March 24 -- "Hiawatha," the Indian play which has been running at the Mechanics' Building, was closed to-day because of the disappearance Sunday of Capt. J.H.A. Dressel, who was managing it. He left 75 New York musicians and singers and 175 Ojibway Indians from Canada behind.

Guerino Cicone, for whom detectives have long been searching in connection with the frauds perpetrated on a number of insurance companies by a gang of Italians in "Little Italy," was arrested yesterday by Detective Sergeant Petrosino and arraigned before Magistrate Pool in the Tombs Police Court, who held him in $2,500 bail for examination.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Senator William J. Stone of Missouri, who has always been regarded as one of the leading Bryan men in the country, was asked to-night what he thought of the recent talk to the effect that the regular Democrats were insisting on too many concessions from Gold Democrats who wanted to come back into the party.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 24 -- Because many of his parishioners have taken offense at his utterances on immigrants and on Catholics, the Rev. Jacob A. Biddle, for ten years rector of St. Mary's Church in South Manchester and prominent in this diocese, announced to-day that he would resign at Easter.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision directing the reinstatement of Patrick Fay, William Colby, and William J. Lahey as Detective Sergeants in the New York City Police Department and the retirement of Fay on a pension of $1,000 per year.

Interesting developments cropped out yesterday in the fight which the Liquor Dealers' Association is waging against Mayor Low because of his refusal to meet their representatives in view of reports that the dealers pay blackmail to the police.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 24 -- Because many of his parishioners have taken offense at his utterances on immigrants and on Catholics, the Rev. Jacob A. Biddle, for ten years rector of St. Mary's Church in South Manchester and prominent in this diocese, announced to-day that he would resign at Easter.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision directing the reinstatement of Patrick Fay, William Colby, and William J. Lahey as Detective Sergeants in the New York City Police Department and the retirement of Fay on a pension of $1,000 per year.

Button's jump shots were again a feature of the match billiard contest which the handless player is playing with Thomas J. Gallagher at Maurice Daly's academy, Broadway and Thirty-first Street, the fifth and sixth games in the series being played yesterday afternoon and evening.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The joint Senate and Assembly Judiciary Committees gave a hearing this afternoon on the Administration Mortgage Tax bill. While it was scheduled to be a joint one, Senators who were members of the Judiciary Committee could only attend at intervals, because of the session on the Excise bill.
LONDON, March 26. -- The Chief Secretary for Ireland, the Right Hon. George Wyndham, introduced the Government's long-anticipated Irish Land bill in the House of Commons yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, March 25. -- The money market is quiet and steady. Call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@ 6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10@8c discount. Clearings, $20,146,432; balances, $817,381. The foreign exchange market is easier.

PARIS, March 25. -- Major Gen. Sir Hector Archibald Macdonald, commanding the British forces in Ceylon and one of the foremost officers in the British Army, against whom charges based on alleged immoral acts were filed some time ago, committed suicide to-day at the Hotel Regina, here. He shot himself in the right temple shortly after noon, and expired a few minutes later.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- There is considerable friction among the several divisions of the Post Office Department which may require a number of changes to be made among the higher officials before the consequent demoralization shall be removed. In the Law Department a scandal is threatened in connection with the rulings on the get-rich-quick schemes, and while the, head of the division.

William N. Amory, as on the first day of the proceedings, was the only witness examined in the action begun by him against H.H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, for libel, when the hearing on the case was resumed yesterday afternoon before Magistrate Barlow in the private examination room of the Centre Street Police Court.

How much of the tendency in the direction of "race suicide" is the natural and inevitable outgrowth of our inclination as a people to live in multiple apartment dwellings when opportunity to do so offers is an interesting subject for speculation. Theoretically, and under certain conditions, practically life in apartments is "ideal."

ALBANY, March 25. -- There was a hearing to-day before the Assembly Railroads Committee on the bill introduced by Assemblyman Finch at the instance of the Merchants, Association of New York City, amending the railroad law so as to permit of the addition to the Railroad Commission of two members from the city, to have charge of the transportation problems there.

The O.B. Potter Trust has bought, through M. L. Hess, from Catherine W. Loney, 740 and 742 Broadway, two fivestory buildings, on plot 50 by 116, adjoining the southeast corner of Astor Place. The purchaser secures by this transaction a Broadway outlet for a large plot at the southwest corner of Lafayette and Astor Places, already owned by it.

Last Fall when we pointed out the tricky nature of the Republican platform as to the canals some of our friends thought that we were much too suspicious, and asked us indignantly if we expected to catch political flies with such sour vinegar. The proceedings of the Senate on Tuesday must give our friends a certain pause.

LONDON, March 26. -- The chief feature of the transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the continued selling of consols, which showed a further sharp fall. During the morning consols fell to 90, and even a shade below that figure. There was practically no home support, but the Continent kept buying small lots.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The revision of the civil service rules codifies the rulings that have been made from time to time for the past twenty years and systematizes the scheme of the Government service. The first rules placed 14,000 places under the aegis of civil service. Later rules added 110,000 places, and now several thousand more are brought in.

In the Autumn of last year the Merchants' Association of New York engaged Mr. C.O. JOHNSON, formerly Water Registrar of this city, to go abroad and study the water systems of the principal cities of Europe, for the information of our people. A synopsis of Mr. JOHNSON'S report has just been published by the Merchants' Association, and it is of the greatest interest and value to every student of this most important of municipal problems.

-- A correspondent of Harper's Weekly, writing from somewhere out in darkest Indiana, declares, as the result of observations made during thirty years of association with school and library work, that "the children who devote their early years to useful studies are the men and women who are filling useful and honored places in life, while those who read fairy tales are still expecting the impossible."
CHICAGO, March 25. -- New York exchange was at par to-day. Time and call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.

ALBANY, March 25. -- While interest at the Capitol to-day centred in the fight over the Excise bill, the canal improvement question came up in both houses. In the Assembly there was a sharp skirmish over the $101,000,000 Improvement bill, and in the Senate the Lewis resolution looking to Federal co-operation in improving the canals was finally killed.
Discussing the condition of the iron and metal trades The Iron Age will to-day say:

ALBANY, March 25. -- Aided by Col. Dunn, Chairman or the Republican State Committee, and Senator Raines, the Senate leader, Gov. Odell to-day overrode the Senators who had been talking of a revolt against his tax programme. Without a vote to spare, but with every Republican member in Albany supporting it, the bill to increase the excise taxes 50 per cent. was jammed through the Senate.

A difference of opinion among the stockholders of the Empire City Trotting Club which arose over the question of increasing the capital of that association from $5,000 to $350,000 has resulted in an amicable arrangement, whereby the interests of the minority have been purchased by the majority.
ALBANY, March 25. -- These bills were passed by the Assembly to-day:
INDIANAPOLIS, March 25. -- E.L. Burdick, the murdered Buffalo man, confided his troubles to Herbert H. Rice, a business man in this city, only a few weeks before Mr. Burdick's death.

Markets of small proportions and declining tone are not stimulating subjects of comment. Such a market was yester-day's. Consolidated Gas was solitary in its advance of a full point, but there were several declines of a point and many of substantial fractions. The copper stocks were weakest, in sympathy with movements in the metal market, testifying clearly enough to the artificial character of the recent advance.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25. -- It is reported here that the California Northwestern Railway and its leased appendix, the San Francisco and North Pacific Railway, have passed from the control of A.W. Foster and his associates to the syndicate over which President Harriman of the Southern Pacific Company dominates.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 25. -- The Toronto Opera House is in ruins. Fire started early to-day, and the building was destroyed, with a loss estimated at from $100,000 to $150,000. The fire is supposed to have originated from electric wires in the box office.

Charles L. Franklin, the manager and editor of an insurance publication known as The Interview, and published at 108 Fulton Street, through Baldwin White his attorneys, has obtained from Justice Greenbaum of the Supreme Court an injunction restraining the officers of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons in New York State from proceeding to the trial of charges that have been brought against him by a fellow-member of Excelsior Lodge.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 24. -- After reading his special message to Congress today, Gen. Castro withdrew his resignation of the Presidency of Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Two favorites and two heavily played second choices won at the third day's racing of the Bennings Spring meeting to-day. Bright sunshine and a fairly good card attracted a big crowd. A brisk wind had dried out the track materially. While the track was heavy, the going was a great improvement over the first two days of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Brig. Gen. Wood left here this afternoon for Boston, whence he will sail in a day or two for the Philippines to assume command of the Military Department of Mindanao, Coincident with his departure from this city Secretary Root to-day issued the following order:
LONDON, March 25. -- The monetary stringency was intensified to-day and relief is not expected until the month-turn.

NEW HAVEN, March 25. -- Yale opened the baseball season, at Yale Field this Afternoon by defeating Wesleyan by the score of 9 to 2. The same was ragged at times, with several brilliant plays on both sides. Raymond, the visiting shortstop, caught a swift liner from Cote in sensational style. For Yale little O'Brien, the Andover player, played a remarkable game at second base, while Chittenden, Metcalf, and Cote earned the remaining fielding honors.

Mixed races in which trotters were matched against pacers were the features of a series of interesting heats that were stepped, in the upper stretch of the Speedway yesterday afternoon in the presence of several hundred spectators. The excellent footing was a great surprise to the drivers, who found the Park drives and Seventh Avenue heavy while the Speedway was smooth and dry.

Mr. CLARENCE CARY contributes to the current Scribner's an instructive account, elaborately illustrated with photographs, of the chief terminus on the Pacific Coast of the new trans-Siberian railway system, under the title of "Dalny, a Fiat City." It is interesting and suggestive not only as showing what the Russian bureaucracy has done in the way of preparing a future capital on what, for such a purpose, may be called virgin soil.
LONDON, March 26. -- The Irish Land bill, from the outline given by Mr. Wyndham yesterday afternoon, may be summarized as follows:

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, March 25. -- There was a grand reception at the theatre here yesterday evening, under the auspices of the Citizens' Committee, in honor of Miss Alice Roosevelt, following an elaborate display of fireworks on the Plaza, which lasted until 10 o'clock, and was witnessed by Miss Roosevelt, who received a tremendous ovation from the people gathered on the Plaza and on the balconies and roofs of the houses.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Police Commissioner Greene appeared before the Senate Committee on Cities to-day and made an argument against the inauguration of the three-platoon system in the New York City Police Department. He said that if his bill for an increase in the officers and men of the force were passed with the three-platoon amendment he would ask the Mayor to veto it.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The Senate passed the "Malby bill, providing for the adoption of uniform text books and their free distribution in the public schools of St. Lawrence County to-day. The vote was: Yeas 26, nays 15. This is the measure which Mr. Malby said was being held up by the "schoolbook trust."

PITTSBURG, March 25. -- Gen. Santos Zelaya, President of the Nicaraguan Government, is coming to the United States for the purpose of getting American ideas and investing the greater portion of his immense fortune here. His coming, however, will depend upon his ability of getting out of his Presidential job.

C.H. Jackson, Captain of the Cutler School golf team, announced yesterday that the interscholastic championship tournament will be played this year at the Westbrook Golf Club, near Islip, L.I., on April 15, 16, and 17. The competition is held under the auspices of the Cutler School, but all the preparatory schools in New York and vicinity are invited to send entries.

Following many rumors that an Automobile Trust was to be formed comes the formal announcement of the organization of the Association of Licensed Automobile Manufacturers. Henry D. Macdona of counsel for the new concern made public yesterday afternoon the fact that the organization had been completed by George H. Day, President of the Electric Vehicle Company.

what was styled upon the programme a "grand orchestral concert" was given last evening in Carnegie Hall before a large and demonstrative audience, the object of which was evidently to give a hearing to several of the compositions of Mr. Louis R. von Gaertner. Mr. Arthur Hochmann's name, however, appeared in equally large type as solo pianist.

The details of the land bill introduced by the Government in the House of Commons yesterday are not all intelligible without a more intimate knowledge of land tenure in Ireland than an American is likely to possess. But the principle of it is very plain.

LONDON, March 26. -- There is a strong disinclination on the part of the Irish and Liberal members of the House of Commons to discuss the Irish Land bill until it is thoroughly digested, except in the most general terms. Michael Davitt and T.P. O'Connor, however, have given signed statements to The Associated Press correspondent.

Most outside stocks were very dull yesterday, and where activity did appear it was generally at the expense of prices. In sympathy with the weakness of the Stock Exchange market some of the most prominent of the curb stocks sold down substantially' and the issues which on Tuesday had shown strength not shared by the list in general were less in demand.

The answer of Fire Commissioner Sturgis to the charges made by Controller Grout was sent to Mayor Low yesterday. The Commissioner not only defends his action, but arraigns Controller Grout and his subordinates and charges his office with the violation of Section 419 of the Greater New York charter in auditing bills in violation of the law.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 25. -- If present plans are carried out, the new America's Cup yacht will be launched at about 5:30 o'clock on the afternoon of April 11, and the yacht will be the first to have a "daylight" launching since 1895.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Mrs. Roosevelt received a few friends this afternoon. Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., and his brother Kermit arrived at the White House to-day from Groton to enjoy a two weeks' vacation. During this time they will accompany their mother and a few friends on a cruise on the Mayflower, which is now in readiness at the Washington Navy Yard.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 25. -- Since the name of Arthur R. Pennell became so prominent in the Burdick inquest the authorities have been accumulating evidence bearing upon the death of Pennell and his wife resulting from the plunge of their automobile from Kensington Avenue into Gehre's quarry.
In the tournament of the Life Insurance Bowling League last night, the Fidelity and Casualty bowlers won two of three games from the Mutual Life team. The scores follow:
According to Pittsburg dispatches, the Iron City Trust Company will increase its capital from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation, Oscar S. Straus presiding, the board disapproved the Goodsell Railroad Franchise bill, the Mullaney Street Car Transfer bill, the Remsen City Employes' Pension bill, the Amended Liquor Tax bill, so far as it relates to grocers; the Water Storage bill, and the Mortgage Tax bill.
LONDON, March 25. -- It is generally agreed, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times, that the Czar's manifesto was due in great part to the influence of personal acquaintances.

On Monday next New York is to be rid of one ancient nuisance, the itinerant fish peddler. Thereafter the only place in which he will be allowed to ply his trade is the new East River Bridge Market, where he may vend his wares under close supervision from 4 A.M. to 2 P. M., when he will be cleared out that the area he has befouled may be thoroughly cleaned.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Exhibitions of the rancorous state of feeling which exists among members of the Senate were shown to-day in various ways. Discussion of a resolution introduced by Mr. Brackett, calling upon the Attorney General to investigate the fire insurance combination, brought out one ebullition.

-- In the current number of The Journal of Zoophily, a Philadelphia publication which, as its name contradicts its purpose, it may be well to explain is devoted to the denunciation of vivisection, there appears a long letter from CAROLIKE EARLE WHITE, Corresponding Secretary of the American Anti-Vivisection Society, addressed to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -- A party of nineteen Roumanians who were sent here recently by the Industrial Removal Office of New York were sent to the country and put to work preparing land for vineyards. They were physically unfit for that labor, and had to give it up.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Assemblyman Bostwick to-day introduced a bill, prepared by the City Club of New York City, providing for a Bureau of Accounts and Statistics in connection with the Controller's Office to collect complete and preserve full information concerning public service.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read your editorial in this morning's TIMES entitled "Crowners' Quest Law," I notice that the writer thereof seems to be laboring under a misapprehension as to the law under which the proceedings in Buffalo therein referred to are being conducted, insomuch as the article states that the proceedings in Buffalo are being conducted under the general law which regulates such matters for the entire State.

NEWARK, N.J., March 26 -- The Essex County Grand Jury late this afternoon indicted the officials and members of the executive board of the North Jersey Street Railway Company, charging each with manslaughter in being responsible for the Clinton Avenue grade crossing disaster of Feb. 19 last, when nine pupils of the Newark High School were killed and a score or more injured.

ALBANY, March, 26 -- Years of agitation for the improvement of the canals of the State on a scale which would restore the commercial supremacy of the City of New York, brought decisive results to-day when the Assembly, by a vote of 87 to 55, passed the Davis-Bostwick bill to submit to the people a proposal for an appropriation of $101,000,000 to be expended in widening and deepening the waterways.

An action has been begun in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to have declared null and void a contract and agreement entered into by the late Edward T. Hunt with the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York whereby he deposited with the company the sum of $225,000 and was to receive an annuity of $17,154.

Yesterday's stock market was as nearly at a balance as is practicable. Among active stocks changes in prices were about equally advances and declines within a range about equally limited in either direction. Pennsylvania showed further depression under the effect of its new issue, and Metropolitan improved, presumably upon the disclosures in court regarding the motives of recent attacks upon this security.

The seventh annual dinner of the Transportation Club was held in the rooms of the club in the Manhattan Club last night. Senator Chauncey M. Depew, its President, in the role of toastmaster, started the oratorical ball rolling, saying in part: "Twenty thousand...
ALBANY, March 26 -- Controller Grout of New York City has written to Senator William Townsend, an up-State Democrat, a letter of protest against the Governor's tax programme. He says:

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day published a circular announcing that, on and after April 1, he will receive for refunding, under authority of Section 11 of the act of March 14, 1900, to an amount not exceeding $100,000,000, any of the bonds of the 3 per cent. loan of 1908-1918 and the 4 per cent. funded loan of 1907.
Ehrenreich Brothers are reported to have sold the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, two four-story apartment houses, with stores, on plot 40 by 70.

AKRON, Ohio, March 26 -- The explosion of a can of gasoline at the plant of the American Cycle Company here to-day resulted in the destruction by fire of the entire works and also the plant of the India Rubber Company adjoining.

The end of the week resolves itself in bridge, and the large bridge party yesterday was the principal social event of the day. The hostesses were Mrs. John McG. Woodbury and Mrs. Charles Whittier and the affair was in the Annex of the Metropolitan Club. About sixty guests were present.

Six members of Columbia's 'Varsity gymnastic team will be unable to compete in the intercollegiate gymnastic championships at New York University this evening, according to an announcement by Manager J.W. Spencer of the Columbia team, yesterday. The reason for their inability to compete is that some of the men are ill, others are debarred.

The Oakland Golf Club, near Bayside, L. I., is planning for a busy season, and a number of competitions will be held for both men and women. Trap shooting has just been added to the club's sports. The officers for the year, recently elected by the Board of Governors, are: President -- John H. Taylor; Vice President -- George Coggill; Secretary -- M.M. Graham; Treasurer -- George L. Shearer; Captain -- A. W. Rossiter.

One man lost his life and another was seriously injured yesterday afternoon during a fire which burned out the three upper floors of the five-story building at 409 East Twenty-fourth Street. The building, with the exception of the top floor, was occupied by Wynn Brothers, roofers. On the third floor were the principal workshops of the firm and here, it was said, a can of paint was upset on a gasoline stove, starting the fire.

The United States Steel Corporation has taken a step to reduce the expenses of maintaining the corporate existence of its subordinary companies, by filing a merger agreement with the Secretary of State of New Jersey, in Trenton, yesterday, under which the Carnegie Company, the National Steel Company, and the American Steel Hoop Company will be consolidated under the style of the National Steel Company.
Mystery surrounds the sudden death last night of James L. Snow, who died just before midnight in an apartment in the Hoffman Arms apartment house at 640 Madison Avenue.

Representatives from the principal universities and colleges of New York State met yesterday at Columbia University in response to the invitation of President Butler to determine the basis upon which the award of the two Rhodes scholarships for New York State should be made. Among those present were: President Schurman, Cornell University; C.H. Livermore, Adelphi College; Alfred G. Compton, College of the City of New York, and Prof. F.H. Stoddard, New York University.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The talent broke even with the bookmakers to-day at Bonnigs. Three favorites, one second choice, and two outsiders captured first money. The track had dried out well, the weather was clear and bright, a large crowd was in attendance, and the sport was excellent.

Spirited bidding among dealers was the feature of the final sale of the collections of the late A. Melrose Burritt of Waterbury, at the American Art Galleries last evening. The offerings comprised Mr. Burritt's etchings and prints, and represented the work of a score of artists. Of the etchings the "By-Road in Tipperary." by Sir Francis Seymour Haddes went to Keppel Co. for $1,160.

The passage by the Assembly of the bill for submitting to the people the question of the development of the canal system is a matter for general congratulation. It will now rest with the voters of the State to decide whether the money shall be expended. We have little doubt as to what their decision will be.

Dr. Richard C. Flower, the mining promoter, who has come into so much public notice Through the Theodore Hagaman estate litigation, and who was arrested and confined in the Tombs on Wednesday under charges of obtaining money under false pretenses by inducing investment in one his mining schemes, has been unable so far to secure any reduction of the $50,000 bail in which he was held.
LONDON, March 27 -- The Times publishes an account of a demonstration of the Daft and Williams system of locating mineral ore which was given at the Telacre lead mine in North Wales.

PARIS, March 26 -- The Chamber of Deputies to-day completed the Government's programme regarding the male religious orders which applied for authorization to remain in France. It refused, by a large majority, the application of the Carthusian monks. They were separated from the other orders in the consideration of the applications as forming a class apart, they being employed in manufacturing a cordial.

The movement of prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday was highly irregular, with some issues up and some down, but with no general tendency. It was the opinion of many usually good observers that the market, as the saying is, "wanted to go up," but was held in check by professional operations and by the persistent weakness in Pennsylvania on what looked to be selling of a substantial character.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Senator Riordan's so-called "Rogues' Gallery" bill passed the Senate to-day. It forbids the use by the police of pictures of persons accused of crime, except for the purpose of apprehending the accused, and requires the destruction of such picture after the death of the subject of the picture.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Dullness and irregularity characterized the session of the Stock Exchange to-day. The weakness in Pennsylvania Railroad caused a feeling of depression in the Street, but there was no noticeable increase in liquidation, except in United Gas, which declined a full point.

BUFFALO, March 26 -- The inquest into the death of Edwin L. Burdick, who was murdered just a month ago in his home in Ashland Avenue, was ended at 3 o'clock this afternoon. At the close of the inquest Judge Murphy announced that an official inquiry into the tragic death of Arthur R. Pennell, who has figured so prominently in the Burdick inquest, will be started next Monday.

The outside, market's continued yesterday to move within narrow limits, and with the exception of Pennsylvania rights the day's totals were in all cases relatively small. Prices were irregular, recoveries occurring in some parts of the list, while in other issues further losses were added to those recorded during the first part of the week.

Prof. Brander Matthews has joined the small band of those who hail "The Girl with the Green Eyes" as a milestone in the development of the American drama. After reading the article in last Sunday's TIMES, he has written: "You seem to me absolutely in the right. I saw the play last week, and it seems to me the best thing Mr. Fitch has yet done.

PARIS, March 26 -- The body of Major Gen. Sir Hector Macdonald, who committed suicide at the Hotel Regina here yesterday, was to-day placed in a leaden casket and removed to the British Mortuary Chapel.

The plans of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for its Manhattan station, at Seventh and Ninth Avenues and Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets, which is to be reached by way of the proposed tunnel under the North River, were exhibited and explained by the architects yesterday at the hearing of the commission that was appointed by the Appellate Division to determine whether the road should be constructed and operated.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The demonstration made here to-day by delegations from New York City in opposition to any legislation intended to detract in the slightest measure from the efficiency of the existing tenement house law was one of the most impressive ever seen in Albany.

HAVANA, March 26 -- The chances for the ratification of the reciprocity treaty with the United States appear slender to-night, unless the United States Government concedes the right to the Cuban Senate to provide that the treaty shall not be effective unless it is ratified by the United States Congress during the present year.

The Rev. Dr. Kaufman Kohler of Temple Beth-El, the newly elected President of the Hebrew Union College at Cincinnati, was the guest of honor last night at a banquet given by the Judaeans at the Tuxedo. Assembled at the dinner were nearly all the leading teachers and expounders of Judaism in New York.

LONDON, March 26 -- Preparations for month's-end requirements tended to increase the monetary stringency to-day, notwithstanding the release of L2,000,000 as the result of the redemption of Treasury bills. Discounts were almost at a standstill.

Controller Grout made an extended reply to Fire Commissioner Sturgis yesterday as to the charges of the city's experts on expenditures of the Fire Department. He intimated that he might bring the matter to the attention of the Grand Jury, and also that Mayor Low might be asked for the removal of the Fire Commissioner.

Patrick J. Quigley, an Assistant Inspector, and Joseph Hare, a Day Inspector of the Custom House were arrested yesterday on the charge that they had bunkoed Capt. Hughes of the ship Kental out of $100, paid to them by the mariner if they would not make complaint against him because he had a china teaset aboard which was not on the ship's manifest.

LOWELL, Mass., March 26 -- The Textile Council, made up of delegates from seven labor unions, to-night formally ordered a strike next Monday morning in seven of the big cotton mill corporations in this city, provided the request for a 10 per cent. increase in wages is not granted by that time.

J. Pierpont Morgan in his capacity as founder and promoter of the Shipping Trust yesterday afternoon held a consultation with a sub-committee of the Nautical School Committee of the Board of Education looking toward the improvement of the facilities for educating the American boys who are destined in the future to command the vast fleets that will carry the American flag about the world.

The fifth annual cable match between six students representing the chess clubs in connection with Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princetor. Universities and students belonging to the chess clubs of the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge will begin this morning, and, if not concluded to-day, will be resumed to-morrow morning.

The fifth annual dinner of the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York was held last night at the Harlem Casino, One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, with 148 wheelmen present. Ten of the most prominent local clubs had separate tables, as follows: Century Wheelmen, New York Athletic Club, Metro-pole Cycle Club.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Senator Malby to-day introduced a bill aimed at the "Book Trust." It provides that in each county except the counties comprising New York City, there shall be a County Council of Education, of which the County Judge shall be the Chairman, and that it shall be the duty of this council to adopt uniform textbooks for the county.

The championship schedule of the Metropolitan District Cricket League has been drawn up by the Executive Committee of that organization, which has decided that in place of the regular series of home-and-home matches, which was formerly the rule, the clubs will this season play three games with each other.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -- Sir Liang-Chen, K.C.M.G., the new Chinese Minister to the United States, arrived here to-day on the steamship Korea. He is accompanied by his entire suite and party, which includes about twenty students. Among the latter is the eldest son of Viceroy Chang Chin Tung.
LONDON, March 27 -- John E. Redmond, thd Irish leader, has written the following for The Associated Press:

GLASGOW, March 26 -- The fitting out of the Shamrock III, is practically finished. She was towed to Gourock Bay this morning to have her sails bent. It is expected that she will have a trial spin on March 28.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The appointment of Dr. William Shaw Bowen of Rhode Island as Consul General at Guayaquil, Ecuador, has been held back pending investigation by the President of certain charges involving Dr. Bowen while an officer of the navy. Guayaquil is acquiring a bad reputation as a consular post.

In an admirably clear article in Scribner's for April, Mr. FRANK A. VANDERLIP, formerly Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, besides giving a striking account of the immense variety of duties with which the department is charged, makes some interesting comments on the practical working of the system of appointment and promotion established by the law and the rules.

ORMOND, Fla., March. 26 -- Alexander Winton did not lower Fournier's American mile record of 0:51 4-5 this afternoon in the big automobile race meet on the Ormond-Daytona beach, held under the auspices of the Florida Automobile Association. He is however, confident that he will create new figures to-morrow.

The championship schedule of the Metropolitan District Cricket League has been drawn up by the Executive Committee of that organization, which has decided that in place of the regular series of home-and-home matches, which was formerly the rule, the clubs will this season play three games with each other.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -- Sir Liang-Chen, K.C.M.G., the new Chinese Minister to the United States, arrived here to-day on the steamship Korea. He is accompanied by his entire suite and party, which includes about twenty students. Among the latter is the eldest son of Viceroy Chang Chin Tung.

LONDON, March 27 -- The Sofia correspondent of The Times says the continual arrival of Macedonian refugees at the Bulgarian capital is an ominous symptom. Several women and children crossed the frontier on Wednesday night.

The extensive alterations now being made in the house at 66 West Forty-fifth Street, as portending the opening at an early date of one of the finest gambling houses New York has ever known, were talked of about town yesterday. Frank Farrell was mentioned as the owner of the house, and the understanding was that he paid about $75,000 for the property, which is situated just east of Sixth Avenue.

Commissioner STURGIS has made a reply to the communication of Controller GROUT calling attention to apparent violations of the law in the letting of contracts for apparatus and supplies which is much less satisfactory than we had hoped it would be. It is, in effect, that he has followed the established custom of the department of which he is the head without troubling himself to learn whether it was legal or not.

LONDON, March 27 -- Chief Secretary Wyndham has no cause to be dissatisfied with the reception given to the Irish Land bill up to the present time. A day's reflection has not modified the first favorable opinions expressed.

The pricking of the bubble of speculation last Autumn was attended with less disturbance to mercantile business than was expected in conservative quarters at the time. In the general business of the country there seems to be preserved a remarkable equilibrium between supply and demand.

PITTSBURG, March 26 -- Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, arrived in Pittsburg this morning, and the results of his trip are expected to be of great importance. It is admitted that this is not a social visit, as was his last one to the city, and strict secrecy is being observed as to his actions.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 26 -- The New York American League baseball team defeated the Atlanta Southern League team this afternoon at Piedmont Park by a score of 9 to 0 Two thousand persons were present. Howell and Wiltse, who did the pitching for the Americans, were practically invincible, yielding only six hits, which were kept so well scattered that nothing in the way of runs resulted.

BOSTON, March 26.--Loaning rates are easier, but no material reductions have been made. The slack demand for loans is the reason for the easier tone. Clearing House rate, 4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount; call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time money, 5 1/4@5 1/2 per cent: exchanges, $19,403,381; balances, $4,319,030.

The Canal bill was framed by A.E. Blackmar, counsel for the Canal Association of Greater New York. It was introduced in the Assembly early in the session by Mr. Bostwick, and later in the Senate by Mr. Davis. It was also adopted as the bill of the Canal Enlargement Committee of Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Col. Bingham, who has been officer in charge of public buildings and grounds in Washington the last six years, and who has been relieved from that duty has received from the President and Secretary Root letters in whicn he is highly commended for the manner in which he discharged his duties.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Odell to-day signed three bills in which the Low administration was interested.

Dr. Duncan Macfarlan of Philadelphia, who since Wednesday of last week has been a patient in the River Crest Sanitarium at Astoria, escaped from that institution yesterday morning, and would have committed suicide had it not been for the heroic efforts of a scow Captain, James Gorman, who discovered the crazed man just in time to prevent him from leaping into the East River.

ALBANY, March 27. -- There lies in the Albany Hospital, with a fractured skull and badly lacerated body, a handsome young woman of twenty, who refuses to disclose her identity. She was found alongside the Delaware and Hudson Railroad embankment at Kenwood, three miles south of this city.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- N.K. Fairbank, millionaire manufacturer and Director in several banks and manufacturing concerns, died at his home here to-day, aged seventy-three. He had been ill only a short time.

It would be very rash for the friends of the development of the canals to infer from the success of the measure in the Legislature that their success next Fall at the polls is assured without systematic and sustained effort. But with such effort there is every reason to suppose that the approval of the voters can be obtained, and it is quite possible that the vote may be overwhelming.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 27. -- New York's National League team of baseball players Played all around the local team this afternoon, winning by 7 runs to 1. Mathewson showed in great form. He pitched five innings, and struck out seven men, four of them being in succession. McGinity, who pitched the last part of the game, had excellent control, plenty of speed, and a large assortment of curves.

A two-volume work on "Leaders of Public Opinion in Ireland" will be issued immediately by Longmans, Green Co. This work was published some years ago in one volume by D. Appleton Co. The Right Hon. William Edward Hartpole Lecky is the author; he has enlarged the previous work, revised it, and in a great measure rewritten it.
LONDON, March 27. -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day, and the exportation of gold to South America strengthened discounts.

The days, as they drift toward Passion and Holy Weeks, are almost devoid of incident. The concert given by Heathe Gregory attracted a number of fashionable people yesterday. There will be the usual meeting of the Badminton Club this afternoon, and Mrs. James E. Martin will give a card party at her Fifth Avenue residence.

BABYLON, L.I., March 27. -- There was a lively hearing to-day at Lindenhurst before the Board of Highway Commissioners to decide whether or not a franchise should be granted to the New York and Long Island Traction Company to extend its trolley lines along the South Country Road from Amityville to Babylon.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- The first day's sale of the second part of the Harold Peirce library at Davis Harvey's realized a total of $17,744. A most complete collection of the productions of the Doves. Vale, Daniel, Essex House, and Kelmscott presses was disposed of, and the prices were in many cases record figures.

According to John W. Gates, who had his turn to explain the Louisville and Nashville Railroad sale to the Inter-State Commerce Commission yesterday, J. Pierpont Morgan told him in a private conference that plans for the formation of a Southern railroad securities corporation might be under consideration, provided there should be a favorable decision in the courts regarding the standing of the Northern Securities Company.

Four additional indictments, charging grand larceny in the first degree, were found by the Grand Jury yesterday against Dr. Richard C. Flower in connection with his various mining ventures, especially the promotion of the Arizona Eastern and Montana Mining Company, which failed more than two years ago.

BUFFALO, March 27. -- Before the inquest into the death of Arthur R. Pennell is begun next Monday the inquest into the Burdick case will be reopened by Judge Murphy at the request of District Attorney Coatsworth. This will be done to introduce the testimony of Alexander J. Quinn, formerly a Roland House (New York) bartender, who says he heard Arthur R. Pennell threaten to kill some one.

LONDON, March 18. -- Mr. Kipling's new poem, "The Settler," induces The Spectator to wish that England had in name, as well as in fact, two Laureates one, the Court Laureate, to be appointed by the Government and the other, the people's Laureate, to be chosen by the people.

An improvement on armored doors and steel bars for defense against police raids was discovered yesterday afternoon by a squad of detectives specially detailed by Inspector McClusky, when, after overcoming the obstacles presented by fortifications, they were all but defeated in the end by a labyrinth, so cunningly arranged that they could not tell whether they were progressing forward or away from the alleged poolroom they wished to enter.

PERHAPS it is not surprising that Great Britain should quite forget John Boyle O'Reilly, unsuccessful conspirator, for during the nearly forty years that have elapsed since he was transported to Western Australia, whence he escaped to win fame and fortune in the only Englishspeaking country open to him.

This is Volume XI. in the Handbooks of Practical Gardening Series, and although a slim little volume "The Book of Pears and Plums," by the Rev, E, Bartrum, (New York: John Lane.) is alive with suggestions and information designed to help those whose ambitions point to pear or plum orchards, or, if not so lufty of desire, may aim only to own a tree or two.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27. -- Two letters which are expected to figure in the Pennell inquest, which begins at Buffalo next Monday, have been sent to Buffalo from this city. Both were written by Mrs. Pennell to a girlhood friend whose name has not yet been disclosed, and one bears a Buffalo postmark dated at 7 o'clock on the night of the automobile tragedy.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Senator Morgan of Alabama to-day outlined to THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent his views of what should constitute the Democratic issues next year. He favors dropping the issues of 1896 and 1900 and the adoption of an aggressive platform based on the oldtime principles of the party.

In the current number of Scribner's Magazine, Henry Childs Merwin talks in a somewhat rambling but entertaining manner on the subject of "Books About Nature," or, as the slang of the modern pedagogue has it. "nature books." Mr. Merwin is plainly a man who likes to be out of doors a good deal and who has a loving eye for most that he sees there.

THE illusion-or reality -- that "An Englishwoman's Love Letters" were genuine amatory epistles is to be still further emphasised in a forthcoming edition of the book by the authorized American publishers, Doubleday, Page Co.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Ex-Senator Jeter C. Pritchard of North Carolina has been chosen to succeed Justice Clabaugh of the District of Columbia Supreme Court, who has been designated by the President to become Chief Justice of the Court following the retirement April 30 next of Chief Justice Bingham.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Attorney General Cunneen has found a way to avoid the serious complications which were threatened through his opinion to the Governor that the Elsberg Nursery and Child's Hospital bill was unconstitutional.
SUBJECT -- Paul's farewell to Ephesus, Acts, xx., 28-38.

LONDON, March 27. -- Only a few people were present at the Criterion this afternoon to witness the opening of the annual cable chess match between university students of Great Britain and the United States. After Sir George Newnes had read the American cable greeting play commenced.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27. -- Manager Lawson of the Football Association announced to-day that a game with Lafayette had been arranged to be played here on Nov. 7. The resumption of football relations is received very favorably here among the undergraduates.

J. BELL'S new Scottish story, "Wee Macgreeger," which is already popular in London and Edinburgh, has been arranged for American publication by Harper Brothers Mr. Bell who is in the neighborhood of thirty, has been locally recognized for some time in Glasgow as a remarked sympathetic interpreter of child nature, but not untill the appearance of "Wee Macgreegor" did he become genrally known.

HAVANA, March 27. -- Three separate reports on the reciprocity treaty with the United States were presented to the Senate this afternoon by the Foreign Relations Committee. One, signed by the Chairman, Senor Bustamente; the President of the Senate, Senor Capote, and by Senator Dolz recommended the approval of all the amendments adopted by the United States Senate.

When one considers, even through its poorest copies, the "Last Supper." which to-day is in a deplorable state of preservation in the refrectory of the Santa Maria delle Grazie, Milan, even the novice must be made to feel that it is the work not only of a great artist but of a very wonderful man.

A society having its headquarters in Elmira, N.Y., has been formed on lines similar to those of the Anderson and Muncie societies in Indiana, and has incorporated under the laws of the State. Its objects, as set forth, in its articles of incorporation, are as follows:
LONDON, March 27. -- Messrs, D. Appleton Co. Will Publish in New York a posthumost novel called "Twixt God and Mammon." by Tirebuck Young. a writer of great promise.

Mayor Low submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday plans for the construction of a large municipal building and terminal station for surface, elevated, and subway trains, to cost $20,000,000. Controller Grout and the other officials approved of the suggestion made by Mayor Low, and Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal was instructed to prepare plans.

In "Lees and Leaven" the lees rather predominate. One does not sain a pleasant impression of New York from its pages. The greed of gain, the "tricks and manners "of yellow journalism, the life of the vaudeville artiste, the careers of a weakly criminal young man and of a stagestruck sirl are more, obvious than the leaven of the fewer wholesome characters -some of these, however, notably the Bannister family, are very healthful and refreshing.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The name of Senator Thomas R. Bard of California :s being mentioned in connection with the Republican Vice Presidential nomination next year. The booms which have been started for various Middle Western men, such as Gov. Vansant and Gov. Cummins, have forced some of the Republican leaders to give a little attention to the subject.

The ancient and honorable sport of coaching was revived in this city yesterday with the first trip of the season of James H. Hyde's coach Liberty, which for the next six weeks or more will ply regularly between this city and Lakewood.

An uncommonly original little book, unhookneyed in its form, continuously interesting, and free from pedantry is entitled "Introduction to Poetry: Poetic Expressioon. Poetic Truth, the Progress of Poetry." (New York. Dutton. 60 cents net.). The title is somewhat cumbersome, and might have been improved.

BERLIN, March 27. -- While the German Empress was galloping through the Grunewaid, a forest three and a half miles southwest of Charlottenburg, this afternoon, her horse, startled by a doe that ran across the path, shied and threw her. Her Majesty broke the fall with her left arm, and one of the bones snapped just above the wrist.

AT DAYBREAK, Sept. 25, 1493. "Columbus started on his second expedition. The money to buy the ships their armaments came in larger part from the confiscated property of the Jews. There were under the Admiral some 1,500 men, and they were mostly greedy, vicious, ungovernable, and turbulent adventurers."

NEW ORLEANS, March 27. -- Officers were elected and Indianapolis was selected as the place of meeting in February, 1904, by the National Council of Women in session here to-day. These officers were chosen:

"A Descriptive Guide to the Best Fiction," compiled by Ernest A. Baker. (Macmillan. $2.50,) is executed on the same plan as the "Readers Guide" and " The Best Books:," works necessary to every reference, college or school library. An even larger circle of readers will welcome this book.

"The Trail of the Grand Seigneur." by a hitherto unknown author, whose "Foreword" is written above the initials "O.L L.," will appear in above a fortnight with the imprint of the New Amsterdam Book Company. The scenes of the story are laid principally in Sacket's Harbor, the home of the author.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 27. -- The "Sunset Limited" on the Southern Pacific and a passenger train came into collision at Lacoste, eighteen miles west of here, at 9:55 o'clock last night. Three passengers were killed and a large number injured. The bodies of the dead were burned.

A sad little tale written in the minor key is the story of "Lord Leonard the luckless." As one reads one cannot help recalling a certain old-fashioned narrative of "Murad the Unlucky," where it sufficiently appeared that all the ill-luck -- and it was various and compendius -- which followed the unhappy Murad was altogether his own fault.

The Women's Health Protective Association of this city has not always directed its efforts wisely, and sometimes it has manifested a distorted sense of proportion in planning its work; but it has been of great public service, and its retirement from its chosen field of effort would be in many ways a public misfortune.

PARIS, March 27. -- The council of Ministers to-day considered the steps to be taken to carry out the decision of the Chamber of Deputies refusing to the religious orders permission to remain in France.

BOSTON, March 27. -- The gymnasium of the Boston Athletic Association was to-day early full of Harvard men and their friends desirous to witness the play in the fifth annual cable chess match between a team of six picked from the chess clubs in connection with Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Prineeton and a like team drawn from the Oxford and Cambridge Chess Clubs.

E.P. Bryan, General Manager of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, announced yesterday his policy in connection with the management of the Manhattan Elevated system that will come under his control at midnight March 31. Mr. Bryan has been for a long time the chief of staff in the transportation interests of August Belmont.

IT is fully thirty-five years since Dr. Brinton, in his book "The Myths of the New World," called the attention of the general public to the wealth of poetic material hidden in the unfamiliar sagas of the American Indians, and yet the late Mr. Leland was justified in prefacing his important work with the remark:

Albert H. Hatch, wholesale and retail dealer in provisions at 400 Greenwich Street, and proprietor of a cold storage warehouse at 402 and 404 Greenwich Street, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities to the amount of $152,209 and nominal assets to the amount of $178,325. The assets consist of real estate, $175,000; accounts, $2,300; fixtures, $700, and stock, $325.

Writing about writing may be as unprofitable a pursuit, intellectually speaking, as the great Goethe found "thinking about thinking" to be. But the potential audience for a discussion about literary technique is wider than that which can be hoped for by the metaphysical psychologist.

MANILA, March 27 -- Two companies of Macabebe scouts signally defeated the main body of San Miguel's force to-day. The enemy fled, leaving forty-five dead on the field. It is believed San Miguel was among the killed. Lieut. Reese was seriously wounded. The scouts lost three men killed and had eleven men wounded.

The preliminary bouts in the tenth annual competition for the intercollegiate fencing championship were contested last night in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club by teams representing West Point, Columbia, Yale, Harvard, Cornell, and the University of Pennsylvania. The trophy is one presented by the Racquet and Tennis Club.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: ACOMPLAINT similar to that made in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of March 21 by an English resident against the historical food of the American youth has been made by citizens of German descent in this country.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 27. -- Twenty-four Michigan railroad companies filed individual bills of complaint to-day in the United States Circuit Court to restrain Auditor General Perry F. Powers from collecting the ad valorem tax levied against them by the State of Michigan under the new taxation law.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The President luncheon with him to-day National Committeeman Shevlin of Minnesota. The conversation took a political turn, according to Mr. Shevlin's account of it afterward:

Yale, Princeton, Columbia, Pennsylvania, Rutgers, Haverford, Amherst, and New York University sent their cleverest performers to compete in the intercollegiate gymnastic championships, which were held last evening in the gymnasium of the New York University, at University Heights. In each event the contests were close and keen.

"John Percyfield" is twisted of a double thread -- delightful, wise, sunshiny talk on the lines laid down by the dear old Auto crat; and an autobiographical love story. The talk can scarcely be praised too much. It touches upon many topics, great and small; Nature, Art, War, Imperialism, So ciology, Theology, people, and things of all sorts and conditions; and always it is original, forcible, juicy.

BOSTON, March 27. -- The money market is easier, though rates are unchanged. The banks are in a strong position, and show more willingness to loan money. The action of the Secretary of the Treasury does not appear to have stirred much enthusiasm, as it is not believed much benefit will be derived.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27. -- Counsel for the United States Steel Corporation to-day filed in the office of the Secretary of State articles amending the charter of the National Steel Company, which were filed yesterday for the purpose of merging the Carnegie Company, the National Steel Company, and the American Steel Hoop Company.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 27. -- William N. Frew returned from New York this afternoon and to-night gave out a statement to the effect that Andrew Carnegie had authorized him, as a Trustee of the Carnegie Library, to announce that he would give an additional $1,550,000, for the purpose of enlarging and extending the Carnegie Library in this city.

The volume entitled "Introduction to the Talmud," written by Prof. Mielziner, is a monument of patient labor and research. The Talmud embodies the "mental labors of the ancient Jewish teachers from about 300 years before and 800 after the Christian era." In it are two distinct works. One is the Mishna, the text; the other the Gemara, "a voluminous collection of commentaries and discussions on that text."

The culmination of a series of attempts to bring to an end the performances of the Irish play "McFadden's Row of Flats" occurred last night, when the actors and actresses were pelted with bad vegetables and worse eggs in the first act of the play at the New Star Theatre, Lexington Avenue and One Hundred and Seventh Street.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- Local issues were dull but easier in sympathy with the New York slump. Swift's sold down close to 117. There was talk of Ohio competition to Can, and the common sold below 8 and the preferred near 44. Lake Street Elevated sold at 5.

The market opened yesterday stimulated by favorable interpretation of Secretary Shaw's refunding order, and by advances in the London market resulting from the same cause. The subsequent course of prices was disappointing to those who have hoped that intrinsic conditions were upon the point of getting relief from oppressive technical monetary conditions.
In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the National team won tow of three games from the Roseville Athletic Association bowlers of Newark, N.J. The scores follow:

TRENTON, N.J., March 27. -- Robert S. Woodruff, special Master to prepare for sale the asphalt collateral held by the Land Title and Trust Company as security for the $30,000,000 gold collateral certificates' issue, reported yesterday that the American Asphalt Company of America owes $30,537,701,77 on that account, and that the National Asphalt Company owes a similar account of $6,054,393,52.
JOSIAH FLYNT'S story called "The Rise of Ruderick Clowd, which Messrs. Dodd, Mead Co. are about to publish his two striking merits which are not generally associated with books of its description.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Sir Michael and Lady Herbert will give a dinner tomorrow evening in honor of Lord and Lady Radnor, who are their guests, en route from Florida to New York.

ORMOND, Fla., March 27. -- Alexander Winton's "Bullet" failed to do the expected to-day on the Daytona section of the great straightaway beach, its best mile of three trials being 58 seconds. Starting from scratch in a handicap at five miles, the clutch of Winton's machine slipped so badly that H.T. Thomas piloted his gasoline car considerably faster.

Nearly all the rank and file in Wall Street were prepared for a generally higher and stronger market yesterday, and in consequence nearly all the rank and file were woefully disappointed. Because of the bond refunding plan of the Secretary of the Treasury, announced over night, the expectation had been that prices would open up and finally on short covering and investment buying, close "in a blaze of glory."

STAMFORD, Conn., March 27. -- Mayor Charles H. Leeds is in favor of a wide-open Sunday for this town. He said so to-day without mincing words to a delegation representing the local branch of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union which called upon him.

ROCHESTER, March 27. -- Richard Gay, the only negro in Nunda, who bears the distinction of having been Gen. Grant's cook during the civil war, is dead and will be buried to-morrow with military honors under the auspices of Craig W. Wadsworth Post, G.A.R.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27. -- After their fifth conference with President Hall and the Directors committee 6f the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, the members of the trainmen's committee to-night declined to make public anything of the proceedings up to date. Their Chairman, Frank E. Keenan, said, however, that matters had reached the point where a formal agreement may be drawn up within a few hours covering the various grievances.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- "Tommy" Foster, at odds as high as 200 to 1 at the opening of the betting, but which soon dropped to 100 to 1, captured the first race at Bennings to-day. True Blue, the favorite in the race, was left at the post. Three favorites and two well-played second choices captured the other events.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Arbitration of labor disputes as a condition of grants to corporations of public service franchises is favored by the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration in its annual report, submitted to the Legislature to-day by State Labor Commissioner McMackin.

Mrs. E.G. Hubbard has sold the two four-story brownstone-front dwellings 13 and 15 East Sixty-fourth Street, on plot 40 by 100.5. It is said that the new owner of the property will erect a handsome residence on the site. Henry D. Winans May and Davis Robinson were the brokers in the transaction.

What, pray, could be more alluring than the title of one of Messrs. Doubleday, Page Co's new publications. "How to Make Money " ($1 net.) This invaluable volume contains eighty suggestions to untrained women. Need the feminine mind sigh any longer for monetary independence? It is only necessary for one to provide herself with this book of financial recipes, and thereafter the ready coin will always be hers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- The market was not apparently affected by the weakness in New York. Of the twelve stocks in which there were net changes, six advanced 1/8@1 3/4 and six declined 1/8@1 7-16, the latter being Pennsylvania's loss. Tradins was more active than on any preceding day of the week, with nearly the whole day's business in the arbitrage stocks.

LONDON, March 27. -- R.S. Sievier has sold his famous racehorse Sceptre to W.A. H. Bass of the Tenth Hussars, nephew and heir of Lord Burton. The price paid has not been divulged. Mr. Sievier last year refused an offer of $150,000 for the horse from W.K. Vanderbilt, but it is probable that he does not get more than $100,000 now.
If Police Captain Dillon of the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station had been so inclined, he might yesterday have gone into the business of a bookmaker, with a ready-made clientele at hand.

Curious changes are shown in the foreign trade of the chief commercial nations of the world in figures about to be published by the Bureau of Statistics at Washington. The most striking fact brought out is the enormous relative and positive advance made by the United States in the last thirty years.
As a result of the conference at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday between Senator Platt, Gov. Odell, and other Republican leaders it can be stated that,

OF THE hundreds of thousands of visitors who annually flock to the Centra Park Menagerie, few know that New York owns at least one rare pachyderm whoso like cannot be found in any other menagerie in the world. "Smiles," the ugly, vicious 3,000-pound rhinoceros, locked in the south stall of the big elephant house, is the "star attraction."
To the Editor of The New York Times: Please give a lover of fair play a little space in THE TIMES to aid the "under dog" in his light for life against "Female Taxpayers" and allied persecutors.

During the next fortnight society will be very quiet. Many do not go out in Passion Week, which begins to-day, and nearly every one stays in during Holy Week. In most of the churches there are to be daily services. The greater number of them have arranged these for the mornings and therefore they do not interfere with the afternoon bridge, which will be the recreation for those who stay in town.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 28.--With the sudden announcement that her daughter, Miss Rebe Clark, had been wedded secretly on Thursday evening to George Poucher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Poucher of this city, Mrs. George W. Clark has awakened to the fact that a little romance was in course of enactment for more than ten years.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Surgeon General of the Navy and Mrs. Rixy entertained this evening at a particularly enjoyable reception at their home, on Sixteenth Street, when their friends of the naval contingent now in Washington were invited to meet the student officers of the Naval Medical School, which will bring its session to a close April 4.
LOWELL, Mass., March 28 -- In preference to fighting the textile unions of Lowell, the agents of seven big cotton mills to-day ordered an entire suspension of work for an indefinite period.
WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., March 28 -- A telegram announcing the discovery of a new star of the eighth magnitude by Prof. Turner of Oxford was received at the Yerkes Observatory yesterday.
Bar silver was quoted in the London market at 22 3/8d per ounce and in New YorK at 49c. Mexican dollars at 38 1/2@39 3/4c.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman has had to call for volunteers to assist him in keeping a watch on city "raid" bills. Not in years have so many measures fraught with danger to the city's interests been introduced in the Legislature as have made their appearance at this session.

LONDON, March 28 -- Seldom since Mr. Gladstone's retirement from Parliamentary life has the House of Commons presented a more animated appearance than during the debates this week. One instinctively recalls Gladstone's name when any attempt at grappling with the eternal Irish question is made.

Highwaymen took desperate chances last evening to rob Bernard J. Molloy, a West Twenty-fifth Street undertaker, of his watch. They were arrested as a result, although only after a hard-fought battle with Molloy, a friend who was with him and also with Policeman Egberth of the West Twentieth Street Station and Policeman Matthews of the West Thirtieth Street Station.

BOSTON, March 28 -- A large audience heard Booker T. Washington in the Twentieth Century Club's course in the Colonial Theatre this forenoon. Dr. Edward Everett Hale was present, as was Mrs. Sharpe, a colored woman, who has been working for the betterment of her race in Africa. Mrs. Sharpe and Mr. Washington's daughter, who is a student at Wellesley, had seats in one of the boxes.
