NOW the Spring hat reigns in all its glory. Few new gowns are seen, but seemingly every woman has at least one new chapeau. Most of these are flat, not merely low, but what might be called "pancaky." The toques and smaller hats may have crowns a shade higher than their brims, but the large hats are aggressively flat.

It is definitely settled that this community is to be invaded in October next by the spectacular Mr. DOWIE and several thousands of his followers. Mr. DOWIE is the founder of the City of Zion, (Illinois,) from which point he says he has projected over Chicago a purifying influence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your issue of the 15th just contained communication from me in which I suggested the appointment of public brake and gearing Inspectors on trolley cars. My remarks were based upon close personal servation and actual faces and indued by the horrible calamity in Newark.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 28 -- The Christian Herald relief party reached the Russian capital yesterday.

A DISPATCH announced last week that Texas proposed to forbid and estop "the Rock Island consolidation." In Wall Street this had grewsome sound. Some speculative manipulators of the security market hailed it as significant and even momentous. Yet, as matter of fact, the bulletined proposal was not so bad as Wall Street calculated -- was, indeed, not at all what "Wall Street thought It.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 28 -- The baseball nine of the Annapolis Academy opened the season to-day in fine style by winning from the team of Lafayette College by a score of 3 to 2. Lafayette scored one run each in the fourth and fifth innings, but in the eighth inning the Navy bunched three hits and these with a balk and some slow fielding on the part of Lafayette netted the Navy three runs.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- According to a letter published here to-day the Hawaiian Government has a white elephant on its hands in the shape of a so-called Chinese fund, from which a second embezzlement has been reported. This fund originally consisted of $235,000, and is still in the neighborhood of $200,000.

From The Swampburst Weel;]y Stalesman. THE picturesque swamps and salt meadows surrounding lovely Swamphurst never looked more calm and beautiful than they do now that they have received their first Spring spraying of crude oil to destroy the mosquitoes.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 28 -- The Atlanta Southern League Baseball team was unable to score against the New York American League nine this afternoon, the score standing 6 to 0 in favor of Griffith's men.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28 -- Louis Roberts, colored, sixteen years of age, who is wanted in Dayton, Middlesex County, on a charge of breaking into the home of George F. Dey, and assaulting Hattie Owen, fourteen years old, was arrested here to-day. Mr. and Mrs. Dey went to church last Sunday evening, leaving Hattie Owen, their niece, and their seven-year-old son Ralph at home.

Much irregularity was shown by the active issues in yesterday's market for out side securities, but at the close of the market prices in some instances were slightly better than the final quotations of the previous day. This, however, was not true of Northern Securities, which after a strong opening sold down more than a point and ended the day very near the lowest.

WHEN I marry a rich man and take to eating in restaurants myself instead of waiting on other people who eat there. I don't intend to talk about anything but the weather, and I shall discuss that with a great deal of caution," said waitress No. 19.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28 -- In the opening game of the baseball season here to-day Princeton defeated New York University by a score of 12 to 0. Princeton used the opportunity to try out a number of new men and made frequent substitutions. The pitching staff was in splendid form. Byram, a freshman, pitched the last inning and produced a very favorable impression.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The President is busy clearing up the accumulation of business before him, in order to leave nothing of importance undone when he starts out on his long swing around the circle next week. He conferred with Secretary Hay, Secretary Shaw, Secretary Root, and Attorney General Knox to-day.

Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court, yesterday denied an injunction to Jacob, better known as "Doc" Owens, restraining the police from keeping Owens's picture in the Rogues' Gallery. Owens also wanted the injunction to be sufficiently far reaching to compel the police to destroy all negatives of the photograph and to return the destroyed plate, with all reproductions therefrom, to him.

WITH many other things highly prized in the old days, the sun dials is coming back into favor. In these times of prosperity, when there is an art sale every other day adorning country homes is a passion. There must be room left in the houses that the occupants can move about in more or less comfort, so that the attention is now largely given to purchasing objects of art to adorn the lawns.

Justice Julius M. Mayer of the Court of Special Sessions will lecture to-morrow night in Public School No. 10, St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, on "The New Children's Court and the Good It Is Doing." In the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, Robert Hunter will lecture on "Child Labor."

BERLIN, March 28 -- The German Foreign Office say they do not believe that a diplomatic incident will result from the recent interview with Admiral ewey, published in a newspaper of New-York N.J., and containing references to the German Navy and the German Emperor. The officials say they are reluctant to believe that the Admiral was correctly quotd, "especially, in view of the good-will he showed foward Germany in the messages exchanged with Prince Henry."

MANILA, Feb. 5 -- For some time there has been a recrudescence of the insurrecto spirit in the neighborhood of Manila, the symptoms being an alarming increase or ladrone-insurrecto bands: in one case, a few miles from Manila, a band of 400 strong was formed, armed with good firearms. This band succeeded in driving a force of the constabulary to cover, and terrorized the district for some time.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 28 -- It became known here to-day that Mrs. Ogden, "the",young widow of Frank M. Ogden, on April 6 is to become the wife of Ernst Drewitz a salesman.
NEW ORLEANS, March 28 -- The National Council of Women to-day adopted the report of its Committee on Resolutions. of which Elizabeth Grannis is Chairman. This resolution was included:

Work was begun yesterday on Belmont Park, on Long Island, which, if several millions of expenditure count, will be one of the finest race courses in the world. The seekers after information about this new race track, designed to take the place of the Morris Park course, have received little information because August Belmont.

Monday evening, April 6, will be a "red hat night" at Madison Square Garden. As an evidence that no jealousy exists between the two "Greatest Shows on Earth" -- Mecca and Barnum Bailey's -- Mecca Temple will pay a visit to the "other circus." The entire lower floor has been reserved for Mecca and its numerous friends.

GREENVILLE, Miss., March 28 -- The flood situation at this city to-night is more serious than last night, as the water is spreading to new sections of the city. The crevasse in the levee five miles to the south of the city is widening, and mile after mile of fertile delta land is being covered by the flood.

The troubles of the members of the Red Cross concerning methods of administration and the idea of retiring Miss Clara Barton, the President, are related in some correspondence given out for publication yesterday by Miss Mabel T. Boardman of Washington, D.C., who has figured conspicuously in the controversies.
PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- The steam-boat Asbury Park was launched at 1 o'clock this afternoon at Cramps's shipyard in the presence of Acting Mayor Keator and numerous officials of Asbury Park, N J:

TACOMA, Washington, March 16 -- The greatest irrigation project in the United States and the third largest in the world has been started in Idaho. It is under the management of a corporation originating in Salt Lake City. The plan contemplates an expenditure of almost $5,000,000 and reclamation of 271,000 acres of the best agricultural lands in the great Snake River Valley of Southern Idaho.

BOSTON, March 28 -- When, after two days of play, the Anglo-American inter-university chess match came to a halt this evening, the score stood perfectly even, with one game pending. So intricate is the position that Pillshury, who had been previously elected adjudicator by unanimous consent, did not vouchsafe to render his decision without a thorough study, which he announced will take several days.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 28 -- As the climax of the season approaches -- the Easter Day parade -- the congestion on the island increases. Accommodations at the big beach-front hotels are at a premium. The indications are now that there will be little or no intermission between Easter and the regular Summer season so far as the number of visitors are concerned.

SUCH a storm of disapproval has arisen with the announcement that the name of the new cup defender is to be Reliance that the American people, prone even in their busy lives to see the funny side, have been suggesting other names seemingly as appropriate, such as the Boastful, the Impossible, the Terrible, and even the Tail Twister.
ECONOMY was under discussion. "A woman knows how to economize much better than a man does," she said, decidedly.

The still small voice that has from time to time been raised in these columns against the rigors of theatrical convention, and the conservatism of what is sometimes called the enterprising manager, may have had little effect among the gods of theatrical things as they are, but it has brought an increasing volume of correspondence from intending dramatists.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 28 -- Miss Laura Alethe Odell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Odell of this place, was married privately on Nov. 26 to Jacob Ferdinand Blankenhorn, proprietor of The Englewood Times. The Rev. Dr. G.C. Houghton, rector of the Church of the Transfiguration.

TRENTON, N.J., March 28 -- Vice Chancellor Emery dismissed the suit of Henry I. Dittman against the Distilling Company of America to-day. Dittman charged the Distilling Company, which is a holding concern, with having diverted the assets of the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company for the benefit of the Distilling Company of America.

The ratification of the canal treaty by Colombia being taken for granted, it becomes a matter of interest to consider the next steps. The treaty provides that the preliminary work shall be completed by the United States Government in the shortest possible time, and within two years from the exchange of ratifications of the treaty the main work of constructing the canal shall begin.

ONE often hears what a queer figure some men cut under certain circumstances, but there is a genuine figure which cuts more capers than all the queer men in Christendom could cut in a lifetime. How it is able to do the many "stunts" it does is apparently inexplicable. It is the figure 9.

The cancellation of the spurious birth certificate of a baby which became "of record" for the purpose of establishing a paternity which did not belong to it calls attention to the fact that more has been made of these records than the law creating them intended. The object of requiring certificates of births, marriages, and deaths to be filed with the Health Department is to keep our vital statistics correct.

LONDON, March 28 -- The annual Oxford-Cambridge field sports took place to-day at the Queen's Club, in dull, showery weather. There was a fair-sized crowd present, including the Prince and Princess of Wales. Cambridge won an overwhelming victory, getting eight firsts in the ten events.
FOLLOWING are a few notes that teachers in an cast side school have recently received:

NEWARK, N.J., March 28 -- The members of the High School Faculty have decided to erect as a memorial to the pupils who were hilled in the Clifton Avenue crossing accident a stained glass window, symbolic of education, in the school library. The subscriptions for the window will be confined to the pupils, relatives, and friends of the nine victims, and institutions or societies with which they were connected.

MAH gran'mammy she cook fo' Missa Hyde, an' Ah totes wood fo' mah gran'mammy. When night come Missa Hyde an' Miss Elsie, dey sits on de po'ch an' Ah crawls unner de honeysuckles, an' Ah listens to em talkin', ca'se Miss Elsie she so sweet an' pretty an' she speak so funny, lak all de Yankee ladies does what comes to Asheville.

AS GASTON strolled out on the lawn with his bride after the banquet they found a seat in a secluded spot. This was not one of the leopard's spots, but just one of those usual spots that two throbbing hearts can always find on a lawn in the good old Summer time.

AT ASTOR LIBRARY the apprentice class has this Winter added another feature to its course of training. This is to regularly visit the stations of the home libraries sent out by the New York Public Library. These collections of books are stationed in some family where there is a girl or boy of school age with interest enough in the matter to keep the books in circulation among his friends.

PARIS, March 28 -- A brief spell of extraordinarily warm weather, beating all records for over half a century, has brought back many people to Paris from the various Winter resorts, and the town is rapidly filling up.

ONE bright morning a ragged indivdual shuffled back and Forth along the busy walks of City Hall Park. He looked very miserable and at first glance would have aroused pity, but closer scrunity made it quite apparent that he had arrived at his present state more through knavery than ill-fortune. For more than an hour he covertly solicited aid, only to be met with refused after refusal in persistent sequence.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 28 -- It was an ideal day at the Palmetto golf links at Alker to-day, and fine golf was played in the finals for the Southern Cross Cup, between Marion Wright of Philadelphia and Harold Sands of New York. Sands won by 3 up and 2 to play. In the Consolation Cup event, J.C. Tappan beat Samuel Bates by 2 up and 1 to play.

CERTAINLY those who know me cannot accuse me of possessing an undue amount of superstition or lacking in personal courage: yet I desire to record a strange adventure that befell me which has awakened in my mind doubts as to whether there are not at limes events happening to every one so startling as to produce effects akin to abject cowardice.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 28.--The action to-day of President John M. Hall of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad in inviting the Grievance Committee of the trainmen of the system to another conference and agreeing that Valentine Fitzpatrick. Third Vice Grand Master of the Trainmen's National Brotherhood, shall take part in the conference, is believed to have cleared for the present at least what was fast becoming a very critical situation.

Although on the point of turning the April corner, when money is supposed to show, and frequently has shown, a decided tendency toward increase in supply and ease in rates, there seems this year an accumulation of doubt on the subject which has rarely been in evidence before. Many events conspire to bring this about, but apparently the stronger the relief in which they are shown the greater the reluctance to accept their testimony.

BERLIN, March 12 -- Miss Duncan, the California exponent of the new art of dancing, has not alone appeared here for weeks before crowded houses, but lately has won laurels in two different lines. In the first place she appeared last Sunday at the new opera house, dancing before an audience consisting of mostly working people, who were admitted free of charge.

Racquets and court tennis have enjoyed a high degree of popularity this season, and the last big tournament for the year will be the National indoor tennis championship, which will begin on Wednesday, April 1, at the Boston Athletic Association. The winner will hold the title of amateur court tennis champion of American for the coming year and the trophy offered by the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

THE present is a period in which books about New York are accumulating. Within the past two years volumes have been published entitled "The Story of Manhattan," "When Old New York Was Young." "Annals of Old Manhattan." "Landmark" History of New York," "New York Old and New," and "Social New York" Under the Georges."
THE rich man was evidently uneasy. He paced the floor two or three times, sat down, rose, and paced the floor again.

HAVANTA, March 24 -- Gradually Cuban women are breaking away from customs which have surrounded them for centuries; gradually they are becoming more independent. There are many, however, who spend much time in the States, and while there adopt our ways, yet immediately upon their return fall into the habits of their countrywomen.
Charles Tredick Co. have been appointed Philadelphia agents of the Allegheny Fire Insurance Company.

Mail advices supplementing and amplifying the somewhat meagre telegraphic mention of the discovery by Dr. ALLAN MACFADYEN of the Jenner Institute of Preventive Medicine, of a typhoid antitoxin serum, show that the editorial comment of The Times on this discovery, for the value of which Lord LISTER has made himself responsible, was substantially correct.

DURING a recent social campfire, held at the big round table in the Quartermaster's corner of a comrade's canteen by several Grand Army survivors of the strenuous "unpleasantness" between Yankee Doodle and Dixie the Major was called upon to contribute his share of heroic and humorous reminiscence.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 28 -- Not in many years have Stamford citizens been so stirred by municipal affairs as they have been by the matter of fact declaration made by Mayor Charles Henry Leeds yesterday that he purposes to ignore the Sunday blue laws because he pledged himself before election that he would do so.
LONDON, March 28 -- Money was much wanted to-day, though Government disbursements relieved the pressure somewhat. Discounts were firm owing to fears of further withdrawals of gold for South America.

With excerpts from Wagner's "Ring of the Nibalungs" and "Parsifal," Frank Damrosch brought to close yesterday afternoon his fifth season of symphony concerts for young people. Carnegie Hall was thronged, and the auditors included many older folk, as well as the juvenile listeners, to whom the series primarily appeals.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 28 -- The United North and South amateur championship golf tournament began here to-day with a list of entries including over fifty names, representing prominent players from all parts of the country. The day was ideal, and an immense crowd thronged the course.

The wife's effort to dissuade her husband from drinking is not in general suffused with the spirit of comedy. It is too serious for that, and the consequences depending on her success or failure' too momentous. It cannot be said that she is always judicious in her expedients nor that they always reach up to the high, serious level of the situation.

PASSAIC, N.J., March 28 -- The 250 Polish girls who went out on strike at the handkerchief factory of Heller Long yesterday created a disturbance at the doors of the factory this morning and threatened the girls who refused to join the movement. One of the strikers was arrested for assaulting a worker.

BOSTON, March 28 -- The week ends with the money market quiet but much easier. Rates show little change, but the banks are in a strong position. Money is expected to be somewhat firmer next week on account of the April disbursements. Call loans, 5@6 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 5@6 per cent.

PARIS, March 3 -- In legal circles the impression is gaining ground that the Humberts will be let off with little or no punishment. The accusations made against them are very difficult to prove. The fact that Cattaui has lost his case is a great point in their favor, because it proves that the Government is not anxious for a condemnation.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Fully 5,000 persons to-day witnessed the Chevy Chase Hunt Handicap steeplechase, gentleman riders, and entries limited to horses which have hunted to the Chevy Chase hounds in 1902-3. It was the society event of the meeting. The course was two and a half miles.

College baseball was fairly opened yesterday for the year, and while nothing of unusual importance was developed from the games played, the inference is clear that the big university teams are in good shape, and some stirring games may be looked for later in the season. Yale defeated the Fordham nine in a closely played game by 5 runs to 2.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 27 -- The Minister of Railways has introduced in the Canadian Parliament a bill for the appointment of a Railway Commission in Canada. The Hon. A.G. Blair has secured and studied the experience of other countries where Railway Commissions have been at work.

LINDSBORG, Kan., March 28 -- This little city of the plains has reached fame through the excellent annual performances of Handel's " Messiah," which has been given during the week preceding Easter each year for almost a quarter of a century, and which will be given this year as usual, with a chorus of more than 500 voices and an orchestra of 60 pieces, in an auditorium built especially for these annual concerts.

MY DEAR, have you discovered a new place in which to hide my spade?" good-naturedly inquired the master of Ivy Nest, as he gave his little wife a resounding kiss on returning home from the city by the three-thirty express, it being Saturday afternoon, and so a day off in Wall Street.

Two automobiles, apparently racing, rushed south along the East Drive in Central Park at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and when Mounted Policeman Fitzgerald overtook them after a gallop of more than half a mile at Eightieth Street, he was astonished to find that the chauffeur of one of them, a huge machine, was a boy.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- An ultimatum issued by union tanners to the leather manufacturers of the city may drive a dozen large concerns from Chicago. At a meeting of representatives of large firms held to-day the manufacturers declared that they would remove their business before they would yield to the demands for a 10 per cent, increase in wages and a nine-hour day.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator Depew had something to say to-day about the efforts being made to unite the Democracy preparatory to the campaign of next year.

Nana, a typical old Southern "mammy," is the nurse for the third generation of an upper west side family. She was sitting in the room next to that of the children. She was well aware that it would take the young people some time to go to sleep, as they had gone with their uncle and with her to the circus in the afternoon.

International polo is not likely to be confined to English and American teams this season, for the French polo players are anxious to have a series of international events, and the Polo Club of Paris has just extended an invitation to American poloists to visit the French capital this year and take part in some of the matches that have been arranged for May, June, and July.

The Princeton baseball team starts on its Southern trip on April 10. Last year the reason assigned by Casper Whitney for the loss of the championship was that it was a team of stars and no workers. This season the majority of the men still have a reputation to make, and all are putting forth their best efforts.

The woman who was run over by a Waldorf-Astoria cab on Fifth Avenue opposite that hotel on Friday night, and who died early yesterday morning in the New York Hospital, had not been positively identified up to 2 o'clock this morning.

Art Students' Fun. SOME of the fair devotees of art known as "Cox's Class" at the Art Students' League decided to give their male fellow-sufferers, who are known as "Curran's Class," a St. Patrick's Day feast. Thereupon there was great commotion, which finally resolved itself into a polite but chaffing invitation to the spread.

MR. FLETCHER has always had a pretty high opinion of himself, but since Mrs. Fletcher set her circulating picture gallery going he has been so stuck up that even his closest friends find it difficult at times to pardon his conceit.

The regular shooting season of the Crescent Athletic Club on the Bay Ridge traps came to an end yesterday with two competitions for the March Cup and three trophy matches. There will be a practice shoot, however, on Wednesday, as the men are anxious to retain their form for the return shoot in the Boston Athletic Association team match, which takes place at Boston next Saturday.

The team representing West Point won the intercollegiate fencing championship for the second consecutive time last night in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club and thereby secured the championship trophy presented by the Racquet and Tennis Club. Columbia finished second, Cornell third, Yale fourth, Pennsylvania fifth, and Harvard last.

It is still unnecessary to abate anything from previous glowing accounts of conditions outside of Wall Street's gloomy precincts. Bradstreet's says: "Weather, crops, distributive trade, transportation, and even collections show improvement this week." This might be filled in with any amount of supporting detail.

Henry J. Braker, the merchant and manufacturer, at 100 William Street, whose name has figured conspicuously in the testimony taken during the hearing on W.N. Amory's action for libel against H.H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Railway Company, appeared before Magistrate Pool in the Tombs Police Court yesterday as complainant against David Weiler, a private detective employed by the Mooney Boland agency in this city.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 28 -- No reply has been received by the executive board of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers to their offer of conciliation extended to the National Association of Structural Steel and Iron Erectors. The employes' association have a membership of 25,000 men of whom 5,000 are now oil strike.

Some changes in the regulations for the competition for business automobiles which the Automobile Club of America will hold next month were made at a meeting of the Contest Committee last week. A rearrangement of the weights of the various classes was made and they will be as follows: First class, 750 pounds; second class, 1,500 pounds; third class, 3,500 pounds; fourth class, 6,000 pounds; fifth class, 10,000 pounds.

THE statement made in the papers that Herr Kubelik's fiancee, Marianne Csaky-Szell, is the niece of the Hungarian Prime Minister, is a mistake. The young lady is merely the namesake of Minister Szell's niece, who, when only seventeen years old, married a Hungarian Hussar officer.

PERHAPS of all those persons who, in one way or another, have a part in connection with the theatrical entertainments of the city, the least known to the general public are the house managers. Proprietors see to it that their names appear on the three-sheet posters, the press agent is pretty apt to get some notoriety during the season in one way or another, but the house manager is generally a silent factor.

Saturday's market turned, like recent previous Saturdays' markets, wholly upon the bank statement. At first there was some check to Friday's demoralization upon London's failure to reflect it, and upon natural hesitancy to make fresh commitments a few moments before publication of news which had capacity for good as well as ill.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The report of John C. Caldwell, United States Consul at San Jose, Costa Rica, just issued by the State Department, shows that of the $3,794,642 value of imports into that country during the year 1902, $2,048,809 was from the United States, or nearly 54 per cent. of the total.
STATISTICS prove so much, and tell so little of the real reasons and hidden principles that underlie them, they are seldom satisfactory.

SOME of the popular names of constellations aid very much in recognizing them in the sky. It requires a vivid imagination to see a bear in both the Big and the Little Dipper or the Ursae, as they are scientifically known. It is equally hard to imagine a dog in either Canis, and thus it is in regard to a constellation that at about 9 o'clock on April evenings will be on our meridian.

IT WAS plain to all that the young man behind the counter was nervous while measuring off the goods, and when one woman remarked that the pattern was very pretty and asked the price of the silk per yard he pretended not to hear, but counted "five, six, seven, eight," so loud as to drown inconvenient questions.

Many collegiate experts were among the competitors who strove for National gymnastic honors in the annual championships of the Amateur Athletic Union, which were decided last night at the New Polo Athletic Club, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Park Avenue. The small gymnasium was filled with competitors and spectators, and owing to the rather limited space only one contest could be decided at a time.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- Only one volume from a noted press in the Harold Peirce collection was left to be sold to-day by Davis Harvey. That was "Seven Poems and Two Translations," by Tennyson, of which 300 copies were issued from the Doves Press in 1902. It brought $63, and went to the collector who hides his identity under the pseudonym of "Bee."

PITTSBURG, March 28 -- Indications point to the settlement of the strike of the structural ironworkers at the Wabash bridge. The American Bridge Companay has received a request from the National authorities of the ironworkers for a conference with a view to a settlement of the strike.

CLEVELAND, March 28 -- A desperate battle was fought early to-day between three robbers on one side and officers and citizens on the other at Bedford, a suburb, resulting in the death of one of the robbers and the wounding and capture of another. Many shots were exchanged.

The performance of Edward Elgar's cantata, "The Dream of Gerontius," by the Oratorio Society has shown that there is in England at least one composer of original and highly imaginative powers, who is able to go outside of the conventional ruts in which English music has so long traveled.

LYTTELTON, New Zealand, March 28 -- The sledging parties of the British Antarctic ship Discovery, whose experiences were reported by the relief ship Morning on the latter's arrival here Wednesday, engaged in much hazardous work. The dash southward of Capt. Scott of the Discovery, as a result of which, he reached latitide 82 17' south, was attended by great hardships and extra strain.

THE car was well filed with men when the young lady with the new Spring costume and the latest thing in hats entered. Because she was young and not feeble, but evidently very strong, three or four men at once offered her a seat. She accepted the nearest with a smile and a nod, and sunk into it.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Admiral Cohglan has cabled the Navy Department as follows relative to the revolution in Honduras:

Controller Grout is going to keep up his fight against Fire Commissioner Sturgis, and it was said yesterday that he would lay before Mayor Low more detailed charges of expenditures alleged to have been made in violation of Section 419 of the charter. Mayor Low issued yesterday a statement about the charges against Commissioner Sturgis, as follows:

ALFRED VANDERBILT still keeps up his fad for queer-looking hats. His headgear this Spring is not a hit better than it was last year. He is one of the men who has certain blocks at his hatter's, and no matter what the fashion is he never changes. His top hats are straight from a narrow brim, very much in the fashion of the fifties.

MARTHA, said Mr. Newcome, arousing from the profound meditation in which he had been entombed all during dinner, "instead of putting the baby to sleep as early as usual to-night, don't you think you could manage to keep her awake till about 9 o'clock?

OUT of a controversy over a single building at Forty-second Street and Broadway there has grown a tangle that is involving the Rapid Transit Commission, the trustees of one of New York's largest estates, a dozen sub-lessees, and a formidable corps of lawyers in complicated arguments which seem to be without end.

Capt. Thomas J. Miller, United States Navy, (retired,) club man, epicure, and a widely known character in New York, died yesterday afternoon at St. Vincent's Hospital, from infirmities brought on by old age. When taken to the hospital about six weeks ago he was suffering from frostbitten hands.

Monroe Doctrine for Morocco. The recent exposition by M. Delcasse of the French foreign policy in the Chamber caused special emphasis to be laid, in the cable dispatches, on his remarks about the Venezuelan affair and his attitude of his country respecting Macedonia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's Topics of The Times you refer to the impressions of Dr. Lorenz, and remark that he said that it may be Interesting to the visitor of the not specified University Club to know that the cleaning of a pair of shoes in America is dearer than a dinner at that club.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 29 -- A north-east storm of considerable severity prevailed all day. Trees were broken and fences blown down in the city. Street railway and telephone traffic were interfered with. At Tybee Island the wind blew 63 miles an hour. Lowlands on the island were flooded.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 29 -- Two savage lionesses, loose in the streets of Pittsfield, caused wild excitement a little after midnight this morning. They were being lowered from the third story of the Academy of Music, where a trained-animal show had been giving exhibitions the past week.

Some interesting statistics upon the birth rate in Milwaukee have been gathered by a woman for presentation to President Roosevelt upon his arrival next month. There are, she says, twelve families in Milwaukee in which, according to the records of the Health Department, there are 100 children, an average of more than 13 children to the family.

LONDON, March 30 -- The Times this morning publishes two messages of over one hundred words from its New York correspondent, giving items of American news sent from America by the Marconi wireless system.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Herman Bowman Esher was the son of E.B. Esher, a lawyer here, and a grandson of Bishop Bowman. His parents up to a late hour had received no definite news of his death and no answer to telegrams sent to his address in New Haven. No reason can be assigned for His presence in New York, and his family is at a loss to understand why he took his life.

Police Commissioner Greene voiced last night his opposition to Senator Grady's three-platoon amendment to the Police bill now pending at Albany and took occasion to say a few things about the attitude of Senator Platt on the question.

For the fourth time since last Tuesday there was a fire last night in the onestory frame building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Sixth Street, and the firemen, disgusted, destroyed the building.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The work of the Coal Commission proves to have been a cost which is exemplary in comparison with the usual expenditures of Government commissions. Assistant Recorder Moseley, who was detailed from his position as Secretary of the Inter-State Commerce Commission to act as Sergeant at Arms for the commission, will be prepared in a few days to submit the final report of the expenditures.
CHICAGO, March 29.--Gustavus Franklin Swift, President of the Swift Packing Company, died at his home, 4,848 Ellis Avenue, early to-day of internal hemorrhages. Mr. Swift was sixty-three years old.

Those who visited the Brooklyn Handball Club yesterday were treated to some very fine exhibitions of the game of handball, and in addition witnessed the defeat of "Mike" Egan, the world's champion, by James Dunne, Jr., in three straight games. Two weeks ago young Dunne played against Egan in the latter's Jersey City court, and the champion won four straight in slashing style, the scores being 21-13, 21-15, 21-11, and 21-16.

There is no doubt that the chief object of the Secretary of the Treasury in refunding $100,000,000 of the threes and fours into 2 per cents is to afford the National banks the means of increasing their circulation as increased currency is needed. There is every reason to infer that a considerable, possibly a great, increase will be required in the Fall.

In view of the many miles or deep excavation which must be made in carrying out the extensive schemes of local improvement now decided upon and in part arranged for, immediate consideration should be given to the subject of rock disintegration by methods less destructive of property and more conservative of human life than blasting with high explosives.
We cannot imagine that the Mayor really wishes the power intended to be given to him by the bill pending in the Senate as to the Brooklyn Magistrates.

To The Editor of The New York Times: It signifies much as an indication of returning sanity in Democratic councils that the renomination of ex-President Cleveland is discussed and tentatively proposed. No man knows the future. We don't know what can be done, but we have found cut What could be done by men who call themselves Democrats in the matter of electing a President.

The Confederate Veterans' Association will hold its annual reunion in New Orleans, meeting on Tuesday, May 10, and continuing until Friday evening. On the first day there will be a Jefferson Davis memorial service, and on the evening of the second day a grand ball given by the Sons of Veterans' Association.

A glance at the map of the Rapid Transit Commission, or at any street map of the city, will show that the Broadway extension of the underground road southerly from Forty-second Street would, for a considerable part of its length, run substantially parallel to the subway already under construction.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Republican State Committee of North Carolina, has been called to meet at Greensborough April 9 to perfect new arrangements, made necessary by the retirement of ex-Senator Pritchard from politics, prior to going on the District of Columbia bench. The State is more or less concerned as to a new Chairman and a National Committeeman, as Judge Pritchard at present holds both those places.

Dr. John McGaw Woodbury's plan for driving the omnipresent pushcart peddlers of fish off the east side streets and into positions prepared for them, about and under the new Williamsburg Bridge, goes into effect to-day, and the fishdealers, about 180, all told will open business in their new stands.

The Building Committee of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday announced its intention not only to complete the choir of the structure, but also to continue to the westward and construct what is called the "crossing," adding to its announcement the condition that all this can be accomplished within three years if funds are provided.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 29 -- Tomorrow morning the Hudson River Traction Company, which operates a line of cars from this place to Shady Side and secures connection with New York by the Manhattanville ferry line, which it operates in connection with its trolley line, will begin to run cars through to Paterson on a twenty-minute schedule.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Forest Committee of the Board of Trade and Transportation claims that the Water Storage Commission bill gives the commission uncontrolled and unlimited power to contract debt for construction of dams and other works upon the rivers of the State and to charge such cost against the localities alleged to be "benefited."

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 29 -- Several thousand people in Pittsburg and Allegheny will be driven from their homes on April 1, which is moving day here, and this in spite of the fact that they have plenty of money and are willing to pay even fancy prices for a place of residence. Their predicament is the result of the unprecedented prosperity of Pittsburg at the present time.

The Belmont Cricket Club of Philadelphia, holders of the Halifax Cup, which is emblematic of the championship of the Quaker City, will play a series of three games with metropolitan clubs in August. The matches arranged are as follows: Aug. 20, against the New Jersey Cricket Club at Hoboken; Aug. 21, against the Paterson Cricket Club at Paterson, and Aug. 22, against the Livingston Field Club at Staten Island.

C.K.G. Billings, who gave a dinner on horseback in the grand ballroom at Sherry's Saturday evening to thirty-six members of the Equestrian Club of this city, formally opened his new stable at One Hundred and Ninety-sixth Street and Fort Washington Road, yesterday afternoon by tendering a luncheon to his friends.

Match or medal play in golf, shall these systems be combined or separated in determining the test of championship golf? Discussion on this topic is sure to be rife this week among all practical golfers for the game in America seems as though it were about to undergo the most radical change since the sport began to be popular in this country.

Following an address by Commissioner Robert G. Monroe of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, 1,400 persons in Cooper Union last evening passed resolutions that iavor the passage of the bill to empower the city to install its own electric light plant. There was just one man who voted against the resolution, and he proved, upon investigation, to be a Chinaman who had not clearly understood the speaker.

The tendency of last week's markets was of an unmistakable sort. Among 144 stocks which altered their prices one point or more no more than seven advanced, and among thirty-six bonds which fluctuated a point one rose. The cause lies in what was experienced rather than in what is to be feared.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The sudden return from Atlantic City last week of the Baroness Hengelmuller, wife of the Austro-Hungarian Ambassador, who went to that resort on the advice of her physician, was not owing to difficulty in securing accommodation for the Baroness and her maid, but for the two pet dogs accompanying them.
BERLIN, March 29 -- An imperial decree issued to-day fixes the elections for the Reichstag for June 16.

The double-decker ferryboat Bound Brook of the Jersey Central Line, plying between Johnson Avenue, Jersey City, and Liberty Street, this city, took fire in her Jersey City slip yesterday afternoon, and all save her hull and machinery was destroyed by flames, which attracted thousands to the river front in both cities.

Half a hundred paintings in the dining room at the Lotos Club are from the collection of Mr. Alexander C. Humphreys, President of the Stevens Institute, in Hoboken. They show that their owner values the landscapists who select from nature the tender and intimate qualities of color, the subtler manifestations of light in Autumn and near sunset, and let the more commonplace pass.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 29 -- Mayor Leeds's attitude on the Sunday-closing question provoked a vigorous attack on him in the pulpit by the Rev. H.H. Beattys this evening Addressing a large congregation in the Methodist Episcopal Church. Mr. Beattys denounced the Mayor for "selling himself to the liquor influences," as he expressed it.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- There is keen interest here in the new Chinese Minister, who, it is expected, will arrive this week and get himself and his suite domiliciled in the legation before the President returns from his Western tour. Sir Liang-Chen, like his predecessor, Wu Ting-Fang, is a highly educated Chinaman, and belongs to the liberal element, so it is expected that he will continue the diplomatic precedents that Mr. Wu set up.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 29 -- A.F. Duffey of Georgetown University won the thirty-five-yard dash last night in four seconds in the Johns Hopkins University indoor games, equaling the world's record for the distance. McNair of the United States Naval Academy, in a mile handicap, won in 5 minutes and 15 seconds, which equals the State record.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the article in your rated paper this morning on the above case and with your kind permission may I he permitted to offer my opinion on the mater having been a citizen and proprietor for over twenty years in Great Britain and having interested myself in criminal cases to some considerable extent.

HANOVER, N.H., March 29 -- Robert M. Baker of Worcester, Mass., and John B. Kenerson of Roxbury, Mass., both freshmen in Dartmouth College, were drowned to-day in the Connecticut River while canoeing.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 29 -- The funeral service for Joseph Kavanagh, Assistant Treasurer of the New York Telephone Company, was conducted this afternoon in the Star of the Sea Church, Father William P. Cantwell officiating. The floral tributes were numerous. A special train from New York brought about 300 officers and employes of companies in which Mr. Kavanagh was Interested.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 29 -- Nearly one-half of the crew which is to man the Re- arrived here from New York to-day. They are mostly Scandinavians, rugged, looking men who have had years of experience in racing on the coast. Tempo- quarters for them were found in lodg- house, but later room for them will be on the steam tender Sunbeam, vessel, with Capt. Barr and the re- of the crew, is expected here Friday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 29 -- Michigan won the annual indoor track meet from Cornell last night by a score of 42 1/2 points to 29 1/2. The feature was Kellogg's run for Michigan in the mile. He set a terrific pace from the start, and had Cornell beaten after three laps. Conger, Michigan's crack miler, started, but owing to illness could not stand the pace.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- Dr. Leslie D. Ward, one of the members of the Executitve Board of the North Jersey Street Railway who were indicted for manslaughter Thursday in connection with the death of the nine High School pupils in the Clifton Avenue trolley disaster of Feb. 19. returned late yesterday afternoon from an extended tour through the South and West.

Herman Bowman Esher, twenty-five years old, of 234 Winchester Avenue, Chicago, a student at Yale University, killed himself by shooting himself in the head some time yesterday in his room at the Hotel Manhattan. From letters found in the young man's room it appeared that he was suffering from tuberculosis of a severe type.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- A conference was hold at the office of Attorney General Thomas N. McCarter in the Prudential Life Building yesterday, the outcome of which, it is said, will be a proposition from the Fidelity Trust Company of this city to finance the deal by which all of the trolley roads in Essex, Hudson, Union, and Passaic Counties will be merged.

The General Federated Union came near taking action yesterday that would have meant a general strike to-day of most of the trades in twenty-three breweries in sympathy with the horseshoers who have been on strike for seventeen weeks. The strike of the horseshoers is for recognition of the label of the Journeymen Horseshoers' Union by the member of the Master Horseshoers' Association.

Recognition of good work in the administration of the affairs of the city is quite as much a duty of those interested in good government as criticism of that which is inefficient, corrupt, or negligent, and of much greater value in promoting the accomplishment of the ends in view.

Mr. POWDERLY'S famous motto, that "the injury of one is the concern of all," with its practical corollary, the "sympathetic strike," has had some tragical and many comical consequences. Its consequences to the Knights of Labor were altogether disastrous. After a few years of faithful endeavor to force "all" out of work when "one" was dissatisfied, Mr. POWDERLY found his followers, at one time numbering hundreds of thousands, dwindled to a corporal's guard.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30. -- After a conference which lasted until nearly 6:30 this evening, the Grievance Committee of the trainmen of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, and the committee of Directors, who have been considering changes in the schedule, adjourned until 10 o'clock next Wednesday morning.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 30. -- The Montgomery Handicap, the first big all-aged stake of the year, was won this afternoon by John W. Schorr's aged chestnut gelding Ordnung in a driving finish with Harry New. Witfull, the New Orleans Derby winner, finished third, two lengths away. McChesney, the odds on favorite, was outrun from the start.

ALBANY, March 30. -- Fearful of a failure to report the Raines Liquor Tax Increase bill to-morrow morning, the Assembly leaders arranged to force it out. Mr. Rogers, the majority leader, gave notice he would move to discharge the Excise Committee at some future date and suspend certain rules so as to take up the bill out of its regular order.
NEW ORLEANS, March 30. -- The revolutionary leader Bonilla is having things all his own way in Honduras, according to news brought to New Orleans to-day by the steamship Breakwater.

-- When Mayor LEEDS of Stamford followed his own impulses and hurried to the defense of certain mice from the thoughtless cruelty of women and kittens, he caused a good many smiles in all parts of the country, but the smiles were more or less approving ones, and the fame he won was a tangible asset for an aspiring politician.
ATHENS, March 30. -- The Minister of War has resigned.

The first decision in the suits that were instituted for the recovery of money lost in bets made on race tracks, Lawyer Steinhardt acting, it was said, in the interest of Peter De Lacy, was rendered yesterday, when an action which made the Westchester Racing Association a defendant, besides the bookmaker who took the bets, was dismissed as far as the racing association is concerned.
ALBANY, March 30. -- There was much discussion in both houses to-night on the bills to regulate the practice of nursing. The measure is advocated by the New York State Nurses' Association.

LONDON, March 30. -- London accorded Gen. Booth. Commander-in-chief of the Salvation Army, a great welcome home at the Albert Hall to-night. The immense auditorium was packed from the floor to the roof. There was not a vacant seat in the building, which has a capacity of 9,600 persons, and in spite of the rainy night hundreds were turned away from the door.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 30. -- The American Bridge Company to-day sent word to the local union, No. 3, that officers of the company would meet representatives of the local to settle the strike. Secretary J.C. Johnson, however, demanded that a general conference be held to discuss all the claims against the American Bridge Company in various parts of the country.
In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the Fidelia bowlers won three straight games from the Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark.

Several laborers who had been employed in the work of leveling the Washington Heights site for the new baseball grounds refused to go to work yesterday unless the contractor paid them a higher rate of wages. Quite a few of the discontented men left the grounds, but many of them went on with the work and new men were quickly secured to fill the vacancies.
LONDON, March 30. -- It is officially annouced that King Edward and Queen Alexandra will visit Ireland in July or August.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial relative to the three platoon bill, in to-day's issue, under the caption of "A Nefarious Scheme," in so far as it relates to the motives of Senator Platt or Mr. Dunn, does not appeal to us, neither can we see how our Mayor, Mr. Low, or Commissioner Greene can be put "in a hole" by advocating the adoption of the three platoon ideas.

Mr. Richard Warding Davis's new play at the Savoy is "a comedy of modern life" in a Door, a Marble Stairway, and a Hansom. Mr. Henry Miller is a talented young American playwright, who is starving in London in a Gibson manner and a gray tail coat, every fold of which has been exquisitely calculated.

It has been generally believed that the Erie Railroad's proposed new Jersey City station and terminal would be established on the site of the present terminal at the foot of Pavonia Avenue, which has been used for nearly fifty years, but the plans on file in the engineer's office indicate a most radical change, the large passenger terminal and ferries being located at the foot of Twelfth Street, four blocks north of Pavonia Avenue.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 30. -- It is confidently expected that in April 10.000 mechanics in the towns of Fairfield County, Conn., and Westchester County, N.Y., will lay down their tools in a strike, having refused to arbitrate their demands with the employing builders and contractors. Never before have the bosses, 800 strong, been in a better position than at present to with-stand the demands.

Carl M. Vom Baur, importer of notions, laces, , at 462 Broome Street, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities to the amount of $274,139, and nominal assets to the amount of $209,377. The assets consist of stock, $190,000, which is the selling value, the cost value being 149,106, and it is held by Boessneck, Broessel Co. as security for a debt of $110,290.

Commissioner John McGaw Woodbury opened his new peddlers' fish market at Attorney Street and the new Williamsburg Bridge in the gray dawn of yesterday morning. Over in the east the sun's first light had begun to streak the cold sky with the warmer and more delicate tints of pink, blending into wonderful purples and rich violet hues.

TRENTON, N.J., March 30. -- The Governor sent to the the Houses to-night a terse message recommending the abolition of the State Board of Arbitration. He said the board never met that it has not the confidence of anybody, and is both a useless and expensive body.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Ex-Judge John S. Tarsney of Kansas City is here, attending to some law business. He was a member of the House of Representatives from Missouri for several years, and took a prominent part in its proceedings. He was a member of the Ways and Means Committee when the Wilson bill was framed, and was known as an uncompromising free trader.

Police Commissioner Greene yesterday announced that he had assigned Deputy Commissioner Piper to the special duty of sitting as an ex-officio member of the Board of Health, which, under the law, is one of the functions of the Commissioner. Up to the present Gen. Greene has attended the Health Board meetings, but in explaining his action, he said that his duties are so many that he finds himself no longer able to do so.

The presentation by the American representative on the Bankers' Commission to the Chinese Government of an indemnity bond giving guarantees of the payment of our indemnity in silver seems to have disturbed the representatives of the nations which are still, though vainly, insisting upon payment in gold.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 30. -- Not until to-day has it been possible to say positively where the wedding of Miss Cathleen Neilson to Reginald C. Vanderbilt would take place.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Judge Kimball of the District Branch of the Police Court announced to-day that unless automobile operators took warning by his action in the cases before him to-day he would fine them as high as $150 apiece for violations of the law.

According to a dispatch received in Bostone yesterday morning Pillsbury adjudicated the game left unfinished in the students' cable chess match as a win for white, and thus the Oxford-Cambridge combination won the match by 3 1/2 points to 2 1/2, and the Rice Trophy will be sent on its third trip across the ocean.

"William Earl Dobson, a broker and accountant, of 40 Exchange Place, yesterday afternoon shot and almost instantly Killed William John Peppler, a clerk, formerly employed in Washington Market, at the home of the latter, 60 East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, after a quarrel between the two men concerning Peppler's wife.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Spenser Springstead, aged seventeen and fifteen years respectively, have returned to their homes in Pleasant Plains, S.I., after a splendid honeymoon of eight days. Samuel and his bride, who was Wilhelmina Cole, have been sweethearts since he used to drag her sled and spend his spare pennies on chewing gum, ginger cakes, "jaw crackers," and the other delights of youth.
LONDON, March 30.--Money was much wanted in the market to-day, supplies were restricted, and rates were firm. Considerable sums were owing to the Bank of England. Discounts were quietly easy.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- President Roosevelt has issued a general order in the nature of amnesty which will affect more than a hundred prisoners confined in the new United States penitentiary at Atlanta, Ga.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 30. -- The warring factions in the Lorimer-Durborrow contest case have apparently declared a truce. It seems the disposition of both sides to let the matter go over until April 10. The Republicans are said to think that this action is wise in view of the intervening city election.
The Nominating Committee of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the following ticket for the annual election, which is to take place May 11:
It is not easy to understand why any sensible member of the Legislature should listen seriously to the pleas for the bill to force the three-platoon plan on the Police Department in this city.

Though yesterday's market was a weak affair from beginning to end, it was much more largely the creature of professional operators than any single market in recent days. Further, despite the fact that quotations declined sharply, and in many instances closed at practically the low for the day, the undertone was distinctly good, the buying being apparently of a much batter character than the selling.

We publish in another column a statement by Mr. MORGAN of his views as to the present financial situation, with especial reference to what are spoken of as "undigested securities." Mr. MORGAN lays stress on the necessity of considering the character of these securities, the purposes for which they were issued, and the condition of general business.

BUFFALO, March 30. -- A general organization of employers for a movement to federate employers by delegates, corresponding to the Central Labor bodies of the employes, will be one of the big propositions undertaken by the National Metal Trades' Association, which meets here on April 1 and 2.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 30. -- The admission of Mayor Charles Henry Leeds that he had told the saloon keepers that he would not enforce the Sunday closing laws before his election continues to be the talk of the town. Mayor Leeds declined to-day to make any comment on the attack which was made on him last night by the Rev. H.H. Beattys in the Methodist Church.

The possibility of the strike of the structural iron workers throughout the country against the American Bridge Company developing into general sympathetic strikes in which all the building trades would be involved, prompted efforts in various directions yesterday toward arbitration of the strike.
WASHINGTON, March 30.--Internal Revenue Commissioner Yerkes has just returned from a visit to Kentucky and says there is likely to be a revival of Republican effort to carry the State.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 30. -- Eighteen men placed under arrest on the charge of assault with intent to kill was the record of activity on the part of the police to-day in their efforts to discover the authors of some of the outbreaks of violence which have occurred since the beginning of the strike of motormen and conductors of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company eleven weeks ago.

Charles S. Lowther of the firm of Lowther Brothers, coal dealers, was examined before the Sheriff's jury yesterday concerning the attachment secured against the coal business as one result of the seventy-five-thousand-dollar suit for alienation of affections brought by A. Royal Guest against Clarence L. Lowther last week.

Persons who recall or who have kept in mind the remarkably confident tone of Mr. MARCONI and Prof. PUPIN in respect to the future of wireless telegraphy at a dinner given to the Italian inventor in this city about two months ago will not be surprised to learn that the Marconi system has already been put to practical commercial use in the daily transmission of dispatches across the Atlantic Ocean from New York to London.

The Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound held its March general meeting last night at the Arena in West Thirty-first Street and much important business was transacted. The officers elected for the ensuing season were: President -- T.H. MacDonald, Bridgeport Yacht Club; Secretary -- Charles P. Tower, Riverside Yacht Club; Treasurer -- E.M. MacLellan, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

The market continues of that uncomfortable if not actually disquieting character which has so long perturbed both the just and the unjust, meaning both wicked speculators and worried investors. Yesterday it was not without its moments of illusory strength, but they availed nothing against general pessimism and liquidation.
J. Pierpont Morgan, in an interview with a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, unequivocally declared himself to be a bull on the country and its future.

Probation Officer Graveur of the Court of Special Sessions had a painful experience yesterday when he went to arrest Francis Haley, sixteen years old; who, after having been arraigned in the Court of Special Sessions some days ago on petty charge, was paroled, but violated his operable.

Before sailing for his home at Sorrento, Italy, last Saturday on the Koenig Albert, F. Marion Crawford affirmed the report that Viola Alien will appear in a play of his writing after she leaves "The Eternal City." He also said that at the expiration of her contract with Liebler Co. she would star under her own management.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The races at Bennings to-day were run in a driving rain. The track was a sea of mud. Two favorites, two second choices, and two outsiders captured the events. Mrs. Frank Foster, at odds of 1 to 4, took the fourth race in impressive style. Daly beat Yellow Tail, an odds-on favorite, in the fifth.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 30. -- Three interesting golf events were played to-day on the links of the Pinehurst Golf Club, in the open tournament for the North and South, amateur golf championship of the United States. Two of the events were at match play, for the championship and consolation cups, respectively, while the third event was the medal play qualifying round for the women's championship cup.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30. -- Head Coach Cranston of Harvard's football team commenced work with the Crimson football candidates to-day, when about twenty-five men reported for Spring training on Soldiers Field. The prospects," Mr. Cranston said, "are not very good. Yale beat us last Fall in a way that we will not forget right away, and it will take the hardest kind of an effort to turn out a winning team next Fall.
CHICAGO, March 30. -- Owing to the inability of the railroads to reorganize their pool on military business the Government is getting as low rates on it as on naval business.

Sewing class meetings and the meeting of the Monday Evening Club were the chief incidents of yesterday. To-day the Adirondack Sewing Class will meet, and others will hold sessions. There will also be a song recital in Mendelssohn Hall by William Harper. Bruno Huhn will be the accompanist. Many society people will be present.

Policeman Nevins, of the West Twentieth Street Station, stood on the curb at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street last night in the blinding rain and said things about the department order that didn't allow policemen to keep in the doorways. Then he saw an old, emaciated horse ambling up toward him.

His Grace the Duke of Manchester had his domestic arrangements rudely disturbed last evening. A Deputy Sheriff was in charge of his apartments in the Cambridge Hotel, having served a writ of attachment on some forty pieces of luggage brought North by the English peer and his American Duchess, formerly Miss Zimmerman of Cincinnati.

BUFFALO, March 30. -- "There is one man I could kill now, even If I hung for it." This threat was uttered by Arthur R. Pennell last December, according to the sworn statement made to-day by Alexander J. Quinn, once bartender in the Hotel Roland, New York, where the words are said to have been spoken.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Trading was active in the Lake Superiors, Pennsylvania warrants, and Reading. Cambria Steel, Philadelphia Electric, and United Gas also displayed a little more life. The feature of the market was the strong advance made by the Lake Superiors, the common advancing 1 15-10, to 6 7-16, and the preferred 1 5/8, to 23 1/3.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Through the Republican organizations of New York City Senator Platt to-day dealt Gov. Odell's Mortgage Tax bill a blow which many of the political diagnosticians describe as "probably fatal."

By a decision just handed down by the Court of Appeals, the Long Island truck farmers who are claiming damages because of the alleged draining of their land by the driven wells and pumping stations of the Brooklyn water supply system, are regarded as having won a point in their fight to recover from the city.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Several matters of interest came up in to-day's session of the State Senate.

BOSTON, March 31 -- The money market continues quiet and unchanged. The demand is not great and banks are not eager to put out funds. Call loans, 5 @ 6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5 @ 6 per cent.; time loans on Mercantile paper, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount.

The fine library of Lawyer David Levy was sold at auction by John Anderson, Jr., 20 West Thirtieth Street, last evening. There were 184 lots, comprising the works of noted authors, in the choicest of bindings, editions de luxe of limited issues, fine are, and illustrated books sumptuously produced, and the works of the great romancists and historians in specially printed editions.

Yesterday's business upon the Stock Exchange affords as strong a contrast to Monday's as could be desired. Upon Monday two casual advances were the exceptions to the general decline. Yesterday two fractional declines were the exceptions to the general advance. The tone, too, was as distinctly good yesterday as it was pessimistic on Monday, and, naturally, whereas prices fell upon the brisker moments on Monday, they advanced yesterday.

When the driver of the Irish jaunting car who had confidentially informed his fare that there were 50,000 home rulers in Ireland armed to the teeth, thoroughly organized and well drilled, was asked why they did not rise and set the island free, he was ready with the answer: "Sh! We are afraid of the police."

There was a general agreement in financial circles yesterday with the views announced by Mr. MORGAN in OUT columns. Naturally the expression of such views by a man of his unique experience and standing would influence many minds, but the recognition of the facts on which his views are based is to be credited with still greater effect.

No further information regarding the probable change in the method of conducting the coming amateur golf championship is likely to be vouchsafed by the Executive Committee of the United States Golf Association until after the April meeting, which is likely to be held on Saturday, April 18.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Pleasant weather, a heavy, sticky track, and a fairly good card were the conditions under which the races at Bennings were run to-day. Favorite players had a bad day, as only two of the first-choice horses won -- Orloff in the first and Gould in the third race. Orloff was at the prohibitive odds of 1 to 20, the race, owing to scratches, being only a two-horse affair.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 31 -- The local baseball representatives of the Southern League were shut out for the third successive time by the New York American League players here to-day, the score being 9 to 0. A large crowd gathered at Piedmont Park, as the weather was delightfully fine, and the men played as if it were in the middle of the regular season.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Less spectacular than the battle in the Senate was the fight in the Assembly to-day, which led to the passage, by a vote of 84 to 61, of the bill of Senator Raines, increasing by 50 per cent. the liquor license fees throughout the State. Assemblymen Ruehl and Patton of the Sixth and Seventh Districts of Erie, both Republicans voted against the measure and were applauded by the Democrats.
PEORIA, Ill., March 31.--Secretary of the Treasury Shaw was the principal speaker at the annual banquet of the Kickapoo Club to-night. In the course of his address he said:

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- According to information received here from Berlin, it appears now highly improbable that Dr. von Holleben, who is still officially accredited as German Ambassador to the United States on leave of absence, will return to Washington in May for the purpose of presenting in person his letters of recall.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Several radical changes were made to the Adirondack Water Storage Commission bill to-day in the Senate Finance Committee. Senator E.B. Brown was responsible for the main amendments and believes that the bill in its present form will better meet the ideas of the people than as it was originally.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31 -- The Senate this morning passed the bill permitting the annexation of Irvington to Newark, the bill permitting gas companies that own plants in two or more municipalities to lay pipes to connect the same, and the bill prohibiting the employment of children under fourteen yeans of age in factories and workshops.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The special train on which the President will leave here to-morrow for his Western trip will be furnished by the Pennsylvania Railroad, and will be one of the finest ever run out of Washington. It has been specially decorated and equipped for the trip. It will consist of six cars, manned by a picked crew, with Conductor William H. Johnson, who has been with the President on many trips, in charge.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Local issues were only moderately Active to-day, and to the main showed a lower tendency. There was ah irregular movement in Swift's shares, but as the weaker accounts disappeared and faith grew in the ability of the management to continue the great packing business without its founder, shorts covered and the price rallied to 117 1/2.

The examination of Whitaker Wright, the London promoter recently arrested on his arrival in this country on charges alleging misconduct as the managing Director of the defunct London and Globe Finance Corporation, was continued yesterday before United States Commissioner Alexander.

VIENNA, March 31 -- The opera-going public here is greatly excited over the rivaly between the Italian premiere danseuse, Signora Sironi, and the Russian danseuse, Mme. Kschensinska. The latter is the premiere danseuse of the famous opera house at St. Petersburg, and is now appearing at the Vienna Opera House, in which she desires to obtain an engagement.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 31 -- Decided progress was made to-day in the police court during the trial of the eighteen men charged with assault with intent to kill William Merna and George Morrisette, conductor and motorman, respectively, of the trolley car which was attacked by a band of masked men on the night of Feb. 26.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 31 -- Perfect conditions greatly aided the golfers to-day in the final rounds of the united North and South amateur championship tournament on the links of the Pinehurst Golf Club. All of the competitions brought out keen and close play. The men's championship proved to be the feature of the day's sport, T. Sterling Beckwith of the Cleveland Golf Club, Ohio, finally gaining the victory.

Miss Mary McLaughlin, sixty years old, was burned to death and four other persons, three of them women, were more or less seriously injured yesterday in a midday fire in the private boarding house kept by Mrs. Eliza J. Mitchell at 58 East Eighty-sixth Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 31 -- The Norwegian steamship Brighton, with a cargo of fruit, bound from Port Antonia, Jamaica, to New York, ran aground on Middle Bar off Absecom Light, last night during a dense fog. The vessel is now hard and fast, and there seems little chance that she can be floated.

In a rear-end collision between two elevated railroad trains in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon the passengers in the cars were thrown about and a man and a child slightly injured. The accident occurred at Adams and Sands Streets, near the bridge terminal.

James Churchill, ex-Sergeant of Police, was expected to divulge something sensational when he took the witness stand at the trial of Inspector Adam Cross yesterday, but he did not have a chance. After saying that his present business was that of advertising agent and salesman for the American Cigar Company, the ex-Sergeant, whose dismissal from the force was due to Cross's charges, was asked:
LONDON, March 31 -- Month-end requirements increased the demand for money in the market to-day. Discounts were lower in anticipation of cheaper money in April.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Assemblyman Conkling to-day introduced a bill providing for an increase in the bond issue of the Rapid Transit Commission of New York City for the subway. It transfers from the Legislature to the New York City Board of Estimate and Apportionment the Assembly authority over bond issues by the Rapid Transit Commission.
In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the Berkeley bowlers won two of three games with the Harlem Circle team, scoring 1,060 in the third game. The scores follow:

The magnificent scale on which New York is expanding, developing, and making provision for the future may very well induce vertigo in the average citizen who hears of sums involved which are in one way or another easily available, but which are as far beyond the individual comprehension as are the interplanetary distances.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Senators Elon R. Brown and Elsberg began a campaign today to compel action by the Assembly on various Senate measures. Mr. Brown's Spring shooting bill, Mr. Elsberg's Coroner's bill, and various other measures in which the Brown-Brackett-Elsberg combination is interested have been permitted to sleep in Assembly committees.

A special meeting as well as the annual meeting of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was held in this city yesterday. At the special meeting the recommendations of the Board of Directors to increase the capital stock of the company from $150,000,000 to $250,000,000 were adopted.

GOUROCK, Scotland, March 31 -- The Shamrock III. had a trial spin to-day, and showed herself superior to the Shamrock I. on all the points of sailing on which she was tested. The yachts were out five hours, and experts expressed the opinion that the new boat demonstrated that in fine weather she is by far the fastest challenger yet sent out.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 31 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt arrived from New York to-night and was met at the boat by her son. Reginald C. Vanderbilt. She was accompanied only by her maid.

"Lou" Belts, who was indicted a week ago by the Grand Jury for conducting a gambling house at 122 West Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday was arraigned before Judge Cowing, in General Sessions, and held in $1,500 bail for trial. Betts furnished the bail in cash.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read the account in your paper this morning of the public meeting neld in Cooper Union last night, at which there was one man who voted against the resolution regarding a municipal gas plant favored by fourteen hundred persons, and that that man, upon investigation, "proved to be a Chinaman who had not clearly understood the speaker."

PORTSMOUTH, England, March 31 -- The royal yacht Victoria and Albert, with King Edward on board, sailed for Lisbon this morning. Royal salutes were fired and all warships dressed and manned ship as the yacht put to sea, escorted by two warships.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Bishop Whitaker, in speaking of the controversy which has been aroused by the utterances credited to the Rev. W.S. Rainsford of New York at St. Stephen's Church in this city, said to-day that if a stenographic report of the remarks had been made he would like to see it, after which he would be prepared to discuss the subject.

Another meeting of the Board of Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was held at the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon to discuss the wages proposition of the men. The subject of the hour schedules was not touched on. President Hall and others said before the meeting that the questions of the hours, on the eleven-hour basis, they regarded as practically settled.

Continued delay on Sections 13 and 14 of the rapid transit subway are threatened by a sub-contractors' fight that got into the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Gildersleeve. Those sections of the work are on the west side, running from West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street to Hillside Avenue, and including some of the deepest tunneling in the entire system.

The strike of the ironworkers against the American Bridge Company appeared to have narrowed down yesterday to the deadlock over the refusal of the American Bridge Company to confer with the officials of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Ironworkers.

Nearly 100 paintings belonging to the estate of H. Wood Sullivan of Brooklyn are at the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street, where they will be sold on Friday evening next, April 3. For the greater part they are by living or recent American painters; only a few European pictures are among them.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 31 -- Arguments will be heard here to-morrow in the contests between the Harriman and Keene interests in the Union Pacific, Central Pacific, and Southern Pacific Railways.

A large, white bull terrier all forenoon yesterday ran through the streets from Eighth Avenue to the North River, and from Twenty-third Street to Thirty-first Street, frothing at the mouth and snapping at and biting pedestrians, lamp posts, standing signs, elevated railroad pillars, and other objects in its path.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 31 -- Two men were killed and sixteen injured to-day in a head-on collision on the Naugatuck Division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad between a passenger train north bound to this city and a wildcat engine. Both engines were demolished and their boilers blown up, and the baggage car next to the passenger engine was telescoped.
