WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Zeal of officers and men to make a thrilling display at the Madison Square Garden, in New York, in April, is responsible for the death of one member of the Fourth Battery of United States Artillery and the serious injury of two others yesterday afternoon.

They have prepared in the shops for those all-over lace waists which must have a lining of some kind or another. There are little silk slips to be worn under them in white or in different delicate colors. They cost $2.75 each, and one can make various combinations of color with the same waist. The slips are of China or India silk, and can be washed if desired.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- At a meeting to-day of the Board of Directors of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company, Cornelius Shields was elected President to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation last December of F.S. Lewis. Mr. Shields was formerly connected with the Great Northern Railway, and is at present First Vice President of the Dominion Iron and Steel Company, Limited, of Sydney, Cape Breton.

Strange elements attach to a double tragedy at the cottage home of Newton Schoonmaker, a mechanic, at 90 Pine Street, near the borough line in the Cypress Hills district of Brooklyn. Late last night Lydia Schoonmaker, twenty-eight years old, the wife and the mother of two little children, and Percival Covert, twenty-nine years old, of 8 Euclid Avenue, who was employed in the branch office of the Williamsburg Trust Company, at 361 Fulton Street.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Attorney General Cunneen, at the instigation of State Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks, has commenced an action in the Supreme Court to procure a permanent injunction to restrain the "United Underwriters of the City of New York" and the "Standard Lloyds of New York City," with its principal business office in Chicago, and the "Lloyds Insurance Company," from doing business in this State.

Mayor Low will give a hearing tomorrow at 11 A.M. as to the measure known as Senate Bill No. 598, entitled "An act granting permission to the New York Butchers' Dressed Meat Company to erect an abattoir in the City of New York." The purpose of the beneficiaries of this bill is to erect an extensive slaughter house at Eleventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.
According to Philadelphia dispatches, the demand for pig iron is still in excess of the supply, though immediate deliveries are being made more freely than for some weeks.

President Buchanan of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers spent a good part of yesterday afternoon in the office of the National Civic Federation and spent much of the time with Samuel B. Donnelly of the New York Civic Federation. Mr. Buchanan issued a statement late last evening giving his side of the trouble.

Mayor Low gave out a statement yesterday in reference to the problem of the ferry from Manhattan to Staten Island, in which it was announced that the differences between the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company and the trolley interests represented by H.H. Rogers of the Standard Oil Company had been settled amicably, and that Staten Island would have better transit facilities in the future.

Some of the most prominent clubmen in this city have launched a new club, like no other in New York. The prevailing idea is uninterrupted service twenty-four hours a day every day in the year. Having in mind the lines from Tennyson --

The answer of the Southern Pacific Company in the suit brought against it by Talbot J. Taylor and James B. Taylor to prevent the Union Pacific Company from exercising proprietary rights in the stock of the Southern Pacific Company was made public here yesterday. Incidentally, there were published affidavits made by E.H. Harriman, Otto H. Kahn, and officials or the Southern Pacific Company to support the defendants' contentions in the injunction proceedings.

Five wrestling competitions were held last night in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club to determine the wrestling championships of the club. The majority of the bouts were closely contested. One of the most spirited was the final bout in the 125-pound class, between James R. Branch, Jr., and A. Nargonez.

BOSTON, April 1 -- Play in the National court tennis championship competition began to-day at the Boston Athletic Association. The first match was between O.S. Campbell of New York and A. Potter of the Boston Athletic Association, and the former won in five hard sets, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

PARIS, April 1 -- The news of the death of Count Zborowski caused a sensation here, where he was one of the best-known automobilists. The Count had long been a prominent social figure, but his dashing performance in the Paris-Vienna race advanced him to the front rank of automobilists.

Angelo Morello a bootblack, was industriously plying his trade at the East Thirty-fourth Street Ferry house at 11 o'clock yesterday morning when a stylishly dressed man about thirty-five years old and wearing a chauffeur's cap rode up to the ferry house in a gasoline automobile. The machine was a two-seated affair and black enameled.

The Merchants' Association of New York wiil be represented at the hearing before the Committee on Cities of the Assembly to be held to-day in support of the bill prepared by Robert Grler Monroe, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas, and Electricity, introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Finch, for the purpose of conferring upon the city the power to establish an electriclighting plant.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- New York Exchange was at par to-day. Time and call loans, 5 1/2 per cent. Local issues were rather dull and irregular. Swift's shares rose to 118 and thus made up the loss occasioned by the frightened liquidation and short selling on the news of the death of Mr. Swift. Later there was a dip close to 116 and a still later rally.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The L'Hommedieu and Cadin street railroad bills, which have recently been the subject of so much criticism because of the general belief that they were in the interest of the Metropolitan Street Railway, were the subject of a hearing before the Assembly Railroads Committee to-day.

The death of Mrs. Mary McLaughlin, at 50 Mercer Street, Jersey City, on Monday, revealed a marriage romance which began in New York two months ago when Miss Mary Brown, as she was then, became the bride of John McLaughlin.

The arrivals and departures of steamships are of great interest, as many people are going or arranging to go abroad. There are few entertainments during this week and these are incidents only. Society is observing Passion week very strictly, and even small dinners are tabooed. Preparations are being made for the Easter weddings.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 1 -- The United States Circuit Court room was crowded today when Judge Horace H. Lurton took up the case of Talbot J. Taylor Co. vs. the Union Pacific and Southern Pacific. Many of the leading members of the local bar and special Judges of the State courts were present, and much interest was manifested.
Only 10 cents for aluminium cups for traveling, and they have been 35 cents.
CONSTANTINOPLE, April 1 -- Details of the disturbances in North Albania show that the revolt which has broken out there against the reform scheme of the powers is very serious.

ALBANY, April 1 -- This was another record day in the Corporation Department of the Secretary of State's Office, the largest number of corporations in any one day in its history being placed on file. The certificates included the following:

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Delightful weather and a card that promised lots of sport drew a big crowd to the races at Bennings to-day. The track was heavy and spongy, but the going was perfectly safe. Three favorites won, Judge, Examiner, and Athelroy, the first two being at odds of 1 to 3.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- Local dealings were largely in the arbitrage stocks, the Consolidated Lake Superior issues, and Philadelphia Electric. The tendency of prices was reactionary, but the losses sustained were largely fractional. Philadelphia Electric was sold on the belief that the company is not interested in the so-called "Electric Snake" bill at Harrisburg, and, therefore, will not have any legislation passed in its favor at this session.

The late Peter Marie was a man of cultivated tastes who inherited a sufficient fortune to permit him to indulge them at a comparatively early age; but these tastes were too many and too scattered to make him a collector in the full sense of the term. Until late in life the collector was always second to the man of society.

A contributor to The North American Review for April who signs his article "An American Business Man," writes in no temperate spirit of the political sins and incapacities of the people of the Latin-American republics, and incidentally of the Monroe Doctrine as "a bar to civilization."
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Agricultural Department's monthly crop bulletin is as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Isthmian Canal Commission has appointed a subcommittee to visit Colombia for the purpose of making a personal inspection of the route of the proposed Panama Canal with a view to completing the preparations for the transfer of the canal property to the United States when the final details for such transfer have been completed.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Postmaster General Payne is expected to return to his desk April 10, and hundreds of clerks in the Post Office Department are counting days that make up the interval. There is an atmosphere of apprehension throughout the big department. As one of the old clerks said to-day: "We shut our eyes every little while as we think the blow is coming.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- With an enthusiastic farewell to the German Envoy and a warning to Secretary Cortelyou to beware of the trusts, the President set off to-day in high spirits for his two months' swinging around the circle. The special train left at 9:05 but the President was there and waiting for it ten minutes ahead of time.

GOUROCK, Scotland, April 1 -- Rain was falling over the Clyde this morning, and the two Shamrocks remained at their moorings during the forenoon. At noon the weather temporarily cleared and orders were issued for the racing sails to be set on both yachts. The rain soon again began falling, but as a party from Glasgow were the guests of Sir Thomas Lipton on the Erin the preparations for a racing trial were continued.

-- While the German Foreign Office has been pleased to accept as adequate the acceptance as adequate by President ROOSEVELT of Admiral DEWEY'S queer apology for his genial remarks about the German Navy, the German newspapers have not been content to let the episode end so quickly, and they are now engaged in giving brilliantly succcessful demonstrations of their ability to speak as scornfully of our ships as the Admiral did of theirs.

ST, LOUIS, April 1 -- Judge Eimer B Adams in the United States District Court here to-day overturned the injunction he granted on March 3 to prevent the firemen and trainmen on the Wabash Railroad from striking. As a result the unions affected are preparing to-night to enforce their demands for higher pay and better conditions of labor.
Richard V. Harnett Co. have sold, through E.L. King, for the Spillane estate, the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, old buildings on plot 41.8 by 100.8.

Yesterday's market, for outside securities opened with considerable show of strength, but this improvement was followed by irregular reactions. Activity was confined to a very few issues, so that the advantage of strength was to a large extent offset by the dullness which the market showed.
ALBANY, April 1 -- These bills were passed by the Senate to-day:

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES is so generally accepted as the paper of fine ideals and high moral standards in our great metropolis that I, as one of its constant readers and admirers, was much shocked to see, a few days ago, an unequivocal defense of suicide as the best thing left to a man (or woman also, presumably,) who had dishonored his (or her) name.
Money on call on stock collateral loaned at 6 @ 15 per cent., with the last loan at 7 per cent. The majority of the day's loans was made at 8 per cent.
LONDON, April 1 -- Count Zborowski was to have entered for the James Gordon Bennett International Automobile Cup, which is to be competed for in Ireland in the Summer.
Discussing the condition of the iron and metal trades The Iron Age will to-day say:

Erie County has, by special act of the Legislature, and alone in the State, a system of Coroners which reformers agree to be more scientific and rational than the old-fashioned system which survives elsewhere. Under this system the medical investigation of a death is confided to medical men, and the legal investigation, should such be proved or indicated to be necessary, to lawyers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn.. April 1 -- The differences between the trainmen of the New York, New Haven, and Hartford Company and their employers were amicably settled late this afternoon. The men appear to be perfectly satisfied with the concessions made by the railroad officials.

It is the opinion of Secretary SHAW that the tariff duties protect the trusts from bankruptcy. If the duties were removed there would be ruin. Here is what he said at a banquet of the Kickapoo Club in Peoria on Tuesday evening:

TRENTON, N.J., April 1 -- The Senate to-day, by a vote of 17 to 2, passed the Passaic Pollution bill, which has been the subject of much discussion in both Houses of the Legislature. The bill went back to the House, which concurred in the Senate amendments at the afternoon session.
NEWARK, N.J., April 1 -- The fortysixth annual session of the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference was begun in the Halsey Street Church at 9 o'clock today. Bishop Henry W. "Warren presiding.

A conference held yesterday afternoon in the New Amsterdam Hotel, and attended by Superintendent of Buildings Stewart, Tenement House Commissioner De Forest, and several prominent builders and building loan operators, is likely to result in an important modification of the tenement house law by creating what will be virtually a new type of seven-story apartment house.

Notwithstanding the fact that it was rejected by the elevated employes' new association when it was submitted to them a week ago by the then General Manager Skitt of the Manhattan Railway Company and General Manager Bryan of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, the new wage schedule was put into effect yesterday by Mr. Bryan when he assumed the management of the amalgamated companies.

Madison Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, northeast corner, for a twelve-story brick hotel, 75 by 79.6; Forty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue Company of 100 Broadway, owner; H. Lucas of 1.133 Broadway, architect; amended cost, $600,000.

PATERSON, N.J., April 1 -- A double tragedy was enacted at Lakeview, a suburb of Paterson, this morning, a young man and his bride ending their lives by taking carbolic acid. The victims were Thomas S. Stothard, twenty-one years old, of Hazel Street, Lakeview, and his wife. Louisa C. Stothard, twenty-three years old.

PUTNEY, England, April 1 -- Cambridge won the sixtieth annual inter-university boat race from Oxford to-day by about six lengths. This makes the twenty-sixth victory for the "light blue" oarsmen, Oxford having won thirty-three times; the race of 1877 resulted in a tie. The race to-day was rowed, as usual, on the Thames, between Putney and Mortlake, a distance of four and a quarter miles.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 1 -- In an exhibition baseball game played here to-day the New York National League team defeated the Louisville nine by the narrow margin of one run, the score being 6 to 5. Mathewson had plenty of speed but poor control of the ball, as he gave three men their bases, while Cronin struck out five men in the five innings which he pitched.

ALBANY, April 1.--Developments in the Republican political situation to-day included a conference on the Mortgage Tax bill, which decided on another caucus, and the abandonment of the three-platoon plan for the New York police force, which Senator Platt had strongly indorsed.
Chairman Richard W. Bainbridge of the Kings County Democratic General Committee issued a statement yesterday relative to the reorganization of the Democratic Party.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 1.--President Roosevelt viewed the scenery around the famous Horseshoe Curve this afternoon from a seat in the cab of a locomotive attached to his special train, and after a ride of about fifty miles expressed himself as delighted with his experience. When his special reached Altoona at 4:50 o'clock this afternoon the President alighted from his car and walked rapidly to the front of the train.

There have been days of smaller business than yesterday's upon the Stock Exchange, but there can scarcely have been days of smaller fluctuations. Sales were fewer than Tuesday by a quarter million shares, but upon the entire active list there was only one change exceeding a fraction, and changes of less than a point were divided nearly equally between ups and downs.

All of the baseball clubs in the Eastern League were represented at the adjourned annual meeting which was concluded at the Victoria Hotel yesterday. The playing schedule for the coming season arranged by President Powers was discussed and adopted without any change of the allotted dates.
LONDON, April 2 -- The latest Balkan news, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, severely tests the optimism of official circles and causes serious misgivings elsewhere.

The hearing of William N. Amory's action against H. H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, as the first step in a prosecution for criminal libel, was resumed yesterday morning before Magistrate Barlow in the Tombs Police Court, and though it resulted in trashing over again the testimony given earlier in the trial, it also threw light on the contention from new points of view.

LONDON, April 1 -- With the month's turn and the completion of the settlement the demand for money slackened to-day, though it was still active, the day being consols pay day. Supplies were considerably increased.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Republican legislators from New York City are complaining bitterly of the manner in which they are being treated by the powers which control legislation and interesting developments may result unless they are accorded more courtesy.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The Catholic Church to-day definitely declared itself in favor of the unification of the educational system of the State under the State Board of Regents. A delegation representing Archbishop Farley and the six Bishops in New York conferred with Gov. Odell this afternoon and told of the attitude of the prelates.

Suicide is the theory that has been accepted by police and relatives in accounting for the disappearance of Adolphe Openhym, senior member of William Openhym Sons, silk merchants, at Grand and Mercer Streets. Mr. Openhym was missed from his home, at 352 Riverside Drive, on Monday last, and a chain of circumstantial evidence leads to the conclusion that he jumped into the Harlem River from High Bridge at about 11 o clock that morning.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1 -- Two answers were filed in the Court of Chancery this afternoon in the suit of Lyman E. Warren against the Fisheries Company. One answer was filed by the Fisheries Company, through its President Capt. Nathaniel B. Church, and the other by J. Harold Pim, Langley Archer West, R. Montgomery Horne Payne, and the Association of Foreign Shareholders of the Fisheries Company, Limited, of New Jersey.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., April 1 -- At the opening of the Spring meeting of the Presbytery of Newark in Westminster Presbyterian Church here to-day a communication from the Rev. John L. Richardson of Salt Lake City urged action in the matter of Senator Smoot of Utah, and asked the Presbytery to use its influence on Senators Kean and Dryden to protest against the Utah Senator being allowed a seat in the United States Senate.

"Let me cook the dinners of our statesmen," says Miss Ethel Barrymore, "and who will elect them to Congress?" She has been the guest of Senator Hanna in Cleveland during the past week. "Each day," according to authentic relations, "the Senator gives a reception to society in her honor, and Miss Barrymore prepares the dinner."

NICE, France, April 1 -- Count Elliott Zborowski of New York was killed to-day in an automobile bill-climbing race between here and La Turble. His car turned a sharp angle too quickly, turned over, and was wrecked. The Count was hurled against a wall, his head was split open, and he died instantly. His friend Baron de Pallange, who was acting as chauffeur, was mortally Injured and died to-night.

NICE, April 2 -- As a result of the death of Count Elliott Zborowski of New York, yesterday, the Prefect has put a stop to the further use of the Nice-La Turbie course for automobiles, and has prohibited a mile race which was to take place next Sunday on the Promenade des Anglais. His action was due to orders received from the Minister of the Interior.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 2 -- It is probable that the Reliance, which will be put overboard on April 11, will be launched in skirts; that is, with sails hanging from the decks over the sides to conceal her lines. No Herreshoff boat has ever been launched in that manner.

The committee that was appointed in February last by the American Dramatists' Club to formulate a plan for presenting the endowed National Art Theatre project to the public had a meeting last evening at 114 West Fortieth Street, and announced the plan. At a more public meeting at Delmonico's on April 19 the plan is to be ratified.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly give me space in your paper to say a few words in defense of Admiral Dewey about that harmless remark made to a citizen in regard to the strength of our gunboats? Now, what could be more natural for any officer (who had a just pride in his war fleet) when asked such a question to defend his own, whether German or Yankee?

The illness of William N. Amory, complainant in the action for criminal libel against H.H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railway, compelled a postponement of the hearing set for yesterday afternoon before Magistrate Barlow in Jefferson Market Court, after a sharp argument between Thomas F. Byrne, Mr. Amory's lawyer, and Messrs. Nicoll and Cravath, counsel for Mr. Vreeland.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Secretary of War has issued a circular announcing the regulations prescribed for the tests for a National trophy and medals and other prizes for marksmanship in accordance with the provisions of the last army appropriation act. These tests will be conducted under the direction of a board of twenty-one members, of whom eight will consist of the President and the Board of Trustees of the National Rifle Association.

One of the interesting developments of the day was a sharp break in the price of copper on the Metal Exchange, the metal going to 14 @ 141/2 cents per pound on heavy offerings, as compared with a quoted price of 14 7/8 on Wednesday. Even on the decline there was very little demand, showing the artificial nature of the recent advance.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Three favorites, two of them at odds-on, won at Bennings to-day before one of the best crowds of the meeting. The particular attraction was the steeplechase at about two miles and a half. As a horse race it was almost a farce, but it teemed with excitement, every horse in the race falling except the favorite, Arius, on which Finnegan made a careful and well-judged ride, winning about as he pleased.

Mayor Low gave a public hearing yesterday on the bill of Senator Elsberg to allow the construction of an abattoir at Thirty-ninth Street and Eleventh Avenue to take the place of the three ramshackle slaughter houses which now occupy the ground. There was a delegation of about 200 butchers of the New York Butchers' Dressed Meat Company present, and they favored the bill.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Five Republican Senators voted with the Democrats to-day, and the three-platoon amendment to the Greene police bill was carried in the Senate by 26 ayes to 21 nays. The Republicans who made this result possible were Senators Wilcox, W.L. Brown, Lefevre, McEwan, and L'Hommedieu.

It is only just now that the Marconi system of wireless telegraphy has been put upon a commercial basis. That is to say, it has just entered the field as a competitor of the older systems of instantaneous communication over land and under sea. The time spent in the experimental stage seems long to newspaper readers who seem to have been knowing all about it for years and wondering when it would become "practical."

NEWPORT, R.I., April 2 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt returned to New York this morning. During her short stay in Newport she inspected the preparations for the opening of her villa, The Breakers, and the Pratt cottage, where the marriage of Miss Neilson to her youngest son, Reginald, it to take place in less than two weeks.

LONDON, April 2 -- It is not thought here that the question whether the international athletic challenge comes from Harvard-Yale or from Oxford-Cambridge will affect the meeting of the universities this Summer. A cablegram from the Harvard-Yale representative received to-day suggests that in view of the fact that Oxford-Cambridge lost the match in 1902 they should send the challenge.

The reports of the Bureau of Statistics show a remarkable increase in the importation of materials for use in manufacturing industry, and that is an element not only in our foreign trade, but in the general situation that must be taken into account and is especially encouraging.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Without any satisfactory explanation, the local market drifted downward to-day, and lower prices were established in nearly all the principal local specialties. Speculative sentiment was chilled from the outset by reason of the fresh outburst of liquidation in Philadelphia Electric securities.

Something like a semi-corset, or bust support, perhaps, to be worn with a ribbon girdle, or something of that kind, is a little garment that will wash, and has the effect of silk, and can be worn with different colored ribbons. It is like a short corset waist of white wash material, laced in the back, and with only straps running lengthwise of the waist at intervals in the front.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 2 -- For the first time since the series of exhibition games began the Atlanta Southern League baseball team scored against the New York Americans this afternoon.

Samuel J. Parks, the leader of the local organization of Structural Iron Workers, who was sent for by President Buchanan of the International Association for consultation as to calling out all the iron workers in the subway and men on other contracts of the American Bridge Company, arrived in this city from Hot Spring's, Ark., last night.

We make room, with pleasure, for an interesting letter from Mr. JOSEPH B. BLOOMINGDALE, proposing an extension of the Mayor's adoption and extension of Mr. LINDENTHAL'S scheme for a combined railroad terminal and municipal office building on the trapezoid of which one end is occupied by the building of The Staats-Zeitung.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Efforts of representatives of the Regents of the university to effect a compromise with Superintendent Skinner of the State Department of Public Instruction in the battle over the unification of the State's educational system came to naught to-day. A proposition was made for a conference to draft a compromise bill to take the place of the three unification bills now pending in the Legislature, but was not accepted by Mr. Skinner.

ALBANY, April 2 -- More than fifty representative citizens from New York, advocates of the municipal lighting plant scheme for that city, arrived in Albany today to attend the hearing on the bill for that purpose before the Assembly Cities Committee. They called on Gov. Odell at noon, and at 4 o'clock began their argument in favor of the measure.

It has been definitely learned that Ben Greet's company, headed by Miss Wynne Mathison, now playing "Everyman" at the Garden Theatre, will be seen in a Shakespearean production in this city prior to the close of the present season.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., April 2 -- The eleven overtures relative to the confession of faith, as proposed by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, were adopted without opposition by the Newark Presbytery in session in the Westminster Presbyterian Church here to-day.

NEWARK, N.J., April 2 -- The session of the Newark Methodist Conference to-day was taken up almost entirely by the reading of the reports of three of the Presiding Elders, the Rev. Warren R. Hoagland, Presiding Elder of the Newark District, deferring his report until to-morrow. All of the reports were gratifying.

DES MOINES, April 2 -- William J. Bryan this evening declared himself as against any party compromise on the silver question, and said that the talk of harmony by Gold Democrats suggests the inquiry "whether the prodigals have repented or demand repentance of the party."
The Beekman estate has sold to Edward Farrell, for about $75,000, the four-story buildings 62 and 64 East one Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, on plot 50 by 100.

The story of yesterday's market is best told in the brief statement that barely 300,000 shares were dealt in throughout the entire business session, with but half a dozen stocks traded in to the total of 10,000 shares or more each. The disturbing part of the matter, however, was that such activity as showed was at the expense of values, with renewed liquidation in the high class shares, notably St. Paul and Pennsylvania.

To-day being Passion Friday, there is nothing on the programme. There was an interesting meet of the Meadowbrook Hunt near the clubhouse on Long Island yesterday, and the coach Liberty made its tri-weekly trip from the Holland House to Lakewood. The Pioneer will start on April 13.

GOUROCK, Scotland, April 2 -- As in her previous trials here, the Shamrock III, today proved to be a remarkably speedy boat in light winds. It is to sail under these conditions, that prevail in American waters during the month of August and early September, that the new yacht was designed and built.
Paul Kline has been appointed Middle Department special agent of the American Central Insurance Company of St. Louis and the Mercantile Fire and Marine Insurance Company of Boston.

Money firm, 6 to 12 per cent, on call. Stocks weak. Yesterday's dealings upon the Stock Exchange were consistently weak throughout the list and the day, both in tone and prices. There was no demoralization, as appears from the smallness of the dealings, but a steady slipping away of prices which left only Brooklyn Rapid Transit a fraction higher.

ALBANY, April 2 -- City Chamberlain E. R.L. Gould brought to Albany to-day a rapid transit bill which is intended to take the place of all of the rapid transit bills now pending, and which, according to Mr. Gould's statement, has the approval of Mayor Low and the city authorities. He gave the measure to Senator Elsberg, and Mr. Elsberg intends to introduce it in the morning.

It is authoritatively announced that the formal agreement entered into by Mr. MORGAN on behalf of the International Mercantile Marine Company with the British Government provides for many things which are likely to be distinctly distasteful to the people of the United States.

NEW HAVEN, April 2 -- The committee representing the conductors of the system met twice to-day with President Hall and other officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and reached an "amicable settlement."

NASHVILLE, April 2 -- The case of Talbot J. Taylor vs. the Southern Pacific and Union Pacific Railroads will go to Judge Lurton to-morrow. It remains only for Senator Foraker to end his argument. which was begun and the greater part of which was ended to-day. His will be the last argument made.

BOSTON, Mass., April 2 -- C.E. Sands of New York and Joshua Crane, Jr., of Boston will meet on Saturday in the final match for the tennis championship of America. Both men successfully came through their preliminary match. Sands yesterday had a hard match with Stockton of Boston and to-day earned an easy victory over Oliver C. Campbell of New York.

District Attorney Jerome was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given to him at the Hotel St. Denis by members of Club C. a good-government organization. In his speech he criticised Mayor Low for "constitutional timidity." Among those who listened to Mr. Jerome's criticism of the Mayor were Police Commissioner Greene, Tenement House Commissioner De Forest, and Commissioner of Charities Folks.

COPENHAGEN, April, 2 -- The German Emperor arrived here to-day from Kiel and received a most cordial greeting from thousands of spectators and from a great gathering of diplomats and civil and military authorities.

In the large anteroom adjoining the meeting hall of the Rapid Transit Commission, at 320 Broadway, enough scenery was rigged up yesterday afternoon for a kinetoscopic show. The showmen were the representatives of the syndicate which has offered to build for the city, or to have the city build, a tunnel for moving platforms connecting the Brooklyn and Wiliiamsburg Bridges and extending down into the financial district around Wall Street.

TRENTON, N.J., April 2 -- The two houses of the New Jersey Legislature adjourned sine die to-day after the adoption of the customary complimentary resolution. Speaker Horner of the House received a handsome silver service from his fellow members. The presentation speech was made by Assemblyman Treacy, the Democratic leader.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg leave to renew the suggestions contained in my former letter, which at the time you were good enough to publish.

One woman was killed and six persons were badly burned in a fire which partly destroyed a five-story tenement house at 172 Rivington Street, last night. The body was discovered after the blaze had been extinguished, but was charred beyond recognition, and who the victim was had not been ascertained last night.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Senate and Assembly Republican caucuses were held to-day on the Mortgage Tax bill. The result is an apparent dead-lock. The Assembly caucus by a vote of 57 to 20 decided to abandon the bill. The Senate caucus took no definite action, but it is admitted generally by Senators that if a vote had been taken on the proposition the result would have been a decision to support the bill.
Capt. Horatio G. Sickel, Seventh Cavalry, and Capt. Andrew G. Hammond, Eighth Cavalry, will report at Jefferson Barracks for examination to determine their fitness for promotion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 2 -- By a vote of 7 to 1 the House Committee on Constitutional Amendments voted this afternoon to report to the Legislature next Tuesday a measure designed to reform the representative system in this State. One country member of the committee voted to keep the system as it is.

LISBON, April 2 -- The British royal yacht Victoria and Albert, with King Edward on board, arrived in the Tagus to-day from Portsmouth, and was saluted by the warships and forts. The yacht steamed up the estuary, followed by the escorting British and Portuguese cruisers, and anchored opposite Black Horse Square, where an immense crowd had assembled, the windows and roofs of the houses and every other point of vantage being packed with people.

BOSTON, April 2 -- Secretary of War Elihu Root was the principal speaker at the banquet of the Home Market Club tonight. In his address he voiced the opposition to revision of the present tariff. A great deal of importance was attached to his argument in the minds of members of the Home Market Club, inasmuch as it was assumed he spoke for the Administration.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 2 -- There has been a rumor for some time that certain outside capitalists were seeking to get extensive charter rights from the Connecticut Legislature without appearing openly as applicants. The result was an endeavor in the House to-day to smoke out these people if they were here.

There is only an apparent, not a real, contradiction between the order of Judge ADAMS granting a temporary injunction to restrain the issue of a strike order on the Wabash Railroad system and his action in dissolving the injunction on Wednesday. It was the purpose of the court to prevent hasty action by the Brotherhoods, to hold the controversy at a standstill until inquiry could be made into the nature of the act contemplated.

In the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday a meeting in the interest of prison work was addressed by Mrs. Ballington Booth and Mrs. E.A. McAlpin. W.J. Schieffelin introduced Mrs. Booth, who said:

Judge F.J. Worcester in the Eleventh District Municipal Court yesterday handed down a decision for the plaintiff in the case of Paul Blume against the Interurban Street Railway, which was brought to determine the right of the road to refuse transfers at points of intersection other than those determined by itself.

LONDON, April 3 -- Messrs. D. Appleton Co. will publish in New York a "Life of Beaconsfield," by Wilfrid Meynell. This book will fill the gap caused by the nonappearance of the authoritative "Life" which Lord Rowton, who was Lord Beaconsfield's secretary, has long been preparing, but which now seems to be indefinitely postponed, as Lord Rowton's health does not materially improve.

In this age, which is essentially pictorial, it may be that there is something akin to satiety when the topic of decoration is presented. You are always looking at grand chambers or libraries or halls. There comes about optical bewilderment, and with it weariness. The word "decoration" has apparently no limitation.

ST. LOUIS, April 3. -- A long conference over the grievances of the Wabash Railroad employes was held to-day at the Wabash general headquarters. Col. W.H. Blodgett, chief counsel for the Wabash; H.W. Ashley, acting head in President Ramsey's absence; F.N. Judson, counsel for the railway brotherhoods: John J. Hannahan, Grand Master of the firemen; W.G. Lee, Vice Grand Master of the trainmen, and a committee representing the employes of the Wabash divisions were present.

In consequence of a dispatch from Albany to the effect that the new Rapid Transit bill taken to the capital by City Chamberlain K.R.L. Gould was designed to give special privileges to the Belmont syndicate, inquiries were made yesterday for the purpose of obtaining the point of view of the Rapid Transit Commission and the city administration concerning the measure.

The Danish critic who writes this volume must have found the subject somewhat uncongenial, for he is a liberal, and the period of reaction, political and literary, is hardly attractive to a man of his convictions. He has undertaken his task, however, in a spirit of fairness, and has traced with great intelligence, as both historian and critic, the influences of the time.

IN "1'Education Musicale," by Albert Lavlgnac, there is nothing of the crank, musical or otherwise -- nothing to suggest the disordered wig or eye in frenzy rolling. The author, who is Professor of Harmony at the Conservatoire de Paris, is, throughout the musical world, regarded as an able teacher, whose words merit attention.

The motor car and the horse must both be handled with care, for iron and steel have their limitations of endurance just as have animal bone and sinews. Questions of cost must necessarily enter into the subject of the motor car. There is a tendency to expect a great deal more from the motor than from the horse.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Secretary Root's protection speech in Boston has created much interest here. It was predicted, in a general way, that he would defend the present tariff, but it was not known exactly how far he would go. Now that he has practically put himself on record as a "stand patter," the question is to what extent he represents the President.

LONDON, April 4. -- Mr. Wyndham, Chief Secetary for Ireland, speaking at Manchester last night, alluded in a distant manner to the possibility of a general election in the near future. He said he believed that when the bell rang for the next elections the Tory Party would be found ready and would again carry its flag to victory.

A.F. Nightingale, Ph.D., LL.D., is editor of the series of Twentieth Century Text-books to which this volume belongs. The series is intended to be representative of the newest methods and scholarship. We find, therefore, in Prof. Munro's little book many carefully chosen illustrations, an abundant apparatus of maps and genealogical tables, and several fac similes of contemporary documents.

The estimates of the Treasury Department based on the return, for nine months of the fiscal year are that the excess of receipts over expenditures will be for the complete year in the neighborhood of $50,000,000. Up to the 1st of April the surplus was a little short of $34,000,000, and the ratio of increase is slightly advancing.

ALBANY, April 3. -- The Assembly Committee on General Laws to-day reported favorably Mr. Remsen's bill "to prohibit bucket-shops and bucket-shopping," and it will come up next week for action by the Assembly.

It is quite safe to predict that the two volumes of "New Letters and Memorials" of Jane Welsh Carlyle, about to issue from The Bodley Head, will make a stir. The curiosity about Carlyle has never ceased, only subsided. The published statistics seem to show a marked revival of late years.

ALBANY, April 3. -- Fiscal Supervisor Harry H. Bender has had a narrow escape from being legislated out of office, and by his own initiative at that. One of the bills which he drafted was killed to-day by motion of Senator McEwan and so he was saved.

Prof. Paul S. Reinsch is completing the third volume of his series, in which "World Politics" and "Colonial Government," already published, are the first two numbers. The third will be "Colonial Administration," and will take up the methods through which the work of Colonial development is carried on.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3. -- The American Philosophical Society decided to-day to observe in January, 1906, the two hundredth anniversary of the birth of Benjamin Franklin, the founder of the society. A committee to arrange plans was appointed as follows:

G.P. Abbott of Emmanuel College, Cambridge, has completed his story of "A Tour in Macedonia." which represents part of an expedition carried out by him under the auspices of the University of Cambridge, with a view to studying the folk-lore of that country. The results of his researches, which have been issued by the University Press in England, will be published here next week by Longmans, Green Co.

BOSTON, April 3 -- The money market continues quiet and unchanged. Call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time loans, on collateral, 5@5 per cent.; time loans, on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 13@ 16 2-3 cents discount. Clearings, $22,790,674; balances, $1,553,309.

The stock market yesterday was sensational enough in its movements to suit even the most ardent lover of the sensational. It was the unexpected that was happening all the time. In the morning there was a severe decline all through the list under heavy liquidating and professional selling in which Southern Pacific, St. Paul, New York Central, and Pennsylvania were the principal sufferers.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Differences in the American National Red Cross Society will be carried to the annual international meeting at Geneva.

As the result of a complaint made by a man from Philadelphia, who alleges that he was cheated out of $560, Capt. Farrell and Detectives Conway, O'Neill, Kammer, and McCormick of the Old Slip Station raided an alleged poolroom late yesterday afternoon on the third floor of the Howard Building, at 176 Broadway.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 3. -- Mrs. Duncan Elliot arrived at her cottage in Believue Avenue this evening.

The volume on "Co-Education." edited by Alice Woods, is in preparation for publication in May by Longmans, Green Co. As Miss Woods says in the preface, the plan of educating boys and girls together is taking hold of the English nation. The volume is the outcome of a trip made by her to various parts of England in order to see what was being done for the advance of co-education in secondary schools.

"Weakness in the morning and greater strength, later in the day left the majority of representative stocks less than a point higher. There was an exceptional advance of 2 for Brooklyn Rapid Transit, which means nothing except to those who can see behind the blanket. The day's dealing's do not merit extended discussion.
ALBANY, April 3. -- Gov. Odell sent to the Senate these nominations:

Mr. Abbatt has had a happy and pious thought in bringing out a new edition of Winthrop Sargent's Life of Andre. The book was originally published forty years ago, and has now, we suppose, fallen quite out of currency, excepting for the special uses of historical investigators. It is worthy of a better fate and a wider audience.
Those who drove to the Speedway yesterday afternoon were agreeably surprised to find the road in good condition for fast work and a number of drivers ready and anxious for a brush.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The State Department has given notice that it is unable to comply with public requests for copies of the Review of the World's Commerce and of Commercial Relations of the United States, 1902. Congress did not make the usual appropriation, and the department has no edition for general distribution.

Announcement was made yesterday by President Gawtry of the Consolidated Gas Company that final arrangements had been made for centralizing the gas manufacturing plants now scattered throughout Manhattan. The proposed location of the new works is at Lawrence Point, on the Long Island shore of Hell Gate, and comprises about 300 acres.

Fiction and nature books are the great satandbys for the book stores at this season. "Fiction of all kinds is piling up on our tables de a matter of course," said a prominent Fifth Avenue bookseller. "The first hint of Summer always lets loose the floods of novels. But the nature books, the illustrated ones, I mean, are being bought up in a way that gladdens our hearts.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3.--Weakness was developed to-day in some of the inactive issues and in the bond department. Seattle and San Francisco Railway and Navigation first 5s sold at 48, six points below its last previous sale, on default in the April interest. United Railways 4s were down 1, Consolidated Traction of New Jersey 5s 1/2, Philadelphia Arctic gold 5s 1/2, and Indianapolis Street Railway 4s 3/4.
HARTFORD, April 3 -- Baron Speek von Sternburg, German Ambassador, was the guest of the Hartford Yacht Club at a reception and banquet at the Allyn House here this evening.

Prof. Edward Howard Griggs, whose loss still pains the Leland Stanford University, is one of the most popular lecturers of the day. He has an easy, flowing style, rich in imagery, full of allusions to history, literature, and art. Nor does his charm lie wholly in his winning voice and graceful presence.

Mrs. Frankland's book is a popular presentation in lively style of what the ordinary unscientific person should know of "bacteria as they immediately affect daily life. She has managed to invest her subject with astonishing interest and to produce a work that any sane man or woman can read without weariness.

In a volume or much charm and well bridled enthusiasm Mr. Edward Hutton writes of Italy as only a man can upon whom has been cast the spell of the poetic and artistic influence of the peninsula. If his book were a little more coherent in form, it could be placed side by side with Fuller's "The Chevalier of Pensieri-Vani " with much benefit to each.

His Majesty the German Emperor and King of Prussia has been pleased to command that those who send in reports should endeavor to write in a concise and clear style. His Majesty desires that in particular long-winded sentences, interpolated clauses, and verbs at the end of the sentences should be avoided.

BETWEEN what we know and what we do not know, the latter is in predominant quantity. It sounds paradoxical to insist that as man's culture increases all the more will he be conscious of his ignorance.

CINCINNATI, April 3. -- A new theatre which is to be erected at Fifth Street and Lawson Alley is understood to be intended for the Weber Fields syndicate. A man who is closely connected with the deal said to-day:

NEWARK, N.J., April 3 -- Bishop Warren and the Presiding Elders of the Newark Methodist Conference have been arranging the list of transfers and other changes. The list will include about sixty changes. The Newark district will have about eight, including new pastors for St. Paul's Church and the South Market Street Church of this city, and possibly the Ferry, Maplewood, and Verona Churches.

The late Mr. Anderson was the author of a work on architecture in Italy and a volume for the use of students on the special field of Renaissance architecture in the same favored land. The present work is founded on a course of lectures Mr. Anderson delivered in the Winter of 1896-7 at the School of Art in Glasgow on the history and development of architecture in Greece.

CHARLES SCRIBNER'S SONS are publishing this week the autobiography and letters of Sir A. Henry Layard, G.C. B., D.C.L., edited by William Napier Bruce. The long life of thin distingushed English diplomat, politician, and archaeologist is said to have offered material for a most entertaining narrative.

MAJOR HERBERT H. AUSTIN, a fine type of a thorough English soldier, in his volumes "With Macdonald in Uganda," describes the many hardships borne by him and his comrades in Africa. England always has her "little wars."

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Charming weather and a card that gave promise of excellent sport attracted the banner crowd of the meeting thus far to the races at Bennings to-day. The track was in fine condition, although a trifle lumpy. The going was altogether the best of the meeting. It was a bad day for the talent, not a single favorite winning, and five out of the six favorites being unplaced.

When the Manhattan Elevated Railroad passed into the hands of the Belmont syndicate on the stroke of 12 o'clock last Tuesday night, only a few persons, guests at an unusual dinner, knew that a symbolical transfer of the great property was taking place.
LONDON, April 4. -- The Sofia correspondent of The Times sends an account by an eye-witness of the recent attack on the village of Carbintzi.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Some reviewers of my novel, "Flowers of the Dust," in American newspapers, accuse me of taking an intolerant attitude toward the French people. I am said to represent them as "almost universally intolerant, ignorant, ill-mannered, and cruel." I submit that that statement is "flagrantly untrue, I will ask any right-minded critic if it is a just and fair estimate of the book.

IT IS Mr. 'Worsfold's wish that his book should present merely "an account of the main principles of literary criticism" and "illustrate these principles by passages from great writers." It is, in other words, an introduction to the study of literature, by no means technical; and intended for that ever-increasing world of readers who wish not merely to read but also to study books.

E.F. BENSON author of "Dodo" "The Vintage," "The Capsina," , is writing a new novel, as yet unnamed, the American bookrights to which have been secured by Harper Brothers. It will probably be published in the early Fall.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3. -- The proposed constitution drawn up by the managers and Captains and several graduate advisers to govern the athletic policy of Yale was submitted to-night to a mass meeting of the undergraduates. It was ratified after a warm discussion and some amendment.
Second Lieut. Edward O. Perkins, Fourth Cavalry, is dropped from the rolls of the army for desertion.

In presenting for public approval his plan for the erection of a municipal lighting plant Commissioner MONROE does wisely in not offering it in the guise of a moneymaking venture for the city. There has been much nonsense talked about the net profits of such ventures, and figures of doubtful accuracy have been compiled to show that the business of lighting is one in which the city may safely engage for profit.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 3 -- Trusts were the theme of President Roosevelt's speech at the banquet tendered him here this evening by the Milwaukee Merchants and Manufacturers Association. The President asserted his belief that remedies for trust evils can be found. He reviewed what has been done by his Administration to compel obedience of laws governing trusts and the new legislation enacted by the Fifty-seventh Congress.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 3. -- Considerable stir in social circles has been caused by the publication in a local paper of the following announcement:

Nina Estabrook is both the editor and the publisher of Paris World, an English illustrated magazine domiciled in Paris. Its March number contains an interesting article on "Avignon: The City of the Popes," by Henri Frantz, which is well illustrated by C. Bourget. A department called the "French Study Club" seems to us more interesting and important than some of the other features of this periodical.

ALBANY, April 3. -- Compromise bills intended to end the long warfare between the Board of Regents and the State Department of Education were introduced today by, Senator Stevens and Assemblyman Landon, Chairmen of the Education Committees of the Senate and Assembly. They are based on suggestions made by Regent St. Clair McKelway before the Senate Committee yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- Indictments have been found by the Grand Jury against leading operators on the Chicago Board of Trade on charges of operating bucket shops. The bills were voted on the testimony of Max J. Riese, an attorney, and William S. Skelly, who testified that they opened deals with the defendants on Saturday and closed them on Tuesday.

ALBANY, April 3. -- That Senator Platt is taking a hand in legislation in Albany is no longer open to question. Members of the Legislature now freely admit that they have received letters from the Senator expressing his views about various bills.

THE CURATOR of the Department of Ornithology of the University of Princeton has devoted his life to the study of birds, and the title of his volume." The Story of a Bird Lover," is most suggestive. You see at once the object of Mr. Scott's studies.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The importance of the investigation in to the Post Office scandals and the fear which is entertained of its expected revelations are shown by the efforts which have been made to have it stopped.

In the volume " The proofs of Life After Death " is to be found a sort of symposium of opinions on the topic, and various are the ideas presented. At least Mr. Robert J. Thompson is to be lauded for his industry in collecting men's ideas, as to what we know about immortality and the innumerable theories in regard to it.

M. Chapsal, writing of Chateaubriand In 1845, three years before the death of the author-diplomat, said: "He awaits tranquilly his death; he has put the last touches to his memoirs, which, according to the confidants of the great writer, form a work entirely unprecedented and which, for all future time, will be the despair of all memorialistes.'"

That Mr. ROOSEVELT should devote his first important speech to a recital of the events of the last two years bearing on what is known as the Monroe Doctrine is doubtless due partly to the extreme importance he attaches to that matter, and, second, to the fact that other subjects in recent history are not so attractive to him.

Another chapter to a very complicated international romance has been added by the announcement that the Duchesse de Dino had procured a separation from her husband, the Due de Dino, with a view to absolute divorce. The news was confirmed yesterday by Frederick Alien, a son-in-law of the Duchess.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 3. -- The Badger State gave President Roosevelt a hearty welcome to-day. His progress to this city was marked by a continuous ovation, which in no wise diminished when he arrived here. The first stop in the State was made at Madison, which the Presidential party reached at 4 o'clock this morning.

The Secretary of War descended far below his natural and accustomed level of candor and fairmindedness when in his Home Market Club speech he said that "the second Administration of CLEVELAND is not so completely forgotten yet" that the question of protection and free trade needs to be argued in this country.

In the present volume of this elaborate work we are treated to a survey of some of the most imposing country seats of England, with a multitude of pictures illustrating general effects and particular details. Most of the gardens are formal in character, and topiary features, statuary, pergolas and terraces, ironwork, and brickwork are abundantly represented.

In those chapters of "My Own Story" which appear in the April Atlantic Mr. J.T. Trowbridge writes with the becoming modesty which characterizes all his utterances about himself, but with sincerity and the never-failing charm that distinguishes this autobiography, of the literary influences of his young manhood.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 3 -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew delivered a eulogy on John Wesley before the Methodist Episcopal Conference here to-night, the occasion being the celebration of the bicentennial of Wesley's birth. The services were held in the Trinity Church. In his address Mr. Depew said:

A CURIOUS specimen of criticism of eighteenth century New England, written by an American, is to be published this Spring by Messrs. Little, Brown Co., in the diary kept by John Quincy Adams while reading law in the Newburyport office of Theophilus Parsons in 1787 and 1788.
Copyright. 1903, by John R Whitney. SUBJECT -- The Resurrection -- I. Cor., xv., 20-21, 51-58.

-- That thoroughgoing exponent of radical unionism, The Coast Seamen's Journal of San Francisco, has been moved by the frequent demands that troubles between employers and employes should be settled otherwise than by prolonged contests of strength that cause loss or suffering to thousands or millions not directly concerned, to ask irritably, "Who are the public?

John Corbin's little volume -- on "A New Portrait of Shakespeare," in which he gives the case of the Ely Palace painting as against that of the so-called Drocshout original, will appear April 7, with the imprint of John Lane. What the author wishes to show is that the Ely Palace portrait is the life picture of Shakespeare, while what is known as the "Droeshout original" is a fabrication; be gives the history of each.

THE three stories by Joseph Conrad in the volume called "Youth and Other Stories " are all of the sea, of strange lands, and of abnormal human beings developed under abnormal conditions. The author's exceptional power is manifest in two directions: in his ability to portray extraordinary scenery and in his equal ability to impress a character upon the credulity of his readers.

Mr. Cooke's foot is on his native heath again when, after a Iong period of "wandering in dry places," (comparatively so for him, as historiographer of Unitarianism in America.) he gets back to the Transcendentalists, whose field he has made so much his own by his assiduous and productive cultivation through a succession of careful and instructive books.

Judge Kirkpatrick. in the United States Circuit Court for the District of New Jersey, sitting at Newark yesterday, received the report of the receivers of the National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America, and in pursuance of this report entered a final decree of sale of all the properties of the asphalt companies.

ENGLISH, Ind., April 3.--A tornado that struck three miles west of here to-day Killed Mrs. George Cunninsham and crushed the skull of her ten-year-old son by blowing down the house. The path of the storm was 100 yards wide and a mile long. Three farm houses and all buildings in its path were destroyed.

Frank Pierce Hill, Librarian of the Brooklyn Public Library, aided by Barnum Lansing Collins of Princeton University has privately printed a linen-bound volume, well made, of 296 pages, with the title. "Book, Pamphlets, and Newspapers Printed at Newark, New Jersey, 1776-1900." It seems that Newark saw a century pass before a printing press was set up within its limits.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 3.--A telegram received here to-night from Capt. Johns of the steamship John J. Hill, who, with six of his crew was rescued by the steamship Excelsior, and is now at New Orleans, verifies the report that the Hill was lost, together with five of her crew, off the coast of North Carolina on the night of April 1.

Two persons lost their lives and many suffered severe injuries in a fire that started just before 8 o'clock yesterday morning in the basement of the six-story tenement at 127 Henry Street. The flames swept up the air shaft, past the first, second, and third stories, but spread on the floors above, where the destruction was complete.

Yon would be in error if you supposed that the Hebrides were rediscovered by Boswell and Dr. Johnson, but somehow there is a close association with these worthies and the islands. Anyhow, Mr. Goodrich-Freer in his "Outer Isles" informs us that there is some obscurity in England concerning them.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--Minister Bowen, the Venezuelan envoy, and the British and Italian Ambassadors and the German First Secretary held a conference at the British Embassy to-day. The meeting began at 11 o'clock, and lasted an hour find a half.

"The Bernards of Abington and Nether Winchendon" is the title of a work by Mrs. Sophia Elizabeth Higgins, which Longmans, Green Co. have in preparation. It will be complete in four volumes, Vols I. and II. to be issued shortly, including a history of the Bernards of Abington. Mrs. Higgins says in her preface:

Prof, patten's little book, which he modestly calls an essay, abounds in bold speculation and startling conclusions. Were it conveyed in some other form than that pecullar language of evolution, so clear and satisfactory to the evolutionary student, but so repellent to the ordinary untrained reader, the book would make a veritable sensation.

LONDON, March 27. -- Mr. Andrew Lang has been writing in The Morning Post concerning circulating libraries, and he inclines to the opinion that they are chiefly means for the dissemination of second and third rate novels and are therefore the enemies of literature.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 3 -- Argument was concluded in the Southern Pacific case to-day, and the matter was taken under advisement by Judge Lurton, who announced that he would file his decision at Louisville next Monday.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 4. -- The New York American League team played its final game against the Atlanta Southern League team this afternoon, winning by a score of 9 to 3. The game was distinctly a hitting one, Griffith and Wolf, who pitched for the New Yorks, yielding 11 hits, while Vittur, Hale, and Cole, who were in the box for Atlanta, allowed 13 hits.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- A letter written by Civil Service Commissioner Foulke to Charles B. Murray of the Cincinnati Price Current adds another chapter to the controversy raised by Mr. Murray regarding the result of an investigation into the statistical work of the Agricultural Department.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Sunday edition of your paper there was a letter signed Mrs. Mary E. Troutman, President of the Women's Health League. This letter asked for the co-operation of your paper in defeating a bill passed by the Legislature, and now awaiting the signature of the Mayor.

IT WAS very quiet in the Quick and Hurry lunch room. The air was heavy and there was that oppressive stillness that precedes the storm. It would soon be the fatal hour of noon, and the host with sandwich appetites would soon descend. It was the Ham Sandwich that broke the silence.

A good many people have estimated the probable output of anthracite coal for the current calendar year -- people, that is, possessing a fair degree of familiarity with the trade and ability to gauge probabilities with some degree of approximation. Their estimates run in the neighborhood of 60,000,000 tons, which would not seem to be a very excessive amount, although it must be presumed that demand will have much to do with regulating supply.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with what was said in your columns of the 27th inst. about "The Girl with the Green Eyes" permit me to ask some questions suggested by the statements of Prof. Brandler Matthews there quoted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As it is generally accepted as a matter of truth that your paper reaches the best thinking class of our population, permit me to call attention to a bin, drawn some time ago by the Corporation Counsel at the request of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, taking from the Board of Aldermen the power to confirm increases in salaries.

The musical season may be said practically to have ended last week with the last concert of the Philharmonic Society. There will be indeed a few more concerts of greater or less importance -- the last of the People's Symphony Concerts, and the annual performance of the People's Choral Union, for instance; there will be the benefit performance at the Opera House for Mr. Grau and a few belated recitals.

BERLIN, March 26. -- In the recent military debate in the Reichstag, the Socialist leader, August Bebel, called attention to a boot entitled "Jena and Sedan," in which the author, Franz Adam Beyerlein, makes startling assertions about the present condition of the German army. His conclusions will be of interest to those who suppose that the German army is the best in the world.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4. -- The baseball nine of the Annapolis Naval Academy sustained their first defeat of the season today, the victors being the team from Cornell University and the score 7 to 2. The visitors won in the first inning, scoring 5 runs by clever stick work and errors of the locals.

LONDON, April 4. -- Money was very strongly in demand until the end of March, and afterward became much easier, large sums being repaid to the Bank of England. The market hopes to succeed in getting free from the Bank during the next few weeks. Loan and discount rates have declined, the tendency of the market being more hopeful than for some time.

Holy Week is not very exciting from a social point of view. There is very little to chronicle. Entertainments are not to be given, not even meetings for bridge, which have been going on until Palm Sunday. Many take the time to make it the week of an ocean voyage, and the steamships yesterday had good bookings.

PARIS, April 4. -- It is reported that the project of American capitalists to purchase the Paris gas franchise is playing a considerable part in the present bitter political controversy before the Municipal Council aroused by the question of extending the franchise. Several newspapers have asserted that one of the leading companies seeking the franchise is American, and the Matin said Rockefeller interests controlled four-fifths of its capital.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 4.--To-night marked the close of one of the most strenuous and exciting Maycralty campaigns in the history of this city. Intense interest has been aroused, with the result that the vote to be cast Monday will by far be the largest ever recorded in a local municipal election.

The Macon (Ga.) Telegraph, which has been endeavoring to educate the Democratic Party up to the point of nominating a Southern man for President, now suggests as a suitable nominee Judge Georgo Gray of Delaware, Chairman of the Coal Strike Commission and formerly in the United States Senate.

A VICE MILBREY stirred, and her wide-open eyes were staring up at Percival Bines like a saloon sidedoor staring at a New York policeman on a Sunday morning. The amazement in them grew--she could not understand. She was up against it as she had never been before.

LONDON, April 4. -- The rates for money were easy in the market to-day, owing to the indebtedness to the Bank of England having been liquidated and to the prospects of a greater ease next week when dividends are released. Discounts were steady.

The exhibition of the sailing qualities of Shamrock III., as shown in her three tryIng-out spins on the Clyde last week, affords sufficient ground for the opinion expressed by yachtsmen here and abroad that the latest challenger for the America's Cup is the fleetest and most formidable yet built.

NEWPORT, April 4. -- Reginald C. Vanderbilt gave his bachelor dinner to-night to his ushers and other friends. The event, the first of the social festivities in connection with the coming marriage of Mr. Vanderbilt to Miss Cathleen Nellson, took place at Hill Top Cottage on Bellevue Avenue, the entire house being at the disposal of Mr. Vanderbilt and his friends for the occasion.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 4. -- Doerrhurs't, the Summer villa on the Shrewsbury which was the home of the late John B. Doerr, has been purchased by H.N. Baruch of New York, who heretofore has been a Summer resident of West End.
"I think it's dreadful!" said Perilla, "Poor Mr. Davis. I am so sorry for him:"

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer read with great interest an editorial in this morning's TIMES relating to an article that recently appeared in The North American Review referring in an unfriendly way to the Latin-American Republics.

A most interesting exhibition of Elizabethan relics was brought together by the Royal Geographical Society of London, in connection with the celebration of the tercentenary of the famous Queen's death. The exhibition was on view for several days in the Society's map room, and was open to the public, which availed itself largely of the privilege of viewing a number of objects which may never be brought together again.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an Irish-American, and as a member of the theatrical profession, I protest against the outrage recently perpetrated upon the "McFadden Row of Flats "Company, while filling a recent engagement in an up-town theatre. Firstly, as an Irish-American, I resent the attitude assumed by these ignorant ruffians as "champions of my race."

Yesterday's weekly Clearing House statement was unexpectedly bad, with a reduction in surplus reserves of over $4,000,000 and a loss in cash of more than $5,300,000. The figures follow: Loans decrease $614,300, deposits decrease $5,497,700, specie decrease $3,315,300, legal tenders decrease $209,200, reserves on all deposits decrease $4,130,073, reserves on deposits other than United States deposits decrease $4,298,025.

SING the song of the chorus man Why not? Along and forgot by the press agent and the interviewer, he makes his solitary way to the theatre each night and, twice weekly, afternoons, has any one ever seen his portrait adorning the pages of the illustrated papers? Is he asked for his indorsement of Somebody's toothwash or Anybody's toilet soap?

The current market will long be remembered as the small man's market -- a condition which ought to be made the subject of reflection on the part of those who have, at different times since the beginning of the present era of realty activity, stopped their friends on the street to say that "the corporations are doing it all."

To the Editor of The New York Times: A visit to the West Indies and near-by territory in South America is likely to develop contrasts with American institutions making the New Yorker regretful. But one chancing to drop into the capital of Demarara, Georgetown, is certain to be impressed with the uniform courtesy of employes of the street railway -- with its electrical installation, cars, and every essential (save department of employes) from the States.

IT WAS A lovely day in June, and the sea was calm off Block Island." That was the way Dr. J.H. Girdner began it. There seemed to have been no aggravation for it except that Ed Gilmore, coming into the Fifth Avenue Hotel, tired from counting the house after a matinee of "The Suburban" at the Academy, had sighed and said:

Squadron A has arranged the most ambitious polo programme for the coming season that its polo club has put forth since its organization about three years ago. Its policy of giving an open tournament, started last Fall, when a number of local clubs entered the events, will be continued this season, but it is the intention to give the big tournament in the Spring, and dates in May have been asked from the Polo Association.

WHAT develops in the Wabash Railway labor situation is of more importance than is popularly estimated in New York. The legal issues raised and determined in the courts, the dismissal of the corporation's prayer for a permanent injunction against the organization of its employes, presented features of interest enough to put aside in the public consideration what actually are the chiefly consequential factors.

ST. PAUL, April 4. -- President Roosevelt spent only three hours in this city to-day before being whisked over to Minneapolis in President Lowry's private electric car for an equally strenuous period in that city. The special arrived one minute ahead of schedule time, at 2:29 P.M., after an unoventful run from Winona, where a large crowd had greeted him.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 4. -- The Hillside Tennis and Golf Club will open its season on Saturday, April 11. George A. Chapman has offered a cup for the club championship, and former Mayor Alexander Gilbert again presents a cup for mixed four-somes. A Golf Committee Cup is a new trophy offered.

WHEN the subway builders get to work in lower Broadway a new method is likely to be introduced for supporting some of the tall buildings situated dangerously near the line of excavation. The engineers think they may have to hold up one or two skyscrapers by freezing the sand foundations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The advocacy of extensive canal improvements by THE TIMES has been a source of surprise to me for a long time past, for in spite of many editorial and other references I still fail to see why the people of this State are to be greatly helped. Permit me, therefore, to put this matter before you in the light in which many of us see it.

There is a charm in the enthusiasm with which a youthful mind appropriates as its own the impressions and ideas derived from matters familiar to the elders. Every youngster of any promise has a fine sense of discovery when he first strikes SHAKESPEARE, or BALZAC, or really begins to catch on to a theorist like HERBERT SPENCER, or a moralist like TOLSTOI.

HALIFAX. N.S., April 4. -- A dispatch from St. Pierre states the passage of the overdue steamers Burgandia and Notre Dame de Salut from France was the roughest ever experienced. One man was lost at sea and four others were drowned in the harbor of St. Pierre after the arrival of the vessels on Friday.

This week it has been as difficult as for a long time to find a ray of hope on Wall Street, or a ray of gloom outside Wall Street. If one can trust ancient and approved tests we are enjoying exceptional prosperity. But this has not prevented the week's registering new low records for securities.

"Colonist" writes to us from Punta Arenas, Straits of Magellan, contrasting the treatment of colonists in Chile and Argentina, respectively. We give the following extracts from his letter: "A few months ago the case of some Grimsby fishermen, who had been induced to emigrate to Chile, and who eventually returned to England reduced to abject poverty, excited some attention.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4. -- The session of the Newark Methodist Conference was held behind closed doors to-day. The morning session was devoted to the consideration of the report of the stewards and the discussion and arrangement of the members' relations to the conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent editorials on the question of taxation and the epistolary rejoinders inspired thereby have interested me exceedingly; so I ask your indulgence while briefly I endeavor to discuss some of the collateral Issues deducible from a theme always of such vital interest to both Government and people.

The two special races in the open games of Company E of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, aroused the most enthusiasm at the armory last night. The first of them, the forty-yard dash, resulted in a stirring finish between P.J. Walsh, Frank Rickert, and W. Edwards. At the start Rickert jumped into the lead, followed closely by Edwards, with Walsh a poor third.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- An amended charter of the United States Packing Company was filed with the Secretary of State here to-day. The new charter provides that the Board of Directors of the company may increase the capital stock of the company from $1,000,000 to $4,000,000. It also provided that the preferred stockholders shall receive 6 per cent. before any dividends are declared on the common stock.

Several leading London metal brokers have said that the rise in copper was justified, and that there was no surplus in the United States. At the same time it is a little difficult to believe that the statistical position has all of a sudden changed so entirely from what it was known to be a few weeks ago, before the American returns were suspended.

Athletes of Company G won the trophy presented by David Austin, a former Colonel of the Thirteenth Regiment, at the annual games of that organization, held at the armory, Niney-fourth Street and Park Avenue, last night, with a score of 27 points. Company B was second with 13 points. Company H and the Hosoltal Corps each scored 6 points, and Companies F and K each scored 1 point.

TO make President Loubet's visit to Algiers, which city he will reach April 14, more imposing, the French Government has decided that the President of the Senate. M. Fallleres, and the President of the Chamber of Deputies, M. Leon Bourgeois, shall accompany the chief of the State.

The special correspondence of THE NEW YORK TIMES from Ithaca, concerning the extent, causes, and consequences of the epidemic of typhoid fever in that city, led to conclusions which are confirmed in every essential particular by the observations of other competent students of the situation.
Manley McLennan have been appointed Duluth agents of the Aetna Fire Insurance Company of Hartford to succeed Little Nolan.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 4. -- With golf and polo tournaments and speedway races, April visitors to Lakewood will have plenty of out-of-door recreation. The Spring tournament of the Country Club of Lakewood, which opens April 16, will attract golfers from all parts of the country. And after the golf tournament comes the polo tournament on the Georgian Court grounds.

Deputy Police Commissioner Ebstein made an announcement yesterday afternoon which caused gloom and dejection among the concert hall keepers at Coney Island.
