Major Ebstein declared that during the coming Summer performers would not be allowed to appear on the stage on Sundays, and that the sale of beer or liquors in the conert halls on the Sabbath would be prohibited.
Corporation Counsel Rives is defending the city in a peculiar proceeding which shows how "squatter sovereignty" may be carried to the limit.

Within four days of his intended marriage. Oscar H. Steuer, a medical student, who had received a diploma from a veterinary school in Berlin, was found asphyxiated early yesterday morning in his room at 1,243 Lexington Avenue. A book and a newspaper were beside him on the bed. He was dressed completely, and it was apparent that he had turned on the gas accidentally.

Money nominally 6 per cent on call. Stocks weak. Yesterday's stock market opened weak under disappointment regarding confirmation of the various rumors of Friday regarding Southern Pacific, and was depressed further by a bank statement both bad in itself and contradictory of anticipations.

MADRID, April 4. -- The rioting here was continued until a late hour last night. The public joined the mob of students in parading the streets. A black flag was raised and there were cries of "Long Live the Republic!" and "Death to the Minister of the Interior!" The police charged with drawn sabres, and fourteen students and six policemen were wounded seriously.

NEARLY six months ago the Carnegie Institution decided to enter the field of botanical research to the extent of establishing a desert laboratory for the direct benefit of botanists interested in the study of vegetation peculiar to the arid regions of America and the ultimate benefit of dwellers in such districts.

BOSTON, April 4. -- Joshua J. Crane defeated C.E. Sands at court tennis to-day, successfully defending his title as amateur champion. The score in Crane's favor was 6 -- 1, 5 -- 6, 6 -- 5, 13 -- 11. Crane represents the Boston Athletic Association, while Sands hails from the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

The American players in this year's cable match with Great Britain have won again, thereby retaining the trophy given by Si George Newnes. Considering that they started yesterday's contest with a clear lead of two games, the match was won by a narrow margin.

WHILE it wouldn't be called a "Mothers' Meeting," in the modern eleemosynary acceptation of the word, yet it was a meeting of two mothers, matrons well gowned and groomed, and the meeting was in a cozy corner of a woman's clubroom, the confidences inspired by a cup of tea.

IN THE course of time the country grew so rich, in spite of all the efforts of the politicians to squander its money, that new ways had to be devised to spend the surplus. To help meet this emergency a member of Congress introduced a bill establishing a National theatre to give high art at low prices to the tolling masses and others.

DID I get April-fooled this year? I should say I did. Alonzo attended to it, and he did it thoroughly! It was to pay me up for the way I fooled him last year, and I dare say I did deserve it, but it made me cross just the same.

SOME people say that a man or animal who has fallen into bad habits -- gets so that he really takes a delight in evil ways -- can't be reformed," reminiscently observed Al Simmons, the old guide, to the party which had been talking over North Woods experiences. "I used to think that way myself. But the complete and thorough reform of Uncle Rufus Wilder's pet porcupine changed my mind.

BOSTON, April 4. -- The end of the week finds the money market quiet, with rates quite firm. Some surprise is occasioned by the fact that the tone is no easier. Rates are expected to rule lower within the next fortnight, but no tendency is noted in that direction as yet. Call loans, 5@6 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is It not time for a check to the lawless aggressions of the Post Office Department on the rights and liberties of the American public? There seems to be nothing which that department considers desirable that it does not feel free to enact into law by its own prerogative in case Congress fails to agree with it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A vast amount of criticism has been made on the transit system of New York city but little has been said about the suffering of commuters on the northern railroads from One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street.

A reward of $100 was offered in Chicago for the return of a lost white English setter, " valued more for his intelligence than for his pedigree," but at latest accounts it had failed to restore him to his owner.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Haste in voting true bills yesterday against prominent Board of Trade firms on charges of bucket shopping led to an investigation of the action of the Grand Jury to-day, and caused the State's Attorney to interfere with the return of the indictments.

PARIS, April 4. -- The body of Count Zborowski of New York, who was killed Wednesday in an automobile accident near Nice, arrived here to-day and was placed in the Chapel of the American Church, in the Avenue de l'Alma. The funeral service will be held Monday, and the remains will then be sent to Melton-Mowbray, England, fur burial.

AS in famous paintings the color and glow of the overcolors is due to the first coating placed on the canvas, so in the decoration of a room, the glow or background is derived from its "underneath," or floor covering. Whether it be a carpet, filling, parquet, or stained flooring, matting or rug, the backing should be chosen with the same care and knowledge that is usually bestowed on the draperies and furniture.

LONDON, April 4. -- There are so many stars of the first magnitude in the political firmament just now that people are getting somewhat bewildered as they turn their admiring gaze from one to the other.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4. -- The Essex County Grand Jury completed its labors today and made a presentment against the Board of Street and Water Commissioners. The Commissioners are censured for not having taken necessary steps to compel the safeguarding of the Clifton Avenue crossing of the Lackawanna Railroad prior to the trolley car accident of Feb. 19, in which nine High School pupils, lost their lives.

The fight to prevent Klaw Erlanger from building an "ornamental projection" extending four feet beyond the building line of the New Amsterdam Theatre, on Forty-second Street, was continued yesterday. Mayor Low was served with an injunction which will prevent his approval of the ordinance allowing the "ornamental projection" to be constructed.

COL. DAN LAMONT presents a rather new type of patriot hurrying home from Egypt to pay his taxes. Those who know him assert that patriotism and humor are his long suits. Once, while at the White House, a reporter ran across Col. Lamont banding over an old yellow paper and laughing until the tears rolled down his cheeks.

Another attempt is being made to raise to an exaggerated extent the price of copper on the very large deliveries last year. What will be the result of such a policy? Consumers will return again to their old system of living from hand to mouth, and they can do it much more easily, as they are provided with stock in hand bought at the low price of 1902.

BERLIN, March 26. -- The news of the coming visit of the German Crown Prince to Milet comes just at a time when a report of the excavations made by Germany on the site of this ancient city of Asia Minor is made public. The work was begun in 1889 under the management of Director Theodor Wiegand, who represents the German Royal Museums.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 4. -- Walter Liginger, President of the Amateur Athletic Union, to-day offered the State Board of Agriculture the championship athletic games of that organization as a feature of the State Fair. The board discussed his proposition, and, while not rendering a decision, the sentiment was to accept the offer if the Legislature, which is now in session, allows the board enough money to provide additional features for the fair week.

THE first two days of the week were devoted at the Lotos Club to ladies' days. There will be a ladies' day at the New York Athletic Club on the 11th, and the Players will have its regular ladies' day on Shakespeare's birthday. But this feature has fallen into disuse in New York.

It is the Paris Temps that warns M. COMBES that he must riot turn the Concordat into a "Discordat." But all the most weighty and conservative organs of French opinion seem to agree with it that M. COMBES has pushed the contest between the republic and the Vatican to a length to which the best French opinion will hardly sustain him in going.

Fencers from New York, Philadelphia, and Boston will be busy during the coming week preparing for the annual National championship tournament, which will be held on Friday and Saturday evenings, April 24 and 25, at the New York Athletic Club. The preliminary bouts to select the eligible competitors will be held this week.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 3. -- Father John of Kronstadt has refused to accept honorary membership in the Council of the University of Dorpat, to which he was elected with the view of appeasing the wrath of the Clerical Party at the election of Count Tolstoi thereto.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Root, in his recent tariff speech, basis his argument on his first statement which is as follows: "First -- That the principle of protection should be maintained. * * * The second administration of Cleveland is not so completely forgotten yet that that question needs to be argued in this country now."

DURHAM, N.C., April 2. -- A chance visitor to the quaint old town of Salem in North Carolina would be impressed immediately upon alighting at the small shanty that serves for a station with the fact that he was in a very unusual place. He could recognize something in the atmosphere and surroundings of the little Moravian settlement which would mark it apart from other Southern towns of the conventional type.
SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, April 4. -- Secretary Moody and his party left here this morning to travel overland to Ponce, where they are due to-night.

THERE was a time when Eugenia reckoned time backward and forward as other people do, but that was before she went into society. After that the Christian era seemed a matter of comparative insignificance, and she revised dates on the basis of her own private calendar.

IN "The Taming of Helen," which Henry Miller produced last Monday at the Savoy, there is a touch of satire much of which deals with life behind the scenes. In the first and second acts, however, allusions to society provide some bright spots in the text.
PARIS, April. 4. -- The horse show has attracted many Americans here, but the weather, which suddenly turned much colder, still keeps Paris in a state of Wintry desolation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to an article in yesterday's issue of your paper under title of "City Employes' Pension," by one J.H. Leon Lauser, in which he gives six objections why said bin should not pass, I desire to put the matter squarely before the public.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 4. -- New York capital is seeking investment in the hotel field in this city. Agents for several metropolitan syndicates are looking over the ground and securing options on desirable hotel sites. A Mr. Baker, the attorney for one of these syndicates, has selected a site, but its exact location is kept secret.

YOU wouldn't, perhaps, think that such a prosaic individual as I had ever had a romance," said the young stock broker as be lifted a battered old coin that hung to the watch-chain spanning his ample waistcoat.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Austrian Minister has announced that in May an international shooting match with army rifles, for young men, will be held under the auspices of the Fgyetemi Athletikai Club at Budapest. This is to be the first competition of the kind ever held. The first prize will be 5,000 kronen and a Bold medal.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 4. -- Capt. John Bennett, aged ninety, the oldest resident of this place, was killed to-day while moving a load of furniture to North-port, where he was to live with his son Frank. He was riding on the loaded wagon when it struck an obstruction in the road and he was jolted off.

"The New West has grown out of its dialects, its red shirts, its mountain primroses. It has its golf links, its craze for grand opera.-its chauffeurs. Strange that these things never figure between book covers" -- From a recent literary criticism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You certainly deserve, credit for the fair and unbiased stand you have taken in regard to the unfortunate conditions at Ithaca. The State authorities have done their duty, and have relieved the situation by taking, prompt action.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:
Capt. Arthur W. Yates, Quartermaster, will make not to exceed one visit monthly to Boston on official business.

It may happen, of course, that Winter wheat will yet have its ups and downs, that it will yet come under the influence of the professional reporter upon the crop, whose interests are not always identical with those of the farmer, and whose views do not always run in close harmony with the facts.

MISS VIRGINIA POPE, the bird specialist, tinds a fund of interest in the study of parrot nature. Among the human traits which make these wise birds interesting she finds a sense of humor, an intents love of approbation, and an obstinacy which at times surpasses the achievements of the most stubborn child.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., April 4. -- The election of Elders occupied to-day's first session of the New York East Conference of Methodists. A warm discussion arose over the motion of Presiding Elder Montgomery to pass Filoteo A. Taglialatela, an Italian mission worker in New York, up to effective elder's orders, despite the fact that he was deficient in one study.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On March 2, 1903, the Hon. Charles P. McClelland introduced in the Senate bill No. 508, (Int. 461.) entitled "An Act to Enable the City of Yonkers to Erect a City Hall and Purchase the Necessary Land Therefor, and to Provide for the Issue of Bonds for the Payment Therefor."

POSTON, April 4. -- The National Woman's Christian Temperance Union announces that Mrs. Mary G. Stuckenberg, Superintendent of the department of temperance and labor, has gone to Bremen, Germany, as a representative from Massachusetts to the Temperance Congress, soon to be held at Bremen.

ST. LOUIS, April 4.--After four months of controversy between the employes of the Wabash Road and the officials of that system, during which, recently a strike was prevented only by an injunction, the differences were finally adjusted, and the controversy settled this evening.

Side Lights on the Balkan Problem. Among those periodicals of revolution or reform which do an immense amount of missionary work among thinking people -- The Anglo-Russian. The Finland Bulletin, Free Russia, -- is Pro Armenia, issued twice a month in Paris under the direction of G. Clemenceau, Anatole France, Jean Jaures.

RUTLAND, Vt., April 4. -- The damage suit of the F.R. Patch Manufacturing Company against Protection Lodge No. 215, Independent Association of Machinists, was decided to-day, the jury returning a verdict in favor of the manufacturers, after having deliberated twenty hours. The company sued for $10,00 damages, alleged to have been suffered as the result of a strike of the machinists some time ago.
EVERY member of the family except the mother voted for the flat at the cornor of columbus Avenue. she said she would not have there on account of the noise from the elevated trains.

Few records were lowered last night by the athletes competing in the forty-third games of the Seventh Regiment at its armory. Sixty-seventh Street and Park Avenue. It was a night of fine and spirited attempts to overcome the marks that have been set by the foremost men in the country. There was the keenest sort of enthusiasm on the part of the spectators.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, March 26. -- The completion of the greater part of the new low-grade ore-carrying branch of the Lake Shore south from this city has made possible an achievement of interest throughout industrial circles everywhere. The long-prophesied 100-car trains, drawn by one locomotive, are now leaving the northern terminal.

The European position of iron and steel appears to be gradually strengthening. The German works, which have for months been aggressive competitors for export business, are full up with orders for near deliveries, are refusing fresh orders where shortness of time is the essence of the contract, and have further advanced their prices, which are gradually getting within measurable distance of those named by some British works.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Despite the unseasonable weather, a tremendous crowd attended the races at Bennings to-day. An excellent card developed some fine sport, notwithstanding a very heavy track due to last night's rain. The talent was happy, as three favorites and two heavily backed second choices won.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- First Lieut. Boss Reese and Frank Nickerson, Philippine scouts, have been recommended by the Commanding General of the Division of the Philippines for commissions in the regular army, in recognition of their participation in the fight with San Miguel's forces last month in which the Filipino leader was killed.

DANDELION salad is now in full season and can be bought at most of the stores where vegetables are sold or dug where there is short sward or rough, unimproved land with the herbage not too rank. Like grapes that make the choicest brands of wine, the best dandelion grows on thin soil where there is a stony substratum.

GOUROCK, Scotland. April 4. -- The Shamrock III. left here, this morning for Weymouth in tow of the Erin. She will return to the Clyde in the middle of May, when she will be jury rigged. The challenger will sail for America at the end of May, about a fortnight earlier than originally intended.

HAVANA, March 28. -- Since Cuba's separation from Spain the titles of nobility, once fairly common, are not so much in evidence. There were not as many Counts and Marquises as our South has Colonels and Majors, still there was a goodly number, and the titles were sanctioned not only by usage but by royal decree.

Highway robbery in broad day light on Centre Street within easy sight of the walls of the Tombs Prison is what occurred yesterday, according to Warren Smith, a messenger boy, who says he was forcibly recieved by three men of $1,380, all but $20 of the money he had just drawn from bank for his employers, Sargent Co., manufacturers of hardware at 151 Leonard Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your able editorials relative to water supply for New York you assume forty gallons of water per capita as ample and proper and all beyond this as probable waste.

TROY, April 4. -- Justice Betts to-day handed down a decision quashing the writ of habeas corpus, with costs, in the case of Edward Hines against James Thompson, a wealthy will owner of Valley Falls. The proceeding was brought by Hines to compel the defendant to restore to him his daughter, Mary, who ran away to marry Hines, but who immediately afterward returned to her parents' home.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 4. -- James P. Sanders, who was admitted to the bar in 1840, and who to-morrow celebrates his eighty-fourth birthday, received a remarkable ovation in the Supreme Court to-day. Upon entering Justice Keogh bowed to him, and as the old man stepped to the bench to shake hands, the Justice abruptly stopped the hearing of the cause that was before him.

The decision of the Consolidated Gas Company, now announced, to remove all its gas works to Lawrence Point, on Long Island, affords matter for public congratulation. It releases, for more profitable and agreeable occupancy than is now possible, very considerable areas. It is thus equivalent to an addition of those areas to the habitable surface of Manhattan Island.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wonder how many people who attend banquets or large dinner parties given at hotels and restaurants pay any attention to the kind of wine which they receive in case they order individually after the dinner is over? I am of the opinion that there are very few.
NEWPORT, April 4. -- Mrs. W. Rogers Morgan and the Misses Morgan arrived from New York this afternoon.

To the Editor of The York Times: It is not altogether surprising that the public obtains a very unfavorable impression of Wall Street methods from such developments as those ou the past few days in the cases now pending involving stockjobbing operations in stock of the Southern Pacific Railway and the Metropolitan Street Railway.

"Hey, Rube!" the cry of the circus man when he finds himself in need of the assistance of his fellows, has been adopted as the battle cry of the liquor dealers of New York in their rage and alarm at the high license law of the Republican Legislature, approved by the Governor of the State.

This being Holy Week, the period of greatest depression during the season in affairs theatrical, the offerings at the playhouses, with one exception, are lacking in novelty to New Yorkers. The managers, however, are not prepared to let affairs drift along until the beginning of Summer marks the customary closing time.

ALTHOUGH they have pleaded to the indictment charging them with manslaughter for the recent killing of a dozen schoolchildren at a Lackawanna crossing in Newark, no one really expects to see President E.F.C. Young and the Directors of the North Jersey Traction Company ever put to trial.

IT TAKES a very little thing to disconcert a minister, even though he has had years of training in his profession. From his perch in his pulpit he has a good view of nearly every person in the congregation; not only of their faces, but of their hands, and often of their feet, when they are very near him.

Fruitless search for the body of Adolphe Openhym, who is believed to have leaped from High Bridge last Monday, went on all day yesterday and far into the night along the Harlem River, and at dusk several heavy charges of dynamite were exploded over the water just north of the bridge, in the hope that the shock would cause the body to rise to the surface.

Collision with a car at Broadway and Thirty-second Street at 9 o'clock last evening frightened the horses that were drawing a carriage in which were Mr. and Mrs. W.A. Rothschild, and they ran down Broadway. In the collision the driver, Sidney Short, of 103 East Sixty-third Street, was thrown from his seat.

Travel was comparatively light on the Sixth Avenue elevated railroad at 12:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a frail-looking woman, clad wholly in black, who was later identified as Mary McGuire, twenty-three years old, a chambermaid, address not ascertained, entered the northbound station at Fiftieth Street.

BOSTON, April 4. -- Dr. Richard Hodgson, Secretary of the American branch of the Society for Psychical Research, has received a letter from Dr. I.K. Funk of New York, in regard to the "widow's mite" coin, the possession of which a spiritualistic medium revealed to Dr. Funk, by whom it had been forgotten for nearly ten years.

In the multiplication of feminine sodalities throughout the country having one aim or another and called by various name's there seems sometimes a lack of judgment in their creation. They are oftentimes called into existence without sufficient cause and do not meet the "long-felt want" which, according to a rhetorical formula now growing obsolete, was once supposed to exist for almost everything.

ALBANY, April 4. -- The new excise law is now in force. Commissioner Cullinan has sent copies of it throughout the State, and any person desiring to engage in the liquor business to-day, or to renew a license, must pay the increased rate.

Following his denial on Thursday of a motion for the dismissal of the charges of oppression preferred against Police Captain Patrick Summers and Patrolmen Thomas Lynch, James Gillen, and John Green, all of the Hamilton Avenue Station, Brooklyn, Supreme Court Justice Gaynor, sitting as a committing Magistrate, yesterday held the four accused men for trial in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn.

OMAHA, April 4. -- From information received here to-day by the Canadian Government agent, W.V. Bennett, it appears that the talk of the extension of the Soo that into the Dakotas and Nebraska is not idle, but that work will actually begin during the present year. The scheme is said to be retaliation for the building of spurs of the Great Northern Railroad into Canadian Pacific territory.

The Pleasure Drivers' Association of Brooklyn has decided to hold a series of four races at its Spring matinee, to be held on the Parkway track Decoration Day, May 30. The events will be the best two in three half-mile beats, for which prizes will be awarded. The quarterly meeting of the association will be held Tuesday evening.

PITTSBURG, April 4. -- All of the primary arrangements for the wedding of Miss Alice Thaw of this city to the Earl of Yarmouth have been completed, the ceremony to be held in the Calvary Episcopal Church on April 27.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Can Mayor Low be re-elected?" is a question that seems to agitate the public mind to a considerable extent just at present, at least It Is an absorbing and most Interesting topic of discussion among those who are opposed to Tammany's return to power.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 4. -- Sixty days in the workshop in the County Jail at Bridgeport was the sentence Judge Charles B. Burns imposed in the Greenwich Borough Court this afternoon upon Charles G. Quintard of Sound Beach, whom he had found guilty of willfully neglecting and refusing to support his wife.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A report to the Navy Department, dated to-day, from Commander Turner of the cruiser Atlanta, at Santo Domingo City, tells of another repulse to the Government troops, who made an attempt to take the city from the revolutionists. Commander Turner was again compelled to land bluejackets to protect the United States Consulate.

The Central Federated Union met yesterday in Grand Central Palace, instead of its regular headquarters, in order to show its sympathy for a labor fair that is now in progress there to raise funds for a Socialist newspaper. It was expected that the meeting would be brief, but it lengthened out until long past the usual hour.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., April 5 -- President Roosevelt is the guest of Sioux Falls and will remain so until 9:10 o'clock to-morrow morning. His special train arrived here about 8 o'clock this morning. He was met by a delegation headed by Mayor G.W. Burnside and State Senator A.H. Stites. Senator Kittridge also greeted him.

CINCINNATI, April 5. -- The local elections in Ohio to-morrow will be especially important, because of the new municipal code enacted recently by the Legislature, which recognizes every municipality. There will be no officers holding over, and for this reason the party advantages, secured will be greater than heretofore at April elections.

Last year Mr. ROOSEVELT set out on his tour of speaking with the apparent purpose of satisfying that portion of his supporters who were restive under the exactions of our very high tariff, and he proposed a non-partisan commission to guide Congress in the reductions which he saw should be made.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 5 -- Justice White has confirmed the report of Hubert C. Minard, the referee who passed upon the accounts of Edward L. Koons, temporary receiver of the Buffalo Racing Association. This is the association which owns the Kenilworth race track. It went into dissolution proceedings a short time ago.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 5 -- Columbia defeated Vale last night in the water-polo contest at the Sportsmen's Show by a score of 6 to 1, the Yale team being completely outclassed and Columbia having an easy time of it. Abbott of Columbia proved the star, making five goals for his team, Camp making the other one.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the present occurrence of at least one case of undoubted rabies in this city, and of the death of a child in consequence of the bite of that diseased animal, it is eminently desirable that every reasonable measure should be taken for the prevention of other similar cases, and also for the quieting of the public alarm.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 5 -- A freak racing boat, and a novelty in this country, is to be used on Long Island Sound during the coming season. It will be seen in all the principal regattas, and doubtless will attract much attention. Thomas F. Smith of Chicago is the designer, and he is now building the boat for Palmer Brothers at their factory on the shores of the Mianus River at Coscob.

Commissioner WOODBURY'S plan of concentrating the fish peddlers under the arches of the Williamsburg Bridge is working well. No doubt it is less convenient for many patrons of these vendors than when they came to their doors; but the public health and the cleanliness of streets are considerations which should not be lost sight of.

The Sunday newspapers printed labor news improving the outlook. The Wabash strike is settled satisfactorily to both sides: spokesmen of both attest the renewal of relations with mutual good feeling. This is as it should be. The strikers can no longer feel that the law favors their employers.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5.--Most of the Methodist churches in the city were occupied to-day by visiting clergymen of the Newark Methodist Conference. The services in the Halsey Street Church were begun with a love feast that was conducted by the Rev. Dr. Richard Van Horne.

After giving a list of places in the borough where, as he declared, poolrooms were maintained, the Rev. Dr. Cortland Myers declared from his pulpit in the Baptist Temple, Brooklyn, last night that the District Attorney was asleep and that the police seemed to be "protecting" instead of trying to put a stop to the operations of the gamblers.

EAST ORANGE N.J., April 5 -- The new course of the Arsdale Golf Club of East Orange will be opened on Memorial Day. The work on the course is being done under the supervision of "Tom" Wells, the club's professional. The addition being built to the clubhouse includes men's lockers, shower bath, and men's smoking room.

LONDON, April 6.--It is reported, Says the Sofia correspondent of The Times, that the greater part of the district of Okhrida is practically in a state of insurrection. It is stated that at the towns of Okhrida, Prilip, and Krushevo the shops are closed.
James R. Keene at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday talked again as to his reasons for making fight on the Harriman interests in the Southern Pacific Company. He said:

Three detectives from the West Forty-seventh Street Station, McGee, Hore, and Dukeshire, acting under instructions from Capt. Dillon, visited "The Spiritualist Science Institute," at 331 West Fifty-first Street, last night, and after an investigation made a report to Capt. Dillon of what they had seen.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 5. -- Owing to the disturbed conditions throughout the anthracite coalfields the district officers of the mine workers have been compelled to ask President Mitchell to come to this city. District President Nichols had a long consultation with other officers here yesterday and then talked with President Mitchell over the long-distance telephone at Indianapolis.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5 -- Oscar Barcliffe, the engine driver whose train was in collision with the trolley car of the Clifton Avenue line on Feb. 19, when nine High School pupils were killed and almost three score injured, has recovered physically, but his mind is gone, at least temporarily.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- In a sermon to-day on "The Fulfillment of the Protestant Religion" the Rev. Oscar B. Hawes of the Germantown Unitarian Church came to the support of the Rev. Dr. Rainsford, whose sermon at St. Stephen's Church has caused so much discussion. In the course of his address Dr. Hawes said:

On Friday last the "Municipal Voters League" of Chicago issued its annual report for the guidance of the voters in the election that occurs to-morrow, signed by the President of the league, Mr. CHARLES R. CRANE, a gentleman of high character and of ability, well known in this city.

Michael Fitzgerald, an elderly man, who said he was the keeper of a livery stable at 548 West Thirty-sixth Street, entered the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last evening and told Sergeant Mott that he had just buried his son Thomas in Calvary Cemetery and that he had been thinking it ought not to have been done, as he wanted the matter investigated.

Jacob Scott, thirty-five years old, of 5 West Third Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Cornell in the West Side Court yesterday morning charged with being a suspicious person by Policeman Mangin of the West One Hundredth Street Station. At the request of the policeman the hearing was set for this morning, and the prisoner was remanded to the One Hundredth Street Police Station.

The examination of George E. Mills, law partner of Dr. R.C. Flower's son Jewell Flower, who was arrested Friday in a Park Row restaurant, charged with having attempted to bribe Detective Sergeant Brindley and Assistant District Attorney Garvan to turn over to him six indictments and all other charges against Dr. Flower, was held by Magistrate Pool, in the Tombs Court, yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, April 5 -- "Tom" Alien, retired heavyweight champion pugilist of the world, who for the past twenty-five years haS conducted a small saloon here, died to-day from general debility. He was born in Birmingham, England, April 22, 1839.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5 -- Joseph S. Mundy, builder of engines and hoisting machinery, at 22 Prospect Street, offered yesterday to meet his employes half way in their demands for higher wages and other concessions and told them that in the event of their refusal they were at liberty to strike.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The growth in the exportation of manufactures from the United States and their distribution to various countries are discussed in much detail in a monograph prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, for publication in the April Summary of Commerce and Finance.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- "No other rabbi has ever achieved what Dr. Wise achieved for Israel's sacred cause," said the Rev. Dr. Joseph Krauskopf to-day in his concluding Sunday lecture this season before the Keneseth Israel Congregation. Dr. Krauskopf is the recently appointed Director General of the Isaac M. Wise Memorial Fund, and is bending all his energies to the completion of the $500,000 endowment for the Hebrew Union College.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 5. -- Mrs. Louise Van Weik was the granddaughter of the late Bishop R. Ames of Maryland, at one time a prominent Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, and daughter of the late Capt. Edward R. Ames, United States Army. She was about thirty-five years of age.

At a meeting of delegates from the various Harlem River rowing clubs, held at the house of the Metropolitan Rowing Club, Macomb's Dam Park, yesterday afternoon, it was decided to hold the annual water carnival on Sunday, May 10, instead of on May 17, as originally proposed. Two Commodores and thirteen Fleet Captains, one each of the latter from each club represented, were appointed to direct the water parade, the full list being as follows:
SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., April 5 -- This was a day of great interest to the delegates attending the New York East Conference, which, is being held in this city.
PEKING, April 5 -- The officials promise the foreign Ministers that the indemnity bonds will soon be signed.

Handball experts are anxiously awaiting the result of the earnest efforts now being made to bring about an international contest between "Mike" Egan of Jersey City and Timothy Twohill of Kanturk, Ireland. Twohill is the handball champion of Ireland, and as Egan is looked upon as the best expenent of the game on this side of the Atlantic, a match between them should prove to be unusually interesting.

"Little Italy" was roused to a pitch of excitement bordering on frenzy yesterday morning by a fire which started in the heart of the Harlem quarter, and for a while threatened to wipe out an entire block, so fierce were the flames. Three alarms were rung in and there were several rescues by policemen and firemen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At this time, when public attention is peculiarly directed to public morals, would it not be wise to break up if possible the centres of youthful corruption -- in the shape of street dice throwing and incipient gambling?

MOBILE, Ala., April 5 -- A gathering of 2,000 persons saw the New York American League baseball team defeat a picked nine of the City League here this afternoon by the score of 8 to 0. The weather was somewhat raw, but the visitors did not seem to mind it, and evidently enjoyed the game after their trip from Atlanta.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Frank Buchanan, who is leading the bridge and iron workers in their struggle with the American Bridge Company, predicted a general labor war throughout the country in an address to-day before the Chicago Federation of Labor. He said:
LONDON, April 6. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times says the revised American commercial treaty with China, which contains sixteen articles, is now being negotiated.

Mrs. Louise Ames Weik, also known as Mrs. Van Weik, daughter of the late Capt. Edward R. Ames, United States Army, and granddaughter of the late Bishop R. Ames of Massachusetts, committed suicide yesterday in the Hotel Washington, Jersey City, by shooting herself through the heart. A few weeks ago she secured a Dakota divorce from Edward W. Wolfbauer, a civil engineer, believed to reside in this city and said to be an Austrian Baron.

BUFFALO, April 6 -- A local newspaper this afternoon published a story in which it was alleged that Arthur R. Pennell, who was killed in an automobile accident on March 10 and was afterward officially declared to be the chief suspect in the Burdick murder case, was a defaulter to the extent of from $150,000 to $200,000.

-- As was said by the President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in the letter which we published yesterday, there would be practically no danger of the communication of rabies from one dog to another if the existing law forbidding the appearance of the animals in the streets unless held by a short leash were strictly enforced.

NEWARK, N.J., April 6 -- More than 100 machinists employed at the hoisting engine works of J.S. Mundy, at 22 Prospect Street, quit work at 1 o'clock to-day, notwithstanding the appeal he uttered on Saturday. The men were ordered out by Delegate Couselman of the Machinists' Union after a conference with Mr. Mundy this morning.

Money easier, 2 1/2 to 7 per cent. on call. Stocks irregular. Yesterday's stock market affords a good although not very necessary lllustration of the disappointment awaiting those who reckon upon sure things in Wall Street. Nothing can be more certain than that the bank statement was adapted to make borrowers and stock operators thoughtful upon the prospects of this year's money market following the precedent of relaxation from now on.

There could scarcely be a more pathetic figure than that which is now presented by the Czar of all the Russias. He is an intelligent man and a humane man. He is, in effect, the "benevolent despot" so often invoked by dreamy persons as the remedy for the evils of more advanced societies than that which he represents.

The St. Andrew's Golf Club, near Chauncey, Westchester County, will open its season on Saturday with an eighteen-hole handicap competition for two cups given by the President, one being for the lowest gross score and the other for the lowest net score. The first monthly handicap event will be on April 18.
Henry Hellman has sold for Joseph Margolies the lot, 50 by 100.8, on the south side of Nineth Street, 150 feet east of Amsterdem Avenue.

PARIS, April 6 -- The Dreyfus affair was brought up in the Chamber of Deputies to-day by M. Jaures, (Socialist,) in the course of a discussion of the validity of the election of M. Syveton. (Nationalist Republican.)

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 6 -- The New York Methodist Episcopal Conference passed a resolution to-day to appoint a committee of five to confer with a like committee of the New York East Conference for the purpose of rearranging the boundaries between the two.

NEWARK, N.J., April 6 -- The forty-sixth annual session of the Newark Methodist Conference, in the Halsey Street Methodist Church, was adjourned this afternoon after the announcement of the appointments for the year. The Rev. T.P. Frost, pastor of St. Paul's Church, this city, was retained, and he was compelled to withdraw his acceptance of a call to Baltimore.

CINCINNATI, April 6 -- Another sweeping victory was won by the Republican organization, dominated by George B. Cox, to-day, the entire ticket, headed by Julius Fleischmann, candidate for re-election as Mayor, being elected.

"Cheerful in Adversity" was the motto of the band of first nighters that gathered yesterday to see "Spotless Town." The gloom of Holy Week has fallen upon the theatrical world, and nowhere is it felt more keenly than in the popular home of Irish melodrama. This is perhaps why the Fourteenth Street Theatre secured the signal novelty of the week.

NEWARK, N.J., April 6 -- It was reported here to-day that negotiations are pending for the formation of a large holding company to take over all the North Jersey trolley companies, together with the New Jersey electric light and gas companies.

SOUTH NORWALK, conn., April 6 -- Presiding Elder Chadwick made the announcement to-day that the business of the New York East Conference probably cannot be concluded to-morrow, and the appointments of ministers may not be announced until Wednesday.

The monograph just issued by the Treasury Department showing the volume and distribution of the exports of manufactures from the United States is probably the best answer which could be given to the recent flood of Administration literature designed to show how essential to the National prosperity is the maintenance of the present tariff, with its highly, and in many cases absurdly, protective duties.

Corporation Counsel George L. Rives was asked yesterday to explain the pending Rapid Transit bill, which has been criticised severely at Albany on the ground that it is designed to give undue privileges to the Belmont underground railroad syndicate.

It appears from all the recent disclosures on the subject that we are suceeeding to the position in the affairs of the Far East which Great Britain for so long held and then in part abdicated. It was, and it is, a noble position for a great nation to hold. It is the position of a "fair field and no favor."
How far can the leaders of the trades unions carry their plan of securing a monopoly of employment with safety to the real interests of the members of the unions?

Yesterday's stock market was largely dominated by the developments, expected and actual, in the Union Pacific-Southern Pacific dispute. In the early trading, aided by higher prices sent over from London, followed by buying from that source to a total of probably 20,000 shares, the market was strong and higher under the influence of purchases for both accounts.

Less than a dozen paintings in one of the Noe galleries, 368 Fifth Avenue, set forth the views that Mr. Frederick Remington, painter and sculptor, takes of the life and looks of those vanished or almost vanished dwellers on the plains who had their short existence cut off by the advance of railways and of farms -- their existence, at any rate, in the picturesque ancestral garb of the Indian and that of the vaquero.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The amount of 3 and 4 per cent. bonds actually exchanged to date for the two per cent. consols, under the Secretary's recent refunding offer, is $14,120,000.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The report of structural defects in the Maine, showing startling weakness in gun position and turrets having been demonstrated by gun practice recently at Norfolk, is denied at the Navy Department. Admiral Taylor, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, said to-day that as far as the department had been advised there was no structural disturbance or defect in the Maine, nor was there trouble with any of the big guns.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Final argument in the franchise tax adjudication began to-day before the Court of Appeals. Attorney General Cunneen and two of the lawyers representing the seven corporations which are testing the Ford law on appeal were heard.

BOSTON, April 6 -- The money market continues quiet, with no perceptible change. Call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 16 2-3 cents discount. Clearings, $17,295,132; balances, $957,052.

SALT LAKE, Utah, April 6.--President Joseph F. Smith, head of the Mormon Church, poured forth vials of fierce wrath to-day on the opponents of Senator and Apostle Reed Smoot. The occasion was the general conference of Mormons held in the Tabernacle. Aiming his remarks especially at the Protestant ministers, President Smith said, among other things:

With an entry list of eighteen competitors a handicap billiard tournament was begun last night in the room of the Amateur Billiard Club of New York, 113 West Seventy-ninth Street. This is the largest number of men that has been engaged in a single tournament in this city for many years.

ST. LOUIS, April 6 -- Injunctions sought by the Chicago Board of Trade to establish the ownership of the quotations on the prices of grains and other commodities were denied by Judge Adams in the United States District Court to-day and dealing in futures condemned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of March 30 there appeared an article in regard to the breaking down from overstudy of a Columbia University student. He was taken to the Insane Pavilion of Bellevue Hospital because he had applied himself too closely to his college work.
ROTTERDAM, April 6 -- The dock laborers, wagon drivers, and all others engaged in industries connected with the port have joined in the general strike.

ALBANY, April 6 -- At last the secret of the series of street railway "grab" bills in the Legislature is out. Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman of New York City to-night gave out a statement in which he declared it was shown beyond doubt that the measures were introduced in the interest of the Union Railway Company of New York City, which is controlled by the Interudban Company.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Gov. Odell to-night sent a message to the Legislature declaring in favor of some character of mortgage tax legislation. He says that the present system of taxing mortgages is wholly inequitable in that the burden of the tax falls largely upon widows and orphans. He would prefer that all mortgages be exempt from taxation rather than that the present system should continue.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., April 6 -- President Roosevelt made an open-air speech here to 6,000 people this morning. While he was speaking snow began to fall, but he was clad in a heavy overcoat, and was well protected. United States Senator Kittredge introduced the President, who spoke on "The Wage Worker and the Tiller of the Soil."

The body of Mrs. Louise Ames Weik, also known as Mrs. Van Weik, who shot herself through the heart before a mirror at the Hotel Washington in Jersey City on Sunday, was sent to Baltimore yesterday by the direction of her brother by adoption, Campbell B. Royston of that city.
Capt. Walter C. Short, Thirteenth Cavalry, will proceed, about April 15, to Crawford, Neb., to inspect ten polo ponies to be delivered to the Quartermaster's Department at that place.

New gun-metal chains are exceedingly smart and rich. They are made of long links, set at intervals of several inches with large balls or beads, each larger than a good-sized marble. These are set with brilliant rhinestones, perhaps four in a bead. The chains are long, and with them are worn sometimes a plain cross of the gun metal, and at others a large heart with a rhinestone in the centre.

UTICA, N.Y., April 6 -- The four Cohans produced a new musical extravangaza called "Running for Office," for which George M. Cohan has written the book and music, to-night at the Majestic Theatre. The action is laid in Tigersville, a village in Vermont, and deals with the Prohibition question.

The April meeting of the Presbyterian Union was held last evening in the parlors and banquet hall of the Hotel Savoy. Before the speaking and musical entertainment there was a reception of the members and their guests. President Robert C. Ogden presided and introduced the speakers.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- It is practically admitted here that the new commercial treaty between the United States and China is in one phase especially designed to test the soundness of Russia's promise to maintain the open door in Manchuria.
WEYMOUTH, England, April 6 -- The Shamrock III. arrived here to-day, having been preceded during the night by the Shamrock I.

Anton Seraphic, a Greek interpreter on Ellis Island, yesterday returned from a 5,000-mile chase that he began more than three months ago to capture Tsonoris Demetrios and Askounls Constantlnos, Greek immigrants who escaped from the Hamburg-American liner Graf Waldersec Jan. 2 last.

CINCINNTATI, April 6 -- Judge Lurton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to-day refused to make permanent the injunction asked for by Talbot J. Taylor Co. of New York, representing James R. Keene, to restrain the Harriman interests from voting the 900,000 shares of stock held by the Union Pacific Railway Company in the Southern Pacific election, set for April 8. and for other relief.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Dullness and firmness prevailed in this market to-day. Several of the active stocks advanced fractionally, while some of the inactive issues were lower. Electric Storage Battery common was off three from its last previous sale and the preferred five, the former on the sale of an odd lot of ten shares.

In his talk before the Central Federated Union on Sunday ex-Senator JOHN FORD, quite unintentionally, of course, put his audience in the way of grievously misunderstanding the provisions and intent of the Mayor's bill amending the Rapid Transit act, and of getting altogether erroneous notions of the relations of the city to the company which has taken the contract to build and operate the subway.

NICE, April 6 -- Yielding to the representations of the Automobile Club, the authorities have reconsidered their decision to prohibit the mile automobile race on the Promenade des Anglais, which was taken in consequence of the fatal accident to Count Zborowski and will now permit the race to take place to-morrow morning.
LONDON, April 6 -- With the release of u7,000,000 in dividends the rates for money and discounts to-day were easier.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 6 -- John D. Rockefeller, according to a report widely circulated here to-day, is to endow the University of Nebraska in the sum of $666,000, provided the State will appropriate a sum sufficient to make the total endowment $1,000,000. An immediate appropriation, however, is impossible, as the Legislature will adjourn to-morrow.
Furlong Leedom have been appointed Milwaukee agents of the Palatine Insurance Company.

In most cases stocks in the outside market yesterday showed some improvement. The advance in prices was in only a few instances accompanied by much activity, but the gain in quotations was a favorable development, notwithstanding the dullness which coutinued to prevail in most parts of the list.

AMSTERDAM, April 6 -- A general strike throughout Holland of all labor engaged in transportation by land and water was ordered last midnight at a meeting of the Workmen's Committee of Defense. The meeting lasted till 4 A.M.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A fine card, a track a bit soft in spots, but so good as to be almost fast, and perfect weather combined to afford excellent sport at the Bennings races today. Three favorites, one second choice, and two outsiders won, and the talent was reasonably happy. Jockeys Redfern and Burns each rode two winners and one place horse.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt was beaten in the tandem class last night at the Durland Riding Academy horse show, which will continue to-night and to-morrow night, in the Durland Academy, West Sixty-sixth Street. The tandem class was one of the most interesting of the nine classes judged. Young Vanderbilt drove his team, a handsome pair of brown horses, and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt watched the progress of her husband with enthusiasm from a box.

ST. LOUIS, April 7 -- The Democratic machine swept the city at to-day's election, winning by majorities ranging from 8,000 to 10,000 on the vote for Councilmen and members of the Board of Education. Every Democratic candidate for City Councilman, School Director, and the candidate for Inspector of Weight and Measures were elected.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The tone of to-day's market was heavy and renewed liquidation was evidenced in United Gas, American Railways, and Philadelphia Electric. Prices did not recede more than small fractions, but even these were sufficient to again throw the Street in gloom. The Street has seen so few bright days lately that it docs not require much to depress local traders in stocks.

In the selection of the members of the Panama Canal Commission President ROOSEVELT has a task as delicate as it is difficult. The immense expenditures necessarily involved in a work of this character offer every temptation to those in politics "for what there is in it" to seek positions on this commission for themselves or for those through whom they can even more safely attain advantages which belong to the fortunate favored ones.

NEW ORLEANS, April 7 -- Manager Griffith of the New York American League baseball team put his men through some strenuous practice this morning in preparation for to-morrow's game. After a lengthy lesson in sign manual between the battery and infield, the men practiced base running, and then were assigned to their regular positions.

Yesterday's market was dull and dragging almost from beginning to end, though in only a few active stocks were the changes consequential. In the early morning session an endeavor was made to stimulate activity by a concerted bidding up of prices around the room, but inasmuch as the only tangible effect of this was to increase the supply of long stock coming on the market the endeavor was promptly abandoned.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 7 -- In the presence only of her foster brother, Campbell Royston, and his wife the body of Mrs. Louise Ames Van Weik, who killed herself in Jersey City, was buried to-day in Greenmount Cemetery.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 7 -- Attorney General Crow to-day wired to New York a request for the arrest of Daniel J. Kelly, who acted for a baking powder concern as legislative agent in Jefferson City during the last session of the Legislature. Attorney General Crow acted on information furnished by Lieut. Gov. John A. Lee.
ALBANY, April 7 -- These bills were signed by Gov. Odell to-day:

The departures from the city are the principal items of interest just now. J. Pierpont Morgan has deferred his trip in the Oceanic, but the Countess Fabricotti, Goold Redmond, and Miss Redmond and Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry and the Misses Gerry are booked to sail to-day. Mrs. Neilson, Miss Neilson, and Mrs. Arthur Kemp are expected to take possession of Arleigh to-morrow.

The annual report of the United States Steel Corporation for the year 1902, as well as the quarterly report for the first three months of 1903, were made public yesterday. The annual report is printed in detail on another page. The quarterly report is given below in full, with some comparisons for the same period in 1902.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Despite the attitude of the Assembly and of Senator Platt, the Republican Senators in caucus to-night decided to insist upon the bill providing for a general tax of 4 mills on mortgages.

LONDON, April 7 -- The Life Saving Society, to which King Edward recently presented a handsome cup for international competition, has dispatched invitations to the leading amateur associations of the United States, Canada, European countries, and the colonies to send representatives to compete in a series of three swimming races for the cup.
ALBANY, April 7 -- Gov. Odell has signed thebull ofSeriator Davis providing for the construction of a barge canal system n this State. It became a law at 11:38 o'clock this morning.

LONDON, April 7 -- Mr. Wyndham, Chief Secretary for Ireland, in an interview with regard to the statements ascribing to the Government a policy of Irish home rule, described them as unfounded and "rubbish."

BALTIMORE, April 7 -- Mayor Hayes and his City Hall machine were overwhelmingly beaten in the Democratic primaries to-day. Robert M. McLane, the present State's Attorney and the regular Democratic organization's candidate, received the nomination for Mayor. His opponents were Mayor Hayes, Gen. F.C. Latrobe, and Francis Yewell.
BRISTOL, R.I., April 7 -- The Herreshoff Manufacturing Company has issued invitations to the launching, as the cards say, of the cup defender Reliance, at 5:30 P.M. on Saturday, April 11.

FARGO, N.D., April 7 -- "The Philippine Islands and the Army" was the subject of President Roosevelt's speech here to-day. In the course of his remarks Mr. Roosevelt declared that President McKinley's promises of a beneficent civil government for the Filipinos has been fulfilled. He defended the army against its critics and praised the American soldier in the Philippines for his courage and his selfcontrol in dealing with a cruel, treacherous foe.

BOSTON, April 7 -- The money market continues firm, with business quiet. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.: time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 16 2/3@20 cents' discount. Clearings, $25,573,683; balances, $2,575,204. The foreign exchange market is somewhat easier without change in rates.

PITTSBURG, April 7 -- Keen rivalry among department stores is promised within a year as a result of the intention of James McCreery Co. of New York to invade this field. The New Yorkers will erect a twelve-story building and open a great store, and the Kaulmans, who are leaders in this field, will add to their big building to meet the new competition.

To picture the treatment accorded to persons who have occasion to visit the police courts, the following instance, which took place yesterday in the Centre Street Court, where Magistrate Pool was sitting, was noted by an observer:

PARIS, April 7 -- The funeral of Mrs. Porter, wife of Ambassador Porter, will take place Thursday morning in the American Church. Dr. Thurber will officiate. The body will then be placed in a vault pending the final plans for its disposition.

NEWARK, N.J., April 7 -- Joseph S. Mundy to-day granted the requests made by the International Association of Machinists' Union, covering a period of one year, and the 120 men who quit work at noon yesterday will return to work tomorrow morning.
The most sensible thing Gov. ODELL has said to the Legislature since he was elected is the following in his message of Monday:

Mr. ROOSEVELT at Sioux Falls. South Dakota, was a long way from Washington, and he may not have had a copy of the Dingley tariff with him, though it is one of those things that even his traveling library should not be without. Had be had one by him, he would have been clearer as to what the "rational action of the Government has done for the farmer."

President Orr and Commissioner Claflin of the Rapid Transit Commission and Edward M. Shepard, the commission's counsel, called on Mayor Low yesterday afternoon and held a protracted conference over the Rapid Transit bill now before the Legislature, and which bill the Mayor, in a statement yesterday, assumed the full responsibility for.

LONDON, April 8 -- The Times's Peking correspondent says the dictum that has gone forth that the surest way to promotion in China is impeachment by foreigners is further confirmed by many recent appointments. The notorious Yuli En San, whose appointment to the Governorship of Shan Si Province was successfully resisted by the Foreign Ministers, will doubtless be rewarded by a Viceroyalty.

Two Frenchmen, brought to this country as important witnesses in the litigation over the estates of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair, were called to testify before ex-Justice Keener yesterday, sitting as referee, to the effect that in the automobile accident of last August, near Paris, Mr. Fair apparently had died instantly, while Mrs. Fair lived for some minutes afterward.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Promise of big fields and excellent sport was spoiled in part at Bennings to-day by a bad track. The going was heavy, and consequently in the six races there were twenty-three scratches. Four favorites and two heavily played second choices won. Summary:

MANDAN, N.D., April 7 -- President Roosevelt has been traveling through familiar country to-day, and has received hearty greetings wherever his train stopped. At many places he recognized old friends, and from his conversation it is evident that this has been one of the most enjoyable days of his trip.

TRENTON, N.J., April 7 -- Because some one dropped out an important amendment in the bill providing for trunk sewer from Paterson to the waters of the New York Bay, which had been signed by Gov. Murphy, Attorney General McCarter today decided that if the facts are as appear after investigation the measure Id not legally on the statute books.
ALBANY, April 7 -- Great progress was made to-day in perfecting the plan to centralize the power over the State hospitals in the hands of a few of the Governor's appointees.

Some interesting statements regarding the long-delayed appearance of the Edison storage battery are given in The Horseless Age, published to-day. After explaining that some recent utterances of the inventor and a number of recently issued patents throw some light upon this subject, the article continues:

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The British Ambassador and Lady Herbert were the guests of honor at a dinner this evening at the Japanese Legation, where the Japanese. Minister and Mme. Takahira were hosts. Among the others present were Justice Holmes of the Supreme Court and Mrs. Holmes, the Assistant Secretary of State and Mrs. Loomis, the Third Assistant Secretary of the State and Mrs. Peirce, and Capt. and Mrs. Cowles.

Frederick Dielman, artist, stood with tears in his eyes amid the desolate wreckage of what had been his beautiful studio In the famous old Studio Building, at 51 West Tenth Street. During his brief absence of two or three hours yesterday morning a mysterious flame had crept out of the floor, whence nobody knows, and had destroyed all the priceless treasures he kept in his favorite corner under the northerly window.
LONDON, April 7 -- Money was in good demand and plentiful in the market to-day. Discounts were easy.
ALBANY, April 7 -- Another hearing on the Elsberg bill, permitting the City of New York to establish its own lighting plant, was given this afternoon by the Senate Cities Committee.

BUFFALO, April 7 -- There is likely to be a bitter fight at the inquest next Friday into the death of Arthur R. Fennell over the authority of the court to compel the administrator and his attorney to testify and produce the dead man's papers. It is claimed by his friends that the inquest is for the exclusive purpose of establishing the cause of death and proving a crime if there was one.

LISBON, April 7 -- King Edward boarded the royal yacht Victoria and Albert this afternoon preparatory to his departure from Lisbon to-night for Gibraltar. The ceremony at his Majesty's embarkation was the same as on his arrival here. King Edward and King Carlos received an ovation along the whole route followed.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Results of the Ohio election formed the universal topic of conversation among politicians here today. It was generally conceded that Melville E. Ingalls had been eliminated as a factor in the Ohio Gubernatorial campaign this year and also in the Presidential campaign next year, and that Tom L. Johnson's prospects for receiving the nomination for Governor were much improved.

ALBANY, April 7 -- When Senator Marshall's bill giving the Fire Commissioner the right to extend the fire alarm telegraph system of New York City whenever he thinks proper and to arrange for the purchase of apparatus, was taken up in general orders in the Senate to-day, Senator McCabe moved that the enacting clause be stricken out.

LONDON, April 7 -- William Hayes Fisher, M.P., Financial Secretary of the Treasury, announced his resignation in the House of Commons to-day as a result of his connection as Director with a financial syndicate and of his acceptance of a bonus of shares in the concern.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 7 -- The elections in the three towns of Nassau County were held under peculiar circumstances to-day. Up to a week ago it did not appear as if there would be an election, as on April 9, 1901, the supervisors by resolution abolished town Spring elections and consolidated them with the general elections in November.

CINCINNATI, April 7 -- F.N. Innes, the bandmaster, and Miss Frances Boyden, who accompanied the Innes Band on its tour last Winter, appearing as the principal vocal soloist, were quietly wedded last night at the bride's home in Auburn Avenue, this city. Only the immediate members of the Boyden family were present.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Carter H. Harrison was elected Mayor of Chicago to-day for the fourth time, his plurality by unofficial count over Graeme Stewart, the Republican candidate, being 6,948. The total vote was: Harrison, 146,323; Stewart, 139,375; Cruice, Independent Labor, 9,999; Breckon, Socialist, 11,212; Haines, Prohibition, 2,848.

The Board of Building Trades, representing 60,000 men engaged in building construction in this city, and said to be the strongest labor organization in the United States, stands ready to precipitate on May 1 a strike which would paralyze building construction here.
ALBANY, April 7 -- These bills Were passed by the Senate to-day:

YONKERS, April 7 -- The police of this city are satisfied that Adolphe Openhym, the missing New York merchant, was alive at least twelve hours after the time he is generally supposed to have leaped from Washington Bridge into the Harlem. As the local police understand it, Mr. Openhym was supposed to have leaped from the bridge about noon on March 30.

Tuesday's Sun contained a modern instance of a very old complaint. The modern instance was the remonstrance of an American merchant doing business in the Republic of Colombia, with which we expect shortly to be doing much more business than we have ever done before, to a firm in New York which had sent him two stoves.
PARIS, April 7 -- W.K. Vanderbilt's Bright ran second in the race for the Prix Lutin, and his Constanzia was seventh in the contest for the Prix Juticier, at the Maisons Laffitte meeting to-day.

Money easier, 4 to 6 per cent, on call. Stocks heavy. The stock market yesterday was of the too familiar dull, declining sort. There was less business doing, and less enthusiasm in doing if, than before the allimportant Southern Pacific decision was rendered.
Socialism is devouring itself in the Netherlands, and the quarrel, though rude rather than pretty as it stands, is bound to be instructive.

PARIS, April 7 -- It seems that the debate in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday and to-day which resulted, by a vote of 281 to 228, in the invalidation of the election of the Nationalist Deputy, Syveton, is likely also to lead to the reopening of the Dreyfus case, and, perhaps, to the rehabilitation of the former prisoner of Devil's Island.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt won a first prize last night at the Durland Riding Academy's horse show in West Sixty-sixth Street. His honors came in the polo pony class, with the lightweight ponies, the nine ponies entered being divided into two classes. Vanderbilt had a pony in each, but in the heavyweight ponies he had to be content with the second ribbon, his exhibit, Brown Jug, being ridden by Robert C. Kernochan.

Although the number of stocks traded in on the curb yesterday was somewhat larger than on the previous day, the transactions in individual issues were in few cases of a kind to attract attention. The further decline in the new steel bonds was the chief event of the day in outside securities, and but for the establishing of a new low record in these bonds the session would have been an exceedingly dull one.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Gov. Odell surprised members of the Senate to-day by sending in the nomination of Frank M. Baker to be a member of the Railroad Commission. It is significant that this action was followed by a favorable report by the Assembly Committee on Railroads of the bill providing for an increase of the commission to five members.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The rejection of the application of Gen. Corbin for membership in the Metropolitan Club of this city has caused decided feeling among army officers and promises to result in proceedings which may lead to the retirement of a very considerable number of that class of the club's membership.

Forty out of some fifty creditors of the dry goods commission firm of Dresser Co., representing about $1,000,000 of the $1,178,037.18 for which that company failed on March 6 last, were told yesterday that D. Leroy Dresser, President, would provide within ninety days for the payment of the $850,000 unsecured liabilities.
Army. Second Lieut Norman H. Davis is transferred from the Twenty-fifth Infantry to the Cavalry arm with rank in that arm from Oct. 19, 1902. He is assigned to the Fourteenth Cavalry. Troop G.

The opposition to Miss Clara Barton in the American National Red Cross has formulated a plan of reorganization whereby it is designed to substitute a representative system for autocratic methods. Their idea is to have an Executive Committee consisting of one member from each State to be appointed by the Governor thereof.

ALBANY, April 8. -- It was evidently the scheme of the men who are behind the railway "grab" bills in the Legislature to avoid any public demonstration against them when a hearing before the Senate Committee on Railroads was set for to-day, and the announcement was withheld by Senator Wilcox until late yesterday afternoon.

NORTHPORT, L.I., April 8. -- John W. Arthur, Democrat, was elected Supervisor in the town of Huntington yesterday by a large majority. He is the first Democratic Supervisor to be chosen since 1888, when his father, Elbert Arthur, was elected. The town gave a large majority in favor of licensing hotels and saloons.

ST. LOUIS, April 8. -- Gov. Dockery to-day issued a requisition on Gov. Odell of New York for the return of Daniel J. Kelly, the pure food advocate and editor of The American Queen, who is charged with offering a bribe of $1,000 to Lieut. Gov. John A. Lee to obtain his influence in opposing the repeal of the baking powder law.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Hugh H. Hanna of Indianapolis, President of the Indianapolis Monetary League, has been appointed the third member of the American delegation which will represent the United States at the approaching International Monetary Congress in Mexico.

Persons connected with the construction of buildings in this city recently received a circular from the "New York District Council United Brotherhood Carpenters and Joiners of America." It set forth a practice alleged to exist in this city of giving contracts to out-of-town firms, who "conduct their business on a system of low wages and long hours," and announced the intention of the brotherhood "to bar out this objectionable material."

An article describing letters received and written by Henry Ward Beecher, prepared by the late Rev. Samuel Scoville. his son-in-law, is printed in The Philadelphia Sunday School Times. A portion of the article follows:

ALBANY, April 8. -- The New York City gas situation was aired in the Senate to-day, When Senator Malby presented the Appropriation bill Senator Elsberg called attention to the fact that the appropriation of $11,000 for the gas meters inspector and his deputies had been cut out of the bill.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 8 -- Good humor marked the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company to-day, no one representing the Keene faction being present. The meeting was held in the office of J.B. Weaver, an Assistant Secretary of the Southern Pacific, at Beechmont, a suburb of this city.

-- Whatever may be the exact extent of the injuries suffered by the Maine in the course of her recent target practice, they are quite serious enough to supply the foreign critics of our navy with an excuse for overlooking the wonderful record with big guns made by the Indiana on the same cruise.

Yesterday's stock market was small in volume, narrow in range, and fitful in tone. Of the declines it is only necessary to say that the maximum was 1 3/8 for Amalgamated, whose movements are due to inward pangs which the manipulators adjudge not matters of public concern to be reported at inconvenient seasons.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The board of officers to whom was assigned the selection of officers for the general staff corps submitted a report to Secretary Root yesterday which was approved and promulgated to-day. Including three general officers the general staff is to consist of forty-five officers.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 8. -- World's records are being smashed here with frequency by the war ships of the Atlantic fleet. The Illinois lowered all records for accuracy with thirteen-inch guns, and to-day the Iowa took the record with six-pounders.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 8. -- Dispatches from several towns in White and Cleburne Counties, in Arkansas, tell of a tornado which swept through that section of the State Tuesday night, leaving death and destruction in its wake. The record of casualties so far is nine dead, three dying, and thirteen others badly injured.

Maundy Thursday and Good Friday are two days in the year on which there is neither feasting nor merriment. To-day, however, is not a fast day in the Roman Catholic Church. The High Church Episcopalians have services in the morning. Last evening there was a large crowd at St. Patrick's Cathedral for the opening of the Tenerbrae.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- It is estimated that Chicago banks have lost fully $15,000,000 in deposits since the last week in March, owing to the desire of depositors temporarily to shift their taxable weath in such manner that no record of its whereabouts would appear. This was accomplished by large purchases of New York drafts, withdrawal of funds, and transfer to safety deposit vaults, and some purchases of Government bonds.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8. -- The New York American League baseball players defeated the New Orleans Pelicans to-day by the score of 8 to 2. For four innings the local pitchers held Griffith's men to two scratch hits, but the fine base running of Keeler and Davis was by far too good for the home players, and they went to pieces.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. April 8 -- Prof. Ernst A. Eggers, head of the Department of German at the Ohio State University, committed suicide this evening by shooting himself at his home. It is said he was despondent front ill-health.

EASTPORT, L.I., April 8 -- In a heavy gale and a tremendous surf the barge Rosemont of Bath, Me., coal laden, bound from Fall River, Mass., stranded on a bar one and a half miles west of the Amagansett Life Saving Station early this morning.
AMSTERDAM, April 8. -- The Workmen's Defense Committee has decided to proclaim a general strike of all the trades throughout the country.
LONDON, April 8 -- The demand for money was active in the market to-day. Discounts were firm.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 8 -- Justice Murphy and District Attorney Coatsworth; held a conference this afternoon on the Pennell inquest, which begins at the Morgue at 3 o'clock Friday afternoon. The course of the public inquiry, so far as it could be discussed beforehand, was settled. The inquests of Pennell and Mrs. Pennell are to be joined.

ROME, April 8. -- The leader of the Socialists has decided to propose that the differences between the typesetters and their employers, which brought about the general strike here, be settled by arbitration. This proposition is likely to be accepted, in which case the general strike will be ended.

George T. Hansell, who for more than half a century has been a Deacon of the Filth Avenue Baptist Church and soliciting agent of the New York Association for the improvement of the Condition of the Poor, was eighty-nine years old yesterday, and gave a birthday reception at his home, at 1 West Eighty-seventh Street, which many of the prominent men of the city attended.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- The movement of prices was irregular to-day, with net changes at the close about evenly divided between gains and losses. All of the Mack-Widener-Dolan stocks were lower -- Electric Storage Battery. 1 3/4; United States Gas, 7/8; Philadelphia Rapid Transit, 1/2; American Asphalt 3s, 1/2, and Philadelphia Electric and Union Traction smaller fractions.
A pretty little gilt cage with a live chicken in it is an Easter gift at a flower shop.

There was a desperate fight with burglars last night shortly before 11 o'clock in Flower Hill Cemetery in North Bergen, Hudson County, N.J., in which fifteen or sixteen policemen from several places took part. Two of the men were caught, one of them wounded, and the third is supposed to be seriously, and perhaps fatally, wounded, if not dead, and to be lying somewhere in the cemetery.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Although the State of New York is represented in Congress by thirty-seven members, the State Commission in Lunacy considered it necessary to send a lobbyist to Washington at the last session of Congress to push legislation in which it was interested and pay him $2,500 for his services.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Results of yesterday's primary election in Baltimore were discussed with the greatest interest to-day. The trial of the system of direct primary nominations in a city as far north as Baltimore serves as a test of the plan which has many advocates.

BOSTON, April 8 -- The position of the Lowell cotton mill operatives and of the strikers at Woonsocket and Manville, R.I., was indorsed at the session of the National Mule Spinners' Association to-day, and preparatory steps were taken toward strikes of spinners in New Bedford, Fall River, Taunton, and factories of the New England Yarn Company in Lawrence, Waltham, Manchester, Dover, Suncook, and Somersworth.
CHICAGO, April 8 -- New York exchange was at 15 cents premium before clearings and 30 cents after. Time and call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.
