Manager McGraw of the New York National League baseball team arrived here early yesterday from Baltimore, and looked up his players, all of whom reported to him in the hope of beginning the preliminary season at the Polo Grounds. The men all showed the effects of their exposure to the southern sun and winds, and with two exceptions they appeared to be as healthy an aggregation of athletes as could be desired.

The Arts Club has attempted what the pessimist on American art would call the impossible, and has succeeded. Foreign critics, and not a few American, even when they admire the works of our painters and sculptors, are in the habit of making a reservation to the effect that our fine art, engaged in the path traced by the realists of France, keeps always to the level of realism, and fears to attempt the ideal.

CINNABAR, Mon., April 8. -- President Roosevelt is in the fastness of Yellowstone Park, and for the next sixteen days he expects to enjoy complete rest and cessation from public duties. He will be in almost daily communication with Secretary Loeb at Cinrabar, but nothing except of the utmost importance will be referred to him.

The Hamburg-American fruit liner Alleghany and the British tramp steamship Joseph Merryweather crashed in the harbor at noon yesterday, and thirty-four passengers of the Alleghany, which was just arriving from South American and West Indian ports, had narrow escapes with their lives.

BOSTON, April 8 -- The money market shows little or no change. Rates continue high and business is dull. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 3/4@ 6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25 cents discount. Clearings, $25,935,496; balances, $2,344,975.

Notwithstanding the various facts leading to the conclusion that Adolphe Openhym, the missing millionaire silk merchant, jumped or fell from High Bridge and was drowned in the stream below on Monday, March 30, the stories of two Yonkers policemen and several other persons yesterday revived the conjecture whether the mystery would or would not ultimately be ended by absolute proofs of death.

TACOMA, Washington, April 8. -- The Northern Commercial Company, through Manager Hibbard, has made a vigorous protest against the awarding of a contract for forwarding troops, signal and hospital corps, and commissary supplies for army posts on the Yukon River to the White Pass Railroad, a British corporation.

An incident occurred at the City Hall in Jersey City yesterday that for a few moments created considerable excitement. The persons concerned were Gen. William B. Mason, Assistant City Collector, and Mrs. Annie Agnew, a woman who for years has been harmlessly insane. She was annoying Gen. Mason, and he picked up a sponge saturated with water, he says, squeezed it, and flirted the water into the woman's face.

LONDON, April 9. -- John E. Redmond, M. P., the Irish leader, made an important speech at Dublin last night, in which he welcomed the Irish Land bill, "in spite of its great defects," as the first measure proposed by an English Minister having the avowed object of carrying into effect the policy of Parnell and the Land League.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Aside from the regulars few persons, except the most venturesome, braved the elements to-day to attend the races at Bennings. Rain fell at intervals during the afternoon, and the sixth race was run in a driving storm. Three favorites won, and all three of the other winners were heavily backed.

The moral of the deplorable story of PENNELL, as we now know it, seems to be no other than the ancient Virgilian moral, how easy it is to go, morally, down hill. How easy, and with what an accelerated motion, when the downward path is once taken. The man's ending, whether suicidal or not, was an epitome of his career, a swift and swifter plunge into darkness and death.

William N. Amory, complainant in the action for libel begun against H.H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court completed his direct testimony in the hearing that has been in progress at intervals before Magistrate Barlow for nearly a month.

An illuminating commentary on the theory of President ROOSEVELT and Secretary ROOT that the attempt to curb the trusts by removing the tariff duties would ruin the industries of the country is furnished by Mr. EDWARD ATKINSON in an article on "Occupations in Their Relation to the Tariff" in the Quarterly Journal of Economics for February.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 9 -- A disastrous explosion occurred on the battleship Iowa to-day while the vessel was at target practice in the gulf. The forward port twelve-inch gun burst from the premature explosion of a shell, twelve feet of the piece outside the turret being demolished. Three men were killed and five injured, two seriously.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 9 -- Justice Keogh of the Supreme Court to-day directed that a bill of particulars be furnished Secretary William McClure of the New York Stock Exchange in the suit for $250,000 damages for alleged malicious libel brought against him by George Alfred Lamb, a lawyer, who figured prominently in the recent Peter Power litigation in regard to the Northern Pacific merger.

LONDON, April 10 -- William Waldorf Astor has purchased Hever Castle, near Sevenoaks, Kent. The castle, which is said to be the birthplace at Anne Boleyn, one of the wives of Henry VIII., and who was beheaded in the Tower of London, contains many relics.

Capt. Julian C. Smallwood, 1904 Science, of the Columbia University gymnastic team, won the all around gymnastic championship of the university at the annual exhibition held in the gymnasium, One Hundred and Eighteenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, last night, with 245 points; Frank S. Shaw, 1903 Science, was third with 237 1/2 points, and Henry Block, 1904 Law, was third with 231 points.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 9 -- Of marked interest to the laity, as well as to the lawyers, will be a decision that Judge William S Case of the Superior Court is expected to hand down within the next ten days. It will furnish a precedent on the question whether Dakota divorces shall be held as valid in Connecticut.

Fourteen hundred local patrons, of baseball were present at the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the New York Nationals opened the preliminary season by defeating the Fordham College players by the score of 8 to 2. The weather was fine and clear, and the diamond was in good condition, notwithstanding the recent rainstorm.

Yesterday's stock market is a conspicuous exception to the rule that narrow net changes indicate a dull market without especial significance. The extreme decline among active properties was 3 3/4 for St. Louis and San Francisco. Not another decline reached 2, and only a half a dozen fell more than fractions.

That the labor unions have created a condition of distrust and uncertainty in the building trades is too obvious to need discussion. It is not a question of wages. That, indeed, is the least part of it. Millions of dollars of waiting capital would go into building operations with avidity if a state of stable equilibrium in the labor market, or anything approaching it, could be insured.

TRENTON, N.J., April 9 -- Gov. Murphy to-day approved 132 bills passed by the present Legislature and vetoed 11. Among the bills vetoed was that providing for a Register of Deeds for Union County, prohibiting the use of the American flag for commercial purposes, vetoed because of a defect in the title.

When Police Inspector Adam Cross began his defense yesterday, before Deputy Commissioner Ebstein, in the trial for neglect of duty. Assistant District Attorney Morgan asked that much of the prosecution's testimony be stricken out, on the ground that they had been unable to connect the evidence properly.

WEYMOUTH, England, April 9 -- Over a thirty-mile course, fifteen to leeward and fifteen to windward, the Shamrock Ill. today beat the Shamrock I. by 17 minutes and 26 seconds. Hitherto the challenger had shown weakness down the wind, but to-day she proved as good on this point of sailing as on any other, and better on all points than she had heretofore shown herself.

Inasmuch as the entire market turned yesterday on the Northern Securities decision -- early strength giving way to weakness, with a rally later appearing -- there is little to be said of the movement of particular stocks.

In a recent theatrical conversation the question was raised of the abilities of Mr. Robert Lorraine, who is playing one of the leading parts in "Pretty Peggy." The general opinion was not complimentary. An actor who bad played in England with Mr. Lorraine in "Henry V." related that he made an impression of the utmost elevation and strength.

By a vote of 4 to 3 the Washington Heights Local Board of Improvements denied the petition of property owners who desired streets to be cut through the new grounds of the Greater New York Baseball Club on Washington Heights. The vote was taken yesterday at an executive session, which followed a second public hearing in the City Hall.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of to-day strikes a point which I have been "up against," and I am glad that it has been taken up.

How Brooklyn has fared during the first year of the Fusion administration is shown by Borough President J. Edward Swanstrom in his report for 1902, which was sent to Mayor Low yesterday. He says that the bureaus have been reorganized and placed on a businesslike basis and that hundreds of useless employes have been dismissed, although the volume of business has greatly increased.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- General weakness was developed in this market to-day, but it was pronounced in only a few stocks. Pennsylvania Steel preferred broke two points on the sale of an odd lot and Welsbach Collateral Trust 5s were forced down 1 1/4 per cent, to 63 1/2. Pennsylvania Warrants were, heavily dealt in and weakened 1/2 in the late trading.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Assistant Attorney General "William A. Day, who took a prominent part in the argument before the United States Circuit Court in the Northern Securities merger case, in speaking of to-day's decision, said:

It will be seen that our remarks the other day about the complaint of an American business man of the bad packing of certain stoves shipped to Central America, and arriving there in the form of scrap iron, have drawn fire from unexpected quarters. The Sun, which printed the original complaint, has since printed several letters in substantiation of it.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Unless the Assembly Committee on Public Education or the Rules Committee of the Assembly reports out the bills introduced by Senator Malby and Assemblyman Merritt of St. Lawrence County to break the hold of the "book trust" on the school districts of the State the Legislature will not adjourn without a revelation of the trust's methods, which it is said will be sensational in character.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Charming weather and a card better than usual attracted a great crowd to the races at Bennings to-day. The track was muddy and heavy, but the horses, despite the track conditions, ran true to form, four favorites and two heavily-played second choices winning.

BOSTON, April 9 -- Money rates are unchanged, and business continues at low ebb. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 3/4@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25 cents discount. Clearings, $21,087,842; balances, $1,253,279.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Mayor Low's amendments to the Bostwick Rapid Transit bill reached here to-day, and were carefully examined by Senator Elsberg, ex-Senator John Ford, Mr. Bostwick, and others who have taken an especial interest in this particular measure. After scrutinizing these amendments carefully ex-Senator Ford said:

ALBANY, April 9 -- An attempt was made in executive session of the Senate Railroads Committee last night to get out the railroad " grab" bill of Senator Wilcox that has created so much opposition and is said to be in the interest of the Union Railway Company in New York City.
Discussing the movements of currency for the year Dow, Jones Co. say:

ALBANY, N.Y., April 9 -- Rumor has it that the annual meeting of the stockholders of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, which will be held next Wednesday afternoon in the Union Station in this city, will develop into a controversy between American and English stockholders, the result, it is asserted, of years of enmity.

DETROIT, April 9 -- Michael Suilivan of Walkerville, Ontario, was shot through the neck and several other men were slightly injured in a fight which took place at the foot of Joseph Campau Avenue here to-night between strikers and non-union workmen of the Canadian Bridge Company's works in Walkerville, across the river from Detroit.

ALBANY, April 9 -- The Remsen Three Platoon Police bill passed the Assembly today after it had been denounced in vigorous terms by the Republican members from the city. When the vote was announced as 79 to 42 in favor of it, Assemblyman Howard Conkling, to whom the result came as a surprise and a shock, jumped up and excitedly shouted:

ALBANY, April 9 -- In the Senate to-day Senator Elon R. Brown declared that a bill of Senator Brackett's to authorize the New York and London Trust Company to purchase stocks, bonds, and other securities and to issue debentures and other obligations against the same would permit of the organization of another such merger corporation as the Northern Securities Company.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 9 -- The Washington American League baseball team defeated the Brooklyn National League team here to-day in a ten-inning game by a score of 5 to 4. The game was slow up to the ninth inning, when the Brooklyn tied the score. The Brooklyns could not find the ball at the right time in the tenth, although they made two hits.
The Manhattan Life Insurance Company has withdrawn from the State of Wisconsin.

The March Grand Jury, of which William G. Rockefeller was foreman, and which was highly commended at the end of its term By Judge Cowing for the amount of work done by it, came in for severe criticism from the bench yesterday by Judge Warren W. Foster in Part III. of the Court of General Sessions.

A fight has broken out in the upper ranks of the Greater New York Democracy, the seriousness of which but few of the leaders would acknowledge yesterday. At the meeting of the Executive Committee on Wednesday evening the members called each other names. President Cantor denounced one of the committee as a "grafter."

The dinner given by Walter Effingham Maynard at the Union Club to his best man and ushers, the Horse Show at Durland's, the trip of the Liberty with a party to Lakewood, and the meet of the Meadowbrook Hunt were the events of yesterday. To-day, of course, is absolutely without social functions.

The stockholders of the Mercantile and the Seventh National Banks yesterday ratified the arrangements already made for the consolidation of these Gould-Morse-Cromwell banks with the National Broadway Bank, which has been coming for months. The Mercantile National met at noon, increased the capital of the institution, made the number of Directors thirtyone, and authorized the purchase of the assets and business of any other banking corporation in the city.

Application was made to Justice Davis in the Supreme Court yesterday by attorneys in behalf of Mrs. Martha Gwynne Woolworth for an allowance of $100 a week alimony pending the trial of the action of Herbert G. Woolworth for an absolute divorce. Mr. Woolworth is a newphew of F.W. Woolworth, who established many 5 and 10 cent stores, and he is in the same business, having headquarters at 415 Broadway.

The Union League Club is enjoying, and will retain for exhibition until Tuesday next, a number of old paintings belonging to Mr. Catholina Lambert of Paterson, N. J., President of the Silk Manufacturers' Association, a collector well known in the Arts and Lotos Clubs, whose home at Paterson is filled with one of the largest and best gatherings in America of works by the British and Continental masters of painting.

Apart from the activity in Northern Securities and the decline which occurred in that stock, yesterday's market for outside securities presented very little of special interest. In the general conditions governing the market there was no change. Price movements continued to be for the most part very, limited and decidedly irregular.

The famous 400,000-share Southern Pacific pool. James R. Keene, manager, expires to-day by limitation with a heavy loss. Because of the fact that to-day is a holiday, the pool actually expired yesterday, the various members of it receiving their long-looked for "accounting" from the pool manager.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 9 -- The position of the United States Government in the suit brought against the Northern Securities Company, the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railways, and individual officials and Directors of those companies was sustained in the decision handed down in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in this city to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., April 9 -- Benjamin Murphy, Chief of Police of Jersey City, and Robert Pearson, a detective of that city, to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court their plea in answer to the suit for $25,000 damages instituted against them by F.W. Bucklin for false arrest. Bucklin was arrested in Jersey City on Jan. 20 last.
NEWPORT, April 9 -- Mrs. George L. Rives and Miss Natica Rives arrived this afternoon.

The general contractors decided yesterday to take concerted action in the strike of the Brotherhood of Carpenters against the Amalgamated Carpenters' Society in order to wipe the latter out of existence. A committee representing the building contractors, affected by the strike held a meeting in the afternoon lasting three hours, in the Townsend Building, 1,125 Broadway, to consider the situation.

An applicant for membership in a social club who is persona non grata to enough of its members to be black-balled, may well pray to be delivered from the fool friends who immediately proceed to proclaim the injustice, done him and to make common cause against those who have decided that the applicant was not eligible for the particular association to which he aspired.

No fewer than 12,668 immigrants arrived in this port yesterday, the largest number in one day recorded in the history, of the immigration service. When Ellis Island opened for business early in the morning in the harbor and waiting to be transferred from seven ships were 8,561 steerage passengers.

ALBANY, April 9 -- In the Senate to-day Senators Brackett, E.R. Brown, and Wagner endeavored to have committees in charge of bills which they had introduced discharged from their further consideration, and their motions were accompanied by criticism which caused something of a sensation in the legislative halls.

LONDON, April 9 -- The demand for money was active to-day in connection with the holidays, the market realizing that the expected era of cheap money had not arrived. Discounts were strengthened by further large shipments of gold to South America.

Tiffany Co. have bought from George C. Boldt as the site for a new store building the entire block front on the east side of Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets, with the exception of the old Pierre Lorillard mansion at the northeast corner of Thirty-sixth Street, now owned by Henry O. Havemeyer.
PITTSBURG, Penn. April 9 -- When informed of the decision in the Northern Securities merger case D.T. Watson, special counsel for the Government, said:

PARIS, April 9 -- The funeral of Mrs. Porter, wife of the United States Ambassador, which took place this morning at the American Church in the Rue de Berri, was an impressive tribute, the heads of the French Government, the members of the Diplomatic Corps, and many representatives of the American colony being present.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The capital stock of the American Security and Trust Company will be increased from $1,250,000 to $3,000,000, one-half the total stock to be purchased by interests that have been organizing the new company. About one-fourth of the stock is held in Philadelphia.

Deputy Sheriff Snedden has received an attachment for $3,100 against Arthur L. Meyer of 25 Broad Street, In favor of Burt F. Parsons, for the amount claimed to be cue on a stock transaction in May, 1902.

The private library of the late Edwin P. Whipple, author, lecturer, arid editor, to be sold in Boston by C.F. Libble Co., contains many notable autographs and first editions of American authors. Among the valuable first editions are the following: Hawthorne's "Celestial Railroad," 1843, a fine copy of this rare little book, even rarer than "Fanshawe," in the original paper covers, uncut.

Froude's veracity, or his lack of it, seems to be again a question of the hour. Last week we commented upon the new light thrown upon the domestic life of Thomas Carlyle by the two volumes of letters of Jane Welsh Carlyle which John Lane will soon publish, letters selected by Alexander Carlyle and introduced by Sir James Crichton Browne.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 10. -- In a baseball game which was cut to six innings in order that the visitors could catch a train, the Yale nine defeated the naval cadets by one run to nothing here this afternoon. The contest was almost devoid of exciting plays, and the winning run in the fifth inning was scored by O'Rourke, who was brought home from third base by Alien's hit.

The first volume at Gabriel Honotaux's history of "Contemporary France," which will be issued by G.P. Putnam's Sons at the end of this month, comprises, along with the government of M. Thiers, the end of the Franco-Prussian war, the peace negotiations, the Commune, the Constitutional crisis, the debates in the National Assembly, the liberation of the territory.
MANILA, April 10. -- Capt. Pershing's force captured Bacolod, Island of Mindanao, on Wednesday, killing a hundred Moros and wounding many others. Three Americans were wounded.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Allow me to suggest some amendments to Mr. Brewster's list of books for a high school graduate about to start a library, given in your issue of Feb 11.

LONDON, March 31. -- This has been a week of biographies. We have had a life of Sir Henry Layard, the discoverer of Nineveh; another of William IV., another of Charlotte Yonge, and another of Bret Harte.
Changes in stations of officers of the Corps of Engineers:

Zwingli was born in 1484. Two of his brothers were ecclesiastics. Ulrich was destined to follow the same calling. The lad had a strong musical talent, and the monks wanted him to enter the convent so that he might sing in the choir. His father was opposed to such instruction, and the boy was sent to the University of Vienna.

Probably when Mr. Vance Thompson described his hero, Gaffney, as having a "streak of the yellow dog" in him, he did not mean the reader to imply that that gentleman was something of a cur. Nevertheless, if the description were left to him that might be the way he would put it.

"We'll have a nine-hour day or nothing," announced President George E. Pepper at 11:30 o'clock last night, after his association of Manhattan Elevated Railroad employes had been in secret session for more than twelve hours. President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor addressed the men, urging them to maintain their rights, but in a conservative manner.

ALBANY, April 10. -- The Merchants' Association has started a State campaign against the Railroad "Grab" bills. Believing that the influence behind these measures is such that their passage is more than likely, unless the public can be thoroughly aroused by agitation, it has concluded not to confine its efforts to arouse public sentiment to New York City, but to send its appeals through the State.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Form players were well rewarded at Bennings to-day, as five of the six races were won by the favorites. The upset came in the sixth race, when Knight of the Garter, the second choice, won handily, the favorite, Black Dick, running last. The card was fairly good and furnished excellent sport throughout.

The decree of the court in the Northern Securities case is an order to restore, not the status quo ante bellum, but the status quo flagrante bello; that is, the state of war as it existed between the Morgan-Hill and the Schiff-Harriman interests on that memorable 9th of May, 1901.

BUFFALO, April 10. -- The evidence given to-day at the inquest into the deaths of Arthur R. Pennell and Mrs. Pennell before Justice Murphy will not help the authorities in any way to a solution of the Burdick murder mystery. Whether the tragedy at Gehres' stone quarry on March 10, in which Pennell was killed and Mrs. Pennell was fatally injured, was due to accident or design was not proved.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, April 6. -- News has been received here that the Venezuelan revolutionists have defeated, the forces of the Government in the neighborhood of Caracas and captured two cannon and a large quantity of ammunition.

We can readily understand that the Japanese are hugely disgusted with the situation in Manchuria, and that the more excitable among them are talking about making war on Russia on account of it. We ourselves have a rather special grievance, touching "our" port of Niuchwang.

President Samuel Gompers of the American Federation of Labor addressed the members of the Longshoremen's Union Protective Association of the Port of New York in Everett Hall, Fourth Street, last night.

Columbia's baseball players did not make nearly so good a showing against the New York Nationals at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Fordham College men did the day before. The St. John's team was Beaten by 8 runs to 2, but McGraw's men defeated Columbia's representatives by a score of 11 to 1.

Good Friday is, of course, a dies non in society. There will be a few small affairs to-day. A large contingent of the Vanderbilt family will go to Newport, where Mrs. Vanderbilt will entertain at dinner at the Breakers this evening. There are also to be the christening of the Reliance, the trip of the Liberty to Lakewood.

"How to Play Baseball," by Tim Murnane, containing fifty pages of pictures of leading players, showing how they play their respective positions, has just been added to the Spalding Athletic Library. It is about the best work of its kind ever published, and the art of pitching is treated very fully and lucidly in it.

Our doubts as to whether ex-District Attorney PHILBIN was right in holding that his story about a consignee who boasted of stealing a part of the goods intrusted to him for sale illustrated the morality of the average business man are evidently shared by The Examiner, for that paper tells a story of quite a different kind, as showing how commercial success can be, and not infrequently is, attained in these latter days.
A small but select gathering of trotters and pacers met on the upper stretch of the Speedway yesterday afternoon and furnished a number of excellent impromptu brushes.

"The Decadence of the Brevet," by Brig. Gen. William H. Carter; " General Interest in the Navy," by Lucfus S. Landreth: " The United Slates West Indies," by Major John P. Wisser, and " England's Position in the North Sea," by Thomas P. Moody, Commander, Royal Navy, retired, are striking articles in the April number of United Service.

A larger number of churches other than Episcopal and Roman Catholic had Good Friday services yesterday. The tendency of observing the Church fast and festival Says has been growing steadily, and Methodist, Presbyterian, Baptist, Congregational, and Reformed Churches observe Good Friday.

Official announcement was made in Jersey City yesterday by the Democratic leaders that when the Passaic Sewer bill comes before the Legislature at the special session to be held on April 21 it will meet the united opposition of the Democratic delegation from Hudson County. Robert Davis said he believed that the bill could be defeated because, when it was passed originally, it had only eleven votes in the Senate.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 10. -- The report circulated in Paris that the Czarina is suffering from peritonitis is untrue. Her Majesty, who is in perfect health, leaves here to-day for Moscow with the Czar.
Courtesy of the nobility was on view yesterday in the dull and gloomy County Court House, but unfortunately none save newspaper men and a few attorneys were on hand to witness it.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 10. -- Engine No. 10, one of the type of camelback engines of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, was overturned at the Broadway branch of the road near Seventh Street this morning. The engineer, the fireman, and a brakeman were killed, two of the men being buried under the engine as it rolled down the embankment.

Those members of the Legislature who have begun an investigation of the State Commission in Lunacy for what they call its unwarranted expenditure in sending an attorney to Washington to secure legislation for the exclusion of insane immigrants have made a false start.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 10. -- The damage to the battleship Iowa, caused by the premature explosion of a shell in the forward port twelve-inch gun, has developed to be more serious than was thought when the first examination was made, and as a consequence the big ship has been ordered to the New York Navy Yard to go out of commission.

LAST week we were called upon to record and comment upon some of the vagaries of children born in Franca of a French father and an English mother, the children of Elizabeth. We have something to say now by way of introducing to the notice of our readers "Wee Macgreegor," whose family name is Robinson, pronounced by all his neighbors and friends in the black but bustling town of Glasgow, "Robison."

The Empire City Realty Company has bought the four-story building 18 West Street, 25 by 95, from the Bowdin estate, together with the adjoining five-story buildings 20 West Street, running through to 32 Washington Street, 25 by 174.6, from J.N. Robbins. L. Tanenbaum, Strauss Co., and E.A. Cruikshank Co. were the brokers in the transaction.

Sir Arthur Helps, as he makes no allusion to kindred works on the same general subject, has this in his preface explaining why he has made no us1/2 of former publications:
