CHICAGO, April 11. -- The wheat pit was the centre of attraction on the Board of Trade to-day, and as a result of the manipulation which had been in progress the past week the May option declined 3 cents and July 2 1/2 cents, but rallied later. May closing 3/4@7/3 lower, with July down 1 1/2 cents.

IN THE bird lore of the old plantation the buzzard bears a prominent part. There are as many stories about Br'er Buzzard as in animal lore there are about Br'er Rabbit. But Br'er Buzzard in character resembles rather Br'er Fox. He is such a great, lumbering fellow! He wins out -- when he does win -- by main strength and length of wing.

Capt. Gorman, who was assaulted by a mob of Italians and thugs in a Bleecker Street saloon early yesterday morning, was resting comfortably in St. Vincent's Hospital last night, and it was said that he would be about again in a week, despite the fact that he had sustained a contusion of the brain and bruises on every part of his body.

NEW ORLEANS, April 12. -- The annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, which will open here Tuesday morning, promises to be well attended. A large delegation from Cleveland, Detroit, and other Western and Eastern cities left Indianapolis this afternoon, and will arrive here Tuesday morning.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 12. -- After a survey of conditions in the West, George J. Gould, who returned yesterday from a two weeks' trip over the Missouri Pacific and Wabash Lines, is convinced that the present era of prosperity which the West is enjoying will continue for a full year.

ALBANY, April 12. -- One man's guess is about as good as another's with regard to this week's doings in the Legislature. The great enigma is, of course, the mortgage tax propositions, and scarcely less of that character is the situation with regard to the educational unification question. Both matters seem to be somewhat securely dead-locked at this writing, with the chance rather better for the latter proposition than for the former.

The report of the Registrar General of Great Britain showing that diphtheria is about five times as prevalent in proportion to population as it was twenty-five years ago, and is now most prevalent in towns which have isolation hospitals, has started a controversy as to whether isolation hospitals may not be a mistake, which promises to be very interesting.

A mongrel dog resembling a collie, ran snapping up and down Riverside Drive a while yesterday, frightening many persons between One Hundred and Fifth and One Hundred and Tenth Streets. It was lean and hungry, and bits of froth dripped from its Jaws.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12. -- Arrangements are being made for the combination of nine wholesale bakeries in this city, Jersey City, and Hoboken, with a capital of $1,500,000. The men at the head of the scheme are interested in the bakery, wholesale grocery, and beef business.

LOWELL, Mass., April 12. -- The beginning of the third week of the great textile strike here finds both sides holding firmly to the stand taken in March. The operatives assert with much confidence that in the end they will win the 10 per cent, increase asked for, while the agents still reply that present conditions make impossible an increase of wages.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The American Pomological Society will hold its next annual convention in Boston Sept. 10 to 12. W.A. Taylor, Chief of the Division of Field Investigations in Pomology of the Agricultural Department, and Secretary of the National Society, will send out the prospectus of the meeting this week.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- It is announced that Assistant Attorney General James M. Beck tendered his resignation to President Roosevelt before the President's departure for the West. In tendering his resignation Mr. Beck took occasion to express his pride and gratification at having been privileged to serve under the President's Administration and that of his predecessor.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 12. -- A thunderstorm which came out of the West this evening broke over Pittsburg, pouring miniature rivers through streets, flooding cellars, and inflicting damage that will reach thousands of dollars.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12. -- None of the relatives and friends of the Misses Baldwin, whose school at Ruk, one of the Caroline Islands, is said to have been interfered with by German officials, can understand the matter. The last letter from one of the sisters came some time since to her brother, Frederick W. Baldwin.

LONDON, April 13. -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Times says that the Sultan, who was much upset by the Albanian outbreak, appears to have recovered his equanimity. Recently he has spent most of his time settling the final details of his new yacht, which is to cost u100,000.

Recent events may in some degree explain why the Anti-Trust act of 1890 was so long permitted to remain, in the language of the agitators, a "dead letter" upon the statute book. That act, in declaring contracts and combinations in restraint of trade or commerce among the States to be unlawful, created no new law.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 12. -- Nathan Morris, one of the best-known attorneys of Indiana, and Frank Haas, the twelve-yearold son of Dr. Joseph Haas, were burned to death this morning. Mrs. Joseph Haas, Miss Belle Haas, Miss Rose Haas, Louis Haas, and Grace Lemon, a governess, were injured more or less seriously.

DALLAS, Texas, April 12. -- It was learned to-night that much friction developed in the meeting of the Texas World's Fair Commissioners held in this city Friday last. The trouble was over the adoption of the star-shaped plan for the Texas Building at St. Louis. The commission refused to reconsider its action, and as a result E. H.R. Green of Terrell and C.A. Keating of Dallas resigned.

As an economic problem, the question of maintaining the food supply of Great Britain in the event of her entanglement in war with a naval power sufficiently strong to give her trouble is important and invites the serious consideration of her statesmen and statisticians. That it will have any popular interest until the conditions now speculatlvely considered are actually reached is scarcely to be expected.

TORONTO, Ontario, April 12. -- The final beuts for the Canadian amateur boxing championship were decided last night. "Jerry" Casey of the New West Side Athletic Club of New York won the 115-pound class in the second round.

The Macbeth Gallery 237 Fifth Avenue, has a number of pictures by Mr. William Sartain, among which notable are a head or an Italian girl, and a fine shore view with sand dunes. A scene of moors with wedges of woodland on the horizon and a creamy, fleecy sky is one of the best. Here is an early Homer D. Martin, painted during the seventies on the shore of Lake Ontario.

AMHERST, Mass., April 12. -- Amherst College, through its Athletic Board, last night adopted eligibility rules to govern students who represent the college in athletic contests. The rules follow closely those in force in other New England college, disbarring as athletic representatives students who have received compensation in exhibitions and requiring students from other colleges entering Amherst to study a full year before securing memberships on the college team.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 12. -- The Executive Board of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners will meet here tomorrow. It consists of Henry Meyer of California, D.A. Post of Pennsylvania, T.J. Sullivan of Connecticut, Joseph Ainey of Montreal, J.P. Ogletree of Alabama, Wesley Workman of Ohio, and Charles Wellman of Missouri.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorials of Friday and Saturday are the most sensible yet published on the recent merger decision.

The Stock Exchange resumes business to-day under the influence of last week's chief event -- the Northern Securities decision. Last week it checked a modest boomlet, and sent the majority of prices below the best. Upon the week's business fifty-three stocks and thirty-three bonds fell a full point or more, and only twenty stocks and six bonds made a similar advance.

To congratulate the police authorities on the fact that they have at last become aware of the existence of certain very specific ordinances regulating and restricting the obstruction of streets and sidewalks with whatever those who do not think they have room enough for indoors choose to put upon them, should not be understood as implying that the present administration of the department has been lax or negligent in its duties.

RICHMOND, Va., April 12. -- Speaking of the decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in the Northern Securities Company case John Skelton Williams, President of the Seaboard Air Line Railway, says he regards it as one of the greatest blessings and the brightest promises for railroad interests and general business that the country could have.
Gov. Odell and Senator Platt did not meet yesterday. The Senator received an invitation to lunch with the Governor at 1:30 o'clock, but had a previous engagement.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- In recent dispatches sent from this city in regard to the investigation being made into the ad- ministration of the Post Office Department it was said that Perry S. Heath, ex-First Assistant Postmaster General, and now residing at Salt Lake City, had come to Washington for the purpose of making an effort to stop the investigation, and that "he did the best he could to that end with- out avail."

CINNABAR, Mont., April 12.-- Secretary Loeb received no news from the President to-day. Most of the telephone wires in the Park are down, and if the President wanted to communicate with Cinnabar it would be necessary to send a messenger from his camp to Major Pitcher's headQuarters.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12. -- In connection with the embezzlement of several thousand dollars of the funds of the Firemen's Relief Association by Capt. Francis J. Meeker, W. Leslie Edwards, formerly legal counsel of the association, has been indicted for the embezzlement of 1,500 of the association's funds also.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Only 24 of the 111 horses entered in the $10,000 Harlem Na- tional Handicap, to be run at Harlem, Chicago, June 6, have been declared out. Horsemen here consider the small percentage of declarations a high compliment to Secretary Mathanson's handicapping, especially as various forms of illness are responsible for nearly half of the declarations.

NEW ORLEANS, April 12. -- Clark Griffith's New York American League baseball team was beaten by a score of 5 to 4 here this afternoon by the local team of the Southern League. Wiltze, who pitched the first half of the game, was hit hard in the fifth inning, when New Orleans scored 4 runs, three men crossing the plate after two were out on Beville's errors, a passed ball, and two hits.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- While society has returned to town, and a short gay post. Lenten season is assured, there was no old-time Easter display on Connecticut Avenue to-day, that fashionable thorough-fare being well-nigh deserted by its usual Sunday habitues. Lage congregations attended the fashionable churches, but as a rule few Spring toilets were in evidence.

The precedent established in the Taff Vale case in the English courts, which resulted in heavy damages for a railroad company against a trade union which had greatly injured it in furtherance of a strike, has been followed in the Vermont courts in a verdict for the plaintiff in the case of the F.R. Patch Manufacturing Company against Protection Lodge of the International Association of Machinists.

DULUTH, April 12. -- Northern Minnesota, North Dakota, and Manitoba will be the scene of the greatest changes on the railway map during the next five years. There is more promised in the way of railway construction of a character to change present lines or traffic in this district than anywhere else.

BRISTOL, R.I, April 12. -- The harbor was alive with small craft to-day and hundreds of people lined the shore and crowded about the wharf where the Reliance is moored. Many well-known yachtsmen saw her for the first time. No one was on deck, but a seaman on the dock warned sightseers against a too near approach to the boat.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 12. -- It looks as if there would have to be a new election in North Hempstead to choose a Supervisor. Eugene V. Willis, who was elected on Tuesday, is now believed to have been ineligible. He is a School Trustee, and it is claimed that a law which has been upheld by the courts makes a School Trustee's election to be Supervisor illegal and void.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Dr. Martin H. Fischer, who accompanied Dr. Loeb from Chicago to the University of California, has announced the results of a series of experiments which show that cane sugar has almost as strong an effect in bringing about the development of life from the eggs of the nereis, a small sea worm, as common salt or potassium chloride, which were employed by Dr. Loeb.

-- Deplorable inattention to the tendencies and lessons of the hour is shown by Attorney General DOUGLAS of Minnesota in putting on exhibition in his office in St. Paul nothing less abhorrent than a plant which is half potato and half tomato -- the too successful result of some grafting experiments made in a dark and evil day at one of the State agricultural stations.

The text of the Irish Land bill was issued by the British Government March 27. It is described as "a bill to amend the law relating to the occupation and ownership of land in Ireland, and for other purposes thereto, and to amend the Laborers' (Ireland) acts."

PARIS, April 12. -- President Loubet, accompanied by M. Fallires, President of the Senate; Foreign Minister Delcasse, and M. Pelletan, the Minister of Marine, left Paris this evening for Marseilles on his way to Algeria. The President was warmly cheered as, accompanied by the usual escort of cuirassiers, he drove across Paris from the Elysee Palace to the Lyons Railway station.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 12. -- Christ Episcopal Church, the Rev. Dr. H.H. Oberly, rector, to-day celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of its founding and opened a new parish hall. This church was one of the first in America to introduce a vested choir. The date was 1871. In the list of boys when the choir was organized was William P. Barber.

The committee that was appointed by the Central Federated Union to get from District Attorney Jerome the names of labor leaders alleged to have been corrupt subMitted a report yesterday. It was alluded to flippantly as the report of the "Committe on Graft," and was handed in by Samuel B. Donnelly, as Chairman, who spoke briefly.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 12. -- About 4,000 persons saw the Columbus American Association team defeated by Pittsburg in a close and exciting game to-day. The score:

BUFFALO, April 12. -- A shooting affray, in which a nine year old boy was killed and a woman mortally wounded, occurred in this city to-night. Joseph Kwaitkowski, filty-one years old, formerly a business man and representative Polish citizen, is locked up at Police Headquarters, charged with shooting his landlady and killing his own boy.

Easter being primarily a religious feast, it was to the churches that the true celebrants looked for the glories and the exultation of the day, and at the churches throughout the city yesterday gathered crowds larger than on any similar day in many years. Nearly every one of the edifires had been decorated for the occasion with an elaborateness rarely before attempted.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 12. -- Official notices to the clergy and laity have been sent out by the Rev. John Keller, Secretary of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, for the annual diocesan convention, which will be held in St. Mark's Church, West Orange, on Tuesday, May 26. Lay delegates to the convention were elected by parishes in the diocese to-day.

Golfers have a busy week ahead of them, for besides the open tournament at Lakewood beginning Thursday, in addition to the interscholastic event at Westbrook for three days beginning Wednesday, there will be a number of important club competitions on Saturday. The events last Saturday were unusually large for so early in the season, and in most of the cases the links were found to be in excellent condition.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day decided the divorce case of Lillie Winston vs. Walker Winston, both of New York, in favor of the latter. The case involved the validity of a decree granted Mrs. Winston by an Oklahoma court, which it was claimed had been granted her without a sufficient residence.

BOSTON. April 13. -- Local money market conditions are unchanged. The demand continues light and rates are firm at previous quotations. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans collateral, 5@6, per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25 cents discount : clearings, $17,462,078; balances. $1,662,337.

MANILA, April 13. -- The warship Reina Christina, flagship of Admiral Montojo, which was sunk by Admiral Dewey in Manila Bay, was floated and beached yesterday. The skeletons of about eighty of her crew were found in the hulk.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Postmaster General Payne, who returned to-day from his West Indian trip, arrived at the Post Office Department at 4 o'clock, and soon after issued a statement in which he assumed full responsibility for the investigation which is now going on, and declared that it would be continued.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The races at Benningrs to-day were run in a drizzling rain and on a track heavy with sticky mud, but despite the unfavorable conditions one of the largest crowds of the meeting was present. Seven races, including a hurdle race at a mile and a half and a steeplechase at two miles and a half, were run. Summary:

PARIS, April 13. -- At the Bols de Boulogne meeting to-day W.K. Vanderbilt's Alpha, with J. Rausch in the saddle, ran second in the race for the Prix Biennal. Mr. Vanderbilt's Marigold was fifth in the same event, with Nash Turner up.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Senator Elsberg came over to the Assembly to-night for the purpose of catechizing Assemblyman Clark with regard to interviews with Clark on the subject of "boodle" in the Legislature which were printed to-day in the New York City newspapers.

The Anti-Mashing Society was formed quite recently in this city by a band of chivalrous defenders of woman in general, and its by-laws declared implacable warfare upon that brand of travelers on the trolley and elevated cars who are in the habit of ogling and otherwise interfering with unchaperoned members of the gentler sex.

What is more striking in the figures of the world's commerce just published by the Bureau of Statistics than the socalled "balance of trade" is the relative growth of the various countries in the total of their dealing's.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Col. George W. Dunn, Chairman of the State Republican Committee, when his attention was called to-night to the statement that he was interested in a time-record clock contract which is one of the matters receiving attention in connection with the Post Office bribery and corruption charges, said:

Coaching around the Holland House was unusually lively yesterday, for the Second public road coach to run this season started on its regular trips. The Pioneer, driven by Reginald W. Rives, began its sixth annual season, running as usual from the Holland House to the Ardsley Club and back, returning to the Holland House at 6 o'clock in the evening.

WEYMOUTH, England, April 13. -- The Shamrock I.'s spinnaker boom, which was carried away by a steam yacht which fouled the old challenger during the race with the Shamrock II. off here Saturday, has been spliced, but it has been decided to postpone further contests under actual racing conditions between the two boats until a new spar can be fitted.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- William J. Bryan, Senator Hoar of Massachusetts, and ex-Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith of Philadelphia were the principal speakers at a non-political dinner given at the Hotel Barton to-night by the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Association in celebration of the one hundred and sixtieth anniversary of the birth of the author of the Declaration of independence, About 140 guests were present.

Many children on their way to school yesterday afternoon had a miraculous escape from injury by a blast fired at One Hundred and Seventy-second Street, near Third Avenue, which bombarded the entire neighborhood for a distance of several blocks with a shower of rock, doing several thousand dollars' damage.

"The bicycle squad of this city needs jacking up very badly," said Street Cleaning Commissioner Woodbury last evening, after he had spent the greater portion of the day speeding about the city in his automobile, for the purpose of testing the efficiency of this section of the police force.

Otto M. Eidlitz, President of the Master Builders' Association, appeared at the meeting' of the Board of Building Trades yesterday as the result of a meeting of contractors in the Building Trades Club in the forenoon. This meeting was attended by the six firms of contractors which formed a tentative agreement last week to stand by the Amalgamated Carpenters' Society.
Changes in stations and duties of officers of the Corps of Engineers:

After a conference with Assemblyman Bostwick in the City Hall yesterday morning, Mayor Low announced that the Bostwick Rapid Transit bill, recently known as "the Mayor's bill," was to be allowed to die in committee. The Mayor explained that he had decided it would be a good thing for rapid transit legislation to remain at a standstill for another year.
Col. MACGOWAN, the editor of The Chattanooga Times, who died on Sunday, was of a type of journalists whose function in our National life has usually more value than recognition.

The Ledger Publishing Company, that published the Ledger Monthly, at Fourth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, has put itself in the hands of its creditors, and its assets are to be disposed of as the creditors decide, so Fredeick S. Randall, President of the company, said yesterday. A meeting of the creditors is to be held this week.
PEKING, April 13. -- Prince Ching, President of the Foreign Office, has been appointed Grand Secretary in succession to the late Yung-Lu.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 13. -- With her steel mast towering aloft, her bowsprit in its station, and the martingale and port and starboard whiskers in place, the new yacht Reliance is fast rounding into shape for her first trial spin. Even with the excellent progress made to-day, however, probably little less than two weeks will be required to place the boat in readiness for her first run under her own canvas.

The People's Choral Union works, hard all Winter and gives one public concert in the Spring to show the outside world what it has been doing. It has worked its way upward from the elements of choral singing, with which it began eleven years ago, and for a number of years now it has coped, and successfully, too, with oratorios of the highest kind.

Stocks demoralized. Money firm, 2 1/2 to 6 per cent. Yesterday's stock market opened with a moderate accumulation of selling orders, and with signs of some support. For the first hour the market was not uncomfortable, the declines scarcely averaging a point.

Charges of treachery on the part of William Jennings Bryan, made by Frank Campbell, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, who held the Nebraskan responsible for the defeat of the State ticket in the last Fall campaign, aroused the diners at the Bronx Jeffersonian banquet last evening to express an unusually vigorous approval of the remarks of the speaker, and in most unmistakable terms their disapproval of the recent Presidential candidate.

Shortly after daybreak this morning the trials to select two members of the team of three automobilists who will represent this country in the race for the Bennett International Automobile Racing Cup in Ireland next July will be held on the Long Island highways, near Garden City, Long Island.

The annual Paas Festival of the St. Nicholas Society, made more impressive by the fact that it was the commemoration of the granting of a municipal government to New Amsterdam 250 years ago, was celebrated last-night by a dinner at Delmonico's, attended by some 400 members of the society and their guests.

The interesting summary which we printed yesterday of the Irish Land bill indicates the conscientious care with which the principle of the measure has been carried into detail. The principle is clear and sound. It is as Mr. WYNDHAM said last year: "No Government can settle the Irish land question.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, accompanied by her aunt, Mrs. Cowles. left to-day for Biltmore, N.C., to visit Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 13. -- The first public performance of "The Catnippers," the comic opera presented by the Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard, was given before a crowded house at the Hasty Pudding Club Theatre in Cambridge this evening. Boston, Cambridge, and New York society was well represented.

That the situation induced in the building trades by the conflict of the two unions representing the carpenters is intolerable goes without saying. The Board of Building Trades cannot permit its continuance, and in taking sides against the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners it rebukes an effort on the part of that body to crush the Amalgamated Union of Carpenters and Joiners.

PARIS, April 14. -- The correspondent of the Figaro at Grenoble telegraphs that an article is published in this morning's Petit Dauphinois in which the editor, M. Besson, repeats his recent charge that he was approached with an offer to secure authorization for the monks of the Grande Chartreuse monastery to remain in France on payment of 1,000,000f.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Mr. Bostwick of New York to-night arose to a question of personal privilege in the Assembly, and made a statement in regard to the amendments to the Rapid Transit act, which he had introduced. He said that it was not in hip individual capacity, but simply as a medium for Mayor Low to make known his desires to the legislature that he had acted.

A mass meeting under the direction of the West Side Citizens' Transit Reform Committee of One Hundred last night not only opposed "sneak" and "grab" legislation, but revived the advocacy of a local Railroad Commission for New York City. The meeting was in the Century Wheelmen's clubhouse, 444 Amsterdam Avenue.

CINCINNATI, April 13. -- President Ingalls of the Big Four Railroad, who has bean spending a few days at Hot Springs, Va., resting after the fatigues of the Mayoralty campaign, returned to-day. Speaking of the recent municipal election, he said
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Admiral Higginson's report to the Navy Department upon the fatal explosion on the Iowa last Thursday shows that a defective shell was not the cause. He says:

BOSTON, April 13. -- At the annual meeting of the Boston Clearing House Association to-day Arthur W. Newell, President of the Fourth National Bank, was elected Secretary, succeeding Otls H. Luke. S.N. Aldrich, President of the State National Bank, was elected to the Committee on Gold Depository, succeeding Mr. Luke.

The principle laid down by the Supreme Court in the Trans-Missouri Freight Association case, and necessarily followed by the Circuit Court in the Northern Securities case, that the Anti-trust act makes unlawful every kind of contract or combination in restraint of trade, whether or not improper or unlawful acts tending to restrain trade are done under it is one to which the country, its corporations, its lawyers, and the legislators may well give serious attention.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 13. -- It was said here to-day that as a direct result of the decision of the United States Circuit Court in the Northern Securities case, a suit of like character will be instituted in one of the Federal courts of Texas by Attorney General C.K. Bell against the Southern Pacific Company.

It seems odd that, after all we have been reading about the brilliant showing Shamrock III., the present challenger, has made against the Fife boat, with which the sportsmanlike Sir THOMAS LIPTON originally challenged for the cup, it should be announced that, in the first formal race between the two over a set course, the bid boat should have won by nearly three minutes in thirty-four miles "on time allowance."

NEWARK, N.J., April 13. -- It is confidently expected that the trolley merger scheme will be held up in Chancery Court here to-morrow. Minority stockholders of the North Jersey look upon the scheme with some suspicion, and it was said tonight that an effort is already being-made to secure an injunction against the plan.

Mayor Low, Dock Commissioner Hawkes, President Cromwell or Richmond Borough. Albert B. Boardman, representing the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad: Edward Lauterbach and Charles L. Spier, representing the H.H. Rogers syndicate, met in conference in the Mayor's office yesterday regarding the two Staten Island ferry plans for improvement of the terminal at St. George.

ALBANY, April 13. -- David B. Hill, in the view of Democratic politicians, tonight put himself forward as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency. At the Jefferson Day banquet of the Democratic editors of the State he made an address in which he arraigned the Republicans in State and Nation and outlined the issues on which he thought the next campaign should be fought.

As a result of heavy selling growing out of the Northern Securities decision. Wall Street had a bad day of it yesterday stock marketwise. Prices on the Exchange and in the outside market dropped sharply to the lowest general level recorded in several years -- this as a consequence of urgent liquidation induced primarily by a determined market attack under the reputed bear leadership of James R. Keene and John W. Gates.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 13. -- Patrick Flynn, eighty-two years old, a reputed miser, known as the "Hermit of Marker's Hollow," a wild and mountainous place a few miles below here, was found dead in his hovel on Saturday by neighbors. They had not seen the old man for several days, and entering his retreat found him sitting dead in an improvised chair.

At a meeting of the Directors of the trolley companies of Hudson Essex, Bergen, Passaic, and Union Counties, held in Jersey City yesterday, the much-talked-of merger was accomplished. It was not based, however, upon the plan proposed by Thomas L. Nevins on March 3.

WEYMOUTH, England, April 14. -- A race of sixteen miles to leeward, from off Weymouth, and a beat back, was laid out for the Shamrocks to-day. When the boats got outside the shelter of the breakwater, however, the wind came in hard gusts and the yachts seemed to have all they could stagger under, and required an occasional luff up to ease them.

LONDON, April 15. -- The Times's Vienna correspondent says that although Russia is said not to have demanded special satisfaction or indemnity for Consul Stcherbina's death at Mitrovitza, the Porte is alleged to have admitted the necessity of hanging the assassin. Penitence is the order of the day in Constantinople just now.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Secretary of State and Mrs. Hay, who by reason of Mrs. Hay's mourning for her mother, did no entertaining last Winter, were this evening the hosts at the first of a series of dinner parties they propose giving throughout the Spring season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is the season for our National game, baseball, and the boys are crying aloud for spaces in which to play the same undisturbed by the interference of their natural enemies, the police.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 14. -- The Empire Theatre Building on Second Street was destroyed by fire this morning soon after daylight. The flames spread from Amiel Stark's furniture store, which occupied a part of the front, to the liquor store of Harry Stein, the other store in the building, and then into the theatre.

Stocks recover. Money firm, 3 to 5 1/2 per cent. It is impossible not to sympathize with those who were sold out of property which they wished to retain in Monday's flurry. And "served them right" is all that it is possible to say regarding those flighty individuals who have no judgment upon values, but buy and sell as sheep jump a fence, and so took unnecessary losses.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Aided by the three Republican insurgents, Messrs. Elsberg, Backett, and Elon R. Brown, the Democratic Senators to-day cut $25,000 off the annual allowance for the metropolitan Bureau of Elections. The debate over this item was bitter, Superintendent John McCullagh coming in for sharp criticism and Senators Elsberg and Malby exchanging caustic personalities.

Twenty years ago the fever of emigration was kindled in the veins of the sturdy farmers of the Northwest by the promises held out by the fertile lands of the Red River of the North, whose valley lay on either side between the States of Minnesota and the Dakotas, some three hundred miles west of the head of Lake Superior.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- The improvement in the New York market and the defeat of the Curry bill in the Pennsylvania House had a stimulating effect upon local values to-day, although the grain in prices did not exceed fractions, except in a few cases. United Gas and Philadelphia Electric issues both developed strength on the killing of the bill, as it was these two companies at which it had been aimed.

PROVIDENCE, April 14. -- The deadlock which has harassed the action of both branches of the Rhode Island Legislature for the past week over the Block Island local option law, was broken to-day, when the Senate Judiciary Committee reported favorably on the repeal of the bill, and the higher body promptly concurred and made the repeal effective.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- All the members of the Board of Election Commissioners and the chief clerk are under arrest for defying Judge Hanecey's injunction in the Lorimer-Durborrow Congressional contest. The specific charge is contempt of court and refusal to pay $100 fine for opening the ballots after being commanded not to do so.

LONDON, April 15. -- The Times in its City article to-day says money was still in demand yesterday, only half of the large debt due the Bank being repaid. The movement of gold to Scotland beginning earlier than usual and the further export of sovereigns to South America being rumored as probable, the discount market was steady.

The White Plains accommodation train, which left the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon at 5:05 o'clock, was run into by "The Wild Cat," as the special train of the American Express Company is known, near the Bronxville Station of the Harlem Division of the New York Central. Ten persons were injured, some of them seriously, in the collision, which, was a rearend one.

ROME, April 14. -- After a lengthy discussion to-day the International Agricultural Congress postponed to the next congress further consideration of Count von Schwerin Loewitz's proposition for a European zollverein against American competition. The discussion on what is styled "Europe's declaration of war against America" aroused groat interest.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The much-discussed Water Storage bill was reported to the Senate to-day by its introducer, Senator Lewis, with two amendments. One was to correct a mistake in printing. The other embodied two propositions. One was a suggestion of William C. Whitney and other wealthy park owners in the Adirondacks, intended to prevent the construction of any dam upon lands which now constitute a private park.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Senator Elsberg will endeavor to have the Cities Committee report out to-morrow the Municipal Electric Lighting bill introduced by him at the request of Commissioner Monroe of New York City. In the event that the committee fails to act favorably upon the bill, Senator Elsberg will move to have it discharged from further consideration of the measure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A most interesting memento has recently come to light of the fierce conflict fought on Manhattan Island. It is a portion of a human thighbone or femur, which has been sawn off about seven inches above the knee, and piercing it to the marrow is a forged iron spike or nail about ten inches in length.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the C.H. Marshall Tenement House bill. This measure was the result of a compromise between those who sought a modification of the present law and the Tenement House Commissioner, and applies to cities of the first class. The amendments are designed to apply chiefly to Brooklyn and the outlying boroughs of New York City.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 14. -- Gloom pervaded the Great Northern Building to-day, for many of the officials were pinched in the slump of Northern Securities stock. Nearly all of them had stock, and some had protected their purchases with margins that were more than swallowed up in the decline.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14. -- Iris, a 50-to-1 chance, was the surprise of the racing at Oakland to-day. E.M. Brattain, favorite for the six-furlong race, was beaten by Fort Wayne and Mexicanna. Glendenning, the second choice, stumbled when the field entered the stretch and threw Buxton, who escaped uninjured.
Henry Hellman has sold for George W. McAdam the plot, 55.6 by 100, on Central Park West, 25 feet south of Ninety-ninth Street, to Leon A. Liebeskind, who will erect an apartment house on the site.
ALBANY, April 14. -- Superintendent of Banks Kilburn to-day authorized this Atlantic Bank of Brooklyn and the Nassau Union Bank of Oyster Bay, to carry on a discount and deposit banking business.

LONDON, April 14. -- Money was in less demand, and there was a better supply in the market to-day. Discount rates were steady. The possibility of an early reduction of the Bank of England's rate of discount restrained holders from discounting freely.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- A new subject was added to-day to the list under investigation by Assistant Postmaster General Bristow. It relates to the repairing of cancellation machines, and was brought to the attention of the department first by the Auditor of the Treasury for the Post Office Department, and then by the Controller of the Treasury.

NEWARK, N.J., April 14. -- Regarding the New Jersey trolley merger, President McCarter of the Fidelity Trust Company said to-day that $8,000,000 of stock is to be issued in addition to the $10,000,000 that the Fidelity is to underwrite.

Trading in the outside market yesterday showed a marked change from the conditions which had prevailed on Monday. The more or less excited state of the market which accompanied the break in Northern Securities was followed by an upward movement which brought about a recovery of nearly 3 points in Northern Securities itself and which was reflected by smaller gains in other parts of the list.

BERLIN, April 14. -- The manner in which the American Tobacco Company cornered the market for cigarette tobacco is reported upon by the Berlin Chamber of Commerce to the Prussian Commerce Minister, Herr Moeller, as follows:

The sane people of the United States have been put to much loss and inconvenience by reason of the conflict between two opposing forms of madness from which the country is suffering. There are certain Americans who are money mad. They want to make millions upon millions, and make them in a minute.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- It was a dreary conclusion on which the bugler sounded "taps" at the Bennings Spring meeting to-day. Rain had fallen incessantly during the day. The track was fetlock deep in slimy mud, but despite the bad conditions the crowd in attendance was fairly large.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 14. -- With the mainmast and most of the rigging in place and the bowsprit attached, the bow of the Reliance has settled, and she floats now with the bow lower than the after part. Even when the main boom is on board, and the boat attains her designed balance, it is thought that she will still be distinguishable at a distance from the other ninety-footers by a dip forward.

The advent of a new racing year will be celebrated at the Queens County Jockey Club track, Aqueduct, L.I., by metropolitan patrons of the turf this afternoon, when the first racing programme of 1903 in New York will be run off after a lapse in the sport that has extended over a trifle more than six months.

NEW ORLEANS, April 14. -- Denunciation of the actions and policies of organized labor was a feature to-day at the first session of the annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers. David M. Parry, President of the association, in his report declared that the labor unions are driving the country toward a Socialistic system that would cause widespread industrial disaster.

On the eve of the city election in Chicago we called attention to the report of the Municipal Voters' League reviewing the record and claims of the various candidates for the City Council, and remarked that it would be interesting to see what effect it had on the results of the election.
CHICAGO, April 14. -- New York exchange was at 30c premium to-day. Time and call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.

BOSTON, April 14. -- The money market continues quiet, with no change in rates. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25 cents discount. Clearings, $23,612,052; balances, $1,854,803.

Mr. HILL made a very plausible, and we are inclined to think a just, point against the President when he "drew the deadly parallel" between a recent speech of his on the tariff and a speech on the same subject made by the Secretary of War last October.

Notwithstanding the fact that London before the opening here sent over generally higher prices, with only one decline and many advances of a point or more over Monday's closing prices here, the market opened highly irregular, with some issues up and some down, but with no important change in any leading issue except Illinois Central, which opened down a full point and a half on a 1,000-share transaction.

Every seat was filled and every inch of standing room crowded with the audience that gathered in the Madison Square Concert Hall last night to hear ex-President Grover Cleveland and the other speakers who discussed the industrial education of the Southern negro at a mass meeting organized by the Armstrong Association.

Much the most important feature of the proceeding's at the Jefferson dinner in the Bronx was the speech of Mr. SHEPARD. And much the least interesting and the most discouraging part of that speech was the part devoted to municipal affairs. It would not be fair to say that "Jeffersonian principles" have nothing to do with municipal affairs.

There was dismay in the hearts of the numerous brides and bridegrooms yesterday at the downpour of rain and the high winds. Some of the weddings were not as well attended as they otherwise would have been. To-day a large church wedding will be that of Miss Chloise Hatch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Denison Hatch, to Cornelius S. Lee. G.G. Haven, Jr., has taken the coach Pioneer for the day.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Rear Admiral Bowles, Chief of the Bureau of Construction, at the request of the Secretary of the Navy, prepared the following statement of the nature of the repairs to be made to the battleship Maine:

The failure of one of the most important witnesses for the prosecution to appear at the trial of "Al" Adams, the "policy king," who yesterday faced a jury for the second time on charges of having violated the anti-policy law, is causing serious concern in the District Attorney's office.

Samuel Untermyer, who is acting as counsel for Whitaker Wright in the pending extradition proceedings, arrived yesterday on the Kronprinz Wilhelm on his return from London, where he was engaged as counsel for various European corporations in effecting a European consolidation of machinery works.

ALBANY, April 14. -- "If the shadow of William Tweed can look down upon this mundane sphere he must be filled with regret that during the days of his power he did not have a Corporation Counsel and a Fire Commissioner who had the nerve to put forward such a bold 'grab' as this."

The annual report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company contains some figures which will be read with interest. This is the parent company of the Bell system. In 1902 it had a gross revenue of $13,277,457 and gross expenses, including interest and taxes, of $5,442,185.

A charity entertainment and reception will be given at the Lexington Avenue Opera House on Friday evening by the Spalding Literary Union, the proceeds of which will be donated to the poor of the Paulist Fathers' parish. The entertainment will be a reproduction of the opera given by the boys of this, club, assisted by the young ladles of the parish, in the early part of last Fall.

ST. LOUIS, April 14. -- Ex-Gov. William J. Stone, newly elected Senator to succeed George G. Vest, was to-day before the local Grand Jury investigating boodling in the State Legislature for an hour and twenty-five minutes. When he issued from the Grand Jury room, looking very serious and somewhat fatigued, the Senator said:
First Lieut. Frank T. Woodbury, Assistant Surgeon, is detailed as a member or the examining board at Fort Rihan Allen, vice Contract Surgeon Charles E. Mittelstaedt.

NEW BRUNSWICK, April 14. -- A dispatch received here late this afternoon from Providence, R.I., telling of the suicide of a woman who was a passenger on the Joy Line steamer Tremont, which left New York Monday night for Providence, verified the suspicion that Mrs. Martha Hamilton Breazeale, who disappeared from here yesterday, had committed suicide.
WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Weather Bureau to-day issued the following weekly summary of crop conditions:

An atrocious murder was revealed early yesterday morning when the body of a man was found in a barrel in front of the building at 743 East Eleventh Street, near Avenue D. The man's throat had been cut from ear to ear -- the head almost severed from the body -- after eighteen knife wounds had been inflicted in the neck.

PARIS, April 14. -- The art events of the year will be inaugurated to-morrow with the opening of the Salon of the National Society of Fine Arts at the Grand Palais, which will be followed a fortnight later by the Salon, held under the auspices of the Government.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Assemblyman George B. Clark of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District of New York, a wealthy legislator, who has attracted much attention recently by statements he has made about bribery in connection with legislation, is writing a book on his experience in the Legislature. He intends to have this book published immediately after the adjournment of the Legislature.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 15 -- A large barge of the Eastern Coal Company, holding 3,000 or 4,000 tons of coal, with a Captain and his family on board, is thought to have gone down in the Sound between Captain's Island and Long Island this morning.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The action of the Pennsylvania Legislature to-day in unanimously adopting a resolution urging the President to appoint Pay Director James N. Speel to be Paymaster General of the Navy caused great surprise among naval officers and excited unfavorable comment.
LONDON, April 15 -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day for contango arrangements. Discounts were firm.
Capt. George P. Howell, Corps of Engineers, is assigned to duty as Engineer of the Sixth Lighthouse District, to relieve Capt. James C. Sanford.
JOPLIN, Mo., April 15 -- A mob took an unknown tramp negro from the city jail this evening and hanged him to a telegraph pole at the corner of Second and "Wall Streets, two blocks from the Jail.

We learn with mingled pain and curiosity that a private cable dispatch received in London from a British source in Bogota says "that the ratification of the Colombia-United States Panama Canal treaty is extremely doubtful."

Bedraggled, damp and cold, the patrons of racing who have earned the right to description as "regulars" triumphed over all difficulties and made a holiday of the opening of the New York racing season at the Queens County Jockey Club's track. Aqueduct. L.I., yesterday, by sheer force of the spirit that moved them to assemble 10,000 strong for the first racing in New York since last Fall.

BOSTON, April 15 -- Rates are unchanged, but the money market shows a slightly easier tone. It is expected that there will be a gradual easing off of rates from this on. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25 cents discount.

Two hundred colored residents of this city and vicinity tendered a complimentary dinner last evening to Booker T. Washington, Principal of the Tuskegee Institute. The diners also subscribed a large sum of money, enough to found two scholarships at Tuskegee, the holders of which are to be named by Booker T. Washington.
Charles G. Gates, son of John W. Gates, has purchased a seat on the New York Cotton Exchange. This gives the firm of Harris, Gates Co. two seats on that Exchange, Mr. Harris being a member already.

PARIS, April 15 -- At the Maisons Laffitte meeting to-day W.K. Vanderbilt's Edna ran fourth in the race for the Prix Coeur Volant, his Bright was fifth in the contest for the Prix Ricquebourg, and his Knickerbocker was sixth in the running for the Prix Mont Geron.

Discussing the condition of the iron and metal trades. The Iron Age will to-day say: Surface indications are adverse in the foundry iron markets of the country, and there is a weaker feeling. Sales are largely confined to spot lots and to early delivery, only little being done for the second half. It must be noted, however, that the volume of these transactions is large, considering the circumstances.
CHICAGO, April 15. -- After a six weeks' visit to the Pacific Coast, Marshall Field returned to Chicago to-day:

The Municipal Art Society has done the public service of issuing, in a simple and intelligible shape, its plan for simplifying and regulating the problem of traffic presented at the "Circle," at Eighth Avenue, Broadway, and Fiftyninth Street.

The peculiar sensitiveness of the present market to so-called "bad news" was well illustrated by the movement of prices yesterday afternoon following upon the announcement that the Interborough Directors had refused to grant the demands of the Manhattan employes for shorter hours. Up to the time of this announcement -- 2:30 o'clock -- the market, though dull, had been consistently strong and with the tendency to a still higher level.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Notwithstanding the fact that the business of the Treasury for the first half of the current month shows a deficit of $1,284,633, the available cash balance to-day is $222,650,854, a slight increase over that on April 1. For the fifteen days of April, 1902, there was a surplus of nearly $2,000,000.

ALBANY, April 15 -- The Sturgis Power of Removal bill which has passed the Assembly was to-day favorably reported by the Senate Cities Committee. It gives to the Fire Commissioner of New York the power to remove at will any firemen or official of the department who has reached the retiring age limit.

Cold weather has interfered much with the pleasures of society this week, and the weddings have not been so gray, owing to rain and clouds. Yesterday there were quite a number in town. The largest church function was that which united Miss Chioiso Hatch and Cornelius S. Lee. The Pioneer started out in the morning, with G.G. Haven, Jr., as host.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Senator Platt or Gov. Odell will control the Railroad Commission during the remainder of the Governor's term, and whether the semblance of cordial relations shall be maintained between the two leaders will depend upon the vote had in the Senate to-morrow upon the confirmation of Frank M. Baker as a member of the commission.

ALBANY, April 15 -- A bill passed by the Senate to-day changes the close season for deer from Nov. 16 to Nov. 10, extending to Aug. 31, both inclusive, and also provides that no person shall take more than one deer in an open season.
CHICAGO, April 15 -- Time and call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent. New York exchange at 20 cents premium.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The attention of the officials of the Department of Justice was called to-day to a published dispatch from San Juan, Porto Rico, to the effect that the United States Attorney there had declined to prosecute criminally several army and naval officers for alleged smuggling explaining his action by the statement that he was acting under instructions from Washington.

Notwithstanding a heavy wind and an almost constant downpour of rain yesterday, the schoolboy golfers opened their interscholastic championship tournament on the links of the Westbrook Golf Club, near Isllp, L.I. Twenty-three ambitious players turned out, and, considering the untoward conditions, the scores were very creditable.
ALBANY, April 15 -- Several important measures were before the Legislature today and the sessions of both houses were interesting.

ALBANY, April 15 -- "Grab" bills again occupied the attention to-day of those who are guarding the interests of New York City. There were developments affecting various measures which showed that public condemnation of several bills had not discouraged the men behind them.

Two well-known painters of New York are showing the original color sketches, various drawings of figures and the canvases themselves that represent two large half-moon-shaped decorations for the Citizens' Bank in Cleveland, Ohio. They are at the studio of Mr. Edwin H. Blashfield, in Carnegie Hall, and are the latest work of that painter and of Mr. Kenyon Cox.
ALGIERS, April 15 -- Algiers was in gala attire to-day in honor of the coming of President Loubet, the first French Chief of State since Napoleon III. to visit the French North African possessions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While in the South a short time since I had occasion to visit the historic City of Richmond, Va. In company with a business acquaintance, I visited all the places of interest, made so especially by the war for the Union and the scenes incident to the war of the Revolution.

After careful consideration the Directors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company have refused the demand of the elevated trainmen for a nine-hour day with increased pay. This decision sustains the management and is based upon sound business considerations. The motormen retain the terms of employment they had when running locomotives.

Eight Sicilians, said to be members of the Italian Mafia and one of the most dangerous bands of counterfeiters that ever operated in this country, were arrested on the Bowery last evening, and the United States Secret Service agents and the local police are certain that they were responsible for the murder of the man whose body was found in a barrel in East Eleventh Street, near Avenue D, early Tuesday morning.

When the members of the International Agricultural Congress now in session at Rome took up the notion of a general central European customs union for the purpose of suppressing the competition of the United States it was found that the only delegates enamored of that peculiarly absurd project were from Germany, with the exception of one from Austria-Hungary.

Stocks irregular. Money easier, 3 to 5 per cent. Yesterday Consolidated Gas declined 1 1/2, and no other security among those sufficiently active to be called representative of the market altered so much as a full point. It may be worth while to say that the fractional changes were irregular, that is, were about equally advances and declines, but it is not worth while to discuss the price movements in detail.

"Did you ever hear the peacock story?" "No. What is it?" "Oh, it's a beautiful tale." The above will do as a starter. Others of a similar brand will follow in due course, They are samples from the verbal hash served by Mooney and Holbein and Barter and Wakefield at Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre.

The signs of an increased wheat crop continue to be encouraging and even flattering. "The condition of Winter wheat," says the latest report of the Weather Bureau, "is generally excellent, and it has made splendid progress since the first of the month." "On the whole the condition of the crop in the Winter wheat belt east of the Rocky Mountains is more promising than for years."

Mayor Low gave a hearing yesterday morning on the Cooling bill to permit the erection of boat club houses on the Harlem River front on the property of the city known as the new Macomb's Dam Park, and also to allow the construction of an athletic field in the park, which was passed by the Legislature last week.

NEW ORLEANS, April 15 -- The National Association of Manufacturers devoted a large part of its session to-day to resolutions setting forth its attitude toward organized labor. It declared Its position by adopting several resolutions touching phases of the labor question. The first resolutions adopted were those reported from the Committee on Resolutions.

Prices in the outside market yesterday were stronger, but inmost stocks there was considerable falling off in transactions. The market in Northern Securities was much less animated than on Monday and Tuesday, and altogether it presented a more normal aspect than it showed on the first two days of the week.

More testimony was taken yesterday in the trial of "Al" Adams, "Policy King," before Justice Scott. Before the adjournment for the day Assistant District Attorney Schurman had all the testimony except that of one witness in, and ex-District Attorney Ridgway of Brooklyn, who appears for Mr. Adams, announced that he would close his case before the noon recess today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The most thoroughly successful amateur theatrical performance known to Washington in many years took place this evening at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. W.J. Boardman, where 230 representatives of official and resident Washington saw the first performance of "The Ambassador's Burglar" and "The Sleeping Car." as given by a company of prominent young people for the benefit of St. John's Orphanage.

BEAUMONT, Texas, April 15 -- A careless workman kicked over a lantern at one of the Caldwell oil wells on Block 38, Hogg-Swayne Tract, on Spindle Top, to-day, and started a fire that resulted in the loss of property valued at $1,000,000 and the bankruptcy of twenty or more of the smaller companies.

The Easter observances in the Church of St. Ann were suggestive. The familiar anthem, "Christ is Risen," cannot be said to have been sung exactly, for the choir was voiceless, but four young women appropriately arrayed in white surplices came forward, and interpreted it by the sign language, relying, wholly upon graceful and synchronous movements to express the sentiment of the hymn.

LIVERPOOL, April 15 -- The White Star liner Celtic, Capt. Lirdsay, scheduled to sail from Liverpool to-day for New York, and the British steamer Heathmore, Capt. Hignett, at Liverpool from Antwerp, collided in the Mersey to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- For a week past heavily loaded wagons bearing queerlooking packages somewhat resembling huge feather dusters wrapped in burlaps have been going in a daily procession from one of the Washington freight stations to the White House. The big burlap bundles swayed back and forth and the wagon wheels creaked and groaned with their load.

A new system of athletic control has been inaugurated at Columbia, according to an announcement by Nicholas Murray Butler, President of the university, yesterday. Under the new plan the students' long fight to do away with the Faculty Committee on Athletics is crowned with success, and beginning this month the Faculty committee, so far as its relation to the purely technical matters of student athletic eligibility is concerned, will be done away with.

Through an order issued by Justice Blanchard of the Supreme Court yesterday it appears that two women claim the Rev. Ralph H. Baldwin as their husband. Mr. Baldwin for two years was a resident of this city, and for some time prior to July 1, 1897, was in the diocese of Bishop Potter and acted as the Bishop's chaplain.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The market displayed a firm undertone to-day, but business was slow, except in bonds, which were more active than for some time past. In the stock department strength was shown in the early trading, but when New York weakened in the afternoon there was some profit taking in United Gas, Reading, and Philadelphia Electric, all of which reacted slightly.

The Starin Line steamboat John H. Starin, which left New York for Bridgeport on Monday night, and which had not been heard from late Tuesday night, is safe. She is now tied up at Locust Grove, near Huntington Harbor. Late yesterday a report was received to the effect that the provisions supplied for the trip had given out and that recourse had to be made to the cargo.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 15 -- The Supreme Court to-day denied the motion of Congressman William E. Lorimer of Chicago for leave to file a petition for a mandamus restraining the election officers of the Sixth Congressional District from producing the ballots in court for a recount of the votes in the contest and election case of Durburrow vs. Lorimer.

ST. LOUIS, April 15 -- Expected revelations in the legislative bribery scandal before the Grand Jury at Jefferson City today were not made because of the collapse of Lieut. Gov. Lee, After a two hours' interview early this morning with Attorney General Crow, in which he is said to have made revelations regarding the use of money to procure legislation, he took to his bed.

Racing at the Aqueduct track plunged straight into the middle of things yesterday, and the crowd of "regulars" in attendance took their sport with a seriousness suggestive of the hard and cold Fall. Their enthusiasm was spent on the opening day, and for the second day they attended to business strictly, and with such acumen that they made post favorites that won five of the six races.
LONDON, April 16. -- The American schooner Ebenezer Haggett, abandoned and dismasted, has been towed into Flores, Azores Islands. Part of her cargo of lumber is gone.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As your paper has the reputation of being both clean and fair, and is a journal to which, for that reason, I subscribed when I lived here formerly, as I have since my return, I venture to request that you will publish this correction of an error in your report of my case appearing in this day's issue.

ALBANY, April 16. -- When the Railroads Committee met this morning a vote was taken on the nomination of Mr. Baker and seven Republicans voted for a favorable report. Three Democrats voted in the negative, and Senator Elon R. Brown, one of the insurgents, refrained from voting.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 16. -- Edwin Gould of New York City arrived here today and registered at Carval Hall. Mr. Gould is awaiting the arrival of his yacht, the Chicota, and will go on a cruise.

NEW ORLEANS, April 16. -- The eighth annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers ended to-day with the unanimous re-election of President David M. Parry of Indianapolis. There had been much talk of a movement to defeat him, owing to his position on the labor question, but there were no surface indications of dissensions when the election took place, the convention ordering the Secretary to cast the ballot of the delegates with vigorous cheering.

The Republican Editorial Association of the State of New York, in session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday indorsed the Administrations of President Roosevelt and Gov. Odell, and had a debate on the negro question. Senator Depew telegraphed regrets, and ex-Gov. Black did not attend, although he was expected.

Ex-District Attorney Eugene A. Philbin made public yesterday the report of his findings in the investigation of the Metropolitan Street Railway's reports and accounts. He was engaged to do the work by Henry J. Braker, stockholder to the extent of 100 shares. The report was handed over to the company, with a demand for explanations.

Officers of the New York Driving Club, which has headquarters at the Empire City track are preparing a new paln for matinee racing that is expected to not alone prove more satisfactory to the drivers, but which will insure keener competition among the horses. The plan under consideration calls for the classification of all the horses according to their ability and without reference to records.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Not less remarkable than the acrimonious debate over the nomination of Frank M. Baker was an incident of the late afternoon session of the Senate, in which Senator Braekett recalled charges of corruption that had been made against Senator Raines, and the Republican floor leader made a bitter reply in which he referred to Mr. Brackett as from "Saratoga and Canfield."

BALTIMORE, April 16. -- A feature of the annual meeting of the American Oriental Society to-day at Johns Hopkins University was the paper of Dr. Paul Haupt, in which he gave some of the latest conclusions of tin Bible critics. In part he said:

BOSTON, April 16. -- Rates show no perceptible change, but the tone of the local money market is easier. Call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25 cents discount.

The immemorial question what to do with ex-Presidents has received the suggestion of a new solution in the case of the present President. The suggestion is that since President ELIOT of Harvard will, in the course of nature, become superannuated about the time when President ROOSEVELT retires from his second term, the Presidency of Harvard shall be offered to this latter as a place of dignified retirement.

CINCINNATI, April 16. -- The National League baseball season of 1903 was inaugurated here to-day, when 12,000 persons paw the Pittsburg team give the Chincinnatis a decisive defeat. Phillippi let Cincinnati down with only two hits, but, combined with a wild throw, these enabled them to escape a shut-out.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 16. -- Concerning the report from the East that the Great Northern Directors will meet in this city in a few days to take action on a dividend which might be prevented by the Government suit, one of the board to-day said to The Associated Press:

The West Publishing Company, law book publishers, of St. Paul, Minn., has begun an action for $1,000,000 damages, in the United States Circuit Court, Brooklyn, against the Edward Thompson Company of Northport, L.I., publishers of the American and English Encyclopedia of Law and the Encyclopedia of Pleading and Practice.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Senator Martin of Virginia is confident that the Democrats will declare in their National platform for tariff revision along moderate lines, and that the declaration will cause no alarm or disturbance of business. He believes the necessity for revenue not only compels conservatism on the tariff question, but that the day has passed when radical and extreme views find lodgment in the minds of the Democrats of the country.

-- There is something agreeably impressive in the idea of a "good road" between New YorK and Chicago, and the fact that an association has been formed and duly incorporated in this State for the purpose of urging the construction of such a highway will doubtless be a cause of general rejoicing.

In the rejection by the Senate at Albany of the name of his candidate for Railroad Commissioner Senator PLATT encountered quite the most serious and calamitous reverse of his political career. It is serious because the rebellious Republican Senators have thrust their knives deep into the political heart and substance of the aged Senator.

Recent experiments in North Wales in the location of ore beds by electricity have been so far successful as to attract to this method of prospecting a great deal of attention in scientific circles. In the case of the Cwmystwyth mines, in Cornwall, new and valuable deposits of lead ore and blende were located, of which the management was in ignorance.

ST. LOUIS, April 16. -- Lieut Gov. John A. Lee, whose statements to Attorney General Crow and Circuit Attorney Folk gave rise to the recent startling exposures in the double Grand Jury investigation of legislative boodling, to-day was served with a subpoena commanding him to appear before the St. Louis Grand Jury to-morrow.

The session of the Executive Commission of the American Section of the Alliance of Reformed Churches Throughout the World Holding the Presbyterian System was contiued yesterday in the Marble Collegiate Church.

ST. LOTTIS, April 16. -- The St. Louis National League baseball team to-day defeated the Chicagoans in a hotly contested game by a score of 2 to 1. Currie and Ryan were in the points for St. Louis, while Taylor and Kling did battery service for Chicago. The local pitcher had slightly the better of a pitchers' battle, allowing the visitors only four hits.

BITFFALO, April 16. -- Gov. Odell was on a train coming to Buffalo during the remarkable happenings in the Senate at Albany to-day. He arrived here this evening and went to the home of William C. Warren. He refused to be seen by any of the many persons who sought him to inquire about the breach in the Republican Party.

ALBANY, April 1:6. -- The Wilcox omnibus street railroad "grab" bill was reported by the Senate Committee on Railroads to-day. It will now go on the calendar, and a determined effort to pass it will be mae. Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman said to-night that he feared the promoters of the measure, will be able to marshal a sufficient number of votes in the Senate to put it through.

Still further charges of fraudulent accounting were advanced against the officials of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company at yesterday's sessions of the Amory-Vreeland libel suit hearings before Magistrate Barlow, in the General Sessions Courtroom of the Criminal Courts Building.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 16. -- In the presence of thousands of spectators, including many visitors from New York, Boston, and other cities, the largest vessel ever built in this country, and the greatest cargo carrier in the world, was launched this afternoon at the yards of the Eastern Shipbuilding Company, in Groton, across the Thames River from this city.

The volume of business on the Stock Exchange showed further contraction yesterday, but with the market undertone continuing decidedly strong and with many net gains showing at the close of the day. Trading was badly distributed, only fifteen issues being dealt in to the extent of 10,000 shares or more each, with four of these -- Pennsylvania.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were somewhat larger than they had been the previous day and in general prices, were better. During most of the day the market drifted uninterestingly, but during the last half hour of trading there was some spirited buying in the Steel bonds and in various other issues which resulted in quick advances and which brought the market at the close to practically the highest prices of the day.

That homicidal brute who murdered an old schoolmate for offering to shake hands with him, in place of distantly and awfully saluting him, has given mankind the crucial and classical example of the effect of Prussian officialism. The murder is, as we say, "the limit." The murderer did well to describe himself as a "Prussian officer."

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Negligence bordering close upon criminal carelessness on the part of some one in the city Engineering Department la said to have been largely responsible for the typhoid fever epidemic last Summer, which resulted in the death of seventy-one persons in the Nineteenth Ward alone.

DUBLIN, April 16. -- By a unanimous vote the Irish National Convention which met here to-day accepted in principle the Irish Land bill, introduced in the House of Commons by the Right Hon. George Wyndham, Chief Secretary for Ireland, and intrusted to John E. Redmond and his party the task of securing in the House of Commons that "serious amendment in various points of vital importance" which the National Convention may consider essential.

Matters are shaping in Great Britain for a very much closer and more intelligent restriction of immigration, looking especially to the exclusion of alien criminals. There are now in custody in England and Wales, undergoing terms of imprisonment for crimes, 625 aliens of comparatively recent importation.
Capt. Edwin B. Babbitt, Ordnance Department, will proceed to Sandy Hook Proving Ground on business pertaining to the manufacture of field and seacoast guns.

The surprisingly vast amount of knowledge of the Italian Mafia -- perhaps the most secret and terrible organization in the world -- that is possessed by the United States Secret Service Bureau was revealed yesterday, when information concerning that order was given out by Agent William J. Flynn.

A woman with a will visited City Hall yesterday to see Mayor Low, and flustered the private secretaries. After the trouble the woman emerged from the combat with an air of triumph, and the Mayor had to acknowledge that her cause was just. Some criticism was made of the treatment that the visitor received.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 16. -- The fitting of the Reliance's rigging is being pushed to-day faster than ever in an effort to make up for the loss of time occasioned by the storm yesterday. Additional riggers are at work attaching the steel wire shrouds to the mainmast. The weather to-day was not of the best, but the light northeast ram was not allowed to hinder the operations.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 16. -- M. Diefenderfer of Wood River, Neb., shooting from the sixteen-yard mark, to-day won the fourth Grand American Handicap at inanimate targets, with a score of 94 out of a possible 100. In winning the event he defeated practically all of the expert marksmen in the country, as most of the shooters of note competed.

An interesting scene in the new comedy, "A Fool and His Money," at the Madison Square Theatre, is that where Jameson Lee Finney instructs Anita Bridger how to play golf. It is a familiar scene on all golf links, but a novelty in stage settings.

LONDON, April 16. -- The supply of money was small in the market to-day and borrowers were dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were firm and transactions were limited, owing to fears of further withdrawals of gold for South America.

Delegates from every section of New York gathered last evening in Cooper Union to take part in the City Convention of the Citizen's Union. Nearly 1,000 delegates were present. Many made speeches in which it was clearly outlined that the Union had now begun in earnest their efforts to elect a Fusion ticket in the Mayoralty campaign next Fall.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 16. -- Moses Fowler Chase, the young millionaire brought back to America from a Paris asylum, arrived here at 1 o'clock to-day in company with his father. A big detail of policemen was at the station. Young Chase declared piteously:

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Local stocks were irregular. The remarkable fluctuation was a drop of over 8 points to around 60 on the sale of 50 shares of Pneumatic Tool. Title and Trust rallied a few points from its break of yesterday. Box Board preferred was firmer to around 23, and Can showed a small improvement.
CHICAGO, April 16. -- Lolita Armour is no longer a cripple.

ALBANY, April 16. -- This was a history making day in Albany for the Republican Party of the State. Through an alliance between the three insurgent Senators, Elsberg, Brackett, and Brown, unexpectedly reinforced by Senator Ambler, and the Democratic Senators, the nomination of Frank M. Baker, Senator Platt's candidate for the office ou Railroad Commissioner was rejected by the Senate by a vote of 28 to 23.

When Luigi and Achilles Porzlo, who say they live at 258 Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, disembarked from the Hamburg-American liner Palatia yesterday afternoon, they had hidden about their persons something like $4,000 worth of jewelry. They had several trunks, and although an Inspector went through them carefully he failed to discover any dutiable articles, and the brothers prepared to leave the pier.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 16. -- A woman of about sixty years of age, supposed to be Mrs. Anne Tompkins, a wealthy resident of Chappaqua, N.Y., was killed on the railroad track at Mamaroneck Station at 10 o'clock this morning. She alighted from a White Plains trolley car and went to the railroad station, following Baggage Master Gedney as he opened the gate at the track to cross to the west side.

LONDON, April 17. -- Russia has tightened her hold on Manchuria, says a correspondent of The Times, wiring from Niu-Chwang. The correspondent says that Niu-Chwang ought to have been restored to the Chinese on April 8, yet Russia is still in full occupation. Her flag is flying over the Custom House, and the native city is still administered by Russians, who patrol everywhere, occupying with troops the temple in the centre of the foreign concession.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 16. -- Galogero Salece was shot and instantly killed late last night in the hallway of his home, at 225 Third Street, where he lived with his wife and two boarders. He had complained of feeling unwell and had gone out to a drug store. Ten minutes later his wife and the boarders, who were asleep, were roused by the shooting, and, rushing down, found Salece's body.

There is to be a hearing before the Board of Estimate to-day on the plans for the construction of an approach to the new Manhattan Bridge, which is to reach the Borough of Manhattan at Fifty-ninth Street and Second Avenue as at present planned. The making of a thoroughfare from the terminal of the bridge up to the centres of traffic is the problem which the city officials will have to solve.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The query of D.F. Bristow of Camden, N. J. in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of April 11 relative to a continuation of "The Count of Monte Cristo" calls in mind one of the picturesque characters of Philadelphia journalism during the past quater century.
