Keidansky is a dreamer, a philosopher, a talker (above all a talker, and a good one,) of the Ghetto.

President H.H. Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, when seen last night at his home, 239 West Seventy-second Street, replied to the charges made against the company in the report of ex-District Attorney Eugene A. Philbin, setting forth that the reports of the company were improper, and the accounts apparently fraudulent.

"Charlotte Mary Yonge, Her Life and Letters." in which are contained her autobiography, a biography by Miss Christabel Coleridge, and her letters, edited by Miss Coleridge, is being published this week by the Macmillan Company. The autobiography, which takes up one-third of the volume, covers the period of Miss Yonge's childhood and early youth.

The many plans for the approaches to be constructed to the Blackwell's Island Bridge, the Manhattan terminal of which is at Fifty-ninth Street and Second Avenue and the Long Island terminal in Astoria, were discussed yesterday before the Board of Estimate. There was a large delegation of property owners present.

The official visit to this country of Gen. BADEN-POWELL, chief of the British cavalry, to examine that arm of our own service, is by no means the first tribute of the same kind our cavalry has received. A distinguished French cavalry General said not long ago that the beginning of the, revolution in cavalry tactics and organization came from the showing of the American civil war.

The situation developed as the result of deliberation among the trainmen and stationmen of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad system is thus far satisfactory to the public, and should be so to all in interest. The men do not want to strike. It probably involves an error of statement to say that the vote was "overwhelmingly in favor of a strike."

The third volume of C.F. Glasenapp's "Life of Richard Wagner," translated by W.A. Ellis, has just been published in London. Mr. Ellis, however, supplies 400 pages to 100 of the German author. The English version is practically Ellis's "Life of Wagner," founded on Glasenapp's. In the new volume, Mr. Ellis publishes this fragment of a letter written by Hans von Billow to his sister in 1851:

ST. PAUL, April 17. -- Circuit Judge Sanborn this afternoon set Monday morning, April 20, as a time for hearing arguments on a request by attorneys for the Northern Securities Company that the decree recently handed down be suspended in so far as it prevented the payment by the Great Northern and Northern Pacific Railways of dividends to the Northern Securities Company, since these dividends were ultimately to reach the same people any way.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 17. -- Prof. Paul Haupt, the noted biblical scholar, criticised Prof. Delitzsch of Germany in a paper on "Bible and Babel," read before the American Oriental Society at Johns Hopkins University to-day. Dr. Haupt said:

HORACE GREELEY in given greater attention and more space in the Encyclopaedia Britannica than either Clay, Calhoun, or Webster, the socalled great trio of American statesmen. He filled a vast space in our National life at a time when really great men were numerous; at a time when our greatest political and social struggles were being fought out to their final end.

CONDITIONS in the Balkan States are simply normal. What is there extraordinary in the boiling over of a pot set over a fire? Only this boiling over is not even intermittent, but constant. Not a pleasing aspect certainly, for there is the likelihood of a terrible scalding before long.

THE Oxford History of Music is not only the most important book of the kind ever undertaken in English since Burney and Hawkins produced their monumental works, but it is not too much to say that it is one of the most important in any language.

MR. W. BISIKER'S volume describes the journey of a party semi-scientific in character, which went around Iceland and through a great part of in 1900. You reach Iceland by means of steamers which ply between Copenhagen, Leith, the Faroes. and Iceland.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17. -- Harvard's inter-class championship crew races, which were rowed on the Charles River this afternoon, proved of an unusually exciting character. A stiff wind blowing diagonally across the course made a very ugly, choppy sea, and only two out of the five boat crews succeeded in finishing the course.

DUBLIN, April 17. -- The Irish National Convention concluded this evening. In two days it got through a large amount of controversial work, and emerged, to quote T. P. O'Connor, M.P., "scathless and honored from a test which the whole world was watching. It was not only shaping the destinies of Ireland, but it held in its hand the fate of the powerful British Ministry."
No reasonable man will deny that Mayor Low has deserved the commendation bestowed upon him by the Citizens' Union. At the meeting held on Thursday evening this resolution was adopted:

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- New charges of abuses in the Post Office Department are pouring in at headquarters from many directions, and are being turned over to Assistant Postmaster General Bristow. Among the latest developments is a report that a "promotion ring" exists to control promotions in the Post Office in the Borough of Brooklyn, N.Y., similar to that which is now being investigated in the Borough of Manhattan.

The New York State Library's list of books of the year, just published, contains 886 titles. These wore chosen from 7,833 books published last year. The list was then, as usual, submitted to the librarians of this State, and other persons, for a vote as to which are the best 50 for the uses of a village library.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: YOUR correspondent who suggests the elimination of "Don Quixote from the list of books that a young man's libray should contain must surely be unfamiliar with the work of Cervantes, or else is lacking in his power of literary discernment and in his judgment of human nature.

RIGHT TO DAMAGES FOR UNLAWFUL REMOVAL. -- The judgment for $800 recovered by John J. Fallen against Robert J. Wright, who was Commissioner of Corrections in 1896, as damages for his unlawful removal as Warden of the City Prison, was yesterday reversed by the Appellate Division. The court held that it was an error to allow Mr. Fallen to recover the amount of a counsel fee which he had paid in his reinstatement proceedings.

No one is likely to have a stronger impression of the crowding array of facts, interesting and important in themselves, that must increasingly perplex the historian than has the journalist. It is his function to report, and, if he may, interpret them as they present themselves. And he feels keenly both the need and the difficulty of so classing them that they may have that meaning which only their relations to each other can disclose.

BOSTON, April 17. -- The money market is much easier, and business is a little more active. Call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 1/2 Per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 20c discount; clearings, $28,047,761; balances, $l,942,122.

NOT long ago Mr. William Archer expressed the opinion that at the present time there was more careless proofreading in books issued by important houses than in the columns of the daily papers, in spite of their hasty production.
High prices were paid for American first editions at the Edwin P. Whipple sale (Boston. C.F. Libble Co.) last week. The best items were the following:

The brethren of the "Amen Corner" gathered at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening for their annual banquet. The funmaking of the "Amenites" made staid Senators laugh until the tears rolled down their cheeks. Supreme Court Judges, wont to spend the day in robes of judicial dignity, laughed until they almost fell off their chairs.

LONDON, April 7. -- The death of poor Charlos Leland at the age of eighty reminds one of the swiftness of the flight of time. It seems but yesterday since Leland and his brother were young men and the pride of literary Philadelphia.

IT SHOWS judgement on the part of Mr. Pemberton that in his "Life of Bret Harte" he should have avoided any special literary criticism. It was in 1879 that the writer of the biography first met Bret Harte.

Work on the Riverside Drive extension from One Hundred and Fifty-second Street to Lafayette Boulevard must be pushed energetically by Borough President Cantor under a decision rendered yesterday by Justice McCall of the Supreme Court. On the application of W.B. Hopping, counsel for the Lansing Improvement Company, the Justice issued a peremptory writ of mandamus to compel the completion of the work, in which property owners holding interests aggregating $20,000,000 are concerned.

LONGMANS, GREEN CO, are to publish next week "The Study of Mental Science: Popular Lectures on the Uses and Characteristics of Logic and Psychology," by Dr. J. Brough; "National Duties and Other Sonmons and Addresses," by the late James Martineau, collected and arranged by Gertrude and Edith Martineau; "Colonial and Camp Sanitation," by George Vivian Poore of the University College.

In studying this lesson it must be borne in mind that there is always a great difference between what any one does and why he does it. For two men may do exactly the same thing -- or any one man may do essentially the same act on two different occasions -- and a true judgment will praise one act and condemn the other.

Vol. VI. of the Vartorum and Definitive Edition of the Works of Edward FitzGerald (Doubleday, Page Co., octavo,) has its chief interest in revealing the vagaries of the author's mind, both in the changes he made in his own texts, which are verbally reproduced, and in his letters to Charles Eliot Norton and to Fanny Kemble.

Abuse more violent than ever characterized the assaults of opposing counsel upon each other and each other's clients at yesterday's session of the Amory-Vreeland hearing before Magistrate Barlow. During the two minutes before the session closed, after several hours of testimony, Messrs. Osborne and Nicoll talked so fiercely that the Magistrate administered a stern rebuke to both of them, saying he would not put up with such behavior again.

Without entering into any of the endless and entangling arguments for and against the nobility of the character of Aaron Burr, one may say truly that Mr. Tyson's little story "The Stirrup Cup" is as dainty a tale of love and wartime as one need card to read. The story, indeed, might have been equally as charming without its background of apparent reality.

After a conference of almost six hours duration with W.D. Mahon, President of the International Association of Street Railway Employes, and President George E. Pepper and the Executive Committee of the recently organized union among the employes of the Manhattan. Elevated Railway, W.E. Bryan, Vice President and General Manager of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, announced last night that he considered the differences between the company and its men as good as settled.
LONDON, April 17. -- Money and discount conditions were practically unaltered to-day.
LONDON, April 17. -- Messrs. Macmillan Co. announce that they have definitely decided to publish John Morley's eagerly awaited "Life of Gladstone," Oct. 2.

IT SEEMS that Capt. Owen Kettle has retired from public life. Invested with a Knighthood and the Order of the Bath, through a curious misunderstanding, he is reported to have retired to the secluded but not unimportant town of Wharfdale, in Yorkshire, where as the founder and leader of the Particular Methodists and head of a well established household he has been heard to express his intention to dwell hereafter in peace and comfort.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 17. -- Walter J. Travis and Findlay S. Douglas, the two great golfing rivals in Lakewood open tournaments, won their two rounds to-day in the match play competition for the leading cup. Travis won both of his games without difficulty, first defeating A.D. Compton.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Opportunity for another, outbreak of the hostility between the Republican factions was not taken to-day when the nomination of George W. Morgan to be State Superintendent of Elections was confirmed unanimously by the State Senate. This development was surprising, as it had been expected by the Democrats and the Republican insurgents that the Platt men would retaliate upon the Governor for the rejection of Frank M. Baker by the Senate yesterday.

Nothing could have been more gratifying to those who hope that the "United Kingdom" may cease to be a misnomer than the temper shown at the Irish National Convention on Thursday. When Mr. WYNDHAM introduced his "healing measure" in the House of Commons Mr. REDMOND, the leader of the Irish Parliamentary Party, complimented him on his good intentions, but beyond that Mr. REDMOND strictly declined to go.

A great producer of golden eggs for its owner was the Blue Goose, a drinking saloon, gaming establishment, and hotel kept by Pierre La Martine, a Frenchman, in Pandora, a Colorado mining town. The golden eggs were stolen front the Rainbow Mill and Mine by workmen, who received as their share of the plunder a very small proportion of the precious metal refined in his cellar by the wily Pierre.

ST. LOUIS, April 17. -- With Lieut. Gov. Lee apparently a fugitive from the State, while evidence unfavorable to him is being almost hourly brought to light, and indictments hanging over the heads of four State Senators, the "boodling" industry in Missouri is in a bad way.
Representatives of Columbia, Cornell, and the University of Pennsylvania met in Earl Hall yesterday and formed the first Intercollegiate debating union ever organized.

Mayer S. Auerbach has bought, through L.J. Phillips Co., 17 City Hall Place, a five-story building on lot 25 by 100. The seller is a Mrs. Dowd. This is the first time this property has changed hands in over fifty years.

"His Friend the Enemy," by William Wallace Cook, is a tale of Dakota in the days before its Statehood was achieved and when life within its borders, if one may rely on Mr. Cook's version of it, came nearer to being farce-comedy than anything off the stage. The advertisement of the book calls it "a stirring tale of the Northwest," and there is certainly no word that could better describe its ruling spirit.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Gen. Greene's Police bill, with the three-platon rider, passed the Senate to-day, through a combination of Democrats and six of the Republican Senators, the final vote being 27 to 20.

"Children of Destiny," although its scene Is laid in tide-water Virginia about fourscore years ago, is neither a historical novel -- Glory be! -- nor yet one which accentuates local color and the characteristics of its time. The picturesque, homogeneous society of the day is vividly portrayed, and the author is at all times true to her period, without perpetually dragging it in, as is the manner of some, by the hair of its head.

As it turned out Peter Minuit's purchase was a good one. Representing the West India Company, the syndicate established in Holland. Peter in exchange for goods valued at 60 guilders took over from the Indians Manhattan Island. The date of the transaction was May, 1626. Supposably the natives were a branch of the Algonquin nation of Lenni-Lenape, and were handsome and fairly industrious savages.

TRENTON, N.J., April 17. -- One of the possibilities of the North Jersey traction merger, it is believed here, is a through trolley line from New York to Philadelphia. Prospectuses and maps issued by a Philadelphia banking house are being circulated under the title of the New York and Philadelphia Electric Railway.

The strength which was shown by the Stock Exchange market early in the day yesterday was reflected in the outside market, where prices generally were somewhat above the closing figures of the previous day. In point of activity the market compared favorably with the earlier days of the week, there being considerable increase in transactions in several of the stocks which recently have been most prominent.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 17 -- In weather which had moderated after the storm of yesterday the riggers continued to-day their work on the Reliance. A number of new ideas are noted about the deck. The most important one is that whereby the main sheet may be stowed below deck instead of on deck as is usually the case.

WEYMOUTH, England, April 17. -- Sir Thomas Lipton's new challenger for the America's Cup was dismasted in a squall to-day shortly after leaving this harbor preparatory 10 another trial spin with the Shamrock I. Her mast, as it fell, over the side, carried several of the crew and all the gear and canvas overboard.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- The National League season opened here to-day with a defeat for the home team, Boston winning by a score of 8 to 3. Pitcher Fraser lost the game in the third inning, when he was hit safely three times, and gave five bases on balls, netting Boston five runs.

PAUL LAURENCE DUNBAR, author of "Candle Lightin' Time" and "Lyrics of Lowly life," is preparing a new volume of verse which will probably be issued in the Fall under the title of "When Mallndy Sings."

ALBANY, April 17. -- The Lewis Water Storage bill, which was denounced by the Board of Trade and Transportation of New York as one of the "most outrageous grabs" ever introduced in the Legislature or the State, was passed by the Senate today by a vote of 28 to 18.

The identity of the murdered man whose body was found in a barrel in East Eleventh Street last Tuesday morning has not been established, but the police and the Secret Service agents are making good progress toward fixing the responsibility for the crime. Inspector McClusky said last night that six or seven of the thirteen men who are detained would be dismissed on Sunday, and that those remaining would be held for the murder.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- The seventh annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science began here to-day at the Manufacturers' Club. The principal question under discussion is that of closer relations between the United States and Latin America. W.W. Rockhill, Director of the International Bureau of American, Republics, presided at to-day's session, and made the introductory address on "International Arbitration on the American Continent."

The third series of Mr. Charles Booth's religio-sociological work. "Life and Labor in London," which comes from the Macmillan Company this week, is entitled "Religious Influences." It includes seven volumes. The first deals with London north of the Thames -- "The Outer Ring"; the second, "The Inner Ring"; Vol. III., "The City of London and the West End," while the last four volumes deal with other sections of the metropolis.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Referring to the application at St. Paul to-day in behalf of the Northern Securities Company, the Department of Justice has made public the following telegraphic instructions of the Attorney General, sent to the United States Attorney at St. Paul on the 14th inst.:

LONDON, April 18. -- The Albanians having disdainfully rejected the conciliatory overtures of the Sultan's special commission, says the Constantinople correspondent of The Times, the Yildiz Palace is greatly embarrassed, and more troops have been ordered to Ipek.

This is a most exciting tale of an Italian boy brought up by his peasant relatives to fulfil their revenge on his father, who is ignorant of his very existence. Horace Vanburg, a rich young New Yorker, idling about the world, encountered a block-eyed young woman in Florence and married her in spite of her frowning Aunt Malenotti and the latter's evil-eyed, scar-marked foster-brother, Pietro.

The races at Aqueduct were run on a dry and good track yesterday for the first time since the Queens County Jockey Club meeting opened. Every winner of the afternoon was heavily backed, and as these victors included three strong post favorites, the results made sad havoc in the ring. The weather was clear, but that favorable circumstance did not materially increase the attendance.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Department of Justice received to-day the following cablegram from the United States Attorney at San Juan, Porto Rico, respecting the pending smuggling cases:

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in Brooklyn, which recently barely escapsd the foreclosure of a mortgage for $32,500 on its property, has had entered against it a judgment for $933.67 that was obtained by Mrs. Jane D. Nies. She sued to recover on a note for $750 given by the church in December, 1896.

No one who listened to or has read the speeches of Mr. CLEVELAND and Dr. BOOKER T. WASHINGTON on Tuesday evening can fail to understand the excellence of the work that is doing at Tuskegee Institute. It is the chief agency administered by negroes for negroes in the South that guides them toward progress by a way that no sensible white man of any section can condemn or seriously criticise.

A.S. Murray's monograph on "The Sculptures of the Parthenon," is published this week by E.P. Dutton Co. With the help of Carrey's drawings, it has been found practicable to give the frieze almost entirely, as we know it, in one long folding sheet, which is reproduced in photogravure and has been placed in a pocket on the back cover of the volume.

"Paddy the Pig," as Clarence O'Brien is known in the Tenderloin, had taken passage on a steamship sailing to-day to have, according to common report, his portrait painted by Whistler. He cannot go because Paul Seidel, a waiter of 428 Second Avenue says he welched on a five-dollar bet on the second race at Aqueduct on Thursday.

GLASGOW, April 17. -- The accident to the Shamrock III. Has caused universal regret in Glasgow and Dumbarton, where it formed almost the exclusive topic of conversation throughout the day. George L. Watson, the designer, in an interview, expressed the deepest regret, but refrained from expressing art opinion on the subject, except to say that the refitting would not militate against the cup challenger's chances.

LONDON, April 18. -- The report of the commission of British workingmen which was taken to the United States at the end of last year by Alfred Moseley in order to study conditions of labor in America was issued yesterday. It presents the views of twenty-three delegates, each separately giving a synopsis of his deductions resulting from the trip.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 18. -- Golf has been the principal topic of interest at Lakewood this week. The tournament of the Golf Club of Lakewood, which began with the qualifying rounds on Thursday, attracted a great crowd of visitors. With the close of the tournament, the Golf Club at Lakewood passes into history, and the new Lakewood Golf Club, of which Lewis Nixon is President, takes possession of the clubhouse and links.
LONDON, April 18. -- Money was in fair demand to-days and rates were easier Discounts were steady. The hopes of a reluction of the Bank of England's rate of discount before the month end increased.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., April 17. -- Fourteen seniors and two instructors from the Yale Forest School are at West Point practicing forestry for the United States Military Academy in the Academy forest along the Hudson. They arrived April 1, and will remain until about June 15.

HOOSICK FALLS, N.Y., April 18. -- Over- seers of the Poor in the town of Hoosick are suing the estate of Mary Gray, late of Hoosick Falls, as a result of an investi- gation which showed that a woman who for several years had been receiving sub- stantial aid from the poor fund, had $1,000 on deposit in a local bank and other money invested in mortgages.

THE murder of an artilleryman named Hartmann by Ensign Hussner of the German Navy, reported from Berlin last week, makes particularly interesting statistics published in the Volks Zeitung, which show cases of maltreatment of soldiers by their superiors. It appears that in the last three months alone forty convictions by courts-martial have been published.

THERE is a plot of ground in Southern Michigan which, probably, not many generations ago formed part of the lake of that name. In course of time it became a fresh-water swamp, as valueless a piece of property as might be found. To-day it is a prosperous, fertile farm, upon which one of the most interesting industries of the world is conducted on a large scale.

NEWARK, N.J., April 18. -- Charles Gardner of 79 Sumner Avenue called on Mrs. Elizabeth Stevens in her home on Broad Street this afternoon, shot her four times, then tunned the revolver on himself and put a bullet through his heart. Gardner died on his way to the hospital. Mrs. Stevens is in the City Hospital in a critical condition.

The tobacco monopoly is one of the chief sources of revenue in France, and some interesting official details on the working of it in 1901 are issued from the Ministry of Finance. The total receipts were 414,733,483f. (u16,589,339) a diminution of 2,741,639f. (u109,635) on the year. The expenses were 82,244,121f., (u3,289,765,) leaving a net profit of 332,489,362f., (u13,299,374,) which was also a decrease of 1,383,463 (u55,338) on 1900.

Papers were served on Magistrate Tighe of the Adams Street Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, by Charles P. Blaney, counsel for the Anti-Policy Society, in an action which will come on in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, on April 27, seeking Tighe's removal on the ground that he is incompetent.

MR. BROADWAY rode home on the rear platform from choice and necessity -- from choice because he wanted to finish the cigar the senior partner had insisted upon his lighting just before leaving the office, and from necessity because he could not get inside the car.

George Arliss is to be credited with this bit of scintidant wit: On the stage of the Belasco Theatre the other night he was chatting with Blanche Bates, Eleanor Moretti, and saveral other members of "The Darling of the Gods" cast. The talk turned to shop -- as actors talk almost always does -- and a certain player of leading parts was under discussion.

TRENTON, N.J., April 18. -- Beryl Hope, the actress, who is known in private life as Mrs. Maude A. Wright, has just obtained a decree of divorce from her husband, William H. Wright, of New York, on the ground of desertion, Chancellor Magie having approved the recommendations made by Referee Cooke, and filed with the clerk of the Court of Chancery.
Eugene A. Philbin made the following reply yesterday to the statement of H.H. Vreeland, made in the Amory matter Friday night:

Corporation Counsel Rives will institute proceedings this week against several men of wealth and prominence for the recovery of their personal taxes for last year. Assistant Corporation Counsel Martin Saxe, in charge of the Bureau for the Collection of Arrears in Personal Taxes, delivered to the chief of the department yesterday a long list of names of men who are in arrears and who have disregarded their notices for various reasons.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Reports from army recruiting officers show that no difficulty is being experienced in obtaining men for regiments serving in the Philippipes; On the contrary, recruits express a desire for assignment to regiments in those islands or under orders to go there.

SHANGHAI, March 14. -- In the relations of the Powers with China the subject uppermost for some time will be that of payments on account of the indemnity of 450,000,000, taels imposed by the peace protocol which followed the suppression of the Boxer outbreak. While the tael is the monetary unit of value in China, it has never had behind it anything more substantial than silver bullion.
MISS WYLLARD had wired me to take a villa for her in Posillipo. Miss Wyllard always wired when possible. I had known her to send quite long letters by telegraph; fifty or sixty words.

The first week of weddings and Easter festivities is over. It has been in some respects quite remarkable. Winter returned with rain and cold winds and everything but snow, and made it extremely gloomy in the beginning. The only consolation was that conditions were somewhat similar elsewhere.

Through an application for a Supreme Court order it became known yesterday that United States Senator William A. Clark of Montana, the copper multi-millionaire, has been sued for $150,000 damages for an alleged breach of promise to marry. The plaintiff in the action was Miss Mary McNellis, at one time a newspaper woman of this city, who met Senator Clark during the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1896.

The reorganized Church Choral Society will give two concerts in St. Bartholomew's Church on Tuesday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock, and on Wednesday evening at 8:15 o'clock, under the direction of Mr. Richard Henry Warren. The performance on Tuesday will be in the nature of a public rehearsal.

With impressive ceremonies the little col- ony of orthodox Russians in this city began at midnight the celebration of Easter in the new church on East Ninety-seventh Street, which has been named for St. Nicholas, the patron saint of all Russia. The church was opened in November last.

The Philharmonic Society has issued a statement, addressed to its subscribers, setting forth for the first time in public the reasons for its action in regard to the proposed endowment fund for its benefit -- "apparently" for its benefit, as its phrase is -- which it recently declined to accept. The statement is as follows:

Yesterday's weekly Clearing House statement, though generally favorable, was disappointing in one important respect -- the loan item, which, despite the heavy stock market liquidation, unexpectedely showed an increase of $2,427,890. In all other respects the statement was favorable. Reserves on all deposit increased $2,200,330, reserve on deposit other than United States deposits increased $2,200,400 specie increased.

ROME, April 18. -- Count von Schwerin-Loewitz, a leading member of the Reichstag and the President of the German Agricultural Council, who was a delegate to the International Agricultural Congress just held here, spoke to-day to the representative of The Associated Press concerning his plans for a European customs union against American goods.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 18. -- In the presence of 25,000 persons the armored cruiser West Virginia was launched at 2 o'clock this afternoon by the Newport News Shipbuilding Company. Thousands of visitors were here to attend the street fair, and they helped to make a throng almost as great as that at the double launching of the Kearsarge and Kentucky.

MISS MABEL COOK, the book surgen at the Astor Library, has long sough eagerly for a real, live bookworm. Whenever a ponderous sixteenth century tome comes to her operating table she eagerly scans its interior on the chance of taking her famous enemy alive. But no bookworm has ever been discovered at the Astor, although they are waiting to frame and glaze him and hang him on the wall when he comes.

On Wednesday of this week the new building of the New York Stock Exchange will be formally dedicated, and on the next day the members of the Exchange, who have been without a home of their own for two years, will trade in the most elaborate and costly hall ever built for dealing in securities.

SENATOR McKEE of Paterson, who is violently opposed to the Passaic River trunk sewer act, Says that if the Legislature attempts at the special session called by Gov. Murphy for Tuesday next to repass it without the amendments he put into it at the regular session he will keep the two Houses busy all the Summer.

THE adoption of the wireless telegraph systems for transmission of messages apparently sounds the doom of the carrier pigeons in army and navy services both this country and Europe; but the relegation of the birds back to the paths of peace and good-will cannot be regretted by their breeders and lovers.

About nine years ago, when R.H. Rew. wrote an account of the Sussex chicken rearing and cramming industry for the Royal Commissison on Agriculture, the profits were highly satisfactory. But it ap- pears that through this and other public notices of the undertaking those who were engaged in it, at one time comparatively few, have been followed by a great number of imitators.
WAMPUM, Penn., April 18. -- In a battle following an unsuccessful attempt to rob the First National Bank of this place early this morning, one man was killed and another seriously wounded.
THE talk had turned to Summer outings, and the lady of the houseboat sat serene, without a trace of care upon her brow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The traveler through the South to-day is thoroughly impressed with the fact that the schoolmaster is abroad in the land, and that he is making himself felt as, perhaps, the most potent factor in the evolution of Southern civilization.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Little Fritzi Scheff put Mme. Sembrich's nose out of joint at the Auditorium this afternoon -- at least, that was the interpretation placed on the incident by the 5,000 persons who listened to a delightful performance of "The Magic Flute."

LONDON, April 18. -- The final game for the Football Association Cup, played at the Crystal Palace this afternoon between Derby County and Bury Borough, attracted the usual enormous crowds. As early as 4:30 A.M. excursion trains from the North began emptying thousands into London, and by 8 o'clock it was estimated that 40,000 provincial football enthusiasts had arrived on the grounds.

WITH the approach of Spring their are many elections and general meetings at a great number of the clubs. The Strollers have had a very lively fortnight with various tournaments, especially the pool affairs, which has excited general interest at the different clubs.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18. -- In a wellplayed game of baseball here this afternoon the nine of Pennsylvania State College defeated the Annapolis cadets by the score of 1 to 0. The batting was poor, owing to the strong wind that blew across the diamond. The fielding on both sides was clean, although the visitors had two errors marked against them, while the middies had 3.

It all conditions of road and weather are favorable, the Racing Committee of the Automobile Club of America will make another attempt to-morrow and Tuesday to hold the trial contests to select the remaining two members of the team of three American automobilists to represent this country in the race for the Gordon-Bennett International Automobile Racing Trophy over the Irish roads next July.

ARTIFICIAL, abrasives are important factors in every machine and industrial plant, and the success of modern machinery is largely due to the perfect grinding and polishing obtained through the use of artificial abrasives suited to each particular class of work. With the manufacture of new kinds of abrasives there has grown up a correspondingly wider employment of them in industries of a very dissimilar character.

SUPERSTITIOUS!" she exclaimed scornfully; "not a bit of It. I have too much sense for that. Of-course there are some little things portending good or bad luck that occasionally claim my attention, but superstition is only the failing of the weak.

Tammany Hall, in view of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court adverse to the claim of William S. Devery to be recognized as a member of the Executive Committee, has decided to ignore the ex-Chief of Police. This course was decided upon by Leader Charles F. Murphy and his immediate advisers, and freely declared at the Wigwam yesterday, although Mr. Murphy individually would not commit himself publicly.

A BILENE, Kan., April 11. -- Throughout the prairie West this is public sale time. Not for years has there been so large a number of " vendues " as this year, for the custom of thus disposing of the used material of the Western farm is just reaching a general acceptance. It is a curious and interesting feature of the modern life of the new States, particularly those where population is unstable.

The third Bach Festival, to be given in Bethlehem, Penn., as has already been announced in THE TIMES, will be more elaborate than either of those that have preceded it. It will occupy the week of May 11. The performance will be given in the Moravian Church, under the direction of Mr. J. Frederick Wolle.

BY TRADITION and reputation the college girl leads a strenuous life, devoted, when not engaged in academic duties, to athletics, dramatics, societies, and class interests. An outsider must wonder sometimes if these pursuits never pall, and if she never really plays or indulges spontaneously in the impromptu or the unconventional.

Although it would be a great mistake to assume that gambling is the chief function of the Stock Exchange, there is nevertheless a good deal of gambling done there, and, as in every other kind of gaming, the bets, especially of the professionals, are laid on the operation of the minds of the players.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18. -- The fourteenth annual open handicap track games of the University Track Association were held here to-day. A strong wind was blowing diagonally across the stretch, but notwitnstading this good time was made in all the events. Princeton led in points with 47, getting five first and two ties for first place, cesides a number of seconds and thirds.

Pride in Chicago's growth and development is not confined to its municipal boundaries or those of its containing Commonwealth, which it has sometimes threatened to overflow. It is felt throughout the country and its glow is reflected upon other lands. None so remote as not to catch at least a stray beam of its radiance.

The first sabre team competition to take place in this country was held last night at the Fencers' Club teams of three men each being entered from the New York Athletic Club, the Fencers' Club, and the New York Turn Verein. The contest was for a handsome silver cup presented by W.S. Gurnee, third and offered by the Feneers' Club, the cup to become the property of the club winning it three times.

DELAFIELD was sitting at a writing table in the window. He had apparently been writing: but Mademoiselle Le Breton found him in a moment of pause, playing absently with the pen he still held. She thought how much nicer it was than if he had been playing presently with his typewriter, as some men do in moments of abstraction such as this.

The Board of Public Service of Cincinnati has abolished all the golf links in the public parks and has forbidden the game therein on the ground that it would be dangerous to women and children who frequent the parks for outing and recreation.

IT WAS a rainy day at Catfish Corners. Quite a few of the Corners' most veracious citizens were in session at Grimsol's grocery. Those meetings at Grimsol's grocery are never in executive session. They are open and above board. Any one may sit by and hear them.

WINSTED, Conn., April 18. -- In a race with a divorce decree as the goal Mrs. Marion G.W. Brinkerhoff of Westhaven, daughter of D.E. Waltermyer of New York, defeated her husband, John R. Brinkerhoff, of Hackensack, N.J., having been granted the decree by Judge Elmer of the Supreme Court yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18. -- Lafayette defeated the university team here this afternoon by a score of 7 to 1. The game was particularly well played by the Eastonians, and Princeton found Johnston an unsolvable puzzle. The home team was badly out of practice from the long spell of bad weather.

Suit has been instituted by Leonhard Michel, one of the stockholders of the old David G. Yuengling Brewing Company, for the recovery of real and personal property said to be worth about $3,000,000, which he declares was obtained from the corpora- tion by John F. Betz, the brewer, who is declared in the Action to have brought about the receivership of the corporation in a friendly action and then bought in the assets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am in receipt of a communication from the Merchants' Association of this city urging me to oppose all railroad bills now before the Legislature except the Finch bill, in which communication, beautifully colored in black and red, I find the following:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one who participated in a previous production of the oratorio of "The Seasons" I feel I must protest against the performance given by the People's Choral Union on last Monday evening.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article headed "The Financial Situation" is so excellent that I cannot forbear expressing to you my appreciation of the same.

I DON'T pretend to e a philosopher. I hate to bear things, and to make the best of bad bargains. Alonzo does that for the family, while I groan and make an awful fuss about everything. He always says "What's the use of crying over spilt milk?" But I say that's the kind to cry over.

The track events were unusually well contested last night at the joint athletic games of Company I, Eighth Regiment, and St. George's Athletic Club in the former organization's armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue. Big fields of sprinters turned out for the shorter distances, which made the races very much of a scramble at the start.

Successive hearings before the Local Board of Improvements and the Board of Estimate upon the Fifty-ninth Street widening project apparently leave that problem as far as ever from a satisfactory solution. No suggestion has yet been made that has not been met with valid and almost unsurmountable objections, and all of these suggestions, together with the various makeshifts which have been proposed, are of a cost admittedly out of all proportion to their ultimate value.

LONDON, April 18. -- Hopes of cheap money after Easter have been disappointed owing to the activity of trade in the provinces. Coin shows no tendency to return from the country, and though the note circulation declined, the Bank of England's reserve was u1,000 lower this week.

Hoi Skolastikoi, the organization of local pedagogues, dined at the Hotel Savoy last evening, with Andrew Carnegie as a guest of honor. There were about 180 educators in attendance, many of them gray-haired men who sang and cheered with the enthusiasm of their long-gone-by college days, evidently enjoying themselves immensely.

CINCINNATI, April 18. -- According to an authorized statement made to-night by George B. Cox, the recognized leader of the Republican organization in Hamilton Coun- ty, the Republican leaders in Ohio have agreed on Myron T. Herrick of Cleveland, the Hanna choice, as the Republican can- didate for Governor.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Gov. Odell would say nothing with regard to the rejection of the nomination of Frank M. Baker as Railroad Commissioner when he arrived from Buffalo to-night at 6:55 o'clock on the Empire State Express, accompanied by Mrs. Odell, Military Secretary Bird, and Adjt. Gen. Henry.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., April 18. -- Two hundred and fifty fishermen from Bonavista Bay were out on the ice floes hunting for seals yesterday when the wind changed, drove the ice off shore, and carried the hunters out to sea. They had great difficulty in reaching land, many being out all night and only getting ashore this morning.

Another vast assemblage of local baseball thusiasts was present at the Polo Grounds yesterday when the New York and Brooklyn teams met for the second time, and the majority of them were more than satisfied with the result, as the local men won by a score of 6 to 1. This victory took the keen edge off their defeat on the opening day, and Manager McGraw was well pleased with the work of his men.

The prospect of a series of races during the coming season between Dan Patch, 1:59 1/2, and Prince Alert, 2:00, has aroused great interest among light harness horsemen. Such a contest would undoubtedly result in a new world's record. Opinion as to the result differs greatly, and while the majority of horsemen think Dan Patch the fastest pacer of the two, Mart Demarest is anxious to make a match,.

Another college town is added to the list of those which have invited epidemics of typhoid fever by persistent neglect of the conditions of safety which lie in pure water and good drainage. The latest candidate for the unpleasant notoriety of exemplary punishment for the disregard of nature's laws is South Bethlehem, which contains the splendid foundation of Lehigh University.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Socialists point out that ever since the division of society into classes the powers of government are wielded to pass such laws, and enforce such only, as would tend to perpetuate the economic system which yields the power of exploiting to a given ruling class.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Edward M. Shepard, speaking at the Jefferson dinner, attacked President Roosevelt, because England, Germany, and Italy were allowed to make war on Venezuela to obtain a reliable regulation of her-unsettled debts. Nobody, indeed, except some wild Westerners expected Mr. Roosevelt to take a different course.

PROVIDENCE, April 18. -- Edward Baxter, a striking coal teamster, was shot today by a non-union driver, and Frank Howland, a negro, is under arrest charged with the shooting. Five shots were fired, and two bullets hit Baxter in the head. Neither wound is regarded as serious.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 18. -- An afternoon paper here contains a report that it is believed the victim of the tragedy is Lazarus Loria, a non-union trolleyman, who worked for a time during the strike here, but who went away some time ago after having had trouble with the driver of one of the strikers' buses.

THE gowns of chief interest during the week have been those worn by the brides, their attendants, and the guests at the various nuptials. Wedding gowns are always more or less conventional, and any variation that makes for novelty is hailed with joy by those with a fondness for the new in dress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Sunday issue of a week or two ago I find this very fair sizing of the inane parody of English pronunciation as taught in Paris for fivepence and without the help of a teacher.
The Camden Fire Insurance Association has increased its capital $100,000 and its surplus $100,000.

With a strong west wind blowing over the grounds, the teams of the Crescent Athletic Club and Swarthmore College contested a game of lacrosse yesterday at Bay Ridge, which was won by the home team by a score of 10 goals to 4. The weather conditions just suited the players, but the large gallery of spectators stretched along the side lines and in the stand found the wind a little more than uncomfortable.

PAPA took them, mother and child, straight from Madison Square Garden to a little table d'hote restaurant in Fourth-Avenue, where he used to go before he was married, and where he knew the salad was always fresh and good at this time of the year.

Many Republicans are finding serious fault with the lack of activity on the part of their Count Committee, which has long been the mainspring of the Platt local organization. Through that organization, which he has held with a firm grip. Senator Flatt has dictated nominations and checkmated others when it so pleased him.
ORIENT, L.I., April 18. -- Andrew Latham of this place was found dead in his stable this morning. He had committed suicide by hanging.

TRENTON, N.J., April 18. -- The 6,000 em- ployes of the John A. Roebling's Sons' Com- pany will receive an increase in wages of from 8 to 10 per cent, the rearrangement of the wage schedules being near com- pletion. The 1,500 laborers receive about $8 a week each for fifty-four hours' work. The company has provided the increase in the absence of any demands for more pay on the part of the men.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 18. -- West Point defeated Dickinson to-day by the score of 18 to 1. The score:

ALBANY, April 18. -- Major Gen. Charles F. Roe issued an order to-day notifying the commanding officers of the organiza- tion selected to be represented in Gov. Odell's escort at the dedication of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition at St. Louis of such selections, and appointing Col. Samuel H. Welch of Buffalo, senior Colonel of the Guard, commanding officer of the provisional regiment which will form the escort.

COMMODORE NOAH is one of the most misunderstood characters in history, Because he took water once, in his life many people are under the impression that he must have been easily imposed upon and lacked the power of decision. But he had ideas of his own, as two instances will show.

It is plain, from the replies and comments that they have elicited, that our remarks upon the appearance that Americans are "bad merchants" in comparison with their foreign competitors have attracted the attention of persons interested.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- It was an uneventful as well as an unproductive day in the local market. About the only redeeming feature was the firm undertone. There were but few of the local issues that received more than the one quotation; these, as a rule, represented either unchanged prices or nominal improvement.

PARIS, April 7. -- At the two Paris Salons this year American art will be well represented. Herbert W. Faulkner, Vice President of the American Art Association in Paris, has two pictures accepted by the New Salon, both of which are studies of Venice in the style which has already made this painter famous.

NEW ORLEANS, April 18. -- A sensation was caused at the New Orleans Cotton Exchange to-day by the receipt of the res- ignation of J.H. Smith of the Birmingham cotton firm of Smith, Coughlin Co. The resignation was held over, and an investi- gation ordered into certain transactions in which the Birmingham house is involved, in which complaint of irregular dealing has been made.

AT THE very outset let us admit that a five-cent stamp is a useful article to any person who has ase for it. Also, that two five-cent stamps are two useful articles when they are needed, while three five-cent stamps are three useful ar -- but we will get into the story.

A well-dressed young man who said that he was Charles Frederick Spang, son of the senior member of the firm of Spang, Chafant Co., iron merchants of Pittsburg, Penn., was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station about 10 o'cloclc last even- ing after he had shot at a man on Broad- way.

The line of argument adopted by the delegation of women who appeared before the Committee on Laws and Legislation of the Board of Aldermen to protest against any restriction of the liberty of dogs to run at large unmuzzled in the streets of New York displayed a breadth of misconception and a comprehensiveness of misinformation which in some respects was typically feminine.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent editorial on "Mr. Shepard and the City" seems to me to be unfair. Undoubtedly Mr. Shepard is abundantly able to defend himself and his views, should he deem it proper to enter the lists, and so I in no way claim to be his champion.

ELIZABETH," complacently remarked Mr. Lendthings, mopping his forehead after the unusual effort of planting row of sweet corn and tamping the seed kernels down carefully with the back of his hoe, "we may not have the proud distinction of raising the earliest radishes in Swamphurst this season -- Mr. Chinwhiskers seems to be invincible in that line -- but I honestly believe that we shall certainly have the honor of raising the very latest.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Attorney General Cunneen to-day announced that he had taken an appeal to the Court of Appeals from the decision of the old General Term of the Supreme Court, Third Department, given some years ago, that public officers have no right to ride on Pullman or sleeping-car passes.

IF THERE is any one question which all New Yorkers have asked within the last few months, it is: How nearly completed is the subway? Owing to the disturbed condition of the streets, even along the blocks where the underground work is finished, it is difficult for the layman to conclude from his own observations exactly what is the present status of the tunnel.

Nine devoted apostles of American land- scape continue the tradition of a special exhibition of paintings of our scenery on land and water. It has often been said that in view of the quantity and excellence of the landscape contingent at the older ex- hibitions shown in New York each year a sufficient reason hardly exists for this so- ciety.

Plans have just been consummated for the immediate completion of a line of railway in Central America extending from the Atlantic to the Pacific Coast, which it is believed will have the effect of diverting a arge share of Central American exports from foreign ports to those of the United States.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 18. -- Walter J. Travis of the Garden City Golf Club won his sixth Lakewood Cup yesterday in the Lakewood Golf Club tournaments. He met his old Lakewood rival, Findlay S. Douglas of the Nassau Country Club, and defeated him in a splendid match by 2 up and 1 to play.

PARIS, April 18. -- Mrs. F. Moulton was at home last Sunday to a few friends at her pretty apartment in the Champs Elysees. The hostess looked handsome in a most original robe d'interieur composed of white and pink pompadour silk. The front and back formed a dalmatique, bordered with pearls, while the loose Japanese sleeves were of soft pastel liberty silk.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The Post says that foreign residents of Argentina who are of Germanic origin, including Austrians, Swiss, Hollanders and Scandinavians, are forming a protective association, with the object of obtaining more effective guarantees of their rights and interests. A similar organization is being created in Brazil.

Driven insane by jealousy and the be- lief that another man had wrecked his home, George Jordan, thirty-five years old, a boat builder, shot and killed his wife Clara and fatally wounded his eleven-year-old son in the woman's rooms, at 1371 First Avenue, near Seventy-fourth Street, yesterday morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of March 21 you quote, with comments, a characterization of Hon. Charles R. Skinner, State Superintendent of Public Instruction, by the School Bulletin of Syracuse.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., April 18. -- The fishing schooner Independence, Captain Cusick, put in here to-day reporting the loss of four of her crew, who were knocked overboard by the main boom, and were drowned during a gale on last Thursday night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Pan-American relations were further discussed at today's session of the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science. The members of the Academy and their guests visited the Commercial Museums early in the day and inspected the special exhibits of South and Central American products.

ALBANY, April 18. -- It is the opinion of the best-informed and most far-seeing of the Republican politicians that the differ- ences between Senator Platt and Gov Odell may well give President Roosevelt cause for great concern as to what New York will do for him in the Presidential contest in 1904.

UTICA, N.Y., April 17. -- A former Philadelphia woman, Miss Anna Newman, a cousin of the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke, owns a farm which has the greatest elevation of any cultivated land in the State of New York. It is located in the town of North Elba in the Adirondack Mountains, four miles south of the village of Newman and Lake Placid, where several thousand tourists gather in the Summer.
Meaning of the Anglo-French Rapprochemen. Just now the Paris correspondents of London papers and the London correspondents of Paris papers seem to be rivaling each other in an exchange of amenities.

THIS year there is a decided craze for Italian gardens, especially in the suburbs, and at the different resorts. The formal Italian garden is one of great beauty and brings one back quickly to sunny Italy. Mrs. Edward J. Berwind has one of the most extensive at her Newport home.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The peculiarities of Capt. " Bill " Emery, now commanding the Indiana, are a fruitful source of gossip in the navy. A pluckier, more determined, more positive man never lived, yet he appears to mankind as a languid swell. He lives in a handsome house in the most aristocratic quarter of Washington.

A thief has been active in the Waldorf-Astoria for the past six weeks, his special method being to steal wristbags and purses from women guests in the corridors and reception rooms adjoining the restaurant. Numerous complaints of the thief's work have been made to the house detectives. It is said that several women prominent in society have suffered.
A DETECTIVE on the staff of District Attorney Jerome and a "sleuth " employed by a big New York detective agency were exchanging experiences.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What greater source of irritation and injury could be inflicted upon the dog than the extremely tight collar so often in use? Recently when calling at a friend's house, her dog (well groomed, a valuable thoroughbred.) came toward me, and it was with difficulty I could slip my finger under the cruel strap, so wax-tight was it.

William A. Clark, a policeman attached to the West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street Station, was arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday charged with beating his two-and-a-half-year-old son Thomas in a cruel and inhuman manner. No fewer than thirty-four contused wounds were found on the child's body, and he was so weak and emaciated as to be unable to walk or talk.

A further conference took place yester- day forenon between representatives of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and of the elevated railroad employes in the Western Union Building. An agreement was prepared covering the points considered at the long-drawn-out conference on Fri- day, and was approved by both sides.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 18. -- Senator M.A. Hanna, has taken notice of the speech of D.M. Parry, President of the National Association of Manufacturers, at the con- vention in New Orleans.

THERE is very little in the way of Summer furniture that is not made in the hand-wrought willow nowadays. Cottages are entirely furnished with it, and one woman who likes the delightfully cool effect it gives has put nearly $3,000 worth of willow furniture into her pretty Summer home.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an attorney who represnets a few of the 15,000 people whose cases are awaiting trial in New York City, I ask your paper to point out to the Legislature and the public the need of immediate legislation for the relief of the crowded courts of New York and Kings Counties.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 18. -- The eagerly awaited and much-vaunted Easter Day parade was a damp, dismal failure. The rain descended in a steady downpour until late in the afternoon, and the spirits of the enormous crowd that had flocked here to see and be seen became as damp and bedraggled as the unfortunates who were forced to brave the storm.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -- Yale won from Amherst in a listless game this afternoon, scoring 12 runs to the visitors 2. Kane, who pitched for Amherst, and Who held Yale to a tie game for thirteen innings last year, was a disappointment to-day, giving nine bases on balls in four innings and then retiring in the middle of the fourth inning.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 18. -- The Constitu- tion arrived here in tow from Bristol this afternoon and anchored in Brenton s Cove. She is to go west to haul out and have her underbody cleaned before taking any practice spins here.

PHOENIX, Arizona, April 18. -- Announce- ment that the Government had Decided to make the largest artificial lake in the world sixty miles from Phoenix was made here this afternoon. It will be in the Tonto Basin, or Hudson reservoir.

MUCH of the dialogue in Opie Read's play, "The Starbucks," now at Daly's Theatre, is unusually bright. The following occurs in a scene between Kintchin, an old colored servant, played by Col. William Lightfoot Visscher, who has inherited $20 from a " mammy," and Mrs. Mayfield, acted by Lida McMillan.

THe attention of Yale baseball leaders has been directed to the problem of how to keep the players in good condition, in view of the results of the recent Southern trip. A movement is now on foot to drop the Southern trip from the Yale schedule next year. The difficulty with the trip is that it gives the players, while green, too much hard work and too much traveling.

CLARENCES entrance to the kindergarten was delayed by a severe cold in the head. Wen he was finally able to take a fling at knowledge in her rudimentary forms his mind was still embittered with memories of past sufferings. When the teacher showed him the picture of a man and put a few simple questions to him concerning the five senses he could not put the painful thoughts entirely aside.

It is a curious comment upon the assembled wisdom of the State of New York that the ridiculous bill to make another legal holiday should have passed both houses of the Legislature. It is to be hoped, and, we suppose, to be expected, that Gov. ODELL will veto this absurd measure.

A note from Helsingfors, the capital of Finland, states that the Czar has given Gen. Bobrikoff, the Governor General of Finland, power to take on his own responsibility all steps which may seem to him necessary in the event of his considering the measures taken by the Finnish authorities insufficient.

The body of the victim of the barrel murder still lay unidentified on its slab in the Morgue last night. At least fifty persons, according to the detectives, had viewed the remains there during the day, but none had been able to make a positive identification.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article in to-day's issue admits of some additional remarks about the wheat crop of 1903.

"If you want to find a good play, take one which you are sure has been refused by all the big managers of New York," yesterday declared George H. Broadhurst, whose farce-comedy, which he put on at the Madison Square last week with success, was successively rejected by four of the best-known managers of Broadway.

We have, of course, no intention to prejudge the charges recently made as to the sale of promotions in the Post Office in this city and in Brooklyn. An investigation is being made by the authorities, and we must await the results.

ST. LOUIS, April 18. -- Four more indictments for bribery, making seven in all, were returned by the Cole County Grand Jury to-day. The names of five of the persons indicted are known. All are accused of connection with the "Alum boodling" in the last two sessions of the State Legislature.

The recent agitation of the police in New York over the subject of Sunday concerts has recalled to a New York musician the experience he had with a series of Sunday concerts in Boston -- it was so different, and also so like the things you read about Boston. Mr. Arthur Whiting gave last season a series of Sunday evening concerts in Boston with the Kneisel Quartet.

LONDON, April 18. -- It seems as if whenever there is a dearth of interesting domestic topics to engage the attention of the English people they will henceforth be able to count on Germany to supply subjects for lively discussion.

HAVANA, April 13. -- With April tourists turn their faces northward, and for six months the incoming steamers bring few passengers; the outgoing ones are crowded. There are few strange faces to be seen on the streets, and many familiar ones are absent, for Cubans begin to go north early in the season.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- It is announced at the Navy Department that the European Squadron which is to be present at the naval demonstration at Marseilles upon the return of President Loubet from Northern Africa will go north and be present at the Kiel celebration.

Of all the plays of the theatrical season now waning none has made a more vivid impression upon the public of intelligent playgoers than the old morality, "Everyman." For almost 400 years it was regarded as a dusty old preachment that laid grisly emphasis on the charnel house aspects of death.

During last week there were no legal or financial developments in the case of the Northern Securities Company, and Wall Street spent the latter days of the week in recovering from the shock the decision gave in the earlier part of the week. But there has been decided progress in the company's material development.

I'VE often thought what great fun it must be to be the wife of a professional humorist," suddenly spoke up the girl who had jilted a promising young grocery clerk to become the wife of the only druggist in town. The Young Ladies' Fortnightly Sewing Circle was holding its regular meeting, despite the fact that the original "young ladies" had long since blossomed into plump matrons.

WEYMOUTH, England, April 18. -- The Shamrock III., challenger for the America's Cup, which was dismasted in a squall off this port yesterday, is being rapidly overhauled. The destruction of her standing gear was practically complete. Almost everything above deck must be renewed. The wrecking crew is not trying to save much, the object being to clear away the wreckage as quickly as possible.

Final arrangements have been made for the annual Spring tournament of the Lakewood Polo Club to be played on the Georgian Court grounds of George Gould. The entries closed last week with the Chairman of the Polo Association, and the pairings were made yesterday. In all, there are five different teams entered for the two trophies, the Herbert prizes, given by H.L. Herbert, and the Georgian Court Cups, given by Mrs. George J. Gould.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 19. -- It was announced to-day that at a meeting of the Board of Trustees of Cornell University held yesterday President Schurman presented a report on the present condition of the university, showing that since April 1 inquiries had been addressed to 2,677 students registered this year at Ithaca, with a view to ascertaining how many would return to the university in September next.

LONDON, April 20. -- The Times's correspondent at Tangier says the discontent in Fez is increasing owing to a great rise in prices, caused partly by the rebellion and partly by the drought. The natives of Tangier are almost daily praying publicly for rain.

The sowing of annuals is best done during April, the hardier ones earlier in the month and the more delicate ones later. As regards soil preparation, it must be remembered that an annual has to complete the cycle of its existence in a few brief months, and its development of roots, shoots, leaves, and flowers are very rapid.

WEYMOUTH, England, April 19. -- The two Shamrocks left here to-day at noon for Southampton. The challenger was towed by the Erin. Before the departure of the yachts Sir Thomas Lipton said in regard to Friday's accident:

TACOMA, Washington, April 19. -- The crisis existing in the lumber and shingle industry of the Pacific Northwest has been taken up by Secretary Shaw of the Treasury Department, with the object of ascertaining whether the inter-State commerce law is being violated. The condition is a tremendously increased producing capacity, with railroads unable to furnish sufficient cars for hauling lumber and shingles to Eastern markets.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Naval experts will pay close attention to the repairing of the battleship Maine at the Cramp yards, where she was constructed. This vessel, the latest to be launched of the greater fighting machines of the navy, and only placed in commission within the past few months, typified, it was believed, the highest development in the art of building war vessel up to that time.

-- That pamphlet of directions with which certain German land owners about to visit this country have been supplied must be, if one may judge from the brief excerpts from it that have been cabled over, well worth reading all through. It is evident that the man who wrote it is not without some knowledge of our ways, but it is equally evident that he does not get things just right.

ALBANY, April 19. -- There is no present reason to doubt that the Legislature will adjourn, according to the official programme, Thursday, April 23, or, with the clock turned back, Friday, but the four legislative days ensuing between now and then have the prospect of being full to overflowing with both work and controversy.
BAKERSFIELD, Cal., April 19. -- James McKinney, an outlaw, was shot and killed here to-day. Deputy Sheriff Tibbetts was also killed and Constable Packard was fatally shot.

The Democratic Party, as it approaches the campaign year, is in the fortunate and unusual position of having in its ranks half a dozen men who are available for the nomination. Republicans have often made the Democracy unhappy by the derisory reminder that it had but one candidate.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 19. -- Miss Edith B. Stevens of Summit has received the commission for designing the pediment of the main entrance to the pavilion of the Liberal Arts Building at the St. Louis Exposition. Her sketch calls for an arch surmounted with a globe and an eagle. The reclining figures will be twelve feet high when placed in position.

Excitement ran high on the Speedway yesterday morning when a great throng of spectators saw the famous little trotter Queen Wilkes beaten two heats out of three, for the first time in her career, by David Lamar's bay trotter The King, 2:10 1/4. The pair have long been rivals for the trotting honors of the road, but until yesterday Queen Wilkes usually succeeded in placing the majority of heats to her credit.

BERLIN, April 19. -- Mrs. Mary H. Hunt of Boston, representing the Women's Christian Temperance Union at the International Anti-Alcohol Congress at Bremen, has sent the following communication, dated to-day, to The Associated Press:

BERLIN, April 19. -- The Boerse had an irregular tendency last week. Trading opened on Tuesday under the influence of the Northern Securities decision and rumors that American buyers were attempting to cancel a large order for German pig iron. The latter assertion caused some selling of iron shares, which depressed quotations several points.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 19. -- A crusade was waged against saloon keepers who sold palls of beer to-day by specially appointed policemen and the regular force. A dozen men, boys, and girls wore arrested. Some of them obstinately refused to tell who sold them the beer, while others readily told the police where they got the beverage.

JEWISH SEMINARY OPENING. Dedication Exercises for Institution Now Headed by Dr. Schechter. The new Jewish Theological Seminary, at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and Broadway, will be opened formally next Sunday afternoon. The old seminary is in lexington Avenue.

PATERSON, N.J., April 19. -- A fire which occurred in this city late to-night destroyed four three-story frame tenements at 919, 921, 923, and 925 Main Street and caused a loss of over $50,000, partly covered by insurance.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Patriots' Day was not observed to any extent to-day outside of the churches, the law providing for its secular celebration on the morrow. The weather was excellent. In conformity with the custom begun some years ago, two lighted lanterns were to be seen last night in the tower of the old North Church, in Salem Street, commemorating the signal given to Paul Revere 128 years ago.

Last week's price movement is not what might have been expected of several good days, and only one distinctly bad. But the good days did not suffice to repair the damage done by the Northern Securities decision on Monday. In the result thirty-nine stocks advanced a full point, and forty-seven declined.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The conflict between the authorities in Washington and the local authorities in Porto Rico over the navy smuggling cases has called forth some remarks from Postmaster General Payne, in which he expressed his views of the alleged violations of law which have resulted in the Grand Jury's indictments.

In one of the collateral branches of the building trades the employers lately held a convention lasting through several days, which resolved itself into a symposium on the practical effect of union control of labor, as seen from the point of view of those taking part in the discussion.

There was a big gathering of club members and visitors at the court of the Jersey City Handball Club yesterday to meet "Mike" Egan and congratulate him on his recent victory over Louts Keegan of Chicago. The champion did not put in an appearance, however, and the members spent the day in playing several interesting matches, the scores of which follow:

Through mutual concession and by the exercise of a proper degree of self-restraint on both sides, the difficulties which confronted the new management of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad at the outset of its career promise to be adjusted to the satisfaction of all in interest.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 19. -- The faith of the residents of Maplewood, a little village in South Orange Township, in their Fire Department is considerably shaken since Friday, when a disastrous fire visited the Randolph A. Gardner estate and destroyed all the outbuildings, including a sumptuous pigsty recently erected by Mr. Gardner at great cost.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- "The Jews are preserving the home and family better than we Christians are doing. I do not know how to account for this, but I do know it to be a fact." Bishop Satterlee of the Episcopal Church made this declaration in a sermon here to-night, in which the main subject of his discourse was divorce.

If an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure -- and it is -- the bill now pending in the Legislature providing a reception hospital for the insane in this city will, if passed, effect a great saving.

PARIS, April 19. -- Henry Vignaud, First Secretary of the United States Embassy here and Vice President of the Americanists' Society of Paris, has closed his controversy with Sir Clements Markham, President of the Royal Geographical Society, which arose from the publication of Mr. Vignaud's book, "Toscanelli and Columbus," by publishing Sir Clements's last letter and his reply thereto.

The Central Federated Union took up the question of rapid transit again yesterday and intimated that Mayor Low is an opponent of municipal operation of rapid transit roads. On the supposition that the Mayor is responsible for the delay in the passage of the Elsberg bill, the following preamble and resolutions were carried unanimously on the motion of School Commissioner Samuel B. Donnelly:

The organization of a permanent society pledged to work for the establishment of the National Art Theatre in New York was resolved upon last evening at the dinner of the American Dramatists' Club at Delmonico's. Heinrich Conried spoke in favor of the plan and presented figures to show that a National theatre could be maintained at a cost much less than it is usual to suppose.

Evolution and the Negro Question" was the subject of a lecture by the Rev. Percy S. Grant, rector of the Church of the Ascension, before the People's Institute at Cooper Union last evening. He began by saying that the people are learning new facts about the negro race which should lead to new expedients.

Three transatlantic liners arrived yesterday morning, bringing the news that the gales and big seas are leaving the Atlantic. The logs of the three vessels showed that none of them had passed any of the huge icebergs that other vessels that arrived recently reported. Commenting on that Capt. Yerlynde of the Champagne said he believed that nearly all of the icebergs had disappeared from the track followed by transatlantic liners.

With simple and impressive ceremonies, funeral services over the body of the Rev. Dr. Gustav Gottheil, rabbi emeritus of the Temple Emanu-El were held in the temple, Forty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning and at noon the body was laid in the grave at Salem Fields, amid a distinguished company of men of the Jewish and other faiths who wished thus to pay a last tribute to the departed leader.

The replacement of Mr. McCULLAGH by Mr. MORGAN in the office of State Superintendent of Elections in this city may have very great importance. For one thing, it secures hearty and intelligent co-operation between the Superintendent of Elections, the Commissioner of Police, and the District Attorney in the task of making and Keeping the elections in this city pure, honest, and fair.

Frank J. Feeley of 246 Eighth Avenue who, according to his landlady, was the son of a well-to-do property owner of Providence, R.I., was drowned in the Hudson River yesterday afternoon, after making a desperate but futile effort to prevent his young wife from committing suicide. Both bodies were recovered within half an hour, and physicians worked over them nearly an hour in a vain attempt to restore life.

Spurred on by the protests of the West End Association to make a vigorous stand against violations of the law by automobilists, the police of the West One Hundredth, West One Hundred and Twentyfifth, West One Hundred and Fifty-second, and East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Police Stations have declared war on everybody who, owning, hiring, or borrowing an automobile, forgets himself and speeds at a rate in excess of the limit fixed by law.

Funeral services for Mrs. Rose Fitzsimmons, the wife of Robert Fitzsimmons, exchampion heavyweight pugilist, were conducted yesterday afternoon in Rose Villa, Bay Parkway and Cropsey Avenue, Bensonhurst. So large Was the attendance at the services that not all of the friends of the pugilist and his wife could crowd into the house.

John H. Finley, Ph. D., LL. D., a friend of ex-President Cleveland and Professor of Politics at Princeton, was selected unanimously last evening for President of the College of the City of New York. He was chosen by the Board of Trustees at their meeting, held in the college building, after nineteen men had been considered for the place since the resignation of Gen. Alexander S. Webb in December last.

Alexander Winton and Louis P. Mooers of Cleveland. Ohio, and Percy Owen of this city will compose the team of three American automobile racers who will represent the Automobile Club of America against similar teams from England, France, and Germany in the annual race for the Bennett International Automobile Racing Cup to be held in Ireland next July.

ALBANY, April 20 -- A delegation of the Merchants' Association of New York City, headed by William F. King and Secretary Mead, called on Gov. Odell to-day in the interest of the bill before the Legislature increasing the membership of the State Board of Railroad Commissioners from three to five, giving two members to New York City and also with regard to the bill for a municipal electric plant.

Benedetto Madonio of Buffalo was the man whose lifeless body was found in a barrel in East Eleventh Street one week ago this morning. He was murdered, all evidence indicates, because he threatened to expose the secrets of the Mafia band of counterfeiters and blackmailers, the unconvicted members of which are under arrest in connection with the murder.

The second annual meeting of the United States Steel Corporation, which was held in Hoboken yesterday, was entirely harmonious. Charles M.
