Schwab, President of the corporation, called the meeting to order at noon and proposed that E.H. Gary, Chairman of the Executive Committee, be elected Chairman of the meeting.

KANSAS CITY, April 20 -- United States Senator William J. Stone, addressing the annual convention of the Missouri Democratic Press Association, to-day made an elaborate explanation of his connection with baking powder legislation and enforcement of the State pure food laws, and bitterly denounced the daily newspapers of the State, which, he declared, had "hounded" him outrageously.

ST. PAUL, April 20 -- Counsel for the Northern Securities Company and other defendants filed their appeal to-day from the decision of the United States Circuit Court in the railroad merger case. Thitry-four points of error are alleged. Exceptions are noted to every paragraph in the decree, and the court is held to be in error in rendering any decree save one for dismissal of the petition and proceedings.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 20 -- Eight persons are dead and ten injured, three of them seriously, as the result of a collision between an express train and a freight train on the Erie Kailroad at an early hour to-day near Red House, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Society was very fully represented this evening at the Lafayette Theatre, where the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania appeared in their new play, "Sir Robinson Crusoe," before an audience that crowded the theatre to the roof. Mrs. Roosevelt occupied a box to the left of the stage, in which she entertained a party of friends.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Consideration of proposed educational unification to stop the friction now existing between the Regents of the University and the State Department of Public Instruction was urged on the Legislature to-night in a message sent by Gov. Odell. The message reads:

With an uncommonly promising programme and the pleasant weather as combined attractions, racing was resumed at the Aqueduct track yesterday under conditions that created a very fair reproduction of the holiday outpouring Saturday.

Yesterday's stock market was an irregular affair, with weakness in the early dealings and strength in the latter part of the day, following the announcement from St. Paul of the modification of the Northern Securities decision, permitting the payment of dividends on the stock pending an appeal.

Yesterday's session of the market for outside securities was made an interesting one by the movements in Northern Securities and American Can. Naturally of these two the one followed with most general interest was Northern Securities, which was really the leader of yesterday's market. It was very active and fluctuated sharply, first downward and then upward.

Everything was very quiet yesterday. The only exciting incident was the reported engagement of William K. Vanderbilt. The coach was taken by R. Penn Smith, who had a party from Philadelphia, including his stepdaughter, Miss May Hobson. There are several weddings to-day in the suburbs and in town.

The New York and Brooklyn baseball teams met for the third, time at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and the game was called on account of darkness, with the score tied, after eleven innings had been played. Over seven thousand persons were present, and, while the contest was dull at times, there were some very interesting episodes which made the game on the whole a rather lively one.

KIEL April 20 -- The warships of the United States European Squadron will be welcomed here during the yachting week and the members of the Executive Commit tee of the Imperial Yacht Club have alleady discussed informally how to entertain the American visitors. The crews will be asked to take part in the boat races, to which one of the days will be given up.

Mary Bischoff has sold the four-story building at the northwest corner of Chambers and Duane Streets, 34.2 by 95.5 by 25 by 70 and having an additional frontage of three feet on Park Row. The property is in the same block as the parcel recently sold by the estate of William M. Ryan, the two being separated by the holdings of the East River Savings Bank.

BERLIN, April 20 -- The thirty-six hours' snowstorm over Middle Europe ceased today at daybreak. The snow is two inches deep in Berlin, increasing to a yard deep in the Hartz highlands and elsewhere. Snow lies deep in East Prussia and Poland. The temperature in most parts of Germany is barely at freezing point, so that the damage to the fruit crops may not be so serious as at first supposed.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 20 -- The Executive Boards of Districts Nos. 1, 7, and 9, of the United Mine Workers of America, which districts embrace the entire anthracite coal region, held their first joint conference at the Hotel Hart here to-night since the Strike Commission made its award.

Northern Securities dominated yesterday's market again. What was expected was clearly enough indicated by the fall of Northern Securities to 94 7/8 upon the curb, accompanied with general sympathetic weakness upon the Exchange. Manhattan showed strength upon the better aspect of the strike, and Reading was uncertain upon its labor and legal troubles.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 -- From information which has recently been placed in his hands, Circuit Attorney Folk is convinced that Lieut. Gov. Lee is hopelessly involved in other boodle scandals than the one connected with baking powder legislation. It is this knowledge, it is believed, which accounts in part for the Lieutenant Governor's anxiety to avoid appearing here before the Grand Jury investigating legislative corruption.

We hope it is safe to assume that the Legislature will pay no further attention to the Elsberg bill amending the Rapid Transit act. It would be a public outrage, a monstrous affront to the sane, responsible, and informed public opinion of this city, if this huge, crude, and ignorantly drawn measure were to be converted into law.

Copies of charges against Supervisor Philip Cowen of The City Record were given out yesterday from Controller Grout's office. It is asserted that the Supervisor's acts are open to criticism because he conducted private bidding in his office for thousands of dollars worth of "open" and "special" orders, "when such bidding was apparently unknown to all but a favored few."

ALBANY, April 20 -- The three insurgent Republican Senators to-night inaugurated a hold-up of all legislation in the Legislature. Their action followed a conference held between Senators Brackett and Brown with the Governor this afternoon. While the insurgents deny that the Governor is in any way responsible for the course they took in the Senate this evening, the general impression was that the Governor at least had a foreknowledge of what they intended to do.
The following artillery officers, recently prorooted, are assigned to the Coast Artillery:

BOSTON, Mass., April 20 -- John C. Lorden of Cambridge won the Marathon race from Ashland to Boston to-day, covering the twenty-five miles in 2:41:29 4-5. This is 0:01:43 3-5 faster than last year's time, and about twelve minutes behind the record held by J.P. Caffrey of Hamilton, Ontario, who won this event in 1900 and 1901.

Liebler Co. yesterday settled the rumors about Viola Allen's change of management this season by announcing her appearance in a Shakespearean role next season. Another actress will be engaged to star in "The Eternal City," which will be continued with practically the same supporting cast as this season.

Since that bad Northern Securities dog was stoned to death all the other dogs have been engaged in explaining how good they are. Such honest, law-abiding, strenuously competing and really public-spirited dogs have never been seen. They do not restrain trade, bless you, no; and as for the Sherman Anti-Trust act, they love, honor, and obey it.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- As a result of the investigations in the Post Office Department by Assistant Postmaster General Bristow an order issued to-day by the Postmaster General that five men now carried on the rolls as "bookkeepers," but really employed to repair cancellation machines, report for duty at the Post Offices to which they are assigned.

NEW ORLEANS, April 20 -- W.H. Butters of Fowler, Ind., an American prospector, returned to-day from Puerto Cortes, Honduras, and gave details of the capture of Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, by the revolutionists on April 15. He said Gen. Manuel Bonilla, the rebel leader, had succeeded in overthrowing President Arias's administration and installing himself as Constitutional President.

LONDON, April 20 -- William Brown, a footman, was remanded to-day at Portsmouth on the charge of making a false entry at the Registry Office there in the middle of December last, when, under the name of "Prince Athrobald Stuart de Modena," he married the first Countess Russell.

Sheriff William J. O'Brien was busy yesterday explaining to inquirers why it was he had taken "Al" Adams, the "Policy King," to the Waldorf-Astoria after his conviction on Friday night instead of to the Tombs, where persons convicted of a criminal offense generally are taken to await judgment.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The market was dull and steady. Not a single feature out of the ordinary was developed. Nearly two-thirds of the trading was in Reading, between the arbitrage houses. No protracted trouble la expected here from the lockout of the miners, but its tendency will be toward increasing the demand for coal, consumers not caring to duplicate their troubles of last Winter.

Braid of all kinds are used on all materials this year and the woman who makes up wash gowns for herself and her children should turn her attention to the wash braids. These are simple, and are to be found in white and colors, cost 4 and 5 cents a yard, and nothing is easier to put on or prettier for simple gowns, particularly for the children.

WEST POINT, N.Y. April 20 -- The presentation of teachers' Bibles by the American Tract Society to the members of the graduating class of the Military Academy was made this afternoon. The old chapel was crowded with the cadets, the officers and their families, and other visitors, and the Rev. Herbert Shipman, the Chaplain, conducted devotional exercises.

Definite arrangements will be made tonight at the annual meeting of the Polo Association for the entertainment of the English polo team, whose visit to America this season is now practically assured. H. L. Herbert, Chairman of the association, said yesterday that he had just received word from England to the effect that the team would surely come, all arrangements regarding expense and other preliminaries having been completed.

ST. PAUL, April 20 -- At noon to-day Judge W.H. Sanborn of the United States Circuit Court handed down a decision granting the request of attorneys for the Northern Securities Company that the recent decree against that company be suspended so far as to permit the payment of Great Northern and Northern Pacific dividends to the Securities Company.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Philip Doblin of Holland boat notoriety came to Albany to-day to urge an appropriation provided for him in the Supply bill for work he did for the State when he was connected with the Controller's office.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- There was heavy buying on the Exchange to-day, through local houses, of American Can stock for New Yorkers and other inside interests of the company. The common rose above 9 and the preferred rose 5 points, to 49. The alleged cuuse of the buying was expectation that the annual statement, to be issued Wednesday, would be very good.
SANTO DOMINGO, April 18 -- Troops of the Government shelled this city yesterday and several houses were damaged.

A scarcity of water has aroused the residents of the block in Forty-fourth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. In the block are hotels, apartment houses, and clubs including the Algonquin, Seymour, Iroquois, and Mansfield apartment hotels; the Yale, Harvard, and New York Yacht Clubs, and the Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- An order issued by Gen. Shafter after the battle of Santiago, congratulating his troops on the campaign, has just found its way to the War Department in a rather strange way. So far as is known the order has never been published in the United States, and its existence has not been known to the department.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 20 -- Mrs. Christopher M. Bell, who has a villa on Bellevue Avenue, arrived this afternoon.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Fully an hour of the Assembly session was taken up with a spirited discussion of Senator Armstrong's bill forbidding the sale or the offering for sale of woodcock or grouse taken within this State, which was finally passed. It is said to represent the issue between so-called "market hunters" and the sportsmen of the State, the latter desiring to limit the destruction of grouse or woodcock to a minimum.

LONDON, April 21 -- The Sultan, according to a dispatch to The Times from Uskub, has tried to appeal to the religious leeling of the Albanian chiefs, saying that the reforms are in accord with the Koran. The Albanians, however, are defiant, and refuse to permit the reforms or to allow Consuls north of Uskub.

Congressman Timothy D. Sullivan of the Bowery and President Lewis Haffen of the Bronx became Sachems of the Tammany Society last evening by election. There was only one ticket in the field, but there were some surprises in store for the public when the list came out.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- President Baer of the Reading Company declined to discuss the lockout of miners in the Schuylkill region to-day. He would not even admit that the company had closed its collieries. It was learned that the company has a large supply of coal in storage.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 21. -- Mrs. Giuseppe Galantuono, the wife of a workingman here, about 2 o'clock this afternoon was found unconscious on the floor of her kitchen at 46 North Fifth Avenue by other tenants of the apartment house. Her face had been beaten almost to a jelly. A physician was summoned, and the woman soon revived and told her story.
John H. Berry has sold for Willet F. Cook to a client for investment the eight-story business building 133 Mercer Street, 29.6 by 71.2, 72 feet south of Prince Street.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 21. -- The rigging of the Reliance was completed to-day, and as soon as the paint is dry on the gaff and boom the great mainsail will be bent on in preparation for the builders' trial, which is expected to take place on Saturday. The crew spent most of the day in the sail loft putting the light sails in stops and stowing them on the tender Sunbeam.

The three-bank merger, under which the National Broadway Bank, the Seventh National Bank, and the Mercantile National Bank were to be consolidated, was brought to a successful conclusion yesterday afternoon, when the stockholders of the National Broadway Bank, at a special meeting called for that purpose, ratified the merger plan.

The Church Choral Society, which flourished between the years 1889 and 1896, performed an interesting and useful function and filled a place that was not otherwise filled in the city's musical life. Now an effort is making; to reorganize and revive it, which will be welcomed by all lovers of sacred choral music of the highest kind.

ALBANY, April 21. -- There was a party division in the Senate this afternoon on the Hughes bill making it a misdemeanor for any labor organization to discriminate against a workman because he is a member of the National Guard. The measure was passed by a vote of 28 to 19, two Democrats voting for it -- Messrs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 21. -- Senator Hanna was to-night the chief speaker at a banquet tendered to the delegates to the convention of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers that is now holding its twenty-eighth annual session here.

One advantage of the method of painting pursued by eight or nine out of the ten American painters who show their impressions of the visible world at the Durand-Ruel Galleries is this: Given a salon of ordinary dimensions and one can sit in a revolving chair in the centre of the room and survey each picture with the utmost comfort.

In sentencing "AL" ADAMS to the full penalty permitted by the law, Justice SCOTT briefly and tersely expressed the feeling that all decent men must have toward a scoundrel so heartless and contemptible. It is not often that a Judge has the opportunity, in administering justice, to give voice to a public sentiment so strong and definite, so justifiable, and so long baffled.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday considered a plan presented by President Cantor for a commission to formulate plans for beautifying the city. Objection was raised when President Cantor asked for $10,000 to defray the expenses of such a commission. It was asserted that the city's engineers should be asked to submit such plans, and it was said that the suggested scheme was simply "to give some nice gentlemen lazy places and unusually good pay."
LONDON, April 21. -- Money was fairly abundant and in good demand in the market to-day. Discounts were easy.

LONDON, April 21. -- Wavelet's Pride won the Great Metropolitan Stakes, a handicap of 1,000 sovereigns, for three-year-olds and upward, about two miles and a quarter, at the Epsom Spring meeting to-day. Richard Croker's Liquidator was second and Prince Florizel third. Nine horses ran.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I observe that THE TIMES, referring to a proposed additional holiday in this State, condemns "Lincoln Day" as "a monument to legislative folly."

ROME, April 21. -- Brig. Gen. Leonard Wood, Major Scott, and Lieut. McCoy were received at the Quirinal to-day. The General was first received alone by King Victor Emmanuel, and had a conversation with his Majesty, who showed great interest in the Philippine Islands. Major Scott and Lieut. McCoy were then presented, and the King conversed with them in fluent English.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 21. -- The officers of the Building Trades Council and of the various locals which compose it to-night were served with copies of an order issued to-day by Justice Marean in Brooklyn requiring them to show cause why an injunction should not issue restraining them from interfering with the building operations here and at other places along the Sound shore in this State.

Brayton Ives's handsome matinee winner Noran McKinney, (2:12 1/4) the latest and must formidable candidate for the trotting championship of the Speedway, caused a genuine sensation on the road yesterday afternoon, when she proved just how fast she could step by winning two straight heats from E.E. Smathers's Grand Circuit campaigner Ida Highwood, (2:09 3/4).

ALBANY, April 21. -- Commissioner Robert Grier Monroe came to Albany to-day to force action upon his bill providing for a municipal lighting plant in New York City. He succeeded in getting the Senate on record on the proposition, but its action was unfavorable.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- Something of a sensation was caused in local financial circles to-day by a break in the stock of the William Cramp Son Ship and Engine Building Company from 54 to 37 1/4. The first sale was of twenty shares at 54. Twenty shares then sold at 50, and the next sale was twenty shares at 37 1/4, followed by five shares at the same price.

ALBANY, April 21. -- The bill creating a commission to investigate the condition of the adult blind of the State passed the Assembly this afternoon by a vote of 79 to 43. Its main purpose is to provide methods whereby the adult blind of the State may be taught trades.

RICHMOND, Va., April 21. -- A petition was filed here to-day by attorneys for Jameson, McKenzie Evans of Baltimore, Merchant Co. of Philadelphia, the Sea-board Casting Company of Pennsylvania, and other creditors, representing large amounts, together with the Commercial Trust Company, trustee, for itself and other holders of first mortgage bonds, asking that the Trigg Shipbuilding Company be adjudged a bankrupt.

The "dedication" of the new building erected for the use of the Stock Exchange marks an era, not merely in the history of the Stock Exchange, but in the business development of the Western world. The new building, doubtless one of the ornaments of the city, one of the most creditable pieces of architecture in New York, is not the only example of a commercial "institution."
ALBANY, April 21. -- These bills were passed by the Senate to-day:

BOSTON, April 21. -- While ribbons were well scattered at the Horse Show to-day and the competitions in the numerous classes keen, E.D. Jordan of Boston gathered in more blues than any other exhibitor, taking three, as well as a number of seconds and thirds. Dr. John L. Wentz of Philadelphia was almost as successful, while Strauss and Hexter were the principal winners among the dealers.

EL KREIDER, Algeria, April 21. -- President Loubet witnessed to-day a remarkable demonstration by the nomadic tribesmen of the desert who acknowledge the suzerainty of France. The tribesmen gathered in thousands from all parts of Southern Algeria for a ceremony of Oriental splendor.

Something new in the way of teapots is after the style of the old toby milk jugs. The teapot is in the form of the quaint figure of a Jolly old fellow in a sitting position, his legs curved up, one with the foot forming the handle of the teapot and the other, a "peg" leg, forming the spout. All this quaintness for 97 cents.

OMAHA, April 21. -- Backed by the National Manufacturers' Association, 800 business men of Omaha have organized into the Business Men's Association for the avowed purpose of protecting themselves from the demands of union labor. It is said that the new organization will fight the labor organizations to the death.

The jury and a large crowd of spectators in Part I., Court of General Sessions, yesterday greatly enjoyed the testimony of Joseph A. McGuire, who appeared as complaining witness against Thomas Courtney of 411 West Thirty-seventh Street, a livery stable keeper, and William Bertram and Frank J. Kinnon, two cab drivers.

BALTIMORE, April 21. -- The market was more active and more cheerful in tone, with better buying in spots, which disclosed itself in higher prices in various stocks and bonds. Seaboards were better on a continuance of increase in the weekly earnings, and United Railways were better on the prospective increase in the company's earning capacity.
LONDON, April 21. -- Samuel Hope Morley, Deputy Governor of the Bank of England, has been elected Governor of the institution for the ensuing year, to succeed Sir Augustus Prevost, Bart.

LOUISVILLE, April 21. -- The sale of a hogshead of tobacco that had been packed twenty-eight years ago has broken all records for this market or for any other market. It was sold privately to a firm who handle the Spanish and Austrian contracts. The tobacco will be used for cigar fillers.

The improvement In the stock market which set in on Monday following the announcement of the modification of the Northern Securities decision was continued yesterday practically without interruption. Prices opened up with sentiment everywhere more hopeful, and rose with more or less steadiness all day.

BOSTON, April 21. -- The money market shows increased ease. Rates, however, are still comparatively high, although the local banks are in a strong position and the demand is light. Call Joans. 5@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 3 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 10@8 cents discount.

That fortune has twice smiled on a poor man was revealed yesterday through an application made by Ignatius Wiltner, attorney for Stephen Neederman of 150 Nassau Street, for permission to serve by publication the papers in a suit brought against Thomas Vezer to compel the surrender of 1,000 shares of stock in the Rapid Envelope Sealing Company.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- A generally firm tone was maintained in the local market. Business was slow, however, traders apparently preferring the New York market owing to the better opportunity to make "turns." Reading was the leader of the local coalers, advancing fractionally, notwithstanding the idleness of its collieries.

ALBANY, April 21. -- Senator Elsberg's bill amending the rapid transit railway act so as to permit the City of New York to either own or control future extensions of the Rapid Transit Railway system was passed by the Senate to-day by a vote of 32 to 7. Senator Grady opposed the bill, but was not upheld in his opposition by the majority of the Democrats.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Considerable attention is being given in official and diplomatic circles to the embarrassing position which Germany is forced to occupy at Washington as a result of the delay in the arrival of the credentials of Baron Speck von Sternburg, who, it has been announced, is eventually to succeed Herr von Holleben as Ambassador here.

The secession of the local bowling organizations from the American Bowling Congress begun at a mass meeting of bowlers held two months ago, was completed on Monday evening, when the New York Bowling Association, in a meeting at the Victoria Hotel, adopted a set of bowling regulations differing materially from those of the Western organization.

The law in regard to the offense of dangerous running of automobiles is none too severe. It is not, as we have frequently pointed out, an effective restraint on the recklessness of offenders. It in no sense reinforces their defective consciences or excites to humanity and decency.

The brokers of the New York Stock Exchange said good-by yesterday to the temporary quarters in the Produce Exchange, where the Exchange found an asylum while its own home was being torn down, and a new palace was being erected. The leavetaking was not tearful, but rather fearful so far as noise went, and cheerful so far as the market sentiment of the members was concerned.

A committee of the Citizens' Union, appointed to see Mayor Low in reference to the Elsberg Transit bill, called at the City Hall yesterday. The delegation, which arrived shortly before noon, was instructed to wait in the large reception room.

The disappearance of Charles T. Blaisdell, cashier for Curtis Blaisdell, the coal dealers, of 120 Liberty Street, has baffled the friends of the family, the police officials, and all who have attempted to solve the mystery. Hospitals, the Morgue, and every place in which the victim of an accident or foul play might appear have been watched.

KANSAS CITY, April 21. -- William J. Bryan, speaking this morning to the toast "Democracy" at the banquet given by the Democratic Jackson County Club and the newspaper men of Missouri complimentary to William J. Stone, at which the addresses did not begin until long after midnight, bitterly arraigned Grover Cleveland and his supporters, who are making the plea for harmony among Democrats.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 21. -- Stephen R. Mallory was elected for another term in the United States Senate to-day by the two Houses of the Legislature in separate session, receiving all the votes in the Senate and 64 in the House to 1 cast for J.M. Toombs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- An order has been issued by the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company which operates several collieries in the Panther Creek Valley reinstating all of its old employes, who have been idle since the end of the strike. About 200 men and boys whose positions had been filled will find work in and about the mines.

-- In demanding that the Aldermen at once pass an ordinance condemning to death all unmuzzled dogs found at large in the city, the members of the Academy of Medicine have the support of both The Medical News and The Medical Journal, and it may safely be assumed that a majority of doctors have enough belief in the recent reports of cases of rabies here to consider vigorous measures necessary for stamping out the disease.
CHICAGO, Ill., April 21. -- New York exchange to-day was 40 cents premium before clearings and 30 cents premium after clearings. Time and call loans 3 1/2@6 per cent.
PARIS, April 21. -- Dr. Jean Charcot, on the advice and suggestion of the Committee of Patronage on his polar expedition, has decided to change the objective of his efforts.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 21. -- The Executive Boards of the three anthracite districts of the United Mine Workers of America, in convention here, issued instructions to-day that all mine workers now on strike or locked out shall return to work immediately pending an adjustment of all differences by the Board of Conciliation provided for by the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The monthly statement of the collections of internal revenue show that for the month of March the total collections were $18,624,908, a decrease as compared with March, 1902, of $2,602,626.

Active consideration was begun yesterday by the Inter-State Commerce Commission of the complaint of William R. Hearst of The New York Journal that the coal roads are violating the inter-State commerce law. The hearing was held in Room 70 of the Federal Building, and will continue, according to every indication throughout the week.

The new North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm II., the much-heralded craft that is expected by her designers and owners to eventually win the title of queen of the seas, arrived at Quarantine at 10:15 last night and anchored. She is expected to arrive at the new piers of the North German Lloyd in Hoboken at about 8 o'clock this morning.

ALBANY, April 21. -- Senator Marshall's bills amending the New York charter so that the city administration may carry out its part of the contract with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and permit work connected with the construction of the tunnel under the Hudson River, were passed in the Assembly this afternoon.

Yesterday's trading in the outside market was not very active, and there was no repetition of the violent fluctuations which marked the previous day's trading. The market in Northern Securities was very quiet after Monday's rather exciting movements in the stock, and the transactions were reduced to a few thousand shares.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Elsberg Rapid Transit bill was reported by the Assembly Committee on Rules to-night, after a message had been received here from Mayor Low through Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman to the effect that the Mayor had no objection to its passage.
CHICAGO, April 22. -- New York exchange, 40c premium before and 5Oc after clearings. Time and call loans, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- While the day's trading was unproductive of any material alteration in prices, the market was cheerful and much more active than expected in view of the suspension of business in New York, and the absence of many of the active members of the local Exchange. This volume of business was largely in those stocks that enjoy an active New York market, with Reading common as the leader.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Upon default of interest on five notes aggregating $1,134,183 the Chicago Union Traction Company, the North Chicago Street Railway Company, and the West Chicago Street Railroad Company to-day passed into the hands of receivers.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Great Britain probably will not insist on referring to The Hague tribunal the question whether the allies or Venezuela shall stand the cost of the blockade.

RICHMOND, Va., April 22. -- In the presence of one of the largest and most distinguished gatherings of Northerners and of Southerners ever assembled in this capital of the South Gov. Andrew Jackson Montague welcomed to Richmond the members of the sixth annual Conference for Education in the South.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The Senate has repassed the Grady Theatre Standing-Room bill defining that lobbies are not aisles, over the veto of Mayor Low. Senator Elsberg spoke against the bill, and said that Mayor Low's reasons for vetoing the bill were good and sufficient. Senator Grady insisted that the bill did not change the existing law, but merely made it clear.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The New York baseball team of the American League inaugurated the League season here to-day by meeting the Washington team. New York lost by 3 to 1 through inability to bat safely at opportune times. The game proved one of the most enjoyable ever witnessed by local cranks. It was closely contested at every point.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The Bailey-Doughty bill, making eight miles an hour the maximum speed at which automobiles may be run in any section where the houses are less than 100 feet apart and within half a mile of any Post Office, and also regulating generally the use of automobiles, slid through the Assembly this morning on the order of second and third reading without debate by a vote of 86 yeas to 30 nays.

OMAHA, Neb., April 22 -- W.H. Bell, President of the Omaha Central Labor Union, is not disturbed by the proclamation issued by the newly organized Omaha Business Men's Association, which is said to have the support of the National Manufacturers' Association. He believes that a decisive contest between the united employers and the united workers would be beneficial to both sides.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 22. -- Delegates representing sixty Congregational churches in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia assembled to-day in the First Congregational Church and participated in the proceedings of the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the Congregational Association of New Jersey, of which the Rev. Dr. M. Ross Fishburn of Washington is the Moderator.

In the statement of the condition of the Banks of the City of New York on the 9th of April, compiled for the members of the Clearing House Association, the net profits of the forty-six banks enumerated were given on that date at $110,830,300. The net profits at the time of the next preceding statement, on Feb. 3, were given as $105,889,100.
The one out-of-town wedding for to-day is to be that of Miss Elizabeth Gummere, daughter of Justice and Mrs. William S. Gummere of Newark, N.J., to Thomas Lynch Redmond, in Newark.
An officer stationed in the Southern Philippines writes to a friend at home:

John M. Wisker, the former New York Central engineer, on trial in connection with the Grand Central tunnel accident of Jan. 8 last year, on a charge of manslaughter before Justice Scott in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court took the stand yesterday afternoon in his own defense.

Baron Speck von Sternburg, the German Minister at Washington, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by Edward Uhl and Hermann Ridder, proprietors of the New Yorker Staats-Zeitung. The purpose of the dinner was to make the new German Minister acquainted with prominent men of this city in financial, political, and professional walks of life.

In a tone of confident prophecy the Washington correspondent of The Evening Post sets forth the Administration programme of prosecutions under the anti-trust law of 1890. We do not know whether the correspondent qualified as a prophet by getting his information in the Department of Justice, nor need there be any speculation on that point.

ALBANY, April 22. -- Assemblyman Finch of New York made a valiant effort in the Assembly this morning to have the Rules Committee discharged from further consideration of the New York Municipal Electric Light Plant bill. His motion to that effect was defeated, 50 to 65.

"Bim the Button Man" known to the politicians all over the country, and who has been a figure at several National Conventions of both parties and State and City Conventions, was arraigned in the Adams Street Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, charged with the embezzlement of $6,385 from the National Equipment Company.

DETROIT, Mich., April 22. -- New York City's municipal problems furnished the subject for a speech delivered at to-day's opening session of the eleventh National Conference for Good City Government by Clinton Rogers Woodruff of Philadelphia, Secretary of the National Municipal League.

LONDON, April 23 -- It is perhaps too soon, says the Sofia correspondent of The Times, to conclude that the Austro-Russian reforms for Macedonia are a total failure, but the slight progress as yet made augurs ill for the future. It is demonstrated that the Turks cannot apply the reforms, and that they will never be realized until European control is established.
First Lieut. James Bourke, Assistant Surgreon, is detailed as a member of the board of officers appointed to meet at Fort Sheridan May 1, vice Major Francis J. Iyes, Surgeon, relieved.

Choler marked the progress of the second day's hearing by the Inter-State Commerce Commission of the complaint of William R. Hearst of The New York Journal against the coal roads, and in one outburst, J. D. Campbell, who appeared for President George F. Baer and the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad system, compared the people of this city to a pack of whipped dogs.

About one-hundred thousand dollars was collected last evening at a meeting in Carnegie Hall to promote an advance movement by the Presbyterian Church in this city. With the amount as a beginning, the Presbyterians of New York mean to collect a fund of $750,000 for the purpose of wiping out the indebtedness of some churches and establishing new churches.

SYRACUSE, Sicily, April 22. -- King Edward left here this morning for Naples on board the royal yacht Victoria and Albert. It is said that his Majesty will make a short stop at Messina. The yacht is escorted by four battleships and two torpedo boat destroyers.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Secretary Root to-day approved the proceedings of the board appointed to prescribe tests to govern awards of a National marksmanship trophy and medals and other prizes for marksmanship. The National match is to be shot Sept. 8 and 9, 1903, at Sea Girt, N.J., and will be open to teams of twelve men from the following:

PARIS, April 22. -- Alfred Dreyfus has submitted to Minister of War Andre a lengthy letter in which he earnestly asks for a reopening of his case by means of an investigation by the Minister as the supreme head of military justice.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The Assembly Committee on Rules failed to take action to-night upon the Finch Police bill, with the three-platoon amendment, which was added to it by the Senate. It will meet again in the morning and every possible influence will be used by the promoters of both measures to have them favorably reported.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Budgett Meakin, the well-known English philanthropist and sociologist, who is traveling in this country studying the conditions of the working classes, publicly declared as the result of his investigations in the city that there are worse places in Washington than the worst quarters of London.

While Giuseppe Morello, leader of the band of Sicilians detained in connection with the barrel murder, was being examined in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning Secret Service agents, in their offices in the Federal building, found among the papers taken by them from the man's house in Chrystie Street a letter written to him by Benedetto Madonia, the murdered man, about a month ago.

LONDON, April 22 -- In the course of the discussion of the Board of Trade estimates in the House of Commons to-day, Thomas Gibson Bowles (Conservative) complained of the length of time between the inception and the execution of the agreement between the Government and the International Mercantile Marine Company, and also of the lack of information supplied by the Government.
TANGIER, April 22. -- Tribesmen have attacked and pillaged Mekines. Thirty-seven inhabitants of the town and thirteen tribesmen were killed in the fighting.

ALBANY, April 22. -- Not in years has there been witnessed such a large and active lobby on the day before the close of the session of the Legislature as that which thronged the corridors of the Senate and Assembly chambers to-day, pulling and hauling at legislators to gain their support for the various interests which they represented.

The probability that the Staats-Zeitung will at some future time be compelled to abandon its present building, if any of the plans for the acquisition of that block for municipal building or railroad terminal purposes shall be carried out, led yesterday to reports that the newspaper had reached an agreement with the city for the sale of its property and had already acquired the site for a new building.
PARIS, April 22. -- William K. Vanderbilt's Cleopatra II. took third place to-day in the race for the Prix Puchero at the Colombes meeting.

The Dally America Publishing Company of 1,435 Broadway, which publishes The Daily America, has applied to the Supreme Court for the voluntary dissolution of the corporation, and Judge Giegerich of the Supreme Court has signed the order to show cause for July 22. The proceedings were brought by three of the Directors -- Graham Rice, Frances Drake Rice, and Julius Levy.

In the period immediately following the civil war, when the currency was greatly inflated and the tide of speculation ran very high, conservative observers were not a little alarmed by the fact that the imports were approaching the half-billion mark. Nor was their concern unwarranted.

Bryan L. Kennelly has sold for the estate of John Mulford and for William E. Finn the plot of about fourteen lots at the foot of West Sixty-eighth Street, running through to Sixty-ninth Street and facing the tracks of the New York Central Railroad. The buyers are William and James Bradley, contractors, who will use the property as a storage yard. The price was about $75,000.

Phantom estates were revealed yesterday through the filing of the will of Lewis Howard Dessel for probate. Mr. Dessel was a man about town and for years he ranked as a wealthy man, and as one of the best dressed men of the hotel district, being known as Capt. Dessel, and for a time in Chicago as Capt. Marshall.
LONDON, April 22. -- Money was in fair demand in the market to-day. The indebtedness to the Bank of England is practically liquidated.

The work of the Merchants' Association, undertaken last May with the cooperation of Mayor Low, to investigate and suggest a better system of accounts for the municipal offices has resulted in a forty-page report by Worthington G. Ford and Frederick B. De Berard, the accountants employed by the committee of the association in charge of the work.

The annual report of the General Electric Company signed by C.A. Coffin, President, for the year ended Jan. 31, 1903, was issued yesterday afternoon. The total sales of electrical apparatus and supplies for the fiscal year amounted to $36,685,598, while the orders received amounted to $39,944, 454, being an increase of 16.4 per cent, upon orders received during the year ended Jan. 31, 1902.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 23 -- At the next meeting of the Riverside Yacht Club, to be held in New York next month, an attempt will be made to inaugurate a new class of eighteen-foot sailabouts, half of which will be built with centreboards and half with bilge boards for the purpose of deciding which is the faster.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- There was a decided increase in local trading to-day, but the market was decidedly irregular, seven stocks scoring net gains and thirteen net losses. The latter extended to a point in United Railways of San Francisco, and it was the only stock in which the decline exceeded fractions.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- This was a blue day for the spectators and a bad day for the local baseball team at American League Park. The patrons of the same were blue because of the wintry weather and the loss of the game, and the local players felt bad on account of their misplays, which gave to New York the second game of the season by the score of 7 to 2.
The five-story building 32 West Twenty fourth Street, on lot 20 by 98.9, has been sold through the McVickar Realty Trust Company. The owner of record of the property is Robert A. Stewart.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission, which is conducting a hearing here, announced a decision yesterday in the case of proposed advances in freight rates on various articles between Chicago and New York, and in the case of Procter Gamble against the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad, involving the classification of common soap.

LONDON, April 24 -- Budget Day in the House of Commons is always attractive, and it was unusually so this year, as the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Right Hon. C.T. Ritchie, had the pleasure of introducing the first peace budget for four years. The House was well filled, and there were many visitors in the galleries when the Chancellor rose to make his statement.

In nothing has President CANTOR shown more civic spirit or more enlargement of mind than in the persistent efforts he has made to secure a revision of the plan of the city, with the view of ascertaining what amendments are still feasible of the plan upon which the city has thus far been built.
CHICAGO, April 23 -- New York exchange to-day was at 50 cents premium before clearings and 40 cents after.
The Assembly expressed a very enlightened and just judgment of the merits of the Elsberg rapid transit law amendments yesterday by killing the bill. The vote was 78 to 38 -- more than two to one.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The failure of Street Commissioner Woodbury's bill in the Assembly to-day was a legislative farce comedy which has excited more talk and laughter than any incident connected with the close of the session. Street sprinkling influences, which were opposed to it, involved it in such a maze of doubt that it was impossible to do anything with it after the plot had been exposed.

Two hundred firemen visited the City Hall yesterday to induce Mayor Low to sign the Two Platoon bill for the Fire Department. Fire Commissioner Sturgis and representatives of one of the firemen's organizations opposed it. The bill, now that the Legislature has adjourned, becomes a thirty-day measure, and the aprpoval or disapproval of Mayor Low is final.

An accident that resulted in a fractured collarbone for William C. Whitney's twenty-thousand-dollar-a-year jockey, Arthur Redfern, and the death of the five-hundred-dollar selling-class horse on which Redfern was mounted furnished the most sensational happening at the Aqueduct race track yesterday.

The final word has at last been said in the characterization of "Everyman." The conversation of two suburbanites was lately overheard while they were on their way into the theatre. "Now I've been so enthusiastic about the play," said one, "that I'm afraid you'll be disappointed in it. It isn't a comedy.

The members of the New York Stock Exchange settled down to business yesterday in their new quarters. The flowers and decorations of the day before had all been removed, and the big board room wore a strictly businesslike aspect, except for a big twenty-four-foot wreath of flowers sent by the Produce Exchange.

The surprising behavior of the anthracite miners identified with the United Mine Workers of America since the award of the Coal Strike Commission is calculated to discourage the friends of organized labor. The Scranton Trlbune sums the whole matter up in few words as follows:

The case of Engineer John M. Wisker before Justice Scott in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, who is on trial on a charge of manslaughter in connection with the tunnel collision on Jan. 8, 1902, will be sent to the jury to-day, the prosecution and the defense having closed yesterday. He was recalled yesterday for cross-examination by Assistant District Attorney Rand.

PEKING, April 23 -- Russia has demanded that China sign an agreement practically ceding to her the sovereignty of Manchuria and excluding other nations from that country. The Russian Charge d'Affaires, M. Plancon, has informed Prince Ching, President of the Foreign Office, that no further steps in the evacuation of Manchuria will be taken until this agreement is signed.

Most people will get from the published accounts of the meeting held by booksellers of the city this week their first knowledge of the existence of a law which not only can be, but has been, so interpreted as to impose upon merchants of this class the restrictions and obligations placed for good reason on junkmen and pawnbrokers.

LONDON, April 24 -- With reference to Great Britain's refusal to co-operate in the Bagdad Railway scheme, the Berlin correspondent of The Times says it may be anticipated that there will be a chorus of German condolences for England's neglect to take the opportunity of securing her own interests by means of private financial participation in and official patronage of the German railway.

At the opening of the outside market yesterday there was some show of strength, and a number of the active issues sold at prices somewhar above the final figures of Tuesday, but in most cases the quotations established during the first few minutes of trading proved to be the highest for the day.

Rome is engaged in vindicating the appellation of the "Eternal City." Here in New York we are preparing to celebrate the two hundred and fiftieth birthday of the municipality. Rome is even now celebrating the twenty-six hundred and fifty-sixth of hers. New York has lived through less than one-tenth of the time that Rome has survived, and during some decade of centuries of which she was the metropolis of the world.
BOSTON, Mass., April 23 -- The actors' home benefit at the Hollis Street Theatre this afternoon netted $2,500. Representatives from every theatre in the city took part.

LONDON, April 24 -- The War Office yesterday received from Brig. Gen. Manning, in command of the British forces in Somaliland, the following dispatch, dated twenty miles westward of Galadi, Somaliland, April 18:

As a result of the Tuskegee mass meeting held on April 14 at Madison Square Concert Hall, Andrew Carnegie has donated $600,000 toward the endowment of the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute in Alabama, and for a life income for its President, Booker T. Washington, and his wife. Mr. Carnegie, it has also become known, has been giving $10,000 to the institute for four years past.

BOSTON, April 23 -- The money market shows increased ease. The supply is large and increasing and the banks are displaying more of a disposition to put out funds. Call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent; time loans, on collateral, 3@5 1/2 per cent; time loans, on mercantile paper, 5@6 per cent. Clearing House loans, 4@4 1/2c.; New York funds, par @5 cents discount.

CINNABAR, Mont., April 23 -- President Roosevelt's vacation it at an end. He greeted the members of his party and a large number of persons at the Mammoth Hot Springs Hotel in Yellowstone Park today, and will resume his tour to-morrow.
Col. Joseph Karr Rickey, famous throughout the country as the originator of the conecetion hearing his name died suddenly yesterday in his home at 24 West Twenty-fifth Street.

The announcement that Frank H. Platt had resigned from the Colonial Club, in which he had been prominent practically from the time of its organization, coming right after the dinner Wednesday night to Horace White, the retiring editor of The Evening Post, set on foot a good bit of gossip yesterday as to the possible connection of the two occurrences.

The sailing of the Cedric, for those who are interested in people gains abroad, and the Lakewood Horse Show at the Country Club, for those who stop at home, are the two events of the day. At Lakewood, Mrs. George Gould has a large house party, in which are Lady Colebrook, Sydney Paget, and William C. Whitney.

Sir Chentung Liang Cheng, the new Chinese Minister, made his debut as successor to Wu Ting Fang as an after-dinner speaker at a dinner of the American-Asiatic Society at Delmonieo's last evening given in his honor. From his place on the rostrum he could behold on every side the Chinese dragon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one who has listened to almost all of the rehearsals of the People's Choral Union this last season, and as one studying under Mr. Damrosch in the Oratorio Society, I wish to say a word in behalf of the Choral Union, which in this morning's TIMES received such harsh criticism as the result of its performance of Haydn's "Seasons" in the Opera House Monday evening.

RICHMOND, Va., April 23 -- After a day and a hall the Conference for Education in the South is well under way and the interest or this conservative city is thoroughly arcused. The Academy of Music is packed at each session and to-night the building is overflowing with educators from every part of the country.

In the course of yesterday's session of the Amory-Vreeland hearing before Magistrate Barlow in the library of the District Attorney's office the lawyers for the Metropolitan Street Railway Company elicited from John C. Hertle. expert accountant, testimony to the effect that the copy of the report first published in the anti-Metropolitan charges came from the office of Talbot J. Taylor, son-in-law of James R. Keene.

Capt. William S. Pierce, Ordnance Department, will make not to exceed six visits per month during May and June to the works of the American and British Manufacturing Company, Bridgeport, Conn., and to the works of the United States Rapid Fire Gun and Power Company, Derby, Conn.

Baseball had another good day all over the country yesterday. Although the weather was too cool for the spectators to thoroughly enjoy outdoor games, the attendance in all the cities on the circuit of the National and American Leagues as well as at the college and other amateur contests was above the usual average.

The commission, recently appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, to report whether or not the tunnel railroad, planned by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, should cross Manhattan Island, under and between Thirty-second and Thirty-third Streets, and be constructed, filed its report in favor of the building and operation of the tunnel with the Appellate Division yesterday:

ALBANY, April 23 -- Provision for a general investigation of State departments was made by the Legislature to-day. A resolution was passed at the suggestion of Senator Green to permit the appointment of a committee of twelve members divided between the houses.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Directors of the Legal Aid Society yesterday Rosalie Loew, the attorney of the society, read a report on the work done in the matter of fraudulent employment agencies, conviction in one case having been secured. The report was in part as follows:

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Stockholders of the North and West Chicago traction lines talked to-day of taking steps toward filing a formal protest against the rule of receivers for these leasing corporations.
PARIS, April 23 -- At the Bois de, Boulogne race meeting to-day W.K. Vanderbilt's Alpha took second place in the race for the Prix Greffulle.

BALTIMORE, April 23 -- Collectors from New York, Philadelphia, Washington, and other cities were included in the scores of bidders and buyers at the second day's sale of the famous collection of antiques of the late Dr. William H. Crim.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The close of the Legislature was attended with much excitement owing to the attempts to rush socalled " grab " bills through in both houses. The efforts in this direction were attended with only moderate success.

Wall Street's wish that the course of prices might be auspicious at the opening of the new temple of Mammon was gratified. The first hour of business upon the Exchange was marked by a gentle and general improvement in the quotations. But sentiment is a poor basis for business and it is necessary to add that the improvement was brief.
RICHMOND, Va., April 23 -- The announcement of Andrew Carnegie's gift to Tuskegee Institute was made known here to-night, and created unbounded enthuslasn.

Taking it all in all the action of yesterday's market on the first dap in the new Exchange was distinctly disappointing. The general belief in speculative circles was that sentiment, if nothing else, would carry prices higher and that, merely for the sake of making a "good start" in the new building the larger interests would advance and sustain the market.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 23 -- Wild disorder arose to-day in the House of Representatives over the municipal ownership bills, in the midst of which members of the majority, enraged at Speaker Miller's rulings in favor of the Lindly bill, attempted to drag him from his chair.

The Legislature has been mercifully preserved from grave scandals, only two of the measures against which public protest had been made having passed to enactment. One of these is the bill extending the time within which the Union Railway Company may avail itself of local consents to extend its lines in Westchester, and the other, the East River Gas bill, some of the objections against which, had been withdrawn.

ALBANY, April 23 -- In the final slaughter in the Assembly this morning, three measures in which New York City is interested were defeated in short order. They were the Elsberg Rapid Transit bill, favored by the Citizens' Union; the Agnew bill, favored by Park Commissioner Wilcox, designed to legalize the elevated railway's terminal in Battery Park, and the Police bill introduced at the request of Commissioner Greene, with the three-platoon amendment attached.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The inclosed clipping from The Minneapolis Journal Junior, April 14, 1903, seems to me both instructive and somewhat amusing. A large amount of space in this paper is devoted to brief essays on assigned topics written by school children of till ages. The topic assigned in this case was, I believe, "Experiences Resulting from Delusions."

Mr. W.J. Cripps's "Old English Plate" leaves little to be desired so far as European silver is concerned, but what about our own? Mr. John H. Beck supplies all deficiencies in his "Old Plate. Its Makers and Marks." The early settlers of Virginia believed that there must be gold in the immediate neighborhood, and so when Capt. Newport set out for Virginia there came with him two goldsmiths, two refiners, and one jeweler.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Bion J. Arnold, an electrical engineer, declared to-day that the end of steam as a railroad motive power is in sight. He left Chicago to-night for Lansing, Mich., where he will make a public demonstration of a system of electric railway construction which he promises will change the methods of railroad transportation all over the world.

The petition of ALFRED DREYFUS for a reopening of his case is the natural and ordained sequel to the recent debate in the French Chamber conducted by M. JAURES for the ostensible purpose of showing that a certain Nationalist Deputy, M. SYVETON, had been elected through misrepresenting certain facts connected with the Dreyfus case.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Judge Grosscup today entered an order in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, enjoining six railroad companies from discriminating against small shippers in the western territory. The decision is especially important as being the first under the new Elkins law.

A writ of habeas corpus yesterday saved "Al" Adams, the convicted "Policy King," from donning the convict's stripes to-day, Justice Scott, in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court, having denied the application for a certificate of reasonable doubt made on Adams's behalf after he had been sentenced on Tuesday last to serve a term of imprisonment in the State prison and pay a fine of $1,000.

RICHMOND, Va., April 24. -- Unmistakable evidence was given at the closing Richmond session of the Conference for Education in the South that a good part of the Northern thinkers and educators who had journeyed here not only to discuss the vast and perplexing negro problem, but to observe it at close range, had undergone a change of heart.
LONDON, April 24. -- Money rates and discount conditions in the market to-day were practically, unaltered.

The bill just passed by the Legislature, of New York relative to the speed of motor vehicles and the conditions to be observed by chauffeurs in their operation on public highways is probably the most drastic measure of its kind yet enacted. It has the approval of the Automobile Club, which is highly creditable to the members of that body.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 24. -- The Reliance was warped into the stream and anchored off the Herreshoff shops this afternoon. She will remain there until to-morrow morning, when the sails will be hoisted and she will start on her trial trip. Shortly before leaving the wharf, where the boat has been ever since the launching, the club top-sail spar and other portions of the racing gear were taken en board.

It takes longer to road than to tell the story of the sad career of Richard Rosny, for sad it was in spite of the wealth and honor that came to him. When he was quite a child his mother forsook widowhood to become the wife of Horace Belton, and from that time on Richard trod the path of thorns.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: IN connection with the Burroughs attack in the March Atlantic on Thompson Seton's natural history, permit me to call attention to an article in the current Forest and Stream (April 18.)

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Through good hitting on the part of the Washington base-ball team and numerous errors on the part of the New York players, to-day's game was given to the former by a score of 7 to 1, the New Yorkers scoring their solitary run in the fourth inning. Pitcher Tannehi was relieved by Wolfe at the end of the third inning.

In "A Summer in New York" the author of "Chimmie Fadden" turns his attention for a time from the servants to the masters and mistresses and tries his skill at hitting off the salient characteristics of the wealthy and fashionable. He Goes it with more than a modicum of success, though not, perhaps, with originality enough to add materially to his fame.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- "If Jesus Christ should return to the earth to-morrow He would be welcomed in every Jewish synagogue in the land, and every Jew would say, with David. Lift up your heads, O ye gates, and be ye lifted up ye everlasting doors, and the King of Glory shall come in."

The Dickens exhibition, recently held in London at the Memorial Hall. Farringdon Street, on the site of a portion of the old Fleet Street Prison, where Pickwick and Sam Weller were immured, contained among the manuscripts, relies, and other "Dickensiana" one page of the original manuscript of "The Posthumous papers of the Pickwick Club."

The story of William R. A. Wilson called "A Hose of Normandy" is founded on the adventures of the Siour de la Salle in his explorations in New France. Its hero is Capt. Henri de Tonti, his Heutenant, and its pages are filled with the names of people and places familiar to one acquainted with the events in America during the reign of Louis the Great.

LONDON, April 25. -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Times says the Sultan would have sent Edhem Pasha as Commander in Chief of the troops in Albania, but Edhem is suffering from asthma, so the Sultan chose Omer Pasha.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I ask the privilege of sufficient space in your columns to reply to a number of critics throughout the country who, since the publication of "A Son of Destiny," have persistently made the accusation that my story was based on "The Conqueror" as a model, and that I deliberately attempted to imitate it in mine, not a few of the critics adding: "And it's a bad imitation."

IT is generally conceded that Booker T. Washington represents the best hope of the negro in Amcrira, and it is certain that of all the leaders of his people he has done the most for his fellows with the least friction with the whites who are most nearly concerned, those of the South.

IRRESPECTIVE of nationality, why should a Field Marshal, even providing he is a Prussian, be sweet-tempered? Bear in mind the responsibilities of a commanding officer, his daily and nightly ten-thousand annoyances, added to the bothering interferences from Secretaries of State or War or of Foreign Affairs.

A good, wholesome story that brings the smile and compels the emotional tear is "The Substitute," by Will N. Harben. Its thread is the repentance of Hiram Hillyer a grain and cotton merchant of Darley. Northern Georgia, who thirty years before had slain a man in a moment of blind passion.

BUTTE, Mont., April 24. -- Acting upon instructions from Superintendent McMichael at Minneapolis, Manager Wild closed the local office of the Western Union Telegraph Company at midnight last night and announced that business through the company's office in this city would be entirely suspended until further notice.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 24. -- Lieut. Gov. Lee told the Grand Jury to-day how Baking Powder Trust boodle was distributed at the Laclede Hotel in St. Louis two years after the defeat of the "alum" bill. Lee, it appears, was employed to distribute the money and engaged the services of a Senator to assist him.

THE first volume of the catalogue of the English portion of the library of Robert Hoe has made its appearance in a privately printed edition of 100 copies. Beginning with Caxton, all the early English printers and hearts all the great masterpieces of English literature will be represented in this important work, which will be completed in five volume, (certainly not more than sixty issued at intervals of three months.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 24. -- The Illinois House of Representatives to-day by a vote of 72 to 60 declared "no confidence" in its presiding officer, Speaker John H. Miller, whose alleged unwarranted use of the gravel in furthering a proposed enactment affecting rich street railway franchises in Chicago led to a riot yesterday.

THIS latest addition to the "Master Musicians" series fulfills the useful purpose that the previous volumes have shown to be the design of its projectors, and is no more ambitious than they, though it is a better piece of work than some of them.

LONDON, April 23. -- The Associated Press learns that there is in contemplation a forcible joint protest on the part of Great Britain, the United States, and Japan against the Russian demands in the matter of the sovereignty of Manchuria.

A sketch of the French Revolution by a theoretical Anarchist is likely to have whatever interest attaches to a peculiar point of view. Mr. James seems to be a theoretic Anarchist, and his book has tho special interest that might be expected of such a work. It is, in fact, a readable essay, for the most part moderate in expression, usually distinguished by lucidity of style, and apparently based upon wide reading.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Lady Herbert, wife of the British Ambassador, entertained this evening at a dance complimentary to Miss Alice Roosevelt, who was absent from the city on the occasion of Lady Herbert's two dances of the past Winter. The guests, who numbered less than 200, were chiefly the personal friends of the hostess from the younger portion of society.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Minister Congrer, at Peking, has cabled to Secretary Hay a synopsis of the demands made upon China by Russia respecting the control of Manchuria.

The Amory-Vreeland hearing came to an unexpected stop yesterday afternoon through the interposition of District Attorney Jerome, who interfered in his capacity as criminal prosecutor of the County of New York. When the representatives of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company had recovered from their astonishment at this action on the eve of the end of the case, and Magistrate Barlow had granted Mr. Jerome's request for an adjournment until next Wednesday morning, ...

AUSTIN, Texas, April 24. -- It is reported in well-informed railway circles of Mexico that a transfer of the ownership of the Mexican Central is about to occur. The Rock Island interests are said to be the prospective purchasers. The present visit of President A.A. Robinson to Chicago, St. Louis, and New York is said to be in connection with the deal.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Representatives of the brewing interests learned to-day much to their chagrin that their efforts to collect rebates upon the surrender of excise certificates had failed owing to a peculiar mistake which was not discovered until after the adjournment of the Legislature.

BALTIMORE, April 24. -- The market today worked up a movement of greater activity, with price changes somewhat mixed. Seaboards were the leading bull feature. The reports of earnings were accounted the most potent favorable feature, because the indications seemed to point to a total increase for the year exceeding $1,200,000.

AUTHOR, printer, and publisher are alike to be congratulated upon the Production of this handsome volume, in which every reader will recognize the handling of a great subject in a manner worthy of it. Mr. Thacher declares his object to be two-fold.

In discussions of recent projects of legislation amendatory of the Rapid Transit act there has been in certain quarters frequent mention of what is called the "Belmont syndicate," with ascriptions thereto of wickedness and appetite which would lead the uninformed reader to infer that the thing alluded to was either the beast of the Apocalypse or an octopus of vast, insatiate maw.

The story of the wonderful voyages of Pere Marquette has been told by Parkman, by Reuben Gold Thwaites, and again, only two months ago by Alfred Hamy: "Marquette au Mississippi." The Rev. Samuel Hedges has written a monograph on "Father Marquette, His Place of Burial at St. Ignace, Michigan."

WE HAVE in the two volumes before us an interesting and almost comlete history of animal magnetism, mesmerism, or hypnotism up to 1877 -- the first volume being concerned with Mesmer and his cotemporaries, the second with other prominent exponents of the same doctrine under various names, from the time of Mesmer to Charcot.
Copyright, 1903, by John R. Whitney. SUBJECT -- Paul Arrested, Acts, xxi., 30-39. GOLDEN TEXT -- If any man suffer as a Christian, let him not be ashamed, I. Peter, iv., 16.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The charges recently made by Herbert Welsn of Philadelphia against Gen. Funston, in which that officer was charged with having given orders to kill Filipinos in violation of the rules of war, were sent to Gen. Funston by the Secretary of the War for remarks.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In his letter in a recent issue Mr. Alden, speaking of Clark Russell and others, says: "When they write of the sea they never make mistakes." This brings to mind an incident of many years ago, when I had just read "The Wreck of the Grosvenor," which was called the best sea story ever written.

Walter Raleigh's study of Wordsworth will be published in this country next week by Longmans, Green Co. The author, who is highly regarded by men like Gosse and Lang, gives an account of Words-worth's childhood and education, the influence of the French Revolution and of Coleridge on the poet, the poetic diction of Wordsworth, Wordsworth in relation to nature and to humanity.

Magistrate Mayo, sitting in the Centre Street Court, yesterday issued a summons for the appearance of St. John Wood, the diamond dealer of 2 Maiden Lane, on May 11, to explain why he should not be proceeded against for the careless conduct of his chauffeur in running down one of the horses of the coach Pioneer in Central Park.

In undertaking to tell the reason of the general dislike of England, Mr. Peel has written a brave and reasonable book. The subject is interesting, its discussion timely and the interest is enhanced by a terse and lively style. The enmity of the Continental nations toward England is admitted by none more freely than by British statesmen.
CHICAGO, April 24. -- New York exchange to-day was at 35 cents premium before and 45 cents premium after clearings. Time and call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.

By a plot that had in it all the elements of dime-novel conception and execution three men held up in a room hired for the purpose at 37 East Twenty-eighth Street yesterday afternoon Otto Jahn, a messenger boy employed by Robert Graves Co., wall paper dealers at 483 Fifth Avenue, and robbed the lad of $250 of his employers' money, which he had just drawn from the bank.

D.R. CHANNING was undoubtedly one of the greatest preachers who ever stood in an American pulpit, and no other has had a more commanding influence. He was widely read in his own day and was listened to with eagerness by those who had Die opportunity to hear him. After his death his books and his biography had a large circulation, and they did much to influence public opinion.
The manner of Mr. CARNEGIE'S gift to Tuskegee was not less gracious than the gift itself was generous.

LONDON, April 11. -- The first volume of the new and complete edition of Ruskin's works has been published, and it cannot fall to be a delight to all who in any Tray admire Ruskin. As every one Knows, the successive editions of Ruskin's writings have been modified to a great extent.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Gov. Odell to-day set to work on the mass of bills which have accumulated as a result of the session of the Legislature, and signed many to which no objection has been made. Among those that he made law were Senator Hill's regulating the hours of labor of women and children in mercantile and other establishments.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: "The Chicago Society of Proofreaders" (latest edict) tells us that we can not print cannot because we should not print shouldnot. Now, there's a difference between the conjunction at two nasals and the conjunction of a sonant mute and a nasal. Further, shouldn't, can't, , defy the separatists.

The deprecation of the Sultan is by no means novel. George Dorys's "The Private Life of the Sultan" left its impression on American readers. Abdul Hamid never is lauded, and Mr. William Eleroy Curtis in "The Turk and His Lost Provinces" has nothing to say favorable about him. The lost provinces, as far as Turkey is concerned, are Greece, Bulgaria, Servia, and Bosnia.

Several hundred people in the down-town district joined with six policemen of the Church Street Station in an exciting chase last night after a supposedly rabid mongrel dog, which was finally killed by three bullets from the revolvers of the policemen.

At a private conference in the Marble Collegiate Church yesterday eight clergymen, designated as the Advisory Committee, considered the proposed union of Presbyterian churches. The Rev. Dr. J. Preston Searic of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary presided, and the Rev. James D. Steele of this city was Secretary.

Last Fall Dr. Eliot, the deeply respected President of Harvard University, delivered a series of three lectures before associations of teachers in three New England States -- Connecticut, Rhode Island, and New Hampshire -- on the common schools, their defects, their achievements, and the policy that should be followed regarding them.

GARDINER, Montana, April 24. -- President Roosevelt this afternoon resumed his tour, going to Livingston from here. Before going, however, he participated in the laying of the cornerstone of the new gate at the nothern entrance to Yellowstone Park. The ceremony was performed according to the Masonic ritual, and was in charge of the grand officer of the State of Montana.

ALBANY, April 24. -- "Whatever else may be said of the action of the three so-called 'insurgent' Republican Senators -- Messrs. Eisberg, E.R. Brown, and myself," said Senator Brackett of Saratoga to-day, "I believe this much can safely be said -- that such independence as they have exercised is not inconsistent with the strictest party regularity, nor with what any reasonable party organization ought to ask.

Mr. Wolf von Schlerbrand has done good service heretofore as an interpreter of the German mind to the American mind as both are concerned with the practical problems of the present, but he has done no better work in the fulfillment of this most useful and dignified function than he has done in the ostensibly humble work of translating and editing "The Kaiser's Speeches," in the volume which Messrs. Harper have just published.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Secretary Root and the Rev. Edward J. Vattmann, Chaplain of the Twenty-ninth Infantry, had an important conference to-day concerning affairs in the Philippines. While both parties to the conference were reticent as to details, it is known that it related to the friar question and to the attitude of the Catholic Church toward the "Americanizing" of the islands.
LONDON, April 24. -- The Royal Commission for the St. Louis Exposition was gazetted to-day. The Prince of Wales is President and Viscount Peel is Chairman. There are thirty-five other members.

Thrilling, indeed, and most agreeably varied, were the adventures by sea and by land of Raphael, or Kalph, Crowninshield, as narrated by himself through the medium of Justin Huntly MeCarthy. They included two love episodes, a shipwreck, a mutiny among castaways turned pirates, battle, murder, and sudden death.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Attorney General Cunneen gave a hearing to-day on an application of Coleridge A. Hart of Brooklyn for an action in the Supreme Court, in the nature of quo warranto proceedings to determine if he was legally elected a Justice of the Supreme Court for the Second Judicial District.

The "inside story" of the development of the Pennsylvania coal and iron mines and the fight for control of the business of transporting the product to the Atlantic seaboard was told by George F. Baer to the Inter-State Commerce Commission at yesterday's hearing in the Federal Building on the matter of the complaint of William R. Hearst of The New York Journal against the coal-carrying roads.

In this volume of poems about half are in the negro dialect, and show Mr. Dunbar at his best. The delicious languor and warmth and melody of the negro songs, their unexpected turns of humor and homely phrases, their sudden flights of poetic imagination, their kinship with wild nature, are inimitable and irresistible.

The lives of the poor spell tragedy. Even their pleasures have an element of tears: indeed, it is in their pleasure more than in their sorrows that the danger and tragedies of their lives lurk. Lillian W. Betts has chosen her family from that crowded district along the East River. It might has chosen her family from that crowedd district along the Mast River.

THE most important paper in the May Atlantic does not occupy the place of honor, for that is very properly given to George A. Gordon's "Emerson as a Religious Innocence," an artistic dealing with what most Atlantic readers will agree in regarding as the chief literary thought of the month.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, April 24. -- Messrs. Longmans, Green Co. will publish, in the next few days, "Social Origins," by Andrew Lang. It is written to supplement and explain a treatise, which it includes, on "Primal Law," by the late J.J. Atkinson, Mr. Lang's cousin, who studied in New Caledonia the question of primitive marriage.

BERLIN, April 24. -- The physicians in attendance on "Jimmie" Michael, the bicycle rider, who sustained a severe fall from his wheel yesterday while training at the suburb of Friedenau for the international races next month, said to-day that he was progressing favorably toward recovery.
