Michael was thrown thirty feet, and when picked up he was senseless and blood was flowing from his ears.

IT IS a difficult task to separate, in the case of the Non-jurors, the religious from the political aspect of their professions. There can be no question but that the Nonjuror has bee very much maligned.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., April 23. -- Swarthmore College, the famous Quaker college and one of the leading educational institutions in the country, to-day selected The Public Ledger or Philadelphia as a text book to be used as a model of journalism in the clashes of literature.

National and local organizations of employers and employes throughout the country are preparing for meetings in the coming week to formulate plans in reference to the demands for higher wages or a shorter workday or other conditions that are to go into effect on Friday next.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 23. -- Brown shut out Princeton. 2 to 0. in a great pitchers' battle at Adelaide Park this afternoon. A total of six hits, divided equally between the two teams, was all that the players could make off Lynch and Stevens, but Lynch was by far the more effective striking out ten men.

A discussion in regard to the salaries of actors, and, incidentally, of the expenses of running theatres, has been started abroad by the utterances of Gordon Craig, son of Ellen Terry. Mr. Craig thinks that expenses will have to be cut down and actors' salaries reduced. He refers to the fact that there are actors now getting u100 a week, while others must be satisfied with less than u2.

A NEAT little figure, a plain gown, the hair worn straight back from the face, almost with the rigid lines employed in the early sixties, the bonnet and the gown already mentioned being of mourning stuff -- this is Mrs. Lewis Rutherfurd, who is so soon to marry William K. Vanderbilt.

ONE of the most interesting occasions in the reptile house in the New York Zoological Park is the feeding hour of the big snakes. Some of these, like the king cobra, the cobra di capello, the fer de lance, the rattlesnake, and the cottonmouth moccasin, are of the venomous species, whose bite would cause the death of a full-grown man within two hours.

When Emperor William wrote his famous letter to Admiral von Hollmann there were many inquiries in regard to the "King Hammurabi," who was placed by the Kaiser on an equality with the other supremely great men in the history of the world. Nothing can be found about Hammurabi in the majority of the encyclopedias, and until recently only the most up-to-date students of Assyriology knew who Hammurabi was or what was his title to fame.

So far as having possessed any great interest or significance is concerned, last week's business was nearly all of the roost commonplace sort, but the volume of small dealing, after a brief period of quiet, again assumed large proportions and indicated no early ending of the Spring season in that branch of the market's activity.

BERLIN, April 25. -- Russia's latest demands on China are no surprise to the German Government. Some Indications even exist that the Foreign Office here was privy to Russia's purposes in advance and expressed indifference to them. This is in exact accord with the policy to resist Russia in nothing in which she is really in earnest.

BERLIN, April 14. -- Josef Kainz, one of the most noted actors of the German stage and at one time the idol of the Berlin fair sex, has returned to this city from Vienna. So great has been the demand for tickets that the management of the Lessing Theatre, where Kainz appears, has extended his engagement.

A novel chess match contested by cable between the Manhattan Chess Club of this city and the Havana Chess Club of Havana, Cuba, was begun at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The encounter consisted of a consultation game, in which the local organization was represented by six metropolitan players, viz.: Eugene Delmar, Julius Finn, Edward Hymes, S. Lipschuetz, H.M. Phillips, and Otto Roething.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps one letter more on the crowded elevated station will not be amiss. At Third Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street the ticket office is placed on the east side of the passageway, so that south-bound passengers, who must come up on the west, or right side, of the stairs, must cross over to set their tickets, and then cross back again to reach their train.

MOUNT POCONO, April 25. -- Great activity prevails at the present time in the entire Pocono region. The month of April on the Pocono Mountains is looked upon by the many boarding house managers and hotel keepers as "cleaning-up" time. There is every indication not only that the season in this section will be one of the best for years, but an early season is anticipated by every one.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Having heard from the President, Secretary Hay is now in position to act respecting the Manchurian matter. Indeed, he has already taken the first steps, although for obvious reasons it is not deemed well to indicate their nature.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 25. -- The Military Academy baseball team defeated Harvard to-day by a score of 6 to 4 in the best and most exciting game ever played on the West Point field. In the third inning West Point made 4 runs on Gardiner's home run hit. At the end of the inning Harvard substituted Clarkson for Colbum as pitcher, after which West Point failed to score a single run.

LONG BRANCH, April 25. -- Under the auspices of the St. Cecllia Guild of St. James's Church a barn, dance was given one evening this week by Miss Florence Carthy at her home, on Second Avenue. Bare walls and what would otherwise be unattractive surroundings were relieved by bunting, flags, and pictures, and this, together with the costumes of the masqueraders, made a pretty scene.

THE loan last week of $7,500,000 to the Cramp Shipbuilding Company of Philadelphia, with plans for an immediate reorganization that will virtually put the great plant under the control of the Morgan interests, means a reconstruction of the cradle of the United States Navy. It is the vessels turned out from Cramps, warships and merchantmen, that have made the Delaware River the greatest shipbuilding seaway in the world, next to the Clyde.

LONDON, April 25. -- William K. Vanderbilt was quietly married to Mrs. Lewis M. Rutherfurd here to-day. This afternoon the bride and bridegroom started for France, where they probably will remain for some time. Only eight persons, including Mrs. Rutherfurd and Mr. Vanderbilt and the clergyman, were present in the dreary St. Mark's Church, North Audley Street, when the ceremony was performed this forenoon.

THE American Museum of Natural History has received from Kentucky interesting specimens of green rock, known as dunite, which, occurring in conjunction with carbon bearing strata, carboniferous sandstones, and shales in portions of Eillott County, that State, has given rise to the suggestion that Kentucky may contain diamond deposits which will one day make it an American Kimberley.

MILWAUKEE, April 25. -- Notification was issued to-day from the office of Acting Secretary Adams of the Chicago. Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad of promo- tions of officers of the railroad due to the resignation of A.C. Bird to become traffic manager of the Gould lines.

Two new volumes have appeared in the elaborate series published by the Oliver Ditson Company of Boston, called "The Musicians' Library." Mr. August Spanuth, well known as musician and critic in New York, has selected and edited twenty of the shorter original compositions for piano by Franz Liszt, and William F. Apthorp, the Boston critic and musical writer, has done a similar service for the songs of Robert Franz, of which his volume contains fifty.

Col. Joseph B. Girard, Chief Surgeon, Department of the Missouri, will proceed to the following-named posts on business pertaining to the inspection of the hospital departments at those posts: Fort Leavenworth and Fort Riley, Kan.; Fort Reno, Okla., and Fort Sill, Okla.; Fort Lcgan, H. Roots, Ark.; Jefferson Barracks, Missouri; Fort Crook, Neb.; Fort Niobrara, Neb., and Fort Robinson, Neb.

A warrant is out for the arrest of William J. Holmes, a messenger of the Chaso National Bank, who disappeared Wednesday with $2,090,70 in cash. It appears that the messenger was sent to a trust company to collect a draft. Instead of paying by check the trust company paid in cash. The boy never got back to the bank.

King Edward's Visit to France. According to Leo Temps, Le Gaulois, and Le Journal des Debats, the official programme concerning King Edward's sojourn in France has been definitely arranged by Sir Edmund Monson.

MR. TIBBETS was seated in his easy chair reading the evening paper and enjoying his after-dinner cigar. His dinner had been a good one; it had agreed with him, and he felt cozy, comfortable, and disputatious. Mr. Tibbets is one of those men who feel most belligerent when we should expect them to feel most otherwise.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 24. -- There was an unusually large attendance this afternoon at the meeting of the Old Maids' Association of Eastern New York, on organization devoted to the promulgation of celibacy among women. In addition to the delegates there were many visitors from the West eager to hear and report to their several States the results of the labors of the Committee on Domestic Infelicity.
To The Editor of The New York Times: In the article "The Balance of Trade," issued last Monday, THE TIMES says:

NEXT in interest after the projects for affording rapid transit facilities within the boroughs of the City of New York comes the problem of caring for the future traveling convenience of the vast multitudes who now go back and forth from the city aboard the overcrowded ferryboats of the North River.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It brings joy to my soul to observe that you are devoting some space in your powerful journal to the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. I have lived only nine months in this town, but that is long enough to convince me that no other road in this country carrying an equal number of passengers is so sublimely indifferent to their comfort.

PARIS, April 14. -- The new melodrama at the Ambigu is from the pen of that wellknown actor of the Comedie Francaise, M. Louis Leloir. Hitherto M. Leloir has been chiefly known for his great height, the prominence of his nose, qualities which generally militate against a stage success, but which, in this instance, have been amply balanced by real talent and a profound knowledge of metier.
The Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston has chosen Nathan Haskell Dole to write its anniversary ode.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- In response to the earnest and repeated requests of Rear Admiral George W. Melville, Engineer in Chief of the Navy, Congress, at its last session, appropriated $400,000 for the equipment and the erection of a fine engineering experimental plant at the United States Naval Academy.

The wedding of William K.Vanderbilt and Mrs Rutherfurd having taken place the week's sensation is ended. It was certainly a surpise in New York, and the secret was very well kept. Few of Mr. Vanderbilt's family were in his confidence. Even certain members of the Harriman family this city had not been apprised of it.

Baseball again was well patronized yesterday on all the professional circuits, and the three clubs which represent New York and Brooklyn in the major leagues were victorious. At Washington the Greater New York American League team defeated the Washington players and broke even on the opening series.

A farewell dinner, preceding the last performance at the Metropolitan Opera House Monday night, will be given to-night at the Metropolitan Club to Maurice Grau, the retiring impresario, by the directors of the Grau Opera Company, of the Conried Opera Company, and of the Metropolitan Opera, and Real Estate Company and some of his other friends.

Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON is reported to have said in a lecture on the drama at Birmingham, Alabama, the other night that he did not believe "a subsidized theatre in this country could be operated successfully."

The Yale track team has met with a series of disasters this year, losing a number of qualifying men through illness and Faculty troubles, and ending with two extremely bad days on which to hold the annual Spring handicap games. Shevlin's hammer throw performance is regarded at Yale as the more notable because he has never thrown the sixteen-pound hammer before, having kept himself to the interscholastic twelve-pound throw.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- The armored cruiser Colorado was launched to-day at Cramps' shipyard in the presence of a gathering of officials from Washington and the State of Colorado, including the entire Congressional delegation. Miss Cora May Peabody, daughter of Gov. Peabody of Colorado, broke the bottle of wine on the prow of the cruiser as the Colorado glided down the ways at 12:35 into the Delaware River.

SALT LAKE, Utah, April 21. -- Charges that the Mormon Church officials are exerting their ecclesiastical authority in the municipal government of this city are likely to lead to an open fight between the Mormons and the Gentiles at the coming municipal election.

WHAT very beautiful eyes R -- has," said the fluffy-haired matinee girl, referring to the actor who is one of the "idols" of her order. "They are of a most peculiar shade, and oh, so fascinating. I never could make out their exact color. I wish you'd ask him, dear, since you know him."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., April 23. -- Many of the cottagers already have arrived in Tuxedo for the Summer, and by the first week in May Tuxedo will be full of life. The fishing in the large lakes and in the Warwick brooks has enticed many here earlier than usual, and in consequence the large club was opened in advance of the customary time, being crowded all week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to thank you for your editorials of yesterday and to-day in regard to the increasing number of vicious lawbreakers among automobilists, and the conduct, of certain of our Magistrates in releasing offenders, and thus making the law of no effect.

ALLIANCE, Neb., April 25. -- President Roosevelt completed a hard day of travel and speechmaking with a fifteen-minute stop at Alliance this evening. Capt. Seth Bullock, Superintendent of the Black Hills Forest Reserve, who joined the President at Gardiner yesterday, left the train here. President Roosevelt, who has great admiration for Capt. Bullock, invited him to go to the coast, but he was forced to decline the invitation.

BIDDINGTON had just moved into a well-located, pretty apartment in Brooklyn with his wife and sister when the latter was taken very seriously ill. The invalid had recovered sufficiently to take her first meal at the table when a note was brought to the door by a youth, who immediately withdrew.

Dr. M.A. Howe led a large audience a pleasant journey along the Florida coast in describing "The Vegetation of the Florida Keys" yesterday afternoon in the lecture hall of the New York Botanical Gerden.

LOWELL, Mass., April 25. -- The statement that the State Board of Arbitration had refused to revise its findings in the case of the Lawrence Hosiery Company was communicated to Agent Nourse, and the was asked as to the future attitude of the company. He said he would not concede a thing and that the State board had made an eror in its findings.

NAVAL officers are watching with interest the case of their brothers in the service who are under indictment on the charge of smuggling in Porto Rico. In fact, officers of the navy are sensitive to the somewhat widespread popular belief that they have special privileges and opportunities in the matter of smuggling.

BOSTON, April 25. -- "Joe" Walcott, the colored prize fighter, filed a petition in bankruptcy in the United States Court today. He represented his liabilities at $1,889.81 and his assets nothing. He owes "Tom" O'Rourke of New York, his former manager, $300.

When Lord LANSDOWNE gave his ex- planation of the Russian agreement in respect to Manchuria, in the House of Lords last August, we took occasion to point out that the fact that Russia had made an agreement raised no probabil- ity that she would keep it. Her perfidy, indeed, is quite unique among civilized nations in its shamelessness.

GOV. SPARKS of Nevada would be known as "Silent John" if he lived in the East. Last Fall he electioneered in the Desert State from a stage coach. He "made" Carson, Virginia City, and Tonapah. After a splendid reception at that great mining camp, where his speech consisted of just thirty-nine words, his election was conceded by his follow-travelers on the coach.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 25. -- Yale signalized the renewal of baseball relations with the University of Pennsylvania after a nine years' lapse this afternoon at Yale Field by beating her old-time rival 2 to 1 in a game that was full of sensational playing.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The Secretary of the Interior is beginning to receive reports on the suspension of timber and stone land entries in California, Oregon, and Washington, and, so far as they go, they confirm the wisdom of the order of suspension which was made last Fall.

Championships with the foils, dueling swords, and sabres were decided last night at the annual tournament of the Amateur National Fencing Association. The bouts were decided in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club, Fifty-ninth Street and Sixth Avenue, before a large and brilliant gathering of spectators, among which women predominated.

An unusual number of Shakespeare birthday entertainments were given last Thursday, and poetry specially provided for the occasion was generally read. One of these efforts came from Annie Bailey Bull of Vassar's class of '80 and was used as a prologue for the Vassar benefit performance of "As You Like It" at the Victoria Theatre, when Minna Gale Haynes and Kyrle Bellew were seen as Rosalind and Orlando.

The most important event in the money market is the reappearance here of Wall Street as a very urgent borrower. American bankers effected large borrowings hero last Summer, and again in December; but since the beginning of the year nothing had been heard of such operations till last week. The recent change in the American money market, however, has created a very large demand for money here from New York bankers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is it not strange and inexplicable the channels into which those who give elect to direct their charity? An appeal to partisanship or to prejudice is answered by an outpouring of thousands, but the needs of a work of pure humanity are passed by and ignored.

IMITATION may be the sincerest flattery, but In the theatre It is not always most profitable. And peculiarly enough it seems that managers will, apparently, never learn the lesson. This fact was again emphasized last week in the production at the Princess of an alieged one-act play, " The Man Who Stole the Castle."

On the faces of the pool sellers in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon there was seen a smile that wouldn't come off. The grin appeared when the news came in from Williamsburs that Capt. Robert Emmet Dooley of the Bedford Avenue Station, spurred on by the gambling revelations made by the Rev. Dr. Cortland Myers, had descended upon and raided a "poolroom" only to discover that it was a station of the Street Cleaning Department.

ABSENT-MINDED!" exclaimed the clothing salesman, as he dealt the cards to a group of his brother travelers in a smoking car. "Say, I'm the limit in that direction, and I haven't thoroughly recovered front the shock I received from my last stunt in the trance line.

WASHINGTON, April 23.-- Before sailing for his home in Scotland yesterday Andrew Carnegie gave $1,300,000 for a Temple of Peace for the permanent court of arbitration at The Hague The gift was made through Baron Gevers, the Minister of the Netherlands to this capital, and was made with the understanding that the Government of Holland will be responsible for Its administration.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 25. -- Lakewood's growth as a resort is attested by the fact that more than a score of new cottages will be built here during the Summer. Work on several of the more pretentious ones has already begun. R.A. Rainey is to build three cottages on the lots in Second Street and Madison Avenue which he recently purchased.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 25. -- An appropriation of $200,000 by the next General Assembly for the erection of a sanatorium for the cure of tuberculosis patients was recommended to-day in a report submitted to Gov. Nash by the Ohio Commission on Tuberculosis appointed by the General Assembly a year ago.

Yesterday's bank statement fulfilled reasonable expectations. There was a considerable decrease in loans, and a cheerful increase in cash, carrying the surplus above last year's, for loans only a small per cent. larger. Nothing is so good that it might not be better, and conditions might be improved by loans falling below deposits.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 25. -- The mitre of the order of St. Vladimir presented by Czar Nicholas of Russia arrived here to-day for Father A. Toth of this city, in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination, which occurs to-morrow.

PREFACE. A HIGH moral purpose -- an intense, soulful, yearnful, palpitant purpose -- throbs and pulsates throughout this tale. Unfortunately, however, because of the demands of the drama and the theatre edition, I have been compelled to cut the high moral purpose out.

There was no lack of exciting sport on the Speedway yesterday afternoon, when the Road Drivers' Association of New York formally opened the Spring season with a series of brushes between well-known trotters and pacers. At the conclusion of the programme a beefsteak dinner was served to about a hundred members and quests in the clubhouse.

Elaborate ceremonies marked the dedication of the Columbia Club's new home at One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue last evening. Covers were laid for 200 guests, and the toasts were responded to by prominent city officials.

Golf, so far as respects the merits of match and medal play for American players, will practically be in an experimental stage during the coming season. The two systems of play have been brought more prominently to the front than ever before, the recent action of the United States Golf Association having directed unusual attention to the subject.

Van Cortlandt Park will be an important coaching headquarters this season. It was so to some extent last year, but the road coach squadron, run by Squadron A, will make more trips this season, and the popularity with which the coach was received by members of the squadron and their friends in its experimental year promises to be well sustained during the coming months.
Two municipal hearings are presently to be given upon two closely related subjects, so closely related that it seems they ought both to be under one jurisdiction and to occur at the same time.

President BAER of Reading, in his testimony before the Inter-State Commerce Commission, gave a striking illustration of the fact that a lawyer is a very poor witness. He cannot divest himself of the idea, that, even on the witness stand, he is his own counsel, and that he must maintain an argument with the counsel for the other side at all times and on all subjects touched in the examination.

PARIS, April 25. -- Miserably cold weather has entirely spoiled the commencement of the Spring season, and people have had to go back to Winter wraps and closed carriages. Naturally there is a tendency to linger longer than usual in the Riviera. Americans, however, are beginning to arrive here in fairly large numbers, and it is certain already that King Edward's visit will prove a great attraction.

"The more I learn about human nature, said the French cynic, "the more highly I appreciate -- dogs." When the hurry and excitement of the theatrical season is passing it would be only natural to give way to the discouragement and the lassitude of Spring; but is there not cause for a gloomy and perhaps a pessimistic outlook?

INDIANAPOLIS, April 25. -- Senator Albert J. Beveridge, who two years ago visited Manchuria, foreshadowed in a series of articles that he wrote on his return to this country almost exactly such a situation as now prevails.

LONDON, April 25. -- Money was still wanted this week, the recent heavy repayments to the Bank of England having strained the market's resources and kept rates stiff. Discount rates hardened after being easier, the expectations of a decline in the official rate being again disappointed on Thursday.

BOSTON, April 25. -- The money market is in a much easier position than it was a week ago. Rates are lower, the supply is large and increasing every day, and the banks show a disposition to put out funds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial to-day on the right to trial by jury is of great interest. In People exrel. Murray vs. Justices. 74 N.Y., 406, the relator, charged with assault and battery, elected to be tried by the Court of Special Sessions in New York County, and after conviction claimed that he had a constitutional right to trial by jury, which he could not waive.

ST. LOUIS, April 25. -- As a result of the recent legislative scandals, which have involved him hopelessly, Lieut. Gov. Lee decided to-night to resign his office on Monday. The decision was reached after a long conference between Lee and his closest friends, and it is asserted was by the advice of Attorney General Crow. Gov. Dockery will not lose any time in accepting the resignation.

To the Editor of The Now York Times: I noticed in last Sunday's paper a letter calling attention to Miss Mary Shaw's fine acting in Ibsen's "Ghosts," and reproving the public for not having properly appreciated it. In my humble opinion the public was not far wrong. No one questions Miss Shaw's great ability, but is a drama constructed on so horrible a theme a good thing to present in public?
Our little communtly is a mighy happy one at present," observed the man who lives in one of Brooklyn's prettiest suburbs, a placid, reminiscent sort of smile spreading over his features.

LAKEWOOD N.J., April 25. -- The managers of the Horse Show were again favored with perfect weather to-day, and there was a large attendance at the Country Club. The pony race was the feature of the closing day. The prize was a silver cup offered by Mrs. George J. Gould, and the contest was for ponies not exceeding 14.2 hands, amateurs to ride, quarter-mile heats, best two in three.

Guayaquil, Ecuador, where Thomas Nast died of yellow fever soon after he took up his work there as United States Consul, and widely published us one of the most unhealthful cities in the world -- a city of 60,000 people, built entirely of wood on low ground, ill-supplied with water, and infested with vermin -- is to be renovated and rendered sanitary by Americans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see the beautifying of the city is up for consideration by the Board of Aldermen and others equally competent to pass upon it. It is not long ago that they and we were discussing the necessity for housing the various departments which are now paying rent.

Henry Alperin died yesterday morning in Gouverneur Hospital, where he was held a prisoner on the charge that he had attempted suicide. Henry was sixteen years old, and lived with his parents at 179 Orchard Street. He returned home from work Friday evening, ate his supper, and went immediately to his room.

Coroners' Physician Albert T. Weston criticised Dr. E.L. McGill of the City Hospital on Blackwell's Island late yesterday evening for having performed, he said, an unauthorised autopsy on the body of Leon Robbins, an inmate of the hospital, who died there on Friday, presumably of blood poisoning, though the autopsy showed that death resulted from the effects of a fractured skull.

No one doubts Mr. ROBERT B. ROOSEVELT'S earnestness nor his longing to see Manhattan possessed of beautiful and adequate municipal buildings, but we are sorry to find him casting a stone against the project to clear the City Hall Park of all buildings save the City Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters appearing from time to time in the people's forum of your Sunday edition awaken the controversial spirit. This is as it should be. Let mind contact mind. Let the sparks and splinters fly. The fires of enthusiasm will discover to us the quickest exit from intellectual ruts.

ALBANY, April 25. -- Gov. Odell signed today the bill of Senator Armstrong authorizing the State fish and game protectors to exercise the right of search in New York and Kings County when in quest of violations of the law. He also signed these bills:

BRISTOL, R.I., April 25. -- The auspicious circumstances which attended the launching of the Reliance two weeks ago were present again to-day when the big yacht took her first spin under canvas. The trial was not so much to determine her speed as it was to find out how her sails set, and no weather could have served better than to-day's for that purpose.

RACINE, Wis., April 25. -- Idleness for every one of the smaller plants operated by the American Linseed Oil Company, eighty in number, and abandonment of the local refinery of that company, is announced to-day. The high cost of labor and the steady increase in the price of the raw material, it is declared, has forced the company to concentrate its operations at a few large establishments.

A committee of Albanian chiefs arrive is Paris the other day and had an interview with Prince John d'Aladro Kastriotis, the Pretender to the Albanian throne, with the result that certain Paris papers state that the Prince is about to go to Albania and place himself at the head of a national movement.

RICHMOND, April 23. -- The surprise to the Conference for Education in the South came to-day in the casual form of a letter of invitation from two of the most influential negroes in the city, that the members of the conference attend divine services to-morrow with the colored people.

AT 11 o'clock the man on the fifth floor paid the bill. At 12 o'clock everybody in the building knew he had paid it. Also, everybody was surprised, because the man had boasted many times that he would see the Hudson River turn round and flow toward Albany before he would pay it. Finally curiosity got the better of discretion, and one of his neighbors asked him why he did it.
LONDON, April 25. -- The Prince of Wales unveiled in St. James's Park to-day a statue erected in memory of the marines recently killed in South Africa and China.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice in this morning's TIMES an editorial on the right of trail by jury and stating that a motion of great interest will be argued before Judge Lacombe, and you also say that it will be raised for the first time. Will you kindly let me correct you on this point?

Tomasso Petto, one of the thirteen Italians arrested on suspicion of having been implicated in the barrel murder, was yesterday formally charged with having killed Benedetto Madonia, the victim. Petto was taken before Coroner Scholer, who held him without bail and committed him to the Tombs pending the inquest.
SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, April 25. -- H.S. Bird, editor of The San Juan News, has been sentenced to five days' imprisonment and to pay a fine of $20 for contempt of court.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- The classic field and track meet of the year, the ninth annual relay races of the University of Pennsylvania, took place on Franklin Field this afternoon. Over one thousand athletes, scholastic and collegiate, participated in the events. While the day was not ideal the usual crowd of about eight thousand spectators cheered on the fleet runners.
Time money rates, 4 1/4 per cent. for sixty to ninety days and 4 1/2 per cent. for four, five, and six months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Highlanders throughout the United States received the mournful intelligence of Gen. Macdonald's death, by his own hand, with feelings of profound sorrow. They regarded him as peculiarly their own; born on the same northern soil, inheriting the same characteristics, and imbued with the same traditions.

As the result of an examination by Commissioner Cutting of the Massachusetts State Insurance Department into the affairs and condition of the North American Insurance Company of Boston, which revealed an impairment of about $60,000 in the company's capital, Charles E. Macullar has resigned the Presidency of the company.

ALBANY, April 25. -- During the year 1891 the State Library sent out 3,657 volumes, placing them in the leading libraries of the world; in 1902 it sent out, under the same system, 38,183 volumes, or more than ten times as many, not including the large number distributed by the Regents' office. This statement is made in the report for 1902 of Director Dewey of the New York State Library.

ON THURSDAY last there was a crush of carriages in Gramercy Park. It was Shakespeare's birthday and Ladies' Day at the Players Club. This is always a great occasion, and it is the one day in the year on which the wives and daughters of the members can have a peep at one of the most cozy and original clubhouses in town.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestion of a wardship for the negro, mentioned in your issue of to-day, raises one more question to be added to the many vexatious problems which are developing in that regard.

For the first time in the history of social settlement work in this city the young athletes of the various settlement houses met in an athletic meeting in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, under the direction of the recently organized Inter-Settlement Athletic League last night.

SHENADOAH, Penn., April 23. -- Meetings of all the miners' locals in this vicinity were held to-day for the purpose of voting on the proposition to return to work on the company's terms pending the settlement of the question as to the number of hours of labor on Saturday. It was decided to return to work on Monday morning.

VENICE, April 25. -- The reconstruction of the famous Campanile of St. Mark, which fell to the ground July 14. 1902, after standing for more than 1,000 years, was begun to-day by the laying of the foundation stone by the Count of Turin, representing King Victor Emmanuel.

LENOX, April 25. -- The continued cold weather has kept away some of the cottagers who intended to have their places open by this time. A few, however, are already here, including J. Frederick Schenck, Thomas Shields Clark, Dr. Richard O. Greenleaf, and Dr. H.P. Jaques, and several others are expected to open their places next week.

WHAT scientific men consider to be the first step of a probable long series of reclamations of swamp and pool lands which is likely to extend over the coming half-century in the valley back of the Orange Mountains, New Jersey, has already been taken most successfully. During the past Winter engineers have drained off a mosquito-breeding lake and changed this, with an adjoining swamp, into good meadow land.

THE old Idea of a missionary was a man who went out with a Bible and hymn book, sat down in front of a savage and talked. I used to have that conception myself when I was a boy, and I would no more desire to be that sort of a missionary now than I did then.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 25. -- The Wellesley-Vassar debate this evening was won by the Vassar team, who supported the affirmative side of the question:

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 25. -- With two substitutes on her nine and a transposed infield. Columbia defeated Lehigh here to-day by a score of 7 to 4. Lehigh made 12 hits to Columbia's 8, but the New Yorkers landed safely when hits were needed. At critical moments Columbia played faultlessly, in the sixth inning Lehigh had three men on bases with none out, but could not score.

ALBANY, April 25. -- The award by the State Court of Claims of $3,000 to Miss Carrie E.T. Chaffee of Syracuse carries with it thirty-seven other claims ranging from $2,068 to $30,000 each and aggregating $527,248. These thirty-eight claims are for injuries sustained by individuals by the collapse of the James Street bridge, Syracuse, April 6, 1902.

Last week an excellent source of Wall Street information published the following: "We have received a copy of the first quotation sheets that were ever issued in Wall Street, being annual circulars issued by Thomas Denny Co., 62 Cedar Street, New York City, from 1859 to 1868. It may be of interest to note a comparison of leading stocks of that date and the present time."

Regardless of the outcome of Magistrate Barlow's inquiry into the merits of Amory's libel charges against President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, it was asserted yesterday that Messrs. Osborne and Philbin would present to District Attorney Jerome, with a demand for action, the fraud allegations they claim to have proved against the company.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, April 25. -- A month more and this picturesque Summer resort will be fully awake for the season. Even now the villagers of the little hamlet are rubbing their eyes and wondering how the Winter sped so quickly. There is a smell of fresh paint in the air, and the noise of hammer and saw is heard from sunup to sundown -- the working day of the Gap resident.

PARIS. April 14. -- France is still torn asunder by the religious question. It has brought about the resignation of M. Revoil. Governor General of Algeria, at a critical moment, when for the first time in French colonial history a chief of the State is about to visit the only colony which France can boast of as being in any way a financial or colonial success.

Last week was historic. After the Stock Exchange shall have ceased, to be the financial centre of New York, and when some touring Mongolian is reading his Baedeker upon the ruins of our Cathedral in which perhaps persons already born may attend service before their death, it shall be on record in this print, more enduring than brass, that on Wednesday last the Exchange moved into its new building, and enjoyed a fragile, fleeting boomlet.

It was inevitable that the negro question should come up at the Conference for Education in the South, which has just closed at Richmond. The imperative need of the negro for education would have forced it if nothing else had. The National character of the movement, which aims at education of all races and all classes, would have compelled its discussion sooner or later.

Through the filing yesterday of the completed appraisement of the estate left by Henry Hart, for forty years President of the Third Avenue Hallway Company, it was learned that the net personal property amounted to less than $100,000, and no real estate was mentioned. This reveals the immense shrinkage in the property of the man who in 1897, at the high tide of his prosperity, was reputed to be worth between $15,000,000 and $20,000,000.
Eve -- Don't you think I'm a dream, Adam?

ALBANY, N.Y., April 25. -- Major Gen. Roe to-day announced the dates of inspections of the various organizations of the State National Guard by regular army officers, pursuant to the provisions of the new National Guard law enacted at the last session of Congress. The inspections in New York City will take place as follows:

On board the St. Paul, which arrived yesterday, was Anthony Fiala, who will remain in this country about four weeks completing arrangements for the Ziegler Arctic Expedition. He has been busy in Europe for a short time looking after that end of the expedition's interests. He said that Mr. Ziegler's vessel, the America, had been brought from Tromsoe to Trondheim, where she is being repaired.
It is evident that the conference for education in the South, which has just closed its sessions at Richmond, has been by far the most effective yet held.

Novelty is guaranteed for racegoers this afternoon on the spick and span new race course of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, at Jamaica, L.I., where, with the running of the $7,000 Excelsior Handicap as the special feature, the new track will be opened to the public for the first time, and formally added to the racing circuit of the East.

ORANGE, N.J., April 26. -- Robert Flagg of Orange owns a horse that residents of Orange think is addicted to the use of liquor and which got its master into the toils this afternoon. Mr. Flagg lives on Hickory Street, and after partaking of his noonday repast to-day concluded to travel out and get a little air.

Caulfield's handball court, in South Brooklyn, was crowded yesterday with visitors and players who expected to see a four-handed match in which Oliver Drew and P.J. Corby were to have been on opposite sides. Although Drew had promised to be present, he did not put in an appearance, and played in Jersey City instead.

With 300 naval apprentices aboard the United States training ship Hartford returned yesterday to the Brooklyn Navy Yard from a long cruise in European and West Indian waters. The Hartford, which is one of the very few old-time fighting ships remaining in the American Navy, was reconstructed at San Francisco several years ago for use as a training vessel for landsmen. Since then she has been on a number of lengthy cruises.

Last week's stock market showed an improving tendency. Sixty-nine stocks advanced a point, while only twenty fell. The movement in the bond market was both equally striking and more significant. Forty-nine advanced and fourteen fell. Doubtless this is a reflection of last week's easier money market.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 26. -- David H. Morton of 456 West Twenty-third Street, New York City, employed as a clerk in the office of Francis R. Master Co. of 45 Worth Street, who mysteriously disappeared on April 16, has been found in a house near here, where he secured lodging. His mind appears to be affected, and he is greatly exhausted, having, as he says, traveled here from New York on foot.

BERLIN, April 26. -- Although the apprehension with regard to the American financial situation has disappeared, the Boerse had a dull week last week, the slight volume of trading resulting in generally lower values.

BERLIN, April 26. -- Hugh J. Cannon, the Mormon missionary, intends to appeal to Emperor William for permission for the Mormon elders to remain in Germany, hoping that his Majesty's policy of religious tolerance may include the Mormons.

Coroners' Physician Weston, who on Saturday criticised Dr. E.L. McGill of the City Hospital on Blackwell's Island for performing an autopsy on the body of Leon Robbins, performed an official autopsy yesterday and reported that the man had died of blood poisoning. Two direct causes for the blood poisoning are given -- a fracture of the ribs and an injury to the right leg.

THEBES, Ill., April 26. -- An unknown negro, aged about seventeen years, was lynched by a mob of angry farmers near the vilage of Santa Fe this afternoon for an attack he had made on the ten-year-old daughter of Branson Davis, a farmer. The lynching was followed by a general onslaught upon a colony of negroes living in tents, who were engaged in bridge construction work.

It must add a little to the bitterness of the resentment the Administration necessarily feels at the policy of Russia in the Orient that, in the matter of trade restriction, the powerful Empire is but adopting the principle that we have so long followed.

It would be quite idle to try to keep track of all the gifts of Mr. CARNEGIE, or even of the more important of them. But his offer to supply the funds to erect a suitable home and offices for The Hague tribunal, including the provision of an adequate library, is especially worthy of note.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26. -- Fire destroyed the Brunson and Union Clothing Company Buildings, at High and Long Streets, and several smaller structures early to-day, and damaged the Nicholas Block, entailing an aggregate loss of about $600,000. Daniel Lewis, Captain of Engine Company No. 11, was caught under a falling wall and instantly killed.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- James N. Tyner has broken his silence on the subject of the emptying of the safe in his office at the Post Office Department. He said: "The Postmaster General and all the high officials of the Post Office Department have lost their heads completely in the last four days.

From his pulpit in the Baptist Temple. Brooklyn, last night the Rev. Dr. Cortland Myers made a second attack upon the local police for failing, as he claimed, to do their duty against pool sellers and other gamblers in the borough. The preacher fiercely assailed Deputy Police Commissioner Ebstein accusing him of untruthfulness and declaring him to be unfit for office.

SANTO DOMINGO CITY, April 22. -- As a result of the fighting between Government forces and the revolutionists which occurred here April 18, the Government has abandoned San Carlos and Guibia, and these suburbs are now occupied by the rebels, who became possessed of the ammunition, rifles, and cannon left by the Government forces.

President Herbert H. Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, against whom William N. Amory brought the charge of criminal libel subsequent to the accusations of falsified accounts against, the company, issued yesterday afternoon a statement made by expert accountants in answer to the allegations made in the recent report of Eugene A. Philbin.

The Kauneonga Apartment House, at 330 West Ninety-fifth Street, was damaged to the extent of about $10,000 by fire last night. The fire started at 9 o'clock, and was caused by the explosion of a large standing lamp which was accidentally knocked over by a Mr. Gagnee, who lives on the third floor of the house.

PEKING, March 23, via San Francisco, April 26. -- The Commissioners of China to the St. Louis Exposition, Prince Pao-Lun, Taotai Wong, and Francis A. Carl, have met in Peking for their first conference.

A very one-sided exhibition game of baseball was played in Weehawken yesterday between the Philadelphia Nationals and the West New York Field Club nine, which the major league team won easily by the score of 16 to 3. After the opening inning had been played the visitors began to hit freely, and made six runs off six hits and a couple of errors in the next two innings.
The Ithaca Journal is in a position to congratulate its readers that

BRISTOL, R.I., April 26. -- The Reliance was taken out again this afternoon, and in a two-hour spin she proved, as was indicated yesterday, a stiff and powerful craft, and very fast in heating and reaching. Under her working rig she left her anchorage shortly after 2 o'clock, and beat down to the lower bay in a light southeast wind.

Thrilling finishes came thick and fast on the Speedway yesterday morning, when the cream of New York City's trotting and pacing stock turned out in full force and flocked to the upper stretch ready and anxious to display its speed to the thousands of spectators that crowded along the curbs and occupied every post of vantage.

The commission that was appointed at the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in 1900 to formulate for the consideration of the General Conference of 1904 a plan for the consolidation of its benevolent societies for the more efficient collection and distribution of church funds has completed its report.

A farewell dinner was tendered Maurice Grau at the Metropolitan Club last evening by the Directors of the Grau Opera Company, of the conried Opera Company, and of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company, in token of their esteem for the retiring impresario. The dinner was served in the main private dining room on the third floor, and was marked by many speeches.

RICHMOND, Va., April 26. -- The delegates to the conference for education in the South and many hundreds of the people of Richmond assembled in the Academy of Music to-night to do honor to the memory of Dr. J.L.M. Curry, agent of the Peabody School Fund, ex-Ambassador to Spain, member of the Directorate of the Southern and General Education Boards, and known widely as the "father of the educational movement in the Southern States."
LONDON, April 27. -- The Sofia correspondent of The Times says a series of new conflicts is reported from Macedonia.

PARIS, April 26. -- Elaborate arrangements are being rapidly carried out for the welcoming here of King Edward. They are on a scale of truly royal splendor. The fetes will follow the style of those held at the time of the visit to Paris of the Czar, and will include a number of events affording opportunities for brilliant spectacular effects.

The Monthly Review of the National Civic Federation calls attention to the interesting fact that, notwithstanding the rumors of a general outbreak of the strike fever in May, there is at the present time no strike in progress of National interest and importance, and none threatened.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The Chinese Legation will be moved this week from the Schneider mantion on Q Street to the beautiful house which has been in course of construction for a year past on the hill overlooking Washington at the corner of Nineteenth Street and Vernon Avenue. The legation has occupied the Schneider mansion for many years, and it has been regarded as possibly the finest home among the diplomatic establishments.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Postmaster General Payne and Attorney General Knox have decided to send the papers in the postal law bureau safe-rifling case to the United States District Attorney for action against the Tyners and Mrs. Barrett, notwithstanding that Mr. Payne is unable to furnish an inventory of the papers that were abstracted.
BALTIMORE, April 27 -- Important changes in officials of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, to take effect May 1, were announced to-day by President Loree.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., April 27 -- Announcement was made here to-day that the Hudson Valley Railway Company Has acquired the property and franchises of the North River Railway Company, which was organized to build an electric railway from Saratoga, to Glens Falls. The line was never built, but the company owned a valuable franchise and property consents in Saratoga.
HAVANA, April 27 -- Gen. Vasquez, the deposed President of the Republic of Santo Domingo, landed at Guantanamo, Cuba, to-day from the Dominican gunboat Presidente.

"It's peanut rolling time now." The phrase is apt to become a popular one if Fred Hallen continues to present "Election Bets," the sketch, by George M. Cohan, which he and Mollie Fuller offered at Hurtig Seamon's Music Hall. Hallen plays the part of a young husband with sporting inclinations, Philip Plunger, by name.

BOSTON, April 27 -- Three shots from a revolver rang out unexpectedly in the office of the Edison Illuminating Company in Head Place to-day, and through the smoke the startled clerks saw one of their number, Stillman M. Bishop, fall to the floor. The shots had been fired by Hartwell Stafford, who was a stranger to them.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 27 -- After only twelve days of usefulness the Government submarine cable connecting the Farallon Islands with the mainland at Point Reyes has been severed.

Interest in coaching and in out-of-door sports is increasing. The polo tournament is to be begun this week at Lakewood, and it promises to be much more of a social success than was the Horse Show. During the tournament Mr. and Mrs. George Gould will have a large house party. Among those at Lakewood are Miss Pomeroy, Miss Natalie Schenck, and Miss Adelaide Randolph.

LONDON, April 27 -- Sir Thomas Lipton respects to have the Shamrock III. refitted next week, and a resumption of the prize races between the cup challenger and the Shamrock I. will probably occur on the Clyde May 6. Both the Shamrocks should sail for America about June 1, and prior to the cup races there will be eleven or twelve, prize races between the Shamrocks off Sandy Hook.

ROME, April 27 -- King Edward arrived here from Naples this afternoon and was received by King Victor Emmanuel, who escorted the visiting sovereign through the densly packed streets. Their Majesties received a great popular ovation.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Local issues were inclined to sag. Particularly was this true in Can stocks, which were liquidated freely. In spite of the probability of a good annual statement to be issued to-morrow, the forecast of which caused the sharp upturn in the stocks a week ago, profit taking continued.

Giuseppe Trepani, the "Little Italy" undertaker, was put on trial yesterday before Justice Scott in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, charged with being one of the leaders in the conspiracies by which a gang of Italians swindled a dozen life insurance companies out of many thousands of dollars.

ASHLAND, Wis., April 27 -- Kimball, a small town near Hurley, was destroyed by fire from the forest this afternoon. Most of the citizens escaped with only the clothes on their backs, and many of them are homeless and destitute. The loss will be about $25,000.

The dissolution of the two-hundred-million-dollar syndicate which was organized to underwrite the securities of the United States Steel Corporation was announced yesterday. The syndicate, according to estimates made in Wall Street yesterday,o was one of the most profitable ever organized.

KANSAS CITY, April 27 -- Judge John F. Philips in the United States Circuit Court here to-day granted a temporary injunction restraining the following eight railroads from discriminating against small shippers: Chicago and Alton, Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul; Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe; Chicago, Burlington and Quincy; Missouri Pacific; Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific; Wabash, and Chicago Great Western.

Immigration at the rate of 100,000 per month, which it is expected will be the record for April, and which is likely to continue and possibly increase as long as present conditions last, is not at all an unmixed cause for congratulation. Not more so is the fact that the total immigration for the fiscal year ending with June will approximate a million.

Certain curious delusions as to the nature of militia service which have recently become rife in this country are slowly being pricked. In Troy and in other communities in this State labor organizations have assumed the right to expel from their unions members who enrolled themselves in the National Guard.

The leasing of the store at the southwest corner of Liberty and Washington Streets to L.W. Duesing, through Stockdale Julian, is another bit of evidence which points to the probable improvement of the Pennsylvania Railroad's plot at Cortlandt and West Streets. Mr. Duesing is at present one of the tenants in the old buildings on the fatter property.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Postmaster General and Mrs. Payne entertained a dinner company of young people this afternoon in honor of Miss Alice Roosevelt. The additional guests were the First Secretary of the French Embassy and Mme. De Margerie, the Countess Marguerite Cassini, Miss Margaret Hitchcock, Miss Josephine Boardman, Mr. Derlng of the British Embassy, Mr. Van Royen Of the Dutch Legation, Woodbury Blair, Van Ness Philip.

At the annual meeting of the Municipal Art Society in the galleries of the National Arts Club last evening several matters affecting the city's interests were brought up in committee reports and from the floor.

To the enlivening strains of "When Johnny Comes Marching Home" the West Point Cadet Corps, commanded by Capt. Treat, last night marched into Madison Square Garden, headed by their band, and the seventh annual military show was begun. The young and stalwart cadets acted as escort of honor to Secretary of War Elihu Root, who acted as the reviewing officer of the night.

The German papers and some of the German officials are very wroth at the action of Canada in imposing a surtax of 33 1-3 per cent. on imports from Germany, and threaten an increase in the taxes on Canadian imports into Germany. It is the old and senseless game of throat-cutting on both sides.

Following the revelations concerning the Boiler Squad, Commissioner Greens yesterday transferred to precincts the four men who had been undisturbed and assigned seven new men to do duty there. Sergt. Brown was allowed to remain in command.

PITTSBURG, April 27 -- Amid scenes as impressive as a lavish display of wealth, the dignity of society, and the solemnity of the ritual of the Protestant Episcopal Church could provide, the marriage of George Francis Alexander Seymour of England, the Earl of Yarmouth, and Alice Cornelia Thaw of Pittsburg, daughter of the late William Thaw, was solemnized this afternoon in Calvary Church.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 27 -- The Russian Foreign Office, when the Peking dispatch of April 23 setting forth the eight alleged demands made by Russia on China regarding Manchuria was shown to it, entered a denial of a number of the points and minimized the importance of others.

When the Brooklyn Democratic Club arranged to hold its annual dinner last night in honor of James Monroe's one hundred and forty-fifth birthday, it was generally understood that Edward M. Shepard and other Democrats were to launch a harmonious Democratic policy for the next campaign.

MANILA, April 27 -- Cholera again is threatening the Island of Luzon. The bad outbreak in the Camarines is apparently spreading northward. The Cagayan Villey is infected, and it is feared the epidemic will extend over all the islands. Past epidemics have generally lasted more than three years.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Schulman has been chosen as the Rabbi of Temple Beth-El, Fifth Avenue and East Seventy-second Street, to succeed the Rev. Dr. Kaufmann Kohler, President-elect of the Hebrew Union College. Dr. Schulman has been for four years the co-Rabbi with Dr. Kohler, and it had been the understanding that he would be the successor.

OMAHA, Neb., April 27 -- President Roosevelt spoke on the labor question to an audience of 10,000 people in the Coliseum here this evening. Omaha is threatened with an industrial strike on May 1, and the President was asked to say something bearing on this subject. The following was delivered in response to this request:

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Dullness was again pronounced in the market to-day, the sales amounting to only 13,193 shares and $102,500 in bonds. The general list sympathized with the arbitrage stocks, which weakened under New York selling. Declines were trifling in most cases, however, exceptions being 1 1/2 in Pennsyivaiila Steel preferred, 5/8 in Arctic Storage Batery, and 1 1/2 in American Asphalt 5s, to 22.

Who are the Four Cohans; where have they come from, and why has it taken them so long to arrive? When the curtain rang down last night on the first act at the Fourteenth Street Theatre the band of first nighters, jaded with the end of the season feeling, and with memories of "Spotless Town," rubbed their eyes and wondered where they could be.

There was nothing about yesterday's stock market to interest anybody off the floor. There were some fractional advances in the earlier trading, but dullness soon followed, and the close was heavy. The net result was a majority of fractional declines, and no advances among representative properties of so much as a full point.

MANILA, April 27 -- Rizal, Bulacan, and Cavite have apparently been pacificed, as a result of the vigorous campaign of the scouts and constabulary. Extensive precautions have been taken to guard against brigandage. It is estimated that 200 of the enemy were killed during the operations.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Observations of and conclusions reached by Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles on his tour of the Philippines last year were made public by the War Department to-day, his report, dated Feb. 19, being given out. It was the intention of Secretary Root to keep this document from publicity, as he holds that officers should be able to make confidential statements in such reports, and therefore they should not be published.

GREBNWICH, Conn., April 27 -- Sunday baseball playing promises to be a feature this Summer as well as golfing on the Fairfleld County Golf Club links owing to the action of William G. Rockefeller, who has provided the ball field for the Volunteer Baseball Club. Last Summer a couple, of church Deacons appealed to William, Rockefeller to stop Sunday ball playing on his property, and he was quoted, as being opposed to it.

LONDON, April 27 -- C. Arthur Pearson, proprietor of The Daily Express, has bought The St. James's Gazette. The chase price has not been announced. The policy of the Gazette, which is Conservative, will not be changed.
LONDON, April 27 -- Money was scarce in the market to-day, and there was a fair demand. Discounts were firm.

BOSTON, April 27 -- The money market continues to grow easier. Rates do not show much change, but instead of the borrower seeking the lender, as was the case a couple of weeks ago, conditions are reversed. Call loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 3/4@5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; New York funds, at par; clearing's, $17,668,832; balances, $1,362,526.

Ex-District Attorney Eugene A. Philbin was asked yesterday if he had anything to say in regard to the expert accountants' report issued by the President pit the Metropolitan Street Railway Company. The experts declared in their report that Mr. Philbin's charges of corporate mismanagement and improper accounts, on the part of the company had no basis in fact.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The latest acquisition to the American League circuit, New York, made its initial appearance in this city to-day and suffered defeat at the hands of the champions by the score of 6 to 0. A crowd of 7,053 paid to see Clark Griffith, Dave Fultz, "Kid" Conroy, "Willie" Keeler, and the other stars composing the New York team.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Gov. Odell, the members of his staff, committees representing both branches of the Legislature, and a party of guests left this city for St. Louis at 11:45 to-night on a special train to attend the dedication of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition on April 30 and May 1 and 2.

The interest of Gen. MILES'S report on atrocities alleged to have been committed by American officers in the Philippine Islands is mainly psychological. That is to say, the questions it arouses are not so much whether the reports are true as why Gen. MILES should have been moved to make them.

Mayor Low may be called as a witness for the prosecution to-day in the case of Henry C. Wilson, a civil engineer, and formerly Chief Clerk of the Army Harbor Board in this city, whose trial on a charge of attempted extortion was begun yesterday before Judge Warren W. Foster in the Court of General Sessions.

ROME, April 28 -- King Edward will go to the Vatican to-morrow afternoon at 4:30 o'clock. Starting from the British embassy he will alight at the Court of St. Damas, in the Vatican, where he will be received by Mgr. Bistleti, Master of the Chamber, accompanied by the Vatican officials.

BOSTON, April 28 -- The money market is in an easy position. Funds seem to be plenty, but the demand is not great. Call loans, 4@4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2 @5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 3/4 @5 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; New York funds, par to 5 cents discount; clearings, $24,950,513; balances, $19,965,334.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 28 -- Colonel and Mrs. Reginald Norman have given up the Barrett cottage on Catherine Street, which they have occupied during the past Winter, and are occupying their new villa at Block Point Farm, Portsmouth.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Local market conditions were unchanged. Trading was dull and professional, with the price movement irregular, six stocks and two bonds advancing, and ten stocks and four bonds declining. The declines extended to a point in Bell Telephone, while Pennsylvania Steel preferred regained the 1 1/2 per cent, it lost yesterday.

It is worth remembering in the general sense of relief and satisfaction at the actual arrival of "AL" ADAMS within the walls of our best-known prison that his road thither would have been hopelessly blocked had it not been for the efficient work of Capt. NORTON GODDARD and THERON G. STRONG in shaping and pressing the statute under which ADAMS was convicted.
Boehm Boehm have sold the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, a plot 100.8 by 90, for $83,000, to a builder, who will erect a high-class elevator apartment house on the site.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- An important conference between the President and the members of his Cabinet will be held in St. Louis probably Wednesday night. The special train bearing the President and his party will arrive at St. Louis Wednesday afternoon at 4:10. President Roosevelt and Secretary Shaw, who is to be of the party at that time, will be joined there by other members of the Cabinet.

PATERSON, April 28 -- Frank A. Taber, said to be connected with District Attorney Jerome's, office, this afternoon took his four-year-old son from this city, and Detectives have gone to New York to try to recover the boy.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 28 -- Announcement that the Mobile and Ohio, which is a part of the Southern Railway system, is to enter New Orleans with its passenger trains direct from St. Louis, portends the sharpest competition for railroad traffic that has been witnessed in the South for years.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, April 28 -- Gen. J. Franklin Bell, United States Army, who is on his way home from the Philippines, and who sails for New York on the North German Lloyd steamer Kronprinz Wilhelm to-morrow, was shown to-day the cabled digests of the report of Lieut. Gen. Miles.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The bats or the champion baseball team resounded with the sharp crack of victory to-day. It was a clean-cut victory, that read Athletics, 7; New York, 3. Not only did the champions defeat the all-star New York combination in the second game of the series, but played a game interesting, to the 6,135 spectators.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The Court of Appeals to-day declared unconstitutional the eight-hour provision of the Penal Code, (Sub-Division 1, of Section 384-H,) in the case of the people vs. the Orange County Road Construction Company, reversing the decision of the Appellate Division, Second Department, and sustaining that of Judge Beattie of the Orange County Court, who ordered the discharge of the defendant company upon its demurrer alleging that the law was unconstitutional.

Leopold Wertheimer, a partner in the dry goods firm of Aaron Wertheimer, whose store in Third Avenue near One Hundred and Twentieth Street was destroyed in a fatal fire on Jan. 16, was shot and dangerously wounded at his home on the third floor of 102 West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street at 5 o'clock yesterday morning by Joseph Simpson, a night watchman in the store.
The committee appointed to investigate alleged irregularities in the American Ice Company's management gathered at the City Club last night and laid out a plan of operation.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Since the last Government purchase of silver last Thursday silver has gone up 2 cents, and Treasury officials are beginning to apprehend further advances in the price. Yesterday 475,000 ounces were bought by the Director of the Mint at an average of 5446 cents an ounce.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 28 -- It was expected that the Reliance would go formally into commission to-day after being turned over by her builders, the Herreshoffs, to the cup syndicate, but the workmen had not finished putting on the final touches and the yacht was towed to Newport about sunset.

Mayor Low and the members of the Board of Aldermen nearly have come to an open breach over a bill which passed the last legislature, which proposes to take away from the board the power to lay out and close streets and change the map of the city, vesting all such powers in the Board of Estimate.

COLON, Colombia, April 28 -- The Deputies of the Department Assembly of Cartagena, by a vote of 9 to 8, have rejected a petition to address a memorial to the coming Congress praying that body to reject the canal treaty. The Assembly declared it possessed full confidence in Congress.

The only stock in the outside market yesterday which was given very much attention was American Can, the fluctuations of which reflected the varying views taken of the company's annual report. Apart from this stock, the day's movement of prices kept within narrow range, but, as had been the case on Monday, the net losses outnumbered the net gains.

President Fritz Lindinger did not preside over a meeting of the Wine, Liquor, and Peer Dealers' Central Association, held yesterday, at which the price of beer by the print was raised, and free lunches were abolished. The meeting took place in Terrace Garden. Mr. Lindinger's absence was regarded as significant and only secondary in importance by the liquor dealers to their decision of radical changes in their business, to go into effect May 1.
LONDON, April 28 -- Money was in fair demand in the market to-day in view of the settlement. Discounts were fairly steady.

Stocks irregular. Money easy, 2@2 3/4 per cent. One of the Wall Street bulletins said about midday yesterday that there had not been a single significant transaction. But then came news of the Philadelphia shipment of gold, and the franchise tax decision.

LONDON, April 28 -- The Gentlemen's Doubles in the covered courts lawn tennis championship games, to-day resulted in the Doherty brothers' retaining the championship, defeating Cazelet and Hillyard by 3 to 0.

ALBANY, April 28 -- Attorney General Cunneen said to-night that the decision of the Court of Appeals on the franchise tax is a victory for the peoplee. He believes that its benefits will be far-reaching. He is pleased over his victory in the case, unaided by outside counsel, but says that he has merely performed his duty.

A correspondent is curious as to why "The Starbucks" was lately called a dramatization of the bookworm disease. As it was written, the word was not "book," but "hook." It was the proofreader who made it "book." By hook or by book the Jethargy is much the same in its effects; but in the case of the poor white trash of Mr. Opie Read's bucolic effort the odds are considerably in favor of the hook.

At Jasper Oval yesterday afternoon Manhattan defeated the Williams College baseball team in an interesting game of twelve innings by the score of 6 to 5. Though the visitors outbatted the local collegians, having made eighteen hits to twelve by Manhattan, they were unable to save themselves from defeat.

ST. PAUL, April 28 -- George C. Squires, an attorney of this city and a brother-in-law of Major Edwin F. Glenn, has written an open letter addressed to Gen. Nelson A. Miles in which he replies to the structures upon Major Glenn in Gen. Miles's report upon alleged atrocities in the Philippines. The letter follows:

BOSTON, April 28 -- Norman W. Bingham, of Somerville, and Edward Davis, of Philadelphia, were to-day appointed by Judge Colt in the United States Circuit Court receivers of the Helios-Upton Company, a New Jersey corporation with places of business at Peabody, Philadelphia, and Chicago, and engaged in the manufacture of electrical appliances.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- The Trustees of the Thomas Orchestral Association at a meeting to-day decided to engage the services of the orchestra for another year, during which time renewed efforts will be made to secure the balance of the $750,000 necessary to put the association on a permanent basis.

The first impression of the general reader from the account of the profits and operations of the syndicate financing the United States Steel Corporation is that the profits are enormous; and they are, but they are not greater in proportion to the operations completed and the obligations assumed than are the profits in many transactions of which the public never hears and which would not be regarded as extraordinary if they were fully known.

-- A new form of "practical politics" has been invented by the Filipino Federal Party. It has decided to send to this country, and to support while here, about 250 students -- ambitious and promising young natives with a desire to enter one or another walk of professional life, and to do so with an educational equipment best calculated to meet the conditions imposed upon the islands by American rule.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Baroness Hengelmtiller, wife of the Ambassador from Austria-Hungary, is confined to her home with a badly sprained ankle, which resulted from a mis-step in her dining room Sunday evening. The accident is distressing, as the passage of the Ambassador and family is engaged on the Campania, sailing from New York on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The following is a summary of the Weather Bureau's weekly crop report:

STAUNTON, Va., April 28 -- H.H. Haas, Assistant Surgeon in the United States Navy, attempted suicide at a hotel here to-day by shooting. The ball entered the right temple and lodged in the left, near the surface, destroying both eyes. He was conscious when found and asked for his pistol to finish the job.

The alternating current of the law darting now this way, now that, at one moment denying and at another affirming identically the same principles, has identically the same application, has finally reached the point of declaring the special franchise tax law to be valid and constitutional.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 28 -- Lawyer Robert M.S. Putnam of New York City has commenced proceedings in the Supreme Court to contest the validity and obtain a judicial construction of the will of his aunt, Mary Putnam Bull, who died at Tarrytown, April 1, 1895, leaving an estate of nearly $1,000,000.

The Military Show, at Madison Square Garden last night was not all imitation warfare, for a member of the engineer corps taking part in the pontoon bridge drill was run over by the big war automobile filled with soldiers and painfully hurt. He was Private Frank Gomme, Company G, Twenty-second Engineers, N.G.N.Y., and stumbled while hurrying off the newly constructed bridge.

Frank B. Forster, until recently chief soliciting agent in this city for the Central Union Life Insurance Company of Cincinnati, was the principal witness yesterday when the trial of Giuseppe Trepani, the Little Italy undertaker, who is accused of being the principal conspirator in the great insurance swindle, was resumed before Justice Scott.

The sailing of the Kaiser Wilhelm II, was the most notable event of yesterday, and many persons were on the pier to see the voyagers depart. Mrs. Ogden Mills and the Misses Mills were among the passengers. They are to go to London, and thence to the Continent. Many of the grand opera artists also sailed on the liner.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 23 -- Dr. H.H. Cate, a physician and proprietor of a large sanitarium, who went to New York with $2,000 to attend to some personal business Tuesday of last week, is missing. No trace of him has been obtained, although his friends have searched for him since Saturday, when his absence first began to cause alarm.

Benjamin Steinhardt, counsel for Leon Stedeker and Samuel Stedeker, who were indicted under Section 351 of the Penal Code on a charge of occupying and keeping a place for the recording of wagers, received word last night that the Court of Appeals had decided the case in favor of the accused and had ordered their discharge.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 28 -- The blue flag of the Polo Association was flung to the breeze from the Georgian Court polo grounds this afternoon, marking the opening of the Spring tournament of the Lakewood Polo Club. The first game in the series for the Herbert trophies was played between the second team of the Country Club of Westchester and the Lakewood second team.

ALBANY, April 28 -- Ex-Wardman Ed- ward G. Glennon, known as the confidential friend of ex-Chief of Police William S. Dev- ery of the New York Police Department, was awarded a new trial by the Court of Appeals in a decision handed down to-day.

April, in closing, drew on the Weather Bank yesterday for a quantity of golden Summer sunshine and dispensed it to the surprised citizens of New York. A temperature of 84 degrees was reached at 3:30 o'clock in the afternoon.

President George F. Baer of the Reading Railroad was again the principal witness yesterday in the hearing before the Inter-State Commerce Commission on the complaint of William R. Hearst against the coal-carrying railroads of the anthracite region. Mr. Baer was on the witness stand during the afternoon session under examination by Clarence J. Shearn, counsel for the plaintiff, and his testimony caused several tilts.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The thanks of the citizens of New York and all who visit it for business or pleasure are due to Capt. Piper for his action in clearing the sidewalks of this city.

The plot of about three lots forming an "L" around the northwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street has been sold by Oppenheimer Hamershlag. The property has frontages of 77.4 feet on Broadway and 25 feet on the street, with a northerly line of 74.10 feet and a westerly line of 100.5 feet.

The Nassau Bank declared yesterday the one hundredth consecutive semi-annual dividend and reached at the same time the end of the fiftieth year of its existence. This bank was organized in 1852, the man most instrumental in its foundation being William Miles, who died last year. The first President was Thomas McElrath, partner of Horace Greeley.

LONDON, April 30. -- In addition to the seven demands in regard to Manchuria already telegraphed says the Peking correspondent of The Times, Russia, in another dispatch, demands that the navigation of the Liau River, which under the inland steam navigation rules is open to vessels of all nations, shall be restricted to vessels flying the Russian or Chinese flags.

Policeman William Clark of the West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street Station, who was held in default of $1,000 ball on Monday, charged with brutal treatment of his three-year-old son Thomas, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by jumping off Washington Bridge.

ST. LOUIS, April 29. -- On the eve of the three days celebration, which will jointly commemorate the Louisiana Purchase and mark the dedication of the exposition to be opened here a year from now, this city is not overwhelmed by a multitude of visitors or laboring under any great strain of excitement.
ST. LOUIS, April 29. -- President Roosevelt, after a day spent in Iowa, Illinois, and Missouri, arrived here this afternoon to participate in the dedication ceremonies of the World's Fair.

Cornelius O'Reilly, a well-known architect and builder, who was the Chairman of the Building Committee of Grant's Tomb, was killed yesterday by a fall at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes which he was erecting at One Hundred and Forty-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BOSTON, April 29. -- Seven Boston Italians called at Police Headquarters to-day to beg for protection against the Mafia, by which they said they had been ordered to contribute to the defense fund in the New York barrel murder case. Inspectors have been sent to the Italian quarter to make investigations.
