With new colors up, Julia M., recognized as one of the smartest of the two-year-old fillies that showed at the Aqueduct meeting, improved so much on her earlier form yesterday that at the Jamaica track she won the Rosedale Stakes actually in a romp from a fairly good field of two-year-olds.
The Mutual Reserve Life Insurance Company has been licensed as an old-line life insurance company in the State of Nebraska.
BUFFALO, April 29. -- An official dispatch from the Canadian Pacific Railway says that the latest reports from Frank, N.W.T., via MacLeod, N.W.T., are as follows:
According to Boston dispatches the First National Bank of Worcester, Mass., has reduced its surplus from $200,000 to $100,000 and cut its annual dividend from 10 to 6 per cent.

Members of the Automobile Club of America who are dissatisfied with the action of President A.R. Shattuck in accepting on behalf of the organization the Doughty-Bailey bill and who have forced the calling of a special meeting of the club for Saturday night to bring the matter to a decision, followed up their action yesterday by sending out a letter to every member of the club requesting him to attend the meeting on Saturday night.
LONDON, April 29. -- Money was much wanted to-day the market being affected by, the approach, of the month-end. Discounts were fairly easy.

VANCOUVER, B.C., April 29. -- Probably ninety-five persons are dead as a result of a mysterious explosion which tore off the top of Turtle Mountain, overlooking the little town of Frank, in the Province of Alberta, early this morning. Great masses of rock were hurled down into the valley of the Old Man's Creek, sweeping away the works at the coal mines on the side of the mountain and demolishing houses in the town below.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- There was a little more animation in the local market to-day and a fair show of strength. The Lake Superior issues were prominent in both departments. The common made a net gain of 5/8, while the preferred advanced 1 1/2 points on the improved condition of the company's prospects.

The unanimous decision of the New York State Court of Appeals, on what would appear to be perfectly logical and incontestable grounds, that the eight-hour law as applied to public and municipal work is unconstitutional, is not unexpected. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court which reversed Judge BEATTIE and affirmed the constitutionality of the law based its conclusions upon grounds not commending themselves to the approval of intelligent laymen, at least.

-- Commissioner GREENE has shown a surprising -- and somewhat disappointing -- inclination to "call off" his energetic subordinate who was worrying the merchants about keeping clear the sidewalks before their places of business, but he has promptly antagonized their suggestion that the police be empowered to use their discretion as to issuing licenses to turn the sidewalks into private storage warehouses.

BOSTON, April 29. -- The money market remains easy, but the demand is less active. Call Joans, 3 1/2@4 1/2 per cent; time loans on collateral, 4 3/4 @5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 3/4@5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount @ par. Clearings, $22,828,319; balances, $1,785,508.

About three hundred representatives of various charitable movements and others interested in such work, including a special committee appointed by Mayor Low, will leave the city Monday to attend the National Conference of Charities and Correction to be held at Atlanta, Ga., from May 6 to 12, inclusive.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 29. -- After having been formally placed in commission here this afternoon, the Reliance was taken put for another trial spin, and during the two hours of sailing she was brought into conditions, of winds and sea which gave her the most severe test she has yet had.

LONDON, April 29. -- Rock Sand, ridden by J.H. ("Skeets") Martin, American Jockey, won the Two Thousand Guineas' Stakes (for three-year-olds, one mile) at the Newmarket first Spring meeting today. Flotsam, with "Danny Maher up, was second, and Rabelais third. Eleven horses started.
ROME, April 29. -- King Edward to-day visited the Pope at the Vatican. The interview between his Majesty and the Pontifs was a private one, and lasted twenty minutes.

Though the stock market was dull yesterday and again largely under professional control. It was strong from beginning to end, with almost every active stock on the list showing an advance (some of the gains being not unsubstantial) at the close of the day. There were several reasons for this reversal of market form and the very much better tone showing.

Daniel Nason, until recently a law partner of District Attorney Jerome, admitted on the stand at the Amory-Vreeland hearing yesterday that he called on William N. Amory last month, and, after representing himself as an agent from William H. Page, Jr., of counsel for the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, offered to buy Amory's stock in a bicycle patent for from $75,000 to $200,000.

The Board of Aldermen has laid over for a week the consideration of the ordinance requiring all dogs running at large in the streets of New York to be muzzled. The object of this postponement is probably to afford the dogs affected by the ordinance an opportunity to be heard for or against it "as their interests may appear."

FORT MONROE, Va., April 29. -- The thirty-fifth anniversary of the Hampton Normel and Agricultural Institute, the parent and the second largest institute of the ininstitutions devoted to the material advancemen of the negro of the Southern States, took place here to-day, and was taken part in by the most representative and distinguished gathering of educators and scholars ever assembled within the grounds.

Someone suggested not so very long ago the value that might accrue to the modern theatre by an application of hypnotic influence to the players engaged. It was pointed out that by means of psychic suggestion or some other equally vague scientific process actors and actresses possessed of only ordinary ability might be made to shine in the limelight with the refulgent brilliancy of a Bernhardt, a Duse, or a Salvlni.

Perez M. Stewart, Superintendent of Buildings in the Borough of Manhattan, was peremptorily removed from office yesterday by Borough President Cantor. No charges were preferred against Mr. Stewart, and he asserts that his removal was for political reasons. Up to two days ago, he says, Mr. Cantor declared to him personally that he was satisfied with his official course.

The Directors of the Van Norden Trust Company and some of the stockholders of the Eastern Trust Company are in a contest over a proposition made by the Van Norden Trust Company under which that company hopes to purchase the Eastern Trust Company.

Two teams from the Squadron A polo Club played a lively game, although the score appears somewhat one-sided, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The team called the "Whites defeated the quartet designated as the Blues by 5 goals to 0. The contest, however, was a decidedly well-played match, and the defeated side lost two or three excellent chances to score by the narrowest margins.

We have several times had occasion to make our compliments, together with our expostulations, to the "live man" in the management of the Manhattan Elevated Railway. Time was, and that not so long ago, when the Manhattan relied entirely upon the fact that its aerial right of way enabled it to make better time than the surface roads could make, with their continual liability to kill passengers at grade crossings.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Post Office investigation is bearing fruit in dismissals and transfers, but only among what may be called minor offenders.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Senator Allee of Delaware is in Washington, attending to the arrears of public matters pertaining to his State which have accumulated during the protracted interim of the Addicks-Du Pont deadlock.

LONDON, April 29. -- The sensation caused in British yachting circles by the announcement that Ratsey Lapthorn, the English sailmakers, who have an establishment at City Island, N.Y., have been given orders for suits of sails for the Reliance, the Constitution, and the Columbia, can be best judged by an editorial article which appears in The Yachting World of April 30 under the heading, "An International (?) Contest."

Although the marine engineers are liable to revocation of their licenses under the Federal law if they fail to observe the terms under which they have been granted, there was a general impression yesterday that the threatened tie-up of the shipping in this harbor would go into effect tomorrow.

LONDON, April 30. -- The shipping agreement between the International Mercantile Marine Company and the British Government has been finally and satisfactorily concluded on the lines previously announced.

Fire destroyed the interior of the Salvation Army hotel at 81 Bowery yesterday afternoon. The damage was estimated at $3,000. The greatest loss was to the stock of H. Linetsky Son, paper warehouse. No one was in the lodging house when the fire started, as the rooms were being fumigated according to the rules of the Board of Health.

This will be a gala day for baseball in Manhattan, and all roads will lead to the new grounds, which from now on will be known as American Leagues Park, on Washington Heights. The American Base ball League has bent all its energies during the last twelve months to locate a playing club in this city, and this afternoon will see the realization of President Ban Johnson's oft-repeated promises.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Russia's part in what has come to be known as the Manchurian incident was explained this evening by Count Cassini, the Russian Ambassador, to a representative of the Associated Press, and, because of the conflicting reports which have come to Washington regarding the Russian-Chinese negotiations at Peking, Count Cassini has consented to the publication of the interview.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Queen Wilhelmina has notified the United States Government that she has appointed Dr. Charles Augustinius Henri Barge to act as umpire in the arbitration between the United States and Venezuela at Caracas of American claims. Dr. Barge formerly was the Dutch Governor of Curacao.

Disinterested men and fair-minded economists will no longer deny that what we have now come to call the special franchises of corporations are a fair subject of taxation. In affirming the validity of the law imposing this tax the Court of Appeals, therefore, has not merely sustained an act of the Legislature, but has put itself in accord with public opinion.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- In recognition of "positive and unquestionable services which he has given to Venezuela during the conflict with the allies," the Congress of Venezuela voted to Mr. Bowen, who is now acting as the republic's plenipotentiary at Washington, the Cross of the Legion of the National Defence.
Capt. Odus C. Horney, Ordnance Department, will proceeed to Washington, Providence, and Hartford on official business pertaining to the manufacture of seacoast guns.

ROME, April 29. -- King Edward this morning reviewed 25,000 Italian troops assembled on the parade ground. It was an imposing spectacle and splendid weather contributed to the brilliancy of the scene.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Four new detention stations for Chairmen will soon be opened on the Canadian border. One of them at Malone, N.Y., will be opened within ten days. The others will be located at Burlington, Vt.; Portal, N.D., and Sumas, Washington.

Apart from an advance of about two points in Northern Securities, yesterday's market for outside securities presented very little of special interest. The general position of the market as compared with the previous day was somewhat improved, most of the changes being on the side of gains. In few cases, however, was the trading on any large scale.

LONDON, April 30. -- A correspondent of The Times, wiring from Uskub, says that M. Mashkoff, the Russian Consul who has succeeded the late M. Stcherbina, is convinced that he will not leave Albania alive.
Stocks strong. Money easy, 2@2 3/4 per cent.

Henry S. Thompson, the new Superintendent of Buildings, took possession of the bureau's offices, at Eighteenth Street and Fourth Avenue, shortly after noon yesterday. He was escorted through the bureau by Percy M. Stevrart, his deposed predecessor, who introduced him to the several heads of departments.

ST. LOUIS, April 30. -- Fifty thousand persons were in the great auditorium of the Liberal Arts Building when the Presidential party entered at 2:15 o'clock and made their way to the platform with difficulty. The President was heartily cheered as he entered and when he ascended to his seat.

A runaway pony, the property of an Italian priest, excited after a long run through Central Park and several streets, and frightened by a crowd of boys that tried to follow him, ran up the steps, through the doorway, and tried to ascend the stairs in the flat building at 164 East Seventy-eighth Street just before the dinner hour on Wednesday evening.

In the presence of a magnificent audience of Americans and of the representatives of many friendly nations President ROOSEVELT yesterday made the dedicatory address in the Liberal Arts Building of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition at St. Louis. Appropriately, these ceremonies marked the centenary of the signing of the treaty which transferred the State of Louisiana and the Great West beyond the Mississippi to the United States.

Talbot J. Taylor was on the witness Stand for two hours at the Amory-Vreeland hearing yesterday. After he was released, having undergone sharp questioning at the hands of James W. Osborne and De Lancey Nicoll, the two lawyers summed up the case, and then Magistrate Barlow announced that he would render his decision to-morrow at noon in the Tombs Court.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- A high official of the Post Office Department is authority for the statement that unless Superintendent of Free Delivery Machen resigns before President Roosevelt's return from the West the President will remove him.
MARSEILLES, April 30. -- The American warships here were in gala attire early to-day, awaiting the coining of President Loubet and the French fleet, which left Blserta, Tunis, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The State Department has received a cablegram, dated yesterday, from Consul General McWade at Canton stating that a mob of anti-foreign Chinese made an attack at Yuan-Tan on a party of American engineers. Mr. McWade appealed to Lieut. Anderson, commanding the gunboat Callao, lying in the stream, and the gunboat went immediately to the rescue. The Consul General meanwhile lodged a formal complaint with the Chinese officials.

George F. Baer, President of the Reading Company, and Eben B. Thomas, President of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, were on the witness stand at yesterday's session of the Inter-State Commerce Commission's hearing on the complaint of William R. Hearst. The full commission, Messrs, Prouty, Clements, Knapp, Yeamans, and Fifer, was in attendance.
All liquor certificates for 1902-3 expired last midnight.
LONDON, April 30. -- Money was in good demand in market to-day, this being Stock Exchange pay day. Discounts were fairly, maintained.

The executive branch of the Citizens' Union's City Committee, at a meeting held at 32 Liberty Street yesterday afternoon, decided to hold a conference on the local political situation at Citizens' Union headquarters, 34 Union Square, on the evening of Monday, May 11.

Opponents of the Doughty-Bailey bill to regulate the speed of automobiles within this State made substantial progress with their plans yesterday. "This bill," said a prominent member of the Automobile Club yesterday." on account of the manner in which it is forcing the automobilists to get together and work for its defeat is almost worth all the trouble it is causing.

FRANK, Northwest Territory, April 30. -- It is definitely known that fifty-six people lost their lives here before daybreak Wednesday by the sliding of the rocky top of Turtle Mountain down upon the sleeping village of Frank.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 30. -- Flour and grain rates from Chicago and Minneapolis to the Atlantic seaboard were reduced 2 cents per 100 pounds to-day. The agreement was reached at a meeting held here of traffic officials of the Central Freight Association lines, the Chicago-St. Paul lines, and the lake lines operated in conjunction with the railroads.

It was still-almost dark early yesterday morning when three employes of Holy Name Cemetery, Jersey City, set out to dig a grave that was needed for a funeral at 10 o'clock. As they passed one of the vaults they heard a voice inside. It plaintively pleaded: "Let me, out! Let me out!"

Prof. Bailey or Tale, who discusses the problems of American sociology with the divinity students known as "Seminoles," and likewise instructs the senior class in American social conditions, headed forty Yale men who came to New York yesterday, to have practical illustration of city life as he had described it.

When the market is artificial -- as this market long was -- it is a very simple matter to operate in it. All that is necessary is to form an opinion; or even a mere resolution, which party to join, and then go with the current to good or bad fortune. That is a very much easier matter than to form an idea about values.

LONDON, May 1. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times says a telegram from the American China Development Company at Canton reports that a party of five American and five Japanese engineers engaged in the construction of the Canton -- Han-Kow Railway was attacked by a mob at Yuan-Tan, sixty miles from Canton, on the North River.

Whitehouse Porter have sold for Gamaliel C. St. John, executor of the esates of Wallace C. Andrews and Margaret M. St. John, 854 Fifth Avenue, between Sixty-Sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets, a four-story stone-front dwelling on lot 30.5 by 120. The price paid for the property is reported at $325,000.

Only five of the eight baseball games on the schedules of the two major leagues were played yesterday, the others being postponed on account of rain or wet grounds. The adverse weather conditions were experienced in Cincinnati, Cleveland, and Chicago, while along the eastern circuit summerlike weather prevailed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- At a special meeting to-day of the Board of Directors of the William Cramp Ship and Engine Building Company the following voting trustees were elected: E.T. Stotesbury of Drexel Co.; Richard H. Rushton, President of the Fourth Street National Bank of this city, and G.F. Baker, President of the First National Bank, New York.

NEW ORLEANS, April 30. -- A cablegram from Bluefields, Nicaragua, received yesterday by the Bluefields Steamship Company, told of another big fire that visited that prosperous tropical seaport on Tuesday last. It has only been three years since the centre of the town was destroyed by a terrific fire, and judging from the localities visited by this last destructive flame, the present fire is as extensive as the previous one.
LONDON, May 1. -- "Dante," by Victorien Sardou and Emile Moreau, was produced by Sir Henry Irving at the Drury Lane Theatre last evening. The Times's critic says of the performance:

Alfred Huidekoper Bond, President of the Calumet Club, and Charles Shepard Bryan, Secretary, were entertained at dinner last evening in the new private dining room of the clubhouse by twenty-two of the members. In the room, which is upholstered in dark red, is a full-length portrait of exPresident George Brown, painted recently by Miss Ethel Wright, an English artist.

BRADFORD, Penn., April 30. -- The worst forest fires in the History of this section of Pennsylvania are raging to-night, and $1,000,000 worth of property has been destroyed. The forests have been ablaze for the past week, but the fires were kept under control by large gangs of men until this morning, when a stiff southeast gale sprang up and fanned smoldering embers into a roaring mass of flames.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Pennsylvania Railroad stock was sold down to-day on the report that the dividend may be reduced, owing to the increased cost of oper ation. Directors of the company said the dividend had not yet been considered, but that it would be at their meeting to-morrow.

There was a distinctly salty flavor to the Military Show in Madison Square Garden last night. It was the first real naval night of the tournament. Rear Admiral Frederick Rodgers. United States Navy, was the reviewing officer. He was escorted into the arena through the Madison Avenue entrance by sailors and marines from the Brooklyn Navy Yard and Naval Militia.

LONDON, April 30. -- At a meeting of the Directors of Charles T. Yerkes's railroads this afternoon the names of James Speyer, Thomas Jefferson Coolidge, J.A. Blair, Leonard F. Loree, Richard A. McCurdy, and James H. Hyde were added to the Directorate.

For some time to come rumors affecting the condition and prospects of the International Mercantile Marine which reach this country from British sources may be taken with such additions of salt as may be needed to enable them to reach us in good merchantable condition.

BOSTON, April 30. -- The money market continues easy. There is a plentiful supply of funds, but hardly any demand. Call money is particularly easy, and a strong borrower almost can make his own rate. Call loans. 3@4 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2@ 4 3/4@5 per cent.: time loans on mercantile paper, 4 3/4@5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; clearings, $22,423,634; balances, $1.136,635.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Reginald c. Vanderbilt returned to-day from their wedding trip, coming by way of Boston from Canada. They went to Sandy Point Farm and will occupy four rooms in the new house which has been finished for the use of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt at this time.

Eleven trained nurses were graduated last evening from St. Mark's Hospital Training School. The graduates and many of their friends were affected so much by the exercises that, they wept. Dr. C.A. Von Ramdohr presided, and Dr. Carl Beck, President of the hospital: Dr. J.M. Rottenberg, and Maximilian H. Ruttenau delivered addresses.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Confidence born of home grounds and a friendly crowd inspired the Phillies to a victory to-day. It was a pleasant and welcome home-coming that almost 3,000 devotees of the sport gave Manager Zimmer, Capt. Thomas, and other players, and a victory under the circumstances was exceptionally gratifying.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 30. -- In the second game in the series for the Herbert trophies, the Lakewood first team, composed of George J. Gould, his sons, Kingdon and Jay, and the veteran Ben Nicoll, won an easy victory over the Rockaway Club team on the Georgian Court grounds this afternoon.

LONDON, April 30. -- At the night session of the London Diocesan Conference yesterday the Bishop of London, the Right Rev. Arthur F. Ingram, made a statement to the effect that he had thrice sent for an explanation from the Rev. Mr. Hadden regarding the Vanderbilt-Rutherfurd wedding, and that none hart been received.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- The one redeeming feature of the market to-day was the strength of the Lake Superior shares, especially the preferred, which advanced 1 3/4 points. The buying was largely for New York, and while the orders appeared to be scattered, it was learned that they had been placed by a large New York house through its local branch.
LONDON, May 1. -- The Sofia correspondent of The Times says the fighting continues on the right bank of the River Struma, where the revolutionary bands have been joined by local Macedonians.

Mayor Low yesterday vetoed the twoplatoon bill for the Fire Department that was approved by a large number of members of the force who believed that, by arranging the hours of work so that they would work fourteen hours one week and ten hours the next, the city's fire service would be improved.

-- Just as in the case of the disaster at St. Pierre, the first reports from the little mining town in British Columbia that has been through such a terrible experience illustrate the fact that the testimony of terrified and excited eye-witnesses of a natural convulsion is almost worthless as a means of arriving at an exact idea of what happened.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- A sullen mob of 3,000 men, women, and girls waited all day around the McCormick harvesting machine plant in expectation of being able to stampede the 6,500 employes there. When the employes left work they were approached in a friendly way by the waiting crowd, many of whom went home with the workers, arguing and trying to convince them that they ought to strike.
Major Benjamin H. Cheever, Sixth Cavalry, will report for assignment to duty in the Department of Dakota, pending the arrival therein of his regiment.

It is to be regretted that the Mayor deemed it consistent with his public duty to interfere to prevent the carrying out of the plans of Deputy Police Commissioner PIPER to enforce sensibly and impartially the ordinances forbidding the obstruction and incumbrance of sidewalks for private and business advantage.

ST. LOUIS, April 30. -- In a loosely played game here to-day the Pittsburg team defeated St. Louts by a score of 13 to 4. Brown, who pitched for the locals, was knocked out of the box in the sixth inning. Rhoades, who succeeded him, did well, but the game was lost before his entry. Phillippi, who pitched for the Pittsburgs, played a good game.

Walter J. Travis, twice National golf champion and the victor of both of the big Northern tournaments this season, Lakewood and Atlantic City, was defeated yesterday in the first match play round of the Garden City tournament. It is the first time that Travis has ever been beaten in a big match on his home links.

The Grand Jury yesterday returned three indictments for manslaughter in the second degree in connection with the death of Leonard F. Roos, a wealthy Fifth Avenue art dealer. Mr. Roos died at his residence, 146 East Forty-seventh Street, on Nov. 26 last year.

Much irregularity was displayed in yesterday's market for outside securities, but except in a few stocks the transactions were very small. Northern Securities and several other representative issues which the previous day had been quite strong showed a reactionary tendency, and from these stocks the market in large part took its character.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- It is now established beyond a doubt that E.M. Simonds of New York, who died here in the County Hospital Tuesday, was the man who was assaulted by two others at 2:30 o'clock Tuesday morning on Clark Street. The police have the stories of several persons whose close descriptions of the man they saw assaulted fit that of Mr. Simonds exactly.

It was learned, yesterday that Mrs. Augusta Harper Lyride of 200 West Fifty-sixth Street, the aged and wealthy widow who has been missing since last Tuesday evening, disappeared from the Erie Railroad ferryboat Chautauqua at about 7:45 o'clock on that same evening while, the boat was on its way from the Jersey City Station to the slip at West Twenty-third Street, this borough.

One cares less for the love story of Mr. Bacheller's new novel, for the heroine and for the hero than he does for the teaching of the clock-tinker and philosopher, whose inspiration and solace were alike found in the Blessed Isles of literature. The plot is original and ingenious. Jack-in-the-box-like introductions of the boy Garfield and the actor Forrest, however, are too obviously galvanic to add anything to the verisimilltude of the story.

Yesterday's sales aggregated 222,282 shares, making the record, with which dull days hereafter, this year must be compared. Among contributory causes was the fact that London makes a holiday of May Day, and doubtless if yesterday's idleness could have been foreseen those discommoded by trying to move and do business simultaneously would have been in such a majority that a holiday would have been ordered here also.

CINCINNATI, May 1. -- In the suit of the Keene interests to enjoin the Harriman interests from voting the stock held by the Union Pacific Company at the postponed annual meeting of the Southern Pacific Company, the appeal papers were filed today in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

W.C. BROWNELL, who probably more than any other Amercian critic receives serious attention abroad, has written an article on Saintsbury's monumental work, "The History of Criticism," which appears in the May number of The Lamp.

So many books on golf have been issued in America since the royal Scotch game became popular here that the novice as well as the expert player is apt to look askance at any addition to the literature of the game. Playing golf by a book is one of the absurdities which the beginner is often cautioned to avoid.
MR.E PHILLIPS OPPENHEIM'S " The Traitors" is to have a companion this season in " a Prince of Sinners." a novel form his pen, added at the last moment to the Spring list of Messers. Little. Brown Co.

Stan. V. Henkels will hold In Davis Harvey's auction rooms, Philadelphia, May 8 9 a sale of great historical interest. The first 209 lots comprise original manuscripts and documents, the finest collection of material relating to Colonial Pennsylvania ever offered at public sale. These papers were collected by Caleb Pusey, David Lloyd, Isaac Norris, John Klnsey, Samuel Smith, and Robert Proud for the purpose of compiling a history of Pennsylvania.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 1. -- E.C. Bradley, Second Vice President of the Postal Telegraph Company, who is a resident of this place, says that on July 4, in connection with the opening of the new cable to the insular possessions of the United States, an effort, which now gives promise of success, will be made to circle the globe in forty seconds.

BOSTON, May 1. -- The money market remains quiet and easy. Call loans, 3@4 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 3/4@ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 4 per cent.; New York funds, 8@10c discount; clearings, $25,042,459; balances, $1,935,497. The foreign exchange market is firm.

BALTIMORE, May 1 -- Something of a stir was caused in stock brokers' circles here to-day by the Merchants' National Bank, which adopted a sliding schedule to govern margins to be exacted from brokers. The action will increase the margins 5 to 10 per cent Formerly the prevailing margins were about 10 per cent, of the market price, and special arrangements often were made by mutual agreement between the broker and the bank.

M. Rene Bazin, with whose work the readers of this REVIEW have already been made acquainted, has produced another of his remarkable pictures of life among the French, pictures so intimate and revealing that they give even to a foreigner the sense of having sympathetically watched and almost shared that life.

Studies of people to whom the world and the fates have not been kind, these sketches are in a minor key, but there is about them little trace of the maudlin so hard to avoid in tales of woe. Instead the reader will find much, if not very cheerful, truth and a manner of presentation not without charm.

A powerful book, with a simple but effective plot. The scene is a remarkable religious colony, and the publishers state in a preliminary note that while, "for obvious reasons the real name of the community described herein is withheld," the scenes are "pictured with almost photographic fidelity, and the life portrayed is the life actually led to-day by a religious co-operative community in a Western State."

MR. BURTON is one of the minor poets whose best verse suggests a standard of taste and performance exacting enough to make his renders rebel when he fails to upheld it. In his present volume both message and melody are somewhat faltering.

"One Religion: Many Creeds," by Ross Wynans, will shortly be published by G. P. Putnam's Sons. This Is a. series of papers which the author wrote years ago abroad, without any idea of publishing them. He gathered his material from various sources and writers. What the author presents in his book he desires to be viewed and considered as an inquiry on behalf of truth."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Wheelock's note relating the genesis of Dr. Cox's continuation of Dumas's "The Count of Monte Cristo," that is, "Monte Cristo's Son" and "Daughter," tells only part of the story, more or less interesting generally, but all confusing to the book trade.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I WAS very glad to read in the March Atlantic Mr. John Burrougha's article exposing the "yarns" and the yarn-like character of the books on wild animals of two of our prominent writers on the subject.

PARIS, May 1 -- King Edward arrived here at 3 o'clock this afternoon and re- ceived a hearty welcome. His Majesty's reception at the Dauphine Railroad Station by President Loubet and the chief officers of state and his drive through the avenues the Bols de Boulogne and the Champs Eiysees presented a continuous succession of brilliant spectacles.

In arguing for a writ of habeas corpus before Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, counsel for Lewis Reeves brought up the issue as to whether or not a State can deprive an accused citizen of his constitutional right of trial by jury. Reeves was tried before Judges Mayer, McKeon, and Wyatt in the Court of Special Sessions on the charge of practicing medicine without a license.

Lake Ontario, during the war of 1812, was a very garden spot of rest compared to Lake Erie and others further west. That it was not wholly barren of incidents and dangers is recalled by this novel. "The Trail of the Grand Selgneur," the maiden effort of one born and brought up on its shores.

PLATTSBURG, May 1. -- A heavy snowstorm set in over the Adirondacks early today, about three inches falling in some places, and checked the firce forest fires that have spread rapidly in the last week. The snow came just in the nick of time. The temperature has dropped about 50 degrees.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 1. -- President Roosevelt spent five hours in Kansas City, Mo., to-day, and then was the guest of Kansas City, Kan., just across the State line, for two hours before he left for Topeka at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. The Presidential party arrived in Kansas City, Mo., from St. Louis at 9:10 in the morning, and was met by a reception committee.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: If not for the sake of the general, public, at least for the critic who reads the books he reviews and the author who wishes him to persist in such a habit, one may be pardoned, let us hope, for taking up the cudgel against two tendencies in current fiction.

THOSE who like to speculate about music in a metaphysical and transcendental sense, to imagine all the various universal significances and symbolisms it may have, will find plenty of food for thought in Mr. Edwards's volume.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have a dim recollection that during the recent agitation for better car service the officers of the transportation companies stated that they were doing everything possible to improve existing conditions, were moving all the cars they could move,

The meetings of the Executive and General Committees of Tammany Hall last night were as eventful as any in the history of the organization. ADDRESS TO THE PEOPLE. Loud calls for Senator Grady were repeated, and he handed in the following address to the people, which vras read by Sir. Smith:

ST. LOUIS, May 1 -- After the first day of parade and pomp the Louisiana Purchase celebration has resolved itself Into a very humdrum affair. The lack of popular interest in the ceremonies is the most astonishing feature of the whole affair. The crowds turn out to witness the parades and the fireworks, but for the less spectacular events they do not seem to care.

MILWAUKEE, May 1. -- According to announcements made here to-day, Milwaukee is soon to rival Pittsburg as a centre of great engine-building establishments. The Allis-Chalmers Company and the Christensen Engineering Company have practically decided to double the size of their great works.

LONDON, April 17. -- Perhaps nothing has attracted more attention during the last week than the announcement that The London Times has instituted a "competition." It was the last thing the public expected.

LONDON, May 1. -- Eighty-seven members of the London Stock Exchange started this morning from Westminster Bridge on a competitive May Day walk to the Brighton Aquarium. E.F. Broad won, covering the distance in 9:30:01. Great interest had been excited in this contest, for which the competing members had been training for weeks past.

James Wells Champney, the artist, was killed yesterday morning by falling down an elevator shaft at 5 Thirty-first Street. Mr. Champney left his home and studio, 96 Fifth Avenue, shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning, saying that he was going to the Camera Club to develop two plates and that he would be home for luncheon.

The latest volume of the Cambridge Edition of the Poets, edited by Hlisa Perry, (Houghton, Mifflin, $2.) contains "The Complete Poetical Works of Alexander Pope," as well as an explanatory preface by H.W. Boynton, a biographical sketch by the same writer, (who is editor of this Pope.) and a copious appendix.
Capt. Charles P. Hardin, Eighteenth Infantry, is detailed as Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the Oregon Agricultural College, Cor- vallis, Ore.

Tomasso Petto -- "El Bove" (The Ox) his countrymen call him because of his powerful physique-accused of the murder of Benedetto Madonia, whose body was found in a barrel in East Eleventh Street early on the morning of April 14, sat sullenly during the first session yesterday of the Coroner's jury that is seeking to determine the responsibility for the crime.

To the busy worker eager for monetary success the acquisition of a million dollars would hardly become a burden within a day after its receipt. If a testy grandfather for whom one felt unbounded esteem and respect, but little warmth of affection, should die and bequeath to one a paltry million in atonement for the disinheritance of one's father, one couldn't help but feel a glow at the heart.

By the widespread adoption of methods of conciliation and by mutual concessions, the dreaded "May Day" passed with far less labor dissension than had been expected. Nevertheless, several serious demonstrations took place, and there were numerous strikes in various branches of industry throughout this city and near-by towns.

THE name of the late John Wesley Powell will always be associated with the canyons of the Colorado River, and Mr. George Wharton James dedicates his volume "In and Around the Grand Canyon" to the man of science who was for twenty years at the head of the United States Bureau of Ethnology.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Extracts from the report of Father E.J. Vattmann, Chaplain of the Twenty-ninth United States Infantry, to the Catholic Bishops' Assembly, in annual convention here last week, on the status of the Catholic Church in the Philippines, were made public to-day. Father Vattmann, with the knowledge and consent of the War Department and under direction of the Church authorities, recently made a careful investigation of Catholic interests in the archipelago.

The remarkable popular welcome accorded to ex-President CLEVELAND wherever he goes is one of the most deeply interesting and suggestive signs of these present times. It is natural that a justminded people should admire a man of Mr. CLEVELAND'S character and achievements; it is to be expected that a warmhearted people should make a generous showing of their esteem and affection for a statesman who has twice filled the Presidential office.

While the concluding rounds of the Garden City golf tournament will be the leading feature in local golf circles to-day, there will be a number of important club matches. The Apawamis course at Rye and the Fox Hills links at Garden City will be formally opened for the competitive season. The event at Fox Hills will be a kickers handicap for a cup presented by George E. Armstrong.

LAST week we printed on this page, for the enlightenment and edification of our readers, some expressions of thought from the works of the great English philosopher, Mr. Herbert Spencer. This week it is both our duty and our pleasure to set forth, in a like manner, some expressions of thought from the writings of a philosopher of American origin and renown, Mr. George Ade:

When Major Gen. Adna R. Chaffee, commanding the Department of the East of the United States Army, marched into Madison Square Garden last night to act as reviewing officer at the Military Show he was greeted by a crowd which packed the spacious amphitheatre from arena to gallery and was easily the largest assemblage of the week.

SOLINGEN, Rhenish Prussia, May 1. -- United States Consul Joseph J. Landger was fined $7.50 to-day by the Judge of a local court for disorderly conduct in the court room, where he was present as a witness. Mr. Landger was afterward sentenced to one day's arrest for continued disorderly behavior.

"The Teaching of English in the Elementary and the Secondary School" is the title of a new volume in the American Teachers' Series, edited by James E. Russell of Columbia University, which Longmans, Green Co. will issue in a few days. The book is the work of Profs. George R. Carpenter and Franklin T. Baker of Columbia University and Prof. Fred N. Scott of the University of Michigan.

To Thomas Nuttall, who was the Curator of the Botanical Gardens of Harvard University in 1822, is due the credit of having first studied the birds of the United States and to have written most intelligently concerning them. "A Popular Handbook of the Birds of the United States and Canada," (1832-4,) has more than any other publication, directed attention in this country to ornithology.

Prof. John Edgar McFadyen's work on "Old Testament Criticism and the Christian Church" will appear on May 16 with the imprint of Charles Scribner's Sons. The volume, says the author in his preface, has been written to aid the man who "honestly desires a dispassionate presentation of what Old Testament criticism is and does, of how it works, and what its bearings are upon vital elements in the Christian faith."

THE second and concluding volume of Prof. Leo Wiener's Anthology of Russian Literature has been issued. It deals exclusively with the Russian writers of the nineteenth century, that is, with that portion of Russian literature the English-speaking world in general is alone famillier with and appreciative of.

One would have said beforehand that every American magazine for May, this year, would be sure to contain an article on Emerson, that every editor would long have been carrying it on his list of "agenda," with a query as to "who was the best man to do it." To our surprise it turns out not so.

IN "Viel Umworben" Freiherr von Schlicht has blended love, humor, and common sense -- surely an uncommon and at tractive mixture, (It must be the humor which makes the blending possible.) The result is a very readable novel and one which it is a pleasure to recommend to those who want a story which is a story, not a veiled sermon on the virtue of being strenuous or the vice of being degenerate.

Peter Newell's painting of Diedrich Knickerbocker, reproduced in colors as frontispiece of The New Metropolitan for May, is full of character and satisfies one's ideal of that illustrious chronicier. Inquisitiveness, zeal, moderation, self-respect, determination, and a sense of both proportion and humor are written on that ample, interesting countenance.

Sometimes one finds among the new novels a book that really commands attention and holds the reader breathlessly to the end; sometimes a trick of writing, a delicacy of expression, an artistic finish, or some other merit lifts the story above the commonplace -- but In "Barbara, a Woman of the West," one looks in vain for the redeeming feature which covers the general Insipidity of the story.

ST. LOUIS, May 1. -- Much quieter than "Dedication Day" was "International Day" at the Exposition. The programme to-day was carried out as originally planned, but there were numerous delays that brought the conclusion of the exercises about three hours later than was originally intended.

An ingenious official in Washington, whose gainful occupation is that of Assistant Secretary to the District Commission, and who by way of recreation and amusement is a student of the statistics and causation of suicide, has reached the interesuing conclusion that many cases of self-destruction are due to eating strawberries out of season.
MADISON, Wis., May 1. -- The joint resolution looking to the election of United States Senators by direct vote was killed in the Assembly to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The remnant, of society left in Washington took itself en masse to the Chevy Chase Club this afternoon, where the second annual horse show opened its two days' meeting. The order excluding automobiles from the grounds resulted in many patrons taking seats on the grand stand, which was a new feature this year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1. -- The will of Warren B. Smith, the millionaire carpet manufacturer of Yonkers, who died in Algiers, was filed at noon to-day in the Surrogate's Court at this place. The estate is estimated to be worth $40,000,000. The will was executed March 5, 1902, and the executors are Eva S. Cochran, a sister; Alexander Cochran, a nephew, and Harold Bond, who was confidential secretary to the testator.

LONDON, May 1. -- Messrs. Longmans, Green Co. will shortly publish "Travels in Southern Europe and the Levant During the Early Part of the Nineteenth Century." The author is Charles Cockerell, the architect, a friend of Lord Byron, who helped to discover the Aegina marbles which are now at Munich.

American advance would have been wanting in one of its most important factors had its ways and methods of cooking not kept pace with the general progress. The world can no longer say there is no good cup of coffee to be had outside of Paris. If Marseilles has her bouillabaise, Nantucket has her clam chowder, Boston her baked beans, Philadelphia her planked shad, New Orleans her gumbo, and Baltimore her stewed terrapin.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- General strength was developed in this market today, but trading was intensely dull, the sales amounting to only 15,048 shares and $54,500 bonds. Net advances were largely fractional, but Consolidated Lake Superior preferred and Fairmount Park Transportation were exceptions.

The 1st of May is no longer moving day. The real estate agents have destroyed that ancient custom, now that nearly all new leases begin in October. So yesterday there was nothing to tell at the real estate offices of wholesale migrations, with bag, baggage, and household furniture.

"The Poultry Book," by Harrison Weir, F. R. H. S., which in England will be published by Hutchinson Co., will begin to appear in this country on May 15 with the imprint of Doubleday Page Co. The American edition is edited by Prof. Willis Grant Johnson, assisted by George O. Brown and a number of other American experts.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 1. -- President Roosevelt made two addresses in Topeka tonight, one at the laying of the cornerstone of the new Railroad Young Men's Christian Association building and the other at the Auditorium before the International Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association.

In a somewhat unusual way the fact became known yesterday that Wilson Royal Crosby, son of Chauncey H. Crosby, Vice President and General Manager of the United States Express Company, of which Thomas C. Platt is the President, and Miss Dorothy Jane McCormack have been married since March 1.

The executive branch of the City Committee of the Citizens' Union, in session at 32 Liberty Street yesterday afternoon, decided to invite to the conference to be held at the headquarters of the Union, 34 Union Square, East, on May 11, representatives of the Republican County Committees in the Greater New York, the German American Reform Union, and the Greater New York Democracy.

NEWPORT, May 1. -- Reginald C. Vanderbilt has had a special telephone line built connecting his Sandy Point Farm with the Newport City service. This line required the placing of half or three quarters of a mile of poles and wires from the east main road, which are used exclusively by Mr. Vanderbilt.

EP. DUTTON CO, are preparing to publish in the course of a week or two three articles on "Dramatic Criticism," by A.B. Walkley, the dramatic critic of The London Times. The volume is printed in large type, has 120 pages, is neetly and substantially bound in linen, and includes the following essays: "The Ideal Spectator," "The Dramatic Critic," and "Old and New Criticism."

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- More than 7,000 men in the building trades went on strike here to-day for higher wages. This action affects directly 1,000 additional workmen, and should the strike continue a week building operations will cease, and over 40,000 men will be rendered idle. Two of the strikes have an important bearing on all other branches of the building trades -- those of the Brotherhood of Carpenters and of the Hoisting Engineers' Union.

CHARLOTTE MARY YONGE began the history of her own life with a description of her younger days. A great deal of space is devoted in her autobiography to the annals of the Yonge family. She sprang from a cultured stock, and was born at Otterbourne on the 11th of August, 1823.

Details of the organization of the London Underground Tube System, in which Charles T. Yerkes and Speyer Co. are interested, became public in Wall Street yesterday. This is the parent company which will absorb and manage the five underground roads which were acquired by the Speyer and Yerkes interests.

Leopold Weil has sold for Arthur Casper and Jennie Rhelnstrom to a client, the northwest corner of Cedar and Pearl Streets, two four-story buildings on piot 71.8 by 35.6 and Irregular. Prior to 1890 this property was owned by the Astor estate. It was sold at auction at that time, when the Astors decided to dispose of several down-town parcels which were isolated from their large holdings.

F.O. Reinhart, the young Princeton golfer who furnished the surprise of the Garden City tournament on the first day by putting Walter J. Travis out of the game for the chief cup, added two more victories to his credit yesterday, and will meet to-day in the final round for the President's Cup Arden M. Robbins, one of the veterans of the St. Andrew's Club.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 1. -- To-day the Fishkill and Newburg Ferry Company, owned by the Homer Ramsdell estate of Newburg, posted a notice that hereafter ferriage across the Hudson will be 7 cents each way. For many years ferriage has been 9 cents. The reduction is voluntary. The line is operated under a Queen Ann charter, and has been owned by the Ramsdell family for many generations.

James Edward McMahon, a brother of ex-Police Justice Daniel F. McMahon, one of the late Tammany Triumvirs, was murdered early yesterday morning in the vestibule of his home, at 268 West One Hun- dred and Fifty third Street. The body, which was terribly mutilated, was discovered at 5 o'clock by Matthew McArdle, fourteen years old, who lives on the fourth , floor of the house.

Curious facts are indeed to be found in tho handbook complied by Don Lemon and edited by Henry Williams. (New York: New Amsterdam Book Company, 75 cents.) After one has searched between its covers he comes forth with a heterogeneous knowledge of the most assorted subjects. There is a curious fact relating to the death of George Washington.

At a net loss of $950 in cash outlay the Mexican Stable, or J.G. Follansbee, won the Newtown Selling Stakes at six furlongs on the Jamaica race course yesterday afternoon, the cost of winning being made to exceed the value of the race by that amount because the owner of the second horse, Demurrer, believed that Cameron, the winner, was worth more than the $1,700 he was entered to sell for.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S exposition of the events that led up to and included the addition to our domain of the vast Louisiana territory which was the occasion of his address at St. Louis, was admirably clear, and as complete as the limitations of time would admit. Yet no careful student of that chapter in our history can deny that the subject obstinately retains a core of mystery which no historian's insight has fully penetrated.

Columbia's gymnastic authorities announced yesterday the list of the university's fifty strong men as sent in to Dr. Dudley A. Sargent of Harvard, in competition for the intercollegiate strength test championship of the various colleges. The records show a total of 73,592.9 scored by Columbia's half hundred representatives as against 72,648.7 tallied last year.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It is a great pity that there are so very many cheap, trashy monthly papers and magazines published and widely circulated in this country, and so few, scarcely any at all, of better character, but no higher in price, to take their places. The class of publications referred to are made up of indifferent reading matter and advertisements, the latter usually predominating.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- There was little opportunity for the 1,391 spectators to enthuse over to-day's baseball game. New York won, 11 to 3. Despite the fact that the contest was well played and for five innings evenly fought, it was far from interesting. New York fielded without an error, in marked contrast to the work of the previous day, while the home team had but a single misplay charged against it.

LONDON, May 2. -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says that at an interview on Wednesday between all the Ministers of the Chinese Foreign Office and the Russian representative the latter pressed for reasons for the rejection of each of the seven demands regarding Manchuria which, under orders from the Russian Government, he had presented and which China on bloc refused.

Not much business was transacted in the outside market yesterday. Only a few stocks were active, and with these few exceptions the market showed no life at all. Such encouragement as the bulls had was found in the fact that in spite of the dullness, nearly all the changes of any importance appeared on the side of gains.

DULUTH, Minn., May 2. -- Since the opening of navigation lake traffic here has been enormous. The opening was delayed a week or more by the strike of lake firemen, and vessels have been badly bunched on that account, but they are now arriving in tremendous numbers.

BOOSICK FALLS, N.Y., May 2. -- The Schaghticoke Electric Company has just been incorporated by George E. Greene, E. Gibson, E.H. Libby, Frank H. White, and H.J. Greene. The capital stock is placed at $30,000 in certificates of incorporation. It is understood that the capital stock will be largely increased.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Seymour W. Tulloch, who is in New York attending to business interests, sent word to Washington to-day over the telephone that he had abundant documentary evidence to prove his charges in connection with the Postoffice scandal, and would like nothing better than to produce it.

VIENNA, May 2. -- The international gambit tournament under the auspices of the Vienna Chess Club was duly begun this afternoon, the following players having arrived in this city: Pillsbury and Marshall, America; Teichmann and Gunsberg, Great Britain; Mieses and Swiderski, Germany; Tschigorin, Russia; Schlechter and Marco, Austria, and Maroczy, Hungary.

On Feb. 22 last began a great fishing for pearls on the coast of Ceylon, under the sanction of the Government, which only permits these to be held at long intervals. It is anticipated that it will prove highly successful, and this fact gave a special interest to the lecture by Prof. Herdman at the Royal Institute, where ladies attended in unusual numbers.

Polo in the American Army has received a tremendous impetus during the past year. Since Squadron A, and then West Point, took up the game the sport has attracted wide attention in military circles, and the result has been the organization of an Army Polo Club, the headquarters of which will remain at West Point.

Mr. Oley Speaks will give a recital of songs of his own composition at the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday at 11 o'clock A. M. Mr. Speaks will have the assistance of the following artists: Miss Ethel Crane, soprano; Miss Marguerite Hall, contralto; Mr. Leo Lieberman, tenor, and Mr. Clarence Reynolds, pianist. The programme will be as follows:

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 2. -- The warm weather of Thursday forced many of the Tuxedy colony set to abandon their city homes and look for cooler resorts in the Ramapo Mountains. The week's end at Tuxedo was exceedingly lively, and as the season opens, the prospects for an unusually successful one are very good.

Brooklyn within the last year or two has Seen a transformation in realty conditions long deferred. With great natural advantages, but without the ability to communicate directly by rail and steam with the rest of the continent, the borough has been looked on as unprogressive ,and antiquated, and land values have not increased with the growth of its population.

BERLIN, May 2. -- The interpellation of the Conservatives in the Reichstag and the Prussian Diet asking Chancellor von Biilow when he would notify foreign countries of the abrogation of the commercial treaties is discussed here with the greatest interest. Count von Billow can indeed say "Deliver me from socalled friends."

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Ex-Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith received to-day a letter from Postmaster General Payne calling attention to the charges made by Seymour W. Tulloch, former cashier of the Washington Post Office. Postmaster General Payne invited Mr. Smith to make a statement concerning the matters mentioned by Tulloch.

The appointment of Superintendent Henry S. Thompson to be the head of the Bureau of Buildings in place of Perez M. Stewart, summarily removed by President Cantor, was secured largely through the personal influence of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., who has of late taken an active interest in the building business, especially in the construction of skyscrapers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading the literature of almost all of the various sects calling themselves Christian, it is clearly apparent that however they may differ in other respects in the statements of their several creeds, they all agree in this, that an earnest belief in Christ is essential to salvation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It must certainly be painful to the many honorable men, rank and file of the Philippine Army, who have served there during the last three or four years, to be constantly reading of charges of cruelty against them, and I wonder that none of them have come forward here in the States, where many occupy trustworthy positions of honor and respect to refute those charges.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your account of the golden jubilee of the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration, in Mott Street, you state that the edifice now occupied by that congregation was erected in 1801. This date is incorrect, so far as it relates to the present building.

Arch W., 2:11 1/4, the famous hoodoo horse, has passed away. He broke his right hind leg a few days ago in Vance Nuckols's Cleveland stable, and it was necessary to destroy him. Arch W. came from the South. Henry Eck of Cleveland bought him and gave him to Vance Nuckols to drive.
An oil portrait of the Hon. Roger Q. Mills was recently presented to the Texas House of Representatives, and will be placed in a prominent place in the State Capitol at Austin.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Adverting to your editorial on "Sidewalk Obstructions," appearing May 1, the following suggests itself to me, and may be of interest to the public.

The permanent orchestra season has, as usual, been financially a bad one all over the country. With the end of April comes the end off the seasons of orchestras of this kind, that have in recent years grown up in the chief American cities outside of New York; and also come the bills for those who pay the piper.

TIS in the merry month of May when Spring puts the old pipe to her lips and blows a note or two that is heard throughout the northern section of this country. At the sound little thrills pass through the still chilled meadows. The bushes are dotted with innumerable specks of green that will soon set the whole on fire.

BALTIMORE, May 2. -- Politicians of both parties figure that upon the result of the election next Tuesday for Mayor, Controller and President of the Second Branch of City Council of Baltimore will depend in great measure the result of the coming State campaign for Governor, the control of the Legislature, and the election of a successor to Senator Louis B. McComas.

Along the western border of Wisconsin all eyes are turned toward the Mississippi River. To the residents of the river towns it was at one time a river of destiny. After a period of prosperity that destiny failed, and with it, apparently, failed the destiny of the cities upon its banks. The lumber industry, which has been the commercial foundation of the Upper Mississippi Valley, is gone forever.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: You urgently suggest that smoking be permitted in all open cars of the elevated on the ground that there is insufficient accommodation for the smoker. Your suggestion is unquestionably proper and in the spirit of the public need, and it is not to find fault with the suggestion but to champion the undeniable rights of others that I write.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos at the present phase of the Manchuria question, permit me to say that, early in 1900, I published in New York and London, under copyrights, a book which was advertised and very favorably reviewed in the Paris edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 7, 1900, and in which occur these remarks (Pp. 227-228):

LONDON, May 2. -- The Cunard Line steamer Ivernia, which sailed from Liverpool for New York to-day, has among her passengers Col. C.L. Watson, Secretary of the Britsh Commission to the St. Louis Exposition. Col. Watson is taking a flying trip to America. He expects to leave New York for home May 23, after spending eight or ten days at St. Louis.

Mrs. Margaret B. Edson, the widow of Marmont B. Edson, was adjudged incompetent on account of age to manage her person and estate, after a hearing yesterday before MacGrane Coxe, Dr. Edgar T. Weed, and Henry J. Hardenberg, as Commissioners, and a Sheriff's jury. She has pased her eighty-fourth year.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Lawyers will find much to entertain them in the cases of rare old lawbooks the Department of Justice will show at St. Louis. Among these are two ancient volumes entitled "The Laws of New York." The first volume contains an order from George III., dated March 13, 1770, creating the Chamber of Commerce of New York.

I AM looking for a book on etiquette containing a chapter on "What to say on certain occasions," said the tall girl. "I don't know whether there is any such book, but if there isn't there ought to be, and the first topic treated therein ought to be the correct reply to make to a man who tells you that you look like his first wife.

F.O. Reinhart, the Princeton golfer, who put Walter J. Travis out of the running for the chief trophy in the Garden City tournament, maintained his victorious career without a break, and in a well-played thirty-six-hole final round yesterday he defeated Arden M. Robbins of the St. Andrew's Golf Club by 8 up and 7 to play.

A serious menace to the legitimate privileges of corporations may be involved in the sweeping interpretations recently given by the courts to the Sherman law, when they are considered in connection with other legislation by Congress and certain events which have recently influenced the stock market.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In all patriotic discourses pronounced by the orators of this country we are sure to find some allusion to the great deeds of "our forefathers," by which term the orators mean to designate the founders of the American Republic.

MILAN, April 9. -- In company with the members of the Institute of Electrical Engineers (writes a special correspondent from Milan) I have visited the Adriatic Railway Company, Italy, which has recently applied electrical working to its sixty-seven-mile section of line originally built for steam locomotives, and running along the shores of the Lakes of Lecco and Como and from the junction of Colico to a terminus at Sondrlo.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2. -- The Naval Academy inaugurated its rowing season this afternoon by winning the eight-oared race from the University of Pennsylvania. The distance was two miles and the time 12:43 1-5. The completeness of the victory was marred, however, by the fact that the rough water caused the visitors' shell to fill, and it swamped a half mile from the finish.

Railroad earnings are being watched with keen interest for changes of a more favorable character in net results. Gross earnings are all that could be desired. Much profit has been compulsorily sacrificed to the demands of the labor and other markets -- much, also, because of the deluge of business inadequately prepared for.

The finding of more indictments against alleged poolsellers in Brooklyn on information furnished by a private law enforcement society caused Deputy Police Commissioner Ebstein to declare with a show of anger yesterday that he had apparently been fooled by certain of the Captains under him, and he threatened to "break" them.

BOSTON, May 2. -- The third annual report of the Pere Marquette Railroad Company covers operations and results in the calendar year 1902. Figures of earnings have been published. The company operated 1,795 miles of road. It paid 4 per cent, or $420,416 in preferred stock dividends from 1902 earnings, besides $159,243 on account of equipment notes; transferred $200,000 to the improvement fund, and carried forward a surplus of $213,477.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., May 2. -- A consignment of honey bees in a freight car caused a good deal of excitement at the Delaware and Hudson station in Bainbridge yesterday. During the banging and jarring incident to traveling, the hives had been tipped over, allowing the occupants to escape into the car.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Washington to-day began a determined effort to break up the practice of spitting on the street. The new law punishing spitters goes into effect to-day, and is the talk of the town. Every spitter caught spitting will be arrested, but for the first day or two the police are contenting themselves with handing printed cards of warning to the offenders.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, May 2. -- The exhilaration in financial circles caused by the budget was of a short-lived nature. On consideration it has been decided that the income tax might have been reduced more, that the abolition of the grain tax is a blunder, and that the sinking fund has been actually diminished.

If Mr. Ben Greet and his English company are deluding themselves with the idea that in "Everyman" they have had the only moral play in town, let them be advised that they are wrong. The real Simon Pure article was on view last week at Proctor's Fifty-eighth Street Theatre. "Only a Shop Girl" is as full of moral as a grape fruit is of juice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of this morning from the Far East intimates the seriousness of the present condition of Manchurian affairs. That Russia was from time to time employing every possible means to insult the other powers, no one will now dare to dispute. Russia ought to have evacuated Manchuria long ago.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 2. -- Two negroes lost their lives and thirty-one horses were burned to death in a fire that destroyed the stables on the property of W. Gould Brokaw this morning. The dead are William Henderson and David Gray, each twenty years, who were employed as stablemen on the estate.

Statistics published the other day at the annual meeting of the Royal Dental Hospital lend color to the belief that people are becoming more concerned regarding the condition of their teeth. This hospital, which may now claim to be the largest and best equipped of its kind, has materially increased its utility by the erection of new and adequate premises.

CARRYING bundles is a fine art. Such is the latest bulletin of the philosopher who spends half his time deducing traits of character from deeds performed and the manner of their performance. With that new scroll unrolled whereby a man's secret thoughts may be read by the observing it behooves the commuter, and the real New York man of domestic habits to look to it the way he carries bundles.

BOSTON, May 2. -- Money is working easier. This phase of the situation has entirely surprised people. It is evident that money is accumulating, and unless speculation assumes greater activity, money rates are likely to decline still further.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2. -- The seventh annual interscholastic track meet to-day under the auspices of the Princeton University Association was the most successful that has ever been held here. The air was cool, and a slight wind that blew down the stretch helped the runners.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 2. -- The Columbia University baseball team defeated the Union College team this afternoon without any trouble, the game being in the nature of a walkover for the visitors. The features were the splendid team work of the Columbias, the pitching of Grant, and the fielding of Goodman, O'Neil, Bloomfield, Griswold, and Mahar.

A DISTINGUISHED scientist, who declines to permit the use of his name until his experiments have been completed, has just made an important discovery. This is nothing less than a trust antitoxin or an anti-trust-toxin -- he has not decided which to call it.

"Have you ever been naturalized?" "Yes; but it didn't take." "Now, that is what we Americans call a joke," explained the Washingtonian to the brand-new Secretary of the Chinese Legation, who has indicated his desire to become conversant with the customs of this country.

No better indication of the duliness that prevailed in the outside market yesterday could be given than the fact that the total trading during the morning in Northern Securities amounted to 100 shares. At the opening of the market some animation was shown by American Can preferred, but even in this stock, to which so much attention has recently been drawn, the transactions amounted to no more than 1,400 shares.
BEAUTY is only skin deep; but as the most of us do not possess X-ray eyes it passes muster very well.

PARIS, April 16. -- There are increasing signs of an attempt on the part of the ultra-Clerical element in France to revive the agitation against the Government and the Parliamentary majority, and to excite against them by a campaign of libel not only the religious sentiment of a certain section of the population but also the indignation of honest men of all phases of opinion.

ROMANTIC and picturesque smugglers of the coast, who plied their dangerous work of luring ships on the rocks by false beacons, have practically disappeared from North America, and with the best lighted and patrolled coasts in the world there is little opportunity for these latter-day pirates to operate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have noticed so many matters of general interest discussed in your paper that I am induced to appeal to you regarding a matter which, while of intense personal interest to me, is, I am certain, of no less importance to very many of your readers.
LONDON, May 2. -- Money was fairly plentiful in the market to-day, the demand slackened slightly and rates were easier. Discounts were steady.

Sergt, Thomas Gilhooley, with Policemen Ernest, O.J.H. Peters, and Joseph Russo, all attached to the Eleventh Inspection District, which embraces Long Island City, were shot by a negro ex-convict named Jefferson Sanders, fifty years old, a waiter in the Lenox Hotel, at Sixth Avenue and Third Street, at 10 o'clock last night.

We gravely doubt whether the President authorized anybody to print, as he is reported to have done, that he "got nothing fit to eat in St. Louis." Because he was entertained in part, while he was in the city, by private hospitality, which Mr. ROOSEVELT is certainly not the man, after he has accepted it, to criticise in public.

SOME people always manage to say the wrong thing. Others who say the right thing on all ordinary occasions say the wrong thing at critical moments; and a few who only make a betise once in their lives are quoted forever after by the hearers.

May Day celebrations, or "May Play," as some term it, in Central Park yesterday were under circumstances that chilled enthusiasm. Although the two warm days of the week had put the trees, lawns, shrubs and Spring annuals in leaf and flower, especially the lilaes, there was a raw, gusty, easterly wind that made those who wore Winter overcoats and wraps envied, especially when the sun was obscured.

The increasing popularity of the New Jersey shore resorts is shown by the fact that to add to the already excellent boat service between New York and Atlantic Highlands, a new steamboat, to be known as the Asbury Park, has been constructed by the Cramps for the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

SHARON SPRINGS, Kan., May 2. -- President Roosevelt wound up a busy day's work when his train reached this place at 8:30 o'clock to-night. He will remain here until Monday morning, when he will go to Denver and other points in Colorado. While the day was extremely busy, it also was interesting, and the President enjoyed it greatly.

BALTIMORE, May 2. -- Arthur E. Duffey, the world's champion sprinter, broke the world's record for 75 yards run in an exhibition at the annual field and track games of the Boys' Latin School at the Maryland Oval this afternoon. His time was 0:7 1-5. Maxey Long of the New York Athletic Club was the former holder of the title at 0:7 3-5.

On the Hamburg-American steamship Pretoria, which reached here yesterday, was a party of about forty scientific, agriculturists, nearly all Germans, who will tour the United States to study farming, dairying, and stock and horse breeding. The party will pass nearly two months in inspection and investigation.

THE French Minister of Public Works, M. Maruejouls, has just opened a new road for the Riviera running from Saint Raphael to Cannes. Some time ago the French Government realized the necessity of the work, and completed one section, which extended from Saint Raphael as far as Trayas Point, but for lack of funds it got no further.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 2. -- There is nothing that createst more of a stir along the seashore at this early season of the year than warm weather. During the past week the hot weather had a tendency to drive more cottagers from their New York homes to this place. Some of them are here for the Summer; others are getting their cottages ready for occupancy.

The graduating class of the West Point Military Academy visited the Proving Grounds at Sandy Hook yesterday and Witnessed the experimental working and firing of the large seacoast guns and also the latest rapid-fire guns.
PACTOLUS? Why, that is the name of the river mentioned in Homer which flowed over golden sands," said the Eminent Antiquarian.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The portrait of the late President McKinley by Murphy was received from New York to-day and hung in the White House. The place assigned to it was at the right of the north door of the vestibule. On the left hangs the portrait of President Roosevelt by Sargent.

The coming week will be a busy one in coaching circles, for four public road coaches will start their season's runs. The first will be the road coach Squadron, which is run under the auspices of Squadron A. It will make its initial trip to-morrow afternoon from the Hotel Savoy, going to the polo grounds at Van Cortlandt Park, leaving the Central Park Plaza at 3:45 o'clock and returning at 7 o'clock.

WHAT unreasonable persons the manufacturing classes are!" growled the handsomely dressed labor leader, blowing a cloud of smoke to the celling from his fragrant Havana, as he tilted his chair back in his sumptuously furnished office at the Labor Union Headquarters one morning in the Spring of 1920.

Drums and bugles sounded taps last night in Madison Square Garden. It was the ceremonial close of the seventh annual military monial close of the Seventh Annual Military and Athletic Tournament, the best and most profitable that the Military Athletic League has ever held in its history. It was a gala day, too, this final one of the show of soldierly pageantry and pomp.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2. -- It was announced to-day that John R. Hardin and Thomas W. Crooks, assignees of the real and personal estate of J. Herbert Ballantine, who assigned for the benefit of his creditors on Aug. 9 last, are about to pay off all claims in full. The assignees will retain a considerable part of the estate, which will eventually be turned over to Mr. Ballentine.

ELYRIA, Ohio, May 2. -- The Rev. Ferdinand Walser, assistant pastor of the Church of the Sacred Heart at Toledo, lies in the County Jail here to-night, charged with the murder of Miss Agatha Reichlin, sister of the Rev. Charles Relchlin, pastor of St. Joseph's Catholic Church at Lorain, Ohio.

PITTSBURG, May 2. -- Taylor's deceptive curves and excellent support by his team prevented Pittsburg from hitting safely except in the third inning, when three of their hits were made. Falkenberg did fairly well until the sixth inning, when he allowed six hits. Score by innings:

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 2. -- The Living Church, the official Episcopalian publication of the West, in its weekly issue today violently attacked the method in which the Vanderbilt-Rutherfurd wedding was solemnized. The fact that The Living Church represents the views of the High Episcopal Church in America more closely than any other publication of the Church adds authority to the editorial.

It was a curious coincidence that at the hour of the entrance of the English King into the French capital on Friday the French Ambassador to the United States should be delivering an eloquent address tracing the sources of the friendship between his country and the greater branch of the English-speaking race on this side of the Atlantic.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2. -- Within the shadow of the wire, Judge Himes snatched from Early the twenty-ninth Kentucky Derby, at Churchill Downs to-day. It was the confidence of the twice-successful Winkfield that lost to the favorite the blue-ribbon event of the Blue Gras State.
