Bourbon, six lengths off, was third, while Bad News, Woodlake, and Treacy finished in the order named.

SOME day," growled Mr. Sneedles, slamming the dictionary shut with a bang, "a man with common, ordinary horse sense is going to compile a dictionary and make his everlasting fortune and have the grateful public put his bust on a marble pedestal in the Hall of Fame. Webster -- "

EASTON, Penn., May 2. -- Lafayette's baseball team beat Lehigh this afternoon by the score of 10 to 5. In the fifth inning Lehigh went up in the air and Lafayette scored eight times. The game from a spectacular point of view was not a success, being marred by errors on both sides. Newberry was in fine form.

The early May days will mark the completion of the Colonial Garden in Van Cortlandt Park. The work is one of far greater magnitude than the visitor can comprehend from a stroll through the preserve, with its graveled walks and well shaven lawns and its precise grouping of flowers and shrubbery.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 2. -- A small army of trackmen, formerly in the employ of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, passed through -- Stamford this noon going east. The men are on strike and for the purpose of winning the strike they have adopted a policy something similar to that of the Coxey invasion a few years ago.

A code of ethics applicable to intercourse by telephone is much needed, and unless we can have it many busy men will find it necessary to establish the rule that they will not have instruments in their private offices or houses, or personally transmit messages or answer calls except through their clerks or servants.

PARIS, May 2. -- King Edward this morning witnessed the manoeuvres of 14,000 picked French troops on the parade ground at Vincennes. It was a martial panorama of imposing proportions, resembling so nearly as possible the conditions of warfare, the troops being uniformed and accoutred for actual field service.
WHEN the automobile skimmed past the stone house on the West-Chester Road the man wearing the blue goggles turned and looked at the receding gables.

This is the phrase used in many Southern papers to describe the movement for promoting and aiding education in the South, with which Mr. ROBERT C. OGDEN of this city is prominently connected. The designation is natural enough, partly because Mr. OGDEN has been so long the President of the successive conferences, and partly because he is the most influential and active of the Northern men who have become interested.

Just as the Surrogates' office was closing for business yesterday objections were filed against the probate of the will of William Weisel, the aged recluse who lived with an attendant in two rooms at 444 Lexington Avenue, and who died on April 10 of this year. The will in question was filed for probate last Thursday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me no more appropriate time could be chosen than now, when we are about to celebrate the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the birth of New York as a municipality, to erect a memorial to the Dutch settlers of New Amsterdam.

SHANGHAI, April 4. -- Preparations are nearly completed for a mission to the Chinese Jews, the first ever undertaken. It will be quite unlike other religious missions in that its purpose will not be to convert but to restore. By reason of misfortunes for which they were not in any way accountable, the Chinese Jews who colonized in Kaifengfu, the capital of the interior province of Honan 2,000 years ago, became impoverished and decimated.
ROME, May 2. -- It was raining heavily here this morning, thus bitterly disappointing the Romans, who had been hoping for fine weather in which to welcome the German Emperor to this city.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- R.E. Mansfield, the United States Consul at Valparaiso, Chile, in a report to the State Department, gives details of the project to build a trans-Andine railway to connect Valparaiso and Santiago with Buenos Ayres. This will be the first line to cross the continent of South America.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 2. -- The officers of the Cornell Steamboat Company conferred to-day with the National President of the Marine Engineers Association regarding the demand for an increase of wages, but the conference was terminated suddenly because the engineers declined to carry out an agreement previously made to continue work for several days.

NO one doubted that Letty Lewis loved Dun Donly or that Dan Donly loved Letty Lewis. Their affection for each other was a double-barreled affair, patent to all. And why should they not love each other? Both lived and labored on the big Gibson farm, and they saw much of each other.

BOSTON, May 2. -- The Boston baseball players celebrated their return to the home grounds to-day by defeating the New Yorks by a score of 5 to 2. The game was one of the snappiest and shortest ever played on the old South End grounds.
OH, LED be be! A-choo! Oh, go away! Yes, I, heugh! heugh! a-choo! was Queed ob Bay.

The week's price movement was inconsiderable, but not unimportant, because it seems to have a certain significance. The week opened with the decision of the New York Court of Appeals affirming the constitutionality of the law taxing public utility franchises as real estate.

The Reliance had her first trial in local waters yesterday. She arrived at New Rochelle from Newport early Friday morning and took up her moorings in Echo Bay off C. Oliver Iselin's residence at Premium Point. Yesterday she ventured out in a 20-knot breeze, which blew east by southeast straight down the whitecap-covered Sound all morning, and in the afternoon quieted down to a 12-mile an hour gait.

There are several standard market apples, though not a long list. It is surprising how nearly the majority of men agree as to which varieties make up this standard list. These are Spy, Greening, Baldwin, Ben Davis, King, Gravenstein, with possibly a few others. The list is short, and one would think that, with such rigorous selection, the surviving varieties ought to be pretty nearly perfect.

The veteran operatic conductor Luigi Arditi, who died on Friday at his home in England, had doubtless a larger experience in operatic matters than any of his contemporaries, a greater acquaintance with the famous singers of the last half of the nineteenth century and with operatic managers, and more variegated adventures in many lands.

PARIS, April 21. -- The event of the week has been the first performance of Octave Mirbeau's three-act drama, "Les affaires sont les affaires." The Comedie Francaise, where this fine work is being played, has, in the opinion of all, even of those who are least sympathetically disposed toward the personality of the author, secured a grand success which will keep the House of Mcliere full to the ceiling for many weeks to come.

BOSTON, May 2. -- Because of the strike of seventeen of its engineers for higher wages and recognition of their union, the Boston Tow Boat Company, which handles the greater part of the towing business in Boston, and all of that done for the trans-Atlantic steamship companies, to-day laid off all of its boats and declared its purpose of keeping them idle until the men are ready to return to work under old conditions.

MANY queer odds and ends of things go through the vats and crucibles in the United States Assay Office on Wall Street -- old silverware, ice pitchers, cups, spoons and forks, cuff buttons, breastpins, and gold chains. People who know this so down from time to time to see if they cannot purchase some of the pieces which, while they are battered, are yet good enough to be used.

One of the most talked of features of Ellen Terry's recent production of Ibsen's "The Vikings" in London was the novel effects of lighting attempted by Miss Terry's son, Mr. Gordon Craig, who Was stage manager, and so many other things besides that his name appeared five times on the programme.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2. -- Summer came with a rush and the crowd followed suit. The trains from New York have been crowded since Wednesday morning, and all of them have been running in sections. The hotel men who had been looking for a slack patronage until the 1st of June have again found their houses filled almost to their capacity.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The board appointed by Secretary Root to arrange the details for the National match rifle contest at Sea Girst for the regular army, the navy, and the National Guard has agreed on the following prizes:
AND now it seems that there will be a new club established at Washington, owing to the failure of Gen. Corbin to be elected a member of the Metropolitan.

Without a single dissenting vote the Automobile Club of America, at a meeting held at the clubhouse, 753 Fifth Avenue, last night, decided to make no organized opposition to the Doughty-Bailey bill, now awaiting the signature of Gov. Odell, and decided to send no representatives to the hearing to be held in Albany next Wednesday.

White Plains, "the birthplace of the State of New York," village and town, is ready for the time when subway rapid transit will mean fifty minutes from its railroad station to City Hall, Manhattan. Local property owners and real estate dealers claim that the scat of Westchester County, to which all its roads lead, has not its equal in the suburbs of the city in point of accessibility, natural advantages, corporate administration, and health.

Magistrate Barlow appeared in the Centre Street Court at 12:10 o'clock yesterday, just after the Stock Exchange had closed for the week, and dismissed the criminal libel complaint of William N. Amory against President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company. The following was the written decision, which the Magistrate read:

When we expressed ourselves the other day in reference to the apparent antagonism between the Mayor and the Municipal Art Society as to the best method of providing municipal buildings, we had not the advantage of having read the report prepared by the committee of the society and approved by the general body.

ONE of the whimsical turns of the story of "There and Back," the farce in which Charies E. Evans and Charles H. Hopper are apearing as joint stars at the Princess Theatre, is the impressions of America in general and New York in particular, which the author, George Arliss, himself an Englishman, puts into the mouths of several Londoners.

GREENFIELD, Mass., May 2. -- The Rev. Charles A. Alden, whose disappearance from New York City on Dec. 31, 1901, was followed by the statement that his accounts as Acting Treasurer of the Department of Charities showed a deficit of several thousand dollars, is at his old home in Montague, a few miles from here.
I READ by the papers, already," remarked Mrs. Kinderhelmer, the janitress, "that people who have children many are not able flats to get.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Gen. Francis V. Greene, Commissioner of Police, whom I regard as the most efficient officer in the City Government and the best that has ever been in that department, says that he is going to enforce the sidewalk ordinance, and I am with him, as I wrote the present one and passed it through the Board of Aldermen unanimously.

None of the local baseball teams in the major leagues, was successful yesterday. At American League Park, the home team was beaten by the Washington men, whom they defeated in the first two games played on the new Washington Heights grounds. These two nines and the Bostons are tied for fourth place in the pennant race, in which Detroit leads, with Chicago second, and the Philadelphia champions third.

FIVE years ago medical circles were startled by the peculiar circumstances attending the death of young Dr. Weatherby. I had known him at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, and our acquaintance ripened into the kind or intimacy that may exist between a man of talent and a commonplace friend.

CLEVELAND, May 2. -- An explosion that caused death and destruction occurred in the plant of the Thor Manufacturing Company, at 647 Orange Street, this afternoon. Thus far three people are dead, while twenty-eight others are lying at hospitals, some fatally and others more or less seriously injured.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- Cleveland for President on a platform of "tariff for revenue only" is the programme suggested, with some reservations, for the Democratic Party in 1904 by Norman E. Mack, Democratic National Committeeman from New York and editor of The Buffalo Times. Mr. Mack, in an interview to-night, declares that Cleveland is more popular in New York now than ever before, and that he certainly can carry the State against Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Mrs. Roosevelt to-day entertained Mrs. James Robert McKee, daughter of ex-President Harrison, at tea at the White House, the occasion being the first time Mrs. McKee has seen the mansion in its renovated form. The visit was altogether informal, although in acknowledgment of a card left for Mrs. Roosevelt early in the week.

The East is but a fleeting show, and the fairy tales of its wonders and delights which thrilled the hearts of our grand-fathers are fast fading, like a Summer mist, Turkey -- nay, Islam itself -- is waking up, aping Western customs, donning Christian garments, and generally marching with the times.

THE NEW YORK TIMES in a column editorial presents a number of names of men mentioned as suitable candidates for the Presidency on the Democratic ticket next year. The name of Judge Parker heads the list, a man of undisputed ability and character, whose strength is enhanced by the fact that nobody knows what his views are on any of the public questions that are being discussed in this day and time.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., May 2. -- One man was killed, one fatally and several slightly injured in a collision between a freight and the accommodation train on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, which leaves here at 5:40 for New York. The dead man is Eugene Cavanaugh of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- There were two developments to-day in the mystery concerning the death of E.M. Simonds, the New York promoter, who died from a fractured skull in the Cook County Hospital. In the first place, letters addressed to Simonds at the Great Northern Hotel were opened by Coroner Traeger.

A letter from Panama received in New York and signed by a prominent citizen of that Colombian State gives the information that public sentiment is strongly in favor of the canal treaty, contrary to the feeling of opposition that is said to be getting stronger every day in other parts of the republic.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 2. -- In the contest for the Golf Committee cup on the Hillside Tennis and Golf Club course today A.R. Fisk won first honors. The leaders were A.R. Fisk, 84, 5-79; E. Barrows, 95, 15-80; E.H. Barrows, 87, 6-81; Leighton Calkins, 88, 6-82; J.E. Erickson, 108, 25-33.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 6. -- A most interesting lecture was delivered here recently by Capt. Kozloff on his scientific expedition to Central Asia and Thibet, lasting from 1899 to 1901. Capt. Kozloff left the village of Altais on July 26, 1899, accompanied by two assistants, MM. Kaznakoff and Ladygine, and an escort of sixteen soldiers, with the intention of making for the town of Kobelo.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- "It is absurd," was the comment made everywhere about the World's Fair headquarters to-day over an alleged interview published in a Kansas City newspaper quoting President Roosevelt to the effect that he had been shabbily treated here and had not had enough to eat.

SENATOR HENRY CABOT LODGE of Massachusetts is noted for the tactful local hits he introduces into his speeches. He is very observant, and takes care that his addresses shall bear some touch that will show that he has the interest of the particular locality in which he is speaking well in hand.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2. -- A large brick house in Bayard Lane, belonging to the estate of the late Willard Humphreys, Professor of German in the university, was destroyed by fire last night. The building was occupied by Mr. Wheaton, his wife, and three small children.

A painter whose works reach this country from time to time, but deserve more appreciation than they have had hitherto, is Joseph Bail or "Bail Joseph," as he elects to sign himself. A particularly able specimen of M. Bail's painting is at the Arthur Tooth Gallery, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, where it hangs near the big "Perseus and Andromeda," by the late Lord Leighton.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Charges of a startling nature were made to-day at the meeting of the North Chicago Street Railway Company at the Sherman House regarding the provisions of the leasing agreements made by the two underlying companies to the Union Traction Company.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 30. -- The discovery at Geneseo, in Livingston County, of a letter written by Millard Fillmore, President of the United States, to a friend in Buffalo describing his boyhood days in the forests of East Sparta, in the early part of this century, has aroused the interest of the antiquarians of Western New York.

IT WAS her first success, and the elation it produced turned her head a trifle. She had labored so lone and so hard to get her poems into a print dress, and at last a good, kind editor had published them. But there was a sharp thorn among her roses -- there always is a thorn.

WHAT shall be the punishment of the dog that is guilty of murder -- deliberate murder -- and has also placed filicide on top of his other crime?" The members of the Green Room Club who heard this question thought it some humor of "the road" that had been brought back by Howard Hall, play-wright and theatrical star, who had just come in from a tour in "The Man Who Dared."

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A court-martial without precedent in many years is soon to take place at Norfolk, when William Anthony, a colored mess attendant on the Olympia, will be tried for murder. It is a long time since the Navy Department has tried a man for an offense involving the possible infliction of the death penalty.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- The last act of the dedication exercises at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition grounds to-night was the sending up of a huge rocket, which broke directly over the towers of the Administration Building, scattering its manifold golden stars directly above the archway.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- Detroit defeated St. Louis this afternoon 5 to 1 in one of the stormiest games played in St. Louis. As a result of a couple of decisions in the seventh inning both Heidrick and Hemphill were ordered off the field for criticising the umpire. The crowd made a demonstration against the umpire, but did not molest him after the game.

An example of E.H. Sothern's care in putting on his plays was shown recently in Boston. At a presentation of a one-act play that Sothern arranged for the stage from Robert Louis Stevenson's story of Markhelm is a scene where Markhelm has commited the murder of the old shopkeeper, and hears the ticking of clocks.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 2. -- The Gould polo team carried the yellow and black to victory over the scarlet and white of the Wesichester County Club's second team in the finals for the Herbert trophies on the Georgian Court grounds this afternoon. The Gould team tallied 13 goals to 5 3/4 for their opponents.
MISS CYNTHIA ROCHE, perhaps the tallest girl in the young set, of late has been wearing trailing frocks of chiffon shirred about the waist and hips and topped by a tremendously large black hat.
LENOX, May 2. -- Grenville L. Winthrop, who purchased the Robeson place, will occupy it this week, and remain here through the season. He is making many repairs.

Yale will meet Princeton in the first of the dual games of the university year at University Field, Princeton, on May 9. To win that meet has been one of the ambitions of the Yale team this season, but just bow the Eli track team is to manage it is an interesting question among Yale athletes.

PARIS, May 2. -- Paris is in a state of great excitement and popular jubilation over the visit of King Edward. The weather has been most favorable, and, to judge from the joyous crowds in the streets, all animosity against England, if it really ever existed, has entirely disappeared.

Russia in the Near and the Far East. That the Russian Government is contemplating some gigantic enterprise of international importance is thought to be evident from the fact that the usually "inspired" Russian newspapers have of late been absolutely silent on all problems which are identified with Russian interests or aspirations abroad.

Ex-Inspector Walter Thompson made his appearance at a dinner given by Capt. Nathaniel N. Shire of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station to his men last night at the Murray Hill Lyceum, Third Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, and began to abuse Col. John N. Partridge to such an extent that his hearers got up in a body and walked out of the place.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Col. Winfield Scott Edgerly of the Second Cavalry, now in command of Fort Myer, takes issue with the criticisms by Gen. Baden Powell on the American soldier. Col. Edgerly is a veteran, having seen over thirty years of active service since he was graduated from West Point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The grounds around the Capitol at Washington are beautiful in blooming May, but cross ever B Street, Southwest, and all is ugly and displeasing. South Capitol, Delaware Avenue, and First Street are a disgrace to the city and a blot upon the National pride.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Brooklyn was outplayed and outbatted by the Phillies in the opening game of the series to-day, the home team winning by the score of 4 to 0. It was a pitchers' battle until the eighth inning, when Evans weakened in the face of ragged support and the Phillies bunched hits with their opponents errors, and scored enough runs to make the victory safe.

Commenting upon certain phenomena presented in the statement showing the condition of the Treasury toward the close of the late fiscal year. United States Treasurer Roberts called attention to the fact that for the first time on record outstanding gold certificates exceeded in volume the United States notes, the latter being a fixed item of $346,801,016.

For the thirteenth time the members of the free lecture corps of the Board of Education held their annual dinner and reunion last evening at the rooms of the Aldine Association, III Fifth Avenue. The dinner marked the conclusion of the present season's work by the lecturers, the season proper closing on Thursday.

There was practically no work done on the rapid transit subway yesterday, the strike of the men of the Excavators and Rock Handlers Union and of the Truck Drivers' Union forcing the men in other lines of work to discontinue either out of sympathy or because they could not work with the other men idle.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- By far the most interesting event in the comparatively barren musical season of Washington was the concert on the 23d ult by the S. Coleridge-Taylor Choral Society, composed entirely of colored people, producing the three parts of "Hiawatha" by the Englishman of African descent after whom the society is named.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- In the judgment of Capt. N.M. Brooks, Superintendent of Foreign Mails of the Post Office Department, there is no immediate prospect of the two-cent foreign postage.
PARAMARIBO, Dutch Guiana, April 10. -- "Hi, Riley!"

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would be very glad indeed if you would be willing, through your columns, to bring before the public at this time the need of the Anti-Policy Society for financial support.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 2. -- The Columbia sailed for Glen Cove to-day. Capt. Miller has received orders from E.D. Morgan to tie up at Glen Cove, and he made an unsuccessful attempt to sail yesterday on account of the high wind. She had a fair southeasterly breeze to-day. It is expected that she may meet the Reliance next week on Long Island Sound.

GLASGOW, May 2. -- The British Steamer Tritonia, Capt. Stitt from St. John. N.B., which arrived here April 27, and the British steamer Furnessia, Capt. Young, which arrived here April 28 from New York, each report having sighted a number of icebergs between latitude 42 degrees longitude 54 degrees, and latitude 45 degrees longitude 45 degrees.

THE wearing of jewels in the morning by fashionable women is a custom which has become quite general in New York. The very fashionable women on the Continent seldom part from the most valuable articles of their jewel cases. The Baroness de Rothschild could often be seen in the Bois de Boulogne wearing the simplest linen gown and the most modest straw hat, but decorated with her pearls or her diamonds.

THE lulluhys bulbul in the brunches of the palpitating palmetto sent forth its tremulous trill upon the semi-tropical Connecticut air, and the kindly stars kissed their twinkles down to the purpling twilight, as two forms night have been seen beneath the umbrageous boughs of the sheltering palms near the old stone steps at Horseneck, where lovers trysted many a trust and hearts beat melodies to hearts that beat again:
GLASGOW, May 2. -- The new sails for the Shamrock III, have arrived at Dumbarton, and will be bent on Monday. The trial races with the Shamrock I will probably be resumed on Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 2. -- Yale's baseball team to-day defeated the University of Pennsylvania in a close game. No runs were scored until the sixth inning, when Pennsylvania made two tallies. Yale tied the score in the eighth, and won in the ninth by timely hitting. Score:

SEABRIGHT, N.J., May 2. -- One of the greatest annoyances that the Summer cottagers have had to contend with at this place for a number of years past is the old toll road between Seabright and Normandie, and a determined effort is being made to get rid of it. The Summer property owners are opposed to the road, and the residents are discussing the best means of making the turnpike a free road.

Public-spirited citizens who have no property interests to be subserved by such declarations, and students of sociology who decry the overcrowded state of Manhattan as a condition that retards the development of citizenship, have been pointing for many years to the wide expanses of Long Island as places for residences.

In the second baseball game this season between the Cuban X Giants and the Ridgewoods at Ridgewood to-day the batteries will be McClelland and Williams for the Giants and O'Brien and Page for the Ridgewoods. The preliminary game at 2 P.M. will be between the Brightons and Bedfords.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For many months it has been my good fortune to attend lectures, given under the auspices of the Board of Public Education, comprising a great variety of subjects, on science, literature, art, and geography, many of them beautifully illustrated by stereopticon views, and I desire to say a few things commendatory of a movement that is most effective in the educational uplift of the people.

THE disbanding of the Deep Gulch Vigilant Committee, after a short and inglorious career, was due partly to general circumstances, but more particularly to the treachery and lack of civic pride in the institutions of the camp displayed by Ike Stanton, whom the committee had marked for its first victim.

BRUSSELS, April 21. -- The new Belgian military system, established on the basis of voluntary conscription, has already proved a failure. Notwithstanding the active efforts of the enlistment committees, but few volunteers have come forward during the past year, and one-half of the men who offered their services were found, upon examination, to be physically unfit for military service.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with resentment and pain a communication that was published in your issue of March 26 intended to hold my old and much-loved commander, Lieut. Gen. Scott, up to ridicule. This writer is entirely ignorant of the history and life of Gen. Scott.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., May 3 -- Late Friday afternoon a bill in equity was filed in the United States Circuit Court at Philadelphia by Tom L. Johnson, executor of the late Albert L. Johnson; Alexis L. Dupont of Delaware, and John B. Hoefgen of New York, as creditors of the Lehigh Valley Traction Company, asking the court for the appointment of receivers.

After many years of planning to build in this city a great structure for a National clubhouse of engineers, the coterie of wellknown members of the proffession who have interested themselves in the scheme are at last on the high road to success, through the munificence of Andrew Carnegie, who has agreed to give financial aid to the extent of $1,000,000, or perhaps more.

PARIS, May 3 -- The picturesque features of King Edward's visit to Paris are practically over. The incidents of to-day were comparatively quiet, but they were still expressive of the renewal of Anglo-French good-will.

A very lively exhibition game of baseball was played yesterday on the grounds of the West New York Field Club, at Weehawken, between the New York Americans and the local team. Free hitting on both sides was the principal feature, and about 1,600 persons thoroughly enjoyed the contest, which resulted in an easy victory for Clark Griffith's men by the score of 22 to 12.

MONTREAL, May 3 -- An attempt to settle the longshoremen's strike was made this afternoon, a conference being held between representatives of the stevedores and shipping agents and the officers of the international union.

The first Sunday in May is usually the opening day for the local cycling clubs, and yesterday, despite the chilliness of the air, was no exception. Upper Broadway, on account of its obstructed condition, lacked the parade of wheels which used to be its distinctive Sunday feature, most of the cyclists taking to Riverside Drive or Central Park West, which were thronged during the afternoon.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 3 -- Greenwich is divided on the question of Sunday ball playing just now, and while many champion the cause of the boys of the Volunteer Baseball Association, contending that baseball is no worse than golf playing on the Fairfield County Golf Club grounds, the church people of the town express themselves in no uncertain manner in condemnation of Sunday playing.

ALBANY, May 3 -- In his report on life, casualty, title, credit, and mortgage guarantee insurance, made to the Legislature under date of April 30, State Superintendent of Insurance Francis Hendricks gives the total receipts of his department for 1902 as $270,210,65 and total expenditures $163,174,14.

A few enthusiastic members of the American Dramatists' Club gathered last night, at a meeting called for the purpose of launching the National Art Theatre Society, the object of which will be to procure from private subscriptions an endowment for the much-talked-of National theatre in New York.

"Phil" Casey and Under Sheriff James Dunne, the old-time handball experts and partners, displayed their ability to hold their own at this lively game in a match against Dr. Shea and James Dunne, Jr., at the Brooklyn Handball Club yesterday. They played three games and beat the younger men two straight after some of the liveliest rallies seen in the court this year.

The fact that British yachtsmen were shocked because the Reliance took a Sunday spin off Newport apparently has had no effect upon the owners and managers of the cup yachts, for both Reliance and Constitution were out on the Sound yesterday. Although a good fifteen-knot breeze was blowing up the Sound, neither yacht was given any serious test.

ROME, May 3 -- Emperor William was received by the Pope to-day. He had a conference with the Pontiff lasting forty minutes, and then returned to the residence of the Prussian Minister to the Holy See. As the Emperor traversed the streets of Rome he was enthusiastically acclaimed.

DETROIT, May 3 -- A day of merrymaking and celebration by 1,500 Polish excursionists from Toledo was brought to a close by a frightful catastrophe at Canfield and De Quindre Streets at 8:30 o'clock this evening, when an express train crashed into the crowd and killed at least seven of the excursionists.

DENVER, May 3 -- Everything is in readiness for the reception of President Roosevelt, who is due to arrive here at 10:30 to-morrow morning. Two and a half hours will be spent here, and during that time the President will deliver an address at the State Capitol and will be escorted through the principal business and residence sections and view the City Park.

The Rev. Cortland Myers, pastor of the Baptist Temple, Brooklyn, returned to his attack on the police force last evening. In the course of his sermon a week ago he declared that Major Ebstein, Deputy Police Commissioner had neglected to perform his duty in suppressing poolrooms in the borough.

SALEM, Mo., May 3 -- State Senator Frank Farris has been indicted again. With him were indicted five of his lieutenants in connection with things alleged to have been done at the election in this district last Fall, when Farris managed to save his seat. The Dent County Grand Jury has just adjourned, after an exhaustive inquiry into the methods adopted by the leader of the "alum" Senators.

LORAIN, Ohio, May 3 -- The Rev. Charles Reichlin. pastor of St. Joseph's Church, in this city, and brother of Agatha Reichlin, who was murdered last Thursday night, to-day made a sensational denunciation of the authorities for the arrest of the Rev. Ferdinand Walser, on the charge of murdering his sister.

MANILA, March 30 -- A race so averse to hard work as the Filipinos could hardly be expected to indulge in recreations of a kind calling for physical exertion. The Filipino does get some exercise in beating his poor little rat of a horse, and the sickening lash of the whip is the most monotonous and common sound in the streets.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 3 -- The Rev. Paul L. Johnson was dismissed from the pastorate of St. Matthew's Lutheran Church by the congregation here to-day because of his declaration from the pulpit that he has received some new revelations on the Bible, particularly with regard to the baptism of the Holy Ghost and to faith in Christ.

The police parade on Saturday was a very creditable and satisfactory display of a force which within less than a year has improved almost beyond recognition. The fact which struck the observant citizen most forcibly was that since the last parade of the uniformed force there has been a remarkable shrinkage in the average girth measure of the New York policeman.

BELVIDERE, N.J., May 3 -- The fruit growers of Warren County are much alarmed over the outlook for fruit. The frosts of the past week have done much damage. This morning at 5 o'clock the mercury stood at 32 degrees, and the early vegetables were frozen stiff. The rhubarb leaves could be broken off like icicles, and the peach buds and strawberry blossoms looked black.

VICKSBURG, Miss., May 3 -- "Bob" Bryant and "Will" Morris, negroes, arrested for the murder of W.H. Legg, a planter, were hanged to the Yazoo Bridge at Hayes Bluff just before daylight this morning. Bryant had made a confession early Saturday evening, implicating Morris, whom he accused of firing the fatal shot.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Radical action against the Union Traction Company is proposed by an element of the stockholders of the underlying companies. Unless the counsel of the more conservative shall prevail, important steps will be taken this week.

The Northern Pacific Railway Company and the Great Northern Railway Company both have Eastern termini on the great lakes, with Western termini on Puget Sound. The Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, which was joined to these two roads in one great system by the creation of the Northern Securities Company, operates a network of lines extending westward from Chicago through Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska, and Kansas.

Jefferson Saunders, the negro who shot three policemen at the Lenox Hotel, Sixth Avenue and West Third Street, late Saturday night, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning for the murder of Patrolman Ernest O.J. Peters. He was held by Magistrate Pool without bail to await the action of the Coroner.

Mrs. Mary Miller, wife of John Miller, a constructing engineer, living in La Vera, an apartment house at 142 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, died of gas poisoning in the J. Hood Wright Hospital yesterday. She was removed on Saturday morning from the Colonial Hotel, at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, there she registered the evening before as Mrs. French of Baltimore, Md.

From all promise, the largest field that ever ran for the Metropolitan Handicap will start for that popular event on Thursday of this week, when, with the seventh running of the race in its present form as a mile handicap, the first great race meeting of the Metropolitan Circuit will be opened on the splendid Morris Park course.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me, as one of your old readers, to make my suggestion in regard to a Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1904. What do the Democrats need and how can they put forward a platform and a candidate of such Democratic integrity that the better part of the people of the United States will be moved to vote for them?

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 3 -- George L. Reis, for the last eight years General Superintendent of the Bay View works of the Illinois Steel Company, will assume charge of the mammoth works of the United States Steel Corporation in South Chicago Tuesday, succeeding C.J. McCullough, Jr., as General Superintendent.

The ceremonies attendant on the laying of the corner stone of the new Roman Catholic Church of St. Malachy, at 239 West Forty-ninth Street, were conducted yesterday afternoon by Mgr. Joseph F. Mooney, Vicar General of the diocese.

It is a matter for general congratulation that the Automobile Club of America should have taken so moderate an attitude toward the Bailey bill as they took at the large meeting on Saturday evening. While declaring the bill to be prejudicial to the interests of their class they resolved to make no organized opposition to it before the Governor.

LONDON, May 4 -- The Rome correspondent of The Times says eight Italian warships have been dispatched to Salonika -- two battleships, two cruisers, two torpedo cruisers, and two torpedo-boat destroyers. They carry 220 guns, 155 officers, and 2,534 men.

Everything in the way of nightdress, from a staid old-fashioned gown to a suit of dazzling pink pajamas, appeared in the lobby of the Hotel St. George, in West Fifteenth Street, yesterday morning about 6 o'clock, and the sleepy clerk suddenly became very wideawake as each new elevator load of actresses and other guests arrived from the upper stories.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is gratifying to see a first-class paper like THE TIMES sound a note of warning in regard to the dangerous influx of undesirable foreigners now being dumped upon us. This influx is not only undesirable but detrimental to the welfare of our country from every standpoint.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 3 -- John P. Bradley, son-in-law of Mrs. Mary Robeson of 49 James Street, this afternoon kidnapped his daughter, Marion Bradley, from her grandmother's house. The taking of the child was brought up to date by the use of a big red automobile, in which the father and child and two men were rapidly ciarried away.

The resolution of the Aldermen suspending for sixty days the ordinances relating to the obstruction of the sidewalks will, we assume, be approved by the Mayor. It is a quite proper step, if it is followed by energetic efforts to secure future action that will serve the best interests of all concerned.
To the Editor of The New York Times: An American friend, one of two brothers, who for many years have been residents of Bordeaux, writes me as follows:

The People's Institute, at the meeting in Cooper Union last evening, the last of the season, voted to begin with plans to devise ways and means for the erection of a people's palace, resembling the one in London. The plan, as outlined by Director Charles Sprague Smith, is to embrace all of the features of the institute on an enlarged scale.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I cannot refrain from commenting upon your editorial entitled "Immigration" and published in to-day's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, because I think, with due respect to its writer, that he takes an altogether too serious view of the question. His apprehension of grave economic disturbances finds no justification in the past, and as regards the future, it is based upon mere speculation.

There is a large demand for high-speed launches this season and several are now being built by the Electric Launch Company of Bayonne. Among the number is a thirty-six-foot electric cabin launch for Adolph Lewisohn, which he will use on Upper Saranac Lake. A thirty-one-foot electric launch is being built for A.J. Cassatt, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

More of mystery has been woven around the delay in the placing of contracts for the two new Cunard express steamers than there is warrant for. In point of fact there is no mystery in the matter. The difficulties and delays have resulted in part from an entanglement of governmental red tape, and in part from the impossible conditions which it was deemed necessary to impose in the specifications.

All arrangements have been completed for the annual water carnival of the New York rowing clubs to be held on the Harlem River next Sunday, and it was estimated by Secretary McEwan of the Carnival Committee yesterday that fully 200 boats and 800 oarsmen will take part in the parade.

ST. PAUL, May 3 -- W.H. Murray, representing the California Promotion Committee of the Commercial Organization of San Francisco and California, arrived here to-day in search of laborers to assist in harvesting the fruit crop. Mr. Murray says that the labor situation in the fruit districts is a very serious one.

Rain caused a postponement of the National League championship baseball game in Boston between the local and New York teams, although the Boston and Washington American League teams played there. The Detroit team, which held the lead in the American League pennant race since the opening of the season, fell back to second place yesterday, and Chicago now holds the post of honor.

The local unions of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters started anew yesterday to order strikes all over the city against the Amalgamated Carpenters' Society; all negotiations for a settlement of the previous strikes having failed. Delegates Gaillard and Odell of the Brotherhood reported that about 10,000 men are now on strike belonging to the Brotherhood, which is an increase of 6,000 to the number previously out.
ALBANY, May 4 -- Probably the most interesting impression which New Yorkers have brought back from the dedication exercises at St. Louis relates to the importance of the Cleveland "boom."

The Phoenix liner St. Andrew, from Antwerp, steamed into this port yesterday having on board sixy-fie French fishermen whom a gallant boat's crew from the liner had rescued off the banks of Newfoundland last Tuesday. The fishermen were the survivors of the original complement of 72 men and boys who had sailed from San Malo, France, on March 28, aboard the brig Sans Souci for the fishing banks of Newfoundland.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- That President Roosevelt is keeping fully alive with current events during his tour in the West is shown by the fact that he took occasion to recognize the anniversary of the great naval victory in Manila Bay May 1, 1898, by sending the following personal telegram to the hero of that occasion:

Ogden Mills Bishop, Captain of the Columbia Unlrerslty track team, was yesterday barred by the Faculty Committee on Athletics from taking part in any further athletic competitions as representing the university this season. The new Faculty committee, which is keeping a strict observance upon athletics, has been looking over the records of some of the Columbia track men, and reported that an unsatisfied condition was found in Bishop's previous class work.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Dickens immortalized Fagin, who was a champion pickpocket.

Very little animation was shown in the outside market yesterday, and, except for a sudden rise in International Mercantile Marine, the day's trading was without incident of importance. Net changes that amounted to as much as a point were exceptional, for most of the changes that were more than fractional were reduced by reactions which followed the advances.

BOSTON, May 4 -- The first annual report of the Copper Range Consolidated Company for the year ended Dec. 31, 1902, was issued this afternoon. It is complete as to detail, and in the opinion of some of the best houses on the Street is satisfactory as to its showing of what has been accomplished in the way of development and of what is now being done as to production and its cost.

Large bands of excited Italians, numbering in all about 3,000, who were employed in rock drilling and excavating in various parts of the city, but who went out on a strike for higher wages on May 1, spent yesterday parading through the streets of Manhattan, the Bronx, and Brooklyn, trying to induce by arguments, threats, and sheer force all of their similarly employed countrymen to join their force.

BOSTON, May 4 -- The money market is very easy, but business continues quiet. Call loans, 3 @ 4 per cent.; time loans, on collateral, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; time loans, on mercantile paper, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 10c discount; clearings, $19,440,601; balances, $1,680,130.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 4 -- Wabash stockholders will meet in this city to-morrow for the purpose of approving a plan for the issuance of bonds in the sum of $10,000,000, the principal of which is to be paid in gold fifty years after date, and to bear interest not exceeding 5 per cent.

Capt. Samuel Hof. Ordnance Department, will make not to exceed five visits during May, June, and July to the works of the Builders Iron Foundry, Providence, on business pertaining to the inspection of ordnance material.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 4 -- After five years of litigation, including a contest for a one-milllon-five-hundred-thousand-dollar estate, a verdict of $15,000 for alienation of affections, prosecution of Mr. Prunier for kidnapping his own son, and a police search for would-be poisoners, Mrs. Melvina Prunier to-day was granted a divorce from Frederick Prunier.

BALTIMORE, May 4 -- The partial recovery in Cotton Duck securities was instrumental in adding firmness to the general list. Cotton Duck was firmer on the official announcement that there had been considerable progress with the proposed new financial plan. Income bondholders are becoming more or less refractory under the delay.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 4 -- The strike among the trackmen of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, inaugurated Friday by a gang of twentyfive men, who quit work at the Harlem River, demanding $2 per day and eight hours' work instead of a ten-hour day for $1.50, has spread throughout the New York Division.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- Christian Science received a legal setback to-day, when the Supreme Court decided that the "First Church of Christ, Scientist," is not deserving of a charter. The opinion, writ- ten by Justice Potter, upholds the late Judge Arnold and ex-Judge Dimner Beeber, the referee to whom the application for a charter had been referred.

After having received and given careful consideration to a report made to him by Arthur W. Teele, the expert accountant employed to examine the books of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, District Attorney Jerome announced yesterday that the charges against the company by William N. Amory some time ago were entirely without foundation so far as they involved criminal wrongdoing or affected the present financial standing of the company.

Mr. JAMES COX, representing the Associated Iron and Steel Workers of Great Britain, and a member of the Mosely Commission, which visited this country last year, makes a shrewd observation in his report on the situation and outlook of the iron and steel industries of the United States.

BUFFALO, May 4 -- John H. Costello, capitalist, mine owner, and lumber merchant, was shot in the back and seriously wounded this afternoon by his wife in the corridor on the fourth floor of the Prudential Building. Immediately after the shooting Mrs. Costello walked down to Police Headquarters and gave herself up.

In his speech before the curtain last night at the Savoy, Mr. Ezra Kendall endeavored to convince the audience that "The Vinegar Buyer" is not a problem play. He didn't believe in making people answer conundrums; he only believed in making them laugh. And in intention, at least, "The Vinegar Buyer" is an uproarious farce-comedy, filled with local color of the rural sort.

The killing of two policemen and the possibly fatal shooting of a third in a saloon on the evening of the parade will no doubt be fully investigated in the trial of the desperate negro who did the shooting, and probably the official police inquiry will be deferred until that before the courts has taken place.

When the police raided the offices of the British-African Finance Company at 6 Wall Street late yesterday afternoon and arrested three men and a girl stenographer who afterward was released, they broke up what they declare to be one of the most elaborate and successful "get-rich-quick" syndicates that ever has operated in this city.
LONDON, May 4 -- Money was somewhat more abundant in the market to-day, but supplies were still much wanted to repay borrowings from the Bank of England. Discounts were barely steady.

To-day's social programme includes the competitions at the Fencers' Club, in which several well-known young women of society will display their skill. Yesterday the Squadron A coach began its trips to Van Cortlandt Park for the polo playing there, starting from the Savoy a little before 4 in the afternoon and returning about 7.
LONDON, May 5 -- The Chief Secretary for Ireland, the Right Hon. George Wyndham, yesterday formally moved the second reading of the Irish Land bill in the House of Commons.

LONDON, May 5 -- A special correspondent of The Times, wiring from Salonika, says affairs are still unsettled, and it is impossible to obtain accurate information of what has taken and is taking place. The reports of an extensive, massacre, however, are untrue. The total Bulgarian casualties are probably considerably less than a hundred.

There is to be a hearing before the Mayor at 11 o'clock this morning upon the proposition to amend the charter by increasing the salary of the Municipal Court Justices in Manhattan, Bronx, and Brooklyn from $6,000 to $8,000.

DENVER, May 4 -- The Centennial State welcomed the President to-day with genuine Western cordiality. At every stopping place great crowds turned out to greet the Nation's Chief Executive. The Presidential special crossed the State line from Kansas early this morning and proceeded to Hugo, where Mr. Roosevelt was treated to a cowboys' breakfast.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Postmaster General Payne has received a reply from ex-Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith to the letter sent by Mr. Payne last week in regard to the charges made by Seymour W. Tulloch, ex-cashier of the Washington City Post Office, in regard to the quashing of the investigation started three years ago by Controller Tracewell.

Herman Ridder, leader of the German-American Reform Union, declared yesterday that the organization would not at first take any part in the conferences called by the Citizens' Union for the purpose of selecting a Fusion candidate for Mayor Mr. Ridder also declared that his organization would not support Mayor Low for a renomination.

PEKING, May 4 -- United States Minister Conger, W.B. Townley, the British Charge d'Affaires, and M. Uchida, the Japanese Minister, have had several interviews recently with Grand Secretary Ching on the subject of the Russian Manchurian negotiations. Prince Ching at first was reserved, but he subsequently discussed the Question with greater freedom.

President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan would not yesterday make public the record as a builder of Superintendent Henry S. Thompson, recently made the head of the Building Bureau. It was said at the City Hall yesterday that if the pressure was hard enough on President Cantor he would make public the first building which the new Superintendent helped to construct as a "builder or architect."

The astonishing differences between the estimates and the cost of the electrification of the South London tramways, as done under the direction of the County Council, will furnish food for thought for those who see in municipal ownership a solution for all the problems of economical and satisfactory transportation.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Gov. Odell, his military escort, and the legislative committees which accompanied him to St. Louis arrived in Albany this morning. The Governor lost no time in getting to work on the accumulated legislative business which demanded his attention, and before he left the Executive Chamber to-night had made considerable progress on the appropriation bills, a large number of the items in which have been marked for veto.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Philippines Commission has put a premium on matrimony by making an increase of $15 (gold) per month in the salary allowances of married officers of the constabulary. The increase is for commutation of quarters. There are many bachelors on the force.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 4 -- The 160 ironworkers who went on strike at the descent Shipyards on Friday will return to work to-morrow, as the strike was settied at a conference between a committee of the men and President Mason S. Chace. The men will so back to work on the same terms that other boilermakers have accepted throughout the country.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- Suffering from the humiliation of having been shut out in Saturday's contest by the Phillies, the Brooklyn players retaliated in kind to-day and administered a similar defeat to the local team, the final seore being 5 to 0 in favor of Hanlon's team. It was, a pretty contest, very evenly played, and abounding in clever field plays.

LONDON, May 5 -- The preamble of the Russian demands in regard to Manchuria, says the Peking correspondent of The Times, states that Russia and China have been friendly neighbors for over two centuries and have a conterminous frontier of 3,000 miles. The interference of strangers in these mutually friendly relations would impair them, impeding a friendly settlement.

Nothing could be more interesting to public-spirited New Yorkers than the project brought forward by Mr. CHARLES SPRAGUE SMITH at the meeting on Sunday of the People's Institute. The project is for a "People's Palace," upon the general lines of the building of the same name in London, a place which shall be a centre at once of education, of amusement, and of "politics" in the right sense of that abused word.

ROME, May 4 -- Owing to the recent heavy rains, the military review in Emperor William's honor to-day did not take place on the regular parade ground, but at Centocelie, on a large plain five miles from this city, a picturesque spot stretching to the Campagna and near the ruined aqueducts.

PARIS, May 4 -- King Edward left the Invalides railroad station on his way to Cherbourg before noon to-day, amid the booming of 100 cannon and the acclamations of an enormous crowd of people. The ceremonies at his Majesty's departure were on the same elaborate and spectacular scale as on his arrival here.
NEW HAVEN, May 4 -- Yale won the annual debate with Princeton to-night. The resolution discussed was:
A.L. Mordecai Son have sold for Potter Brother 34 and 36 East Thirty-second Street, a plot 40 by 98.9, to George L. Felt, who will erect thereon a nine-and-a-half-story apartment hotel.

Charles L. Schauwecker, who was formerly in charge of the police school of instruction has been suspended pending trial on self-confessed charges of receiving money, while the shields of three of the last class of probationers are in danger, because of their answers when asked if they had paid with the rest for a present to the Sergeant's wife.

Jack was ashore last night in all his glory. He was out with sweetheart or wife, and they made their way to the Lexington Avenue Opera House to attend the reception, banquet, and ball given by the crew of the United States battleship Indiana in honor of the thirteen-inch guns and the men behind them, who just had smashed world records in Southern waters.

DALLAS, Texas, May 4 -- H.C. Frick, John W. Gates, and George J. Gould are forming the largest coal-land pool yet developed in the Southwest. They have for some time had agents in the Choctaw Nation and other sections of the Indian Territory buying up every acre of land known to contain coal.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Differences arising over the manner in which the special commission to pass on the El Triunfo claim performed its duty are likely to culminate in sharp measures between the United States and the Republic of Salvador.

Stocks strong. Money easy, 2 12/ @ 2 3/4 per cent. The market yesterday continued professional in character, but gained somewhat in activity, and more in tone. There was some dullness about midday, but the opening and closing activity was so marked in comparison that in so professional a market there was a suggestion of intention rather than accident.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 5 -- The valuable stallion, Exile, owned by Elliott C. Cowdin, became apparently crazy this afternoon. He broke loose in his stall, and the trainer, Joseph Brennan, and his assistants hurried all the other animals out of the stable.

Stocks irregular. Money easy, 2@2 3/4 per cent. The list of price changes in the stocks active yesterday showed an advance of 2 1/4 for Reading second preferred. Other changes representative of the market were fractional in range, and about equally, divided between advances and declines.

BOSTON, May 5 -- There is an abundant supply of money, the demand for accommodation is light, and, as a result, local money rates are rather heavy. Call loans, 3@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., May 5 -- Continued dry weather and strong winds have started the forest fires again on the northern slope of the Adirondacks, causing the death of one person. Bert Eseltine, a farmer near Everton, four miles from St. Regis Falls, lost a son fifteen years old and a horse.

The memory of Emma Lazarus, a writer of note in her day, has been revived by her friend, Miss Georgina Schuyler, by a graceful act. Yesterday a memorial bronze tablet was unveiled on Bedloe's, or Liberty Island, as it is now called, just inside the entrance to the pedestal of Bartholdi's gigantic statue of Liberty Enlightening the World.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Still another organization of stockholders in the underlying companies of the Chicago Union Traction Company is in process of formation. The latest body proposes to follow the ordinary rule of voting, by which the stock held, rather than the number of individuals present, goes to make up majorities.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- John Farson, the wealthy broker who said in New York last week that he was willing to leave a million dollars to a servant who in the future would fill the ideal character of a domestic, has been flooded with letters from the East. Some of them are quite serious. A woman at Rutherford, N.J., twenty-nine years of age, is recommended by her husband for the place.

Perhaps the most, striking feature of yesterday's market was the very heavy selling of stocks in certain parts of the list, while strength was being maintained elsewhere for the very purpose of permitting such sales. So skillfully conducted was this selling that it showed very little during the day, but stood out in bolder relief when business was over, and people had an opportunity to study the figures.

District Attorney Jerome said last night that he would be willing to try the case of David W. Bucklin, Canfield's manager, in Saratoga County, where for a number of years Canfield has conducted an exclusive gambling resort, seemingly without interference on the part of the authorities.

The one hundred and twenty-second annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York was opened yesterday in the Grand Lodge Room, Masonic Hall, at Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, with representatives of 737 Masonic lodges with a membership of more than 181,000 present.

Arrangements for a race meeting to be held on the South Shore Speedway, Staten Island on the afternoon of Memorial Day, were completed at a meeting of the Staten Island Driving Club, held at The Staten Islander office, St. George, on Monday evening. There will be two events, for which the following entries have been received:

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- Brooklyn closed the series with the Philadelphias here to-day with a ten-inning victory. It was a pitchers' battle between Jones and Sparks, and when eight innings had been played it looked as if the home team had the game, but an error by Brasher, which prevented an easy double play and a victory, allowed the visitors to tie the score.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Census Office to-day made public the final figures of cotton production, obtained from the reports of cotton ginners. The quantity of cotton ginned from the growth of 1902, exclusive of linters amounted to 11,073,882 running bales. Bales as pressed at the ginneries equal to 10,630,945 bales of 500-pound standard, or counting round bales as half bales, 10,588,250.

It is one of the commonplaces of Shakespearean criticism, which is not yet so commonplace as to be always true, that the great tragedies play themselves. Certain it is that, granted adequate costumes an amountings and actors capable of giving a loose interpretation to the lines of the poet, no performance can be without interest and dramatic effect.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 5 -- Scoring 27 goals, the highest number ever tallied in a polo game on the Georgian Court polo grounds, the Westchester Country Club's first team gave the Rockaway polo team a bad beating in the opening game in the series for the Georgian Court cups this afternoon.

For reasons it is not necessary to recite there is at present quite a little discussion going on in the press in regard to the third term tradition relating to the Presidency. As we remarked the other day, this tradition is deeply rooted in the American mind, and it undoubtedly dates from the close of the second term of WASHINGTON, who might have had another term find did not wish it.

BALTIMORE, May 6 -- Robert M. McLane and the Democratic managers at 1 o'clock this morning claim the election of Mr. McLane as Mayor of Baltimore by a plurality of 350. The returns show a plurality for McLane of 174, with the count in two precincts not yet reported. It is said that they will not make any appreciable differences.

Ex-Assemblyman William L. Sanford, one time lieutenant of Col. Michael J. Dady, and who was appointed to be Under Sheriff by Charles A. Guden, who was removed from his office by the Governor, was convicted of selling pools on the races by a jury in the County Court before Judge Crane late yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- Irregularity developed in the market to-day, with the result that fourteen issues advanced 1/8 to 3/4, seven declined 1/8 to 1/2. The largest loss was in Consolidated Lake Superior preferred. There was a good deal of realizing and some short selling in both stocks, the common being especially active, 5,790 shares changing hands within a small fractional range.

Yesterday was quite gay for this season, with its coaching parade -- that of the Ladies' Four-in-Hand Driving Club -- and the fencing contest. To-day there will be little doing, but to-morrow will bring the races at Morris Park and a charitable entertainment or two in town.

To the Empire City track, Yonkers, has been awarded the $10,000 match race between Major Delmar, 2:03 1/2, and Lord Derby, 2:05 3/4, which is to be trotted on July 4. Bids for the race closed on Friday with David Bonner, the stake-holder, and yesterday the interested parties decided to accept the offer made by the Empire City Trotting Club.

In connection with the meeting of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church at Los Angeles on May 21, the Southern Pacific Company announces a reduced special rate from New York to New Orleans by the Southern Pacific's new passenger steamships, and thence by the Southern Pacific Railroad to Los Angeles, and return to New York by any direct all-rail route.

ATLANTA, May 5 -- Revelations made to the Ware County Grand Jury in regard to horrors of the Georgia convict camps reached Gov. Terrell to-day, and promise to cause such a sensation that the lease system will be shaken. Edward McRae, one of the leading members of the Georgia House of Representatives, is involved by the findings of the Grand Jury.

The situation in the building trades owing to the renewal of the strikes of the carpenters, was looked on so seriously yesterday that meetings of the Executive Committee of the various employers of the building trades were held all day in the Townsend Building, 1,127 Broadway, to discuss the new conditions.

Some of the Incidents of yesterday's market for outside securities were interesting as indicating considerable strength underlying some parts of the market, but the day's changes showed rather a development of recent movements than any new tendency. American Light and Traction sold at record prices, and several other securities were dealt in at figures much above those recently quoted.
LONDON, May 5 -- The rates for money were easy in the market to-day and there was a good demand. Discounts were quiet.

The focusing in a definite and immediate purpose of a plan which has been under consideration for many years, the bringing of the great engineering societies of the United States under one roof, has been made possible by the generosity of Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE in the offer of a million dollars for the erection of a suitable building.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 5 -- Not a line is being sent out of Jackson, Ky., by the local or resident correspondents, for fear of the feudists. A reliable man who came to-day from Jackson to Lexington over the Lexington and Eastern Railway, on being promised that his name should not be used, said that the conditions at Jackson were deplorable and renewed hostilities between the friends of Marcum and those now in power are imminent.

--In explaining the plan for a great "people's palace," Mr. CHARLES SPRAGUE SMITH evidently had in mind what he as evidently considered the danger that the ever-ready Dispenser of Millions wpuld hear of the proposition and get his check for the amount needed over here before any other and better method of raising the money could be evolved.

LONDON, May 5 -- Commenting on the Manchurian crisis the correspondent of The Times at Peking says that the divergent assurances given by the Russian Government to the various powers concerned are exciting much interest at the Chinese capital. It is noted that denials are gradually merging into admissions of the designs of Russia to hold Manchuria.

That was a very good phrase which The London Times used in its leading article, which was cabled to us yesterday, about the policy of Russia in the Far East. That was the phrase which described the bewilderment of Western Europe and America at the Oriental diplomacy of Russia, saying that these Russian diplomatic procedures were incomprehensible "to nations which mean what they say and expect others to mean what they say."

ROME, May 5 -- Emperor William and King Victor Emmanuel went to the abbey it Monte Cassino this morning, accompanied by Crown Prince Frederick William, Prince Eitel, the Duke of Aosta, the Duke of the Abruzzi, the Duke of Genoa, and the Count of Turin.

There was an exciting scene at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, when one of the most important franchises granted during Mayor Low's administration was nullified. Some members of the board changed front after voting several months ago, and by opposing the grant defeated one franchise and seriously impaired another.

Stockholders of the Universal Tobacco Company yesterday received a circular from William H. Butler, President of the company, in which he intimates that action may be brought against the Tobacco Trust for interfering with the business of the Universal Tobacco Company. James W. Osborne has been engaged to represent the interests of the Universal Company in this tigation.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 5 -- The result of the tax assessment for the present year was announced to-day, and shows an unexpectedly small increase in the valuation of taxable property in the city. The total valuation is $42,032,800, of which $34,668,200 is in real estate and $7,364,000 is in personal property.

The new cup yacht Reliance, which for the past few days has been roaming about the Sound looking for something against which she might try her speed, ran alongside Columbia yesterday, and Columbia did not decline the obvious challenge, as did Constitution on Saturday. As a matter of fact, she was waiting for it.

There was a very marked difference in the quality of baseball played by the New York and Philadelphia teams in the game decided yesterday at American League Park. The home team won by a score of 11 to 3, because Griffith's men individually and collectively played well, while the visitors played badly.

ELYRIA, Ohio, May 5 -- At the end of an investigation into the cause of the death of Agatha Reichlin, who was murdered last Thursday night, Coroner French of this county this evening gave as his conclusion the verdict "That Agatha Reichlin came to her death from wounds inflicted by a stone in the hands of a person unknown."

District Attorney Jerome's cross-examination of the star witness for the defence at the trial of "Lou" Betts on a charge of maintaining a gambling house at 122 West Thirty-fourth Street enlivened the proceedings before Judge Cowing yesterday afternoon.

Mrs. Howard Gould gave eighteen of her friends a springtime luncheon in the Astor dining room at the Waldorf-Astoria at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, remarkable for the beauty of the floral decorations. The blooms selected were lilacs, sweet peas, apple blossoms, orchids, moss roses, violets, and palms. Both the reception room, as well as the dining room itself, were veritable floral bowers.

The Tribune yesterday published an excellent and suggestive news article showing the difference between the status of the "pushcart men" under an honest and under a Tammany municipal administration. In Tammany days these unfortunate people were the sport and also the spoil of the vitiated patrolman, who insulted and oppressed them at the same time that he was blackmailing them.

ATLANTA, May 5 -- Officers of the Colored National Emigration and Commercial Association have issued a call for a National convention of those who are interested in their objects, to be held in Montgomery, Ala., on June 24.

LONDON, May 5 -- King Edward VII. received a great popular welcome on his arrival in London to-day from France. The railroad station was closed to the public, but the approaches were thronged by large crowds and the road to Buckingham Palace, which was gayly decorated with flags, was thickly lined with people.

"Between politics and matrimony," as he expressed it, William S. Devery had rather a busy time of it yesterday. The matrimony feature was rather abruptly crowded into his life on Monday evening by a note which was thrust into his hand, at "the pump," and which read:

NEW BRUNSWICK, May 6. -- The delegates from the Particular Synod of New Brunswick of the Dutch Reformed Church to the General Synod of that church will go instructed to use their best endeavors toward the federation of the Reformed Church the Reformed Presbyterian, and the United Presbyterian, and other churches holding the Presbyterian system.

LONDON, May 7. -- The separation of Church and State, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, has become one of the great questions of the day in France. Both sides are closing their ranks, and it is generally recognized that a grave crisis is imminent.

Because he had not been in the Philippines since January, Gen. J. Franklin Bell declined to discuss conditions in the archipelago when he arrived yesterday on board the North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm. He will go to Fort Leavenworth, Kan.

A remarkable accident occurred yesterday afternoon, when Louis Lubliner, three years old, of 217 East Eighty-fifth Street, fell from a south-bound train of the Second Avenue elevated line at Eighty-sixth Street to the street. He was caught by two men who had seen him fall, and the only injury he sustained was a bruise on the forehead, received when he struck the guard rail outside of the tracks in his fall.

Yesterday was socially blank in town. To-day there will be the races at Morris Park and a number of coaches will run to the park. The Reliance, Richard F. Carman's coach, will start at noon from Sherry's. The Good Times and the Free Lance will, leave the Waldorf-Astorla at about noon.

CANSO, N.S., May 6 -- The American fishing schooner Gloriania, Capt. George Stoddart of Gloucester, ran ashore during a thick fog on the cliffs at "Whale Cove, near White Point Ledges, last night, and fifteen of the crew, including the Captain, were drowned out of a total of eighteen.

TRENTON, N.J., May 6. -- Henry C. Spinks of Newport, Ky., who fought the proceedings that resulted in the appointment of a receiver for the Asphalt Company of America and an order for the sale of the company's property on May 15, filed to-day another bill in the United States Court.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The delegates to represent the United States at the international conference at Geneva, Switzerland, for the purpose of revising and extending the Geneva treaty of 1864, under which the various Red Cross societies are recognized, have been designated by the President. They are Francis B. Loomis, the Assistant Secretary of State; Gen. George B. Davis, Judge Advocate General of the army, and Commander Nathan Sargent, United States Navy.

A general alarm was issued last night for George A. Kolb, business agent, Secretary, and Treasurer for the Marine Engineers' Benevolent Association, which threatened to tie up all the freight and passenger business of the city last week, and which is now trying to arrive at a settlement with the marine interests through arbitration.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 6. -- By hard riding and straight hitting, George J. Gould, his sons, Kingdon and Jay Gould, and Ben Nicoll of the Lakewood first team, won a well-earned victory over the Westchester Country Club's second team, in the second polo game of the Georgian Court Cup series, this afternoon on the Georgian Court field.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 6 -- Congressman Frank Wachter, the Republican candidate for Mayor in yesterday's election, and the Republican City Committee still assert that only the official count will determine who is elected. On the face of the returns, with the vote in three precincts not counted and in dispute, Robert M. McLane, Democrat, has 317 plurality.
CHICAGO, May 6. -- New York exchange was at par to-day. Time and call loans, 5@6 per cent.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 6. -- The delegates to the convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New Jersey voted to-day on the proposition to change the name of the church. The vote was: Clerical, 30 yeas and 35 nays; laity, 15 yeas and 56 nays. The following-named officers were elected:

The first race meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club came to a close on the Jamaica track yesterday under conditions that rounded out the success achieved on earlier days and left no room for doubt as to the future prosperity of the association.

BINGHAMTON, N.T., May 6. -- Edward M. Shepard was the chief speaker at a Democratic banquet given here this evening. Mr. Shepard's speech was largely devoted to a comparison of the work of the McKinley and Roosevelt Administrations with those of Mr. Cleveland. He referred to the recent address of President Roosevelt at the dedication of the St. Louis Fair.

Senator Thomas C. Platt, who controls a large majority of the Republican County Committee, and through it the City Committee, including representatives from the several counties in the Greater New York, said yesterday:

GRAND CANYON, Arizona, May 6. -- Arizona welcomed President Roosevelt here to-day and the welcome it gave him was a warm one. A special train from Flagstaff brought a large crowd and people also came in from the surrounding country on horse-back and in wagons.

Adolph Philips, who managed the Germania Theatre in Astor Place, which was torn down recently to make room for the subway construction, according to Berlin advices, will star there in a new theatre, producing plays of American life. This theatre, which was the old Bunte Theatre on Koepnickerstrausser, will be opened this August by his brother, Paul Philipp, as the German-American Theatre.

The views of President BUTLER, which we quoted yesterday morning from The Columbia Literary Monthly, relating to the laxity of discipline in modern college life, have a somewhat antique but a very wholesome flavor.

LONDON, May 7. -- In moving in the House of Commons yesterday a formal resolution guaranteeing the Transvaal loan of u35,000,000, the Colonial Secretary, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, delivered a lengthy optimistic speech on the future of the new South African colonies. His remarks were mostly a reiteration of former statements.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. May 6. -- Alexander Winton in a trial run with a gasoline automobile covered a mile at the Glenville track in 1:02, or one-fourth of a second better than the world's record for a circular track. Winton will enter the race for the Gordon-Bennett International Cup in Ireland next July.

The Senate sub-committee, selected at the last session to study plans for improving the currency, announces its intention to meet at various places during the next three months and to take counsel with the best-informed financial and business leaders, with the hope of reaching some conclusions that Congress will approve.

ALBANY, May 6. -- There was a hearing before Gov. Odell to-day on the Bailey bill making eight miles an hour the maximun speed at which automobiles may be run in any section where the houses are less than 100 feet apart and within half a mile of any Post Office when a sign is displayed on the road warning the automobilist to reduce his speed.

NEWARK, N.J., May 6. -- Articles of incorporation of the new trolley, gas, and electric combine, which will be known as the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, were filed for record in the County Clerk's office to-day. The concern is capitalized at $25,000,000 in shares of $100 each, while the paid-up capital will be $100,000.
