LONDON, May 7. -- The Foreign Secretary, the Marquis of Lansdowne, has proclaimed a British Monroe Doctrine in the Persian Gulf, and has practically notified the competing powers that any attempt on their part to establish a naval base or fortified port in those waters means war with Great Britain.

It is a nautical axiom that "all boats sail fast when they are alone." Shamrock III. seems to be able to sail fast when she is in company with Shamrock I., even though the only set race had between the two was won, even in that competition, by the old boat.

At the opening stocks showed a better tone upon a smaller business than on Tuesday. The prices were best about midday, and the close, if a little dull, was not soft. The chief feature was a rise of three in St. Louis and San Francisco, and over one in the Rock Island descriptions.

The property at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, best known as having been the residence of the late Austin Corbin, has been leased by the United States Realty and Construction Company to Siebrecht Son, through Brokers Pease Elliman. The lease covers a term of twenty-one years, at an annual net rental of $38,000.

BERLIN, May 6 -- Business on the Boerse to-day was somewhat adversely affected by the fact that operators on the London Stock Exchange were waiting for the announcement to-morrow of the Bank of England's rate of discount and for a definite statement regarding the terms of the Transvaal loan.
Capital stock of the Toledo Furnace Company increased from $1,000,000 to $1,350,000.
LONDON, May 6. -- Money was abundant in the market to-day, and there was an increased demand owing to requirements for the consols settlement.

Philadelphia's American League baseball champions won the final game of the series with the Greater New York Club's team at American League Park yesterday by the score of 6 to 1. Plank, the visiting pitcher, was particularly prominent during the contest, and to his efforts both in the box and at the bat, the success of the Athletics was due.

With the score 2 to 1 in favor of Pennsylvania in the ninth inning, with two Columbia men out, and two men on bases Taber, at bat, failed of a possible chance to win the annual game between these colleges at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The score remained 2 to 1 for the Quakers after a very close game, in which enthusiasm and exciting incidents were plentiful.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Late advices from Porto Rico state that there is considerable popular dissatisfaction with the action of the Washington authorities in directing that no prosecution shall be made of those persons who were charged with having smuggled liquors into the island, several of whom are navy and army officers.

Judge William H. Moore carried off the ion's share of the blue ribbon awards last night at the opening of the eleventh annual horse show of the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn. The show, which will continue during the remainder of the week at the clubhouse, fronting the Prospect Park Plaza, opened under unusually fortunate auspices.

NEWPORT, May 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. William B. Carter and Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Hoffman, Jr., are here inspecting their cottages. Mr. and Mrs. Carter have completely remodeled their cottage on Narragansett Avenue, and the work is nearly completed. Mr. Hoffman bought the George G. Wales estate at Reef Point, and will occupy it this Summer.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Consul General Skinner at Marseilles has sent the State Department a communication about olive oil manufacture in France, in which he explodes certain popular beliefs about the importing of adulterated products.

They have been expensive, the emblems of the colleges, in any form in which they could be found for wall decorations, but there are some charming ones to be obtained now, enameled on tin, and they cost from 75 cents to $1.50 each. Many of them ore ready-made, and they can be had on demand; others are painted to order for the same price.

The serious situation which has developed in the local building trades has the misfortune of having been precipitated by the owners of the brick and lumber yards to forestall the unionization of their truckmen and laborers. In anticipation of possible inconvenience to result from such unionization, the owners of the yards agreed upon a lock-out.

OMAHA, Neb. May 6. -- Judge Munger of the United States District Court late this afternoon granted a temporary injunction restraining the striking union teamsters of Omaha from interfering in any way with non-union teamsters. The injunction is the most sweeping of the kind ever issued in the West.

Police Inspector Adam A. Cross was dismissed from the force yesterday by Commissioner Greene for neglect of duty and conduct unbecoming an officer on recommendation of First Deputy Commissioner Ebstein, before whom Cross was tried. Under the two general charges were five specifications of allowing disorderly houses and poolrooms to exist in the "red light " district, where Cross commanded two years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The President has appointed the following Postmasters:

Reliance and Columbia did not meet yesterday, but only lack of wind prevented another brush, for their intentions were excellent. Both yachts were out, and while Reliance wanted a better opportunity to display the speed which theoretically her lines and driving power should give her, Columbia, encouraged by the brush of the day previous, was quite willing to give her the chance.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 6 -- Gov. Beckham this afternoon offered a reward of $300 for the arrest of the assassins of J. B. Marcum, who was killed at Jackson, Breathitt County, on Monday. The reward was offered at the request of County Judge Hargis, but this step was not voluntary on his part.

The New York Security and Trust Company is the latest trust company to announce its intention to withdraw from its connections with the Clearing House Association. The capital of this company is $1,000,000, its surplus is $3,000,000 and its deposits are over $40,000,000. Its President is Charles S. Fairchild.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 6. -- For the first time in the history of the Republican Party in this State, at the Republican conference held, in the hall of the House of Representatives to-day, the whites took seats on one side of the hall and the negroes on the other. This conference was called by what is known as the "President's Board of Referees."

The Sun raises the curious and interesting point whether ministers of religion can lawfully refuse to perform the marriage ceremony between persons who are lawfully entitled to contract a marriage. Inasmuch as ministers are civil officers for the particular purpose in question and their marriage certificates are accepted by the other civil officers, are they not bound to issue such a certificate.

Twenty-three survivors of the crew of the French fishing brig Ile de Terre Neuye, bound out from St. Servan, France, to the Newfoundland Banks, arrived in this port yesterday on the German tank steamship Phoebus, Capt. Schierholst, listed "shipwrecked."

Without any apparent warning a general shut-down took place yesterday both in the yards of the building material dealers and the lumber dealers all over the Greater New York and its vicinity, as a culmination of the demands of the Building Material Drivers' Union and the Material Handlers' Union.
Mayor Low issued the following proclamation yesterday calling on the citizens of the city to duly observe the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of the municipality as a city:

ATLANTA, May 6. -- Persons interested and occupied in sociological work met in the First Baptist Church this evening for the thirtieth National Conference of Charities and Corrections. An address of welcome was delivered by Mayor Howell, to which response was made by Dr. Frederick H. Wines of Washington.

NORFOLK, Va., May 6 -- It was learned to-day that among the passengers on the steamer Hamilton at the time of the disaster early yesterday morning was Miss Schley, daughter of Rear Admiral Schley. With other women passengers on the Hamilton, she raised $95, which was distributed among the most needy of the Saginaw's survivors.
These officers of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York, now in session in Masonic Hall were re-elected yesterday:

VICTORIA, B.C., May 6 -- It is regarded as highly probable that Sir Thomas Shaughnessy. President of the Canadian Pacific Railroad, will come here to give evidence, before the legislative committee which is inquiring into the scandal in connection with subsidies to the Columbia and Western branch of that road.

BALTIMORE, May 6. -- Sperry, Jones Co., bankers, who have conducted some extensive financial deals, failed to-day, and in the Circuit Court Vernon Cook of the law firm of Cans Haman was appointed receiver.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 7 -- Acting, they say, under instruction from the Secret Service Bureau at Washington, the police to-day arrested a man who is said to be one of the four brothers of Czolgosz, the assassin of President McKinley. No charge has been lodged against him, the police simply detaining the man "on suspicion" until after Mr. Roosevelt shall have left this city.

George G. Williams, President of the Chemical National Bank, died at 10:45 o'clock last night in his home, at 34 West Fifty-eighth Street. He had been confined to his bed for two weeks with heart weakness, the result of an attack of the grip in February last. At the deathbed were Mrs. Williams, Mrs. Frank Keech, their only child; Frank Keech, and Dr. Garmany, the family physician.
The communication of the Grand Lodge of Masons of New York was concluded yesterday in Masonic Hall. The officers were installed by Past Grand Master John Stewart.

LONDON, May 7 -- The annual meeting of the Iron and Steel Institute here to-day was largely attended. After being formally installed in the Chair, the new President, Andrew Carnegie, who remarked that he was the first President of the institute who was not a British subject, presented to Sir James Kitson, a former President of the institute, the Bessemer Gold Medal for 1903

MEDFORD, Mass., May 7 -- There is great excitement here over the murder last night of Miss Nellie A. Sturtevant, by a man who attempted to rob her father, James H. Sturtevant, Treasurer of the Medford Co-operative Bank. Tomasso Lombardo, en Italian carpenter, who was arrested in Boston, five miles away, two hours after the shooting, was held without ball to-day on suspicion of having committed the crime.

Negotiations are nearly concluded for the sale of one of the largest companies manufacturing tobacco for export in the country to the British-American Tobacco Company. The concern which is to be acquired for the British company is the T.C. Williams Company of Richmond, Va. It has been in existence for fifty years, and its export business in chewing tobacco amounts to nearly 5,000,000 pounds of tobacco a year.

The Rockmen and Excavators' Union yesterday decided to reject the agreement signed by the Rapid Transit Committee of the Central Federated Union, by which the strikers were to return to work on the subway pending arbitration of their demands. In this decision they turned down their own officer, two of whom, with the Rapid Transit Committee of the Central Federated Union, had signed the agreement.

It Is a pleasure to respond to the Mayor's appeal to the newspaper press to take advantage of the celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the founding of our Municipal Government "to bring home to the people a sense of New York's long history." It is, indeed, highly desirable that this should be done.

The one, hundred and thirty-fifth annual meeting of the New York Chamber of Commerce and its first annual reunion in its new Liberty Street home was yesterday attended by about 400 members. This ticket for officers for 1903-4 and class committeemen, voted on by 164 members, was ejected without opposition:

Disregarding entirely a divorce secured in the Florida courts against her, Mrs. Anna Ogden Pell has begun proceedings in this State to secure an absolute divorce from Duncan C. Pell, naming as co-respondent the woman whom Mr. Pell married last October in Connecticut after he had secured his Florida decree.

LONDON, May 8 -- In its City article to-day The Times says the applications for the Transvaal 3 per cent, loan caused a very strong pressure for money yesterday, the Bank of England lending an enormous amount. Discount rates were nominally higher.

President R.C. Morris and Secretary George R. Manchester of the Republican County Committee yesterday sent out a call for a meeting of that body at the Assembly Chamber in the United Charities Building for to-morrow night. The call says that the meeting is "for the purpose of appointing a Conference Committee to meet with other anti-Tammany organizations to perfect a plan of fusion."

ROME, May 7. -- Mgr. Veccia, Secretary of the Propaganda, was received by the Pope to-day, and submitted the report of the Congregation of the Propaganda on the vacancy in the Bishopric of Buffalo, N.Y.

In a record-breaking race from every standpoint, William C. Whitney's filly Gunfire, the popular favorite for the race, yesternay won the fourteen-thousand-dollar Metropolitan Handicap, at the Morris Park race course, in the presence of the largest crowd that ever gathered on the famous Westchester track.

BOSTON, May 7 -- The New York American League team lost the first game of a series with the Bostons to-day by a score of 6 to 2. Batting when hits counted was the deciding element in a game which was interesting from start to finish. Until the seventh inning was reached clever fielding by the visitors had kept the Boston score down to 3 runs.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 7 -- Louis S. Brugiere has rented the De Rham cottage in Bellevue Avenue for the Summer.

-- This is the season for annual meetings of the medical societies of the country, and the reports of their proceedings have reminded The Medical News of the fact, noted long ago, that a surprisingly large number of the men who, though active practitioners, gave much time to the establishment and conduct of these organizations were still capable of hard and fruitful professional labor long after they passed the allotted span of human life.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association yesterday completed its Spring session at the Murray Hill Hotel and adjourned, to meet again on the first Tuesday in December. At the meeting Major P.P. Johnston of Lexington, Ky., was in the chair.

Bishop, Potter, who was the principal speaker at the annual supper of the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor, held last night at the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, took issue with the doctrine taught by District Attorney Jerome in his address before the Central Federated Union a few weeks ago.

REDLANDS, Cal., May 7 -- President Roosevelt was formally welcomed to California to-day before a crowd estimated at 10,000 persons. The President's special train arrived here at noon, exactly on time.

Coroner Scholar's inquest into the death of Benedetto Medonia, the barrel murder victim, will be finished by noon to-day, and the case will-go to-the jury. Yesterday there was a six hours session and a number of witnesses were examined, but none of them gave any testimony that connected, more than circumstantially, the Sicilian suspects with the crime.

BOSTON, May 7 -- The money market does not change much. Rates remain easy, but business is very dull. Call loans, 3 @ 3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, par. Clearings, $22,986,208; balances, $1,469,037.

Editorial remarks in THE TIMES of Thursday have given pain to leading representatives of the trade in building materials. This we regret; whether the facts warranted our comment is largely a question of fact.

GOUROCK, Scotland, May 7 -- The Shamrock III. went out this morning on her first trial spin since she had been refitted, after having been dismasted off Weymouth. A light northeasterly wind was blowing. The cup challenger's new mainsail, which is cross cut, like the old one, did not set satisfactorily.

DUBLIN, May 7 -- In the fourth round of the ladies' golf championship tournament, now being contested at Portrush, County Antrim, the present holder of the championship. Miss May Hezlet, was defeated by 1 up by Miss M.E. Stuart of the Boyal Portrush Club. The contest will conclude to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Venezuelan negotiations were completed this evening in the British Embassy in the presence of Herbert W. Bowen, Venezuela's Plenipotentiary; Signer Mayor des Planches, the Italian Ambassador; Sir Michael Herbert, the British Ambassador; Baron Speck Von Sternburg, the German Ambassador, and Secretary Dering of the British Embassy.

BOSTON, May 7 -- Instead of accepting a call to the rectorship of the Church of the Holy Trinity of Brooklyn, the Rev. Henry Sylvester Nash, professor of the Episcopal Teological School and rector of St. John's Chapel, Cambridge, will go to Newport to take charge of a church for one year. If at the end of that time the Brooklyn church extends to him a call, it is said, he may accept.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Seymour W. Tulloch, formerly cashier of the Washington City Post Office, who tried to get Postmaster Charles Emory Smith to investigate the accounts of the office three years ago and also charged that Controller Tracewell "called off" the investigation of irregularities in the postal service, has sent a letter to Postmaster General Payne in reply to a request for proof of his charges:

The address delivered by Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE as President of the British iron and Steel Institute is as unique among documents of this character as the man who delivered it is unique among ironmasters. To the representative capitalists of the iron and steel industries it will come as something of a revelation.

VIENNA, May 7 -- The fourth round of the international gambit tournament was played to-day, when the men faced each other as follows: Marshall vs. Swiderski, Tschigorin vs. Pillsbury, Teichmann vs. Maroczy, Schlechter vs. Marco, and Mieses vs. Gunsberg.

ROME, May 7 -- The Rev. Father Baudenilli, ex-Provincial of the American Passionist Fathers, and the Rev. Father Francis J. Van Antwerp of Detroit, Mich., were., received in private audience by the Pope today, and presented to the Pontiff President Roosevelt's jubilee gift of ten handsome volumes of Presidential messages.

Latest reports, coming in the shape of telegrams and private letters, show that at least 100 Jews and some non-Jews acting in sympathy with them were butchered in Kishineff, the capital of Bessarabia, between April 20 and 23. Not until three days after the slaughter began did the Governor take heed and give the Jews permission to shoot their assailants.

The Metropolitan Street Railway Company made a determined but unsuccessful effort on Wednesday afternoon to compel a carload of passengers on the Columbus Avenue line to consent to a violation of the "car-ahead" ordinance. The company failed to carry its point, owing to the resistance of a sturdy band of six men and one woman, who stood out for their rights as passengers for more than three hours.
Robert Wallace has sold, through John H. Porges, the five-story American-basement dwelling 312 West One Hundred and First Street.

Stocks weak. Money easy, 2@2 1/2 per cent. Yesterday there were bits of news and fractional fluctuations and neither were any more significant than the statement indicates, except to those of X-ray powers of perception. The news was not very good and the price changes were mostly small declines.
LONDON, May 7 -- Money was in active request in the market to-day in connection with the Transvaal loan. Discounts were quiet and rates were firm.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The State Department to-day announced the appointment of Hamilton King of Michigan as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Siam. Mr. King was Minister Resident in Siam, and his elevation is in accordance with an act of Congress.

A little shower yesterday spoiled a fine opportunity to test the relative speed of Reliance and Columbia, just as lack of wind prevented their meeting the day before. There was almost a flat calm when the Reliance left her moorings at New Rochelle, but a good ten-knot breeze came out of the northeast before she had reached half way across the Sound.

Corporation Counsel Rives has begun action to set aside a lease granted during the last weeks in office of the Van Wyck Dock Board for bulkhead rights between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets on the North River. The charge is that there was conspiracy and fraud in the granting of the lease first for a term of three years, which was afterward increased to three terms of ten years each.

LONDON, May 8. -- The issue of the prospectus of the Transvaal loan was awaited with the greatest interest in financial circles here, and there was an unprecedented scene at the Bank of England yesterday. People congregated hours before the prospectus was given out, and at the hour of issue thousands of persons stood in the pouring rain, four deep, in the streets leading to the Bank.
ALBANY, May 7 -- Gov. Odell to-day sent to the Secretary of State a large number of bills which he had signed. Among them were several that have attracted much interest.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Postmaster General Payne received telegrams from Gallatin. Tenn., to-day, informing him that a rural free delivery carrier, a negro, had been held up by masked men and warned under penalty of death not to make another trip. The first telegram was as follows:

OMAHA, Neb., May 7 -- Gov. Mickey left Lincoln for this city to-night in response to a request from persons affected by the strike. An appeal has been made to the Governor for protection in the way of militia or otherwise, but he is not satisfied that such action is necessary and will look over the ground personally.

ROME, May 7. -- Replying in the Chamber of Deputies to-day to a demand made by Signor Cirmeni for an explanation of the present status of the investigation of the lynching of Italians at Erwin, Miss., in July, 1901, Under Foreign Secretary Baccelli said that, in spite of the activity of Italian Consular and diplomatic officials, no convictions had been secured, owing to the reticence of witnesses, who persisted in declining to make depositions.

ALBANY, May 7 -- The hearing before Gov. Odell to-day on the L'Hommedieu Street Railway bill was productive of information as to the extent of the franchise privileges which would be revivified under that measure which was in the nature of a startling revelation of the scope of the franchise "grab" conspiracy in the recent Legislature.

Americans will read with peculiar interest the declaration of the Marquis of LANSDOWNE in the House of Lords, speaking upon this occasion not for the Ministry or for a party, but for the British Empire, that no other Power would be permitted by Great Britain to establish a naval base or a fortified place on the Persian Gulf.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- As a result of the increasing demands of organized labor, which have a tendency to fix by rule all relations between employer and employe, Chicago business men have decided to eliminate all sentiment from the relations between them and the workers.
LONDON, May 8. -- The Irish Land bill last evening passed its second reading in the House of Commons by 443 votes to 26.

GREENFIELD, Mass., May 7 -- District Attorney Dana Malone, who was prosecuting officer in the case, has declined to indorse a petition for the release of Euclid Madden, the motorman who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in upsetting President Roosevelt's carriage and causing the death of William Craig of the President's bodyguard last Summer.

Comparisons have resulted in taking the pleasure out of the reading of many a good book, and so when his publishers in an effort to awaken interest in Mr. Basnford's "Tommy Wideawake" compared the little volumes of Kenneth Grahamo's glowing recollections of child-life they at ouce set a standard high indeed for poor Tommy to reach.

LONDON, May 8. -- The Methuens are preparing to reissue Edward FitzGerald's "Euphranor," described by him as "a dialogue of youth." It has never been reprinted separately, though, of course, it is included in the scheme of Messrs. Doubieday, Page Co.'s Variorum FitzGerald, and copies of the first edition now bring as much as $30 when they are offered for sale.

At Jasper Oval yesterday the Manhattan College baseball team defeated the Syracuse University nine after a close contest by the score of 4 to 3. Minahan pitched cleverly for the locals, only allowing one base on balls and striking out four men. Henderson's splendid drive to deep centre scored a home run for the visitors.

Mayor Low yesterday sent a communication to Gov, Odell saying: "I hope you will not sign L'Hommedieu bill. I am convinced that it affects New York importantly, in virtual violation of our charter, and it seems to me legislation of a very vicious type.
DUBLIN, May 8. -- Miss Rhona Adair of the Portrush Club won the ladies' golf championship at Portrush to-day, defeating Miss Leigh by 4 up and 2 to play.

Giovanni Zacconi, owner of the Stanton Street butcher's shop, where the Secret Service agents saw Benedetto Madonia, the barrel murder victim, with some members of the gang on the last night he was alive, was arrested last night by Detectives Carey and McCafferty at his home, 145 Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn, and taken to Manhattan Police Headquarters.

IS it Shakespeare?" is the title of a volume by "a Cambridge Graduate," which E.P. Dutton will publish in this counnext week. It is published in London by John Murray. This "great question of Elizabethan literature," is, the sub-title says, "studied in the light of new revelations and new contemporary evidence."

Geographical conditions have much to do with the settlement of a new country. The French, when they made their landing in Canada, had for a road the broad St. Lawrence, and this noble stream bore them far onward. The Frenchmen reached the Mississippi without great mishap. Strategically, mountain ranges are great obstacles to progress.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- For the annual Junior promenade dance this evening the Casino was decorated with bunting and tapestries, and there were several decorated boxes for the comfort of the dancers and chaperons. The attendance was large. The dancing was preceded by the customary senior singing and a Glee Club concert in Alexander Hall.

The study of history is to be made more intelligent and the resulting knowledge to be of a broader range by means of "General History Way Marks," by Charles C. Boyer, author of "Psychic Initiative in Education." This is a 200-page book of "predigested" history, meant to supplement such works as those of Myers, Duruy, , in the schoolroom.

Rear Admiral John G. Walker, Brig. Gen. Peter C. Hains, and Prof. William H. Burr of Columbia University, composing the Panama Canal Commission's Inspection Committee, returned from the Isthmus yesterday aboard the steamship Allianca, having examined the route of the proposed waterway.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Continued fair weather favored the players competing in the tournament of the Chevy Chase Golf Club to-day. Some fine work was witnessed, notably that by Horstmann of the Chevy Chase Club, who defeated Byers of the Alleghany Country Club, and Carnegie of the St. Andrew's Club, in the first and second rounds respectively of the contest for the President's cup.

The experiences of George, Tom, and Emily, with their friend Prof. Williams, who know all about the queer and out-ofthe-way facts of New York City history and their records in existing landmarks, have clearly aroused an interest among young people, and very likely among older ones.

There is a curious thing about the habitual love of "Nature." It seems not to prevent but to promote in certain souls a feeling not at all lovely or loving toward fellow-victims of the passion. We shall not call this feeling hatred, for that is a good strong name for a manly sentiment, reserved by sensible people for some object of intrinsic and considerable importance.

Policeman James Howard, thirty-one years old, of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station, and his sevenyear-old son. George, were drowned in the East River at the mouth of Bronx Kills soon after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon by the upsetting of the flat-bottomed boat in which they and James Howard, Jr., four years old, the policeman's other child, were returning from a day's fishing.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 8. -- Six weeks ago the strike of the workers in the building trades began and to-night came the first break. The masons' union was the first to yield, Ignoring the Building Trades' Council, it came to an agreement with the Builders' Association, and its men will so back to work on Monday, although the Building Trades' Council agreement was that all should stay out until all went back.

The bi-centenary celebration of St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, Burlington, N.J., is to be begun to-morrow morning. The Rev. William Allen Johnson, who was the eleventh rector of the church, will preach a sermon. At the evening service the Rev. John Fearnley will officiate.

"BONNIE PRINCE CHARLIE!" "Even to-day hearts are stirred when the band plays 'Will ye no come back again?' " writes Mr. Andrew Lang. Strange as it may seem, there are snatches of Scotch ballads, sung in precisely those portions of mountainous Tennessee described by Miss Murfree, and the words show their Prince Charlie origin.

When Mr. JOSEPH PULITZER bought The World newspaper twenty years ago he wrote in his inaugural article: "Performance is better than promise. Exuberant assurances are cheap. I make none. I simply refer the public to the new World itself, which henceforth shall be the daily evidence of its own growing improvement, with forty-eight daily witnesses in its forty-eight columns.

Those three men, Hillel, Akibah, and Judah, gave to the Jews, by means of rabinnie literature, that strength of purpose which has enabled them to endure centuries of subjection. In burburous Russia it was only, yesterday that many Jews were murdered, and yet the Israelite keeps steadfast to his belief in a merciful God.

Any new work of fiction by Quiller-Couch is always welcome. In a season of many novels of mediocre quality "The Adventures of Harry Revel" is thrice welcome. It is a spirited tale full of imagination and humor, full of "Q's" odd fancies, graphic in the descriptive passages, and with a good enough plot to serve.

PITTSBURG, May 8. -- All the union bricklayers in Western Pennsylvania, themembers of the International Stone Union, the members of the National Association of Brick and Tile Makers of America, their helpers, and the clay miners and their helpers, all of whom are affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, will quit work at noon to-morrow.

Miss Keeler describes all the shrubs from the region extending from the Atlantic Ocean to the Mississippi, and from Canada to the borders of the Southern States. Then she tells, too, of those particular shrubs found in our gardens, which are of foreign origin, and of the latter class it is curious to learn how many there are.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 8. -- One man was fatally shot and another was badly beaten in a riot of striking Italian laborers at Field Point Park to-day. Had not Sheriff Ritch and a posse hastened to the scene of the trouble more fatalities might have resulted. Ten arrests were made. As the prisoners, chained together, were taken to the lock-up at midday much excitement prevailed.

Goethe's "Egmont," edited with introduction and notes by Prof. Robert Waller Deering of Western Reserve University, is being published this week by Henry Holt Co. When Prof. Deering begun work on the play no edition of it had appeared in America that was adequate for modern needs.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The State Department has received official confirmation from its agents in China of the increase of the Russian garrison in Niu-Chwang, and there is reason to believe, if President Roosevelt approves, that it will take vigorous steps in the matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES in its editorial of Friday morning hits the nail squarely on the head when it suggests that some explanation is due the public from either Mr. Stewart or Mr. Cantor regarding the former's removal from the head of the Building Department.

Horace C. Stanslaw, a young man who came from Alabama a few days ago to take part in a debate on the negro question at the Manhattan Liberal Club in East Fifteenth Street, last night was hissed off the platform because he read the declarations of Abraham Lincoln on that question, which he expressed in his famous debate with Stephen A. Douglas.

This minute study is a dissertation for a doctor's degree at Columbia, and exhibits in the most characteristic way the scientific method of the study of literature. The subject is one that has been much discussed. In Chauer's poem of "Trollus and Criseyde," he twice mentions as the author from whom he derived his story a "Lollius," from whose work he declares he has merely made a translation.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Ex-Senator Lindsay of Kentucky, a member of the National Commission on the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, has returned to Washington from St. Louis, where he took a prominent part in the dedication ceremonies. Mr. Lindsay was present at all the functions at St. Louis and had abundant opportunity of observing events and forming judgment upon them.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Secretary Root left here for New York to-night. He will attend a dinner at the Lotus Club to-morrow evening.
YOKOHAMA, May 8. -- There are persistent reports in circulation regarding the movements of Russian troops along the Yalu River.
ALBANY, May 8. -- Gov. Odell signed another lot of bills to-day, among them some which have provoked much discussion.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt was thrown from his horse last night at the Horse Show of the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club. The accident happened at the conclusion of a riding off exhibit in the class for polo ponies. Mr. Vanderbilt and Clarence H. Robbins were showing the merits of their horses, Oakland and Little Billie.

It is useless to discuss yesterday's prices at any length. Of over fitty representative properties only four changed so much as a point. The rest shifted up and down according to the higgling of the market. There were some who thought the coppers were kept strong in order to sell the rest of the market.

Meetings of the Lumber Dealers' Association and the Building Material Dealers' Association were held all yesterday at 18 Broadway. The Labor Committee of the lumber dealers said that the shut-down in the yards was just as complete as ever, with the exception of the firms which had been mentioned before and whose yards are still open.

GOUROCK, Scotland, May 8. -- The weather to-day was well suited for racing. In the afternoon Capt. Wringe, anxious to give the challenger's sails a stretching before to-morrow's set race, went out with her alone. The yacht made a couple of trips from Gourock to Holy Loch and return, and negotiated a slight sea well, in a fresh breeze, standing up excellently under her canvas.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Permit me, on the strength of a fairly seasoned education, to assert with very great confidence that the venerable author of "Willson's Readers," by all means deserves to be ranked in the worthiest company of genuine authors the world over. And this though his ninety long years had produced nothing but Willson's Readers.

A historical novel and a love story of grout merit and quite unusual interest is "The Ward of King Canute," by Ottilie A. Liljencrantz, author of "The Thrali of Lief, the Lucky." The plot is laid in the troub- lous time of the invasion of England by the Danes under Canute, and the story opens on the eve of one of the fiercest battlea between the invaders and the Angies under Edmond Ironsides.

PERSONS who knew the into Paul du Chaillu many years are inclined to doubt the statement of some of the biographical dictionaries, accepted by writers of obituary notices in some of the newspapers of May 1, that the distinguished explorer and author was born in New Orleans, July 30, 1838, Allibone gives the date as 1835.

AN UNILLUSTRATED Library Edition of the historical novels of G.P.R. James, in twenty-five volumes, is about to be published by E.P. Dutton Co. The set will include many novels which have long been out of print and others still which are only to be met with in America in cheap, poorly made, pirated editions.

LONDON, May 9. -- At a general meeting of the Seiyu-Kai, says the Tokio correspondent of The Times, the Marquis Ito declared that there was nothing more injurious to national interests than frequent changes of Ministry, of which the average in Japan had been one annually since the Chinese-Japanese war.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A LETTER in the issue of May 8. signed by J.C. Watkins, dwells on the necessity of improving the reading matter of the cheap magazines because they reach each a large number of people.

There is much originality in the plot of "Red-Headed GILL." Interwoven with a romance growing out of a nominal marriage of the Delafield-Julle kind, is the strange potency of a piece of silk coming out of ''the mysterious East, the poisonous East -- birthplace and home of an ill-wind that blows nobody good."

PHILADELPHIA, May 8. -- It was one of the dullest days of the year in the local market. The only movements that called for comment were the early rally in the Consolidated Lake Superiors, which was not maintained, and the hardening tendency exhibited by United Gas Improvement, which opened, ex-rights, at 94 7/8, shaded to 94 3/4, and then rallied to 95 1/8.

Gov. ODELL has signed the bill adding two new sections to the Penal Code, and designed to protect members of the National Guard from molestation or persecution by the trades unions. The additions to the Penal Code are reasonably drastic, but have terrors only for those who deem free riot essential to the attainment of the ends sought by organized labor.

BOSTON, May 8. -- The money market continues quiet and easy. Call loans, 3@3 1/2 per cent; collateral, 4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/4@5 per cent.: Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.: New York funds, par; clearings, $21,893,658; balances, $1,234,132. The foreign exchange market remains firm. Rates remain unchanged.

PEKING, May 8. -- The Russians have reoccupied Niu-Chwang with a large fore, and have also put garrisons in the forts at the mouth of the Liau River. They are further reported to be making extensive warlike preparations.

BOSTON, May 8. -- The statement of the Boston and Maine Railroad Company for the quarter ended March 31 shows gross earnings in that period were $7,804,997, an increase of $692,740. Operating expenses increased $757,726, however, and there was a decrease in net earnings of $72,562. For the nine months ended March 31 the net income decreased $106,485.

PITTSBURG, May 8. -- As the result of a resolution passed to-night at the final session of the convention of the Amalgamated Association of Street Railway Employes a telegram was sent to President Roosevelt, asking him to intervene to prevent the unlawful use of the United States postal system to hurt this union.

The placing of the entire amount of the Mexican loan of $12,500,000 in the form of 4 1/2 per cent. two-year Treasury notes through the house of SPEYER Co. is another evidence of the gradual rise of New York as a money centre in the international sense. The process is not a sudden one.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- The terms under which the Union Traction Company is to be reorganized after its receivership troubles are ended are gradually being outlined. The complete plan cannot be given until R.R. Govin returns from New York, where it is now being discussed, but in a general way the following is now known, in Chicago.

Miss Daskam's little volume should bring joy to the heart of the spinster, for it seems that it la never too late for the boy god to find her out. Between sober, dark green covers, these seven short love stories are attractive enough for light reading. True, the reader finds his enthusiasm not quite so keen after having read the seventh as after the first.

"An English Garner" is to be reissued in twelve volumes of Prof. Arber's ingatherings of the history and literature of England. The texts contained in the previous editions, which consisted only of eight volumes, has been rearranged and classified. The pamphlets have been arranged in four groups -- historical, geographical, social, and literary.

Two men, two scenes, two results, are now brought before us. The two men are Felix and Paul. The one is the Roman Governor of Judea. The other is a missionary of the cross. Both are representative men. The two scenes are judicial trials. In the first Paul the missionary stands before Felix the Governor.
BALTIMORE, May 8. -- An interesting contest is on between the Gould-Wabash interests and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for possession and control of coal lands in West Virginia.

One of the most serious of the French foretellers of future events is Mme. de Thebes, who, as all who write about her are careful to state, was believed in by so able and so practical a person as Alexanadre Dumas fils. Recently she published a small book of predictions for the year 1903. Attention is directed to the volume, as in it the writer foretold the burning of a provincial theatre.

Poe once remarked, in one of his critical, otherwise bilious, moments, that the "Bostonian critics" must think poets were porpoises, they were so fond of representing them an running in "schools." Therein Poe, who at the time happened to hold a sectional "Southern" literary brief, unamiably displayed the same foible which the "Bostonian critics" displayed, amiably.

OMAHA, May 8 -- A plan for the settlement of the strike which now involves more than 3,000 teamsters, restaurant workers, freight package handlers, and members of the building trades was reached late this afternoon.

After one has taken his courage in his hands and manfully pierced, so to speak, the awful green wrappings of "The Joyous Heart," he may find it in his own heart to be glad of his hardihood, but it must be confessed that the vivid tone of the book's cover, surmounted, as it is, with a decorative medallion set with a nosegay of red, yellow, and blue blossoms, strikes terror to the faint-hearted.

ALBANY, May 8. -- Gov. Odell to-day characterized the story that his friends and the friends of Senator Hanna were desirous of having him take the Chairmanship of the National Republican Committee as nonsense.

LONDON, April 30. -- The Times is spending an immense amount of money in advertising its "competition," and the other papers apeak of it with as much lightness as is consistent with a due regard for the interests of their advertising columns.

Chief Engineer Hill of the Aqueduct Board yesterday reported to the commission on the weakness of the new six-million-dollar Croton Dam, and outlined the changes and reconstruction work deemed necessary as the result of investigation.

Author or "An American at Oxford." "A New Portrait, of Shakespeare." MR. LAURENCE HUTTON does not acknowledge any great assistance from local authority in preparing his "Literary Landmarks of Oxford." Oxford's ignorance of Oxford, he says in so many words, is phenomenal and startling.

GOUROCK, Scotland, May 8. -- The British cutter Khama, of thirty-eight tons register, recently purchased by Seymour Hyde of New York, which sailed from here May 3, returned to Gourock to-day in a damaged condition. The Khama got fifty miles beyond Tuskar, when she encountered terrific weather, during which her jib and main halyards were carried away and she was forced to return to this port.
LONDON, May 8. -- Money was in strong demand in the market today. Discounts were harder.

MELBOURNE, Victoria, May 9. -- All the State-owned railroads of Victoria were tied up at midnight to-night in consequence of a curious dispute between the Government and the railroad employes regarding the right of the latter to affiliate themselves with the Victoria Trades' Hall, the headquarters of trades unionism in this colony.

In order to "get square" with one of the woman teachers, against whom he had a fancied grievance, ten-year-old Eddie Luke of 4l Underhill Avenue, a pupil in Public School 133, in Butler Street near Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, on Thursday deliberately set fire to the big school building, in which 1,500 children were assembled at their studies.

BRET HARTE'S "Trent's Trust," published this week, is the forty-second of the little volumes of his works that have appeared from time to time. The sixteen volumes of the Riverside Edition include all expect the last five, and they will in time be added to it.

PARIS, May 8. -- W. K. Vanderbilt, Jr., has entered for the Paris-Madrid automobile race, which will be started May 25 and May 27. King Alfonso of Spain and the Minister of Public Works will give prizes for the contest, and the King will entertain the participants at a garden party.

VIENNA, May 8. -- Doubt is expressed in political circles here whether Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria will have the courage to return to Sofia at the present critical juncture of affairs. It is even hinted that he may never return to the principality. This doubt has been increased by the receipt of two telegrams from Bulgaria this evening.

An article on Findlay Douglass's style in driving, J.F. Taylor's views on "The Art of Putting," and the revised rules of the United States Golf Association help to make Golf for May an unusually interesting number.

ATLANTA, May 8. -- New York charitable institutions and their administration caused a clash between D.C. Potter and Homer C. Folks, Commissioner of Public Charities, at to-day's session of the conference of charities and corrections. Mr. Potter charged that there was maladministration of the New York institutions.

With the coaching parade, the races at Morris Park, and the many coaching trips, to-day will be very gay. In the Church of the Incarnation there is to be the wedding of Miss Sophie Griswold Marshall, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Marshall, to Jullen Jacquelln Mason, and in Albany is to be that of Miss Gertrude Sard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grange Sard, to George Crawford Clark, Jr.

BALTIMORE, May 8. -- Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, professor of economics in Johns Hopkins University, has declined the appointment by the Government as special Unite States Commissioner to the Philippines for supervising the establishment of the gold standard currency system there.

SOCIAL ENGLAND, the fourth volume of which has just appeared, is somewhat encyclopedia in character, and when completed will give in a connected manner the record of the English people in religion, laws, learning, commerce, science, literature, and manners.

At a meeting last night of the officers and delegates of the Rockmen's and Excavators' Union, held at the Free Society Hall, 308-310 East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, it was decided by unanimous vote to prolong the strike for a period of six months or longer, if necessary, in order to obtain the demand they now make on the contractors.
The Chamber of Commerce has now an opportunity, which we doubt not it will improve, to render a substantial service to the business interests of the city.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 8. -- President Roosevelt made his entry into Los Angeles at 1 o'clock this afternoon. The enthusiastic welcome that has greeted him at each stopping place within the boundary of California reached a climax when the special train drew into La Grande Station. Los Angeles had for many days been preparing for him, and she was ready, dressed in her best.

Heroic incidents followed fast when John Montgomery, forty years old, and powerfully built, living at the Olive Tree Inn, in East Twenty-third Street, was seized with vertigo on the East Twenty-first Street pier, at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning and fell overboard. He had no sooner risen to the surface than Thomas Hartin of 336 East Forty-ninth Street leaped after him.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Mr. Jenkins of Wisconsin, who was Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee in the last Congress and is likely to be at the head of that important committee in the Fifty-eighth Congress, says the effect on trusts and combinations of the operations of the law creating the Department of Commerce is problematical.
ALBANY, May 8. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed Senator Green's bill amending the liquor tax law in the respects asked for by the State Excise Commissioner.

ALBANY, May 8. -- Statements that exSenator David B. Hill is in favor of the nomination of Groyer Cleveland for President by the Democrats next year were effectually set at rest here to-day. In fact, it came out that he was strongly opposed to the idea.
Official disclosure can now be made or the practical completion of the Mexican Government's plan to give that country's silver currency fixed value.

THIS is a remarkable book by the talented French theorist and writer whose previous works hare in recent years made a decided impression in their English form. The subject is perhaps not a novel one, but its treatment with such breadth and philosophic thoroughness and at the same time such practical directness, at such great length and in such technical detail, is surely an achievement that stands by itself.

True to its purpose of showing from time to time some of the more interesting foreign Work, the National Arts Club has taken advantage of the visit of Miss Loie Fuller to New York in order to exhibit her collection of sculpture by Rodin and others.

In flat violation of turf tradition, an immense attendance gathered at the Morris Park race track yesterday, though the day fell between two racing holidays. The public favorites were beaten in five of the six races.

Presidents Pulliam and Johnson of the National League and American League, respectively, are determined to maintain order and discipline on the baseball fields of the major leagues at any cost. The forner has announced the suspension of Wagner of the Pittsburg team for three days for threatening to strike Umpire Halliday on the Pittsburg grounds during Thursday's game.

PARIS, May 8. -- The airahlp constructed for the Lebaudy brothers made a highly successful trip to-day under Pilot Juchmes and Engineer Rey. The start was made at 9 A.M. from St. Martin in a light rain and with a brisk wind blowing.

BOSTON, May 8. -- It is likely that some or all of the life insurance companies, who had issued policies aggregating $485,000 on the life of Edwin N. Thayer, will contest payment, or at least cause a rigid investigation to be made. Thayer was twenty-eight years old, and all the insurance had been taken out within the past eighteen months, some of it within three months.

LONDON, May 8. -- Andrew Carnegie presided to-night at the annual dinner of the Iron and Steel Institute at the Hotel Cecil. Prime Minister Balfour was seated at the right and the Duke of Devonshire at the left hand or the Chairman.

Two more volumes of Prof. de Sumichrast's translation of "The Works of Theophile Gautier" have come to hand. The bookish qualities of thin edition have already been dwelt upon in these columns, as has also the utility of the Harvard professor as a translator. With the volumes now before us, XXIII, and XXIV., the edition closes.

The veteran skippers and Captains of the remote coast village of Killick Cove who assembled nightly to gossip around the stove in Cap'n Simeon Roundturn's store had a tine contempt for book learning. As Cap'n Job Gaskett "allowed," and Cap'n Roundturn agreed, "there's dozens and dezens here to this cove that never would once know their own names ef they see 'em writ on a barn door in big overgrowed letters five loot high."

SINGAPORE, May 8. -- The Currency Commission in its report declares that a gold standard for the Straits Settlements is practicable, and recommends the introduction gradually of a special Straits Settlements dollar of the same weight and fineness as the British dollar and circulating concurrently with the British and Mexican dollars.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- It appears that high prices are quite as much the rule in Great Britain as in the United States at the present time. Prof. Sauerbeck's anual statement, "Prices of Commodities," published in The Journal of the British Royal Statistical Society, for March 31, 1903, just received by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, show high prices in foodstuffs, in iron, and in textiles during 1902.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8. -- Pennsylvania defeated Columbia in the annual dual games between the two universities on Franklin Field this afternoon, the final score after the thirteen events had been contested being 68 to 49. Firsts counted 5 points, seconds 3 points, and thirds 1 point. In only one event was every place taken by one university, that being in the broad jump, the Morningside Heights team winning all three places.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 8. -- The Department of English Literature of Wellesley College has arranged for an out-of-door performance on May 29 of the morality play "Everyman," and of Ben Johnson's pastoral "The Sad Shepherd." "Everyman'' is to be given in the afternoon and "The Sad Shepherd" in the evening.

PARIS, May 9 -- United States Senator Scott, of West Virginia, now at the Continental Hotel, is making his way home after a delightful journey, which lasted four months, through Egypt, the Holy Land, and other Oriental countries, coming to Paris by way of Italy and Switzerland.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 9 -- Mrs. Neilson returned to-night from New York and was met at the boat by Mr. and Mrs. Reginald C. Vanderbilt.

ANDOVER, Mass., May 9 -- Sir Chen Tuns Liang-Chang, the new Chinese Minister to the United States, who received his education at Phillips Andover Academy in 1870 and 1880, has accepted an invitation to attend the exercises commemorating the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary or the founding of the academy to be held at the commencement exercises in June.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Another accident at sea -- another wholesale loss of life on the treacherous deep; and yet no word of complant from any source against the rotten "lifeboats." How is this? Is the power of invention paralyzed? Has the last word been said on the question of saving human life at sea?

Property owners of Whitestone, L.I., are wondering whether they are not blessed with a too numerous Fire Department. There are 4,000 inhabitants and 183 firemen. The firemen are so many and their rivalry is so keen that some of the flame-fighters have been accused of setting fire to buildings to start the engines running in the hope that they will be first at the blaze.

Dr. John McGaw Woodbury, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, has installed an extemporized garbage incinerator in the abandoned public school building at North Moore and Varick Streets, and he spent the day there yesterday demonstrating the possibilities of dry rubbish of which 90 per cent. is waste paper, as a substitute for coal.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F. May 9 -- The immense number of icebergs off the Newfoundland coast and the Grand Banks interferes seriously with steamship traffic.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Chevy Chase Golf tournament was brought to a close to-day. Perfect Weather favored the contestants, who were followed over the course by a large gallery. Dr. L.L. Harban won the President's Cup. Byars made the second hole, a distance of 287 yards, in two strokes.
PARIS, May 9 -- Stuyvesant Fish and Elisha Dyer, Jr., will sail on May 13 for New York.

THE receptivity of the juvenile mind and the unrestricted liberality with which it bestows attribute," said the fair Bostonian, "always interested me, and I frequently wonder what ingenuous concentration of thought enables a child to deduce from a conglomeration of immature mental impressions an expression of belief at once striking and apposite, thereby exciting the risibilities of persons whose intellectuality is fully developed."

TACOMA, Washington, May 9 -- Tacoma and Seattle are at odds over the question of which shall have charge of President Roosevelt and his party when he is escorted to the Puget Sound Navy Yard, at Bremerton, two weeks from to-day.

Robert C. Morris tendered his resignation as President of the Republican County Committee last night, to take effect immediately. It was not acted upon, for the reason that it was not made public until after the adjournment of the committee. This course was construed as indicating that Mr. Morris's successor has not been agreed upon, although his letter was dated last Wednesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of to-day you give a synopsis of a sermon preached by the Rev. H.B. Chapman of London yesterday at the Church of the Holy Communion, in your city, in which sermon, if correctly reported, as doubtless it is, the learned gentleman declares New York to be a "desolate place."

LONDON, May 9 -- The heavy lockup of funds in connection with the Transvaal loan disorganized the money market today, and brokers were entirely dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were quiet and rates were firm.

BERLIN, April 11 -- The success of the imperial loan last Friday was far beyond what anybody expected. Estimates made by leading bankers before the subscription ranged between fifteen and twenty fold the amount of the loan; nobody was so sanguine as to predict a forty-seven-fold oversubscription.
LOCAL allusions abound in "Skipper Co., Wall Street," which was produced at the Garrick Theatre last Monday night.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 9 -- The special session of Congress which President Roosevelt intends to call will meet Nov. 9, according to Representative Joseph G. Cannon of Illinois, who is here to-day. Mr. Cannon said: "I believe there will be a special session of Congress called to meet Nov. 9.
Citizens of Northampton, Mass., are already interesting themselves in the celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the town next year.

A week ago there arrived in New York from England a young man who said his right name was George R. Reynolds. Thursday August Belmont wanted an assistant butler for his home at Blemton Manor, Hempstead, L.I., and went to an intelligence office for assistance. Reynolds was recommended, and obtained the job.

In a batting matinee at Jasper Field yesterday afternosn the Manhattan College baseball team defeated the Lehigh University nine by the score of 17 to 1. Manhattan had the visitors shut out up to the ninth inning, when, with one man on second base, Davison hit for two bases and brought in the run, thereby saving Lehigh from a complete shut out.

An exciting poolroom raid was carried out yesterday afternon by Capt. Farrell of the Old Slip Station under the supervision of Inspector Schmittberger. Nine detectives attached to the Inspector's staff and to the First Precinct were used to gain access to the alleged poolroom, and to make the seven arrests that followed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Accepting the correction by "J.C." in today's TIMES of my misdated reference in your issue of April 26 to the matter of the "hasty plate of soup," allow me to add that the Gate itself is of no importance. It was the use of the expression at all in an official communication that excited the risibles of a generation, but not that only.

The Vesuvia Hotel, at Bleecker and Tompson Streets, and the "Hole-in-the-Wall "Hotel, on Thompson Street, near Bleecker Street, were raided last night by Capt. Wiegand of the Mercer Street Police Station, and twenty of his men. One hundred and forty prisonecs in all were taken, ninety men and fifty women.

THE opening of the Morris Park Clubhouse has been the club event of the week. The races began on Thursday, and yesterday the Coaching Club had its parade in Central Park and afterward drove out to Morris Park for its annual luncheon. There was an unusually large contingent of spectators in the Park to see the coaches.

The tombs of Alexander Hamilton and Capt. James Lawrence in Trinity Churchyard are well known. The grave last alluded to below is that of Capt J. Tollemache of H.M.S. Zebra, who, during the British occupation of the city, fought a duel in a private room of the City Arms Tavern with Capt. Pennington of the Guards. Capt. Pennington received seven wounds, but recovered.

THERE are several thousands of women on the plains and among the mountains and canons in the Far West who deserve to be well up toward the top of the catalogue of those who are prominent for achievements in those fields of human energy which for years have been occupied exclusively by the sturdiest of men.

BOSTON, May 9 -- The end of the week finds the money market in a very easy position. The supply of funds is being constantly increased, as the demand for accommodation is extremely light. Call loans, 3 @ 3 1/2 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 4 1/2 per cent. Time loans, mercantile paper, 4 @ 5 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading THE TIMES of May 4, I was surprised to see an article (copied from a London paper) on the Scilly islanders and the wreck of the steamship Schiller, giving the impressions of a man who visited the islands at that time, some twenty-six years ago.

TRAVERS looked the intruder over disapprovingly. What he saw was a very ragged, unkempt, suspenderless boy of twelve or thereabouts, with a frowsy, dejected-looking green and gold parrot tucked under one arm.
BUFFALO, May 9 -- There was a run on the Fidelity Trust Company to-day, and the Board of Trustees issued the following explanatory statement:

To the Editor of The New York Times: What "A Democrat, Westport, Conn.," under the headline "Views of An American Abroad," says in Monday's paper is interesting. If it appear, however, even on cursory examination, that it is, in part at all events, inaccurate, the interesting feature in that case acquires an ornamental value merely.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 -- For the first time in nine years Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania engaged in a dual athletic contest to-day, and Pennsylvania won the first baseball contest since the break in athletic relations, by a score of 7 to 3. It took twelve innings to decide the contest, which was filled with brilliant plays on both sides, and interest never lagged from the start.

THERE resides at Big Tupper Lake, in the Adirondacks, a tall, angular, old gentleman by the name of Martin Van Buren Moody, whom the sportsmen and woodsmen since the days when Chester A. Arthur first went into the mountains to fish and hunt have delighted to honor as "Uncle Mart."

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- The Peking correspondent of The Associated Press, writing under date of April 6, says that the alarming stories emanating from certain quarters, to the effect that a massacre of foreigners by Chinese is contemplated, are untrue. The correspondent writes that the reverse of this situation exists in Peking.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- Peace negotiations between the Deering Harvester Company and its 6,000 striking employes have been broken off, and the fight is to continue.

FROM Fort George to Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, without change seems a far cry perhaps, but that trip will be possible when the East River section of the Rapid Transit Subway is completed. Of no other part of the lone subway is so little known to the public, because it sees nothing of it and is not disturbed by it, but nowhere else on the line are there conditions and difficulties more deserving of general interest.

"Dear me! ejaculated Frederick W. Downes, a clerk employed by the Gold Hill Copper Mining Company of 25 Broad Street, when he opened his morning paper at breakfast at his home at 76 Second Place, Brooklyn, yesterday.

BERLIN, May 9 -- The German Government regards the Turke-Bulgarian situalion as being grave, but responsible officials say that if a collision can be averted this Summer more sober counsels can set a hearing in the Winter, when military action is impossible.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 9 -- Outgeneralled at every stage of the game and out-weighed by an average of about twenty pounds the Johns Hopkins University lacrosse team was defeated by the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn this afternoon by 10 goals to 4. While the John Hopkins still holds the lacrosse championship of the college teams, the Crescent team, which has also defeated Toronto, the champions of Canada, played all around them.

Police Headquarters was thrown into a turmoil of excitement, and the, Detective Bureau stirred into unwonted activity yesterday by a mysterious letter received at Headquarters shortly after noon. Following is a copy of the letter:
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The State Department has received from Minister Conger at Peking a dispatch saying that the Russians re-entered Niu-Chwang and then retired.

With thirteen games won out of seventeen played, the New York Nationals have made an excellent showing up to the present time and they have more than fulfilled the premises made for them by Manager McGraw. During the past week the attendance at the Polo Grounds grew larger each succeeding day, and yesterday there were over 18,000 persons present when the local team again defeated the Philadelphians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the great success which has attended the People's Symphony Concerts, of which I have the honor to be regarded as the rounder, I trust that you will allow me to trespass briefly upon your space to correct certain misapprehensions regarding the enterprise which I find existing in many quarters, and even in certain newspapers.

The nearer the season approaches its end the more numerous seem the openings. The feature of the list of plays given this week is the open air performance on Thursday afternoon at South Field, Columbia University, of the forest scenes from Shakespeare's "As You Like It," in aid of the University Settlement Kindergartens.

I DON'T know what you girls are going to give Mabel for a wedding present, but I know what I am not going to give her -- and that is silvers -- table silver. I shall get her a lamp or a pet of books or a rocking chair or -- or -- anything, providing it isn't silver!"
AT EIGHTY-FIRST STREET they passed a broad-shouldered young fellow who was striding up the avenue.

Mabel McKinley, niece of the late President and daughter of Abner McKinley, has signed with Barney A. Myers of 147 West Forty-second Street for a tour of twenty-five weeks in vaudeville at $1,000 a week and an accompanist and a maid to be furnished by the management. The money, it is said, is no inducement.

THE growing Russo-Austrian rapprochement which began with the joint submission of the reform terms to Turkey has been signally emphasized by the terms of the Czar's letter to Count Kapnist, the Russian Ambassador at Vienna, in which his Majesty, in conferring the Order of St. Alexander Newsky on the Ambassador, recognized the zeal which his Excellency has displayed in promoting "the friendly relations between the two countries."

The Spring season of matinee racing on the Speedway was opened yesterday afternoon under the most favorable auspices by the Road Drivers' Association of New York. Every one of the twelve races on the card was hotly contested from start to finish, close and exciting finishes marking the majority of them.

BERLIN, May 9 -- In addition to Capt. Scheder, who some time ago received the decoration of the Order of the Red Eagle of the Second Class for his services while commanding the German squadron in the Caribbean, seven other naval officers who took part in the Venezuelan blockade were decorated by Emperor William to-day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 9 -- Vassar students to-night presented "A Midsummer Night's Dream" in the open air. The scene was laid on a hill near the college. There was a large audience present, including a number of friends of the players from out of town. The dark pines formed the background, and moonlight and music added their witchery.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Mr. and Mrs. William S. Campbell to-day celebrated the sixtieth anniversary of their marriage by a reception from 4 to 7 o'clock at the residence of their daughter, Mrs. Kelton, widow of Gen. John C. Kelton, former Adjutant General of the army. They have resided with Mrs. Kelton since Mr. Campbell's retirement from public life in 1898.
The South Dakota State Insurance Department has licensed the Souix Falls Mutual Fire Association and the Retail Merchants' Mutual Fire Insurance Association to begin fire underwriting operations.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- Warm sunshine, a straw hat, a bather, and a rescue are the ingredients needed for a formal opening of the season in Atlantic City, and all these were supplied during the past week. In addition to that, the trains from New York and Philadelphia have been crowded and the beach-front hotels are well filled.

I DON'T know what I shall do by that boy of mines," said Mr. Katzenlieb, as he handed the real estate man a receipted bill for a month's groceries, "unless the Bishops and the Bonk Presidents quit writing pieces by the paper telling him how he shall make some successes already.

The Northern Securities Company was the outcome of a combination of exceptional circumstances, unforeseen and unexpected. Had more time been devoted to the formation of the company, we do not doubt that means would have been found of unifying the control of the Northern Pacific and of the Great Northern without any infringement of the law.

WE GIVE them a clear track and a seventy or a seventy-five-mile-an-hour engine and the wrecking master does the rest," said the yardmaster, knocking the ashes out of his pipe and leaning comfortably in his old revolving chair. "All the wreckmaster knows is that at such and such a point on the road such and such a train with so and so many cars has been smashed.

THE coaching party that went to Ardaley a few flays ago as the guests of Robert L. Gerry on the road coach Pioneer had a somewhat chilly and a decidedly windy day, Cut they arrived at the Holland House at the hour of 6 as trig in appearance as when they started out, owing to Judgment in dressing.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week eaded Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Because of the despoliation of the interior of the brick building that is hemmed in by tall apartment houses at 10 West Ninety-third Street, and is owned by Russell Sage, attention was attracted yesterday to a rather unusual state of affairs. There is scarcely a window pane that has not been broken.

As upon other recent Saturdays yesterday's market was little more than a debating society upon the bank statement. It showed surplus reserves triple last year's, larger than 1901 by a quarter, and quite as large as it has been or should be in normal years.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 9 -- Robert Abbott. Morris Dumont and H.D. Hibbard divided first honors in play for the golf committee cup on the Hillside Tennis and Golf club course this afternoon. Their net scores were 77 strokes.

Ribbons and special prizes received their final distribution at the Horse Show of the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn last night. There was the most intense rivalry in several of the classes reserved for judgment at the closing of the show. This was particularly noticeable in the tandem class, which brought out several entries for the cup offered by the Whip Club of Brooklyn.

JOHANNESBURG, (Transvaal) April 5 -- A brief summary of the experience of an American engineer visiting Johannesburg on business, in getting there from Cape Town, may be of interest to Americans contemplating the trip or to business men now represented in South Africa by salesmen who are not realizing expectations.
IN THS municipal campaign of the town of Celeste the battle cry of the Repub-- lican Party was the abolition of phonetics.

THE people of the State of New York will vote at the election to be hold next November upon the advisability of expending $101,000,000 upon the improvement of the Erie, the Oswego, and the Champlain Canals. This is the most stupendous scheme of internal improvement which has ever been proposed to a commonwealth in this country, and has few parallels in the history of the world.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 9 -- The resolution which passed the Senate a few days ago instructing the Florida delegation in Congress to take steps looking to the impeachment of Charles Swayne. Judge of the United States Court for the Northern District of Florida, on charges of corruption, non-residence, ignorance, and incompetency, passed the House to-day by a vote of 40 to 10, after a spirited debate.

LONDON, May 9 -- Journalism is a profession which, whatever other disadvantages it may possess, cannot be said to be monotonous. Few callings afford greater variety of interest and occupation to their votaries. These reflections are prompted by the fact that since my last message was dispatched I have witnessed several of those events which have engrossed the attention of two nations by reason both of their spectacular magnificence and their far-reaching political importance.

THEY will tell you -- the men of wisdom whose lives run around an oval course that is built for the "sport of kings" -- that Uncle Ben belongs to another day. They grant him cheerfully the veneration that tradition demands for the one who made monarchs of the turf out of Marmaduke and the Marquis.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The spirit of your editorial in this morning's TIMES, entitled "Not Restraint of Trade," places you squarely as defending trusts and doubtless clearly states the position of the founders and controllers of trusts.

IT IS now the lilac season, and these fragrant blooms fresh from the country are peddled on the streets. One would hardly think that women of fashion who can command the highest-priced flowers and plants would stop and buy these humble flowers, but on fifth Avenue this week there was a perfect furor for them.

From the humble coffee house to the marble palace seems a far cry. Yet the commerce of to-day possesses a magic wand, and so it happens that in St. Mary-axe there has arisen a gigantic new Exchange quite calculated to disturb the repose of the departed habitues of Garraway's, Robins's, or Jonathan's.

The Board of Managers of the Municipal League of Philadelphia in its report for 1902-3, which post-dates the installation of John Weaver, the new Mayor of the city, a League-Republican candidate, who was elected over Francis F. Kane, Democrat, on Feb. 17, tells of the activity of the league in the interest of clean municipal government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is to be regretted that some of our citizens are so prone to believe every idle or malicious tale of cruelty told against our soldiers who are serving in the Philippines and gallantly contending against cruel and treacherous foes, ignorant of the art of civilized warfare, but adepts in the art of cold-blooded butchery and ambuscades in a country difficult of access.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At all times much has been said and written concerning the way unto salvation. And, indeed, it is such an important matter that it dare not be ignored by any one. But the greater part of what has been said and written on the subject has not been conducive in the least of dispelling the darkness which hovers about the natural mind.

Secretary of War Root was welcomed at the Lotos Club last evening, and a dinner was given in his honor on his "temporary return to New York City." Several of the speakers spoke as if Secretary Root had completed his appointed task in reorganizing the army and doing other work of administration in Cuba and the Philippines, and that his return to private life was not far distant.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Postmaster General Payne to-day dismissed James Dower, a fireman employed in the Post Office Department, as a result of charges that Dower recently filed against Chief Engineer James O'Donnell and other superior officers. Dower alleged that a ring to govern promotions and other matters existed in the engine room and that improper contracts had been made.

To the Editor of The NEw York Times: Certain private friends, gentlemen representing the average of good position in this city, have asked me what I mean, specifically, by advising that, in case of war between Japan and Russia, or between Great Britain and Japan allied for a really free Manchuria and an absolutely integral China, the United States take active part with either Japan or her conditional ally, or with both.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 9 -- Reliance and Constitution were both at Bristol this morning, the Reliance having arrived from New Rochelle at 4 o'clock and there was a general rush to make the necessary alterations. Mr. Iselin said that the yacht had had a good trip from New Rochelle, but the wind was light, and it was decided to tow her on that account.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 9 -- There is every indication that the cottagers at Elberon. South Elberon, and Deal will join together and purchase a tract of land to be used for a speedway. Members of the Monmouth County Speedway met a few evenings ago and were pleased with the proposed site for the new road.

It was a day of triumph for the athletic schoolboys yesterday. They met on the old Berkeley Oval, at University Heights, now known as University Field, in the twenty-fifth annual Spring championship games of the New York Interscholastic Athletic Association. Those to carry off the major portion of the honors in the track and field events sported the colors of Berkeley School.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- An indication of the troubles experienced toy Mr. Ieishman, United States Minister to Turkey, in his dealing's with that Government, is disclosed in the Turkish diplomatic correspondence made public at the State Department to-day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 9 -- Officers in several counties are engaged to-night in a search for Curtis Jett, one of the desperate characters who have terrorized Breathitt County. He is formally charged with the assassination of James Marcum at Jackson on Monday.

The teachers and others interested in public education in Philadelphia have taken up seriously the question of increaslng the pay of public school teachers. Acting President Merchant of the Board of Education calls attention to the fact that teachers' salaries in Philadelphia are so unequal as to be unjust.

Several important intercollegiate athletic contests are scheduled for the Columbia teams this week. The chief event will be the annual dual track meet with Princeton on Saturday at South Field. Columbia showing against Pennsylvania was unexpectedly good in the opinion of a majority of the undergraduates, and it has give both them and the team hope that Columbia will be able to defeat Princeton.
