The action of the Anti-Policy Association in the matter of Magistrate TIGHE, in inducing the Appellate Division of Kings County to investigate the conduct of that officer in discharging from custody a number of persons arrested for policy gambling, is in the highest degree commendable.

Mr. JAMES McNEIL WHISTLER'S letter to Mr. WILL H. Low concerning the absurd and wholly unnecessary rumpus in the Society of American Artists about the Whistler paintings lent for exhibition leaves the former gentleman in that position of triumphant impishness where we expect to find the Old Campaigner.

In honor of the seventy-first birthday of ex-Mayor William R. Grace hundreds of people went to Grace Institute, 149 West Sixtieth Street, yesterday afternoon, to make in annual inspection of the results of the unique work done there and to wish long life and continued good health to the venerable co-founder.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The entertaining article, on the editorial page of Saturday's TIMES, headed "The President on Expansion," says, in reference to the Louisiana purchase:

The thirty-sixth annual report, of St. John's Guild contains a hundred pages of detail about a charity by no means the least interesting or serviceable in the city and an appeal to the public for more funds to enlarge and render more efficient for the Summer the guild's work for small children.

Last week was disappointing. It neither fulfilled expectations nor laid the basis of future great things, nor did anything entitling it to honorable mention upon its own account. It will be remembered that a week ago all the wise men of the Street were agreed that the market had warrant for some advance upon the better performance of the railways.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 9 -- Through the evidence of a young woman who was returning from a party early Thursday morning the police at the close of their day's labor to-night believe that they have traced the slayer of Miss Nellie A. Sturtevant, who was shot on her father's doorstep at 11:30 o'clock Wednesday night, for a distance of a mile from the scene of the murder.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 9 -- The navy eight-oared crew lost a two-mile race on the Severn this afternoon, being beaten by the Yale crew by three lengths.

Dr. F.S. Earle, Assistant Curator at the New York Botanical Garden, sailed for Porto Rico yesterday on the steamer Coamo to make an investigation of the diseases which affect the vegetable products of the island.

The information published yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the Mexican remonetization proposition, to which Senor Limantour, Mexican Minister of Finance, has so much devoted himself, came in for much attention and discussion in the financial district yesterday.

ST. LOUIS May 9 -- Mobile and Ohio conductors, brakemen, yardmen, and baggagemen all along the line between St. Louis and Mobile went out on strike at 9:30 o'clock to-day because they did not get a 10 per cent. increase in wages for freight service and a 7 per cent. increase for passenger service, which they have been trying to get for several months.

UNTIL June the children's Mayday parties have the run of the playgrounds in Central Park. Then the baseball players, cricketers, and tennis players have an innings that lasts until the leaves begin to fall from the trees. The extent to which the public makes use of them may be judged from the fact that always more than 100 and sometimes 300, applications for permits are received every day.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Julius Wiltrax, a boy who has been in the custody of the police for a week, to-day declared that his father, John Wiltrax, a saloon keeper, shot and killed six-year-old Paul Paszkowski, whose body was found in the cellar of the Wiltrax home.

The curious frankness of the suggestion "given out" by the State Department concerning the situation in Manchuria invites an equal frankness, we may fairly say, "in return." For the statement that the Secretary of State has felt bound to consult the President on the latest aspect of the Manchurian question was unnecessary for its avowed object.

The New York World issues this morning a newspaper of 136 pages, said to be the largest newspaper ever printed to mark its twentieth anniversary under the ownership and direction of Joseph Pulitzer. It has 1,000 columns of matter in eleven sections, and it weighs two and a half pounds, but aside from its mere bulk, it is remarkable in many ways.

The fight of the Building Material Dealers' Association and the Lumber Trade Association for the control of their yards has stirred the general contractors for buildings to action, for fear that, in case these associations submit to the demands for unionizing their yards, the Board of Building Trades would have absolute control of the entire building industry.

LONDON, May 9 The Transvaal loan was the only topic of interest this week. The report was circulated early in the week that the rate would be 3 instead of 2 3/4 per cent., as before anticipated. Consequently there was a temporary sharp recovery in consols and more buoyant markets generally.

CLINTON, N.Y., May 9 -- The New York State interscholastic oratorical contest and field day came off here to-day under the auspices of Hamilton College. Twenty-one high schools and academies, representing all parts of the State, were entered in the contest. In the oratorical contest the first prize was awarded to Earl Clark of the Binghamton High School, who declaimed a dramatic selection, "The Rough Riders."

Bids for the contract for the erection of the De Witt Clinton High School for Boys will be opened by C.B.J. Snyder, Superintendent of Buildings, in the hall of the Board of Education, on or before June 1. The plans have been drawn, the specifications are in the hands of the printer, and in a few days the bids will be advertised in The City Record.

A BRIEF cable dispatch in the American papers of Sunday, April 26, announced the fact that the foundation stone of the Venice Campanile had been laid the day before at 3 o'clock In the afternoon. The master of ceremonies was the Count of Turin, who, in the absence of the King -- detained in Rome to welcome King Edward -- performed the chief office.

ONE youngster who is popular in Boytown can do more to make a street unendurable than anythting I know of," said the man who finds fault. "I used to wonder why it was that certain streets that are comparatively free from traffic were so much noisier than others. I know now.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., May 9 -- Presi- dent Roosevelt's train left Los Angeles at 5 o'clock this morning and made its first stop at Ventura, where the President made a brief speech to the crowd at the station.

Some interesting announcements in polo will be made to-morrow when the adjourned meeting of the Polo Association will be held. Apart from the completed schedule of club tournaments, some dates, at least, will undoubtedly (be announced for games with the visiting English team which promises to be the most interesting feature in American polo this year.
THE DOOR behind the prisoner opened and closed softly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The figures contained in your editorial of yesterday, if correct, were very convincing for the purpose to which they were put, viz.: to show that the Northern Securities Company was not a combination in restraint of trade. In fine, it is doubtful if any such thins as a combination in restraint of trade exists.

The conditions now existing in the building trades are intolerable. That they are so is perhaps the natural result of the fact that in these trades the relation between employer and workman Is casual, forming and dissolving as buildings are begun and finished. There can be no community of interest among persons thus accidentally and temporarily related.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 -- Yale easily defeated the Princeton University track team here to day in the first dual meet that has ever been held between the two colleges by a score jot 75 points to 29. The day was perfect for the meet, and a large crowd which had gathered for the Pennsylvania-Princeton baseball game witnessed the contests, all of which were close enough to keep up interest.

ATHENS, Ga., May 9 -- B.F. Holder, Jr., editor of The Athens Banner, recently wrote a letter to Grover Cleveland telling the result of a poll of the business men of Athens, showing a strong sentiment for the nomination of Mr. Cleveland and asking this question: "Are you now considering or would you consider making the race for the Presidency next year on the Democratic ticket?"

While holding out her arms and calling in greeting to her father, Florence Mclvor, four years of age, fell from the window of her home in the third story of the building at 1,686 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon to the sidewalk. The child's skull was fractured and she died at midnight in the Harlem Hospital.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 9 -- Columbia's batters knocked but Vorhis, the crack pitcher of the local team in the sixth inning of the baseball game with the Englewood Field Club this afternoon and won by a score of 13 to 5. The game was a closely contested one and full of good plays. The score at the beginning of the sixth inning was 4 to 2 in favor of Englewood.

A woman who described herself as Mrs. Annie Phillips, forty years old, of 258 West Thirty-seventh Street, where she boarded with a Mrs. Patterson, called at the West Thirtieth Street Station house last night and inquired about a prisoner who had been arrested during the past week, charged with attempting to defraud a prominent hotel by giving a worthless draft.

It has already been announced by cable that toward the end of the last session of the French Chamber an elaborate and sensational scheme providing for the absolute separation of Church and State was laid upon the table. The document was drafted by M. de Pressense The full text of the bill was published in Le Temps, the Ministerial organ, on April 25, in which paperit occupies two pages.

A German Document. The following letter which was addressed by Prince von Munster, German Ambassador in Paris, to Joseph Reinach, forms the most important document in the accumulation of evidence that is being gathered to reopen the Dreyfus case:

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 9 -- The large carriage house and stable on W.R. Grace's summer place was destroyed by fire to-day. There were sixteen horses in the stable and half a dozen fine carriages were stored in the place. The stablemen succeeded in getting out the horses, carriages and harness. The loss is $20,000, fully covered by insurance.

Several persons have observed that electricity has already wrought great changes in the conditions of life; also it is a matter of comment that the use of this mysterious force is still in its infancy. Indeed, the utility and the infancy of electricity have almost supplanted meteorological observations as the staple of ordinary conversation.

Nothing in Mr. CARNEGIE'S interesting and suggestive address as President of the Iron and Steel Institute is more interesting and suggestive than an inference which he fails explicitly to draw, but which observant readers cannot help drawing. That inference is that the scheme of promotion and profit sharing which he outlines would almost infallibly be the end of "labor troubles" in the business to which it might be intelligently applied.

GOUROCK, Scotland, May 9 -- After a few informal brushes to-day the two Shamrocks finally were sent off on a real rating trial. The challenger was trimmed to her work, every sail drawing well, and she outpointed, outran, and outreached the older boat. They ran first with spinnakers to Cloch, five miles, and the Shamrock III, caught and passed her opponent and led her by quite a quarter of a mile at that point.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 -- Harvard played her first lacrosse game of the season on Soldiers' Field this afternoon and defeated the College of the City of New York by the score of 6 to 2. The game was by no means a brilliant one. Harvard's defense was very weak, and the men showed that they are still far from having mastered the simplest elements of team play.

Private advices received yesterday from Caracas tell of the resignation of President Castro's Cabinet and the Governor of the Federal District. Col. E. Gonzalez Esteves. Consul General of Venezuela in this city, and Senor Augrusto Pulido, Venezuelan Secretary at Washington, declare they have not received any official announcement of the cabinet change.
NEWARK, N.J., May 9 -- The News has the following from its' Lincoln (Neb.) correspondent:

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- H.C. Ide of the Philippines Commission, who is Secretary of Finance and justice under the insular Government, is in Washington on leave of absence, and will confer with the Secretary and other officials of the War Department in regard to Philippine affairs.

The Coach Club had its annual parade yesterday. As in former years, the meet was at the Eighth Avenue entrance to Central Park. There was a little confusion because there had been some statements to the effect that the rendezvous would be at the Metropolitan Club. In the roadways were many carriages and automobiles, occupied by members of fashionable society.

At the risk of some misunderstanding we venture the assertion, on official authority, that the modern Scot shows a tendency toward shrinking. We do not wish to be taken as implying that his disposition is changing, or that he is losing any of that simple self-confidence which enables him "to stand before Kings" or before any other sort of living beings, with modest dignity and assurance.

THE taxidermist turned the spreading wings of the red-shouldered hawk sideways and squinted thoughtfully at them. Then patting a ruffled neck feather here, and straightening out a tail feather there, he continued in half-reminiscent monotone: "Yes, I like live pets, and I have some; but they are not wild animals -- just plain cats and dogs."

Had Met Her Before. THE members of the New York Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church of Brooklyn recently tendered a reception to their new pastor, the Rev. Dr. F.J. McConnell, when it was desired that he should meet personally every member of the congregation.

NEW YORKERS may justly pride themselves on their splendid snake collection, but I'd like to see a few more of the most deadly ones of my own country included in the exhibit," said an Anglo-Indian visitor to the reptile house in the New York Zoological Park. "Somehow, the cobra has become so identified with India that persons are apt to forget we have still other poisonous species worth mentioning.

BALTIMORE, May 9 -- The Alliance Universelle Israelite is to hold a meeting here to-morrow evening to discuss the recent outrages against the Jews in Russia. Representative Goldfogle of New York was invited to attend, but instead he sent the following letter, which will be read at the meeting:

Possibly no other line of business shows the movement forward as does the coal trade, both hard and soft. It is at present on lines of advancement such as it has not experienced in many years, for the reason that a small ratio of increase means a very considerable amount added to the sum total.

Beyond the fact that the market declined practically all of the session yesterday there is very little to be said. There were only two factors in the situation to which any attention was paid, namely the Manchurian situation and the bank statement. As both of these were unfavorable it is perhaps no wonder that the market declined, with closing prices at the lowest for the day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to a letter published in the Sunday Supplement of THE TIMES, headed "The Harlem Free Libraries," and signed "Science," and dated April 14, and if not too late I shall be very glad if you will let me say a word or two on the subject.

At St. George's Cricket Grounds, Hoboken, yesterday the Boston National League baseball team was defeated by the Hoboken Club's nine by the score of 7 to 5. Six thousand persons saw the game, and during the early innings the visitors by lively batting scored three runs off Lindeman, while Malarkey held the home team safely until the fourth inning, when they made two runs.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 10. -- Maddock, the University of Michigan athlete, disqualified from entering the collegiate contests by a condition in English, won three firsts in the annual Varisity track meet here yesterday. He put the shot 41 feet 9 inches; discus 117 feet 3 inches, and the hammer 141 feet 8 inches.

Last week's market, otherwise uninteresting, afforded a significant contrast between the bond and stock dealings. More stocks declined (41) a full point than advanced, (37.) But twenty-nine bonds rose a point, while only seventeen fell a point. The movement of the stocks well enough represented the speculative position.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Civil Service Commission makes the following explanation of the circumstances attending the appointment to his position of John C. Allgood, the Tennessee negro rural free delivery letter carrier, who has been prevented from performing the duties of his office by the patrons of his route:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I trust you will be so good as to permit me to say a few words in your paper in behalf of a patient though overworked class of men, viz., the retail grocery clerks of our city.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., May 10. -- Foster Ely Brackett of Washington, D. C., a senior in the Department of Latin, died to-day of typhoid fever. Brackett had been down with the fever for more than three weeks. He would have received his Bachelor of Arts degree this month. Funeral services were held in the Memorial Church this afternoon, and the body was sent to his home.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read in your valued paper about the tribute to Emma Lazarus by her friend, Miss Georgia Schuyler, by placing a tablet on Liberty Island to her memory, I take the opportunity, if you will permit, to say a few words about Emma Lazarus as "The Daughter of the Jewish Nation, the Zionist."

The graceful recognition by Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE of the fact that in his selection for the Presidency of the British Iron and Steel Institute the man of affairs was given an honor which has hitherto been conferred only upon those who have become distinguished by great technical achievements in invention or discovery or the adaptation of means to ends is not the outgrowth of personal modesty.

William H. Crane has recently been visiting San Francisco, and, like many other actors, finds the place conducive to reminiscences. To an interviewer from The Call, who sought him out during his stay in the city, Mr. Crane discoursed pleasantly about old times. He referred to the days when he was a member of "Tom" Maguire's company at the Bush Street Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The area, population, commerce, and methods of government of the colonies of the world are discussed in detail by a monograph just issued by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, entitled "Colonial Administration, 1800-1900."

The attendance and brushing on the Speedway yesterday morning would have done credit to a big trotting meeting. Almost every contest was fought out to the very last stride, and many of the finishes were so close that only those in a direct Line with the two finishing posts could decide as to the winner.

An open-car going south on Third Avenue broke into flames shortly after 7 o'clock last night as a result of defective insulation, and between thirty and forty persons, men, women, and children, were compelled to jump from the swiftly moving vehicle. About a dozen were hurt, but hone seriously.

The box with the iron handle that some mysterious persons carted to the Cunard Pier on Friday for storage aboard the Cunarder Umbria, and which the police and Inspector Murray of the Bureau of Combustibles say contained 100 pounds of dynamite and a perfect set of mechanism to set the same off, is now in Inspector McClusky's private office at Headquarters.

NEWARK, N.J., May 10. -- The members of the Newark Catholic Infantry, an organization connected with St. Mary's Catholic Church of this city, have been ordered, it is said, to disband under penalty of being excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church.

There was subdued excitement in the Various headquarters of labor yesterday over the possible outcome of the failure "of the negotiations between the Rapid Transit contractors and the Rapid Transit Committee of the Central Federated Union to end the strike of the rockmen and excavators of the subway.

Surrounded by many of his old friends and associates, the Rev. Dr. Kaufmann Kohler, retiring rabbi of the Temple Beth-El, received yesterday a last godspeed from the congregation to which he ministered for twenty-four years. His long career in this city has closed with the acceptance of his new post at the Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati.

That the total amount of money spent each year by the Federal Government has increased enormously within the last hall century is, of course, known, to every one. That the growth of expenditure is fairly proportioned to that of the population and the wealth of the country is the general impression, but it is a vague one and by no means very well justified.
LONDON, May 11. -- "While adressing his party last Friday evening concerning Manchuria," says the Tokio correspondent of The Daily Mail. "Marquis Ito hinted that there was trouble ahead."
OAKLAND, Cal., May 10. -- Joaquin Miller, the "Poet of the Sierras," died here suddenly to-night.
"Did my lovely new hat get drownded? Mamma will whip me awful if it did, 'Cause I promised to take good care of it."

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., May 10. -- Anson Phelps Stokes's schooner yacht Sea Fox, New York Yacht Club, now undergoing the overhauling process at the Jacob yard, has been chartered to Arthur T. Kemp of Newport. The yacht wlll be placed in commission on Memorial Day, and after a cruise in Long Island Sound will sail for the Bermudas, en route for the West Indies.

More than twelve hundred Daughters of the Revolution began the twelfth annual convention of the general society by attending a service in St. Paul's Chapel yesterday afternoon. Scarcely a nook or corner of the interior of the chapel was there which did not gleam resplendently with the Stars and Stripes, with here and there a bit of buff and blue.

Golfing will be very active during the coming week, for although there is no big tournament scheduled the prominent local players will use the time to prepare for some of the important contests that will soon follow each other in rapid succession. Considerable practicing will be done this week on local links in preparation for the three-day open event at the St. Andrew's Golf Club next week.

The statements made in THE TIMES of Saturday by Senor LIMANTOUR, the Mexlean Minister of Finance, leave no room for doubt as to the nature of the change which Mexico is to make in her currency system. "We are not trying to make Mexico a gold country," says the Mexican Minister.

HOTEL, DEL MONTE, California, May 10. -- President Koosevelt to-day spent one of the most restful Sundays he has had since his trip began. In one of the most beautiful spots in California, two miles from the nearest city, unhampered by cuplous crowds, he had a chande to prepare for the coming week, which promises to be one of the busiest of his journey.
Five horses perished in a fire which destroyed a stable at 279 Rider Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon. Five other horses were saved by a negro stableman, Lionel Gilmore.

PATERSON, N.J., May 10. -- The body of a man was found in the canal at the head of Morris Street yesterday by some boys. His coat was found later behind the retaining wall which supports the Lackawanna tracks alongside the canal. It was believed at first that the man had been hit by a train, and hurled over the wall into the canal.
MANILA, May 10. -- The quarantining of transports bound for San Francisco has been resumed on account of the cholera. The epidemic is making slight gains in Luzon.

Five major league baseball games were decided yesterday in Western cities. In Cincinnati the Pittsburg and local team attracted 20,000 spectators, and the National League champions won by the score of 1 to 0. The Chicago and St. Louis nines played a double header in St. Louis, the visitors winning both games in the presence of 12,000 people.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 10. -- Everything is in readiness for hauling out the Reliance in order that she might have her underbody cleaned, and the work probably will begin early to-morrow. On account of the fine breeze yesterday, she was not put on the ways, but was taken out for a trial spin, during which her big clubtopsail had its first airing.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 10. -- Postmaster William V. Campbell of McKeesport has made the discovery that hundreds of dollars' worth of business that should be handled by the home Post Office is going to the credit of other offices, principally Pittsburg and Braddock. The discovery is the result of an investigation that has been undertaken by Postmaster Campbell.

The eighty-seventh annual report of the Board of Managers of the American Bible Society, to be made to the society at its annual meeting in the Bible House next Thursday, gives a summary of the year's work of the organization that entitles it to rank with the large business houses of the city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Refeiring to your editorial of this date you will do the business world a great service by stating what is the "very simple enactment giving to our currency the quality of elasticity," Many suggestions have been made in Congress and in the press -- complicated, elaborate, difficult and objectionable -- the Fowler bill, the Aldrich bill, abolish greenbacks, discontinue the Sub-Treasury,
MADRID, May 10. -- The result of the recent elections in Spain has insured the Government a large majority in the Senate.

PANAMA, May 10. -- The convocation of the Colombian Congress for June 20 is believed by people acquainted with Government affairs to mean that President Marroquin is confident of having sufficient support to assure the approval of the canal treaty.

To The Editor of The New York Times: As a matter of justice to me, will you kindly express my repudiation of the distorted and untrue report of my speech before the Manhattan Liberal Club last night that appears in your paper this morning?

ATLANTA, Ga., May 10. -- Before an audience of several thousand people this afternoon the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst of New York discussed the negro problem in the annual convention sermon before the National Conference of Charities and Correction. The Baptist Tabernacle, the largest auditorium in the city, was crowded to hear the New York clergyman, and he evoked considerable applause when he declared:

LONDON, May 11. -- Mr. Houdret, Consul General of the Congo Independent State in London, has published a letter, which he has addressed to the Rev. William Morrison of Lexington, Va., a member of the American Presbyterian Mission, who recently made public here charges of tyrannical behavior on the part of the whites in the Congo over the native population.

Quite a few Republican politicians yesterday expressed the belief that a very strong string is attached to the resignation tendered by Robert C. Morris an President of the Republican County Committee. While Senator Platt Knew of the Contemplated act a week ago, and Executive Chairman W.H. Ten Eyck recieved the letter of resignation from Mr. Morris last Wednesday, nothing was done about filling the position.

LONDON, May 11. -- The Sofia correspondent of The Times says the Turkish note to Bulgaria has neither been accepted nor returned, but there are excellent personal relations between Premier Daneff and the Turkish Commissioner, both desiring to find a solution of the difficulty.

Contrary to what seems to be the general impression, The American Syren, speaking from its larger knowledge of harbor conditions here, holds that, despite the small number of boats tied up, the marine engineers have in effect attained the ends for which they "resigned," and that both their example and their success will soon be imitated, first by the masters and pillots, and later by the cooks, deckhands, and firemen.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Last year, within two weeks, over $12,000,000 worth of timber and other property was destroyed by forest fires in Oregon and Washington. This enormous loss occurred upon a restricted area and represents only a very small part of the annual loss from this source.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- There is some speculation about the effects to follow the issue of the new sliver coins in the Philippines in July. The new currency is intended to take the place of the Mexican silver, which will thereafter cease to circulate as legal tender or be received in payment of customs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, "Horse Lover," whose communication in this morning's issue doubtless refers to that implement known as the "over-draw check," is certainly right in making a protest against its use.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The changes which the investigation in the Post Office Department has caused point strongly to legislation by Congress next Winter and a reorganization of the department. Enough has been discovered to justify the expectation that Congress will object to making the appropriations on any basis heretofore followed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Upon the hypothesis that the philosophy of a certain distinguished American citizen is sound -- namely, "that it is disgraceful to die rich," it would seem to follow inferentially that when a man has spent the most vigorous years of his life in the acquirement of a genteel sufficiency he should withdraw from the clash and turmoil of life's arena and give the other fellow a chance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A brief letter in your paper this morning regarding the brutal overhead checking of horses has influenced me to try once more to attract the attention of some one to the condition of animals in this city with the hope that they may have it in their power to do something for alleviation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Activity in the market to-day was confined largely to Consolidated Lake Superior issues and United Gas. Superior was inclined to advance, but the small gains made were difficult to hold on account of the general heaviness and indisposition on the part of the public to trade.

ALBANY, May 11 -- Another batch of bills was signed by Gov. Odell to-day. Among these was Assemblyman Nye's bill legalizing the marriage of Albert K. Shorey of Cornwall, Orange County, and the late Catherine Cacouna Buntin. The woman had been divorced from her first husband by an act of the Parliament of Canada, where she and a first husband had lived.

PARIS, May 11 -- Magistrate Leydat has concluded his investigation of the Humbert case and has decided to commit Therese Humbert; her husband, Frederic, and her brother, for trial on the charges of forgery, the use of forged documents, and swindling.

PITTSBURG, Penn.,May 11 -- At a meetig of stockholders here to-day the organization of the Grand, Central Railroad Company of Nicaragua was perfected by the election of Robert Pitcalrn of this city President. The other officers are:

PANAMA, Colombia, May 11 -- It is reported here that President Marroquin has been compelled to resign office on account of political troubles, and that Gen. Raphael Reyes, Second Vice President of Colombia, will assume the Presidency. Friends of the canal are anxiously awaiting confirmation of this report.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 11 -- The strike of the trackmen, of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad seems to be a failure. In this city men went to work this morning for Foreman Mahon of the local section gang. Most of the men were old employes who quit work a week ago when the marching strikers were here.

NEWPORT, May 11 -- Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt returned from New York this afternoon. By a later boat Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt arrived, and is a guest at her son's farm, Oakland, in Portsmouth. This is Mrs. Vanderbilt's first visit to the Farm since her son's marriage.

GOUROCK, Scotland, May 11 -- The Shamrock III's, windward work to-day was little short of marvelous, and even more so was the manner in which she carried way while going about. She stayed on the weather bow of the old boat and practically kept pace with her opponent with light winds and through smooth water.

Feeling that they, too, are persecuted in the world, Chinamen invited Jews of the east side to affiliate with them at benefit performances last night in their theatre in Doyers Street. Three performances were given by the Chinese actors for the sufferers at Kishineff. All expenses were borne by the Chinamen.

ATLANTA, May 11 -- Decidedly the most sensational feature of the Conference of Charities and Corrections was the statement made by experts to-day that the negro race is in danger of being destroyed by insanity. The discussion was brought about by a paper read by Dr. Searcy, Superintendent of the Alabama Hospital for the Insane, who claimed that his experience showed that insanity was increasing among the negroes at an alarming rate.

Yesterday was one of the most sensational markets ever known on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices fluctuated violently all day, and all day an excited crowd of brokers struggled around the pit railing endeavoring to snatch up the offers of long cotton, which the bull clique was handing out freely, because on each bale sold, at the high prices of yesterday they realized a heavy profit.

Four horses attached to a brake owned by George G. Haven, Jr., the banker, of 36 Broad Street, and living at 6 East Fifty-third Street, ran away at Columbus Avenue and Ninety-second Street early last evening. Before they were stopped the heavy vehicle had crashed into two electric cars and two of the animals had leaped the Central Park wall.

Ever since, and long before, the publication of DE QUINCEY'S essay on "Murder as a Fine Art," mankind has taken the liberty of considering the comic aspects of tragedies, even of real tragedies. But of tragedies which do not come off we are all the more at liberty to consider the comic aspects.

BOSTON, May 11 -- The money market continues easy, but the demand is still extremely light. Call loans, 3@3 1/2 per centt.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4@5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 2 1/2@3 per cent.; New York funds, par. Clearings, $16,898,040; balances, $1,267,660.

NEW ORLEANS, May 11 -- The cotton market was a surprise even to the long side this morning. At the opening, prices of futures took a jump of from 20 to 37 points in the active months and the advance was so strong and wild that prominent longs, seeing danger in store for local traders, sold the market down almost immediately.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Postmaster General Payne has again requested a statement from Seymour W. Tulloch, ex-cashier of the Washington City Post Office. It was done this time through Fourth Assistant Bristow, Mr. Payne thus being able to ignore the letter Tulloch wrote requesting copies of communications sent him by several officials on the subject of the Tulloch interview.

A woman was buying eggs in the grocery store at 317 Henderson Street, Jersey City, and a man was making a polite gesture previous to quieting his nerves in the saloon next door, at No. 315, yesterday morning, when a tremor not unlike an earthquake disturbed both customers and proprietors in the two establishments.

OSSINING, N.Y., May 11 -- "Al" Adams, the convicted "Policy King," and William F. Miller of 520-per-cent, syndicate fame, will soon be transferred from Sing Sing prison to the State hospital at Dannemora.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The marriage of Miss Anne French, daughter of Dr. William B. French of this city, to Walter Meiggs Brush of New York took place to-day at noon at the home of the bride's parents, on Capitol Hill, in the presence of a small company. The bride was attended by her schoolgirl sister, Miss Louise Russell French, and the bridegroom by his brother, Mr. Noel Bush, also of New York.

Many persons interested in philanthropic matters were present at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, at Second Avenue and Thirteenth Street, yesterday, when the Schermerhorn Aural Pavilion, the gift of the late William C. Schermerhorn, was dedicated. This addition, which cost $75,000, contains two operating rooms, special rooms for patients with brain complications, and a separate ward for children.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 11 -- Shakespeare as a character in a play was portrayed for the first time to-night at Ford's Opera House in George Fawcett's prize play. "The Favor of the Queen." in which Mrs. Percy Haswell will star next season. The character of Shakespeare is a striking feature of the production, and as portrayed by De Witt Jennings, was a correct representation of the immortal playwright as known in story and history.

The members of the organization calling themselves the Rockmen and Excavators' Union, being mostly alien immigrants following an occupation requiring no special skill, cherish the very natural conviction that what they want is paramount to every consideration of the public interest.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Mr. Beaupre, the United States Minister to Colombia, to-day confirmed by cable the report that a special session of the Colombian Congress has been called for June 20.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The record in the case of the United States vs. the Northern Securities Company, recently decided by the United States Circuit Court for the District of Minnesota adversely to the Securities Company, reached the United States Supreme Court to-day on appeal and was docketed as No. 696.

Lieut. Col. John W. Pullman, Deputy Quartermaster General, and Capt. Andrew G. Hammond, Eighth Cavalry, will proceed to Louisville, Ky., for the inspection of cavalry horses to be delivered under contract for the army.

LONDON, May 12 -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says that Jean Carrere, the journalist, who has the reputation of being well-informed in regard to Papal affairs, states in Gil Blas that Emperor William's project in visiting Italy was to prepare the way for the election of a successor to Pope Leo who would favor his (the Kaiser's) projects.

John B. McDonald, the subway contractor, yesterday delivered his ultimatum to the Italian strikers, which is that unless the excavators and rockmen back down row the position they have taken, to-morrow morning will find their places along the tunnel taken by outside laborers.

SAN JOSE, Cal., May 11 -- President Roosevelt arrived here this afternoon, and will spend the night here in his private car. A good part of the day was spent in examining the characteristic features of this part of California, but the President made several short speeches from his train at stations, and one in the course of his visit to Santa Cruz.

There is one element in the situation of China and the relations of foreign Powers to it and to each other with reference to it that is not generally clearly appreciated. It is the extreme backwardness of the empire in all that constitutes the commercial and industrial life of the modern world.

From West Hoboken and the General Post Office in this city there was obtained yesterday the first information that may result in the capture of the persons who last Saturday had 100 pounds of dynamite placed on the Cunard Line pier to be put on board the Umbria.

BETHLEMEM, Penn., May 11 -- Bethlehem entered to-night upon its third festival of Bach's music and marked the beginning of a week's activity in music such as cannot be matched in any other festival of a similar sort in the world. Considering all the circumstances, it is a most remarkable occasion.

A fairly courageous and persistent effort was made by the bulls yesterday to put the market up. The effort was not altogether without success -- was, in short; rather encouraging in its results in view of the fact that it was made in the face of an export engagement of $1,500,000 in gold, with more likely to go out at any time.
LONDON, May 11 -- Money was scarce in the market to-day in connection with the Transvaal loan. Discounts were quiet.

Official announcement of the acquisition of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad by the Rock Island system was made yesterday at the office of J.P. Morgan Co., when the official circular to stockholders was made public. The offer of purchase is open to all holders of 'Frisco common stock, but it will not take effect unless 225,000 shares take advantage of the offer, or just enough to carry control of the road.

In some parts of the outside market yesterday prices were strong, but nowhere in the list was there much activity. The gains, however, were so intermingled with declines that the market was from no point of view wholly satisfactory. Some of the stocks which a few days ago were attracting attention because of the advances they were showing were yesterday as weak as they were strong last week.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The War Department has received the following dispatch concerning operations in the Island of Mindanao:
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The monthly crop bulletin issued by the Agricultural Department to-day is as follows:

Philadelphia will be the scene of the polo championship tournament this season, the event having been awarded yesterday to the Philadelphia Country Club, and the time will be between June 18 and 30. Squadron A was an applicant for the big polo event of the year, and special efforts had been put forth to get the fields at Van Cortlandt Park, in prime condition for championship polo.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The War Department has received the following dispatch concerning operations in the Island of Mindanao:

A suggestion of great weight and moment was made in a letter which the Rev. Dr. LYMAN ABBOTT sent on Sunday night to the Cooper Union mass meeting called to consider Mr. CHARLES SPRAGUE SMITH'S plan of a People's Palace. " It is of the first importance," wrote Dr. ABBOTT, " to know whether the men for whom this plan is proposed desire it enough to contribute something toward establishing it."

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Assistant Secretary of the Navy Darling said to-night that he had no knowledge of the order to vessels at New York to unload ammunition. He assumes that the inspection has been ordered by the Ordnance Bureau in the regular course of business. The unloading of ammunition for inspection is of frequent occurrence.
Details will be found in another column relative to the erection of a twenty-three-story addition to the Commercial Cable Building.
BALTIMORE, May 11 -- The stock market opened with a fair show of firmness.

Because of the demands of the labor unions the employing associations in the building trades have decided for the first time in their history to call a general meeting of the organizations affiliated with the Building Trades' Association to take place at the Building Trades Club. 1,127 Broadway, Its headquarters, some time this week.

That the fusion conference held last night at the headquarters of the Citizens' Union in Union Square adjourned without passing a resolution indorsing the administration of Mayor Low was considered by political observers as the most significant fact in connection with the proceedings.
Joseph Jefferson, who has been counted among the opponents of the National Theatre scheme, denies this in the following letter, written by him yesterday:

The production of "The Runaways," the costliness of which has been so widely advertised, took place last night at the Casino. "Oh, what is a dollar," said the persuasive solicitor of subscriptions. "Yes, what is a dollar?" said his intended victim; "I haven't seen one since last November." What, indeed, is a dollar? And what are 75,000 of them to the confiding, uncalculating press agent?

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12. -- A hearty greeting was given to President Roosevelt by the City of San Francisco on his arrival here to-day. Through miles and miles of cheering, densely packed, enthused humanity the President passed, bowing his acknowledgments, evidently wearied by maintaining an erect position in his carriage, but buoyed up by the magnificent ovation he was receiving.

At a meeting of the Chicago Public School Principals' Association last week one of the members created a vast amount of emotion that would have been horror if it had not been wisely turned into amusement by delivering a long and impassioned denunciation of SHAKESPEARE as an author whose works were poor things in themselves and particularly unsuitable for the study or even the reading of children.

DALLAS, Texas, May 12. -- At a public mass meeting at Temple Shaareth Israel a resolution was adopted condemning the outrageous acts on the Jewish communities at Kishineff. A committee was elected to raise funds for the relief of the sufferers. Another public mass meeting has been called for Sunday, May 17.

BOSTON, May 12. -- The money market continues very easy, but with no improvement in business. Call loans, 2 1/2@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/2@4 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2@ 5 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, par. clearings, $23,506,544; balances, $1,743,420.

Police Captain Miles O'Reilly, erstwhile the "Terror of the Tenderloin," had a bout with occult science in Brooklyn yesterday, and, as one of his patrolmen afterward described it, "went down and out in the first mix-up."
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The weekly crop report of the Weather Bureau is as follows:

DETROIT, Mich., May 12 -- By scoring four runs in the first inning and four more in the fourth the local baseball team defeated the Greater New York nine by the score of 8 to 4 today. Chesbro was not by any means in good form, while Deering, a young pitcher from the Connecticut State league, did remarkably well up to the ninth inning, when he was hit hard.

Robert Smith has bought from Sarah J. Wyckoff-Bent 61 West Fourteenth Street, a four-story building on lot 25 by 100. Mr. Smith has leased the property for a short term to L.B. Jeffcott. At the expiration of this lease Mr. Smith will erect a business building on the lot.
LONDON, May 12. -- The tension in the money market is expected to be somewhat relieved to-morrow, when, with the allotments of the Transvaal loan, the locked-up money will be released.

BALTIMORE, May 12. -- The Republicans contesting the election of Robert M. McLane, Democrat, as Mayor were surprised to-day by the Board of Supervisors of Election, controlled by the Democrats, which decided that the ballots in the four disputed precincts could not be counted. The Republicans will take the matter to the courts, contending that even under the Australian balolt law the Supervisors decision opens the way to frauds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In last Sunday's paper you quote an incident which occurred during the course of a debate in the Massachusetts House of Representatives at Boston. One of the speakers is said to have quoted the Ninth Commandment as the Eighth, which circumstance provoked laughter on the part of other members of the House, who referred him to the Bible for better information.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Dr. Thomas Herran, Colombian Charge d'Affaires here, said to-day that he had not been advised by his Government that President Marroquin has resigned, as reported in dispatches from Panama. There is some dispute as to the title of Gen. Reyes to the position of "designado," (the one designated by Congress to succeed to the Presidency in the event of death or incapacity of the President.)

Much interest is taken in the renting of cottages at Newport and the various changes there, although the season proper does not begin before July. Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Lehr are among the new additions to the cottage colony for the early Spring months. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Havemeyer, who sailed yesterday, will be in Newport in July.

Stocks irregular. Money easy, 2 1/4@2 1/2 per cent. Yesterday's market opened with cheer and vigor which soon faded away. There was activity at the close, but such cheer as it disseminated among the bears will not be generally shared, nor welcome to anybody else.

Another complication was added yesterday to the struggle for light and air among the owners of the buildings on the southerly end of the Stock Exchange Block. This complication came in the shape of an announcement that William T. Havemeyer and Frank W. Savin, who own the two little buildings at the southeast corner of New Street and Exchange Place, had decided to unite their holdings and erect thereon a seventeen-story building.
SHERMAN, Texas, May 12. -- The Texas Bankers' Association met here to-day and listened to the reading of a number of letters from prominent bankers in other States.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 12. -- Owing to a great strike of dock laborers at Valparaiso all business has been suspended there. Riotous strikers have destroyed street cars and have committed other excesses, several persons have been killed and great excitement prevails.

The results of the Stock Exchange elections which were held on Monday were made public yesterday. There was no opposition, except to two nominees for members of the Governing Committee. In this contest the opposition was partly successful, as it had the satisfaction of defeating one of the regular candidates by the election of its own nominee.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Army officers are very much interested in the vacancies that will be created within the next three months in the grade of Major and Brigadier General. On July 26 Major Gen. George W. Davis, now in command of the forces in the Philippines, will reach the retiring age, and on Aug. 8 Lieut. Gen. Miles will reach the statutory limit and retire from active service.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 12. -- The second day of the Bach festival has been in all respects more auspicious than the first. The day has offered ideal festival weather, mild and fragrant with fresh Spring odors, and with a certain vigor in the air that has been good for both listeners and musicians.

Meetings of various associations of employers in the building trades were held yesterday to consider plans for bringing about normal and settled conditions in the building trades industry in order that the strike epidemic all over the Greater New York and through the country may not put an abrupt end to the building season.

J.P. Morgan Co. announced yesterday that under the terms of a private agreement they offer to holders of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company 7 per cent, mortgage bonds maturing July 1 next the privilege of extending these bonds until July, 1905, with interest at 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- William Nelson Cromwell, general counsel of the New Panama Canal Company, to-day made public a statement regarding current reports affecting the company, including that emanating from Panama that the company had offered the Colombian Government $12,000,000 of the $40,000,000 the company is to receive from the United States.
First Lieut. Emory S. West, Seventh Cavalry, will remain on duty with the Sixth Cavalry until further orders.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Additional complications have developed in the E.W. Simonds mystery with the statement of a private watchman that the morning the New York broker suffered his fatal injuries he was with Watchman Burns, when a man staggered up to them and said he had been assaulted.

Passers-by in Twenty-third Street just west of Broadway yesterday afternoon were thrilled or shocked, according to their view of dog fighting, by a battle between a bull terrier owned by Mrs. Eleanor Sedley of 127 East Thirty-first Street and a fox terrier owned by another woman, who also rode in a carriage.

Prof. Leong Kai Cheu, founder and Vice President of the Chinese Empire Reform Association, ex-teacher in the palace of the Emperor of China and second to Kang Yu Wei, the leader of the Chinese National reform movement, which, despite the unrelenting opposition of the Empress Dowager is spreading all over the empire, arrived in this city late Monday evening, having come from Japan by way of Canada.

The construction of the subway must not be delayed. In that matter the public interest is paramount. The comfort and convenience of a great cityful of people cannot be subordinated to the demands of a few thousand strikers. The time for parleying hag been exhausted. Work must be and will be resumed today on the Subway Rapid Transit route, and the new force of men must be protected from violence.

It is announced from Washington that the calling of Congress is fixed for the 9th of November, the Monday after election day. This will give nearly a month before the usual meeting time, and as this is the first session of the new Congress it may be expected to get to work with some earnestness and to accomplish a good deal before adjournment for the National campaign.

The "spite" phase of the competition in skyscrapers is illustrated by the story told in our news columns yesterday and continued to-day. A skyscraper was erected which had, at the time of its erection, excellent lighting on one side, but the property on that side was owned by another owner who did not see why he should keep the revenue of his land down in order to keep that of his towering neighbor up.

A very much cut and rewritten version of "The Taming of the Shrew" was presented yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan under the title of "Katharine and Petruchio." The title parts were taken by Elsie Leslie and by her husband, Jefferson Winter, who is a son of William Winter and godson of Joseph Jefferson.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12. -- President Roosevelt was the guest this morning of the Leland Stanford, Junior, University, at Palo Alto. He left San Jose at 8:30 o'clock, and a half hour's ride through orchards and fields brought him to his first stopping place.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The experiments being made with the White House and its adornment have provoked the opposition of Mrs. Roosevelt. Mrs. Roosevelt has given orders that hereafter no changes are to be made without her approval.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 12. -- F.W. Holls, who was asked to act in the capacity of umpire in the dispute of Germany and Italy against Venezuela, said to-night that he would have to decline the honor. He would not state whether he had sent word to President Roosevelt to that effect, but he intimated that he had.

The financial district was considerably exercised yesterday by a report that a further cut of 50 cents had been made in the Price of pig iron, and by the additional report from Pittsburg that a sale of a 5,000-ton lot of steel billets had been made there at a reduction of $2 a ton. The selling price was said to have been $29 a ton.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 12. -- The following are among the candidates who have passed their mental examinations for admission to the Naval Academy, and the districts from which they are appointed. This list does not include the names or those who passed in Washington, which has been already given out and published, but only those who were examined before the Civil Service Commission throughout the country.

The subway strike is at an end, at least for the present. The Presidents of the rockmen and excavators met the Central Federated Union's committee yesterday afternoon at 85 East Fourth Street and agreed to order the men back to work.

London is just now very much interested in two surgical cases, giving results in changing the nature of the subjects which promise to render valuable assistance in pointing the way to the reformation of criminals. One of the patients was a boy of good family who had developed brutal instincts which seemed to be beyond control.

It was announced at the meeting of the Wine and Liquor Dealers' Central Association, held in Terrace Garden yesterday afternoon, that there is some backsliding on the part of Saloon keepers from the recent agreement, to charge 15 cents a pint for beer and abolish free lunches.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 12. -- Willis L. King, Vice President of the Jones Laughlins Company, when seen to-night regarding the report of a cut in the price of pig iron, said there was absolutely no truth in the rumor. He also denied that there was any change in the price of steel billets.

GOUROCK, Scotland, May 12. -- Sir Thomas Lipton and Designer Fife have decided that it is not necessary to devote further time to trials between the Shamrocks on this side of the Atlantic. Consequently, Saturday's race will be the last, and the two yachts will be sent to the Greenock yard on Monday in order to the fitted with their ocean rigs. Racing, however, has been arranged for every day this week.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 12. -- The Reliance had successful tests yesterday of her spars and rigging in beating to windward and running with a spinnaker and ballooners set. Her refitted sails, new mainboom, and lengthened gaff were held to snappy tests in the beat out from Bristol Harbor all the way down to Gould Island, after which the wind fell from nine miles an hour to five or six.

VIENNA, May 12. -- The seventh round of the international gambit chess tournament was duly played yesterday, when the pairing was as follows: Pillsbury vs. Marco, Swiderski vs. Schlechter, Gunsberg vs. Teichmann, Marshall vs. Tschigorin, and Maroczy vs. Mieses.

A violent break occurred yesterday afternoon in the cotton market. Almost within half an hour the price of the July option broke over 30 points from 10.77 to 10.43, with the rest of the market tumbling after it and closing at almost the lowest for the day. The break was caused by very heavy selling of the brokers for the Sully bull clique, who offered the option down very freely.

Candlelight in an old New England living room. Over in one corner a cradle minus an occupant; a "kettle singing on the stove, the soft strains of "Rock a bye Baby" wafted from the orchestra. Old Squire Tappen, white-haired, genial, mellow, fussing about getting things in readiness for the arrival of Bill Biffin's baby.

OMAHA, Neb., May 12. -- Judge Dickinson, in the District Court, to-night, on application of John O. Yeiser, an attorney representing the labor unions whose members are on strike, issued an injunction against the business men and proprietors even more sweeping than that issued by the Federal court against the unions last week.

Philip C. Germond, the convict son of the Rev. Dr. Philip Germond, pastor, of the Chelsea Methodist Episcopal Church in West Thirtieth Street, was last night locked up in the Tombs on charges of forgery. It is believed that he obtained at least $5,000 from forgeries committed since last September in many of the large cities.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 13 -- Additional details of the Kishineff massacre of Jews are printed here daily. The correspondents give the number of victims thus far buried in the Jewish cemetery at 44, and say that 84 persons seriously wounded are still in the Jewish hospital.

For the first time in years every policeman in the city was ordered to remain on emergency duty yesterday. The Italian laborers along the subway voted early in the morning to disregard their leaders' advice and remain on strike, and Commissioner Greene saw to it that there should be no danger of rioting.

James Bergman, who conducts an installment business in watches and jewelry at 37 Maiden Lane, was arrested last night at the instance of District Attorney Jerome. Justice Mayer of the Court of Special Sessions held him in $3,000 bail on a charge of subornation of perjury.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The methods of Prof. Adolph Lorenz, the Austrian surgeon, in the treatment of congenital hip disease and club feet furnished the feature of general interest at the meetings of the American Surgical and Orthopedic Association held here to-day. To the Surgical Association the case of Charles Willett, operated upon last November by Dr. Lorenz for club feet, was presented.

The issue of the subway strike promises to be very different from what the leaders of the rockmen and excavators expected. The teamsters have returnee to work. Most of the Italian trend laborers have refused to do so, and, in accordance with the promise of Contractor MCDONALD, their places are being filled as rapidly as confidence in the police protection will permit.

BOSTON, May 13. -- The position of the money market shows practically no change. Money is cheap, but the demand continues light. Call loans, 3 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 1/4 @ 5 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent.; clearing house loans, 2 @ 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, par. Clearings, $22,475,749; balances, $1,046,448.

ALBANY, May 13 -- In cleaning up the thirty-day bills in his bands the Governor finds that two bills are in the hands of the Mayors of New York and Buffalo that will not be returned here till next week. Outside of that the Governor Can if so dis- posed close up his work on the bills to-morrow or Friday.

Mrs. John Henry McCarthy, wife of the Justice of the City Court, was rewarded for a long search for her nineteen-year-old son, Herman Kopppleman, by learning yesterday that he had been secretly married.

Two fair-haired girls in flat sailor hats and brown gingham frocks were the central figures yesterday in an all-day proceeding before Vice Chancellor Pitney in Jersey City. The proceedings were in pursuance of the efforts of Gen. Emil Schaefer, the retired brewer of this city, to get possession of his two children, five and seven years old.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 161 Broadway:

Police Commissioner Greene, speaking at the annual dinner of the Civil Service Reform Association last evening at the St. Denis Hotel, discussed the City Magistrates. He was introduced by Carl Schurz, who presided.

DETROIT, Mich., May 13 -- Manager Griffith still has great confidence in his Greater New York baseball team, although his men were beaten again here to-day, Detroit winning by the score of 7 to 1. Griffith says that luck is against his men, and certainly all the good luck fell in the way of the local players to-day.

BOSTON, May 13 -- With reference to the high price of cotton and the possibility of a general curtailment of production by cotton manufacturing concerns. Treasurer Arthur Silsbee of the Cocheco Manufacturing Company, Dover, N.H., said to-day:
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Mordecai Raisman of this city has received a letter from his son Aaron, who witnessed the massacre of Kishineff. Writing from Pashetu, Aaron Raisman says:

An Amsterdam Avenue car that came swiftly over the brow of a hill at One Hundred and Eighty-first Street put an end to a tally-ho drive yesterday afternoon at about 3:30 o'clock. It smashed into the rear of a four-in-hand coach driven by James G. Marshall of McIntyre Marshall, commission merchants.

As an expression of regard for Helen Miller Gould and a recognition of her philanthropic works, Mrs. Russell Sage yesterday presented to the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless a stained-glass window. Miss Gould presented $5,000 to the society as a starter toward the $50,000 to be raised to enable the society to erect its own school building.

Walter J. Travis secured his revenge over F.O. Reinhart, the Princeton sophomore, yesterday on the Garden City links by defeating the latter by one hole in an 18hole match. The Princetan golfers came on with a team of seven to play the Garden City club, and Travis and Reinhart were pitted against each other.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Hugh H. Hanna, Jeremiah M. Jenks, and Charles A. Conant, who compose the United States Commission on International Exchange, will sail for Europe next week, and while an the steamer will map a detailed programme for the work in hand. After a stay of three or four weeks in London the commission will visit Paris.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed a letter signed by Louis A. Cuvillier, in your edition of yesterday, in which he attempted to explain why he was against granting a franchise to the Union Railway Company to cross the Macomb's Dam Bridge, which to me was a very makeshift excuse.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A petition for a writ of certiorarl in the case of W.O. Johnson versus the Southern Pacific Railroad Company was docketed in the United States Supreme Court to-day. The case involves the construction of the act of 1893 requiring railroads engaged in inter-State commerce to equip their cars with automatic couplers.

The London Times of May 2, in a dispatch from a correspondent at Kieff, makes plain the origin and purpose of the recent frightful massacres at Kishineff. It seems that the Russian peasantry in that department of South Russia really believe that the Jews of their respective vicinages are in the habit of slaughtering Christian children in order to make their blood available as one of the propitiatory sacrifices of the Jewish "Easter."

Lieut. Col. Timothy E. Wilcox. Chief Surgeon, Department of Columbia, will proceed to such posts of that department in Alaska as may be necessary, on business pertaining to the sanitary and medical inspection thereof.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 13 -- The rain which had been falling incessantly since yesterday assumed about daybreak almost the proportions of a cloudburst, and when the citizens prepared to leave for their places of business many of them found their homes completely surrounded by water.
WESTFIELD, N.J., May 14 -- A trolley car on the Central New Jersey trolley line between Elizabeth and Plainfield jumped the track to-night near Cranford.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Executive Committee of the Carnegie Institute reports that the entire sum of $200,000 allotted to grants for original research has been distributed, and that of the $40,000 set aside for publications to be made this year $20,000 has been assigned to special publications, leaving $20,000 still at the disposal of the Executive Committee.

Application was made to the Supreme Court yesterday for the dissolution of the Excelsior Shirt Company of 716 Broadway, on the ground that Isaac Nebenzahl, the Treasurer, had disappeared, leaving the affairs of the corporation in such a condition that the other officers do not know exactly how it stands.

In discussing a lecture by Prof. HENSLOW on "Present-Day Rationalism" in the University College Christian Association course, Lord KELVIN was more successful than most eminent scientists have been in an effort to show that science leads adily toward, rather than away from, a sound religious faith.

PARIS, May 13 -- The Paris-Madrid automobile races were inaugurated this morning, fifty-eight contestants in the tourists' class starting from the Automobile Club of France, on the Place de la Concorde, between 7 A.M. and noon. Although the main speed tests are to be made later, great interest was taken in the tests of the heavier vehicles and the opening of this year's long-distance races.

That ex-Wardman Bissert was convicted of bribery on perjured testimony was learned yesterday from an authoritative source. Lena Schmidt, keeper bi a disorderly house In the "red light" district, on the wardman's trial swore that she had paid him $500 for protection, and it was on that testimony that the verdict of the jury was found.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 13 -- Mrs. Alice Lycett, an art teacher of 232 West Lincoln Avenue, Mount Vernon, was held up in Elm Street, not far from Poplar Place, at 11 o'clock this morning by two men who were afterward captured.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt, Mrs. Vanderbilt, Sr., and Miss Gladys Vanderbilt have all returned from Newport, where they had gone to bid bon voyage to Mr. and Mrs. Reginald C. Vanderbilt, who will sail for Europe from Boston to-day. Alfred Vanderbilt tooled the coach Pioneer to and from Ardsley yesterday.

TACOMA, Washington, May 13 -- The fight between the Hill and Harriman railroad systems and their trans-Pacific steamship connections for handling the Government transport business to the Philippines is renewed by bids opened to-day for such transport service during the year beginning July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The speculative dead-lock in the stock market was broken to-day at the expense of values. The market exhibited an unmistakable tone of heaviness -- in several parts genuine weakness. There was also evidence of real liquidation. Philadelphia Rapid Transit recorded its lowest price since July, 1902, Pennsylvania Railroad the lowest since 1900, United Gas Improvement the lowest since 1807, and Tidewater Steel the lowest in its history.

BOSTON, Mass., May 13 -- Not a little astonishment was caused in this city to-night by information of the arrest in New York of Moody Merrill. He has not been in Boston since 1890, when he disappeared under a financial cloud. He has been in New York City most of the time, it is said, although rumors had him in South America.

The man whose name was given as G. Rosseo or Rousseau, and who on last Thursday sent the infernal machine to the Cunard pier, had not been arrested at an early hour this morning. All yesterday scores of Central Office men were searching the city for a trace of him. Gen. Greene said the detective force was doing its best, and that he hoped to have the man in custody soon.
On the long chains that are worn around the neck are carried those little Empire fans.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The volume relating to appropriations made and new offices created during the last session of Congress has been completed for the second session of the Fifty-seventh Congress by Thomas P. Cleaves and James C. Courts, Chief Clerks, respectively, of the Senate and House Appropriation Committees.

The cotton market yesterday continued to be wildly speculative, with quotations running up and down and up again, and the biggest brokers on the floor seemed to have about as much of an idea as to what the market would do next as the holiday bettor has about the way the ponies will finish.

BETHLEHEM, Perm., May 13 -- This evening's session of the Bach festival was a sort of interlude in the general scheme, interrupting the succession of great choral works, and giving the chorus a period of rest.

Stocks heavy. Money easy, 2 @ 2 1/2 per cent. Yesterday's opening was what might have been expected from the news which caused Tuesday's weak close. The opportunity was made the most of by those to whom lower prices were welcome. Stocks of certain issues were sold by thousands of shares, causing comparatively moderate declines.
Preparatory to sailing for Europe next Tuesday, Heinrich Conried gave out a statement yesterday regarding his plans for the coming season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

BRISTOL, May 13 -- Reliance hoisted sail at 1 o'clock this afternoon, and at 1:30 left for a beat down the bay in a southwest wind. She will remain at Newport to-night, the plans being to proceed under sail probably to-morrow to New London and then up the Sound. It has been decided not to haul the boat out for cleaning the underbody until just before the Glen Cove races.

Charles Harper Thaw, a cousin of the new Countess of Yarmouth and a son of a late St. Louis millionaire, appeared by attorney before Justice O'Gorman of the Supreme Court yesterday, and moved to open his default in an application made last June by his wife, Euphonia Jeannette Thaw, for alimony and counsel fees pending the cross actions for divorce pending between them.
Bar silver was quoted in the London market at 24 7/8 d per ounce and in New York at 54c. Mexican dollars at 42 @ 44 c.

The Laureate Stakes, chief event of the programme at the Morris Park race track yesterday, was the means of introducing at least one uncommon two-year-old to the New York racing public in the winner Boxwood. Whatever else may be said of that colt or the merits of his performance yesterday, his race left no question as to his courage.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The Directors of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company to-day, declared the regular semi-annual dividend of 1 1/2 per cent., payable June 19 to stockholders of record June 5.
The following securities were listed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 sold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:

The newspapers of the State of Pennsylvania are now published subject to the pains and penalties of a new law of libel. This law, which while under discussion in the Legislature was known as the Salus-Grady bill, was signed on Tuesday by Gov. PENNYPACKER, who accompanied his signature by a message, memorandum, or statement to the public, giving the reasons which prompted him to approve the measure.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- At the Mcchanics' Pavilion the President to-night made the most important speech he has delivered since he left St. Louis. His subject, "Expansion and Trade Development and Protection of the Country's Newly Acquired Possessions in the Pacific," together with the advocacy of a greater navy, was one that made his discourse of particular interest to the Californians, and he aroused his auditors to a high pitch of enthusiasm.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- New York exchange to-day was at 25 cents premium before and 20 cents premium after clearings. Time call loans, 5 @ 6 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The opening this morning gave promise of a better local market. There was a cessation of the urgent selling on liquidation of the two preceding days, and in several quarters of the list prices showed an inclination to rally. This tendency, however, was soon offset by the appearance of fresh scattering liquidation in United Gas shares.

PATERSON, N.J., May 14 Patrick Griffen and Charles McDonald are locked up in this city, and a third man, John McCarthy, is being sought for by the police to throw some light on the finding of the body of an unknown man this morning at the foot of the cliffs near the Beattle Mill in Little Falls by William S. Hawley, who was on his way to work.

Funds for the aid of the sufferers in Kishineff, Russia, continue to come to the committees having the matter in hand, and increase not only in number, but in amount. Arnold Kohn, Chairman of the Central Relief Committee, said yesterday that $2,000 had been contributed from the east side alone during the day, and that the checks coming from places outside New York City indicated that the sum total would be far beyond expectation.

LONDON, May 14 -- There was a remarkable scene in the City Temple at the midday service to-day, when the pastor, the Rev. R.J. Campbell, the successor of the late Dr. Parker, announced his adhesion to the "Passive Resistance" movement against the education act.

CINCINNATI, May 14 -- The mystery of the broken package of poisoned whisky which caused the death of one and the serious illness of four other Adams Express Company employes last night has not been solved. There will be no further deaths as a result of drinking the deadly potion.
LONDON, May 15 -- The Times's correspondent at Tangier says that troops from Arzila which have arrived there en route for Tetuan pillaged inoffensive villages on the way, and arrived laden with loot.
